headline: U.S. Appeals Court Rejects Fifth Attempt to Move Boston Marathon Bombing Trial
abstract: Upholding a federal district judge’s three denials, a panel voted 2 to 1 to allow the trial to proceed in the city where the attacks occurred.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — A divided federal appeals court has rejected a motion by Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, accused in the Boston Marathon bombing, to move his trial out of the city, paving the way for opening statements in the case to begin Wednesday.

headline: Golf’s Spring Training Comes With Balls, Gloves and Cleats, but No Batting Cage
abstract: In Florida, players hone their skills in preparation for the sport’s “opening day” — the Masters.
lead_paragraph: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla. — A few minutes from the spring training home of the Miami Marlins and the St. Louis Cardinals, several of the best players in the world have spent this week honing their swings. They have worked on moving the ball in different directions and set different goals for each day.

headline: Mexico Moves to Save Endangered Porpoise
keywords: ['Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Dolphins and Porpoises', 'Fishing, Commercial']
abstract: The government’s new policy bans gillnets for two years across the northern Gulf of California and compensates shrimp fishermen for their lost catch.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The Mexican government is making a final effort to save the vaquita, a tiny porpoise that has been driven to the edge of extinction as a result of illegal fishing for another endangered species that is served as a delicacy in China.

headline: At St. John’s, a Heralded Class Still Seeks a Capstone
abstract: Four years ago, St. John’s brought in a group of recruits that seemingly had the potential to return the program to the top tier, but now those seniors are still looking for their first N.C.A.A. tournament berth.
lead_paragraph: They arrived four years ago, a small army of prize recruits that was supposedly Coach Steve Lavin’s message to the college basketball establishment that St. John’s was back, and perhaps soon to be better than ever.

headline: Germans at the Crux of Crises, but Reluctantly
abstract: Europe’s indispensable nation, at the center of crises over Ukraine and Greece and often uncomfortable with leadership, has had a rocky month.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Germany has become Europe’s indispensable nation, at the center of crises over Ukraine and Greece. But a country uncomfortable with leadership, often labeled a reluctant hegemon, has had a rocky month.

headline: G.O.P. Race Starts in Lavish Haunts of Rich Donors
abstract: In one resort town after another, the Republican presidential hopefuls are making their case to exclusive gatherings of donors whose wealth was unleashed by the Supreme Court’s Citizens United decision.
lead_paragraph: PALM BEACH, Fla. — Instead of the corn dogs and pork chops on a stick ritually served up on the hustings of Iowa, the latest stop on the donor trail featured meals of diver scallops and chocolate mousse. The setting was the Breakers, a sprawling Italian Renaissance-inspired hotel here, where the cheapest available rooms fetched $800 a night. And for the half-dozen Republican presidential candidates invited to the annual winter meeting this weekend of the Club for Growth, an influential bloc of deep-pocketed conservatives, the prize was not votes. It was money.

headline: Tupperware’s Sweet Spot Shifts to Indonesia
abstract: As in 1960s America, many Indonesian women stay at home, creating an audience for parties run by women who have begun to sidle past conservative mores and into the work force.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — The party had the feel of 1960s America, almost. A group of women, thrilled to get a break from the daily routine of hanging laundry and shuttling their children to and from school, sat in a circle, listening to a friend hawk plastic storage bowls in a dizzying array of pastels.

headline: In Tributes, Knicks Remember Anthony Mason
abstract: Before their game against the Toronto Raptors on Saturday night at Madison Square Garden, the Knicks saluted Mason, a former player who died early Saturday morning after experiencing congestive heart failure a few weeks ago.
lead_paragraph: There was a somber undercurrent before the Knicks’ game against the Toronto Raptors on Saturday night as the organization paid tribute to Anthony Mason, a former player who died early Saturday after suffering congestive heart failure just over three weeks ago.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 28, 2015
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, March 1, 2015
abstract: Quotation of the day for Sunday, March 1, 2015.
lead_paragraph: “Do I have rogue correction officers at Attica or Clinton or Great Meadow? Yep. Do I have to rigorously pursue those rogue officers when I find evidence that they’ve engaged in excessive force or have done something untoward to the inmate population? Absolutely.”

headline: Six Singers Win the George London Awards
abstract: The six singers each won $10,000 awards. Past winners include Joyce DiDonato and Renée Fleming.
lead_paragraph: Six young American and Canadian opera singers were given George London Awards Friday night after winning the final round of a singing competition at the Gilder Lehrman Hall at the Morgan Library & Museum in New York.

lead_paragraph: Sarah Anne Cooper and Jeffrey de Blanc Palm were married Wednesday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau by Angel L. Lopez of the New York City Clerk’s office. On Feb. 7, Pastor Cory Casterton, who was ordained through the Elim Fellowship in Lima, N.Y., led another ceremony on the beach at La Concha Resort in San Juan, P.R.

Rubinov and Simon Rubinov of Brooklyn. Rabbi Gary M. Katz is to officiate at the Plaza Hotel in Manhattan.

lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Ann Joyce and Ronald George Magnusson were married Saturday evening at Pierre’s, a restaurant in Islamorada, Fla. The Rev. Stephen W. Brown, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

lead_paragraph: Ashley Hudson Wisneski and William Jordan Heward were married Saturday evening at the Boston Public Library. Thomas A. Welch, a Massachusetts justice of the peace, officiated.

lead_paragraph: Ronald Lee Strouse and Frederick Lloyd Cresson were married Saturday by Libby White, a former mayor of Doylestown, Pa. The marriage took place at the Mercer Museum in Doylestown.

lead_paragraph: Barbara Lazear Ascher and Strobe Talbott were married Saturday evening at the New York Society Library. The Rev. Chloe Breyer, an Episcopal priest, officiated, with her father, Associate Justice Stephen G. Breyer of the United States Supreme Court, taking part.

headline: Corrections: March 1, 2015
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Sunday, March 1, 2015.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL

headline: What to Expect on the Fifth Day of Milan Fashion Week
abstract: After celebrating its 20th anniversary last year, Marni has promised to move forward with its fall 2015 women’s show.
lead_paragraph: Marni celebrated its 20th anniversary last year, with its September show as a marker of the occasion — though not, Consuelo Castiglioni said at the time, a retrospective. That would be backward-looking, and Marni is still moving forward.

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (CBS) BATTLE CREEK Two mismatched law-enforcement officers — Russ Agnew (Dean Winters), an old-school detective who dislikes anything new, and Milt Chamberlain (Josh Duhamel, above right with Mr. Winters), a debonair F.B.I. agent assigned to set up a high-tech satellite office — are forced to work together as partners in a dilapidated Michigan city best known for Kellogg’s cereal. This new series “lies somewhere between a lighthearted procedural and a black-lined comedy,” Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. A collaboration between Vince Gilligan, who created AMC’s “Breaking Bad,” and David Shore, who came up with Fox’s “House” — and with reminders of both shows — it’s “a mixing of rare breeds that works,” she added.

headline: South Korean President Urges Japan to Admit Past Wrongs
abstract: In a speech marking the anniversary of the 1919 uprising against Japanese rule, President Park Geun-hye said Japan should apologize for holding Korean women in military brothels during World War II.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — President Park Geun-hye of South Korea urged Japan on Sunday to have the “courage and honesty” to admit to its historical wrongdoings against Koreans and other Asians, including its enslavement of Korean women in military brothels during World War II.

headline: Bouncing to the Beat of Kaboom
abstract: A couple has traveled the world creating explosive spectacles at air shows.
lead_paragraph: Rich and Dee Gibson have found a familiar comfort in an unlikely place: under a mushroom cloud amid flames and explosions. For the past 30 years, the couple has made a living going around the world blowing up things — creating mesmerizing spectacles at air shows.

headline: 1915: Americans Are Glad French, Not British, Warship Captures Dacia
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Americans respond to the vessel’s seizure in 1915.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — The seizure of the Dacia by a French warship causes satisfaction here. Commenting on the capture of this vessel, the NEW YORK HERALD says: ‘‘Because of the rigidity of French law it was always expected that the seizure would be made by the French navy. It is regarded as fortunate to have a French test case, since there are no issues between France and the United States, while there are issues between Great Britain and the United States. Germany misses an opportunity of twisting the Lion’s tail over this incident.’’ The feeling among the public is that this is the only satisfactory outcome possible of the Dacia case, in view of the extremely friendly feelings which exist between this country and France. On every side I hear admiration expressed of the extreme wisdom shown by the French nation in resisting the temptation to imitate Germany and some of the neutrals in sending propagandists here to meddle in American international affairs, since the public sentiment here is still fighting capably for the Allies. — The New York Herald, European Edition, March 2, 1915

headline: Documentary on Air Pollution Grips China
abstract: Since its online debut on Saturday, “Under the Dome” has inspired an unusually passionate eruption of public and mass media discussion.
lead_paragraph: Millions of Chinese, riveted and outraged, watched a 104-minute documentary video over the weekend that begins with a slight woman in jeans and a white blouse walking on to a stage dimly lit in blue. As an audience looks on somberly, the woman, Chai Jing, displays a graph of brown-red peaks with occasional troughs.

headline: As Common Core Testing Is Ushered In, Parents and Students Opt Out
abstract: On Monday, many public school students in New Jersey will begin to take standardized tests that are opposed by an unusually diverse coalition of enemies.
lead_paragraph: BLOOMFIELD, N.J. — On Monday morning, a few hundred students will file into classrooms at Bloomfield Middle School, open laptops and begin a new standardized test, one mandated across New Jersey and several other states for the first time this year.

headline: Afghan Women, Preparing to Serve
abstract: Years of efforts to train women for the police force have often often foundered against the strength of Afghanistan’s sexual conservatism.
lead_paragraph: Years of efforts to train women for the police force have often often foundered against the strength of Afghanistan’s sexual conservatism.

headline: Afghan Policewomen Struggle Against Culture
abstract: In a clash between Western ideals and Afghan realities, an effort to elevate the status of women by recruiting them to the police force has often backfired.
lead_paragraph: JALALABAD, Afghanistan — Parveena almost got away.

headline: 1965: Montreal Explosion Kills 28
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: At least 50 people were injured in a morning explosion and fire in a suburban block.
lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — At least 28 people were killed today [Mar. 1] and more than 50 injured in a breakfast-hour explosion and fire in a suburban block of apartment buildings. Schoolchildren, whose books and satchels were found among debris, were preparing to leave for school when the explosion rocked the apartment building in the Montreal suburb of La Salle at 8:15 a.m. Wind quickly spread the fire from the blast to three adjacent apartment buildings, police said. Two hours later, the fire department declared the fires were under control and the search for victims began. About 100 people were missing, a police official said, as he announced the death toll in the building where the explosion occurred. It housed about 10 families. There were none dead in the adjacent buildings. The middle section of the three-story, U-shaped complex, containing at least 12 apartments was flattened. Two wings of it were heavily damaged by fire from the explosion. Rescue workers — guided by screams and moans — dug into the debris trying to reach an undetermined number who were trapped when the building collapsed with a ‘‘big boom,’’ according to witnesses. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 2, 1965

headline: Kerry Welcoming, but Wary of Netanyahu
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry tried to lower the temperature in the three-way fight among congressional Republicans, the Obama administration and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State John Kerry tried to lower the temperature on Sunday in the three-way fight among congressional Republicans, the Obama administration and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, saying that Mr. Netanyahu was welcome to speak in the United States.

headline: Spring Awakening
abstract: In which we attempt to summon the season of spring.
lead_paragraph: TIMES INSIDER — It’s probably too early to start wishing for it, but spring is coming soon, right? And we’ll be able to go outside again, right?

headline: Minnie Minoso, Helped Integrate Baseball With White Sox, Dies at 89
abstract: Minoso, the major leagues’ first black player out of Latin America, was often cited as the only modern major leaguer to play in five decades.
lead_paragraph: Minnie Minoso, the hugely popular All-Star outfielder from Cuba who was the major leagues’ first black player out of Latin America and a treasured figure in the history of the Chicago White Sox, died on Sunday in Chicago. His true age was never entirely clear, but by an account in his autobiography, he would have been 89 when he died.

headline: Icy Stillness and Muted Fishing in a New England Port
abstract: The icy winter has slowed commerce in normally bustling New Bedford, Mass., the nation’s top commercial fishing port.
lead_paragraph: NEW BEDFORD, Mass. — Mark Abraham, who has fished the New England coast for decades, kept a sharp eye on his catch as the slimy haddock spilled onto a dockside conveyor belt. He had just returned from 10 frigid days at sea, among the most brutal he has spent.

headline: ‘Focus’ Takes Top Box-Office Spot
abstract: Bad weather led to a weak turnout at the box office.
lead_paragraph: Will Smith will have to wait for another movie to vanquish concerns about his popularity among moviegoers. Terrible weather across the United States contributed to weak multiplex turnout over the weekend, with ticket sales down 14 percent compared with the same period last year, according to Rentrak, which compiles box-office data. In his first major role since the 2013 bomb “After Earth,” Mr. Smith helped “Focus” collect roughly $19.1 million in North American ticket sales, easily enough for first place but a bit less than most analysts had expected.

headline: Dolce & Gabbana’s Romantic, Sexy Mama Buns
abstract: T shares the best hairstyles from the runways. Today’s pick: sophisticated ‘dos accented with enchanting gold clips and bands.
lead_paragraph: T shares the best hairstyles from the runways.

headline: Milan Remembers John Fairchild
abstract: Many at fashion week express their sense of loss at the publisher's death.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — For an industry in the unbreakable slipstream of fashion shows, news of John Fairchild’s death broke slowly. Mr. Fairchild died during fashion week, a fact he might have liked, or at least deemed appropriate. So while the fact was spreading on social media Friday morning New York time, it was late afternoon in Milan, and most of the editors — including Mr. Fairchild’s successors at Women’s Wear Daily — were watching Alessandra Facchinetti’s collection for Tod’s.

headline: Samsung Galaxy S6 and Galaxy S6 Edge, Unveiled at Mobile World Congress, Offer Best of iPhone and More
keywords: ['Mobile Commerce and Payments', 'Mobile World Congress (Trade Show)', 'Smartphones', 'Virtual Reality (Computers)']
abstract: Samsung has been accused of being a copycat, but after adding its own design twists to popular features borrowed from the competition, its new flagship phone feels like a real flagship.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — Samsung has often been accused of being a clever copycat. In the case of its new flagship Galaxy S phones, announced Sunday at the Mobile World Congress in Barcelona, Spain, Samsung has created phones that unquestionably borrow on the most appealing elements of the iPhone. But they also stand out with their own impressive design twists.

headline: Hindu Party in India in Coalition for Kashmir
abstract: Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s Bharatiya Janata joined a regional party to create a state government in Kashmir, the first time the Hindu party has held a leadership role in the disputed region.
lead_paragraph: JAMMU, India — After months of negotiations, India’s governing Hindu nationalist party joined a regional party dominated by Muslims to create a state government in the disputed Kashmir region, the first time the Hindu party has ever held a leadership role here.

headline: When Fashion Gossip Becomes an Accessory
abstract: Emilio Pucci will not confirm or deny that Peter Dundas is leaving, the kind of comment that keeps turning up recently and draws everyone's attention from the clothes.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — The most ubiquitous, and worst, trend in fashion these days may not be a silhouette, or a shade, but a strategy: the acceptance of ambiguity and gossip around a creative transition.

lead_paragraph: As the disease moved closer to elimination, fishermen back from a trip at sea were believed to have started a new cluster in a phase that health officials call “the bumpy road to zero.”

headline: Turning a Subway Car Into a Gallery, Until the Last Stop
abstract: At 55, Fernando Miteff, known in the 1970s as Nic 707, has found his way back to the work he once loved.
lead_paragraph: Fernando Miteff was inside an empty subway car waiting for the go-ahead from a friend who stood sentry by an open door, scanning the platform for conductors, police officers or anyone else who might disrupt his plan.

headline: Review: Barbara Cook Sang Standards, With Audience Members as Acolytes
abstract: At 87, in the twilight of her career, Ms. Cook’s concert at the packed Appel Room drew audience members who came to pay tribute and to bask in her still-radiant presence.
lead_paragraph: Barbara Cook’s American Songbook concert at the Appel Room on Saturday evening had the air of a family gathering at the bedside of an ailing but still vital matriarch. “I’m not dying,” she assured her flock, for whom she is a voice of sanity and wisdom like none other. Her difficulty in walking she ascribed to two lower-back fractures that may be treatable.

headline: Review: ‘The Light Princess,’ a Musical at the New Victory Theater
abstract: “The Light Princess,” a richly imagined and delightfully acted musical based on a story by George MacDonald, is at the New Victory Theater.
lead_paragraph: If only NASA had existed in days of yore. Its scientists might have had coping strategies for the heroine of “The Light Princess,” who has an unusual fairy tale problem: weightlessness.

headline: Review: In ‘Rocket to the Moon,’ a Dentist Deals With a Midlife Crisis
abstract: In a revival of this Clifford Odets play, directed by Dan Wackerman, the protagonist dreams of a less soul-sucking life, yet lacks the courage to try to build one.
lead_paragraph: The Depression is raging, and so is the summer heat. The patients with money have left the city for the beach, and the others can’t afford to have their teeth fixed, anyway.

headline: Review: ‘Hitting Bedrock’ at La MaMa Taps Into War’s Confusion
abstract: The war transformed a benign theater project into a docuplay that tries, with some success, to convey the feeling of living in a country being plunged into chaos.
lead_paragraph: When I was first told to leave the theater during the beginning of “Hitting Bedrock,” I grinned, thinking I’d misheard. A repeated request, however, was hard and clear enough to let me know that this was no joke.

headline: Frozen Harbor in New Bedford, Mass.
abstract: The Coast Guard cutter Ida Lewis made its way through the harbor ice in New Bedford, Mass., last week. The harsh winter has slowed commerce in the nation’s No. 1 commercial fishing port.
lead_paragraph: The Coast Guard cutter Ida Lewis made its way through the harbor ice in New Bedford, Mass., last week. The harsh winter has slowed commerce in the nation’s No. 1 commercial fishing port.

headline: Review: ‘John & Jen,’ a Revival Starring Kate Baldwin and Conor Ryan
abstract: In this musical, a woman has complicated relationships with her brother and then her son.
lead_paragraph: Growing up isn’t easy. Just take a look at Richard Linklater’s “Boyhood” if you need reminding. But imagine how difficult it must be to do so — and I mean the hard part, from early childhood to the end of adolescence — in less than two hours, and in song, and in front of a live audience.

headline: Review: ‘Comfort Dogs’ Explores the Solace of Communing With Canines
abstract: This experimental play by William Burke, whose cast includes dogs played by humans and real dogs, forces you to look at the nature of communication a little differently.
lead_paragraph: The performers in the playwright and director William Burke’s “Comfort Dogs: Live From the Pink House” are unusually brazen. They will sniff your hand, nuzzle your thigh, leap into your lap. Some of these actors are dogs. Some are people playing dogs. All are pretty cute.

headline: Review: ‘Tap Lab,’ From the Bang Group, Conveys Musical Scores Through Footwork
abstract: At the 92nd Street Y, the company, led by David Parker, attempted to realize scores by Mozart, Morton Feldman and Steve Reich with foot and body percussion.
lead_paragraph: If tap dancing is music as well as dance, then why not use tap to play musical scores? Such was the plausible idea behind “Tap Lab,” the Bang Group’s contribution to the Harkness Dance Festival. At the 92nd Street Y on Saturday, the company, led by David Parker, attempted to realize scores by Mozart, Morton Feldman and Steve Reich with foot and body percussion. “Tab Lab” was an accurate title for a collection of dogged exercises and weak experiments. Rather than metal on wood or skin on skin, the dominant sound was a kind of silence: the absence of inspiration.

abstract: There are so many new plot threads in the first few minutes of this episode that we thought we had mistakenly skipped ahead.

headline: Review: In Olen Steinhauer’s ‘All the Old Knives,’ Exes Recall Love and Blood
abstract: In this thriller, former lovers and colleagues in espionage meet at a California restaurant to recall a tryst and resurrect memories of a hostage crisis.
lead_paragraph: The inspiration for “All the Old Knives,” Olen Steinhauer’s unusually short and wily spy novel, was a television adaptation of a poem. As he watched Alan Rickman and Emma Thompson in the 2010 British dramatization of the Christopher Reid poem “The Song of Lunch,” Mr. Steinhauer was excited by its structure. The poem describes two lovers meeting for a meal long after the end of their affair, and it is essentially confined to a restaurant. Could a good spy novel be written if an author played by those same rules?

headline: Juilliard and the Manhattan School of Music Play Strauss’s ‘Ein Heldenleben’
abstract: Two orchestras say they performed the challenging “Ein Heldenleben” without knowing the other institution had planned to do the same.
lead_paragraph: “Ein Heldenleben” (“A Hero’s Life”), Richard Strauss’s grandiose paean to himself, which makes huge demands on a symphony orchestra, does not leap to mind as grist for a student performance. Yet there it was last week, twice, performed by students of the Juilliard School and the Manhattan School of Music. The Juilliard Orchestra played it on Tuesday at Carnegie Hall, led by the veteran maestro David Zinman, and the M.S.M. Symphony performed it on Thursday at the Manhattan School, conducted by George Manahan, the school’s director of orchestral activities.

headline: ‘Fault in Our Stars’ Team to Adapt Another Novel
abstract: The screenwriters Scott Neustadter and Michael H. Weber have signed on to write the adaptation of John Green’s debut novel, “Looking for Alaska.”
lead_paragraph: John Green’s debut novel, “Looking for Alaska,” is coming to the big screen, and the screenwriters Scott Neustadter and Michael H. Weber have signed on to write the adaptation. The screenwriting pair previously worked with Mr. Green on the box office hit “The Fault in Our Stars,” as well as Mr. Green’s 2008 novel, “Paper Towns,” to be released in theaters this summer. “Looking for Alaska” won the Michael L. Printz Award, and depicts a teenage boarding school romance gone awry. The novel currently sits at No. 4 on The New York Times Young Adult Best Sellers list. (“The Fault in Our Stars” still holds the top spot.) Mr. Neustadter and Mr. Weber previously teamed up to write “The Spectacular Now” and “(500) Days of Summer.” They are also involved in adapting another best-selling novel, “Where’d You Go, Bernadette,” which Richard Linklater has been tapped to direct.

headline: Nick Offerman Joins ‘Confederacy of Dunces’
abstract: The “Parks and Recreation” alumnus will star in the world premiere production of “A Confederacy of Dunces” with the Huntington Theater Company in Boston.
lead_paragraph: It’s not quite The Cones of Dunshire, but it’s close. This November, the “Parks and Recreation” alumnus Nick Offerman will star in the world premiere production of “A Confederacy of Dunces” with the Huntington Theater Company in Boston. The play is being adapted by Jeffrey Hatcher (“Stage Beauty”) from the beloved 1980 novel of the same name by John Kennedy Toole. Alan Friedman called the novel a “masterwork of comedy” in his review for The New York Times Book Review. Mr. Toole was awarded the 1981 Pulitzer Prize for the novel posthumously; he committed suicide in 1969. Many efforts have been made to adapt the novel. John Belushi, Will Ferrell and Jack Black were among those attached to various film projects that never fully developed. Mr. Offerman will be the first lead in the role, and will move from one outlandish egotist (on “Parks”) to another. “I am simply tumescent at the prospect of assaying the beloved character of Ignatius J. Reilly with our team of magnificent and weird artistic champions,” Mr. Offerman said in a statement. “It seems only fitting that I should follow seven seasons of Ron Swanson’s beef with the pudding of Toole’s corpulent fop.” David Esbjornson will direct. Performances are scheduled to run Nov. 11 through Dec. 13.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Dolce & Gabbana Fall/Winter 2015
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Filippo Mutani.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Filippo Mutani.

headline: Cumming and Hall to Play Café Carlyle
abstract: The Carlyle will welcome Alan Cumming and Lena Hall for its spring season.
lead_paragraph: Alan Cumming isn’t done with New York just yet. After wrapping up his return to his Tony-winning role as the M.C. in “Cabaret” in March, Mr. Cumming will make his debut at the Café Carlyle for a two-week stint from June 2 to 13. The program is “Alan Cumming Sings Sappy Songs,” and will also feature the Emmy-winning musical director Lance Horne and the cellist Eleanor Norton. The Carlyle will welcome another Broadway star for its spring season: Lena Hall, fresh after starring as Yitzhak in “Hedwig and the Angry Inch,” which won the 2014 Tony Award for best musical revival. Ms. Hall will be performing April 7 to 18. Other performers announced include John Pizzarelli (April 21 to May 2) and Judy Collins (May 5 to 16).

headline: NXP and Freescale, Two Semiconductor Giants, Said to Be Near a Merger
abstract: NXP Semiconductors is closing in on a deal to acquire a smaller peer, Freescale Semiconductor, in a cash-and-stock transaction.
lead_paragraph: NXP Semiconductors, a big chip manufacturer, is near a deal to acquire a smaller peer, Freescale Semiconductor, in a cash-and-stock transaction, people briefed on the matter said on Sunday.

headline: The National Museum of Iraq Reopens
abstract: In response to the destruction of ancient artifacts by militants in northern Iraq, the museum has officially reopened for the first time in 12 years.
lead_paragraph: In response to the destruction of ancient artifacts by militants in northern Iraq, Iraq’s National Museum, in Baghdad, has officially reopened for the first time in 12 years. The museum suffered great losses after the American invasion in 2003 — it was one of the many sites that fell prey to rampant looting during the war. Some 15,000 pieces, including ancient statues, sculptures and cuneiform tablets, were pillaged. But museum officials announced the recovery of hundreds of items in 2010, and now report that one-third of the missing items are back in the collection. Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi was on hand for the ceremonies and condemned the Islamic State, which posted videos of militants taking sledgehammers to statues and reliefs in the Mosul Museum in northern Iraq. “Those barbaric, criminal terrorists are trying to destroy the heritage of mankind and Iraq’s civilization,” Mr. al-Abadi said, according to the BBC.

headline: Speech by Netanyahu Opens Political Divisions in Israel, Too
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s coming speech to Congress is taking place in a highly charged election period in Israel and has spawned a fraught debate.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — At Jerusalem’s bustling Mahane Yehuda market, a traditional bastion of support for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s conservative Likud Party, Israeli divisions played out among the fruit and vegetable stalls on Sunday as Mr. Netanyahu departed for Washington with plans to deliver a contentious speech on the Iranian nuclear threat before a joint meeting of Congress.

headline: Xi Jinping’s ‘Four Comprehensives’ Give Shape to a Crowded Agenda
abstract: President Xi Jinping’s “Four Comprehensives,” praised lavishly by state-run media, shows how party messages are crafted with vagueness to give an aura of grandeur to the business of ruling.
lead_paragraph: Slogans studded with numerals and abstract exhortations are central to the dramaturgy of the Chinese Communist Party, intoned like spells to exalt leaders, cajole citizens and malign enemies. Yet as President Xi Jinping’s latest contribution shows, the magic of a party slogan often works through its supple vagueness.

headline: Radio Station Identification
abstract: Andrea Carla Michaels starts off our solving week.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — The nice thing about Monday puzzles is that you can depend upon them to make you feel smart, especially if you have already tumbled to the “crossword solver’s way of thinking.” A good Monday puzzle should feel like a break in the proceedings, a smooth solve that restores your faith in your abilities after the weekend battles with the constructors and Will Shortz. If you’re very lucky, the puzzle will be entertaining as well, enough so as to bring out a smile on your face.

headline: Gray Matter
abstract: The prolific documentarian Alex Gibney, who finds intrigue — and Oscar acclaim — in subjects rich in ambiguity, takes on the Church of Scientology.
lead_paragraph: The filmmaker Alex Gibney is drawn to the murky area between good and evil, truth and fiction. The Church of Scientology may be his most perfect subject yet.

headline: White Collar Crimes: Where Are They Now?
abstract: L. Dennis Kozlowski wasn’t the only corporate executive of his era who was convicted for fraud and other wrongdoing.
lead_paragraph: L. Dennis Kozlowski wasn’t the only corporate executive of his era who was convicted for fraud and other wrongdoing.

headline: Tyco’s ‘Piggy,’ Out of Prison and Living Small
abstract: Convicted in 2005 of looting nearly $100 million from Tyco, L. Dennis Kozlowski was the face of Wall Street gluttony. Now a free man, he speaks for the first time of his more modest life.
lead_paragraph: These days, his shower curtain is from Bed Bath & Beyond in a nondescript white.

headline: Argentine President Denies Cover-Up in Bombing Inquiry
abstract: Cristina Fernández de Kirchner defended her role in the investigation into the fatal bombing of a Jewish community center here in 1994, after a judge dismissed criminal allegations against her.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner of Argentina made an impassioned defense on Sunday of her role in the investigation into the fatal bombing of a Jewish community center here in 1994, days after a judge dismissed criminal allegations against her.

headline: Data Security Is Becoming the Sparkle in Bitcoin
abstract: With the price of Bitcoin plummeting, the technology that stores the currency’s transactions is gaining value as a safe and open way to keep other kinds of records.
lead_paragraph: Some couples opt for a traditional wedding, while others go for the Elvis impersonator in Las Vegas. But David Mondrus and Joyce Bayo may be the first to have incorporated Bitcoin.

headline: Towns Made for Burning
abstract: The Union army’s scorched earth campaign reached its climax in South Carolina.
lead_paragraph: “I never saw so much destruction before,” Charles Wright Wills of the 103rd Illinois Infantry wrote in his diary on Feb. 7, 1865. This was no idle hyperbole. Wills had been at war for nearly four years, moving through the ranks from private to major. He’d seen hard fighting throughout the Atlanta Campaign, and plenty of devastation along the March to the Sea. But now he was in South Carolina, and the entire tenor of the March had changed.

headline: To Questions, Alex Rodriguez Has but One Real Reply
abstract: In an abbreviated 85-second meeting with reporters, Rodriguez brushed off questions about when he might take the field in a game with “I’ll talk to Joe first” or a variation of it.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Move over, Marshawn (“I’m just here so I don’t get fined”) Lynch and Rasheed (“Both teams played hard”) Wallace. Alex (“I’ll talk to Joe first”) Rodriguez may be prepared to join you on the Mount Rushmore of pat answers.

headline: Conversation With Orrin Hatch
abstract: Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah answers questions about the current political landscape.
lead_paragraph: Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah answers questions about the current political landscape.

headline: 10 Questions for Senator Orrin Hatch
abstract: The chairman of the Senate Finance Committee is a key figure in efforts at revising the tax code, but he says partisanship will be an obstacle.
lead_paragraph: When Republicans recaptured the Senate last fall, Orrin G. Hatch of Utah became chairman of the Finance Committee overseeing the federal tax code. As the chamber’s longest-serving Republican, Mr. Hatch, 80, is also Senate president pro tempore — third in the line of presidential succession after the vice president and the speaker of the House.

headline: Netanyahu’s Visit Bringing Uninvited Problems for Jewish Democrats
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The division caused by the Israeli prime minister’s coming speech to Congress is keenly felt among the Jewish members of Congress — all but one of them Democratic — and seems to reflect the dismay of American Jews.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaker John A. Boehner’s unilateral invitation to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to address Congress on Tuesday has turned a foreign policy issue that has had near unanimous support in both parties — Israel — into a bruising political showdown.

headline: Anthony R. Cucci, Combative Jersey City Mayor, Dies at 92
abstract: Mr. Cucci, a Jersey City guy through and through, won a bruising campaign in 1985 but later lost a re-election bid to the same opponent, Gerald McCann.
lead_paragraph: Anthony R. Cucci, whose term as mayor of Jersey City was rife with the bitterness of local politics and colored with sidelights both tragic and comic, died on Thursday in Jersey City. He was 92.

headline: Syria: 19 Christians Have Been Released by the Islamic State, Local Leaders Say
abstract: Nineteen of the Assyrian Christians seized by Islamic State militants last week in northeastern Syria have been freed, and they met with church officials in a cathedral in the city of Hasaka, local leaders said Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Nineteen of the Assyrian Christians seized by Islamic State militants last week in northeastern Syria have been freed, and they met with church officials in a cathedral in the city of Hasaka, local leaders said Sunday. Three of those freed were women, and according to videos and photographs, some appeared to be elderly men. Dawoud Dawoud, an official with the Assyrian Democratic Organization, said that Islamic State fighters were reported to be looting some of the villages they seized along the Khabur River, where many of the hostages were captured. Scores of the captives remain unaccounted for, though Sunni Arab local leaders have been mediating between Assyrian Christian leaders and Islamic State militants to free the rest, officials said. Meanwhile, the United States-led coalition against the Islamic State bombed targets near Hasaka for the third day in a row, according to Central Command. The strikes suggested a stepped-up operation in response to the advance by Islamic State militants that drove more than 1,000 of the Assyrian Christians, a minority in Syria, from their homes.

headline: Algeria: Violence Erupts at Protest Over Shale Gas Drilling Project
abstract: Protests in southern Algeria turned violent over the weekend when the police clashed with demonstrators outside a base run by the American company Halliburton near the town of Ain Salah.
lead_paragraph: Protests against hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, for shale gas in southern Algeria turned violent over the weekend when the police clashed with demonstrators outside a base run by the American company Halliburton near the town of Ain Salah. Tensions were still running high on Sunday, but no further violence was reported. Antifracking protests against the government oil and gas company Sonatrach and its international partners have occurred almost daily for two months, but had been peaceful until now. Clashes broke out when protesters approached Halliburton’s walled compound and burned tires in the roads. The police fired tear gas and detained at least a dozen. About 20 protesters were injured, three of them seriously, according to a local hospital. Algeria, which gets much of its revenue from the export of oil and gas, has been conducting a pilot project to test for shale gas near Ain Salah and announced in December that it was ready to start extracting gas by hydraulic fracturing. Groups that oppose the government have joined the local protesters in Ain Salah to demand a moratorium on fracking, citing environmental concerns.

headline: In Los Angeles, Stadiums Battle Heats Up
abstract: With three N.F.L. teams vying to move to the same city, studies criticize one proposal for a stadium in Inglewood, Calif.
lead_paragraph: For years, the N.F.L. played cat and mouse with the city of Los Angeles. Every so often a team in, say, Minnesota, would threaten to move to L.A. in an effort to crowbar concessions out of its government leaders back home. Once the team got public financing, it stayed put.

headline: Colorado Yogis Balk at State Regulation of Teacher Training
abstract: A debate that has roiled Colorado’s growing yoga world pits studio owners against a state agency that says programs to train yoga teachers must be certified.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — It was evening at one of this city’s most popular yoga centers, and teacher training was about to begin. Students wore flowing genie pants. Votive candles lit a classroom. Annie Prasad Freedom, the studio’s founder, greeted arriving yogis.

headline: News Corp. Set to Rehire Rebekah Brooks, Acquitted Executive
abstract: After being acquitted in a British phone hacking scandal, Ms. Brooks is expected to take an executive role seeking ways to expand the company’s digital endeavors, people familiar with its plans said.
lead_paragraph: Rebekah Brooks, the former head of Rupert Murdoch’s media holdings in Britain, acquitted last year on charges related to the phone hacking scandal, is likely to return to News Corporation to focus on new avenues for digital and social media, people familiar with the company’s plans said.

headline: Recordings Suggest Emirates and Egyptian Military Pushed Ousting of Morsi

lead_paragraph: Audio recordings of senior Egyptian officials that were leaked Sunday suggest that when Mohamed Morsi was president, the United Arab Emirates gave the Egyptian Defense Ministry money for a protest campaign against him.

headline: Industry Issues Intrude in ‘Blurred Lines’ Case

lead_paragraph: Before a special audience in Los Angeles last week, the velvet-voiced pop singer Robin Thicke performed his 2013 hit “Blurred Lines,” ran through a medley at the piano and discussed artistic inspiration.

headline: Shoestring Legal Aid Group Helps Poor in Rural India
keywords: ['Legal Aid for the Poor (Civil)', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']

lead_paragraph: JAGDALPUR, India — On a quiet night last November, the human rights lawyer Shalini Gera was brewing tea in her drab, small-town office, which doubles as an apartment, when her basic Nokia phone began vibrating on a plastic table.

headline: AT&T’s Chief of Mobile and Business Explains the World Beyond Phones
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles', 'Mobile Applications', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Wireless Communications']

lead_paragraph: AT&T, the second-largest wireless carrier in the United States, says it is has found life beyond being a phone carrier.

headline: Marina Abramovic to Publish a Memoir in 2016
abstract: The book, to be published by Crown Archetype, will coincide with the artist’s 70th birthday.
lead_paragraph: Marina Abramovic has never been shy about exposing herself for the sake of art. She’s stretched out naked on the floor under a model skeleton in one piece of performance art, shivered nude on a block of ice in another, and lived on a platform for 12 days in a Chelsea gallery, where visitors watched her bathe, sleep and go to the bathroom.

headline: 2=Jeter, 3=Ruth, 4=Gehrig. ... In the Bronx, Numbers Are Finite.
abstract: The Yankees retire numbers with gusto, 18 to date and three more soon, but this zest also limits options when it comes to assigning numbers to current players.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — When Garrett Jones was traded to the Yankees in December, he was hoping to bring with him his good-luck charm of a number, 46. When the Yankees acquired shortstop Brendan Ryan, he knew he would be denied his favorite childhood number, 7. And when Jacoby Ellsbury signed a free-agent contract with the Yankees, he realized that even though the team was giving him $153 million, the Yankees would not give him a jersey with 2 on the back.

lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Until its advertising software was discovered deep inside Lenovo personal computers two weeks ago, a little company called Superfish had maintained a surprisingly low profile for an outfit once named America’s fastest-growing software start-up.

headline: American Ballet Theater and Fired Worker to Go to Trial Over His Temper
keywords: ['Bipolar Disorder', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Discrimination', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Dancing']

lead_paragraph: At the Metropolitan Opera House, Frank La Mantia was known as a tempestuous, behind-the-scenes man for American Ballet Theater. For years, he helped position the sets, the props and the shimmering backdrops, the scenery that transported audiences from their seats to another world.

headline: Justice Department to Fault Ferguson Police, Seeing Racial Bias in Traffic Stops
keywords: ['Police', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Discrimination', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: A Justice Department report will accuse the police in Ferguson, Mo., of making discriminatory traffic stops of African-Americans that created racial animosity leading up to an officer’s shooting of a black teenager, law enforcement officials said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department has nearly completed a highly critical report accusing the police in Ferguson, Mo., of making discriminatory traffic stops of African-Americans that created years of racial animosity leading up to an officer’s shooting of a black teenager last summer, law enforcement officials said.

headline: Poor and Forgotten, a South Bronx Park Gets a Small Boost
keywords: ['Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Playgrounds']
abstract: St. Mary’s Park, which got a grant from the City Council speaker, was too large to be included in the mayor’s initiative to renovate parks in rundown communities.
lead_paragraph: Pity St. Mary’s Park. Too small and too poor to be supported by a park conservancy that might fix up its faded charms. Too big to make it onto the list of 35 parks in Mayor Bill de Blasio’s Community Parks Initiative, which is funneling $130 million in capital money into shabby parks in low-income neighborhoods across the city.

headline: The Strange Urge to Raise Rates
abstract: Obsessions, beyond the usual crazy.
lead_paragraph: Monetary policy attracts crazy people like moths to a flame; goldbugs, 100-percent-reserve-banking types, amateur historians who think they know exactly what happened when Diocletian ruled Rome but have no idea what happened in Japan in the last decade. One thing that has surprised and depressed me in recent years, however, has been the obsession with raising interest rates among economists who used to seem sensible.

lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Seven o’clock on a Tuesday, and the gold-clad, goose-calling, Tim McGraw-crooning fans of the Nashville Predators are offering an updated primer in Southern hospitality.

lead_paragraph: Women in Afghanistan have seen considerable improvement in living and working conditions since the Taliban’s gradual exit. But key indicators of progress lag behind those of nearby developing countries.

abstract: Mason, who died Saturday at 48, had the tenacity and talent that made him one of the select few to achieve the dream of becoming a professional athlete.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Mason was one in a million: a caring son, a loving father, a loyal friend and brother.

headline: Marching in One St. Patrick’s Parade, de Blasio Spurns Another
abstract: At the inclusive St. Pat’s for All parade in Queens, Mayor Bill de Blasio vowed to continue to boycott the city’s marquee parade, saying its admission of one gay group this year was “too small a change.”
lead_paragraph: There were shamrock ears, bagpipers and green top hats, and more than a little politics on display Sunday at a St. Patrick’s Day parade in Sunnyside, Queens, that emphasized a message of inclusiveness as it moved down Skillman Avenue.

headline: First for Ian Poulter Fades Quickly at Delayed Honda Classic
abstract: Poulter held the lead after 54 holes, but Paul Casey caught up to tie him the final round, which was half-completed when darkness fell.
lead_paragraph: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla. — Ian Poulter cruised to his first 54-hole lead in a PGA Tour event on Sunday — not that he had much time to dwell on it. Less than an hour after signing for his third-round, four-under-par 66, Poulter returned to PGA National’s Champion course for his fourth round in the weather-delayed Honda Classic.

headline: Popular Demand
abstract: Wendy’s campaign for its pretzel bacon cheeseburger was the commercial best recalled by millennials last year. Recall varied among millennial demographic groups. lead_paragraph: Wendy’s campaign for its pretzel bacon cheeseburger was the commercial best recalled by millennials last year. Recall varied among millennial demographic groups. headline: What’s On TV Monday

lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (El Rey) EL REY NETWORK PRESENTS: THE DIRECTOR’S CHAIR The El Rey network founder Robert Rodriguez interviews Francis Ford Coppola about his inspiration, his reluctance to direct both “The Godfather” (starring Marlon Brando, above) and “The Godfather: Part II,” and his struggles with “Apocalypse Now.” The talk is followed at 9 by “The Conversation” (1974), starring Gene Hackman as Harry Caul, a surveillance expert who has been hired to eavesdrop on a married woman (Cindy Williams) and her lover (Frederic Forrest) by her husband, known as the Director (Robert Duvall). But three people have died because of Harry’s work, and now he’s worried that two more may soon die. The film received three Oscar nominations but lost for best picture to “The Godfather: Part II.” Writing in The New York Times, Vincent Canby called “The Conversation” haunting and bothersome: “Haunting because its suggestion that technology has gotten out of hand, though not exactly new, is so convincingly and fastidiously detailed. It’s bothersome because Mr. Coppola, the writer as well as the director, has nearly succeeded in making a great film but has, instead, made one that is merely very good.”

headline: Walmart’s Visible Hand
keywords: ['Wages and Salaries', 'United States Economy', 'Minimum Wage', 'Income Inequality', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)']
abstract: A pay raise by America’s largest employer shows that low wages are a choice, and that we can and should choose differently.
lead_paragraph: A few days ago Walmart, America’s largest employer, announced that it will raise wages for half a million workers. For many of those workers the gains will be small, but the announcement is nonetheless a very big deal, for two reasons. First, there will be spillovers: Walmart is so big that its action will probably lead to raises for millions of workers employed by other companies. Second, and arguably far more important, is what Walmart’s move tells us — namely, that low wages are a political choice, and we can and should choose differently.

headline: ‘Please Stop Helping Us’ and ‘Shame’
abstract: Two black conservatives argue that a sense of victimhood, not social forces, creates problems for African-Americans.
lead_paragraph: One of the few things conservatives and liberals agree on about the ’60s is that it was a decade of radical change in the nation’s politics, ethnoracial and gender relations, popular culture and international policies. For liberals, the decade marked the nation’s greatest transition toward a new era of personal, socioeconomic and political liberation and inclusion, especially for blacks, initiated by the courts, the civil and voting rights acts and the Great Society programs. To most conservatives, the period, with few exceptions, was a terrible turn for the worse. And for African-­American conservatives like ­Jason L. ­Riley and Shelby Steele, beyond the ending of formal discrimination in voting, education and civil rights, the era was for black Americans an unmitigated disaster, the consequences of which persist to this day.

headline: The Slippery Slope of Disinflation
abstract: Too-low inflation is not OK.
lead_paragraph: Arguments for tight money often rest on claims that inflation, even at low rates, is a slippery slope: say that 2 percent is OK, then people will make the case for 4, then 10, and before you know it we’re Weimar. It’s not clear whether that has ever really happened: actually existing Weimar, like all hyperinflations, was a byproduct of political chaos, and the 1970s had as much to do with oil shocks as with policy misjudgments. In any case, it’s certainly nothing we’ve seen in advanced countries for a long time.

headline: 1940: Roosevelts in Divorce Court
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: James Roosevelt asks his wife for divorce in 1940.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — After meeting Romelle Schneider, a nurse at the Mayo Clinic where he was treated last summer, James Roosevelt twice asked his wife for a divorce, Mrs. Roosevelt testified in divorce court here today [March 2]. Both times, Mrs. Roosevelt, born Betty Cushing, refused to give her husband, the President’s oldest son, a divorce, she said. On February 15 he filed a suit for separation, charging his wife with desertion. Mrs. Roosevelt filed a cross-suit in which she asked for a settlement of $50,000, which would be paid immediately, and an additional $25,000 annually until she dies or re-marries or her husband dies. She is also asking the custody of their two daughters. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 3, 1940

headline: Rev. Malcolm Boyd, an Author, Activist and Counterculture Rebel, Dies at 91
abstract: Father Boyd was among a handful of white clergymen who became nationally known for civil rights and protesting war, and — after disclosing in 1976 that he was gay — fought for women and homosexuals in the church.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Malcolm Boyd, an Episcopal priest and author who challenged racism, war and religious complacency in the 1960s and ’70s, and was one of the first prominent clergymen in America to acknowledge his homosexuality publicly, died on Friday in Los Angeles. He was 91.

headline: Los Angeles Philharmonic Chief Heads to Harvard
abstract: Deborah Borda, who has led the Philharmonic for 15 years, will take a four-month sabbatical to join the Center for Public Leadership at the Harvard Kennedy School.
lead_paragraph: Deborah Borda is going from Walt Disney Concert Hall and the Hollywood Bowl to Harvard.

headline: Philadelphia Fed Picks Patrick Harker, University of Delaware President, to Lead It
abstract: Mr. Harker, an engineer by training who has spent most of his career as an academic, has served on the Philadelphia Fed’s board for three years.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia said Monday that it had named as its new president Patrick Harker, president of the University of Delaware.

headline: The Unknown Notebooks of Jean-Michel Basquiat

lead_paragraph: Graffitist, painter, actor poet: The late artist’s rarely seen personal writings and sketches are expressions of 1980s downtown New York, and, perhaps, of his truest vision.

headline: Removing an Artist’s Lifework
abstract: After 40 years in the diamond district of Manhattan, the Ney family is being evicted on March 19. Joel Ney is rushing to move about 4,000 pieces of his father’s artwork from the premises.

headline: 15 Pieces of Art Snatched From Fontainebleau
abstract: The burglary took place early Sunday, and the thieves were in and out of the castle, southeast of Paris, in about seven minutes – the time from when the alarm was set off to when the police arrived.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — French investigators are searching for 15 gold and bronze artworks stolen from the Château de Fontainebleau in an early morning break-in on Sunday. The target was a crown that once belonged to the king of Siam.

headline: In Eviction From Diamond District, Losing Much More Than Home
keywords: ['Art', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Evictions', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']

lead_paragraph: The small room is cluttered with paintings and sculptures — some colorful, some stark, some fresh and pliant, some old and burned. Whatever their state, all appear to incandesce.

headline: Nature’s Fighter Jets With Flapping Wings

lead_paragraph: The goshawk, a powerful predatory bird that can take down prey like pheasants, rabbits and crows, is having a literary moment with “H Is for Hawk,” an award-winning memoir by Helen Macdonald that mixes a tale of personal loss with the struggle to train a goshawk to hunt.

Parties and celebrities were thin on the ground; the biggest trends to emerge have been Lurex and fur for the feet (really: sheared-mink shoes will be big come September). The ’80s are of interest to some. Rumors have swirled with no closure.

But for Jean Bardet, a semiretired chef with two Michelin stars to his name, there was little confusion about the worthiness of such bottles.

headline: Nose Sniffling
The Brilliant Boris Nemtsov: A Reformer Who Never Backed Down
abstract: What will remain is not a murder case, but the image of the opposition politician who had once personified so many of Russia’s hopes.
lead_paragraph: Eventually they’ll arrest someone for murdering Boris Nemtsov, especially after President Vladimir Putin was said to be giving the case his personal attention. The authorities have already begun to spin conspiracy theories, including the outrageous suggestion that he may have been killed by political allies to create a martyr. What will remain is not a murder case, but the image of the opposition politician who had once personified so many of Russia’s hopes, lying dead within sight of the Kremlin fortress and the whimsical cupolas of St. Basil’s Cathedral.

headline: Maggie Smith Says She Will Leave ‘Downton Abbey’ After Next Season
abstract: “They say this is the last one, and I can’t see how it could go on.”
lead_paragraph: The Dowager Countess is done and there’s no use in trying to convince her otherwise. Maggie Smith, who plays the quip-ready matriarch on the hit British series that just finished its fifth season in the United States, said in an interview with The Sunday Times that she was done with the character following the upcoming season.

headline: 1965: Jets Blast North Vietnam
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: United States attacks North Vietnam in 1965.
lead_paragraph: DA NANG, South Vietnam — More than 160 U.S. and Vietnamese Air Force planes hammered two targets in North Vietnam today [March 2] in the biggest air strike to date against the Communists in the North. The massive raid — described as a resounding success — was the first that has been launched as a purely offensive action. All previous U.S. air strikes on the North have been in retaliation for specific Communist attacks in the South. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 3, 1965

headline: Lowering Diabetes Risk After Pregnancy
abstract: About half of women with gestational diabetes eventually develop Type 2 diabetes, but lifestyle changes and metformin can reduce the chances.
lead_paragraph: About nine percent of pregnant women have gestational diabetes, which usually goes away after they give birth. But about half these women will develop Type 2 diabetes later in life. A new study suggests two ways to significantly reduce the risk.

headline: It’s Tough to Be the King Every Night
abstract: After Houston beat the Cleveland Cavaliers on Sunday, the Rockets declared James Harden the new King James, a premature pronouncement.
lead_paragraph: It has been an incredible season for James Harden. The Houston Rockets guard is leading the N.B.A. in scoring, dominated the All-Star Game and has found himself in the conversation for the Most Valuable Player Award. But the Rockets made quite a statement Sunday after an overtime win over the Cleveland Cavaliers when their Twitter account declared Harden the new King James.

abstract: The Internal Revenue Service is not emailing you to request personal information. Not now. Not ever.

headline: Near or Far, Head South to Escape the Winter
abstract: From St. Vincent to South Africa, the Travel section has some suggestions for sunny getaways — just in time for spring break.
lead_paragraph: We seem to be trapped in a winter of extremes — cold snaps, snowfall that feels fit for a Disney movie, droughts that have farmers almost looking at storms in the Northeast with envy. If you just want to run away from it all, you’re not alone. The Travel section has you covered, just in time for spring break.

headline: Disclosure Can Produce Meaningful Change
keywords: ['Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Disclosure is the first, necessary step on the way to ensuring that problematic public actors can be held accountable for bad action.
lead_paragraph: In a recent The Trade column, Jesse Eisinger of ProPublica criticizes Justice Louis Brandeis’s advice that “Sunlight is...the best of disinfectants” for social problems. He describes the reliance on transparency and disclosure as an ineffective “regulatory crutch,” saying that “if lawmakers want to end a bad practice, ban it. Having them admit it is not enough.”

headline: 3 Attica Guards Resign in Deal to Avoid Jail
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Assaults', 'Prison Guards and Corrections Officers']
abstract: The correction officers at the western New York prison, who were accused of beating an inmate, made last-minute plea deals to a misdemeanor misconduct charge.
lead_paragraph: Three guards accused of beating an inmate at the Attica Correctional Facility so severely that doctors had to insert a plate and six pins into his leg each pleaded guilty on Monday to a single misdemeanor charge of misconduct. The last-minute plea deal spared them any jail time in exchange for quitting their jobs.

abstract: All nine of the artist’s rephotographed advertisements will be shown together for the first time at Nahmad Contemporary.
lead_paragraph: The contemporary art market is “almost a fraud,” the billionaire art dealer David Nahmad famously said to the Independent on Sunday several years ago, following another interview in Forbes in which he called the work of artists like Jeff Koons and Richard Prince “luxury products.” Asked about his comments, another member of the prominent clan weighed in: “I don’t think Richard Prince decided to waste his life making trash, so to someone they’re worth something,” Helly Nahmad, of the eponymous London-based gallery, told the Financial Times in 2011. “What they’re worth is a different argument.”

lead_paragraph: CAIRO — An explosion outside a central courthouse killed two people and injured at least nine others on Monday, extending a series of small bombings around Cairo. Security officials said most of those injured were policemen.

headline: ‘My Friend Has a Son Who Is Autistic’
abstract: At first, I didn’t get that the clumsy idle talk was an attempt at showing compassion.
lead_paragraph: When I attend a school function to watch my 11-year-old, who has a language-based learning disability, I am content to stand solo. I love keeping an eye on him from a distance as he sings in a concert or runs around with his classmates.

headline: Questions to Ask a Prospective Financial Adviser
abstract: We shouldn’t care about titles, job descriptions or even where advisers work. Before you hire them, focus instead on what they actually do.
lead_paragraph: There’s a fight brewing in Washington. While fighting in Washington isn’t new, the cause of this particular fight might shock you. People are arguing about financial advice. Last week, the debate gained national attention as President Obama waded into the discussion.

headline: Five More Years for ‘Judge Judy’
abstract: CBS Global Distribution, which syndicates “Judge Judy” around the world, said that Judge Judith Sheindlin, the program’s no-nonsense star, had agreed to extend her contract through 2020.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – Judge Judith Sheindlin has signed on for five more televised years of sorting out rancorous rent disputes, adjudicating stranger-than-fiction dognapping cases and, as ever, zinging litigants as coming from a long line of idiots.

headline: India Begins Campaign to Eliminate Elephantiasis
abstract: The hope is to hand out free pills once a year to 400 million Indians at risk of the disease, which disfigures limbs.
lead_paragraph: India recently began one of the biggest drug-distribution campaigns in its history in an effort to eliminate “elephant’s foot disease,” also known as elephantiasis or lymphatic filariasis.

headline: Mark Zuckerberg Goes on Charm Offensive for Internet.org
abstract: The chief of Facebook outlined why he thinks Internet.org, a service to provide people in emerging markets with free access to some online applications, would help telecommunications carriers persuade customers to spend more on streaming content to their cellphones.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — In front of a packed audience here, Mark Zuckerberg turned on the charm.

headline: A 125-Year-Old Textiles House Teams Up With a ’60s-Inspired Fashion Label
abstract: The designer Lisa Perry created a 13-piece capsule collection using fabrics from the Schumacher archives.
lead_paragraph: When Natasha Garnett profiled the 125-year-old textile company Schumacher for T’s Fall 2014 Women’s Fashion issue, she illustrated the brand’s historic and steadfast dedication to designer collaborations, helmed by its creative director Dara Caponigro. And its latest, a 13-piece capsule collection created with Lisa Perry, is available in New York beginning today at the designer’s Madison Avenue boutique. The tunics, dresses, pants, coats and skirt are a mashup of the two houses’ greatest hits: the designer recreated a handful of her signature styles using a selection of Schumacher’s most popular fabrics. Despite their throwback roots, the resulting looks — ’60s-inspired silhouettes printed with bright colors and fauna-inspired motifs (zebra stripes, prancing deer, leopard spots) — are youthful and refreshingly modern.

headline: Readers Respond: On ‘How We Learned to Kill’
keywords: ['Civilian Casualties', 'Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Veterans']
abstract: An Op-Ed by Timothy Kudo, “How We Learned to Kill,” provoked an outpouring of comments about our military, killing and wars.
lead_paragraph: Timothy Kudo’s Sunday Review piece, “How We Learned to Kill,” a reflection on killing from a veteran of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, drew an extraordinary number of comments from veterans of wars past and present.

headline: Police Are Criticized for Use of Force in Shooting in Los Angeles’s Skid Row
abstract: A video of the encounter has become a new symbol of what many people see as police abuses directed against minorities and the homeless.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A line of tents and people huddled in blankets filled the sidewalks of San Pedro Street on Monday in the heart of this city’s Skid Row. The occasional police car drove by. In the middle of the block, flowers were piled next to a note bidding goodbye to a man who had called this piece of sidewalk his home until Sunday afternoon.

headline: Vitamin-Packed With Promises
keywords: ['Dietary Supplements and Herbal Remedies', 'Vitamins', 'Niacin', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: How supplements became ubiquitous in our food and in our stores, even though evidence they work is scant.
lead_paragraph: In the late 1800s a disfiguring and often fatal disease became epidemic in the South. Called pellagra (Italian for “rough skin”), it caused diarrhea, mental confusion, and severe scaling and flaking of the skin. By 1911, pellagra had become the leading cause of death in asylums. Eventually, the Public Health Service dispatched the physician Joseph Goldberger to determine its cause.

headline: Two Strains of H.I.V. Cut Vastly Different Paths
abstract: Researchers traced the origins of two subtypes of H.I.V.-1. One subtype stayed in Cameroon; the other spread throughout the world.
lead_paragraph: Thirty-four years ago, doctors in Los Angeles discovered that some of their patients were succumbing to a normally harmless fungus. It soon became clear that they belonged to a growing number of people whose immune systems were hobbled by a virus, eventually known as human immunodeficiency virus, or H.I.V.

headline: Saving Big on Energy Bills, People Take It to the Bank
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Savings', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Energy prices began falling last summer, but economists are stumped on what consumers are doing with the extra money. They’re not shopping.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, even the supposed experts can lose track of a billion dollars or two. Or, in this case, $100 billion.

headline: In Performance | Pinkins and Wiest

headline: Researchers Link Syrian Conflict to a Drought Made Worse by Climate Change
abstract: Researchers said Monday that a recent extreme drought in Syria was most likely linked to climate change, and that the drought was a factor in the violent uprising there.
lead_paragraph: Drawing one of the strongest links yet between global warming and human conflict, researchers said Monday that an extreme drought in Syria between 2006 and 2009 was most likely due to climate change, and that the drought was a factor in the violent uprising that began there in 2011.

headline: Termites: Guardians of the Soil
abstract: From jungles to drylands, colonies are preserving landscapes and protecting ecosystems. Just keep them out of the house.
lead_paragraph: The giant termite mounds that rise up from the sands of the African savanna are so distinctive it’s tempting to give them names, like “Art Deco Skyline” or “Trumpeting Elephant” or “Flagrantly Obvious Fertility Totem.”

headline: ‘Infinite Monkey Cage’ Brings Playful Science Series to U.S.
abstract: “Do not be scared of science.” That’s the message of a science-meets-comedy radio show on BBC’s Radio 4, according to one of its hosts.
lead_paragraph: “Do not be scared of science.” That is the message of “The Infinite Monkey Cage,” according to one of its hosts, the comedian Robin Ince. The science-meets-comedy radio show, which has been broadcast on BBC’s Radio 4 since 2009, has also become one of Britain’s most popular podcasts, and is gaining a following in the United States. This month, Mr. Ince and his scientist co-host, Brian Cox, are taking the show on a brief American tour, kicking off on Thursday night at the Skirball Center for the Performing Arts in New York, where the guests will be the astrophysicists Neil deGrasse Tyson and Janna Levin, the comedian Lisa Lampanelli and the actor Tim Daly.

headline: Shooting Style
abstract: Marie Rime photographs the uniforms of Swiss gun culture.
lead_paragraph: Marie Rime photographs the uniforms of Swiss gun culture.

headline: Review: ‘Lucky Alan,’ Jonathan Lethem’s Dreamlike Tales of Seclusion
abstract: The people in this collection of stories tend to live in their own fortresses of solitude, cut off by fate, choice or temperament.
lead_paragraph: In two of the stories in his superfluous new collection, Jonathan Lethem uses the snow globe as a symbol for isolation and removal from the hustle and bustle and Sturm und Drang of ordinary life. It’s a favorite image, which has popped up in earlier books like “Motherless Brooklyn” and “Chronic City,” and an apt metaphor for the separation that so many of his characters feel, whether it’s Dylan Ebdus in “The Fortress of Solitude,” who was bullied as a child, or Lionel Essrog, the detective with Tourette’s syndrome in “Motherless Brooklyn.”

lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Her first child survived eight months before succumbing to pneumonia; her second was stillborn; her third, delivered in a rickshaw, gasped for an hour before dying.

headline: Extra Sleep Linked With Stroke Risk
abstract: Sleeping more than 8 hours may be an early sign of stroke risk, a new study shows.
lead_paragraph: Sleeping more than eight hours a day is associated with a higher risk for stroke, a new study has found.

headline: A Quest to Solve Ceres’ Mysteries
abstract: NASA’s Dawn mission will begin orbiting Ceres, the largest known asteroid, on Friday. Scientists want to know what its two bright spots are.
lead_paragraph: What are the bright spots on Ceres, the largest known asteroid? No one knows, including scientists working on NASA’s Dawn mission, which begins orbiting Ceres on Friday. The two reflective spots, in a 57-mile-wide crater, could be ice or salt, the scientists speculate. “The team is really, really excited about this feature, because it is unique in the solar system,” Carol Raymond, the mission’s deputy principal investigator, said in a news conference Monday. “The mystery will be solved, but it is one that’s really got us on the edge of our seats.”

headline: A Surgery Standard Under Fire

abstract: A definition of success for doctors, 30 days of survival after an operation, may not serve the interests of older adult patients.
lead_paragraph: What she wanted, the patient told the geriatricians evaluating her, was to be able to return to her condominium in Boston. She had long lived there on her own, lifting weights to keep fit and doing her own grocery shopping, until a heart condition worsened and she could barely manage the stairs.

headline: Arming the Immune System Against Cancer
abstract: James P. Allison, who saw the devastating effects of cancer on his family, discovered a way to disable one of its main defenses.
lead_paragraph: James P. Allison is the chairman of the immunology department at the University of Texas M.D. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston. His seminal research opened up a new field in cancer treatment: immunotherapy. Instead of poisoning a tumor or destroying it with radiation, Dr. Allison has pioneered ways to unleash the immune system to destroy a cancer.

headline: An East Hampton Bookstore Pops Up in Manhattan
keywords: ['ARMORY SHOW, THE INTERNATIONAL FAIR OF NEW ART (NYC)', 'Art', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: To coincide with the Armory Show, opening this week in New York, Harper’s Books brings some of its coveted stock to the Carlyle Hotel for a three-day exhibition.
lead_paragraph: To coincide with the Armory Show, the annual contemporary and modern art fair that opens this week in New York, the East Hampton-based bookshop and gallery Harper’s Books (Reed Krakoff is a fan) will bring some of its rare inventory to Manhattan for a three-day pop-up at the Carlyle Hotel.

headline: Hospital Rating Systems Differ on Best and Worst
abstract: Authors of a new analysis say the lack of agreement could add to the confusion over health care quality, rather than alleviating it.
lead_paragraph: Four popular national rating systems used by consumers to judge hospitals frequently come to very different conclusions about which hospitals are the best — or worst — potentially adding to the confusion over health care quality, rather than alleviating it, a new study shows.

headline: Harrington, 43, Beats the Yips and, in a Playoff, a Rival Half His Age
abstract: Harrington, 43, a three-time major winner ranked 297th entering the tournament, topped Berger, 21, on Monday on the second playoff hole at the P.G.A. National Champion course.
lead_paragraph: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla. — Rory McIlroy was not going head-to-head against Rickie Fowler for the Honda Classic crown in a duel of young, photogenic players that no doubt would have piqued the casual sports fan’s interest in golf. The top-ranked McIlroy missed the cut in the weather-plagued event, and Fowler finished outside the top 40.

headline: Venezuela Tells U.S. to Reduce Embassy Staff

lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — With diplomatic relations fraying rapidly between the United States and Venezuela, the government of President Nicolás Maduro has given the American Embassy here 15 days to come up with a plan to drastically shrink its staff, Venezuela’s foreign minister announced Monday.
