headline: Shooting of Boris Nemtsov Draws Comparisons to Death of Another Putin Foe
abstract: As Russians mourned Mr. Nemtsov in Moscow, an inquiry into the poisoning death of Alexander V. Litvinenko in 2006 entered its 18th day in London.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The fatal shooting in Moscow last week of a Russian opposition leader, Boris Y. Nemtsov, has prompted comparisons with the 2006 poisoning of Alexander V. Litvinenko, another foe of President Vladimir V. Putin, who fled to Britain in 2000 and secured British citizenship weeks before he died of what was almost the perfect poisoning.

headline: A Few Reasons to Love Bleeding
abstract: In at least a few specific ailments, periodic blood donations have advantages for the donor.
lead_paragraph: Q. Does donating blood improve health?

headline: Slow Start for ‘The Heidi Chronicles’ on Broadway
abstract: Sales were slow for the new revival of Wendy Wasserstein’s Tony-winning play, starring Elisabeth Moss.
lead_paragraph: Ticket sales were off to a slow start last week for the new Broadway revival of Wendy Wasserstein’s “The Heidi Chronicles,” starring Elisabeth Moss of “Mad Men” fame, according to box office data released on Monday. “The Heidi Chronicles,” which won both the Tony Award for best play and the Pulitzer Prize for drama in 1989, grossed $305,345 for eight performances, or 34 percent of the maximum possible amount – on the low side for a well-known play with a star performer. Ms. Moss is an Emmy Award nominee for her years as the copywriter Peggy Olson on “Mad Men.”

headline: Review: ‘The Man in the Woman’s Shoes,’ a Mikel Murfi Solo Play
abstract: In this play at the Irish Arts Center, Mr. Murfi’s cobbler has to deliver goods to a customer, and the audience gets to hear his internal monologue.
lead_paragraph: If Mikel Murfi ever fails as an actor (and this seems highly unlikely), he could make a killing at children’s birthday parties. The man has a rare talent for animal sounds. In the brief span of “The Man in the Woman’s Shoes,” at the Irish Arts Center, he voices chickens, bees, sea gulls, songbirds, sheep, a pig, a dog and a dying turkey, that last with enough realism to put you off drumsticks for life.

headline: Pierre Hardy Shares His Favorite Hometown Haunts in the City of Light
abstract: On the eve of Paris Fashion Week, the revered accessories designer opens up about where to eat, work out and shop.
lead_paragraph: Pierre Hardy shoes are as Parisian as escargot. And as Fashion Week kicks off in the City of Light, the revered accessories designer — who has also logged stints at Dior, Hermès and Balenciaga and collaborated with Gap, Frédéric Malle and Nars — is as excited to be there as any visitor. “I love to just hang out in town; I rarely go away for the weekend,” he says. “Paris is always, in any season, a great relief, and a source of pleasure to look at.” Here, the native and Marais resident opens up his Paris black book for T.

lead_paragraph: DURHAM, N.C. — Prosecutors will seek the death penalty for the man charged with the killings of three Arab-American students in a Chapel Hill, N.C., apartment complex, the district attorney’s office handling the case said Monday.

headline: Court Skeptical of Arizona Plan for Less-Partisan Congressional Redistricting
abstract: The Supreme Court is hearing arguments in a case in which the Arizona Legislature says it has been cut out of the district line-drawing process.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An independent redistricting commission created by Arizona voters in 2000 seemed to be in trouble on Monday at the Supreme Court. Several justices suggested that the commission, meant to make the process of drawing congressional district lines less partisan, crossed a constitutional line.

headline: Review: Vienna Philharmonic’s Familiar and Fierce Show of Brahms
abstract: Under the direction of Daniele Gatti, the orchestra felt at home in the music but not without taking some risks.
lead_paragraph: After City of Dreams, the adventurous and arduous three-week festival that the Vienna Philharmonic presented at Carnegie Hall and elsewhere around the country last year, the orchestra may be forgiven for having reverted to a tidy package of core repertory for its annual weekend in New York. Namely, music of Brahms: It performed his First and Third Symphonies at Carnegie on Friday evening, the Second and Fourth on Saturday evening and the “German Requiem” on Sunday afternoon, all conducted by Daniele Gatti.

headline: Review: In ‘Billy & Billie,’ a Step-Sibling Romance Tests Taboos
abstract: This new half-hour, 10-episode series that begins Tuesday comes from Neil LaBute, who is known for his provocative theatrical work.
lead_paragraph: Take the time restrictions off of a playwright — “Don’t worry about saying what you have to say in two-and-a-half hours or less” — and what do you get? Something that looks like “Billy & Billie,” a new half-hour, 10-episode series about stepsibling romance from Neil LaBute that begins Tuesday on DirecTV’s Audience Network.

headline: Review: ‘Alice in Wonderland,’ by Unsuk Chin, Told With Restraint
abstract: Ms. Chin’s musical take on Lewis Carroll’s novel finally gets a showing in Los Angeles, where it was originally commissioned.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Beginning with a subterranean, almost inaudible rumble, Unsuk Chin’s “Alice in Wonderland” isn’t quite the madcap spectacle you might expect from an opera based on Lewis Carroll’s novel. While there is ample zaniness in the two hours of music that follow, it is the score’s sober core that keeps the opera’s mood pleasurably disconcerting.

headline: Paul Beatty, Author of ‘The Sellout,’ on Finding Humor in Issues of Race
abstract: Mr. Beatty’s satirical take on race spares no person or piety.
lead_paragraph: Even in elementary school, the novelist Paul Beatty knew how to make waves with words. At a cafe in the West Village recently, he recalled attending a summer camp in Santa Monica, Calif., where he and other children decorated the outside of a bus in a “hippie” style. Mr. Beatty painted a poem about the police near the top of the bus, and once on the road his verse attracted the attention of the actual police. “I wish I could remember the poem,” he said. “Something ‘pigs,’ ‘fuzz.’ The thing must have been four lines. They made me get out and erase one or two of the words.”

headline: Billionaire Grocer Is Said to Be a Suitor for The Daily News

headline: Tatiana Trouvé Unwinds History in Public Art Project
abstract: Tatiana Trouvé’s work, “Desire Lines,” for the Public Art Fund, is — in a manner of thinking — the size of Central Park itself.
lead_paragraph: As a pastoral sculpture socked into the heart of a metropolis, Central Park has fascinated and provoked artists for decades. Claes Oldenburg hired gravediggers to excavate and refill a hole in it, to form an “invisible monument.” Christo and Jeanne-Claude gated and orange-ified it. Diane Arbus used her camera to draw deeply from its well of the weird. Robert Smithson, creator of the monumental “Spiral Jetty” in the Great Salt Lake, suggested that the idea belonged to the park’s beginnings: He called Frederick Law Olmsted, its chief designer, the “first ‘earthwork artist.’ ”

headline: Review: ‘Romantic Piano Quartets,’ From Chamber Music Society
abstract: The society is presenting works by Mahler, Schumann and Brahms at Alice Tully Hall.
lead_paragraph: Not every work of music written during the so-called Romantic period fits the most common definition of that word: describing something expressing, or conducive to, amorous feelings. Perhaps the Highly Strung period would be a more accurate way to characterize the 19th century, when raw sensitivity and indulgence in heightened emotions — be they anger, foreboding or desire — prevailed in music.

headline: The Fashion-Forward Gun Clubs of Switzerland
abstract: Marie Rime photographs the sartorial splendor of Swiss shooting culture.
lead_paragraph: The Swiss photographer Marie Rime grew up with a rifle in her hands. The daughter of a sport shooter, she took up the pastime at 14, and soon won a state championship in riflery. “On Saturdays,” she says, “I would just put my rifle on my back, get on my bike and go to the shooting range.”

headline: Björk Is on Display, Up Close and in 3-D at MoMA
abstract: The exhibition, which opens to the public on Sunday, is an immersive sonic and visual landscape, covering more than 20 years of her career.
lead_paragraph: At the Museum of Modern Art on Sunday afternoon, Björk was seemingly everywhere. An artist known as Shoplifter sewed strands of hair onto Björk’s face. Around the corner, a textile conservator restrung pearls onto a topless wedding gown by Alexander McQueen, which was also worn by Björk. Nearby, Björk’s crystal-encrusted face floated in midair. A miniature Björk was on her way.

headline: Tena Stivicic Wins Blackburn Drama Prize
abstract: Ms. Stivicic is the author of “3 Winters,” which was presented at the National Theater in London.
lead_paragraph: The playwright Tena Stivicic was to be awarded the 37th annual Susan Smith Blackburn Prize on Monday night for her play “3 Winters,” a dark, era-hopping drama about a Croatian family in post-World War II Zagreb. At a ceremony at Playwrights Horizons, Ms. Stivicic was to receive $25,000 and a numbered print by the artist Willem de Kooning.

lead_paragraph: The nurse who was the first person to contract Ebola in the United States filed suit on Monday against the Dallas hospital where she worked, saying it knowingly left workers without the training or equipment needed to handle the disease.

lead_paragraph: EVEN as a child, I took a couple flights a year. I’ve learned to love everything related to flight, so business trips don’t bother me.

abstract: Dr. Zakir Naik, a prominent Muslim from India, has said that “the Jews” control America and that the United States government was responsible for the Sept. 11 attacks.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — He has publicly declared that “the Jews” control America, that apostates can be killed, that the United States is the world’s “biggest terrorist” and that the Sept. 11 attacks were an “inside job” by President George W. Bush.

abstract: A federal judge in Cleveland reduced the sentences for eight men in a breakaway Amish sect but rejected a call by defense lawyers that they be freed immediately.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Monday reduced the prison sentences for the leader of a breakaway Amish sect and seven followers who were convicted in a series of beard-cutting attacks on rival Amish in 2011.

headline: New York Sponsor of Port Authority Reform Bill Rejects a New Jersey Compromise
abstract: Assemblyman James F. Brennan of Brooklyn said that the bill did not include several elements that he felt were necessary, including requirements to disclose the compensation of top officers.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — A legislative sponsor of an effort to overhaul the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said on Monday that a possible compromise bill suggested by a leading New Jersey Republican would not be acceptable in New York, all but dooming its chances as currently imagined.

headline: Custer’s First Stand
abstract: Long before Little Bighorn, George A. Custer won a dashing victory at the Battle of Waynesboro.
lead_paragraph: In July 1864 Lt. Gen. Jubal A. Early led 14,000 battle-hardened and enthusiastic Confederate veterans to within six miles of the new Capitol dome in Washington. Six months and several crushing defeats later, Early found himself wintering in Staunton, Va., with fewer than 2,000 dispirited troops.

headline: Removing an Artist’s Lifework
abstract: After 40 years in the diamond district of Manhattan, the Ney family is being evicted on March 19. Joel Ney is rushing to move about 4,000 pieces of his father’s artwork from the premises.
lead_paragraph: After 40 years in the diamond district of Manhattan, the Ney family is being evicted on March 19. Joel Ney is rushing to move about 4,000 pieces of his father’s artwork from the premises.

headline: Under Law, Christie Can Use Exxon Settlement to Help Balance Budget
abstract: The current New Jersey appropriations law says that any funds beyond the first $50 million collected in damages or other environmental recoveries shall go to the state’s general fund.
lead_paragraph: A debate over New Jersey’s proposed $250 million settlement of what had been an $8.9 billion pollution lawsuit against Exxon Mobil Corporation has highlighted an obscure provision of a state law that would appear to allow Gov. Chris Christie to apply most if not all of the settlement toward balancing the state budget.

headline: Central Figure in the Atlanta Schools Cheating Scandal Dies
abstract: Beverly Hall, the former superintendent who was awaiting trial for her alleged participation in a conspiracy to alter test results, died Monday after a battle with breast cancer, her legal team said.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Beverly L. Hall, the former superintendent of the Atlanta public schools who was awaiting a criminal trial for her alleged participation in a conspiracy to alter students’ standardized test results, died Monday after an extended battle with breast cancer, her legal team said.

headline: For the U.S. and China, a Test of Diplomacy on South Sudan
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']

lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The United States may have midwifed the birth of South Sudan, the world’s youngest nation. But China has quickly become among its most important patrons, building its roads and pumping its oil.

headline: A Viral Defense of Russian Imperialism, Addressed to Obama
abstract: A Russian video blogger defends his nation’s invasion and occupation of its neighbors, in the form of an open letter to President Obama.
lead_paragraph: A Russian video blogger’s strident defense of his nation’s invasion and occupation of its neighbors, in the form of an open letter to President Obama uploaded to the web on Saturday, has become an instant hit among Russian nationalists, but raised alarm bells in other former Soviet republics.

headline: Senior Myles Mack Doesn’t Regret Choosing Rutgers
abstract: The senior guard Myles Mack survived a coaching scandal, teammates’ defections and lots of losing, yet he remained “a strong person.”
lead_paragraph: PISCATAWAY, N.J. — Favorite day? The senior guard Myles Mack did not hesitate on that one. It was Dec. 29, 2011, when Rutgers upset No. 10 Florida in a double-overtime thriller during his first season. A heralded class of talented freshmen led the way. Fans stormed the court and celebrated well after workers began to clean up.

headline: China Names 14 Generals Suspected of Corruption
abstract: The generals, including the son of a former high-ranking leader, were the latest to fall under President Xi Jinping’s sweeping anticorruption campaign.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China’s military authority on Monday released a list of 14 generals who are under investigation or have been convicted of graft, among them the son of one of China’s once highest-ranking generals.

headline: Cleveland Mayor Apologizes for Language Used to Blame Tamir Rice for His Death
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Mayor Frank G. Jackson apologized on Monday for language that the city’s lawyers used in court filings to assert that the 12-year-old boy’s death was his own fault.
lead_paragraph: Moving to stem fresh anger over how Cleveland has handled the killing of 12-year-old Tamir Rice, Mayor Frank G. Jackson apologized on Monday for language that the city’s lawyers used in court filings to assert that the boy’s death was his own fault.

headline: Terrorism Case Against Pakistani Man Is Going to Jury
abstract: Jurors in Brooklyn will have to decide if Abid Naseer’s emails were innocent chitchat about women or coded messages to a Qaeda handler about a bombing plot.
lead_paragraph: As arguments in Abid Naseer’s trial on terrorism charges came to a close on Monday, jurors had heard from British intelligence officers in disguise, an F.B.I. attaché who observed Osama bin Laden’s dead body and Mr. Naseer himself arguing that he was an innocent man.

headline: Hillary Clinton Used Personal Email Account at State Dept., Possibly Breaking Rules
keywords: ['Archives and Records', 'E-Mail', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton did not have a government email address while secretary of state and may have violated federal rules that officials’ correspondence be retained.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hillary Rodham Clinton exclusively used a personal email account to conduct government business as secretary of state, State Department officials said, and may have violated federal requirements that officials’ correspondence be retained as part of the agency’s record.

headline: A Yankee Hurler Shows Great Mechanics
abstract: Teams may almost universally use live pitching during scrimmages, but Manager Joe Girardi chose not to for the Yankees’ first intrasquad game.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — The Yankees, who this season will be counting on a starting rotation that appears to be held together by duct tape and baling wire, on Monday employed a pitcher who could throw all day (and all night, too) without wearing out knee cartilage, elbow ligaments or shoulder sockets.

headline: A Warning From Buffett About Banks
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Private Equity', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Warren E. Buffett, the billionaire chairman of Berkshire Hathaway, has released his annual shareholder letter, and it is unusually critical of the financial industry.
lead_paragraph: “Money-shufflers don’t come cheap.”

headline: New York Fire Dept., Diversifying Ranks, Is Set to Swear In First Lesbian Chaplain
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Fires and Firefighters', 'Chaplains', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Clergy']
abstract: The Rev. Ann Kansfield of the Greenpoint Reformed Church in Brooklyn is also the first female chaplain in a department that for decades resisted efforts to diversify it.
lead_paragraph: Maybe it is her short, spiky hair, or the cigarettes, which she gives to the men repairing the wiring in her Brooklyn apartment. Maybe it is because she swears. For whatever reason, the Rev. Ann Kansfield does not fit the stereotype of a minister.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 2, 2015
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: March 2, 2015

headline: Climate Change Researcher Offers a Defense of His Practices
abstract: Wei-Hock Soon, who is at the center of a controversy over fossil-fuel funding for climate research, denounced his critics and said he would be happy to comply with possible additional disclosure requirements.
lead_paragraph: The scientist at the center of a controversy over fossil-fuel funding for climate research denounced his critics on Monday and said that he would be “happy to comply” with possible additional disclosure requirements from scientific journals publishing his papers.

headline: Senate Democrats Block Joint Negotiations on Homeland Security Funding
abstract: A vote forces Speaker John A. Boehner to try again to corral an unruly group of conservative House members.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats on Monday blocked a House attempt to force joint negotiations over legislation to fund the Department of Homeland Security through the fiscal year.

headline: Europe Unlikely to Meet Climate Goal, Study Finds
abstract: The European Union will most likely fail to meet an ambitious goal of reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 2050, a report has found.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The European Union will fail to meet an ambitious goal of significantly reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 2050 unless it takes more aggressive measures to limit the use of fossil fuels and adopts new environmental policies, according to a report scheduled for release on Tuesday.

headline: Libyan General’s Promotion Could Hinder United Nations Peace Talks
abstract: One of Libya’s Parliaments appointed Gen. Khalifa Hifter on Monday be the commander in chief of the army in its war against Islamists, possibly damaging negotiations to stop the war in the North African nation.
lead_paragraph: MISURATA, Libya — The speaker of Libya’s internationally recognized Parliament named Gen. Khalifa Hifter on Monday to the recently created position of commander in chief of the army, potentially hindering United Nations-sponsored talks to end the country’s internal strife.

headline: Massachusetts: Boat Is Subject of Sparring in Bombing Case
abstract: Lawyers for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the defendant in the 2013 bombing of the Boston Marathon, said Monday that they wanted the jury in his trial to view the entire boat in which he hid while the authorities searched for him several days after the bombing.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the defendant in the 2013 bombing of the Boston Marathon, said Monday that they wanted the jury in his trial to view the entire boat in which he hid while the authorities searched for him several days after the bombing, not just cut-out panels on which he is said to have written a message. During a hearing at Boston’s federal courthouse, William Fick, a defense lawyer, called the boat a powerful piece of evidence and compared Mr. Tsarnaev’s lying in it to the way a body might lie in a crypt, adding that he did not see why the boat could not be brought to the courthouse. Prosecutors said that the suggestion was impractical, in part because the boat is still covered in blood and broken glass, and that many photographs of it exist. Judge George A. O’Toole Jr. said he may wish to view the boat himself before making a decision. Also Monday, defense lawyers filed their fourth change-of-venue motion with the court. The jury is to be seated on Tuesday, and opening arguments are expected to begin Wednesday.

headline: Sentencing for Former Principal at Bronx High School Is Delayed
abstract: The former principal, Christopher Keogan, pleaded guilty in September to stealing money from Cardinal Hayes High School in the Bronx. He was supposed to pay back about $8,200 this week.
lead_paragraph: A former principal at Cardinal Hayes High School who was charged with stealing thousands of dollars from the Bronx institution was given an extra two weeks on Monday to pay about $8,200 in restitution to avoid going to jail for one year.

headline: Review: ‘The Mystery of Love and Sex’ Looks at Identity and Secrets Too
abstract: In Bathsheba Doran’s perfectly wonderful new play, a young woman’s parents wonder how to adjust to her evolving relationship with a childhood friend.
lead_paragraph: The detective work in “The Mystery of Love & Sex,” a perfectly wonderful new play by Bathsheba Doran that opened on Monday at the Mitzi Newhouse Theater, extends well beyond the matters of high importance referred to in the title. In this tender and funny exploration of the lives of two couples from two generations, Ms. Doran also probes such fertile mysteries as the fluidity of identity, our ability to keep secrets from both our family and even ourselves, and the difficulty — and the rewards — of forgiveness.

headline: Gambler’s Last Words
abstract: An edgy puzzle by Kristian House.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Each generation likes to think they invented stuff. Nothing angers a young person who thinks they have come up with a spiffy and original idea more than to find out that someone in the past had thought of it first. I believe that’s because we, as a species, are still hunter-gatherers at our core and the biggest piece of meat always went to he who felled the animal.

headline: Some Owners of Private Colleges Turn a Tidy Profit by Going Nonprofit
abstract: Under a government crackdown on for-profit schools that leave students with useless credentials and punishing debt, some colleges have converted to nonprofits, in lucrative deals.
lead_paragraph: After a recent government crackdown on the multibillion-dollar career-training industry, stricter limits on student aid and devastating publicity about students hobbled by debt and useless credentials, some for-profit schools simply shut down.

headline: 2 Veterans and 2 Rookies Seek Mets’ Last Bullpen Slot
abstract: The right-hander Buddy Carlyle and the left-handed Scott Rice, seeking to return to the majors after surgery, are competing with two prospects.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Around 11 a.m. Monday, on one of the main fields at the Mets’ spring training complex, Matt Harvey toed the rubber for his latest bullpen session. A horde of fans watched his every move. General Manager Sandy Alderson, Manager Terry Collins and several other members of the team’s hierarchy made sure to be there, too.

headline: Monroe Freedman, Influential Voice on Legal Ethics, Dies at 86
abstract: Professor Freedman, who was credited with inventing legal ethics as a serious academic subject, was especially concerned with lawyers’ responsibilities toward their clients and with access to justice.
lead_paragraph: Monroe H. Freedman, a dominant figure in legal ethics whose work helped chart the course of lawyers’ behavior in the late 20th century and beyond, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 86.

headline: Toronto Police Say Tunnel Mystery Is Solved
abstract: The site near where the Pan Am Games will be held raised suspicions, but officials say that two men simply dug a hole with plans to hang out there.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Toronto’s mystery tunnel has turned out to be a place for a couple of guys to get away from it all, more a “man cave” than a terrorist threat.

headline: Giants’ Pierre-Paul Gets Franchise Tag; Lions’ Suh Does Not
abstract: Defensive end Jason Pierre-Paul is virtually certain to stay with the Giants for at least one more season, but Ndamukong Suh will be a free agent.
lead_paragraph: In a move that was expected, the Giants on Monday designated defensive end Jason Pierre-Paul as their franchise player, a maneuver that virtually ensures that he will remain with the team at least one more season.

headline: Australia to Send More Troops to Iraq as Trainers in ISIS Fight
abstract: Prime Minister Tony Abbott said that 300 more troops would be sent to train Iraqi forces, expanding Australia’s role in the fight against the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Australia on Tuesday expanded its commitment to the international coalition fighting the Islamic State extremist group, with Prime Minister Tony Abbott announcing that an additional 300 troops would be sent to Iraq to train local forces.

lead_paragraph: An important player made his Rangers debut on Monday, but the team relied on an established, popular commodity to defeat the N.H.L.-best Nashville Predators, 4-1, at Madison Square Garden.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Monday called for prompt action to change police practices across the country after the deaths of unarmed black men in Ferguson, Mo., and Staten Island at the hands of white officers exposed frustrations about law enforcement in minority communities.

headline: Bruised Hip of Nets’ Teletovic Leads to Blood Clot Awareness

lead_paragraph: It was in mid-December that Mirza Teletovic of the Nets first began feeling, in his words, “weak, weird and kind of dizzy.” Initially, though, there was no discernible reason.

lead_paragraph: Recent basketball matchups between two high schools on the Navajo reservation in Arizona showcased the up-tempo style known as rez ball.

headline: Ernie Hemmings, Founder of a Bible of Classic Cars, Dies at 88
abstract: Mr. Hemmings turned an auto parts mail-order catalog into the popular magazine Hemmings Motor News.
lead_paragraph: In 1945, when Ernie Hemmings took over the auto parts business his father had founded in Quincy, Ill., Model T and Model A Fords were still too contemporary to be called classics.

abstract: Recent basketball matchups between two high schools on the Navajo reservation in Arizona showcased the up-tempo style known as rez ball.

headline: Larger-Than-Life Advertising Imagery, Brought Down to Size
abstract: Natan Dvir’s “Coming Soon” photography series captures the collision between aspirational commercial displays and the mundanity of everyday life.
lead_paragraph: In this weekly series, T’s photo editors share the most compelling visual projects they’ve discovered.

headline: David Letterman: A Look Back
abstract: A look back at his three-decade-long reign as late night’s curmudgeonly king.
lead_paragraph: After 33 years as the cigar-chomping, larger-than-life face of late-night television, David Letterman, 67, will count down his last top-ten list when the final episode of "Late Show with David Letterman" airs in May. The Indianapolis native grew up worshiping Johnny Carson, and after getting his start as a wisecracking TV weatherman, went on to host both "Late Night" on NBC and "Late Show" on CBS. Renowned for his biting wit and hard-nosed interview style, Letterman has made his name poking fun at his employers and quarreling with guests like Madonna and Cher. Now, as he prepares to say goodbye to the Ed Sullivan Theater, a look back at the career of TV's most lovable misanthrope.

headline: In Buenos Aires, a Hub of Local Culture Under One Exquisite Roof
abstract: The new Casa Cavia features a patisserie, flower shop, perfumery, bookstore, publisher and, of course, restaurant and bar.
lead_paragraph: Over the weekend, a hybrid concept space called Casa Cavia opened its doors in the upscale Palermo Chico neighborhood in Buenos Aires. The building, which dates back to 1927 and was originally built as a two-story residential home, retains much of its original design but was recently upgraded by its new owner, the restaurateur and film producer Lupe Garcia. Inspired by local cafes from the 1920s and 1930s, she recruited KallosTurin architects to integrate marble, brass, leather and terrazzo floors into the space, which now houses a restaurant and bar, patisserie, flower shop, perfumery, bookstore and publisher all under one exquisite roof.

headline: A New Chapter
abstract: In the reassembly of a book’s torn-out pages, the artist Mark Hagen finds a symbol of rebirth to echo the poet Michael Dickman’s sonnet about welcoming a child into the world.
lead_paragraph: In the reassembly of a book’s torn-out pages, the artist Mark Hagen finds a symbol of rebirth to echo the poet Michael Dickman’s sonnet about welcoming a child into the world.

abstract: The 20,000 fighters and others lost last year cast further doubt on Afghanistan’s ability to maintain security without help from United States-led coalition forces.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Afghan Army lost more than 20,000 fighters and others last year largely because of desertions, discharges and deaths in combat, according to figures to be released Tuesday, casting further doubt on Afghanistan’s ability to maintain security without help from United States-led coalition forces.

lead_paragraph: So much of life is about leave-taking: moving from home to college, from love to love, from city to city and from life stage to life stage.

headline: Finding Refuge in a Visual Language
abstract: As a young refugee unfamiliar with a new language, Sylvia Plachy learned to watch her surroundings. A new retrospective tracks 50 years of her journey.
lead_paragraph: Sylvia Plachy’s approach to photography has remained constant, even if her gear or technique has changed at times. She tries to make everything disappear, to forget who she is. For one, she does not like to talk when she takes pictures. “Of course, you have to with people,” she said. “Sometimes. But I usually prefer just to smell it and be there and understand it through instinct.”

headline: Will the Supreme Court Say No to Gerrymandering?
abstract: Arizona’s legislators are fighting to regain their redistricting power, taken away from them by fed up citizens.
lead_paragraph: The citizens of Arizona — like so many others nationwide — were long fed up with their elected officials drawing skewed electoral districts to keep themselves, and the majority party, in power.

headline: How Warren Buffett Does It
abstract: Going from “cigar butt” investing to the greatest conglomerate ever in 50 years.
lead_paragraph: Fifty years ago, a young investor named Warren Buffett took control of a failing textile company, Berkshire Hathaway. “I found myself ... invested in a terrible business about which I knew very little,” Buffett relates in his annual letter to shareholders, which was released over the weekend. “I became the dog who caught the car.”

headline: Are You Really Allergic to Antibiotics?
abstract: There are serious consequences to limiting the drugs you can receive.
lead_paragraph: NOVI, Mich. — ALLERGIC reactions to antibiotics can be severe, including symptoms ranging from hives and wheezing to anaphylactic shock. People with such allergic reactions are right to steer clear. The problem is that many, and probably most, people who say they’re allergic to antibiotics actually aren’t. For penicillin, the most commonly reported allergy, many studies have estimated that up to 90 percent of claims of allergies are not legitimate.

headline: To Hurt ISIS, Squeeze the Cash Flow
abstract: The terrorist group’s needs are so great that shutting down its financing is a major opportunity for the West.
lead_paragraph: The fight against the Islamic State must be a multipronged effort, designed to counter the terrorists, their ideology and their murderous strategy on every level.

headline: The Education of ‘Jihadi John’
abstract: Britain’s universities have been infiltrated by Islamist extremists for years. I was one of them.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — LAST week, the man called “Jihadi John” by the world’s media was unmasked as Mohammed Emwazi, a Kuwaiti-born Muslim and naturalized British citizen from London. Not only that, but the Islamic State’s most notorious Western recruit was identified as a graduate in computer science from the University of Westminster.

headline: Test Yourself | The Winter That Won’t End

headline: Confessions of a Pebble Thief
abstract: After each therapy session, I took a souvenir.
lead_paragraph: During my first year of therapy with Dr. Conger, I began what started as a random gesture and soon became a ritual. After each session, on the short, pebbly path from his home office to the street, I’d secretly pick up a small rock and pocket it.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (TCM) THE ARTIST (2011) George Valentin (Jean Dujardin, in an Oscar-winning performance), a silent-screen star, finds his luster fading when he refuses to speak on film with the arrival of sound, while Peppy Miller (Bérénice Bejo), a young extra he helped get a break, becomes the next big thing. Then Peppy insists that Valentin star in her next movie. This film, written and directed by Michel Hazanavicius, also won for best director and best picture. “Though its protagonist mourns the arrival of sound, ‘The Artist’ itself is more interested in celebrating the range and power of a medium that can sparkle, swoon and suffer so beautifully that it doesn’t really need to have anything to say,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times, choosing the film as a critics’ pick. And because of the expressiveness and dexterity of Mr. Dujardin and Ms. Bejo — “they dance beautifully and also portray emotion with just the right blend of naturalism and melodramatic exaggeration — ‘The Artist’ is more than a clever pastiche of antique amusements,” he wrote. “It may be something less than a great movie, but it is an irresistible reminder of nearly everything that makes the movies great.”

headline: What Makes a Good Teacher
abstract: As American students lag behind their peers in other countries, how can the U.S. ensure and improve the quality of school instruction?

headline: Barclays Logs $268 Million 2014 Loss, After Charges for Potential Legal Costs
abstract: Excluding legal provisions and other one-time charges, Barclays’ full-year pretax profit rose 12 percent to $5.5 billion, exceeding analysts’ expectations.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British bank Barclays said on Tuesday that it fell to a loss in 2014, its annual results dragged down by charges related to potential fines and litigation costs for conduct by its employees. It also posted lower income in its investment bank as it continues to shrink that business.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Nature’s Fighter Jets With Flapping Wings
abstract: When have you observed a bird pursue its prey? What did you notice about the bird’s strategy?
lead_paragraph: In “Nature’s Fighter Jets With Flapping Wings,” James Gorman writes about new research on how hawks capture their prey.

abstract: Do any noises keep you awake at night? Do they distract you in class or get in the way of your doing your homework? Do they ever prevent you from enjoying a movie?
lead_paragraph: Gum snapping? Soup slurping? Dog barking? Popcorn munching?

headline: Simon Rattle to Return to His Roots, Taking Over the London Symphony
abstract: After a long tenure with the Berlin Philharmonic, Simon Rattle will go home to England to conduct the London Symphony Orchestra.
lead_paragraph: Their long flirtation is over, and now they are engaged: Simon Rattle, the Liverpool-born maestro who rose to become chief conductor of the Berlin Philharmonic, said on Tuesday that he would return to Britain in 2017 as music director of the London Symphony Orchestra.

headline: Driven | 2015 Volkswagen Golf TSI
abstract: The classic silhouette of the Volkswagen Golf hasn’t changed much in 40 years, but its high-end touches and fuel-efficient power make it a good value.
lead_paragraph: The classic silhouette of the Volkswagen Golf hasn’t changed much in 40 years, but its high-end touches and fuel-efficient power make it a good value.

headline: Video Review: 2015 Volkswagen Golf, a Crowd-Pleaser in Many Forms
abstract: The car offers plenty of powertrain choices, including the gasoline TSI, the all-electric e-Golf, the TDI diesel and the high-performance GTI and R models.
lead_paragraph: THE Volkswagen Golf was introduced in 1974, effectively replacing the original people’s car, the Beetle. Now, 40 years later, Golf is not as beloved (there’s no reboot of “The Love Bug” with a Golf as Herbie, is there?), but this seventh-generation hatchback deserves immense respect. It has won nearly every award, including North American Car of the Year and World Car of the Year.

headline: BlackBerry Announces Leap Phone, Moving Back Toward Touch Screens
abstract: The company also teased, in the briefest of fashions, that a curved phone with a slider keyboard might be “coming later this year.”
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — After returning in force to its keyboard roots last year, BlackBerry jumped back into touch-screen phones this week at the Mobile World Congress here, announcing the five-inch BlackBerry Leap.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: David Vann’s ‘Aquarium’
abstract: A seemingly chance encounter cracks open dark family secrets in David Vann’s novel.
lead_paragraph: David Vann’s new novel, “Aquarium,” about a lonely young girl who meets an old man at the Seattle Aquarium, begins on a deceptively light note. Its cinematic quality is due largely to a series of lovely, well-curated fish photographs that accompany 12-year-old Caitlin’s observation of the exotic fauna. But the momentary lightness of these early pages soon unspools into psychological darkness — and the intricate, colorful pictures diminish — as Caitlin moves away from the tranquillity and beauty of the aquarium and into the more dangerous spaces of a world populated by humans.

headline: Neil Gaiman’s ‘Trigger Warning’
abstract: In horror stories and science fiction, fairy tales and poetry, Neil Gaiman explores the transformative power of imagination.
lead_paragraph: If there is any contemporary cognate to the kind of literary celebrity once enjoyed, in a vastly different cultural setting, by Charles Dickens or Leo Tolstoy, it is surely found in Neil Gaiman. A wildly popular tale-spinner as well as a writer of considerable gifts and transcendent ambition, Gaiman has been embraced by critics even as he has amassed a Kardashian-­scale Twitter following. He has written novels for children and comic books for adults (advancing both forms in the process), and vice versa.

headline: Ascap Topped $1 Billion in Revenue Last Year, Lifted by Streaming
keywords: ['Royalties', 'Music', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Company Reports', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The music licensing agency tracked 500 billion performances of songs last year, paying $883 million to composers and publishers.
lead_paragraph: Ascap, the music licensing agency, is in one sense fighting for its survival, seeking to change decades-old rules to fit the economics of online music. In another, it is finding ways to distribute more money than ever to its thousands of songwriters.

headline: New York Today: Boys of Spring
abstract: Tuesday: The Yankees and Mets get set to play ball, a snowy evening, and a brief display of Hurricane Sandy artifacts.

headline: 20 Killed as Bus Falls Off Cliff in Central China
abstract: The vehicle was said to be carrying members of a traveling opera troupe, and 13 other people on board were injured.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The weeks around the start of the Lunar New Year are busy ones for entertainers in China, like acrobats and traveling opera troupes. But the journeys of one such group during the nascent Year of the Sheep ended in disaster when a bus carrying 33 members plunged off a cliff in central China on Monday night, killing 20 people on board and injuring the other 13.

headline: European Banking Regulator Postpones Next Stress Tests to 2016

headline: In Congress, Netanyahu Faults ‘Bad Deal’ on Iran Nuclear Program

abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said that negotiations over Iran’s nuclear program were proceeding on a false hope that Iran is acting in good faith. President Obama dismissed the speech as “theater.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With dark warnings and a call to action, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel used one of the world’s most prominent venues on Tuesday to denounce what he called a “bad deal” being negotiated with Iran and to mount an audacious challenge to President Obama.

headline: Cross Section of Democrats to Snub Netanyahu’s Speech to Congress
abstract: At least 49 House and Senate members said they would not attend the Israeli prime minister’s address, with some calling it a political stunt.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Some are standing with President Obama. Some are protesting the actions of the House speaker, John A. Boehner. Still others say they do not want to be props in Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s re-election campaign.

headline: For Netanyahu and Obama, Difference Over Iran Became a Chasm
abstract: Over six years of disagreements about how to deal with the Iranian nuclear threat, the leaders never described their ultimate goal the same way.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Over six years of bitter disagreements about how to deal with the Iranian nuclear threat, President Obama and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel kept running into one central problem: The two leaders never described their ultimate goal in quite the same way.

headline: In Chapel Hill, Suspect’s Rage Went Beyond a Parking Dispute
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Muslims and Islam']

lead_paragraph: CHAPEL HILL, N.C. — On the last day of Razan Mohammad Abu-Salha’s life, it was too cold to run.

headline: Man Convicted of Rape in Delhi Blames Victim
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Women and Girls', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: In an interview for a film that will air Sunday on the BBC, Mukesh Singh, who drove the bus on which the woman was raped, said she should not have resisted the attack.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — In the months after the death of a young woman who was brutalized and gang-raped on a moving bus in New Delhi in 2012, thousands of politicians, activists and ordinary citizens crowded India’s airwaves and its public spaces to say their piece about the crime.

headline: The ‘Loser Edit’ That Awaits Us All
abstract: Fifteen years after reality TV gave us the “loser edit,” the phrase has become a metaphor with which we can explain our failures.
lead_paragraph: If you have ever watched a reality TV show and said, “He’s going home tonight,” you know what the “loser edit” is. I imagine it started as a matter of practicality. If you have 20 contestants, they can’t all receive equal airtime. When an obscure character gets the heave-ho, the producers have to cobble together a coherent story line. Intersperse the snippets across the hour, and we can identify sins and recognizable human frailty that need to be punished. Anyone tuning in for the first time catches up quickly. The loser edit is not just the narrative arc of a contestant about to be chopped, or voted off the island, whatever the catchphrase. It is the plausible argument of failure.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: LaCroix Sparkling Water
abstract: “My seltzer fixation broadcasts to the world that I’m getting older.”
lead_paragraph: I was introduced to them at work, the same place where most of us worry about contracting respiratory viruses. I’d just landed a job in sunny Los Angeles, where I ate breakfast, lunch and dinner at a standing desk in a windowless office. I was paid more money than I’d ever made before, which was just enough that I could never stop counting it, over and over until it lost meaning, like that thing that happens when you do acid and stare at your hand.

headline: The Doom of the American System?
abstract: On Matthew Yglesias’s prophecy of a constitutional crisis.
lead_paragraph: Vox’s Matt Yglesias has an essay this week making an extended, detailed version of a case that he (and others) have made before: That our era of partisan and ideological polarization is exposing weaknesses inherent in America’s presidential system of government, and that those weaknesses may threaten the stability, if not the survival, of the American constitutional order. It’s an essay that I suspect will be dismissed unread by a number of conservatives as just the latest iteration of the “America the ungovernable”/”the system has failed the president” genre popular among liberal writers in the waning days of struggling Democratic administrations. (Well, Jimmy Carter’s, in particular.) But Yglesias’s argument, to his credit, isn’t a lament for brilliant liberal reforms thwarted by filibustering bad guys and Madisonian mistakes; instead, he argues that President Obama has found ways to govern in the face of gridlock, mostly by the creative/Caesarist application of executive power to domestic policy, and that the next president, Republican or Democratic, will probably find ways to do the same. His point is that governance is increasing happening outside constitutional norms, not that it isn’t happening at all, and that it’s happening that way for reasons that are independent of particular chief executives and whose influence neither political party is likely to soon roll back.

headline: 1940: Stained Glass Stored for War
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Stained glass in France stored for the war in 1940.
lead_paragraph: Some 18,000 square meters, or nearly five acres, of Medieval stained glass from the churches and cathedrals of France has been packed in more than 7,000 cases and stored away for safekeeping, it was revealed yesterday [March 3] with the publication of reports given at the last meeting of the Commission of Historic Monuments. In addition, 236 historic buildings have been reinforced in their most vulnerable parts by nearly 2,000,000 sandbags. Works of art from churches and museums have been shipped to various parts of the country. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 4, 1940

headline: Government Declassifies Surveillance Court Documents on “Raw Take” Sharing
abstract: In response to Freedom of Information Act lawsuits by The New York Times and the Electronic Frontier Foundation, the government has declassified a set of previously secret motions and rulings involving the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court. headline: 1965: Congo Jails Unesco Teacher
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: UN teachers jailed by Congo in 1965.
lead_paragraph: LEOPOLDVILLE — A UN-sponsored teacher in the Congo was behind bars today, two others in hiding, three awaiting imminent expulsion, and one in refuge in the Polish embassy. It was a part of continuing Congolese police harassment of United Nations employees here, UN sources said, in spite of Premier Moise Tshombe’s order that such harassment stop. A senior UN official said the situation ‘‘would be comical if it weren’t so tragic.’’ The incident came 11 days after 13 United Nations teachers and their 22 dependents were expelled, only to be invited back to the Congo hours after their plane left for Athens. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 4, 1965

abstract: Experts from some of the city’s best cafes share tips of the trade.

headline: Jason Moran and Other Guest Artists to Curate Kennedy Center Season
abstract: New programs will be curated by Mr. Moran, the center’s artistic director for jazz; Mason Bates, its composer in residence; the composer Chris Thile; and the choreographer Damian Woetzel.
lead_paragraph: The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington plans to present several new programs next season that will be curated by artists, the center’s new president, Deborah F. Rutter, announced on Tuesday.

headline: Big Investor in BPI of Portugal Seeks to Derail CaixaBank Bid
abstract: Isabel dos Santos, the daughter of the president of Angola, is pushing for the bank to merge with a domestic rival, Millennium BCP.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Isabel dos Santos, the daughter of the president of Angola and the second-largest investor in BPI, a Portuguese bank, is pushing for the bank to merge with a domestic rival, Millennium BCP, rather than accept a takeover bid from CaixaBank, a Spanish bank.

headline: An App That Connects Travelers With Locals
abstract: A travel feature on the mobile application Skout lets members make contact with residents of destinations of interest to them.
lead_paragraph: These days there are any number of social networks available to a traveler who wants to connect with other tourists while on the road. But one mobile application is now using its network as a direct route to locals as well.

headline: A Conservative Christian’s Case for Legal Marijuana
abstract: David Simpson doesn’t believe that “when God made marijuana he made a mistake that government needs to fix.”
lead_paragraph: America, meet David Simpson, a Republican state representative in Texas who believes in God, limited government, individual rights – and legal marijuana.

headline: Netanyahu’s Full Speech Before Congress
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel delivered a speech at a joint meeting of Congress on Tuesday, outlining his case for a tougher strategy in a nuclear deal with Iran.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel delivered a speech at a joint meeting of Congress on Tuesday, outlining his case for a tougher strategy in a nuclear deal with Iran.

headline: California Apartments Raided in Federal Investigation of Chinese ‘Birth Tourism’
abstract: The raids were part of a federal inquiry into an industry that helps pregnant Chinese women travel to the United States to deliver babies who will have American citizenship.
lead_paragraph: Federal agents stormed 37 locations in Southern California early Tuesday, gathering evidence about what they say are three illegal “birth tourism” businesses for wealthy Chinese women.

headline: Disqualified for Pink on Uniforms, Basketball Team Is Reinstated to Playoffs
abstract: Narbonne High of Los Angeles, which broke rules by wearing uniform colors that weren’t a combination of the official school colors as it tried to raise cancer awareness, was penalized in other ways.
lead_paragraph: Until a three-person panel overturned a decision Tuesday, only one thing could keep the Narbonne High School girls’ basketball team in Los Angeles out of this weekend’s city championship game: the color of its uniforms.

headline: Via Carota
abstract: Italian fare from the chefs Jody Williams and Rita Sodi in the West Village.
lead_paragraph: Italian fare from the chefs Jody Williams and Rita Sodi in the West Village.

headline: Restaurant Review: Via Carota in the West Village
abstract: The chefs Jody Williams and Rita Sodi, partners in business and domestic affairs, are the owners and chefs of Via Carota in Greenwich Village.
lead_paragraph: Hanging from Via Carota’s ceiling, menacing a large farmhouse table that had been surrounded by smiling customers just a few minutes earlier, was a row of long iron spikes, bent into hooks at their ends. They’d been retrofitted with light bulbs to make a functional if terrifying chandelier, but what was their original purpose? Several possibilities suggested themselves, from medieval torture device to a particularly inhumane way of catching fish.

headline: Mary-Louise Parker to Star in ‘Heisenberg’ Off Broadway
abstract: Simon Stephens’s “Heisenberg,” about the spark lit when a woman kisses a much older man at a London train station, will begin its run in May.
lead_paragraph: The British playwrights Simon Stephens and Nick Payne are likely competitors in June for the Tony Award for best play, given the critical acclaim and popularity of their current Broadway shows, “The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time” (Mr. Stephens) and “Constellations” (Mr. Payne). And now, just as the theoretical-minded “Constellations” is winding down its run at Manhattan Theater Club this month, the club announced on Tuesday that it will produce another new play this spring that has echoes of quantum mechanics – this one by Mr. Stephens.

headline: Jerome Kurtz, Leader of I.R.S. During Carter Era, Dies at 83
abstract: As the I.R.S. commissioner, Mr. Kurtz, considered one of the leading tax policy experts of his time, was known for cracking down on tax shelters.
lead_paragraph: Jerome Kurtz, who as commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service during the Carter administration was known for cracking down on tax shelters and other tax advantages for the wealthy, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 83.

headline: Key Points From Netanyahu's Speech to Congress
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Tuesday warned against what he considers an ill-advised nuclear deal being negotiated with Iran. Below are some of the highlights from his speech.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Tuesday warned against what he considers an ill-advised nuclear deal being negotiated with Iran. Below are some of the highlights from his speech.

headline: Tribeca Film Festival Announces Competition Films
abstract: Competition films feature movies starring James Franco and Richard Gere.
lead_paragraph: Films covering subjects as diverse as sake and nuclear power plants will be in competition at this year’s Tribeca Film Festival, organizers announced Tuesday. The world narrative competition will feature 12 films, with  James Franco, Faith Hill, Richard Gere and Olivia Wilde among the stars. The dozen films in the world documentary competition include new work from Albert Maysles, Ricki Stern and Annie Sundberg. And the Viewpoints section features 27 films from around the world raising questions of identity.

headline: Kiin Thai Eatery Opens in East Village
abstract: The owners of Somtum Der have opened another offshoot. This time, instead of Isan food, they’re serving home-style country Thai.
lead_paragraph: Headliner

headline: Anthony Vaccarello: Fall 2015 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Harsh Winter Weather Bit Into U.S. Auto Sales in February
abstract: Ford fared poorest among the major automakers, with most of the company’s lineup taking a hit. The Fiesta, Focus and Taurus all fell by double digits.
lead_paragraph: After the frigid winter last year, when many buyers stayed home, analysts expected the auto industry to post robust sales gains in February since higher percentages would be easier to achieve.

headline: Even Composting Comes With Sticker Shock
abstract: Stickers have become all too common in grocery stores, creating headaches for composters.
lead_paragraph: EVERETT, Wash. — The most bedeviling problem for the company that turns most of the Puget Sound region’s kitchen waste into compost is on a piece of fruit. Almost every piece of fruit.

headline: ‘The Contemporaries’ Looks Forward at the Ever-Changing Art World
abstract: Roger White’s new book, written with an insider’s sense of intimacy, provides an in-depth look at some of the debates that animate the current scene.
lead_paragraph: When Roger White, the artist and co-founder of the art journal Paper Monument, went to California to meet with the conceptual art pioneer Stephen Kaltenbach, he saw much of the artist’s life there: his home in Davis, his studio, his unfinished projects. Kaltenbach told White about his early career in New York, living in SoHo back when it was in its artistic prime. Kaltenbach even explained how, after a number of LSD trips, he began to hear what he interprets to be the voice of God. “I was hearing God, he was telling me things that were going to happen, and they would happen. It was just not possible.”

headline: Ferguson Police Routinely Violate Rights of Blacks, Justice Dept. Finds
abstract: A department report, which says officials made racist jokes about blacks on their city email accounts, concluded that officers made unjustified traffic stops for years.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ferguson, Mo., is a third white, but the crime statistics compiled in the city over the past two years seemed to suggest that only black people were breaking the law. They accounted for 85 percent of traffic stops, 90 percent of tickets and 93 percent of arrests. In cases like jaywalking, which often hinge on police discretion, blacks accounted for 95 percent of all arrests.

headline: Tips to Reduce Food Waste
abstract: A guide to storing food wisely and using nearly every bite, scrap and smidgen in your kitchen.
lead_paragraph: Being a better cook is more than mastering recipes. It’s also getting the most from your food, wasting little and repurposing leftovers in creative, even ingenious ways. Below, Food reporters and editors share their ideas for improving kitchen storage and using up odds and ends. Have a suggestion? Post it in the comments section.

headline: Starve a Landfill
abstract: Restaurants, home cooks and now a growing number of cities are embracing the belief that efficiency, composting and wasting less in the kitchen are just smart economics.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — The nation’s first citywide composting program based largely on shame began here in January.

headline: Citigroup to Benefit From Losing Its Most Profitable Unit
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Federal Taxes (US)']
abstract: The bank’s deal to sell its subprime consumer finance unit OneMain gives it a shot of income, frees up capital and removes a distraction.
lead_paragraph: Trust Citigroup to benefit from getting rid of its most profitable business. The huge bank has at last sold its subprime consumer finance unit OneMain Financial to a rival, Springleaf, for $4.25 billion. The unit has generated returns that far exceed anything else at Citigroup. And yet the deal provides all manner of relief for the lender run by Michael L. Corbat.

headline: An Improved Vaccination Against a Virus — and Some Cancers
abstract: “A possible side effect of not getting the vaccine is cancer, and it’s far more common than any side effects of the shots.”
lead_paragraph: Dr. Ronald A. DePinho likes to call the HPV shot series a “cancer vaccine.”

headline: M. Stanton Evans, Who Helped Shape Conservative Movement, Is Dead at 80
abstract: At 26, Mr. Evans drafted the statement of principles upon which Young Americans for Freedom, the first substantial national conservative organization, was created.
lead_paragraph: M. Stanton Evans, an early leader of the conservative movement in American politics and an author of its central manifesto, the Sharon Statement, died on Tuesday at a nursing home in Leesburg, Va. He was 80.

headline: Countries Questioning Indonesia’s Push to Execute Drug Offenders
abstract: With six convicts put to death in January, and 10 more set to be executed soon, countries like Australia, Brazil and the Netherlands are questioning the harsh policy.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA — Declaring illegal drug use a “national emergency,” the Indonesian government has embarked on a campaign of executions of drug offenders, most of them foreigners convicted of smuggling. The executions have alienated the country’s allies and set off diplomatic disputes on three continents.

headline: Germany to Bolster Investment in Cities and Towns
abstract: The country said it would commit an additional 5 billion euros to helping needy municipalities.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Germany announced on Tuesday that it would commit an additional 5 billion euros to helping the country’s needy municipalities, sweetening a €10 billion, or $11.2 billion, investment plan announced last fall.

headline: Ivy Player Has Eligibility Remaining, but Not in Ivy League
abstract: An Ivy League rule forbids the participation of graduate students, so Shonn Miller, a Cornell forward, will essentially be a free agent come his graduation in May.
lead_paragraph: ITHACA, N.Y. — After one of his final basketball practices at Cornell, Shonn Miller sat in the bleachers at Newman Arena, his eyes fixed on teammates who were still shooting jumpers.

headline: In Bed-Stuy, a New Store Is Like a Petting Zoo for Clothes
abstract: The looks are loose and international at Sincerely, Tommy in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: The brownstones off Tompkins Avenue in Bedford-Stuyvesant are lined up like stripes of Neapolitan ice cream: brown, white, pinky-beige.

headline: The Plot Thickens in a Sequel
abstract: Holding out hope that Jeremiah Tower, formerly of Chez Panisse, can rescue Tavern on the Green.
lead_paragraph: You can’t help hoping that Jeremiah Tower will rescue Tavern on the Green if you’ve ever seen a movie about an aging rogue coming out of retirement for one last heist, con, caper, battle, boxing match or, in this case, a 700-seat restaurant that combines certain qualities of each of those things.

headline: Flexible Spending Accounts Still Have Deadlines That Can’t Be Ignored
abstract: The rules on these tax-advantaged medical accounts have been eased, but not all companies have adopted the changes.
lead_paragraph: Now that employers may allow workers to carry over some funds in their flexible health care accounts from year to year, annual spending deadlines may seem less significant.

headline: Tune In to The Times
abstract: Michael S. Schmidt appeared on MSNBC’s Morning Joe to discuss The Times’s coverage of Hillary Clinton’s use of private emails while serving as secretary of state.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times reporter Michael S. Schmidt joined MSNBC’s Morning Joe to discuss The Times’s special report on Hillary Clinton’s use of private emails as secretary of state.

headline: Obamacare Goes to the Supreme Court
keywords: ['Constitution (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: The magazine’s Emily Bazelon and The Times’s Supreme Court correspondent, Adam Liptak, discuss what’s at stake and what the justices might be thinking.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday morning, the United States Supreme Court will hear arguments in King v. Burwell, the case that could decide the fate of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, the landmark “Obamacare” legislation passed by Congress in 2010. Emily Bazelon, a staff writer for the magazine, and Adam Liptak, The Times’s Supreme Court correspondent, have been exchanging emails about what’s at stake in the case and how the court might approach its decision.

headline: Private Equity Payouts Leave the Rest of Wall St. in the Dust
abstract: The gulf between the earnings of Lloyd C. Blankfein and Stephen A. Schwarzman illustrates the power of dividend income for private equity’s top brass.
lead_paragraph: In many ways, Lloyd C. Blankfein and Stephen A. Schwarzman are similar. Both are senior statesmen of Wall Street, both at the helms of powerful financial firms.

headline: In Health Law Case, Plaintiffs Dislike Rules on Purchases and Penalties
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The four plaintiffs argue that rules on federal subsidies apply only in states that created their own insurance exchanges; their state, Virginia, has not.
lead_paragraph: FREDERICKSBURG, Va. — People sometimes wonder why David M. King would fight health insurance subsidies all the way to the Supreme Court, which is scheduled to hear his case on Wednesday. Even his sister is puzzled.

headline: Nordic Food Is a Doorway for Scandinavian Spirits
abstract: The New Nordic cuisine opens the way for Baska Snaps, Bjork Birch Liqueur and other Scandinavian-style drinks.
lead_paragraph: The New Nordic cuisine is no longer the new kid on the culinary block. All grown up, it has even acquired some drinking companions.

headline: A New Guardian at the Hirshhorn
abstract: Stéphane Aquin is the new curator of an institution that has never quite lived up to its potential.
lead_paragraph: Stéphane Aquin is the new curator of an institution that has never quite lived up to its potential.

headline: Eleonore Toulin Transforms at Jacquemus
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall 2015 Fashion Week in Paris.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall 2015 Fashion Week in Paris. Here, the model Eleonore Toulin before (left) and after (right) makeup by Lyne Desnoyers, artistic design by Sebastian Bieniek and hair by Holli Smith.

headline: Review: In ‘Abundance,’ by Beth Henley, Mail-Order Brides Find Husbands and Lice
abstract: Ms. Henley’s play, in a revival by the Actors Company Theater, is a rare western in which women are the stars.
lead_paragraph: Was it a delayed reaction to the Reagan era, eight years of watching a cowboy president ride horses on his California ranch? Something, anyway, made the early 1990s an exceptionally rich time for unconventional westerns.

headline: Obama Responds to Netanyahu’s Speech
abstract: President Obama said that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel “didn’t offer any viable alternatives” on Iran during his address to Congress.
lead_paragraph: President Obama said that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel “didn’t offer any viable alternatives” on Iran during his address to Congress.

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Erin Baiano.

headline: Review: Eberhardt’s Fierce Ride, in ‘The Nomad’
abstract: “The Nomad,” from Elizabeth Swados and Erin Courtney, follows the journey of a Western woman who finds freedom posing as a man in North Africa.
lead_paragraph: Shoulders back, chin out, the young woman in the fez is bemused, defiant, yet intrigued by her circumstances. “I am dead; this is the state of things,” Isabelle Eberhardt sings at the start of “The Nomad,” and she seems curiously willing to make the most of it.

headline: Upholding Internet Sales Tax Law, a Justice Invites a New Case
abstract: The issue was notable for Justice Anthony M. Kennedy’s concurrence in saying that the court went astray in a 1992 decision on online sales taxes.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday handed a victory to a trade group challenging a Colorado law seeking to aid state authorities in the collection of sales taxes on out-of-state purchases made online.

headline: First Draft Focus: A ‘Clean’ Bill for Homeland Security
abstract: In the end, Speaker John A. Boehner overrode the objections of his more hard-line members and pushed through a “clean” bill to fund the Department of Homeland Security.

headline: Review: Sarah Manguso Offers Crumbs Relating to Her Diary
abstract: “Ongoingness: The End of a Diary,” Sarah Manguso’s third book of nonfiction, is a piece of work about 800,000 words of introspection.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Manguso’s best book, “The Two Kinds of Decay,” came out seven years ago. It’s about her long battle with a crippling neurological disease, one that forced her during her 20s to have her plasma replaced more than 50 times. It’s a harrowing book. It’s also a funny one. A boyfriend visits her in the hospital and declares her condition “greasy but stable.”

headline: New York City Plans to Study the Diversity of Its Cultural Groups
abstract: A survey to be undertaken this summer is aimed at reviewing the racial, ethnic and gender makeup of New York City’s cultural groups.
lead_paragraph: In a major study to be undertaken this summer, the de Blasio administration will review the diversity of the boards, staffs and audiences of New York City cultural organizations, such as museums, orchestras and dance troupes.

headline: Mr. Netanyahu’s Unconvincing Speech to Congress
abstract: The prime minister of Israel offered no new reasons to reject the agreement being negotiated by the United States to constrain Iran’s nuclear program.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel could not have hoped for a more rapturous welcome in Congress. With Republicans and most Democrats as his props, he entered the House of Representatives to thunderous applause on Tuesday, waving his hand like a conquering hero and being mobbed by fawning lawmakers as he made his way to the lectern.

headline: Review: Roman Rabinovich Plays Bach and More at SubCulture
abstract: Mr. Rabinovich, chosen by the pianist Andras Schiff for a concert series, played works that included elements of dance and folk music in an 80-minute recital.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes a concert appearance by a young artist results from winning a competition. Mostly, though, artists are engaged because the director of a hall is interested.

headline: Review: Ekmeles Performs John Cage at the Avant Music Festival
abstract: The vocal ensemble performed Cage’s complete choral works at Wild Project on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: In 2006, Trogen, a Swiss town, began hosting a series of performances of the complete choral works by Bach, with their sequence determined by the liturgical calendar for which they were written. According to the Swiss J. S. Bach Foundation, which is behind the project, the series will have covered all of his cantatas, masses, oratorios and motets by 2030.

headline: Karl Lagerfeld on Fur (Yea), Selfies (Nay) and Keeping Busy
abstract: Now in his 70s (or 80s), the German-born designer is as prolific as he is tenacious, with a terse wit and a predilection for Delphic pronouncements.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — Karl Lagerfeld, arguably the most recognizable fashion designer in the world, is in a back office at Fendi’s headquarters on the Via Solari, receiving from an assistant a gift someone has sent for his Birman, Choupette.

headline: U.N. Moves Closer to Sanctions in South Sudan Conflict
abstract: While the Security Council voted to sanction those who disrupt peace efforts, it stopped short of barring the warring factions from buying more arms.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The United Nations Security Council on Tuesday unanimously adopted a resolution to impose sanctions on those who disrupt efforts to restore peace in South Sudan, but it stopped short of barring the warring factions from buying more arms.

headline: Seeing Stars at Anthony Vaccarello
abstract: On the designer’s fall 2015 runway, little motifs drawn under the models’ eyes matched the rock-‘n’-roll feel (and look) of the collection.
lead_paragraph: The constellation prize for today’s shows in Paris went to the hairstylist Anthony Turner and the makeup artist Tom Pecheux for the beauties they sent down the runway at Anthony Vaccarello. For Turner, the off-duty look they collaborated on was dictated by casting. “All the girls are beautiful,” he says, “so it wasn’t about creating characters or turning them into something they are not.” For tousled rock-‘n’-roll strands, Turner worked L’Oreal Professional PLI from roots to ends, letting each model’s hair part naturally. Pecheux, for his part, was feeling more Chrissie Hynde and less David Bowie with the tattoo-looking designs he created under one of each of the models’ eyes. Inspired by the clothes, he drew the shape of a star out of the corner of the eye — “but we have seen that before,” he says. So he began erasing the star’s lines until he arrived at a more subtle geometric touch. And despite the heavily-lined eyelids, Pecheux didn’t use a drop of mascara; he didn’t want the models to look “too bourgeoisie.”
