abstract: Can I hide my beliefs during jury selection?
lead_paragraph: Can I hide my beliefs during jury selection?

headline: What Do Unions Know About Running Schools?
abstract: A union-run charter school in New York struggled from the start.
lead_paragraph: The charter school movement got its foothold two decades ago by promising that independently operated schools would outperform their traditional counterparts if they were allowed to receive public money while being exempted from some state regulations — including the requirement that they be unionized. Charter advocates made the deal more compelling by vowing that charter schools would be closely overseen and shut down when they failed , in contrast to traditional schools, which were allowed to fail in perpetuity without consequence.

headline: Clock Ticks for Paul Rudolph’s Orange County Government Center
abstract: Thursday is the deadline for legislators in Goshen, N.Y., to rescue Mr. Rudolph’s modernist building from demolition.
lead_paragraph: This week, lawmakers in Goshen, N.Y., have a last chance to save an archetype of midcentury modernist architecture — and themselves from going down as reckless stewards of the nation’s heritage.

headline: A West Indian-Style Oceanfront Villa in Anguilla
abstract: The house, which has three bedrooms and a guest cottage on the island’s northern shore, is on the market for $3.4 million.
lead_paragraph: The house, which has three bedrooms and a guest cottage on the island’s northern shore, is on the market for $3.4 million.

headline: Americans Aren’t Saving Enough for Retirement, but One Change Could Help
keywords: ['Retirement', 'Mutual Funds', '401(k), 403(b) and 457 Plans', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Individual Retirement Accounts', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans']
abstract: The typical remedy is that people should put more money aside in investments. This glosses over a critical driver of unpreparedness: Wall Street is bleeding savers dry.
lead_paragraph: Here is something every non-rich American family should know: The odds are that you will run out of money in retirement.

headline: Review: ‘The Lesson’ Is a Test of Conscience and Patience
abstract: This Bulgarian film, written and directed by Kristina Grozeva and Petar Valchanov, follows an English teacher as her carefully organized life comes undone.
lead_paragraph: We first encounter Nade (Margita Gosheva) in the classroom, preceded by the sound of chalk on the blackboard. An English teacher in a provincial Bulgarian town, she is stern but not without a hint of warmth. At the moment, though, she is preoccupied with finding out which of her students has been stealing money from unattended backpacks. This turns out to be a sign of worse trouble to come.

headline: The 17th Armory Show, New as Ever
keywords: ['ARMORY SHOW, THE INTERNATIONAL FAIR OF NEW ART (NYC)', 'Art', 'Collectors and Collections']
abstract: The annual international art fair, helmed by the young director Noah Horowitz, has evolved to meet the art market’s continually changing demands.
lead_paragraph: What’s that old adage about New York real estate? Location, location, location. So how is it that the Armory Show, which opens its 17th iteration this week, absolutely thrives on Piers 92 and 94 — which sit on the West Side Highway at 55th Street, otherwise known as Manhattan’s Siberia? The secret: its director, Noah Horowitz, who swooped in four years ago to save the fair from what was widely regarded as its hemorrhaging status. At the age of 35, Horowitz, who penned the art-market manual “Art of the Deal” and is a faculty member at Sotheby’s Institute of Art, commands expert status in the ways of the contemporary scene, and has made the fair his own. “Overall, I think the feeling is of renewed strength to the fair. We’ve made a huge emphasis on quality, in the stature of the galleries themselves — and I don’t mean just blue-chip galleries, but also young and mid-career ones, too,” he explains of his strategy. Since finding its foothold in 1999, the Armory Show, which draws its namesake from the Park Avenue Armory and its inspiration from the 1913 exposition accredited with bringing “shock of the new” modernism to America, has always emphasized, well, evolution. “One of the challenges in the market we operate in these days is things have become very flat, and a lot of things start looking the same,” says Horowitz, who stresses his investment in new artists and galleries.

headline: What You Get for ... $1,250,000
abstract: This week’s properties include two cottages in Hawaii, a modern house in Oklahoma and a 19th-century house in Maryland.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties include two cottages in Hawaii, a modern house in Oklahoma and a 19th-century house in Maryland.

headline: Dangerous Passage and Multiplying Fines as Ice Is Left Uncleared
abstract: Building owners in New York City are fined for failing to clear sidewalks of slippery ice, but it can be difficult to determine who is responsible for vacant buildings, resulting in millions in unpaid fines.
lead_paragraph: There was no safe way across the thick slab of ice on the sidewalk.

headline: ‘Broadchurch,’ a Mystery Series, Returns to BBC America
abstract: Season 2 of this British mystery series begins on Wednesday night with a messier, more contingent arc than its previous season.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago I was on the conservative end of the spectrum in my praise for the British mystery series “Broadchurch,” using the words “superior entertainment” but also “intelligent but not particularly original.”

headline: Review: ‘My City’s Just Not That Into Me,’ a Real Estate Series on FYI
abstract: On this new show, a quiz is part of the home search for buyers tired of living in their current town.
lead_paragraph: Television already has more real estate shows than necessary, but if you can’t get enough of peering inside strangers’ houses, FYI offers a new series on Wednesday night that at least varies the formula. The only trouble is, you have to watch it as if you were touring a fixer-upper. Envision a real estate agent whispering in your ear, “Pay no attention to those holes.”

headline: Review: In ‘CSI: Cyber,’ CBS Digitizes the Forensics Formula
abstract: The latest “CSI” spinoff stars Patricia Arquette as a cybercrime investigator.
lead_paragraph: “CSI: Crime Scene Investigation,” now chugging along in its 15th season, keeps leaving its spinoffs in the dust. “CSI: Miami” gave up after 10 seasons, “CSI: NY” fell away after nine. But the hope for advertising dollars springs eternal, so here we have “CSI: Cyber,” making its debut on CBS on Wednesday night.

headline: Living on Sutton Place
abstract: The affluent neighborhood has many longtime residents, but it is also attracting younger people.
lead_paragraph: The affluent neighborhood has many longtime residents, but it is also attracting younger people.

headline: A Conversation With Winston C. Fisher
abstract: Mr. Fisher is a partner of Fisher Brothers, a family real estate company, with around 1.5 million square feet of space under development, largely in Manhattan and Washington.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Fisher, 42, is a partner of Fisher Brothers, a New York-based family real estate company, founded in 1915, with around 1.5 million square feet of space currently under development, largely in Manhattan and Washington. Mr. Fisher is a partner along with his cousins Kenneth and Steven Fisher and his uncle Arnold.

headline: Members of Newtown Shootings Panel Recall Toll Their Work Took
keywords: ['Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'Gun Control']
abstract: Some of the 16 commissioners appointed by Gov. Dannel P. Malloy of Connecticut said that studying the December 2012 killings changed their lives.
lead_paragraph: In the emotional weeks after the shootings at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., in December 2012 that left 20 first graders and six faculty members dead, Gov. Dannel P. Malloy assembled 16 experts — emergency workers, psychiatrists, trauma specialists, teachers, a pediatrician, a mayor — to examine the event.

headline: Scooter LaForge’s Paintings Suit Walter Van Beirendonck (and Beyonce, Too)
abstract: The Antwerp Six designer commissioned colorful work from the artist for the “Whambam! collection,” his spring/summer 2015 line.
lead_paragraph: Like so many modern relationships, the collaboration between the designer Walter Van Beirendonck, one of the famous “Antwerp 6,” and the New York artist Scooter LaForge started on Facebook. Beirendonck began following LaForge’s public profile several years ago, and the rest will sound familiar: “One day, we started to chat,” Beirendonck says. After asking the artist to paint an invitation and poster for an earlier collection, the designer more recently commissioned several paintings from LaForge with imagery relating to “topics I wanted to refer to in the Whambam! collection,” Beirendonck’s spring/summer 2015 line. LaForge’s paintings depicting a shark, birds of paradise, a bloody beach, a machine gun, a warplane and a kitten were then scanned digitally and translated into woven fabrics.

lead_paragraph: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin said Tuesday that he would sign a ban on abortions after 20 weeks, coming out strongly on an issue important to social conservatives that he played down in his re-election campaign last year.

headline: Britain: Man Linked to Militants in Yemen Is Extradited to the U.S.
abstract: A Vietnamese man accused of helping develop online propaganda for Al Qaeda’s affiliate in Yemen has been extradited from Britain to face trial in Manhattan, United States prosecutors said Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: A Vietnamese man accused of helping develop online propaganda for Al Qaeda’s affiliate in Yemen has been extradited from Britain to face trial in Manhattan, United States prosecutors said Tuesday. The defendant, Minh Quang Pham, 32, had been living in Britain. He went to Yemen in 2010; swore an oath of allegiance to the group, Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula; and provided it with “expert advice and assistance in photography and graphic design of media,” an indictment charges. In Yemen, he worked with an American citizen who helped produce Inspire, an English-language online magazine published by the group, the authorities said. The indictment does not name the American, but he appears to have been Samir Khan, who was later killed in a drone strike. Mr. Pham’s lawyer did not respond immediately to messages seeking comment.

headline: For White House Spokesman, Clinton Emails Trump Netanyahu Speech
abstract: The White House spokesman spent nearly his entire news conference Tuesday discussing Hillary Rodham Clinton’s email use as secretary of state, not the speech by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel.
lead_paragraph: Josh Earnest, the White House press secretary, found himself spending nearly his entire news conference Tuesday discussing  Hillary Rodham Clinton’s use of a personal email account when she was secretary of state, rather than the speech delivered earlier in the day by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel.

headline: Namibia: President Is Awarded $5 Million Prize for Good Governance
keywords: ['Ibrahim, Mo, Prize for Achievement in African Leadership', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors']
abstract: Namibia’s departing president, Hifikepunye Pohamba, has been awarded the 2014 Ibrahim Prize for Achievement in African Leadership.
lead_paragraph: Namibia’s departing president, Hifikepunye Pohamba, has been awarded the 2014 Ibrahim Prize for Achievement in African Leadership. In making the announcement on Monday in Kenya, the prize committee’s chairman, Salim Ahmed Salim, said, “President Pohamba’s focus on forging national cohesion and reconciliation at a new stage of Namibia’s consolidation of democracy and social and economic development impressed the prize committee.” The Ibrahim Prize, the largest annually awarded prize in the world, is worth $5 million over the first 10 years, followed by a stipend of at least $200,000 a year. The Mo Ibrahim Foundation, established in 2006 by a Sudanese-British telecom mogul, makes the annual awards. Mr. Pohamba, 79, has served two terms as president and is due to hand over power at the end of the month. He was a founding member of the governing party, Swapo, which fought for Namibian independence from South Africa in 1990. Since the prize’s inception, four former presidents have received it. In the past two years, no prize was awarded.

headline: Supreme Court May Be Open to Hotel Registry Checks
abstract: The Supreme Court debated whether the police can inspect guest registries without a judge’s permission.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday seemed inclined to let the police in Los Angeles inspect hotel and motel guest registries without permission from a judge.

headline: Drugs Using Testosterone Will Label Heart Risks
abstract: The F.D.A. ordered that labels on testosterone drugs warn of heart attack and stroke risks, and advised that the drugs should not be prescribed to treat symptoms in men brought on by age, such as declining sexual drive.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Food and Drug Administration said Tuesday that manufacturers of testosterone drugs used by millions of Americans will be required to change labels for the drugs to warn that they could increase the risk of heart attacks and strokes and should not be prescribed to treat symptoms in men brought on by age, such as declining sexual drive.

headline: Pension Funds Trail Individuals in Embracing Index Funds
abstract: As more individuals pour money into index funds, institutions like pension funds and endowments have been slower to follow suit.
lead_paragraph: More individuals are pouring money into so-called passive investing or index funds, which aim to match the performance of the main stock and bond markets, but larger institutions like pension funds and endowments have been slower to follow suit, despite the potential for higher returns and lower fees.

headline: Netanyahu’s Nuclear Deceptions

Yet all his predictions about how close Iran was to acquiring a nuclear bomb have proved baseless.

headline: Confessions From New York’s Era of Fury Show Their Cracks
keywords: ['Confessions', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Central Park Jogger Case (1989)', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments']
abstract: Once considered airtight, some confessions in the 1990s — the high tide of rampage and murder in modern New York — have led to grave errors.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, Pascal Carpenter, age 42, left prison after serving 25 years, his sentence for being the lookout in a mugging that became a murder. Under New York law, if someone is killed during the commission of a felony — say, a robbery — everyone who took part in the lesser crime can be held liable for the homicide. It’s not just New York; some states execute the lookouts.

headline: Virginia: Women’s College Will Close Over Finances
abstract: Sweet Briar College, a century-old women’s liberal-arts college near Lynchburg, announced Tuesday that it will close in August.
lead_paragraph: Sweet Briar College, a century-old women’s liberal-arts college near Lynchburg, announced Tuesday that it will close in August. The college, which has 700 students and 329 employees, cited “insurmountable financial problems” and the shrinking number of students interested in a rural women-only college. Sweet Briar will be the third liberal-arts institution in the state to fold in the last two years, after Saint Paul’s College and Virginia Intermont College. There is no decision yet on what will become of the 3,250-acre campus.

headline: What Bibi Didn’t Say
abstract: Now that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has had his say, it’s time to ask: What is in America’s best interest?
lead_paragraph: Now that Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has made his case on Iran before Congress, with all the circus atmosphere it involved, let’s get to the serious questions: What is America’s interest in striking a deal with Iran? Because our interests and Israel’s are not fully aligned. What is the minimum we need to satisfy our interests? And how should we balance the critiques of our policy from the serious Bibi versus the cynical Bibi?

headline: And the End Came

lead_paragraph: As the Civil War entered its final spring, its history already needed to be told. Fittingly, one of the earliest attempts came from the man whose election to the presidency, four years earlier, had precipitated the conflict.

headline: David Wright Takes On New Role With Mets: Clubhouse Disciplinarian

lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Early in the Mets’ intrasquad game Tuesday, David Wright made a backhand play on a ground ball and then threw smoothly to first for the out. Wright has made that play hundreds of times. But this time, it was a small reminder that Wright’s left shoulder was healthy again after a season of discomfort and that he was at full strength for a 2015 campaign that he has said he hopes will end the Mets’ long run of futility.

lead_paragraph: In losing to the Sacramento Kings, 124-86, on Tuesday night, the Knicks were terrible as a team. But that shouldn’t disguise the fact that individually, they were also terrible.

headline: What’s On TV Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8:05 P.M. (Starz Cinema) THE DREAMERS (2004) Louis Garrel (top), Eva Green (center) and Michael Pitt (above) portray the points of a photogenic triangle in this drama from Bernardo Bertolucci (“Last Tango in Paris”) about an American who befriends French twins in Paris during the 1968 student riots. This adaptation of Gilbert Adair’s novel “The Holy Innocents” is “disarmingly sweet and completely enchanting,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “The sex in this movie is, as measured by the display of body parts and the amount of time the actors spend out of their clothes, more explicit than even the most notorious scenes in ‘Last Tango,’ ” he said. “But it is hard to imagine a voyeur more benevolent than Mr. Bertolucci, whose eager scrutiny of the eros of the young is, like Jeremy Irons’s in ‘Stealing Beauty,’ less a matter of prurience than of an honest, nostalgic appreciation of natural human vitality.”

headline: Delivering Unwelcome Species to the Mediterranean
abstract: Egypt’s plan to expand the Suez Canal threatens the sea’s fragile biodiversity.
lead_paragraph: The Mediterranean Sea is among the world’s great environmental jewels. The sea is highly saline, almost entirely enclosed by land and contains immense biodiversity. Scientists have long worried that its health is imperiled. Swelling coastal populations and ship traffic have brought overfishing and pollution. Climate change threatens to roil the waters still further.

headline: Photos Hopscotch Through Cortázar’s Paris
abstract: For the centennial of Julio Cortázar’s birth, Hugo Passarello took portraits of the Argentine’s writer’s fans and friends in Paris, the setting of his celebrated novel “Hopscotch.”
lead_paragraph: Hugo Passarello was young and starry-eyed when he first encountered “Hopscotch” by the Argentine novelist Julio Cortázar. Like most readers, he was enthralled by the stream-of-consciousness narrative that shattered notions of structure. Set in Paris and written episodically, the novel boasts 155 snapshots which Cortázar gives readers three options to move through: progressively; hopscotching with instructions; or blazing a unique path.

headline: China’s Military Budget Increasing 10% for 2015, Official Says

lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The Chinese military budget for 2015 will be about 10 percent bigger than last year’s, a senior Chinese official said on Wednesday, meaning that such spending is growing at a pace faster than the overall growth rate of the Chinese economy.

headline: Las Vegas Gets a New Act
abstract: Can the city clean itself up and still remain diverse?

headline: Abuse at Attica Calls for Federal Scrutiny

abstract: With deep problems very apparent at the state prison, the Justice Department should examine the case of a savage beating of an inmate in August 2011.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department, which went to court in December to stop an epidemic of brutality in New York City’s jail system, may need to scrutinize New York State’s prisons as well. That seems fairly obvious from two recent articles published by The Times and The Marshall Project exploring a case of prison guards who beat an inmate nearly to death within view of witnesses at the infamous Attica prison in western New York in 2011.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Use of Personal Email

abstract: By using a private account to conduct government business as secretary of state, there is no way of knowing that all official correspondence was preserved.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s decision when she was secretary of state to use only her personal email account to conduct official business was a disturbing departure from the normal practice of relying primarily on departmental emails for official business.

headline: May (or May Not) Cause Weight Gain
abstract: For me, body image and depression have always been tightly woven together.
lead_paragraph: In the fall of 2014 the author decided to quit the prescription medications she has been taking to treat her anxiety, depression and insomnia, and began the process of gradually reducing her dosages. In Going Off, a series of Anxiety posts in the coming weeks, she will chronicle the challenges she faces from both the drugs and the withdrawal in her pursuit of a drug-free life.

headline: Their Dying Wishes
abstract: By the time patients have accepted that their lives are ending, their bucket lists often shift to the simple things: music, Twinkies, a hand to hold.
lead_paragraph: I met Mr. C. because he was dying and his wife needed someone to sit with him Saturday nights while she attended Mass. I was a relatively new hospice volunteer, not long out of training, and Mr. C. was my first assignment with a patient at home, rather than in a hospital or health care facility. He had been given a diagnosis of Parkinson’s disease 25 years before I first entered their small apartment in the Baruch housing projects, which stand where the Williamsburg Bridge meets Manhattan.

headline: The Hardest (and Most Important) Job in Afghanistan
abstract: A week on the front lines with the Afghan National Police.
lead_paragraph: Early one cold January morning on the high plains of eastern Afghanistan, Maj. Mohammad Qasim and a few of his officers gathered in the rundown barracks that serve as a district headquarters for the Afghan National Police in Baraki Barak. Qasim and his officers were the only government security available to the 100,000 people living in a district roughly twice the size of Manhattan, and about half of the district was now controlled by the Taliban. Kabul is just 40 miles away, but the Afghan National Army had not been to Baraki Barak in two years. The ceiling in Qasim’s office leaked when it rained, and the electricity was out indefinitely, so the men had taken to sitting on floor cushions around the wood stove in Qasim’s bedroom, drinking green tea from smudged glass mugs and dealing with the problems of the day. This morning, the first problem was the death of Hajji Khalil.

headline: ‘New York Spring Spectacular’ Brings High Kicks to Radio City Music Hall
abstract: The show, featuring the Rockettes and others, is a springtime counterweight to the theater’s Christmas program.
lead_paragraph: Two monumental puppets representing Patience and Fortitude, the lions guarding the entrance to the main branch of New York Public Library, tapped their paws and swished their tails onstage at Radio City Music Hall the other day. It was break time during rehearsals for Radio City’s “New York Spring Spectacular,” and in an orchestra seat, Randy Weiner, one of the show’s creative directors, leaned back and began formulating, aloud, a few interesting notions.

headline: ‘The Strategist: Brent Scowcroft and the Call of National Security’
abstract: A political scientist examines the trials and successes of Brent Scowcroft’s years as a national security adviser.
lead_paragraph: In foreign policy, every success is just the start of the next crisis. Brent Scowcroft has pointed this out often in his four ­decades at the top of the American national security establishment. When the Soviet Union was conceding defeat in the nuclear arms race, he wondered if Gorbachev would instead “kill us with kindness.” When the Evil Empire was crumbling, he fretted about loose ­nuclear weapons and ethnic slaughter. When American troops were routing Saddam Hussein in the Persian Gulf war of 1991, he worried that “Iraq could fall apart,” leaving us to pick up the pieces. Again and again, this taciturn Mormon has been the Woody ­Allen of American foreign policy.

headline: How Do You Express Yourself Creatively?
abstract: Do you play an instrument? Draw? Take photos? Write poetry? Dance? Or do express your creativity in less traditional ways? How do you express your creativity?
lead_paragraph: Do you play an instrument? Draw? Take photos? Write poetry? Dance?

abstract: Several miners were killed in the explosion, and dozens more were trapped underground and feared dead.
lead_paragraph: KRASNOARMIRSK, Ukraine — An explosion ripped through a coal mine in the separatist-held eastern city of Donetsk, Ukraine, early Wednesday morning, killing several miners and leaving dozens more trapped underground and feared dead.

headline: A Lawyer Taking Aim at the Health Care Act Gets a Supreme Court Rematch
abstract: Michael A. Carvin lost the first fight three years ago, when the justices ruled in favor of the Obama administration, but now he is taking another shot.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The lawyer Michael A. Carvin is blunt-talking, rumpled and passionately libertarian. When he urged the Supreme Court on Wednesday to dismantle President Obama’s health care law, Justice Sonia Sotomayor — an ardent liberal — could not get in a word.

headline: Mayor de Blasio Seeks Stronger Ties With Jewish Voters
abstract: Bill de Blasio has reached out to both liberal and conservative factions of the community to create a role for himself as a spokesman for Jewish concerns both in New York and abroad.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, Mayor Bill de Blasio stood shoulder to shoulder with France’s chief rabbi at the Park East Synagogue and challenged European leaders to break their “atmosphere of indifference” toward anti-Semitism. A few days later, he slipped out of New York City to attend the wedding of a Hasidic leader’s grandson. Last week, he loosened city regulations on a medically questionable ultra-Orthodox circumcision ritual.

headline: Standard Chartered Profit Fell 37% in 2014
abstract: The British bank said it was targeting $1.8 billion in cost cuts over the next three years and was reducing risk in its businesses as part of an overhaul.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British bank Standard Chartered, which generates most of its earnings in Asia, said on Wednesday that profit fell 37 percent in 2014. It cited higher charges for bad loans and other credit risks, an accounting charge on its Korean business, and a previously announced settlement with the United States authorities.

headline: One Twin Exercises, the Other Doesn’t
abstract: Identical twins who shared the same sports and other physical activities as youngsters but different exercise habits as adults soon developed quite different bodies and brains, a new study from Finland found.
lead_paragraph: Identical twins in Finland who shared the same sports and other physical activities as youngsters but different exercise habits as adults soon developed quite different bodies and brains, according to a fascinating new study that highlights the extent to which exercise shapes our health, even in people who have identical genes and nurturing.

headline: ‘Our Kids,’ by Robert D. Putnam
abstract: Robert D. Putnam finds that equal opportunity no longer exists in America.
lead_paragraph: Robert D. Putnam is technically a Harvard social scientist, but a better description might be poet laureate of civil society. In successive versions of “Bowling Alone” (as a 1995 article and an instant-classic book), Putnam argued, to bipartisan acclaim, that civic life is declining with ominous consequences. Bill Clinton brought him to Camp David. The campaigns of Al Gore and George W. Bush sought his advice. Barack Obama gave him a medal.

keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'States (US)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Federal Aid (US)']

keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: As Donald B. Verrilli Jr. returns to the Supreme Court on Wednesday morning to defend the health law, he has reason to be nervous. His defense of the law in 2012 drew harsh reviews.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Three years ago this month, Solicitor General Donald B. Verrilli Jr. stood before the Supreme Court to defend President Obama’s health care law against a constitutional challenge that threatened to destroy its central provision. His oral argument drew harsh reviews, but in the end he managed to persuade five justices to accept his backup argument, saving the law.

He is 34 years old, married, a father and a well-regarded leader of his neighborhood association in Sacramento. Local government officials and business owners know who he is, Mike Isaac reports.

headline: Can I Hide My Beliefs During Jury Selection?
abstract: The Ethicists consider reader questions about honesty in the courtroom, parking spots and the guilt-inducing coins mailed to us by charities.
lead_paragraph: I live in a Midwestern state that has the death penalty. I am scheduled to be a juror for the first time in March, and I’m afraid I will face a difficult ethical choice if I am selected for a capital case. Though I consider myself an atheist, I was brought up Quaker and still hold dear many of those values — nonviolence, a belief in the goodness of each person, peace and simplicity, to name a few. I believe that the death penalty is inherently wrong, unethical and unjust. Should I be put on a capital case, I am considering hiding my beliefs to improve my odds of selection so I can subvert an unfair system. I know it is unethical and possibly illegal to lie to the judge and lawyers, but do the means justify the ends in order to save a life? NICO

headline: Morning Agenda: Equity Firms Push Into Landlord Loans

lead_paragraph: EQUITY FIRMS PUSH INTO LANDLORD LOANS | In the aftermath of the financial crisis, large private equity firms spent tens of billions of dollars buying foreclosed homes across the United States to operate them as rental properties. Now, three big firms ‒ the Blackstone Group, Colony Capital and Cerberus Capital Management ‒ are providing loans to smaller investors who are looking to do something similar, Matthew Goldstein reports in DealBook. These firms are betting that so-called landlord loans to small and midsize investors will become the next big opportunity to profit from the rebound in the United States housing market.

headline: Hirshhorn Museum’s New Curator Brings a Different Perspective
abstract: Stéphane Aquin, a Canadian, is the new guardian at America’s national museum of modern art, where impact and vision, rather than dollars and bodies, may be the measure of his success.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two days into his job as chief curator at the Smithsonian’s Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden, Stéphane Aquin is, as he would say, dépaysé — away from home and off kilter. Heading out to our breakfast meeting, he makes the mistake of hailing a cab which, in classic Washington fashion, takes him all over town before depositing him at his destination — a few minutes’ walk from where he started out. At a grill, hungry for an egg sandwich, Mr. Aquin is offered such a dizzying array of options that he switches his order to sausage, which arrives as pancake-shaped patties of meat. Not quite the saucisse he’d have been served at any bistro in his native Montreal.

headline: Hermosa Beach, Calif., Voters Give Thumbs Down to Oil Drilling

According to unofficial returns, the measure was defeated 3,799 to 1,016.

headline: 1890: Forth Bridge Is Completed
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Forth Bridge finished construction in 1890.
lead_paragraph: EDINBURGH — The great railway bridge that now spans the Firth of Forth, to-day [March 4] received from the Prince of Wales its formal dedication. Here, amid wind and a drizzling rain the last rivet was driven home, the Prince using a silver key to turn the valve of the hydraulic riveting machine. The Prince, with some difficulty, made his way to the end of the platform and declared the bridge open.  The Forth Bridge, without doubt, is the highest effort of engineering skill in metal construction that the world has seen. An international significance attaches to the event from the presence of a large number of distinguished foreign guests. — The New York Herald, European Edition, March 5, 1890

headline: What the Fed’s 2009 Transcripts Reveal About Its Handling of the Recession
abstract: In the early months of that year, the Fed pressed ahead with the bold measures it had initiated in 2008 to arrest the financial crisis. By summer it had largely succeeded.
lead_paragraph: In the early months of that year, the Fed pressed ahead with the bold measures it had initiated in 2008 to arrest the financial crisis. By summer it had largely succeeded.

headline: 1994: Eurostar Tunnel Links Britain to the Continent
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Queen Elizabeth II traveled on the Eurostar to meet President François Mitterrand and inaugurate the tunnel between their two countries.
lead_paragraph: CALAIS, France — There was fog in the English Channel on Friday, but the Continent was not cut off. Queen Elizabeth II traveled through the Channel Tunnel in a gleaming Eurostar express to meet President François Mitterrand and inaugurate the first land link between England and the Continent.

headline: Ludo Lefebvre’s Roasted-Carrot Salad
abstract: A simple, sophisticated take on French cuisine.
lead_paragraph: “I used to cook for critics,” Ludo Lefebvre said, standing next to the narrow open kitchen at Petit Trois in Los Angeles, where producers and script wranglers and people who go on auditions eat steak frites with béarnaise sauce, then lurch back to studio lots for meetings and naps.

headline: David Hallberg Out for American Ballet Theater’s Spring Season
abstract: Mr. Hallberg, a principal dancer, is recovering from foot surgery last fall and will not perform.
lead_paragraph: David Hallberg, the American Ballet Theater principal dancer, is injured and will not perform during the company’s Metropolitan Opera House season, the company announced on Wednesday. Mr. Hallberg, who is also a principal dancer with the Bolshoi Ballet, had foot surgery last fall.

headline: Jean-Michel Othoniel Shares His Process in a Small but Poignant Exhibition
abstract: The artist, whose redesign of the Water Theater at Versailles with the landscape architect Louis Benech opens this spring, has a new show in Boston called “Secret Flower Sculptures.”
lead_paragraph: For his second American museum exhibition, the French artist Jean-Michel Othoniel says he shares “the hidden part of my work.” “Secret Flower Sculptures,” on view beginning March 12 at the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston, explores the artistic process he began developing four years ago, when he was an artist in residence at the Gardner. (It was then that he also discovered an 18th-century book, “The Art of Describing Dance” by Raoul-Auger Feuillet, which informed the new Water Theater grove design he created in collaboration with the landscape architect Louis Benech, which opens to the public at the garden of Versailles this spring.)

headline: With Eye on 2016, Rand Paul Courts Sheldon Adelson

lead_paragraph: Rand Paul said Wednesday that he met with the Las Vegas casino magnate Sheldon Adelson this week while Mr. Adelson was in Washington for a congressional address by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel.

headline: 1940: French Develop Pursuit Planes
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: The French develop a warplane in 1940.
lead_paragraph: The French aviation industry has developed a pursuit plane whose speed exceeds that of the renowned Messerschmitt 110, it was learned yesterday [March 4]. According to an official source the plane will be in mass production by the end of June. A spokesman of the Air Ministry said the development of this craft would not mean the curtailment of purchases of Curtiss pursuit planes in the United States. He said the Curtiss ships are equal in speed to the Messerschmitts and far more maneuverable and would supplement the French production. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 5, 1940

headline: Actavis’s Bond Sale Demonstrates Investor Hunger for High-Yield Debt
abstract: As government bond yields worldwide get pushed down, corporate debt issuers edging toward junk status are in a sweet spot.
lead_paragraph: Actavis is showcasing the value of being barely investment grade. The company, a drug maker that has been making many acquisitions, attracted huge demand this week for $21 billion of bonds it is selling at a mere notch above junk status. They yield less than a bigger and higher-rated debt issue that Verizon did in 2013. Buyers of top-tier debt can’t help but keep looking further downward.

headline: 36 Hours in Rome
abstract: Early spring in the Eternal City means few crowds at its magnificent museums, convivial cafes and ancient sites.
lead_paragraph: Paolo Sorrentino’s mesmerizing film “La Grande Bellezza” (“The Great Beauty”), which won an Oscar for best foreign-language film in 2014, sparked controversy and endless conversation about the current state of the Italian capital. But one fact was indisputable: Rome, as the film’s seductive backdrop, was gorgeous. This is true in every season, but especially in colder months when the summer flood of tourists ebbs. From outlying neighborhoods that beckon with new restaurants and bars, to the historic center, where Mr. Sorrentino’s protagonist, Jep, wandered through so many scenes, Rome remains poised to prove that its beauty runs deep.

headline: High Rent, Low Wages
abstract: For the economy to be healthy, there is no substitute for decent and rising wages.
lead_paragraph: Recently, gasoline prices have been falling, and pulling down inflation with them. But prices have also dropped for a range of other consumer goods, including new and used cars and trucks, appliances and furniture, groceries and alcoholic beverages. It is possible to chalk up oil prices to volatile movements that are as likely to go up as down. But falling inflation more broadly is a sign of economic weakness, because in a healthy economy, prices rise along with improving conditions.

headline: Classical Playlist: Schumann, Bach, Prokofiev and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: SCHUMANN: String Quartets No. 1, 2 and 3Ying Quartet(Sono Luminus DSL-92184)Though the 200th anniversary of Schumann’s birth was celebrated in 2010, this year, for whatever reasons, has seen a burst of new Schumann recordings, especially of the four symphonies. Now the impressive Ying Quartet offers this rewarding recording of Schumann’s three string quartets (No. 1 in A minor, No. 2 in F, No. 3 in A). The ensemble, originally comprised of four siblings, came to attention in 1992 upon the members’ graduation from the Eastman School of Music. (Three of the siblings remain; Ayano Ninomiya has been first violinist since 2010.) These insightful performances balance Romantic impetuosity with refinement and intelligence. (The album comes with a standard CD and an additional Pure Audio Blu-ray version.) (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: Iraqis Want Lead Role in Driving ISIS From Mosul
abstract: Amid concerns about Iranian involvement in the offensive against the Islamic State, the Iraqi defense minister said the Mosul mission would be “planned, timed and executed by Iraqis.”
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Underscoring the Iraqi government’s determination to control the timetable and tactics in the battle against the Islamic State, the country’s defense minister declared on Wednesday that the most challenging operation, driving the militants from Mosul, Iraq’s second-largest city, would be “planned, timed and executed by Iraqis.”

headline: JPMorgan Promotes Two to Run Mergers in North America

headline: Bouchra Jarrar’s Paris Short List
abstract: The designer shares her favorite places to read the newspaper and to be captivated by magical, historic design in her hometown.
lead_paragraph: Like Paris itself, Bouchra Jarrar’s clothes fuse traditional elegance with contemporary cool. The designer founded her namesake line, which includes both haute couture and ready-to-wear collections, in 2010 after a decade and a half spent in some of the city’s top ateliers, including stints as Nicolas Ghesquiere’s studio manager at Balenciaga and as head of couture design at Christian Lacroix. Her fastidiously tailored daywear has since achieved cult-favorite status thanks to such signatures as couture-grade motorcycle jackets and expertly cut pants.

headline: European Court Upholds British View on Euro Clearinghouses
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The decision is a setback for the European Central Bank, which had declared a policy that the clearinghouses be based inside the single-currency zone.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In a judgment with political and financial ramifications, a European court on Wednesday ruled that the European Central Bank cannot require financial houses that clear trades of euro-denominated securities to be in eurozone countries.

headline: Is There Life After Hermès?
abstract: Since Christophe Lemaire left the global brand last fall, he and his partner, Sarah-Linh Tran, have focused on their own label.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Christophe Lemaire, the whispery, whiskery designer of Lemaire, is an odd avatar of steel-spined grit. He’s a philosophe of fashion, given to long pauses for thought as he chews over how and why he makes the clothes he makes. He dresses plainly, in Japanese-denim work shirts tucked into Japanese-denim jeans. He doesn’t broadcast bravery.

headline: British Property Secrecy Could Hide Crimes, Report Says

headline: Atomic Dilemma: Debating How to Prevent Iran From Developing Nuclear Weapons
abstract: In this lesson students debate whether negotiations are an effective way to stop Iran from getting nuclear arms, and then write their own op-ed detailing their position.
lead_paragraph: Overview |  The United States, Israel, Saudi Arabia and other allies agree that Iran must not be allowed to develop a nuclear weapon. But beyond that consensus, there is a fundamental split in what is the best way to achieve that goal. Is it diplomacy? Is it punishment, in the form of economic sanctions, and threats, in the form of imminent military action? And even if negotiations yield an agreement, will a country like Iran, with which the United States has had no formal relations since 1979, abide by an agreement, or will it simply use the accord as a cover for producing a breakout weapon? These are tough questions. And the best answer is up for debate — the kind of complex real-world debate students can participate in, write about and learn from in this lesson.

lead_paragraph: Notes from Abraham Lincoln’s autopsy will be on display at the Fenimore Art Museum in Cooperstown, N.Y., starting April 1.

headline: Jittery Alex Rodriguez Gets a Hit and Fist Bumps in His Spring Debut
abstract: Playing for the Yankees for the first time in more than a year, Rodriguez singled in his first at-bat in a spring training game, grounded out and walked.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — A fly ball had barely settled into the glove of Yankees left fielder Ramon Flores — the final out of the top of the first inning — when Alex Rodriguez popped out of the dugout and into the on-deck circle. He was taking practice swings with a weighted bat before all of his teammates had made it off the field.

headline: Review: ‘American Crime,’ a Series Where Justice Is Far From Black or White

headline: Syrian Opposition to Post Dead Detainees’ Photos
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Torture']
abstract: The opposition members hope that the victims can be identified and that family members can potentially serve as plaintiffs in war crimes cases.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Syrian opposition on Wednesday began posting about 4,000 photographs of detainees who have died in President Bashar al-Assad’s prisons so that family members can try to identify the victims and potentially serve as plaintiffs in war crimes cases that could be filed in courts in Europe and possibly the United States.

headline: Outdated Encryption Keys Leave Phones Vulnerable to Hackers
abstract: Apple and Google said they were releasing patches to fix the problem, which results in part from 1990s American technology export restrictions.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — A government policy that forbade the export of products with strong encryption in the 1990s has years later left users of devices like Android and Apple phones vulnerable to hackers when they visit one-third of all websites, including whitehouse.gov and nsa.gov.

headline: The Supreme Court and the Fate of American Health Care
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Editorials', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Wednesday’s oral argument provided few clues, but a surprise came from Justice Anthony Kennedy.
lead_paragraph: In 2012, the chief justice of the United States, John Roberts Jr., saved the Affordable Care Act by a single, surprising vote. On Wednesday morning, the chief justice was again expected to hold the decisive vote as the Supreme Court heard extended oral argument in the latest assault on President Obama’s signature health care law.

headline: Clash of Views on Netanyahu’s Speech
abstract: Sampling the responses to the Israeli leader’s address to Congress.

headline: Herringbone Hits the Runways for Fall 2015
abstract: Donna Karan, Marc Jacobs and Prada pushed long lengths of the traditional men’s pattern in their new women’s wear collections.
lead_paragraph: Herringbone, traditionally a men’s wear suiting pattern, is no stranger to the women’s wear runways. And for fall 2015, designers are pushing long, dramatic lengths of it, nearly from head to toe. Back in New York, DKNY and Marc Jacobs introduced it on a large coat and ladylike cape, respectively. And in Milan, Prada went for a more masculine shape befitting the fabric’s roots: a retro suit accented with bright gem tones in keeping with the house’s colorful show.

abstract: President Obama thanked Congress before signing the bill approving appropriations for the Department of Homeland Security this fiscal year.

headline: More Children Eat Fruit in School, Study Shows
keywords: ['Lunch and Breakfast Programs', 'Children and Childhood', 'Fruit', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Education (K-12)', 'Food']
abstract: The study found that from the time new nutritional guidelines went into effect in 2012 through last year, the percentage of students choosing fruits increased to 66 percent from 54 percent.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Changes made to government-subsidized meals by the Obama administration to get schoolchildren to eat more fruits are having their intended effect, according to a study released on Wednesday.

headline: Ferguson Police Tainted by Bias, Justice Department Says
abstract: A report examining the deadly shooting of an unarmed black teenager by a white police officer in Ferguson, Mo., said that the city had engaged in multiple constitutional violations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department on Wednesday called on Ferguson, Mo., to overhaul its criminal justice system, declaring that the city had engaged in so many constitutional violations that they could be corrected only by abandoning its entire approach to policing, retraining its employees and establishing new oversight.

headline: Big Sean Opens at No. 1
abstract: The 26-year-old rapper Big Sean’s new album, “Dark Sky Paradise,” opened at the top of Billboard’s album chart.
lead_paragraph: The 26-year-old rapper Big Sean is a protégé of Kanye West, and gets plenty of paparazzi attention as the boyfriend of the pop starlet Ariana Grande. Now he has another claim to fame: a No. 1 album.

headline: F.D.U.-Florham, Division III Champion, Sets Its Sights on Repeating
abstract: Coach Marc Mitchell, whose team begins defense of its national title this week, has made F.D.U.-Florham of Madison, N.J., a recognizable name in Division III women’s basketball.
lead_paragraph: Marc Mitchell was born and raised in Newark. Now 46, he has coached New Jersey basketball teams — recreation league, middle school, high school and college — for more than 20 years.

headline: ‘House of Cards’ Season 3, Episode 10 Recap: Petrov and the Jordan Valley
abstract: Also, was that a Cashew cameo?
lead_paragraph: Season 3, Episode 10: Chapter 36

headline: Taxi Flings Take a Back Seat to Uber
keywords: ['Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Sex', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs']
abstract: The illicit thrill of a back-seat tryst is under threat these days with ride-sharing apps like Uber, where anonymity is no longer part of the transaction.
lead_paragraph: It started innocently enough: Rachel Rabbit White, a journalist in her 20s who writes about sex, was hailing a taxi with her boyfriend at the time and a female friend after a Lower East Side party.

headline: Split Over Obama’s Affordable Care Act
abstract: Outside the Supreme Court on Wednesday, supporters and opponents of the Affordable Care Act gathered ahead of the arguments over the fate of President Obama’s health care law.
lead_paragraph: Outside the Supreme Court on Wednesday, supporters and opponents of the Affordable Care Act gathered ahead of the arguments over the fate of President Obama’s health care law.

headline: Washington Fights for Its Right to Sled
abstract: Representative Eleanor Holmes Norton, who represents the District of Columbia, has written to the Capitol Police urging them to overturn a ban on sledding on Capitol grounds.
lead_paragraph: News from the nation’s capital: Let there be snow! And sledding!

headline: Yale Report Clears Police Officer in Encounter With Student
abstract: The officer had approached the student, who was leaving a library, with his gun drawn and briefly detained him after reports of an intruder.
lead_paragraph: An internal investigation by the Yale University police found that one of its officers did nothing wrong when, with his gun drawn, he approached a student matching the description of a burglary suspect and ordered him to the ground.

headline: Review: Keith Jarrett at Carnegie Hall, Precise and Aglow
abstract: Mr. Jarrett’s fan base tends to accept that the intensity of feeling in his playing is worth whatever limits he chooses to impose.
lead_paragraph: In his improvised solo piano concerts, Keith Jarrett has made it a custom to save a familiar song or two for the encores — a gleaming prize at the finish line. But of his three encores at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night, just one fit that bill: “I’m a Fool to Want You,” an abject cry of romantic despondence introduced by Frank Sinatra in 1951.

headline: Frozen Yoga? It’s Snowga
abstract: The latest version is often a mash-up with sports like skiing and snowshoeing.
lead_paragraph: It seemed as if yoga should have exhausted its opportunities for expansion by now, considering it has already made such unlikely alliances as marijuana, dogs, karaoke and stand-up paddleboards. But the yoga creep carries on with what may be the practice’s strangest bedfellow yet: snow.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Ukraine, Iraq, South Africa and Nepal.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Ukraine, Iraq, South Africa and Nepal.

headline: Youth Symphony Cancels Program That Quotes ‘Horst Wessel’ Song
abstract: Jonas Tarm, 21, had won a commission from the New York Youth Symphony, which canceled a performance after getting a letter of complaint.
lead_paragraph: Jonas Tarm had won the kind of opportunity most young composers can only dream of: the New York Youth Symphony had commissioned a piece from him and planned to play it this Sunday at Carnegie Hall. But the youth symphony pulled his piece this week after learning that it includes a musical quotation from the “Horst Wessel” song, the Nazi anthem.

headline: The Ferguson Police Department: The Justice Department Report, Annotated
abstract: The Justice Department’s investigation into law enforcement in Ferguson, Mo., found that the police and courts meted out illegal and unduly harsh treatment, particularly to black people.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department’s investigation into law enforcement in Ferguson, Mo., found that the police and courts meted out illegal and unduly harsh treatment, particularly to black people.

headline: Ice Cream as Health Food? This Bar Comes Close
keywords: ['Small Business', 'Ice Cream and Frozen Desserts', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Entrepreneurship']
abstract: Sales of Enlightened ice cream bars, which have fewer calories and more nutrients than regular ice cream, have been going impressively well.
lead_paragraph: When Alexander Soros, a son of the billionaire hedge fund manager George Soros, hosted a charity dinner in the Hamptons on a hot summer evening in July 2012, Michael Shoretz parked an ice cream cart just outside the dining area to offer samples of his new Enlightened ice cream bars.

headline: Review: Yonatan Gat Shreds Protocol in a Rampant Concert
abstract: Promoting the release of his band’s second album, “Director,” at Union Pool in Brooklyn, this guitarist played expandable riffs with interludes of anything goes.
lead_paragraph: For six years, until 2011, the guitarist Yonatan Gat was in Monotonix, a kind of garage-punk incursion unit from Tel Aviv. Generally, Monotonix set up on the floor of clubs, or in the middle of crowds in outdoor places, and ran rampant. The singer Ami Shalev set fire to things, swung from pipes, charged out of the room with the microphone, climbed on the audience and the other band members; the drummer Haggai Fershtman pummeled and crashed. Mr. Gat had to be the steady center of it. He had to keep the riffs going.

headline: An Eye for an Eye at Rochas
abstract: Makeup artist Lucia Pieroni created a bold, groovy look with a paisley motif at the label’s fall 2015 show.
lead_paragraph: If spring/summer 2015 was the moment of no-makeup makeup, then fall/winter may be the season of “Can you see me now?” In a move that echoed other runways prominently featuring shapes and symbols painted onto the face (Anthony Vaccarello, Jacquemus, Gareth Pugh, Vivienne Westwood), Lucia Pieroni added paisley motifs to the model’s browbones for today’s Rochas show at the Palais de Tokyo. Using matte black Clé de Peau Beauté Intensifying Cream Eyeliner, she added accents above the eye and on the lower lid to create a bold look that made last season’s doe-eyed girl seem downright grown-up. To offset the groovy statement shape, Pieroni skipped mascara and brought a natural glow to the skin, ever so slightly groomed the girls’ brows and finished off the look with a barely-there pink pout. “We didn’t want strange,” she says. “We wanted just a little something slightly off.”

headline: Natalia Revuelta Clews, Fidel Castro Ally And Mother of His Daughter, Dies at 89
abstract: Ms. Revuelta, who was born into Havana society, provided refuge and money to Cuban rebels and fell in love with their leader.
lead_paragraph: She was the emerald-eyed knockout of Havana society, and everyone knew her as Naty. She belonged to the Havana Country Club and lunched aboard yachts. She was married to a distinguished surgeon, and they lived in one of the best neighborhoods in the city.

headline: A Fashion Magazine’s Successful Business Model (Hint: It’s Free!)
abstract: American magazines are looking across the pond at Stylist for a new “freemium” model.
lead_paragraph: Every Thursday evening, attractive young men and women gather outside select Métro stations in Paris to hand out free copies of the fashion and beauty magazine Stylist to specific commuters.

headline: Shelf, iPad, Bed Table: Reading, February 2015
abstract: What I bought, what I read, what I thought I’d read and what I put down and never picked back up this February.
lead_paragraph: How can you rely on someone’s opinion of a book if you don’t know what else that person likes?

headline: Vionnet: Fall 2015 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

abstract: Photos from Ukraine, South Africa, Nepal and the United States.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Ukraine, South Africa, Nepal and the United States.

keywords: ['Watches and Clocks', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: With smartphones as alarm clocks, the timepiece near your pillow can simply be attractive.
lead_paragraph: With smartphones as alarm clocks, the timepiece near your pillow can simply be attractive.

headline: Children’s Lung Health Improves as Air Pollution Is Reduced, Study Says
abstract: The new study, conducted in Southern California, provides evidence that better air quality improved health among children, experts said.
lead_paragraph: For the first time, researchers have shown that reducing air pollution leads to improved respiratory function in children ages 11 to 15, a critical period of lung development.

headline: Are Manhattanites Becoming Brooklyn’s Bridge-and-Tunnel Crowd?
abstract: A native Brooklynite who moved to Manhattan grouses about becoming bridge-and-tunnel again, as the downtown scene shifts to the outer boroughs.
lead_paragraph: I’m a two-time bridge-and-tunnel person. Having regularly fled my native Brooklyn because it wasn’t fun enough, I’m now insinuating my way back in there because my adopted borough isn’t fun enough.

headline: Jerry Saltz, New York Magazine Art Critic, Suspended From Facebook
abstract: Mr. Saltz said that his access to his Facebook account had been suspended because of complaints; he believes the cause was provocative images of art that he posted.
lead_paragraph: For the last eight years the veteran New York magazine art critic Jerry Saltz has built a lively and enviable following on Facebook, which he has described as his 21st-century version of art haunts like the Cedar Tavern or Max’s Kansas City. But on Wednesday, Mr. Saltz was seized by the elbows and shown the door, digitally speaking.

headline: The Supreme Court: A Full Hearing
abstract: The Supreme Court reporter Adam Liptak reflects on how best to cover a major Supreme Court hearing.
lead_paragraph: Covering a big Supreme Court argument presents special challenges. There are no cameras in the courtroom, and the court does not release audio recordings until the end of the week. No electronic devices are allowed. Reporters bring only pen and paper, as in the old days.

headline: Spray Deodorants Are Rehabilitated, With Help From Europeans
abstract: Companies are reintroducing antiperspirant sprays in the United States. One plus, they don’t leave excess goop or white crumbles under your arms.
lead_paragraph: The underarm area is about the size of a Post-it note, but our individual notions about what keeps it dry and decent smelling are as impassioned as if it were a more substantial patch of skin.

headline: Brocade Ankle Boots to Complement a Girl-Power Message at Dries Van Noten
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: Far East-inspired texture in a ladylike palette.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Review: Malpaso Dance Company Presents Two New York Premieres at the Joyce
abstract: The Cuban dance troupe performed works by Trey McIntyre and Osnel Delgado on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Last spring, New York received a gift from Cuba: a premiere by Ronald K. Brown courtesy of Malpaso Dance Company. For its return visit to the Joyce Theater on Tuesday, the troupe, formed in 2012 by Osnel Delgado, Daile Carrazana and Fernando Sáez, hosts another impressive guest choreographer, Trey McIntyre. This prolific and much-admired dancemaker expresses playfulness without settling into a frivolous place.

headline: Raising an Artists’ Colony
abstract: An artists’ community has sprouted upstate among disused industrial buildings. If it continues to thrive, there will be pizza and beer for everyone.
lead_paragraph: An artists’ community has sprouted upstate among disused industrial buildings. If it continues to thrive, there will be pizza and beer for everyone.

lead_paragraph: The 9,000-square-foot house in Los Angeles with a pool and a past was an impulse buy.

headline: How to Wear Nude Lips Without Looking Washed Out
abstract: Jennifer Lopez and Kim Kardashian have finessed the beigey lip expertly. But before you attempt at home, mind the pitfalls.
lead_paragraph: Celebrities like Jennifer Lopez and Kim Kardashian have finessed the beigey lip so expertly that it feels timeless and seductive — a signature. And nude lips are everywhere at the fall runway shows: Vera Wang, Altuzarra, Rodarte, Burberry, Prada.

headline: New Tracy Letts Play Coming to Steppenwolf Theater Next Year
abstract: Mr. Letts’s new play, “Mary Page Marlowe,” and a new adaptation of John Steinbeck’s “East of Eden” are among the highlights of the Chicago company’s 2015-16 season.
lead_paragraph: Steppenwolf Theater Company in Chicago announced on Wednesday that two notable world premieres would be part of its 2015-16 season: a new play by Tracy Letts, the Pulitzer Prize-winning author of “August: Osage County,” and a new adaptation of John Steinbeck’s “East of Eden” by members of the Steppenwolf team who won acclaim for an earlier staging of Steinbeck’s “Grapes of Wrath.”

headline: Justice Department’s Report on the Ferguson Police Department
abstract: In a scathing report released Wednesday, the Justice Department concluded that the Ferguson Police Department had been routinely violating the constitutional rights of its black residents.
lead_paragraph: In a scathing report released Wednesday, the Justice Department concluded that the Ferguson Police Department had been routinely violating the constitutional rights of its black residents.

headline: Van Hollen to Run For Mikulski’s Senate Seat in Maryland
abstract: The race to replace retiring Senator Barbara A. Mikulski in Maryland is officially on.
lead_paragraph: The race to replace retiring Senator Barbara A. Mikulski in Maryland is officially on.

headline: At Evening Bar in TriBeCa, a Homey Feeling
abstract: The bar, tucked off the lobby of the Smyth hotel, is a tiny but inviting place that feels like a stylish friend’s studio apartment.
lead_paragraph: A new TriBeCa spot tries something different from the usual high-end hotel bars: a feeling of home. Evening Bar, tucked off the lobby of the Smyth, is a tiny but inviting place that looks like a stylish friend’s studio apartment. A handful of leathery love seats and midcentury modern chairs is scattered around a fireplace that competes with the backlit glow of the mahogany bar.

headline: Review: On USA’s ‘Dig,’ a Murder Investigation Takes an Apocalyptic Turn
abstract: The 10-part show, an American-Israeli coproduction, combines a murder mystery with an ancient-history primer.
lead_paragraph: A red calf is born in Norway, an eerie 12-year-old boy is raised in captivity in New Mexico and a young American archaeologist is murdered in Jerusalem. The connection? Too early to tell, but all signs point to the world being saved 10 weeks from now.

headline: The Forgotten Emancipation
abstract: The Enlistment Act, enacted on March 4, 1865, was one of the most revolutionary steps toward abolition during the Civil War.
lead_paragraph: March 4, 1865, is remembered as the day of Abraham Lincoln’s Second Inaugural address, but it was also a moment that has been forgotten in the long history of slave emancipation in America.

headline: Shopping Events and Sales Happening This Week in New York
abstract: A Patrik Ervell sample sale; Maison Kitsune releases a new Effortless French spring collection, for those yearning to be in Paris for Fashion Week and more shopping news.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, Dressbarn will unveil DRESSBAR, a curated collection of spring frocks available in stores and online. For the occasion, the high-street retailer will also open a New York City pop-up where you’ll find pretty numbers like a Luxe by Carmen Marc Valvo floral print fit and flare ($58). At 102 Fifth Avenue.

headline: The 20-20 Hindsight of an Instructive Deal
abstract: Teachers like Steve Conrad of Manhasset, N.Y., usually have a good eye for an instructive deal.
lead_paragraph: Steve Conrad of Manhasset, N.Y., teaches bridge on cruise ships. Teachers usually have a good eye for an instructive deal. Conrad sent one to me, modestly acknowledging that he had misplayed, immediately saw what he had done wrong and wished he could have taken a mulligan.

headline: Bank of England in Money Market Inquiry
abstract: Britain’s Serious Fraud Office, is investigating whether the Bank of England played any role in rigging money market auctions during the financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Serious Fraud Office, the British agency that investigates and prosecutes fraud and corruption, is investigating whether the Bank of England played any role in rigging money market auctions during the financial crisis in 2007 and 2008.

headline: A Pop-Up Dinner Series With an Artsy Edge
keywords: ['ARMORIES', 'ARMORY SHOW, THE INTERNATIONAL FAIR OF NEW ART (NYC)', 'Art', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Parties (Social)', 'Restaurants']
abstract: An offshoot of the events project Babël, Escena Magica hosted its second supper, which doubled as a preview of the “(un)Scene” art show, last night.
lead_paragraph: “There’s absolutely nothing about exclusivity in what we do,” explains Waël Mechri-Yver, the founder of Babël, a New York events program he created in 2013 that has collaborated with Queen of the Night, Sleep No More and the Bowery Hotel and has just launched a monthly pop-up dinner series titled Escena Magica. “What we try to cultivate is word of mouth, and there’s no barriers. We sell our tickets online. Everything is open.”

headline: Lung Cancer Treatment Using Immune System Wins F.D.A. Approval
abstract: Opdivo, from Bristol-Myers Squibb, which harnesses the body’s own immune system to attack tumors, was approved after strong results in a study.
lead_paragraph: The first immune-based treatment for lung cancer won approval from the Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday, and it could displace more conventional chemotherapy for certain patients, at least.

headline: World Press Photo Revokes Prize
keywords: ['Photography', 'News and News Media', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors']
abstract: The photography organization said Giovanni Troilo’s entry in the Contemporary Issues category failed to comply with its contest rules.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Following days of intense controversy, the jury of one of photojournalism’s top awards, the World Press Photo contest, stripped an Italian photographer of a first prize after it found that he had misrepresented the location of one of the atmospheric images.

headline: Trailer: Rendez-Vous With French Cinema
abstract: A preview of the series.
lead_paragraph: A preview of the series.

headline: Review: Erik Larson’s ‘Dead Wake,’ on the Sinking of the Lusitania
abstract: Mr. Larson, who treats nonfiction like high drama, looks at the German torpedoing of the British ocean liner, in time for the 100th anniversary.
lead_paragraph: The Lusitania is about to sink — and sink, and sink — all over again. This May is the 100th anniversary of the attack on the grand British ocean liner by a German submarine, and the expected crop of books will commemorate the occasion. But the most attention-getting of the bunch is guaranteed to be Erik Larson’s “Dead Wake,” because Mr. Larson is an old hand at treating nonfiction like high drama. As he demonstrated with “In the Garden of Beasts” and “The Devil in the White City,” he knows how to pick details that have maximum soapy potential and then churn them until they foam.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: César Winners Fill Roster at Rendez-Vous With French Cinema
abstract: This year’s Rendez-Vous With French Cinema is devoid of the comedic froufrou that used to serve as filler.
lead_paragraph: For most of its 20-year existence, the annual film series Rendez-Vous With French Cinema has promoted a vision of France as the most civilized and sophisticated country on earth, one ruled by a benign, eternal beauty, Catherine Deneuve. The very expression “rendez-vous” evokes a dream world of delicious secret liaisons in Parisian haunts.

headline: Where Howard Hughes Was Underfoot
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The 9,000-square-foot house was an impulse buy with a pool room and a past.
lead_paragraph: As a house tour enticement, “Do you want to see Howard Hughes’s vault?” is pretty irresistible. Of course you want to see Howard Hughes’s vault. Who doesn’t?

headline: AbbVie to Pay $21 Billion for Pharmacyclics, Maker of a Promising Cancer Drug
abstract: AbbVie announced that it has agreed to buy Pharmacyclics, a maker of a cancer drug that some analysts predict will eventually become one of the best-selling treatments.
lead_paragraph: AbbVie announced late Wednesday that it had agreed to buy Pharmacyclics, maker of a cancer drug that some analysts predict will eventually become one of the best-selling treatments for the disease, for about $21 billion.

headline: The Wassaic Project: A Festival, a ‘Beautiful’ Flood and Now Art
abstract: An artists’ community evolves in upstate New York.
lead_paragraph: WASSAIC, N.Y. — When Bowie Zunino is interviewing candidates for residencies at the Wassaic Project, she spends a lot of time trying to talk them out of coming.

headline: Bruce Willis to Make Broadway Debut in ‘Misery’
abstract: Mr. Willis will star as a writer imprisoned by a psychotic fan, in a stage adaptaion of Stephen King’s novel by William Goldman.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Willis will make his Broadway debut this fall as the bedridden novelist in a stage adaption of “Misery,” best known from the 1990 film thriller that starred James Caan and, in an Oscar-winning performance, Kathy Bates as the psychotic fan who holds the writer hostage.

lead_paragraph: The House committee examining the 2012 attacks on American outposts in Benghazi sent a subpoena to Hillary Rodham Clinton’s lawyer on Wednesday, requesting all emails she had in her personal account as secretary of state that relate to Libya.

abstract: Scott McGlasson uses organic materials to build heirloom furniture pieces. But is his method sustainable?
lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL — What is the value of a dining-room chair? You can’t eat it. And you can sit on the floor free, as millions (billions?) of people do.

headline: Reading The Times With David Axelrod
abstract: Mr. Axelrod, a former senior adviser to President Obama, assesses coverage of the Netanyahu speech, the House vote on homeland security funding and the Supreme Court case involving the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: Now director of the Institute of Politics at the University of Chicago, David Axelrod was senior adviser to President Obama and is the author of “Believer: My Forty Years in Politics.”

abstract: It may seem disloyal to your team, but most buyers would prefer seeing a clean, uncluttered, neutral space.

headline: As Hope Solo Returns to Field, U.S. Rallies Past Norway in World Cup Tuneup
abstract: Solo returned from a 30-day suspension but was not completely happy with her performance as the Americans opened the Algarve Cup with a 2-1 win.
lead_paragraph: VILA REAL DE SANTO ANTÓNIO, Portugal — About four minutes into Wednesday’s Algarve Cup game between the United States and Norway, a Norwegian player lofted a cross toward the area in front of the Americans’ goal.

headline: The Story That Came From a Dog
abstract: The ceramist Rae Dunn wanted to write a children’s book, but in the end, the story came from Wilma, her dog.
lead_paragraph: Over the last two decades, the ceramist Rae Dunn has attracted many admirers with her intentionally imperfect handmade pieces: pared-down tableware with subtle details, whimsical teapots, earthy vases with wobbly forms. So when she published her first book, “Wilma’s World” (Chronicle Books, $15.95), it was natural to expect that it would be about ceramics.

headline: Seeking Drugs and Weapons, Rikers Locks Down Inmates for 34 Hours
abstract: The lockdown, which confined more than half the inmates at the Rikers Island jail complex to their cells, was an effort to curb growing gang violence.
lead_paragraph: New York City correction officials this week took the unusual step of locking down more than half of the inmates at Rikers Island in their cells for 34 hours straight, as part of an effort to curb escalating gang violence.

headline: Stylish Bedside Clocks
abstract: Now that smartphones have replaced the utilitarian alarm clock, the timepiece next to your pillow can simply be attractive.
lead_paragraph: Daylight saving time begins at 2 a.m. on Sunday, and in the spirit of springing forward, the interior designer Antonino Buzzetta, 30, went looking for stylish bedside clocks.

headline: Family Wedding Forces Rubio to Skip Iowa Candidate Forum
abstract: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida withdrew from an agriculture forum in Iowa planned for Saturday, one of the largest gatherings of Republican 2016 hopefuls so far.
lead_paragraph: And then there were 10.

headline: Not a Banister Was Changed
abstract: A show at the New York School of Interior Design is dedicated to the city’s landmarked interior spaces.
lead_paragraph: Fifty years ago, the New York City Landmarks Preservation Law was enacted to ensure that important buildings survived the whims, greed or cultural indifference of developers and city officials. Among the 31,000 properties designated as landmarks, only 117 are interiors, like City Hall, left, and the New Amsterdam Theater, right. This small fraction gets special treatment in “Rescued, Restored, Reimagined: New York’s Landmark Interiors,” a show opening on Friday at the New York School of Interior Design.

headline: Sales at Love Adorned, Waggo, Ladies & Gentlemen Studio and Design Within Reach
abstract: Reduced prices on bedding, home furnishings, dishware, wind chimes, sofas, consoles and more.

headline: A Timeless Portrait of Nepal
abstract: Kevin Bubriski arrived in Nepal as a Peace Corps worker. He has returned over the decades to capture its stark landscapes and resilient people, reminders of a vanishing world.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Bubriski arrived in Nepal as a Peace Corps worker. He has returned over the decades to capture its stark landscapes and resilient people, reminders of a vanishing world.

headline: Mark Lippert, U.S. Ambassador to South Korea, Is Hospitalized After Attack
keywords: ['Assaults', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The ambassador, Mark W. Lippert, was in stable condition after the attack by a South Korean assailant protesting joint American-South Korean military exercises.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The United States ambassador to South Korea, Mark W. Lippert, was attacked Thursday morning by a knife-wielding man who said he opposed joint American-South Korean military exercises, according to the South Korean police and journalists who were at the scene.
