headline: Paying Homage to Burgundy and Michel Lafarge
abstract: The winemaker, known for his graceful and captivating Burgundys, celebrated the 65th vintage he has worked at what is now called Domaine Michel Lafarge.
lead_paragraph: It was a seemingly incongruous scene: 55 worldly gastronomes who had traveled to New York from all parts of the country rising to applaud an 86-year-old farmer at one of Manhattan’s best restaurants. Only in wine do the worlds of agriculture and conspicuous consumption collide with such joyous reverence, especially when the wine is Burgundy and the farmer is Michel Lafarge.

headline: Scott Walker’s Electoral Record Is Less Impressive Than It Looks
abstract: The Wisconsin governor’s record of winning three elections in four years in a state that often goes Democratic is much cited, but it needs a closer look.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Scott Walker is the rare conservative favorite who emphasizes electability. He won three contests in four years in Wisconsin, which hasn’t voted for the Republican candidate in a presidential election since 1984. He did so without compromising on the Republican Party’s core principles; instead, he prevailed in a high-profile fight with organized labor.

headline: Bravo, Ringling Brothers, for Taking Elephants Out of Circuses
abstract: The elephant, for more than a century a circus icon, is moving out of center ring.
lead_paragraph: Circuses can be entertaining and wonder-filled without relying on confined, prodded and abused elephants. That’s long been the argument of animal welfare campaigners and elephant-free circuses.

headline: New Publisher for German-Language Edition of Martin Amis’s ‘The Zone of Interest’
abstract: The Swiss publisher Kein & Aber has picked up Martin Amis’s concentration-camp satire after the author’s longtime German publisher rejected it.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Swiss publisher Kein & Aber has picked up Martin Amis’s concentration-camp satire, “The Zone of Interest,” months after the author’s longtime German and French publishers rejected it.

headline: Balmain’s Diamond in the Coif
abstract: For the house’s fall 2015 fashion show, the stylist Sam McKnight slicked the hair back behind one ear to reveal a single, enormous agate earring.
lead_paragraph: At Balmain’s fall 2015 fashion show, the designer Olivier Rousteing sent the house’s signature brand of no-nonsense foxiness down the runway. For the hair, the stylist Sam McKnight took cues from Lauren Hutton in “American Gigolo” and Michelle Pfeiffer in “Scarface,” but wanted to “modernize the gloss,” he says. McKnight started by ironing out any wave in the hair, squared off the edges for a blunt, clean line and then went for a deep side part. The real key, however, was to have one side slicked back and tucked behind the ear so that the single, enormous agate earring that accessorized many of the looks was properly shown off.

headline: House of Inasal
abstract: Filipino comfort food in Woodside, Queens.
lead_paragraph: Filipino comfort food in Woodside, Queens.

headline: Straight From Filipino Streets
abstract: House of Inasal delivers straightforward Filipino comfort food in a stretch of Woodside, Queens, that has earned the nickname Little Manila.
lead_paragraph: “Unlimited rice”: It is a siren call. At House of Inasal, a Filipino restaurant that opened last year in Woodside, Queens, it’s the happy surprise waiting on the first page of the menu, announced by a speech bubble cut out of kraft paper and taped in the margin.

headline: Barcelona’s Mobile World
abstract: Many of the world’s top smartphone makers — with the notable exception of Apple — converged at the Fira Gran Via complex in Barcelona this week with the aim of enticing buyers around the globe.
lead_paragraph: Many of the world’s top smartphone makers — with the notable exception of Apple — converged at the Fira Gran Via complex in Barcelona this week with the aim of enticing buyers around the globe.

headline: Peter Madoff’s Former Home Sells for $3.5 Million
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Ponzi and Pyramid Schemes']
abstract: The Long Island estate of Peter B. Madoff, the younger brother of Bernard L. Madoff, sold for several million less than its original asking price.
lead_paragraph: The Long Island estate of Peter B. Madoff, the younger brother of Bernard L. Madoff, has been sold for several million dollars less than its original asking price, after years of efforts to find a buyer.

headline: Andrew Solomon Named President of PEN American Center
abstract: Mr. Solomon will take over for departing president Peter Godwin.
lead_paragraph: The author Andrew Solomon has been elected to be president of the literary and human rights organization PEN American Center.

headline: Larger-Than-Life Advertising Imagery, Brought Down to Size
abstract: Natan Dvir’s “Coming Soon” photography series captures the collision between aspirational commercial displays and the mundanity of everyday life.
lead_paragraph: Natan Dvir’s “Coming Soon” photography series captures the collision between aspirational commercial displays and the mundanity of everyday life.

headline: South Korea Says Attacker of U.S. Ambassador, Mark Lippert, Acted Alone
keywords: ['Assaults', 'United States International Relations', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The South Korean police said on Friday that they were seeking to bring attempted murder and other criminal charges against an anti-American activist who slashed the United States ambassador to South Korea.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The South Korean police said Friday that they were seeking to bring attempted murder and other criminal charges against an anti-American activist who slashed the United States ambassador to South Korea, Mark W. Lippert, with a kitchen knife.

headline: 1977 | Home Opens Its Doors
abstract: With Home coming to an end, the report David Dunlap looked at the section’s beginnings.
lead_paragraph: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 40 years.

headline: Bertrice Small, 77, Writer of Risqué Romance Novels, Dies
abstract: Ms. Small, who was educated in a convent, was called “Lust’s Leading Lady” for her many bodice-ripping books.
lead_paragraph: Bertrice Small, a convent-educated writer whose dozens of bodice-ripping romance novels titillated readers for decades, died on Feb. 24 at her home in Southold, N.Y., leaving her 57th novel unfinished. She was 77.

headline: Chef Lineup Announced for Dan Barber’s Food Waste Pop-Up, WastED
abstract: Daniel Humm, Danny Bowien and April Bloomfield are among those who will cook at the pop-up at Blue Hill, which will serve dishes devised from food scraps.
lead_paragraph: A high-profile experiment in wasting nothing will start on March 13 at Dan Barber’s Blue Hill restaurant in Greenwich Village. That’s when the restaurant will turn into a pop-up called wastED, to run through the end of the month, with a menu of dishes devised from leftovers like stems, peelings, rinds and bones, by a roster of guest chefs who will change each evening.

headline: Last Known Ebola Patient in Liberia Is Discharged
abstract: Beatrice Yardolo lost two sons and a daughter to the disease, but she gave thanks to God as she returned home to the rest of her family.
lead_paragraph: Liberia’s last Ebola patient was discharged on Thursday after a ceremony in the capital, Monrovia, bringing to zero the number of known cases in the country and marking a milestone in West Africa’s battle against the disease.

headline: Boehner Sticks to Foreign Policy, Pressing to Arm Ukraine
abstract: Facing dissension from his party over funding the Department of Homeland Security, Speaker John A. Boehner deepened his focus on foreign policy on Thursday by urging President Obama to arm Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Days after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel spoke before Congress at his invitation, Speaker John A. Boehner deepened his focus on foreign policy on Thursday by urging President Obama to arm the Ukrainian military.

headline: Explicit Artwork on Display in London, but Not for Everyone
abstract: Jake and Dinos Chapman’s sexually explicit artwork “Bring Me the Head Of …” can be viewed only through a peephole.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Jake and Dinos Chapman’s sexually explicit artwork “Bring Me the Head Of …” — a video, played on loop, of a 10-minute lesbian sex scene — was banned by the police when it was first displayed at the Ridinghouse Editions gallery here in 1995.

headline: The Red Carpet, Fashion's 5th City
abstract: When celebrities wear designer outfits for events like the Oscars, the publicity can exceed anything advertising or marketing could do.
lead_paragraph: Fashion month marches into its homestretch. And yet, despite the recreating of Diana Vreeland’s apartment at Marc Jacobs in New York, a waterfall at Hunter in London and a giant boom box at Moschino in Milan, it’s hard not to think the most headline-grabbing show of the season may have already happened in a town not generally known for its ready-to-wear cred.

headline: After Menopause, Female Killer Whales Take Lead in Finding Food
abstract: Postmenopausal killer whales were more likely to take the lead on the hunt than male whales, especially in times of scarcity, researchers found.
lead_paragraph: Despite no longer reproducing, postmenopausal female whales play a crucial role in the survival of killer whales, researchers have found. With extensive knowledge of their environment, female whales in their 70s and 80s lead younger whales to food in times of scarcity.

headline: LVMH Celebrates Its Designer Search
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Paris Fashion Week', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors']
abstract: Celebrities, designers and competitors gather at a cocktail party for semifinalists in the LVMH Young Fashion Designer Prize, now seeking its second winner.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — “Is this the god of London?” Kanye West exclaimed to the English designer Craig Green before hopping into Mr. Green’s booth and gamely strapping into one of his armor-like, tunic-cum-breastplate designs.

headline: In Paris, Affairs à La Mode
abstract: Collections like those from Olivier Rousteing at Balmain and Alessandro Dell'Acqua at Rochas proved the subject is still romance.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The thousands of cadenas d’amour, or love locks, attached to the Pont des Arts are hidden by graffiti-covered hoarding these days, there to discourage anyone from adding to the wishes that are endangering the bridge, but along the sides the locks poke out, impossible to contain. It’s not that dissimilar from the situation on the runways.

headline: Julien Dossena on His 10 Most Prized Possessions
abstract: The Paco Rabanne creative director, who showed his fall/winter 2015 collection at Paris Fashion Week today, shares with T his photographs and words about his favorite things at home.
lead_paragraph: In just a few seasons, Julien Dossena has made Paco Rabanne new again. The young Frenchman, who spent several years toiling under Nicolas Ghesquière at Balenciaga before his appointment, has created a high-tech, athletic-inflected style that’s true to the house’s space-age spirit yet free of mod clichés. (Even the brand’s signature material, chain mail, looks new — and feels light — under his direction.)

headline: Out There | Einstein’s Telescope
keywords: ['Space and Astronomy', 'Stars and Galaxies', 'Hubble Space Telescope', 'Gravitation and Gravity']
abstract: From 2015: A century after Albert Einstein proposed that gravity could bend light, astronomers now rely on galaxies or even clusters of galaxies to magnify distant stars.
lead_paragraph: From 2015: A century after Albert Einstein proposed that gravity could bend light, astronomers now rely on galaxies or even clusters of galaxies to magnify distant stars.

headline: Astronomers Watch a Supernova and See Reruns
keywords: ['Stars and Galaxies', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Hubble Space Telescope', 'Dark Matter (Astronomy)']
abstract: Astronomers have been watching the same star explode over and over again, thanks to a trick of Einsteinian optics, which may help them better understand mysteries like dark matter.
lead_paragraph: It’s “Groundhog Day” in the cosmos.

headline: Patricia Arquette and Mary J. Blige Starring in Films Added to Tribeca Festival Lineup
abstract: The spotlight section features 24 world premieres.
lead_paragraph: New films featuring Patricia Arquette, Oscar Isaac, Jessica Biel and Matthew Broderick will screen in the Spotlight section of the Tribeca Film Festival, organizers announced Thursday.

headline: Ancient Mars Had an Ocean, Scientists Say
abstract: If confirmed, the findings would lend new weight to the view that ancient Mars had everything needed for life to emerge.
lead_paragraph: After six years of planetary observations, scientists at NASA say they have found convincing new evidence that ancient Mars had an ocean.

headline: Iowa Radio Host’s Call to Abandon G.O.P. Falls on Deaf Ears
abstract: In Iowa, the power of deeply conservative talk-radio hosts on the powerhouse station WHO-AM is fabled. A drive-time host in 2008 who relentlessly criticized Mitt Romney was partly credited with his poor caucus showing.
lead_paragraph: In Iowa, the power of deeply conservative talk radio hosts on the powerhouse station WHO-AM is fabled. A drive-time host in 2008 who relentlessly criticized Mitt Romney was partly credited with his poor caucus showing.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
abstract: In the news: blood letting, attention deficit and sleep risks. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: In the news: blood letting, attention deficit and sleep risks. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: In Germany, an Ugly Past Rears Its Head
keywords: ['ANTI-SEMITISM', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: While Europe's leaders wrestle with the challenges of a tortured present, Germany seems hauled back to its history, as if condemned never to overcome it.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The past lurks here like a tripwire.

headline: El Niño Forms, but Forecasters See Little Weather Impact
abstract: The weather pattern over the Pacific had been expected, but it is described as so weak that it is not likely to bring much-needed rain to California.
lead_paragraph: Federal government scientists say that a long-anticipated El Niño weather pattern formed in the Pacific Ocean last month, but that it will most likely have little significant impact worldwide.

headline: Gerhard Richter, Damon Albarn and Björk Among Highlights of Manchester International Festival
abstract: Mr. Richter and the composer Arvo Pärt will exhibit work inspired by and dedicated to each other at the fifth festival.
lead_paragraph: Gerhard Richter, Arvo Pärt, Björk, Douglas Gordon, Charlotte Rampling and Damon Albarn are among the artists participating in this year’s Manchester International Festival, which announced its schedule on Thursday.

headline: Indians Find Ways to See Rape Documentary Despite Ban
abstract: The Indian government tried to suppress a BBC documentary about a 2012 gang rape, but those efforts only increased interest in the film.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A British-made documentary about a grisly gang rape in India spread throughout social media on Thursday, thwarting official efforts to block it and gaining a wide audience despite a government ban.

headline: Rick Owens: Fall 2015 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Google Introduces Long-Anticipated Insurance Shopping Site
keywords: ['Automobile Insurance and Liability', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: The Google Compare auto insurance shopping site could rattle the insurance industry and change how individual brokers do business.
lead_paragraph: The United States insurance industry has been anticipating — or dreading — Google’s entry into insurance shopping for the better part of a year. The wait is over.

headline: Björk, a One-of-a-Kind Artist, Proves Elusive at MoMA
abstract: The music videos of this Icelandic musician are the heart of the MoMA retrospective, compared to which everything else seems slightly undeveloped.
lead_paragraph: The prodigious Icelandic musical phenomenon Björk is the most avant-garde popular artist of her time, the creative force behind extraordinary music videos and also one of the most instinctive of talents. So she probably should have trusted her first response — No thanks — when the Museum of Modern Art came calling.

headline: Sacred Space
abstract: The photographer Massimo Vitali lives with his wife and son in Lucca, Italy, in a 14th-century church that lay empty for 17 years.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Massimo Vitali lives with his wife and son in Lucca, Italy, in a 14th-century church that lay empty for 17 years.

headline: Egypt Replaces Minister Who Helped Quell Dissent
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Foreign Investments']
abstract: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi removed the interior minister, Mohamed Ibrahim, in a cabinet shake-up ahead of a meeting of foreign investors in Egypt.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt’s interior minister, who played a central role in the military-backed government’s far-reaching and ruthless crackdown on political dissent, was removed from his post on Thursday in a cabinet shake-up announced by the president’s office.

headline: Attacks Cripple 11 Oil Fields, Libya Says
abstract: The Libyan National Oil Company declared the oil fields nonoperational because of “theft, looting, sabotage and destruction” by “unidentified armed groups.”
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The Libyan national oil company declared 11 oil fields nonoperational because of “theft, looting, sabotage and destruction” by “unidentified armed groups,” the company said in a statement late Wednesday.

headline: Christie Administration Officials Praise Deal With Exxon
abstract: The New Jersey governor’s office, heavily criticized for accepting a settlement for environmental damages that was called too low, released details of the deal for the first time Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The administration of Gov. Chris Christie offered details for the first time on Thursday about its settlement of a legal battle with Exxon Mobil Corporation over contamination in which the company agreed to pay a fraction of the damages that the State of New Jersey had sought.

headline: Fastest Star in the Galaxy Got an Unusual Start
abstract: Scientists say US 708— thought to be the fastest unbound star in the galaxy — was set in motion not by the black hole at the center of our galaxy, but by a former companion.
lead_paragraph: Hurtling through the galaxy at about 1,200 kilometers per second is a compact helium star with an unusual origin. Unlike most high-velocity stars, scientists say this one — thought to be the fastest unbound star in the galaxy — was set in motion not by the black hole at the center of our galaxy, but by a former companion.

headline: Heavy Politics
abstract: BMI and the GOP.
lead_paragraph: A few days ago Bloomberg had a great story about the politicization of pizza — which is part of the broader pattern in which nutrition and obesity have become deeply partisan. Big Pizza is now an industry as dedicated to the GOP as coal or tobacco.

headline: The Ferguson Nightmare
abstract: Racism tainted virtually every decision local government made.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department report on the bigoted law enforcement practices used in Ferguson, Mo. illustrates two things very clearly. First, that racism tainted virtually every decision local government made. Second, the city’s decision to raise significant revenue through fines transformed both the police department and the courts into instruments of white supremacy and economic repression. These excerpts give a sense of the nightmarish conditions under which black citizens of Ferguson and nearby St. Louis County municipalities have lived as a result.

headline: Eaton Vance Charts Exchange-Traded Future
abstract: The fund company is seeking to marry the best features of active and passive investing and holding it up as a model for others.
lead_paragraph: Thomas E. Faust Jr. does not come across as an industry disrupter. He is the chief executive of Eaton Vance, a midsize fund company in Boston that has carved out a solid yet unspectacular niche as a provider of investment funds and advice.

headline: De Blasio and Developer Are Close, but Not on Lower-Cost Housing
abstract: Rob Speyer’s company is rushing to qualify for a tax break on a big residential complex in Queens without a key part of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s agenda: affordable units.
lead_paragraph: Unlike many of his more wary real estate brethren, Rob Speyer moved quickly to build a strong relationship with New York’s liberal mayor, Bill de Blasio, after his election in 2013.

headline: Glacier to Yellowstone on a Bike
keywords: ['Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Glaciers', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: The Cycling House in Missoula, Mont., has a new seven-day trip from Glacier National Park to Yellowstone.
lead_paragraph: Cycling from Glacier National Park to Yellowstone might seem like an intense endeavor, but to guides at the Cycling House in Missoula, Mont., “it’s just a chance to take off work, see some beautiful scenery and get to know people,” Shaun Radley, the company’s director of operations, said of its new summer excursion.

headline: Big Donors Are Asked to Encourage a ‘Civil’ G.O.P. Primary
abstract: Foster Friess, the businessman who helped finance groups supporting Rick Santorum’s 2012 presidential campaign, is asking his fellow multimillionaire donors to press the Republican field to be “civil” during the party’s primary in 2016.
lead_paragraph: Foster Friess, the businessman who helped finance Rick Santorum’s 2012 presidential campaign through large donations to the outside group supporting his candidacy, is asking his fellow multimillionaire donors to press the Republican field to be “civil” during the party’s primary in 2016.

headline: Live Chat About Finding That ‘Sweet Spot’ in Life and Work
abstract: Join me and “The Sweet Spot” author Christine Carter for a live chat about finding your groove at home and work on Friday, March 6, 2015 from 1:00-2:00 Eastern.
lead_paragraph: Join me and “The Sweet Spot” author Christine Carter for a live chat about finding your groove at home and work. Christine coached three readers with three very specific problems: finding more time to exercise, ending an email obsession, and focusing on work in a home office where distractions are just a kitchen away.

headline: ‘House of Cards’ Season 3, Episode 11 Recap: Every Seven Years
abstract: As we approach the end of this season — only two more episodes left after this one — the old Frank and Claire are coming back to life.
lead_paragraph: Season 3, Episode 11: Chapter 37

headline: Cardinal Edward M. Egan, 82, Dies; Led New York Archdiocese in Trying Time
abstract: Cardinal Egan was a stern defender of Roman Catholic orthodoxy who presided over the New York archdiocese for nine years.
lead_paragraph: Cardinal Edward M. Egan, a stern defender of Roman Catholic orthodoxy who presided over the Archdiocese of New York for nine years in an era of troubled finances, changing demographics and an aging, dwindling priesthood shaken by sexual-abuse scandals, died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 82.

headline: Broncos’ Peyton Manning to Play in 2015
abstract: Manning, who turns 39 this month and has battled injuries, faded in the last quarter of the 2014 season and did not deny that he was considering retirement.
lead_paragraph: Quarterback Peyton Manning, a perennial Pro Bowl selection and a sure shot for the Pro Football Hall of Fame, will return for the 2015 season after he reworked his contract with the Denver Broncos.

headline: Success Runs Deeper Than All the 3-Pointers
abstract: The Florida Gulf Coast University women’s basketball team, which is averaging 9.6 made 3-point attempts a game, is 27-2 — 209-45 since joining Division I in 2007.
lead_paragraph: FORT MYERS, Fla. — About an hour before the start of an afternoon practice last week, Kaneisha Atwater shot dozens of 3-pointers as a wall-mounted computer called the Noah Instant calculated the trajectory of each attempt.

headline: Why AbbVie May Have Overpaid for Cancer Drug Maker
abstract: With a $21 billion deal, the pharmaceutical giant gets a blockbuster drug, but at a high cost: It must share profits with rival Johnson & Johnson.
lead_paragraph: AbbVie’s chief executive may have overpaid once again.

headline: Letters: ‘Chasing the Scream’
abstract: Readers respond to recent reviews of Johann Hari’s “Chasing the Scream,” Anya Kamenetz’s “The Test” and more.
lead_paragraph: ‘Chasing the Scream’

headline: California Senate Race Gets a Republican Contender
abstract: California now has a Republican contender for its soon-to-be open senate seat: Rocky Chávez, a state assemblyman.
lead_paragraph: California now has a Republican contender for its soon-to-be open Senate seat.

headline: J. Crew’s New, Very French Stripes — and Address
abstract: Tomorrow, the retailer opens the doors its first Paris boutique with an exclusive capsule collection created in collaboration with Saint James.
lead_paragraph: Come tomorrow, J. Crew will be the new American in Paris when it opens its first shop in the Marais, the brand’s second location in Europe apart from its four London posts. The 1,800-square-foot space, housed inside a restored storefront made of lacquered brass, antique oak and marble, will be dedicated to the women’s collection (a men’s boutique is set to debut in the City of Light later this year). In celebration, the design team has partnered with Saint James, famous for its Parisian chic sailor stripes, on a 33-piece collection of one-of-a-kind tees exclusive to the new address (€85 – €250). “We thought about Brigitte Bardot, baguettes and berets,” the creative director Jenna Lyons explains about the tops. She sums them up as being “unique and a bit bonkers.”

headline: Guest Post | Analyzing the Elements of Art: Six Ways to Think About Shape
abstract: a collaboration with KQED Art School to explore one of the seven elements of visual art — shape — and suggest ways to apply the ideas to images and articles found in The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: March is National Youth Arts Month, and we’re collaborating with KQED Art School to explore one of the seven elements of visual art — shape — and suggest ways to apply the ideas to images and articles found in The New York Times.

headline: A Wink at the Quirks of a Famed Collector
abstract: The Barnes Foundation is asking three installation artists to play off Albert Barnes’s idiosyncratic method of installing art.
lead_paragraph: Now that the Barnes Foundation has weathered its move from Albert Barnes’s home in suburban Merion, Pa., to downtown Philadelphia in 2012, it seems newly game to look at itself with a bit of irreverence.

headline: Nasdaq Changed in Its Climb to 5,000
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Nasdaq Composite Index', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Unlike the Nasdaq composite index at its dot-com peak in 2000, today’s index has companies that are more mature and less concentrated in technology.
lead_paragraph: That the Nasdaq composite index closed over 5,000 this week for the first time in 15 years is not just a reminder of the virtues of patience. It’s even more a testament to the transformative power of capitalism.

headline: States Weigh Legislation to Let Businesses Refuse to Serve Gay Couples
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'States (US)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Discrimination', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: With conservatives anxious that the Supreme Court will legalize same-sex marriage nationwide, states are taking up bills that would allow businesses to opt out of serving gay couples.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — As it looks increasingly likely that the Supreme Court will establish a nationwide right to same-sex marriage later this year, state legislatures across the country are taking up bills that would make it easier for businesses and individuals to opt out of serving gay couples on religious grounds.

headline: Review: ‘The Last Flight of Poxl West’ by Daniel Torday
abstract: This new novel finds a teenager enthralled by an uncle who has written a memoir that may or may not be false.
lead_paragraph: In summary, the plot of Daniel Torday’s evocative first novel, “The Last Flight of Poxl West,” may sound a little schematic. A 15-year-old boy named Eli worships his uncle Poxl, who writes a well-received memoir about his heroic exploits as a bomber pilot during World War II. But in the wake of the book’s success, Eli discovers that Poxl is not exactly who he has pretended to be.

headline: McDonald’s Asks a Band to Play for Free Food, but No Money at SXSW
keywords: ['Music', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: A Brooklyn band criticized McDonald’s for not paying performers for an event at this year’s South by Southwest music festival.
lead_paragraph: With each passing year, raging against the invasion of brands at the South by Southwest music festival feels more futile. Once known as a pre-Internet launching pad for emerging independent musicians, the industry bacchanal in Austin, Tex., taking place this year from March 17 to 22, has grown into a sometimes uncomfortable hodgepodge of acts still striving to make it big and more established stars performing amid an onslaught of hashtags, according to some veteran observers.

headline: ISIS Is Adept on Twitter, Study Finds
abstract: While Twitter has suspended many users linked to the Islamic State, a study says at least 46,000 accounts publicize the group’s message of death.
lead_paragraph: The Islamic State, the violent extremist group that espouses a return to a seventh-century caliphate, has been astonishingly successful at spreading its message using 21st-century social media, according to a study released Thursday.

headline: A Different Kind of Protest in Washington
abstract: Many used Thursday’s snowstorm to hold a “Sled-In,” openly defying a ban on sledding on Capitol Hill grounds.
lead_paragraph: Many used Thursday’s snowstorm to hold a “Sled-In,” openly defying a ban on sledding on Capitol Hill grounds.

headline: In Ellen Pao’s Suit vs. Kleiner Perkins, World of Venture Capital Is Under Microscope
abstract: What is really under examination in this trial is the question of why there are so few women in leadership positions in Silicon Valley.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Speak up — but don’t talk too much. Light up the room — but don’t overshadow others. Be confident and critical — but not cocky or negative.

headline: Review: ‘Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt’ Features a Midwestern Fish Out of Water
abstract: Created by Tina Fey and Robert Carlock, this sitcom on Netflix sends a woman who’s been captive in a bunker in Indiana for 15 years to New York City.
lead_paragraph: There was a time when just being from the Midwest was funny. That was the joke of “Wonderful Town,” the 1953 musical about two sisters from Columbus, Ohio, who move into a basement apartment in Greenwich Village with eccentric neighbors and a kooky landlord. (“Why, oh why, oh why, oh — why did I ever leave Ohio?”)

headline: First Draft Focus: Civil Disobedience, by Sledding
abstract: Many used Thursday’s snowstorm to hold a “Sled-In,” openly defying a ban on sledding on Capitol Hill grounds.

headline: Events at the Brooklyn Museum and the United Palace Theater
abstract: Target First Saturdays at the museum and a screening of Hitchcock’s “Rear Window” at the theater are two events welcoming visitors this weekend.
lead_paragraph: In a city like New York, having countless entertainment options to choose from on a Saturday night can lead to paralyzing indecision and the strange feeling that there’s nothing to do.

headline: Young Designers Revive Sweater Dresses on the Runway
abstract: Thomas Tait, Marques’Almeida and Ann Demeulemeester upgraded the lazy-day staple to cool, covetable status.
lead_paragraph: Ah, the sweater dress: an easy piece to dress up or down, and a year-round, lazy-day staple. But thanks to this season’s new ribbed knit dresses, updated by a trio of cool, new, young designers, the garment will become less of a throw-on-and-go piece and more of an I-have-arrived look by fall. In London, Thomas Tait and the design duo at Marques’Almeida both introduced dresses in bright, poppy colors and asymmetrical silhouettes. And today in Paris, Sébastien Meunier presented a darker version on the Ann Demeulemeester runway. Each drapes the body for a cozy yet sophisticated feel — even when matched with a pair of chunky white sneakers.

headline: Florida Gulf Coast Women Aim High
abstract: Images from a day with the women’s basketball team at Florida Gulf Coast University, which is 27-2 and ranked No. 20 entering the quarterfinals on Friday of the Atlantic Sun Conference tournament.
lead_paragraph: Images from a day with the women’s basketball team at Florida Gulf Coast University, which is 27-2 and ranked No. 20 entering the quarterfinals on Friday of the Atlantic Sun Conference tournament.

headline: Art of Internment Camps Will Head to Auction
abstract: Rago auction house in Lambertville, N.J., will offer about 450 artifacts made by Japanese-Americans during World War II while they were living at internment camps.
lead_paragraph: ART OF INTERNMENT CAMPS

headline: A Giant Picture of Snow Across the United States
abstract: These composite satellite images compare snow cover in February from 2013 to 2015.
lead_paragraph: These composite satellite images compare snow cover in February from 2013 to 2015.

headline: McConnell Changes Course on Iran Vote
abstract: Senator Mitch McConnell, the Republican majority leader, changed course Thursday and opted against pushing ahead with a bipartisan Iran bill in the face of opposition from Democrats.
lead_paragraph: Senator Mitch McConnell, the Republican majority leader, changed course Thursday in the face of opposition from Democrats and opted against pushing ahead with a bipartisan bill that would give Congress the authority to review any nuclear deal with Iran.

headline: A Year After Flight 370’s Disappearance, Grief and Anger Endure
abstract: Families of the Chinese passengers on Flight 370 described the pain of holidays without their loved ones, their frustration at the lack of answers and their anger over their treatment by the Malaysian authorities and the airline.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a year ago, on March 8, Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 left Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, for Beijing. The Boeing 777 was due to arrive with 239 crew members and passengers, among them more than 150 Chinese citizens. About 40 minutes after takeoff, contact between the aircraft and air traffic controllers ceased. Hundreds of relatives of the Chinese passengers traveled to Beijing and waited for weeks in a hotel for news of their loved ones.

headline: How Not to Be ‘That’ Sports Parent
abstract: If your child can tell you’re unhappy during the game, you’re doing it wrong.
lead_paragraph: There really is a right way and a wrong way to watch a child’s sporting events. Whether it’s soccer, hockey, baseball or dressage, the best parent-spectator is the one whose biggest concern is his child. Not whether his child’s team wins. Not his child’s performance on the ice or the field. Not his child’s playing time, his child’s penalties, his child’s coaches or his child’s teammates. Just the child. The one out there playing a game and (one hopes) having fun.

headline: Court Upholds Right of Reporter to Publish Excerpts From Diary of James Brown’s Wife
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Wills and Estates']
abstract: South Carolina’s Supreme Court, ruling in a case tied to the debate over the distribution of the singer James Brown’s estate, has upheld the right of a reporter to publish excerpts from the diary of Mr. Brown’s wife.
lead_paragraph: In a freedom of speech case, South Carolina’s Supreme Court ruled Wednesday that Sue Summer, a reporter for The Newberry Observer, could publish the diary of a woman recently recognized as the wife of the singer James Brown. Ms. Summer had published excerpts from the diary as part of her coverage of the continuing dispute over the distribution of Mr. Brown’s estate.

headline: Mail Trucks of the Past
abstract: A look back at postal vehicles of the last 120 years.
lead_paragraph: A look back at postal vehicles of the last 120 years.

headline: Review: ‘Ennion,’ at the Met, Profiles an Ancient Glassmaker
abstract: This small exhibition features mold-blown cups, beakers and other pieces made about 2,000 years ago.
lead_paragraph: If the name Ennion is familiar to you, you probably are a scholar or collector of ancient glassware, and you’ll appreciate the significance of “Ennion: Master of Roman Glass,” a small exhibition of ancient glassware at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. But you don’t have to be a specialist to profit from this lovely and informative show.

headline: To Explain Missing Malaysia Airlines Flight, ‘Rogue Pilot’ Seems Likeliest Theory
keywords: ['Malaysia Airlines Flight 370', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Pilots']
abstract: The former chief pilot for Malaysia Airlines said he is convinced that human intervention was to blame for the disappearance of the plane, but he said he had no reason to believe the captain did it.
lead_paragraph: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — The retired chief pilot of Malaysia Airlines is torn between logic and loyalty to an old friend. Nik Huzlan, 56, was one of the first captains to fly the 12-year-old Boeing 777 that disappeared over the Indian Ocean a year ago this Sunday. He has known the pilot who flew the plane that day, Zaharie Ahmad Shah, for decades.

headline: Organic Ice Cream for Tongue-in-Cheek Types
abstract: Two new pints being introduced this week by Three Twins are winking, organic homages to beloved Ben & Jerry’s flavors.
lead_paragraph: If the two new flavors being introduced by Three Twins Ice Cream this week, in honor of its 10th anniversary, sound a little familiar, it’s with good reason: “We’ve heard these flavors remind some people of those two guys up in Vermont,” the brand’s founder, Neal Gottlieb, says slyly. Banana Nut Confetti and Cherry Chocolate Chunk were designed as winking homages to Ben & Jerry’s beloved Chunky Monkey and Cherry Garcia, respectively — but with the distinction of being fully organic, which Ben & Jerry’s is not. Even the packaging is in on the joke: “We’re not monkeying around with this combination of banana, walnuts and chocolate,” declares the Banana Nut Confetti pint, while Cherry Chocolate Chunk insists, “You’ll be grateful that this sumptuous combination is available in organic.” Both ice creams are smooth, rich and fruit-driven, a fitting tribute to — dare we say improvement upon? — their inspiration.

headline: Fed's Stress Test of Big Banks: Part One
abstract: The nation’s largest banks have adequate capital to withstand a severe economic downturn and market turmoil, the Fed has found in its latest annual stress test.
lead_paragraph: The nation’s largest banks have adequate capital to withstand a severe economic downturn and market turmoil, the Fed has found in its latest annual stress test.

headline: Search at Sea for Flight 370 Yields Optimism Amid Disappointment
keywords: ['Malaysia Airlines Flight 370', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters']
abstract: Although it has been almost a year since the Malaysia Airlines jet disappeared, the search director says he is confident the debris will be found.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Despite months of disappointment, toughing out seas lashed by cyclonic winds and thousands of hours of searching for debris thought to be on a seabed almost three miles deep, Paul Kennedy is determined.

headline: Big Banks Pass Muster in Latest Stress Tests
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: All 31 institutions are found to have enough financial strength to survive a severe downturn in the United States economy.
lead_paragraph: The nation’s largest banks appear to have the financial strength to survive a nightmarish world where unemployment soars, house prices plummet and Wall Street crashes, the Federal Reserve said on Thursday.

headline: Jonas Kaufmann Withdraws From Second Met Performance
abstract: The tenor has withdrawn from Saturday’s matinee of “Carmen” at the Metropolitan Opera, citing illness.
lead_paragraph: The star tenor Jonas Kaufmann has withdrawn from Saturday’s sold-out matinee performance of “Carmen” at the Metropolitan Opera, citing illness — meaning that Mr. Kaufmann, who was scheduled to sing only two performances there this season, will miss both.

headline: ISIS Attacks Nimrud, a Major Archaeological Site in Iraq
keywords: ['ARCHAEOLOGY', 'Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Terrorism', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: The Iraqi site, one of the world’s most important archaeological operations, is a source of priceless antiquities from the Assyrian empire.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The Islamic State militant group attacked the ancient archaeological site of Nimrud in northern Iraq and damaged it with heavy vehicles, Iraq’s Ministry of Tourism and Antiquities said Thursday.

headline: Yulia P Transforms at Rick Owens
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall 2015 Fashion Week in Paris.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall 2015 Fashion Week in Paris. Here, the model Yulia P before (left) and after (right) makeup by Lucia Pieroni and hair by Luigi Murenu.

headline: Jeff Koons: ‘Jim Beam — J. B. Turner Engine and Six Individual Cars’
abstract: This beautiful time capsule of a show recalls a Koons exhibition from 1986.
lead_paragraph: In 1986, Jeff Koons produced “Luxury and Degradation,” an exhibition at International With Monument Gallery in the East Village. It featured reproductions of ads for alcoholic beverages and cast stainless-steel copies of novelty liquor decanters made by Jim Beam. Among these was a set of seven model railroad cars on a single track. Within each car was a fifth of Jim Beam whiskey with a tax-stamped top.

keywords: ['Snow and Snowstorms', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters']

lead_paragraph: A passenger on the Delta Air Lines flight that skidded off the runway at La Guardia Airport described the scene and an official from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey gave a statement.

headline: Frank Talk on Race
abstract: Answers to questions on race, birthday-party etiquette and appreciating veterinary workers.
lead_paragraph: I am an experienced public relations consultant in business for myself. Usually I am hired sight unseen after clients review my portfolio, speak with me on the telephone and check my references. But occasionally, after positive conversations, would-be clients ask to meet me in person. When they discover I am black, I almost never get the work. How can I avoid wasting my time with these meetings and alert people in advance about my race? I send my LinkedIn profile, but they rarely look at it. (And for the record, people find me affable and attractive.)

headline: Reveling in a Role
abstract: As the number of remaining regular-season games dwindles, ushers reflect on their experiences at Nassau Coliseum, where their jobs often felt more like a family reunion than work.
lead_paragraph: As the number of remaining regular-season games dwindles, ushers reflect on their experiences at Nassau Coliseum, where their jobs often felt more like a family reunion than work.

headline: A Long Island Goodbye
abstract: The ushers at Nassau Coliseum are institutions at the arena, which is the home rink of the Islanders until next season.
lead_paragraph: The ushers at Nassau Coliseum are institutions at the arena, which is the home rink of the Islanders until next season.

headline: Review: Handel’s ‘Semele’ Comes With Sumo Wrestlers at BAM
abstract: The Chinese artist Zhang Huan’s production of Handel’s “Semele” has playful, colorful staging saturated with Buddhist imagery.
lead_paragraph: Knowing nothing about opera should disqualify a director from being invited to stage one. At least you would think so. Yet many companies boast of recruiting neophyte directors as a way to shake up the art form. Alas, a lot of trendy, clueless productions have resulted.

headline: Joan Waltemath: ‘One does not negate the other’
abstract: The total effect of Ms. Waltemath’s show is pleasing, surprising and structurally very sound.
lead_paragraph: Painting and architecture used to be much closer, such that at least during the Renaissance artists sometimes practiced both. Joan Waltemath is a painter, although she taught at the architecture school at Cooper Union for many years, but her works are planned and constructed almost like buildings.

headline: ‘Once Upon a Time and Now’
abstract: This exhibition links art from the past with work from today’s young artists.
lead_paragraph: In 1989, when AIDS and the culture wars were slamming the art world, the Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender Community Center in New York mounted a big morale-boosting group exhibition on the 20th anniversary of the Stonewall riots. Of the 50 pieces — half by men, half by women, gay and not — in that show, a few were site-specific murals and remain visible, even as the interior has changed. A current show, “Once Upon a Time and Now,” highlights and adds to them.

headline: Claudia Comte: ‘No Melon No Lemon’
abstract: This Berlin-based artist’s American debut features a sculptural-architectural ensemble displayed on and against striped pedestals and walls.
lead_paragraph: Since opening in 2008, the Gladstone Gallery’s space on West 21st Street has emphasized large sculptures or environmental installations. In December, for example, the painter R. H. Quaytman put abstract painting and architecture on a collision course with challenging, if decidedly confused, awkward results. Now the Swiss-born, Berlin-based artist Claudia Comte makes her American debut with roughly the opposite: a sculptural-architectural ensemble resembling a designer boutique, home furnishings store or art fair stand. This totality makes a delightful first impression, but its sources and references are startlingly obvious.

headline: U.S. Auction Suggests Lingering Interest in Bitcoin
abstract: The United States Marshals Service said that 14 bidders took part in an auction on Thursday for 50,000 Bitcoins, worth around $14 million.
lead_paragraph: The falling price of Bitcoin has not entirely quashed investor enthusiasm for the virtual currency.

headline: Pablo Helguera: ‘Strange Oasis’
abstract: You might not even know this was a social practice-type show, except that Mr. Helguera is well known in the field.
lead_paragraph: Social practice, a recent term developed to describe art projects often staged in distinct communities and concerned with social justice issues, is hard to translate into a gallery in Chelsea. You might not even know this was a social practice-type show, except that Pablo Helguera, who also works in the education department at the Museum of Modern Art (museum education departments are hotbeds of social practice activity), is well known in the field.

headline: Lanvinrtw: Fall 2015 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Review: Sara Baras in a Flamenco Whirlwind
abstract: Sara Baras pays tributes to six of the greats of her art form in her program “Voces, Suite Flamenca.”
lead_paragraph: In “Voces, Suite Flamenca,” the Spanish flamenco star Sara Baras pays tribute to six luminaries of her art who have influenced her. Their likenesses appear on mobile flats that suggest monumental headstones. Their voices can be heard in recordings, expounding in Spanish on the meaning of flamenco. Live singers and guitarists add resonant voices of their own. That most of the show rings hollow is the fault of Ms. Baras.

headline: 11 Little-Known Facts About John Galliano and Alexander McQueen
abstract: Shocking and endearing anecdotes culled from Dana Thomas’s new book, “Gods and Kings,” about the rise and fall of the fashion designers.
lead_paragraph: Shocking and endearing anecdotes culled from Dana Thomas’s new book, “Gods and Kings,” about the rise and fall of the fashion designers.

headline: Thomas Struth’s Entanglement
abstract: On the operating table and what comes after.
lead_paragraph: The German photographer Thomas Struth, who was recently the subject of an exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, seems to work at the descriptive limits of photography. His eye is meticulous, and each of his images contains a tremendous amount of information. He is perhaps best known for his large-format photographs of people in art museums. Those photographs thrill the eye with double vision: We are looking at people who are looking at something. In fact, it gets more reflexive than that: We are generally looking at these pictures in a museum, and the images are usually of people who are themselves looking at something in a museum.

lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Independent and other art fairs in New York.

abstract: T shares the best hairstyles from the runways. Today’s pick: a characteristically avant-garde look for the designer’s models.
lead_paragraph: T shares the best hairstyles from the runways.

headline: Madonna on ‘Rebel Heart,’ Her Fall and More
abstract: Madonna was contemplative in an interview ahead of the release of her latest album, “Rebel Heart.”
lead_paragraph: Madonna was perfectly turned out and running nearly an hour late for an interview at her Upper East Side home on Wednesday evening. She looked tense as she apologized. “I’m late for everything now,” she said.

headline: Review: ‘The Art Show’ at the Park Avenue Armory Covers the Creative Map
abstract: The annual fair of the Art Dealers Association of America is showing 39 single-artist and 33 theme exhibitions at the Park Avenue Armory.
lead_paragraph: What you see on entering “The Art Show,” the annual fair of the Art Dealers Association of America, is yourself and other visitors reflected in a giant mirror. Displayed in Luhring Augustine’s booth, “Cords,” by the veteran Italian conceptualist Michelangelo Pistoletto, consists of four mirrored panels with a cutout, photographic rendering of stanchions connected by fat ropes. The ropes evoke the atmosphere of exclusivity fostered by high-end galleries like the 72 convened here. On the other hand, the mirror inclusively reflects viewers themselves and, by extension, the broader public they belong to. In art, the public might find reflections of itself and its own, ever-evolving cultural identity.

headline: Review: The 2015 Armory Show Overlaps History and Cultures
keywords: ['Art', 'ARMORY SHOW, THE INTERNATIONAL FAIR OF NEW ART (NYC)']
abstract: Some 200 galleries from 28 countries are participating in New York’s largest art show, at Piers 92 and 94.
lead_paragraph: Now in its second decade, the Armory Show — which in 1999 itself appropriated the name from the historic 1913 Armory Show — is far past its mythic origins of 1994, when the fair opened in the Gramercy Hotel and art was displayed on hotel room beds.

headline: Review: Independent Art Fair Combines Less Is More and Growth
abstract: Despite some nods to convention, Independent 2015 still feels more like an art experience than a shopping experience, and that sets it apart from the competition.
lead_paragraph: Six years ago, when it started out, the art fair called Independent really was sort of that. It had a cool guerrilla buzz. In the former Dia headquarters on West 22nd Street in Chelsea, it was tiny compared with the cattle-call Armory Show. More rebelliously, admission was free. And the look was new. Instead of booths the size of stockyard stalls, there were wide-open prairies of exhibition space on all three floors. Within these democratic vistas, you could hardly tell where one gallery ended and another began.

headline: Furor Over Clinton Emails Tests Relationship With White House
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The uproar over Hillary Rodham Clinton’s use of a personal email while she was secretary of state is the most public test of her relationship with the White House since her book tour last summer.
lead_paragraph: The uproar over Hillary Rodham Clinton’s personal email account when she was secretary of state is the most public test of her relationship with the Obama White House since her book tour last summer.

headline: An Ankle Boot with a Futuristic Heel at Paco Rabanne
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: a black leather bootie that takes on a new dimension when viewed from behind.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: ‘Audubon’s Aviary: The Final Flight’ Alights at the New-York Historical Society
abstract: This is the final annual installment of the New-York Historical Society’s exploration of the 435 watercolors that Audubon executed for “The Birds of America.”
lead_paragraph: JOHN JAMES AUDUBON painted many birds, but for sheer stage presence, his great gray owl is hard to beat. Perched on a rotten branch, it turns halfway, as though disturbed, and fixes the viewer with an imperious stare. The yellow eyes glow, their intensity magnified by concentric ringlike markings that spread outward, like a feathery vortex. The plumage is regal — thick drapery, in a gray and brown pattern, falling in soft folds. The owl exudes the heavy solemnity of one of Velázquez’s popes or Holbein’s portrait of Thomas More.

headline: Review: In ‘Buzzard,’ an Angry, Unkempt Antihero
abstract: An unsparing portrait of an office temp and scam artist near the bottom of the economic food chain.
lead_paragraph: Marty Jackitansky (Joshua Burge), the repellent protagonist of the bleakly amusing indie film “Buzzard,” is a slovenly office temp at a mortgage company in Michigan who supplements his meager income from a $9.50-an-hour job with small-time con artistry. The bank for which he works and the neighborhood where he lives are so drab that his daily routine of clerical drudgery, fast-food snacks and toxic junk-culture distractions is a living hell.

headline: Reaction to Regulation: 1934 vs. Today
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Net Neutrality', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Many of the arguments against the F.C.C.’s net neutrality plan echo those made when the Communications Act of 1934, which created the F.C.C., was passed.
lead_paragraph: Last week, the Federal Communications Commission voted to regulate Internet service as a public utility, reclassifying broadband providers under Title II of the Communications Act of 1934 and subjecting them to stricter rules. Republicans and many broadband providers have criticized the decision, arguing that it was driven by the president and gives the federal government too much control, draws on dated laws and will result in subjective interpretations of broad mandates.

headline: With Nemtsov’s Killing, a Leadership Void Widens for Russia’s Opposition
abstract: The killing of Boris Y. Nemtsov leaves Russia’s critics at a crossroads over whether and how they take a role in the nation’s political life.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Among the motley collection of former ministers, retired spies, billionaire oligarchs, intellectuals and others who constitute Russia’s anemic liberal opposition, Boris Y. Nemtsov, the Kremlin critic fatally shot last week, always stood out.
