headline: Making Egypt’s Streets Safe for Women
abstract: Eman Helal hopes to not only document the widespread harassment of women on Cairo’s streets, but also aims to spur changes in public attitudes and behavior.
lead_paragraph: Eman Helal hopes to not only document the widespread harassment of women on Cairo’s streets, but also aims to spur changes in public attitudes and behavior.

headline: Review: In ‘Chappie,’ a Smart Robot Runs With the Wrong Crowd
abstract: The latest film from the director of “District 9” and “Elysium” is set in the usual bummer future and wavers uncertainly between laughter and tears.
lead_paragraph: Frankenstein’s monster gets a titanium makeover in “Chappie,” a science-fiction blood-spurter and would-be heart-warmer that wavers uncertainly between laughter and tears. Set in South Africa in the usual bummer future — yet again, it’s man against man, as well as machine — the movie imagines a scenario in which tin-can police march in lock step with their human analogues to roust the usual tattooed and dreadlocked gun-toting degenerates. All the aerial shots of the dangerously swarming and swelling multitudes suggest that such draconian tactics are necessary.

headline: Lincoln and Douglass’s Last Encounter
abstract: Lincoln’s Second Inaugural capped an ongoing discussion with Frederick Douglass over the meaning of freedom.
lead_paragraph: As the presidential coach plowed through thick mud on Pennsylvania Avenue, Frederick Douglass sensed danger. The editor and abolitionist activist began walking as closely behind as he could, studying every onlooker for a hint of conspiracy. When they reached the Capitol for Lincoln’s Second Inaugural without incident, a relieved Douglass joined the vast crowd, finding a place in front of the East Portico.

headline: Review: ‘October Gale’ Stars Patricia Clarkson
abstract: The film, written and directed by Ruba Nadda, finds a woman alone in a lakeside home who comes across a man with a gunshot wound.
lead_paragraph: A woman alone in the movies is rarely alone for long. In “October Gale,” a low-key character study gives way to increasingly clamorous melodrama when a widowed doctor, Helen (Patricia Clarkson), finds a bleeding man making a mess on the floor of her lakeside vacation home. Having gone out to inspect a noise (and left her front door open), she’s returned to find William (Scott Speedman), a handsome stranger — good looks being a prerequisite for gigs like this — with a bullet in his shoulder. While some women might run for a kitchen knife, this good doctor starts dressing his wound.

headline: This Week’s Movies | March 6, 2015
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel,” “Merchants of Doubt” and “Chappie.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel,” “Merchants of Doubt” and “Chappie.”

headline: Review: ‘Kidnapping Mr. Heineken’ Revisits a 1983 Dutch Crime
abstract: Anthony Hopkins is the title character in this uninvolving fictionalized account that plays out as a shopworn tale of greed, stupidity and comeuppance.
lead_paragraph: The sole object lesson in the true-crime drama “Kidnapping Mr. Heineken” is that not every crime deserves its own movie. That much becomes clear in the director Daniel Alfredson’s dreary, uninvolving fictionalized take on the real 1983 snatching of Alfred Heineken, chairman of the company bearing his family’s name. A few years ago, the same story was turned into “The Heineken Kidnapping,” a Dutch movie with Rutger Hauer in the title role, which racked up some business in the Netherlands and is available on Amazon on demand.

headline: Mayor de Blasio Urges New York Businesses to Raise Hourly Wages to Over $13
abstract: Lacking the support of lawmakers to increase the minimum wage to that level , Mayor Bill de Blasio, addressing the Association for a Better New York, urged employers to increase pay voluntarily.
lead_paragraph: Facing resistance in Albany over his calls for a minimum wage exceeding $13 an hour in New York City, Mayor Bill de Blasio took his case directly to business leaders on Thursday, urging them to raise workers’ pay to that level voluntarily.

headline: ‘The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel”
abstract: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews “The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews “The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel.”

headline: Reinventing the Mail Truck
keywords: ['Postal Service and Post Offices', 'Trucks and Trucking', 'Delivery Services', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Innovation']
abstract: The United States Postal Service is asking automakers to produce a truck that is more fuel efficient, safer and with room for all the packages mail carriers are increasingly handling.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Va. — On a recent snowy morning, Michael Ellis prepared his mail truck for the daily route he has run here for the last decade, through a neighborhood in the Washington suburbs.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Merchants of Doubt’
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Merchants of Doubt.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Merchants of Doubt.”

headline: Movie Review: ‘Chappie’
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Chappie.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Chappie.”

headline: Immigration Fight Shouldn’t Stall Vote to Confirm Lynch, Democrats Say
keywords: ['Attorneys General', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Loretta E. Lynch’s defense of President Obama’s immigration actions has made her confirmation as attorney general more tenuous.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats on Thursday intensified their push for a vote on the confirmation of Loretta E. Lynch as attorney general, arguing that her nomination should not be held up because Republicans are angry with President Obama over executive action on immigration.

headline: Alberto Nisman, Argentine Prosecutor, Was Killed, His Ex-Wife Says
abstract: Citing a report by investigators that she had hired, Sandra Arroyo Salgado, a judge and the former wife of Mr. Nisman, said, “Suicide and an accident are totally ruled out.”
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — The former wife of a federal prosecutor who died of a gunshot wound to the head after making explosive accusations against Argentina’s president charged Thursday that he had been murdered — reviving a bitter debate here over the mysterious circumstances shrouding his death.

headline: Lack of Diversity Persists in Admissions to New York City’s Elite High Schools
abstract: Five percent of the students offered placement in eight specialized high schools were black and 7 percent were Hispanic, according to statistics released on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Amid calls for new admissions procedures to increase diversity in New York City’s elite public high schools, the number of black and Hispanic students winning seats remained virtually unchanged this year, according to statistics the Education Department released on Thursday.

headline: Review: In ‘Two Men in Town,’ a Parolee Is Hounded by a Cop
abstract: Forest Whitaker plays an ex-convict who faces formidable obstacles as he tries to rebuild his life.
lead_paragraph: Paroled after serving 18 years in prison for the killing of a sheriff’s deputy, William Garnett tries to build a normal life in a small border town in the New Mexico desert. William, who converted to Islam in the penitentiary, buys a used motorcycle, finds a job at a ranch and begins a romance. His peace is threatened by a grudge-holding sheriff and by an old friend who wants to drag William back into his criminal ways. His parole officer does what she can to head off what seems like an inevitably tragic turn of events.

headline: Palestinian Council Questions Security Arrangement With Israel
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: A leadership body called for curtailing the longstanding cooperation with Israel, but left final decisions to President Mahmoud Abbas and the Palestine Liberation Organization’s executive committee.
lead_paragraph: RAMALLAH, West Bank — A Palestinian leadership body called Thursday night for curtailing longstanding security coordination with Israel, but left decisions on when or whether to take such a step to President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority and the Palestine Liberation Organization’s executive committee.

headline: Vice Media C.E.O. Begins Move Into Washington by Meeting Senators
abstract: Shane Smith’s visit came amid news that Vice will soon open a Washington bureau as it expands its political and presidential campaign coverage.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Shane Smith, the burly, bearded chief executive and self-described “pit bull” of the fast-growing Vice Media, rumbled into Washington on Wednesday for a tour, including his first private meetings with several senators.

headline: Review: In ‘Faults,’ Mind Games Don’t End Beyond the Cult
abstract: This twisty, winningly unsettling feature debut of the director Riley Stearns adds a sometimes darkly comic strain to cult-centric movies.
lead_paragraph: Cult mind games — the cultivation of blind obedience from communal devotees — are entering their own as a dramatic staple. “Sound of My Voice,” from 2012, cast Brit Marling as the charismatic leader of a mysterious sect; “Martha Marcy May Marlene,” from 2011, offered Elizabeth Olsen as a shattered escapee from a guru’s domination; and Paul Thomas Anderson’s “The Master,” from 2012, starred Philip Seymour Hoffman as a fraud sapping the free will of Joaquin Phoenix.

headline: Review: ‘An Honest Liar,’ a Documentary About the Debunker James Randi
abstract: This film focuses on the Amazing Randi, a magician on a crusade to expose fakery.
lead_paragraph: “Magicians are the most honest people in the world,” the illusionist James Randi says at the beginning of “An Honest Liar.” “They tell you they’re gonna fool you, and then they do it.” Documenting a lifetime spent gulling audiences and pursuing con men, the directors Justin Weinstein and Tyler Measom have produced a jaunty, jovial portrait with a surprising sting in its tail.

headline: Review: ‘The Mind of Mark DeFriest’ Is a Documentary About a Prison Houdini
abstract: The mental state and experiences of a Florida inmate known for numerous breakouts (often through outlandish means) are explored in this chronicle.
lead_paragraph: The indomitable personality and talents of the serial prison escapee Mark DeFriest outshine the weaknesses of this documentary that bears his name. Gabriel London’s “The Mind of Mark DeFriest” recounts how this Florida man landed in prison and kept breaking out through illegal (and often outlandish) means.

headline: Review: ‘Earth’s Golden Playground,’ a Documentary on Prospecting in the Yukon
abstract: This film removes any luster from prospecting in the Canada territory where the Klondike gold rush took place more than a century ago.
lead_paragraph: Early in Andreas Horvath’s “Earth’s Golden Playground,” a look at modern-day prospectors in the Yukon territory of Canada, an underground shot at a gold dig suggests an ultra-lo-fi variation on the opening of “There Will Be Blood.” But Mr. Horvath’s procedural, increasingly dry documentary takes the “rush” out of “gold rush.”

headline: Ed Modzelewski, Fullback for Maryland and the Browns, Dies at 86
abstract: A fullback known as Big Mo, he starred with his brother Dick, the defensive tackle called Little Mo, on an undefeated University of Maryland team, then collided with him in the N.F.L. in the 1950s.
lead_paragraph: Ed Modzelewski, the fullback known as Big Mo, who starred with his brother Dick, the defensive tackle called Little Mo, on an undefeated University of Maryland team, then collided with him in the N.F.L. of the 1950s when his Cleveland Browns faced Dick’s Giants, died on Saturday in West Sedona, Ariz. He was 86.

headline: Review: In ‘Unfinished Business,’ Vince Vaughn and Sienna Miller Are Rivals
abstract: The slick, innocuous comedy “Unfinished Business” fails to seal the deal.
lead_paragraph: A “EuroTrip” with balance sheets, the slick, innocuous comedy “Unfinished Business” fails to seal the deal. Dan Trunkman (Vince Vaughn) is a St. Louis executive and father whose company is being restructured by Chuck Portnoy (Sienna Miller), a shark already demanding too many hours from employees. Enraged, Dan starts a rival outfit, hiring Tim McWinters (Tom Wilkinson), an older colleague forced into retirement, and Mike Pancake (Dave Franco), a young, pretty dullard.

headline: Robert G. Dean, Whose Theories on Sand Saved Beaches, Dies at 84
abstract: The techniques he advanced are routine today almost everywhere on developed coastlines; without them, many beach towns would be without beaches.
lead_paragraph: Though they have probably never heard of him, beachgoers regularly see the work of Robert G. Dean, especially if they visit towns on the barrier islands that line the East and Gulf Coasts.

headline: Schwab’s Service for Investors Seeking Thrifty Advice Raises Eyebrows
abstract: Whether the service, called Schwab Intelligent Portfolios, is truly free — or is just intended to seem that way — is a matter of debate.
lead_paragraph: Charles Schwab is poised to introduce an investment service for consumers who crave low-cost personalized advice but do not have a lot of money to invest. And it is dangling an attractive lure in front of investors, in a way that its competitors have not: It says its service is free.

headline: Cardinal Edward M. Egan Dies at 82
abstract: Cardinal Egan was one of America’s most visible Catholic leaders.
lead_paragraph: Cardinal Egan was one of America’s most visible Catholic leaders.

headline: Review: ‘Deli Man’ Is a Documentary on Jewish Delis, Schmaltz and All
abstract: Through the experiences of a third-generation deli owner, this film touches on the history of delis in New York and sits down to a full table of discussion on the topic.
lead_paragraph: “Deli Man” examines the state of the Jewish deli through David Gruber, known as Ziggy, a founder of Kenny & Ziggy’s New York Delicatessen Restaurant in Houston. Trained in culinary school, he represents the third generation in his family to run such a restaurant, the film says; Ziggy’s grandfather was a source for many of his recipes and Yiddishisms. “Since he was a little kid, he’s been an 80-year-old Jew,” says J. Mackye Gruber, Ziggy’s brother (and the co-director of the 2004 film “The Butterfly Effect”).

headline: Harrison Ford Crashes Plane on Golf Course
abstract: The 72-year-old actor was injured when a single-engine, World War II-era training plane he was piloting crashed in Venice, Calif., soon after takeoff.
lead_paragraph: The actor Harrison Ford was injured on Thursday when a single-engine, World War II-era training plane he was piloting crashed onto a golf course in Venice, Calif., shortly after takeoff from Santa Monica Airport.

headline: Companies Turn Tables on Human Rights Lawyers
keywords: ['Corporations', 'Legal Profession', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Alien Tort Statute (1789)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: American companies accused of human rights abuses abroad are on the counterattack, seeking to bring down the lawyers who targeted them.
lead_paragraph: Over the past decade, companies doing business in Colombia, like Chiquita Brands and Dole Food, have incurred the wrath of Terrence Collingsworth, a lawyer who has accused them of mistreating workers or conspiring to kill labor activists.

headline: AbbVie Wins Bidding War for Maker of Cancer Drug, Then Goes on Defensive
abstract: Strategically, the $21 billion deal for Pharmacyclics seems to make sense for AbbVie, but at least some analysts said the company had paid too much.
lead_paragraph: Robert Duggan, according to his many websites, has played basketball with Pat Riley of the N.B.A., taught his children to surf by the time they were 3 and made fortunes starting and selling companies in fields as varied as cookies and robot surgery. He is the largest donor to the Church of Scientology.

headline: A League Full of Professionals, in Actions if Not in Pay
abstract: In its eighth season, the Canadian Women’s Hockey League continues to face challenges as the home for women’s professional hockey in North America.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — In the Canadian Women’s Hockey League, job titles are often ambiguous.

headline: Review: ‘The Mafia Kills Only in Summer’ Is a Comical Look at the Mob
abstract: Pierfrancesco Diliberto plays a virginal klutz whose lifelong brushes with mob misbehavior in Italy parallel his ceaseless yearning for a beautiful woman.
lead_paragraph: The best that can be said for the Italian television host Pierfrancesco Diliberto — as far as his comic, feature-film debut is concerned — is that he’s not nearly as annoying as Roberto Benigni. Granted, that’s a very low bar to clear.

headline: Gov. Christie Goes Easy on a Big Polluter
abstract: A $250 million deal with Exxon to recover $8.9 billion in damages for environmental contamination is a colossal mistake.
lead_paragraph: The state of New Jersey invested more than 10 years in a lawsuit to recover $8.9 billion in damages from Exxon Mobil Corporation for environmental contamination of more than 1,500 acres of wetlands, marshes and meadows in northern New Jersey. Exxon’s liability was not in dispute. But just as a state judge was nearing a decision on damages, Gov. Chris Christie’s administration intervened and quietly agreed to settle the claim for a stunningly low $250 million.

headline: With Eyes on His Vote in Health Subsidies Case, Roberts Lets on Little
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: In Supreme Court arguments Wednesday on the fate of the health care law, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. traded his usual display of intellect and competitiveness for a sphinxlike demeanor.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. usually displays his supple intellect and competitive nature at Supreme Court arguments, where he makes points and punctures the positions of the lawyers who appear before him.

headline: Pushing Limits of a Sport, and a Budget
abstract: After a harrowing spring injury, the Reds’ Aroldis Chapman had one of the most dominant seasons. Chapman can be a free agent after 2016, which puts the Reds in a quandary.
lead_paragraph: GOODYEAR, Ariz. — You hear it from just about every major league hitter: Strikeouts are rising because pitchers throw really, really fast. Relievers trot in from the bullpen, one after another, and overpower the hitters.

headline: Review: In ‘These Final Hours’ an Imminent Apocalypse Incites Depravity
abstract: In this Australian drama by Zak Hilditch, a man is conflicted about how to spend his waning moments alive.
lead_paragraph: Every time the world ends, somebody has to learn a lesson, generally about Love and What’s Really Important. In “These Final Hours,” an Australian drama, it’s James’s turn. The lesson may not be particularly original, but the film has some striking moments as it follows him to his destiny.

headline: Iran Gains Influence in Iraq as Shiite Forces Fight ISIS
abstract: Iran’s powerful influence in Iraq has been on display as the fight against the Islamic State militants around Tikrit has unfolded, with strong support for Shiite leaders where they were once feared.
lead_paragraph: AWJA, Iraq — All along the green irrigated plains in the heart of what American occupying troops used to call the Sunni triangle, lampposts and watchtowers are flying the flags of the Badr Organization, a Shiite militia long hated and feared by many Iraqi Sunnis.

headline: Review: Adam Carolla’s ‘Road Hard,’ a Comedy About a Comic
abstract: A stand-up comedian struggles to escape a rut of his own making.
lead_paragraph: Adam Carolla really wants people to know that he hates show business. And Los Angeles. And the road. And his audience. And any younger performer who gained popularity with the help of the Internet or social media.

headline: In U.C.L.A. Debate Over Jewish Student, Echoes on Campus of Old Biases
abstract: A student board debated whether the religion of a second-year economics major meant she would be biased in dealing with sensitive governance questions, and the discussion has upended the campus.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It seemed like routine business for the student council at the University of California, Los Angeles: confirming the nomination of Rachel Beyda, a second-year economics major who wants to be a lawyer someday, to the council’s Judicial Board.

headline: Back to a Short Putter, Adam Scott Is Happy With the Results
abstract: For the first time in four years and 83 worldwide starts, Scott used a short putter in his round of two-under 70 at the World Golf Championships event at Doral.
lead_paragraph: DORAL, Fla. — Adam Scott looked as if he were paying tribute to the recently departed Leonard Nimoy on Thursday on the greens of Doral’s Blue Monster. Holding his putter in his left hand, Scott rested his right hand, palm down, lightly on the grip and gave his golf ball a modified Vulcan salute.

headline: Mexico: Gunmen Kill a Navy Officer
abstract: A navy officer put in charge of Mexico’s second-largest port in an effort to wrest control of it from a drug gang was shot and killed in what the authorities said Thursday was a robbery attempt.
lead_paragraph: A navy officer put in charge of Mexico’s second-largest port in an effort to wrest control of it from a drug gang was shot and killed in what the authorities said Thursday was a robbery attempt. The officer, Rear Adm. José Luis Corro Chávez, was shot Wednesday after he refused to leave his vehicle when gunmen demanded it outside his house in the port city of Lázaro Cárdenas, in Michoacán State. Two suspects have been arrested. Admiral Corro had served at the port since November 2013, when the navy began trying to root out the Knights Templar gang, which had been smuggling iron ore to China and extorting mining interests in the area. The authorities said the shooting was not related to organized crime, but it came nearly a week after the arrest of the former top leader of the Knights Templar, Servando Gómez.

headline: 529 College Savings Plans in a State of Evolution
abstract: Small adjustments aimed at making the popular accounts more flexible have either been enacted or are proposed.
lead_paragraph: EARLY this year, 529 college savings plans stirred a lot of attention — outrage, really — when President Obama proposed eliminating the tax-free status of withdrawals from the accounts, which millions of Americans use to save for higher education costs.

headline: Senate Will Postpone Debate on Iran
abstract: Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky and the majority leader, will postpone consideration of a bill giving Congress the authority to review any deal President Obama reaches with Iran on its nuclear program.
lead_paragraph: Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky and the majority leader, will postpone consideration of a bill giving Congress the authority to review any deal President Obama reaches with Iran on its nuclear program, bowing to opposition from Democrats who charged that he was rushing the measure. Mr. McConnell, who this week set the stage for a procedural vote on the legislation on Tuesday, decided on Thursday that he would wait to bring up the bipartisan measure. Don Stewart, a spokesman for Mr. McConnell, said that would give Democrats time to “decide whether or not they believe they and Congress as a whole should be able to review and vote on any deal the president cuts with the leaders of Iran.” The decision merely delays what promises to be an intense debate in Congress over whether Mr. Obama should be able to seal a deal with Iran aimed at blocking it from acquiring nuclear weapons and under what terms. A growing bipartisan coalition of lawmakers believes Congress must have a say over any such accord, and they are moving to lay out tough requirements for Mr. Obama that could shape any deal.

headline: Success is a Great Deodorant
abstract: Friday fun with David Phillips.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — David Phillips goes into quite a bit of detail about his puzzle, so I’m going to be brief and then get out of his way. The one point I would like to make is that I am starving right now.

headline: Review: ‘Fish in the Dark,’ Larry David’s Antic Broadway Debut
abstract: In his Broadway debut as an actor and playwright, Mr. David plays a character not unlike his TV persona who gathers with his family at his father’s deathbed.
lead_paragraph: The fish itself — the one that figures in ads for the new play “Fish in the Dark” and can be seen on the drop curtain at the Cort Theater — is pretty great, a charming and maddening creature destined to capture your heart. O.K., if you insist: It is pret-ty, pret-ty, pret-ty great.

headline: Is Boxing Dead? Some Are Betting Heavily That It Isn’t
abstract: Al Haymon plans to spend at least $20 million annually over three years to present bouts on NBC and NBCSN instead of pay cable or pay per view.
lead_paragraph: Al Haymon makes a habit of not speaking to reporters, but that’s fine. What Haymon is attempting speaks louder than anything he might say anyway. Haymon, a Harvard-educated boxing manager and adviser, is challenging the pay-per-view model that has enriched a few people at the expense of an entire sport.

headline: Brown Family Lawyer Announces Civil Case
abstract: Anthony Gray, a lawyer for the family of Michael Brown, a teenager killed by a police officer in Ferguson, Mo., said that the family would be filing a civil suit against the police department.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Gray, a lawyer for the family of Michael Brown, a teenager killed by a police officer in Ferguson, Mo., said that the family would be filing a civil suit against the police department.

headline: Some in Ferguson Who Are Part of Problem Are Asked to Help Solve It
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Many of the officials who are cited in the Justice Department’s scathing report on the city’s justice system are still in power and will be counted on to implement an overhaul.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — When Mayor James Knowles III announced Wednesday that one official had been fired and two others were under investigation in connection with racist emails, he said that the behavior was “in no way representative” of the city or its employees.

headline: When Clinton Joined Obama Administration, Friction Was Over Staff, Not Email
abstract: The uproar over Hillary Clinton’s use of only a private email account as secretary of state calls to mind the mutual distrust that characterized the Obama administration and Mrs. Clinton’s team early on.
lead_paragraph: When President-elect Barack Obama invited Hillary Rodham Clinton to be his secretary of state, he did not just get Mrs. Clinton. He also got the extended circle of political aides she and her husband had collected over her years in the White House, the Senate and the 2008 presidential campaign.

headline: Ferguson Report Puts ‘Hands Up’ to Reality Test
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: The report, which cleared Officer Darren Wilson while sharply criticizing Ferguson’s justice system, called into question the story behind the rallying cry “Hands up, don’t shoot.”
lead_paragraph: They were four words that became the national rallying cry of a new civil rights movement: “Hands up, don’t shoot.”

headline: A Secret Indictment Over Errors That Have Rarely Been Crimes
abstract: Indictments over 2009 campaign finance filings involve common mistakes that typically result only in a refiling of paperwork.
lead_paragraph: If one of your ambitions is obscurity, being a staff worker for a City Council member is not a bad line of work. Sure, it comes with plenty of irregular hours, late evenings at civic meetings, weekend “celebrations” of something. But there’s little risk of much public recognition.

headline: Yankees’ Captaincy Is Open, and It May Stay That Way
abstract: General Manager Brian Cashman reiterated on Thursday what he said on at least two occasions last season — that he would like to have the title of captain retired along with Derek Jeter.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Didi Gregorius will replace Derek Jeter at shortstop for the Yankees this season because, well, somebody has to.

lead_paragraph: Tumblr 483 — 485

headline: Prosecutor Denies Creating a ‘Media Firestorm’ Over Sheldon Silver’s Arrest
abstract: In an effort to dismiss the charges against Assemblyman Sheldon Silver, his lawyers argue that statements by Preet Bharara, the United States attorney, convicted Mr. Silver in the news media.
lead_paragraph: The office of Preet Bharara, the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York, asked a federal judge on Thursday to deny a motion by Assemblyman Sheldon Silver to dismiss his indictment on grounds that Mr. Bharara orchestrated a “media firestorm” around the arrest of Mr. Silver.

headline: Umbrella Cam’s View of Wintry New York
abstract: A camera mounted on an umbrella captures scenes of New Yorkers struggling through a late winter snow across the Brooklyn Bridge into Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: A camera mounted on an umbrella captures scenes of New Yorkers struggling through a late winter snow across the Brooklyn Bridge into Manhattan.

headline: Bronx Woman Is Fatally Shot After Getting a Mystery Call
abstract: The police said Michelle Cox’s partner told them Ms. Cox received a call from a person named Blue and was found dead outside their apartment soon afterward.
lead_paragraph: A mother of five, Michelle Cox formerly worked as a security guard. She also had run-ins with the law over the years, the police said.

headline: Train Carrying Crude Oil Derails in Illinois
abstract: There were no reported injuries from the accident, but the authorities were recommending that residents evacuate a one-mile radius around the crash site.
lead_paragraph: A train carrying crude oil along the banks of the Mississippi River derailed Thursday in a rural area of northwestern Illinois south of the town of Galena, starting a fire and leading the authorities to recommend that nearby residents leave their homes.

headline: Mets Get Preview of N.L. Rival
abstract: Bartolo Colon was a pleasant surprise for the Mets in a Grapefruit League game against the Washington Nationals, who started Max Scherzer for the first time.
lead_paragraph: VIERA, Fla. — Mets Manager Terry Collins was on a golf course in January when the news broke that the Washington Nationals had signed Max Scherzer. Recalling that moment, Collins joked that he shanked his next putt 10 feet past the hole.

headline: Video: An Umbrella’s View of Snowy New York
abstract: A camera mounted on an umbrella takes a trip across the Brooklyn Bridge.
lead_paragraph: As the snow fell across New York on Thursday, a New York Times reporter mounted a video camera on the top of his umbrella and traveled across the Brooklyn Bridge from Brooklyn to Manhattan to capture scenes of weary city residents coping with what many fervently hoped would be the winter’s last major snowfall.

abstract: After some back-and-forth drama in a Manhattan courtroom, Franklin Reyes Jr. admitted killing Ariel Russo with his car and, separately, assaulting a police officer.
lead_paragraph: Franklin Reyes Jr. tried to plead guilty without admitting his guilt.

headline: Anthony Mason, a Former Knick and a Native Son of Queens, Is Mourned
abstract: Mr. Mason was a combative player in the Knicks’ mid-1990s heyday, a tough defensive specialist who sometimes clashed with opponents and, occasionally, with his own coaches.
lead_paragraph: They trudged through the flurries in a slow, steady stream on Thursday to pay their respects to Anthony Mason, the former New York Knick who died on Saturday at 48 after being hospitalized for congestive heart failure three weeks earlier.

headline: The Colossal Strangeness of China’s Most Excellent Tourist City
abstract: Ordos, like so many of the country’s hundreds of new towns, is famous for being empty — a symbol, some would say, of the hubris of rampant urbanization. But the few people who live there see it differently.
lead_paragraph: Ordos, like so many of the country’s hundreds of new towns, is famous for being empty — a symbol, some would say, of the hubris of rampant urbanization. But the few people who live there see it differently.

headline: Word of the Day | incandescent
abstract: This word has appeared in 88 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: incandescent • \ˌin-kən-ˈde-sənt\ • adjective

headline: Maika Monroe Runs for Her Life in ‘It Follows’
abstract: Ms. Monroe, 21, who is stalked by an evil force in the new film “It Follows,” says, “I’d never thought of horror as being so challenging, but it is.”
lead_paragraph: Maika Monroe has spent a lot of time running for her life. Last year, in the thriller “The Guest,” she played a girl who must flee from the strange and dangerous man (Dan Stevens) staying with her family. In the horror movie “It Follows,” opening March 13, she’s stalked by an evil force in human form that will kill her if it catches her. The only way to break the curse is to have sex with someone and pass it on.

headline: New York City Parking Alert: Alternate-Side Rules Are Suspended on Friday
abstract: Because of snow removal, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Because of snow removal, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Friday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: Hemlines and Heartbreak in Fassbinder’s ‘The Bitter Tears of Petra von Kant’
abstract: Rainer Werner Fassbinder, the prolific if short-lived German writer-director, created a metaphor of sorts for his own existence with this all-female movie from 1972.
lead_paragraph: Rainer Werner Fassbinder (1945-82) was a comet whose brief, productive career belied even as it blazed forth the decline of imported film culture. At the time of his death from a drug overdose, at 37, Fassbinder left some 40 features, a pair of TV mini-series and two dozen stage plays. But none were more Fassbinderian than this German writer-director’s 1972 film, “The Bitter Tears of Petra von Kant,” part confession, part travesty.

headline: What’s on TV Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Starz) MALEFICENT (2014) In this live-action back story to the 1959 Disney animated musical “Sleeping Beauty,” a happy young fairy (in a role shared by Isobelle Molloy and Ella Purnell) living in the moors becomes friends — and then something a bit more, involving a kiss — with a human farmhand (played by Michael Higgins and Jackson Bews). But eventually the boy grows into a man (Sharlto Copley) and helps wage war against the mossy wonderland of the fairy (now Angelina Jolie), whose wings are literally clipped. Now in an eternally foul mood, she retreats into a dark place, where years later she plots against his child, Aurora (Elle Fanning), who is destined to fall into a deep sleep after pricking her finger on a spindle. Ms. Jolie “makes a fabulous monster” as “she breezes through the movie, part superstar, part superfreak,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “Consciously or not, coherently or not, ‘Maleficent’ tells a new kind of story about how we live now, not once upon another time. And it does so by suggesting, among other things, that budding girls and older women are not natural foes, even if that’s what fairy tales, Hollywood and the world like to tell us. And while that may sound drippy, it’s exactly the kind of hokey that, movie by movie, may finally make a real difference.”

headline: Revenge Movies Offer Mythic Middle-Aged Protectors
abstract: Characters like the ones played by Liam Neeson and Sean Penn in new films provide wish-fulfillment avatars for graying Gen Xers beginning to long for their adolescence.
lead_paragraph: Time was, a prestigious actor midway through the journey of life would guest star on a cable show to get through the dark wood of his career. But premium television is no longer second-tier entertainment, and middle-aged actors, in contrast to their female counterparts, have no shortage of material from which to choose. That’s especially true with the booming subgenre of revenge movies made for, by and essentially about them.

headline: A Team Whose Fans Are Few but Devoted
abstract: The Boston Blades are the only team in the Canadian Women’s Hockey League based in the United States, and many of their players work part-time jobs to supplement their income.
lead_paragraph: The Boston Blades are the only team in the Canadian Women’s Hockey League based in the United States, and many of their players work part-time jobs to supplement their income.

headline: In the Documentary ‘GTFO,’ Female Video Gamers Fight Back
keywords: ['Movies', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Women and Girls', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Discrimination', 'Cyberharassment', 'Threats and Threatening Messages', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: Shannon Sun-Higginson’s documentary talks to female video game players and designers about the pervasive sexism in the video game industry.
lead_paragraph: In the documentary “GTFO,” Jenny Haniver is relaxing in her living room in Wisconsin, thumbs on her Xbox controller, settling in for another session of Call of Duty. But when her fellow online combatants discover that the shooter in their midst is, to their chagrin, female, the comments commence. One player takes potshots at women — they are poor game players, they can’t drive — before commanding Ms. Haniver to leave the game. “You’re useless when your hymen is broken,” he tells her.

headline: Making Egypt’s Streets Safe for Women
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Photography', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Eman Helal hopes to not only document the widespread harassment of women on Cairo’s streets, but she also aims to spur changes in public attitudes and behavior.
lead_paragraph: Like her male Egyptian colleagues, Eman Helal often dons a gas mask and helmet when she photographs protests in Cairo. But the protective gear provides her an extra level of security — from men in public. Her helmet and mask hide her hijab — the only hint she is a woman, as she otherwise dresses like a man while working — making it far less likely that she will encounter the verbal abuse or physical and sexual assaults that women have come to expect on Cairo’s streets.

headline: The Temptation of Hillary
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Education']
abstract: The shift on the left from human capital progressivism to redistributionist progressivism is potent, damaging and based on a misinterpretation of the data.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton’s record is more moderate than the Democratic primary voter today. So it was always likely that she would move left as the primary season approached. It’s now becoming clearer how she might do it. She might make a shift from what you might call human capital progressivism to redistributionist progressivism.

headline: Hillary’s Step
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: She can’t run on inevitability or on being the smartest person in the room, but must present a reason why she should reside again in the White House.
lead_paragraph: On Mount Everest, just shy of the summit, the final rock-and-ice obstacle that stands between a climber and the highest point on the planet is known as the Hillary Step. It was named for Sir Edmund Hillary, who made the first ascent of the mountain along with Tenzing Norgay in 1953.

headline: Alabama’s Dangerous Defiance
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Federal-State Relations (US)', 'States (US)', 'Supreme Courts (State)', 'Federal Courts (US)', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: The state’s stance on gay marriage threatens judicial federalism.
lead_paragraph: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — ON Tuesday the Supreme Court of Alabama prohibited the state’s probate judges from issuing marriage licenses to same-sex couples. This decision effectively throws down the gauntlet, challenging the federal courts to make earlier federal rulings stick — including last month’s refusal by the United States Supreme Court to stay a federal judge’s decision requiring the state to recognize same-sex marriages. It draws on a disturbing line of thinking in the history of American federalism, one that, were it to gain currency as a model, could compromise our entire system of law.

headline: Pepperoni Turns Partisan
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: The politics of Big Pizza resemble those of Big Coal or Big Tobacco and tell you a lot about what is happening to American governance in general.
lead_paragraph: If you want to know what a political party really stands for, follow the money. Pundits and the public are often deceived; remember when George W. Bush was a moderate, and Chris Christie a reasonable guy who could reach out to Democrats? Major donors, however, generally have a very good idea of what they are buying, so tracking their spending tells you a lot.

headline: The President’s Weak Privacy Proposal
keywords: ['Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Privacy', 'Editorials', 'Law and Legislation', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: A recent bill will do little to help individuals while giving companies great leeway in determining how they collect, use and share personal data.
lead_paragraph: President Obama has said that the country needs a strong privacy law so consumers can protect personal information from advertisers, Internet firms, employers and other businesses. But the country is not going to get it from Mr. Obama. The bill his administration recently offered will do little to help individuals while giving companies great leeway in determining how they collect, use and share personal data.

headline: Deferring Those Huge College Tuition Bills
abstract: Responses to an Op-Ed article, “How to Make College Cheaper.”

headline: India’s Careful Plan for Growth
abstract: For decades, the country’s leaders have promised reform without actually effecting change. Now, the challenge is inescapable.
lead_paragraph: Narendra Modi chose incremental pragmatism in proposing his first full budget since becoming India’s prime minister last year. The $288 billion budget did not fulfill the expectations for economic reform that he has fostered since his election. But he offered enough initiatives on spending, taxes and other areas of economic policy to satisfy many investors for now, and to keep alive hopes that he can guide India to greater growth and development.

headline: Don’t Kill Keystone XL. Regulate It.
keywords: ['Keystone Pipeline System', 'Trans-Alaska Pipeline System', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Pipelines', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Oil Spills']
abstract: Instead of fighting for or against pipelines, fight for safe infrastructure.
lead_paragraph: BOULDER, Colo. — TWO years ago, I spent a month watching engineers inspect the Trans-Alaska Pipeline, one of the world’s biggest, most remote and most complicated pipelines. The endeavor entailed sending a five-ton “smart pig” — a rust-detecting robot — 800 miles across the length of Alaska, like a spitball in a giant straw, as it hunted for signs of metal loss.

headline: A Call From Selma
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)']

headline: ‘A Call From Selma’
keywords: ['Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: This short documentary explores how the murder of a white minister in Selma, Ala., helped galvanize support for the Voting Rights Act of 1965.
lead_paragraph: When many of us think about the civil rights movement, we remember the courage of the black protesters who risked their lives and livelihoods to push for equal rights. But obscured in this history is the fact that it took the murder of a white clergyman to trigger the national outrage about rights abuses in the South that led to real change.

lead_paragraph: It’s often been said that the key to success is being able to handle failure. For example, from Winston Churchill: “Success is stumbling from failure to failure with no loss of enthusiasm.” Or C. S. Lewis: “One fails forward toward success.”

headline: Netanyahu’s Iran Thing
abstract: The prime minister's obsessive Iran demonization runs on hyperbole and selective history.
lead_paragraph: Let’s begin with Benjamin Netanyahu’s Iran logic. He portrays a rampaging Islamic Republic that “now dominates four Arab capitals, Baghdad, Damascus, Beirut and Sana,” a nation “gobbling” other countries on a “march of conquest, subjugation and terror.” Then, in the same speech, he describes Iran as “a very vulnerable regime” on the brink of folding.

headline: How to Drive a Getaway Car
keywords: ['Robberies and Thefts', 'Automobiles', 'Kidnapping and Hostages', 'Security and Warning Systems']
abstract: Don’t try to speed away. Disappear instead.
lead_paragraph: Never mind trying to outrace another vehicle when you need to escape, says Walter Farrer, a security consultant who teaches evasive-­driving courses to business executives and wealthy Mexican families who want to avoid kidnappings. Disappear instead: drive a mini­van, which is like an automotive duck blind, mobile camouflage for the road. “They make you hard to follow,” Farrer says. A newish mini­van or midsize S.U.V. in gray with no bumper stickers is ideal. “Make sure both taillights work,” Farrer says. “You don’t want anything on your car that is easily identifiable.” In particularly high-risk cities — kidnappings for ransom are a persistent problem in Mexico — he presses his clients to drive cars covered in dust bearing local plates.

headline: Massimo Vitali Moves Into a 14th-Century Church
abstract: The photographer and his family live in a converted structure in Lucca, Italy.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Massimo Vitali lives with his wife and son in Lucca, Italy, in a 14th-century church that lay empty for 17 years. “The church was used mainly for storage,” Vitali said. “There were mice and birds in it, there was water. In Italy, when you purchase an ancient church, you have to keep it open; you cannot divide the space into smaller rooms.” For additional living space, Vitali’s architect, Paola Sausa, attached a former sacristy to the church.

headline: Cover to Cover
abstract: The illustrator Tom Gauld on book guilt.

headline: ‘Outside the Abandoned Packard Plant’
abstract: Poem selected by Natasha Trethewey.
lead_paragraph: There is a driving rhythm in this poem — the industry of crickets, the forward motion of the lines — even as there is no man-made machinery at work in the defunct auto plant. The contrast between the two heightens the tension between what is lost and the image, in the last line, of a possible future. Poem selected by Natasha Trethewey.

headline: Birdman
abstract: Did Arlan Galbraith really think he could turn pigeon meat into the next chicken? Or was he running an elaborate Ponzi scam all along?
lead_paragraph: The Pigeon King delivered his closing statement to the jury dressed in his only suit. His name was Arlan Galbraith, and he was representing himself. He had abruptly fired his lawyer nearly two years earlier, during the long lead up to the trial, and then ignored the judges who advised him to hire another. He seemed adrift but also supremely confident. One of his former employees, who testified for the prosecution, speculated that he must have watched too much “Law & Order”: “I think he sat down one day and said, ‘Yeah, I can do this.’ ”

headline: Re: The Unimpeachable Manly Truth
abstract: Readers debated the merits of Gary Shteyngart’s cushy yet torturous immersion in Russian TV.
lead_paragraph: It was “a weird but productive sociological experiment,” in the words of one journalist: Put Gary Shteyngart in a 600-square-foot luxury cage at the Four Seasons in Manhattan and force him to watch nothing but Russian television for seven days on three giant screens arranged around his plush, king-size bed. It was “an (oddly) rare look at what [President Vladimir] Putin is actually telling the Russian people,” tweeted Whitney Kassel, a columnist for ForeignPolicy.com.

headline: Redefining Gender in Mexico City
abstract: I lived in a binary world, but I always pushed against it.
lead_paragraph: When you see a person, how many seconds do you have to make a mental model? Immediately, the first thing you notice — man or woman? But I always had issues with my gender. And when people can’t understand, they get uncomfortable.

headline: Restaurant Report: Selfie in Moscow
abstract: Scoff if you want, but the name is perfect for this restaurant, which has a tongue-in-cheek approach, a renowned chef and a focus on local ingredients.
lead_paragraph: Scoff if you want, but the name is perfect: Selfie, from the team behind the fashionable Moscow restaurant White Rabbit, is a pouty-lipped snapshot of the current insular moment among the city’s cosmopolitan elite.

headline: Hidden Gems on Ecuador’s Emerald Coast
abstract: Eco-tourism is gaining a foothold in Esmeraldas, an Afro-Ecuadorean province that has rugged jungles, giant mangroves and coconut-lined beaches.
lead_paragraph: Reggaeton blaring, we zoomed along the coast of Esmeraldas, past a series of resort towns, white sand beaches spoiled only by concrete hotel towers. Our Ranchera, an Ecuadorean open-air bus, paused just long enough for schoolchildren to climb atop the roof before we veered slightly inland away from the jagged, rocky coast and into the remnants of a jungle canopy.

headline: Discovering the Ruins of Italy’s Ionian Coast
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Roman Civilization', 'ARCHAEOLOGY', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: Tracing ancestral connections in the Basilicata region, where Greeks built temples, monks painted in caves and Francis Ford Coppola opened a hotel.
lead_paragraph: It was my first day back in Metaponto in a decade, and I was anxious. As my train from Rome pulled into the station, after a six-hour descent past Vesuvius, the craggy Lucanian Dolomites, olive groves and pebbly streams, and finally the small hill towns and low, pale mountains (calanchi) of the Basilicata region, I wondered what had changed in this place since my last visit. My family was from this area originally, four generations back, and I had come here twice before to do genealogical research. But it had been a while.

headline: A Prince Who Would Be King Challenges Sepp Blatter for FIFA’s Presidency
abstract: For the first time in more than 12 years, Blatter, whose FIFA presidency has been shadowed by controversy, will face at least one serious opponent: Prince Ali bin al-Hussein of Jordan.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Sepp Blatter has been elected to four consecutive terms as president of FIFA, a run that dates to 1998. In his first election — the process gives every FIFA-affiliated country a vote — Blatter defeated a former head of the European soccer confederation. In the second, he defeated the leader of the African soccer confederation. In the third and fourth, he ran unopposed.

headline: When Rural Meets Resort

lead_paragraph: The tiny town of Amenia, N.Y., population 4,436, is perhaps best known for its hamlet of Wassaic, the last stop on the Metro-North Railroad’s Harlem line and home to an artists’ community that hosts an annual festival there. Bordering Connecticut in rural Dutchess County, Amenia has had a tough time since its largest employer, an institution for the developmentally disabled, closed two years ago.

headline: Kate Tempest, a British Triple Threat, Crosses the Pond
abstract: Ms. Tempest — whose poems, plays and recordings about struggling Londoners have been winning acclaim in her native Britain — is about to tour America.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Kate Tempest — poet, playwright, rapper, cross-genre talent — took to the stage at Electric Brixton, a club in the historically working class neighborhood one recent Sunday night, and looked into the crowd of more than a thousand people. “I don’t want to see you hidden behind your phone screens!” she called out in her unmistakable South London accent. “This is real! This is happening!” Being together in one room, living the same moment, she said, is “as close to connecting” as many of us ever achieve.

headline: How to Find More Time
abstract: New research suggests our concept of time is malleable — and some simple strategies could make us feel like we have more of it.
lead_paragraph: Want to add some hours to your day? O.K., you (probably) can’t alter the fabric of time. But a new study suggests that the way you feel about your goals can alter your concept of time — and that some simple strategies could make you feel less rushed.

headline: ‘House of Cards’ Season 3, Episode 12 Recap: Their Only Child
abstract: What kind of a legacy do the Underwoods hope to leave?
lead_paragraph: Season 3, Episode 11: Chapter 38

headline: Briton Arrested Over Cyberattack on U.S. Defense Department
keywords: ['Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Cyberwarfare']
abstract: Data were stolen in June from a messaging service used by the department’s employees, including email addresses and phone numbers for about 800 contacts.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A 23-year-old British man has been arrested over a cyberattack in which data was stolen from the United States Department of Defense, the police said on Friday.

headline: 11 Little-Known Facts About John Galliano and Alexander McQueen
abstract: Shocking and endearing anecdotes culled from Dana Thomas’s new book, “Gods and Kings,” about the rise and fall of the fashion designers.
lead_paragraph: Fashion-philes are on high alert: This evening in Paris, at the Grand Palais, John Galliano will stage his first ready-to-wear collection — and make his first on-schedule appearance at Paris Fashion Week — as creative director of the recently rechristened Maison Margiela. (Galliano was famously fired from his post at Dior in 2011 after a pair of anti-Semitic outbursts in Paris.) The designer’s extraordinary rise and sudden downfall, precipitated by the pressures of delivering multiple product lines for an international conglomerate — together with the similar trajectory of his contemporary and sometime rival, the late Alexander McQueen — is the subject of the T contributing editor Dana Thomas’s new book, “Gods and Kings” (Penguin Press, $29.95), an occasionally titillating and ultimately poignant read released just in time for the start of one of fashion’s most scrutinized third (or, more accurately, fifth or sixth) acts.

headline: Letter From the Editor: Inequality at the Supreme Court
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: Liberals are winning the battle over civil rights, but conservatives are prevailing on economic inequality, and that may include a key health care case.
lead_paragraph: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshot’s weekly newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

headline: Stuff We Liked
abstract: Interesting links include improvements on a measles graphic and a comparison of Girl Scout cookie variations.
lead_paragraph: Here are a few things that the staff of The Upshot enjoyed on the web this week.

headline: NBC Brings Back Andrew Lack to Lead Its News Division
abstract: Mr. Lack led the division from 1993 to 2001 but is returning to a unit engulfed in turmoil since the crisis involving its news anchor, Brian Williams.
lead_paragraph: NBC Universal reached into its past to chart a new path forward on Friday, hiring Andrew Lack to lead its news division after a series of missteps that culminated with the suspension of Brian Williams last month.

headline: Introducing Motherlode’s New Artist-In-Residence: Abigail Gray Swartz
abstract: Welcome Abigail Gray Swartz to the Artist-in-Residence role on Motherlode.
lead_paragraph: We’re thrilled to welcome Abigail Gray Swartz to the Artist-in-Residence role. She’ll be accompanying essays and posts here with art that’s like an essay in a different format. The longer I look at her work, the more it says. She first appeared in this space illustrating Margaret Gilmour’s essay, “My Friend Has a Son Who Is Autistic.” If you read a little further, you’ll get a sense of how that came about.

headline: Before Starting as a Coach, It Helps to Go Into Training
abstract: The term life coach is fading, as those in the field specialize, receive training and obtain credentials from accreditation bodies.
lead_paragraph: LESLIE YALOF GARFIELD, 54, a professor at Pace Law School, faced an empty nest as her last child headed off to college. Ilona Shinkar, 42, is a former French teacher living in Larchmont, N.Y., with three children at home.

headline: French Court Rules It Has Jurisdiction Over Facebook in Nude Painting Case
abstract: A court says it can rule in a case against Facebook over suspending a user’s account over a link to a documentary on a Courbet painting, “The Origin of the World.”
lead_paragraph: PARIS – A court ruled on Thursday that it had jurisdiction over Facebook in the case of a teacher who sued the company after he was suspended from the social network for posting a picture of a famous nude painting.

headline: Wisconsin Votes to Limit Collection of Fees by Unions
abstract: The State Assembly approved legislation barring unions from requiring workers to pay the equivalent of dues. Gov. Scott Walker has said he will sign the measure.
lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis. — The State Assembly on Friday approved legislation barring unions from requiring workers to pay the equivalent of dues, leaving Wisconsin poised to become the 25th state with what advocates describe as a right-to-work law.

headline: In Boon to Its Stock, Apple Will Replace AT&T in Dow Index
abstract: The step is a reminder of the soaring valuations among consumer-driven technology and social media companies.
lead_paragraph: Apple, the highest-valued company in the world, will be added to the Dow Jones industrial average next month in yet another sign of how popular the computer giant has become for investors.

headline: Standing Till the End
abstract: Ushers who work at Islanders home games are preparing for the team’s move to Barclays Center, which will be its home rink beginning next season.
lead_paragraph: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — Standing at ice level and facing the Islanders’ runway, Mike Artusa smiled broadly and had a handshake or a hug ready for all the familiar faces. And there was a seemingly endless supply of those.

headline: 1915: General Receives Medal
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: General receives French honor in 1915.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A communication from the British General headquarters, dated Thursday [March 4], says: — Sir John French was this afternoon presented by General de Lacroix, late Commander-in-Chief of the French army, with the Military Medal, the highest French military honor obtainable. Sir John French is the only Englishman on whom it has ever been bestowed, and King Albert of Belgium and Grand Duke Nicholas are the only other foreigners.

headline: Ferguson Police Bias Not an Isolated Case, Obama Says
abstract: President Obama said Friday that he thought the pattern of racial discrimination described in a report by the Justice Department about the Ferguson police department is not an isolated example.
lead_paragraph: President Obama on Friday said that he thought the pattern of racial discrimination described in a report by the Justice Department about the Ferguson Police Department was not an isolated example.

headline: The NAIRU Straitjacket and Cromwell’s Rule
abstract: We don’t know how far we are from full employment.
lead_paragraph: Today’s employment report continued the pattern we’ve been seeing for a while. Unemployment is falling, and is now very close to previous estimates of the NAIRU, the unemployment rate at which inflation begins accelerating. But inflation isn’t accelerating; in particular, there is still no hint of wage pressure in the data. So what should the Fed do?

headline: Christian Dior: Fall 2015 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: BP Signs $12 Billion Deal to Develop Natural Gas in Egypt
keywords: ['Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'Natural Gas', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: The deal is a sign that Egypt’s relations with the oil industry might be improving.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In a sign that Egypt’s strained relations with the international oil industry may be improving, BP said on Friday that it had reached an agreement to invest with a partner about $12 billion to develop natural gas resources in the country.

headline: The Below-Zero Lower Bound
abstract: Vaulting back to the past.
lead_paragraph: Further to my earlier post on negative interest rates: here’s what may be a simpler way to think about it. When central banks push interest rates on government debt below zero, the effective lower bound is the return on cash held by people who would otherwise be holding that government debt — not people looking to expand their checking accounts. So the liquidity advantages of bank deposits over cash in a vault are pretty much irrelevant. It’s all about the cost of storage.

headline: At Museo del Prado, Blind Visitors Can Touch Masterpieces
abstract: An exhibition at the Madrid museum includes three-dimensional copies of works for visually impaired patrons to touch.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Guards make sure visitors to the Museo del Prado stay at arm’s length from its masterpieces. But here on a recent morning was José Pedro González running his fingers over one of El Greco’s most famous paintings, “The Nobleman With His Hand on His Chest.” He went back and forth over the nobleman’s eyes, rubbed his beard and eventually reached his hand, tracing the edges of each digit.

headline: Game Over for the Astrodome, ‘Stadium of the Future’
abstract: The stadium was a gargantuan advertisement for the possibilities suggested by American technology, and yet was rendered a relic within decades.

headline: Color-Coded Makeup at Christian Dior
abstract: In a dramatic departure from the thin adhesive strips of pastel eyeliner he sent down the house’s runway last season, Peter Philips created a darker, fuller eye look for fall 2015.
lead_paragraph: Backstage at Christian Dior, Peter Philips created a beauty profile that mirrored the swoops and swirls of color printed on the house’s fall 2015 collection. The creative and image director of Christian Dior Makeup carefully complemented each look with a single shade of eye shadow (deep green, navy, aubergine or brick), which he applied wet, to intensify the pigment, over the socket and up to the orbital bone. The unifying application on each face: four to five coats of mascara and heavy black kohl liner. “We wanted graphic makeup with a little twist,” Philips says. It is indeed a dark departure from the thin adhesive strips of pastel eyeliner he created for the house’s spring 2015 runway.

headline: Saints’ Owner Marches Out of Step With His Heirs’ Expectations
abstract: The future of the Saints and the Pelicans is at stake as their owner, Tom Benson, and his wife of 10 years battle his children, who sued to declare him mentally unfit.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Tom Benson sat at the head of a wooden conference table unruffled in a dark business suit, with a crisp aqua necktie and a handkerchief tucked neatly in his breast pocket. One after another, the top executives who run his two teams — the N.F.L.’s Saints and the N.B.A.’s Pelicans — offered details about how their ad campaigns, ticket sales and digital signboards were doing.

headline: F.D.A. Approves Zarxio, Its First Biosimilar Drug
abstract: The approval paves the way for alternatives to an entire class of complex and costly drugs to go on the market.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration has approved the first so-called biosimilar drug for use in the United States, paving the way for less expensive alternatives to an entire class of complex and costly drugs.

headline: Daniel Von Bargen, Actor in ‘Seinfeld’ and ‘Malcolm in the Middle,’ Dies at 64
abstract: Mr. Von Bargen, who had a long career in film and TV, was perhaps best known for his part as a boss of George Costanza on “Seinfeld.”
lead_paragraph: Daniel Von Bargen, a character actor who played both bumbling and menacing authority figures and was probably best known as George Costanza’s thickheaded boss on “Seinfeld,” died on Sunday in Cincinnati. He was 64.

headline: Finding Equilibrium in Seesawing Libidos (Updated With Podcast)
abstract: A medication leads to a hypersexualized wife, and a husband puffing to keep up. In time, the mismatch subsides, leaving them partners in a bigger way.

abstract: Times critics on “The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel,” “Merchants of Doubt” and “Chappie.”
lead_paragraph: In this video, Times critics share their thoughts on “The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel,” “Merchants of Doubt” and “Chappie.” See all of this week’s reviews.

abstract: Marine One took off on Friday with President Obama onboard, heading to Andrews Air Force Base for a scheduled flight to South Carolina.

headline: A Proper Stew for St. Patrick’s Day
abstract: Corned beef and cabbage is so American. For something that may actually be served on Irish soil, look to a stew with lamb and potatoes.
lead_paragraph: With St. Patrick’s Day just around the corner, you may be thinking about corned beef and cabbage. There’s nothing wrong with it, but that’s Irish-American. For something that may actually be served on Irish soil, have a go at a proper Irish stew.

abstract: This week’s properties include co-ops in the Sutton area, Greenwich Village, Ditmas Park, and a house in Riverdale.

headline: Through It All, Pelosi Keeps House Democrats Moving in One Direction
abstract: Representative Nancy Pelosi demonstrated her lasting authority this week in a Homeland Security vote, and she may be a vital tool for the White House at the end of President Obama’s tenure.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The quarterback Brett Favre has long retired. Cher shut down her most recent tour. Representative Nancy Pelosi — repeatedly written off and derided since her party lost the House in 2010 — powers on.

headline: After a Fire, Learning to Cook Again, One Grilled Cheese at a Time
abstract: I loved to cook. But after the fire, I couldn’t do it for over a year.
lead_paragraph: Four months pregnant, with my 19-month-old son at the kitchen table eating chicken fingers, it happened. I’d been in full-on nesting mode, and no recipe on the Food Network was too big or too small. That night, I was experimenting with Sandra Lee’s corn dogs — a secret guilty pleasure for both my husband and me. Just like Sandra Lee instructed, I filled my pot with oil, and while it was heating up, I put the batter together for the hot dogs.

headline: Selma Hosts Its Own Civil Rights Concert
abstract: The three-hour concert features performances by Rick Ross, Kirk Franklin, Tamar Braxton, Doug E. Fresh — and Vanilla Ice — and will be live-streamed.
lead_paragraph: It has been a big year for Selma, Ala., with the country renewing focus on the city, thanks to an Oscar-nominated film carrying its name, and the celebrations of the 50th anniversary of the civil rights march from Selma to Montgomery, Ala.

headline: Exclusive | 285 Lafayette Street
abstract: A four-bedroom loft in a sought-after prewar condominium conversion is poised to enter the market at $11.5 million.
lead_paragraph: A four-bedroom loft in a sought-after prewar condominium conversion is poised to enter the market at $11.5 million.

headline: Roos Abels Transforms at Dior
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall 2015 Fashion Week in Paris.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall 2015 Fashion Week in Paris. Here, the model Roos Abels before (left) and after (right) makeup by Peter Philips and hair by Guido Palau.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE BURIED GIANT,  by Kazuo Ishiguro. (Knopf, $26.95.) Ishiguro’s exceptional seventh novel, a mixture of fantasy, historical fiction and myth set in a semi-historical medieval England, remains in the mind long after it has been read.

headline: ‘Girl in the Dark: A Memoir,’ by Anna Lyndsey
abstract: A memoir of a debilitating sensitivity to light.
lead_paragraph: A reader trolling the bookstore’s memoir section, sampling passages from random volumes, finally encountering Anna Lyndsey’s melodic, penetrating prose among the drama-heavy movie-of-the-week wannabes, might be excused for any unbecoming public outburst: a fist in the air, say, and a bellow of “Score!” For although “Girl in the Dark” is based on the author’s experience of a startling medical condition — full-body light sensitivity so severe that Lyndsey becomes largely restricted to a stifling blackout room — a spot-check of its paragraphs reveals the quiet, ingenious consciousness of a poet.

headline: Found Fiction
abstract: Is a favorite book from childhood worth tracking down?
lead_paragraph: I grew up in a Massachusetts town in which the recycling and disposal facility was a paragon of Yankee thrift and was restricted to members, like a country club.

headline: ‘The Last Good Paradise,’ by Tatjana Soli
abstract: Tatjana Soli’s jaded characters converge on a South Pacific atoll.
lead_paragraph: Ann and Richard, a married Los Angeles couple, have their own vision of the American dream — he wants to be a big-time restaurateur, she a big-time lawyer — but it’s crumbling before their eyes. Their goal, and that of their peers, was once to be so busy they could say, without irony, “My people will call your people.” Instead, they’re on a treadmill of anxiety. Their professions — and the people around them — have turned fickle. Ann realizes that she hates the law and her regimented life: Unable to become pregnant, she’s being shot up with hormones in between meetings. Richard is struggling even to start a restaurant, let alone keep one running.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: The crime novelist Joanne Fluke, whose “Double Fudge Brownie Murder” is No. 13 on the hardcover fiction list, wrote thrillers in a darker vein before she added desserts to the mix.
lead_paragraph: Death By Chocolate: The crime novelist Joanne Fluke has come up with a winning formula for her best sellers — think of a luscious dessert, then add death. Thus far in Fluke’s series of Hannah Swensen mysteries-with-recipes, in which a small-town Minnesota baker keeps stumbling across corpses, 10 titles have hit the list, including “Cream Puff Murder,” “Cinnamon Roll Murder,” “Blackberry Pie Murder” and the latest, “Double Fudge Brownie Murder,” new at No. 13 in hardcover fiction. (The series has also spawned a best-selling cookbook, “Joanne Fluke’s Lake Eden Cookbook,” that might as well have been called “Saturated Fat Murder.”) Before starting the Hannah Swensen series, Fluke wrote more than 30 thrillers in a darker vein, but she dreamed of striking out in a new direction. “I always wanted to write a cookbook,” she explained in a 2013 interview with a Seattle television station, “and I couldn’t sell the darn thing. So, actually, what happened is, my editor said, ‘Would you like to write cozy mysteries?’ And I said, ‘Can I put recipes in them?’ . . . I decided I would write something kinder, gentler, and use my baking.”

headline: MC Hamilton
abstract: Ron Chernow discusses “Hamilton,” the hip-hop musical based on his acclaimed 2004 biography of Alexander Hamilton.
lead_paragraph: Ron Chernow always knew his acclaimed 2004 biography of Alexander Hamilton would someday be turned into a hip-hop musical. Well, not always, but since 2009, when he first met the composer and actor Lin-Manuel Miranda, whose “Hamilton” has been a smash hit Off Broadway at the Public Theater. (The show will move to Broadway in July.)

headline: Paying Tribute to Thomas Stanley and His ‘Millionaire Next Door’
abstract: Mr. Stanley, who was killed in a recent car accident, wrote a book with William Danko that became a classic in personal finance by showing ordinary people how to accumulate assets.
lead_paragraph: The rich are different from you and me, though maybe not quite like we think they are.

headline: ‘Gods and Kings,’ by Dana Thomas
abstract: The designers Alexander McQueen and John Galliano pushed boundaries.
lead_paragraph: Karl Lagerfeld has a wonderful reply to those who think fashion could use more innovators. No doubt, he says, but in any period only a few individuals are crucial. The 1920s had Chanel and Patou, the ’30s Vionnet and Schiaparelli. The ’40s belonged to Dior. By the ’50s, Chanel was back and her twin engine was the saintly Balenciaga. Genius is rare. It sustains the rest of the industry with ideas, energy and, of course, drama.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: SHOTGUN LOVESONGS,  by Nickolas Butler. (Thomas Dunne/St. Martin’s Griffin, $15.99.) Lifelong bonds are tested in Butler’s big-hearted first novel when four boyhood friends — and the woman who has meant something special in each of their lives — are reunited in middle age in their small Wisconsin hometown. “Butler has written an unmistakably American novel — and a good one,” Jonathan Evison said in the Book Review.

headline: ‘The Tusk That Did the Damage,’ by Tania James
abstract: A rogue bull is one of the narrators of this novel.
lead_paragraph: Tania James’s impressive new novel, “The Tusk That Did the Damage,” brings a sharp and unnerving sensibility to bear on dismal and necessary events. A wild elephant’s post-mortem exam, for instance, finds that a poacher’s bullet has left a “burn hole like a black star” in its body; as officials search for the bullet itself, “they took a saw to the animal’s side, the sound like a zipper going up and down.” Such matter-of-fact yet startling associations make for the kind of unexpected fusions that can be found across these pages.

headline: French Translation
abstract: New books by Dominique Fabre, Romain Puértolas, Denis Thériault and Michel Déon.
lead_paragraph: GUYS LIKE ME

headline: A Racy Silicon Valley Lawsuit, and More Subtle Questions About Sex Discrimination
abstract: Women can find themselves caught in a double standard at work, needing to promote themselves and yet not appear too pushy.
lead_paragraph: A gender discrimination trial is gripping Silicon Valley this week with lurid details about an office affair, a nude photo book and a bathrobe-clad man showing up at a female colleague’s hotel room.

headline: Ben Jealous Considers Run for Maryland Senate Seat
abstract: Ben Jealous, the former president of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and a veteran activist, is considering a run for the U.S. Senate seat in Maryland that Senator Barbara A. Mikulski is retiring from.
lead_paragraph: Benjamin T. Jealous, a former president of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and a veteran activist, is considering a run for the Senate seat in Maryland that Barbara A. Mikulski will be leaving in 2017.

headline: Cutting Out the Meat With Mushrooms
abstract: A roasted mushroom base can be used as a kind of Hamburger Helper in everything from tuna burgers to moussaka.
lead_paragraph: A couple of years ago I gave you a recipe for a roasted mushroom base, a sort of vegetable Hamburger Helper that I had learned to make from Scott Samuels, a Culinary Institute of America chef. Chef Samuels combined it with ground beef to make delicious burgers. It has caught on among food service professionals who want to improve the nutritional profile of their offerings. Now they refer to it as, simply, “The Mix,” and they are keeping mushroom growers very busy.

headline: During Bakery Break-In, Only Recipes Are Taken
abstract: After a recipe theft at Mr Holmes Bakehouse in San Francisco, lines there for cruffins, the West Coast’s answer to New York’s cronut, seemed to grow even longer.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It takes three days to make a cruffin, a muffin-croissant hybrid that is the signature of Ry Stephen, a 28-year-old pastry chef. His shop, Mr Holmes Bakehouse, has been open three months and inspired a wild following, with customers lining up early to buy the ice-cream-cone-shaped cruffins, which reliably sell out before the line is gone.

headline: Albert Maysles, Pioneering Documentarian, Dies at 88
abstract: Mr. Maysles and his brother, David, made notable films like “Gimme Shelter” and “Grey Gardens,” and received a National Medal of Arts in July.
lead_paragraph: Albert Maysles, the award-winning documentarian who, with his brother, David, made intensely talked-about films, including “Grey Gardens” and “Gimme Shelter,” with their American version of cinéma vérité, died Thursday night at his home in Manhattan. He was 88.
