headline: Haitian Griot Is a Postcard From the Caribbean
abstract: The classic Haitian dish of pork cubes simmered in chiles and citrus, then fried, can be hard to forget.
lead_paragraph: “Have you ever had griot?”

headline: Facts & Figures: Vaccines Under Fire
abstract: A new poll has found that Americans are less likely to consider vaccination “extremely important” than they were in 2001.
lead_paragraph: Americans are less likely to say vaccination is “extremely important” than they were in 2001, according to a poll released Friday. They are also much more likely to have heard about disadvantages of vaccines — 30 percent said they’d heard “a great deal” about such disadvantages, up from 15 percent in 2001.

headline: Down in North Carolina, One Family Makes Maple Syrup in Its Own Backyard
abstract: At the mountainside Waterfall Farm in the northwest region of the state, indigenous trees are tapped, and the sap is stewed in a handmade sugarhouse.
lead_paragraph: At the mountainside Waterfall Farm in the northwest region of the state, indigenous trees are tapped, and the sap is stewed in a handmade sugarhouse.

headline: Troubleshooting Android in Safe Mode
abstract: Third-party apps and recent operating system updates are often the cause; starting the phone in Safe Mode can help narrow down the search for a culprit.
lead_paragraph: Q. My Android phone just started freezing and crashing a few days ago. What would cause it to do so?

headline: Putin Takes a Pay Cut, as Does Most of the Kremlin
keywords: ['Wages and Salaries', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: With ordinary Russians grumbling about the sharp rise in food prices, the president announced that he and other officials will take a 10 percent cut in pay.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — With ordinary Russians grumbling about the sharp rise in food prices, President Vladimir V. Putin made a populist move on Friday, announcing that he and almost everyone who works for him will take a 10 percent cut in pay.

headline: Whiting Awards Celebrate 30 Years With 10 Winning Writers
keywords: ['Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: This year’s winners include the playwrights Lucas Hnath and Anne Washburn.
lead_paragraph: The winners of the 2015 Whiting Awards were announced on Thursday night at the New-York Historical Society. Each of the 10 chosen writers receives a cash award of $50,000. The awards are “based on early accomplishment and the promise of great work to come,” according to the Whiting Foundation.

headline: In One Case, State Dept. Criticized Use of Personal Email
abstract: The case of an ousted ambassador to Kenya who served the State Department while Hillary Rodham Clinton was the Secretary of State has gained fresh attention in light of the controversy surrounding her exclusive use of a personal email account for government business.
lead_paragraph: The case of an ousted ambassador to Kenya who served while Hillary Rodham Clinton led the State Department has gained fresh attention in light of the controversy surrounding reports that she exclusively used a personal email account for government business.

headline: Syracuse Basketball and Coach Jim Boeheim Hit Hard by N.C.A.A.
abstract: A startling report says the university’s athletic department violated rules for more than a decade, and the severe punishment includes suspending Boeheim, the men’s basketball coach, for nine games.
lead_paragraph: Members of the athletic staff forged classwork. Players were handed cash for appearances as volunteers. Others were allowed to skirt the university’s drug policy without consequence.

headline: What I Love | Gilbert Gottfried
abstract: The gravel-voiced comedian and actor shares a recently decorated Chelsea loft with his wife, Dara, and their two children.
lead_paragraph: The gravel-voiced comedian and actor shares a recently decorated Chelsea loft with his wife, Dara, and their two children.

headline: Alec Baldwin Selected to Be Mayor of New York on HBO
abstract: Mr. Baldwin is to star as the city’s mayor in an untitled HBO series, his first TV project since the end of “30 Rock.”
lead_paragraph: Several years ago, the actor Alec Baldwin told The New York Times that he was interested in being mayor of New York City. “I am someone who is fully prepared for the fact that I could go into this and do it and completely have my ass kicked,” he said at the time of the prospect of running for office. “I could throw a party and no one could come. And it would be this staggering lesson for me.”

headline: Margherita Missoni Amos’s New Children’s Wear: Meant for Mixing and Matching and Playing Dress-Up
abstract: The granddaughter of Ottavio and Rosita introduces her first line outside the family’s brand.
lead_paragraph: For a little kid, playing dress-up can be one of the most thrilling forms of discovery. And for Margherita Missoni Amos, of one of fashion’s most storied families (she’s the granddaughter of Ottavio and Rosita), playing dress-up has always been a way of life. It’s no surprise, then, that the 32-year-old mom is launching her own children’s collection inspired by the possibilities of fun that exist in wearing clothes. Simply called Margherita, her first venture outside of the Missoni label was conceived for baby boys and girls ages 0-2, and for girls up to age 7. And all the pieces — washed-linen dresses with bright Balinese-batik inspired prints, color-blocked sweaters, seersucker striped tees ($30-$80) — are meant to be mixed and matched. “I want children to express their creativity through choosing their own clothes,” Missoni Amos explains. “That’s why I didn’t create any perfect matching outfits.”

headline: Madonna is Still Madonna On ‘Rebel Heart’
abstract: Jon Pareles and Ben Ratliff discuss “Rebel Heart,” the new album by Madonna.
lead_paragraph: Jon Pareles and Ben Ratliff discuss “Rebel Heart,” the new album by Madonna.

headline: A Prediction Market for Inflation, or Deflation
abstract: Falling prices and economic stagnation — what Japan has endured — are still seen as unlikely in the U.S., but market signals suggest cause for concern.
lead_paragraph: Something unusual is happening to prices right now: They are falling.

headline: At Dior, Lanvin and Rick Owens: The Power Woman in Winter
abstract: The fall 2015 collections stressed strong clothes for dynamic women.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — For a while there it looked as if the hair was going to overshadow the clothes.

headline: Views at One57 for $29,329,100
abstract: A three-bedroom three-and-a-half-bath apartment on the 65th floor of One57 was the sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: A three-bedroom three-and-a-half-bath apartment on the 65th floor of One57, the glassy-blue skyscraper where the priciest transaction for a single residence in New York City recently took place, sold for $29,329,100 and was the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: MoMA to Host Wikipedia Editing Marathon, to Improve Coverage of Women in the Arts
abstract: The group Art + Feminism is organizing its second edit-a-thon to address gender imbalance on Saturday, with tutorials at the Museum of Modern Art and satellite sessions around the world.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, in conjunction with International Women’s Day, the group Art + Feminism will be hosting its second international edit-a-thon, with the goal of improving Wikipedia’s coverage of women and the arts and encouraging more women to contribute to the online encyclopedia.

headline: Los Angeles Police Leader Makes Outreach to Muslims His Mission
abstract: In a 33-year career, Deputy Chief Michael Downing has forged bonds both durable and contentious between the police force and minority groups.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — On a damp and dreary Saturday two months ago, several hundred mourners gathered outside City Hall here for a memorial service honoring Dr. Maher Hathout. Born in Egypt and trained as a cardiologist, Dr. Hathout, 79, had devoted decades to espousing a moderate version of Islam and reaching across denominational lines to other faiths.

headline: A Casualty of a Frigid New York Winter: Outdoor School Recess
abstract: New York City’s Education Department discourages schools from taking children outside if certain temperature, ice and other metrics are met, but polices in many other cold weather cities make the guidelines seem overcautious.
lead_paragraph: Midmorning on Tuesday, several hours before snow would return in a ritual that now seems as consistent as receiving the mail, temperatures in New York were cold but not abusive. It was the kind of day, unlike so many others recently, in which forgetting your gloves did not necessarily mean you would feel as if you needed treatment at an urgent-care clinic before you got to work. And yet with the temperature in the 20s, under skies vaguely the color of moleskin, it was neither objectively comfortable nor pleasant.

headline: Verbatim: Jeb Bush Says He’s Baffled by Clinton Emails
abstract: Jeb Bush on Hillary Rodham Clinton’s use of personal email.
lead_paragraph: — Jeb Bush, speaking to an Iowa radio station about Hillary Rodham Clinton’s use of a private email account.

headline: Rare Mark Rothko Painting Leads Christie’s New York Auction
abstract: “No. 36 (Black Stripe),” which was painted in 1958, a banner year for the artist, could exceed the artist’s auction record of $87 million.
lead_paragraph: Mark Rothko once said that his formula for a good painting included a dollop of hope – “10 percent to make the tragic concept more endurable.” When bidders gather on May 13 at Christie’s to do battle for the next big Rothko to come to auction – a blazing red and black work, “No. 36 (Black Stripe),” painted in 1958, a banner year for the artist – they will have to bring a lot more than hope.

headline: In Two Worlds
abstract: For young Muslims in New York, it is sometimes a struggle to balance religion and middle school.
lead_paragraph: For young Muslims in New York, it is sometimes a struggle to balance religion and middle school.

headline: Balancing Islam and Middle School in Queens
abstract: By most measures, New York is a religiously tolerant place, but public school, especially middle school, can be a testing ground for young Muslims.
lead_paragraph: Somewhere between stepping off the school bus and climbing into the go-kart, Sandra Ibrahim, 14, took off her pink hijab. She was on a trip to an indoor amusement park in New Rochelle, N.Y., with her Islamic weekend school, surrounded by other Muslim children, parents and teachers. She knew the adults would like her to keep the head scarf on. But there she was, zooming along the track, her dark brown ponytail swinging freely behind her.

headline: N.C.A.A. Infractions Committee's Report on Syracuse
abstract: The N.C.A.A. issued a 94-page report Friday on violations committed by the Syracuse athletic department.
lead_paragraph: The N.C.A.A. issued a 94-page report Friday on violations committed by the Syracuse athletic department.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Erik Larson’s ‘Dead Wake’
abstract: This week, Erik Larson talks about “Dead Wake: The Last Crossing of the Lusitania”; Alexandra Alter has news from the literary world; Orlando Patterson discusses two new books by black conservatives, “Please Stop Helping Us” and “Shame”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Erik Larson talks about “Dead Wake: The Last Crossing of the Lusitania”; Alexandra Alter has news from the literary world; Orlando Patterson discusses two new books by black conservatives, “Please Stop Helping Us” and “Shame”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Robert Christgau’s ‘Going Into the City’
abstract: The rock critic Robert Christgau calls himself an “opinionated bigmouth.”
lead_paragraph: Since nobody asked, what’s my favorite piece of writing by Robert Christgau? His elegant 17-word assessment of the Beatles’ “Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band” approaches pure poetry, and his takedowns of sitting ducks like Emerson, Lake and Palmer’s “Trilogy” and Cybill Shepherd’s “Cybill Does It . . . to Cole Porter” are delectable morsels of schadenfreude. But nothing delighted me quite like the criteria he provided for the letter grades that accompanied his nugget-size record reviews in his long-running Consumer Guide feature.

headline: ‘To Explain the World,’ by Steven Weinberg
abstract: A physicist surveys the misguided and evolving methods used to decipher scientific phenomena.
lead_paragraph: Steven Weinberg doesn’t think much of Plato or Pythagoras. Nor does he hold René Descartes or Francis Bacon in ­especially high regard. But in his new book on the origins of science, “To Explain the World,” Weinberg casts particular aspersions on science historians themselves.

headline: Nina Stibbe’s ‘Man at the Helm’
abstract: Two sisters living in an English village seek out suitors for their single parent in this comic novel.
lead_paragraph: Nina Stibbe: “I’m trying to write a novel. . . . Was just about to show AB a little synopsis and a few pages. . . . ”

headline: ‘There’s Something I Want You to Do,’ by Charles Baxter
abstract: Charles Baxter’s stories hinge on “request moments,” when taking action involves a suggestion or a demand.
lead_paragraph: Some of our sturdiest atheists now allow that those inexplicable, ineffable, somehow enlarging experiences traditionally classed as religious also happen to people who adhere to no particular doctrine, lack acquaintance with the theologians and ­reject all deities.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Erik Larson’s ‘Dead Wake’
abstract: This week, Erik Larson and Orlando Patterson.
lead_paragraph: This week, Erik Larson and Orlando Patterson.

headline: Madonna Is Still Madonna on ‘Rebel Heart’
abstract: Jon Pareles and Ben Ratliff discuss “Rebel Heart,” the new album by Madonna.
lead_paragraph: Madonna’s new record, “Rebel Heart,” is the full version of the album that was partly leaked in work-tape form last December. It’s a résumé of power and influence: a flex-rospective. In songs like “Veni Vidi Vici” she’s essentially reminding you who she is. (Literally so, in the case of “Bitch I’m Madonna.”)

headline: ISIS Bulldozing of Ancient Nimrud Site in Iraq Stirs Outrage
abstract: Archaeologists despaired that the Islamic State aimed to systematically destroy the relics at a wellspring of civilization.
lead_paragraph: News that Islamic State fighters had bulldozed and vandalized the ancient city of Nimrud in northern Iraq provoked outrage on Friday, as archaeologists despaired that the militant group was systematically destroying priceless antiquities in a wellspring of civilization.

headline: At the Independent Fair, Art Not Quite on the Margin
abstract: The Armory Week satellite offers a trim, well-curated selection of up-and-coming and under-the-radar artists and galleries.
lead_paragraph: The Armory Week satellite offers a trim, well-curated selection of up-and-coming and under-the-radar artists and galleries.

headline: Off Court, Red Storm’s Fiercest Rebounder Is Anything But
abstract: Amber Thompson’s teammates describe her as painfully reserved, but on the court she is one of the nation’s most aggressive rebounders, ranking 17th with 11.1 a game.
lead_paragraph: When Amber Thompson arrived at St. John’s four years ago as the recipient of a basketball scholarship, her body language was not promising. She would hold her hand in front of her face when she spoke. She would look away from others to avoid eye contact. She was so painfully reserved it raised questions about her ability to assert herself on the court.

headline: Revisiting Selma
abstract: Recollections from those who took part in the march for freedom.
lead_paragraph: Recollections from those who took part in the march for freedom.

headline: NASA’s Dawn Probe Begins Orbiting Dwarf Planet Ceres
abstract: The spacecraft, launched in 2007, is now circling Ceres in the asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter.
lead_paragraph: NASA’s Dawn spacecraft entered orbit around the asteroid Ceres on Friday morning at an altitude of just under 38,000 miles. Currently, the spacecraft is above the night side of Ceres, limiting the amount of information that can be gathered.

headline: Apple’s Entry Will Help an Antiquated Dow Catch Up
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Dow Jones Stock Average', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index", 'Smartphones']
abstract: The Dow dates from a computer-free era when working out the average of 30 stock prices counted as added value. Including Apple in the index was overdue.
lead_paragraph: Apple’s entry into the Dow Jones industrial average is a bit like polishing an antique. The average share price of 30 stocks selected by committee will finally include the world’s biggest company in place of AT&T. It’s an overdue move for an outdated yardstick — one that, like landlines and checkbooks, lives on.

headline: C.I.A. to Be Overhauled to Fight Modern Threats
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism']
abstract: The C.I.A. director, John O. Brennan, said the restructuring of the 67-year-old agency would improve its success against modern global threats.
lead_paragraph: LANGLEY, Va. — John O. Brennan, director of the Central Intelligence Agency, is planning to reassign thousands of undercover spies and intelligence analysts into new departments as part of a restructuring of the 67-year-old agency, a move he said would make it more successful against modern threats and crises.

headline: Earning the Trust of Afghan Women: Reporter’s Notebook
abstract: To write the first piece in a series, Alissa J. Rubin had to overcome cultural obstacles to get as close as possible to the day-to-day life of Afghan policewomen.
lead_paragraph: In a March 1 article, Alissa J. Rubin, the Paris bureau chief, wrote about Afghan policewomen and their struggle against culture. The article was the first in a series that examined the legacy of efforts to help Afghan women and girls.

headline: Short Circuits Reported in Mars Rover’s Drilling Arm
abstract: NASA engineers are diagnosing an electrical problem on the Curiosity Mars rover, which may limit the drilling of rocks.
lead_paragraph: The Mars rover Curiosity appears to be suffering intermittent short circuits in its robotic arm, which could limit its drilling of rocks, NASA said on Friday.

headline: Why Not Retire the Circus Elephants Now?
abstract: These magnificent creatures shouldn’t have to spend three more years on the road, wearing costumes and performing stunts.
lead_paragraph: If the welfare of elephants were truly its only concern, the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus would stop using them in performances now, and put them on a train to sunny Florida, where they could enjoy a comfortable retirement. Instead, as The Associated Press reported Thursday, its 13 wrinkly troupers will be touring the country, doing lumbering tricks in costume for paying customers, until 2018. Then they will be sent to the company’s park near Polk City, Fla., and perform no more.

headline: Menendez Is to Face Corruption Charges, U.S. Official Says
abstract: The Justice Department expects to charge Senator Robert Menendez, a New Jersey Democrat, in an inquiry that has focused on his ties to a Florida eye doctor, an official said.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department is preparing to file corruption charges against Senator Robert Menendez, a scrappy 61-year-old veteran of New Jersey politics, after a two-year investigation into allegations that he accepted gifts and lavish vacations in exchange for political favors for a longtime friend and political benefactor.

headline: Matt Harvey Has Can’t-Miss Outing in Must-See Return to Mound
abstract: Harvey, in his first competitive game since Tommy John surgery, struck out three batters in a spring training game against the Detroit Tigers.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Mets fans started applauding Matt Harvey as he left the bullpen Friday afternoon, before he threw a single pitch. The whole way, as Harvey made his way toward the dugout, fans stood and cheered him as he passed.

headline: Millennials on the Homeownership Path
abstract: While college debt continues to dog this generation, several indicators suggest a widening path to homeownership in the next few years.
lead_paragraph: Besieged by the recession and buried in student loan debt, the so-called millennials, born from the early ’80s through the late ’90s, have largely lacked the financial wherewithal to buy their own homes. Even 30-year-olds were as likely to be stuck in their childhood bedrooms as they were to own their own place as of 2013, according to a recent report from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

headline: Ontario’s Beer Bottleneck Is Under Siege by Brewers and Buyers
keywords: ['Beer', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Retailers, beer makers and the provincial government are increasingly skeptical of the longstanding retail system for beer sales.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Brewers Retail has sold beer pretty much the same way since it opened 88 years ago.

headline: The New Jobs Report Shows Janet Yellen’s Quandary in a Nutshell
keywords: ['Interest Rates', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Some numbers suggest the Fed should raise interest rates, but wages are still stagnant, and the number of people in the labor force just shrank.
lead_paragraph: The biggest decision that Janet Yellen has faced in her year-old Federal Reserve chairmanship was laid bare in a single report on the domestic job market released Friday.

headline: China Blocks Web Access to ‘Under the Dome’ Documentary on Pollution
abstract: “Under the Dome” had hundreds of millions of views on Chinese websites within days of its release, more than any other video in recent years, but websites were promptly ordered to delete it.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — “Under the Dome,” a searing documentary about China’s catastrophic air pollution, had hundreds of millions of views on Chinese websites within days of its release one week ago.

headline: The Osprey’s Springtime Return to New York
abstract: The annual arrival in places like the Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge of these large, lanky hawks is a sure sign of spring.
lead_paragraph: Science may have branded the exact hour and minute of Earth’s entry into spring’s cosmic alignment (March 20 at 6:45 p.m. this year), but many prefer more personal markers of the coming season. Whether you find yourself staring at the pallid face of the full moon; listening to the first cold, unmusical trills of frogs; or considering March’s swelling tree buds, it is comforting to discover the earthly evidence of what is clearly ancient magic. We are still connected to the timeless.

headline: CaixaBank of Spain Pushes Ahead With Offer for Portuguese Bank BPI
abstract: The Spanish bank said on Friday that it had no intention of sweetening its bid, even though BPI’s board rejected it a day earlier.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — CaixaBank of Spain said on Friday that it would push ahead with a takeover bid for the Portuguese bank BPI, even after BPI’s board rejected its offer of about 1.08 billion euros and one of BPI’s largest investors urged it to consider another merger plan.

headline: “Mommy, Will You Marry Us?”
abstract: Lori Cimino, left, and Julie Durden, right, were married Feb. 21 in a group same-sex ceremony at the James Royal Palm Hotel in Miami Beach.
lead_paragraph: Lori Cimino, left, and Julie Durden, right, were married Feb. 21 in a group same-sex ceremony at the James Royal Palm Hotel in Miami Beach.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: Thinner Solved!
abstract: Readers solve the case of a middle-aged woman with arthritis who developed a wasting illness after what looked like a simple cold.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday we challenged Well readers to solve the case of a middle-aged woman with arthritis who developed a wasting illness after what looked like a simple cold. Her rheumatologist was worried that the immune suppressing medications the patient took to treat her joint disease had caused the new illness. More than 300 of you took on the challenge, and 17 of you correctly identified this rarity. The correct diagnosis is …

headline: A Modern Marriage With Multiple Parts
abstract: Lori Cimino and Julie Durden shared a great deal as work colleagues. That was the beginning of a relationship.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in Miami, Lori Cimino described herself as, “stubborn and bratty” and someone who “dug my heels into whatever it was I thought I wanted.”

headline: Meet the Margiela and Louis Vuitton Alum Who Staged Paris Fashion Week’s Buzziest Show So Far
abstract: Vetements is a three-season-old label headed up by the Georgian-born, Paris-based designer Demna Gvasalia.
lead_paragraph: A mob scene gathered outside of the seedy Paris gay club Le Dépot last night, awaiting entry to Vetements’ fall/winter 2015 show. Inside, major critics and major stars — Kanye West and Jared Leto among them — were on hand to witness the Vetements creative director Demna Gvasalia’s third collection. Gvasalia, a Georgian-born, Paris-based designer, learned his skills at the Royal Academy of Fine Arts in Antwerp and honed his craft at Maison Martin Margiela and Louis Vuitton. After becoming frustrated with the business model of designers keeping established fashion houses afloat, Gvasalia stepped out on his own, making his own rules on the way.

headline: Jets Will Acquire Brandon Marshall and Re-Sign David Harris
abstract: In addition to adding Marshall, a tall and talented receiver, the Jets also signed their most important free agent, middle linebacker David Harris.
lead_paragraph: It will take far more than one bold move, one major trade and one critical re-signing for the Jets to contend again. But after an off-season of sweeping change throughout the organization, the Jets’ march toward respectability continued Friday with the biggest personnel decisions made so far by the team’s new general manager, Mike Maccagnan.

headline: Black Comedians in South Africa Put Power in the Punch Lines
abstract: A thriving comedy scene is provocatively stretching the limits of what can be laughed at in the post-apartheid era.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — It was a warm Friday morning in Braamfontein, a hip neighborhood here. Inside an airy loft with views of the Nelson Mandela Bridge, a young television crew was assembled around a conference table, in heated debate about the coming week’s broadcast.

headline: Paul Taylor, at 84, Has a New Mission With American Modern Dance
abstract: Mr. Taylor hopes the new version of his company will be a home for American modern dance, presenting masterworks along with pieces by a new generation of choreographers.
lead_paragraph: So, how often does Paul Taylor attend dance performances?

headline: Murry Sidlin’s ‘Defiant Requiem’ Returns to Avery Fisher Hall
abstract: A production that commemorates and partly re-enacts 16 makeshift performances of Verdi’s Requiem by a chorus of prisoners at the concentration camp at Terezin.
lead_paragraph: Can there be more than one way to think and feel about “Defiant Requiem,” the concert-drama based on musical activity in the Nazi concentration camp at Terezin during the Holocaust, conceived by the conductor Murry Sidlin? On the surface, at least, the production seems to represent only good — noble intentions, spiritual uplift and redemption — and it unquestionably holds profound meaning for many who are connected with it or have witnessed it.

headline: 50 Years On, Association for Advancement of Creative Musicians Influences Jazz
abstract: An engine of experimental music remains a sustaining avant-garde, with a value system that has gradually altered the fabric of the jazz mainstream.
lead_paragraph: Muhal Richard Abrams, the restlessly inventive pianist and composer, is a next-step thinker, not the type to rhapsodize about the past. But he has lately found cause to reflect on a time, 50 years ago on the South Side of Chicago, when he began to mobilize his peers in pursuit of originality and self-determination, ending up with a collective called the Association for the Advancement of Creative Musicians.

headline: Germany Sets Gender Quota in Boardrooms
abstract: Germany passed a law Friday that requires some of Europe’s biggest companies to give 30 percent of supervisory seats to women beginning next year.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Germany on Friday became the latest and most significant country so far to commit to improving the representation of women on corporate boards, passing a law that requires some of Europe’s biggest companies to give 30 percent of supervisory seats to women beginning next year.

headline: Heems Talks About ‘Eat Pray Thug’
abstract: This Indian-American rapper discusses his first solo album, “Eat Pray Thug,” which touches on rap, race and dualities.
lead_paragraph: Himanshu Suri, the musician and artist known as Heems, is an operator across worlds that may seem, at first, incompatible.

headline: Maison Margiela: Fall 2015 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: A Makeover, With Monsters
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: The gravel-voiced actor Gilbert Gottfried and his wife, Dara, share a recently redecorated Chelsea loft.
lead_paragraph: Gilbert Gottfried doesn’t remember his parents ever owning furniture that matched. Thus, as a child growing up in Brooklyn, he found it strange to visit people whose sofa had even a nodding acquaintance with their easy chair or lounger. When the gravel-voiced comedian and actor was old enough to move to his own place, a two-bedroom rental in Chelsea, he outfitted it with a motley assortment of curbside castoffs.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Undercover Fall/Winter 2015
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Paris Fashion Week', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

headline: In Two Worlds
abstract: For young Muslim in New York, it is sometimes a struggle to balance religion and middle school.
lead_paragraph: For young Muslim in New York, it is sometimes a struggle to balance religion and middle school.

headline: Out of a Struggle With Infertility, Success
abstract: After marrying in 2009, Ariella Perlman and Robert Johnson struggled with his diagnosis of infertility but they persevered and now have twin boys.
lead_paragraph: Fourteen years ago, when Robert Johnson, now 31, donned his navy blue trumpet jacket, he never thought that getting outfitted like a “screaming” nerd would attract anything other than an acceptance to the college of his choice, let alone a wife. The circle of young instrumentalists was small and exclusive, so meeting someone new was rare: Everyone just knew one another.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Undercover Fall/Winter 2015
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Russ McClintock.

headline: An Old Friend Comes Calling
abstract: The venerable saloon, where Auden and Ginsberg drank, is back.
lead_paragraph: New York City is suffering from dive-bar-collapse disorder, with old gin mills either disappearing (Jackie’s Fifth Amendment, Blarney Cove), forced to move (Subway Inn) or sanitized beyond recognition (Mars Bar).

headline: Menendez and Melgen, Florida Eye Doctor, Have a Long History
abstract: Senator Robert Menendez is expected to face federal corruption charges related to his relationship with Dr. Salomon E. Melgen, a Florida eye doctor who has been his longtime political benefactor.
lead_paragraph: Senator Robert Menendez, Democrat of New Jersey, is expected to face federal corruption charges related to his relationship with Dr. Salomon E. Melgen, a Florida eye doctor who has been his longtime political benefactor.

headline: Home Sales Around the New York Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: The Little Hotel That Couldn’t
abstract: Originating as a carriage house in 1799, the building that now houses the Mount Vernon Hotel Museum & Garden on the Upper East Side later served as a country hotel, and then had turns as a private home and antiques showroom.
lead_paragraph: Pinched between behemoth buildings on East 61st Street and within earshot of the Queensboro Bridge’s stampeding roar, and most easily spied by looking down from the Roosevelt Island tram, is the Mount Vernon Hotel Museum & Garden, a fashionable resort in the era of Andrew Jackson.

headline: Balenciaga: Fall 2015 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Deaths Reported in Syria of Top Figures in Group Affiliated With Al Qaeda
abstract: The deaths of so many top figures, if confirmed, would be a blow to the affiliate of Al Qaeda, one of the strongest insurgent factions in Syria’s civil war.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A loyalist of Osama bin Laden who trained fighters to battle American troops in Iraq and became a commander of Al Qaeda’s affiliate in Syria was killed there in the last week along with three fellow leaders, according to Syrian insurgents and a monitoring organization.

headline: Hampton Creek, Maker of Plant-Based Protein Foods, Signs Distribution Deal With Foodbuy
abstract: Foodbuy, the procurement unit of Compass Group, has begun selling Hampton’s Just Cookies and will soon add Just Mayo, both made without eggs.
lead_paragraph: Hampton Creek, the upstart maker of foods that incorporate plant proteins instead of eggs, has signed a deal that will significantly increase distribution of its products.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Erik Larson’s ‘Dead Wake’
abstract: Mr. Larson discusses his new book about the Lusitania, and Orlando Patterson talks about two new books by black conservatives.
lead_paragraph: In The New York Times Book Review, Hampton Sides reviews Erik Larson’s “Dead Wake: The Last Crossing of the Lusitania.” Mr. Sides writes:

headline: At the Independent Fair, Art Not Quite on the Margin
abstract: The Armory Week satellite offers a trim, well-curated selection of up-and-coming and under-the-radar artists and galleries.
lead_paragraph: New York is literally a flurry. As yet another fresh blast of snow blankets the city, the art set has descended upon Manhattan for the whirlwind series of art fairs collectively known as Armory Week. As part of the lineup, the Independent fair, entering its sixth year, has once again set up camp in the former Dia exhibition space in West Chelsea. Compared to the vast pier complex housing the Armory Show itself, organizers of the Independent have opted to remain in the decidedly smaller location, featuring a trim and well-curated selection of 50 galleries — a welcome amuse-bouche to what can otherwise seem like a glut of exhibitors.

headline: Lupita’s Dress Returns, Left Sharknado and Gaultier at 7-Eleven
abstract: Plus, “difficult” Madge, Kim Kardashian and Jared Leto’s dos and more from the week in style.
lead_paragraph: All the week’s fashion news that’s fit to reprint.

headline: La amistad de los animales
abstract: Videos de parejas de animales inverosímiles se han vuelto tan comunes que están despertando el interés de algunos científicos.
lead_paragraph: Videos de parejas de animales inverosímiles se han vuelto tan comunes que están despertando el interés de algunos científicos.

headline: Investigator Admits Guilt in Hiring of a Hacker
abstract: A private investigator in New York has pleaded guilty to hiring a hacker to help with his investigation.
lead_paragraph: A private investigator who has done work for small New York City law firms that specialize in personal injury and medical malpractice litigation pleaded guilty on Friday in federal court in Manhattan to one charge of conspiracy in hiring a hacker to help with his investigation.

headline: Urging Persistence on Racial Gains, Obama Recalls Sacrifice in Selma
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: The president, speaking at a historically black school in Columbia, S.C., said that Ferguson was “not just a one-time thing.” He also spoke of the courage of protesters in Selma, Ala., 50 years ago.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C. — For the nation’s first African-American president, it was a week of two documents that told the story of a country still grappling with its own history.

headline: What a College Stunt Says About Higher Education Today
abstract: One man went to class at top colleges without actually enrolling or getting a degree. The payoff: “social capital.”
lead_paragraph: In an age rife with “disruptions” to the higher education system, one man claims to have employed an appealingly simple one: Just show up on campus, and never actually enroll.

headline: Families of Flight 370 Victims Fear Silence as World Moves On
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Malaysia Airlines Flight 370']
abstract: Relatives of those who were on Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 have spent the past year in a limbo of grief, anger and hope. But to them, the fact that the world may have moved on is worse.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Most of the time, Ghyslain Wattrelos believes that his wife and two of his three children are dead.

headline: U.S. Constricts Snake Trade, But Boa Wriggles Free
abstract: The boa constrictor is already too widely distributed to restrict under new snake-trade rules.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service today extended trade and import bans to four species of constricting snakes that can devastate native wildlife, but the agency dropped the boa constrictor from consideration because it is already so widely reared and kept as a pet.

headline: Sleek Sideburns and Debutante-Style Buns at Balenciaga

headline: Klimt Work Should Remain in Austria, Panel Says
abstract: Austria’s Art Restitution Advisory Board recommended that “Beethoven Frieze” should remain the property of the government despite claims by heirs of Erich Lederer, who had sold the work in 1972.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Gustav Klimt’s gold leaf and mother-of-pearl masterpiece, the “Beethoven Frieze,” should remain in Austria, a government panel said in rejecting a claim that its Jewish former owner had been forced to sell it. Austria’s Art Restitution Advisory Board “recommended unanimously” that the 112-foot-long work remain in possession of the government, which bought it from Erich Lederer in 1972.

headline: At D’Amico Coffee Roasters, Old and New Brooklyn Meet
abstract: Old-timers at D’Amico’s, a Carroll Gardens coffee shop, are happy to chat with the younger customers bearing computers or strollers.
lead_paragraph: Late on a Saturday morning, a small flock of retired longshoremen settled around the low tables of D’Amico’s. A young woman with earbuds sat focused on her laptop as the old-timers took their seats around her, boxing her into a corner next to an enormous, gleaming coffee roaster. The old-timers bickered and dissected the day’s tabloids, cheerfully criticizing one another in vanishing Brooklyn vernacular. Occasionally, Frank or Tony would nudge the young woman for an opinion: “Is this guy nuts or what?” She would momentarily remove an earbud and nod, then go back online. Augie, a neighborhood electrician, punctuated the din with the stamping of coffee bags.

headline: For Zhang Huang, Love’s Battlefield Is a Ming Dynasty Temple
abstract: The performance artist’s staging of the 18th-century Handel opera “Semele” at the Brooklyn Academy of Music incorporates many traditional Chinese and Buddhist elements.
lead_paragraph: Retold throughout Greek and Roman antiquity, the myth of Semele, consort to Jove and mother of Bacchus, has come to symbolize the amorous heights of love as well as the precipitous fall that so often follows; it’s a classic tale of love betrothed and betrayed, divine dalliance and mortal downfall. Indeed, for the contemporary Chinese artist Zhang Huan, whose restaging of Handel’s 18th-century operatic version of the myth opens for its first U.S. run this week at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the constant of any opera “is found in the attention it pays to the human desire.” Speaking via an interpreter from his Shanghai studio a few days before the curtain was set to raise, Zhang freely admitted that he initially lacked interest in opera as an art form. Known for large-scale bronze statues of disembodied Buddhas and performance pieces entailing body suits made of raw meat, Zhang’s appointment to direct Handel’s opera in 2009, for the Brussels-based opera house La Monnaie, raised the eyes of both opera and art-world aficionados. “I had hoped people not only saw an opera, but also performance art,” Zhang says. “‘Semele,'” he quickly adds, “was my very first opera, and it will be my very last.”

headline: State of Change
abstract: Culture and behavior change slowly, so it’s not as though anyone is going to topple over from the force of the new ideas in T’s new Men’s Style issue, but the currents are strong nonetheless.
lead_paragraph: As we were organizing this issue, we were struck — and rather hard — by the myriad confounding ideas and influences percolating right now in the world of men’s fashion and style. It’s as if a tectonic shift is happening beneath us — a bit destabilizing but full of possibility. Culture and behavior change slowly, so it’s not as though anyone is going to topple over from the force of the new ideas here, but the currents are strong nonetheless.

headline: Bagels, Basketball, Banchan and Burrata
abstract: The chef and entrepreneur Dale Talde, a 36-year-old former “Top Chef” contestant who is “never not doing work,” plans to cater his own wedding.
lead_paragraph: As co-owner of three restaurants in Brooklyn (Talde, Pork Slope and Thistle Hill Tavern) and two recently opened in Jersey City (Talde Jersey City and Carrino Provisions), the chef and entrepreneur Dale Talde spends much of his time putting out fires: a no-show cook, an inadequate bread delivery, the perpetual turnover of employees. Now Mr. Talde, a 36-year-old former “Top Chef” contestant, has a new project. He is catering his own wedding. In October, he will marry Agnes Chung, 28, a reporter for NY1, in the Hudson Valley. The couple lives in Downtown Brooklyn.

headline: An Argument for Hearing a Work With a Nazi Reference
abstract: The issue of musical quotation is nothing new, and the “Horst Wessel” song has been used before as commentary in music.
lead_paragraph: The Germans who invaded the Soviet Union in 1941 are represented in Shostakovich’s “Leningrad” Symphony by an unexpectedly bright tune that hardens into a bitter march. Recent Metropolitan Opera audiences may recognize it from Lehar’s operetta “The Merry Widow” as an echo of the melody to which Count Danilo sings “I’m off to Chez Maxim.”

headline: Inside T’s Spring Men’s Style Issue
abstract: From our cover subject, the legendary Jean-Michel Basquiat, to the legend-in-the-making Shayne Oliver of Hood by Air, our latest issue celebrates men who embrace contradiction.
lead_paragraph: T’s latest issue examines the many conflicting ideas at play in men’s fashion and style today. No one embraced those contradictions more than our cover subject, the legendary Jean-Michel Basquiat: We peek inside his closely guarded notebooks and shine a light on the painter as you’ve never seen him before. Shayne Oliver, the Hood by Air designer who likely would have rolled in Basquiat’s circle had he been born 20 years earlier, shares with us the many diverse influences behind his gender-fluid street wear. In an essay focusing on clothes like Oliver’s, Jon Caramanica traces how rap icons such as Raekwon and Kanye West have influenced not only street fashion, but the runway as well. We’ve also dressed some of France’s most talented men in some of the season’s best clothes — proving that some things, like brooding-French-artist chic, never lose their appeal. Elsewhere, Andrew O’Hagan combs through the male overgrooming epidemic, looking for chaos amid the order; Jody Rosen travels to Ordos, China, one of the world’s most famous ghost towns that wants to be so much more; the artist Pablo Bronstein takes us inside his home in Deal, England, where antique glamour and campy kitsch live in curious harmony; and Marilyn Manson and John Waters test out an urban scooter and one-legged pants, with predictably weird results. See all stories from the issue >>

headline: Memo to Therapists: It’s Not Me, It’s You
keywords: ['Psychology and Psychologists', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation']
abstract: Even in an age of online relationships, “breaking up” with a therapist is hard to do.
lead_paragraph: How should I tell my therapist, on Day 2 of our relationship, that we aren’t a good fit? Of all of therapy’s potential etiquette minefields — the client who unleashes his searing revelations three minutes before the end of sessions; the therapist who nods off, or whose picture keeps popping up on clients’ People You May Know feature on Facebook — termination seems like one of the more challenging ones. How do you skitter without scratching the parquet?

headline: Review: Vladan Nikolic’s ‘Allure’ Shows New York Through Immigrants’ Eyes
abstract: The Occupy movement is a backdrop to this film about four women from different countries and diverse backgrounds and their American experiences.
lead_paragraph: The complicated lives of four immigrant women casually intersect in “Allure,” a title that accurately reflects the seductive quality of its black-and-white images. The Serbian-born director, Vladan Nikolic, seems to have a knack for choosing dexterous cinematographers. (He has twice used his wildly gifted countryman Vladimir Subotic.) Here he passes the reins to Aleksandar Kostic, who turns New York City into a dreamy melting pot of conflict and yearning.

headline: From the Archives: Where’s the Spirit of Selma Now?
abstract: This story ran in The New York Times Magazine on May 30, 1965, almost three months after the attacks on demonstrators at the Edmund Pettus Bridge in Selma, Ala.
lead_paragraph: This story by Gay Talese ran in The New York Times Magazine on May 30, 1965, almost three months after the attacks on demonstrators at the Edmund Pettus Bridge. In advance of the 50th anniversary of the 1965 march, he returned to Selma to report on Selma today and what has changed and what has not over the past half century.

lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — In the first two years of his papacy, Pope Francis has stirred great expectations for change among Roman Catholics who believe that the church has not kept pace with the social transformations of secular society.

headline: Resolution Censures Chemical Weapons
abstract: In an unusual display of unity over the divisive four-year-old conflict in Syria, the Security Council passed a resolution on Friday that condemned the use of chlorine as a chemical weapon in that country.
lead_paragraph: In an unusual display of unity over the divisive four-year-old conflict in Syria, the Security Council passed a resolution on Friday that condemned the use of chlorine as a chemical weapon in that country, and threatened sanctions that could include a military response to any further violations. The resolution, drafted by the United States, was approved 14-0, with one abstention, from Venezuela. The resolution followed a report this year by the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons that chlorine bombs had been used in the conflict, even after the Syrian government had signed the global treaty banning such munitions and had agreed to the destruction of its arsenal, which was basically completed by June. Like that report, the Security Council resolution did not specify which side in the conflict had used the chlorine bombs. But critics of the Syrian government, including the United States, have pointed out that the bombs had been seen dropped from helicopters, which are only possessed by the Syrian military.

headline: The Labor Picture in February
abstract: The Labor Department said Friday the unemployment Rate in the United States decreased to 5.50 percent in February of 2015 from 5.70 percent in January of 2015. That’s the lowest unemployment rate since May 2008. This month 295,000 jobs were created, exceeding economists’ expectations.
lead_paragraph: The Labor Department said Friday the unemployment Rate in the United States decreased to 5.50 percent in February of 2015 from 5.70 percent in January of 2015. That’s the lowest unemployment rate since May 2008. This month 295,000 jobs were created, exceeding economists’ expectations.

headline: Books on New York’s Role in the Civil War, and Coney Island
abstract: Two recent books include a look at New York City’s substantial role in the Civil War effort and a companion publication to an exhibition charting Coney Island’s transformation.
lead_paragraph: The sesquicentennial celebration of the Civil War culminates next month with 150-year-old images of City Hall draped in black. “The Nation Mourns,” a banner proclaims from the portico, and thousands of curious and inconsolable New Yorkers queue up to view the body of Abraham Lincoln for the last time.

lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Iraq’s largest offensive against Islamic State militants came a step closer to the city of Tikrit on Friday, with Shiite militiamen and Iraqi troops advancing into the town of Dour, according to Iraqi state television.

headline: In Mexico, an Extreme Race in the Shadow of Extreme Danger
keywords: ['Marathon Running', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Drug Cartels', 'Gangs', 'Ultramarathon Running', 'Running']
abstract: The threat of violence has always simmered in the background of the ultramarathon, held every March in the Copper Canyon region in northwestern Mexico.
lead_paragraph: Josue Stephens, one of the organizers of the Caballo Blanco ultramarathon last week in Urique, Mexico, realized something was amiss when he was warned not to drive along the coastal route because so many people had been killed there recently. When he finally got to Urique, he saw armed men in bulletproof vests swarm into the local police station, take everyone’s guns and throw two officers into the back of a truck before barreling away.

headline: A Third Blast on Oil Trains Stirs Scrutiny
abstract: A string of fiery accidents prompts some to question whether safety upgrades are good enough or coming soon enough as rail transportation of oil keeps growing.
lead_paragraph: For the third time in less than a month, a train carrying flammable crude oil has derailed and burst into flames, prompting questions over whether stricter measures being considered to ensure their safety will be enough.

headline: Pakistan Honors Victims of School Massacre
abstract: Education officials in northwestern Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Province have renamed more than a hundred schools after the children killed last year in a Taliban attack on an army-run public school in Peshawar.
lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — Education officials in northwestern Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Province have renamed more than a hundred schools in honor of the children killed last year in a Taliban attack on an army-run public school in Peshawar, the provincial capital.

headline: The Boring Life of a Private Investigator
keywords: ['Detectives (Private)', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Bribery and Kickbacks']
abstract: We need to recast detective stories with law-abiding gumshoes.
lead_paragraph: WHEN I first became a private investigator, I was enthralled by the idea of the brash gumshoe who was modeled on the American cowboy and incubated in the pulps — a lawless lone wolf.

headline: After Rory McIlroy’s Shot Drops Into Water, His 3-Iron Suffers the Same Fate
abstract: McIlroy, the world No. 1, overcame the lost ball and his lost temper to card a two-under 70 that left him eight strokes off the lead.
lead_paragraph: DORAL, Fla. — Rory McIlroy fleetingly considered giving the 3-iron in his right hand a reprieve. Then frustration got the better of him, and he flung it into the same water hazard on the Blue Monster course that seconds earlier had swallowed his golf ball.

headline: U.S. Attorney Keeps Talking, but Leaves Out Sheldon Silver
abstract: Preet Bharara, the United States attorney in Manhattan, offered a notable silence on a corruption case involving the speaker of the New York Assembly after his public remarks became part of it.
lead_paragraph: One day after the arrest of Sheldon Silver, the former State Assembly speaker, in January, Manhattan’s top federal prosecutor spoke at a local law school about public corruption, alluding repeatedly to Mr. Silver when castigating the way deals were made in Albany, by “three men in a room.”

headline: U.S. Relied on Unarmed South Korean Officer to Protect Envoy
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Assaults', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The assignment of a single unarmed South Korean police bodyguard to accompany Ambassador Mark W. Lippert on his movements in the country added to questions about security when he was attacked.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The United States was relying on a lone, unarmed South Korean police bodyguard to protect Mark W. Lippert, the American ambassador to South Korea, when he was attacked Thursday, a senior United States official said Friday, adding to questions in South Korea about whether security had been too lax.

headline: Asking Megadonors for Just a Million
abstract: With the presidential public funding system in tatters, both parties are money-bingeing. A Justice Department vow offers some hope.
lead_paragraph: The coffers of Jeb Bush’s not-quite-declared campaign for president are filling at such a rate that fund-raisers have reportedly been instructed not to ask megadonors to give more than $1 million each this quarter. The concern is seemliness — that acceptance of multimillion-dollar checks from deep-pocketed supporters could bolster the impression that Mr. Bush, the former Florida governor, is in their debt, according to a Washington Post report.

headline: Brian Carman, Surf Rocker, Dies at 69
abstract: As a member of the Chantays, Mr. Carman helped write the instrumental hit “Pipeline.”
lead_paragraph: Brian Carman, who as a high school student in the early 1960s helped write the instrumental surf-rock hit “Pipeline” for his band, the Chantays, died on Sunday at his home in Santa Ana, Calif. He was 69.

headline: Jobs and the Federal Reserve
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Unemployment', 'Editorials', 'Productivity', 'Interest Rates', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The Fed should continue to hold off on raising rates until wages are growing in tandem with inflation and productivity.
lead_paragraph: The latest jobs report showed that unemployment fell to 5.5 percent in February and that 295,000 jobs were added to the economy. But the labor market is not as healthy as those figures might suggest.

headline: Better Bonding Through Telenovelas
abstract: Two people are unable to console each other during their mutual bereavement in “Guadalupe in the Guest Room” in Red Bank.
lead_paragraph: Two people are unable to console each other during their mutual bereavement in “Guadalupe in the Guest Room,” the first of three world premieres being staged in the coming months by Two River Theater in Red Bank. There is a language barrier between the 30-something Steve (Charles Socarides) and Guadalupe (Socorro Santiago), his mother-in-law, as they mourn the untimely death of his wife, Claudia. A native of Mexico, the widowed Guadalupe possesses only a rudimentary knowledge of English. Steve’s command of Spanish is equally poor.

headline: Harve Bennett, Quiz Kid and ‘Star Trek’ Producer, Dies at 84
abstract: Mr. Bennett started out as a young radio star then went on to produce four “Star Trek” films and television movies.
lead_paragraph: Harve Bennett, who navigated a rocky path from childhood stardom to youthful disaffection to adult success as a producer of four “Star Trek” films and an Emmy-winning TV movie, died on Feb. 25 in Medford, Ore. He was 84.

headline: When the Elephants Exit the Big Top
abstract: Was Ringling Brothers right to ban the elephants from their shows?

headline: Holidays That Reflect New York’s Students
abstract: A public school calendar accommodation to the Muslim community is a gesture of welcome — and a welcome gesture.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s decision to add two Muslim holidays to the public school calendar is welcome news — not just for Muslim pupils, an estimated 10 percent of the city’s 1.1 million public school children, who will no longer have to skip school to celebrate with their families, but for all New Yorkers who believe that the school system is made stronger when it adapts to reflect the diverse and growing communities it serves. The holidays are Eid al-Fitr, which marks the end of the holy month of Ramadan, and Eid al-Adha, a commemoration of the willingness of Ibrahim, or Abraham, to sacrifice his son at God’s command.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 6, 2015
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: March 6, 2015

headline: Republicans Set Up Shop in Iowa, Where Few Will Prosper
abstract: With 11 months to go before caucuses, Republican hopefuls are fighting for attention, expert advisers and an early advantage.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — There are so many reasons for Republicans to ignore Iowa.

headline: Bullets Over Washington
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Police', 'Bullet-Proof Clothing', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: When some armor-piercing ammunition was banned in the ’80s, the regulations were largely uncontroversial. My, how things have changed.
lead_paragraph: In 1986, Congress passed, and Ronald Reagan signed into law, the Law Enforcement Officers Protection Act. It directed the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives to ban certain types of ammunition that could pierce the body armor worn by police officers. The National Rifle Association had originally opposed the legislation — which, in fact, was one of a series of events that caused a split between the N.R.A. and most police associations — but the logic behind it was irrefutable.

headline: Around the World in a Song
abstract: On March 20 and 21, two musicians will offer the fruits of their explorations as part of “Crossing Borders: Memory and Heritage in a New America,” a series at ArtsWestchester’s performance space in White Plains.
lead_paragraph: In the age of the global village, a musician need not have vast experience living in a particular country to evoke its culture. Commitment and a connection to that country’s wider community — actual or virtual — can suffice.

headline: Journeys in Gender
abstract: Gender transitions are difficult but rewarding for many, including Sheela-Marie Padgett, a former dancer.
lead_paragraph: Gender transitions are difficult but rewarding for many, including Sheela-Marie Padgett, a former dancer.

headline: Review: In ‘Reverberation,’ Singles Adrift in the Big City
abstract: In Matthew Lopez’s new play, a free-spirited woman and her reclusive gay neighbor form a sustaining friendship.
lead_paragraph: HARTFORD — Grief begets isolation, and isolation begets loneliness in “Reverberation,” a keenly felt, haunting drama by Matthew Lopez about two New Yorkers adrift in their lives who strike up a sustaining friendship. The play, making its premiere here at Hartford Stage, has the cool but precise observational feel of current television shows about singles in the city like HBO’s “Girls” and “Looking,” at least until an ill-judged spasm of violence at the end shatters the elliptical mood.

headline: Science as a Vocation
abstract: David C. Duncan Dekker makes his New York Times crossword debut.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Most people don’t notice when a puzzle is a PANGRAM (the grid uses every letter FROM A TO Z, once), but you might have a vague sense of it while solving. Every time you fill in a “rare” letter, like J, K, Q, V or Z, you might wonder if you’ll eventually run into all 26 letters of the alphabet in your crossword puzzle.

headline: Federal Court in Alabama Is Asked to Clear Way for Same-Sex Marriages
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Lawyers filed a motion with a District Court judge to force probate judges in the state to again issue licenses to gay couples.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Lawyers for gay and civil rights groups on Friday asked a federal court in Mobile, Ala., to force the state’s probate judges to once again issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples, three days after the Alabama Supreme Court ordered them to stop.

headline: In New Haven, an Exhibition on a Yale Professor Who Helped Rescue Art During World War II
keywords: ['Art', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: “An Artist at War: Deane Keller, New Haven’s Monuments Man” is on view at the New Haven Museum through May 9.
lead_paragraph: As the Allied forces advanced north in Italy  during the last year of World War II, Capt. Deane Keller arrived in Pisa and found that the fighting had left much of the ancient city reduced to rubble.

headline: Harlem Man Is Convicted of Murdering His Girlfriend
abstract: Bismark Lithgow, 26, faces a maximum of 25 years to life in prison for stabbing his girlfriend 38 times and hiding her body in a plastic barrel in his bedroom in Harlem.
lead_paragraph: A Harlem man was convicted of second-degree murder on Friday in the death of his girlfriend, whom he stabbed 38 times before hiding her body in a plastic barrel in his bedroom.

headline: Cardinal Egan Is Recalled Fondly at a Chapel He Called Home
abstract: To parishioners of the Chapel of the Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary on East 33rd Street, where he retired in 2009, Cardinal Edward M. Egan was known as a good-humored man with a weakness for pineapples.
lead_paragraph: As the leader of the sprawling Archdiocese of New York, Cardinal Edward M. Egan could be seen as a fierce defender of church doctrines and a no-nonsense administrator who closed or merged parishes and schools to help restore the archdiocese to financial stability.

headline: Jeb Bush Kicks Off Courtship of Iowa
abstract: Jeb Bush, making his first visit to this presidential kickoff state as a likely candidate, began his bid to win the caucuses here by paying tribute to two Iowa touchstones and calibrating his message on why he supports education standards loathed by many conservatives.
lead_paragraph: URBANDALE, Iowa – Jeb Bush, making his first visit to this presidential kickoff state as a likely candidate, began his bid to win the caucuses here by paying tribute to two Iowa touchstones and calibrating his message about why he supports education standards loathed by many conservatives.

headline: Bridgehampton Chamber Music Festival Adds a Spring Series
abstract: The Bridgehampton Chamber Music Festival will expand its summer offerings with concerts in March and April, in part to attract a younger audience.
lead_paragraph: The Bridgehampton Chamber Music Festival, a highly regarded summer event, will expand its offerings this month with a new spring series.

headline: Yale Beats Harvard to Take Control of Ivy League
abstract: The Bulldogs, who lead the Crimson by one game with one to play, moved a step closer to clinching their first N.C.A.A. tournament berth since 1962.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — The basketball rivalry between Harvard and Yale dates to the 1900-1 season, when John Kirkland Clark, a former Bulldog, introduced the sport to the Crimson athletic department while attending law school at Harvard.

headline: Carlos Beltran Has No Hits, but No Pain, in His Return for Yankees
abstract: Beltran, who needed off-season surgery after his 2014 season was hurt by elbow problems, said he experienced no pain in his first exhibition game this year.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — What Carlos Beltran did Friday night against the Pittsburgh Pirates did not show up in the box score. Making his spring training debut, Beltran struck out twice, walked on four pitches and made one meaningful throw, corralling Neil Walker’s double and getting the ball back in cleanly.

headline: Readers Drawn Into Debate Over U.C.L.A. Student’s Jewish Background
abstract: An article on the controversy involving Rachel Beyda, a Jewish student questioned by a student council about her views, drew hundreds of comments.
lead_paragraph: In Kerckhoff Hall, the bustling student union building at the University of California, Los Angeles, a student council meeting was underway. Not exactly newsworthy, one would argue, if not for what came after.

headline: Room to Breathe In the Mediterranean
abstract: Fattoria Dinner House, in Armonk, focuses on dishes from Italy but offers some from Greece and Spain, too, in a spacious restaurant.
lead_paragraph: Here’s the question: In Armonk, a town chockablock with a range of dining spots, some highly lauded, how does newcomer Fattoria Dinner House distinguish itself, apart from its unwieldy name?

headline: A Japanese Pub on the Saugatuck
abstract: Kawa Ni, the third restaurant in Westport from the chef Bill Taibe, is a Japanese pub with a creative spin.
lead_paragraph: The chef Bill Taibe began his gustatory takeover of Westport modestly, with the minuscule Le Farm. Then he opened the Welk. His newest venture is Kawa Ni, which is Japanese for “on the river” — it is at the bridge overlooking the Saugatuck River.

headline: Where Mediterranean Leans Lebanese
abstract: Pierre Hage-Boutros, a native of Lebanon, runs Labebe Mediterranean Cuisine, in North Brunswick, with his son Tony.
lead_paragraph: When I walk into a “Mediterranean” restaurant, it’s hard to know what kind of food to expect. It could be Israeli or Syrian or Turkish or Egyptian. I could be looking forward to kofta and end up with a menu full of risottos or spinach pies, given the diverse countries that surround that sea.

headline: Portuguese Flavors, and Plenty to Take Home
abstract: Lisbon Cafe in Carle Place offers generous portions, and seafood is among its specialties.
lead_paragraph: Here are two helpful hints on visiting Lisbon Cafe in Carle Place: Come hungry and don’t be shy about asking for doggy bags. Generosity should be the middle name of this Portuguese restaurant, which opened in January.

headline: Corrections: March 7, 2015
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, March 7, 2015.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, March 7, 2015.
lead_paragraph: “I have always conducted myself in accordance with the law.”

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (Showtime) INSIDE LLEWYN DAVIS (2013) Oscar Isaac portrays Llewyn, an aspiring folk singer mourning the death of his musical partner (the voice of Marcus Mumford) and leaving mayhem — a crying hostess, a pregnant woman, an escaped cat — in his wake as he bounces from couch to couch in Greenwich Village during a single week in 1961. Carey Mulligan, Justin Timberlake, Stark Sands and Adam Driver round out the cast as Llewyn’s fellow folk singers; John Goodman is a drug-addicted jazzman; and Garrett Hedlund is a Beat poet. And while Llewyn’s background and antics were inspired by the life of Dave Van Ronk, “this is not a biopic, it’s a Coen brothers movie, which is to say a brilliant magpie’s nest of surrealism, period detail and pop-culture scholarship,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “Mr. Isaac, a versatile character actor here ascending to the highest levels of his craft, refuses the easy road of charm.” One of the film’s lessons, as Mr. Scott sees it, is: “We are, as a species, ridiculous: vain, ugly, selfish and self-deluding. But somehow, some of our attempts to take stock of this condition — our songs and stories and moving pictures, old and new — manage to be beautiful, even sublime.”

headline: What to Expect on the Fourth Day of Paris Fashion Week
abstract: Shows from Junya Watanabe, Haider Ackermann, Elie Saab, Acne and an old stalwart, Nina Ricci, where Guillaume Henry will make his big debut.
lead_paragraph: Junya Watanabe is a strong, silent type. The man makes the Sphinx look chatty. So you’re as unlikely to get a preview of his collection as you are to get an explanation after.

headline: Grim Prospects Drive an Exodus From Kosovo
abstract: For months now, buses have been bringing Kosovo Albanians through Serbia to the porous land border with Hungary, which is in the European Union.
lead_paragraph: For months now, buses have been bringing Kosovo Albanians through Serbia to the porous land border with Hungary, which is in the European Union.

headline: Kosovars Who Fought for Land Are Now Eager to Leave
abstract: A disastrous economy, static politics and a newly created opening in the border with Serbia have enticed tens of thousands of Kosovars to leave their troubled land.
lead_paragraph: STANOVC, Kosovo — The extended Cakaj family has built a few dozen homes here, along Tony Blair Street, between the Dubai supermarket and the French peacekeepers base, in a clannish faith that closeness would bring security. But recently the family of Kosovo Albanians has begun to splinter, as a disastrous economy, static politics and a newly created opening in the border with Serbia have enticed tens of thousands of Kosovars to leave their troubled land in search of opportunity and work.

headline: Brazil Bribery Inquiry Targets Top Politicians
abstract: The leaders of both houses of Congress are among those to be investigated, by order of the Supreme Federal Tribunal, the nation’s highest court.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil’s highest court on Friday authorized an investigation of dozens of prominent political figures, including the leaders of both houses of Congress, intensifying a sweeping bribery scandal that is bedeviling President Dilma Rousseff’s government at a time when she is grappling with a sluggish economy.

headline: 2 Suspects Are Detained in Killing of Kremlin Critic
abstract: The director of Russia’s Federal Security Service named two men as suspects in the brazen shooting of the opposition leader Boris Y. Nemtsov in Moscow on Feb. 27, but questions remained over who orchestrated the killing.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Two suspects have been detained in the killing of the opposition leader Boris Y. Nemtsov, the head of Russia’s internal law enforcement agency announced on Saturday.

headline: Gunman Kills Five in Restaurant in Mali
abstract: A ranking security official said Saturday morning that two people had been arrested in connection with the attack, for which a group of extremists are said to have claimed responsibility.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — A masked gunman opened fire on a restaurant in Mali’s capital, Bamako, early Saturday morning, killing at least two Europeans — a Frenchman and a Belgian — and three Malians.

headline: At Hotels, One-Day-Only Vacations
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Swimming Pools', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: If the “staycation” was the travel industry’s response to the Great Recession, the “daycation” is perhaps another sign of recovery from it.
lead_paragraph: If the “staycation” was the travel industry’s response to the Great Recession, the “daycation” is perhaps another sign of recovery from it.

headline: Elie Saab’s Fall 2015 Collection at Paris Fashion Week
abstract: The latest women’s collection from Elie Saab at Paris Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: The live stream from Elie Saab at Paris Fashion Week has ended. Watch the live stream here.

headline: 1951: Department Store Celebrates 2,000 Years of Paris
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: A Boston department store throws a luncheon for the 2,000th birthday of the city of Paris.
lead_paragraph: PARIS is celebrating her 2,000th anniversary this year. It completely slipped our mind until the other day when we were invited to a luncheon at the Plaza-Athénée to celebrate the occasion. The luncheon was given by Filene’s, a Boston department store, well known for remembering birthdays and anniversaries. The store’s executives had loaded down two of their representatives with 2,001 candles and instructions to bake a cake and throw a big blowout for the French capital.

lead_paragraph: More on the Cromwellian aspect of monetary policy: the Philadelphia Fed has a helpful summary of Fed estimates of the NAIRU reaching back to 1989. Here’s what their numbers looked like on the eve of the great Clinton/Greenspan boom:

headline: Obama, at Selma Memorial, Says, ‘We Know the March Is Not Yet Over’
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: In an address on the spot of what became known as “Bloody Sunday” in Alabama 50 years ago, President Obama rejected the notion that race relations had not improved since then.
lead_paragraph: SELMA, Ala. — As a new generation struggles over race and power in America, President Obama and a host of political figures from both parties came here on Saturday, to the site of one of the most searing days of the civil rights era, to reflect on how far the country has come and how far it still has to go.
