headline: Secret Service Briefly Locks Down White House After Bomb-Sniffing Dog’s Alert and Nearby Fire
abstract: As President Obama and his family prepared to depart for Selma, Ala., the Secret Service began examining a car parked near the presidential residence.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House was put under a security lockdown Saturday morning by the Secret Service after a bomb-sniffing dog alerted its handlers to examine a car not far from the presidential residence and offices, a spokesman for the agency said.

headline: Vivek Gupta of Zensar Technologies: Beware of Hiring People Just Like You
abstract: The chief executive of a software services company said, “I want to hire people who are very different from me or better than me in certain areas so that one plus one equals more than two.”
lead_paragraph: This interview with Vivek Gupta, C.E.O. of Zensar Technologies, a global software services company based in Pune, India, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Variety: A Fatigued Acrostic
abstract: An acrostic by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon that will keep you awake.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — Do you have trouble finding time to get to your daily crossword puzzle? I do, although I never miss a New York Times crossword, of course. It’s part of the job. What I have trouble with is finding the time to do some of the other indie puzzles out there, like the ones listed in the Blogroll. They’re fun and maybe, one day when the emus don’t need as much care, I will have a chance to actually solve some of them.

headline: Stagflation Predictions
abstract: A gem from 2009.
lead_paragraph: Matt O’Brien catches a piece by Dick Morris a few years ago predicting that Obama’s legacy would be stagflation. But I say, oh yeah? I’ll see your Dick Morris (who cares, really?) and raise you a … Paul Ryan: Thirty Years Later, a Return to Stagflation.

headline: Jihadists May Have Wrecked an Ancient Iraqi Site
abstract: Iraqi officials are investigating reports that the Islamic State destroyed Hatra, an archaeological site dating to the first century B.C., two days after confirming that it bulldozed an ancient Assyrian city.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Iraqi officials said Saturday that they were investigating reports that Islamic State militants had destroyed Hatra, an archaeological site that dates to the first century B.C., two days after officials confirmed that the group had bulldozed another nearby site, the ancient Assyrian city of Nimrud.

headline: Yu Darvish May Need Season-Ending Surgery on Elbow
abstract: The Texas Rangers ace has partially torn ligaments in his right elbow, the same elbow where inflammation shortened his 2014 season, and Tommy John surgery is being considered.
lead_paragraph: SURPRISE, Ariz. — Yu Darvish, a star right-hander for the Texas Rangers, may soon become the latest ace pitcher to have Tommy John surgery. The Rangers said Saturday that Darvish had a sprained ulnar collateral ligament in his right elbow and that their doctor had recommended the operation, which would cost Darvish the entire 2015 season.

headline: In Iowa, Christie Highlights His Agricultural Credentials
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie on Saturday sought to appeal to hundreds of Iowans at a farming forum by reminding them that he, too, is from an agricultural state.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Gov. Chris Christie on Saturday sought to appeal to hundreds of Iowans at a farming forum at the State Fairgrounds here by reminding them that that he, too, is from an agricultural state: “New Jersey is the Garden State, remember,’’ he said.

headline: Move Over Mao: Beloved ‘Papa Xi’ Awes China
abstract: Not since Mao Zedong dominated the nation with his masterly blend of populism, fervor and fear has a Chinese leader commanded as much public awe as President Xi Jinping.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The must-see tourist sights of the Chinese capital form a grandiose circuit: the Great Wall, the Forbidden City, Tiananmen Square and, for early birds willing to brave long lines, the mausoleum of Mao Zedong.

headline: To Break In Their Gloves, Yankees Dunk, Tenderize and Lather Up
abstract: There is nothing more personal for a baseball player than the varied ways in which they break in a glove so that it is just right for their hand and their position.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — When Alex Rodriguez played in Texas, he noticed that as the hot, humid summers dragged on, they would take a toll on the glove he used to play shortstop. It would become heavy and malleable, losing the firm shape that he liked.

headline: At the Fed in 2009, Rolling the Dice in a Crisis
keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'United States Economy', 'Mortgage-Backed Securities', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Newly released transcripts from Federal Reserve Board meetings in 2009 cover some of the darkest days of the financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: Ben Bernanke and his colleagues at the Federal Reserve Board have earned accolades from all corners for the extraordinary actions they took to rescue the financial system in 2009. While 2008 was the Fed’s annus horribilis, exposing how unaware the central bank had been of the risks building in the financial system, 2009 was its year of redemption.

headline: Mike Huckabee Strikes a Populist Tone at Iowa Agriculture Summit
abstract: Former Arkansas governor Mike Huckabee made clear Saturday at an industry summit here that he is more of a populist than many of the other would-be Republican presidential hopefuls.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — The agriculture industry generally supports free trade and an immigration overhaul, but former Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas made clear Saturday at an industry summit here that he is more of a populist than many of the other Republican presidential hopefuls.

headline: Warren Buffett’s Awesome Feat at Berkshire Hathaway, Revisited
abstract: In its 50 years under Warren Buffett, Berkshire Hathaway’s shares have gained a cumulative 1,826,163 percent.
lead_paragraph: Warren Buffett is taking a victory lap, and on the 50th anniversary of his reign at Berkshire Hathaway he is entitled to it. From a failing New England textile company, Berkshire became the vehicle for one of capitalism’s greatest investing feats.

headline: After Talks, Nuclear Deal on Iran Is Seen as Close
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']
abstract: With an end-of-March deadline for drafting the outline of a potential agreement, Secretary of State John Kerry faces an array of challenges in completing an initial accord and defending it to Congress.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Secretary of State John Kerry wrapped up a week of diplomacy in Europe and the Middle East within what many experts say is striking distance of an initial accord with Iran over its nuclear program.

headline: Unarmed Man Is Shot Dead by Police After Scuffle in Wisconsin
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: The man, identified by friends and family as Anthony Robinson, 19, was shot in an apartment in Madison on Friday, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A 19-year-old Wisconsin man was shot and killed Friday by a police officer during a scuffle inside an apartment in Madison, police officials said. The shooting prompted protests that continued on Saturday and led officials to call for restraint while the shooting is investigated.

headline: Bosses Who Love Themselves
abstract: People who lack empathy and have grandiose views of themselves tend to have a damaging effect on all levels of business, researchers say.
lead_paragraph: Try to avoid working for a company with a narcissist at the top. That’s because narcissistic C.E.O.s tend to overspend on investments and deliver substandard results. On top of that, they are often paid more than their humbler yet better-performing peers, according to a recent study.

headline: Zing and Talent Add Up to Hope for the Mets
abstract: The mood at Port St. Lucie, the spring training lair of the Mets, is indisputably upbeat, especially with the return of pitcher Matt Harvey. Players have trained their eyes on the playoffs.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Pop. Pop! POP!

headline: Lawyers Seek Reprieve for Killer Who Lost Part of His Brain Decades Earlier
keywords: ['Capital Punishment', 'Intellectual Disabilities', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Lawyers for Cecil Clayton, who lost 7.7 percent of his brain in a sawmill accident, say his life should be spared because he cannot grasp the significance of his death sentence.
lead_paragraph: In January 1972, Cecil Clayton was cutting wood at his family’s sawmill in southeastern Missouri when a piece of lumber flew off the circular saw blade and struck him in the forehead. The impact caved in part of Mr. Clayton’s skull, driving bone fragments into his brain.

headline: Hiring a Coach to Spark the Job Hunt
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Coaches and Managers', 'Bullies', 'Careers and Professions', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Workplace Environment']
abstract: The wife of an out-of-work executive seeks help finding her husband a coach to motivate his job search.
lead_paragraph: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

headline: Martin O’Malley Steers Clear of Hillary Clinton Email Issue
abstract: Former Maryland Gov. Martin O’Malley demurred on Friday when asked about the controversy over Hillary Rodham Clinton’s email use at the State Department.
lead_paragraph: Martin O’Malley, the former Maryland governor who is considering a bid for the Democratic presidential nomination in 2016, took a pass on Friday when asked about the controversy over Hillary Rodham Clinton’s email use at the State Department, but called transparency “required in the modern age.”

headline: Charter School in Miami Fails, but Proves Useful on Jeb Bush’s Résumé
abstract: The Liberty City Charter School, the first of its kind in Florida and a pioneer in what became a national movement, is now defunct.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — “That’s where the classrooms were,” said Katrina Wilson-Davis, pointing at the deserted building that housed the school where she was once principal. She climbed the chipped stairs that children used to race down at recess in their cherry-red school uniforms and walked past a street sign that still warns drivers of a 15-mile-an-hour speed limit on school days.

headline: The Brands in Art Basel’s Orbit
keywords: ['Art', 'ART BASEL (FESTIVAL)', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Luxury Goods and Services']
abstract: Luxury companies want to be part of the global fair, and not just because it draws the 1 percent.
lead_paragraph: When visitors arrive at Art Basel Hong Kong this month, they will be able to explore artwork by Richard Serra, Keith Haring and Ai Weiwei — along with a plethora of luxury brands decked out to show their artistic side.

headline: Tangled Case of a Baylor Football Player Poses a Test for the Rules of Eligibility
abstract: There remain more questions than answers about a Baylor football player being declared ineligible, and about the procedure by which college students are barred from playing sports.
lead_paragraph: An apparently homeless Baylor football player was recently declared ineligible because of N.C.A.A. violations, resulting in a spasm of outrage followed by bewilderment. One week later, there remain more questions than answers about this case and, more important, about the procedure by which college students are barred from playing sports, an increasingly significant topic as the N.C.A.A.’s power to regulate its member institutions, from academics to amateurism, erodes.

headline: Heartbreak in Gaza
abstract: In Gaza, Nicholas Kristof finds the place still in ruins after last year’s war with Israel.
lead_paragraph: In Gaza, Nicholas Kristof finds the place still in ruins after last year’s war with Israel.

headline: Jeb Bush Stakes Out Contrary Position on Energy Subsidies in Iowa
abstract: Jeb Bush said he wanted to phase out federal benefits for renewable fuels and wind energy, a pair of benefits that are widely supported by Iowa’s political and industry leaders.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Jeb Bush said Saturday that he wanted to phase out federal benefits for renewable fuels and wind energy, using an agricultural summit here to side with his party’s free-market advocates over the industry groups who staged the forum.

headline: At Roger Vivier, Ankle Boots for Punk Sophisticates
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: tough but elegant footwear dotted with gold caviar studs.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

lead_paragraph: Netanyahu in Congress, health insurance subsidies, a “sled-in” and more.

headline: In Greece, Desperate Times and Offbeat Measures
keywords: ['Tax Evasion', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Athens is coming up with radical ways to fill its shortfall as it nears a deadline to meet financial obligations, including wiring tourists, students and housekeepers to catch tax evaders.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Despite the European accord last month to extend a financial lifeline to Greece, Athens is rapidly running out of cash.

abstract: Netanyahu in Congress, health insurance subsidies, a “sled-in” and more.

headline: A Sexual Desire Drug
abstract: Responses to an Op-Ed essay that criticized a drug aimed at women who lack sex drive.
lead_paragraph: Responses to an Op-Ed essay that criticized a drug aimed at women who lack sex drive.

headline: Anne Curzan
abstract: A linguist on sports and swimming from island to island in Croatia.
lead_paragraph: Anne Curzan is a professor of English at the University of Michigan who specializes in the dynamism of modern language and gender differences in language use.

headline: Christians Loving Jews
keywords: ['Evangelical Movement', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: The Republican support for Israel on display last week is largely faith-based.
lead_paragraph: HE was almost lost in the whirl of lawmakers, pundits, plutocrats and other boldface names who showed up for Benjamin Netanyahu’s speech to Congress last week. But the presence of Pat Boone was a key to understanding why John Boehner was playing a smart game of party politics to stand so solidly with the Israeli prime minister.

headline: The Case for Old Ideas
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Religion and Belief', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Our most effective reformers often blend innovations with tried-and-tested moral and religious commitments.
lead_paragraph: ONE of the anxieties haunting the 21st century is a fear that technological change will soon make many human lives seem essentially superfluous.

headline: What Ending Health Subsidies Means
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Editorials', 'Hospitals']
abstract: Obamacare’s political adversaries refuse to acknowledge the devastation, both economic and human, that destroying a crucial provision would bring about.
lead_paragraph: If the Supreme Court rules that no federal tax credit subsidies can be provided to Americans buying insurance on federal health exchanges in 34 states, the economic effects could be devastating.

headline: Protect the Police From Armor-Piercing Bullets
abstract: Officers very much need a ban, but the gun lobby is already marshaling legislative allies for a fight.
lead_paragraph: The nation’s police forces should be the first to rally behind a federal proposal to ban the sale and manufacture of the 5.56-millimeter steel-core bullet. The bullet can be used in newly adapted handguns to provide lethal force to pierce the vests and body armor used by law enforcement officers.

headline: Making Clinton Coverage Bulletproof
keywords: ['Public Editor (Times Column)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'E-Mail', 'News and News Media']
abstract: When it comes to a political figure as polarizing as Hillary Rodham Clinton, it is not enough for a news article to just be right.
lead_paragraph: IN an “open letter” to The Times last week, the author David Brock claimed that a high-profile story about Hillary Rodham Clinton’s email practices “had unraveled under scrutiny,” and was riddled with ”innuendo.” He demanded an immediate correction.

headline: With the Clintons, Only the Shadow Knows
keywords: ['E-Mail', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)']
abstract: For the Clintons and their Clintonistas, it’s never simple.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — SOMEWHERE in Smithsonian storage sits a portrait of Bill Clinton with two odd features: He is standing next to a shadow meant to conjure Monica Lewinsky’s blue dress, and he is not wearing his gold wedding ring.

headline: Winds of War in Gaza
abstract: Conditions in Gaza are miserable and exacerbated by pessimism on the ground and by the iron grip of Israel and Egypt.
lead_paragraph: GAZA — IT is winter in Gaza, in every wretched sense of the word. Six months after the latest war, the world has moved on, but tens of thousands remain homeless — sometimes crammed into the rubble of bombed-out buildings. Children are dying of the cold, according to the United Nations.

headline: Warhead Checklist: 12 Issues, 11 Unaddressed
abstract: Iran has declined to give technical replies to all but one of twelve specific allegations about its atom-bomb development.
lead_paragraph: Iran has declined to give technical replies to all but one of twelve specific allegations about its atom-bomb development.

headline: What Iran Won’t Say About the Bomb
abstract: Should it have to say how much it knows about bomb design?
lead_paragraph: OVER the course of a dozen years, ever since atomic sleuths from the United Nations began scrutinizing Iran’s nuclear program, hundreds of inspections have uncovered a hidden world of labs and sprawling factories, some ringed by barbed wire and antiaircraft guns, others camouflaged or buried deep underground. Yet despite that progress, Iran has so far managed to evade a central question — whether it knows how to build an atom bomb.

headline: America Needs Its Own Emojis
keywords: ['Smartphones', 'Symbols', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'English Language']
abstract: There’s so much we can’t express because the symbols don’t exist: no Vulcan salute, no pickup truck, no bacon.
lead_paragraph: ALL I wanted to do was wish my fiancée happy birthday using emojis. But I couldn’t replicate the rebus of the classic Sandra Boynton greeting card: Hippo, Birdie, Two Ewes. My vocabulary was too limited.

headline: Sabotaging a Deal With Iran
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Instead of playing political games, Congress needs to think hard about the best way to support a verifiable nuclear pact.
lead_paragraph: Congressional critics of an emerging international agreement to limit Iran’s nuclear program moved with uncommon speed last week to force a vote that could have blown up the negotiations, which are now at a delicate stage. Cooler heads prevailed, and action was delayed. But Congress could still sabotage the deal.

headline: A Cable (and Girder) Guy
keywords: ['Careers and Professions', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Bridges and Tunnels']
abstract: David Flores is a bridge inspection assistant team leader in New York.
lead_paragraph: David Flores, 31, is a bridge inspection assistant team leader for HNTB, an architecture, engineering and construction firm. He is based in New York.

headline: Turned Away From Iowa Ag Summit
abstract: A group of Democrats in Iowa are saying they were being denied entrance to the Iowa Ag Summit without any explanation.
lead_paragraph: The Iowa Ag Summit, which has drawn Jeb Bush, Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin and other leading 2016 Republican presidential hopefuls, is billed as a bipartisan event, but organizers turned away some ticket-holders who were registered Democrats without explanation.

headline: The Right Caddie? It Depends on the Golfer
abstract: In the absence of a Tinder-like app to match golfers and caddies, Adam Scott filled the role the old-fashioned way. He organized tryouts.
lead_paragraph: DORAL, Fla. — After Adam Scott’s high-profile split with his caddie, dozens of suitors reached out to him, including a man who enclosed a photo of himself and claimed to have ties to Japan’s Imperial House. A match made in Snapchat, it was not.

headline: On the Case at Mount Sinai, It’s Dr. Data
abstract: Jeffrey Hammerbacher, who started Facebook’s data science team, now uses his skills to improve medical treatments, a switch inspired by his own health crisis.
lead_paragraph: Jeffrey Hammerbacher is a number cruncher — a Harvard math major who went from a job as a Wall Street quant to a key role at Facebook to a founder of a successful data start-up.

headline: The Cost of Paying Attention
abstract: Clean air makes it possible to breathe. Silence makes it possible to think.
lead_paragraph: A FEW years ago, in a supermarket, I swiped my bank card to pay for groceries. I watched the little screen, waiting for its prompts. During the intervals between swiping my card, confirming the amount and entering my PIN, I was shown advertisements. Clearly some genius had realized that a person in this situation is a captive audience.

headline: Egypt Executes an Islamist Supporter of Ousted President
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Capital Punishment', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Egypt’s government carried out the death penalty against a man convicted of murder during the political violence that followed the military takeover of the government in 2013, the Interior Ministry said.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt’s government carried out the death penalty for the first time against an Islamist supporter of the ousted President Mohamed Morsi on Saturday, executing a man convicted of murder during the political violence that followed the military takeover of the government in 2013, the Interior Ministry said.

headline: Listeners Will Get the Birthday Gift
abstract: Longevity can assume a different order of magnitude in the jazz realm.
lead_paragraph: Longevity can assume a different order of magnitude in the jazz realm, where wisdom and experience are revered, and no one ever seems to retire. Still, there’s something singular about the staying power of the redoubtable drummer Roy Haynes, who will turn 90 on Friday, celebrating the occasion on the bandstand at the Blue Note.

headline: Amid Challenges, Humanity Arises
abstract: The annual ReelAbilities: NY Disabilities Film Festival is a workout for the emotions.
lead_paragraph: The annual ReelAbilities: NY Disabilities Film Festival is a workout for the emotions, full of both triumphant movies about overcoming adversity and sobering ones about struggle and loss. This year’s festival, the seventh, which runs from Thursday through March 18, is no exception.

headline: Ravishing Works Too Rarely Seen
abstract: “The Plains Indians: Artists of the Earth and Sky,” one of the greatest exhibitions of American Indian art you may ever see, opens Monday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: “The Plains Indians: Artists of the Earth and Sky,” one of the greatest exhibitions of American Indian art you may ever see, opens Monday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The show was originated by the Musée du Quai Branly in Paris and the Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art (where I saw it) in Kansas City, Mo., and organized by the inestimable Gaylord Torrence, the Nelson-Atkins’s curator in the field and also the orchestrator of its acclaimed permanent collection galleries.

headline: A Company Debut Is Also a Salute
abstract: When Merce Cunningham died in 2009 his company embarked on a legacy tour, as he had instructed.
lead_paragraph: When Merce Cunningham died in 2009 (it seemed sudden, though he was 90), his company embarked on a legacy tour, as he had instructed, performing around the world for two years before dissolving in New York on the eve of 2012. During this time, the privilege and burden of maintaining the celebrated Cunningham repertory fell to Robert Swinston, a veteran of the company for three decades. He joined as a dancer in 1980, became Cunningham’s assistant in 1992 and was named director of choreography after Cunningham’s death.

headline: Youth Isn’t Always Wasted
abstract: The music director of the New York Youth Symphony is often a rising star, and the talented, energetic Joshua Gersen, who currently holds the post, is no exception.
lead_paragraph: The music director of the New York Youth Symphony is often a rising star, and the talented, energetic Joshua Gersen, who currently holds the post, is no exception. He was recently named assistant conductor of the New York Philharmonic, a prime steppingstone to a major career. On Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall, he leads his superlative youth orchestra in Beethoven’s Violin Concerto (with Elena Urioste as soloist) and Rimsky-Korsakov’s colorful “Scheherazade.” The concert was also supposed to feature the premiere of Jonas Tarm’s “Marsh U Nebuttya,” but it was removed from the program when the orechestra discovered that it quoted a Nazi anthem. (2 p.m., 212-247-7800, nyyouthsymphony.org.)

headline: Tourist Traps Stand No Chance
abstract: What if you detoured around the tourist attractions when visiting a place for the first time and ventured off the beaten path?
lead_paragraph: What if you detoured around the tourist attractions when visiting a place for the first time and ventured off the beaten path? In “American Canvas,” which makes its premiere on Wednesday on Ovation, Dave Holmes focuses on the culture and history, not always mentioned in guidebooks, that make three cities distinctive. His journey begins in San Francisco, where he watches the Spidey-esque members of Bandaloop dance on the faces of skyscrapers with the help of rock-climbing equipment; traces the footsteps of Jack Kerouac and Allen Ginsberg; tosses a coin into an antique arcade machine; and samples the fare at the country’s oldest Chinatown. He also tours “@Large” an exhibition at Alcatraz, the former penitentiary, centered on freedom and confinement. Its creator, the Chinese artist and activist Ai Weiwei, considers himself to be in “soft detention,” he told The New York Times, his own passport withheld by his government.

headline: For Once, Expectation Returns the Cubs’ Embrace
abstract: With the signing of Jon Lester and the hiring of Manager Joe Maddon, the Cubs appear to be rounding into shape.
lead_paragraph: MESA, Ariz. — David Ross has felt it once before, the euphoria of romping out to the mound as a World Series champion, bathed in the lights of an ancient ballpark in a flagship baseball town. He wants to do it again, which is why he picked the Chicago Cubs as a free agent this winter.

headline: A Bittersweet Bow for the Elephant
abstract: “Jumbomania” is a long American tradition.
lead_paragraph: ON Thursday, Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus announced that its 13 traveling elephant performers would retire by 2018, ending a storied tradition for the Greatest Show on Earth.

headline: A Former Star Is Prepared for One Final Shot
abstract: Once a top-10 player and the highest-ranked American man, Mardy Fish, 33, is back for a last go — if for nothing else than to “reaffirm that I can still play the game.”
lead_paragraph: These days, tennis comebacks arrive in all shapes and sizes, driven by injury, illness, burnout or suspension, sometimes after years away from the professional tours.

headline: M.L.S.’s Expansion Siblings Are Set to Begin Rivalry, and Central Florida Is Abuzz
abstract: Orlando City, which rose from soccer’s lower tiers, will play New York City F.C., a team built from scratch, at the sold-out Citrus Bowl on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — With a threatened work stoppage seemingly averted and 2,000 standing-room-only tickets hastily added to a sold-out Citrus Bowl, Major League Soccer was set to introduce its two newest teams here Sunday.

headline: Selma Commemorates 50th Anniversary of ‘Bloody Sunday’
abstract: President Obama and a host of political figures from both parties arrived in Selma on Saturday to reflect on how far the country has come and how far it still has to go.
lead_paragraph: President Obama and a host of political figures from both parties arrived in Selma on Saturday to reflect on how far the country has come and how far it still has to go.

headline: Kentucky Finishes 31-0, but That’s Just a Warm-Up for the Ultimate Run
abstract: The Wildcats defeated Florida to finish their regular season undefeated. Now comes the hard part: college basketball’s postseason.
lead_paragraph: LEXINGTON, Ky. — Last month, Kentucky Coach John Calipari garnered attention for seeming to root for Louisiana State to defeat his team in a close contest that Kentucky eventually won, 71-69, to push its record to 24-0.

headline: Boko Haram Generates Uncertainty With Pledge of Allegiance to Islamic State
abstract: The Nigerian terrorist group appeared to make a spiritually binding oath to follow the authority of the Islamic State, but experts said the practical significance of the move was unclear.
lead_paragraph: With thousands of fighters and some parts of northeastern Nigeria under its control, Boko Haram is believed to be the largest jihadi group to pledge fidelity to the Islamic State. But terrorism experts say that the practical significance of the move announced Saturday is as yet unclear.

headline: Executives Are Jailed in Chile Finance Scandal
keywords: ['Frauds and Swindling', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Money Laundering', 'Corporate Taxes']
abstract: Four executives of one of Chile’s largest financial groups, a tax auditor and a former government official were taken into custody in a case that has shaken the economic elite and the main opposition party.
lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — Four executives of one of Chile’s largest financial groups, a tax auditor and a former government official were taken into custody on Saturday after prosecutors filed charges of tax fraud, bribery and money laundering against them in a scandal that has shaken the economic elite and the main opposition party.

headline: Treated as Part of the Team, Regardless of Playing Time

headline: After Syracuse Is Stripped of Wins, Jim Boeheim Is Unable to Gain Another
abstract: After his team lost its final game of the season, Coach Jim Boeheim did not attend the postgame news conference to address the N.C.A.A. sanctions imposed on his team Friday.
lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — Jim Boeheim walked onto the court at PNC Arena on Saturday wearing a cheerful pink tie, sporting his standard smirk and carrying 108 fewer career victories than he had one day earlier. Television and still cameras surrounded Boeheim, Syracuse’s coach, following his every move, capturing every one of his pleading gestures with referees and recording every pep talk with his players in a 71-57 loss to N.C. State.

headline: Did a Human or a Computer Write This?
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: A shocking amount of what we’re reading is created not by humans, but by computer algorithms. Can you tell the difference? Take the quiz.

lead_paragraph: Gay Talese reflects on how events in Selma, Ala., affected race relations in the United States.

headline: If an Algorithm Wrote This, How Would You Even Know?
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Language and Languages', 'Artificial Intelligence', 'News and News Media']
abstract: With software creating ever more of what we read, the idea that language is what makes us human is obsolete.
lead_paragraph: LET me hazard a guess that you think a real person has written what you’re reading. Maybe you’re right. Maybe not. Perhaps you should ask me to confirm it the way your computer does when it demands that you type those letters and numbers crammed like abstract art into that annoying little box.

abstract: President Obama addressed a crowd of thousands on the 50th anniversary of civil rights demonstrations in Selma, Ala.
lead_paragraph: President Obama addressed a crowd of thousands on the 50th anniversary of civil rights demonstrations in Selma, Ala.

headline: With Case Hanging Over Menendez, Democrats Lack a Clear Successor
abstract: As New Jersey has grown steadily more Democratic, power in the party has stayed mainly with a few long-serving officials. Among them is Senator Robert Menendez, embroiled in a corruption case.
lead_paragraph: For decades, Senator Robert Menendez has been one of the immovable objects of New Jersey politics. Even now, staring down expected criminal charges, the Democratic lawmaker has vowed not to give way.

headline: Back in Afghanistan, Modern Romeo and Juliet Face Grave Risks

lead_paragraph: BAMIAN, Afghanistan — After nearly a year on the run, a pair of star-crossed young lovers are back in the Afghan village where both their love affair and their problems began.

headline: Despite Protections, Miami Port Project Smothers Coral Reef in Silt
abstract: A multimillion-dollar project to expand a shipping channel at the Port of Miami has produced tons of sediment, suffocating large numbers of staghorn coral, an endangered species.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The government divers who plunged into the bay near the Port of Miami surfaced with bad news again and again: Large numbers of corals were either dead or dying, suffocated by sediment.

lead_paragraph: Russell Westbrook of the Oklahoma City Thunder has joined a long list of masked men roaming the courts of the N.B.A.

headline: $5,200 or $5.2 Million? It’s All in How It’s Framed
abstract: At a time when the attribution of paintings can be so litigious, a startling reassessment provides a rare window into the often imprecise, and debate-riddled, field of identifying the authorship of artworks.
lead_paragraph: The viscountess had decided to downsize.

headline: African Troops Train With Urgency as Terrorist Groups Make Advances
abstract: Hundreds of African, Western and American troops joined forces in military training exercises aimed at warding off the expansion of terrorist groups.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of African, Western and American troops joined forces in military training exercises aimed at warding off the expansion of terrorist groups.

headline: African Training Exercise Turns Urgent as Threats Grow
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: New ties between Boko Haram and the Islamic State have reinforced American and European concerns that have led to the training of African troops.
lead_paragraph: MAO, Chad — An oath of allegiance from Boko Haram, the Nigeria-based militant group, to the Islamic State on Saturday reinforces Western fears that the terrorist group is growing beyond its base in Iraq and Syria. These worries have prompted American and allied commandos to rush to train African counterterrorism troops to fight extremists on the continent.

headline: Kentucky Primary Change Would Allow Rand Paul to Run While Keeping Senate Seat
abstract: The state Republican Party leadership agreed to switch to a caucus so that Mr. Paul would not break a law prohibiting a candidate from appearing twice on a ballot.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Rand Paul succeeded on Saturday in persuading the leadership of the Republican Party in Kentucky to help him resolve a predicament that could threaten his plans to run for president in 2016: a state law that prohibits candidates from appearing twice on the same ballot.

headline: Obama Says He Didn’t Know Hillary Clinton Was Using Private Email Address
keywords: ['E-Mail', 'Archives and Records', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The president said he did not know until last week that Hillary Rodham Clinton was using private email while secretary of state, but said he was pleased that she was releasing the emails to be archived.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama said Saturday that he had learned only last week that Hillary Rodham Clinton used a private email system for her official correspondence while she was secretary of state.

headline: In Iowa, Jeb Bush Risks Support With Unpopular Stances
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: In his debut in the state as a likely presidential candidate, Mr. Bush did not back off his support of Common Core and immigration overhaul.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Jeb Bush made his Iowa debut as a likely presidential candidate by reiterating his support for two issues unpopular with conservative activists and announcing his opposition to a pair of federal benefits prized by industry here, a risky wager in the state that kicks off the nomination process.

headline: Dean Hess, Preacher and Fighter Pilot, Dies at 97
abstract: Colonel Hess unwittingly bombed a German orphanage during World War II and later helped rescue hundreds of Korean orphans. He recorded his exploits in an autobiography that was made into a film.
lead_paragraph: Dean Hess, a flying preacher who unwittingly bombed a German orphanage during World War II and six years later helped rescue hundreds of Korean foundlings endangered by Communist troops converging on Seoul, died on Monday at his home in Huber Heights, Ohio, near Dayton. He was 97.

headline: Ferguson Became Symbol, but Bias Knows No Border
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Poverty', 'Traffic and Parking Violations', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: The unfairness in Ferguson’s court system that is highlighted by a Justice Department report is not limited to it or even to Missouri.
lead_paragraph: If the shooting of Michael Brown had taken place about 500 yards to the southeast, he would have died not in Ferguson, Mo., but in the neighboring city of Jennings. The court system there, which is overseen by a white judge but has almost exclusively black defendants, routinely sends people to jail for failure to pay minor traffic fines, a new lawsuit alleges.

headline: Dirk Shafer, Playgirl Centerfold Who Revealed He Was Gay, Dies at 52
abstract: In a mock documentary called “Man of the Year,” Mr. Shafer explored the ramifications of being a closeted gay man who is a sex symbol for straight women.
lead_paragraph: Dirk Shafer, a former Playgirl magazine centerfold who chronicled his experiences as a closeted gay man in a 1995 mock documentary, “Man of the Year,” was found dead on Thursday in West Hollywood, Calif. He was 52.

headline: Bill Clinton Defends Foreign Donations to Family Foundation
keywords: ['Philanthropy', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The former president said that the Bill, Hillary & Chelsea Clinton Foundation has received money from around the globe, even from countries whose policies he disagrees with, but said donations supported the foundation’s work.
lead_paragraph: Former President Bill Clinton spoke out in defense of his family foundation’s acceptance of donations from foreign governments on Saturday, after a series of news reports that raised questions about the practice, which quietly resumed after Hillary Rodham Clinton stepped down as secretary of state.

headline: J. B. Holmes Leads Cadillac Championship by Five After a Round of Maintenance
abstract: Holmes and Dustin Johnson had a hole in one on the par-3 fourth, but Holmes also strung together four consecutive birdies on the back nine to stay atop the Cadillac Championship leaderboard for the third straight round.
lead_paragraph: DORAL, Fla. — J. B. Holmes is like the miler who runs a blistering first lap and tries to hold off the pack. In his first loop around Trump National Doral’s Blue Monster, Holmes tied a course record with a 10-under-par 62. He has played the next 36 holes in one under, including a two-under 70 on Saturday to maintain his lead at the Cadillac Championship, a World Golf Championships event.

headline: African Troops Train With Urgency as Terrorist Groups Make Advances
abstract: Hundreds of African, Western and American troops joined forces in military training exercises aimed at warding off the expansion of terrorist groups.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of African, Western and American troops joined forces in military training exercises aimed at warding off the expansion of terrorist groups.

headline: Winter Racing Is Staying at Aqueduct, but Not All the Horses Are
abstract: A prominent owner decided against sending a Kentucky Derby hopeful to Aqueduct Racetrack for the Gotham Stakes in the wake of 14 equine fatalities and 15 cancellations at the track since Dec. 3.
lead_paragraph: Barbara Banke, who owns horses competing at the highest level of racing, was so concerned about wintry conditions at Aqueduct Racetrack that she opted to have her two Kentucky Derby hopefuls oppose each other in Tampa, Fla. In the process, she scrapped plans to send one to New York for the $400,000 Gotham Stakes, held Saturday.

headline: Twenty Years Later, Devils Toast the Men Who Hoisted the Team’s First Stanley Cup
abstract: Twenty players and all three coaches from the 1994-95 Stanley Cup winners returned for festivities marking the milestone.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — The N.H.L. experienced a few firsts during the 1994-95 season. The league went through its first lockout, which cost it 111 days of its season and pushed the playoffs into the final week of June.

lead_paragraph: March 7, 2015

headline: Review: Björk at Carnegie Hall, Heartbreak and Pathos
abstract: The Icelandic singer-songwriter performed at Carnegie Hall on Saturday afternoon in what was the first of seven concerts in New York City.
lead_paragraph: The one indelible moment in “Björk” — a worshipful retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art, which has met with something other than critical approval — happens in “Black Lake,” a sound and video installation commissioned for the show. Björk is depicted alone, in a stark Icelandic landscape, furiously pounding a fist against her chest. She seems riven with despair, possibly trying to jolt her heart back into its rhythm, as unseen strings sustain a restive chord for an eternal half-minute or so.

headline: Kansas City Royals Sign Pitcher

headline: Mystery of the Murillo Artwork That Vanished at MoMA
abstract: Someone walked out with a painting by the Colombian artist Oscar Murillo that had been displayed on the floor of the Museum of Modern art, an official said. The painting was recovered, but not much else is clear.
lead_paragraph: When the Museum of Modern Art opened an exhibition of contemporary works in December, eight unstretched canvases by the celebrated young Colombian artist Oscar Murillo were not hung on walls, but were instead placed on the floor, where visitors were invited to handle them.

abstract: Céline, Chloé, Givenchy. Sunday is a quiet day in Paris, but the shows will be buzzing.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Paris shuts down on Sundays. Just try to find a dinner reservation; half the world is closed. Fashion Week, on the other hand, is open for business. “Neither snow nor rain” will stop it, as the United States Postal Service’s unofficial motto goes.

headline: No Sign of Distress in Malaysia Jet’s Crew, Report Says
keywords: ['Malaysia Airlines Flight 370', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters']
abstract: The captain and co-pilot of Flight 370, which disappeared a year ago, had shown no signs of distress, a Malaysian government report said Sunday.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Malaysian government released on Sunday the most comprehensive report to date on the circumstances surrounding the disappearance of a Boeing 777 jetliner one year ago, revealing for the first time that the pilot and co-pilot of the plane had displayed no discernible signs of distress before the ill-fated flight.

headline: Who Spewed That Abuse? Anonymous Yik Yak App Isn’t Telling

headline: Threats to Voting Rights Remain, Selma Gathering Is Told
abstract: Attorney General Eric Holder told the crowd at a commemorative march Sunday that access to the polls was “under siege” by a flurry of recent state laws.
lead_paragraph: SELMA, Ala. — Echoing a speech given by President Obama a day earlier, Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. said Sunday that access to the polls was “under siege” by a flurry of recent state laws, and by a 2013 United States Supreme Court decision that weakened the Voting Rights Act, the landmark legislation that was the great prize for the civil rights activists who marched here a half-century ago.

headline: Older Moviegoers Bolster Box Office of ‘The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel’
abstract: “The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel,” which cost Fox Searchlight about $15 million to make, took in an estimated $8.6 million from a relatively limited 1,573 screens in North America, according to Rentrak, which compiles box office data.
lead_paragraph: An audience that Hollywood often ignores — older moviegoers — turned “The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel” into an immediate success over the weekend, while the director Neill Blomkamp and the actor Vince Vaughn fell flat in their pursuit of younger crowds.

headline: 1940: Police Guard Judy Garland After Kidnap Warning
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Police responded to Judy Garland kidnapping in 1940.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Acting on a mysterious telephone warning that Judy Garland, the seventeen-year-old film star, was to be kidnapped, the police raced to her home and sent out radio cars patrolling the district. The telephone switchboard operator at the police station received an anonymous message asking if he knew who Judy Garland was and saying: ‘‘Get to her house quick. She is going to be kidnapped.’’ While the police kept guard outside her home, Judy went on with a party she was holding. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 9, 1940

headline: Kenzo’s Battle-Ready White Shadow
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Paris Fashion Week', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: The label’s fall/winter 2015 hair and makeup recalled Amazonian warrior women.
lead_paragraph: At the Kenzo fall 2015 show, the label’s co-creative directors (and co-founders of Opening Ceremony) Carol Lim and Humberto Leon celebrated the collective conscious. “We wanted a look that would be symbolic of the women’s strength and give an element of protection,” Lim says. The hairstylist Anthony Turner interpreted this as “almost Amazonian,” he said backstage, by giving the models deep side parts lined up with the outer edge of the brow and slicking hair into long, thick, low ponytails with a blunt edge. By contrast, the makeup artist Aaron de May brought the free-spirited warrior women to life with dewy, pearlescent complexions, glassy lips and a thick swath of opaque white shadow applied with a chopped-up paintbrush to create an erratic edge. “The makeup feels like they took something from nature and put it on with their fingers,” Leon says. “It looks like the girls did it themselves,” de May adds.

headline: 1965: Marines Land in Vietnam by Sea, Air
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: first American Marines land in Vietnam in 1965.
lead_paragraph: DA NANG, South Vietnam — Two battalions of U.S. marines today [March 8] landed by sea and air in South Vietnam to guard the strategic Da Nang air base, about 80 miles from the North Vietnamese border. Viet Cong guerrillas fired at the U.S. transport planes carrying many of the troops, but apparently the only result was a bullet hole in the wing of a C130 aircraft. No Marines were hurt. South Vietnamese government troops had spent the weekend flushing out Viet Cong guerrillas in the area to make the region around Da Nang as safe as possible for the 3,500-man Marine force to land. But the Marine deployment around the air base could soon lead to the first ground fighting between U.S. combat units and Communist guerrillas in Vietnam. U.S military men have been serving as advisers to South Vietnamese Army and Marine outfits in the field. But until now, there have been no American ground combat formations in South Vietnam. Spokesmen for the U.S military mission in Saigon said the Marines would remain under U.S. control, but their duties would be assigned after consultation with South Vietnamese military officers. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 9, 1965

headline: Review: The New York Philharmonic Highlights Nordic Works
abstract: As part of the Contact! new-music series, Alan Gilbert led a program of composers he encountered while conducting the Royal Stockholm Philharmonic Orchestra.
lead_paragraph: The Contact! new-music concerts were among Alan Gilbert’s first ideas at the helm of the New York Philharmonic, and they remain some of his best. At times, the series has seemed a missed opportunity, stuck in sleepy Manhattan halls and too focused on prominent composers. But high hopes have often been musically fulfilled.

headline: Review: Michael Meyer’s ‘In Manchuria’ Documents a Changing Rural China
abstract: Michael Meyer’s new book is part travelogue, part sociological study, part reportage and part memoir.
lead_paragraph: In Chinese, the region that was once the cradle of the mighty Qing dynasty is today rather prosaically known as Dongbei, the Northeast. Home to 110 million people, it has smoggy cities and bitingly cold weather. It can seem drab or worse to a visitor. But Michael Meyer has a more refined sense of history and poetry, and with his new book, “In Manchuria: A Village Called Wasteland and the Transformation of Rural China,” he seizes the opportunity to dig beneath the region’s gritty surfaces.

keywords: ['Nursing and Nurses', 'Infant Mortality', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Parenting', 'Women and Girls', 'Poverty']

lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — When it came time to have the baby, Shirita Corley was alone. Her mother was at the casino, her sister was not answering her cellphone, her boyfriend had disappeared months earlier, and her father she had not seen in years.

headline: Review: Hozier at Beacon Theater With Somber Songs of Love and Other Futilities
abstract: With doleful songs that ponder passion, mortality, compassion and sin, Hozier is also a hitmaker who was greeted with the squeals of pop adoration.
lead_paragraph: Hozier, the Irish songwriter who performed at the Beacon Theater on Friday night, is a somber phenomenon. His songs ponder passion, mortality, compulsion and sin. His voice is a richly melancholy moan, with echoes of Van Morrison and Jeff Buckley; his music is grounded in blues, soul and Celtic ballads, and it’s full of minor chords, starkly syncopated guitar picking, blunt tom-tom beats and moody drama. Yet Hozier, whose debut album was released last fall, is also a hitmaker who was greeted, between his doleful songs, with the squeals and whistles of pop adoration and female voices calling out, “I love you!”

headline: Review: ‘The Legend of Mulan’ Choreographs a Chinese Folk Tale
abstract: The Hong Kong Dance Company presented its version of the story about heroism and honor, beloved by Disney fans.
lead_paragraph: Mulan, the girl who disguises herself as a man to join the army in place of her frail father, is beloved by Disney fans. But does it work as a dance? The Hong Kong Dance Company, in residence at the David H. Koch Theater, presented its version of that Chinese folk tale on Thursday with a four-act production of “The Legend of Mulan.”

headline: Review: St. Paul Chamber Orchestra Opens Its New Concert Hall
abstract: This ensemble celebrated its new space with concerts featuring work by Beethoven and others.
lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL — While the world has many splendid opera houses and orchestra halls, performance spaces ideally suited to chamber orchestras of, say, 30 to 35 players, are rarer. These ensembles are like hybrids between chamber groups and full orchestras. What’s needed is a hall that allows clarity and detail in the playing to come through while providing orchestral resonance and bloom.

headline: On the Fall 2015 Runways in Paris, Black Patent Leather Coats Are Slicker Than Ever
abstract: Loewe, Dior and Margiela have all shown long, sleek versions of the look this week.
lead_paragraph: Patent leather, in all its glossy glory, has made a return to the runway in a big way for the fall/winter 2015 season — from a prim and proper skirt suit at Emilia Wickstead and J.W. Anderson’s ode to the ’80s in London to thigh-high boots at Versace. In Paris, especially, we’ve seen lots of black patent leather outerwear. First, Jonathan Anderson’s flirtation with the decade of excess at Loewe included a loose coat. At Maison Margiela, John Galliano’s debut prêt-à-porter collection for the brand featured a sleek, floor-grazing belted coat. Finally, at Dior, Raf Simons’s interest in the material (as evidenced by his couture presentation in January) was again demonstrated by a netted black patent coat.

abstract: The group’s program Saturday at Zankel Hall featured two world premieres and a dedication to one of its longtime lighting designer who died last year.
lead_paragraph: The Kronos Quartet offered a program of new and recent works full of ideas in the Late Nights at Zankel Hall series on Saturday, and the composers’ program notes were sometimes more compelling than the music.

headline: Review: The Peggy Spina Tap Company at the Spina Loft in SoHo
abstract: Ms. Spina’s troupe performed in the loft where she has lived since the 1970s, with music led by the jazz pianist Joel Forrester.
lead_paragraph: It has been many years since lofts in SoHo were the province of musicians, dancers and artists. There are holdouts, though, and on Friday one of them invited the public in. Passing the high-end stores on Prince Street, audience members climbed a rickety staircase to sit on folding chairs in Peggy Spina’s loft. Ushers took care to keep slush-wet shoes off the wooden floor. That was reserved for footwear with metal on the soles. Ms. Spina is a tap dancer.

lead_paragraph: Plays that mix realism and absurdity can be difficult to stage effectively. The director and actors have to figure out how to do that Durang-ian swing between “could happen” and “deliriously improbable.”

headline: Jack White to Release Elvis’s First Recording
abstract: Billboard reported that Mr. White was the anonymous bidder who bought the 1953 recording at a Graceland auction this January.
lead_paragraph: The musician Jack White portrayed Elvis Presley in “Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story” in 2007. Now, he’s bringing Elvis back to life in another way: by releasing Elvis’s first-ever recording on Third Man Records, Mr. White’s label, after paying $300,000 for the acetate disc. Billboard reported that Mr. White was the anonymous bidder who bought the 1953 recording at a Graceland auction this January. The record features two covers of ballads, “My Happiness” and “That’s Where Your Heartaches Begin,” and was recorded by an 18-year-old Presley in Memphis three years before his breakout single, “Heartbreak Hotel.” Third Man Records will release the recording on April 18, Record Store Day, as a 10-inch, 78-r.p.m. facsimile. Mr. White has broken a few vinyl-related records recently. On Record Store Day last year, he set the world’s fastest time (3 hours, 55 minutes and 21 seconds) for recording, pressing and releasing a vinyl disc, and his 2014 album, “Lazaretto,” is the biggest-selling vinyl album since 1994.

headline: 6 Stabbed at Migos Show
abstract: Six people were stabbed at a concert by the rap group Migos on Friday night in Albany.
lead_paragraph: Six people were stabbed at a concert by the rap group Migos on Friday night in Albany, said Steven Smith, the public information officer for the Albany police. The concert, at the Washington Avenue Armory, took a violent turn between 12:50 and 1:35 a.m. None of the injuries were life threatening. In addition, a 19-year-old woman reported that she was robbed and assaulted in a venue bathroom by six women. She sustained minor injuries to her head and face. The police are investigating, but no arrests have been made. In October, three people were shot, one fatally, outside Club Hive in Queens, following a Migos after-party at the site.

keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Voter Registration and Requirements']
abstract: The mind imagines the horror at the Edmund Pettus Bridge, but the president’s speech was not only about the past.

headline: DC and Marvel, Beware: Valiant Is to Make Films
abstract: DC’s Justice League and Marvel’s Avengers are going to have to make room for even more heroes coming to the big screen.
lead_paragraph: DC’s Justice League and Marvel’s Avengers are going to have to make room for even more heroes coming to the big screen. The independent comic book publisher Valiant Entertainment and the Beijing-based DMG Entertainment announced on Sunday a nine-figure investment and partnership for feature-film financing as well as publishing, television and licensing opportunities. Valiant’s library of characters and concepts include X-O Manowar, an alien abductee from the past thrown into the present with high-tech armor, and the series Harbinger, about teenagers with special abilities at odds with a corporation out to shape the destiny of the world. Comic superheroes are profitable and highly sought intellectual properties for film franchises, said Dan Mintz, the chief executive officer of DMG, in a statement, “so taking a stake in the last independent massive comic universe is a strategic investment for DMG that will produce movies and TV that are both appealing and relevant to a global audience.” In addition to developing films for release in the United States and China, the two companies will develop Valiant’s characters for new audiences in China and the Asia-Pacific region. There are plans for Chinese-language publishing, animation and theme parks, as well as toys and apparel.

headline: The Song That Drove Sherman Crazy
abstract: One of the Civil War’s biggest hits, “Marching Through Georgia” captured what the war was about — but was played so often that Sherman tried to ban it at reunions.
lead_paragraph: By the time Maj. Gen. William T. Sherman arrived in Boston for the 1890 national encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic, he was already sick of hearing “Marching Through Georgia,” a song commemorating his historic 1864 campaign from Atlanta to the Atlantic coast. The opera singer Clara Louise Kellogg, a friend of his, later asserted that Sherman had always hated it “above all songs,” but something snapped in the old general’s mind that day in Boston. We can only imagine his growing discomfort as he stood on the grandstand and heard no less than 250 different bands parade by playing the tune. Although Sherman kept his composure at the time, rumors quickly spread that he vowed then and there to never attend another reunion without a guarantee that no one would play it.

headline: What’s On TV Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9:10 A.M. (HBO Signature) ATONEMENT (2007) Saoirse Ronan (above with James McAvoy) received an Oscar nomination for her portrayal of Briony, a 13-year-old aspiring playwright who accuses the son (Mr. McAvoy) of a family servant — and the lover of her older sister (Keira Knightley) — of a crime in this drama directed by Joe Wright and based on the Ian McEwan novel. Romola Garai and Vanessa Redgrave play Briony at different times in her life. “The main casualty of the film’s long, murky middle and end sections is the big moral theme — and also the ingenious formal gimmick — that provides the book with some of its intensity and much of its cachet,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “As the title suggests, ‘Atonement’ is fundamentally about guilt and the attempt to overcome it, and about the tricky, tragically imperfect power of art to compensate for real-life crimes and misdemeanors.” The film received six more Oscar nominations, including one for best picture, and won for Dario Marianelli’s score, featuring the pianist Jean-Yves Thibaudet and a clacking typewriter.

headline: University of Oklahoma Fraternity Closed After Racist Video Is Posted Online

lead_paragraph: Sigma Alpha Epsilon, one of America’s largest college fraternities, closed its chapter at the University of Oklahoma late Sunday after a video posted hours earlier appeared to show fraternity members singing a racist chant. The university administration said it was investigating.

headline: The World’s Problem With Sex Ed
abstract: Disputes over teaching kids about their bodies are only growing.
lead_paragraph: ONTARIO was thrown into an uproar recently when officials presented the first changes to the province’s sex-education curriculum since 1998. Starting in the fall, second graders will learn about “saying no” and “improper touching”; third graders will be introduced to gender identity and sexual orientation; and seventh graders will learn of the dangers of “sexting” and of sexually transmitted diseases.

headline: Our Navy Is Big Enough
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'Ships and Shipping']
abstract: Don’t heed Republican demands to increase the size of its budget.
lead_paragraph: AT General Dynamics Bath Iron Works in Maine, workers are completing a warship unlike any the world has seen. The $3.3 billion Zumwalt destroyer uses all-electric propulsion, employs stealth features, carries a huge arsenal of guided missiles, and mounts advanced cannons that can hit targets 63 miles away. Most likely it will never be tested in battle, because no other nation is even attempting to build a warship like the Zumwalt, which symbolizes the gigantic advantage the United States Navy enjoys.

headline: Partying Like It’s 1995
abstract: Now, as then, unemployment is down to a level at which the economy should be overheating, but it isn’t. How should the Fed react?
lead_paragraph: Six years ago, Paul Ryan, who has since become the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee and the G.O.P.’s leading voice on matters economic, had an Op-Ed article published in The Times. Under the headline “Thirty Years Later, a Return to Stagflation,” he warned that the efforts of the Obama administration and the Federal Reserve to fight the effects of financial crisis would bring back the woes of the 1970s, with both inflation and unemployment high.

headline: No Cause to Delay the Afghan Pullout
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'Editorials']
abstract: The Pentagon is trying to build support for a slower drawdown of troops. But without strong evidence of its impact, a new schedule would be a mistake.
lead_paragraph: Last year, the Afghan Army lost more than 17,000 troops and civilian employees as a result of desertions, combat deaths and discharges, leaving a force that is authorized to employ 195,000 people significantly understaffed. In the fight against the Taliban, Afghan forces have been getting killed and injured at a significantly higher rate than in 2014, exacerbating attrition levels that appear to be unsustainable.

headline: A Complicated Future for a Banlieue on the Outskirts of Paris
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Suburbs', 'Editorials', 'Religion and Belief', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Forces of gentrification and tolerance in a working-class suburb.
lead_paragraph: PANTIN, France — Life in my neighborhood, a banlieue on the northeastern edge of Paris, has been changing for a while. In October, the local green market moved to a new public square that has a new bistro with cafe tables and a lavish new bakery, even a new vendor selling organic kale. Pantin, dubbed the “Brooklyn of Paris” because of its booming cultural scene, seemed to be turning into a French version of Williamsburg.

headline: A Reckless Call From the Senate’s Leader
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Governors (US)', 'Electric Light and Power', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Air Pollution']
abstract: It is shocking to see Mitch McConnell try to undermine President Obama’s efforts to regulate power plant emissions.
lead_paragraph: For all his partisan animus toward President Obama, it is still shocking to see the Senate’s majority leader, Mitch McConnell, urge the nation’s governors to undermine the Obama administration’s efforts to regulate power plant emissions of carbon dioxide, the main greenhouse gas responsible for global warming.

With a combination of still images, video, text and informational graphics, it seeks to use as many different tools to capture the reader’s imagination. But what it really is aiming for is something that is time-tested: to create a community.

abstract: Older people are the most frequent victims of serious falls. Here are some ways to prevent them.

Especially not this winter, and especially not in cities and towns like Atlanta where experience negotiating ice and slush under foot is limited.

headline: ClassPass and the Joy and Guilt of the Digital Middleman Economy
keywords: ['Exercise', 'Delivery Services', 'Venture Capital', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Health Clubs']
abstract: Should I feel bad about using my new favorite app?
lead_paragraph: Each month, I pay $99 to a company called ClassPass for the luxury of taking an unlimited number of fitness classes in and around Brooklyn, where I live. In the depths of this winter, regular exercise — a key to calming my hyperactive and anxiety-prone brain even when it’s less awful outside — has become crucial enough to maintaining my sanity that I find myself prioritizing my ClassPass bill over other splurges, like ordering in, taking cabs and expensive nights out.

headline: Today in Politics: ‘Common Core’ to Hit Iowa Airwaves
abstract: A group backing an education overhaul is poised to begin showing television commercials in Iowa promoting Common Core to potential Republican caucusgoers.
lead_paragraph: Good Monday morning from Washington, where spring is in the air and alleviating (real) gridlock is on the agenda. Hillary Rodham Clinton’s emails continue to be the talk of the town, and former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida is enlisting his son to help fill his would-be campaign war chest. We start off the week with a look at what future Iowa caucusgoers will be seeing a lot of: Common Core ads.

headline: Morning Agenda: Stress Tests Threaten Goldman Profit
abstract: Goldman’s poor performance on the Fed’s stress tests has raised concerns. | Another look at Warren Buffett’s success. | G.M. seeks to avoid a proxy fight with the investor Harry J. Wilson. | Blackstone is near a deal for the former Sears Tower.
lead_paragraph: STRESS TEST RESULTS THREATEN GOLDMAN PROFIT | After Goldman Sachs’s poor performance on Federal Reserve stress tests, analysts and investors are worried that the bank could be barred from buying back its own stock or increasing dividends, an important profit source for the bank, DealBook’s Nathaniel Popper writes. The bank has used dividends and share buybacks to appeal to investors, which generally increase the amount of profits attributed to every share, at a time when other elements of the bank’s business have faced challenges. The Fed will publicly give its final verdict on Goldman’s buyback plans on Wednesday.

headline: When a Presidential Nominating Contest Isn’t a Contest
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Democrats are on the verge of a campaign unlike in any recent memory.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic Party is on the cusp of a primary-election campaign unlike any in memory. It does not have an incumbent president running for re-election. It does not even have a sitting vice president with an easy path to the nomination. Yet the party may conduct one of the least competitive nominating contests in modern political history.

abstract: Reaganomics versus Boehnernomics.
lead_paragraph: With job growth finally running at the pace we’d expect to see after a deep slump, we’re not hearing as much about how Obama’s anti-capitalist policies are the reason we’re not having a V-shaped recovery, the way we did under the Blessed Reagan. But it’s true that recovery was a long time coming. Why?

headline: Hillary Clinton Is More Vulnerable in 2016 Than You Think

headline: U.N. Reveals ‘Alarmingly High’ Levels of Violence Against Women
keywords: ["Women's Rights", 'Women and Girls', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Domestic Violence', 'Sex Crimes', 'Sexual Harassment']
abstract: Despite progress for women on other fronts, violence is a persistent problem, with about 35 percent of women saying they have been attacked, a United Nations report says.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The evidence is ubiquitous. The gang rape of a young woman on a bus in New Delhi sets off an unusual burst of national outrage in India. In South Sudan, women are assaulted by both sides in the civil war. In Iraq, jihadists enslave women for sex. And American colleges face mounting scrutiny about campus rape.

headline: Changing Tastes Blamed for Slide at McDonald’s
abstract: The fast-food giant reported a startling 4 percent drop in February sales in the United States, and a 1.7 percent decrease globally.

headline: Leon Wieseltier Takes New Humanities Post at Brookings
abstract: Leon Wieseltier, the former longtime literary editor of The New Republic, is joining Brookings as the Isaiah Berlin Senior Fellow in Culture and Policy, where he will focus on “the influence of culture and the humanities on various realms of American life, society and international affairs,” according to a news release.
lead_paragraph: The Brookings Institution was founded in 1916 with the mission of becoming “the first private organization devoted to analyzing public policy issues at the national level.” Now, the think tank known for its work on economics, governance and foreign policy (and a steady drip of news releases with titles like “Innovation and manufacturing labor: a value-chain perspective”) will be adding the humanities to its portfolio.

lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The European Central Bank began its long-awaited bond-buying program on Monday, an unprecedented 1.1 trillion euro bid to help revive the eurozone economy.

headline: Japanese Women Play Without Their Superstar
abstract: Homare Sawa, the most famous Japanese women’s soccer player and one of the country’s most beloved athletes, has been dropped from the national team for now.
lead_paragraph: VILAMOURA, Portugal — The players of the Japanese women’s national soccer team went through a training drill here last week, scooting short passes in from the wings before sprinting toward the penalty area and blasting shots on goal. One after another after another they went, mostly working in silence except when they broke into loud cheers after a player hit a particularly pretty shot that found the side netting. The mood was upbeat — the sunny weather on Portugal’s south coast surely helped — but also serious and focused.

abstract: Shares of Macerich were trading above Simon’s hostile bid, suggesting that some investors believe the final price will go higher.
lead_paragraph: Across America, many shopping malls are dying. Stagnant middle-class incomes, overbuilt retail space and competitors like Amazon.com and Costco are turning these former fixtures of the retail landscape into abandoned boxes, devoid of clients or customers.

headline: Unions Suffer Latest Defeat in Midwest With Signing of Wisconsin Measure
abstract: The so-called right-to-work law prevents organized labor from forcing all workers to pay union dues, making Wisconsin the 25th state to adopt such a policy.
lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis. — For decades, states across the South, Great Plains and Rocky Mountains enacted policies that prevented organized labor from forcing all workers to pay union dues or fees. But the industrial Midwest resisted.

headline: In Forecasting Health Costs, Let Technology Be Your Guide
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Innovation', 'Medical Devices', 'Medicare', 'Medicaid']
abstract: The ability to sustain lower growth in costs will depend in large part on how investments in health care technology are encouraged.
lead_paragraph: The expansion of health care insurance can drive the development of new technologies that can drive up health care spending. But it doesn’t have to.

headline: New Research on Antidepressants and Pregnancy Finds No Link to Asthma
abstract: New research suggest that taking S.S.R.I.s while pregnant does not increase the risk of asthma in the resulting babies, but the decision to take medication or not remains difficult.
lead_paragraph: Many women with a history of depression who take antidepressants assume that once they get pregnant, they should try to wean themselves off their meds to avoid negative side effects for the baby. A new large study published in the journal Pediatrics challenges one reason behind that assumption. The research found that taking selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (the antidepressants also known as S.S.R.I.s) while pregnant does not increase the risk of asthma in the resulting babies. What is associated with an increased risk of asthma? According to this study and other research, untreated prenatal depression.

headline: How to Get More Women to Join the Debate, Part II
abstract: There were great questions to my original post on the lack of female commenters on the New York Times website. Here are some answers.
lead_paragraph: Many people asked good questions in response to my article about how only 25 percent of comments in the New York Times are made by women. Here are responses to several of them.

headline: Wet and Ever-So-Slightly Wild Ponytails at Stella McCartney
abstract: Spritzes of water and piles of mousse created a just-out-of-the-pool beauty look for the house’s fall 2015 runway.
lead_paragraph: “It’s really quite directional in an effortless way,” says the hairstylist Eugene Souleiman of the look he created for the Stella McCartney fall 2015 fashion show. “The collection is really very beautiful, so I didn’t want to do romantic, I didn’t want to do pretty, I didn’t want to do glamorous. I wanted to do something that wasn’t so refined.” Backstage at the Paris Opera House, Souleiman spritzed models’ dry hair until damp and used his fingers to work through piles of mousse to achieve a wet-look effect with texture and hold. After pulling hair into a ponytail at the crown of the head, he matted wisps around the face. “We wanted to make it look as if the girls pulled their hair back into a ponytail after they had been swimming,” he says. “We haven’t dipped our feet into the water, we dove right in.”

headline: Secede? Separatists Claim Texas Never Joined United States

headline: 1915: U.K. Wants Power Over All Factories During the War
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: The British government looks to take over factories for war munitions in 1915.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Great Britain is the main arsenal of the Grand Alliance. This aspect of the war received new emphasis from Mr. Lloyd George in his speech in introducing the Amending Defence of the Realm Bill in the House of Commons this afternoon. The Chancellor said it is of vital importance to the country that the Government should be given every facility for the output of munitions of war. Under the act of 1914 the Government obtained the power to take over any works where war material is being produced. It now asks for power in respect to works where war material is not being produced at present, but which are capable of being used for the purpose. — The New York Herald, European Edition, March 10, 1915

headline: Herblock’s Sharp Pen, and Others’, to Go on Display at Library of Congress
abstract: An exhibition at the Library of Congress will look at how the political cartoonist Herblock and some contemporaries dealt with six issues.
lead_paragraph: The Library of Congress  will showcase the power and punch of the political cartoon in the exhibition “Pointing Their Pens: Herblock and Fellow Cartoonists Confront the Issues,” which opens March 21. Herbert L. Block, who died in 2001, was the chief editorial cartoonist for The Washington Post for more than half a century. His work forms the core of the exhibition, which focuses on six subjects that inspired some of his most memorable cartoons: World War II, the McCarthy era, the Cold War, the Vietnam War, Richard M. Nixon and the Middle East. Each will have two cartoons by Herblock and three by his contemporaries.

headline: 1965: Alabama Brutality Condemned
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: President Johnson comdemns brutality against Selma demonstrators in 1965.

Mr. Johnson also said he has directed the Justice Department to act as a ‘‘friend of the court’’ in seeking a ruling that would permit Negroes to exercise what he termed their right ‘‘to walk from Selma to Montgomery in order to focus attention on their efforts to secure the right to register and vote.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 10, 1965

A Cadillac hearse pulled up, and traffic was halted by the police. The great double doors of the cathedral swung open, and a small procession of priests, along with Cardinal Timothy M.
