headline: Brooklyn Style, Transported to the Suburbs of Connecticut
abstract: Introducing Gather, a recently opened fashion and home décor shop in Old Greenwich, and its new collection of women’s basics.
lead_paragraph: Brooklyn might be the cradle of the maker movement, with its deep appreciation for all that’s handcrafted and artisan-made, but predictably that cultural aesthetic has increasingly found a home in the borough’s surrounding suburbs. Case in point: Gather, a recently opened fashion and home décor shop tucked away in the front-porch-loving town of Old Greenwich, Connecticut. Co-owned by Rebecca Karson, a former prop stylist who grew up in Brooklyn Heights, the 80-square-foot space is tiny (even by New Yorkers’ standards) and filled with a well-edited selection of small batch goods, including porcelain clay pottery hand-carved by the artist Elizabeth Benotti; Jess Brown’s rag dolls, which are filled with sustainable corn fiber and dyed using Persian black tea; slim, delicate gold jewelry sculpted by Rebecca Peacock (who works out of her farmhouse studio in the Catskill Mountains); and delicate clothing from Nuthatch, which hails from Maine and employs local mills. In other words, it’s a mix you can imagine browsing, matcha tea in hand, at the Brooklyn fleas. Still, Karson didn’t set out to curate her shop that way. She simply scouts for pieces that catch her eye. “I’ve always gravitated towards things that are handmade or vintage,” she explains. “They tell a more interesting story.”

headline: Lisa Bonchek Adams: She Did as Much as She Could for as Long as She Could
abstract: Lisa Bonchek Adams did not write like a woman resigned. She did not want to die. But even more, she did not want to disappear.
lead_paragraph: Lisa Bonchek Adams lived her life on her own terms, regardless of her diagnosis. She fought long and hard against death, and she refused to be silenced, even when others questioned her decision to live her cancer out loud — and to die out loud. Her death on March 6, 2015, was not unexpected by any who followed her, nor was it expected. Lisa always told her readers when things were bad. But she never gave up, or at least, not publicly. In every update, no matter how grave, Lisa looked forward to spring.

headline: A New Tool to Investigate Inside Tippers

But recent charges against a corporate officer show that passing along confidential information can be perilous, even if the intent is something other than insider trading.

headline: Blocking the Paths to Suicide

headline: Discerning Plant Picks Its Pollinators
abstract: When it comes to pollinators, plants aren’t usually picky. But one tropical plant seems able to choose its suitors, a new study has found.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to pollinators, plants are not usually picky. But one tropical plant seems able to choose its suitors, a new study found. When Heliconia tortuosa resisted researchers’ attempts to pollinate it by hand, they tried introducing the plant to six species of hummingbirds and a butterfly. Only two types of the hummingbirds — those with the longest bills and that travel most extensively — were consistently successful in getting pollen from the plant. Writing in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, researchers at Oregon State University and the Smithsonian suggest this coyness may be a way for the plants to ensure genetic diversity.

abstract: The American ambassador to France transformed her home into a one-night-only art exhibition for a cocktail party in honor of T.

Hartley hosted in honor of T magazine.

headline: The Most Memorable Costumes of ‘Mad Men’ Get the Museum Treatment
abstract: A new exhibition highlights, among other aspects of the show’s production design, its strikingly precise ’60s-era wardrobes.
lead_paragraph: As compelling as the storylines and characters on “Mad Men” — which airs the second half of its final season beginning April 5 on AMC — are the show’s meticulously researched 1960s-era costumes. (In many instances, the outfits — Ginsberg’s stained shirt, Megan’s “Zou Bisou Bisou” dress — almost feel like characters themselves.) Now, a new exhibition opening March 14 at the Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, “Matthew Weiner’s Mad Men,” brings the show’s wardrobe, and the rest of its creative process, to life. More than 25 of the ensembles developed by the show’s costume designer, Janie Bryant, will appear alongside props, advertisements and other ephemera from the show’s production department, giving fans the chance to see such garments as Joan’s blood-stained dress from the lawn-mower episode and Sally’s first minidress up close. Bryant worked closely with the museum’s curators to assemble the collection, even going so far as to track down clothing that had since disappeared into Hollywood costume houses. “To see a costume in full action on screen and then see it standing still,” she says, “is a whole different kind of visual experience.”

headline: Keeping Your Hair in Chemo
abstract: A growing number of breast cancer patients are freezing their scalps as a way to preserve their hair during chemotherapy.
lead_paragraph: Hair loss is one of the most obvious side effects of cancer treatment. Now, a growing number of breast cancer patients are freezing their scalps as a way to preserve their hair during chemotherapy.

headline: Rubio-Lee: Promise and Problems
abstract: The strengths and (unfortunately) weaknesses of the latest Republican tax proposal.
lead_paragraph: Last week, Senators Marco Rubio and Mike Lee released the outline of a comprehensive tax reform, which adds changes to corporate and investment taxes to their earlier proposal for a more pro-family revision of the individual code. The plan earned generally favorable comments from Yuval Levin, Ramesh Ponnuru and James Pethokoukis, all writers associated with the tendency we’re calling reform conservatism, but the addition of tax cuts on the business side drew praise from a wider range of conservative and libertarian policy writers and economists as well. The reformist interest in reorienting Republican tax policy toward middle-class families has created tensions with the party’s supply-side wing, but because it reforms the corporate/business code the Rubio-Lee plan clearly has the potential to be a politically-unifying vision, marrying pro-family and pro-growth policy while putting the era of “9-9-9″ and Fair Tax-style unicorns in the rearview mirror.

headline: New Umberto Eco Novel, ‘Numero Zero,’ Coming This Fall

lead_paragraph: Umberto Eco, the Italian writer and philosopher best known for novels like “Foucault’s Pendulum” and “The Name of the Rose,” will publish a new novel in the United States this fall, with Houghton Mifflin Harcourt.

He was 59.

headline: Fighting Back Against Malware
keywords: ['Computer Security', 'iOS (Operating System)', 'Reservations (Airlines, Hotels, Etc.)', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Travel and Vacations', 'iPad', 'iPhone']
abstract: A flurry of pop-up ads, an unfamiliar search toolbar and a changed home page are just some of the symptoms of malicious software.
lead_paragraph: Q. My husband recently asked me to download a boat manual onto my Dell laptop. Not only did the manual not load, but all of a sudden I am getting too many pop-ups that make working from my laptop all but impossible. headline: Review: ‘The Liquid Plain,’ a Naomi Wallace Drama at the Signature Theater
abstract: Ms. Wallace’s soggy play centers on two runaway slaves in Rhode Island who hope to board a ship to freedom in Africa.
lead_paragraph: In “The Liquid Plain,” the soggy play by Naomi Wallace at the Signature Theater, a pair of runaway slaves eke out a living on a dock in Rhode Island, desperately hoping to escape across the sea to Africa. Adjua (Kristolyn Lloyd) and Dembi (Ito Aghayere) are lovers determined to forge new lives for themselves, and they sustain each other with ardent affection and dreams of a future that will ease memories of the brutalities they endured in the past.

headline: Life and Warmth in Fed Transcripts: Reporter’s Notebook
abstract: The Times reporter Binyamin Applebaum explains how he sped through a 1,600-page Federal Reserve transcript and filed a story shortly after the transcripts were released.
lead_paragraph: Every so often I get an admiring note from a reader who is impressed that I have published an article about some new report almost as soon as the report was released. Sometimes I just say thank you. Sometimes I tell them the secret: I got the report in advance, on condition that I would not publish an article until it was released publicly. It was not magic; it was just careful choreography.

headline: Review: ‘Woyzeck, FJF’ Is a Quixotic Adaptation at the New Ohio Theater
abstract: This adaptation of Georg Büchner’s challenging fragment of a play, by No-Win Productions, teeters between reality and fantasy.
lead_paragraph: Georg Büchner, who died in 1837, was a playwright so ahead of his time that the theater is still playing catch-up. Before his young demise, he wrote the historical epic “Danton’s Death,” the odd comedy “Leonce and Lena” and perhaps his trickiest play of all, the unfinished “Woyzeck,” which exists only in jumbled fragments. A definitive text, production or even an ordering of scenes proves elusive.

headline: Review: In ‘Powers,’ Bad Guys With Superhero Status
abstract: This show, on Sony’s online PlayStation Network, combines the genres of superhero fantasy and the police procedural.
lead_paragraph: For a show that exists as an offshoot of a video-game console, “Powers” plays less like a video game than you might expect, or fear. The new 10-episode series — available beginning Tuesday through Sony’s online PlayStation Network, console not required — is action-oriented, with doses of violence and crude language, but it’s a television show, not a first-person shooter. And it’s a reasonably entertaining one in its CW-style, low-rent, formulaic way.

This tale, a political thriller about a sergeant during the Korean War who is brainwashed and turned into an oblivious assassin for a Communist conspiracy, is best known from the 1962 film version directed by John Frankenheimer.

headline: Reggie Jackson to Auction Off Sign From Old Yankee Stadium
abstract: Jackson bought the 10-foot-high letters that spelled out the old stadium’s name before it was razed. Now he plans to auction off the 13 letters.
lead_paragraph: Like many former Yankees, Reggie Jackson wanted some things to remember the old Yankee Stadium by after its final season in 2008. He bought his old locker. He acquired a section of the black bleacher seats, where he hit the last of three home runs in Game 6 of the 1977 World Series that cemented his reputation as Mr. October.

headline: Lew Soloff, Trumpeter for Blood, Sweat and Tears, Dies at 71
abstract: Mr. Soloff played across many genres, but he reached his broadest audience as a member of one of the first jazz-rock bands.
lead_paragraph: Lew Soloff, a jazz trumpeter who reached a broader audience with the jazz-rock band Blood, Sweat & Tears, especially with a memorable solo on the original version of the 1969 hit “Spinning Wheel,” died on Sunday in Brooklyn. He was 71.

headline: Bratton and de Blasio Offering Mixed Signals Over Marijuana
abstract: A law enforcement issue highlights the distinct sensibilities of New York City’s mayor and his police commissioner.
lead_paragraph: It was a leading initiative of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s first year in office: policing the possession of small amounts of marijuana with summonses, not arrests.

headline: A New Tack in the War on Mining Mountains
abstract: PNC Financial joins a growing list of banks that no longer finance coal-mining companies that pursue the mountaintop removal of coal, an environmentally devastating practice.
lead_paragraph: Last week, with little fanfare, PNC Financial, the nation’s seventh-largest bank, disclosed a significant strategic shift. The bank said it would no longer finance coal-mining companies that pursue mountaintop removal of coal in Appalachia, an environmentally devastating practice that has long drawn opposition.

headline: Rockies Hope That Once Troy Tulowitzki Recovers, They Will, Too
abstract: The Rockies, coming off another losing season, are hoping for a return to form by Tulowitzki, a shortstop whose on-field brilliance has been obscured by injuries.
lead_paragraph: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — Troy Tulowitzki reported to work on Monday and played a baseball game. He had not done this since last July, before his latest major surgery. It was going to be a good day.

headline: Tech Blog GigaOm Abruptly Shuts Down
abstract: The technology blog, founded in 2006, became a fixture in Silicon Valley and claimed 6.4 million monthly readers.
lead_paragraph: Gigaom, a pioneering technology blog that became a fixture in Silicon Valley and claimed 6.4 million monthly readers, abruptly announced on Monday that it would shut down.

headline: Rays Welcome Hot Prospect: A Manager Born in 1977
abstract: Kevin Cash, the new manager of the Tampa Bay Rays, is the youngest manager in the four major professional sports leagues, and through Monday he has managed five exhibition games in his career.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Kevin Cash said he was honored to meet Cal Ripken Jr. last week, but he is too young to recall Ripken’s sensational rookie season of 1982 or the next year, when the Orioles won the World Series.

headline: Budget Office Again Reduces Its Estimate on Cost of the Affordable Care Act
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Slower growth in health spending helps consumers and businesses, which shoulder most of the costs, and contributes to lower federal budget deficits.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Congressional Budget Office on Monday again lowered its estimate of the cost of the Affordable Care Act, citing slow growth of health insurance premiums as a major factor.

headline: Fred Wilpon Meets With Terry Collins to Discuss Mets
abstract: The owner Wilpon stopped by Manager Collins’s office and talked about the team’s left-handed relievers and the pitching staff’s high walk total in spring training, Collins said.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — On Monday afternoon, after the Mets were drubbed by the Miami Marlins in an exhibition game, the owner Fred Wilpon dropped by Manager Terry Collins’s office for more than 20 minutes to discuss the Mets’ roster. Afterward, Collins spoke to reporters; Wilpon did not, although that is nothing new.

headline: Chunk of New Jersey’s Money From Exxon Settlement Is to Go to Legal Fees
abstract: If the broadly criticized deal is approved, New Jersey’s recovery will most likely total about $180 million or so, after legal fees and costs are deducted, records show.
lead_paragraph: New Jersey’s decision to settle a multibillion-dollar pollution lawsuit with Exxon Mobil Corporation has come under broad criticism, as lawmakers and environmentalists have questioned why the state would agree to accept only $225 million — a small fraction of the $8.9 billion in damages it was seeking in court.

headline: Suspect in Etan Patz Case Had Hallucinations, His Daughter Says
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: Becky Hernandez, a defense witness, spoke of Pedro Hernandez’s hallucinations and other occurrences, in support of the argument that his confessions are fictional stories invented by a mentally ill man.
lead_paragraph: There was a lady in white who walked around the house and could pass through him like a ghost. There was a muscular man with tattoos who choked him in his bed, then vanished. There were shadows that became menacing figures, and ancient people who stood silently behind his wife and daughter.

headline: Typewriter Part
abstract: Allan E. Parrish gets me confused.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — You know all those people who say “This is not a Tuesday puzzle!” and who like to hold newspaper crossword publishers to the strictest letter of the law that supposedly says that crosswords have to progress in difficulty and concept as the week goes on? Well, we’re going to hear from them today.

headline: Safety of Herbal Supplements Pulls Prosecutors Together
keywords: ['Attorneys General', 'Consumer Protection', 'Dietary Supplements and Herbal Remedies']
abstract: An investigation by the New York State attorney general’s office, which prompted four national retailers to pull herbal supplements from their shelves, has led to a broader effort.
lead_paragraph: A group of attorneys general is expected to announce on Tuesday that they are forming a coalition to crack down on fraud and quality control issues in the herbal supplement industry.

headline: Lisa Bonchek Adams Dies at 45; Chronicled Fight With Breast Cancer
abstract: Ms. Adams was known for her thousands of blog posts, Facebook updates and Twitter messages detailing her struggle with breast cancer.
lead_paragraph: “I am waiting for test and scan results, laying low after a busy and stressful week,” Lisa Bonchek Adams wrote on her blog in 2013, one of hundreds of posts to go along with thousands of Twitter messages documenting her life after she learned she had breast cancer in 2007, when she was 37.

headline: Dustin Johnson’s Case Is a Compelling Argument for Transparency
abstract: Johnson, one of the PGA Tour’s marquee names, went on hiatus while he was at the top of his game, resulting in rumors and speculation.
lead_paragraph: DORAL, Fla. — If the PGA Tour needed any more convincing that its lack of transparency in meting out fines and suspensions was hurting its product, Dustin Johnson’s news conference after his victory Sunday at the World Golf Championships event at Doral was the clincher.

headline: A Battle for Light and Air at an Upper East Side Building
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Windows', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Evictions', 'Landlords', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: A pair of windowed air shafts have become a coveted amenity for some residents and the focus of court cases brought by the landlords.
lead_paragraph: On floor plans, the pair of air shafts running down the middle of 1664 Third Avenue in Manhattan look like inconsequential rectangles, barely bigger than a phone booth.

headline: New York’s First Taste of Spring
abstract: After a frigid winter, New York’s first 50-degree day in months hinted at the coming spring.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in months, it seemed as if this frigid winter might actually end. On Monday afternoon, the temperature in Central Park reached 54 degrees, the first time it had risen above 50 since Jan. 4.

headline: Iran: U.S. Offers $5 Million for News on Ex-F.B.I. Agent
abstract: The United States announced Monday that it had increased to $5 million its reward for information that could lead to the safe return of Robert A. Levinson, a former F.B.I. agent who disappeared in Iran in 2007.
lead_paragraph: The United States announced Monday that it had increased to $5 million its reward for information that could lead to the safe return of Robert A. Levinson, a former F.B.I. agent who disappeared in Iran in 2007. The move comes as the Obama administration appears to be closing in on an agreement with Iran under which Tehran would accept limits on its nuclear program in return for the lifting of economic sanctions. The fate of Americans who have been detained by Iran — or in Mr. Levinson’s case who have disappeared there — is not formally part of the talks. Monday was the eighth anniversary of Mr. Levinson’s disappearance, which occurred during a visit he made to Kish Island, Iran. His family received photographs and a video in late 2010 and early 2011. The F.B.I. offered a $1 million reward in 2012 for information about Mr. Levinson and increased it by $4 million on Monday. Iran has denied that it knows his whereabouts.

headline: 4 Homes Are Badly Damaged in a Brooklyn Fire
abstract: Six firefighters were taken to hospitals with non-life-threatening injuries from battling a blaze in Mill Basin.
lead_paragraph: A fire in southern Brooklyn left four homes on a canal badly damaged and six firefighters injured on Monday, the authorities and neighbors said.

headline: Peace Corps Suspends Program in Jordan
abstract: Turmoil and terrorism in neighboring countries is cited as the reason for the temporary removal of 37 volunteers from Jordan.
lead_paragraph: The Peace Corps has temporarily suspended its volunteer program in Jordan because of regional instability, officials said.

headline: Obama Criticizes Walker Over Union ‘Assault’
abstract: President Obama took a direct swipe at Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, a Republican and likely presidential candidate in 2016, for signing a so-called right-to-work bill that will limit the power of private-sector unions.
lead_paragraph: President Obama took a direct swipe at Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, a Republican and likely presidential candidate in 2016, for signing a so-called right-to-work bill that will limit the power of private-sector unions.

headline: Like Kentucky Men, Princeton Women Close In on Perfection
abstract: The 13th-ranked Tigers (29-0) won the Ivy League crown on Saturday and face their archrival Penn on Tuesday at the Palestra in Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: Courtney Banghart, the women’s basketball coach at Princeton, believes one pivotal defeat has put the Tigers on the cusp of a historic regular season.

headline: Pilots Say Brakes Didn’t Slow Jet That Slid Off Runway at La Guardia
abstract: Investigators are trying to determine why Delta Air Lines Flight 1086 skidded through a perimeter fence on Thursday when previous flights had arrived safely on the same runway.
lead_paragraph: Runway 13 at La Guardia Airport appeared to be all white to the pilots of a Delta Air Lines jet that skidded off it and through a perimeter fence during a snowstorm on Thursday, they told federal investigators over the weekend.

headline: New York State Changes Plan to Reduce Its Swan Population
abstract: While emphasizing nondeadly control measures, the new proposal would still allow the killing of the birds, which are seen as a nuisance by some but a symbol of romantic love by others.
lead_paragraph: In response to public pressure, state environmental officials on Monday released a revised plan to thin out the invasive mute swan population in New York. While emphasizing nondeadly control measures, the new plan would still allow the killing of the birds.

headline: Naked Black Man Fatally Shot by White Police Officer in Georgia
abstract: The man was running through an apartment complex northeast of Atlanta when he charged at the officer, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A naked man who was apparently unarmed was shot and killed by a police officer on Monday at an apartment complex in Chamblee, Ga., northeast of Atlanta, the authorities said.

Biden Jr. released a blistering statement that denounced an unusual open letter from 47 Republican senators cautioning Iran against a potential nuclear deal with President Obama, saying that the senators’ maneuver was “beneath the dignity of an institution I revere.”
lead_paragraph: Vice President Joseph R. headline: China: Dalai Lama Supporter Burns Herself in Protest
abstract: A Tibetan woman who supported the exiled Dalai Lama set herself ablaze and died in a Tibetan part of southwest China, advocacy organizations abroad said Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: A Tibetan woman who supported the exiled Dalai Lama set herself ablaze and died in a Tibetan part of southwest China, advocacy organizations abroad said  Tuesday. Her self-immolation on Thursday was the first such episode reported in a Tibetan area this year, resuming a grim form of protest against Chinese rule that has spread since 2009. The woman, Norchuk, who was in her late 40s, set herself on fire in her home village in Ngaba County, a heavily Tibetan part of Sichuan Province that is next to the official Tibetan Autonomous Region, according to the exiled Central Tibetan Administration, which is based in northern India. Many Tibetans use only one name.

headline: Armenian Leaders Establish Rights Award to Commemorate Centenary of Genocide
keywords: ['Armenians', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Contests and Prizes']
abstract: The award is part of an effort to go beyond remembering the 1.5 million people who died, emphasizing how survivors led successful lives.
lead_paragraph: Leaders in the Armenian diaspora, preparing to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the Armenian genocide, have collaborated with Hollywood celebrities and human rights advocates to create a prize to be awarded annually to those who put themselves at risk to ensure that others survive.

headline: As ‘Redskins’ Issue Splits Upstate Community, District Is in No Rush to Decide
abstract: A board of education meeting centered on Lancaster High’s nickname, with critics calling it an insult and supporters saying it reflected strength and honor.
lead_paragraph: LANCASTER, N.Y. — One week after a community forum intended to promote dialogue over the use of the nickname “Redskins” for scholastic sports teams, this Buffalo suburb remained divided, with supporters of each side attending a board of education meeting Monday night.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (DirecTV) BILLY & BILLIE Adam Brody plays the reticent Billy and Lisa Joyce is the profanity-spewing Billie, stepsiblings turned lovers in this romance from the playwright Neil LaBute. This second episode finds the couple putting their relationship on standby after a too-close-for-comfort encounter with family members. “The premise might seem tabooish — it’s the basis of a whole subgenre of heavy-breathing romance novels — but Mr. LaBute is going for something more subtle,” Neil Genzlinger wrote in The New York Times. Yes, Billy and Billie “are trying to figure out how guilty they should feel, but at the same time they’re interacting like feuding brother and sister and like ordinary young people navigating the casual hookup scene.”

headline: What to Expect on the Seventh Day of Paris Fashion Week

This morning Chanel is inviting showgoers to something called “la Brasserie Gabrielle” (Gabrielle was Coco’s real name, pilgrims), so perhaps there will be some Coffee Cups with the brand’s famous interlocking Cs, distributed at the Grand Palais and eBay-bound, or maybe just some Cute Coasters, with Karl as maître d’. ...

keywords: ['Ethanol', 'Gasoline Tax (US)', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Bioenergy and Biofuels', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']

headline: It’s Not Always Depression
keywords: ['Depression (Mental)', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation']
abstract: Sometimes, it’s shame.
lead_paragraph: How can it be that a seemingly depressed person, one who shows clinical symptoms, doesn’t respond to antidepressants or psychotherapy? Perhaps because the root of his anguish is something else.

headline: Was the Burning of Columbia, S.C. a War Crime?
abstract: Neoconfederates argue that Sherman purposely burned the city in 1865. The facts show otherwise.
lead_paragraph: When Gen. William T. Sherman’s troops left Columbia, S.C., on the morning of Feb. 20, 1865, about a third of it lay in ashes behind them, with thousands left homeless. Within weeks, Southerners had begun to publish what they considered evidence of an orchestrated Northern atrocity. Ten years later, the dispute remained so sharp that Sherman felt it necessary to defend himself in his memoirs by accusing Confederates of setting the city on fire themselves. Even today, many neoconfederate websites argue that the burning of Columbia was a Union war crime.

headline: Leaving Hospital, U.S. Envoy Vows to Stay ‘Open and Friendly’ in South Korea
abstract: Ambassador Mark W. Lippert, being discharged five days after a knife attack, said his belief in the two countries’ bond had only been strengthened.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The American ambassador to South Korea, Mark W. Lippert, said on Tuesday that he would continue to be “open and friendly” in his dealings with people here, as he was released from a Seoul hospital five days after a knife attack that raised concerns about his security.

headline: College for a New Age

lead_paragraph: Kevin Carey has a 4-year-old girl. Carey, the director of the education policy program at the New America Foundation, has been thinking about the role of universities in American life for virtually his entire career. But after his daughter was born, that thinking took on a new urgency.

headline: Matthew Barney Gets Museum Show of His Own in Los Angeles
abstract: The show, at the Museum of Contemporary Art, will consist of sculptures, photographs and other material plucked from Mr. Barney’s film “River of Fundament.”
lead_paragraph: Matthew Barney has often been called the most important American artist of his generation, but last week, he became newly famous as a former boyfriend. The pop singer Björk (loudly) bemoans the collapse of her long relationship with him in the survey of her work that opened at the Museum of Modern Art on Sunday. “Black Lake,” a music video projected onto two large screens in a specially constructed theater, is a breakup ballad in surround sound.

headline: As Demand for Welders Resurges, Community Colleges Offer Classes
keywords: ['Welding and Welders', 'Vocational Training', 'Community Colleges', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Series', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: The demand has created an unusually close partnership between the Gulf Coast energy industry and community colleges to train people for disappearing skills.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Ryan Gassett had already put in a full day, moving heavy boxes and furniture for $15 an hour, when his introductory welding class began at 10 p.m. By the time he arrived at Lone Star College north of Houston, the highway toll collectors at the exit for the school had closed for the night and the campus janitors were mopping bathrooms.

headline: What Do You Remember Best About Being 12?
abstract: Whether you were 12 a year ago or a decade ago, what do you remember about that in-between age? Which of the students in the WNYC video most reminds you of yourself? What was good, bad, awkward, awesome and essential about 12 for you?
lead_paragraph: We’re collaborating with our friends at WNYC for this question, which grows out of a series they are running called “Being 12: The Year Everything Changes.”

headline: In Relating to Foreign Leaders, Obama Keeps It Mostly Business
abstract: President Obama has only occasionally invested time in cultivating relationships with the leaders of other countries.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Less than three months into President Obama’s first term, a top White House national security official told reporters that the new commander in chief’s diplomacy would be different from the regular-guy friendships with foreign leaders sought by President George W. Bush.

headline: ‘The Musical Brain,’ Stories by César Aira
abstract: The characters in César Aira’s stories inhabit a shifting landscape of events.
lead_paragraph: A child races giddily from table to table in a crowded café, accepting objects fashioned by the patrons from paper napkins for her amusement. All are lovingly devised and impossibly elaborate: a plane, a bouquet of flowers, a diorama, a kangaroo with a movable tail, the Guggenheim ­Museum in Bilbao, a clown made of “paper so fragile a gaze could tear it.” As each fantasy falls apart in her eager little hands, it is discarded in favor of the next. The concentrated creative aura enveloping the patrons serves as a mere backdrop for her energetic engagement with the moment that keeps turning into the next moment.

headline: Kim Gordon’s ‘Girl in a Band’
abstract: Questlove reviews Ms. Gordon’s new memoir, which doesn’t shy away from unpleasantness in discussing life before, during and after Sonic Youth.
lead_paragraph: The way you read a memoir has everything to do with how much you know about the subject going in. If I’m reading a memoir by, say, a scientist I’ve ­never heard of, I’m likely to swallow what’s ­being fed to me without question, bias and errors included. On the other hand, if the memoir is by a pop culture figure I’ve followed obsessively, I might go the opposite way, zooming in on any minor inaccuracies: You say that television special came out in 1978, but I know for a fact it was the tail end of 1977, because the “Saturday Night Fever” soundtrack wasn’t even out yet, and now how can I trust you about anything? Either extreme has its dangers, and both run the risk of putting me in a place where I’m not looking at a book with clear eyes.

headline: Spring Break for Families
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Children and Childhood', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Families and Family Life', 'AMUSEMENT AND THEME PARKS']
abstract: Suggestions on where to go, and how to travel, for parents taking their kids on the road for spring break.
lead_paragraph: Given the scheduling, the long hours spent in cramped spaces and the energy needed to shepherd the herd from place to place, there’s a lot that could go wrong on a family trip. So even though spring break is just around the corner for many, you can forgive yourself for not planning your trip yet. Our Getaway column recently tackled last-minute trips for those who want to avoid the crowds. Here are a few suggestions for traveling with your own personal crowd.

headline: Apps to Help Navigate Cruise Lines
abstract: A guide to digital tools that allow you to virtually explore hundreds of ships, stay on budget and even identify the constellations in the sky above.
lead_paragraph: Anyone planning a cruise these days quickly learns that major lines such as Disney, Norwegian and Royal Caribbean have their own smartphone apps to help passengers navigate their floating cities and discover on-board entertainment, spa services and ports of call. And for most travelers, that’s more than enough information. But should you wish to immerse yourself in cruise culture, there are a handful of apps that allow you to virtually explore dozens of lines and hundreds of ships, stay on budget, even identify the tropical fish swimming below you and the constellations in the dark sky above. Some of the apps don’t even require an Internet connection, so you can play and learn without having to pay for on-board Wi-Fi.

headline: Aldermore Is Valued at $982 Million in London I.P.O.
abstract: The so-called challenger bank to Britain’s traditional financial powers sold about 35 percent of its capital in the offering of 117.9 million shares.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Aldermore Group, a so-called challenger bank to Britain’s traditional financial powers, said on Tuesday that it had priced its initial public offering, valuing the company at 651 million pounds, or about $982 million.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: New York Today: Idle No More
abstract: Tuesday: A plan to end vehicle idling, more mild weather, and Cardinal Egan’s funeral.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this bright Tuesday.

headline: Daily Report: Using the Apple Watch
abstract: Initial impressions of the Apple Watch are that it is good-looking for a smart watch and not hard to use, but whether it is yet a necessary purchase remains unsettled.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, Apple allowed a closer look at its much anticipated watch. Farhad Manjoo gives his impressions of the timepiece on three fronts: the hardware, the interface and the watch’s uses.

headline: Verisk Analytics Agrees to Buy Scottish Energy Research Firm
abstract: The Jersey City-based company said it would pay about $2.8 billion for Wood Mackenzie of Edinburgh.
lead_paragraph: Verisk Analytics said on Tuesday that it had agreed to acquire the Scottish energy research firm Wood Mackenzie from its private equity owners for 1.85 billion pounds, or about $2.8 billion.

headline: Refugee Crisis in Philippines as Peace Deal Is at Risk
abstract: The intensified fighting against Islamic militants is taking place as lawmakers in Manila are debating a bill that would formalize the provisions of a landmark peace deal reached a year ago with the country’s largest rebel organization.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — The Philippine military is fighting Islamic militants on two fronts in the country’s south, with recent battles having left dozens dead and driven more than 82,000 people from their homes, according to government officials and international organizations. An aid worker said a “growing humanitarian crisis” was underway in camps for people who had fled the violence.

headline: From Jamaica to Minnesota to Myself
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: I knew I had to leave my home country — whether in a coffin or on a plane.
lead_paragraph: I had just left my parents’ house in Portmore, a suburb outside Kingston, for my own apartment in the city: a one-bedroom studio, barely 600 square feet, with yellow shag carpeting, a tiny terrace enclosed in jail bars, a bedroom looking out on somebody else’s bedroom and a ceiling I could reach. I locked myself away from the neighbors with two deadbolts.

headline: You and I Change Our Minds. Politicians ‘Evolve.’
abstract: There is an immediate rush to portray politicians as “flip-floppers” when they shift position on anything, but some are starting to employ a nifty new rhetorical disguise.
lead_paragraph: As a general rule, it is difficult for people in public life to change their minds. There is an immediate rush to portray politicians as “flip-floppers” when they shift position on anything, even if they do so following a careful consideration of an issue rather than a meeting with a pollster. The hecklers will reliably accuse them of lacking the “courage of their convictions,” of being “typical politicians,” even though the typical politician actually tries to change his mind as rarely as possible, to avoid the hecklers.

headline: Re: My Saga, Part 1
abstract: Banality was either an outrage or a joy to readers of Karl Ove Knausgaard’s story of traveling from Newfoundland to Detroit.
lead_paragraph: It was “fun,” it was “looong,” it was “frankly somewhat bizarre,” it was a “wonderful disaster.” Our first installment of the Norwegian novelist Karl Ove Knausgaard’s account of his journey from Newfoundland to Detroit — with lengthy digressions on going bowling, fixing a clogged toilet and a meal at the Pizza Delight in the Viking Mall — was one thing for sure: provocative.

headline: Your Passwords Revealed
abstract: Our readers respond to ‘The Secret Life of Passwords.’
lead_paragraph: Late last year, I wrote an article for the magazine, “The Secret Life of Passwords,” in which I looked at the humanity that often hides in a simple string of characters, and reflected on why we imbue these codes with meaning even when we’re explicitly told not to. A motivational mantra, a swipe at the boss, an ode to a lost love, an inside joke with ourselves, a defining emotional scar — there was something captivating, inspiring even, about these tchotchkes of our inner lives.

headline: Today in Politics: Iran Showdown Brings Obama and Congress to New Low
abstract: The escalating fight over a potential Obama administration nuclear deal with Iran has sent relations between President Obama and congressional Republicans plummeting to a new low as the White House on Monday accused Senate Republicans of actively undermining administration foreign policy.
lead_paragraph: Good Tuesday morning from Washington, where the clock is ticking ahead of Hillary Rodham Clinton’s email news conference and possible Republican presidential candidates are lining up to face the firefighters. The Senate would rather discuss human trafficking than the attorney general nomination of Loretta E. Lynch, but after Republicans in the chamber tried to derail negotiations with Iran, foreign policy is the biggest hot spot between Congress and the White House.

headline: For The Times, a New Beginning on Instagram
abstract: This week, The Times begins a new Instagram feed highlighting a wide range of photography. On Monday, Bryan Denton showed how, after the ravages of Ebola, people in Sierra Leone are starting to reach out and touch their neighbors.
lead_paragraph: When Bryan Denton saw a woman in Freetown, Sierra Leone, kneel on the ground and cuddle a baby, he was struck by the moment’s intimacy.

headline: Henan Delegates Protest Inequality in University Admissions
keywords: ['ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Equal Educational Opportunities', 'Tests and Examinations']
abstract: Delegates from the rural province complained during the National People’s Congress that quotas for university places were allocated in favor of wealthier places like Beijing and Shanghai.
lead_paragraph: Henan Province in central China is mostly a flat expanse of fields, towns and villages, whose 100 million or so people are sometimes slurred by others as bumpkins. Adding to the insult, the Chinese government has long skewed opportunities away from Henan in an area of life that matters intensely to many in China: getting their children into universities.

headline: Morning Agenda: Credit Suisse Names New Chief
abstract: Credit Suisse is replacing its longstanding leader. | The Simon Property Group bids for a rival. | Banks are no longer financing certain coal-mining companies. | The tech blog Gigaom has shut down.
lead_paragraph: CREDIT SUISSE NAMES NEW CHIEF | Brady W. Dougan is stepping down as chief executive of Credit Suisse, the bank said on Tuesday, ending his tenure as one of the longest-serving chieftains of a global banking powerhouse, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Jenny Anderson write in DealBook. Mr. Dougan ‒ an American who has led the Swiss bank since before the financial crisis and has been called “the Teflon man” for his ability to deflect troublesome issues ‒ will be succeeded by Tidjane Thiam, who heads the British insurance company Prudential, where he has been praised for his leadership.

lead_paragraph: Yvette L. Campbell, who helped lead the Harlem School of the Arts out of a period of financial struggle as president and chief executive for the last four years, will step down in June, the school is to announce Tuesday.

headline: In Performance: Christina Bianco of ‘Application Pending’
abstract: A scene from the show, written by Greg Edwards and Andy Sandberg.
lead_paragraph: This week’s video features the actress Christina Bianco in a scene from “Application Pending,” a one-woman comedy about an elite New York City private school. Ms. Bianco, known for her work as an impressionist, plays the school’s kindergarten admissions director in addition to over 40 other characters. In his review Neil Genzlinger writes: “The speed with which she switches among them as she portrays dozens of characters is remarkable. Must we trot out the phrase ‘tour de force’? Yes, we must.”

headline: Herzog Emerging as Credible Challenge to Netanyahu in Israeli Race
abstract: Long dismissed as not quite prime ministerial material, Isaac Herzog, the leader of the center-left opposition, is now a contender in an election many see as a referendum on Benjamin Netanyahu.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Isaac Herzog was getting nervous about the traffic as his car crawled north out of Tel Aviv, on the campaign trail, so he instructed his driver to use the “tchakalaka” — the deep, hornlike siren that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s convoy regularly employs to clear the way.

abstract: The Democratic front-runner seems to simultaneously have too many advisers and too few.

How did her staff not warn her about the political and security risks? And why didn’t they protect her more effectively once those risks became clear?

lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Hillary Rodham Clinton revealed on Tuesday that she had deleted about half her emails from her years as secretary of state, saying she had turned over to the Obama administration all correspondence about government business but had erased records of communications about private matters, like yoga routines, her daughter’s wedding and her mother’s funeral.

headline: 1940: Turmoil After Wagner Played
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: 1940: Turmoil After Wagner Played in Paris
lead_paragraph: The attempt of the well-known Colonne-Lamoureux Orchestra to play Wagner for the first time since the outbreak of the war led to a tumultuous demonstration at the Châtelet Theater between partisans and foes of the Master of Bayreuth yesterday afternoon. Three Wagnerian numbers were originally listed on the program for yesterday, namely, the ‘‘Lohengrin’’ overture, the prelude from ‘‘Tristan and Isolde,’’ together with Isolde’s love-death and the overture to ‘‘Tannhauser.’’

lead_paragraph: LONDON — In a deal that could be a lifeline for the gasping British shale gas industry, the private chemical giant Ineos said on Tuesday that it was acquiring a package of stakes in licenses held by Igas Energy, a British onshore oil and gas company.

headline: 1965: French Wives Gain Freedoms
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: French law emancipates women in 1965.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The government announced today that it will emancipate the French wife from tyrannical marriage customs of the Napoleonic Code of 1804. Under a new law that soon will be submitted to parliament and is certain to pass, a wife will be able to open a bank account or go into business for herself — without her husband’s consent. The new measure goes so far as to strip from the husband his traditional title of ‘‘lord and master’’ of the family. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 11, 1965

headline: Donna Edwards Announces Bid for Maryland Senate Seat

lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — After a long day of throwing and fielding drills, Mets reliever Vic Black retired to his hotel room Sunday afternoon, slouched in a chair directly in front of the television and started playing Destiny, a first-person-shooter video game.

headline: Claude Sitton, 89, Acclaimed Civil Rights Reporter, Dies
abstract: A son of the South, Mr. Sitton delivered unwavering and perceptive coverage of the tumultuous civil rights movement and was hailed as a benchmark of 20th-century journalism.
lead_paragraph: Claude Sitton, a son of the South whose unwavering coverage of the civil rights movement for The New York Times through most of that tumultuous era was hailed as a benchmark of 20th-century journalism, died on Tuesday in Atlanta. He was 89.

headline: Video: The Night Everything Seemed Perfect
abstract: The filmmaker Joey Daoud explains what attracted him to the story of the bowler Bill Fong and his shot at a 900 series.
lead_paragraph: As a boy I used to bowl in a league. The bowling alley hadn’t quite been retrofitted with computerized scoring when I started, so you had to keep score by hand, with a grease pencil and an overhead projector. One day we wanted to figure out what the score would be if you got nothing but strikes. That would be 12 in a row, which we totaled up to a score of 300 — a perfect game. For us, getting the ball to stay on the lane without using bumpers was victory enough. Making a strike was usually a result of luck more than skill. To accomplish 12 of those, perfect shot after perfect shot, required a mental sharpness that was difficult to imagine.

headline: One Way to Pay a Tax Bill: Donate Churchill’s Paintings
abstract: The British government will accept 37 paintings by Winston Churchill in lieu of an inheritance tax on the estate of his daughter.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — “Artist” isn’t the first word that comes to mind when you hear the name Winston Churchill, prime minister of Britain from 1940 to 1945 and then again from 1951 to 1955. But a part-time artist he was, and a collection of 37 of his paintings has been accepted by the British government in lieu of an inheritance tax, and will be displayed at his family home, Chartwell, which has been open to the public since 1966.

headline: A Spare, Minimalist R&B Video Influenced by Marina Abramovic
abstract: The London-based, Solange-approved musician Petite Noir, along with his girlfriend Rochelle Nembhard, directed and starred in his visual for “The Fall.”
lead_paragraph: It’s been two and a half years since the debut single “Till We Ghosts” introduced the world to the crooning, beat-heavy brand of indie rock proffered by the Belgian-born, Cape Town-raised, London-based musician Yannick Ilunga, who records as Petite Noir. Since then, he’s collaborated with Mos Def, signed with the U.K. label Domino, opened for Solange and been featured on her “Saint Heron” compilation album. But Ilunga would tell you his most notable achievement to date is coining the term “Noirwave,” a new, ideologically influenced artistic genre that identifies as African first, and everything else second. “The term ‘African music’ is so overused,” Ilunga says, “to the point that when some people say it, it just sounds cheesy. Noirwave was always meant to include clothing, art, photography, music obviously — all types of things. It’s taking the Africa that we know, turning it upside down and bringing people a new black. Solange is super Noirwave. So is Beyoncé. Noirwave is pop culture — it’s coming, but right now it’s just boiling.”

headline: Police Killing of Unarmed Georgia Man Leaves Another Town in Disbelief
abstract: Anthony Hill, a 27-year-old Air Force veteran who was naked and unarmed, had written on social media about race and mental illness.

headline: Caesarism Without Apology
keywords: ['Constitution (US)', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Midterm Elections (2014)', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: An Obama adviser’s apologia for crown government.
lead_paragraph: In two recent posts touching on America’s increasing constitutional decadence, I strove (no doubt only semi-successfully) for evenhandedness, acknowledging the extent to which President Obama’s expansive use of executive power is part of a larger trend, shaped by structural forces, etc., and conceding as well the particular challenges of dealing with a Congress that’s both incompetent (particular the Republican caucus in the House) and all-too-eager to abdicate its constitutional responsibilities. This post, though, will be more straightforwardly partisan and anti-Obama, because I think what Dan Pfeiffer, the outgoing White House advisor, has to say to Jonathan Chait in this exit interview deserves the scorn of anyone who cares about limits on presidential power.

lead_paragraph: During the dot-com boom, reporters could actually gain access to the big stars. Interviews are strictly promotional, and woe unto the writer that ventures off topic.

A rival label, Creedmoor, was trying to poach its artists, threatening to undermine Empire’s coming initial public offering. In the company’s conference room, a screen displayed financial information as the tug of war unfolded. Projected revenue: $343,546,002 for Empire; $491,546,002 for Creedmoor.

headline: Tribeca Film Festival Announces Immersive Programming
abstract: The festival will include a handful of projects that incorporate virtual reality and other forms of immersive storytelling.
lead_paragraph: Instead of 3-D glasses, the Tribeca Film Festival will add blindfolds to its movie accessory list. At least that’s the case with one interactive documentary project that is part of the innovation programming the festival announced Tuesday. The project is called “Door Into the Dark,” and uses audio and locative technology to take blindfolded participants through an immersive experience of feeling lost. The project is one of five in the festival’s Storyscapes program, which employs virtual reality and other means to tell cinematic stories in unusual ways.

headline: Review: In ‘The Man of the Hour,’ Back-Room Politics Is Ageless
abstract: This revival of George H. Broadhurst’s 1906 political drama, inspired by Tammany Hall cronyism, is at the Metropolitan Playhouse.
lead_paragraph: George H. Broadhurst’s 1906 political drama, “The Man of the Hour,” a long-running Broadway hit in its day, has good bones, and the Metropolitan Playhouse does it justice in its current revival. Inspired by the historic cronyism of Tammany Hall, the story, about the temptations facing an honest politician, runs the risk of resembling a civics lecture, which the production nimbly sidesteps. The play’s lessons bear repeating, and the actors infuse them with life.

headline: Assistant Director Convicted of Manslaughter in ‘Midnight Rider’ Death
abstract: Hillary Schwartz, the first assistant director on the film “Midnight Rider,” was convicted of involuntary manslaughter in the death of Sarah Jones, who was killed by a freight train.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Hillary Schwartz, the first assistant director on the film “Midnight Rider,” on Tuesday was convicted of involuntary manslaughter and criminal trespass in the death of Sarah Jones, who was killed by a freight train last year while working on the film. A clerk of the court in Wayne County, Ga., where Ms. Schwartz had a bench trial on Tuesday morning, confirmed the convictions and said that Ms. Schwartz was sentenced to 10 years’ probation and will pay a $5,000 fine.

headline: Date of Armenia’s Birth, Given in 5th Century, Gains Credence
abstract: Geneticists found Armenians to come from a mixing of populations that occurred from 3000 to 2000 B.C., coincident with the date given by a historian in the fifth century.
lead_paragraph: Movses Khorenatsi, a historian in the fifth century, wrote that his native Armenia had been established in 2492 B.C., a date usually regarded as legendary though he claimed to have traveled to Babylon and consulted ancient records. But either he made a lucky guess or he really did gain access to useful data, because a new genomic analysis suggests that his date is entirely plausible.

headline: Deployment Is Confusing for Children, Which Makes Children Hard on Parents
abstract: He wouldn’t go to bed. He just wouldn’t go to bed. Finally, I asked him why. His answer caught me by surprise. “I miss my daddy!”
lead_paragraph: I recently read somewhere that doing the same thing over and over again and expecting different results was not the definition of insanity, but rather, the definition of parenting. The sentiment perfectly sums up bedtime with our 2½-year-old: routinely insane. We’ve cried it out and cuddled it out. We’ve bathed, read and rocked our way into different routines, to no avail. We’ve finally settled on “good enough” which consists of a bath, a story, only two trips to the bathroom, bedtime prayers and a hug and a kiss. In my son’s defense, I was (and, let’s be honest, am still) the same way. The struggle is real. I don’t like going to bed any more than he does.

headline: Bolivian Clubs Are at Home in Thin Air
abstract: Altitude has long been a challenge for teams visiting Bolivia, forcing them to adjust travel schedules, training regimens and tactics and, at times, to accept an unthinkable result.
lead_paragraph: Tucked tightly among the high-rises of the Miraflores district of La Paz, Bolivia, the Hernando Siles stadium is one of those great South American dust bowls drenched in character. Yet few stadiums anywhere can match its home-field advantage: Nestled in the Andes at a lung-tightening 11,932 feet, it brings soccer to the very roof of the Americas.

headline: Glitz and Glamour at Iris van Herpen
abstract: Barely there makeup, lacquered hair and pearlescent skin complemented the designer’s shiny fall 2015 collection.
lead_paragraph: “There are a lot of things, a lot of shiny things, happening,” the makeup artist Inge Grognard says of Iris van Herpen’s fall 2015 collection. For today’s show at the Palais de Tokyo, Grognard balanced out the glitz with barely there makeup, evening out models’ skin tones, filling in brows and covering up any redness in their lips and cheeks. The hair, on the other hand, was full-on gloss. The stylist Maria Kovacs created what she describes as a “futuristic elegance” look by pulling hair into a tight ponytail at the nape of the neck, pinning it into a V-shaped twist (to mimic the angles in van Herpen’s designs) and using layers and layers of hairspray for a slick, lacquered finish. It caught the light on the catwalk in the same way as the models’ bare arms and legs, which were brushed with a subtle blue and pearlescent sparkle.

headline: Review: Ratmansky’s ‘The Sleeping Beauty’ Has Premiere in California
abstract: American Ballet Theater’s new production of Tchaikovsky and Marius Petipa’s fairy tale opens at Segerstrom Hall in Costa Mesa, Calif.
lead_paragraph: COSTA MESA, Calif. — The wealth of detail that informs American Ballet Theater’s new production of “The Sleeping Beauty” brings to life a classic that has often gone stale. Much more, however, is also achieved: The old ballet has become transformed into something full of surprises. Though the production, staged by Alexei Ratmansky, Ballet Theater’s artist in residence, is based on deep research into the ballet’s original 1890 production and various records from 1890 to 1906, it doesn’t feel quaint or dated or archival. It feels loved: The characters and their often unfamiliar steps glow from within.

headline: Your Move, Grandmaster. (To the U.S., Please.)

It is not sending its three best players, and even if it were, it would not have enough talent to compete with the stacked teams from Russia and China.

headline: Political Jabs in Ink at Library of Congress
abstract: The Library of Congress will showcase political cartoons in an exhibition opening March 21.
lead_paragraph: The Library of Congress will showcase the power and punch of the political cartoon in the exhibition “Pointing Their Pens: Herblock and Fellow Cartoonists Confront the Issues,” which opens March 21. Herblock (Herbert L. Block, who died in 2001) was the chief editorial cartoonist for The Washington Post for more than half a century. His work forms the core of the exhibition, which focuses on six subjects that inspired some of his most memorable cartoons: World War II, the McCarthy era, the Cold War, the Vietnam War, Richard M. Nixon and the Middle East. Each will have two cartoons by Herblock (including one, above, from 1968) and three by his contemporaries. The library has more than 14,000 Herblock drawings, donated by the Herb Block Foundation in 2002. The exhibition, in the library’s Graphic Arts Galleries, will also draw on the Art Wood Collection of Cartoon and Caricature, which has more than 17,000 original editorial cartoons, donated to the library in 2001. An online version of the exhibition will be available at loc.gov/exhibits/.

headline: Review: In ‘Of Horses and Men,’ the Animals Often Walk on Two Legs
abstract: The director Benedikt Erlingsson looks at the human-equine relationship in a small, Icelandic community.
lead_paragraph: Set among hearty horse owners in ever-photogenic Iceland, Benedikt Erlingsson’s dryly witty “Of Horses and Men” is like an animal documentary, but about people. Life revolves around mares and stallions in the film’s windswept terrain, but the animals’ orblike eyes direct us to the many follies of their owners, who are driven by petty desires and, occasionally, courage.

headline: Getting the Whole World Online
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Wireless Communications', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Rural Areas', 'Cellular Telephones', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Most of the world’s 7.2 billion people still do not have Internet access, but there is a lot that governments can do to make sure their citizens are not left in the dark.
lead_paragraph: Years before big technology companies like Google and Facebook began talking about using balloons, drones and cellphones to provide Internet access to billions of people in developing countries, leaders like President Bill Clinton were talking about bridging the “global digital divide.” And while progress has been made in recent years, most of the world’s 7.2 billion people still do not have access to the Internet.

lead_paragraph: SOMERVILLE, N.J. — Gov. Chris Christie on Tuesday defended his administration’s decision to settle a multibillion-dollar pollution suit against Exxon Mobil Corporation for a fraction of what the state had originally sought, saying the $225 million deal was “on top of” the company’s obligation to clean up the damage it caused.

headline: The Snow Is Melting! But What a Mess It Left Behind

lead_paragraph: The snow is melting. Spring has almost sprung! The mercury pokes upward, and New Yorkers’ spirits rise apace. It would be understandable, after this winter that seemed delivered from deepest Siberia, if all city dwellers walked around with upturned faces, basking in the sun’s rays. But the last throes of winter require having a care for what lies underfoot.

But he remains unconvinced that they would help.

headline: Frei Otto, Architect, Dies at 89; the Soap Bubble Was an Inspiration
abstract: A lack of construction materials after World War II forced Mr. Otto to innovate; he created dazzling tensile structures while minimizing the use of material.
lead_paragraph: Frei Otto, an architect and engineer known for creating dazzling tensile structures that inspired generations of architects to dangle roofs from poles and cables, died on Monday in Germany, weeks before he was to be named the recipient of the Pritzker Prize, architecture’s most prestigious honor. He was 89.

headline: 6 Decades On, a Patriotic Plea Still Resonates

lead_paragraph: At the lectern, Dwight D. Eisenhower was every bit as dull as Tony Smith, 17, had expected. On a June afternoon in 1953, Mr. Smith was at Dartmouth College to see his grandfather, Joseph Proskauer, receive an honorary degree.

headline: Jordanian City Votes to Avoid ISIS Aesthetic
abstract: The brother of a fighter pilot who was burned alive by Islamic State militants said that city workers have the right to carry out their duties without wearing “this ugly color,” as ISIS hostages are forced to wear.
lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — Push brooms in hand, the sanitation workers who clean the streets of this capital could be easily recognized by their bright orange work suits. The city’s mayor, Aqel Biltaji, even donned the municipal uniform in 2013 to help show Jordanians that there was no shame in a job that requires “dedication and loyalty.”

lead_paragraph: For months it has been a favorite statistic of Mayor Bill de Blasio and his police commissioner, William J. Bratton: a declining number of complaints about the conduct of New York City officers.

abstract: In this solo show, the British actress Cush Jumbo plays both a version of herself and the boundary-crossing, Paris-conquering Josephine Baker.
lead_paragraph: When Cush Jumbo says she has fire inside her, you have no reason to doubt it. Portraying both title characters in “Josephine and I,” which opened on Tuesday night at Joe’s Pub at the Public Theater, Ms. Jumbo projects the kind of five-alarm charm that threatens to set rooms ablaze.

Mr. Steinberg tells us the interesting story in his notes below, so I will get right to his puzzle.

headline: Gamma Rays May Be Clue on Dark Matter
keywords: ['Dark Matter (Astronomy)', 'Stars and Galaxies', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Milky Way Galaxy']
abstract: Researchers say a newly discovered galaxy is emitting a surprising amount of gamma rays, which, if confirmed, may provide answers as to the mysterious dark matter that permeates the universe.
lead_paragraph: A small, newly discovered galaxy orbiting the Milky Way is emitting a surprising amount of electromagnetic radiation in the form of gamma rays, astronomers reported Tuesday. The finding may be the latest in a long string of cosmic false alarms, they said, or it might be that the mysterious dark matter that permeates the universe is finally showing its face.

headline: In Spain, Rapid Rise of Leftists Has a Familiar Ring
abstract: Pablo Iglesias, the leader of the left-wing Podemos party, believes he can emulate the electoral successes of the Syriza party that swept to power in Greece.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — He has promised to restructure the debt. He has said it is time to change laws “that allow the rich to keep stealing from us.” He has vowed that Brussels “cannot threaten us” and that “we don’t want any more heads of government who obey and don’t negotiate.”

headline: Colombia President Halts Bombing of Rebel Camps
abstract: In a move to accelerate peace talks with the country’s largest rebel force, President Juan Manuel Santos of Colombia on Tuesday said he had ordered a halt to bombings of the group’s encampments.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — In a move to accelerate peace talks with the country’s largest rebel force, President Juan Manuel Santos of Colombia on Tuesday said he had ordered a halt to bombings of the group’s encampments.

headline: Albinos Are Being Hunted in Eastern Africa, U.N. Says
abstract: The United Nations said Tuesday that at least 15 people with albinism, including children, had been attacked over the past six months in eastern Africa, where albino parts are prized by practitioners of witchcraft.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations said Tuesday that at least 15 people with albinism, including children, had been attacked — and in some cases abducted, killed and dismembered — over the past six months in eastern Africa, where albino parts are prized by practitioners of witchcraft. Prince Zeid Ra’ad Zeid al-Hussein, the United Nations high commissioner for human rights, said in a statement that he was horrified at the “stunningly vicious attacks,” which have surged in Tanzania, Malawi and Burundi. Albinism, a hereditary condition, has been linked by researchers to inbreeding. In Tanzania there is one case per 1,400 people, versus one in 20,000 in the West. The persecution of albinos has been a longstanding problem in the region. Witch doctors will pay as much as $75,000 for a complete set of albino body parts, according to a landmark report from the Red Cross.

headline: Maple Leafs’ Season, Like Fans’ Discarded Jerseys, Lands in a Heap
abstract: After showing early promise, Toronto plummeted out of playoff contention, fired its coach and endured fans’ tossing team jerseys onto the ice in protest over the team’s poor play.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — In the final stretch of a season that flirted with promise but has degenerated into a sideshow, the Maple Leafs arrived here last week for a rare three-game homestand.

headline: Patz Trial Jury, in Blow to Defense, Is Told Suspect Was a Longtime Cocaine Addict
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Domestic Violence']
abstract: A psychiatrist testified that Pedro Hernandez started abusing the drug in the mid-1980s and continued until 2005, when he quit, according to his medical records and toxicology test results.
lead_paragraph: The man on trial for the murder of Etan Patz used cocaine for two decades and had several physical fights with his wife over money used to buy drugs, a psychiatrist testified on Tuesday.

headline: Teacher in Pornography Case Asked Students for Photos, Prosecutors Say
keywords: ['Child Pornography', 'Education (K-12)', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Search and Seizure']
abstract: During a bail hearing for Jon Cruz, a teacher at the Bronx High School of Science who faces pornography charges, authorities said he also asked his own students for nude or suggestive images.
lead_paragraph: The teacher and debate coach at the Bronx High School of Science who was charged last week with enticing teenage boys he contacted online to send him nude or suggestive photographs also asked his own students for photos, prosecutors said during a bail hearing on Tuesday.

headline: Senate Vote Expected Next Week on Attorney General Nominee
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Attorneys General']
abstract: Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the majority leader, said Tuesday that he expected to bring the nomination of Loretta E. Lynch to be attorney general to the Senate floor for a vote next week.
lead_paragraph: Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the majority leader, said Tuesday that he expected to bring the nomination of Loretta E. Lynch to be attorney general to the Senate floor for a vote next week. Despite being approved by the Senate Judiciary Committee last month, the nomination of Ms. Lynch, the United States attorney for the Eastern District of New York, has been held up in Congress by Republicans who are angry with President Obama over his executive action on immigration. Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the minority leader, said Tuesday that in his time in the Senate, “no one I’ve seen is more qualified in experience, education, background and character than Loretta Lynch.” He added, “It’s time that we move forward on this.”

headline: Yankees Hire Hideki Matsui as Adviser to General Manager

lead_paragraph: SARASOTA, Fla. — Hideki Matsui broke a barrier of sorts when he became the first slugger from Japan to have a successful major league career. Now he is embarking on a new career as an executive with the Yankees.

headline: Florence Arthaud, Celebrated Solo Sailor, Dies at 57 in Helicopter Crash

lead_paragraph: Florence Arthaud, the French sailor who died at 57 in a helicopter crash in Argentina on Monday along with nine others, including two French Olympians, was celebrated by the French yachting world as the only woman to have won the Route du Rhum, a grueling solo trans-Atlantic race.

headline: St. Francis Falls Short of Earning First N.C.A.A. Bid
abstract: St. Francis of Brooklyn, which has not even made the N.I.T. since 1963, cut a 10-point second-half deficit to 3 in the waning seconds, but Robert Morris secured the NEC tournament title.
lead_paragraph: The gold ball was at one end of the court, and the St. Francis of Brooklyn players — stunned, drained, devastated — were at the other, walking quickly out of the arena, toward a quiet locker room and another year of longing.

headline: Recipes From the Ranch in Malibu Bring the Wellness Spa Into Home Kitchens
abstract: A new cookbook shares culinary secrets from the Live Oak retreat in California.
lead_paragraph: There’s something to be said about wellness being the epitome of true luxury, what with a single, precious green juice costing more than a 12-pack of soda and monthly gym memberships averaging the price of a standard cable subscription. And for the truly elite, spa retreats — fitness-oriented getaways that strip both calories and stressors from one’s system, jamming in meditative hikes and vegan, gluten-free everything in their place — are the ultimate spring break destination. One of the most expensive such programs is the Ranch at Live Oak in Malibu, where the likes of Bobbi Brown, Kate Spade and, just last month, Mandy Moore and Minka Kelly escape to detox, reset and rejuvenate. Now, though, the Ranch’s culinary secrets are available to the masses in their first, self-titled cookbook. Cue the spring spa staycations!

headline: Sporty Suits and Stripes for Spring
abstract: Among the season’s on-trend set of luxe sportswear are a lot of athletic separates and accessories that are as practical as they look.
lead_paragraph: Among the on-trend set of luxe sportswear in stores now for spring is a beach-ready lot of athletic separates and accessories that are as practical — for a fast game of volleyball or a leisurely dip in the pool — as they look. Loud rugby stripes freshen up sporty shorts and sandals. And with the addition of a terry cloth tunic, toweling off and covering up can all be done in a chic flash.

headline: A Chef’s Guide to Eating in Paris
abstract: Jérôme Banctel of the recently opened Le Gabriel restaurant shares his favorite food-related hangouts in the City of Light.
lead_paragraph: For a certain set of fashion editors, deciding which brasseries, bistros and cafes to visit during Paris Fashion Week is second only to tracking down their seat assignments. And this season, the new restaurant in the recently opened La Réserve hotel, Le Gabriel, is attracting attention and fashionable appetites thanks to its chef, Jérôme Banctel.

headline: What’s On TV Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (BBC America) BROADCHURCH After learning that her husband, Joe (Matthew Gravelle), murdered Danny Latimer, Detective Sgt. Ellie Miller (Olivia Colman, above) returns to Broadchurch to hear what she assumes will be his guilty plea. But then he declares his innocence, forcing a courtroom battle that will re-examine the case. Detective Alec Hardy (David Tennant), meanwhile, finds himself embroiled in an unsolved murder and disappearance from his past. “Season 2 is, from the start, an entirely messier, more contingent affair, enjoyable in a different and, to me, more appealing way,” Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times. Having Joe plead not guilty enables Chris Chibnall, the show’s creator and writer, “to keep all the central characters of Season 1 around without the usual implausibility of plunging the town into a new mystery. It’s also a device to get Ms. Colman’s Ellie Miller back into the center of the story” — where she once again steals the show. “She’s a wonderful comic actress, and now even more than before Mr. Tennant is her straight man — Miller has had it, and Hardy has to absorb all of her (amusing) petulance and disgust.”

headline: With Plan to Walk Across DMZ, Women Aim for Peace in Korea
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Korean War', 'Women and Girls', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT']
abstract: Leading female advocates of disarmament formally announced their intent to cross the Demilitarized Zone, which has divided the Korean Peninsula since 1953.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — It was the women who helped end the bitter political and ethnic strife that ravaged Northern Ireland in the 1970s. It was the women who said enough to the atrocities in Liberia, peacefully resolving a civil conflict there more than a decade ago. Now, women are turning their attention to the divided Korean Peninsula, where a technical state of war has endured for more than 62 years.

headline: Tougher Laws for Safer Streets
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Buses', 'Organized Labor', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: An essential part of a lasting solution to eliminating traffic deaths in New York City is a stricter web of laws.
lead_paragraph: Let’s acknowledge at the outset that this is New York City we’re talking about, not Mayberry. The code on our streets is pre-emptive aggression. Crowds and cars mix and move to a kind of intuitive, propulsive rhythm that can be terrifying to tourists but somehow is efficient and relatively safe.

headline: Is It Sheldon Adelson’s World?
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Palestinians', 'Political Action Committees', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The influence of Sheldon Adelson, the casino magnate and financial backer of right-wing causes, is being felt in both the United States and Israel.
lead_paragraph: The symbolism was too powerful to ignore. As anyone who watched Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s speech last week in Congress knows, one of the people prominently seated in the House gallery was the casino magnate Sheldon Adelson, a primary financial backer of both the Republican Party and Netanyahu. As The Washington Post’s Colby Itkowitz reported, at one point Adelson’s wife, Miriam, accidentally knocked her purse off the House gallery railing and it hit Representative Brad Ashford, a Nebraska Democrat seated below. The Post noted that Adelson had given $5 million to the G.O.P.’s Congressional Leadership Fund super PAC, which had spent $35,000 in a failed effort to defeat Ashford in his 2014 race against Representative Lee Terry. Ashford later joked to The Omaha World-Herald: “I wish I’d opened the purse. Do you think she carries cash?”

headline: Feeding Kids Well
keywords: ['Lunch and Breakfast Programs', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: New guidelines gently nudge school lunches into the 21st century. So why would the School Nutrition Association work against their implementation?
lead_paragraph: How the School Nutrition Association became an ally of what you might call the “let them eat cake” forces is a long story. What matters is that if, like the association, you’re taking a stand against the 2010 Healthy, Hunger-Free Kids Act — from a food perspective, among the two or three most progressive pieces of legislation of the Obama administration — you are simply on the wrong side. You’ve pitted yourself not only against better nutrition for current school kids but, even more important, against better nutrition for future students and adults. The School Nutrition Association’s position may not be the equivalent of the American Diabetes Association insisting that, say, we serve Coke at all meals, but it’s in that ballpark.

headline: Memento Mori
abstract: I have A.L.S. I can’t protect my wife from grieving because grief is the price we pay for love.
lead_paragraph: I would not have chosen A.L.S. at the Pick Your Disease store, but there are worse things that can happen and worse ways for a life to end. The very fact that it was happening to me and not to my family was itself a relief. Navigating one’s own pain or fear is much easier than navigating a loved one’s.

headline: The Carnage of Barrel Bombs in Syria
keywords: ['Bombs and Explosives', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: As a surgeon in Aleppo, I see the civilian slaughter firsthand.
lead_paragraph: ALEPPO, Syria — MARWAN was on the operating table when the lights blinked and fizzled out. I turned on the headlamp I wear for situations like these, but it flickered, indicating low batteries. The nurse to my left pulled her cellphone from her pocket and turned it on, creating the only light in the pitch-black basement. Others in the room followed suit with their phones, shining the devices at the wound and producing just enough light to allow me to finish repairing the little boy’s broken body.
