headline: Can I Shop at Hobby Lobby?
abstract: The ethicists consider patronizing a store whose values you don’t support and keeping secrets for a neighbor.
lead_paragraph: I am an inveterate crafter — I have a crafting room — but ever since the Hobby Lobby decision, I have studiously avoided its stores despite my deep and abiding love of the place. I know there are some decent retail substitutes out there, but none that can match the giant warehouse of glitter and balsa wood that is Hobby Lobby. Would it be ethical to shop there if I were to make a donation to Planned Parenthood every time I did, sort of like buying ethical carbon offsets? If so, what percentage of my total purchase price should I be donating? NAME WITHHELD, AUSTIN, TEX.

headline: My Saga, Part 2
abstract: In this second installment from Karl Ove Knausgaard, the Norwegian travels through the Midwest in search of a distant relative, a supposed Viking relic and the peculiar essence of Americanness.
lead_paragraph: In Part 1 of “My Saga,” which was published March 1, the Norwegian novelist Karl Ove Knausgaard journeyed from his home in Sweden to Canada, with the intention of tracing the Viking trail from L’Anse aux Meadows, the first European settlement in North America, into the United States and westward to Alexandria, Minn., site of a possibly fraudulent Viking runestone. After several setbacks, and with just days to spare before he had to catch his return flight to Sweden, Knausgaard met the photographer Peter van Agtmael in Cleveland, and the two of them drove to Detroit.

headline: Cruising for All Tastes
keywords: ['Cruises', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Rivers', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Ships and Shipping']
abstract: Ships large and small are widening their appeal with themes, from stargazing to regional cooking, and expanding to ever farther ports of call.
lead_paragraph: The efforts of cruise lines to meet consumer demand has exploded into an expansive array of vacation options, from intimate yacht-like departures to floating family-friendly theme parks. The 63 cruise company members of the Cruise Line Industry Association estimate passenger volume will grow to 23 million this year, up nearly a million over 2014. Most of the traffic circulates in the Caribbean, but the following trends signal growing wanderlust among cruisers.

headline: Today in Politics: Both Sides See Political Advantages on Iran
abstract: The fight between congressional Republicans and the White House over negotiations with Iran shows no sign of easing and while it appears contentious, both sides find the deadlock somewhat advantageous.
lead_paragraph: Good Wednesday morning from Washington, where Republicans are saying Hillary Rodham Clinton’s meeting with reporters raised as many questions as it answered, lawmakers need to read their bills more carefully, and President Obama is focusing on domestic issues while Congress locks horns over Iran. For Republicans, at least, an old-fashioned foreign policy dispute is just what was needed to bring the party together.

headline: Morning Agenda: Citigroup’s Resurgence
abstract: Citigroup’s traders and investment bankers have come roaring back since the financial crisis. | Credit Suisse gets a risk expert in new chief. | Emerging markets are losing their luster. | Former JPMorgan executive joins a Bitcoin start-up.
lead_paragraph: CITIGROUP’S RESURGENCE | Seven years after Citigroup teetered on the brink, the bank’s traders and investment bankers have come roaring back, Peter Eavis writes in DealBook. The bank’s resurgence on Wall Street, which has involved acquiring huge amounts of derivatives, comes as many of its rivals pull back in the face of new regulations intended to make the financial system safer. But even as the bank has surged ahead, it has not trumpeted its comeback. Instead, its most senior executives have largely emphasized streamlining operations that have little to do with Wall Street, like agreeing to sell a unit that focuses on subprime loans.

headline: Boerum Hill, Brooklyn: Urban Energy, Brownstone Charm

headline: A Manners Manifesto
abstract: Table etiquette has long served as a tool of exclusion, but some rules bring us closer together.
lead_paragraph: For 4,000 years, humans have implored one another to mind their manners. I am personally invested in the crusade for two reasons. First, my brother and I were raised by a man who, as a child, was sent from the table hungry if he so much as slouched. At my own table growing up, when we small savages a) failed to put our napkins in our laps; b) ate before everyone was served; c) served ourselves first; d) opened our mouths while chewing; e) moved our forks from the left to the right hand; f) ate with our hands; g) failed to say please, thank you or excuse me; h) put our elbows on the table; i) did not ask permission to stand; or j) failed to eat soup properly (a nearly impossible task, requiring always spooning away, sipping noiselessly while sitting bolt upright, obtaining any final spoonfuls by a discreet tip of the bowl), we were ordered to push back from the table and contemplate our philistinism for several monstrous minutes before we could return, rehabilitated, to try again.

headline: 1915: British Again Sweep Forward
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: The British advance on Neuve-Chapelle in 1915.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Following up their splendid advance near La Bassée, in the course of which they carried the entire village of Neuve-Chapelle, the British forces have pressed on, driving the disorganized enemy before them, until the only Germans left over an area of a mile and a half to the east of the town are the dead and wounded. The advance is one of the most extensive that has been made by the British since the long siege of the trenches began. That the Germans were completely demoralized by the onslaught at several points is indicated by the comparatively small return fire that was offered. — The New York Herald, European Edition, March 12, 1915

headline: 1965: Rights Group Stages Sit-in
keywords: ['Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Segregation and Desegregation', 'White House Building (Washington, DC)']
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: A civil rights group stages a sit-in at the White House in 1965.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A group of civil-rights advocates today staged a six-hour sit-in demonstration in the White House. The demonstrators said they would remain there on a hunger strike until allowed to see the president. But at 6 p.m. tonight they were removed by police. The demonstrators, white and Negro, entered the building with one of the regular sightseeing tours. Presidential press secretary George E. Reedy said they got as far as the ground-floor hallway when suddenly they plopped to the floor and began chanting: ‘‘We shall not be moved.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 12, 1965

headline: 36 Hours in Los Cabos, Mexico
abstract: Where the desert meets the sea, you can take a glass-bottom boat, sign up for a zip-line course or just indulge in a soothing fusion massage.
lead_paragraph: Cancún meets San Diego on the southernmost tip of Mexico’s Baja Peninsula where two towns, rowdy Cabo San Lucas to the west and quieter San José del Cabo to the east, bookend a booming 20-mile tourist corridor of lavish resorts, scenic golf courses and blond beaches. Collectively called Los Cabos, or just Cabo, the desert destination was upgraded in 2012 with newly paved roads and a new international airport terminal, much of it undone last fall by Hurricane Odile, the category-3 surprise that ravaged the region and stranded some 30,000 tourists. While evidence of the damage remains in construction crews and shorn palm trees, most of the resorts have reopened; two new golf courses, including the first from Tiger Woods, have debuted; and Delta Air Lines began seasonal direct flights from J.F.K. in December. Though margarita-inspired indolence rules the region, rent a car to explore the peninsula’s less explicit charms, including surf breaks, organic farms, the Baja desert and a pair of art-centric colonial towns.

headline: Turning Chores Into Habits
abstract: One reason our chore systems always descend into chaos is that it’s never clear what our children need to do, or when.
lead_paragraph: Entropy has attacked our chore chart. Left to its own devices, the tendency of any system is to descend into chaos, and after a month of inconsistent schedules, travel, snow days and vacation time, it was clear that our descent had more than begun. When we looked around after a particularly challenging bedtime at the end of February, we saw a kitchen full of dishes, homework strewn across the counter, unemptied lunch boxes, cat dishes filled but not set out for the cats and the coats and boots solidly obscuring the mudroom floor.

headline: Did Earth’s ‘Anthropocene’ Age of Man Begin With the Globalization of Disease in 1610?

headline: Strange but True
abstract: Two picture book biographies recount the lives of extraordinary men — one a scoundrel, one an unlikely paragon.
lead_paragraph: Here’s one happy result of our nation’s new Common Core standards: A deluge of good nonfiction picture books are being published, thanks to the requirement that public elementary school teachers use a “true balance” of fiction and nonfiction literature in the classroom. This means children are getting more exposure to history, not from writers of textbooks or other dreary “educational materials,” but from picture-book authors and illustrators. In other words, from some of the most interesting, creative people around.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Email and the Challenges of Data Storage
keywords: ['E-Mail', 'Archives and Records', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Data Storage']
abstract: Archiving rules that have, until recently, prioritized paper records over electronic ones are a product of a system that understands and values paper.
lead_paragraph: The reason it is difficult to know exactly what happened with Hillary Clinton’s email during her time as secretary of state (aside from the fact that she has not provided a detailed technical accounting) boils down to this: A culture in which information technology is treated as a service from someone else made it less likely that Mrs. Clinton, her staff or even reporters would ask specific questions about it.

headline: Known for a Dribble, God Shammgod Crosses Over to Teaching
abstract: Shammgod, who led the Friars to the round of 8 in 1997, is now an undergraduate assistant for the team and on track to graduate in May, 20 years after he first enrolled.
lead_paragraph: With a name and a game few could forget, God Shammgod carved out his niche on New York’s playground courts and later at Providence College. In 1997, after his sophomore season, he declared for the N.B.A. draft, a decision his father strongly opposed.

headline: Bento Wants to Be Your App Matchmaker
keywords: ['Android (Operating System)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Mobile Applications', 'Start-ups', 'Venture Capital', 'Wireless Communications']
abstract: Bento is one of a number of start-ups that are trying to re-imagine search for mobile phones by anticipating what you want to do with your device.
lead_paragraph: If you are like most people, there are but two reasons you pick up your mobile phone. The first is when you want to do something specific, like send an email. The second is when you are bored. Nikhil Chandhok wants to figure out which one it is.

headline: A DiCaprio Donation Kickstarts an Expedition and Film Seeking a Solitary Whale
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Whales and Whaling']
abstract: A documentary about a solitary whale gets the green light with a big donation from Leondardo DiCaprio.
lead_paragraph: After several years of planning and a nail-biting Kickstarter campaign that ended today, filmmakers Josh Zeman and Adrian Grenier have passed their $300,000 financial target, thanks to a $50,000 donation from the Leonardo DiCaprio Foundation. (I made a donation, too, although it was a lot smaller!)

headline: Kerry Criticizes Republican Letter
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry criticized the letter 47 Senate Republicans sent to the leaders of Iran, saying that it contained “erroneous” assertions.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State John Kerry criticized the letter 47 Senate Republicans sent to the leaders of Iran, saying that it contained “erroneous” assertions.

headline: $15 Million Gift for Clark Art Institute
abstract: The gift, from Felda and Dena Hardymon, will support the institute’s expansion on its campus in Williamstown, Mass.
lead_paragraph: The Clark Art Institute in Williamstown, Mass., on Tuesday announced a $15 million gift — one of the largest donations in its history — to support the Clark’s campus expansion and programs.

headline: Emily Jenkins’s ‘A Fine Dessert,’ and More
abstract: John Lithgow reviews three picture books that celebrate the places we inhabit and the traditions they contain.
lead_paragraph: Margaret Wise Brown firmly believed that home is where the heart is. For nearly 70 years, her classic bedtime story “Goodnight Moon” has lulled children to sleep with a picture of the warm comforts of home. But if the book is disarmingly heartfelt, it is also undeniably strange. It is set in a mysterious “great green room” where, page by page, the light grows more weirdly crepuscular. The room’s curious props include a comb, a brush and a bowl full of mush. Its most memorable line, “Goodnight nobody,” could have been written by Samuel Beckett. It is a brilliant children’s book, but its brilliance lies in its dreamlike oddity. Like a good witch, Brown weaves a kindly spell, and children succumb.

headline: ‘The Honest Truth’ and ‘Wish Girl’
abstract: Gravely ill and facing debilitating treatments, two resolute protagonists take matters into their own hands.
lead_paragraph: “The Honest Truth,” a debut novel by Dan Gemeinhart, and “Wish Girl,” by Nikki Loftin, both involve kids trying to escape cancer treatment. Each novel features a main character who gets beaten up by other kids and an intense friendship between a boy and a girl. In both books we see children keeping secrets from adults, running away from home and facing nature with little preparation. What should you do when you see what may be your last chance — a potentially dangerous one — to defy your cancer and live the way you want? In these books the characters take that risk. Yet somehow they’re entirely different stories, “The Honest Truth” an adventure yarn about a boy and his dog, “Wish Girl” a quietly poetic story about psychological truths.

headline: ‘Echo,’ by Pam Muñoz Ryan
abstract: In this middle-grade novel, a harmonica touches the lives of three embattled children across years and continents.
lead_paragraph: So, the harmonica. We can probably all picture one in the hands of some 4-year-old, pressed to the child’s lips as she makes a wheezy, buzzy racket. Or being played by a convict in an old jailhouse movie as he lies on his bunk. But it’s not a serious instrument, not something you’d associate with real music. Or with words like magic, power or beauty.

headline: ‘Hold Tight, Don’t Let Go,’ by Laura Rose Wagner
abstract: In the wake of Haiti’s 2010 earthquake, a teenage girl is left to fend for herself in this young adult novel.
lead_paragraph: When we are uncertain that the ground beneath our feet will not rumble and shift and swallow us whole, even the very next minute carries with it looming doubt. This is one of the ways Haitians say goodbye: ­Demen si Dye vle — “Tomorrow if God is willing.” Tomorrow is not promised, and when it does come, with all its roils and jolts, kenbe fèm, pa lage, “hold tight, don’t let go.” That is the title of Laura Rose Wagner’s debut novel, in which such Haitian idioms abound. This coming-of-age story conveys the country’s deeply entwined faith and fear of the unknown through the eyes of a teenager named Magdalie Jean-Baptiste.

headline: 2015: Rubio and Kerry Clash Over ISIS
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Senator Marco Rubio, a Florida Republican, clashed with Secretary of State John Kerry over whether the United States’ strategy toward ISIS was influenced by the nuclear talks with Iran.
lead_paragraph: Senator Marco Rubio, a Florida Republican, clashed with Secretary of State John Kerry over whether the United States’ strategy toward ISIS was influenced by the nuclear talks with Iran.

headline: Miu Miu’s Spunky, Effortless (Dare We Say, Flirtatious) Ponytails
abstract: T shares the best hairstyles from the runways. Today’s pick: a nostalgic look with all the charming innocence of a girl playing dress-up.
lead_paragraph: T shares the best hairstyles from the runways.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Turkey and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Turkey, Israel, Iraq and Spain.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Turkey, Israel, Iraq and Spain.

headline: Global Movie Ticket Sales Rise 1% as China Surges
abstract: Sales in the United States and Canada fell about 5 percent in 2014, but in China they rose 34 percent.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The world movie box office was up 1 percent last year from 2013, but ticket sales in the United States and Canada fell about 5 percent as growth became concentrated in China, the Motion Picture Association of America said on Wednesday.

headline: The Truth About Entitlements
abstract: When you’ve got health care in your calculation, you’ve got just about everything.
lead_paragraph: As part of another project, I was looking at CBO historical budget data, and realized that you can summarize a lot about all those much-denounced “entitlements” with this figure:

abstract: Photos from Turkey, Israel, Iraq and Spain.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Turkey, Israel, Iraq and Spain.

headline: Metropolitan Museum of Art Names an Architect for Its New Wing
abstract: The English architect David Chipperfield was chosen for the project, which will most likely involve demolishing the Lila Acheson Wallace Wing in the museum’s southwest corner.
lead_paragraph: Opting for a more subdued choice outside the galaxy of starchitects, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has selected David Chipperfield to design its new wing for modern and contemporary art, Thomas P. Campbell, the museum’s director and chief executive, announced on Wednesday.

headline: Kelly Clarkson Hits No. 1
abstract: “Piece by Piece,” the latest by Ms. Clarkson, topped the album chart.
lead_paragraph: This week on the music charts, Kelly Clarkson scored her third No. 1 album and Mark Ronson’s “Uptown Funk” is the top single for the 10th week in a row.

headline: Review: Maureen McGovern at 54 Below, Feminism Through Pop
abstract: Ms. McGovern suggests an American Julie Andrews, supplying a spoonful of sugar that can sweeten the bitterest medicine.
lead_paragraph: “Goin’ to the chapel/and we’re gonna get married.” So goes the triumphant proclamation by the Dixie Cups in “Chapel of Love,” their blissfully naïve No. 1 hit in 1964. Sung by Maureen McGovern at 54 Below on Tuesday evening, it was the finale of a medley of six girl-group hits in her show “Sing, My Sisters, Sing!,” which celebrates female singers and songwriters.

headline: Teenagers and Extremism: Investigating the ISIS Recruitment Pipeline
abstract: In this lesson, students will explore some of the complex reasons some teenagers are drawn to ISIS, and investigate how a recruitment pipeline funnels young people from their computer screens to the middle of the Syrian civil war.
lead_paragraph: Overview |  Stories of young people leaving their families in places like Colorado, Minnesota, Britain and France, and making their way to join the Islamic State, a terrorist group also known as ISIS, have repeatedly made the news over the past several months.

headline: When Values Disappear
abstract: William Julius Wilson was right.
lead_paragraph: Back in the 60s and 70s — which I, sad to say, actually remember — there was much talk about the disintegration of the black family and of African-American values more generally, and how that was the root cause of America’s poverty problem. And the social dysfunction was clearly real. But was it cause or effect? William Julius Wilson, in When Work Disappears, famously argued that it was a symptom: good jobs in inner cities, where African-American men could take them, went away, and the cultural changes followed.

headline: China’s Tensions With Dalai Lama Spill Into the Afterlife
abstract: A comment by the Tibetan spiritual leader that he might not reincarnate has run afoul of the Communist Party.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Chinese Communist Party leaders are afraid that the Dalai Lama will not have an afterlife. Worried enough that this week, officials repeatedly warned that he must reincarnate, and on their terms.

headline: Review: In Memoir, Barney Frank Presses for a Results-Oriented Philosophy
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The former representative from Massachusetts makes a case for how political advocacy is most practically handled.
lead_paragraph: The expectations, from both readers and publishers, for a political memoir are that the author will use the book to give what-really-happened insider details, offer a healthy portion of score-settling and provide ample introspection on a life in elected office.

headline: Fed's Stress Test of Big Banks: Part Two
abstract: All U.S. banks passed the annual test. But Bank of America passed only provisionally and Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase and Morgan Stanley had to reduce payouts.
lead_paragraph: All U.S. banks passed the annual test. But Bank of America passed only provisionally and Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase and Morgan Stanley had to reduce payouts.

headline: Review: Google Chromebook Pixel
abstract: The top-of-the-line Google laptop, back in a new version, is meant more as a testing ground for new technology than a mass-market product.
lead_paragraph: GOOGLE’S Chromebook Pixel is a mysterious beast.

headline: Richard Branson’s Virgin Group Sued by Ex-Partner Over Cruise Line Plans
abstract: Colin Veitch, former chief executive of Norwegian Cruise Line, says the idea for a line of “ultra” cruise ships was his.
lead_paragraph: When Richard Branson, the entrepreneurial billionaire, announced the formation of Virgin Cruises in December, he promised to “shake up the cruise industry.”

headline: Video Feature: Pointing the Way to Good Reads, Videos and Music
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: StumbleUpon, Soundwave and the popular Pinterest help users find articles, videos, images or music, and share it with others.
lead_paragraph: HOW do you sift through all the clutter on the web and find the best stuff to read? And once you find the best stuff, what’s the best way to share it with others?

headline: App Smart | Discovery on the Social Web
abstract: Discovery and sharability are key to finding new things online, and there are many apps that can help. Pinterest, which caters to the visually-oriented, might be the most recognizable of this genre.
lead_paragraph: Discovery and sharability are key to finding new things online, and there are many apps that can help. Pinterest, which caters to the visually-oriented, might be the most recognizable of this genre.

headline: Buccellati Celebrates Its New York Flagship With Art-Inspired Jewels
abstract: The jewelry house’s first female designer, 25-year-old Lucrezia, created five one-of-a-kind designs based on Impressionist and Post-Impressionist works from her husband’s private collection.
lead_paragraph: The jewelry house’s first female designer, 25-year-old Lucrezia, created five one-of-a-kind designs based on Impressionist and Post-Impressionist works from her husband’s private collection.

headline: The Senate’s Email Holdouts
abstract: Several senators rarely or never use email. They’re part of a long tradition of lawmakers resisting technological change.
lead_paragraph: Thanks to Hillary Rodham Clinton’s email problem, we have been reminded that several senators, including Charles Schumer, Democrat of New York, and Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, rarely or never use email. This should perhaps come as no surprise since there is a long tradition of lawmakers resisting technological change.

headline: ‘The Originalist,’ a New Play About Justice Antonin Scalia by John Strand
abstract: Edward Gero, an actor steeped in Shakespeare, found a connection with the Supreme Court justice, whom he portrays in John Strand’s play at the Arena Stage in Washington.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In December, after more than a year of research and reflection, Edward Gero went to see an argument at the Supreme Court. He was in the final stages of preparing to portray Justice Antonin Scalia onstage, and it was time to see his subject in his element.

headline: Dealing With the Dreaded Bereavement Trip
abstract: Traveling for funerals and memorial services can become a major concern as people live longer and, in turn, watch close friends and family members die.
lead_paragraph: Dealing with bereavement travel can mean grief in more ways than one. Just ask William Shatner.

headline: Training the Mind to Ward Off Falls
abstract: In a new approach to the problem of falls among older people, an exercise physiologist at Wichita State has introduced cognitive drills into the exercise classes at a senior center.
lead_paragraph: WICHITA, Kan. — The first part of the hourlong Standing Strong exercise class at the Linwood Senior Center proceeds pretty much as you might expect.

headline: Retirement Reality Is Catching Up With Me
keywords: ['Retirement', 'Personal Finances', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Financial Planners']
abstract: Nearly 58, a writer has largely ignored his cursory efforts to plan for retirement. But his ignorance keeps gnawing at him, and it’s time to take a hard look at where he stands.
lead_paragraph: I am an idiot.

headline: Odds of Being a Champ at 95? Pretty Good
abstract: People are now competing in their 70s, 80s and 90s, some of them in sports not associated with retirement.
lead_paragraph: Larry Johnson keeps himself busy in his retirement — 90-minute indoor cycling classes three times a week and upper-body workouts on the alternate days, taking Saturdays off. In the winter, he goes into the mountains above his Albuquerque home to ski at least once a week.

headline: Two Generations, Retired and Together
abstract: Dual-generation retirements are becoming more common because of longer life spans and children’s wrapping up their careers early.
lead_paragraph: Almost every morning, Lauri McBride, 62, a retired middle-school science teacher, spends a half-hour chatting with her father, William Fink, 88, while he eats breakfast. Most evenings, Ms. McBride returns for another 30 minutes as her father sips a martini.

headline: The Rub: Remodel or Move?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Retirement', 'Elderly', 'Home Repairs and Improvements', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: Baby boomers are often choosing to live in places outside the usual retirement spots — or stay where they are and remodel their homes.
lead_paragraph: Neil Shapiro considers himself “within shouting distance” of retirement. He and his wife could have sold their home near Chicago and bought a condo in the Sun Belt, long a lure for American retirees.

headline: Apps Especially Useful for Retirees
abstract: A list of apps that are helpful for retirees who like to plan in advance.
lead_paragraph: Many smartphone applications can be particularly useful to retirees with time to manage their lives and pursuits. The apps listed below can help keep track of finances, plan trips and generally make life in retirement a little easier.

headline: Managing Estate Sales Becomes Big Business
abstract: The estate sale business is growing as the parents of baby boomers reach the end of their lives and the boomers themselves retire and downsize.
lead_paragraph: When Gary Berman’s mother died in January, at age 81, leaving behind the two-story house in Forest Hills, Queens, where she had lived for more than 60 years, he and his sister divided the items with sentimental value, then decided they wanted to sell the knickknacks and the big-ticket items, mostly a collection of midcentury modern dining room furniture.

headline: Live Long and Prosper? Insurance Might Help
keywords: ['Longevity', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Insurance', 'Retirement', 'Long-Term Care Insurance', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Asset Allocation (Personal Finances)']
abstract: The policies provide income for later years if you come up short, but payments don’t begin until you reach a certain age.
lead_paragraph: For those heading deep into retirement with relatively stable health, “rage against the dying of the light” often translates into a fear of outliving their nest egg.

headline: This Health Account Can Add to a Nest Egg Too
keywords: ['Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Retirement', 'Personal Finances', 'Medicine and Health', 'Savings', 'Taxation', 'Inheritance and Estate Taxes']
abstract: An account intended to cover out-of-pocket medical expenses can also supplement retirement savings.
lead_paragraph: As savings vehicles go, Health Savings Accounts, or H.S.A.s, are rainy day funds with generous benefits.

headline: U.S. Banks Pass Stress Tests, Some With an Asterisk
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Bank of America must resubmit its capital plan, while units of Deutsche Bank and Santander of Spain failed the tests outright.
lead_paragraph: All the large United States banks passed an annual regulatory test that aims to assess whether they can make it through a financial and economic calamity, the Federal Reserve said on Wednesday.

headline: Greek Debt Talks Are Tested by Fraying Ties With Germany
abstract: A demand by the Greek prime minister for wartime reparations from Germany intensified the rancor between the two nations.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Growing Greek antagonism toward Germany is coming at a bad time for Athens as it seeks a better debt deal with its European partners.

headline: Residents Spar Over How to Maintain ‘The Last Free Place in America’
abstract: The residents of Slab City, an unregulated squatter settlement, are divided over what to do if the California State Land Commission sells the land.
lead_paragraph: The residents of Slab City, an unregulated squatter settlement, are divided over what to do if the California State Land Commission sells the land.

headline: Talk of a Sale Fills a Hippie Haven With Bad Vibes
abstract: Some in California’s Slab City, a squatter colony of ex-hippies, rebels and self-identified misfits, fear they will face dreaded codes and health and sanitation rules.
lead_paragraph: NILAND, Calif. — Over the decades, the legend of Slab City as “The Last Free Place in America” has grown, fed by portrayals in magazines and film as an endless Woodstock.

headline: Classical Playlist: Stravinsky, Schumann and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: STRAVINSKY: Works for Piano and Orchestra; ‘Petrouchka’Jean-Efflam Bavouzet, pianist; Yan Pascal Tortelier, conductor; São Paulo Symphony Orchestra(Chandos CHSA 5147; one CD)Stravinsky wrote three ingeniously original works for piano and orchestra. Perhaps it’s because these pieces are so unconventional that they are seldom performed, a big loss for audiences. The excellent, inquisitive French pianist Jean-Efflam Bavouzet plays all three in bold, incisive performances on this new recording, with Yan Pascal Tortelier, another fine French artist, conducting the impressive São Paulo Symphony Orchestra. There is the flinty, Neo-Classical Concerto for Piano and Wind Instruments; the inventive Capriccio for Piano and Orchestra, a beguilingly strange work drenched in Russian musical styles and colors; and the compact, amazing 12-tone Movements for Piano and Orchestra, heard today mostly at New York City Ballet as a score for a seminal George Balanchine ballet. This recording includes a vibrant account of “Petrouchka” (1957 version), with Mr. Bavouzet playing the formidable piano part. (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: Louis Vuitton’s Wear-All-Season Pointy Black Ankle Boots
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: to close out Paris Fashion Week, booties that epitomize French cool.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Review: Compagnie CNDC-Angers Dances Cunningham
abstract: The French troupe Compagnie CNDC-Angers performed “Event,” composed of Cunningham pieces arranged by Robert Swinston, at the Joyce Theater.
lead_paragraph: What will happen next? Why is she falling back into his arms when he’s sitting there minding his own business? Who would have expected that man with his legs spread eagle on the floor to scurry across it? Why does that group of people stand motionless and then all switch position in a way that transforms them? Why did the mood just change and then change again because of movement alone?

headline: A Hitting Partner Switches Sides, From Serena Williams’s to Victoria Azarenka’s
abstract: Sascha Bajin was Serena Williams’s hitting partner and confidant for eight years and for 10 of her 19 Grand Slam titles. Now, he hopes to have similar success with Victoria Azarenka.
lead_paragraph: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — With Serena Williams making her return to Indian Wells after a 14-year boycott, her longtime hitting partner, Sascha Bajin, came to the tournament for the first time this week.

headline: Murry Sidlin Conducts ‘Defiant Requiem,’ a Tribute to Defiance With Verdi
abstract: The conductor assembled this work, which incorporates Verdi’s “Requiem,” to commemorate the choir that the conductor Rafael Schächter assembled at the Terezin concentration camp.
lead_paragraph: In desperate times music has been used by the persecuted as both a means of resistance and as spiritual sustenance. During his internment in Terezin, the concentration camp in Czechoslovakia that the Nazis claimed was a model community for Jews, the conductor Rafael Schächter led an inmate choir in performances of Verdi’s “Requiem” that served both as a morale booster and subtle rebellion.

headline: Art Sales on the Rise
abstract: Higher art prices and a greater number of transactions pushed global art market sales up 7 percent last year.
lead_paragraph: Higher art prices and a greater number of transactions pushed global art market sales up 7 percent last year to 51.2 billion euros (about $68 billion at an average exchange rate for the year), according to the annual report for the European Fine Art Foundation, published Wednesday.

headline: Growing Pains Subside for a Reborn Big East
abstract: The basketball-focused league’s first season was rocky, but now it has six teams projected to play in the N.C.A.A. tournament — twice as many as the Pacific-12.
lead_paragraph: Val Ackerman, the commissioner of the Big East, has her own offices now, and a full staff, and an email system, and a host of corporate sponsors, and all of this has made Year 2 of the new league considerably less rocky than the first.

headline: Tracing the Route of a Proposed AirTrain to La Guardia Airport
abstract: If built, the line would be similar to ones already running at Kennedy and Newark Liberty Airports. A review of the new route by car revealed some of the project’s challenges.
lead_paragraph: “Maybe here,” Sean Hennessey said, walking in a circle in a snowy parking lot — specifically, Lot P1 at La Guardia Airport.

headline: ‘The Tales of Hoffmann,’ Newly Restored, Opens at Film Forum
abstract: Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger’s 1951 film shows off Moira Shearer’s dancing much better than “The Red Shoes” did.
lead_paragraph: Admirers and detractors of Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger’s film “The Tales of Hoffmann,” from Offenbach’s opera, are equally vociferous. The newly restored edition, playing at Film Forum Friday through next Thursday, reminds us why. This 1951 film belongs to a bewildering number of categories. It’s lip-sync opera, multilayered meta-theater (indeed, a dizzyingly baroque exercise in overt artifice), kitsch extravaganza of luridly colored design (by Hein Heckroth) and keenly musical ballet.

headline: Louisiana National Guard on Crash
abstract: Maj. Gen. Glenn Curtis of the Louisiana National Guard spoke about the crash of a Black Hawk helicopter off the Florida coast during a training mission.
lead_paragraph: Maj. Gen. Glenn Curtis of the Louisiana National Guard spoke about the crash of a Black Hawk helicopter off the Florida coast during a training mission.

headline: The Clinton Emails: Questions Linger
abstract: Readers offer varying views of Hillary Rodham Clinton’s use of a private email server for her government work.

headline: Better Judgment at the Championship Level
abstract: A deal from the final day of the American Contract Bridge League’s fall championships in Providence, R.I.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — The American Contract Bridge League’s Spring North American Championships are underway here. To lead into our coverage, here is a look at a deal from the final day of the league’s fall championships in Providence, R.I., in December.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: What’s Wrong With the ‘Blurred Lines’ Copyright Ruling
abstract: In basing its verdict on sheet music, a critic argues, a jury in Los Angeles ignored how songs are actually created today.
lead_paragraph: Here’s how songs, especially hip-hop and R&B songs, are made today : the framework is built in the studio by a producer, working on some combination of keyboard, drum machine, sampler and computer program. Songwriters contribute topline melodies and conceptual ideas, and sometimes all the words. Generally speaking, at the moment of creation, there is no sheet music, no notation that’s meant to guide musicians.

headline: What I Almost Called My Play
abstract: A look at the titles that clicked and those that didn’t for writers with current productions. Would you buy a ticket to “Free Beer”?
lead_paragraph: Before there was “Oklahoma!” there was “Away We Go!” That was the original title of the Rodgers and Hammerstein musical that opened in New Haven in 1943. When it moved to Broadway weeks later, it was renamed after its rousing, now-famous second-act number.

headline: Multimedia Works That Explore the State of Nature
abstract: The artist Nadja Frank’s practice combines photography, silkscreening and sculpture.
lead_paragraph: The artist Nadja Frank’s practice combines photography, silkscreening and sculpture.

headline: Slack, the Office Messaging App That May Finally Sink Email
abstract: The start-up Slack is changing the way workers communicate, with a group chat app that eschews privacy and automatically archives almost everything.
lead_paragraph: People in the tech industry have been digging a grave for email for more than a decade, but their predictions have always seemed a little out of touch.

headline: Juliette Lewis’s Beauty Secrets (A Lot of Coconut Oil and Then Some)
abstract: The actress on her love for fake lashes, why she prefers edible scents and more.
lead_paragraph: Juliette Lewis, 41, is known for roles in films like “What’s Eating Gilbert Grape,” “Natural Born Killers” and “Cape Fear,” for which she was nominated for an Oscar. She now plays a flinty detective in the ABC series “Secrets and Lies,” which had its debut on March 1. Ms. Lewis, who is also a musician, formerly toured with her rock band, Juliette and the Licks, and is set to release a solo album this year. She lives in her native Los Angeles.

headline: Republican Idiocy on Iran
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Instead of being leaders and statesmen, Republicans in Congress seem to think their role is outside the American government.
lead_paragraph: After helping to ignite a firestorm over a possible nuclear agreement with Iran, Senator John McCain, a former Republican presidential candidate, is now sort of acknowledging his error. “Maybe that wasn’t exactly the best way to do that,” he said on Fox News on Tuesday.

headline: Cocktail Hours at the Plaza Hotel
abstract: The Palm Court has been a lot of things since 1907, but one thing it had never been was a bar, until now.

headline: Obama Hands Venezuelan Leader a Cause to Stir Support
abstract: Washington’s hope that freezing assets of Venezuelan officials would focus attention on deteriorating conditions may have given President Nicolás Maduro momentum to crack down on his opposition.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — Just a few weeks ago, President Obama was being praised across Latin America for his decision to re-establish relations with Cuba, while President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela appeared increasingly isolated — a wobbly, unpopular leader resorting to ever more aggressive tactics to confront an economic crisis and clamp down on the political opposition.

headline: Darrelle Revis Cashes In With Jets as Other N.F.L. Stars Choose to Walk Away
abstract: Revis signed for a guaranteed $39 million for five years, while four of his contemporaries declared that rather than sign for millions, they had had enough and were retiring.
lead_paragraph: Darrelle Revis, who has torn up and rehabilitated a knee in service of the N.F.L., established this winter that his market value was $39 million for five years.

abstract: Many youngsters today would rather wear sweatpants, much to their parents’ chagrin.

headline: Republicans’ Iran Letter Ignites Fierce ‘#47Traitors’ Debate Online
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Social Media', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The online political conversation in the United States continues to be dominated by a bitter debate over an open letter to the leaders of Iran.
lead_paragraph: The political conversation on social networks in the United States this week continues to be dominated by a partisan debate over the open letter to the leaders of Iran posted online Monday by 47 Republican senators.

headline: P.S.G. Survives a Red Card, a Penalty and Two Deficits to Dispatch Chelsea
abstract: Zlatan Ibrahimovic, P.S.G.’s star forward, was sent off under debatable circumstances, but the Parisians twice rallied to earn a draw and advance to the Champions League quarterfinals on the away-goals rule.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A few minutes after the referee blew the final whistle here on Wednesday night, the Paris St.-Germain players ripped off their shirts in the bitter cold, ran toward the end of the field at Stamford Bridge and danced, their arms thrown around one another, in front of a band of giddy, frothy fans.

headline: Dinner at Ralph’s
abstract: The Polo Bar has quickly become the place for the city’s elite to meet, and to dazzle.

headline: Expulsion of Two Oklahoma Students Over Video Leads to Free Speech Debate
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Fraternities and Sororities', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Some legal experts say that the racist chants uttered by the fraternity members were, however odious, protected by the First Amendment.

Here are some of these various duos and what we can learn from them, culminating in the two highest-stakes pairings of all.

It was the first inning of an exhibition game between the Mets and the Miami Marlins, the count was full, and Harvey hurled a 96-mile-per-hour fastball toward home plate, where Stanton stood waiting, bat in hand.

headline: Anti-Abortion Provision May Stop Human Trafficking Bill in Senate
keywords: ['Human Trafficking', 'Law and Legislation', 'ABORTION', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A bipartisan Senate bill that would increase penalties for perpetrators and support for victims of human trafficking met potentially fatal resistance Wednesday over an anti-abortion provision.
lead_paragraph: A bipartisan Senate bill that would increase penalties for perpetrators and support for victims of human trafficking met potentially fatal resistance Wednesday over an anti-abortion provision. Senate Democrats blocked consideration of the legislation many had supported as recently as Monday, accusing Republicans of sneaking in language that would ban money from a victims’ fund from being used for abortions. Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the Democratic leader, said his party would not allow it to move forward with that provision. Senator John Cornyn, the Texas Republican who introduced the bill, said Democrats had rejected his suggestion to introduce an amendment stripping out the language. He said the Senate would vote Thursday to end debate on the bill, but it seemed unlikely that he would have the 60 votes needed to overcome Democratic opposition.

headline: Illinois: Jesús Garcia Gains Backing of Key Black Figure in Chicago Race
abstract: Willie Wilson, the African-American businessman, will endorse Jesús G. Garcia, who is known as Chuy, over Rahm Emanuel in the runoff on April 7, Mr. Wilson said Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Willie Wilson, the African-American businessman who won more than 10 percent of the vote in the Chicago mayor’s race last month, will endorse Jesús G. Garcia, who is known as Chuy, over Rahm Emanuel in the runoff on April 7, Mr. Wilson said Wednesday. “All the data came in and the community asked me to endorse Chuy over the mayor,” Mr. Wilson said, adding that black voters disagreed with Mr. Emanuel’s decision to close nearly 50 public schools.

headline: Cuba: Leader of Dissident Group Retains Her Post After Challenge
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Political Prisoners']
abstract: Cuba’s most high-profile opposition group, the Ladies in White, voted Wednesday to keep their leader, Berta Soler, in a referendum prompted by complaints that she was autocratic and should resign.
lead_paragraph: Cuba’s most high-profile opposition group, the Ladies in White, voted Wednesday to keep their leader, Berta Soler, in a referendum prompted by complaints that she was autocratic and should resign. The challenge to Ms. Soler’s leadership exposed divisions within the group as it grapples with the changing relationship between Cuba and the United States and the group’s shifting status among Cuba’s increasingly diverse opposition groups. Ms. Soler said by telephone that she had won 180 of a total of 201 votes cast. Sixteen members of the group voted against her, and the remaining ballots were blank or annulled, she said. More than 30 members did not vote. Several members called for Ms. Soler’s resignation after a video emerged in which some in the group surrounded a member, Alejandrina García de la Riva, in December, waving their fists and chanting, “Down traitor.” The Ladies in White was formed in 2003 to protest the imprisonment of 75 dissidents. Most of the dissidents have since been released, but the group continues to march weekly to demand democratic reform and freedom of speech.

headline: With TV Deals Ahead, Players Reject Salary Cap Limits
abstract: The N.B.A. hoped to phase in gradual increases to the salary cap — a process it called smoothing — to avoid a single dramatic spike in free-agent contract amounts.
lead_paragraph: The players’ union formally rejected an N.B.A. proposal to artificially limit increases to the salary cap once lucrative new national television deals begin next year, the league said in a statement Wednesday.

headline: Canada: U.S. Consulate Attack Was Foiled, Panel Says
abstract: A man from Pakistan who was a permanent resident of Canada told an undercover officer that he planned to bomb the United States Consulate or the financial district in Toronto, an immigration panel revealed on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: A man from Pakistan who was a permanent resident of Canada told an undercover officer that he planned to bomb the United States Consulate or the financial district in Toronto, an immigration panel revealed on Wednesday. The man, Jahanzeb Malik, was detained on Monday. A lawyer for the immigration department said that Mr. Malik, who traveled to Canada as a student in 2004, told the undercover officer that he had fought in Bosnia and trained at terrorist camps in Libya. He also said that he had associated with Anwar al-Awlaki, an American cleric who was deemed a terrorist by the United States and killed in a drone strike in Yemen in 2011. The government wants to deport Mr. Malik to Pakistan. He is not facing any criminal charges.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (ABC) AMERICAN CRIME Thirty-six hours after the murder of Matt Skokie, his parents, Barb Hanlon (Felicity Huffman) and Russ Skokie (Timothy Hutton), encounter two of the suspects — the drug addicts Carter Nix (Elvis Nolasco) and Aubry Taylor (Caitlin Gerard) — at their arraignment. A third, the teenager Tony Gutiérrez (Johnny Ortiz), is placed is juvenile detention, while the fourth, Hector Tontz (Richard Cabral), is told that he will be extradited to Mexico. “This series is at heart a murder mystery — someone has been killed, and the show withholds who did it,” Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times about this limited series, created by John Ridley, the Oscar-winning screenwriter of “12 Years a Slave.” “But solving the crime isn’t the point.” What matters “is not just what is said but also the prickly sting of what is left unstated,” she added. “Miscommunication, misunderstandings and, on occasion, a stab of ice-cold reality are all part of the bereavement and also the investigation. ‘American Crime’ is a depressing story told so skillfully that it’s almost impossible not to be happy to see it unfold.”

headline: Failure to Thrive
abstract: The plant was a thoughtful gift, but it’s too beautiful, too vibrant, to be trapped in this depression den.
lead_paragraph: In the fall of 2014 the author decided to quit the prescription medications she has been taking to treat her anxiety, depression and insomnia, and began the process of gradually reducing her dosages. In Going Off, a series of Anxiety posts in the coming weeks, she will chronicle the challenges she faces from both the drugs and the withdrawal in her pursuit of a drug-free life.

headline: Dark Money, Blurred Principles

abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s decision to play the big-money, outside-influence game in a city with an exemplary campaign-finance law is disheartening.
lead_paragraph: Beware the politician who professes a devotion to goodness and idealism, and working for “the people” while quietly taking unlimited sums of cash from big donors, supposedly because these benefactors love the values he fights for and not the access and influence that buckets of money can buy.

headline: Hillary Clinton Comes Back
abstract: Is the email crisis a bad start to a 2016 campaign or a preview of the next 20 months?
lead_paragraph: Right now you’re probably asking yourself: What am I supposed to do with all this Hillary Clinton stuff? True, I am a concerned citizen, but I have a big deadline at work and a lot of social activities scheduled for the weekend.

headline: Stop the ‘Decline of Our Navy,’ a Congressman Says

headline: Lent: It’s Not Just for Catholics
abstract: A true individualist accepts suffering for the benefit it brings.
lead_paragraph: ARE you a conformist or an individualist? Most Americans believe they are the latter — to be exact, 64 percent of us in 2011, according to the World Values Survey. Perhaps you’re a cage-busting entrepreneur, or a transgressive artist. Or maybe you’re just a freethinking outlier at your Thanksgiving table. My own nonconformity in early adulthood took the form of religious conversion from Protestant to Catholic, bailing out of college to play avant-garde music, and — most schismatic of all to family and friends — voting Republican.

headline: A Failing Relationship With Venezuela
abstract: While the Obama administration moves to sanction officials in the Venezuelan government, President Nicolás Maduro wears the punishment as a badge of honor.
lead_paragraph: By imposing sanctions on seven officials in the Venezuelan government on Monday, the Obama administration took a gamble. The move appears intended to signal to members of that government that persecuting the political opposition and limiting an independent press will have consequences.

headline: Unraveling the Church Ban on Gay Sex
keywords: ['Bible', 'Ethics (Personal)', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Philosophy', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: The time has come for the Roman Catholic Church to rethink its claim that homosexual behavior is immoral. Here’s how.
lead_paragraph: Last month, Salvatore Cordileone, the archbishop of San Francisco, made controversial changes to a handbook for Catholic high school teachers in his jurisdiction. The changes included morals clauses, one of which forbids those teachers from publicly endorsing homosexual behavior. There are plausible legal and educational objections to this move. But there is a deeper issue, one that raises fundamental questions about Catholic teachings on homosexuality and other sexual matters.

headline: Dangerous Trains, Aging Rails
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Railroad Accidents and Safety', 'Railroads', 'Freight (Cargo)', 'Explosions (Accidental)', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)']
abstract: Every day, tons of oil moves over poorly regulated bridges.
lead_paragraph: A CSX freight train ran off the rails last month in rural Mount Carbon, W.Va. One after another, exploding rail cars sent hellish fireballs hundreds of feet into the clear winter sky. Gov. Earl Ray Tomblin declared a state of emergency, and the fires burned for several days.

headline: A New Gay Fairy Tale
abstract: He showed me the wild side of San Francisco. And then he showed me how to go home.
lead_paragraph: KOLKATA, INDIA — In the mid ’90s, about five years after I had moved to the United States, I got rid of the part in my hair. It was the most daring thing I had ever done to my appearance. That side part, with me since my childhood in India, was the emblem of the well-behaved, well-groomed good boy, and I had carried it diligently into adulthood.

headline: NASA Mission to Measure Earth’s Magnetic Collisions
keywords: ['Magnets and Magnetism', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Energy and Power', 'Satellites']
abstract: Scheduled for launch Thursday night, NASA’s latest mission aims to measure a region of colliding magnetic fields about 38,000 miles above Earth that can potentially disrupt satellites and power grids.
lead_paragraph: A NASA mission called Magnetospheric Multiscale, scheduled to be launched Thursday night, aims to make the first detailed measurements of a region of colliding magnetic fields about 38,000 miles above Earth. The magnetic collisions, which can potentially disrupt satellites and power grids, are not well understood.

lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — United Nations experts have painstakingly documented a litany of torture, rape and execution committed in Syria in the past four years. No one has been held accountable.

lead_paragraph: In “Disenchanted by Civilian Life, Veterans Volunteer to Fight ISIS,” Dave Philipps and Thomas James Brennan write about some American volunteers who have offered to take up arms against the Islamic State, working with local militias in Iraq and Syria.

headline: How Much Can an Artist Borrow From Earlier Musicians Before It Becomes Stealing?
abstract: Do you think the jury made the right decision in ruling that “Blurred Lines” crossed the line into plagiarizing Marvin Gaye?
lead_paragraph: Sam Smith recently agreed to pay Tom Petty royalties and share songwriting credit for his hit “Stay With Me” because the song resembled Mr. Petty’s “Won’t Back Down.” And on Wednesday a jury ruled that Robin Thicke and Pharrell Williams have to pay $7.3 million to Marvin Gaye’s family for plagiarizing the song “Got to Give It Up” in Mr. Thicke’s 2013 hit “Blurred Lines.” Isn’t music all about borrowing and building on the past? Or, is there a line that should not be crossed?

lead_paragraph: ALBANY — The legislators were annoyed. The state official testifying before them did not have many answers. And the subject of her appearance — the “multiyear transformation” of New York’s information technology system — had been pretty much cast aside.

lead_paragraph: Every recipe published in The New York Times comes with three components: an introduction to the food; the instructions on how to make it; and a photograph of the dish itself. I spend a great deal of time on the first two briefs. Andrew Scrivani is often responsible for the third.

lead_paragraph: His parents met while playing for the Washington Generals, eternal foils of the Harlem Globetrotters, but this is no losers’ narrative, not by a long shot.

headline: Conservationists Denounce Chinese Show Where Celebrities and Wildlife Share Stage
abstract: A show in which entertainers hug whale sharks, kiss lions, feed pandas and dress up baby chimpanzees has come under fire from groups that say such activities are cruel and dangerous.
lead_paragraph: A new Chinese television reality show where entertainers hug whale sharks, kiss lions, feed pandas and dress up baby chimpanzees has come under fire from wildlife conservationists who want it taken off the air, saying such activities are cruel and are dangerous for both the humans and animals.

headline: A Falcon in the City
abstract: Watching a wild falcon hunt pigeons in an industrial ruin ushers you into a silent world.
lead_paragraph: I’m standing on cracked asphalt by a high security fence at the eastern edge of Ireland. The sky is cold pewter, the salt wind bitter. I’ve come all the way here to watch wildlife, and I have just turned my back on the only birds I can see. The miles of sand behind me have been washed by the Irish Sea into a perfect blankness, pearled with gulls and flocks of migrant waders. It’s beautiful. But my friends Hilary and Eamonn have told me to look instead at Dublin’s Poolbeg Power Station, a giant’s play set of brutal turbine halls facing the shining sands. Set amid sewerage works, derelict red-brick buildings, wharves, cranes and shipping containers, this is a bizarre spot for a wildlife pilgrimage. Two decommissioned cooling chimneys tower above us, marked with vertical washes of rust and horizontal bands of red and white. Rising from the horizon, they are your first sight of Ireland if you arrive from the east by sea and the last when you leave. Visible throughout the city, they have come to mean home for a whole generation of Dubliners — and for the peregrine falcons that have nested on them for years.

headline: Imagining 2016 Without Hillary Clinton
abstract: Without her, the Democratic race would be chaotic, which helps explain why she enjoys such support within the party.
lead_paragraph: We’re on record here at The Upshot as believing that Hillary Clinton is in an extremely strong position to win the Democratic nomination. And as Brendan Nyhan has explained, the furor over her private email account is likely to affect far fewer voters than may now appear to be the case.

headline: Sailing to the End of the World in Patagonia
abstract: A three-night cruise through southern Argentina brings views of mountains, glaciers and 100,000 penguins — and not a cellphone in sight.
lead_paragraph: In Ushuaia, Argentina, the capital of the province of Tierra del Fuego, where I began a three-night cruise through southern Patagonia, the daily newspaper is called El Diario del Fin del Mundo — The Journal of the End of the World. It’s a startling name for a newspaper but an apt description of the cruise, during which it is easy to believe that you have, indeed, sailed to the very end of the earth.

headline: Cruising the Past, from Baltimore to Charleston
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Cruises', 'Ships and Shipping', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)']
abstract: It wasn’t the antebellum mansions or the bird life I’d miss from my seven-night trip aboard the American Glory; it was my fellow shipmates.
lead_paragraph: I staggered from my single stateroom into the empty corridor, bilious and desperate. I was aboard the American Glory, a 50-passenger cruise ship that had, for five days, proceeded effortlessly down the Intracoastal Waterway. Until we hit open water north of Charleston, S.C., and I learned, around 2 a.m., that I am uncommonly disposed to seasickness.

headline: ITV to Pay Up to $1.2 Billion for ‘The Voice’ Producer
abstract: The acquisition of Talpa Media, established by John de Mol, the “Big Brother” creator, is the latest move by the British broadcaster to bolster its content and sell shows globally.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — ITV, the British television broadcaster and producer, said on Thursday that it had agreed to pay up to 1.1 billion euros, or about $1.2 billion, for Talpa Media, the Dutch producer of the singing competition show “The Voice.”

headline: Today in Politics: As Clinton Wobbles, Black Congressional Leaders Show Support
abstract: More than a week after controversy erupted over Mrs. Clinton’s email practices at the State Department, there is no sign of Democrats abandoning their presumed presidential nominee.
lead_paragraph: Good Thursday morning from Washington, where the F.B.I. is celebrating a special anniversary and former Representative Michele Bachmann of Minnesota has started an acting career, of sorts. Congressional oversight has shifted from President Obama to his potential successor, but when it comes to Democrats, Hillary Rodham Clinton appears too big to fail.

headline: Was a Patient’s Arthritis Medicine Making Her Sick?
abstract: She had been on medication for years. Was it possible that it was actually making her sicker?
lead_paragraph: She had been on medication for years. Was it possible that it was actually making her sicker?

headline: Morning Agenda: U.S. Banks Pass Fed Tests
abstract: All the large U.S. banks pass the Fed’s stress tests. | The Utah Legislature approves a white-collar felon registry. | Endo tops Valeant’s offer for Salix. | Alibaba plans to invest in Snapchat.
lead_paragraph: U.S. BANKS PASS FED EXAM | The Federal Reserve said on Wednesday that all the large United States banks passed its so-called stress tests, which aim to assess whether they can weather a financial storm, DealBook’s Peter Eavis writes. Bank of America passed only provisionally and could still fail later this year if it does not fix deficiencies that the Fed identified. Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase and Morgan Stanley each had to alter their planned payouts to investors to achieve passing grades. The American units of Deutsche Bank, the German banking giant, and Santander of Spain failed the tests outright.

headline: Free-Throw Distraction: The Best Fans in the N.C.A.A.
abstract: Many college fan sections view themselves as passionate and zany, but which ones excel at making opponents miss from the foul line?
lead_paragraph: Who are the most effective fans in college basketball — and which fans aren’t effective at all?

headline: A Balancing Act as Iraq Claims Gains in Tikrit
abstract: A major step for the Iraqi government in fighting ISIS came with Shiite militias and Iranian military officials in a leading role, which has American officials worried.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi declared Thursday that victory in Tikrit was near and “achieved totally by Iraqi hands” as his troops sought to root out Islamic State militants from their last few footholds in the city.

lead_paragraph: The author Daniel Duane discusses Alex Honnold’s free solo climb of Heaven, a 3,000-foot vertical wall with a 40-foot overhang in Yosemite.

headline: Asia Gears Up for Art Basel Hong Kong
abstract: With a new start date, the Hong Kong fair is trying to separate itself from the pack.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — When the third edition of Art Basel Hong Kong, Asia’s hottest contemporary art fair, opens to the public on Sunday, the atmosphere will be noticeably cooler, for reasons that have less to do with the region’s overall economic slowdown than with the shift in the fair’s dates from humid May to balmy March.

headline: The Heart-Stopping Climbs of Alex Honnold
abstract: The master of climbing without ropes spends his life cheating death.
lead_paragraph: Fifteen miles outside Yosemite Valley, a beeping iPhone alarm awakened Alex Honnold at 4 a.m. in the white Ford Econoline van that he has called home for the last seven years. Honnold, who is 29 and one of the two or three best rock climbers on earth, sat up on his cheap foam mattress and switched on his headlamp in the darkness. The nearby Merced River made a soft rushing sound, and crickets hummed in the grass in the dry heat of June. Honnold rolled back his van’s sliding side door to greet his ponytailed friend David Allfrey, who was also 29, emerging just then from an old VW camper van parked 10 feet away.

headline: Review: Alex Gibney Takes On Scientology in ‘Going Clear’
abstract: This documentary by Alex Gibney charts the evolution of Scientology from its outsider beginnings to its current status as that church Tom Cruise belongs to.
lead_paragraph: Soon into Alex Gibney’s investigative documentary “Going Clear: Scientology and the Prison of Belief,” you hear him lob a question at Lawrence Wright, the author of the 2013 nonfiction book the movie is based on. “Scientology is such a subject of fascination for people,” Mr. Gibney says off camera. “How did you get engaged in the story?”

headline: At Georgia State, a Father and Son Tread a Fine Line

lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Four years ago, the high school basketball standout R. J. Hunter entered his mother’s bedroom in Indianapolis and interrupted her sleep with some news: He would cast his college basketball lot with Georgia State.

headline: French Win Latest Battle of Waterloo
abstract: Belgium is withdrawing its design for a 2 euro coin featuring an image of a monument that commemorates the defeat of Napoleon.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It was to have been a commemoration that would have placed France’s humiliation at the Battle of Waterloo in every European’s purse or pocket. Instead, it turned into a tussle of a different kind, redolent of history’s long shadow, in which France finally emerged triumphant.

headline: Broadway Dreams in Astoria, Queens

lead_paragraph: Like many girls with Broadway dreams, Hannah Peterson played the lead in “Annie.” Her run was five years ago at the Alban Arts and Conference Center near her home in Charleston, W.Va.

headline: Buccellati Celebrates Its New York Flagship With Art-Inspired Jewels
abstract: The jewelry house’s first female designer, 25-year-old Lucrezia, created five one-of-a-kind designs based on Impressionist and Post-Impressionist works from her husband’s private collection.
lead_paragraph: Since 1919, generations of Buccellatis have produced highly elaborate, often gem-centric jewelry from the family’s design studio and boutique in Milan. Today, the jewelry house opens the doors to its new five-story flagship store on Madison Avenue and unveils its new Art collection. Co-designed by Lucrezia Buccellati, who at age 25 happens to be the first female designer for the brand, the five signature, one-of-a-kind pieces were inspired by rare works privately owned by her husband, David Wildenstein, a gallery owner and avid collector. He loaned the same five paintings — one each by Claude Monet, Pierre Bonnard, Winslow Homer, Mikhail Larionov and Odilon Redon — to the flagship boutique, where they are on view in a temporary gallery space on the fourth floor.

headline: 14 Million Children Suffering as Result of War in Syria and Iraq, Unicef Says
abstract: The report was one of a slew of statements by international relief agencies detailing the plight of Syrian civilians in a conflict that has killed more than 200,000 people.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Around 14 million children are suffering hardship and trauma from the war in Syria and Iraq, the United Nations children’s agency said on Thursday, highlighting the needs of children struggling to cope with severe violence, and the danger to the rest of the world of failing to help a generation preyed on by extremist groups.

lead_paragraph: A worker from Partners In Health, the prominent American medical aid organization, and an emergency worker from the British military have been infected with the deadly Ebola virus in Sierra Leone, health officials said Thursday.

headline: F.C.C. Sets Net Neutrality Rules
keywords: ['Net Neutrality', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The agency said it would decide on what was acceptable on a case-by-case basis, taking on a more prominent role in the high-speed Internet arena.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Communications Commission on Thursday released extensive details of how it would regulate broadband Internet providers as a public utility, producing official wording that almost certainly sets the stage for extended legal fights.

headline: New Wing at Corning Museum of Glass Invites the Light
abstract: The museum’s new 100,000-square-foot wing, which opens March 20, will finally allow the museum to properly display large-scale works.
lead_paragraph: CORNING, N.Y. — The first thing the architect Thomas Phifer did after being awarded the commission for the Corning Museum of Glass’s new 100,000-square-foot Contemporary Art + Design Wing here was to go back to his downtown Manhattan office and take an Alvar Aalto vase out on Varick Street. Aalto’s Savoy vase — the classic wedding gift for an architect — has thick glass walls that bend and curve, and a footprint that looks a little like a splotch. “It was a really sunny day, and as we looked at that vase in the light, it began to really glow,” Mr. Phifer said. “The more light you pushed into it, the more it glowed.”

headline: Ken Watanabe Moves From ‘Samurai’ to ‘The King and I’
abstract: A movie star in Japan, Mr. Watanabe, who still keeps a translator nearby, makes his Broadway debut with a role about a cultural divide.
lead_paragraph: In the wrong hands, “The King and I,” with all those adorable children scampering about, could feel a little Disneyish. And then there’s the Yul Brynner problem. The show was originally written for Gertrude Lawrence, fanning the embers of her career, but it was Brynner, with his gleaming head and firm torso, who put his stamp on it when the show opened in 1951 and made a lifetime job of playing the King of Siam. He was still doing the role just months before his death in 1985, at the age of 65, and for all we know he’s doing it still.

headline: Iowa Straw Poll, Loved and Loathed, Is Moving to Boone

headline: Roof Collapse Kills Workers in Bangladeshi Cement Factory
abstract: At least six people are dead, around 40 were rescued and as many as 70 remained trapped, a government safety official said.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The roof of a cement factory collapsed Thursday afternoon in the southwestern Bangladeshi city of Mongla, killing at least six people and leaving scores more in the wreckage, a government safety official said.

headline: Faye Toogood’s Radical, Genderless, Brand-Free Concept Space at Selfridges
abstract: The British designer conceived a back-to-basics retail area for the London department store: cagelike structures that span three levels and are comprised largely of chicken-wire mesh.
lead_paragraph: Can retail ever really be radical? That’s the question raised by a new concept space opening today at the Selfridges department store in London. Agender is the brainchild of Faye Toogood, the protean British designer whose artisanal approach to interiors has seen her recruited by the likes of Hermès, Comme des Garçons and Alexander McQueen. Set across three levels of the store, this string of cagelike structures towers above the existing shop floor like a primeval Tardis. Its ambition: the kind of genderless, brand-free shopping that’s the stuff of normcore dreams.

headline: Vacation Photos, by Pros
abstract: The new service Flytographer connects travelers with local photographers.
lead_paragraph: High-quality vacation pictures are the most memorable souvenirs — at least according to Flytographer, a new service that connects visitors with more than 200 local photographers in 130 cities around the world, including Istanbul, Buenos Aires, Dubai, Hong Kong and Orlando.

headline: Review of New York Shelter System Finds Hundreds of Violations
abstract: City investigators examining 25 shelters and temporary housing programs found that the sites “are too often unsafe and unhealthy for children and families,” a report said.
lead_paragraph: A New York City homeless shelter system that was supposed to provide a refuge for families with children instead forced some of them to live in squalid conditions that included a dead rat in an apartment; garbage strewn in hallways and stairways; and a puddle of urine in the only working elevator of one building.

lead_paragraph: Videos posted online are said to show the moment two police officers were shot as bystanders took cover in Ferguson, Mo.

headline: My Coach, My Father
abstract: Georgia State Coach Ron Hunter and his son, R. J., are experiencing a hodgepodge of emotions as their college basketball journey together is apparently approaching the finish line.
lead_paragraph: Georgia State Coach Ron Hunter and his son, R. J., are experiencing a hodgepodge of emotions as their college basketball journey together is apparently approaching the finish line.
