headline: G.O.P. Letter by Republican Senators Is Evidence of ‘Decline,’ Iranian Says
abstract: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran’s supreme leader, said the letter was “a sign of a decline in political ethics and the destruction of the American establishment from within.”
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Iran’s highest leader issued a sharp response Thursday to a letter to the country’s leadership by Republican lawmakers, deriding it as an indication that Washington is “disintegrating” from within.

headline: Mercenaries Join Nigeria’s Military Campaign Against Boko Haram
abstract: A foreign force that includes hundreds of South Africans is now fighting the Islamist group, officials said. Separately, the Islamic State accepted Boko Haram’s pledge of allegiance.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Hundreds of mercenaries from South Africa and other countries are playing a decisive role in Nigeria’s military campaign against Boko Haram, operating attack helicopters and armored personnel carriers and fighting to retake towns and villages captured by the Islamist militant group, according to senior officials in the region.

headline: Hillary Clinton Tackling an Urgent Task: Building a Press Team
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton is bringing on Jesse Ferguson, who recently led communications at the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, to serve as one of the key spokespeople for her likely campaign.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s team of advisers is moving quickly to build a communications team that will handle her campaign’s messaging and play a crucial role in responding to attacks from opponents and critical news coverage, tasks that have grown more urgent after a month in which she has been forced to deal with controversies involving her email use and foreign donations to her family’s foundation.

headline: Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge, Pays a Royal Visit to the ‘Downton Abbey’ Set
abstract: The duchess visited with actors and toured the set where the show is filming its sixth season.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Dowager Countess has been outranked.

headline: The Husband-Wife Musical Duo Who Hit a Note for Lars von Trier and Ai Wei Wei
abstract: Katherine Mills Rymer and Jens Bjørnkjær, who record as OOFJ, share their gossamer electro-pop single “Cliffdive” exclusively with T.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles minimalist musical duo OOFJ was bred from a chance meeting and an unprecedented tragedy. Back in the ’90s, the Danish producer and multi-instrumentalist Jens Bjørnkjær, a classically trained saxophone player, was attending conservatory in New York; but disillusioned with jazz standards, he quit the New School in his third year. Several years later, he happened to attend a production of “Twelfth Night” starring the South African vocalist (and then-acting student at Stella Adler Studio of Acting) Katherine Mills Rymer. By then, Bjørnkjær had begun to craft electronic music and had just contributed to the score of “Melancholia,” Lars von Trier’s metaphysical 2011 drama — “a great pickup line,” he says over the phone. Rymer hums in agreement. She recalls that he wore all beige that night, a “restful thing to the eye.”

headline: A Railway Catastrophe in the Making
abstract: American cities are at risk of horrific oil-train derailments unless the oil industry and the administration make changes now.
lead_paragraph: So far, Americans have been spared the kind of terrible tragedy that occurred two years ago in the small tourist town of Lac-Mégantic in southern Canada.  On a midsummer morning, a row of tank cars filled with crude oil suddenly slammed into the center of town and exploded, killing 47 people in what bystanders called “a tsunami of fire.”

headline: Lumber Liquidators Offers Flooring Customers Free Air Tests for Formaldehyde
abstract: The air quality testing follows a news report that the retailer sold laminate flooring from China that violated safety limits.
lead_paragraph: Lumber Liquidators said on Thursday that it would provide free air testing to consumers after a report that accused the company of selling laminate flooring from China that contained high levels of formaldehyde.

headline: 1940: Soviet-Finnish Pact Concluded
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Soviet-Finnish peace pact reached in 1940.
lead_paragraph: Following a day of rumors, American short-wave stations broadcast a message from the official German news agency late last night [March 12] asserting that a peace treaty had resulted in Moscow from the four-day negotiations between the Finnish delegation and the Soviet government. According to the Berlin report, the peace treaty contained the following three points: an immediate armistice; cession of the Carelian Isthmus to the Soviet government; and granting of a military base to Russia on the Hango Peninsula. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 13, 1940

headline: Report on Violations in Homeless Shelters
abstract: The Department of Investigation found family shelters in New York City are too often unsafe and unhealthy for children and families, according to its report. But these problems are the result of decades of neglect, the report said.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Investigation found family shelters in New York City are too often unsafe and unhealthy for children and families, according to its report. But these problems are the result of decades of neglect, the report said.

headline: De Blasio, at Rikers, Unveils a Plan to Reduce Violence and Smuggling
abstract: Many proposals in Mayor Bill de Blasio’s plan have already been underway, showing just how difficult the task of reforming the jail complex is proving to be.
lead_paragraph: Faced with surging violence at Rikers Island, Mayor Bill de Blasio visited the New York City jail complex on Thursday for the second time in three months to unveil a 14-point plan focused on curtailing inmate fights and stopping the smuggling of drugs and weapons.

headline: Hong Kong Finds Small Amount of Radioactivity in Sample of Japanese Tea
keywords: ['Radiation', 'Food', 'Japan Earthquake and Tsunami (2011)', 'Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)', 'Tea', 'Food Contamination and Poisoning']
abstract: Other samples of Japanese food have occasionally been found to have low levels of radiation since the Fukushima disaster, the Hong Kong food center said.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A sample of powdered tea imported from the Japanese prefecture of Chiba, just southeast of Tokyo, contained traces of radioactive cesium 137, the Hong Kong government announced late Thursday evening, but they were far below the legal maximum level.

headline: Wondering What the Fed’s Statements Mean? Be Patient
keywords: ['English Language', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Quantitative Easing', 'Speeches and Statements']
abstract: Ten years after Ben Bernanke proclaimed the end of “Fedspeak,” the Federal Reserve, try as it might, still seems to be speaking in ambiguities.
lead_paragraph: patient adj. “bearing or enduring pain, trouble, etc. without complaining or losing self-control; refusing to be provoked or angered, as by an insult; forbearing; tolerant; calmly tolerating delay, confusion, inefficiency, etc.” — Webster’s New World College Dictionary

headline: What Yoga Taught Me About the Balanced Life
abstract: Is it ever possible to be balanced? Depends on your definition of balance.
lead_paragraph: I had been drinking the “Life in Balance” Kool-Aid for decades now, seeking to embrace the power of now; to eat, pray and love. So why was I suddenly not so sure?

keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Speeches and Statements']
abstract: Mary Jo White publicly addressed for the first time a debate over whether her agency allowed banks to avoid certain repercussions for their misdeeds.
lead_paragraph: One of Wall Street’s top regulators on Thursday shot back at criticism that the nation’s biggest banks enjoy special treatment in Washington, delivering a sweeping defense of the government while also rebuking the financial industry’s “repeated and disturbing violations of law.”

headline: With a Big Sale Looming, a New View of Rothko
abstract: Annie Cohen-Solal sees Mark Rothko as a man with the messianic goal of mending the world and deeply hostile to the commercial side of art. One of his paintings is leading Christie’s May auctions.
lead_paragraph: It was one of life’s small contradictions. On Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Annie Cohen-Solal, the author of “Mark Rothko: Toward the Light in the Chapel,” just published by Yale University Press as part of its “Jewish Lives” series, was presenting her view of the artist as a man of “constant displacements,” wedded to an artistic vision with the messianic goal of mending the world and deeply hostile to the commercial side of art.

headline: Back in Camp, Sidelined Pitchers Find Hope and Worry
abstract: The Yankees’ Masahiro Tanaka is trying to beat a partial tear in the ulnar collateral ligament, but Kris Medlen and Ryan Madson are examples of pitchers who had arm surgery with varying outcomes.
lead_paragraph: SURPRISE, Ariz. — Kris Medlen could not help noticing Matt Harvey’s spring training debut last week. Medlen was in the Kansas City Royals’ camp here, watching on MLB Network, when it all came rushing back.

headline: Banks Can Now Prep for a Tougher Exam
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)']
abstract: Banks have shown they can weather a flood, but not yet a break in the levee. That comes next with the Fed and F.D.I.C resolution requirements.
lead_paragraph: Ater an arduous couple weeks of putting their institutions through a series of stringent stress tests, America’s top bankers might want to kick back and earn some money, perhaps even whistling to the possibility of higher interest rates. If only it were so easy. The only suitable tune would be Led Zeppelin’s bluesy stomp, “When the Levee Breaks.”

headline: Lagers Enjoy a Renaissance
abstract: In time for spring training, the beer panel rates 20 American lagers.
lead_paragraph: Spring training for Major League Baseball is well underway, and you might say I’ve begun my training for spring, jettisoning reflexive winter moves and reawakening old impulses.

headline: 1915: U.S. Outrage Over Sinking
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: U.S. outraged at the sinking of the William P. Frye in 1915.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Despatches from New York state that great indignation has been caused throughout the United States by the sinking of the American sailing ship William P. Frye, which was sent to the bottom by the German auxiliary cruiser Prinz Eitel Friedrich, one of the last of Germany’s commerce raiders. The ‘‘Daily Telegraph’s’’ correspondent at Washington states that, according to reports received by the Treasury and Navy Departments, the destruction of the William P. Frye is the most wanton example of flagrant disobedience to all rules of international law that has been presented for fifty years. — The New York Herald, European Edition, March 13, 1915

headline: Josh Edgin’s Elbow Injury Raises Questions for Mets’ Bullpen
abstract: Edgin, a reliever who has a stretched ligament and tendinitis in his left elbow, must decide whether to rest and rehabilitate the arm or have Tommy John surgery.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The Mets announced Thursday that Josh Edgin, their top left-handed reliever, had a stretched ligament and tendinitis in his left elbow. Within the next day or two, he is expected to decide how to proceed.

abstract: A new study suggests that people who live in the Atacama Desert are more resistant to arsenic than other people, thanks to natural selection.
lead_paragraph: Around 11,000 years ago, humans first set foot in the driest place on Earth.

headline: Lines Are Blurred in Donor Event for Jeb Bush ‘Super PAC’
abstract: A Miami donor conference next month hosted by Jeb Bush will be organized by a super PAC controlled by his allies, according to an invitation sent to supporters, an example of how Mr. Bush and other candidates have blurred the lines between their nascent presidential bids and supposedly independent outside groups.
lead_paragraph: A “super PAC” controlled by allies of Jeb Bush is organizing a donor conference that he will host next month in Miami, according to an invitation sent to supporters, an example of how Mr. Bush and other candidates have blurred the lines between their nascent presidential bids and supposedly independent outside groups.

headline: Le Marécage
abstract: West Africa meets the Caribbean at this East Village restaurant.
lead_paragraph: West Africa meets the Caribbean at this East Village restaurant.

headline: Sharing Their World With You
abstract: At Le Marécage in the East Village, the husband-and-wife team draws on French backgrounds from West Africa and the Caribbean.
lead_paragraph: Le Marécage: the Swamp. It is an unexpected name for this elegant little restaurant, chastely dressed in lace curtains tied with twine and glowing inside, with dark live-edge wood tables under hand-carved lamps whose luminous craters look like honeycomb in the making.

headline: Egypt Arrests 75 in Connection With Recent Attacks

headline: General in El Salvador Killings in ’80s Can Be Deported, Court Rules
abstract: The ruling by the Board of Immigration Appeals will make it easier to deport foreigners who were top commanders based on violations by soldiers serving under them.
lead_paragraph: In a decision setting a significant human rights precedent, an immigration appeals court has ruled that a former defense minister of El Salvador, a close ally of Washington during the civil war there in the 1980s, can be deported from the United States because he participated in or concealed torture and murder by his troops.

headline: Red-Light Camera Debate Is a Stew of Anger, Revenue and Safety
abstract: Many drivers say the systems are unfair, but communities say they make money and reduce accidents.
lead_paragraph: GETTING a $50 ticket for missing a red light is unpleasant enough. But when it is received in the mail without warning, generated from an unmarked camera, it can cause resentment.

headline: In 'Backcountry' and Other Movies, a Bear Makes a Mean Co-Star
abstract: On the big screen, bears can be a punch line or a predator.
lead_paragraph: On the big screen, bears can be a punch line or a predator.

headline: Review: ‘The Plains Indians,’ America’s Early Artists, at the Met
abstract: This show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art includes about 130 pieces of some of the earliest surviving art by Native Americans.
lead_paragraph: Some of the earliest surviving art by native North Americans left America long ago. Soldiers, traders and priests, with magpie eyes for brilliance, bundled it up and shipped it across the sea to Europe. Painted robes, embroidered slippers and feathered headdresses tinkling with chimes found their way into cupboards in 18th-century London and Paris, and lay there half-forgotten. Now, in “The Plains Indians: Artists of Earth and Sky” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, some of those wondrous things have come home.

abstract: New research focusing on behavior upends what was previously thought about the so-called ideological happiness gap.
lead_paragraph: Conservatives are happier than liberals, or so decades of surveys that ask about life satisfaction would suggest.

headline: At Manischewitz, the Private Equity Owner Keeps Kosher
abstract: It’s up to Rabbi Yaakov Y. Horowitz to ensure Manischewitz stays true to its principles under its new owner. “We schmooze a lot,” he said.
lead_paragraph: Private equity firms have plenty to worry about when buying companies, including improving revenue and keeping costs in check.

headline: In Colin Barrett’s ‘Young Skins,’ a Small Irish Town’s Aimless Denizens
abstract: In this decorated debut story collection, Irish men and women in the early stages of adulthood make a racket while going nowhere.
lead_paragraph: “I am young,” one of Colin Barrett’s narrators tells us, “and the young do not number many here, but it is fair to say we have the run of the place.”

headline: Awash in Information, Historians Fear Loss of Rich Material
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s decision to delete thousands of personal emails has fueled broader concerns that invaluable historical details are being lost.
lead_paragraph: When Hillary Rodham Clinton disclosed that she had destroyed more than 30,000 emails about personal matters during her tenure as secretary of state, it was painful for historians and biographers. Some imagined themselves or their successors in 20 or 50 years prowling the archives with little success for the most intimate, revealing raw material.

headline: ‘For Love of Country,’ by Howard Schultz and Rajiv Chandrasekaran
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A celebration of the courage, dedication and sacrifice of this generation of American veterans.
lead_paragraph: Howard Schultz and Rajiv Chandrasekaran are a formidable team. Chandrasekaran, a reporter and editor for The Washington Post who is about to start a media company in partnership with Starbucks, has served as a foreign correspondent in Iraq and Afghanistan, and is the author of compelling books on those wars. Schultz, the chief executive of Starbucks, has initiated comprehensive programs in that corporation to hire veterans. His account in the book’s introduction of a trip to West Point, where he realized the extent of the disconnect between ordinary Americans and those who serve in their military forces, is itself inspiring.

headline: Terry Pratchett, Novelist, Dies at 66
abstract: Mr. Pratchett, an accomplished British satirist, was known for his Discworld series. He created wildly imaginative alternative realities in his more than 70 books.
lead_paragraph: Terry Pratchett, the immensely popular British fantasy novelist whose more than 70 books include the series known as Discworld, died on Thursday at his home near Salisbury, England. He was 66.

lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton gave a paid speech at the headquarters of eBay in San Jose, Calif., on Wednesday, a previously undisclosed appearance that fell a day after a news conference in which she explained her use of a private email account while she was secretary of state.

headline: Hope of Finding Survivors in Army Helicopter Crash Fades
keywords: ['Helicopters', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']

lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The Coast Guard suspended its search-and-rescue operation in the waters off the Florida Panhandle on Thursday, an acknowledgment that the seven Marines and four Army soldiers aboard the Black Hawk helicopter that crashed Tuesday in Navarre, Fla., were unlikely to be found alive.

lead_paragraph: Commerzbank agreed to pay nearly $1.5 billion to settle civil and criminal charges related to its role in enabling a huge accounting scheme and other illicit transactions.

headline: The Political Art of Not Being a Scientist
abstract: A report alleges that after Florida Gov. Rick Scott took office, state officials were barred from using the term “climate change.”
lead_paragraph: Florida Gov. Rick Scott is one of many prominent Republican politicians who prefer to say “I’m not a scientist” as they avoid specific policy positions on climate change and global warming. Even so, the allegedly unwritten policy of his administration for the past four years has been a ban on the use of those very terms — “climate change” and “global warming” — by state environmental officials, according to an investigative report published Sunday in the Miami Herald.

lead_paragraph: It had been so long that even Coach Steve Lavin could not remember the last time St. John’s won a game in the Big East tournament. He had near-perfect recall of games he lost while at U.C.L.A. in overtime — who hit the shot, the time on the clock, the most minuscule of details — but the Red Storm’s record at Madison Square Garden in postseason play escaped him.

headline: Kerry Washington to Play Anita Hill in HBO Film
abstract: She is set to star as Anita Hill in an HBO movie about the Clarence Thomas Supreme Court confirmation hearings.
lead_paragraph: Kerry Washington cannot stay away from Washington D.C. As first reported by The Hollywood Reporter, the “Scandal” star will portray Anita Hill in an HBO movie titled “Confirmation.” Ms. Washington confirmed the news on her Twitter account. The film will deal with the 1991 Supreme Court confirmation hearings in which Ms. Hill, a law professor, detailed accusations of sexual harassment against Clarence Thomas. No date has yet been set for the film’s HBO premiere.

headline: Comentario: Las lecciones que aprendemos durante los 40
abstract: No existen los adultos. Perdona a todos tus “ex”. Está bien que no te guste el jazz.
lead_paragraph: PARÍS — Si todo salió conforme a lo planeado, habré cumplido 44 años poco tiempo después de la publicación de esta columna. Hasta ahora en mi vida adulta, no he logrado entender el objetivo principal de una década sino hasta mucho tiempo después de que ha terminado. Resulta que en vez de haber pasado mis 20 buscando esposo con desesperación, debí haberme concentrado en mi carrera y en disfrutar el último suspiro de libertad. Posteriormente, en mis 30 me la pasé rumiando las cosas que me hicieron sentir inconforme a los 20.

headline: Charles Ray at Matthew Marks
abstract: Charles Ray’s “Baled Truck,” at Matthew Marks, is a machine-milled rendering of a truck that was compacted into a 10-foot-long box shape.
lead_paragraph: Charles Ray’s “Baled Truck” is a machine-milled, stainless-steel rendering of a truck that was compacted into a 10-foot-long box shape weighing 13 tons. It’s the only object occupying the gallery’s main showroom, which has been constructed into a cruciform layout like that of a minimalist church interior. The sculpture sits at the intersection of transept and nave like a coffin. It’s conceptually interesting, but visually inert.

headline: Olivier Zahm, Miriam Odemba and the Faces of New York Fashion Week, Part Two
abstract: The illustrator Damien Florébert Cuypers shares his impressionistic portraits of the stylish personalities around the City of Light this week.
lead_paragraph: The illustrator Damien Florébert Cuypers shares his impressionistic portraits of the stylish personalities around the City of Light this week.

headline: Audra McDonald Will Return to Broadway in ‘Shuffle Along’
abstract: She will star in a show, written and directed by George C. Wolfe, that explores the history of an all-black 1921 musical.
lead_paragraph: In the annals of Broadway history, the 1921 musical “Shuffle Along” holds a special, if little-known, place: it was the rare all-black show, and started the career of Josephine Baker, among others.

headline: ‘The Painter of Modern Life’ at Anton Kern Gallery
abstract: Organized by the independent curator Bob Nickas, this show presents more than 70 works by 21 artists.
lead_paragraph: Given its title, taken from an essay by Baudelaire, you might suppose that “The Painter of Modern Life” would offer an alternative to the abstract and conceptually self-reflexive approaches to painting that are so prevalent today. But while it’s a lively and engaging show, it doesn’t have a lot to do with life as ordinarily construed. Organized by the independent curator Bob Nickas, it presents more than 70 works by 21 artists, most of whom focus on formal and procedural aspects like surfaces, shapes, repetition, color and sensually assertive materials.

headline: Barry Gerson: ‘The Parting of the Clouds’
abstract: An exhibition of four films from the early 1970s piques your desire to see more work by Mr. Gerson.
lead_paragraph: Barry Gerson was a well-known member of the generation of 1960s and ’70s Americans working alongside minimalism and associated with experimental — known as structuralist — filmmaking. After exhibiting his work at most of the major museums in the city and following his inclusion in the 1983 Whitney Biennial, Mr. Gerson quit making films for two decades. This small, thoughtful show offers a reintroduction — for many, a first glimpse — of his work.

headline: ‘Frozen 2’ Is on the Way, Disney Says; More ‘Star Wars’ Plans Revealed
abstract: The company used its annual shareholder meeting to make several movie announcements, which also included a release date for “Star Wars: Episode VIII.”
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The blizzard continues: “Frozen 2” is coming to theaters.

headline: The Top 10 Moments From Fall/Winter 2015 Paris Fashion Week
abstract: T’s market director rounds up the most memorable happenings both on and off the runways.
lead_paragraph: T’s market director rounds up the most memorable happenings both on and off the runways.

headline: Judge Refuses to Lift Injunction on Argentine Bond Payments
abstract: The decision is a defeat for Citigroup and Argentina in a long-running legal dispute with a group of hedge funds.
lead_paragraph: A New York judge at the center of a multiyear battle between Argentina and a group a hedge funds has dug in his heels once again.

headline: New York Attorney General Suspends Automatic Email Purge in His Office
abstract: Eric T. Schneiderman, the state attorney general, said that the automatic deletion of emails after 90 days would be turned off while the office formulated a new policy.
lead_paragraph: Eric T. Schneiderman, the New York State attorney general, will suspend a policy started by his predecessor, Andrew M. Cuomo, in which emails in his office are automatically deleted after 90 days, his office said on Thursday.

headline: Visit the Barber? Maybe Not, Says Holder
abstract: Gerard Contee, a participant in President Obama’s “My Brother’s Keeper” mentoring initiative, told the president last month that he wanted to be attorney general someday.
lead_paragraph: Gerard Contee, a participant in President Obama’s “My Brother’s Keeper” mentoring initiative, told the president last month that he wanted to be attorney general someday during a luncheon at which the young men in the program went around the table stating their dream jobs.

headline: Olivier Zahm, Miriam Odemba and the Faces of Paris Fashion Week, Part Two
abstract: The illustrator Damien Florébert Cuypers shares his impressionistic portraits of the stylish personalities around the City of Light this week.
lead_paragraph: The illustrator Damien Florébert Cuypers shares his impressionistic portraits of the stylish personalities around the City of Light this week.

headline: Asia Week Celebrates an Array of Art as Vast as a Continent
abstract: Asia Week New York and the Japanese Art Dealers Association fair offer a wide range of painting, calligraphy, sculpture, ceramics and photography to admire.
lead_paragraph: New York’s museums are filled with stellar exhibitions devoted to Asian art — and several more open on Friday. A much-anticipated exhibition of ukiyo-e prints featuring cats debuts at the Japan Society. The Queens Museum opens a survey of art in India from 1947 to 1997 and the Rubin Museum introduces a show of masks from Tibet, Nepal and other regions. An exhibition of works by the Iranian abstractionist Monir Shahroudy Farmanfarmaian joins the Guggenheim’s already lauded show about the conceptual painter On Kawara. Meanwhile, the Asia Society continues a season of programming dedicated to the art of Myanmar.

headline: Michael Graves, 80, Dies; Postmodernist Designed Towers and Teakettles
abstract: Mr. Graves, one of the most prominent and prolific American architects of the latter 20th century, was perhaps best known for his teakettle and pepper mill.
lead_paragraph: Michael Graves, one of the most prominent and prolific American architects of the latter 20th century, who designed more than 350 buildings around the world but was perhaps best known for his teakettle and pepper mill, died on Thursday at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 80.

headline: Venice Biennale Shows its Political Stripes
abstract: The art fair will offer an epic reading of the volumes of Marx’s “Das Kapital”
lead_paragraph: The curator of the 56th Venice Biennale, which opens May 9 – and which celebrates the 120th anniversary of the international art exhibition – announced his lineup of artists on Thursday, a highly diverse global group whose work often focuses on the tangled aftermath of colonialism and the effects of late capitalism.

headline: Who Are Pope Francis’s Critics?
abstract: A taxonomy of various sorts of Francis-era doubt.
lead_paragraph: The latest cover of the new New Republic features Elizabeth Stoker Bruenig taking on conservative anxieties about Pope Francis’s possible “radicalism.” The essay isn’t just about the pope; it offers a larger critique of the way that conservatives, Catholic and otherwise, relate to and interpret the human/Western/Christian past. I have a few disagreements with this depiction, and a few critical generalizations I’d make about the liberal tendency in Catholic thinking and debate right now. But I’ll save those for another post; for now I think it would be helpful for the discussion of Catholicism in the Francis era to spend some time distinguishing between the different groups who have doubts, or flirt with having doubts, about this pontificate, because in Bruenig’s account they run together a bit and I think the distinctions are actually enormously important.

headline: The East Harlem Explosion, One Year Later
abstract: Family members, emergency workers and politicians paid tribute to the eight people who died in the explosion on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Family members, emergency workers and politicians paid tribute to the eight people who died in the explosion on Thursday.

headline: Japanese Coastal Town Still Struggling to Rebuild From 2011 Tsunami
keywords: ['Japan Earthquake and Tsunami (2011)', 'Tidal Waves and Tsunamis']
abstract: Those who want to stay in small northern communities worry they could face more waiting as memories fade and focus turns to the 2020 Olympics in Tokyo.
lead_paragraph: OTSUCHI, Japan — The spot where the town’s center once stood is now a dusty construction site filled with diggers and dump trucks toiling amid huge, man-made mesas of earth and gravel. The work is part of an $850 million project to elevate the land by seven feet and shield it behind a towering 48-foot wall.

headline: A Moment Atop the World for Bhutan’s Last-Ranked Team
abstract: Crediting the ability of the current generation to watch soccer on TV, Bhutan’s national team won its first World Cup qualifying match, beating Sri Lanka on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — Nikola Kavazovic sat alone in the hot and sticky interior of Sugathadasa Stadium this week, waiting for someone to talk to.

headline: New Year-Round Routes on Eurostar Trains
abstract: The high-speed Eurostar rail service is adding year-round routes between England and the French cities Lyon, Avignon and Marseille.
lead_paragraph: Travel between England and France is about to be streamlined with new, year-round routes on the Eurostar direct to Lyon, Avignon and Marseille from London and Ashford.

headline: Charles Atlas: ‘The Waning of Justice’
abstract: Mr. Atlas’s current show includes wraparound images, flashing words and a drag performer.
lead_paragraph: The career of the American filmmaker Charles Atlas has been a steady but slow-burning fire for more than 40 years, beginning in the 1970s, when he initiated a series of video collaborations with Merce Cunningham. Those videos went well beyond being documents of Cunningham’s dance — though they were certainly that — to become acts of filmic choreography in themselves. Over time, the network of Mr. Atlas’s collaborators expanded to include other choreographers (Douglas Dunn, Yvonne Rainer, Michael Clark) and the transgender performer Leigh Bowery, with whom he did extraordinary work.

headline: ‘Artists of Earth and Sky’
abstract: A look at a new show of art by the Plains Indians, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: A look at a new show of art by the Plains Indians, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Subodh Gupta: ‘Seven Billion Light Years’
abstract: The works on display include stainless-steel cooking vessels and kitchen utensils transformed into sculptures.
lead_paragraph: Subodh Gupta’s latest gallery show makes the best, and worst, argument for his art.

headline: Here Comes Trouble
abstract: New picture books include “Use Your Words, Sophie!” and “Wolfie the Bunny.”
lead_paragraph: New picture books include “Use Your Words, Sophie!” and “Wolfie the Bunny.”

headline: Police Officers Shot in Ferguson, Mo.
abstract: Two police officers were shot outside the Ferguson police station early Thursday, the St. Louis County police said.
lead_paragraph: Two police officers were shot outside the Ferguson police station early Thursday, the St. Louis County police said.

headline: On Sascha Braunig’s Trippy Canvases, Op Art Meets Surrealism
abstract: The painter, one of the most talked about talents at this year’s New Museum triennial, has a solo show opening today at Foxy Production.
lead_paragraph: The New Museum’s recently opened triennial exhibition “Surround Audience” has largely been praised for its embrace of genres influenced by technological advances — so it’s a bit curious that one of the show’s most talked about talents is the thoroughly analog painter Sascha Braunig. Based in Portland (Maine, as opposed to the West Coast bastion of progressive proclivities), Braunig creates portraits that have frequently been described as a merging of Op Art and Surrealism. She terms her approach “superficial realism,” as the undulating, trippy forms she commits to canvas are faithful interpretations of still lives she stages herself. Typically, she molds and lights sculptures as the subject of each piece, before entering a meditative state in which she skins her creations with ornate patterns.

headline: Honda, to Hasten Takata Airbag Fixes, Turns to Ad Campaign
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: The company has recalled more than six million vehicles, but only 14 percent of the defective parts have been replaced.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With millions of its cars still under recall but not yet repaired, Honda Motor said on Thursday it was beginning an advertising campaign aimed at persuading owners to get them fixed.

headline: The Living Room and Irish Arts Center Celebrate St. Patrick’s Day
abstract: The Living Room, in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, will feature Liam O’Maonlai as well as the band Pugwash.
lead_paragraph: St. Patrick’s Day, like its cousins SantaCon and Halloween, has a tendency to make people wince. There’s something about a drunken reveler, stumbling down the sidewalk and wearing an oversize green top hat, that many people just don’t find endearing.

headline: ‘Life of Cats’
abstract: Works highlighting the infiltration of felines in a nation’s cultural landscape are in a new show at Japan Society.
lead_paragraph: Works highlighting the infiltration of felines in a nation’s cultural landscape are in a new show at Japan Society.

headline: Review: ‘Life of Cats’ Spotlights a Centuries-Old Fascination in Japan
abstract: An exhibition at Japan Society shows how cats became fixtures in art, literature and folklore.
lead_paragraph: Cats are strange. Aloof, elegant and always clean, they radiate Buddha-like equanimity and spiritual superiority. A cat will gaze intently into your eyes and then look away as if you were not of the slightest interest. They can be maddeningly passive-aggressive opportunists and zany clowns, as attested to by countless, stratospherically popular YouTube videos of cats behaving badly and ridiculously. (See, for example, YouTube cats knocking things off tables.)

headline: Review: ‘Peter Saul: From Pop to Punk,’ a Firebrand Willing to Offend
abstract: A show at Venus Over Manhattan, with works from the collection of the art dealer Allan Frumkin, sheds light on a crucial period in the development of this painter.
lead_paragraph: The New York art dealer Ileana Sonnabend once avowed — somewhat self-servingly — that the best collectors are people in her line of work. Every so often the evidence mounts, as it does with “Peter Saul: From Pop to Punk” at Venus Over Manhattan. This poetically named art gallery established in 2012 by Adam Lindemann, a collector and occasional writer for The New York Observer, does not represent artists, but it regularly stages relevant exhibitions, and this is one of his best.

headline: European Fine Art Fair Showcases Shaker Furniture
abstract: Two dealers at the European Fine Art Fair in Maastricht, the Netherlands, collaborated to recreate a Shaker environment filled with 30 pieces of furniture and objects.
lead_paragraph: MAASTRICHT, the Netherlands — For a moment, as you peer through the window and see that plain wooden chest next to that plain wooden bedstead, you could be in New Hampshire 180 years ago, rather than in a 1990s exhibition center in the middle of the eurozone.

headline: Mayor de Blasio Marks Anniversary of Fatal Explosion in East Harlem
abstract: A year after eight people were killed when a gas explosion leveled two buildings on Park Avenue, Mayor Bill de Blasio visited the site with the friends and families of the victims.
lead_paragraph: One year after a gas explosion leveled two buildings in East Harlem and left eight people dead, Mayor Bill de Blasio visited the site on Thursday with the families and friends of those killed.

headline: Review: ‘Long Story Short,’ Till Death Do Us Part
abstract: This two-character show from Prospect Theater Company follows a couple from first date till death.
lead_paragraph: Time is doing odd things on and off Broadway. It’s fracturing in “Constellations,” hopscotching in “Bright Half Life,” and in “Long Story Short,” a newish musical by Brendan Milburn and Valerie Vigoda, it is executing a halfhearted loop-de-loop.

headline: Childbirth in Bolivia’s High Plains
abstract: Mistrust of modern medicine has been a factor in high infant mortality rates among indigenous communities in Bolivia. Recent efforts seek to stem the crisis while respecting traditions.
lead_paragraph: Mistrust of modern medicine has been a factor in high infant mortality rates among indigenous communities in Bolivia. Recent efforts seek to stem the crisis while respecting traditions.

headline: Review: Avi Avital and the Venice Baroque, in Sizzling Communion
abstract: The mandolinist joined the orchestra at Zankel Hall for a program of 18th-century concertos, including some from their new joint album, “Vivaldi.”
lead_paragraph: The words “superstar” and “mandolinist” still look odd next to each other. Yet in the classical world they are starting to be joined with some frequency to describe two players who, in very different ways, combine virtuosity on an instrument with generous helpings of onstage charisma. One is Chris Thile, an American trained in bluegrass who has recently made notable ventures into classical repertory. The other is the Israeli-born Avi Avital, who on Wednesday gave a performance of 18th-century Italian concertos at Zankel Hall with the Venice Baroque Orchestra that was nothing short of electric.

headline: Secret Service Agents Said to Have Driven Into Police Investigation Before Crash
keywords: ['Drunken and Reckless Driving', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'United States Politics and Government', 'White House Building (Washington, DC)']
abstract: Surveillance footage showed two Secret Service agents ignored a cordon set up around a suspicious package, people briefed on the investigation said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two Secret Service agents suspected of drinking were captured on video last week driving a car that bumped into a barricade and rolled to a stop in an area cordoned off by the police because of a suspicious package, two people briefed on the video said Thursday.

headline: Jackson Sees Opportunity as Knicks Visit Lakers
abstract: Phil Jackson, the Knicks’ president, said the game against the Lakers on Thursday night in Los Angeles was “a chance to play a game that’s decent."
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — If there was one Knicks road game that Phil Jackson was certain to attend, it was Thursday night’s visit to Staples Center for a second and final meeting with the Lakers, the team he coached to five N.B.A. titles from 2000 to 2010 and whose co-owner Jeanie Buss has been his longtime companion.

headline: One Agency in Harper Lee Inquiry Ends Its Role, Saying Author Is ‘Aware’ of Book Deal
abstract: Investigators interviewed Ms. Lee and found “she has opinions and seems to be aware of what is going on with her book and the book deal,” a regulator said.
lead_paragraph: An Alabama agency that had been helping with an investigation into whether Harper Lee, 88 and infirm, was manipulated into agreeing to publish a second novel this summer said on Thursday that it had ended its role in the inquiry.

headline: Review: Paul Taylor’s American Modern Dance Opens Its Season
abstract: The renamed company began its run at Lincoln Center with live music and four works by Mr. Taylor.
lead_paragraph: For all the fanfare surrounding the new structure of the Paul Taylor Dance Company, things weren’t too different on Tuesday at the inaugural performance of Paul Taylor’s American Modern Dance. The biggest change was the live music, played by the terrific Orchestra of St. Luke’s under Donald York’s baton, a major upgrade from the troupe’s usual taped accompaniment. But whereas other programs this season will feature, for the first time in the company’s 61-year history, outside artists — the Limón Dance Company in Doris Humphrey’s “Passacaglia,” Shen Wei Dance Arts in Mr. Shen’s “Rite of Spring” — opening night at the David H. Koch Theater was devoted to Mr. Taylor.

headline: The New Net Neutrality Rules
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission is to take a more active role in regulating the Internet as a public utility, which is expected to provoke court cases from major broadband providers.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Communications Commission is to take a more active role in regulating the Internet as a public utility, which is expected to provoke court cases from major broadband providers.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Review: ‘The Royals’ on E! Is Another Pretender to the Throne
abstract: This tongue-in-cheek nighttime soap about a make-believe decadent British royal family should be a hoot, but it actually grows old, and dull, quickly.
lead_paragraph: “The Royals,” a new E! scripted series that begins on Sunday, is trying to usurp the throne of reality television’s reigning monarchy, which debuts a 10th season of “Keeping Up With the Kardashians” on that network the same night.

headline: Review: Mivos Quartet Performs Gesualdo, Berg and Kate Soper
abstract: A Mivos Quartet program paired madrigals by Carlo Gesualdo with new works by Kate Soper and Clara Iannotta.
lead_paragraph: It might seem odd to open a concert of new string quartets with arrangements of vocal madrigals by Carlo Gesualdo, as the indispensable Mivos Quartet did in its impressive evening with the composer-soprano Kate Soper at Columbia University’s Italian Academy on Wednesday.

headline: Weekend Entertainments From the Archives of The New York Times
abstract: Josephine Baker did not catch on quickly in the United States in the 1920s, as reflected in some often derisive accounts in The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: 90 YEARS AGO

headline: ‘Remote New York,’ a Tour From Brooklyn to Greenwich Village
abstract: Rimini Protokoll, a German arts collective, puts a new twist on the city walking tour. Make that “pedestrian-based live art experience.”
lead_paragraph: ON a rainy afternoon this week, passers-by may have paused to wonder about a headphone-wearing group assembled in front of a guardhouse at Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn, staring at a nondescript commercial strip outside the gates before suddenly bursting into applause.

headline: Review: Kirill Gerstein Plays Liszt’s ‘Transcendental Études’
abstract: In his performance at Zankel Hall on Monday night, Kirill Gerstein showed why he is considered among today’s great concert pianists.
lead_paragraph: Kirill Gerstein is evidently determined to prove his mettle as one of the great piano virtuosos of the day, and he made a strong case to be considered as such with his recital at Zankel Hall on Monday evening. In a fascinating program consisting of pedagogical forms run more or less amok, he ended with a dazzling performance of Liszt’s 12 “Transcendental Études,” some of the most difficult music ever written for piano.

headline: Review: Brandi Carlile’s Life Is Embedded in Her Music
abstract: Among the many messages in Ms. Carlile’s songs is a celebration of “the love that lets us share our name.”
lead_paragraph: Stakes are high in Brandi Carlile’s songs: emotionally, romantically, meteorologically, spiritually. Vocally, too. Playing a rare club show on Wednesday night at the Music Hall of Williamsburg — she’s usually in theaters — Ms. Carlile sang about family, memories, mortality, guilt, hurricanes, starry skies, suicide and eternal love, scaling personal experience up to grand pronouncements. In “The Stranger at My Door,” with a verse about watching a house burn down, she sang, “An all-consuming flame, that refines and new begins/It’ll take your family heirlooms, but it can take your darkest sins.”

headline: Paul Taylor Chooses Three Choreographers to Make New Work
abstract: Mr. Taylor has commissioned new dances by Larry Keigwin, Doug Elkins and Lila York for his company Paul Taylor’s American Modern Dance.
lead_paragraph: When the choreographer Paul Taylor reinvented his company as Paul Taylor’s American Modern Dance, his plan called for it to continue to present his work along with other modern dance masterpieces and new dances by contemporary choreographers.

headline: A Dream, or a Premonition, Leads to a New Beginning
keywords: ['Modern Love (Times Column)', 'Dreams', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Babies and Infants']
abstract: How a nighttime vision shaped lives and love one summer in Richmond, Va.
lead_paragraph: As a single parent, I was trying to make a go of it in Laguna Beach, Calif. My daughter wasn’t even a year old and my partner of many years hadn’t wanted to make it “legal,” so he was back East, as were the rest of my family and friends.

headline: Antonio Cromartie Is Reunited With Darrelle Revis on the Jets
abstract: Cromartie, who helped form a stifling secondary with Revis from 2010 to 2012, agreed to a four-year deal worth $32 million.
lead_paragraph: Darrelle Revis and Antonio Cromartie, who formed a stifling secondary for the Jets from 2010 to 2012, were reunited Thursday as the team reached an agreement with Cromartie.

headline: Review: In ‘Brothers From the Bottom,’ Jousting About Gentrification
abstract: Siblings spar about the fate of their neighborhood in New Orleans in “Brothers From the Bottom,” a play at the Billie Holiday Theater.
lead_paragraph: In a scene from Jackie Alexander’s timely and sympathetic “Brothers From the Bottom,” at the Billie Holiday Theater, two men stand on a shared front porch and argue about the fate of their neighborhood. Trey (Wendell Franklin) is involved in a plan to replace rundown houses with gleaming condos. His brother, Chris (Wendell Pierce of “The Wire” and “Treme”), is skeptical.

headline: Nancy Snyderman Resigns as NBC’s Chief Medical Editor
abstract: Dr. Snyderman drew criticism last fall when she broke a self-imposed quarantine after returning from covering the Ebola outbreak in Liberia.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Nancy Snyderman has stepped down from her post as NBC’s chief medical editor, following a controversy that erupted last fall when she broke a self-imposed quarantine after returning from covering the Ebola outbreak in Liberia.

headline: ‘Frank,’ Barney Frank’s Memoir
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Former Representative Barney Frank, a liberal mainstay, offers his views on the political process and his role within it.
lead_paragraph: Barney Frank’s career in Congress spanned enough time and elevated him to enough prominence that most of the significant American political figures from the last four decades flitted through it, playing some part. And many make cameos, at the least, in his autobiography, “Frank.”

headline: FEMA to Review All Flood Damage Claims From Hurricane Sandy
abstract: Lawmakers and homeowners have questioned for months whether doctored engineering reports led to minimizing or even denying insurance payments after the 2012 storm.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Emergency Management Agency has agreed to review every flood insurance claim filed by homeowners affected by Hurricane Sandy, amid accusations that damage assessment reports were fraudulently altered to minimize claims.

headline: Administration Asks Court to Lift Order Halting Immigration Programs
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Illegal Immigration', 'States (US)']
abstract: Calling the reasoning behind the Feb. 16 injunction “unprecedented and wrong,” an emergency stay was sought in the Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit in New Orleans.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration, fighting a lawsuit by 26 states against the president’s executive actions on immigration, asked a federal appeals court Thursday to lift an order by a judge in Texas that halted the programs.

headline: Once Unique, LeapFrog Has Rivals in the Educational Toy Market
keywords: ['Toys', 'Education (K-12)', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Children and Childhood', 'Games', 'Tablet Computers', 'iPad']
abstract: LeapFrog, a dominant maker of educational toys and games, has watched its sales plummet because of cheaper alternatives.
lead_paragraph: On a weekday afternoon, Flora Bojadziev, a chef from Harlem, browsed through a Toys “R” Us in Manhattan.

headline: Review: In ‘It Follows,’ a Shape-Shifting Horror Stalks a Teenager
abstract: David Robert Mitchell’s second feature film is set in a Detroit suburb, where a deadly menace is passed from one person to another through sex.
lead_paragraph: The nameless, shape-shifting horror that stalks the blond, 19-year-old Jay (Maika Monroe) in David Robert Mitchell’s cool, controlled horror film, “It Follows,” might be described as the very incarnation of paranoia. The menace, which only she can see, takes any number of forms, from a naked man standing on the roof of a house to an unsmiling old lady heading purposefully in her direction. When it appears, it is usually first glimpsed from a distance, walking slowly toward her like an expressionless zombie. Although Jay repeatedly flees, she can never shake the sense that it is out there somewhere and knows her precise location.

headline: Pop, Rock & Cabaret Listings for March 13-19
abstract: A selected, critical guide to performances of rock, pop, hip-hop and more in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

abstract: A selected, critical guide to jazz performances in New York City.

headline: Truth and Consequences
abstract: Answers to questions about a fake ID, adult playdates, flu etiquette and vacation tipping.
lead_paragraph: My daughter lost her wallet on her college campus. Someone returned it to the campus police. (With all of its contents!) But when my daughter picked it up, the officer berated her for having a fake ID. Her driver’s license was in plain sight, so there was no need to rummage through the wallet. He told her possessing a fake ID was a crime, but he wasn’t going to charge her. (Is he even an actual police officer?) Instead, he would report her to the dean, who may put her on probation. I think he was way out of line; she wasn’t using the ID. You?
