headline: Giants Lose Safety Antrel Rolle to Bears
abstract: The Giants need help at safety after Antrel Rolle, a defensive mainstay for the last five seasons, left to sign a three-year contract worth $11.25 million with Chicago.
lead_paragraph: The Giants’ search for help at safety began in earnest on Thursday after Antrel Rolle, a defensive mainstay for the last five seasons, left to sign a three-year contract worth $11.25 million with the Chicago Bears. He received $5 million in guaranteed money.

headline: The Problem Is Bigger Than Ferguson
abstract: Housecleaning among the town’s political leadership is necessary, but bigoted practices are not limited to that troubled municipality.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department’s exposé of the bigoted law enforcement practices at play in Ferguson, Mo., has rightly led to an exodus of officials from the town government. In the week since the report was made public, the police chief, the city manager and the municipal court judge have all stepped down, and the city’s court has been placed under state supervision.

headline: Language of Greek Crisis Shifts From Financial Jargon to Humiliation
keywords: ['Reparations', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: With Greece and its European creditors locked in bitter negotiations this week over the terms of the country’s bailout, the politesse of the talks has disintegrated into starkly personal terms.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Greece’s financial crisis has often been framed in the dry, impersonal language of finance. At issue were credit ratings, bond yields and repayment schedules. The pulse of a collapsing nation was often measured in technical jargon about borrowing costs and primary surpluses.

headline: Key Chicago Figure, Despite a Plea by Obama, Gives a Lift to Emanuel’s Rival
abstract: Willie Wilson, a businessman eliminated last month from the Chicago mayor’s race, on Thursday endorsed Jesús G. Garcia, who is challenging the incumbent, Rahm Emanuel.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Several weeks ago, President Obama was at an event in Chicago when he approached Willie Wilson, a businessman who had challenged Rahm Emanuel in the mayor’s race, with a gentle plea, Mr. Wilson said.

headline: Senators Remain at Impasse Over Bill’s Abortion Provision
keywords: ['Human Trafficking', 'United States Politics and Government', 'ABORTION', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The sides are refusing to yield their positions on a provision that would ban money from a human trafficking victims’ fund from being used for abortions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senators on Thursday continued to struggle to come to terms with an unexpected impasse over a bipartisan human trafficking bill, with the sides refusing to yield their positions on a provision that would ban money from a victims’ fund from being used for abortions.

headline: Ebola, Thief of Rituals, Leaves No Graves to Decorate
keywords: ['Ebola Virus', 'Holidays and Special Occasions', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Epidemics', 'Cremation']
abstract: Decoration Day is for sprucing up burial sites and celebrating life, but after 3,000 bodies were cremated because of the Ebola outbreak, Wednesday’s holiday was a somber affair.
lead_paragraph: MONROVIA, Liberia — Finda Fallah sat in her tiny one-bedroom apartment, boiling up rice and leftovers with one of the few children in her family still alive.

headline: This Week’s Movies | March 13, 2015
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “Cinderella,” “Going Clear” and “Seymour: An Introduction.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “Cinderella,” “Going Clear” and “Seymour: An Introduction.”

headline: Univision Fires Host Rodner Figueroa for Insult to Michelle Obama
abstract: Mr. Figueroa, a fashion and entertainment commentator, said that Mrs. Obama looked like someone from the cast of the film “Planet of the Apes.”
lead_paragraph: Univision fired the talk show host Rodner Figueroa after he said that Michelle Obama looked like someone from the cast of the film “Planet of the Apes.”

headline: From the Gates Foundation, Direct Investment, Not Just Grants
keywords: ['Philanthropy', 'Biotechnology and Bioengineering', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Vaccination and Immunization']
abstract: The philanthropic giant is deploying funds and influence into for-profit companies with bright ideas, instead of focusing only on grants to nonprofits.
lead_paragraph: The Ebola crisis underscored a problem that vexes experts in global health: Vaccines are one of the most cost-effective ways to save lives, especially in developing countries, yet traditional vaccines can take years to develop.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Cinderella’
abstract: Kenneth Branagh narrates a sequence from the film.
lead_paragraph: Kenneth Branagh narrates a sequence from the film.

headline: Kenneth Branagh Narrates a Scene From ‘Cinderella’
abstract: Kenneth Branagh discusses a scene from “Cinderella,” with Lily James and Richard Madden.
lead_paragraph: In this video, the director Kenneth Branagh discusses a sequence from the new version of “Cinderella,” featuring Lily James and Richard Madden.

headline: Iran: New Appeal for Detained Reporter
abstract: The Iranian lawyer for Jason Rezaian, the Washington Post reporter incarcerated in Iran for nearly eight months, has requested a five-day release for him starting March 21, the beginning of Iran’s New Year, so he can be with his family.
lead_paragraph: The Iranian lawyer for Jason Rezaian, the Washington Post reporter incarcerated in Iran for nearly eight months, has requested a five-day release for him starting March 21, the beginning of Iran’s New Year, so he can be with his family, Mr. Rezaian’s brother, Ali, said Thursday at a news conference in Washington. Ali Rezaian also said the lawyer, Leila Ahsan, had not yet been allowed to meet with Mr. Rezaian, a native Californian of Iranian descent, but had been given access to the case files. Iranian officials have not disclosed the nature of the charges but have hinted that they are related to espionage.

headline: Clip: ‘Seymour: An Introduction’
abstract: A scene from the documentary.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the documentary.

headline: Review: ‘Seymour: An Introduction’ Is a Lesson in Perseverance
abstract: This film directed by Ethan Hawke is a big-hearted documentary of a pianist, composer, teacher, philosopher and ultimate New Yorker.
lead_paragraph: As its title suggests, “Seymour: An Introduction” doesn’t try to offer the final word on its subject, Seymour Bernstein, the pianist, composer, teacher, philosopher and ultimate New Yorker. Instead, in 81 transporting minutes, this intimate, big-hearted documentary draws you so completely into his world that you feel as if you know all there is to know, even as questions linger. So effectively does it close the distance between you and Mr. Bernstein that afterward you may find yourself scanning the streets, hoping to catch sight of him, as if for an old friend.

headline: His Skill Finally Unmasked, Goaltender Devan Dubnyk Finds a Home
abstract: After bouncing from team to team for two seasons, Dubnyk has started every game since his debut with the Minnesota Wild — a club-record 25 straight.
lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL — The idea sprang as a brainstorm from a first-time father. After Nathaniel Dubnyk was born in August 2013, his father, Devan Dubnyk, then a goaltender for the Edmonton Oilers, asked the noted Swedish mask designer David Gunnarsson to incorporate an image of the baby on the mask he planned to wear that season.

headline: Senator Corker Pushes Obama for Congressional Vote on Iran Deal
abstract: The warning from Senator Bob Corker, Republican of Tennessee, was the latest twist in an increasingly tense standoff between the White House and congressional Republicans over the potential nuclear accord.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee urged President Obama on Thursday not to seek a United Nations endorsement of the emerging nuclear agreement with Iran without first giving Congress a chance to vote on it.

headline: California’s Ailing Sea Lions
abstract: Record numbers of sea lions are being discovered up and down the state’s coast.
lead_paragraph: Record numbers of sea lions are being discovered up and down the state’s coast.

headline: Starving Sea Lions Washing Ashore by the Hundreds in California
abstract: Animal rescuers are reporting five times more sea lion rescues than normal. Experts suspect unusually warm waters are driving mothers away to look for food, leaving pups to swim from home.
lead_paragraph: CAPISTRANO BEACH, Calif. — By the time Wendy Leeds reached him, the sea lion pup had little hope of surviving.

headline: ‘Lila’ Honored as Top Fiction by National Book Critics Circle
abstract: Marilynne Robinson won the National Book Critics Circle Award for her novel “Lila,” the final book in her trilogy set in the fictional Gilead, Iowa.
lead_paragraph: Marilynne Robinson won the National Book Critics Circle Award on Thursday for her novel “Lila,” the final book in her trilogy set in the fictional Gilead, Iowa.

headline: Stopping Online Harassment Before It Starts
abstract: It behooves new social apps like Yik Yak to consider the potential for abuse — not as an afterthought, but as part of the development process.
lead_paragraph: Yik Yak, created in 2013, is a relatively young social network. But it already has a problem with harassment.

headline: Review: In ‘Cymbeline,’ a Drug Kingpin
abstract: Michael Almereyda’s version of “Cymbeline” reaffirms that Shakespeare can always survive every interpretive trick.
lead_paragraph: Was the director Michael Almereyda watching an episode of “Sons of Anarchy” when he decided to tackle “Cymbeline”? For an overextended seven seasons (2008-14), that FX show retold “Hamlet” through the trials and tribulations of a violent motorcycle gang and its circle. Back in 2000, Mr. Almereyda, an independent American filmmaker, wittily conceptualized his own “Hamlet” to suit the indie-movie times, casting Ethan Hawke as a film student who wonders whether to be or not while strolling in a Blockbuster video store near a sign labeled “action.”

headline: Serena Williams Strikes the Right Note in a Time of Turmoil
abstract: The Williams family vowed never to return to Indian Wells after Serena was booed without mercy during the championship match in 2001.
lead_paragraph: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — Serena Williams officially ended her 13-year boycott of the annual tennis tournament held here when she addressed members of the news media Thursday to explain why she returned.

headline: Just as Ferguson Was Making Progress, Shooting Deals a Setback
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Just as Ferguson, Mo., seemed to be moving past the stunning abuses detailed by the Justice Department, four gunshots on Thursday threatened to rekindle tensions.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — In her three years as a city councilwoman, Kim Tihen has not been afraid to speak against the powers in her own city.

headline: Review: In ‘Cinderella,’ Disney Polishes Its Glass Slippers
abstract: Much of the fairy tale remains the same in the latest version, but the writer does add some dimensionality to the standard conception of the stepmother.
lead_paragraph: Poor Cinderella — she still can’t catch a break. In the 1950 Disney animated musical, her friendly neighborhood mice know the score and give it song: “Night and day, it’s Cinderelly! ‘Make the fire, fix-a breakfast, wash the dishes, do the mopping, and the sweeping and the dusting.’ They always keep her hopping!” In Disney’s latest version, directed by Kenneth Branagh, the mice stick to squeaking and look about as real as most computer-generated rodents. And, fascinatingly, much remains the same, including a fairy tale that opens with clear skies but soon plays the poor-little-girl blues before you-know-who comes along. “Maleficent” and its revisionism are so last year.

headline: Holder Calls Ferguson Gunman a ‘Punk’
abstract: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. condemned the attacks on two police officers in Ferguson, Mo., calling the attacker “a damn punk.”
lead_paragraph: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. condemned the attacks on two police officers in Ferguson, Mo., calling the attacker “a damn punk.”

headline: De Blasio Names 3 to Rent Board as Annual Fight on Increases Nears
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Rent Control and Stabilization', 'Affordable Housing']
abstract: The Rent Guidelines Board, whose nine members are now all appointees of Mayor Bill de Blasio, is the mayor’s best bet as he fights on two fronts to influence the cost of housing.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio has appointed three new members of the board that sets rents for about one million rent-stabilized apartments in the city, completing the process of filling all nine seats with his selections just in time for the annual fight over rent increases.

headline: Events in Connecticut for March 15-21, 2015
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Events on Long Island for March 15-21, 2015
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in New Jersey for March 15-21, 2015
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Westchester for March 15-21, 2015
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Jurors Hear Harrowing Account of Boston Bombers’ Hostage
abstract: The demise of the Tsarnaev brothers, testimony in Federal District Court in Boston indicated, was hastened by the quick, composed and methodical thinking of the man they took hostage.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The murderous rampage of the Tsarnaev brothers that engulfed this city two years ago began to come apart when they encountered someone they could not possibly have seen as a threat: a mild-mannered apps designer who had pulled his car over to text a friend.

headline: Suddenly, It Seems, Water Is Everywhere in Solar System
keywords: ['Space and Astronomy', 'Water', 'Enceladus (Saturn Moon)', 'Hubble Space Telescope', 'Saturn (Planet)', 'Jupiter (Planet)', 'Solar System', 'Galileo (Spacecraft)', 'Cassini (Spacecraft)', 'Ganymede (Jupiter Moon)']
abstract: Enceladus, a moon of Saturn, appears to have a roiling ocean with hydrothermal vents, while Ganymede, orbiting Jupiter, may have an ocean under ice, researchers report in two new papers.
lead_paragraph: Oceans trapped under ice appear to be pretty common in the solar system and one of them, on a small moon of Saturn’s, appears to be quite hot.

headline: Move Over, Clinton. Albany Email Farce Takes Center Stage.
abstract: As of Thursday morning, New York State had two policies on keeping emails of its public employees — one silly and the other scandalous.
lead_paragraph: This may be the first time in history that a column about digital storage must be rendered as a kind of drawing room comedy.

headline: Powerful Lasers Easy to Buy, Experts Say
keywords: ['Laser (Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation)', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: Laser pointers, like the one that a Bronx man is accused of shining at airplanes above New York City, are a growing concern for federal authorities, who have sought to limit their spread.
lead_paragraph: Stargazers use them to pick out constellations, teachers to direct students’ eyes, and pet lovers to make their cats dance.

headline: Review: ‘3 Hearts,’ With Three Stars, by Benoît Jacquot
abstract: The movie, with Charlotte Gainsbourg, Chiara Mastroianni and Catherine Deneuve, is an unashamedly old-fashioned romance of missed connections.
lead_paragraph: The French filmmaker Benoît Jacquot’s “3 Hearts” has the incalculable advantage of teaming three of Europe’s most revered actresses, Charlotte Gainsbourg, Chiara Mastroianni and Catherine Deneuve, in a proudly old-fashioned romantic melodrama. Those names alone make it sound delectable, and in its outlines, this quintessential Gallic bodice-ripper might be described as a hybrid of “An Affair to Remember” and the German filmmaker Dominik Graf’s recent “Beloved Sisters.”

headline: In New Hampshire, Clinton Backers Buckle Up
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'E-Mail', 'Presidential Election of 2008', 'Women and Girls', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: At Café Espresso, the diner where Hillary Rodham Clinton’s eyes welled up with tears the day before the 2008 primary, women said they were buckling up for a bumpy ride with Mrs. Clinton into 2016, but certainly not backing away.
lead_paragraph: PORTSMOUTH, N.H. — If Hillary Rodham Clinton is dying to roll her eyes at all the questions about her private email server, she has a soul mate in Laura Donohoe, who did just that, in utter disgust, as she defended Mrs. Clinton on Thursday between spoonfuls of clam chowder.

headline: Dawn’s Direction
abstract: The voices in Victor Fleming’s puzzle.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Let’s talk about the voices I hear. Don’t call my doctor, I’m not hearing random ones. Today, I’d like to talk about the very distinctive voices of the puzzle constructors we love. Because, if you listen very carefully when you solve a puzzle, you can hear them. Will Shortz edits the clues, but he is very good at letting the original voices of the constructors comes through.

headline: Patz Judge Denies Mistrial Request Over Suspect’s Drug Use
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: Justice Maxwell Wiley had not allowed evidence about Pedro Hernandez’s drug use, later reversing the ruling.
lead_paragraph: A prosecutor cross-examining an expert witness on Thursday suggested the hallucinations of the man on trial for the murder of Etan Patz could have been caused by cocaine abuse, not mental illness. That line of questioning prompted the defense to move for a mistrial because the judge had only recently allowed it.

headline: Review: In ‘Run All Night,’ Liam Neeson Sticks to What Works
abstract: In yet another action film, Mr. Neeson plays a longtime underworld enforcer who goes on a killing spree to save his son’s life.
lead_paragraph: Yes, “Run All Night” is another action film starring Liam Neeson, with a title as generic as you might expect. But the movie, directed by Jaume Collet-Serra, who directed Mr. Neeson in the efficient airborne thriller “Non-Stop,” has two saving graces: a tight script and terrific acting.

headline: New Rules Are Issued for Testing of Medical Devices
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration issued the new requirements in the wake of news that two people in a Los Angeles hospital had died from a deadly bacteria traced to medical scopes.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Food and Drug Administration said Thursday that it was toughening testing procedures for manufacturers of reusable medical devices. It issued the new requirements in the wake of news that two people in a Los Angeles hospital had died from a deadly bacteria traced to medical scopes.

headline: Review: ‘Champs’ Tyson, Holyfield and Hopkins Recount Careers
abstract: This documentary by Bert Marcus assesses boxing through three success stories.
lead_paragraph: “Champs” spends about a third of its time perpetuating the myth of boxing as a path out of poverty, a third of it taking a cursory look at what’s wrong with the sport and a third being a greatest-hits compilation.

headline: At Baruch, a New York Rental to the Stars, the Wood Floors Tend to Squeak
abstract: Over the past decade, Baruch has established itself as host to the basketball stars, lending its court to more than 60 N.B.A. and N.C.A.A. Division I teams passing through New York City.
lead_paragraph: As the N.C.A.A. tournament approaches, the best basketball scene in the country is not Rupp Arena, home of the undefeated Kentucky Wildcats, or even Cameron Indoor Stadium, the Duke Blue Devils’ noisy home. Rather, it is a nondescript gym in Manhattan, home of the commuter school Baruch College.

headline: Review: ‘The Cobbler,’ With Adam Sandler, a World in Others’ Shoes
abstract: This Tom McCarthy film centers on a shoe repairman who can assume the appearance of his customers by donning their footwear.
lead_paragraph: The good news is that “The Cobbler” isn’t another “Grown-Ups” sequel. Adam Sandler, as he did with Jason Reitman’s little-seen “Men, Women & Children,” works outside his sophomoric-humor comfort zone in this urban fairy tale directed by Tom McCarthy (“The Station Agent”). The bad news is that he is not very well served. “The Cobbler,” which Mr. McCarthy wrote with Paul Sado, speaks to the fabulist side of Mr. Sandler, the one that appeared in “Click” and “Bedtime Stories.” But it’s an uneasy fit, in a trite story.

headline: At Chinese Political Meetings, the Fashion Is Restraint
abstract: Once a stage for some of China’s most powerful politicians and high achievers to strut the trappings of their success, the sessions have been characterized by conspicuous nonconsumption this year.
lead_paragraph: Simple meals, plain boiled water instead of the bottled mineral kind, a paucity of designer logos.

headline: After Bilking Victims of $10 Million, Serial Swindler Is Sentenced to Nearly 22 Years
abstract: William Lange pleaded guilty last fall to defrauding homeowners and builders in the area hit by Hurricane Katrina in a loan scheme and in an Alaskan gold-mining operation.
lead_paragraph: Like many white-collar criminals, William Lange spent freely with the money he made from his fraud: $115,000 on Harley-Davidson motorcycles; a $2,350 stay at the Mirage in Las Vegas; landscaping work and $5,000 worth of fancy railings for his Gig Harbor, Wash., waterfront mansion; a testosterone-laden moose hunt.

headline: Review: In ‘Eva,’ Robot Designer Loves Cute Kid
abstract: In Kike Maíllo’s Spanish drama, a prodigy returns to his hometown to work on programming an android with the emotional life of a real child.
lead_paragraph: Robots haven’t become an integral part of the everyday world as quickly as some people had predicted, but in the not-too-distant future of “Eva,” an appealing film from Spain, they’re very much a factor. We learn this early on, when the central character, Alex (Daniel Brühl), steps off a plane trailed by his robotic cat.

headline: Where Beijing’s Trash Is Reborn
keywords: ['Recycling of Waste Materials', 'Waste Materials and Disposal']
abstract: Sim Chi Yin describes the recycling yards on the outskirts of Beijing that she photographed for the launch of the @nytimes Instagram account.
lead_paragraph: When The New York Times asked Sim Chi Yin, a photographer based in Beijing, to photograph a story about “beginnings,” she started thinking about the outskirts of her city, which she has been exploring for the past year as part of her continuing work on urbanization in China. This week, we are marking the launch of our primary Instagram account, @nytimes, with images of beginnings by seven photographers around the world. The photos by @chiyin_sim were published on the account over the course of the day on Thursday. — Kerri MacDonald

headline: Review: In ‘Home Sweet Hell,’ Married Life Isn’t Heaven
abstract: This marital satire stars Katherine Heigl as a suburban status seeker whose goals are threatened when her husband embarks on an affair.
lead_paragraph: Mona (Katherine Heigl), the chief villain of the shrill comedy “Home Sweet Hell,” is the sort of terrifying suburban status seeker who might inspire fond memories of the 1994 John Waters film “Serial Mom.” She insists that her children “argue constructively” and requires nothing less than perfect hedges. She indulges in casual bigotry and refuses to mingle with the employees of the furniture company she runs with her husband, Don (Patrick Wilson). She lists 15 precise minutes of sex with him on her calendar. She keeps an album of goals for her perfect family.

headline: Not to Worry: Masahiro Tanaka Looks Like His Old Self
abstract: With 19 precision pitches Thursday, Tanaka did more to calm the nerves of anxious Yankee fans than any of his declarations of good health possibly could.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — With 19 precise pitches, Masahiro Tanaka did more to calm the nerves of anxious Yankees fans than any of his declarations of good health possibly could. People needed to see it live, and Tanaka, the right-handed pitcher who sneered at the surgical knife last summer, put his ability on display Thursday with striking resolve.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Thursday, March 12, 2015
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: March 12, 2015

headline: Obama Discusses Ferguson With Jimmy Kimmel
abstract: President Obama on Thursday said that whoever shot at police officers in Ferguson, Mo., this week are “criminals” and should be arrested, but added that their actions should not detract from the civil rights issues that have been raised.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — President Obama on Thursday said that whoever shot at police officers in Ferguson, Mo., this week were “criminals” and should be arrested, but added that their actions should not detract from the civil rights issues that have been raised.

headline: Review: ‘Like Sunday, Like Rain,’ a Sentimental Intersection of Two Lives
abstract: In Frank Whaley’s film, a young New Yorker (Leighton Meester) ends up as an unlikely companion to a 13-year-old prodigy.
lead_paragraph: Leighton Meester of “Gossip Girl” acquits herself quite well in “Like Sunday, Like Rain,” and so does a young newcomer named Julian Shatkin. It’s a bittersweet story that thins out toward the end as it turns too obviously sentimental, but it’s still a nicely etched tale of the intersection of two unrelated lives.

headline: Funeral for Shannan Gilbert Is Outlet for Family’s Grief, and Suspicion
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Prostitution']
abstract: Unanswered questions about how Ms. Gilbert, whose remains were found on Gilgo Beach four years ago, died meant it was hardly a typical service.
lead_paragraph: AMITYVILLE, N.Y. — The scene at the cemetery here on Thursday was rather quotidian: a silver-colored coffin topped with pink-and-white carnations in union beneath the kind of light-pink ribbon bow normally found atop a wrapped gift.

headline: Rangers’ Klein, Injured by Puck, Will Miss at Least Three Weeks
abstract: Klein was struck on the left arm by an Alex Ovechkin shot with 41 seconds remaining in Wednesday’s 3-1 win at Washington.
lead_paragraph: The Rangers said Thursday that Kevin Klein, a stalwart defenseman who has a knack for scoring key goals, would miss three to four weeks with an upper-body injury.

headline: Review: ‘The Lovers’ Portrays Romances Intertwined Across Time
abstract: In this film from Roland Joffé, the fortunes of two rings in 1778 India have a ripple effect on a diving mission hundreds of years later.
lead_paragraph: The title of “The Lovers” refers not just to characters but also to two rings that join together. In this inert, exasperatingly proportioned phantasmagoria from Roland Joffé, who wrote the screenplay and directed, the jewels’ fortunes in 1778 India have a ripple effect on a futuristic diving mission hundreds of years later. Or perhaps it’s the other way around.

headline: Review: ‘Walter’ Is Obsessed With Fate
abstract: An obsessive-compulsive in his early 20s believes himself to be a son of God, required to decide the final destination — heaven or hell — of every individual he sees.
lead_paragraph: In “Walter,” the title character is a ticket taker at a multiplex, a good gig for someone who enjoys fantasy. Walter, an obsessive-compulsive in his early 20s, believes himself to be a son of God, required to decide the final destination — heaven or hell — of every individual he sees. Folks lining up to get into the theater just make his true calling easier.

headline: Review: ‘The Wrecking Crew’ Hails the Music Behind the Faces
abstract: This sentimental documentary revolves around a cabal of versatile Los Angeles session musicians fluent in rock, soul, country and getting out of the way.
lead_paragraph: THE WRECKING CREW

headline: NASA Mission to Study Magnetic Explosions Lifts Off
abstract: The Magnetospheric Multiscale mission, consisting of four identical spacecraft, will study a phenomenon that is key to understanding solar storms.
lead_paragraph: A NASA mission to study magnetic explosions high above Earth successfully launched to orbit on Thursday night.

headline: As Protesters Disparage Bratton, an Unlikely Defender Emerges: City Council
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Attacks on Police']
abstract: The relationship between New York City lawmakers and police officials, damaged over a few turbulent months last year, appears to be improving.
lead_paragraph: With relations between New York City lawmakers and police officials warming, it was left to a handful of protesters at a budget hearing at City Hall on Tuesday to voice outrage over current policing policies.

headline: Staten Island Judge Allows Suit on Teacher Tenure to Proceed
keywords: ['Tenure', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Education (K-12)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Performance Evaluations (Labor)']
abstract: A State Supreme Court justice allowed a lawsuit to move forward that argues that laws protecting bad teachers from dismissal violate children’s rights to a sound education.
lead_paragraph: Opponents of New York State’s teacher tenure laws won a small but important victory on Thursday, when a Staten Island judge allowed a lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of those rules to move forward.

headline: Big East Tournament: Xavier Advances With Overtime Victory Over Butler
abstract: Five Xavier players scored in double figures as the Musketeers edged the Bulldogs in a thrilling finish to an otherwise mundane day of games at Madison Square Garden.
lead_paragraph: Even the most ardent of Big East rivals can usually wrap up a game in regulation. That was true of Butler and Xavier in their two regular-season meetings this year.

headline: Alexander McQueen-Inspired Tea Treats: Almost too Pretty to Eat
abstract: A London hotel celebrates the city’s “Savage Beauty” exhibition.
lead_paragraph: As Fashion Month comes to a close and London ramps up for a longer-running fashion presentation of sorts — the March 14th opening of “Alexander McQueen: Savage Beauty” at the Victoria and Albert Museum — the Berkeley hotel is feting the exhibition’s European launch with its own very McQueen-inspired spin on the afternoon teatime ritual.

headline: A Notebook With Pop-Art Bona Fides
abstract: A new journal from Princeton Architectural Press features a scaled-down reproduction of “Noise,” Ed Ruscha’s massive 1963 oil “word picture.”
lead_paragraph: Those who still prefer to carry around a physical notebook, rather than relying on Evernote (or just tweeting every passing thought), are a peculiar bunch possessed of inflexible loyalties: whether you’re a Moleskine or a Rhodia person tells journal snobs everything they need to know. (There’s some ego involved, to be sure: “Our notebooks give us away,” as Joan Didion famously wrote, “for however dutifully we record what we see around us, the common denominator of all we see is always, transparently, shamelessly, the implacable ‘I.’”)

headline: Life or Movie? ‘Kumiko, the Treasure Hunter’ and ‘The Wolfpack’ Blur Lines
abstract: “Kumiko, the Treasure Hunter,” the documentary “The Wolfpack” and other films explore blurred lines between films and actual living.
lead_paragraph: In a dark apartment in Tokyo, a lonely woman is transported to the snowy vistas of Minnesota. She gets lost in the fuzzy images on her TV, fast-forwarding, rewinding and pausing, searching for clues and meaning. When the worn-out tape is snarled in her VCR, she pulls the unspooled mess into her face and inhales reverently.

headline: Boy, 15, Dies Trying to Jump Between Rooftops in Brooklyn
abstract: The teenager fell to his death in Crown Heights on Thursday when he tried to jump from one four-story apartment building to another, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A 15-year-old boy fell to his death in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, on Thursday when he tried to jump from the top of one four-story apartment building to the top of another, the police said.

headline: Word of the Day | prolixity
abstract: This word has appeared in two New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: prolixity • \pro-ˈlik-sə-te\ • noun

headline: Mardy Fish Ends Hiatus but Falls at Indian Wells
abstract: In his first singles match in more than 18 months, Fish held two match points in the third set at the BNP Paribas Open before losing to Ryan Harrison, 6-4, 4-6, 7-6 (3).
lead_paragraph: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — In his first singles match in more than 18 months, Mardy Fish held two match points in the third set Thursday at the BNP Paribas Open before falling to Ryan Harrison, 6-4, 4-6, 7-6 (3).

headline: In ‘La Sapienza,’ Eugene Green’s New Film, a Man Works on His Artistic Soul
abstract: The movie concerns an architect’s crisis of creative conscience and his efforts to rehabilitate both his artistic soul and his marriage.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1970s, when the director Eugene Green first visited the church Sant’Ivo alla Sapienza, a Baroque masterpiece in Rome, he encountered Roman intransigence. “The guardian kept saying he didn’t have the key; one of his colleagues had the key.” Then along came a tourist.

headline: Agitating With Animation: ‘When the Wind Blows’ and ‘Coonskin’
abstract: Cartoons with a conscience: Jimmy T. Murakami’s “When the Wind Blows” (1986) gently addressed nuclear annihilation, while Ralph Bakshi’s “Coonskin” (1975) tackled racism.
lead_paragraph: No one, post-Charlie Hebdo, can doubt a cartoon’s capacity to change the world — R. Crumb’s breezy remonstrance “It’s only lines on paper, folks!” notwithstanding. Animated cartoons are generally more circumspect than static drawings, but some have been agitators as well.

headline: The Letter From John Lennon Behind ‘Danny Collins’
abstract: In real life, it was intended for Steve Tilston, a British folk singer. In Dan Fogelman’s new film, Al Pacino plays the recipient, an aging, overtanned singer who lost his soul to celebrity but may have a second chance.
lead_paragraph: In 1971, a British folk singer named Steve Tilston gave an interview to ZigZag — a small, underground-rock rag named for a Captain Beefheart jam and a popular brand of rolling papers — in support of his debut LP, a collection of earnest, fingerpicked guitar songs that recall Nick Drake and Jackson C. Frank. When asked if he thought fame and fortune might prove toxic to his songwriting, Mr. Tilston did not equivocate. “Yes, yes, of course it will,” he recalls saying. “My heart will suffer.”

headline: SEC Chooses Greg Sankey as Its Next Commissioner
abstract: Greg Sankey will be the next commissioner of the Southeastern Conference, replacing Mike Slive.
lead_paragraph: Greg Sankey will be the next commissioner of the Southeastern Conference, replacing Mike Slive, the conference announced Thursday. Sankey, currently the SEC’s executive associate commissioner and chief operating officer, will be introduced Friday morning in Nashville, where the conference is holding its men’s basketball tournament.

headline: Jenna McMahon Dies at 89; Created Popular Sitcoms
abstract: Ms. McMahon wrote for many series, including “Diff’rent Strokes” and “The Mary Tyler Moore Show.”
lead_paragraph: Jenna McMahon, who teamed up with Dick Clair, her partner in a comedy act, to create the long-running sitcom “The Facts of Life,” died on March 2 in Monterey, Calif. She was 89.

headline: Childbirth in Bolivia’s High Plains
keywords: ['Babies and Infants', 'Birth Rates', 'Caesarean Section', 'Infant Mortality', 'Midwives', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Social marginalization and mistrust of modern medicine have caused high infant mortality rates among indigenous communities in Bolivia. Efforts over the last 10 years seek to stem the crisis while respecting traditions.
lead_paragraph: Correction appended below.

headline: Yoshihiro Tatsumi, Formative Manga Artist, Dies at 79
abstract: Mr. Tatsumi, an innovator in the manga subgenre he called “gekiga,” helped establish the adult comic and graphic novel genres.
lead_paragraph: Yoshihiro Tatsumi, a Japanese cartoonist whose dark, psychologically astute tales helped establish the genre of adult comics and graphic novels, died on March 7 in Tokyo. He was 79.

headline: New York City’s Week in Pictures: Feb. 13
abstract: Photographs from the past week from New York City and the region include images from Cardinal Egan’s funeral Mass and the end of winter.
lead_paragraph: Photographs from the past week from New York City and the region include images from Cardinal Egan’s funeral Mass and the end of winter.

headline: What’s on TV Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10:30 A.M. (Encore) HOOSIERS (1987) Norman Dale (Gene Hackman) is the new basketball coach in a small Indiana town in this tale of competition and redemption set in the early 1950s. His unorthodox coaching style initially rankles the townspeople and alienates the players but ultimately proves successful. Dennis Hopper, in an Oscar-nominated role, plays Shooter Flatch, an alcoholic who helps coach the team. “Who could resist a tiny Middle Western town where the barber shop is called Rooster’s and the game of basketball is foremost on every mind?” Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times about this sports classic, directed by David Anspaugh. “Probably no one, and the quaintly innocent ‘Hoosiers’ is irresistible in much the same way.”

headline: Quotation of the Day

lead_paragraph: “This was not someone trying to bring healing to Ferguson. This was a damn punk, a punk who was trying to sow discord.”

headline: Book on Sandy Alderson Set for Release as Mets Try to Turn Page
abstract: With the Mets entering a season of optimism, “Baseball Maverick” will cover the general manager’s time with the team as well as his college years, a stint in Vietnam and more.
lead_paragraph: In his first four seasons as the general manager of the Mets, Sandy Alderson put together a body of work that included a lot more losses than victories, a surprising number of quips and a steadfast ability to never point a finger at the team’s owners for repeatedly saddling him with payrolls that were meager by major-market standards.

headline: St. Joseph’s Coach Phil Martelli Finds Grandson Mellows Him
abstract: At 5 years old, Philip Stephen Martelli has become an imitator of, and an influence on, his grandfather, who saw his basketball team’s season end in the Atlantic 10 tournament.
lead_paragraph: This week, for his preschool class’s show and tell, Philip Stephen Martelli brought in a printout of the Atlantic 10 tournament bracket and demonstrated how teams advance to the championship.

headline: Q. and A.: Michael Meyer on Living and Writing ‘In Manchuria’
abstract: The American writer’s new book on China is based on the time he spent in his wife’s childhood village, a region known to people of a bygone era as Manchuria.
lead_paragraph: The American writer Michael Meyer first arrived in China in 1995 as a Peace Corps volunteer and has since documented changes in disparate corners of the country.

keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']

abstract: Readers urge immediate action to protect girls and women.

headline: We Have a President for a Reason
keywords: ['Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Constitution (US)', 'United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Revolutionary War, American (1775-83)']
abstract: The history of random Americans negotiating with foreign powers. It didn’t work out.
lead_paragraph: CHAPEL HILL, N.C. — THE letter that 47 Senate Republicans addressed to Iranian leaders this week, warning them about making a nuclear deal with President Obama, came as a surprise to many Americans. But it would not have surprised our earliest forefathers. After all, it was not uncommon, in the years immediately following the American Revolution, for individual Americans to negotiate directly with representatives of foreign governments.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Big Test
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The all-but-declared presidential candidate needs to rise above the warring tactics that helped to shape her political career if she hopes to be successful in 2016.
lead_paragraph: The political world is stuck in the middle of an accelerating protocol crisis. All sorts of customary acts of self-restraint are being washed away. It used to be that senators didn’t go out campaigning against one another. It used to be they didn’t filibuster except in rare circumstances. It used to be they didn’t block presidential nominations routinely.

headline: The Southwestern Water Wars
abstract: Droughts are driving up tension between urban and rural residents.
lead_paragraph: WIMBERLEY, Tex. — “WE don’t want you here,” warned the county commissioner, pointing an accusatory finger at the drilling company executives as 600 local residents rose to their feet. “We want you to leave Hays County.”

headline: Congress’s Duty on Authorizing Force
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Editorials', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'War Powers Act (1973)']
abstract: Senate Republicans have shown little interest in drafting a reasonable authorization for war against ISIS, but the job is squarely within their constitutional mandate.
lead_paragraph: The Republicans in the Senate seem to have had no trouble inserting themselves into the Iran nuclear negotiations, when they had no business interfering. Yet they have shown little interest in carrying out a job that is squarely within their constitutional mandate — drafting an authorization for war against ISIS that Democrats can support and President Obama will sign.

headline: Strength Is Weakness
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'US Dollar (Currency)', 'Euro (Currency)', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Deflation (Economics)']
abstract: The strong dollar is actually bad for America, giving Europe a way to export its troubles to the rest of the world.
lead_paragraph: We’ve been warned over and over that the Federal Reserve, in its effort to improve the economy, is “debasing” the dollar. The archaic word itself tells you a lot about where the people issuing such warnings are coming from. It’s an allusion to the ancient practice of replacing pure gold or silver coins with “debased” coins in which the precious-metal content was adulterated with cheaper stuff. Message to the gold bugs and Ayn Rand disciples who dominate the Republican Party: That’s not how modern money works. Still, the Fed’s critics keep insisting that easy-money policies will lead to a plunging dollar.

headline: Digital Dog Collar
abstract: This has nothing to do with Apple — we can still be friends. My animus is for the smartwatch and what it will do to us. Things are too complicated as it is.
lead_paragraph: I hate the new Apple Watch. Hate what it will do to conversation, to the pace of the day, to my friends, to myself. I hate that it will enable the things that already make life so incremental, now-based and hyper-connected. That, and make things far worse.

headline: Reaching Math Students One by One
abstract: A digital-based program lets teachers divide up a class of 30 students into 30 different levels at which to teach them critical skills.
lead_paragraph: Like middle school math teachers everywhere, the seventh-grade math teachers at Middle School 88 in the southern part of Brooklyn’s Park Slope have an impossible job. At this high-poverty school, which not long ago was considered failing, students enter with levels of math skills ranging from kindergarten to eighth grade. How can anyone teach to them all?

headline: North Korea Is Said to Fire 7 Missiles Off Its East Coast
keywords: ['Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The test-firing into the sea was the latest to coincide with joint United States-South Korean military drills, which the North has repeatedly condemned.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea has fired seven surface-to-air missiles into waters off its east coast, South Korean officials said on Friday, in the country’s latest missile test coinciding with joint United States-South Korean military exercises.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | ‘Ambush’ Seen in Shooting of 2 Police Officers in Ferguson
abstract: How do you think Ferguson and the surrounding communities will heal from all this anger and violence?
lead_paragraph: In “2 Police Officers Shot in Ferguson ‘Ambush’ Are Released From Hospital,” John Eligon and Richard Pérez-Peña report on more violence in Ferguson, Mo.

headline: Test Yourself | One Last Dance at Johnson’s Barn
abstract: Here are several paragraphs from a Feb. 25 article, “Johnson’s Barn, a North Dakota Institution, Plans Its Last Dance.” Can you choose the best word for each blank?
lead_paragraph: Here are several paragraphs from a Feb. 25 article, “Johnson’s Barn, a North Dakota Institution, Plans Its Last Dance.”

headline: Valerie Jarrett: ‘I Intend to Stay Until the Lights Go Off’
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The president’s senior adviser and confidante on immigration, working with Republicans and whether she’s the Democratic Dick Cheney.
lead_paragraph: The president’s senior adviser and confidante on immigration, working with Republicans and whether she’s the Democratic Dick Cheney.

headline: How Much Should Fans Be Allowed to Distract Opposing Teams?
abstract: Can spectator antics sometimes get in the way of the game? Or should everything and anything be allowed as long as it isn’t mean-spirited or offensive, or actual fan interference?
lead_paragraph: Isn’t basketball, baseball or any other sport supposed to be about great athleticism and sportsmanship? May the best team win? Or are fans part of the game too?

headline: Carly Fiorina Shapes Herself as the Republican Foil to Hillary Clinton
abstract: The former Hewlett-Packard chief is distinguishing herself among possible Republican contenders for president with pointed attacks on the leading Democrat.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — She has been the chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, a senior adviser to a Republican presidential nominee and a candidate for the United States Senate. But Carly Fiorina recently took on her boldest role yet: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s loudest critic.

headline: Key to Hawks’ Team Play: Nourish the Individual
abstract: Hawks coaches insist the team’s fine play comes from the hard work that happens behind the scenes, through an emphasis on player development.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The Hawks’ practice gym has bare walls, some cardio equipment crammed behind a baseline and patchwork flooring, a result of a recent leak. Most N.B.A. teams have gleaming, multimillion-dollar facilities. The Hawks spend their time in something that looks straight out of the Cold War.

headline: Vague Email Rules Let Federal Agencies Decide When to Hit Save or Delete
keywords: ['E-Mail', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Archives and Records']
abstract: The controversy over Hillary Rodham Clinton’s email use while secretary of state has opened a window into how unclear guidelines have been for top government officials.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. used an email alias named for the Temptations, the Motown group. Lisa P. Jackson, a former Environmental Protection Agency administrator, used “Richard Windsor” — a combination of her dog’s name and a New Jersey town — for her electronic alter ego.

headline: Essex Street Market on the Lower East Side Is Forgotten but Not Gone
keywords: ['Relocation of Business', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores']
abstract: Vendors say the city has mismanaged a struggling market, failing to promote its shops even as it plans for its move and expansion in 2018.
lead_paragraph: If you were prone to quick and superficial judgments, you might take one look at Anne Saxelby, a young and winsome purveyor of costly artisanal cheeses on the Lower East Side, and cast her in the role of bad witch in your own little gentrification play. For nearly a decade, Saxelby Cheesemongers has occupied a stall in the Essex Street Market, a municipal food hall built by Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia. And yet few have done more than Ms. Saxelby to work to preserve the market’s character and unite its disparate group of vendors, among them old-school Hispanic grocers dealing in unusual root vegetables and other inexpensive produce and retailers of the meticulously cured, the refined and the handcrafted.

headline: Wet Wipes Box Says Flush. New York’s Sewer System Says Don’t.
keywords: ['Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Sewers and Sewage', 'Bathrooms and Toilets']
abstract: The city’s wastewater treatment plants are little match for the wipes, which have grown in use and do not disintegrate the way toilet paper does.
lead_paragraph: With its sewer system under siege, tallying millions of dollars in equipment damage across its underground maze, New York City is confronting a menace that has gummed the gears of plumbing networks around the world: the common wet wipe.

headline: For Brooklyn’s District Attorney, Year One Is a Trial by Fire
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'District Attorneys', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Kenneth P. Thompson set out to enact his own agenda as Brooklyn district attorney, but his debut has been complicated by the death of Eric Garner and other high-profile cases.
lead_paragraph: One Sunday morning in February, Kenneth P. Thompson, the Brooklyn district attorney, showed up with some fellow politicians to celebrate the 249th anniversary of the African Wesleyan Methodist Episcopal Church. The event, in Bedford-Stuyvesant, was supposed to be one of those occasions elected officials love: a straightforward, stress-free gathering of voters that focused on history, not headlines.

headline: Battered but Unbowed, ISIS Is Still on Offensive
abstract: In the seven months since allied warplanes in the American-led campaign began bombing select Islamic State targets, the Sunni militancy is holding its own.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Islamic State is facing growing dissension among its rank-and-file fighters and struggling to govern towns and villages it has seized, but the militant Sunni group is still managing to launch attacks and expand its ideological reach outside of Iraq and Syria, senior American officials said.

headline: ‘The Last Flight of Poxl West,’ by Daniel Torday
abstract: A World War II memoir by a Jewish R.A.F. bomber is the book-within-a-book in Daniel Torday’s first novel.
lead_paragraph: Early on in “The Last Flight of Poxl West,” Daniel Torday’s expertly crafted first novel, an irksome grad student with dandruff asks the title character if we have “reached a point of saturation with all the first-person accounts” of World War II.

headline: Ask Well: Arsenic in Rice Crackers?
abstract: Foods that contain rice, including rice crackers and vinegar, routinely contain some level of arsenic, scientists say. But it’s unclear how serious a health risk they pose.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: China’s Middle Class Chafes Against Maze of Red Tape
abstract: An ambitious and worldly middle class is increasingly unwilling to tolerate the constraints of a Mao-era bureaucracy that dictates how people can live.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A rambunctious girl with a fondness for drawing and robots, Jessica Cherry looks like a typical 5-year-old. But in the eyes of the Chinese government she is invisible.

headline: New York Today: Global Trekker Rolls Into Town
abstract: Friday and the weekend: Stopping in the city on a human-powered journey, deteriorating weather, and don’t flush those wet wipes.

lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Where’s Putin?

headline: Official Report Describes Blunders in Deadly Police Raid in Philippines
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Attacks on Police', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The operation in January that killed 44 elite officers and jeopardized a landmark peace deal involved missteps by officials all the way up to the president, the report says.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — A botched police raid that killed 44 elite officers and jeopardized a landmark peace deal in the Philippines involved blunders by officials from the field commander all the way up to President Benigno S. Aquino III, according to a report released on Friday.

headline: Daily Report: New Rules for Net Neutrality May Set Stage for Legal Battles
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Net Neutrality', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Opponents of the rules, including many of the leading Internet providers, spent Thursday poring over the document. It was not known who would file the first legal challenges, or exactly what legal arguments would be made. Many experts, though, said the document included plenty of opportunity for different interpretations.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Communications Commission on Thursday released extensive details of how it would regulate broadband Internet providers as a public utility, producing official wording that almost certainly sets the stage for extended legal fights, Rebecca R. Ruiz reports.

headline: UBS Chief Executive’s Pay Rose Nearly 5% in 2014
abstract: Sergio P. Ermotti’s total compensation was about $11.1 million despite the bank’s performance being “tempered” by legal and regulatory charges in 2014.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Sergio P. Ermotti, the UBS chief executive, saw his compensation increase nearly 5 percent in 2014, despite the Swiss bank’s financial performance for the year being “tempered” by legal and regulatory charges, the lender said on Friday.

headline: With Plan to Join China-Led Bank, Britain Opens Door for Others
abstract: Britain’s joining the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank over American objections will encourage allies like South Korea and Australia to follow suit, analysts say.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A surprise decision this week by Britain to join China’s new development bank for Asia, despite opposition from the Obama administration, will almost certainly encourage other American allies to become members, particularly Australia and South Korea, analysts said Friday.

headline: Leatherback Turtles Don’t Need Google Maps
abstract: The big sea turtles’ use of Earth’s magnetic field gives them the navigational skills to travel thousands of miles each year.
lead_paragraph: Leatherback turtles can travel thousands of miles through the ocean each year. Yet when females are ready to nest, they somehow manage to return to the same beach again and again.

headline: Tracing Jewish Heritage Along the Danube
keywords: ['Cruises', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Synagogues', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: In Hungary, Slovakia, Austria and Germany, the river was a guide and a witness to vanished Jewish life.

headline: 3 Day-Cruises Worth the Trip
abstract: Itineraries in Chicago, San Francisco and New York offer the chance to admire the cities’ architecture, nature and history — in just a few hours.
lead_paragraph: Itineraries in Chicago, San Francisco and New York offer the chance to admire the cities’ architecture, nature and history — in just a few hours.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
abstract: In the news: healthy ‘cheese,’ happy conservatives and simple concussion tests. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: In the news: healthy ‘cheese,’ happy conservatives and simple concussion tests. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Skiing
abstract: “It is nothing if not improvising inside the vanishing moment.”
lead_paragraph: If I hadn’t become a writer, I’d be living in a rusty car with a ski rack, roaming the Rockies in perpetual pursuit of fresh powder. I dream of skiing constantly; as soon as the first snowflake of the season starts its descent from the gray skies of Chicago to its flatlands, I begin following snowfall reports from various ski resorts, occasionally and arbitrarily informing my wife, Teri, that Jackson Hole or Alta got a foot overnight. The thought that some skiable place somewhere has received fresh powder makes life worth living between November and April — and beyond, and forever.

headline: The Last Volunteer
abstract: The ideals of a California farmworker led him to fight in the Spanish Civil War.
lead_paragraph: It was 1937, and the Fascists had already revolted in Spain. I was walking down a street in Hollywood when I saw a sign — “Friends of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade” — written on the side of a building. I turned the corner, opened the door and went in. The people inside said, “What can we do for you?” I said, “I want to go to Spain.” They couldn’t legally send people to Spain, they told me, but did I want to help? I did. My life started with poverty and then came the Depression. I felt a certain responsibility to help the Spanish workers and farmers.

headline: How to Teach a Bird to Talk
abstract: Find one that thinks of you as its flock.
lead_paragraph: A single parrot cannot forage for fruit and watch for predators at the same time; it depends on its chittering flock for protection. Therefore, to teach a bird that can talk — parrots, parakeets or mynas, for example — to talk, find one that for lack of better options thinks of you as its flock. “Don’t get an old, disappointed bird,” says Sri Ganapathy Sachchidananda Swamiji, a 72-year-old guru who, when not traveling the world playing synthesizer concerts for his followers, can be found at his bird sanctuary in Mysore, India, home to more than a thousand birds, including some 40 trained talkers. “Buy a baby bird.” Specifically, opt for one bred in captivity (or rescued) rather than one snatched from the wild.

headline: ‘Starting to Show’
abstract: Selected by Natasha Trethewey.
lead_paragraph: In this poem, the visual delight of the imagery — the sun’s brightness “in the belly of the sky” — is undergirded by a pattern of rhyme and almost-rhyme. With the rhyme occurring in the middle of a line instead of at the end, combined with the rhythm of the short lines, the poem calls to mind the activity of the unborn child, a counterpoint to what is seen: that which is felt in the body. Poem selected by Natasha Trethewey.

headline: Jane Goodall Is Still Wild at Heart
keywords: ['Monkeys and Apes', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Sustainable Living', 'Forests and Forestry']
abstract: Half a century ago, she journeyed into the Tanzanian jungle to change how the world saw chimpanzees. Today the world’s most famous conservationist is on a mission to save their lives.
lead_paragraph: Jane Goodall was already on a London dock in March 1957 when she realized that her passport was missing. In just a few hours, she was due to depart on her first trip to Africa. A school friend had moved to a farm outside Nairobi and, knowing Goodall’s childhood dream was to live among the African wildlife, invited her to stay with the family for a while. Goodall, then 22, saved for two years to pay for her passage to Kenya: waitressing, doing secretarial work, temping at the post office in her hometown, Bournemouth, on England’s southern coast, during the holiday rush. She had spent her last few days in London saying goodbyes and picking up a few things for the trip at Peter Jones, the department store in Chelsea. Now all this was for naught, it seemed. The passport must have fallen out of her purse somewhere.

headline: 19th-Century Tourists Took Silly Vacation Photos, Too
abstract: Early images of Yosemite National Park’s Overhanging Rock.
lead_paragraph: On the cover of this week’s magazine, Alex Honnold peers over the edge of Overhanging Rock, a famed outcropping at Glacier Point in Yosemite National Park. Honnold, one of the world’s greatest rock climbers and a master of climbing alone and without ropes, is known for doing things few others do — but this isn’t one of them. The adventurous, or at least vertigo-unafflicted, have been inching out onto Overhanging Rock for photo ops for more than a century.

headline: Mets Hitters and New Coach Start to Mesh, With Help From a Net
abstract: Kevin Long, the Mets’ hitting instructor, is introducing the team to a drill he developed that aims to help players tighten their swings.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — When batting practice ended on Tuesday morning, Ruben Tejada stuck around the field for extra work. Kevin Long, the Mets’ new hitting coach, wanted him to try a new drill that Long had developed.

headline: Hillary Clinton, and Names Fit to Print
abstract: Mrs. Clinton’s name first appeared in The New York Times in 1977, but she falls short of Mitt Romney’s standard.
lead_paragraph: It has been nearly 46 years since Hillary Clinton’s name first appeared in The New York Times. Were she to win the Democratic nomination for president in 2016, her time in the news in this publication before becoming a presidential nominee would be longer than that of any other Democrat.

headline: Link to Protests Unknown in Ferguson Police Inquiry
abstract: Investigators pursued several leads in the shooting of two officers, but said it was unknown how many suspects were involved or whether the attack was link to the demonstrations.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — Investigators pursued several leads on Friday as they tried to determine who shot two officers standing outside the police station at a protest here, but they said it was unknown how many suspects were involved or whether there was any link between demonstrators and those who fired the shots.

headline: Assange’s Lawyer Welcomes Swedish Prosecutors’ Officer to Question Him in London
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Extradition', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)']
abstract: Prosecutors had refused to go there to interview Julian Assange, who took refuge in the Ecuadorean Embassy in 2012, about sexual assault allegations from 2010.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A lawyer for Julian Assange, the WikiLeaks founder who has taken refuge in the Ecuadorean Embassy in London since June 2012, welcomed an offer by Swedish prosecutors on Friday to travel to Britain to question him on allegations of sexual assault, and suggested that the offer would be accepted.

headline: Today in Politics: Republicans Set Sights on First Primary State
abstract: The 2016 action will move to New Hampshire this weekend as early front-runners in the Republican race visit the Granite State for the first time.
lead_paragraph: Good Friday morning from Washington. After a week filled with discussion of email servers and smartphones, President Obama revealed to Jimmy Kimmel that he delegates his tweeting and never sends a text. Former President George W. Bush, motivated by the situation in Myanmar, made a rare foray into foreign affairs; and don’t try pestering Supreme Court justices about coming decisions – they don’t budge. But in the meantime, for those seeking a campaign fix, the Granite State is the place to look this weekend.

headline: For Michaela DePrince, a Dream Comes True at the Dutch National Ballet
abstract: The 20-year-old American ballerina lived through a civil war in Sierra Leone to become a celebrity after fulfilling her ambition to perform onstage.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — Michaela DePrince was appearing here in the third act of Balanchine’s “Jewels” with the Dutch National Ballet on a recent evening. There were about a dozen ballerinas in bejeweled white tutus arrayed across the stage, and there she was all the way stage right in the front line.

headline: An Update on Our Second Annual Student Editorial Contest
abstract: In which we answer some frequently asked questions — for example, “When will you announce the winners?”
lead_paragraph: First of all, thank you for your enthusiasm.

headline: Defense in Marathon Bombing Has Echo of Clarence Darrow
abstract: When Dzhokhar Tsarnaev’s lead lawyer admitted her client’s role in the Boston Marathon bombings, she was using a play from Clarence Darrow’s book.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — When Judy Clarke, the lead defense lawyer for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, announced at the outset of his trial last week that her client was responsible for the Boston Marathon bombings, she was following a strategy laid out by Clarence Darrow almost a century ago.

headline: Morning Agenda: Commerzbank in U.S. Settlement
abstract: Commerzbank agrees to pay nearly $1.5 billion in U.S. settlement. | How 3 banks passed the Fed’s stress tests. | The Gates Foundation is investing directly in for-profit companies with bright ideas.
lead_paragraph: COMMERZBANK IN U.S. SETTLEMENT | Commerzbank, one of Germany’s biggest lenders, agreed on Thursday to pay nearly $1.5 billion and dismiss some of its employees to resolve an array of charges in the United States, DealBook’s Ben Protess reports. “The case, the latest black eye for a giant global bank accused of sending tainted money through the American financial system, closes the book on several investigations into Commerzbank,” he adds.

headline: Can an Evil Man Change?
abstract: Over the years, a South African killer transformed himself into somebody who helped the families of his victims.
lead_paragraph: CAPE TOWN — South Africa’s most notorious apartheid-era assassin, Eugene de Kock, has received parole after spending 20 years in prison. The government’s decision to let him walk free has unleashed a sort of identity crisis among South Africans. Could a man once known as “Prime Evil” really have changed? Why are we showing such charity to the deadliest cog in apartheid’s racist machine? And more important, why are so many South Africans — mostly white — so angry that this specific prisoner has been freed?

headline: If It’s Thursday, It Must Be ‘Home’ — No More
abstract: Readers miss the Home section, shuttered after 38 years.
lead_paragraph: For many longtime readers of The Times, Thursday was tinged with sadness. One of their favorite weekly sections, Home, was no longer in the paper. The section was discontinued after the March 5 edition, almost exactly 38 years after its debut.

In recent years “Saturday Night Live’ alumni like Amy Poehler, Tina Fey, and Seth Meyers have all hosted a major award show. (Ms. Poehler and Ms. Fey did the Golden Globes for three years in a row and Mr. Meyers was the host of the 2014 Emmys.)

headline: Got College Admissions Frenzy? Read ‘Where You Go Is Not Who You’ll Be’
abstract: Who our children are when they go to college matters a whole lot more than the name on the sweatshirt.
lead_paragraph: It really is the season. Facebook updates, most at least self-depreciating, have begun announcing the college choices of my friends’ children. Many include some big names in the campus world — but for a lot of reasons, many don’t. Many, if not most, of my old friends’ kids are off to places like Kansas University, Wichita State, Washburn University in Topeka, or maybe to Southern Methodist University or even the University of Texas at Austin. I’m delighted for them. I’m thrilled.

lead_paragraph: As part of a trip to France in 1984 to study floral painting, Dianne Bernhard spent time in Monet’s gardens at Giverny. It was there, among the flowers that inspired him, that she heard Cartier was creating a new perfume in Paris made with jasmine, roses and vanilla.
