lead_paragraph: It turns out that President Obama really does read the tweets, or at least some of the meaner ones.

headline: Layers of Spring
abstract: With spring approaching, here’s a pasta offering with broccoli rabe that is emblematic of the season.
lead_paragraph: Lasagna, that many-layered marvel, is a dish that shifts with the seasons. Like fashion, it comes in different hues and textures that match the weather.

headline: From The Upshot’s Editor: Political Mysteries
keywords: ['Presidential Elections (US)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Elections are generally won and lost on fundamentals, like the economy and demographics. But that is not to say that campaigns don’t matter — they do.
lead_paragraph: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshot’s weekly newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

headline: Letters: James Baldwin, Richard Wright
abstract: Readers respond to recent essays about James Baldwin’s reaction to Richard Wright’s “Native Son.”
lead_paragraph: James Baldwin, Richard Wright

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: DEAD WAKE: The Last Crossing Of The Lusitania, by Erik Larson. (Crown, $28.) The 100th anniversary of the great ship’s sinking is the occasion of this entertaining book by the masterly author of “The Devil in the White City.”

headline: Mario Vargas Llosa’s ‘Discreet Hero’
abstract: Characters from previous Mario Vargas Llosa novels return in this tale of privilege, extortion and greed.
lead_paragraph: When I think of the writers I adored in my 20s, during the 1970s and ’80s, it almost makes me think that winning the Nobel Prize in Literature must not be so hard, because nearly every one of them has won it: García Márquez, Bellow, Morrison, Coetzee, Naipaul, Grass and, in 2010, the youngest and only surviving member of the Latin American “boom,” Mario Vargas Llosa. I mention this not to pitch myself as a reliable Nobel handicapper but to point out the futility of ascribing any politically correct left-wing bias to the Swedish Academy, since at least three of those favorites — Bellow, Naipaul and Vargas Llosa — are about as politically correct as Margaret Thatcher. All three have been identified with the cultural and political right, none more so than Vargas Llosa, who ran seriously for the presidency of Peru and who to this day is probably, partly through the opinion columns he publishes in Spain’s El País, the Spanish language’s most prominent conservative intellectual.

headline: ‘The Illuminations,’ by Andrew O’Hagan
abstract: A war-scarred man finds comfort in unraveling secrets from his grandmother’s past.
lead_paragraph: The literature of war is by its very nature political. If a writer’s sentences are ­personal — what else, really, can they be? — and a writer has trained his lens on a bloody battleground, in reading him we will come to know where he stands, where his passions lie. When it comes to fiction, this passion can often result in ­rhetoric-spouting characters whose sole purpose is to service the author’s ideas. But in “The Illuminations,” the Scottish novelist and critic Andrew O’Hagan has created a story that is both a howl against the war in Afghanistan and the societies that have blindly abetted it, and a multilayered, deeply felt tale of family, loss, memory, art, loyalty, secrecy and forgiveness.

headline: ‘The Unraveling of Mercy Louis,’ by Keija Parssinen
abstract: A teenager navigates a series of disasters.
lead_paragraph: American television would have it that high schools are the site of endless intrigue: In cult favorites like “Twin Peaks” and “Veronica Mars,” teen­agers enact adult dramas in miniature, sleuthing in trench coats before joining their peers in ill-fitted dresses and wrinkled suits at prom. Such is the lot of the American teenager, a creature at once juvenile and jaded.

headline: Rock ’n’ Write
abstract: Odds are that if you were on MTV at anytime in the 1980s, you’ve published your life story in the past decade.
lead_paragraph: Kim Gordon’s memoir, “Girl in a Band,” is reviewed this week by the musician, writer and producer Questlove. Gordon, a founder of the seminal art-rock band Sonic Youth, is the latest in a cavalcade of rock stars (of a certain age) to write a memoir. Odds are that if you were on MTV at anytime in the 1980s, you’ve published your life story in the past decade.

headline: Religious History
abstract: New books by Hubert Wolf, Peter Manseau and James J. O’Donnell.
lead_paragraph: THE NUNS OF SANT’AMBROGIO

headline: ‘The Tell-Tale Heart,’ by Jill Dawson
abstract: A philanderer’s life is transformed after a heart transplant.
lead_paragraph: Patrick Robson, the main character in Jill Dawson’s novel “The Tell-Tale Heart,” is a 50-ish divorced British academic whose least complicated relationship is with his BMW. A well-practiced philanderer, Patrick juggles Helen, his ex-wife, and Lucy, a former mistress, as well as a scorned girlfriend, a younger (of course) colleague who avenges herself by bringing Patrick up on sexual harassment charges before a university committee. Patrick knows he’s a rogue; he also admits to being the “world’s worst father” to his two children: Alice, his daughter with Helen, and Ben, his son with Lucy.

headline: Reif Larsen’s ‘I Am Radar’
abstract: Reif Larsen’s novel takes on race and self-reinvention.
lead_paragraph: Set aside for the moment the black baby born to white parents, the avant-­garde puppeteers and the quantum physics that swirl around the whole kit and caboodle. The most interesting facet of Reif Lar­sen’s 600-plus-page novel, “I Am Radar,” is that it reads like something far more compact than its bulk might suggest. There are maps, diagrams and pictures (e.g., an elephant plummeting from a bridge, a Cambodian prisoner of the Khmer Rouge) that remind one of the ­visual arrangements in W. G. Sebald’s novels. Then there is a deeply patterned narrative that darts easily from small-bore domestic dramas to sweeping historical catastrophes with just the right fillip of silliness and levity to keep the whole text eminently ­approachable.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Joseph Kanon, whose “Leaving Berlin” is No. 11 on the hardcover fiction list, spent 30 years “in the service of other people’s books” before writing his own.
lead_paragraph: The Insider: Joseph Kanon’s seventh historical thriller, “Leaving Berlin,” enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 11. Kanon first cracked the list with his debut novel, “Los Alamos,” in 1997 — but he was already well known in the book business before then, having spent some 30 years as an editor and publishing executive, including a stint as president of Dutton. During that long first act, Kanon worked with fiction writers including Muriel Spark, Louis Auchincloss, Frank Conroy and Jayne Anne Phillips. But he never dreamed of writing a novel himself, he told an Australian newspaper in 2009. “I didn’t have manuscripts secretly in the bottom drawer,” he said. “Honestly, I didn’t. I was happy in publishing. I was in the service of other people’s books. The last thing you want is to be in competition with your writers.” That all changed after Kanon left the industry in the mid-1990s, when he vacationed in New Mexico and was struck by the idea for a crime novel set during the Manhattan Project. “I never told anyone I was doing it,” he said. “I didn’t even tell my wife. I didn’t know if I could do it. What could be more embarrassing than a publisher who couldn’t write?”

headline: Mary Helen Specht’s ‘Migratory Animals’
abstract: Adulthood hasn’t come easy for the 30-somethings in this novel.
lead_paragraph: Tales of naïve Americans abroad may have defined our national fiction around the turn of the last century, but the literature of the early 21st abounds with an entirely more sophisticated sort of traveler, perfectly exemplified by Flannery, the hard-as-nails heroine of Mary Helen Specht’s delightfully ambitious first novel, “Migratory Animals.” A far cry from Henry James’s Isabel Archer, Flannery — like many of her generation and station — is “on the lam” from both her middle-class, middlebrow roots and the lifestyle-driven superficiality carefully honed by her onetime college friends. She has settled in Nigeria less because her work as a climate-change scientist has repercussions for local farmers and more because it’s a few continents away from her sister, Molly, “an emotional tar pit” for whom Flannery served as a surrogate mother during the years when the girls’ actual mother was slowly, grotesquely deteriorating from Huntington’s disease.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE SPLENDID THINGS WE PLANNED: A Family Portrait, by Blake Bailey. (Norton, $15.95.) Bailey, the biographer of Richard Yates, John Cheever and Charles Jackson, takes up his own family’s turbulent history in this achingly honest memoir. He tells of his failings and his parents’ — his father was a prosperous Oklahoma lawyer, his mother a German immigrant with a bohemian streak — but the dark heart of the story is Bailey’s older brother, Scott, and his alcohol- and drug-fueled fall from grace.

headline: ‘In Every Way,’ by Nic Brown
abstract: In this novel, a woman takes a job as nanny to the baby she gave up for adoption.
lead_paragraph: It sounds impossible: Give up your baby for adoption and still spend every day with her. But Maria, the 19-year-old protagonist of Nic Brown’s novel “In Every Way,” does just that, becoming the full-time nanny of the daughter she gave away. This is an ingenious feat, considering Maria opted for a mostly closed adoption. That the reunion is nonetheless entirely believable is a credit to Brown’s gift for realism, and evidence that there is no anonymity in the digital age.

headline: ‘The Death of Caesar,’ by Barry Strauss
abstract: Barry Strauss examines the assassination of Julius Caesar and its aftermath.
lead_paragraph: Among the most poignant objects that survive from the era of the Ides of March — March 15, 44 B.C., the day Julius Caesar fell to the knives of Brutus, Cassius and perhaps 21 other senators — is a dime-size silver denarius, minted by Brutus a year or two after the murder. One side of this rare coin shows ­military-style daggers flanking a felt pileus cap, a symbol of freedom from slavery, and the abbreviation EID MAR. On the other side, remarkably, Brutus had his own portrait stamped. Before this, Caesar was the only Roman who had dared put himself on a coin, for to do so was to assume the stature of a monarch — or a god.

headline: ‘The Rebellion of Miss Lucy Ann Lobdell,’ by William Klaber
abstract: This historical novel’s protagonist lived as a man.
lead_paragraph: There are only two basic plots in fiction, writers occasionally say: “Somebody goes on a journey” and, the other side of the coin, “A stranger comes to town.” Brilliantly, William Klaber has managed to combine them. In this deeply satisfying historical novel, he recreates the voice of Lucy Ann Lobdell, a real mid-19th-­century New York woman who abandoned her young daughter and set out — dressed and passing as a man — to find the independence (and money) denied her as a woman. After many years of wandering as Joseph Lobdell, she married another woman and eventually found herself locked away as a lunatic.

headline: Abandonment Issues
abstract: Is a certain amount of discarding beneficial?
lead_paragraph: The older I get, the more preoccupied I become with the number of things I’ve given up on over the years. I’m fond of the line, often attributed to Paul Valéry, about how “a work of art is never finished, merely abandoned,” but as I look back with mounting unease at a path strewn with half-started and half-finished projects, I wonder if I might have taken this counsel too much, and too literally, to heart.

headline: EQT and Goldman Sachs Funds Sell Remaining Stake in ISS
abstract: At the same time, the Kirk Kristiansen family, the owners of the Lego brand, increased their stake in the Danish outsourcing company.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Swedish private equity firm EQT Partners and funds advised by Goldman Sachs have sold their remaining stake in the Danish outsourcing company ISS for about $1 billion a decade after acquiring the company.

headline: 1940: Ex-Governor of Punjab Slain
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: 1940: The former governor of Punjab is assassinated.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A mysterious assassin today [March 13] shot and killed Sir Michael O’Dwyer, former Lieutenant Governor of the Punjab, and wounded Lord Zetland, Secretary of State for India, Sir  Louis W. Dane and Lord Lamington at the conclusion of a meeting in Caxton Hall while 150 of Britain’s highest ranking civil servants looked on in horror. The outrage is believed to be an act of vengeance arising out of the Amritsar shooting of 1919.

headline: In China, a Building Frenzy’s Fault Lines
keywords: ['Foreign Investments', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Credit and Debt', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)']
abstract: As foreign investors clamored for a piece of China’s real estate boom, it was easy to overlook the type of risk that brought down the property developer Kaisa.
lead_paragraph: As the real estate market in the United States was collapsing in the mid-2000s, Wall Street went in search of new terrain, and found it in China. All across the country, from Beijing to Shenzhen, sprawling housing developments and business districts were popping up, seemingly overnight. Real estate prices were soaring. Western banks, hedge funds, private equity firms and other investors wanted a piece of the action.

headline: Netanyahu Shifts Tactics as His Likud Party Appears to Slip in Final Surveys
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who is running for his third consecutive term, is confronting the very real possibility of a political about-face in Israel.

The charge is one that the Chinese authorities have increasingly used in recent years to quell activism and discussion of social and political issues.

headline: Greenwich Village Townhouse Brings $9,500,000
abstract: A 20-foot-wide Greenwich Village townhouse, with an unassuming brick front, was the most expensive sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: A 20-foot-wide townhouse in Greenwich Village, with a dual-personality exterior that includes an unassuming brick front and a whimsical rear facade boldly accented with a rainbow of colors, sold for $9,500,000 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Letting a Broken Arm Heal Without Surgery
abstract: Broken arms are routinely operated on, but a randomized trial has found that many breaks can be allowed to heal on their own.
lead_paragraph: Broken arms are routinely treated with surgery, but a randomized trial has found that many breaks can be allowed to heal on their own.

headline: Notes on an ‘Idiot’s’ Guide to Retirement
abstract: The reporter John Schwartz explained that “having an assignment to write on the subject made me finally take my own financial life seriously.”
lead_paragraph: My article in this week’s special section on retirement was an attempt to get off my behind and actually think about my finances. As the article points out, I’ve been avoiding any real confrontation with issues like retirement for many years, though I always made sure to set up a regular contribution to a 401(k) account. Was it enough? Finding out was the point of the article. And since, like many reporters, I do almost nothing without a deadline, having an assignment to write on the subject made me finally take my own financial life seriously.

headline: 1890: Revelers Pack Paris Streets
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Revelers Pack Paris Streets for the Mid-Lent festival in 1890.
lead_paragraph: Paris offered yesterday a perfect picture of metropolitan bliss. Years have passed since the city had enjoyed itself so thoroughly on the occasion of the Mid-Lent festival. It was not that the masks were more numerous or the perambulating blanchisseuses more gaily attired than in former fêtes of the Mi-Carême, but simply that the sun shone down with spring-like warmth and brightness, giving an extra glitter to every spangle, and making each peal of laughter sound with double merriment.

headline: Vaccines Face Same Mistrust That Fed Ebola
abstract: The same mix of fear and distrust that helped the Ebola epidemic spread is hampering doctors conducting trials on new medicines.
lead_paragraph: MONROVIA, Liberia — West Africa’s Ebola epidemic may be waning, but another outbreak in the future is a near certainty, health officials say.

headline: Childless by Choice
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Children and Childhood', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth']
abstract: I didn’t trust myself not to recreate the unhappy family I’d known.
lead_paragraph: ALTADENA, Calif. — I WENT to a fortuneteller when I was 25. Her house was on a busy street, its shingled siding a strange, marigold orange, the trim a clashing bright red and blue. A banner advertised: “Special: $5.”

headline: Readers Respond: On ‘Republican Idiocy on Iran’
abstract: For many readers, Republican senators’ open letter to Iran violates basic principles of American government. Others, however, see it as a necessary corrective.
lead_paragraph: For many readers of Thursday’s editorial on the subject, Republican senators’ open letter to Iran represents a dangerous new low in U.S. politics and international relations.

headline: Fortum Agrees to Sell Swedish Power Distribution Grid for $6.9 Billion
abstract: The sale marks the exit of the Finnish utility from the electricity distribution business after earlier sales of grids in Norway and Finland.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Fortum, the state-controlled Finnish utility, said on Friday that it had agreed to sell its Swedish electricity distribution network to a consortium of Swedish funds and Borealis Infrastructure Management of Canada for 6.6 billion euros, or about $6.9 billion, including debt.

headline: Fear of Frying
abstract: When it comes to frying and deep-frying food it’s not so much the frying you need to consider, but what you are frying and the type of oil you use.
lead_paragraph: Nutritionists will tell you that “butter is back” is not quite the right message to be sending to the public about the significance of fat in a healthy diet. We can, however, let go of our fear of frying, especially if we use monounsaturated fats like olive oil and polyunsaturated fats like grapeseed oil. Study after study has indicated that refined carbohydrates play a much more insidious role in our national health problems than fats do, and that a moderate-fat (but low-saturated fat) diet like the Mediterranean diet (about 40 percent calories from fat) is a healthy way to eat, and even more important, an enjoyable, very easy way of eating to adhere to.

headline: What I Love | James Klein and David Reid
abstract: Two ceramists live with their own and others’ works, vintage furniture and a few beloved unidentified objects.
lead_paragraph: Two ceramists live with their own and others’ works, vintage furniture and a few beloved unidentified objects.

headline: In Queens, Ceramics, History, and a Bit of Mystery
abstract: The ceramists James Klein and David Reid live in Jackson Heights with their own and others’ works, vintage furniture and a few beloved unidentified objects.
lead_paragraph: The ceramists James Klein and David Reid came to live in the borough of Queens as many do, after a stint in Brooklyn.

headline: The Trouble With Advance Directives
keywords: ['Elderly', 'Living Wills and Health Care Proxies', 'Medicine and Health', 'Death and Dying', 'Elder Care']
abstract: Even a patient’s seemingly specific instructions for care can be less than direct, or unavailable when needed.
lead_paragraph: The man had written an advance directive four years ago, before his advancing dementia had made communication difficult. He had been very specific.

headline: All You Need to Know About Income Inequality, in One Comparison
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'Minimum Wage', 'Bonuses', 'Wages and Salaries', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The Wall Street bonus pool for last year is roughly double the total earnings of all Americans who work full time at the federal minimum wage.
lead_paragraph: The Wall Street bonus pool for last year is roughly double the total earnings of all Americans who work full time at the federal minimum wage.

headline: Valeant Said to Be Planning to Raise Its Bid for Salix Pharmaceuticals
abstract: The company is said to be teaming up with shareholders including Pershing Square Capital Management to bring its offer above $160 a share.
lead_paragraph: Valeant Pharmaceuticals is planning to team up with Pershing Square Capital Management and other top shareholders, including ValueAct Capital, to raise its bid for Salix Pharmaceuticals this weekend, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: Watching ‘Fresh Off the Boat’ at Asia Roma in Chinatown
abstract: On Tuesdays, diners are viewers, too, gathering at the restaurant to watch the ABC sitcom “Fresh Off the Boat,” the television version of the chef Eddie Huang’s memoir about growing up Taiwanese-American in Florida.
lead_paragraph: According to the Tuesday-night bartender, Asia Roma “used to be an Italian mobster bar” when it was still known as Antica Roma.

headline: Tumblr 486 — 489
abstract: Tumblr 486 — 489
lead_paragraph: Tumblr 486 — 489

headline: Like Taking a Luxury Bus: Via, a Ride-Share App, Offers Manhattan Trips
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Car-Pooling and Ride-Sharing']
abstract: Via, a Manhattan ride service that carries multiple passengers, is not as fast or efficient as Uber, but it is friendlier and low-cost.
lead_paragraph: I’ve recently started using the city’s public bus system, and I love it. It’s not the fastest or most efficient way to get from Point A to Point B. But it’s very comfortable, it’s somewhat relaxing, and it feels as if I’m participating in a new aspect of civic life.

headline: Progress Is Slow at V.A. Hospitals in Wake of Crisis
abstract: Delays in receiving care are still common, underscoring the reality that overhauling a federal department with almost 300,000 employees is a difficult and tedious process.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — The nation’s largest hospital system has made only halting progress in hiring new doctors, replacing incompetent supervisors, upgrading outdated computers and rebuilding trust with veterans, nine months after President Obama concluded that a “corrosive culture” had led to systemic problems at hospitals run by the Department of Veterans Affairs.

headline: Assange’s Lawyer Welcomes Questioning
abstract: Per Samuelson, a lawyer for Julian Assange, said he welcomed the decision of a Swedish prosecutor to question the WikiLeaks founder Mr. Assange in London over sexual assault accusations.
lead_paragraph: Per Samuelson, a lawyer for Julian Assange, said he welcomed the decision of a Swedish prosecutor to question the WikiLeaks founder Mr. Assange in London over sexual assault accusations.

headline: Grilling a Supreme Court Justice Is No Easy Task
abstract: The trick to interviewing a justice of the Supreme Court as it prepares to issue major decisions is to ask seemingly general questions that might nonetheless elicit a preview of what is to come.
lead_paragraph: The trick to interviewing a justice of the Supreme Court as it prepares to issue major decisions is to ask seemingly general questions that might nonetheless elicit a preview of what is to come.

headline: Cookie Is an ‘Empire’ Builder for Fox
abstract: “Empire,” Fox’s hit soap opera, is the year’s biggest new TV show, and Taraji P. Henson’s Cookie is the biggest reason why.
lead_paragraph: Who is your favorite character on “Empire”? Is it Jamal, the multitalented gay singer-songwriter? It is Porsha, the constantly put-upon, but ever loyal, assistant? Could it possibly be Hakeem, the immature rapper with the Kid ’n Play-esque flattop?

headline: A Chess Master Tries to Turn Rabbits Into Wolves
abstract: Jerald Times, who was one of the best black players in the world when he was in his 30s, is now trying to teach the style of chess he grew up with in Harlem to private school students.
lead_paragraph: In the rear of a Harlem chess club last Sunday night, amid the hubbub of trash-talking players, a group of polite schoolchildren took turns playing speed chess against a large man whose dreadlocks were mostly covered with a wool hat.

headline: Tobias Jesso Jr.’s Take on His New Album, Adele and Fame
abstract: Mr. Jesso had played just three proper shows as a solo artist before his television debut last month. His album comes out on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The first time Tobias Jesso Jr. performed a song from his album, “Goon,” with other musicians was last month on “The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon.” His backing band was the Roots.

headline: Ben Mendelsohn: A Good Bad Man to Have Around
abstract: Mr. Mendelsohn, who stars in the new Netflix series “Bloodline,” has a way with menace.
lead_paragraph: The most terrifying moment in the premiere episode of “Bloodline,” Netflix’s dark new drama, occurs when the actor Ben Mendelsohn stands up.

headline: Ballet West Comes to the Joyce
abstract: A dance company from Salt Lake City builds on the exposure it gained from participating in “Breaking Pointe,” a reality-TV show.
lead_paragraph: “We suffer physical pain and shocking injuries,” a female voice intones as images of calloused and bandaged toes flash across the screen. “There’s rivalry,” says a pretty brunette, “and relationships.” Cut to a glimpse of an anxious dancer biting her lip in the studio, followed by a couple gazing into each other’s eyes while locked in a balletic embrace. “Why do we do it?” the voice continues. “To have that one single moment onstage when everything comes together.” Then: “We do it,” pause, “to be perfect.”

headline: Courtney Barnett Prepares Her Debut Album
abstract: The Australian singer and songwriter will release “Sometimes I Sit and Think, and Sometimes I Just Sit” on March 24.
lead_paragraph: The Australian songwriter Courtney Barnett writes about the little, not always simple, things in life. An asthma attack. Insomnia in hotel rooms. House-hunting on a meager budget. Trying (and failing) to impress the swimmer in the next lane at the pool. Roadkill. And all sorts of ambivalence: about success, romance, the state of the world. “I’m no sociological genius,” she said via Skype from her home in Melbourne. “I just know what I know.”

headline: When Employee Engagement Turns Into Employee Burnout
abstract: Too often “engagement” refers to employees who get to work early, stay late and remain connected. That’s not a recipe for enduring high performance.
lead_paragraph: Is there a company of any significant size that doesn’t seek and venerate “employee engagement?”

headline: In Israeli Race, Winning First Place Is No Guarantee of Becoming Premier
abstract: Getting the most votes is no guarantee that an Israel party leader will be able to form a government and become prime minister.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — When the first election results begin to flow in on the night of March 17, Israelis may need to get out their calculators.

headline: Things To Do When You’re Dead To Davos
abstract: Nationalism and populism finally make their debut.
lead_paragraph: The Greek government has deployed a lot of populist and nationalist rhetoric, and eurocrats seem shocked. But the miracle is that this hasn’t happened until now.

headline: Will Hillary Clinton Follow Democrats on Capital Gains?
keywords: ['Capital Gains Tax', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Income Tax', 'Income Inequality', 'Federal Taxes (US)']
abstract: One of the big questions facing the Democratic front-runner is how eager she is to tax the rich with a higher rate on capital gains.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague David Leonhardt notes, one of the big policy questions for Hillary Clinton is how eager she is to tax the rich. But this isn’t just a question of the top rate on wages. If she runs for president, it will be very interesting to see whether Mrs. Clinton takes a position substantially to Barack Obama’s right on capital gains taxes, as she did in 2008.

headline: An Avant-Garde ‘Odyssey’ From Les Délices Ensemble at Columbia
abstract: Concerts and recordings by the ensemble are journeys of discovery, often featuring composers few people have heard of and even fewer have performed.
lead_paragraph: For years, Ulysses has roamed the campus of Columbia University. The hero of Homer’s “The Odyssey” is an annual specter for students here: The epic is mandatory reading for every freshman. This year they’ve been able to encounter him up close in the exuberant collages of Romare Bearden’s “Black Odyssey,” part of an exhibition at the Wallach Art Gallery that closed this month. “The Odyssey” is also the subject of a program of French baroque music titled “Myths and Allegories,” which the period-instrument ensemble Les Délices is scheduled to present at the university’s Miller Theater on March 28 with the soprano Clara Rottsolk.

headline: In Mexico Oil Market, Mood Moves From Excited to Anxious
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: As oil prices plunge, the government has scaled back its heady predictions of big-time investing while also taking steps to drum up interest.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Mexico kicked off the opening of its oil industry to great fanfare. At a packed event at the Technology Museum here seven months ago, maps flashed on a giant screen showing dozens of oil fields that would be put up for bid to private companies for the first time in more than 75 years.

headline: Crash Victims Include Decorated Marine
keywords: ['Helicopters', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters']
abstract: Among the 11 servicemen killed in a helicopter crash off Florida on Tuesday was Staff Sgt. Andrew C. Seif, who was named “Marine of the Year” in 2013 and who was awarded the Silver Star just four days before the crash.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Before a military helicopter disappeared into a thick bank of fog off the Florida coast, killing all 11 servicemen aboard, military officials had conducted an “operational risk assessment” and determined that the weather was safe enough to fly in, Maj. Gen. Joseph L. Osterman, commander of the Marine Corps Forces Special Operations Command, said Friday.

headline: On the Front Lines in Ferguson
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: John Eligon described the scene in Ferguson, Mo., where protests about the treatment of residents by the police continued.
lead_paragraph: John Eligon has been reporting on the developments in Ferguson, Mo., since last summer, when Michael Brown, an unarmed black teenager, was killed by a white police officer.

headline: Some Wedding Sites Also Play Hard to Get
abstract: If you want to get married in these places, you may have to make a very early commitment.
lead_paragraph: When Julia Greenberg, 27, became engaged last Thanksgiving to her longtime boyfriend, Carl Wolf, she didn’t realize she would have to wait more than a year and a half to get married at her favorite place, the Adler Planetarium in Chicago. In January, with other couples circling, they quickly signed a contract for a Saturday in July 2016.

headline: Looks Real, but Look Closer
abstract: “Richard Estes: Painting New York City” offers more than 40 paintings and works on paper dating from the mid-1960s to the present.
lead_paragraph: A new trend rocked the New York art world in the late 1960s: Photorealist painting, in which people, places and things were rendered with shocking lucidity. One of the genre’s best practitioners was and still is Richard Estes, a Chicagoan who has lived in New York since 1958. Working from photographs that he takes himself, Mr. Estes paints images of cars, storefronts, subways, bridges and theater marquees, incorporating the ordinary, banal and overlooked into formally acute and uncannily vivid images. You see as if through the eyes of someone whose perceptions have been somehow intensified.

headline: Speed Propels Rangers to Front of Pack in East
abstract: Tactics built around speed helped carry the Rangers to the Stanley Cup finals last season and have vaulted them into first place in the Eastern Conference this year.
lead_paragraph: As a youth hockey player in Boxford, Mass., Rangers forward Chris Kreider was always the fastest skater on his team. Even as he shot up to what he is today — a 6-foot-3, 226-pound menace — he has maintained his superlative speed.

headline: They Still Bristle and Snarl
abstract: Most of the original Pop Group reunited in 2010, but it has taken the band until this year to release a new album.
lead_paragraph: The Pop Group emerged in the post-punk scrum of late-1970s England, where abrasive sounds and political outrage forged an enduring alliance. The Pop Group was pioneering and extreme; Nick Cave has called it “unholy, manic, violent, paranoid, painful music.” Its songs crunched together tight funk, deranged noise, exotic instruments, free-jazz improvisations, electronic manipulations and sonic anarchy, while Mark Stewart yowled, screamed, barked, ranted and occasionally sang about the depredations of money and power. The band lasted from 1977 to ’80 and released only two albums, though Mr. Stewart went on lead his own punk-funk band, Mark Stewart and the Maffia, in the 1980s.

headline: Collective Percussion
abstract: Kodo, the sensational Japanese drum ensemble, is to play the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: Kodo, the sensational Japanese drum ensemble, plays the Brooklyn Academy of Music as part of “Kodo One Earth Tour: Mystery,” a new work. This acclaimed troupe practices a tradition of massed drumming that traces back to the sixth century and often includes other instruments and even some singing. (7:30 p.m. Thursday-Saturday, Howard Gilman Opera House, 718-636-4100, bam.org.)

headline: New Music From War on Women, Rixton and Mourn
abstract: Indie rock that indicts, inspires, rambles and whines is on these new albums.
lead_paragraph: War on Women

headline: Intimate Ties Above and Below
abstract: “Of Horses and Men,” the acclaimed first feature by the Icelandic stage director Benedikt Erlingsson, explores the man-beast relationship.
lead_paragraph: “Of Horses and Men,” the acclaimed first feature by the Icelandic stage director Benedikt Erlingsson, explores the man-beast relationships between short-legged Icelandic horses and human characters. Its extraordinary scenes of equestrians and high-strung animals interacting in the stunningly beautiful Icelandic countryside point up the temperamental similarities between species.

headline: This Old Thing? It’s Back in Style
abstract: The Smithsonian Channel’s “L.A. Frock Stars” is a guilty pleasure but makes you feel a little smarter for having watched it.
lead_paragraph: Reality shows built around fashion, whether “Project Runway” or “Say Yes to the Dress,” tend to rely on histrionics — competing designers argue, frantic brides melt down, and so on. The Smithsonian Channel’s “L.A. Frock Stars,” which returns for a second season on Thursday night, is a different animal, a mix of history and Hollywood glamour that is still a guilty pleasure but makes you feel a little smarter for having watched it.

headline: Verbatim: Walker Calls Bush a ‘Name From the Past’
abstract: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, talking to The Tampa Bay Times about his rival Jeb Bush.
lead_paragraph: — Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, talking to The Tampa Bay Times about his rival Jeb Bush.

headline: Mets’ Bolstered Rotation Is Again in Doubt
abstract: Matt Harvey has returned to the Mets’ rotation, but three other pitchers, including Zack Wheeler, are now dealing with injuries that will cause Mets fans to hold their breath again.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The Mets decided years ago to build their team around elite young pitching, a strategy that carried some inherent risk. Strong and vibrant pitchers are lost to arm injuries every year, so general managers almost have to walk around with their fingers crossed, hoping for the best.

headline: Lights! Camera! Food!
abstract: For the past seven years, photographer Andrew Scrivani has tempted our taste buds with delicious food photographs for the Recipes for Health series. A behind-the-scenes look at food photography and how he captures food looking its best.
lead_paragraph: For the past seven years, photographer Andrew Scrivani has tempted our taste buds with delicious food photographs for the Recipes for Health series. This video report gives a behind-the-scenes look at food photography and how he captures food looking its best.

headline: Blurred Legal Lines
abstract: Ben Sisario, Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss the “Blurred Lines” copyright trial.
lead_paragraph: Ben Sisario, Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss the “Blurred Lines” copyright trial.

headline: Know Your Heirloom and Ancient Grains
abstract: Here’s an introduction to the prehistoric wheat varieties that are reaching the fringes of the mainstream, along with other formerly marginalized grains.
lead_paragraph: WHEAT BERRIES Whole kernels of wheat, with the bran intact. Depending upon the variety of wheat, wheat berries can run from mild and starchy in flavor to earthy and mineral.

headline: 3 Persian Gulf Nations Pledge $12 Billion in Aid for Egypt
abstract: The pledges from Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates came during an international investment conference billed as the centerpiece of the government’s economic program.
lead_paragraph: SHARM EL SHEIKH, Egypt — Three Persian Gulf monarchies on Friday pledged a total of $12 billion in aid to Egypt, adding to a total of more than $20 billion already contributed since the military ouster of President Mohamed Morsi of the Muslim Brotherhood nearly 20 months ago.

headline: Beyond Quinoa: The New Ancient Grains
abstract: Chefs in New York are being seduced by the same nutty, rich and earthy flavors and high nutritional content that lured our ancestors from berries and antelopes.
lead_paragraph: You’ve cooked your way through quinoa of every color, dabbled in amaranth and moved beyond millet. That farro and kale salad? It’s been in your dinner party rotation for at least two years.

headline: Is Your Babysitter an Employee? It Matters to Tax Liability
keywords: ['Taxation', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Child Care', 'Elder Care', 'Cleaning Services', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Federal Taxes (US)']
abstract: The I.R.S. has strict criteria on when a worker should be considered an employee, and it’s not just the difference between a babysitter and a nanny.
lead_paragraph: TAX time can be particularly taxing for families who pay an in-home caregiver or housekeeper.

headline: How Josh Lebowitz of Brother Jimmy’s Spends His Sunday
abstract: Mr. Lebowitz, the chairman of the company that owns the Brother Jimmy’s barbecue restaurant chain, puts his two young children first on Sundays.
lead_paragraph: March Madness is here, so let the basketball bacchanal begin. Outfitted with multiple screens and school logos, Brother Jimmy’s, the barbecue chain, blends school spirit and Southern hospitality. This time of year, college sports fans flock to its five Manhattan restaurants, overseen by Josh Lebowitz, chairman of Dining Entertainment Group. Not that the 45-year-old comes from a sports powerhouse; he played squash for Tufts University. On Sundays, Mr. Lebowitz is more likely to be at home, taking parent-proud videos with his phone (while monitoring restaurant security feeds), rather than out, carousing with regulars. He and his wife, Adriana, live with Logan, almost 3, and Wyatt, 5 months, in a TriBeCa loft.

headline: G.M. Settles Switch Suit, Avoiding Depositions
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Lawyers for the parents of Brooke Melton said General Motors agreed to settle a second lawsuit that linked her death to faulty ignitions in millions of cars.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — In a notable victory for General Motors, a lawsuit that helped spur the biggest safety crisis in the company’s history has been withdrawn in exchange for a settlement from its compensation program, according to two people briefed on the agreement.

headline: The Blurred Lines Between Homage and Plagiarism
abstract: Ben Sisario, Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss the “Blurred Lines” copyright trial, from the amazing Robin Thicke deposition to Pharrell Williams’s “bluegrass defense.”
lead_paragraph: The “Blurred Lines” trial wrapped up in Los Angeles this week. Robin Thicke and Pharrell Williams were ordered to pay the family of Marvin Gaye about $7.4 million in damages and profits earned, for what a federal jury understood to be a copyright infringement.

headline: Because It’s Friday
abstract: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. multitasks, doing curls while on the phone.
lead_paragraph: Michelle Obama’s latest part of the Let’s Move! initiative is called “GimmeFive,” which asks Americans to share five things they’re doing to live a healthy life.

headline: French Prosecutor Seeks Trial for HSBC’s Swiss Operation
abstract: The Swiss unit, HSBC Private Bank (Suisse), has a month to respond to judicial authorities before magistrates decide whether the case goes to trial.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — HSBC’s Swiss unit, the source of so much recent trouble for the British bank, has further problems.

headline: U.S. Targets Shabab Unit in Somalia
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Targeted Killings', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism']
abstract: It is unknown if a senior member of the Shabab militant group, believed to have helped plan the 2013 attack on the Westgate mall in Kenya, was killed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States has carried out airstrikes against a senior member of the Shabab extremist group who is believed to have helped plan the 2013 attack on the Westgate mall in Kenya, American officials said Friday.

headline: Kosher Supermarket Attacked in Paris to Reopen
abstract: Hyper Cacher, which has been closed since a Jan. 9 attack that left four people dead, is to welcome customers again starting on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Hyper Cacher, the kosher supermarket here that was targeted in a terrorist attack in January that left four people dead and deeply shook France’s Jews, will open its doors on Sunday, senior Jewish officials said on Friday.

headline: For Love of Country, and Each Other
abstract: A Marine captain intent on finding a soul mate outside the corps discovers her husband much closer to home.
lead_paragraph: When Capt. Lorelei M. Gaus moved from Camp Lejeune in North Carolina to Washington, D.C., in 2011, she was looking forward to living in a bustling city where her dating prospects would extend beyond Marines.

headline: On the Market in the New York Region
abstract: This week’s properties include a four-bedroom ranch on one-third of an acre in Flower Hill, N.Y., and a four-bedroom Tudor-style house in Summit, N.J.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties include a four-bedroom ranch on one-third of an acre in Flower Hill, N.Y., and a four-bedroom Tudor-style house in Summit, N.J.

headline: A Race Among Equals, and Also Dogs
abstract: Gender matters little in the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race, in which mushers drive their dogs through extreme Alaskan terrain and weather. Nearly a third of this year’s entrants were women.
lead_paragraph: Gender matters little in the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race, in which mushers drive their dogs through extreme Alaskan terrain and weather. Nearly a third of this year’s entrants were women.

headline: Enduring the Iditarod as Equals
keywords: ['Dog Sledding', 'Women and Girls', 'Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race (Alaska)']
abstract: Gender matters little in the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race, in which mushers drive their dogs through extreme Alaskan terrain. Nearly a third of this year’s entrants were women.
lead_paragraph: It is difficult to tell if the musher standing behind a sled pulled by 16 dogs and wearing a puffy red parka and a face protector shrouded in frost is a man or a woman. But in competitive sled dog racing, it does not really matter.

headline: Guardrails Said to Pass Safety Tests
abstract: Critics questioned the testing standards and pointed to the one test in which a bent piece of rail pushed a driver’s door in 6.75 inches.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A potentially dangerous guardrail cleared a crucial hurdle on Friday when federal officials released their analysis of four crash tests and gave the product passing grades, even for the final test, in which the driver’s door was severely damaged.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
abstract: This week’s properties include a four-bedroom ranch on one-third of an acre in Flower Hill, N.Y., and a four-bedroom Tudor-style house in Summit, N.J.

abstract: Video from the eighth crash test of a Trinity guardrail, which shows a Geo Metro spinning out after hitting the guardrail, causing the driver’s door to strike a bent piece of metal.
lead_paragraph: Video from the eighth crash test of a Trinity guardrail, which shows a Geo Metro spinning out after hitting the guardrail, causing the driver’s door to strike a bent piece of metal.

headline: International Criminal Court Formally Ends Case Against Kenya’s President
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The proceedings against President Uhuru Kenyatta were closed three months after prosecutors dropped charges linking him to postelection violence in 2007.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Criminal proceedings against President Uhuru Kenyatta of Kenya were formally closed on Friday by the judges of the International Criminal Court, three months after the prosecution dropped charges linking him to postelection violence in his country.

headline: Israel’s Inequality Election
abstract: Goodbye kibbutz, hello Gilded Age.
lead_paragraph: I haven’t been following Israeli politics at all — actually, if truth be told, after being out front so much against the Iraq venture, I’ve spent the era of financial crisis taking a personal vacation from Middle East issues. But I have noticed that Netanyahu is in big trouble — not over foreign policy and security, but over economics. Oddly, however, much of the reporting seems to either neglect or downplay the background here, which is the extraordinary rise in Israeli income inequality over the past generation. Here’s Israel compared with the US, from the LIS data:

headline: 3 Brooklyn Men Accused of Plotting to Aid ISIS Plead Not Guilty
abstract: The men, who were arrested last month and indicted this week, are accused of conspiring and attempting to provide material support to the organization also known as the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: Three Brooklyn men accused of plotting to join the Islamic State gave bare biographical details in response to a judge’s questions as they pleaded not guilty to various charges on Friday.

headline: Activists Crowd Into Bank of New York Mellon Fight
abstract: Aggressive investors can force good changes at companies. But too much clamor at once can distract from sensible initiatives already underway.
lead_paragraph: Bank of New York Mellon is under fire. Again. Marcato Capital Management is seeking to oust Gerald Hassell, chief executive of the $44 billion financial institution. That’s after Nelson Peltz’s activist hedge fund Trian Fund Management secured a board seat. Activism is starting to look like a crowded strategy.

headline: Fashionably Frozen in Time, Cobblestones Sells Vintage Clothing in the East Village
abstract: The conviviality of the proprietor of Cobblestones, Delanee Koppersmith, is inviting.
lead_paragraph: “Well, how are we today, young man?” the glamorous proprietor of Cobblestones, Delanee Koppersmith, sang out to a New York University student in horn-rimmed glasses who gingerly entered her vintage clothing store one snowy Tuesday. He was shopping for a gift for his long-distance girlfriend — always an intimidating prospect. The man broke into a relieved smile as Ms. Koppersmith started singing along to the Ella Fitzgerald tune playing in the store: “No, no, they can’t take that away from me ...”

headline: Neighborhood Joint: Cobblestones
abstract: Cobblestones, an East Village shop, is known for its vintage clothing, and for its convivial owner.
lead_paragraph: Cobblestones, an East Village shop, is known for its vintage clothing, and for its convivial owner.

headline: Islamist Websites in Turkey Manage to Evade Strict Internet Censorship
keywords: ['Censorship', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: A hallmark of Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s leadership has been a crackdown on freedom of expression, but critics say censorship reflects the government’s Islamist values.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The websites of an atheist association, the French satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo and a Kurdish separatist organization are blocked to Turkish Internet users. But many sites that promote extreme Islamist messages — even some that are outright sympathetic to the Islamic State, the militant organization that has marauded through Iraq and Syria — escape Turkey’s censors.

headline: A Site Finds the Fastest (and Slowest) Flights
abstract: The site FiveThirtyEight.com has introduced an interactive graphic to help users identify the fastest flight from one city to another.
lead_paragraph: As dynamic as its selection can be, browsing the Hudson News store or hunting for open electrical outlets is  not what most travelers look forward to when heading to the airport. Booking a flight has never been easier, but completing one seems to be proving more and more difficult.

headline: A Race Among Equals, and Also Dogs
abstract: Gender matters little in the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race, in which mushers drive their dogs through extreme Alaskan terrain and weather. Nearly a third of this year’s entrants were women.
lead_paragraph: Gender matters little in the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race, in which mushers drive their dogs through extreme Alaskan terrain and weather. Nearly a third of this year’s entrants were women.

headline: Credit Suisse Promotes New Bankers to Lead Mergers Advisory Unit
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Scott Lindsay, head of global M.&A., will become chairman of global M.&A., while Robin Rankin and Greg Weinberger will assume his previous role.
lead_paragraph: Credit Suisse has reshuffled its mergers and acquisitions ranks, according to an internal memo signed by James Amine, head of the investment banking division.

headline: Review: Andras Schiff Turns Mischievous at Carnegie Hall
abstract: Mr. Schiff’s program in the Isaac Stern Auditorium on Tuesday night included late sonatas by Haydn, Mozart, Beethoven and Schubert.
lead_paragraph: What was Andras Schiff, the eminent Budapest-born pianist, up to when he sat down to begin a recital program, the first of two, at Carnegie Hall this week? A part-time London resident who was knighted last year by Queen Elizabeth II, Mr. Schiff commands international respect as a paragon of refinement and musical integrity. Yet, on this night, as he settled into recital mode, was that a glint of mischief I caught in his eyes?

headline: Review: Thomas Adès Leads the Philharmonic, and Björk Listens
abstract: Mr. Adès’s debut leading the New York Philharmonic included the American premiere of his own “Totentanz.”
lead_paragraph: That elusive mix came to Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday: a real musical event that drew a packed house and a young audience — and even Björk. Listening was close, the excitement palpable and the applause spontaneous.

headline: Jay Z Buys the Music Streaming Firm, Aspiro
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Music', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: The rap star made a $56 million bid for the Swedish technology company and announced that it had acquired enough shares to take over.
lead_paragraph: It’s official: Jay Z is buying an online streaming company that competes with Spotify and Apple.

headline: Bolaño’s ‘2666’ Coming to the Stage, Thanks to a Powerball Jackpot
abstract: The Goodman Theater will produce an adaptation of Roberto Bolaño’s novel, with funds provided by Roy Cockrum, who won a Powerball jackpot in Tennessee last summer.
lead_paragraph: An actor and stage manager turned Episcopal monk who pledged last year to give away much of his $153 million Powerball jackpot to support the performing arts has made his first grant — to a theatrical production as improbable as his own story.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Going Clear’
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Going Clear: Scientology and the Prison of Belief.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Going Clear: Scientology and the Prison of Belief.”

headline: Vote for the Next Big City Book Club Selection
abstract: What should the Big City Book Club read next? Cast your vote.
lead_paragraph: We recently asked readers to suggest the selection for our next installment of the Big City Book Club, and great ideas came forth, with dozens of books nominated. We have narrowed the field down to three, representing a range of interests and eras, that also fit the criterion of being widely available, and we are asking you to vote on the final choice. The nominees are:

headline: Review: Jose Llana Radiates Youthful Bravado in ‘American Songbook’
abstract: Mr. Llana, who recently played Ferdinand Marcos in the musical “Here Lies Love,” projected a keen resolve to be himself in a concert at the Stanley H. Kaplan Penthouse.
lead_paragraph: Jose Llana may be 38. But this Filipino-American singer, who made his Broadway debut in 1996 singing “We Kiss in a Shadow,” in a revival of “The King and I,” radiated the eagerness and enthusiasm of a young pup in his American Songbook concert at the Stanley H. Kaplan Penthouse on Thursday evening.

headline: Visiting Le Corbusier’s Grave
abstract: We wanted to see where Corbu lived and died after reading a strange story: He kept his wife’s backbone.
lead_paragraph: This is the first piece in Gravehopping, a series within The End on visiting grave sites.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Cinderella’
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Cinderella.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Cinderella.”

headline: Mets Resolve Suit With Executive They Fired When She Was Pregnant and Unmarried
abstract: Leigh Castergine, a former senior vice president for ticket sales, and the Mets resolved the case on Friday, with no terms disclosed.
lead_paragraph: The discrimination accusations made last year by a former Mets executive portrayed the team and its chief operating officer, Jeff Wilpon, as intolerant of a pregnant, unmarried woman.

headline: Challenger Offers a Financial Plan for Chicago
abstract: Jesus G. Garcia, who is challenging Mayor Rahm Emanuel, did not say specifically how he would solve budget and pension shortfalls.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — After spending months avoiding questions about how he would solve Chicago’s dizzying fiscal problems, Jesus G. Garcia released a plan on Friday that he said would right the city’s “listing financial ship.”

headline: Housemate Takes Blame for Shining Laser at Planes in Bronx
keywords: ['Laser (Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation)', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Pilots', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Confessions']
abstract: Elehecer Balaguer, who is dating the stepsister of the man initially charged with the assault, said in court that it was he who actually shined the laser beam at pilots.
lead_paragraph: After being charged this week with injuring several pilots by shining a laser beam at their planes, Frank J. Egan was held up as a pest, his arrest an example of pinpoint investigative work leading the authorities to a typically elusive target.

headline: The Social Security Maze and Other U.S. Mysteries
abstract: Many government programs are needlessly complicated, and the Social Security system is one of the worst. A new book tries to guide the unwary.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, the Boston University economist Laurence J. Kotlikoff has made something of a game — and then, eventually, an art — of cornering smart people and convincing them that they were leaving tens of thousands of Social Security dollars on the table.

abstract: This week’s properties include co-ops in Chelsea and Manhattan Valley, and a house in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties include co-ops in Chelsea and Manhattan Valley, and a house in Brooklyn.

headline: Clinton Said to be Close to Choosing Brooklyn for Campaign Headquarters
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s aides are close to locking in space for a campaign headquarters in Brooklyn Heights.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s aides are close to locking in space for a campaign headquarters in Brooklyn, people familiar with the decision confirmed.

headline: Comings and Goings
abstract: The current hosts of “The View” are Whoopi Goldberg, Rosie Perez and Nicolle Wallace. Here is what their predecessors have gone on to do after leaving the show.
lead_paragraph: The current hosts of “The View” are Whoopi Goldberg, Rosie Perez and Nicolle Wallace. Here is what their predecessors have gone on to do after leaving the show.

headline: A Week of Beginnings
abstract: To kick off our Instagram account, @nytimes, we asked photographers to find stories about beginnings.
lead_paragraph: To kick off our Instagram account, @nytimes, we asked photographers to find stories about beginnings.

abstract: This week’s properties include co-ops in Chelsea and Manhattan Valley, and a house in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in New York City:

headline: Steve Ditko’s Thugs and Mystics
abstract: Two new books reinforce Mr. Ditko’s reputation as a master of Cold War paranoia.
lead_paragraph: An occasional series on vintage comics.

headline: The Rise of Early-Morning Dance Parties
abstract: At Daybreaker, people get started early in the morning without alcohol, cover fees or bottle service.
lead_paragraph: It was around 7:15 on a recent Tuesday morning when I realized, arms linked through his and lying, face up, on his back, that I had known this man — his name was Dijon, and he was wearing leggings — for only 10 minutes. We were in the middle of a partner yoga session at one of the San Francisco editions of Daybreaker, an early-morning dance party that descends, every month, on an increasing number of cities around the world.

headline: For Homeless Photographers, Pride of Place in Paris
abstract: In partnership with a charity, Paris’s city hall is exhibiting photographs taken by impoverished men and women who were given digital cameras and mentored.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The images capture a different Paris from the one beloved by tourists: refuse in a garbage bag that could be mistaken for a bloom on water; a dank tunnel opening onto a light-filled avenue of trees; a longhaired figure in a heavy coat silhouetted in a window, deeply alone.

headline: The Problem With ‘Fat Talk’
abstract: It makes you feel worse. And it harms others, too.
lead_paragraph: ON Tuesday, in the wake of an online petition signed by thousands of people, Facebook announced that it was removing “feeling fat” from its list of status update emoticons. The petition argued that the offending emoticon, with its chubby cheeks and double chin, reinforced negative body images, and Facebook seemed to agree.

headline: Review: ‘C.O.A.L (Confessions of a Liar)’ Opens at 59E59 Theaters
abstract: This new play by David Brian Colbert retraces a man’s life through the lies he told along the way.
lead_paragraph: When Tommy Maloney, a cocky first grader, mentions his $10-a-week allowance, Coal announces that he gets $100. And not only that, little Coal adds: “My dad is a pirate.”

headline: Rand Paul Focuses on Criminal Justice in Talk to Black Students
abstract: The senator discussed inequities in the judicial system in remarks at Bowie State University, a historically black college in Maryland.
lead_paragraph: BOWIE, Md. — Senator Rand Paul laid out his vision on Friday for a legal system that makes it easier for people with criminal records to get jobs and to vote, telling students at a historically black college here that he believes there are still “two Americas” as the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said almost a half century ago.

headline: Village Vanguard Celebrates Its 80th, Adding Poetry and Comedy to Jazz
abstract: The Greenwich Village jazz club puts stand-up comics and poets on the bill, along with Jason Moran and the Bandwagon.
lead_paragraph: The Village Vanguard is unlike most of the rest of New York life: a rarefied basement that’s been here since before most of us were born and will be here after we die. (Or perhaps not, but there seems no other way to think about it.) It is not a grasping or anxious place. It remains idiosyncratically competitive in the cultural marketplace, cultivates its own favorites, presents them regardless of whether the bands have something new to promote.

headline: In the Northeast, Retreating Snowbanks Hint at Spring, but Winter Is Not Over Yet
abstract: Snowbanks are retreating quickly in the East, but another cold blast is coming with spring’s arrival.
lead_paragraph: For two months, there was an intensifying sense of “when will it end” here in the Northeast, as persistent cold sustained banks of snow built by an exhausting sequence of storms.

headline: Review: Alabama Shakes Lifts Soul to a Different Plane
abstract: Led by Brittany Howard, the band unleashed raw confessions and extreme tempos at the second of two sold-out shows at the Beacon Theater.
lead_paragraph: A straightforward soul revival would be too banal for the Alabama Shakes, who finished a sold-out two-night stand at the Beacon Theater on Thursday night. It would be easy for the band to stay retro. Its lead singer, Brittany Howard, can be achingly subtle or an unstoppable force of nature; she also happens to be an authoritative lead guitarist. Ms. Howard and the rest of the band are steeped as well in the patient grooves and storytelling strategies of soul, particularly the sounds of Memphis and Muscle Shoals.

headline: More Networks Jumping on the Biblical Bandwagon
abstract: In the next few weeks, religion-themed shows will be found on NBC, CNN, PBS, the Smithsonian Channel, even the Weather Channel.
lead_paragraph: Television is largely a godless place, some would say, but not this month. Programs with biblical or other religious themes are sprouting up, some in places where you might not expect them. If nothing else, costumers who traffic in robes and sandals are doing a booming business.

lead_paragraph: Email use, college debt and appearances by 2016 White House hopefuls made headlines again this week.

headline: Review: In ‘Breaking Borders,’ a Chef Cooks for Sworn Enemies
abstract: In this series on the Travel Channel, a chef and journalist host grand dinners for foes in conflicts around the world.
lead_paragraph: Take a shopworn, simplistic concept, apply it in an unexpected way, and what do you get? An entertaining and informative travel program.

headline: ‘Cabaret’ and ‘Hedwig’ Get Tougher Onstage
abstract: Sienna Miller and John Cameron Mitchell, taking over roles played by other well-known actors, have given their characters new interpretations and new life.
lead_paragraph: The things a girl has to endure to get ahead in show business. The humiliation, the rejection, the objectification, the manhandling and — worst of all — the being treated as if you didn’t even exist. It’s enough to make even the sunniest chorine feel burned out by the end of a working night.

headline: A Bridge Deal From the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams
abstract: The Vanderbilt Knockout Teams is the premier event at the Spring North American Championships in New Orleans.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — The Vanderbilt Knockout Teams is the premier event at the Spring North American Championships here. Last year’s final was between the two favorites, Monaco (Fulvio Fantoni, Claudio Nunes, Geir Helgemo and Tor Helness) and Nickell (Nick Nickell, Ralph Katz, Bobby Levin, Steve Weinstein, Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell).

headline: ‘The View’: TV’s Most Dysfunctional Family
abstract: Nearly two decades of petty squabbles, dramatic walkouts and on-set outbursts have made “The View” both compelling viewing and a frequently exhausting experience for hosts and viewers alike.
lead_paragraph: For more than 17 years, “The View” has been TV’s most dysfunctional family.

headline: Remembering Lisa Adams
keywords: ['Cancer', 'Social Media', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Writing and Writers', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Death and Dying']
abstract: The death of a writer who became a friend to legions through social media leaves her followers feeling a personal loss.
lead_paragraph: Wendi Aarons stood in her kitchen in Austin, Tex., and looked at her iPhone. She felt a sudden rush of tears. She glanced at her husband and children, who were eating breakfast. She wasn’t sure she could articulate her sadness to them, so she turned to the place where she knew others would understand. “It is hard to explain to your family why you’re crying over the loss of someone you’ve never even had a cup of coffee with,” she posted to her Facebook page.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Review: Paul Taylor’s American Modern Dance Gala Looks to Past
abstract: Paul Taylor’s season has started, with “Sea Lark” in its New York premiere on Wednesday, and “Troilus and Cressida (reduced)” at its gala on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Paul Taylor’s “Sea Lark,” which had its New York premiere on Wednesday, is entirely disappointing. A trivial frolic set to Poulenc’s irresistibly energetic “Les Biches,” the dance, new in October, is a boating adventure, with painted waves, a large toy sailboat and boring young people being frightfully jolly. There are pleasures to be found in the bright color schemes of the costumes and sets by Alex Katz, a long-term Taylor collaborator, but they can’t save the day.

keywords: ['Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Magazines', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']

lead_paragraph: “I love working with all kinds of boundaries,” said the prolific independent magazine publisher Luis Venegas. “Or against them,” he added impishly.

headline: Meanwhile, Back in the Wall St. Bonus Pool
keywords: ['Bonuses', 'Income', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: A new report drives home just how excessive Wall Street bonuses are.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street bonuses are galling, a point that was driven home again this week with the release of the annual report on bonuses by the New York State comptroller.

headline: Taking On the Food Industry, One Blog Post at a Time
abstract: The writer of the Food Babe blog attracts numerous fans and critics with her comments on the food industry.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Thursday, Vani Hari, perhaps Public Enemy No. 1 of big food companies, sat at ABC Kitchen in the Flatiron district wearing a purple sweater with a giant pink heart and pink heart-shaped crystal earrings. Ms. Hari, 35, who is better known as Food Babe, the name of her blog, flipped through photographs of her that her mother had recently unearthed, pausing at one taken immediately after college at a Mexican restaurant.

headline: Stockard Channing and Friends Usher in a New Chelsea Bar
abstract: A night out with Ms. Channing, who currently stars in Terrence McNally’s name-dropping satire, “It’s Only a Play.”
lead_paragraph: Shopworn volumes lined the room, lanterns shed an amber light, and a pair of ancient bed irons weighed down the tartan tossed across the bed. Those cozy atmospherics didn’t escape Stockard Channing, who had gusted into the Lodge at Gallow Green, a new rooftop bar in Chelsea, on a blast of sleety air the other night.

abstract: In spring, a person’s fancy turns to online dating, and it doesn’t hurt to be prepared.
lead_paragraph: Thank you, ladies and gentlemen and those of you still making up your minds. Welcome to the OkCupid refresher course.

lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Friday ruled on behalf of Citizens United, a conservative advocacy group, in its lawsuit against the State Department for documents related to Hillary Rodham Clinton’s tenure there.

headline: Channeling a Hollywood Baby Boom for Charity
abstract: Kelly Sawyer Patricof and Norah Weinstein are the co-presidents of Baby2Baby, a charity for children that supplies diapers to low-income families.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Kelly Sawyer Patricof does not seem like the kind of woman who would devote her life to diapering the children of the poor.

lead_paragraph: A short visit with a friend led Rony Zakaria to spend years exploring how faith shapes the relationship between people and nature in Indonesia.

lead_paragraph: Not long ago, Jordan Rodman, a 23-year-old publicity assistant, was paying her respects at a shiva on the Upper West Side when her online dating life became a topic of conversation.

lead_paragraph: Steven Lutvak, 55, who composed “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love and Murder,” had given up on having a family until he met Michael T. McGowan. He used his talents to thank his fiancé with a wedding song.

headline: Bill Cunningham | The Return of Happy Days
abstract: Winter’s fierce grip was finally broken early this week, and people reacted by shedding their puffy coats and pouring into the parks for lunch.
lead_paragraph: Winter’s fierce grip was finally broken early this week, and people reacted by shedding their puffy coats and pouring into the parks for lunch. On Fifth Avenue, the police horses pranced joyfully. Men took off their socks and juggling classes began in Bryant Park along with table tennismatches. The winter covers were taken off the carousels and the kiddies rushed on. Even a few bicyclists seemed to jump for joy, balancing on one wheel.And a very stubborn puppy had to be dragged down Fifth Avenue by his owner.

headline: Evening Hours | Defrosted
abstract: Warmer temperatures brought extra cheer to the week’s celebrations.
lead_paragraph: Warmer temperatures brought extra cheer to the week’s celebrations.

abstract: Cartoons about current affairs from 2014.
lead_paragraph: Cartoons about current affairs from 2014.

headline: Bush Says He Has ‘Backbone’ on the Common Core
abstract: Speaking in New Hampshire, the likely presidential candidate implicitly criticized his rivals for shifting their stances on contested issues.
lead_paragraph: HUDSON, N.H. — Jeb Bush, making his first visit to New Hampshire as a likely presidential candidate, implicitly criticized his Republican rivals for the nomination for changing their positions on difficult issues.

headline: Digging Through the Jewels of the Past to Bring Customers a Morsel of Nostalgia
abstract: Libby Diament spends days scouring vintage earrings, bracelets and other pieces in warehouses and eBay before reintroducing them in a retro-inspired line.
lead_paragraph: One morning several weeks ago, Libby Diament prowled through the CJS Sales warehouse, in New York’s garment center, a cardboard box tucked under her arm. Ms. Diament, a jewelry designer based in Washington, D.C., uses vintage parts in her Diament Jewelry line, and she was at CJS Sales, a wholesale liquidator, looking for inspiration in the cartons crammed with closeout crystals, cameos and other components acquired from companies that had gone out of business.

headline: Video of Female Arab Anchor Shutting Down Rude Male Guest Amazes Western Viewers
abstract: A Lebanese television host achieved viral fame after she cut off a long-winded Islamist guest, in part because of inaccurate reports of what was said.
lead_paragraph: When a Lebanese television host, Rima Karaki, abruptly ended a live interview with an old friend of Al Qaeda’s leader, Ayman al-Zawahri, two weeks ago — cutting off his microphone when he told her to “be silent” and let him continue — her station, Al Jadeed, was so pleased with her performance that it proudly posted the clip on YouTube, where it earned praise from dozens of her fans.

headline: Albert Vecerka’s Harlem
abstract: A photographer’s view of a neighborhood’s changing streetscapes.
lead_paragraph: A photographer’s view of a neighborhood’s changing streetscapes.

headline: How Harlem Has Changed: Photographs by Albert Vecerka
abstract: The photographer Albert Vecerka’s images tell the story of a block, like Malcolm X Boulevard between 124th and 125th Streets, through its architecture.
lead_paragraph: Albert Vecerka first came to Harlem in 1993 to study architecture at the City College of New York, and he quickly learned two things. The first was that he was more interested in photographing buildings than in designing them. The second was that the neighborhood around him provided a story that could be told visually through its architecture. It was a story of money, which really does change everything: the height of buildings, the people living in them, the light in the morning or evening, the sounds and smells that constitute urban life.

headline: Queens Woman Pleads Guilty in Fatal 2012 Subway Shove
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Subways', 'Hate Crimes', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Erika Menendez will face 22 to 25 years in prison for pushing Sunnando Sen to the tracks at the 40th Street-Lowery Street station in Sunnyside.
lead_paragraph: A Queens woman who pushed a man to his death from an elevated train platform two years ago in what the authorities said was a hate crime pleaded guilty on Friday to first-degree manslaughter.

headline: Catholics, Plastic Surgery, and ‘the Truth of the Feminine Self’
abstract: A working paper issued before the recent Vatican plenary assembly on women offers a glimpse of the latest Catholic thinking about cosmetic surgery.
lead_paragraph: May a good Roman Catholic get a nose job? What about a tummy tuck? Or a breast enhancement? Does the tradition of Pope Francis, which has been getting such enthusiastic attention lately, have wisdom to offer about cosmetic surgery?

headline: Oil Prices Drop as Production Hums Along Despite a Brimming Supply
abstract: A report from the International Energy Agency warned that unabated oil production in the United States and elsewhere threatened to flood capacity and further undermine prices.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Just as the oil market appeared to be stabilizing, the price of crude resumed its descent on Friday.

headline: An Early History of Blacks on Madison Avenue
abstract: A reader asks, When did blacks manage to break down the barriers in advertising and become ad executives?
lead_paragraph: Q. I was reading about the new “Mad Men” exhibition at the Museum of the Moving Image, and I got to wondering: When did blacks manage to break down the barriers on Madison Avenue and become ad executives?

headline: Pope Francis Predicts His Papacy Will Be Brief

lead_paragraph: For generations of thrill-seeking New Yorkers, the city’s landscape of tall buildings and byways has been an obstacle course of adventure, a test of courage and stamina.

headline: Dell Williams, Founder of Sex Boutique, Dies at 92
abstract: Ms. Williams started Eve’s Garden, widely described as the nation’s first sex shop catering to women, after an embarrassing experience buying a vibrator at a department store.
lead_paragraph: Dell Williams, who in 1974, after being humiliated by a department-store clerk when she tried to buy a vibrator, was moved to start Eve’s Garden, the New York boutique widely described as the nation’s first sex shop catering specifically to women, died on Wednesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 92.

lead_paragraph: For most of Virginia Commonwealth University’s 70-67 victory over Richmond on Friday afternoon in the Atlantic 10 conference quarterfinals in Brooklyn, Briante Weber sat in a chair next to the V.C.U. bench and leaned against the scorers’ table.

lead_paragraph: This is the time of year when we start to think about global warming. Because the weather is about to get warmer. Please God.
