As the chaplain for the Villanova men’s basketball team, he had just been on the winning end of a Big East tournament quarterfinal game, feeling the highs of seeing the Wildcats advance to the next round. After his team departed the news conference room, Hagan stayed behind to listen to Marquette, the team Villanova had just defeated.

headline: You Try Living on the Minimum Wage
abstract: Gov. Andrew Cuomo has acknowledged that a person can’t survive on $8.75 an hour in New York City. But he has watered down his proposed solution.
lead_paragraph: Over half a million workers in New York State subsist on the minimum wage of $8.75 an hour. That’s about $18,000 a year for those working 40 hours a week. Anyone who thinks that is generous should try spending just $350 a week on food, housing, gas and heat.

headline: Turkey’s Drift From NATO
abstract: An increasingly ambivalent commitment to the alliance has Western allies worried.
lead_paragraph: The website of Turkey’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs acknowledges that NATO has played a “central role” in the country’s security and insists that Turkey, which became a member in 1952, “attaches utmost importance” to it. Yet Turkey’s commitment to the alliance has never seemed more ambivalent than it does now.

headline: U.S. Clinician With Ebola Under Care in Maryland
abstract: An American aid worker was infected while working in Sierra Leone, and he may have exposed colleagues in West Africa to the virus.

headline: As Yankees’ New Roommate, New York City F.C. Is Redecorating Carefully
abstract: On Friday, New York City F.C. players got their first look at their temporary home, Yankee Stadium, where the field will be converted from baseball to soccer several times during the season.
lead_paragraph: A few players at a time, New York City F.C. trickled into Yankee Stadium, which was receiving a power wash and a good scrub on Friday afternoon. Two days ahead of the home opener for N.Y.C.F.C., one of Major League Soccer’s two new teams, nearly all the players were getting their first peek at the club’s home for the next three seasons — and perhaps longer.

headline: Don’t Expect Math to Make Sense
abstract: Pi’s combination of utility and enigma is the perfect metaphor for the subject.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — EACH year, March 14 is Pi Day, in honor of the mathematical constant. Saturday is the once-in-a-century event when the year, ’15, brings the full date in line with the first five digits of pi’s decimal expansion — 3.1415. Typical celebrations revolve around eating pies and composing “pi-kus” (haikus with three syllables in the first line, one in the second and four in the third). But perhaps a better way to commemorate the day is by trying to grasp what pi truly is, and why it remains so significant.

headline: A Holocaust Survivor Tells of Auschwitz at 18 and, Again, at 90
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Concentration Camps', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: Eva Fahidi, who was sent to Auschwitz as a teenager, has been determined to share her memory of that place and to encourage scrutiny of the past.
lead_paragraph: BUDAPEST — HIGH above the hubbub of Budapest’s main tourist street, Eva Fahidi flits, birdlike, around her warm apartment, lined with books and plants. The setting is cozy, and the hostess and narrator, at 90, a lingeringly beautiful charmer. So the contrast with the Holocaust horror she is describing is all the more complete.

headline: Keep Mom Away From the Pet Rabbit: A Review of ‘The Effect of Gamma Rays on Man-in-the-Moon Marigolds,’ in Croton Falls
abstract: An experiment becomes a metaphor for the gloomy lives of the family in a revival of Paul Zindel’s play.
lead_paragraph: Beatrice, who dominates Paul Zindel’s “The Effect of Gamma Rays on Man-in-the-Moon Marigolds,” has scarcely taken the stage before she calls her youngest daughter ugly, sick, a stone tied around her neck. Within minutes she threatens to use chloroform on the girl’s pet rabbit, and you know what Chekhov taught us: If a gun, or in this case chloroform, is introduced in the first act, you’d better worry that it might be used by the last.

headline: A Funeral, an Heirloom, and What It All Means: A Review of ‘Bad Jews’ in New Haven
abstract: In his play at the Long Wharf Theater’s Stage II, Joshua Harmon is content to wring laughs from the manifestly unfunny situation.
lead_paragraph: If looks could kill, no one would survive long in Daphna Feygenbaum’s company. A senior at Vassar, she’s supersmart, superconceited and super-self-righteous. And she has no compunctions about flaunting her utter contempt for the lesser beings who cross her path, throwing them hostile glances and baleful stares. In “Bad Jews,” the corrosive comedy by Joshua Harmon at Long Wharf Theater’s Stage II, the objects of her scorn are her cousins, Jonah and Liam, and Liam’s latest non-Jewish girlfriend, Melody, whom Daphna rightly if rudely describes as having the appearance of something conceived in a Talbots store.

headline: Cuba: U.S. Diplomat to Return for Third Round of Talks
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: The United States and Cuba will hold a third round of talks next week about restoring diplomatic ties and reopening embassies.
lead_paragraph: The United States and Cuba will hold a third round of talks next week about restoring diplomatic ties and reopening embassies as they seek to work through sticking points that have emerged since President Obama and President Raúl Castro of Cuba announced a push toward normal relations in December. The talks were abruptly scheduled at the invitation of the Cubans. The United States will be represented by Roberta S. Jacobson, Washington’s top diplomat for the Americas. Ms. Jacobson will travel to Havana on Sunday, and a senior official at the State Department said she would probably stay until midweek. No announcements were expected, but the sides planned to discuss issues holding up plans to reopen embassies before a regional summit meeting in April. Cuba wants to be removed from the State Department’s list of nations that sponsor international terrorism and seeks access to banking for its diplomatic posts in the United States. American officials are pushing for an increase in the number of staff members at the planned American Embassy in Havana and unrestricted travel for diplomats on the island. The two sides held talks in Havana in January and in Washington last month, reporting progress but no breakthroughs.

headline: Myanmar Warplane Kills Four Farmers in China
abstract: One or more bombs released from a warplane from Myanmar Friday struck a sugar cane field, as fighting between government forces and an ethnic group pressed against the frontier with China.

headline: Portugal’s Heritage, Soaked in Wine and Garlic: A Review of Primavera Pub in Hartford

headline: Warming Up for Love
abstract: These poems about love amid the thaw were all found in recent days in the Missed Connections section at newyork.craigslist.org.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a winter in which, like worried prehistoric tribesmen, many of us wondered whether the snow and cold would ever end. But now that they have — at least for the moment — people have opened their jackets and their hearts. These poems about love amid the thaw were all found in recent days in the Missed Connections section at newyork.craigslist.org. They are reprinted verbatim with only line and stanza breaks added; their titles are their subheadings.

headline: Serena Williams Gets a Win and an Ovation in Her Return to Indian Wells
abstract: Williams spoke of creating “new memories” after defeating Monica Niculescu, 7-5, 7-5, in her first tournament appearance at Indian Wells since the 2001 final.
lead_paragraph: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — Serena Williams was conspicuously absent from the BNP Paribas Open for 13 years, so she could be forgiven for lingering in her return. Making her first appearance at the tournament since the 2001 final, Williams, the world No. 1, defeated Monica Niculescu, 7-5, 7-5, in 2 hours 3 minutes in front of fans so firmly behind her, their cheers were like a wind at her back.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) TAMMY (2014) After losing her car, her job and her husband in a single day, a fast-food worker (Melissa McCarthy) embarks on an adventure of self-discovery in a blue Cadillac with her grandmother (Susan Sarandon), like an intergenerational Thelma and Louise. “Tammy’s journey, as they like to say in movieland, is into self-worth,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times about this road movie, written by Ms. McCarthy with her husband, Ben Falcone, who directed. “Yet the far more interesting trip here, at least until her self-actualization kicks in, is through an America of lousy jobs, tyrannical bosses, nickel-and-diming poverty and real-looking women.” The jokes about Tammy’s appetite “register as both tedious and borderline desperate,” Ms. Dargis added, and suggest that Ms. McCarthy may not yet be comfortable in her own skin on screen. “But the radicalness of Ms. McCarthy’s success,” she added, “is that she’s a beautiful, funny, wildly popular female comic with terrific timing, movie star presence and oodles of charm. That she also happens to be fat may be historically notable although it is, finally, the most ordinary thing about her.”

abstract: The remaining issues in the talks on Iran’s nuclear program include when economic sanctions would be lifted and how inspections would be conducted.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States and Iran are closing in on a historic agreement to limit Iran’s nuclear program, but are confronting serious last-minute obstacles, including when United Nations sanctions would be lifted and how inspections would be conducted, American and European officials said.

headline: Cyclone Hits Island Nation of Vanuatu, Killing 8
abstract: Tropical Cyclone Pam bore down on the island nation of Vanuatu with winds of around 160 miles an hour.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A cyclone mauled the Pacific island nation of Vanuatu on Saturday, killing at least eight people, tearing apart many homes and leaving residents to fear even worse death and destruction on remoter parts of the archipelago that remained out of contact.

headline: ‘Unfriended’ and ‘The Final Girls’ Generate Screams at SXSW
abstract: A selection of horror films made for a particularly creepy Friday the 13th at the SXSW film festival.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — On Friday the 13th, the South by Southwest film festival started off with a creepy and occasionally funny bang. Audiences had a variety of horror options, including demon possession dramas, haunted Skype chillers and ’80s slasher remixes.

headline: Seattle’s Magic Number for Playoffs? 700 Runs, Manager Says
abstract: Lloyd McClendon, the Mariners’ manager and a former hitting coach, wants his team to score 700 runs, something it has failed to do the past seven seasons.
lead_paragraph: PEORIA, Ariz. — Lloyd McClendon has a figure in mind for the Seattle Mariners, a dream that has eluded this franchise in each of the last seven seasons. McClendon, the Mariners’ manager and a former hitting coach, wants his team to score 700 runs.

headline: Americans Evacuated From Sierra Leone After Possible Ebola Contact
abstract: The group of 10 aid workers, with the group Partners in Health, may have come in contact with the virus in Sierra Leone, officials said.
lead_paragraph: The first of a group of 10 American aid workers who may have come into contact with the Ebola virus in Sierra Leone were evacuated on Saturday, American government and aid officials said. They will be the largest group of Americans to have returned home over fears of exposure to the virus since an outbreak in three West African countries was declared last year.

headline: Stephen J. Immelt of Hogan Lovells: Raised to Believe ‘You Can Fix This’
abstract: The chief executive of a global law firm says he came to appreciate that in an international setting “your own views about how the world is set up go out the window.”
lead_paragraph: This interview with  Stephen J. Immelt, C.E.O. of Hogan Lovells, an international law firm, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: S.E.C. Wants the Sinners to Own Up
keywords: ['Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: In a shift to its policy, the regulator is asking for more than settlements. It wants companies and individuals to admit to their misdeeds.
lead_paragraph: For decades, the Securities and Exchange Commission has allowed companies and individuals to make settlements without admitting any wrongdoing. Even a company committing an egregious sin that cost investors millions of dollars could walk away from the proceedings without ever acknowledging its role.

headline: A World Cup Late in the Year Promises Smiles and Headaches
abstract: A November-December World Cup could cause potentially major financial hits for professional leagues and competitions in Europe, Australia and elsewhere, but it is good news for the Olympics, Wimbledon, audiences in Asia and marketers.
lead_paragraph: Presumably even the credulity-straining organization that is FIFA would have voted for a host other than Qatar if it had been clear the 2022 World Cup was to be held in November and December.

headline: A New Look for College?
abstract: Readers discuss the pluses and minuses of the online learning model.
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss the pluses and minuses of the online learning model.

headline: The Church of TED
keywords: ['TED Conference', 'Religion and Belief', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The popular talks are today’s evangelical tent revivals.
lead_paragraph: CHANCES are you will not attend TED this year. Tickets to the gathering that begins Monday in Vancouver are sold out, this despite or rather because of the fact that gaining entry to the ideas conference entails more than pulling out your credit card. There’s a velvet rope of an application process, and questions to answer: “How would a friend describe your accomplishments?” “What are you passionate about?” Two references have to vouch for you.

headline: What My Friends Mean to Me
abstract: If only there were some way — besides calling or visiting — to show I cared.
lead_paragraph: MY phone doesn’t ring much anymore. It used to at all hours, but since I stopped answering, most of my friends have stopped calling. Mostly, I receive invitations by email, which is good, as it gives me time to compose my regrets. “I’m way too busy this week, how about next month?” All week I field invitations this way, worried constantly about my schedule being overwhelmed. Then the weekend arrives, and I find myself with nothing to do.

headline: Birth of a Freedom Anthem
keywords: ['Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Music', 'Income Inequality', 'Organized Labor', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Discrimination', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)']
abstract: The long, biracial history of “We Shall Overcome.”
lead_paragraph: FRESNO, Calif. — FIFTY years ago today, on March 15, 1965, President Lyndon B. Johnson announced plans to submit a new voting rights bill before a joint session of Congress. His speech came after several weeks of violence in and around Selma, Ala., that had taken the lives of two civil rights activists and left dozens of others bloodied. Seventy million Americans watched on television as Johnson, a Texas Democrat who had supported segregationist policies early in his career, proclaimed racial discrimination not a “Negro problem” but “an American problem.” It is not, he said, “just Negroes, but really it is all of us, who must overcome the crippling legacy of bigotry and injustice.” Then, after a pause, he added, “And we shall overcome.”

headline: A Christian Nation? Since When?
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Corporations', 'Religion and Belief', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Big business promoted “Christian libertarianism.”
lead_paragraph: AMERICA may be a nation of believers, but when it comes to this country’s identity as a “Christian nation,” our beliefs are all over the map.

headline: College Applications and Criminal Records
abstract: Screening prospective students for convictions is driving away large numbers of people who present no danger to campus safety and are capable of succeeding.
lead_paragraph: Americans who have criminal histories are often stymied when they encounter college entry applications that ask if they have ever been convicted of crimes. The process, which often brings greater scrutiny to people who answer “yes,” is driving away large numbers of people who present no danger to campus safety and are capable of succeeding academically.

headline: Slavery’s Enduring Resonance
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Slavery (Historical)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Equal Educational Opportunities', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Discrimination']
abstract: My family owned people. What would those people think of America today?
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — LAST week, a milestone passed for my family in South Carolina — the 150th anniversary of the last day of slavery. We were the slaveholders.

headline: Offering a Choice to the Terminally Ill
abstract: Health care providers in states where assisted suicide is illegal face wrenching decisions.
lead_paragraph: Last year, the radio host Diane Rehm watched in agony as her husband, John, starved to death over the course of 10 days.

headline: The Strip
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Letters', 'Comic Books and Strips']
abstract: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.
lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: More and Better Telecom Options
keywords: ['Net Neutrality', 'Editorials', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Wireless Communications', 'Consumer Protection']
abstract: Congress should certainly review the nation’s main communications law, but it should revise it only if doing so would serve consumers’ interests.
lead_paragraph: Even before the Federal Communications Commission adopted strong net neutrality rules last month, some Republican lawmakers were saying that what the country really needed was an update to the nation’s main communications law. It is old, they argued, and does not address the ways in which people use the Internet today. Congress should certainly review the law, but it should be careful not to undermine a statute that has contributed to the success of the Internet and wireless telecommunications.

headline: To Kill a Chicken
keywords: ['Chickens', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Slaughterhouses', 'Poultry', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Livestock']
abstract: Most Americans don’t want animals killed for food to suffer needlessly. Yet that’s exactly what happens to hundreds of thousands of chickens every year.
lead_paragraph: IF you torture a single chicken and are caught, you’re likely to be arrested. If you scald thousands of chickens alive, you’re an industrialist who will be lauded for your acumen.

headline: For Poorer and Richer
keywords: ['Poverty', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Income Inequality', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: In a substantially poorer past, lower-income Americans found a way to cultivate monogamy, fidelity, sobriety and thrift.
lead_paragraph: SOME arguments are hard to settle but are too important to avoid. Here is one: whether the social crisis among America’s poor and working class — the collapse of the two-parent family, the weakening of communal ties — is best understood as a problem of economics or of culture.

headline: An Open Letter to hdr22@clintonemail.com
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'E-Mail', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Since open letters to secretive regimes are in fashion, here’s one to the Leaders of the Clinton Republic of Chappaqua.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — SINCE open letters to secretive and duplicitous regimes are in fashion, we would like to post an Open Letter to the Leaders of the Clinton Republic of Chappaqua:

headline: Gabriele Rausse
abstract: The director of gardens at Monticello on Elvis Presley, Swiss newspapers and making wine from Thomas Jefferson’s grapes.
lead_paragraph: Gabriele Rausse is the director of gardens and grounds at Monticello, Thomas Jefferson’s former home and experimental farm in Charlottesville, Va.

headline: Don’t Mess With Auntie Jean
keywords: ['Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: The civil rights movement was part of our immediate past, something that could have killed my mom and her siblings.
lead_paragraph: EVERYONE in my family has an Auntie Jean story.

headline: Lessons From a Traffic Light
abstract: Why we are afraid of getting what we want.
lead_paragraph: Jeremy will be here in a few minutes. I like Jeremy enormously and really want to help him. But I know how it will go. He’ll smile and apologize. He’ll talk about feeling weak and inarticulate and unsuccessful. He’ll be angry with his father for being dismissive and pigheaded. I’ll struggle to find a new way to speak to him about these old issues. We’ll both sound repetitive and tired. But right now, in these several minutes before his session, I sip my coffee and observe the pedestrians outside my window.

headline: How Many Mutual Funds Routinely Rout the Market? Zero
abstract: An ongoing S.&P. Dow Jones study finds a shrinking number of actively managed mutual funds that have managed to outperform the market in recent years.
lead_paragraph: The bull market in stocks turned six last Monday, and despite some rocky stretches — like last week, when the market fell — it has generally been a very pleasant time for money managers, who have often posted good numbers.

headline: Coaxing a Tight-Lipped Insurer to Speak Up
abstract: The health services company Optum denied a claim because of an incorrect code, but it would not tell its client the correct one, or much of anything at all.
lead_paragraph: To begin, a quick update from our last episode, which was about Ideal Image, the laser hair-removal chain. In 2013, the company began including skin care products with treatments. The products were promoted as free, but the price for services went up by the same amount as the retail price of those oils and lotions once they were part of the treatment package — adding $250 or more to the bill.

headline: An Ever-Bleaker Syria, From All Vantage Points
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Syria enters its fifth year of conflict amid a growing humanitarian crisis that is echoing far from its borders.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Government helicopters rained barrel bombs on villages across Syria last week, killing civilians and demolishing homes. Hundreds of combatants died in battles that failed to move the front lines. And activists spread videos of hungry, war-weary Syrians through social media.

headline: Auditioning for the Role of Young Professional
keywords: ['Careers and Professions', 'Television', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: How a year of moonlighting as an actress turned an entry-level office worker into a survivor.
lead_paragraph: Working as an employee can be infantilizing, as I discovered during the two entry-level office jobs I held as a recent college graduate in the late 1980s. Take no more than an hour for lunch and await your biweekly paycheck the way a hatchling anticipates a worm. Request vacation and hope for approval from on high. Learn whether you’ve been good or bad in your annual review.

headline: Nassau Coliseum Offers Little Room for TV Crews or Visiting Backup Goalies
abstract: The Islanders are vying for the N.H.L.’s best record, despite playing in an antiquated building with space-challenged announcing spots and less-than-optimal camera positions.
lead_paragraph: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — Brian Engblom was looking forward to one last visit to Nassau Coliseum, even if it meant wedging himself into a corner of the Islanders’ bench.

headline: Walkie Talkie
abstract: The secret language of professional dog walkers.
lead_paragraph: The secret language of professional dog walkers.

headline: Chinese General Warns Myanmar Over Bombing
abstract: A Chinese military commander warned of a strong response unless Myanmar prevented warfare with ethnic rebel groups from spilling into Chinese territory, deepening the tensions between the two countries.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Tensions between China and Myanmar deepened on Saturday when a Chinese military commander warned of a strong response unless Myanmar prevented warfare with ethnic rebel groups from spilling into Chinese territory.

headline: The Child of a College Basketball Referee Recalls Years of Fairness
abstract: A daughter looks back at the career of her father, who recently retired after 41 years as an N.C.A.A. Division I men’s basketball official.
lead_paragraph: My father, Michael Eggers, was an N.C.A.A. Division I men’s basketball official for 41 years. Few, if any, officials have been able to say the same, or ever will.

headline: New Hampshire, Shaping Up as Free-for-All, Gets Early G.O.P. Attention
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The New Hampshire primary has often proved crucial in determining party nominees and eventual presidents, but the already-crowded 2016 Republican race could prove especially critical.
lead_paragraph: DOVER, N.H. — The Belknap County Republican Committee’s “First-in-the-Nation Presidential Sunset Dinner Cruise” on Lake Winnipesaukee is still over two months away. But three potential presidential prospects have already committed, and Alan S. Glassman expects even more candidates to join the annual fund-raiser on New Hampshire’s largest lake.

headline: Chris Wallace of Fox News: Not the Biggest Office, but the One That Gets the Guests
abstract: The office of Chris Wallace, the anchor of “Fox News Sunday,” features many reminders of his reporting career, including a poster given to him by Donald Rumsfeld.
lead_paragraph: A capital spot

headline: 14 Students Are Accused in Los Angeles Sexual Assaults
abstract: Fourteen students at Venice High School are under investigation in a series of assaults involving two underage schoolmates that investigators believe started in December 2013.
lead_paragraph: Ten male students at a Los Angeles high school have been arrested in a series of sexual assaults against two underage girls that went on for more than a year and recently intensified, the police said, and officers on Saturday were searching for four more boys who are suspects in the case.

headline: A Victory for Both Serena Williams and Indian Wells
abstract: Williams returned to the Indian Wells tournament after a 13-year boycott, and the occasion proved emotional for everyone involved.
lead_paragraph: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — Ray Moore sat in an office at Indian Wells Tennis Garden Stadium on Friday evening, the picture of a weary but contented man.

headline: 5 Teenagers in Custody After Attack on Another Girl in Brooklyn
abstract: Investigators were seeking a sixth girl in connection with the assault at a McDonald’s on Flatbush Avenue on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Ariana Taylor, 15, lay limp on the beige tile floor of a McDonald’s in Brooklyn, her body crumpled. For two minutes, the blows had rained down, her head caught in a windmill of swinging fists before being kicked seven times by one of her attackers.

headline: Nun Raped During Robbery at Convent School in India
abstract: Men armed with knives broke into the Convent of Jesus and Mary in Ranaghat and stole about $9,000 in cash and valuables, a police official said. One of them raped the nun, the Catholic archbishop of Kolkata said.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A nun in her 70s was raped during the robbery of a convent school in West Bengal before dawn on Saturday, police and church officials said.

headline: Rev. Willie T. Barrow, a Fighter for Civil Rights, Dies at 90
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: Ms. Barrow campaigned on behalf of minorities, women, gays and other groups, as well as serving as a mentor to activists, including Barack Obama.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Willie T. Barrow, who championed civil rights for minorities, women, gay people and consumers; opposed the war in Vietnam and apartheid; and mentored generations of community organizers, including a young Chicagoan named Barack Obama, died on Thursday at her home in Chicago. She was 90.

headline: Brian Sutton-Smith, Scholar of What’s Fun, Dies at 90
abstract: Professor Sutton-Smith sought to answer fundamental questions: What is play? Why do human beings engage in it? What psychological, cognitive and cultural functions does it serve?
lead_paragraph: Brian Sutton-Smith, a developmental psychologist whose work — prolific, scholarly and precedent-setting — was quite literally child’s play, died on March 7 in White River Junction, Vt. He was 90.

headline: Hillary Clinton Seeks to Reassure Democrats on Email Controversy
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton wasn’t speaking to reporters when she gave her 21-minute press conference earlier this week about her State Department emails. She was talking to Democratic voters and seeking to assure them that the controversy could be easily explained.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton was not speaking to reporters when she gave her 21-minute news conference this week about her State Department emails. She was talking to Democratic supporters and seeking to assure them that the controversy could be easily explained.

headline: Swedish Prostitution Law Targets Buyers, but Some Say It Hurts Sellers
abstract: More than 15 years after it criminalized the purchase of sex while allowing its sale, Sweden continues to grapple with issues that could limit progress in reducing prostitution and trafficking.
lead_paragraph: GOTHENBURG, Sweden — Not far from the Sticky Fingers nightclub, three Romanian women were hunched against the cold on a street corner. When a man walked by, the women, in broken Swedish and English, tried to tempt him to buy sex.

headline: Breaking Silence, Survivor Sets Out to Meet Holocaust Past
keywords: ['Movies', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Concentration Camps', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: Tomi Reichental, who was sent to a concentration camp as a child, has mesmerized students in Ireland with his stories of wartime atrocities.
lead_paragraph: MULTYFARNHAM, Ireland — The setting could hardly have been more incongruous. Outside the window, lush pastures spread in the perfection of a late winter morning. Inside, a small man with a yellow star pinned to his sweater captivated an audience with the horrors of his boyhood in the concentration camp called Bergen-Belsen.

headline: Davidson Math Students Lend a Hand to Basketball Team
abstract: A math professor and his students presented a way to show the efficiency of every five-man lineup that No. 24 Davidson used in games this season.
lead_paragraph: Before Davidson’s first season in the Atlantic 10, the conference’s preseason poll forecast the Wildcats to finish 12th out of 14 teams.

headline: Making Connections

headline: Hanley Ramirez Has New Position and Attitude in Return to the Red Sox
abstract: After nine seasons as a shortstop and third baseman with the Marlins and the Dodgers, Hanley Ramirez has returned to the Red Sox as a left fielder.
lead_paragraph: FORT MYERS, Fla. — Missing out on the Red Sox’ World Series championship in 2007 was particularly agonizing for Hanley Ramirez. The Red Sox were supposed to be his team, and he was supposed to be the star shortstop with a World Series ring, maybe two.

lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Coach Tom Izzo’s voice is comfortably in late-season form, sounding as grizzled and raw as ever.

lead_paragraph: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India brought his rock-star appeal to this island nation Saturday in a visit that has charmed this once deeply divided society.

headline: More Democrats Are Going Their Own Way, and That’s Away From Obama
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Trans-Pacific Partnership']
abstract: President Obama is finding that his biggest difficulties in pushing his agenda in Congress lately are not with Republicans but with members of his own party.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congressional Republicans may be singularly focused on unraveling President Obama’s executive orders and actions, but when it comes to what is left of his viable policy agenda on Capitol Hill, Mr. Obama’s biggest problems are now often with Democrats.

lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Ben Rubin arrived here completely invigorated.

headline: SXSW 2015: A First Look at ‘Angie Tribeca,’ Steve Carell’s New TV Series
keywords: ['South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: Steve Carell and Rashida Jones bring their new TV comedy “Angie Tribeca” to the festival.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — The first five minutes of the pilot for the TBS comedy “Angie Tribeca,” co-created by Steve Carell, contain more gags than a full episode of most sitcoms. It starts with the titular police officer (Rashida Jones) going through her morning training ritual, which becomes more and more outrageous as the scene progresses. In the tradition of spoof comedy series like “Police Squad” and “Sledge Hammer” this new show takes satirical aim at the procedural. The festival showed the first two episodes as part of their Episodic program, which presents television premieres.

headline: A Frontier Land Dispute, Circa 2015, Pits Modernization Against the Past
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Land Use Policies', 'ARCHITECTURE']
abstract: As in many larger cities across the country, modernization and history are facing off in Cheyenne, Wyo., the scene of a battle over the fate of three homes.
lead_paragraph: CHEYENNE, Wyo. — For five years, a sign has stood on a patch of grass in this small city, beckoning to each passer-by. “FREE houses,” it reads, along with a phone number.

headline: A Scratch, but Little Concern for Zack Wheeler
abstract: Wheeler, the Mets’ right-handed starter, did not make a scheduled start on Saturday, but he insisted that it was only because of minor discomfort and that he would have started if it were a regular-season game.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Throughout his young career and without the public’s knowledge, Zack Wheeler, the Mets’ right-handed starter, has pitched at times with tenderness in his right elbow. Last year, it flared up more than usual, but he still made every start, threw every bullpen session and had a fine season.

headline: One Dies and Three Are Rescued After Tugboat Sinks Near Fire Island
abstract: The tugboat, which sank after radioing for help on Saturday afternoon, had been doing work on the eastern tip of Long Island, the Coast Guard said.
lead_paragraph: One man died when a tugboat sank off the coast of Fire Island on Saturday, said the Coast Guard, which rescued three other members of the ship’s crew from frigid ocean waters one mile offshore.

headline: Late Shot Extends Harvard’s Run and Yale’s Drought in Ivy League

lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — It was a throwback game played in a throwback gym, Harvard’s spellbinding 53-51 victory over Yale on Saturday, a sublime relic of dusty yearning and desperation.

headline: A Young Manager for Clinton Juggles Data and Old Baggage

headline: Al Rosen, Who Missed Triple Crown by a Step, Dies at 91

lead_paragraph: Al Rosen, a slugging third baseman for the Cleveland Indians who was unanimously named the American League’s most valuable player in 1953, when he came within a hit of winning the batting triple crown, but whose career was cut short by injury, died on Friday in Rancho Mirage, Calif. He was 91.

abstract: The couple will be married at L’Espalier Restaurant in Boston.
lead_paragraph: Max Avi Kaplan, the son of Grisel A. Kaplan and Michael J. Kaplan of Westfield, N.J., and Dr. Seth Nathan Levin, a son of Bernice K. Levin and Mark L. Levin of Assonet, Mass., are to be married Sunday. Rabbi Katy Allen, staff chaplain at Brigham and Women’s Hospital, will officiate at L’Espalier, a restaurant in Boston.

headline: Ashley Futrell and Fletcher Smith III
abstract: Ashley Futrell and Fletcher Smith III were married Saturday in Greenville, S.C.
lead_paragraph: Ashley Ann Futrell and Fletcher Nathaniel Smith III were married Saturday evening at Allen Temple A.M.E. Church in Greenville, S.C. The Rev. James E. Speed Sr., a pastor in the African Methodist Episcopal Church, performed the ceremony.

headline: Mary Gazella,  Gabe Ghearing
abstract: The bride and groom have changed their surnames to Giosia.
lead_paragraph: Mary Christine Gazella and Gabe Ryan Ghearing were married Saturday at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York. The Rev. Scott Black Johnston, a Presbyterian minister and the senior pastor at the church, performed the ceremony.

headline: Stephanie Kane,  Eric Hochberger
abstract: The bride works for Fox News and the groom is an owner of two companies in Florida.
lead_paragraph: Stephanie Augusta Kane and Eric Philip Hochberger are to be married Sunday by Cantor Carrie Barry at Casa Marina, a hotel in Key West, Fla.

headline: Christine Hew and Dawson Kaaua
abstract: The couple was married at Kahua Ranch in Kamuela, Hawaii.
lead_paragraph: Christine Mika Pualoke Nyuk Foon Hew and Dawson Kealakekuawela Zenho Kaaua were married Saturday at Kahua Ranch in Kamuela, Hawaii. The Rev. Tom Fernandez, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated.

headline: Elizabeth Ackerman,  Matthew LaCasse
abstract: The bride and groom, who met at Yale, were married in Big Sky, Mont.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Warren Ackerman and Matthew Parrish LaCasse were married Saturday at the Big Sky Chapel in Big Sky, Mont. The Rev. Brad Lartigue, a Southern Baptist minister and the chaplain of Big Sky Resort, performed the ceremony.

headline: Running and Traveling the World Over
abstract: The couple, who met at Yale, want to complete a half-marathon in every state and a full marathon on every continent.
lead_paragraph: Sophia Mengfei Lee and Christopher Alan Suarez were married Saturday at the Edison Park Lutheran Church in Chicago. The Rev. Dr. Michael D. Sparby, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony.

headline: Steven Lutvak,  Michael McGowan
abstract: One man is a composer and lyricist, and the other is the head of a school’s performing arts department.
lead_paragraph: Steven Jaret Lutvak and Michael Todd McGowan were married Saturday evening at Lafayette Grand Café and Bakery in New York. Cantor Daniel Neiden officiated.

headline: Bus Plunges Off Cliff in Brazil, Killing Scores of Passengers
abstract: At least 40 people were killed after the driver of the bus carrying families to an evangelical Christian event in Paraná State lost control, officials said.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — A bus plunged off a cliff in the southern Brazilian state of Santa Catarina on Saturday, killing more than 40 people, emergency response officials said.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (E!) THE ROYALS Elizabeth Hurley and Vincent Regan portray the foul-mouthed Queen Helena and bewildered King Simon, the rulers of a decadent if fictional British dynasty in this nighttime soap, the network’s first scripted series. Leading their unruly brood is Prince Liam (William Moseley, above center, with Ms. Hurley and Mr. Regan), the heir apparent after his older brother dies, who angers his mother by sleeping with the daughter (Merritt Patterson) of the queen’s head of security. Princess Eleanor (Alexandra Park), meanwhile, likes to drink, take drugs, seduce servants and bodyguards, and party in Paris nightclubs without any underwear. “The Royals” “should be a hoot, but it actually gets old, and dull, very quickly,” Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. “It turns out that campy faux queens and princes can’t keep up with the real-life Elizabeth II and her progeny — or with reality show royals.” The Season 10 opener of “Keeping Up With the Kardashians” — in which Kim and her husband, Kanye West, have sex in a bathroom, and family members act as if nothing were going on with Bruce Jenner, despite his ponytail and changing face — leads in at 9. Of the two series, “the Kardashians are better at keeping up appearances,” Ms. Stanley added. “The monarchy has survived in Britain for so many centuries partly because it protects its mystique and doesn’t bend to reality. The Kardashians have held onto their perch on cable television for 10 seasons for much the same reason.”

headline: Sex and Violence, Beyond the Script
abstract: A group of actors is pressing unions and others to create clear-cut protocols for registering and handling grievances about harassment in the theater.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2012 the actress Marin Ireland, a past Tony Award nominee, was dating Scott Shepherd, a fellow theater star. They were in London, preparing to perform as the title lovers in “Troilus and Cressida.” Offstage, though, they were arguing about their relationship. According to interviews with both, Ms. Ireland slapped Mr. Shepherd one night at their apartment; two nights later he slapped her with enough force that he knocked her to the floor. When Ms. Ireland walked into rehearsal the next morning, she had a black eye.

headline: Corrections: March 15, 2015
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Sunday, March 15, 2015
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Myanmar Is Issued Warning by Chinese Premier Over Bombing Deaths
abstract: China’s premier, Li Keqiang, condemned the deaths of four Chinese farmers he said were killed by a bomb from a Myanmar warplane.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China’s premier, Li Keqiang, delivered his government’s highest-profile warning yet to Myanmar over violence spilling across the border, when he used an annual news conference on Sunday to condemn the deaths of four Chinese farmers he said were killed by a bomb from a Myanmar warplane.

headline: Chinese Premier Vows Tougher Regulation on Air Pollution
keywords: ['Air Pollution', 'Web-Original Programming', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions']
abstract: Premier Li Keqiang acknowledged that there was a gap between the government’s efforts and public ire about pervasive smog.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Premier Li Keqiang of China said on Sunday that the government was failing to satisfy public demands to stanch pollution and would impose heavier punishments to cut the toxic smog that was the subject of a popular documentary belatedly banned by censors.

headline: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the week’s top stories.

headline: In Los Angeles, a Street-Smart Art Tour
abstract: Art and Seeking offers public-art tours in and around Los Angeles, including works by Hueman and Paige Smith.
lead_paragraph: While preparing to teach a contemporary art course last spring, Lizy Dastin found herself exploring urban art sprinkled throughout Los Angeles, be it tucked away in a park, splashed across the side of a building or painted on a sidewalk.

headline: Flights Over Vanuatu Are Expected to Reveal Cyclone Devastation
abstract: Aid workers on the ground said the tiny nation’s capital had been flattened after the powerful storm tore through the archipelago.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Struck by a ferocious cyclone, the South Pacific islands that make up Vanuatu were expected to discover widespread destruction and a sharply higher death toll with aerial surveys beginning Monday.

headline: ‘I Miss My Daddy. Divorce Stinks.’
abstract: My ex-husband and I are over, and that’s as it should be. But there’s one person who’s not buying that this divorce is “for the best”: our daughter.
lead_paragraph: It has been almost a year since my ex-husband and I separated. And today, we walked into a mediator’s office and got a majority of a divorce agreement drafted. Before you ask how we did that so fast, let me share that we have no property to fight over and no money. We had also already worked out our own custody schedule together, and know we have plenty of time to work out the kinks, at least before our daughter starts elementary school. All we needed to do was deal with the fine print. As sad as it was to have it almost over, I know it’s for the best and so does my ex.

headline: Suicide Attacks on Pakistan Churches Kill 15
abstract: The attacks, on two Christian churches in Lahore, were the latest on religious minorities in the country.
lead_paragraph: LAHORE, Pakistan — Suicide bombers attacked two Christian churches here during Sunday services, killing at least 15 people and wounding dozens in the latest attack on religious minorities in the country.

headline: Bowling Perfection, Three Times Over
abstract: Bill Fong “felt like a human robot” as he bowled three games of strikes. It was a moment made for film.
lead_paragraph: Bill Fong wasn’t confident he was going to bowl 900 until the last shot. It was a regular Monday night league game at his local bowling ally, where he had practiced many times before.

headline: Chicago Candidate With Sunny Attitude Is Cloudy on Specifics
abstract: Jesus G. Garcia, known as Chuy, is trying to unseat Mayor Rahm Emanuel, but critics contend he is inconsistent in his positions, and vague about his plans to improve Chicago.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — When asked for his position on the pressing issues facing Chicago, Jesus G. Garcia, the man trying to unseat Mayor Rahm Emanuel, often has an answer — and sometimes more than one.

headline: Robert Durst of HBO’s ‘The Jinx’ Says He ‘Killed Them All’
abstract: In the final episode of a six-part documentary, Mr. Durst, the scion of a wealthy New York real estate family, seemed to veer toward a confession in three deaths over the course of three decades.
lead_paragraph: Since his first wife vanished more than three decades ago, Robert A. Durst, the eccentric and estranged son of one of New York’s most prominent real estate dynasties, has lived under the suspicious gaze of law enforcement officials in three states.

headline: Styles Collide to Serve Flamenco
abstract: “Generations of Gypsy Flamenco,” an event at Town Hall, promises flamenco for its own sake.
lead_paragraph: When flamenco comes to large theaters, it sometimes gets carried away, with splashy theatrical concepts masking the essence of music and dance. “Generations of Gypsy Flamenco,” an event at Town Hall, promises the opposite: flamenco for its own sake, danced by three revered practitioners whose roots in the form run deep. Concha Vargas, Pepe Torres and the up-and-coming Gema Moneo, all from the southern Spanish region of Andalusia, belong to different branches of flamenco’s intricate family tree.

headline: Tests of Cholesterol Drugs Offer Hope of Reducing Heart Attacks and Strokes
abstract: Researchers cautioned, however, that the studies were small and meant to assess whether the drugs safely lowered cholesterol, not whether they staved off heart attacks.
lead_paragraph: A new class of experimental cholesterol drugs might sharply reduce the risk of heart attacks and strokes, researchers reported on Sunday, citing what they described as preliminary evidence.

headline: A Week of Beginnings on Instagram
abstract: The Times debuted on Instagram last week, featuring a range of work that captured reader interest and even prompted a few to reach out and try to help the people in the pictures.
lead_paragraph: This past week’s @nytimes Instagram launch, seven projects on the theme “Beginnings,” concludes today with three portraits by Newsha Tavakolian (@newshatavakolian), a photographer in Iran whose work will be featured soon on NYTimes.com.

headline: JetBlue Mint to Travel to Caribbean in High-Flying Style
abstract: JetBlue‘s special Mint service will be available between J.F.K. and Aruba and Barbados, starting in November.
lead_paragraph: JetBlue — which last summer introduced private suites, the longest beds in the United States domestic market and a tapas-style menu as part of its new Mint business-class cabin — plans to announce on Monday that it will expand its Mint service to the Caribbean.

headline: 1915: Blind Child Sends Scarf to British Admiral
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Adm. John Jellicoe receives mail from a young girl back home.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — “All the other blind girls thank you and all the brave sailors and soldiers for defending us,” wrote Kathleen Torr, a blind child, living at York, to Admiral Sir John Jellicoe in a letter in Braille, accompanying a scarf she had knitted herself. Kathleen added that if Sir John would accept the gift she would be the happiest little girl in England, and the admiral not only accepted it, but sent a long letter of thanks in reply. “Directly the admiral saw your scarf,” wrote Sir John’s secretary, “he put it on and said: ‘I shall put on dear little Kathleen’s scarf when I am very cold.’ ”

headline: Filmmaker Won’t Weep for the Cuba He Left Behind
abstract: Archivists recently found negatives to “Azúcar Amarga,” Leon Ichaso’s 1996 film about a disillusioned young man in Cuba. It will be shown as part of the Queens World Film Festival.
lead_paragraph: Thirty years ago, Leon Ichaso made “Crossover Dreams,” a heartfelt independent movie that starred a young Ruben Blades as an ambitious salsa singer. Both Mr. Ichaso and Mr. Blades went on to greater success. Unfortunately, the film itself — the actual negatives stored in reels inside cans — has languished in obscurity. Mr. Ichaso has no idea where.

headline: Forget the Ball, ‘Cinderella’ Is the Belle of the Box Office
abstract: The Disney film, a live-action retelling of the classic fairytale with Lily James in the title role, took in $70.05 million at North American theaters over the weekend.
lead_paragraph: Never underestimate what Disney can do with a princess. “Cinderella,” a live-action retelling of the classic fairytale with Lily James in the title role, took in $70.05 million at North American theaters over the weekend, a result on par with the initial sum generated by Disney’s smash hit “Maleficent” last year.

headline: Advocates Press Cuomo to Take Action on Paid Family Leave Legislation
keywords: ['Paid Time Off', 'Family Leaves', 'Women and Girls', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Law and Legislation', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: Supporters of paid leave have told Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo there is plenty of interest for such a law after he said there was little “appetite” for it in Albany.
lead_paragraph: Ask Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo whether he champions the working women of New York and he proudly points to his agenda: his efforts to bolster laws against sexual harassment, domestic violence and salary discrimination, as well as his push to increase the minimum wage.

headline: 1965: Martin Luther King Jr. Leads Walk in Selma
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Dr. King led protesters to the Dallas County courthouse to honor the Rev. James J. Reeb, who was fatally beaten.
lead_paragraph: SELMA, Ala. — City officials lowered the “Selma Wall” today and the Rev. Martin Luther King led more than 1,500 Negroes and whites to the Dallas County courthouse to honor the Rev. James J. Reeb, fatally beaten here last week. Police and state troopers, under order to give the marchers “maximum protection,” lined the route to the courthouse, which is only three blocks from the spot where Mr. Reeb was clubbed.

headline: Human Trafficking Bill Stands in Way of Pick for Attorney General
abstract: Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, said the nomination of Loretta E. Lynch will not be considered until the Senate moves forward on the stalled bill.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate will not consider the nomination of Loretta E. Lynch to be attorney general until it moves forward on a stalled human trafficking bill, Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the majority leader, said Sunday.

headline: Caught by Surprise: One-Second Win in N.Y.C. Half
abstract: Stephen Sambu broke from the pack with a half-mile to go, but his countryman and training partner stayed close and caught him at the tape to capture the N.Y.C. Half.
lead_paragraph: It started as a half-marathon and ended as a sprint.

headline: Man, 20, Is Arrested in the Shooting of 2 Officers in Ferguson
abstract: Jeffrey L. Williams was charged with assault in the shooting of two officers during a demonstration last week outside Police Headquarters in Ferguson, Mo.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — A 20-year-old suspect was charged Sunday with shooting two police officers during a protest outside Police Headquarters here Thursday. Law enforcement officials said the man, Jeffrey L. Williams, claimed to have been targeting someone other than the officers and shot them by accident from inside a car.

headline: Iranian Court Sentences Son of Former President to 15 Years in Prison
abstract: Mehdi Hashemi, the son of former President Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, had been convicted of bribery and embezzlement.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — An Iranian court handed down a 15-year prison sentence to the son of former President Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, after he was convicted of bribery and embezzlement, a judiciary official said on Sunday.

headline: Asia Week Is Highlighted by Robert Hatfield Ellsworth Sale
abstract: This nine-day event, which draws dealers, curators, scholars and collectors from around the world, includes a five-day auction at Christie’s of the Ellsworth collection of Chinese art.
lead_paragraph: The piece was jade, a cylindrical Chinese cong from the sixth century B.C., and Lu Yizheng, a 33-year-old collector from Shanghai, was all over it. Nose to the stone, he followed the pinpoint beam of his small penlight, looking for imperfections, as four friends pressed against him for a closer view and loudly debated the merits. “This is the best of the jade I have seen,” Mr. Lu said. “The size and the quality are good; so is the provenance of the jade.”

headline: Review: ‘Death and the Damsel,’ a Paul Taylor Premiere on Sex Trafficking
abstract: “Death and the Damsel,” with its images of sexual coercion set to Martinu’s Sonata No. 2 for piano and cello, has a layered ambiguity characteristic of this choreographer.
lead_paragraph: A man, gripping a woman’s raised and parted legs by the ankles, presents those straightened legs to us like a V between him and us. Those ankles might be the handlebars of some motorcycle he’s riding; her supine torso and head are invisible to us. But he’s looking down fixedly at her groin, and there’s no doubt she’s being used for sex.

headline: At Gridiron Club Dinner, Anyone and Everyone Is Fair Game for Obama
abstract: The president took some humorous swipes at politicians across the spectrum, including House Speaker John Boehner, Hillary Clinton, and Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama often seems weary of being a political punching bag. But on Saturday night, he was loose and relaxed-looking as he turned the tables for a few minutes.

headline: Courting Favor
abstract: In a series of articles, Eric Lipton of The New York Times examines the explosion in lobbying of state attorneys general by corporate interests and the millions in campaign donations they now provide.
lead_paragraph: In a series of articles, Eric Lipton of The New York Times examines the explosion in lobbying of state attorneys general by corporate interests and the millions in campaign donations they now provide.

headline: Boston-Area Bridge Duo Win the Baldwin North American Pairs
abstract: Mark Aquino and Shome Mukherjee finished a board and a half ahead to capture the first title of the Spring North American Championships.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — The first title of the Spring North American Championships, the Baldwin North American Pairs, was decided here on Thursday evening.

headline: Review: ‘The Dream of My Return,’ by Horacio Castellanos Moya
abstract: Mr. Castellanos Moya’s new novel is realistically enough plotted to ask for our whole involvement in its story, yet still full of the moments of slippage and dissociation that magical realism is so adept at evoking.
lead_paragraph: There are dozens of moments in “The Dream of My Return,” the swift, stunning new novel by Horacio Castellanos Moya, when the reader expects its narrative to move toward the surreal. It’s a reasonable expectation. His first book published in the United States had the telling title of “Senselessness” and featured a narrator who began, “I am not complete in my mind,” then became decreasingly reliable from there.

headline: N.C.A.A. Tournament 2015: Villanova, Duke and Wisconsin Join Kentucky as No. 1 Seeds
abstract: The unbeaten Wildcats were named the top overall seed in the N.C.A.A. tournament. Virginia and Arizona were denied No. 1 seeds despite their strong cases.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — CBS broadcast Maryland’s team at the moment the Terrapins learned where they would be seeded in the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament. The looks on their faces conveyed a mix of punch-drunk disbelief and dread. They had been placed in Kentucky’s quadrant.

headline: Etsy’s Success Gives Rise to Problems of Credibility and Scale
abstract: The online marketplace and those who use it say that imitation handmade goods, and rules restricting how popular vendors can grow, are complicating the site.
lead_paragraph: Depending on whom you ask, Alicia Shaffer, owner of the hit Etsy store Three Bird Nest, is a runaway success story — or an emblem of everything that has gone wrong with the fast-growing online marketplace for handmade goods.

headline: Review: ‘iZombie,’ the Undead as a Force for Good
abstract: This CW series shifts away from complete doom and gloom and takes an inspired leap toward a police procedural.
lead_paragraph: Let’s see, what’s the right adjective to describe the CW series that begins Tuesday night and is centered on the eating of human brains? Heck, there’s no getting around it: “Tasty” is the word.

headline: Review: Martha Graham Dance Company in an Intimate Performance
abstract: This presentation, part of the Harkness Dance Festival at the 92nd Street Y, offered audience members an opportunity to walk around an Isamu Noguchi set.
lead_paragraph: Have you ever wanted to take off your shoes and walk around an Isamu Noguchi set? On Friday night at the 92nd Street Y, this intermission treat came courtesy of the Martha Graham Dance Company. Preceding a performance of Graham’s “Cave of the Heart,” a distillation of the Medea story, audience members were given the rare chance to examine a serpent topped by a wire dress and a series of stones leading to an aorta-shaped sculpture, among the many pieces of décor that Noguchi designed for Graham.

headline: China and the Dalai Lama
abstract: China’s Communist party leaders have warned the Dalai Lama that he must reincarnate.
lead_paragraph: China’s Communist party leaders have warned the Dalai Lama that he must reincarnate.

headline: V.C.U. Gets the Victory in Showcase of a Legacy
abstract: Players like Melvin Johnson, who helped V.C.U. beat Scoochie Smith’s Dayton Flyers, learned important lessons during their time at Rice High School in Harlem, which closed in 2011.
lead_paragraph: Melvin Johnson grew up on West 125th Street in Harlem, dreaming of following in the footsteps of local basketball legends like Kemba Walker and Felipe Lopez by playing at Rice High School.

headline: Review: Herb Alpert and Lani Hall Bring Rhythmic Precision to Café Carlyle
abstract: Mr. Alpert’s trumpet solos were models of rhythmic precision, tonal subtlety and expressive understatement, executed without showboating.
lead_paragraph: A relaxed feeling of enjoyment along with a certainty of being in good hands warmed Café Carlyle on Friday evening as Herb Alpert and Lani Hall wafted a mood of easygoing optimism into the room. Mr. Alpert, who mentioned that he will soon turn 80, still embodies the musical attitude nicknamed “laid-back” decades ago, when Southern California was America’s frontier of pleasure.

headline: Empac Shrugs Popularity to Promote Creative Liberty in Troy, N.Y.
abstract: The Talea Ensemble performed at this experimental arts center to an audience at roughly 6 percent of capacity, low enough to give most artistic directors panic attacks.
lead_paragraph: TROY, N.Y. — On Saturday evening, chilly and foggy here, a small group of people stood at the edge of the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute campus and gazed up at the looming facade of the Curtis R. Priem Experimental Media and Performing Arts Center.

headline: Review: ‘Jamaica Inn’ on BBC Resurrects a ‘Downton Abbey’ Star
abstract: The mini-series is based on the Daphne du Maurier novel and stars the actress who played the beautifully tragic Lady Sybil.
lead_paragraph: The BBC mini-series “Jamaica Inn” has a variety of hooks. For readers of Gothic thrillers, it’s based on a novel by the queen of the form, Daphne du Maurier. For film buffs, it’s a counterpart to an already well-known adaptation of the book, the 1939 movie of the same title by Alfred Hitchcock.

headline: Without Joan Rivers, ‘Fashion Police’ Is Falling Apart
abstract: After losing two hosts in recent weeks, and in the absence of Ms. Rivers’s signature style, the show has come to seem unhinged.
lead_paragraph: Ever since Joan Rivers died in September, “Fashion Police” — the E! show devoted to poking holes in celebrity pageantry that she had hosted since its inception — has been collapsing in plain view.

headline: American Dance Festival Announces 2015 Lineup
abstract: Shen Wei Dance Arts will premiere “Untitled #12-2,” one of 11 commissions that compose the 82nd annual season of the festival.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese choreographer and visual artist Shen Wei is in some ways a child of the American Dance Festival, where his blend of aesthetic drama and calligraphic movement was nurtured, and where he started his company 15 years ago. To honor that anniversary, Shen Wei Dance Arts returns to Durham, N.C., this summer to premiere “Untitled #12-2,” one of 11 commissions that compose the 82nd annual season of the festival, which runs from June 11 to July 25. Mr. Shen’s new work, inspired by his paintings at Art Basel Miami, is paired with a reimagined version of his 2005 work “Map” (June 11-13). Other headliners will include the festival staples Pilobolus, which will introduce “Thresh|Hold,” a world-premiere collaboration with the Venezuelan choreographer Javier de Frutos (June 18-20); and the newly renamed Paul Taylor’s American Modern Dance, bringing classics from Mr. Taylor’s six-decade career (July 2-4). As usual, the festival will feature work by North Carolina choreographers, like Kristen Jeppsen Groves and Karola Lüttringhaus, who are tackling political and social issues (June 25), and spotlight dance in cinema with the International Screendance Festival, on four consecutive Sundays, starting June 28.

headline: Managers Turn to Computer Games, Aiming for More Efficient Employees
keywords: ['Software', 'Productivity', 'Social Media', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Executives and Management (Theory)']
abstract: BetterWorks is part of a growing office software niche that aims to whip workers into shape through compulsory competition and public scoring.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — A few days before he testified in a sex discrimination lawsuit that has captivated Silicon Valley, John Doerr, arguably the most famous venture capitalist in the world, was sitting at a conference room table laying out his ideas on good management.

headline: Chitchat
abstract: A little bit of crossword puzzle goodness by Ian Livengood.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — There’s something you should know about me. I’m on the petite side. And I don’t appreciate being called names, Ian Livengood.

headline: A Rare Look Into One’s Life on File in China
abstract: There is a largely invisible mechanism of social control that governs hundreds of millions of urban residents in China: the dang’an, or personal file, that documents matters mundane and profane.
lead_paragraph: Whether it is national identification cards embedded with biometric chips or “birth permits” for expectant mothers, the Chinese are accustomed to authoritarian intrusions into their private lives.

headline: In Nationwide Protests, Angry Brazilians Call for Ouster of President
abstract: Protests throughout the country are calling for Dilma Rousseff to resign after an embarrassing bribery scandal at the national oil company that will not go away.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Hundreds of thousands of protesters took to the streets in cities across Brazil on Sunday to express their ire at President Dilma Rousseff, raising pressure on her as she grapples with an onslaught of challenges including an economy mired in stagnation, a sweeping bribery scandal and a revolt by some of the most powerful figures in her governing coalition.

headline: Revival of ‘Ghost Airport’ Stirs Hope in Spain
abstract: Ryanair will begin flights in September to Castellón four years after construction of what came to symbolize the country’s excessive spending.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — The “ghost airport” of Castellón on Spain’s east coast had become a symbol of the country’s reckless spending and its boom-to-bust construction crisis. Could it now turn into an emblem of Spain’s economic revival?

headline: SXSW 2015: Sally Field on ‘Hello, My Name Is Doris’
abstract: The actress discusses her comedy directed by Michael Showalter.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Perhaps nobody expected the  collaboration between Michael Showalter and Sally Field less than Sally Field. The Oscar-winning actress had never crossed creative paths with the director, who has built a career on sketch comedy and screenplays with an off-kilter approach to humor.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of March 16
keywords: ['Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: 2 Months After Attack, Paris Kosher Market Reopens
abstract: The market opened for business for the first time since a Frenchman who claimed allegiance to the Islamic State killed four people there on Jan. 9.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The shelves were still not fully stocked, and employees were hastily adding price tags, as customers returned to a kosher supermarket in the Porte de Vincennes neighborhood here on Sunday morning for the first time since a Frenchman who claimed allegiance to the Islamic State took hostages and killed four people there on Jan. 9.

headline: For the Yankees’ Other Rodriguez, Little Fanfare but Big Adventures
abstract: There is another Rodriguez in Yankees camp: Eddy Rodriguez, a 29-year-old journeyman catcher.
lead_paragraph: DUNEDIN, Fla. — When the Toronto Blue Jays’ public-address announcer boomed the arrival into the batter’s box of a Yankees player named Rodriguez on Saturday, there was neither a boo nor a cheer, nor even a single pair of clapping hands from among the 5,511 fans at Florida Auto Exchange Stadium.

headline: Assyrian Artifacts to Be Returned to Iraq
abstract: American officials plan to return about 65 objects, seized during smuggling invesigations, to the Iraqi government on Monday.
lead_paragraph: American officials on Monday are expected to repatriate about 65 objects to the Iraqi government, among them the head of a massive statue that was stolen in 2007 or 2008 from the same ancient Assyrian archaeological site where Islamic State militants have been rampaging in recent weeks.

headline: Treasury Department Faults Veterans Affairs in Feud Over Employee
abstract: The inspectors general of two government agencies are embroiled in a highly unusual dispute that centers on a senior employee who has worked for the Department of Veterans Affairs and the Treasury Department.
lead_paragraph: Inside the federal bureaucracy there are 72 inspectors general charged with combating waste, fraud and abuse at their agencies.

headline: Corey Kluber, Indians’ Ace, Rises as Precisely as His Two-Seam Fastball Dips
abstract: Kluber, who won the American League Cy Young Award last season, took time to develop as a pitcher, but with his devastating sinking two-seam fastball, he now dominates.
lead_paragraph: GOODYEAR, Ariz. — As the actor Will Ferrell skipped merrily from camp to camp last Thursday in a madcap Cactus League odyssey, the best pitcher in the American League worked stoically on a back field at the Cleveland Indians’ training complex. No numbers on the scoreboard, no paying customers, not even an umpire.

headline: An N.C.A.A. Bracket for Risk-Takers
abstract: For this bracket, the more unusual that your picks are, the more points you’ll receive — so long as those picks are correct.

Putin sent military forces to secure Crimea and even weighed putting Russia’s nuclear arsenal on alert because of his concerns about both anarchy and Western intervention, the Russian leader said in a documentary broadcast Sunday.

headline: Q. and A.: David Shambaugh on the Risks to Chinese Communist Rule
abstract: The highly influential American scholar of Chinese politics argues that his recent essay about the ‘‘endgame’’ of the Communist Party envisions a protracted period of decline.
lead_paragraph: David Shambaugh, a professor of political science and international affairs at George Washington University, is one of the United States’ most prominent experts on contemporary China. He has also been prominent in China. His books have been translated and published there, and his views cited in the state media. He was profiled by the overseas edition of People’s Daily, and in January researchers at the China Foreign Affairs University, which comes under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, named him the second-most influential China expert in the United States, behind David M. Lampton at the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies.

headline: Villanova Shrugs Off Shortcomings in Recent Tournaments

The thinking went: Breeze through two games in Buffalo, make it to New York for the regional and then on to the Final Four. Except its season ended on Saturday of the first week.

headline: Leading Role for France as Africa Battles Back
abstract: France has joined an increasingly violent campaign to combat Al Qaeda’s affiliate in North Africa and other Islamist extremists, and more recently to thwart Boko Haram.

Minutes later, French attack planes and helicopter gunships swooped down on the convoy of Qaeda-backed fighters, turning the militant caravan into smoldering wreckage.

headline: Review: Doug Wright’s ‘Posterity,’ a Portrait of Ibsen
abstract: The Australian actor John Noble plays Henrik Ibsen and Hamish Linklater plays the Norwegian sculptor Gustav Vigeland in this drama loosely based on real events.
lead_paragraph: An impeccable performance by the Australian actor John Noble lends gravity and a measure of emotional depth to “Posterity,” the new play written and directed by Doug Wright about Henrik Ibsen in his later days. With his face fringed in imposing whiskers, his brow stormy with incipient outrage, and a Grinch-like grimace almost cemented in place, Mr. Noble does a formidable job of making a flesh-and-blood figure of Ibsen, renowned for his standoffishness and chilliness in public, if not in private.

headline: Review: ‘On the Twentieth Century,’ With Kristin Chenoweth, Opens on Broadway
abstract: Scott Ellis’s revival of this 1978 musical about dueling egos on a train between Chicago and New York knows that when it comes to being hyperbolic, there’s no people like show people.
lead_paragraph: In the theater, there is overacting, which is common and painful to watch. Then there’s over-the-moon acting, which is rare and occupies its own special cloud land in heaven. I am delighted to report that this latter art is being practiced in altitudinous-high style at the American Airlines Theater, where Kristin Chenoweth and Peter Gallagher are surfing the stratosphere in “On the Twentieth Century.”

headline: What’s On TV Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 11:20 P.M. (Starz) THE AMAZING SPIDER-MAN 2 (2014) Peter Parker (Andrew Garfield, above) pines for information about his deceased parents and agonizes over his relationship with Gwen Stacy (Emma Stone) while attending to his responsibilities as Spider-Man in this sequel directed by Marc Webb. An Oscorp employee turned electrified, unhinged villain (Jamie Foxx) has a debilitating effect on New York City. Peter’s friend, the Oscorp heir Harry Osborn (Dane DeHaan), desperately seeks to cure the illness he inherited from his recently deceased father, with ghoulish consequences. The film “balances blockbuster bombast with human-scale drama, child-friendly comedy and gushers of tears,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “There are moments — as when the image freezes on the tucked, airborne Spider-Man, ready to spring into action like an Olympian — in which the movie taps into the giddy freedom and near-unboundedness that the character’s physical transformation has brought him.”  Hints of future villains should please fans.

headline: Letter Calls Plea Deal for David Petraeus a ‘Profound Double Standard’
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'News and News Media']
abstract: A lawyer for an imprisoned government contractor who revealed classified information has criticized the plea deal given to retired Gen. David H. Petraeus, who gave military secrets to his mistress.

Petraeus, which spares him prison time even though he gave military secrets to his mistress, reveals a “profound double standard” in the way the Obama administration treats people who leak classified information, a lawyer for an imprisoned government contractor wrote in a letter to prosecutors.

headline: Israel’s Gilded Age
abstract: Why is the country’s inequality a political issue? Because it didn’t have to be this extreme.
lead_paragraph: Why did Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel feel the need to wag the dog in Washington? For that was, of course, what he was doing in his anti-Iran speech to Congress. If you’re seriously trying to affect American foreign policy, you don’t insult the president and so obviously align yourself with his political opposition. No, the real purpose of that speech was to distract the Israeli electorate with saber-rattling bombast, to shift its attention away from the economic discontent that, polls suggest, may well boot Mr. Netanyahu from office in Tuesday’s election.

headline: Death Sentences, With or Without a Jury
abstract: Laws being challenged in Florida and Alabama are only more proof of the moral disgrace of capital punishment in this country.
lead_paragraph: In the states that continue to put their own citizens to death, virtually every part of the process is warped by injustice and absurdity. In Florida and Alabama, death row inmates are challenging perverse state laws on the jury’s role in capital trials. The Supreme Court, which has been intervening more often in death penalty cases, last week agreed to review the Florida law.

headline: In Rural India, Hoping for Jobs and Education in a Growing Economy
abstract: Even with a college degree, opportunities are still scarce.

headline: The Kurds’ Heroic Stand Against ISIS
abstract: The Kurds, a stateless people, have held the front against ISIS in Iraq. Is America helping them?
lead_paragraph: ERBIL, Iraq — THE Islamic State continues to control a huge section of Syria. But in Iraq, its advance has stalled. While Shiite militias and their Iranian allies fight the Islamic State ferociously, the Kurds have held a 640-mile front against the Islamic State’s advance. Their steadfastness should prompt America to rethink its alliances and interests in the region and to deepen its relationship with the Kurds — who are sometimes described as the world’s largest stateless nation.

headline: Medicaid Expansion in Red States
keywords: ['Medicaid', 'States (US)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Editorials']
abstract: Ideological gridlock is inflicting serious harm on state budgets, but the greatest losers are poor people who cannot afford health coverage.
lead_paragraph: A number of states that had previously refused to expand their Medicaid programs for the poor are reconsidering that policy. They would be smart to embrace expansion as soon as possible to cover millions of people who would be left uninsured if the Supreme Court wipes out federal subsidies for low-income people buying insurance on the federal health exchanges.

abstract: In May, properties on Long Island will be up for auction at prices between 20 percent and 30 percent of their prestorm values.
lead_paragraph: LINDENHURST, N.Y. — Nobody on Pacific Street saw the Atlantic coming.

headline: New Demands Endanger a Giant Cement Merger
abstract: They planned to combine on equal terms to form the world’s largest cement and construction materials company, but diverging results and currency concerns put the agreement at risk.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The planned merger of Holcim and Lafarge, two European cement-making giants, appears to be on the verge of falling apart after Holcim demanded a revision to the agreed to terms.

headline: Haversham Holdings Says It’s in ‘Advanced’ Takeover Talks
abstract: The acquisition vehicle, which went public in London last year, did not disclose the target, but it said it was discussing a potential reverse takeover.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Trading of shares of Haversham Holdings was suspended on Monday morning as the acquisition vehicle said it was in “very advanced discussions” regarding a takeover.

headline: Looking for Parkinson’s Sooner
abstract: REM sleep behavior disorder, characterized by a tendency to act out one’s dreams while asleep, is one of the strongest prediagnostic symptoms.
lead_paragraph: The Holy Grail in any progressive disease is to find it early enough to start effective treatment before irreversible damage has occurred. For Parkinson’s disease, which afflicts 1.5 million Americans and growing, a new study has brought this goal a little closer.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Standard Chartered Names 3 Advisers to Financial Crime Panel
