abstract: The British bank added the former leaders of Interpol and the Swift bank messaging network and a former counterterrorism adviser to President George W. Bush.
lead_paragraph: The British bank Standard Chartered said on Monday that it had named three external advisers, including the former president of Interpol, to a new committee to oversee its compliance program, set up to identify and prevent financial crime.

headline: New York Today: Pothole Season
abstract: Monday: Rough streets, some sun, and the twisted trail of Robert Durst.
lead_paragraph: Good chilly Monday morning to you.

headline: GE Capital Agrees to Sell Australia and New Zealand Operations for $6.3 Billion
abstract: The business is to be acquired by a consortium including Deutsche Bank and the private equity firms Värde Partners and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — GE Capital, the financing arm of General Electric, has agreed to sell its consumer lending business in Australia and New Zealand in a deal that values the business at 8.2 billion Australian dollars, or about $6.3 billion.

headline: Daily Report: Etsy’s Success Opens It to Problems of Credibility and Scale
abstract: The online marketplace and those who buy and sell on it say that imitation handmade goods, and rules restricting how vendors can grow to meet demand, are complicating the site’s drive for authenticity.
lead_paragraph: Depending on whom you ask, Alicia Shaffer, owner of the hit Etsy store Three Bird Nest, is a runaway success story — or an emblem of everything that has gone wrong with the fast-growing online marketplace for handmade goods, Hiroko Tabuchi reports.

headline: Today in Politics: Democrats to Ramp Up Push for Attorney General Vote
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Human Trafficking', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Democrats say they will intensify the pressure on Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky to allow a vote this week on Loretta E. Lynch for attorney general.
lead_paragraph: Good Monday morning from Washington, where Hillary Rodham Clinton is lining up her fund-raising team and former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida is batting back comparisons to his brother. President Obama spent the weekend dusting off his comedy routine, but when it comes to getting his attorney general nominee confirmed, there is not much for him to laugh about. Will the logjam in Congress end this week?

headline: SolarCity, a Vocal Critic of the Utility Industry, Joins It
abstract: SolarCity will design and operate small, independent power networks called microgrids for cities, remote communities, campuses and military bases.
lead_paragraph: As SolarCity, the rooftop solar system provider, has rapidly expanded its reach over the last few years, its executives have pushed hard against the utility industry, criticizing it as a hidebound monopoly standing in the way of change.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | March 16, 2015
abstract: On Mondays, we publish a Times photo without a caption, headline or other information about its origins. Join the conversation by posting about what you see, and why. A live discussion is offered from 9 a.m. to 2 p.m. Eastern time.
lead_paragraph: Updated: March 17, 2015

headline: Should Philosophers Be Loners?
abstract: Isn’t philosophizing for yourself like keeping your own score in tennis, according to your own judgments of what was in or out?
lead_paragraph: Warning: Both participants in this dialogue are figments of the author’s imagination.

headline: Alcohol or Marijuana? A Pediatrician Faces the Question
keywords: ['Marijuana', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Alcohol Abuse', 'Research', 'Drunken and Reckless Driving']
abstract: It would be nice to imagine your children won’t abuse any substances, but also unrealistic. The question is what to warn them against most strongly.
lead_paragraph: As my children, and my friends’ children, are getting older, a question that comes up again and again from friends is this: Which would I rather my children use — alcohol or marijuana?

headline: Pardons Elude Men Freed After Decades in North Carolina Prison
abstract: Henry L. McCollum and Leon Brown have clung to a minimal existence, absent substantive remuneration, counseling or public aid in transitioning back to society.
lead_paragraph: FAYETTEVILLE, N.C. — In the days leading up to the one last summer when Henry L. McCollum left North Carolina’s death row, it seemed that inmates and staff members could not stop talking about what awaited him beyond Central Prison.

headline: Why I Am Not a Taxidermist
abstract: Living with Rupert the mangled, misshapen fox taught me that making taxidermy came with a responsibility.
lead_paragraph: Some years ago, a friend gave me a mangled, stuffed fox for Christmas. And I don’t mean a plush toy. I mean a genuine red fox, a once-living creature, reduced to a misshapen carcass. The wizened face had the twisted, brittle look of a mummy. Some teeth were missing. Its limbs were just fur-covered bones.

headline: Morning Agenda: Authorities Circle JPMorgan Hackers
abstract: Federal authorities close in on hackers who stole data from JPMorgan. | Buyers flock to Santander’s subprime loan deal. | Cement giant seeks new merger terms. | S.E.C. shifts policy on admissions of guilt.
lead_paragraph: AUTHORITIES CIRCLE JPMORGAN HACKERS | Federal authorities investigating the attack last summer at JPMorgan Chase ‒ which resulted in hackers gaining access to email addresses and phone numbers for 83 million households and small businesses ‒ are increasingly confident that a criminal case will be filed against the hackers in the coming months, Matthew Goldstein and Nicole Perlroth write in DealBook, citing unidentified people briefed on the investigation.

headline: Boston College Seeks to Give Others Pause in the Overhaul of Scholarships
abstract: The college’s resistance in a 79-1 vote in January provided a reminder of disparities among the 65 members of the N.C.A.A.’s so-called Big 5 athletic conferences.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — On a recent afternoon, snow fell on Boston College’s tidy campus in suburban Chestnut Hill, piling atop the upper stands of Alumni Stadium and the tennis-style bubble enclosing the football field.

headline: Designing Private Cities, Open to All
abstract: How the company town offers an alternative model of urban development.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — The world is building more cities, faster than ever before. China used more cement in the last three years than the United States used in the entire 20th century. By 2050, India will need new urban infrastructure to house an additional 404 million people — a task comparable to building every city in the United States in just 35 years. The global urban population is expected to rise to well over six billion by 2050 from 3.9 billion today.

headline: Raising Its Bid, Valeant Cinches a Deal
abstract: The bidding-war triumph is a much-needed win for Valeant after it failed last year in its pursuit of Allergan, the maker of Botox.
lead_paragraph: Faced with the prospect of letting another deal slip through its fingers, Valeant Pharmaceuticals International substantially increased its bid for Salix Pharmaceuticals on Monday, putting a quick end to a bidding war with Endo International.

headline: China Unveils Plan to Bolster Its National Soccer Team
abstract: The men’s national team has never lived up to the expectation of Chinese fans. Now the government is pushing for changes that it hopes will bring better results
lead_paragraph: The State Council, China’s cabinet, released details on Monday of a plan for Chinese soccer that calls for cleaning up the administration of the sport and increasing the number of young players. It also recommended that the country compete to host a men’s World Cup tournament.

headline: ISIS Keeps Hold in Tikrit as Iraq Pauses Offensive
abstract: Officials said they were slowing the operation to call for reinforcements and to preserve property and civilian lives.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Islamic State militants on Monday continued to hold parts of the city of Tikrit against a much larger pro-government force after two weeks of battle, as Iraqi officials said they were pausing their offensive to call for reinforcements and to preserve property and civilian lives.

headline: Putin Returns After Curious Absence and Shrugs Off Rumors
abstract: The Russian leader reappeared in public after more than 10 days, appearing healthy and commenting wryly that things “would be boring without rumors.”
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia reappeared in public on Monday after a curious absence of more than a week, commenting wryly that things “would be boring without gossip.”

headline: Cameron Promises Another Dose of Austerity as British Elections Near
abstract: Prime Minister David Cameron has made cutting the budget a signature of his platform, but compared with much of Europe, the cuts are modest.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British election campaign now underway here revolves in large part around a single issue: the economy, and whether its rebound is the result of an austerity policy championed by the Conservative-led government, or in spite of it.

headline: Life Time Fitness to Be Taken Private in $4 Billion Deal
abstract: The investment firms Leonard Green & Partners and TPG Capital are buying out the gym operator, which runs 114 centers in North America.
lead_paragraph: The investment firms Leonard Green & Partners and TPG Capital agreed on Monday to buy Life Time Fitness, a gym operator, for about $4 billion, including the assumption of debt.

headline: St. Augustine and Secular Stagnation
abstract: Chastity can and must wait.
lead_paragraph: Brad DeLong reminds me of Simon Wren-Lewis’s excellent piece on Eurozone fiscal policy, which emphasizes the extent to which European officials still don’t get the basic macroeconomics of their position. I realized, however, that recent discussion of secular stagnation — which seems like a realistic possibility for Europe, even more so than the US — adds a twist to the story, one that I’m not sure is widely appreciated.

headline: ScienceTake | Bird in the Wind
abstract: Hummingbirds have a remarkable ability to hover in the midst of turbulence.
lead_paragraph: Hummingbirds have a remarkable ability to hover in the midst of turbulence.

headline: Tiny Masters of Turbulent Air
abstract: Ruby-throated hummingbirds can overcome changing winds to feed on nectar, using rapid wing and tail adjustments to hold steady.
lead_paragraph: Big airplanes can power through turbulence, but for smaller planes like drones, shifting winds and air currents can cause more than discomfort. And hovering is particularly complicated.

headline: Daughter of Jailed Malaysian Opposition Leader Is Arrested
abstract: Nurul Izzah Anwar, a daughter of Anwar Ibrahim, was arrested over criticism of the country’s judiciary she made during a speech in Parliament, her lawyer said.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A daughter of the jailed Malaysian opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim was arrested Monday afternoon over criticism of the country’s judiciary she made during a speech in Parliament, her lawyer said.

headline: Netanyahu Says No to Statehood for Palestinians
abstract: As Israelis go to the polls, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s stance is being seen as a push to appeal to right-wing voters. His chief challenger supports the two-state solution.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Under pressure on the eve of a surprisingly close election, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Monday doubled down on his appeal to right-wing voters, declaring definitively that if he was returned to office he would never establish a Palestinian state.

headline: Night of Drug Overdoses Jolts Liberal Tradition on Wesleyan Campus
abstract: After a bad batch of the drug Molly sent 12 people to the hospital last month, Wesleyan University has been trying to balance open-mindedness with student safety.
lead_paragraph: MIDDLETOWN, Conn. — When a Wesleyan University student who had taken drugs at a party last month began feeling ill, his friends took him to his dorm room, gave him water and Triscuits, and assumed he just needed to sleep it off.

headline: Diversification Is the Sane Alternative to Betting Big on One Investment
abstract: Without a crystal ball, an investor must make sure a portfolio spreads out the risk, a financial planner writes.
lead_paragraph: You made a huge mistake last year with your money. You know this now, right? The only investments in your portfolio that did very well were probably United States stocks. Bonds may have held their own, but everything else was just pitiful. International stocks performed horribly and emerging markets weren’t much better.

headline: Could the South Have Won the War?
abstract: The Union’s overwhelming strength and morale made Northern victory all but inevitable.
lead_paragraph: By March 1865, it was obvious to all but the most die-hard Confederates that the South was going to lose the war. Whether that loss was inevitable is an unanswerable question, but considering various “what if” scenarios has long been a popular exercise among historians, novelists and Civil War buffs.

headline: Paying a Price to Play at South by Southwest
keywords: ['Music', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: For better or worse, struggling bands often spend their own money to play the South by Southwest Music and Media Conference in Austin, Tex.
lead_paragraph: This week, the Prettiots, a largely unknown, ukulele-led trio of young women, will join more than 2,000 other acts at the annual South by Southwest Music and Media Conference, and like many of these musicians, they will pay a lot for the privilege of playing several shows, mostly for free.

headline: Yet Another One: Mets Lose Zack Wheeler
abstract: The team expects Wheeler, who has a torn ulnar collateral ligament in his pitching elbow, to have Tommy John surgery.
lead_paragraph: FORT MYERS, Fla. — Just before Matt Harvey went for a pregame run Monday morning, preparing for his third start of spring training, he checked the Twitter updates on his cellphone and spotted the dismaying news. Zack Wheeler, one of the Mets’ top pitchers, had a fully torn ulnar collateral ligament in his elbow, which meant he was now facing the same Tommy John surgery that Harvey underwent in 2013 and the same long rehabilitation that would follow.

headline: Sotheby’s Names a New Chief Executive: Tad Smith
abstract: Mr. Smith, 49, was most recently president and chief executive of the Madison Square Garden Company.
lead_paragraph: Sotheby’s reached outside the art world on Monday to appoint Tad Smith, a businessman with a background in the entertainment, sport and media industries who most recently led the Madison Square Garden Company, to replace the departing chief executive, William F. Ruprecht.

headline: ‘The Age of Acquiescence,’ by Steve Fraser
abstract: Unlike their 19th-century counterparts, today’s superrich face little organized opposition.
lead_paragraph: For two years running, Oxfam International has traveled to the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, to make a request: Could the superrich kindly cease devouring the world’s wealth? And while they’re at it, could they quit using “their financial might to influence public policies that favor the rich at the expense of everyone else”?

headline: With Bill Buford Around, It’s Never Dull
abstract: The editor, author and well-trained cook has mastered the sharpening steel.
lead_paragraph: There was a thin line of blood on Bill Buford’s arm, brimming and bright, too neat for a scratch: a perfect slit, like the narrowest of peepholes into the skin.

headline: Putin Laughs Off Rumors of Ill Health
abstract: After days of unexplained absence, Russian President Vladimir V. Putin appeared with the president of Kyrgyzstan to discuss the integration of the Kyrgyz economy with Russia and its allies.
lead_paragraph: After days of unexplained absence, Russian President Vladimir V. Putin appeared with the president of Kyrgyzstan to discuss the integration of the Kyrgyz economy with Russia and its allies.

headline: ‘The Summit,’ by Ed Conway
abstract: In 1944, while war raged on, a raucous three-week summit overhauled the international monetary system.
lead_paragraph: For many people, Bretton Woods stands for that rarest of moments: when governments and experts come together to restore order to a chaotic global economy. After the financial meltdown of 2008, the president of the World Bank and the financier George Soros joined Bill Clinton’s and Tony Blair’s earlier call for a “new Bretton Woods.” It didn’t happen. The world and especially America may yet come to regret that.

headline: Bush Sees Benefits, and Drawbacks, From Brotherly Comparison
abstract: By the end of his first visit to New Hampshire as a likely presidential candidate, Jeb Bush had little appetite to again address the dynasty issue.
lead_paragraph: By the end of his first visit to New Hampshire as a likely presidential candidate, Jeb Bush had little appetite to again address the dynasty issue.

headline: Get on the Grid
abstract: The clean, geometric look has been popping up everywhere, giving interiors an updated ’80s feel.
lead_paragraph: The clean, geometric look has been popping up everywhere, giving interiors an updated ’80s feel.

headline: N.C.A.A. Tournament Schedule
abstract: The N.C.A.A. tournament begins on Tuesday, with two play-in games. The round of 64 begins on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament schedule. All times are Eastern.

headline: Director of Durst Film Says He Is ‘Relieved’ About Arrest
abstract: The director Andrew Jarecki and his co-writer and cinematographer, Marc Smerling, discuss the Robert Durst case, “The Jinx” and its aftermath.
lead_paragraph: The director Andrew Jarecki and his co-writer and cinematographer Marc Smerling didn’t know what they were getting themselves into when they agreed to interview Robert Durst. The real estate heir contacted them following the release of their 2010 film “All Good Things,” a thinly veiled dramatization of the 1982 disappearance of Mr. Durst’s first wife, Kathleen McCormack. Mr. Durst said he wanted to tell his side of the story. The results of Mr. Jarecki’s and Mr. Smerling’s investigation became “The Jinx: The Life and Deaths of Robert Durst,” a six-part documentary whose final episode aired Sunday night, one day after Mr. Durst was arrested in New Orleans on charges stemming from an investigation into the murder of his friend Susan Berman in Los Angeles in 2000. In the final episode, Mr. Durst is heard, on a live microphone he’s wearing in the bathroom following a formal interview in April 2012 with Mr. Jarecki, seeming to confess to three murders. Mr. Jarecki and Mr. Smerling spoke by phone this morning about the case, “The Jinx” and its aftermath. Here are edited excerpts from the conversation:

headline: Robert Durst, Saying He Was Worried, Fled to Familiar Refuge Before His Arrest
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Television', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: Robert A. Durst, who had checked into a JW Marriott in New Orleans under an alias, agreed to be taken to Los Angeles to face a murder charge in the killing of Susan Berman in 2000.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Not for the first time in his life, Robert A. Durst had left his home and sought to disappear. And not for the first time, he went to New Orleans.

headline: U.N. Monitor Says Iran Is Worsening on Rights, Despite Pledges
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Capital Punishment']
abstract: The monitor, Ahmed Shaheed, said Iran’s use of the death penalty was accelerating and that government critics faced harassment and prison.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Iran’s use of the death penalty is rising and its repression of political critics is worsening despite promises by President Hassan Rouhani of a less restrictive society, a United Nations human rights monitor said on Monday.

headline: Looking at the Promise and Perils of the Emerging Big Data Sector
keywords: ['Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Bruce Schneier, an expert in cryptography and security, has deep knowledge of the uses and abuses of data collection, but his viewpoints seem to subvert the democratic principles he supports.
lead_paragraph: There is a certain predictability to media and technology finance. Any company looking for money is inevitably characterized as similar to whatever has recently garnered the highest valuations.

headline: For Ruben Gallego, a Ride on Air Force One and a Presidential Aside
keywords: ['Series', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: Mr. Gallego, an Arizona Democrat, talked about life at Harvard as the first in his family to go to college, his military service in Iraq and how he met his wife at a fraternity date auction.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For Representative Ruben Gallego, a freshman Democrat from Arizona, joining the 114th Congress started with a heady ride.

headline: Stephen Colbert and George Lucas in Conversation at the Tribeca Film Festival
abstract: The session is one of several events added to the Tribeca Film Festival, including the New York premiere of a documentary on Kurt Cobain.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Colbert once battled Jon Stewart over who could lay claim to the title of biggest “Star Wars” fan on the planet. Mr. Stewart may have won that round, but Mr. Colbert’s expertise will be put to the test again when he sits down for a public conversation with George Lucas on April 17, one of several events, including talks with Courtney Love and Harvey Weinstein, announced Monday by organizers of the Tribeca Film Festival.

headline: π Dollars
abstract: Your restaurant check comes to π dollars. What are your options?
lead_paragraph: Our π Day celebration continues this week with a recent pi-related question posed on Quora that has received an astounding 700,000-plus views. There’s no single right answer — just fun to think about what you’d actually do. And the question is —

headline: At Oregon Festival, Films About (and on) Bicycles
abstract: The Filmed by Bike Festival in Portland, Ore., will showcase films about bicycles, some of them shot on wheels.
lead_paragraph: In Portland, Ore., motion pictures are the heart of the Filmed by Bike Festival, screening short films about cycling, often shot from rolling bicycles.

headline: Economic Ignorance Blogging
abstract: A corollary to Dunning-Kruger.
lead_paragraph: We need a name for a syndrome related to, but not quite the same as, the Dunning-Kruger effect. That effect, you may or may not know, shows that truly incompetent people are so incompetent that they believe themselves competent.

headline: Taking Care With Calcium Supplements
keywords: ['Calcium', 'Menopause', 'Heart', 'Women and Girls', 'Stroke', 'Dietary Supplements and Herbal Remedies']
abstract: Should women stop taking calcium supplements after menopause, because of a danger of heart attack and stroke?
lead_paragraph: Q. I have been told that women should stop taking calcium supplements after menopause, as there is a danger of heart attack and stroke. Is this true?

headline: The Kaisa Bandwagon
abstract: Excited by China’s property boom, wealthy investors poured money into the distressed property developer, Kaisa. Those who jumped in later have suffered.
lead_paragraph: Excited by China’s property boom, wealthy investors poured money into the distressed property developer, Kaisa. Those who jumped in later have suffered.

headline: New York’s Sewer, Up Close
abstract: The Times reporter Matt Flegenheimer and the photographer Karsten Moran investigate the havoc wet wipes wreak on the city’s sewer system.
lead_paragraph: New York City politics can be unseemly. Sometimes a walking tour of used wet wipes is part of the deal.

headline: Beauty Tips for Girls, From Lego
abstract: The new “Lego Club Magazine” features a page of “Beauty Tips” for its 5-12 year old audience.
lead_paragraph: My 7-year-old wants to know if she has an oval face. Why? Because “oval faces can often have almost any style haircut because almost everything looks great on this face shape!” Her sudden concern with her hairstyle “looking great” comes courtesy of her new Lego Club Magazine, which included “Emma’s Beauty Tips” in the March-April 2015 Lego Club Magazine.

headline: The New Optimism of Al Gore
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Solar Energy', 'Wind Power']
abstract: Mr. Gore has warned of the dangers of climate change for years. Now he has found a new role: prophet of possibility.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Al Gore wants to make a point about cellphones, and he has a helpful set of slides on his laptop. “Do you want to see that?” he asks, and starts to turn the MacBook around.

headline: Jessica Lange Says She’s Done With ‘American Horror Story’
abstract: She won’t return for the fifth season of the show, which is to star Lady Gaga.
lead_paragraph: Really, what is there left for one to do after playing a nun in charge of an insane asylum, a powerful New Orleans witch, and the proprietor of a Florida freak show? For Jessica Lange, apparently, not much more.

headline: 1940: Limits on Bread and Chocolate
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Sale of fancy chocolate in Paris is banned in 1940.
lead_paragraph: Further restrictions regarding the baking and selling of bread, effective April 1, and control of the manufacture of chocolate candy anticipating its removal from the market on September 1 were announced yesterday [March 16] in decrees of the Department of Agriculture published in the ‘‘Journal Officiel.’’ The law regarding chocolate forbids the manufacture after June 1 of fancy chocolates, chocolate ‘‘fondant’’ or milk chocolate, or confectionery made with fancy chocolate, permitting only common, unsweetened chocolate used for cooking. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 17, 1940

headline: Closing Arguments Begin in Test Cheating Trial of 12 Atlanta Educators
abstract: A case centers on whether improvement on standardized testing was the result of teachers and principals changing answers.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — After more than five years of controversy and five months of testimony, a prosecutor used seven words on Monday to recap the accusations against the dozen Atlanta educators seated in a courtroom here.

headline: Netanyahu Warns of New ‘Hamastan’
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel spoke at a Jewish settlement the day before the Israeli election, warning that his opponents Tzipi Livni and Isaac Herzog would fail to protect residents.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel spoke at a Jewish settlement the day before the Israeli election, warning that his opponents Tzipi Livni and Isaac Herzog would fail to protect residents.

headline: Fringe Gone Wild
abstract: Not the wispy embellishment of days past, but a full-on takeover of a garment by its trim. At last, the ornamental becomes essential.
lead_paragraph: Not the wispy embellishment of days past, but a full-on takeover of a garment by its trim. At last, the ornamental becomes essential.

headline: 2 Years On, Cypriots Still Seething Over Banking Crisis
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: A slow recovery is underway and European officials have moved on, but in Cyprus many people are still bitter over the “bail-in” that was put in place.
lead_paragraph: A slow recovery is underway and European officials have moved on, but in Cyprus many people are still bitter over the “bail-in” that was put in place.

headline: U.N. Orders Review of 1961 Crash That Killed Dag Hammarskjold
abstract: The cause of the plane crash in September 1961 that killed the United Nations secretary general has never been established.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The plane had flown deep into the African night on a mission for peace. Finally, it drew near its destination in the copper mining region of what is now northern Zambia. The crew radioed for permission to descend. Then there was nothing.

headline: As Cyprus Recovers From Banking Crisis, Deep Scars Remain
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: Two years after an internationally brokered “bail-in,” in which many depositors were forced to help fund a eurozone rescue, there is much resentment.
lead_paragraph: NICOSIA, Cyprus — The financial world has pretty much moved on since Cyprus was briefly the epicenter of market anxiety.

headline: Russell Page, a Natural Artist
abstract: For the first time, his personal photographs, notes and unrealized designs have been brought together, by London’s Garden Museum.
lead_paragraph: This spring, London’s Garden Museum is exhibiting the work of the landscape designer Russell Page, perhaps the leading horticultural talent of the 20th century, who was, by his own account, “the most famous garden designer no one has ever heard of.” A master of structuring nature with an architect’s eye, Page, whose clients included Marella Agnelli, Oscar de  la Renta and Lady Bird Johnson, created mesmerizing green spaces with clipped shrubs, gleaming ponds and sweeping vistas. For the first time, his personal photographs, notes and unrealized designs have been brought together, shedding light on the passion and process of the late luminary.

headline: ‘Color Purple’ Revival Names Its Celie and Shug
abstract: Cynthia Erivo will play the lead role, with Jennifer Hudson also starring, in a stripped-down revival of the musical that is to begin performances in November.
lead_paragraph: A stripped-down production of “The Color Purple,” the musical adaptation of the Pulitzer Prize-winning novel, will feature an up-and-coming British theater star and an Academy Award-winning American actress when it opens on Broadway this fall.

headline: Court Strikes on Insider Trading, and Congress Lobs Back
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Insider Trading']
abstract: Two bills would broaden the law, but the proposed changes could make it even harder to recognize the line between permissible and illegal trades.
lead_paragraph: Sir Isaac Newton’s third law of motion was that “for every action there is an equal and opposite reaction.” The response from Congress to an appeals court decision in United States v. Newman, which overturned the insider trading convictions of two hedge fund managers, is perhaps more an overreaction.

headline: The Moment
abstract: Pieces for the home that bring elegance of form to the most basic functions.
lead_paragraph: Pieces for the home that bring elegance of form to the most basic functions.

headline: Memories Weaken Without Reinforcement, Study Finds
abstract: A report shows that people’s ability to remember something and the pattern of brain activity that thing generates both appear to diminish when a competing memory gets stronger.
lead_paragraph: What happens to forgotten memories — old computer passwords, friends’ previous phone numbers?

headline: What We’re Reading Now
abstract: Food news from K-Cups to a yogurt cartel.
lead_paragraph: The Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics is rolling out a new nutrition seal, “Kids Eat Right,” for select foods. However, it’s unclear what exactly the label implies, since the first food to display the seal is Kraft Singles, a product whose connection to real cheese is so dubious that the FDA ordered the company to stop calling it “cheese food” in 2002. Bizarrely, the academy insists the seal is not an endorsement but just an advertisement for its Kids Eat Right educational website. No wonder parents think sugary drinks are healthy.

headline: Obama Grass-Roots Group Trying to Find a Role for 2016
abstract: The remnants of President Obama’s grassroots campaign apparatus, Organizing for Action, has been in a period of flux in the last month as it tries to find a place among Democratic groups heading into 2016.
lead_paragraph: The remnants of President Obama’s grass-roots campaign apparatus, Organizing for Action, have been in a period of flux in the last month as the organization tries to find a place among Democratic groups heading into 2016.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Sen. Tom Cotton’s Geography Lesson
abstract: The senator made some unusual comments about territory Iran controls.
lead_paragraph: Republican Sen. Tom Cotton of Arkansas, who last week wrote an open letter to Iran asserting that its leaders “may not fully understand our constitutional system,” helpfully noted on Sunday that Iran already controls Tehran, which is its capital.

headline: Angels Maintain Realm Amid a Star’s Relapse
abstract: The Angels have learned to thrive without the best version of Josh Hamilton, whose latest drug-related relapse has further clouded his future.
lead_paragraph: TEMPE, Ariz. — Matt Joyce joined the Los Angeles Angels in an off-season trade, and his new teammates sometimes amaze him. Joyce made an All-Star team once, for the Tampa Bay Rays, but players like Mike Trout and Albert Pujols seem otherworldly to him in batting practice.

headline: Kendrick Lamar on His New Album and the Weight of Clarity
abstract: With “To Pimp a Butterfly,” a challenging 75-minute story of “survivor’s guilt,” Mr. Lamar is doubling down on the concept album.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Following the success of his major label debut, “good kid, m.A.A.d. city,” in 2012, the rapper Kendrick Lamar did not indulge in earthly luxuries. Instead, he got baptized.

headline: Expansion by Mideast Airlines Sets Off a Skirmish in the U.S.
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Travel and Vacations', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues']
abstract: Domestic airports, travelers and hotels worry that questioning open skies agreements could turn the clock back to more protectionist policies.
lead_paragraph: Like many airports around the country, Orlando International in Florida has made efforts to attract foreign carriers in recent years. They have paid off; Orlando now gets more than 40 foreign flights a day from places like Germany, Brazil and Colombia.

headline: 1965: Deputies Beat Rights Marchers
keywords: ['Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Segregation and Desegregation']
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Mounted deputies club demonstrators in Alabama in 1965.
lead_paragraph: MONTGOMERY, Ala. — Mounted sheriff’s deputies swinging clubs, canes and ropes charged civil-rights demonstrators today [March 16], injuring at least eight. One of those injured was a white college professor, Donald Hope, 38, of Juniata College, Huntingdon, Pa. He suffered scalp lacerations. The 600 demonstrators, mostly students, were taking part in a march on the Capitol building. Though the mounted police charge broke up the march, the demonstrators later regrouped and reached the Capitol building armed with a parade permit and escorted by city police. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 17, 1965

headline: Paying for Hurricane Sandy
abstract: Victims of the storm rely on complicated government programs to receive money for their damaged homes.
lead_paragraph: Victims of the storm rely on complicated government programs to receive money for their damaged homes.

headline: Rand Paul Is Capturing an Audience; the Challenge Is Winning Votes
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In his unorthodox campaign for the 2016 Republican nomination, Senator Rand Paul is bringing his libertarian conservatism to audiences that are more inclined to vote Democratic.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — While his rivals were slogging their way across New Hampshire this weekend, Senator Rand Paul was here, some 1,700 miles away at the South by Southwest festival, where he was competing for oxygen not with other Republicans but with a Judd Apatow premiere and with Grumpy Cat — the Internet meme, in the fur.

headline: Wall Street Prosecutor Will Join WilmerHale
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Legal Profession', 'United States Attorneys']
abstract: WilmerHale said on Monday that it had hired Anjan Sahni, a senior federal prosecutor in the United States attorney’s office in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: A white-shoe law firm has poached another Wall Street prosecutor.

headline: Seamus Mullen’s El Colmado Butchery Fits in the Neighborhood
abstract: The chef’s combination butcher shop-restaurant opens in the meatpacking district; a spring-loaded muddler; Passover and Easter meals in a restaurant; and more.
lead_paragraph: To Shop: A Butcher in the Neighborhood

headline: Hillary Clinton Gets Irish Honor, and a Warm Embrace
abstract: On the eve of St. Patrick’s Day, Hillary Rodham Clinton was lucky enough to bask in the approval of a crowd of Irish and Irish-American power brokers who gathered in Manhattan for her induction into the Irish America Hall of Fame.
lead_paragraph: On the eve of St. Patrick’s Day, Hillary Rodham Clinton was lucky enough to bask in the approval of a crowd of Irish and Irish-American power brokers who gathered in Manhattan for her induction into the Irish America Hall of Fame.

headline: In Performance: T. Oliver Reid
abstract: Mr. Reid, with Lawrence Yurman on piano, sings “Take the A Train,” a number Mr. Reid performs in his show “Drop Me Off in Harlem,” on Sunday at the Metropolitan Room.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Reid, with Lawrence Yurman on piano, sings “Take the A Train,” a number Mr. Reid performs in his show “Drop Me Off in Harlem,” on Sunday at the Metropolitan Room.

headline: Sale of an Astérix Page Helps Families of Charlie Hebdo Victims
abstract: A page from an Astérix comic book is sold, with the proceeds going to families of the people killed in the attack at the Charlie Hebdo offices in Paris.
lead_paragraph: PARIS – An original Astérix comic book page fetched 150,000 euros, or about $160,000, at a sale at Christie’s here, with all the proceeds going to the families of those killed in the attack on the offices of the Charlie Hebdo satirical newspaper in January, according to the auction house.

headline: In Performance | T. Oliver Reid
abstract: Mr. Reid, with Lawrence Yurman on piano, sings the jazz standard “Sophisticated Lady,” a number Mr. Reid performs in his show “Drop Me Off in Harlem,” playing on March 22 at the Metropolitan Room.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Reid, with Lawrence Yurman on piano, sings the jazz standard “Sophisticated Lady,” a number Mr. Reid performs in his show “Drop Me Off in Harlem,” playing on March 22 at the Metropolitan Room.

headline: It May Be Time to Lighten Up When You’re Scaring the Kids
abstract: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas has made a name for himself by firing up the Republican base with blazing speeches that shred his opponents.
lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas has made a name for himself by firing up the Republican base with blazing speeches that shred his opponents.

headline: Lawyer Doubts Suspect’s Role in Ferguson Shootings
abstract: The lawyer for the man charged with shooting two police officers said he did not believe his client had fired the weapon.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — A lawyer for Jeffrey L. Williams, the 20-year-old suspect charged with shooting two officers during a demonstration outside the police station here, said Monday that he did not believe that his client had fired the shots.

headline: Retro Striped Knits for Spring
abstract: With a pair of well-worn, washed-out Levi’s, these throwback shirts and sweaters are charming, youthful and the best of the season.
lead_paragraph: With a pair of well-worn, washed-out Levi’s, these throwback shirts and sweaters are charming, youthful and the best of the season.

headline: Care Differs for American and African With Ebola
abstract: The latest American aid worker to contract Ebola overseas was quickly transported back to the United States; the course of care has been markedly different for a Sierra Leonean colleague who developed Ebola within days of the American.
lead_paragraph: The latest American aid worker to contract Ebola overseas, last week in Sierra Leone, was swiftly evacuated to a specialized treatment center for infected health workers run by the British Defense Ministry in the country’s capital, Freetown, then on to the National Institutes of Health clinical center in Bethesda, Md. Doctors at the center said Monday that his condition had worsened from serious to critical since his arrival on Friday.

headline: Haitian Leader’s Power Grows as Scandals Swirl
abstract: Michel Martelly runs Haiti without a Parliament and has been accused of protecting a network of friends who have been arrested on charges like murder and drug trafficking.
lead_paragraph: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — With a brisk clap of his hands, Michel Martelly summed up the first steps he would take if he ever left the music business and became the president of Haiti.

headline: Behind Closed Doors
abstract: Bombarded by imagery all day at work, the renowned advertising provocateur Sam Shahid comes home to, well, very little.
lead_paragraph: Bombarded by imagery all day at work, the renowned advertising provocateur Sam Shahid comes home to, well, very little.

headline: Imaging the Israeli Settlements
abstract: Jeremy Ashkenas describes what went into creating the graphics and visuals that accompanied an article about expanding Israeli settlements.
lead_paragraph: Jodi Rudoren’s recent article on expanding Israeli settlements was accompanied by striking visuals that helped to tell the story of how rapidly the settlements have grown.

headline: Houthi Rebels Release Detained Yemeni Ministers
abstract: Houthi rebels released Yemen’s former prime minister and members of his cabinet after nearly two months, in a sign of some progress between the groups.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Houthi rebels released Yemen’s former prime minister and members of his cabinet after nearly two months of house detention on Monday, in a sign of some progress toward easing the country’s chaotic political crisis.

headline: A New Showcase in Paris Celebrates the Art of Pen and Paper
abstract: “Écriture,” at the concept boutique Merci, highlights iconic stationery and desktop accouterments.
lead_paragraph: The pen may be mightier than the sword, but it has admittedly lost some of its potency in the Internet age. “Écriture (Writing),” a new product showcase at the Paris concept store Merci, aims to celebrate the analog with a display of historic and iconic paper goods and desktop accouterments. Notable wares include those by the century-old Swiss manufacturer Caran d’Ache, from high-quality Technograph graphite pencils and water-soluble Prismalo colored pencils, both of which the company has been making for 80-plus years, to ballpoint pens in the brand’s 849 model, which are being sold for the first time outside of Switzerland. Other featured products include notepads and folio cases by the French brand Exacompta and gold ballpoint pens and molded glass pencils by the Danish company Hay.

headline: Why Female Athletes Shouldn’t Have to Beat Men
keywords: ['Athletics and Sports', 'Domestic Violence', 'Gender', 'Mixed Martial Arts', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: The mixed martial artist Ronda Rousey says she won’t fight a man — and she shouldn’t be expected to.
lead_paragraph: The mixed martial artist Ronda Rousey has defeated 11 opponents, the most recent one in only 14 seconds. Perhaps predictably, this has led to questions about whether she will fight men.

headline: Netanyahu Rules Out Palestinian State
abstract: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, in an interview with NRG the day before the general election, said that a Palestinian state would not be created if he remained prime minister.
lead_paragraph: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, in an interview with NRG the day before the general election, said that a Palestinian state would not be created if he remained prime minister.

headline: Uniting Arabs in a Race for the Knesset
abstract: In Ayman Odeh’s campaign for a seat in the Knesset, he hopes to unite Arab Israeli political factions and boost voter turnout.
lead_paragraph: In Ayman Odeh’s campaign for a seat in the Knesset, he hopes to unite Arab Israeli political factions and boost voter turnout.

headline: Decoding the Rules of Conversation
abstract: The French love to land zingers. The British live in the land of irony. And Americans? It’s all about reassurance.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — MY kids have recently picked up a worrying French slang word: bim (pronounced “beam”). It’s what children say in the schoolyard here after they’ve proved someone wrong, or skewered him with a biting remark. English equivalents like “gotcha” or “booyah” don’t carry the same sense of gleeful vanquish, and I doubt British or American kids use them quite as often.

headline: Questioning the Value of Health Apps
abstract: More than 100,000 apps claim to help consumers track their conditions. That doesn’t mean they are all accurate.
lead_paragraph: A bodybuilder presses the iPhone’s camera with a fingertip, and his heart rate and blood oxygen levels appear on the screen. A fellow in pajamas steps onto a scale, peers at his smartphone, and sighs dejectedly. A runner races along the waterfront, a cellphone strapped to her pumping arms.

headline: Tool of N.C.A.A. Bracket Ignorance: Your Basketball Smarts
abstract: If the annual rite of picking the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament winners gives fans anything, it’s the illusion of control.
lead_paragraph: There are more than 9.2 quintillion ways to fill out the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament bracket, and as March Madness gets underway, more than 100 million Americans are determined to get it exactly right.

headline: Johann Johannsson’s ‘Drone Mass’ Bridges Ancient and Modern at Temple of Dendur
abstract: A performance of “Drone Mass,” scheduled for Tuesday, reflects the resonance that the musical drone has gained amid fascination with the airborne variety.
lead_paragraph: Audience members won’t have to duck their heads at Tuesday’s world premiere of Johann Johannsson’s “Drone Mass,” and security guards at the Temple of Dendur need not worry about unauthorized surveillance photography. No pilotless aircraft accompanies this oratorio, which the Metropolitan Museum of Art presents in a performance by the vocal group Roomful of Teeth and members of the American Contemporary Music Ensemble, with Mr. Johannsson on electronics.

headline: U.S. Oil Prices Fall to Six-Year Low
abstract: The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries remains reluctant to prop up prices, saying that American production should level off.
lead_paragraph: Oil prices fell to six-year lows on Monday in the face of concerns that a glut in the United States was outpacing already-brimming storage facilities.

headline: Clever Coastline Coasters
abstract: These North, East, Gulf and West drink holders discourage guests from swapping springtime germs — and look great doing it.
lead_paragraph: Customized coasters — linen squares embroidered with friends’ names, thick felt cutouts emblazoned with their initials — are so much more than an opportunity to protect the furniture while posing as a thoughtful host. For me and my fellow hypochondriacs, they’re really just a vehicle for containing each guest’s … germs, especially now that the seasons are changing and warmer days will give way to spring colds and mucous-y allergies. “No, no, Emily. That’s not your glass. See? It’s sitting on Katherine’s coaster. Speaking of glasses, how’s your pinkeye coming along?”

headline: Older Really Can Mean Wiser
abstract: Research is catching up with the idea that, in some ways, people apparently grow smarter with age.
lead_paragraph: Behind all those canned compliments for older adults — spry! wily! wise! — is an appreciation for something that scientists have had a hard time characterizing: mental faculties that improve with age.

headline: Review: Christopher Wheeldon’s ‘Swan Lake’ Focuses on the Men
abstract: Mr. Wheeldon’s 2004 production of Tchaikovsky’s 1870s cygnine classic, revived by the Pennsylvania Ballet, moves the story to the dance studios of the Paris Opera.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — When, oh, when will America acquire an even half-decent staging of Tchaikovsky’s full-length “Swan Lake”? Having long had most of the world’s best “Nutcracker” productions, it now has the world’s two best stagings of Tchaikovsky’s “The Sleeping Beauty”: at American Ballet Theater (Alexei Ratmansky’s, new this month) and Boston Ballet (Ninette de Valois’s, with supplementary choreography by Frederick Ashton). But what about “Swan Lake”?

headline: Review: In ‘One Big Happy,’ It’s Mom and Dad and Mom
abstract: A lesbian (Elisha Cuthbert of “24”) becomes pregnant with the help of a straight friend who then impulsively marries, on this new NBC comedy.
lead_paragraph: It’s no longer unusual to find nontraditional families on television and for people in those families to be having babies. Apparently the makers of “One Big Happy,” an intelligence-insulting sitcom that begins Tuesday night on NBC, haven’t noticed, because every minute of their show screams: “Hey! We’ve got a pregnant lesbian! Bet you’ve never seen that before!”

headline: Live and Kicking: Soccer Games to Watch
abstract: This is one of those weeks that builds to a terrific finish on Sunday, but there will be plenty to watch before then.
lead_paragraph: This is one of those weeks that build to a terrific finish Sunday. But there will be plenty to watch before then. The Times soccer editor, Andrew Das, a shameless Ajax supporter, suggests what to watch.

headline: Seeking Hospitality Outside Its Traditional Realm
abstract: Tony Chi, founder of Tonychi & Associates, says business travel may have lost its intimacy in the era of big planes and tighter security.
lead_paragraph: I’M a control freak, and I guess I’m proud of that because that means that my clients don’t have to worry — I’ll do that. Since I’m a designer, and principal and founder of Tonychi & Associates, it’s very important for me to go where the jobs are, and my travels can take me anywhere throughout the United States, Europe or Asia.

headline: Smaller Airports Struggle Against Big Airports’ Lures
keywords: ['AIRPORTS', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Business Travel', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: As large airports attract travelers with more flights and lower fares, small and midsize airports use incentives and marketing to increase traffic.
lead_paragraph: TUCSON — THERE were so many people booked on the 8 a.m. bus trip to the Phoenix airport the other morning that the Arizona Shuttle company had to call in a bigger vehicle.

headline: Preparing for Ebola, but Stopping Lassa Fever
abstract: When the disease killing residents of Benin turned out to be Lassa fever, the World Health Organization used protocols for Ebola to stem the illness.
lead_paragraph: Last fall, with the Ebola epidemic raging, the small nation of Benin, a few countries away from the outbreak zone, experienced a cluster of unexplained deaths.

headline: At 73, a First TV Job at the Final Four
abstract: Bill Raftery, who has called the Final Four on radio since the early 1990s, is a rare sportscaster to wait until 70 or older to reach a television pinnacle.
lead_paragraph: Bill Raftery’s summons to call his first Final Four for CBS and TBS next month came at age 73 — and was only 32 years in the making.

headline: Why Is the Timeline of ‘The Jinx’ So Confusing?
abstract: The question of whether chronology has been obscured or fudged for dramatic effect might leave some feeling cheated.
lead_paragraph: Following Sunday’s finale of “The Jinx: The Life and Deaths of Robert Durst” on HBO, questions have arisen about the timeline of events presented in the documentary. (Gawker has a particularly detailed account here.) Whether it’s because of those unanswered questions or for other reasons, the director Andrew Jarecki has canceled previously scheduled appearances on “The Tonight Show” and MSNBC’s “All In With Chris Hayes,” as well as with other media outlets.

headline: The Writer’s Room
abstract: Surrounded by photographs, family mementos and the clamor of everyday life, five authors offer a glimpse into the spaces where they create.
lead_paragraph: Surrounded by photographs, family mementos and the clamor of everyday life, five authors offer a glimpse into the spaces where they create.

headline: A Sixth Season for ‘Community,’ Rescued by Yahoo Screen
abstract: The sixth season of “Community” opens Tuesday online with the introduction of a new character who has been hired as an administrative consultant at Greendale Community College.
lead_paragraph: It’s an insufficiently appreciated fact that for five seasons, television’s most highly conceptual, self-referential, pulverize-the-fourth-wall show was carried by a television dinosaur — NBC, the oldest of the big broadcasters. That show was “Community,” and while NBC may not have been entirely happy with it — the seasons got shorter and farther apart, and the show’s creator, Dan Harmon, was banished for Season 4 — the network stuck it out for 97 episodes of sometimes forced but often sweetly hilarious meta-comedy.

headline: Neanderthal Jewelry: The Eagle Talon Line
abstract: The early humans may have used the talons of white-tailed eagles to make jewelry 130,000 years ago.
lead_paragraph: Neanderthals may have used the talons of white-tailed eagles to make jewelry 130,000 years ago, long before the appearance of modern humans in Europe, according to a new study published in PLOS One. At an archaeological site in Croatia, researchers discovered the talons, above, with notches and abrasions suggesting they had been made into necklaces or bracelets. Eagle talons may have had symbolic value to Neanderthals, the researchers said.

headline: Banco de Madrid Files for Bankruptcy Protection
abstract: The filing was aimed at stopping a flight of deposits from the bank, whose parent company in Andorra was accused by the U.S. of money laundering.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Banco de Madrid, a small Spanish bank, filed for bankruptcy protection on Monday after a United States government report last week accused its parent company in Andorra of laundering money on behalf of organized crime groups in China and Russia, as well as for government officials in Venezuela.

headline: Cablevision to Offer HBO Now Streaming Service for Internet Customers
abstract: HBO Now, which will offer all of HBO’s original programming, will make its debut in early April, coinciding with the start of the new season of “Game of Thrones.”
lead_paragraph: Cablevision said on Monday that it would offer HBO’s new Internet streaming service, HBO Now, becoming the first cable provider to announce plans to distribute the service, which does not require a traditional TV subscription.

headline: Why Icicles Look the Way They Do
abstract: An atlas, not surprisingly out of Canada, documents the drip, drip, drip that determines those curious and beautiful shapes.
lead_paragraph: The reason Stephen Morris studies icicles is simple. They are common and beautiful, and they make you wonder. And they are now documented online in all their chilly, wet glory in the Icicle Atlas.

headline: Dark Knight
abstract: Fleeing the sunny Southern gentility of his childhood, a budding film director turns a New York house into a louche fantasy.
lead_paragraph: Fleeing the sunny Southern gentility of his childhood, a budding film director turns a New York house into a louche fantasy.

headline: White House Treading Carefully in Israeli Elections
abstract: President Obama, whose bitter differences with Prime Minster Benjamin Netanyahu have intensified in recent weeks, is closely watching the outcome of Israeli elections on Tuesday, in which Mr. Netanyahu’s power is on the line.
lead_paragraph: President Barack Obama, whose bitter differences with Prime Minster Benjamin Netanyahu have intensified in recent weeks, will be closely watching the outcome of Israeli elections on Tuesday, in which Mr. Netanyahu’s power is on the line.

headline: Out of Kony’s Shadow
abstract: Allowing focus on Kony to slacken could be a grave misstep that costs thousands of lives.
lead_paragraph: Since 2011, when President Obama sent U.S. Special Forces to central Africa to support the mission to capture warlord Joseph Kony, things on the ground in northeastern Congo have improved: The world has recently celebrated the capture of the top Lord’s Resistance Army commander, Dominic Ongwen. Violent attacks have declined dramatically. Some folks are farming again, and markets are now packed with rice, vegetables and peanuts.

headline: Robert Durst Says He ‘Killed Them All’
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Serial Murders', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Television']
abstract: “What the hell did I do? Killed them all, of course,” Robert Durst whispered to himself in the final episode of the HBO documentary “The Jinx.”
lead_paragraph: “What the hell did I do? Killed them all, of course,” Robert Durst whispered to himself in the final episode of the HBO documentary “The Jinx.”

headline: Lost in Transition After Cancer
abstract: It took me a long time to be able to say I was a cancer patient. Now that my treatment is done, I’m struggling to figure out who I am.
lead_paragraph: “You are being deported,” a surgeon announced to me last fall. That’s a scary thing for a child of two immigrants to hear. But he was referring to the removal of my port, a medical device implanted just beneath my right collarbone — a gateway for the dozens of rounds of chemotherapy, antibiotics and blood transfusions that have entered my body since I received a leukemia diagnosis at age 22.

headline: Review: ‘The Top of His Game,’ a W. C. Heinz Sportswriting Collection
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Athletics and Sports', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: This collection, edited by Bill Littlefield, offers a journey back to an era when boxing and horse racing loomed large in the psyche of the American sports fan.
lead_paragraph: W. C. Heinz performed so splendidly as a correspondent during World War II that upon reporting home, The New York Sun rewarded him with a long vacation, a handsome bonus and a new assignment. Heinz, 32, had proven overseas that he had an uncommon eye for human interest stories, so he was offered a promotion to the Washington bureau. It was a coveted position at which many of his colleagues would have jumped.

headline: The Toll of a Solitary Life
abstract: New research shows that loneliness and social isolation, even for people who prefer their own company, is bad for their health.
lead_paragraph: Do you like being alone? New research from Brigham Young University shows just how bad loneliness and social isolation, even for people who prefer their own company, can be for health.

headline: Don’t Flush That Wipe!
keywords: ['Bathrooms and Toilets', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Waste Materials and Disposal']
abstract: Manufacturers need to admit that their wipes are not actually “flushable.”
lead_paragraph: This is not a particularly savory topic, but the brave people who run modern sewer systems around the world face a growing menace: the “flushable” wet wipe.

headline: U.S. Announces Plan to Combat Illegal Fishing
keywords: ['Fishing, Commercial', 'Seafood', 'Black Markets', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: A new enforcement program would attempt to track fish from where they were caught to how they were shipped.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has announced a plan to crack down on the multibillion-dollar global black market in seafood, an effort that would try to trace a fish’s story from where it was caught to how it was shipped.

headline: National Guard Praises Record of 4 Who Died in Helicopter Crash
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Helicopters', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The four men had several deployments to war zones and a long record of responding to hurricanes, floods and oil spills, Guard commanders said Monday.
lead_paragraph: The four Louisiana National Guard members who died last week in a helicopter crash near the Gulf Coast had multiple deployments to war zones and a long record of responding to hurricanes, floods and oil spills, Guard commanders said Monday.

headline: Too Much Cardiac Testing
abstract: A new guideline from the American College of Physicians says such tests on adults without symptoms are not doing any good. The lesson: Ask why.
lead_paragraph: The electrocardiogram you got at your most recent physical may have been a waste of time and money.

headline: Review: Meghan Trainor Performs at Irving Plaza
abstract: In her second sold-out show in New York, Ms. Trainor gave the concert performance of an almost-star.
lead_paragraph: There were about a dozen items of clothing for sale at Meghan Trainor’s concert Sunday night at Irving Plaza. T-shirts in loud colors and sweatshirts that trumpeted “All About That Bass,” after Ms. Trainor’s breakout hit, took up a large swath of the wall behind the merchandise table, as if they’d been eagerly wheatpasted. Nearby, the tour sponsor, HP, set up a photo booth encouraging fans to “Capture Your Meghan Moment.”

headline: Review: Charles Lloyd Returns to the Village Vanguard
abstract: Mr. Lloyd’s quartet performed at the New York club for the first time in about 40 years.
lead_paragraph: Charles Lloyd seemed perfectly at home onstage at the Village Vanguard on Sunday night, working with standard equipment: his tenor saxophone, his quartet, his tunes. Awash in the dimensions of his sound in the room, it was almost possible to imagine that this was a regular visit, a piece of the usual bounty for jazz lovers in New York.

headline: The Gardner Masterpieces, Still Missing, But Visible Again Online
abstract: The Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston has created a virtual tour online that details the 13 works stolen from the museum in 1990.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON – To mark a somber date, the 25th anniversary of the largest art theft in American history, the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum here, has created a “virtual tour” of the 13 items, including paintings by Rembrandt and Vermeer, that were stolen from the museum on March 18th, 1990.

headline: Hillary Clinton Criticizes Republicans for a ‘Trifecta Against Women’
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton scolded congressional Republicans for mounting a “trifecta against women” by delaying the nomination of Loretta E. Lynch for attorney general and playing politics with legislation on human trafficking.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton scolded congressional Republicans on Monday for mounting a “trifecta against women” by delaying the nomination of Loretta E. Lynch for attorney general by tying it to stalled legislation on human trafficking.

headline: MoMA Lands Jasper Johns’s ‘Painted Bronze’
abstract: A hand-painted bronze recreation of a painter’s tools will be the first important early sculpture by Jasper Johns to enter the Museum of Modern Art’s collection.
lead_paragraph: It’s a small work of art — precisely the size of an old Savarin coffee can jammed with artist’s paintbrushes — but in the history of postwar art and in the career of Jasper Johns, one of the most important artists of the last half century, it looms large.

headline: Dreams on Wheels, and Their Unsung Stylists
abstract: A look at the sketches of artists who worked at Ford, Chrysler and General Motors between 1946 and 1973.
lead_paragraph: A look at the sketches of artists who worked at Ford, Chrysler and General Motors between 1946 and 1973.

headline: Schneiderman Issuing Ethics Plan Aimed at New York Legislators
keywords: ['State Legislatures', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Campaign Finance', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Attorney General Eric T. Schneiderman wants to prohibit lawmakers from holding outside jobs and to end a widely criticized system of per diem payments.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Staking out a broad vision of ethics reform amid a swirl of other proposals in the capital, New York’s attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, called for an elimination of all outside jobs for state legislators and the end of a widely criticized system of per diem payments.

headline: New Albums From Sirens, Zaleski and Miller
abstract: Glenn Zaleski’s “My Ideal,” Marcus Miller’s “Afrodeezia” and Sleeping With Sirens’ “Madness” are being released on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: SLEEPING WITH SIRENS

headline: What Patients Prefer to Know
abstract: Whether “doctors aren’t discussing it or if patients aren’t hearing it,” when it comes to cancer and its treatment a study found that many patients knew little.
lead_paragraph: If you had a serious illness, how much would you want to know about it?

headline: Music in Review: Performances by Sasha Cooke, Escher String Quartet and Ensemble Signal
abstract: The mezzo-soprano performed at Zankel Hall; the Escher String Quartet played a passionate show at Alice Tully Hall; and Ensemble Signal covered works by Bach and Michael Gordon at Miller Theater.
lead_paragraph: ESCHER STRING QUARTET

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers respond to articles about science and health.

headline: Valeant’s Sweetened Bid for Salix May Have Delivered 2 Knockouts
abstract: The higher offer quickly put an end to Endo’s rival bid, but the added cost, along with the debt Valeant already holds, may hurt the company.
lead_paragraph: The sweetened $11 billion bid by Valeant Pharmaceuticals for Salix Pharmaceuticals may have scored two knockouts. By coming up with an extra 9 percent over its previous offer, the acquisitive drug maker, now backed by the hedge fund executive William A. Ackman, quickly put an end to a rival bid from Endo International. But the extra cash required, and the debt already on its balance sheet, leave Valeant’s business model looking wobbly.

headline: Layoffs at Food Start-Up Hampton Creek
abstract: While layoffs at start-ups are not uncommon, it’s unusual for them to occur so soon after their coffers have been replenished with cash.
lead_paragraph: Hampton Creek, a high-profile food start-up that has attracted investors and talent from the technology industry, laid off nearly a fifth of its work force last month, just months after announcing it had raised $90 million in funding.

headline: Walkabout: St. Patrick’s Day Parades in Unexpected Places
abstract: A weekly capsule of travel news curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Seeing Green Some say everyone is Irish on St. Patrick’s Day. Here, several places to watch a parade — including a couple you probably would never expect. (petergreenberg.com)

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Tuning Out Digital Buzz, for an Intimate Communion With Art
abstract: Nothing can substitute for physically experiencing an artwork, despite the convenience of viewing it online.
lead_paragraph: Once upon a time, our big museums were the “quiet cars” of a fast-track American culture industry. Like libraries, they were places where the volume was low, the energy slow, the technology unobtrusive. You came to them to look, to think and, in the days before museums became the prime social spaces they are now, to be alone in a small, like-minded crowd. You could take a little art home by hitting the postcard rack in the gift shop. But the only way you would retain most of what you saw was by spending time in the galleries and imprinting things on your brain.

headline: The Forgotten Man of Bauhaus, Almost
abstract: The Xanti Schawinsky show is the latest in a series of expositions to reassess the reputations of lesser-known members of the Bauhaus.
lead_paragraph: The Xanti Schawinsky show is the latest in a series of expositions to reassess the reputations of lesser-known members of the Bauhaus.

headline: In Miami Beach, the Faena Forum Is to Open in December
abstract: The Argentine developer Alan Faena calls his newest project a multidisciplinary center, and one of those disciplines is art.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — In the last few years, the Miami arts landscape has both rapidly expanded and been roiled with upheavals as the region tries to shore up a permanent cultural beachhead in a place better known until recently for an annual art fair and an actual beach. The next entry onto the scene, the Faena Forum, will be unusual in its format, design and leadership, and it won’t resemble anything else nearby when it is completed in December in a formerly sleepy section of Miami Beach.

headline: Paul Ha Raises the Cultural Profile at M.I.T.
abstract: Mr. Ha, the director of the List Visual Arts Center, has worked to raise awareness of the arts collection at a school more closely linked to science.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, MASS. — Shortly after Paul Ha became director of the List Visual Arts Center at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in late 2011, he was surprised to learn that Joan Jonas, the pioneering performance art and video artist, was a longtime faculty member at the university. He invited her to lunch to introduce himself and reveal his plan: to propose her as the artist representative for the United States at the 2015 Venice Biennale.

headline: Archive of Xanti Schawinsky, Bauhaus Artist, Is Exhibited in Zurich
abstract: The most comprehensive survey of the work of this designer, a core figure in mid-20th-century avant-garde circles, is on display at the Migros Museum.
lead_paragraph: How could an artist and designer as prolific, gifted and charismatic as Xanti Schawinsky — a central figure in mid-20th-century avant-garde circles in Europe and the United States — have come close to being forgotten?

headline: In ‘Magna Carta: Law, Liberty, Legacy,’ a Document Resonates
abstract: An exhibition at the British Library explores how people around the world have harnessed the 1215 charter in pressing for individual liberties.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When King John of England and a group of rebellious barons gathered in a marshy field just outside London in 1215, creating a foundation of modern democracy was not on their minds.

headline: Museums Seek to Lure, Then Lock In, Teenage Connoisseurs
abstract: Mindful of the need to cement relationships early, art institutions are pouring creative energies into programs that are likely to beguile the young.
lead_paragraph: Walking past Ghirlandaio’s “Old Man With a Young Boy” at the Louvre over Christmas break, I listened as my 18-year-old son, Ethan, explained how the artist was among the first to portray eye contact within a portrait; how Leonardo used the color blue to convey distance; how Raphael was a favorite of the Medicis. At the Musée d’Orsay, I watched as my 16-year-old daughter, Maya, dragged Ethan over to Manet’s “Le Déjeuner sur l’Herbe” — a painting they had both studied — and then debated its merits.

headline: Four Museums Plan Their Centennials
abstract: The Baltimore Museum of Art, the Cleveland Museum of Art, the Memphis Brooks Museum of Art and the Minneapolis Institute of Arts are set to celebrate.
lead_paragraph: Four American museums, established after the first generation of major museums got their start in the 1870s, are observing their centennials this year and next: the Baltimore Museum of Art, incorporated in 1914 and celebrating its anniversary through early summer; the Minneapolis Institute of Arts, opened in 1915; the Memphis Brooks Museum of Art, which opened in 1916; and the Cleveland Museum of Art, which opened in 1916. And, not surprisingly, the centennial celebrations of the four museums look back at their history and the civic leaders who founded them, in many cases using 21st-century ways to engage local communities.

headline: A Document That Resonates Far and Wide
abstract: From original documents to curios, items from the British Library’s exhibition on Magna Carta.
lead_paragraph: From original documents to curios, items from the British Library’s exhibition on Magna Carta.

headline: At Museum of Arts and Design, a Swan Song for Lowery Stokes Sims
abstract: Lowery Stokes Sims is retiring as chief curator of the Museum of Arts and Design with a valedictory show that reflects her inclusive philosophy.
lead_paragraph: Robin Cembalest, an arts consultant and former executive editor of ARTnews, used the Yiddish word “haimish” to describe Lowery Stokes Sims, the chief curator of the Museum of Arts and Design. Roughly translated, “haimish” means all the good qualities associated with home: informal, warm, approachable and comforting.

headline: A Sly Fusion of Creativity and History
abstract: Exhibits at the International Museum of the Reformation in Geneva include everything from talking table settings to 16th- and 17th-century sheet music for hymns.
lead_paragraph: Exhibits at the International Museum of the Reformation in Geneva include everything from talking table settings to 16th- and 17th-century sheet music for hymns.

headline: A Sampling of Art Exhibitions, From Coast to Coast
abstract: Leonardo da Vinci, meet Frida Kahlo. Spring 2015 shows at American museums showcase artists from around the world and through the centuries.
lead_paragraph: Leonardo da Vinci, meet Frida Kahlo. Spring 2015 shows at American museums showcase artists from around the world and through the centuries.

headline: Museums Showcase Attitudes and Beliefs as Well as Objects
abstract: The Museum of Tolerance in Los Angeles and the planned New York City Peace Museum are among the institutions that exist to promote specific ideas.
lead_paragraph: Most museums are defined by the objects they display. A fine-arts museum exhibits paintings and sculptures. A history museum shows artifacts and documents. A science museum presents experiments.

headline: Reformation Museum in Geneva Blends Humor and Wonder
abstract: To beguile visitors, the International Museum of the Reformation has created inventive and often witty displays that immerse onlookers in the period.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Finding the International Museum of the Reformation is almost as complicated as explaining the historical movement it chronicles.

headline: Spring Museum Exhibitions, From Masks to Renoirs
abstract: Art shows from Maine to Southern California will offer — you name it — the Renaissance masters, Nigerian palaces and international Pop Art.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a sampling of promising exhibitions around the country this spring.

headline: Cedar Grove, Peabody Essex and Other Niche Museums Foray Into Contemporary Art
abstract: Smaller historical institutions are reframing their core holdings to engage newer, younger audiences.
lead_paragraph: Cedar Grove, the Thomas Cole National Historic Site in Catskill, N.Y., is devoted to the life and art of that Hudson River School painter, who is known all over the world for his richly detailed landscapes.

headline: Met Founds Research Institute Centered on Lauder’s Cubist Gift
abstract: A scholarly center at the Metropolitan Museum, founded with a promised donation, will focus on the history of Modern art, particularly Cubism.
lead_paragraph: When the cosmetics magnate Leonard A. Lauder was trying to decide which museum should inherit his $1 billion collection of Cubist art, he asked those he was considering how they would keep the collection alive as a focus of intellectual inquiry and public interest. “We wanted to avoid the usual ‘donation, installation, catalog and then what?’ ” said Emily Braun, Mr. Lauder’s longtime curator.

headline: Children’s Museum of Pittsburgh Leads Movement to Acquire Tenants
abstract: Institutions with extra space are supplementing their incomes and even helping develop communities by acting as landlords to other organizations.
lead_paragraph: Across the country, museums are playing landlord.

headline: A Fervid Experiment Recalled
abstract: Images of Robert Rauschenberg, Merce Cunningham, Josef Albers and others in their Black Mountain heyday.
lead_paragraph: Images of Robert Rauschenberg, Merce Cunningham, Josef Albers and others in their Black Mountain heyday.

headline: For Lower East Side, Chinese-Americans and Brontës, Museums of Their Own
abstract: The Lower East Side Tenement Museum and the Brontë Parsonage Museum are among the institutions concentrating on small communities.
lead_paragraph: Pushcart peddlers once filled Orchard Street. Early-20th-century Socialists gathered in Straus Square. The streets of the Lower East Side of Manhattan are indelibly stamped with the lives of the immigrants who made them their entry points to the United States. Walking these same streets today “can be the best classroom to the city’s history,” said Annie Polland, senior vice president for programs and education at the Lower East Side Tenement Museum.

headline: In the Spirit of Black Mountain College, an Avant-Garde Incubator
abstract: A museum in Asheville, N.C., celebrates a home to art titans in the 1930s, ’40s and ’50s, that champions experimentation among artists working today.
lead_paragraph: In the annals of 20th-century American art, few legends loom quite as large as that of Black Mountain College. Founded in 1933 by the classics scholar John Andrew Rice and the engineer Theodore Dreier, it was a progressive institution based in Black Mountain, a small North Carolina town that aimed to place art making at the heart of a liberal arts education. That same year, the Nazis forced the closing of another grand experiment, Germany’s Bauhaus school, prompting many of its teachers and students to decamp for the United States. Several landed at Black Mountain, most prominently Josef Albers, who was chosen to lead the art program, and his wife, Anni, who taught textile design and weaving.

headline: ‘American Dreaming’ Celebrates a Heady Era of Car Design
abstract: The show, at Lawrence Technological University, features sketches by more than 100 stylists who worked for the big automakers between 1946 and 1973.
lead_paragraph: Rodell Smith started drawing cars in grade school in the early 1930s. More than 80 years later, at 92, he’s still drawing them on the days he feels up to it. Mr. Smith worked nearly 40 years as a professional automotive stylist at Ford and Chrysler, and along with thousands of other mostly unheralded artists and craftsmen, he helped define the look of American progress in an era fueled by 300-horsepower optimism.

headline: The Met and RISD Are Among Museums Redisplaying Antiquities
abstract: Expensive renovations at institutions here and abroad come even amid demands for repatriation of ancient art.
