lead_paragraph: For years, the windows of the antiquities galleries at the RISD Museum, at the Rhode Island School of Design, were blocked out with color transparencies of ancient sites. The idea was to immerse visitors in the ambience of antiquity by shutting out external distractions.

headline: Museums Flex Their Multilingual, Multicultural Muscles
abstract: Museums across the country are expanding their programming for non-English speakers, from art workshops to activities rooted in other cultures.
lead_paragraph: As the Americans who are at least 5 years old and speak a language other than English at home now exceed 20 percent of the population, museums across the country are responding with bilingual and non-English educational programs for all ages.

headline: How a Rising Dollar Is Creating Trouble for Emerging Economies
keywords: ['US Dollar (Currency)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Interest Rates', 'Credit and Debt', 'Quantitative Easing']
abstract: As Fed policy makers try to guide the United States economy to prosperity, their actions are having outsize, often unpredictable effects worldwide.
lead_paragraph: In India, it is a leading electric utility, Jaiprakash Power Ventures, selling off facilities and negotiating with lenders to avoid a default, having increasing its debts thirtyfold in six years.

headline: Rangers’ Martin St. Louis Is Expected to Miss 10 to 14 Days
abstract: St. Louis, who appeared to hurt his right leg in Sunday’s win, joined goalie Henrik Lundqvist and defenseman Kevin Klein on the sidelines for the first-place Rangers.
lead_paragraph: The Rangers, who were already without goalie Henrik Lundqvist and defenseman Kevin Klein, said Monday that forward Martin St. Louis was expected to miss 10 to 14 days with a lower-body injury.

headline: Photos of the Day: India and Elsewhere
abstract: India and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: India and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: March 16, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Israel, Pakistan, Israel and Japan.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Israel, Pakistan, Israel and Japan.

headline: How to Be Both
abstract: Vulgar and restrained, loud and retiring, straight-up and mysterious. On the undiminished charisma of Sarah Lucas, the former rude girl of British art.
lead_paragraph: Vulgar and restrained, loud and retiring, straight-up and mysterious. On the undiminished charisma of Sarah Lucas, the former rude girl of British art.

headline: Crowning Preteen Beauty Queens
abstract: Ilana Panich-Linsman was forced to question her ideas about youth and beauty as she followed one contestant in the world of children’s beauty pageants.
lead_paragraph: Ilana Panich-Linsman was forced to question her ideas about youth and beauty as she followed one contestant in the world of children’s beauty pageants.

headline: Uber’s Chief Financial Officer to Leave Company
abstract: Brent Callinicos, the chief financial officer of Uber, plans to leave the ride-sharing company, in what will be one of the highest-level departures yet for the six-year-old start-up.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Brent Callinicos, the chief financial officer of Uber, plans to leave the ride-sharing company, in what will be one of the highest-level departures yet for the six-year-old start-up.

headline: Quirky $200 Million Art Venture Proves Just the Ticket for Tasmania
abstract: David Walsh, owner and creator of the Museum of Old and New Art, describes his showplace as a “subversive adult Disneyland.”
lead_paragraph: HOBART, Australia — For most of its existence, Tasmania was known as a faraway island at the bottom of Australia, a grim 19th-century redoubt where British colonial officers imprisoned convicts in the harshest of the empire’s jails and killed much of the aboriginal population.

headline: Review: In ‘Buyer & Cellar,’ a Visit to the Babs Cave
abstract: The Jonathan Tolins play, “Buyer & Cellar,” at the George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick, imagines the hiring of a caretaker for Barbra Streisand’s underground mall of keepsakes.
lead_paragraph: “Buyer & Cellar,” at the George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick, starts off with a warning. Its lone performer announces that the “premise is preposterous.” The story is fictional, he tells us. “You know that, right?”

headline: Marine Veteran Requests Deportation From Iran
abstract: Amir Hekmati, a dual citizen of the United States and Iran, has been imprisoned in Iran for more than three years.
lead_paragraph: Increasingly desperate to return to the United States, a Marine veteran of Iranian descent who has been incarcerated in Iran for three and a half years has renounced his Iranian citizenship, requested deportation and accused Iran of using American prisoners as “bargaining chips,” his family said Monday.

headline: As Cosmos Head to Cuba, Fans May Be Unable to Follow
abstract: The Cosmos are scheduled to play an exhibition match in June, but travel restrictions could make things difficult for their faithful to watch them.
lead_paragraph: The New York Cosmos will play in Cuba in June, but it may prove difficult for their fans to join them on the trip.

headline: Brazil Official Charged in Petrobras Bribery Case
abstract: The charges prosecutors on Monday filed against the treasurer of the ruling Workers Party, João Vaccari, and 26 others including a former high-ranking Petrobras executive, moved the payoff scandal closer to President Dilma Rousseff.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Prosecutors on Monday filed new corruption charges arising out of the huge bribery scheme at Petrobras, the national oil company, against the treasurer of the ruling Workers Party — putting additional pressure on President Dilma Rousseff at a time when she is fighting calls for her ouster over the burgeoning scandal.

headline: Failed by Law and Courts, Troops Come Home to Repossessions
keywords: ['ARBITRATION, CONCILIATION AND MEDIATION', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Deployed service members often cannot sue lenders for violating laws that protect them from repossessions and foreclosures because of legal language that forces them into arbitration.
lead_paragraph: Charles Beard, a sergeant in the Army National Guard, says he was on duty in the Iraqi city of Tikrit when men came to his California home to repossess the family car. Unless his wife handed over the keys, she would go to jail, they said.

headline: Vanuatu: Cyclone Toll Rises
abstract: International aid agencies were preparing to begin emergency helicopter flights on Tuesday to the remote outer islands of Vanuatu, as the death toll from a cyclone late last week rose to at least 24.
lead_paragraph: The cyclone that lashed the Pacific island nation of Vanuatu over the weekend killed at least 24 people, a United Nations office said, while on Tuesday relief workers said initial glimpses of the devastation on remoter islands indicated the death toll could rise, perhaps sharply. The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs said in a report issued Monday about Cyclone Pam that it had confirmed the 24 deaths across three parts of the islands: Tafea, Efate and Tanna. But that count did not include more isolated islands where fierce winds of 160 miles an hour and more leveled many homes.

headline: N.Y.U. Professor Is Barred by United Arab Emirates
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Foreign Workers', 'ACADEMIC FREEDOM', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Andrew Ross, who teaches at the New York campus and specializes in labor issues, has been an open critic of the poor treatment of migrant laborers in the monarchy.
lead_paragraph: The United Arab Emirates, where New York University opened a new campus last year, has barred an N.Y.U. professor from traveling to the monarchy after his criticism of the exploitation of migrant construction workers there.

headline: Egypt: Militants Claim Ambush
abstract: Militants identifying themselves as the Sinai Province of the Islamic State said Monday that they had captured the engine of an American-made M60 tank from the Egyptian military in an ambush.
lead_paragraph: Militants identifying themselves as the Sinai Province of the Islamic State said  Monday that they had captured the engine of an American-made M60 tank from the Egyptian military in an ambush. A spokesman for the Egyptian armed forces said no engine had been taken. The militants, who went by the name Ansar Beit al-Maqdis before they pledged their loyalty last fall to the Islamic State, have killed hundreds of soldiers and policemen in a campaign against the military-backed government. President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi has declared an all-out war on the militants around their base in the North Sinai, but has nonetheless struggled to end their attacks. The militants posted six pictures on Twitter of what appeared to be the engine, describing it as “spoils” of an ambush on “the apostate army.”

headline: Malcolm Brogdon, Virginia Star, Is Pursuing Master’s Ahead of N.B.A.
abstract: Brogdon, a junior guard for the Cavaliers, who are seeded second in the East Region of the N.C.A.A. tournament, has already made his decision to return to campus and the team next season.
lead_paragraph: GREENSBORO, N.C. — Amid the academic scandals at Syracuse, North Carolina and elsewhere around the N.C.A.A., maybe it just seems unusual these days to find athletes who also happen to be high-achieving students. But consider Malcolm Brogdon, the redshirt junior guard who helped lead Virginia to the Atlantic Coast Conference regular-season title and a top-five ranking for much of this season — all while he was working on a master’s degree in public policy.

headline: New Jersey Senate Upholds Christie’s Veto of Port Authority Curbs
abstract: The bill, aimed at limiting patronage and political interference, passed both legislatures unanimously but was vetoed by Govs. Chris Christie of New Jersey and Andrew M. Cuomo of New York.
lead_paragraph: The New Jersey Senate failed in its effort on Monday to override Gov. Chris Christie’s veto of legislation aimed at curbing patronage and political interference at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey in the wake of the George Washington Bridge lane closing scandal.

headline: G.M. Will Face Further Discovery in Broader Class-Action Case
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: G.M. settled a wrongful-death lawsuit just last week with the parents of a crash victim. But the information uncovered in that case is being built on for a broader class action against the company.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — While General Motors has settled one potentially explosive lawsuit related to defective ignition switches, the company still faces the possibility of depositions of its employees in a broader class-action case.

headline: German Media Want Greek Finance Minister’s Head Over ‘Fingergate’
abstract: Greece’s finance minister, Yanis Varoufakis, has become a lightning rod for populist anger in Germany over acrimonious debt negotiations.
lead_paragraph: Speaking to a small group of Croatian radicals in 2013, an obscure Greek economist suggested that Greece should have simply defaulted on its debts in 2010 and told the German government to deal with the consequences. For emphasis, he used a crude expression and extended his middle finger, in an ancient gesture considered obscene even in the days of Diogenes.

headline: Blackstone Group Purchases Landmark Willis Tower in Chicago
abstract: The private equity firm paid roughly $1.3 billion, a record for Chicago real estate, for the Willis Tower, the 110-story property once known as the Sears Tower.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan D. Gray grew up in the Chicago suburb of Highland Park, just a 40-minute drive from the Sears Tower, one of the most recognizable office buildings in the world.

headline: SXSW 2015: A Look at ‘Raiders!’
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Movies', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: A documentary about two men who spent the summers of their youth remaking “Raiders of the Lost Ark” had its premiere at the festival on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Some fedoras were spotted, but no snakes were present at the premiere of “Raiders!” at SXSW on Saturday at an Alamo Drafthouse theater in Austin. The documentary tracks the enduring artistic commitment of Chris Strompolos and Eric Zala, two friends who spent their adolescent summer vacations creating a shot-for-shot remake of Steven Spielberg’s 1981 thriller, “Raiders of the Lost Ark.” Now in their 40s, the men reunited in June to shoot the one scene they never completed: the airplane fight sequence that pits Indiana Jones against a brutish mechanic near the blades of a moving airplane. (A camel and a few complicated explosions are also involved.)

headline: Curtis Gans, 77, Is Dead; Worked to Defeat President Johnson
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Mr. Gans mobilized thousands of college students to join Senator Eugene J. McCarthy’s challenge against Lyndon B. Johnson, who eventually quit the race.
lead_paragraph: Curtis Gans, who helped organize a quixotic crusade to depose President Lyndon B. Johnson in 1968 and transformed the movement’s improbable electoral success into what became a lifelong object lesson in the virtues of voting, died on Sunday in Frederick, Md. He was 77.

headline: Data on Health Law Shows Largest Drop in Uninsured in 4 Decades, the U.S. Says
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Obama administration said that 16.4 million uninsured people had gained health coverage since major provisions of the Affordable Care Act began to take effect in 2010.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said on Monday that 16.4 million uninsured people had gained health coverage since major provisions of the Affordable Care Act began to take effect in 2010, driving the largest reduction in the number of uninsured in about 40 years.

headline: Adidas to Exit the N.B.A., Opening the Door to Rivals
abstract: Adidas said that it would not bid for a new contract with the N.B.A. when its deal expires in 2017, letting slip a high-profile partnership.
lead_paragraph: Adidas said Monday that it will not bid for a new contract with the N.B.A. when its deal expires in 2017, letting slip a high-profile partnership that has allowed it to outfit some of the country’s top athletes.

headline: Tour Bus Companies Agree to Settle Antitrust Lawsuit
abstract: Twin America, a joint venture of City Sights and Gray Line New York, would give up nearly 50 stops and pay $7.5 million after officials said the companies effectively monopolized the industry.
lead_paragraph: Two of New York City’s biggest tour bus operators have agreed to pay $7.5 million and give up nearly 50 of their stops in Manhattan to settle an antitrust lawsuit brought by state and federal officials.

headline: Pointing Fingers in Apple Pay Fraud
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Credit Cards', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Mobile Commerce and Payments']
abstract: Some of the nation’s banks are privately complaining that Apple Pay may not be so great after all, but the banks may largely have themselves to blame.
lead_paragraph: When Apple was planning its Apple Pay electronic payment system last summer for its iPhones, the nation’s banks raced to be included among the first credit card issuers associated with the new technology.

headline: Iranian Officials Ask Kerry About Republicans’ Letter
abstract: Amid questions for Secretary of State John Kerry, Iran’s foreign minister called the letter “a political move,” but said it raised concerns about the U.S. government’s stance.
lead_paragraph: LAUSANNE, Switzerland — Iranian officials questioned Secretary of State John Kerry about a letter that Tom Cotton of Arkansas and 46 other Republican senators issued last week arguing that a potential nuclear accord would not be binding unless it was approved by Congress.

headline: Daevid Allen, Guitarist and Singer in Progressive Rock, Dies at 77
abstract: Mr. Allen, an Australian-born guitarist, singer and poet, was an innovator of the progressive rock genre.
lead_paragraph: Daevid Allen, an eccentric Australian-born guitarist, singer and poet who was an original member of the psychedelic rock group the Soft Machine and went on to found Gong, an aggressively avant-garde band whose influence far exceeded its relatively modest success, died on Friday in Australia. He was 77.

headline: Mexican Journalist Is Fired After Report About First Lady
keywords: ['Freedom of the Press', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Carmen Aristegui, who has a long record of exposing the foibles of Mexico’s elite and exposed a possible conflict of interest involving the first lady, was fired Sunday from MVS Radio.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — One of Mexico’s best-known journalists, who exposed a possible conflict of interest involving the first lady’s purchase of a house from a government contractor, was fired on Sunday in a dispute that defenders see as an act of retaliation and an attack on press freedom.

headline: Sharing Files via Dropbox With People Who Don’t Have an Account
abstract: When sending files using Dropbox, a service that stores documents in the cloud, it’s not necessary for the recipient to also use the service.
lead_paragraph: Q. I am having trouble trying to figure out how to send tax files to my parents on Dropbox, but since they are not Dropbox users, I don’t know how to share my files with them. How can I do this?

headline: Radio Broadcasters Seek Changes in Disclosure Rules for Paid Programming
abstract: Nine broadcasters have asked the Federal Communications Commission to waive the longstanding requirement that stations say on the air when a sponsor or promoter has paid for a song or other programming.
lead_paragraph: A group of radio broadcasters has asked for changes to federal rules about how stations disclose paid programming, raising fresh concerns about one of the music industry’s most enduring scandals — payola.

headline: Capturing 46th Title, Hannah Kearney Ends Her Moguls Career on Top
abstract: Kearney closed out her international career with a victory in Sunday’s dual moguls event at the F.I.S. Freestyle World Cup finals in Megève, France.
lead_paragraph: Five years after Hannah Kearney won an Olympic gold medal in moguls skiing, her dream came true: She closed out her international career with a victory in Sunday’s dual moguls event at the F.I.S. Freestyle World Cup finals in Megève, France.

headline: Michelle Obama Going to Asia to Push Education
abstract: The first lady will leave Wednesday for a five-day trip to Japan and Cambodia to promote Let Girls Learn, an effort to expand access to education for millions of girls in developing countries.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Michelle Obama will travel to Japan and Cambodia this week to kick off the administration’s new effort to promote the education of millions of girls worldwide.

headline: New York Police Begin Using ShotSpotter System to Detect Gunshots
abstract: As part of a pilot program, sensors are being placed in precincts in the Bronx and in Brooklyn, a total area of 15 square miles, where there have been a high number of shootings.
lead_paragraph: The New York Police Department has started using a detection system that pinpoints the location of gunfire and sends the information to law enforcement, the latest move to modernize the nation’s largest police force, the department announced on Monday.

headline: Intersection | Harajuku Style in Tokyo
abstract: Mademoiselle Yulia, a fashion designer and style icon with dyed blue hair, is very inspired by the stylish and colorful Harajuku neighborhood of Tokyo.
lead_paragraph: Mademoiselle Yulia, a fashion designer and style icon with dyed blue hair, is very inspired by the stylish and colorful Harajuku neighborhood of Tokyo.

headline: Remarks on Family by Dolce and Gabbana Bring Swell of Criticism
keywords: ['In Vitro Fertilization', 'Music', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Social Media', 'Children and Childhood', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']
abstract: When the Italian designers Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana criticized nontraditional families and I.V.F. in a magazine interview, it caught the attention of the singer Elton John and sparked anger online.
lead_paragraph: What began as a brush fire over the weekend for the fashion designers behind the Dolce & Gabbana label spread quickly across the Internet.

headline: House Republican Budget Overhauls Medicare and Repeals the Health Law
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Medicare', 'Medicaid', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Republicans’ proposed budget partly privatizes Medicare, turns Medicaid into block grants to the states, repeals the Affordable Care Act and reaches balance in 10 years.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Republicans on Tuesday will unveil a proposed budget for 2016 that partly privatizes Medicare, turns Medicaid into block grants to the states, repeals the Affordable Care Act and reaches balance in 10 years, challenging Republicans in Congress to make good on their promises to deeply cut federal spending.

headline: Irresistible TV, but Durst Film Tests Ethics, Too
keywords: ['Television', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: “The Jinx,” a six-part HBO documentary series about Robert A. Durst, raises questions about whether the filmmakers had a responsibility to share their discoveries with the police.
lead_paragraph: It was the sort of publicity you cannot buy. The day before HBO broadcast the final episode of the six-part documentary series “The Jinx,” the subject of the film, Robert A. Durst, was arrested on a murder charge.

headline: Utah’s Season Is So Sweet, Even the Lockers Smell Nice
abstract: The Utes’ coach, Larry Krystkowiak, lights a blend of sacred plants before games to inspire his team, which is going to the N.C.A.A. tournament for the first time since 2009.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — The locker room was empty except for the Utah men’s basketball coach, Larry Krystkowiak, who reached into his bag and pulled out what appeared to be a short section of braided rope. It was black on one end.

headline: Police Recall Dodging as Marathon Bombing Suspect Ran Over Brother
abstract: A jury heard firsthand accounts from police officers and neighbors in the trial of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who the prosecutors said had run over his brother, Tamerlan, while fleeing.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — One of the most shocking details to emerge from the night of mayhem two years ago when the Boston Marathon bombers engaged in a shootout with the police in suburban Watertown was that Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who was fleeing the scene, drove over his brother, Tamerlan.

headline: Pinterest Valuation at $11 Billion After New Round of Fund-Raising
abstract: The success of the financing shows that investors remain infatuated with the online scrapbooking service.
lead_paragraph: Less than a year after being valued at $5 billion, Pinterest has joined the 11-digit valuation start-up club.

keywords: ['Environment', 'Water Pollution', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: Lawmakers passed a resolution urging a judge to reject a proposed $225 million settlement. They believe the state could reap as much as $8.9 billion in damages.
lead_paragraph: The New Jersey Senate approved two measures on Monday contesting Gov. Chris Christie’s attempt to settle a pollution lawsuit against Exxon Mobil Corporation for a fraction of the damages that the state had originally sought.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With Congress pushing to complete a budget plan this week that reflects the cost-cutting priorities of the new Republican majority, President Obama plans to devote much of his week to laying out an alternative approach that would increase spending on domestic programs such as education and health care.

headline: United Nations Workers Accused of Sexual Abuse
abstract: A report’s findings showed that the bulk of the cases involved peacekeepers deployed to some of the most troubled parts of the world.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — United Nations personnel were accused in nearly 80 cases of rape, sexual assault and sex trafficking in 2014 alone, with the bulk of the cases involving peacekeepers deployed to some of the most troubled parts of the world.

abstract: In a case that set off unrest in the French suburbs a decade ago, two police officers are accused of failing to help people in danger.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A decade ago, two teenagers were electrocuted when they hid in a transformer at an electrical substation while running from the police. Their deaths set off a wave of unrest that plunged the French suburbs into chaos.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Iran has deployed advanced rockets and missiles to Iraq to help fight the Islamic State in Tikrit, a significant escalation of firepower and another sign of Iran’s growing influence in Iraq.

abstract: In the bracket for the women’s N.C.A.A, tournament, UConn was awarded a No. 1 seed for the ninth consecutive year.
lead_paragraph: It has been 20 years since Rebecca Lobo led Connecticut to the undefeated season that started it all for Coach Geno Auriemma and the Huskies. On Saturday, UConn will begin its quest for a 10th title over that span.

abstract: Melissa James Gibson’s play centers on a couple preoccupied by his unfinished classics dissertation and her clinical trials of a drug.
lead_paragraph: Pliny the Elder — naturalist, philosopher, warrior and all-around sage of the early Roman Empire — plays an unlikely role in “Placebo,” the new play by Melissa James Gibson that opened on Monday at Playwrights Horizons.

headline: Hillary Clinton at Irish American Event
abstract: Former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton spoke at her induction into the Irish America Hall of Fame, recalling an early decision of her husband’s in the Northern Ireland peace process.
lead_paragraph: Former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton spoke at her induction into the Irish America Hall of Fame, recalling an early decision of her husband’s in the Northern Ireland peace process.

headline: In Accepting Irish-American Honor, Hillary Clinton Recasts Her Role in a Peace Pact
abstract: Mrs. Clinton, who was inducted into the Irish America Hall of Fame, did not miss the chance to curry favor with a devoted ethnic constituency, one that helped her husband get elected in 1992.
lead_paragraph: The subjects of Ireland and tea made for an unpleasant brew in Hillary Rodham Clinton’s 2008 campaign for president. Her primary opponent, Barack Obama, once belittled her as having merely “had tea with” world leaders as first lady. Her husband defended her as “a peacemaker, not a tea maker.” Then she was accused of overstating her own contribution to the Northern Ireland peace process.

headline: For Pawn in Disputed Transfer, a Winning Move
abstract: Daisha Simmons needed to be closer to home to help her single mother and an ailing brother, but the N.C.A.A. and her former university made things tough on her.
lead_paragraph: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J. — On her way to helping Seton Hall earn its first berth in the N.C.A.A. women’s basketball tournament in two decades, Daisha Simmons had to make a few stops. Literally.

lead_paragraph: A short visit with a friend led Rony Zakaria to spend years exploring how faith shapes the relationship between people and nature in Indonesia.

headline: Bad Luck or Bad Practices? It’s Tough for Mets to Tell

lead_paragraph: So extensive is the growing list of Mets pitchers who have needed Tommy John surgery in recent years that even their general manager had difficulty recalling all of them on Monday.

lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Sparring over pensions, red-light cameras, public education and gang violence, the mayoral candidates Rahm Emanuel and Jesus G. Garcia confronted each other in their first one-on-one debate on Monday, three weeks before the runoff election.

lead_paragraph: RaShawn Stores often prayed alone. At other times, he prayed with family members. They all sought guidance, unsure how to respond when a dream collided with harsh financial reality.

headline: A Laid-Back Alternative to Miami Hot Spots
abstract: A quietly quirky restaurant opens off of the beach’s most boisterous strip.
lead_paragraph: A quietly quirky restaurant opens off of the beach’s most boisterous strip.

headline: Ad-Rock and Num Pang Share a Recipe for Their New, Charitable Banh Mi
abstract: The trio created a limited-edition sandwich, complete with chili Russian dressing, proceeds of which will benefit local animal shelters.
lead_paragraph: Food, hip-hop and ’90s street style converge at the well-traversed, brightly colored graffiti-tagged sandwich empire Num Pang (established in 2009, the name is Cambodian for bread). This spring, the restaurant’s co-chefs and owners, Ben Daitz and Ratha Chaupoly, teamed up with the New York native Adam Horovitz (“Ad-Rock”) of the Beastie Boys to re-engineer pastrami on rye, a sandwich as iconic in New York as the boys behind it. Their creation, a limited-edition banh mi, is on menus at Num Pang’s six locations today.

headline: Behind Sam Shahid’s Closed Doors
abstract: Bombarded by imagery all day at work, the renowned advertising provocateur comes home to, well, very little.
lead_paragraph: Bombarded by imagery all day at work, the renowned advertising provocateur comes home to, well, very little.

headline: Design With a Bit of Drama
abstract: This year, the British furniture and lighting designer Lee Broom will return to the Milan Furniture Fair with a unique take on the department store.
lead_paragraph: The British furniture and lighting designer Lee Broom is known both for his clever, often nostalgic creations and the elaborate ways he displays them: In 2012, during the Milan Furniture Fair, he showed inside an old pub that he bought in London, disassembled and rebuilt in Milan. This year, he’ll return to the prestigious event with a unique take on the department store — Memphis-style chairs and fragmented mirrors in the “gents’ fitting room,” fluted tables that furnish the “bookstore” and tubular fluorescent lamps with cut crystal that illuminate the “perfumery.” “I always try to do something theatrical,” he says. “And once I learned that the department store was an English invention, I knew I had the right idea.”

headline: Obama Wades Into Marijuana Debate in Vice Interview
abstract: President Obama has a number of speaking styles in his repertoire, from soaring oratory to serious policy wonkishness, withering sarcasm and cocky defensiveness. For an interview with Vice News released Monday, he went with optimistic paternalism.
lead_paragraph: President Obama has a number of speaking styles in his repertoire, from soaring oratory to serious policy wonkishness, withering sarcasm and cocky defensiveness. For an interview with Vice News released Monday, he went with optimistic paternalism.

abstract: First announced last July, the initiative will bring scores of Sotheby’s less expensive items — which range from about $1,000 to $50,000 — to eBay’s customers, a crowd that both companies hope will be eager to purchase works of art online.
lead_paragraph: EBay, the giant online auction site, sells millions of items to customers all over the world every single day. It wants to sell a whole lot more.

headline: Louise Erdrich Wins Library of Congress Award
abstract: The Library’s American fiction prize, awarded this year to Ms. Erdrich, is given to writers with “unique, enduring voices” whose work addresses the American experience.
lead_paragraph: Louise Erdrich, author of the novels “Love Medicine” and “The Round House,” will receive the Library of Congress Prize for American Fiction this year.

headline: Soccer Sites Set for Rio
abstract: Matches for the soccer tournament at the 2016 Rio Olympics will be held in six Brazilian cities.
lead_paragraph: Matches for the soccer tournament at the 2016 Rio Olympics will be held in six Brazilian cities. The most surprising inclusion was that of Arena Amazônia in Manaus, more than 1,800 miles from the main Olympic park.

headline: Tax Cuts Still Don’t Pay for Themselves
abstract: A new report says a Republican tax cut plan would increase tax revenue in the long run, but economists disagree.
lead_paragraph: Last week, I wrote about the new tax plan from Senator Marco Rubio and Senator Mike Lee as the “Puppies and Rainbows Tax Plan,” because it’s a plan that includes something for everyone. It calls for big tax credits for middle-income families with children, corporate tax cuts and complete elimination of the capital gains tax — and as a result would cost trillions of dollars in revenue over a decade.

lead_paragraph: Diana Taurasi, one of the top players in women’s basketball, is not returning to the W.N.B.A. this season, honoring the wishes of her better-paying Russian team.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (CW) IZOMBIE Olivia Moore (Rose McIver), a formerly driven medical student, becomes depressed and slovenly when she is turned into a zombie. She must now subsist on human brains, culled from the bodies in the morgue where she works, which give her flashes of the memories they contain. She uses them to aid a homicide detective (Malcolm Goodwin) in solving murders in this new series, which counts Rob Thomas and Diane Ruggiero-Wright of “Veronica Mars” fame among its executive producers. Writing in The New York Times, Neil Genzlinger called the show “ridiculously likable.”

headline: Vanuatu Death Toll Is Likely to Rise as Glimpses of Cyclone’s Fury Emerge
abstract: Accounts trickling in from remote islands indicate widespread devastation to crops and homes in the wake of Tropical Cyclone Pam, relief workers said.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Initial glimpses of remote parts of the Pacific island nation of Vanuatu, which was lashed by a cyclone over the weekend, indicated widespread devastation, relief workers said Tuesday.

headline: Gen. Petraeus’s Light Punishment
abstract: While whistle-blowers and other leakers of classified information have been imprisoned, the general stands to emerge largely unscathed from his case.
lead_paragraph: Granted, Americans love a comeback story.

headline: The Hidden Talent of Steve Jobs
abstract: Genius alone didn’t bring Apple back. It took management chops.
lead_paragraph: The relationship between journalists and Steve Jobs could often be fraught, but there were always a handful of reporters he liked and trusted. They included John Markoff of The New York Times; Steven Levy, formerly of Wired magazine (he’s now at Medium); Walt Mossberg, the longtime technology columnist for The Wall Street Journal (he’s now at Re/code); and Brent Schlender of Fortune. They had all been on the technology beat seemingly forever, and they had known Jobs for decades.

headline: Could Obama Bypass the Supreme Court?
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Constitution (US)']
abstract: If it rules against the exchanges, the health law could still survive.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — IT is time to talk about President Obama’s contingency plan for health care. The Supreme Court heard oral arguments earlier this month in King v. Burwell, a case challenging the provision of tax credits on federal insurance exchanges. While the legal issues are dry lawyers’ fare — how to interpret several interconnected phrases of the Affordable Care Act — the practical stakes are high. The government estimates that millions of Americans will be left without affordable health insurance if it loses.

headline: Skills in Flux
keywords: ['Teachers and School Employees', 'Performance Evaluations (Labor)', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Education']
abstract: We are already using a set of subtle, flexible new skills to fit the new economy. It’s time we understood them.
lead_paragraph: Several years ago, Doug Lemov began studying videos of excellent teachers. He focused not on their big strategies but on their microgestures: How long they waited before calling on students to answer a question (to give the less confident students time to get their hands up); when they paced about the classroom and when they stood still (while issuing instructions, to emphasize the importance of what’s being said); how they moved around the room toward a student whose mind might be wandering.

headline: Venture Capital’s Boys’ Club on Trial
keywords: ['Venture Capital', 'Women and Girls', 'Discrimination', 'Editorials', 'Workplace Environment', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: A gender discrimination lawsuit raises the curtain on an industry with a terrible record of hiring and promoting women.
lead_paragraph: Venture capitalists are widely considered to be men — and they are almost all men — who can see the future. But there is at least one thing they have not been able to see clearly or willing to do anything about for a long time: A terrible record of hiring and promoting women.

headline: ‘A Conversation With My Black Son’
abstract: In this short documentary, parents reveal their struggles with telling their black sons that they may be targets of racial profiling by the police.
lead_paragraph: For generations, parents of black boys across the United States have rehearsed, dreaded and postponed “The Conversation.” But when their boys become teenagers, parents must choose whether or not to expose their sons to what it means to be a black man here. To keep him safe, they may have to tell the child they love that he risks being targeted by the police, simply because of the color of his skin. How should parents impart this information, while maintaining their child’s pride and sense of self? How does one teach a child to face dangerous racism and ask him to emerge unscathed?

lead_paragraph: Here are several paragraphs from a March 14 article, “Davidson Math Students Lend a Hand to Basketball Team.”

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Kendrick Lamar on His New Album and the Weight of Clarity
abstract: What does Joe Coscarelli mean when he writes, “Mr. Lamar is working to purify hip-hop”?
lead_paragraph: In “Kendrick Lamar on His New Album and the Weight of Clarity,” Joe Coscarelli writes about Mr. Lamar’s new album.

headline: How Do You Solve a Problem Like Ben Carson?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: His chances of victory are minuscule, but he and other hard-right candidates will still be a headache for the G.O.P. in the 2016 primaries. Can mainstream Republicans stop him? Should they try?
lead_paragraph: Late in February, Dr. Ben Carson, the celebrated pediatric neurosurgeon turned political insurrectionist, was trying to check off another box on his presidential-campaign to-do list: hiring a press secretary. The lead prospect, a public-relations specialist named Deana Bass, had come to meet him at the dimly lit Capitol Hill office of Carson’s confidant and business manager, Armstrong Williams. Carson sat back and scrutinized her from behind a small granite table, as life-size cardboard cutouts of more conventional politicians — President Obama, with a tight smile, and Senator John McCain, glowering — loomed behind each of his shoulders. (The mock $3 bill someone had left on a table in Williams’s waiting room undercut any notion that this was a bipartisan zone; it featured Obama wearing a turban.)

headline: Are Manners Important?
abstract: What role do manners play in your family? Do you have good manners?
lead_paragraph: Put your napkin on your lap. Keep your elbows off the table. Chew with your mouth closed. Society imparts all sorts of manners for us to follow at the dinner table, and elsewhere.

headline: Labels, Digital Included, Assume New Importance at Museums
abstract: Museums are paying more attention to labels, emphasizing clarity, concision, cleverness and even digital interactivity to engage and educate visitors.
lead_paragraph: Like a primatologist observing gorillas in the wild, Judy Rand sometimes prowls around museums to spy on visitors. Ms. Rand, a museum consultant in Seattle and an acclaimed writer of exhibit labels, loves spotting guests reading her work aloud.

headline: Diana Taurasi Focusing on Playing in Russia, Where the Money Is
abstract: Taurasi, a veteran star, chose to sit out the coming W.N.B.A. season to honor the wishes of her foreign team, which pays her a lot more than the Phoenix Mercury do.
lead_paragraph: YEKATERINBURG, Russia — The noise inside the arena is deafening. Thousands of Russians in off-brand tracksuits and snow pants are shouting and beating inflatable foil batons together as Diana Taurasi, perhaps the greatest women’s basketball player in the world, dribbles across the court.

headline: For the Walker Art Center, a Shop That Peddles Evanescence
keywords: ['Museums', 'Art', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Pop-Up Stores and Restaurants']
abstract: In a conceptual online pop-up store called Intangibles, the museum will enlist artists as shrewd marketers of their own ideas.
lead_paragraph: Visitors to the gift shop at the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis will soon be able to buy something a little more esoteric, alongside their Chuck Close posters and Pantone mugs. “On Mother’s Day,” the promotion might go, “how about a new ringtone calibrated by the composer Nico Muhly, just for stressful family calls?”

headline: Museums Turn to Technology to Boost Attendance by Millennials
abstract: How do static galleries of canvas and artifact engage a generation raised on the reactive pleasures of right swipes and hyperlinks?
lead_paragraph: If museums face an uncertain future, you wouldn’t know it from “Henri Matisse: The Cutouts,” which recently drew 664,000 to the Museum of Modern Art. The show was so thronged that MoMA kept its doors open round-the-clock on the closing weekend last month.

headline: A More Public Option for Investigating Shootings by Police Officers
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Forensic Science']
abstract: Coroners’ inquests are finding fresh support from some people critical of the process that cleared police officers in killings in Ferguson, Mo., and Staten Island.
lead_paragraph: MISSOULA, Mont. — In most places, the actions of the police officer who fatally shot Kaileb Williams, 20, would have been judged in secret, by an anonymous grand jury weighing criminal charges behind closed doors.

headline: Streetcar Revival Is Wavering in Some Cities
keywords: ['Transit Systems', 'Cable Cars and Trams', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: While several cities inaugurate new systems or expand older ones, the streetcar revolution, faced with fiscal and operational challenges, has stalled elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — First, suburban Arlington, Va., abandoned long-laid plans last fall to build a streetcar line its leaders hoped would help revitalize a neglected corridor.

headline: Afghan Militia Leaders, Empowered by U.S. to Fight Taliban, Inspire Fear in Villages
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The leaders, brought to power amid an American counterinsurgency strategy, continue to rule villages, where people say the militias have turned to kidnappings and extortion.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Rahimullah used to be a farmer — just a “normal person living an ordinary life,” as he put it. Then he formed his own militia last year and found himself swept up in America’s exit strategy from Afghanistan.

headline: Sex-Trafficking Bill, Ensnared by Politics, Is Left in Limbo by a Senate Vote
abstract: A measure to create a victims fund hit an impasse over an abortion provision, and Republicans said they would not vote on President Obama’s attorney general nominee until it was resolved.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congress headed into another major legislative standoff Tuesday when a measure to create a fund for victims of sexual trafficking failed to clear a procedural hurdle, leaving in peril a bill that once had the support of a majority of lawmakers.

headline: ‘Culture Crash,’ by Scott Timberg
abstract: It has become almost impossible to make a living in or around the arts.
lead_paragraph: In 2010, the Louisville Orchestra filed for Chapter 11 protection. Reader comments generated by a newspaper article on this development, Scott Timberg writes in “Culture Crash,” “gave a sense of the way many people think about culture and the market.” Timberg reproduces some of the comments “in all their typo-filled glory.” “Pack up your fiddles and go home boys and girls,” one reader advised. “Maybe find real jobs. Go to Nashville and vie for some sessions work.” Another commenter opined: “Sale all of assets to pay these people off, fire them all and get rid of the Orchestra. It isn’t popular with the residents or they would have packed crowds and not have to worry about $$$.”

headline: I.P.O. Could Value Refresco Gerber at Up to $1.36 Billion
abstract: The offering will consist of new shares issued by the European bottler and a sale of about 30.9 million shares held by its private equity owners.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Refresco Gerber, one of Europe’s largest bottlers of soft drinks and fruit juices, said on Tuesday that the expected price range for its initial public offering could value the company at up to 1.29 billion euros, or about $1.36 billion.

headline: Myanmar Sentences 3 to Prison for Depicting Buddha Wearing Headphones
abstract: A court in Yangon sentenced the three men to two-year terms, saying that the depiction, part of a promotion for a restaurant event, denigrated Buddhism.
lead_paragraph: YANGON, Myanmar — A bar manager from New Zealand and two Burmese men were sentenced to two years in prison in Myanmar on Tuesday for posting an image online of the Buddha wearing headphones, an effort to promote an event.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get the Morning Briefing in your inbox first thing? Sign up.)

headline: Exploring Indianapolis, for the Final Four and Beyond
abstract: In addition to the playoffs, there’s plenty to do in the city’s walkable downtown.
lead_paragraph: The brackets are filled in, and the betting pools are rich. It must be mid-March.

headline: The Virtues of Microadventures
abstract: The author Alastair Humphreys preaches the gospel of short, perspective-shifting bursts of travel closer to home.
lead_paragraph: Alastair Humphreys adventure-hopped for a decade, starting with a four-year round-the-world bicycle trip after college. From there, the British author, blogger and motivational speaker traversed southern India, rowed across the Atlantic Ocean and trekked 1,000 miles across the Arabian Peninsula’s Empty Quarter.

headline: Hotels for the Next Generation
abstract: Marriott, Hilton and other big chains are appealing to “lifestyle” travelers, with lower prices, industrial design and high-tech everything.
lead_paragraph: Longing for alternatives to the conventional, cookie-cutter hotel? Along with crocuses and daffodils, new specialty chains from major hospitality companies including Marriott, Hilton, Hyatt and Carlson Rezidor will be springing up across the globe in the coming weeks and months.

headline: In Geneva, Art Thrives Where Watches Were Made
abstract: A city known for timepieces, banks and global institutions now has its own little SoHo.
lead_paragraph: When the strikingly redesigned Musée d’Ethnographie de Genève (Geneva Museum of Ethnography) reopened in October 2014, the Quartier des Bains, the neighborhood that’s become Geneva’s own little SoHo, got a defining new landmark. Bound by the Rhone and Arve rivers in the southern part of the city, this unexpectedly hip gallery- and museum-studded neighborhood in a town best known for banks, international institutions like the Red Cross and luxury watches has emerged as one of the liveliest and most innovative contemporary art districts in Europe.

headline: IBM Introduces Twitter-Fueled Data Services for Business

abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and his chief challenger, Isaac Herzog of the center-left Zionist Union, appeared to win about the same number of parliamentary seats in the Israeli election on Tuesday.

headline: Japan’s Central Bank Warns of Temporary Return to Deflation

lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Over the last two years, the Japanese central bank governor, Haruhiko Kuroda, has accomplished what a string of more cautious predecessors failed to do: reverse a prolonged and damaging slide in the price of goods and services in Japan.

headline: Detention of Rights Activists in China Soared in 2014, Report Says
abstract: Those held encompass a wide group of people, including opponents of sexual discrimination, groups pushing for migrant workers’ rights and those who argue for better treatment of ethnic minorities.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese authorities last year detained more people advocating greater civic rights than at any time since at least the mid-1990s, a United States-based organization said in a new report.

headline: A Sucker Is Optimized Every Minute
abstract: Now that we have hard data on everything, we no longer make decisions from our hearts, guts or principles.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, our blockbuster business books spoke in unison: Trust your gut. The secret to decision-making lay outside our intellects, across the aisle in our loopy right brains, with their emo melodramas and surges of intuition. Linear thinking was suddenly the royal road to ruin. Dan Ariely’s “Predictably Irrational” tracked the extravagant illogic of our best judgment calls. The “Freakonomics” authors urged us to think like nut jobs. In “Blink,” Malcolm Gladwell counseled abandoning scientific method in favor of snap judgments. Tedious hours of research, conducted by artless cubicle drones, became the province of companies courting Chapter 11. To the artsy dropouts who could barely grasp a polynomial would go the spoils of the serial bull markets.

headline: The Lost Glove Waves Farewell to Winter
abstract: As winter recedes, we remember the many accessories it claimed.
lead_paragraph: Perched on the cusp of spring, we watch the soot-gray snowbanks melt and feel the deep-winter blues flow down the storm drain. In the gutter we see a soggy record of the season left behind: fossil layers of litter, unfrozen unscooped poop and, quite touching, long-lost gloves waving their final goodbyes.

headline: Object Lesson
abstract: Things have the longest memories of all; beneath their stillness, they are alive with the terrors they have witnessed.
lead_paragraph: In November 2013, thousands of people gathered in Maidan Nezalezhnosti, the central square in Kiev, to protest their government’s refusal to ratify an agreement with the European Union. The demonstrations went on for months; when brutal attempts were made to stop them, they only became more popular. The crowds were enormous, containing, at times, more than 100,000 people. Many of the photographs from the protests had the organized disorder of medieval battle scenes: spiky barricades, rows of tents, patches of soil and ash, flashes of color where flags were held aloft, sudden brightness from reflections and fires, a great swirl of angry humanity and dark-helmeted riot police massed behind shields, all of it set against backdrops of smoke, fog or falling snow. So epic and cinematic were the photographs from the Maidan that it took some effort to remember that they were first and foremost news images, unstaged depictions of real, ongoing human suffering.

headline: Morning Agenda: Blame Game in Apple Pay Fraud
abstract: Banks and Apple Pay tussle over fraud. | Valeant wins the bidding war for Salix. | Pinterest garners $11 billion valuation. | Troops come home to repossessions.
lead_paragraph: BLAME GAME IN APPLE PAY FRAUD | When Apple was planning its Apple Pay electronic payment system last summer for its iPhones, the nation’s banks rushed to be included. Now, some of the banks “are privately complaining that Apple Pay may not be so great after all,” Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook column. “But the banks may largely have themselves to blame,” he adds. “A raft of headlines over the last week about unusually high fraud rates from thieves using stolen credit numbers on Apple Pay has exposed what many of the banks privately acknowledge they have been trying to fix for months.”

headline: Left and Right, Family and Economics
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Families and Family Life', 'Income Inequality', 'Marriages', 'Poverty', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Teenage Pregnancy', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Why the two sides in the “culture or economics” debate sometimes end up talking past each other.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column weighed in on the latest (and presently very intra-Timesian) version of the neverending “does culture or economics explain family breakdown?” debate. Responding, in part, to the critics of my colleague David Brooks’s earlier column on morals and the social fabric, I made the case that there just hasn’t been the kind of significant increase in privation (or the kind of cuts to welfare programs; quite the reverse) that some writers on the left invoke as an explanation for why today’s poor and working class Americans are so much less likely than in prior eras to have children within wedlock and stay married when they do. Instead, notwithstanding all the burdens they bear and challenges they face, downscale Americans have somewhat more income and a much stronger safety net than their grandparents and great-grandparents did. So as much as economic burdens clearly play a role in family instability, and would be plausible explanations for the existence of a persistent rich-poor family-structure gap, they seem like weaker explanations for why out-of-wedlock birth rates have gone up so rapidly over the last half-century, not only among the underclass but increasingly in Middle America as well.

headline: 1890: Strike Takes Riotous Turn
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Liverpool strike develops into riot in 1890.
lead_paragraph: LIVERPOOL — The most critical stage in the history of the great dock strike was reached to-day [March 17], when the refusal of a large proportion of the carters to cease work in order to strengthen the hands of the dock laborers culminated in an alarming riot. The disturbance began by those teams-men who had ceased work in defiance of the grace remonstrance by the treasurer of the Union, falling upon those in charge of the horses, knocking them about, and tearing bales of cotton off their carts. A large body of police was hurriedly marched to the scene, and after much trouble the rioters were dispersed. — The New York Herald, European Edition, March 18, 1890
