headline: Video Review: Volvo V60 Cross Country, Good for the Long Haul
abstract: The Cross Country is quiet, controlled and supremely comfortable during long trips, coddling occupants with seats that may be the best in the business.
lead_paragraph: ARE luxury automotive brands banned from using comprehensible names? It would explain the baffling alphanumeric monikers that Acura, Audi, BMW, Infiniti, Lexus and Mercedes use. Volvo forks off this trail with the newest V60 variant by adding two actual words: Cross Country.

headline: For St. Patrick’s Day Parade, Shamrocks and Green Eyeshadow
abstract: Performers converged on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan for the annual celebration of Irish culture, and it was the first time an openly gay group marched in the event.
lead_paragraph: Performers converged on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan for the annual celebration of Irish culture, and it was the first time an openly gay group marched in the event.

headline: Exchange Rates and Balance Sheet Effects
abstract: This time is not different.
lead_paragraph: Neil Irwin writes about concerns that a rising dollar will damage developing countries where corporations have borrowed in dollars; as he says, this raises echoes of the Asian crisis of the late 1990s and the Argentine crisis of 2002.

headline: Works Sighted: Female Amputees Deserve Better
abstract: Most prosthetics are designed for men, leaving women at a disadvantage.
lead_paragraph: Most prosthetics are designed for men, meaning female amputees can struggle with moving comfortably, finding shoes that fit, or holding a child. Things are changing, but slowly.

headline: Iran and U.S. Differ on Optimism About Nuclear Talks
abstract: Contrasting assessments were delivered Tuesday in Switzerland as the deadline neared for a framework agreement on limiting Iran’s disputed nuclear program.
lead_paragraph: LAUSANNE, Switzerland — Iran and the United States issued contrasting assessments Tuesday on their progress toward an agreement to limit Iran’s nuclear program as Energy Secretary Ernest J. Moniz met here with his Iranian counterpart.

headline: Retro Striped Knits for Spring
abstract: With a pair of well-worn, washed-out Levi’s, these throwback shirts and sweaters are charming, youthful and the best of the season.
lead_paragraph: Nautical tends to be the go-to stripe for the spring and summer months; but this season, the best men’s striped knits, from polos to pullovers, are instead retro in nature. In burnt oranges, acid greens and electric blues, they feel as charmingly youthful as one of the boys captured in a Daniel Meadows photograph circa 1973 — especially when paired with well-worn, washed-out Levi’s.

headline: Lawyer: Durst Did Not Kill Susan Berman
abstract: Dick DeGuerin, the lawyer for Robert A. Durst, said that Mr. Durst did not kill his friend Susan Berman and that the murder charge was based on a television show and not on fact.
lead_paragraph: Dick DeGuerin, the lawyer for Robert A. Durst, said that Mr. Durst did not kill his friend Susan Berman and that the murder charge was based on a television show and not on fact.

headline: Sources of Slow Recovery
abstract: Different? Maybe. Necessary? Definitely not.
lead_paragraph: The other R&R — Christina and David Romer — have an interesting new paper questioning the other Reinhart-Rogoff result, the claim that financial crises consistently lead to deep, sustained slumps. I’m not ready to referee this one, at least not yet. Romer and Romer clearly have done an impressively systematic job of identifying financial distress in an objective way; but I wonder, very tentatively, if they’re looking at the wrong variable. My sense is that the aftermath of credit and housing bubbles is consistently remarkably bad – Alan Taylor and colleagues have been documenting this proposition — and that may not be well captured by reports of credit-market distress.

headline: Springtime in California
abstract: Mark Bittman embraces the vegetables of the season.
lead_paragraph: Mark Bittman embraces the vegetables of the season.

headline: Spring’s Opening Act
abstract: The writer, a new resident of the Bay Area, takes a joyful look at the region’s fresh fruit and vegetables.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — Back in the ’80s, I resented the existence of Meyer lemons and anyone who championed them. Those groovy Bay Area people would write recipes calling for Meyer lemons, as if anyone could find them, and insist that a regular lemon just wouldn’t do.

headline: Lone Star State of Mind
abstract: I’m working, working I tell you.
lead_paragraph: Will Butler of Arcade Fire [and it’s a different Will Butler! You see, I’m on a panel with the AF Butler brothers Thursday, so I just assumed …] has a somewhat downbeat piece about the corporatization of SXSW. And I have just arrived in Austin to do some investigative reporting on the scene, remaining clearly focused on the socioeconomic issues – that is, aside from the concerts and the parties, which I will of course attend purely for research purposes. The same for my beer consumption.

headline: At Chicago Hotel, an App About the Art and Architecture
abstract: The Radisson Blu Aqua Hotel in Chicago has introduced a digital application that gives guests a tour of the distinctive building in which it is located.
lead_paragraph: A new digital application is designed to give guests a better understanding of the wavelike, Jeanne Gang-designed Aqua Tower in Chicago, where the Radisson Blu Aqua Hotel is located.

headline: 1940: Nazi Planes Bomb Naval Base
keywords: ['Bombs and Explosives', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Nazi planes bomb Scapa Flow in 1940.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Fourteen Nazi warplanes last night [March 16] bombed units of the British fleet at Scapa Flow in the second raid on the naval base since war started, damaged at least one warship and killed eight men, including one civilian, the first killed on British soil. One German plane was shot down and others were damaged, the official British report said. The air raiders previously made a brief reconnaissance flight over the Orkney Islands. The German communiqué said three British battleships and one cruiser were ‘‘badly damaged’’ during the raid. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 18, 1940

headline: Congress Scrutinizes F.C.C. Following Release of New Internet Rules
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Net Neutrality', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Facing a tough tone from Republican lawmakers about his handling of the rules, Tom Wheeler, chairman of the F.C.C., pushed back repeatedly.
lead_paragraph: Nearly three weeks after the Federal Communications Commission voted to regulate broadband Internet like a public utility, Congress is putting the agency and its new rules under the microscope.

headline: Aaron Schock, Facing Questions on Spending, Is Resigning
abstract: Representative Aaron Schock, Republican of Illinois, is resigning his House seat at the end of the month.

headline: Results at Jefferies Expose the Bank’s Weaknesses
abstract: After missing the rebound in most fixed-income trading and other issues, the Wall Street firm cannot afford another dismal quarter.
lead_paragraph: Jefferies is rubbing salt into its own wounds. The Wall Street firm managed to avoid a second straight quarterly loss, but only barely.  Net income for its first quarter was a dismal $12.5 million as the three months to February exposed some of the investment bank’s weaknesses.

headline: Northern Tiger Set to Open Downtown
abstract: Erika Chou and Doron Wong of Yunnan Kitchen are finally ready to open their Northern Chinese counter for dumplings and noodle dishes at Brookfield Place.
lead_paragraph: Headliner

headline: Intriguing Sketches Reveal the Depths of Geoff McFetridge’s Quirky, Beautiful Mind
abstract: The artist, who illustrated visuals for Spike Jonze’s “Her” and has created everything from Nike sneakers to a stop-motion music video filled with toast, shares 30 drawings in a new zine.
lead_paragraph: Like most artists, Geoff McFetridge relies on early drawings to inform his final works. An illustrator based in Los Angeles, the 43-year-old creates graphic images in fine lines and bold colors, and his output is as prolific as it is varied: He has produced skateboard decks and album covers, cleaning product packaging and beer bottle labels, often collaborating with high-profile names like Spike Jonze and Nike. In one memorable stop-motion film, for the fun-loving alt-rock band OK Go, McFetridge burned illustrations into 2,430 pieces of toast. “I am always interested in creating work that lies between image and language,” he says.

headline: Facebook Announces a Payments Feature for Its Messenger App
abstract: The feature will at first be limited to people who are Facebook friends, but Wall Street expects that such transactions will become a big business.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook‘s instant messaging service isn’t just for sending smiley faces and photos anymore. Now you can use it to send money instantly to your friends.

headline: Neville Wakefield’s Many Muses
abstract: From the toy sailboats he made as a boy to the large-scale installations he’s overseen in his career, the art world curator credits his rural childhood and his own children for sharpening his keen aesthetic.
lead_paragraph: From the toy sailboats he made as a boy to the large-scale installations he’s overseen in his career, the art world curator credits his rural childhood and his own children for sharpening his keen aesthetic.

headline: Behind the Poster: ‘Into the Woods’
abstract: The designer Chris Everett discusses the artwork that features German visual accents, like an alpine hat with a wolf’s ears poking through.
lead_paragraph: For its new production of the musical “Into the Woods,” Theater Latté Da in Minneapolis didn’t look to fairy tales for inspiration. It went for something with more oom-pah: a German beer hall.

headline: Beyond Pop
abstract: A revival of interest in the iconic 1960s and ’70s work of the French designer has revealed an artist whose career was more varied and extensive than most realize.
lead_paragraph: A revival of interest in the iconic 1960s and ’70s work of the French designer has revealed an artist whose career was more varied and extensive than most realize.

headline: SXSW Music 2015: Early Show-Hopping, Taking In Known and Unknown Bands
keywords: ['Music', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: Show-hopping before the show begins, listening to sultry, argumentative pop and a barn-burning set by Courtney Barnett.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex.­­ — The sprawl of the South by Southwest Music and Media Conference gradually shifts today toward the festival’s original core: music.

headline: Where the Republican Budget Plan Meets Reality on Health Care
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Medicare']
abstract: Repealing Obamacare is much more complicated than cutting its spending programs, and the plan uses vague accounting to justify its claims.
lead_paragraph: The budget proposal released by House Republicans on Tuesday promises it can repeal Obamacare and save the government a lot of money in the process. But the document relies on some vague accounting to justify this claim.

headline: The Columbus Theatre’s Folk Revival
abstract: The happy saga of a vaudeville-turned-movie-turned-porn venue.
lead_paragraph: The happy saga of a vaudeville-turned-movie-turned-porn venue.

headline: To Butler’s Delight, Roosevelt Jones Finds Way to Score
abstract: A 6-foot-4 guard with a unique game, Jones seldom attempts a jump shot. Instead, he relies on teardrop, scoop and push shots, mostly within 10 feet of the rim.
lead_paragraph: When Matthew Graves was an assistant at Butler, he was known as a shooter’s coach. Graves believed that all players, from the point guard to the big men, needed a perimeter game. So when he called the former Butler coach Brad Stevens in the fall of 2009 and said that he had just scouted a unique talent, Stevens thought Graves had stumbled upon a phenomenally gifted shooter.

headline: U.S.-Cuba Talks on Restoring Diplomatic Ties End Abruptly
abstract: Officials had hoped for an agreement before both Presidents Obama and Castro attend the Summit of the Americas in April.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The United States and Cuba have ended their third round of talks on re-establishing diplomatic relations as abruptly as the meeting was announced, with no breakthrough on sticking points and in an atmosphere of rising tension over Venezuela.

headline: Self-Justifying Swedes
abstract: Deflation? Who could have predicted?
lead_paragraph: One fundamental principle in the years since the financial crisis, with all the bad judgments and policy missteps we’ve seen, is that nobody ever admits having been wrong about anything. And it turns out that people can not admit error in Swedish, too. Lars Svensson has the details on the Riksbank’s deputy governor Jansson.

headline: SXSW 2015: Will Ferrell Discusses Fraternities, ‘Get Hard’ and More
keywords: ['South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: Will Ferrell responded to reader questions at the South by Southwest film festival.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — The actor and comedian Will Ferrell arrived here on Monday with Kevin Hart to present the comedy “Get Hard.” Last week, we asked readers to submit questions for Mr. Ferrell. He sat down with us at the Four Seasons to answer some of them. Here are his responses:

headline: Review: In ‘Running Away From the One With the Knife,’ a Suicide Pondered
abstract: Characters in Aaron Landsman’s play at the Chocolate Factory reflect on an inexorable act they failed to prevent.
lead_paragraph: Percolating coffee drips into a pot at the front of the Chocolate Factory stage. Boiling grounds are a familiar scent, burbling water a familiar sound, the sort of routine you reach for when the world seems inexplicable, unmoored.

headline: Hungary Without Two Thirds
abstract: A covert, scary coalition.
lead_paragraph: A guest post from my Princeton colleague Kim Lane Scheppele, head of the Law and Public Affairs program:

headline: After I.V.F.: Pregnant, but Still Stuck in the Past
keywords: ['Babies and Infants', 'In Vitro Fertilization', 'Infertility', 'Parenting', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth']
abstract: Every time I tell someone I’m pregnant, I think, “What if I have to tell them I’m not?”
lead_paragraph: Every time I tell someone I’m pregnant, the first thought that grips my heart in terror is, “What if I have to tell them that it didn’t work?”

headline: Drugs on Campus: A Reporter’s Challenge
abstract: Tatiana Schlossberg describes a Friday night spent trying to learn about the Wesleyan drug scene after a spate of drug overdoses for which five students have been arrested.
lead_paragraph: What’s a young reporter to do when she’s assigned to investigate a college drug scene after a series of overdoses? Try to blend in. Tatiana Schlossberg realized recently that it’s harder than one might think.

headline: Netanyahu Soundly Defeats Chief Rival in Israeli Elections
abstract: After a bruising campaign focused on his failings, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu seemed all but certain to form a new government, though he offended many in the process.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — After a bruising campaign focused on his failings, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel won a clear victory in Tuesday’s elections and seemed all but certain to form a new government and serve a fourth term, though he offended many voters and alienated allies in the process.

headline: S.E.C. Chief Voices Support for Higher Advice Standard for Brokers
keywords: ['Financial Brokers', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)']
abstract: The agency’s chairwoman, Mary Jo White, said she would explore ways to oblige stockbrokers to put their clients’ interests ahead of their own.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — The chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission announced on Tuesday that she planned to explore setting a higher standard for brokers in dispensing investment advice, putting the agency in the middle of a potential fight between the Obama administration and the financial industry.

headline: Cultivating Genius
abstract: Cy Twombly painted some of the 20th century’s great works in the hilly Italian coastal town of Gaeta. All the while, Nicola Del Roscio, who watched over him, quietly created his own Eden.
lead_paragraph: Cy Twombly painted some of the 20th century’s great works in the hilly Italian coastal town of Gaeta. All the while, Nicola Del Roscio, who watched over him, quietly created his own Eden.

headline: Voting for Israel’s Next Prime Minister
abstract: As the results of Israel’s tight election roll in, Israelis reflect on the issues they hope the next prime minister will make priorities.
lead_paragraph: As the results of Israel’s tight election roll in, Israelis reflect on the issues they hope the next prime minister will make priorities.

headline: Air Force Veteran From New Jersey Tried to Aid ISIS, U.S. Charges
abstract: Tairod Nathan Webster Pugh, 47, an airplane mechanic, tried to travel from Egypt to Turkey to Syria, prosecutors say, but was ultimately deported to the United States.
lead_paragraph: An Air Force veteran from New Jersey, recently fired from his job as an airplane mechanic, has been charged with trying to support the Islamic State by seeking to join the group.

headline: Review: Pierre-Laurent Aimard and Tamara Stefanovich in All-Boulez Program
abstract: Mr. Aimard and Ms. Stefanovich played some of Pierre Boulez’s most difficult piano works at a concert in Zankel Hall on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Pierre Boulez emerged in the late 1940s in Paris as a combative modernist, the brash new leader of the avant-garde. By 1952 he declared that any musician who had not felt the “necessity of the dodecaphonic language” was “of no use.” Despite subsequent decades of winning over mainstream classical music audiences through his work as a conductor with lucid, colorful performances of everything from Wagner operas to Mahler symphonies, Mr. Boulez, who turns 90 on March 26, has never shaken his early reputation for writing pieces of off-putting complexity.

headline: So Glad You Could Make It, Mr. Mayor
abstract: The mayor needs to do something about his chronic lateness.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio was late again this morning. The Daily News reported that he arrived 15 minutes behind schedule to a St. Patrick’s Day Mass at St. Patrick’s Cathedral. This was after he somehow managed to be equally late to a St. Patrick’s Day breakfast and reception in his own house, Gracie Mansion.

headline: Obama Takes St. Patrick’s Day-Themed Swipe at Republicans
abstract: The White House fountain was running green and a green tie-wearing President Obama was full of St. Patrick’s Day puns when he blasted Republicans’ newly unveiled budget on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The White House fountain was running green and a green tie-wearing President Obama was full of St. Patrick’s Day puns when he blasted Republicans’ newly unveiled budget on Tuesday.

headline: Taxes Take Away, but Also Give Back, Mostly to the Very Rich
keywords: ['Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Income Inequality', 'Taxation', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Of the $540 billion in tax subsidies for housing, education, retirement and savings in 2013, the top 1 percent received more than the money received by the bottom 80 percent combined.
lead_paragraph: “Get your billions back, America,” the tax preparer H&R Block urges in television advertisements.

headline: Eleven Madison Park
abstract: Daniel Humm and Will Guidara pull out all the stops with food and service.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Humm and Will Guidara pull out all the stops with food and service.

headline: Men, Money and the Marriage Crisis
keywords: ['Hispanic-Americans', 'Income', 'Income Inequality', 'Men and Boys', 'Nineteen Hundred Sixties', 'United States Economy', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Do falling male wages explain rising family instability?
lead_paragraph: As promised in my last entry, this will be the first of two posts on the theme of whether economic trends largely explain post-1960s family breakdown (my answer: no), addressing counterarguments that I didn’t have room to discuss in Sunday’s column. The first counterargument is about men: It concedes that there is a modest upward post-’60s trend in household income, rather than a steep decline, but it argues that focusing on the general trend ignores a collapse in earnings for low-skilled men, which — since it takes two to tango, and marry — suffices to explain why it’s become harder for working class males to successfully fill the roles of husband and father … especially since, with women entering the workforce, they aren’t as economically dependent on men as they once were and don’t need to settle for a guy whose wages keep on falling.

headline: Review: Paul Taylor Troupe’s Dizzying New Palette Takes Shape
abstract: The group presented the Limón Dance Company in Doris Humphrey’s “Passacaglia and Fugue in C Minor,” reflecting an expanded mission of honoring other choreographers.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, on the cusp of its 60th anniversary, the Paul Taylor Dance Company announced its new identity as Paul Taylor’s American Modern Dance. On Saturday night at the David H. Koch Theater, one aspect of the troupe’s expanded mission — to preserve modern dance masterworks by artists other than Mr. Taylor — began to take shape, with the presentation of Doris Humphrey’s 1938 “Passacaglia and Fugue in C Minor.”

headline: Patching Up the Social Safety Net
keywords: ['Social Security (US)', 'Poverty', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Income Inequality', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'United States Economy', 'Federal Taxes (US)']
abstract: Universal programs financed by broader taxes could appear unfair, but targeted social insurance financed by progressive taxes is likely to be stingy and politically weak.
lead_paragraph: Few people played as critical a role in the construction of the American social safety net as Wilbur Cohen.

headline: A Villa With Caribbean Views
abstract: The house, set on two and a half acres above Plum Bay, is on the market for $3.9 million.
lead_paragraph: The house, set on two and a half acres above Plum Bay, is on the market for $3.9 million.

headline: Injuries Leave Rangers Reduced but Not Diminished
abstract: Martin St. Louis is just the latest Ranger to be sidelined for an extended period of time, but the team rolls on at the top of the N.H.L.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The list of Rangers who have played in every game this season is short, and it will shrink by one on Wednesday, as Martin St. Louis will not suit up against the Chicago Blackhawks because of a lower-body injury.

headline: Cleveland Clinic Grapples With Changes in Health Care
keywords: ['Medicine and Health', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Hospitals']
abstract: To keep pace with insurers’ expectations, the renowned health system is trying to become as good at primary care as it is at performing complicated procedures.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — In downtrodden East Cleveland, a three-story family health center has replaced the city’s full-service hospital. Seven thousand miles away in Abu Dhabi, a gleaming 24-story hospital is preparing to admit patients this year.

headline: Iowa G.O.P. to Walker: Drop Adviser Who Trashed State
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Iowa Republicans demanded the dismissal of an adviser to Gov. Scott Walker, after she attacked the state and its caucus.
lead_paragraph: Iowa’s Republican leadership blasted Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin on Tuesday for hiring a senior adviser who has mocked the state’s caucus and its voters, and called on Mr. Walker to fire her.

headline: Coming of Age as a Guide at Ground Zero
abstract: In a new initiative at the National September 11 Memorial & Museum, students from local high schools summon the emotional maturity to serve as guides.
lead_paragraph: Annalee Tai, a 16-year-old junior at Bard High School on Manhattan’s Lower East Side, has only the sketchiest recollection of planes smashing into the World Trade Center in 2001.

headline: So, Print Is Dying? Don’t Tell the Megazine
abstract: Lisa Anne Auerbach embraces a traditional format in outsize proportions to let her photos breathe, but also to comment on the state of publishing.
lead_paragraph: Like chocolate bars and Arctic ice caps, printed periodicals have shrunk over the last decade. The Wall Street Journal, Rolling Stone, The New York Times and dozens more have reduced their physical dimensions to maintain fiscal fitness.

headline: Trips for Cyclists Who Want to Sample the Tour de France
keywords: ['Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Tour de France (Bicycle Race)', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Two tour companies are offering trips for cyclists to ride a stage of the Tour de France while race competitors have a rest day.
lead_paragraph: For cyclists who want to crank more than coast, two American tour operators are offering cycling trips highlighting the Alpine L’Étape du Tour (French for “stage of the Tour”).

lead_paragraph: Pakistan and More — Pictures of the Day

lead_paragraph: This week’s properties include a condo in Missouri, a contemporary in Los Angeles and a townhouse in Philadelphia.

headline: March 17, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Pakistan, Israel, London and the United States.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Pakistan, Israel, London and the United States.

headline: General Motors’ Stock Buyback Follows a Worrying Trend
keywords: ['Shareholder Rights and Activism', 'Stock Options and Purchase Plans', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index"]
abstract: The automaker gave in to the demands of activist shareholders looking for a quick return at the expense of the harder work of building value.
lead_paragraph: General Motors’ announcement that it will buy back $5 billion worth of stock raises the question of whether the stock buyback has turned into a shareholder activist shakedown.

headline: Review: In ‘Lucia di Lammermoor’ at the Met, Singing Through Sickness
abstract: The tenor Joseph Calleja, recovering from the flu, starred in that Donizetti work on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Whatever glamour and passion there is in the Metropolitan Opera’s blandly efficient revival of Donizetti’s “Lucia di Lammermoor” hovers around Joseph Calleja. Though he was announced at Monday’s performance as recovering from the flu, and had the wear in his tone and coughs to prove it, this invaluable tenor nevertheless sang Edgardo with plangent vigor. The characteristic sob in his throat, dimmed only slightly by his illness, was both affecting and exciting.

headline: Criminal Complaint Against Mr. Pugh
abstract: An 11-page complaint that sets forth the United States’ charge that Tairod Nathan Webster Pugh attempted “to provide material support and resources” to ISIS.
lead_paragraph: An 11-page complaint that sets forth the United States’ charge that Tairod Nathan Webster Pugh attempted “to provide material support and resources” to ISIS.

headline: ‘Empire,’ the Meteor That Never Fell to Earth
abstract: With its mix of family rivalry and skulduggery, Fox’s hip-hop prime-time soap opera racked up ratings that kept growing, surprising its producers and Fox executives.
lead_paragraph: The plotlines of “Empire,” Fox’s hip-hop prime-time soap opera, tell a complicated tale of family rivalry and skulduggery. The text messages exchanged by Fox executives as the show’s success improbably grew week by week told a more succinct story.

headline: New Directors/New Films Festival Gives Spotlight to Youth
abstract: Selections from this festival emphasize young protagonists and young filmmakers navigating obstacles and seizing opportunities.
lead_paragraph: Like the first buds on the trees and the hint of springtime softness in the air, New Directors/New Films is an annual sign of renewal. The program, a joint presentation of the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art, dispels the lingering post-Oscar malaise and imports some energy and novelty from Sundance. Its geographically and stylistically wide-ranging selection of first and second features and short films emphasizes youth — (mostly) young protagonists and (mostly) young filmmakers navigating obstacles and seizing opportunities.

headline: Review: In Richard Maxwell’s ‘The Evening,’ Going Gentle Into the Night, or Not
abstract: In this play at the Kitchen, three characters represent a multiple-choice way of dealing with life, and death.
lead_paragraph: Everybody knows that life ends in death. And for much of our waking hours, we do our best to push this awareness to the very back of our minds. There are times, though, when such kindly amnesia isn’t possible. And then everything we look at is suddenly and abruptly heightened by the sense that existence is defined by extinction.

headline: Review: ‘Kumiko, the Treasure Hunter,’ Inspired by an Urban Legend
abstract: A Japanese woman gets the disastrously incorrect idea that the Coen brothers’ movie “Fargo” depicts a true story in this movie by two other siblings, David and Nathan Zellner.
lead_paragraph: The real-life story that inspired “Kumiko, the Treasure Hunter” was too good to be completely true, but that doesn’t diminish the film, a delicate, haunting study of a woman who has in several senses lost her way.

headline: A Conversation With James Wacht of Lee & Associates
abstract: Mr. Wacht is the president of Lee & Associates NYC, a commercial real estate brokerage firm and is also an owner of Sierra Real Estate, a property management company.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Wacht, 59, is the president and an owner of Lee & Associates NYC, a commercial real estate brokerage firm affiliated with Lee & Associates Commercial Real Estate Services, which has its headquarters in Newport Beach, Calif. He is also an owner of Sierra Real Estate, a property management company, and the Cogswell Lee Development Group, which specializes in property acquisitions.

headline: Review: ‘Amour Fou,’ About the Woman in a Poet’s Suicide Pact
abstract: Jessica Hausner’s drama about a 19th-century German suicide pact is based on the angst and death of the poet and playwright Heinrich von Kleist.
lead_paragraph: Romantic longing takes a beating in “Amour Fou,” an eccentric, coolly deadpan story of love, including that of the self. Set in Germany in the early 19th century, it tells of a middle-class woman, Henriette (Birte Schnoeink), who, to her great surprise, catches the eye of an insistently gloomy young poet, Heinrich (Christian Friedel).

headline: Kendrick Lamar, Emboldened, but Burdened, by Success
abstract: The rapper’s new album emotes on living under constant racialized surveillance and how that can lead to many types of internal monologues, some empowered, some self-loathing.
lead_paragraph: Calling mainstream hip-hop a series of compromises is unfair, but the genre is far from where it was even a decade ago. It’s still a privileged space for black expression, but has also become extremely conscious of everyone else listening in. Broadly speaking, it has reframed its concerns as universal, not specific. It is, by and large, polite — a warm and welcoming host.

headline: Review: A Darker ‘Pinocchio’ Strays From Disney’s Wholesome Take
abstract: Bearing shadows truer to Carlo Collodi’s 19th-century tale, this family-friendly show manifests robust energy, visual flair and an aversion to modern-day phoniness.
lead_paragraph: The truths in the retelling of “Pinocchio” now at the New Victory Theater are more contemporary than we’re used to hearing. Bearing shadows truer to Carlo Collodi’s 19th-century tale than Walt Disney’s version, this family-friendly show, from the Windmill Theater and the State Theater Company of South Australia, manifests robust energy, visual flair and an aversion to modern-day phoniness.

headline: Recent Commercial Transactions

abstract: Notable properties that have been recently listed for sale, sold or leased in New York City.
lead_paragraph: RECENT SALE

abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Kendrick Lamar’s New Album, ‘To Pimp a Butterfly,’ Is a Streaming Hit
abstract: Spotify announced on Tuesday afternoon that “To Pimp a Butterfly” racked up more streams on Monday — its first full day out — than any album has in a single day in the history of the service, which started in 2008.
lead_paragraph: Since its surprise release on Sunday night, the rapper Kendrick Lamar’s highly anticipated album “To Pimp a Butterfly” (TDE/Aftermath/Interscope) has been insta-analyzed and tweeted about constantly, generating high praise from Kanye West, among many others.

headline: Living In Sunnyside, Queens
abstract: In western Queens, an old-fashioned neighborhood of squat prewar apartment buildings, rowhouses and bustling shopping streets.

headline: Syria: Reports Claim Downing of a U.S. Surveillance Drone
abstract: The Syrian state news media reported Tuesday that the country’s air defense systems had shot down an American surveillance plane near the northwestern city of Latakia.
lead_paragraph: The Syrian state news media reported Tuesday that the country’s air defense systems had shot down an American surveillance plane near the northwestern city of Latakia. American defense officials confirmed that United States military controllers had lost contact with an unarmed, remotely piloted craft — an MQ-1 Predator — over northwestern Syria but said they had no information to corroborate that it had been shot down. They said they were investigating. Syrian state television showed footage of what it said were the remnants of the plane being loaded into a truck by soldiers. If confirmed, the downing would be the first of an American aircraft in Syria since a United States-led coalition began bombing Islamic State extremists there last year.

headline: Go Ahead, Ruin My Day
abstract: In looking at Israel, Iran and ISIS, why does it seem as though we have only bad choices, and nothing ever works?
lead_paragraph: As the saying goes, “to err is human, to forgive is divine,” to which I’d add: “to ignore” is even more human, and the results rarely divine. None of us would be human if we didn’t occasionally get so wedded to our wishes that we failed to notice — or outright ignored — the facts on the ground that make a laughingstock of our hopes. Only when the gap gets too wide to ignore does policy change. This is where a lot of U.S. policy is heading these days in the Middle East. Mind the gaps — on Iran, Israel and Iraq. We’re talking about our choices in these countries with words that strike me as about 10 years out of date. Alas, we are not dealing anymore with your grandfather’s Israel, your father’s Iran or the Iraq your son or daughter went off to liberate.

headline: Bangladesh’s Third Gender
keywords: ['Hinduism', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Photography', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: A Bangladeshi photographer has been documenting the lives of hijras, men who sexually identify as women and live under the watch of a guru.
lead_paragraph: Shahria Sharmin had gone to her husband’s factory in Dhaka, Bangladesh, looking to tell a positive story about the garment industry, one that would offset negative public perceptions. What she found, instead, was an even more challenging topic: the lives of five hijras, the local term for the culture of men who identify as women. By day, they presented themselves as men, but at night they dressed as women and kept a home for their boyfriends.

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (ABC) THE UNTOLD STORY OF ‘THE SOUND OF MUSIC’ Diane Sawyer travels to Austria with Julie Andrews in this “20/20” special celebrating the 50th anniversary of the film “The Sound of Music,” and explores its cultural impact during a time of unrest in the United States. In Salzburg they trace the steps of the von Trapp family, who inspired the movie; tour the former home of Maria von Trapp, the character Ms. Andrews portrayed; visit the train station where the family escaped the Nazis; and speak with the Mother Abbess of the Nonnberg Abbey, where Maria was a postulant after World War I. Christopher Plummer, who played Captain von Trapp, also shares his recollections of the film and his relationship with Ms. Andrews, who chimes in about a few of her favorite things.

lead_paragraph: If the budget resolution released on Tuesday by House Republicans is a road map to a “Stronger America,” as its title proclaims, it’s hard to imagine what the path to a diminished America would look like.

headline: George Osborne Offers Tax Breaks to British Voters in Budget Statement
abstract: With an upturn in tax receipts and a dip in inflation, the chancellor of the Exchequer outlined a range of breaks, including measures for savers, first-time home buyers and beer drinkers.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — With British elections approaching, George Osborne, the chancellor of the Exchequer, used a budget statement on Wednesday to claim credit for the economic recovery and to offer some relief to hard-pressed voters.

headline: Test Yourself | Virtual Reality Games
abstract: Here are several paragraphs from a March 8 article, “Virtual Reality’s Potential Displayed at Game Developers Conference.” Can you choose the best word for each blank?
lead_paragraph: Here are several paragraphs from a March 8 article, “Virtual Reality’s Potential Displayed at Game Developers Conference.”

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Alcohol or Marijuana? A Pediatrician Faces the Question
abstract: What question comes up “again and again” for this pediatrician, and what does he say is “the easy answer”?
lead_paragraph: In “Alcohol or Marijuana? A Pediatrician Faces the Question,” Aaron E. Carroll looks at studies and data to assess risk.

headline: More Nigerian-Americans Are Reaching Highest Levels of Sports
abstract: Immigrants from the African country, and their descendants, are excelling at the top levels of high school, college and professional sports, largely as an outgrowth of their pursuit of education.
lead_paragraph: TEMPE, Ariz. — At Arizona State’s recent Senior Day celebration, guard Promise Amukamara was escorted onto the basketball court by her four sisters, whose mellifluous names spoke of royalty and hope: Peace, a teammate, along with Princess, Precious and Passionate.

headline: As Chinese Tourism Increases, American Museums Adapt
abstract: Museums across the United States are adding audio tours in Mandarin, accepting a Chinese credit card and promoting their exhibits on Weibo.
lead_paragraph: It’s now easier for mainland Chinese to visit the United States, thanks to relaxed visa rules instituted late last year, allowing 10 years before visa renewal rather than one year. The change is expected to increase Chinese tourism and real estate investment, but it will also have a less obvious beneficiary: American museums.

headline: Considering a Counterintuitive Path to Escape a Fire: The Elevator
keywords: ['Elevators and Escalators', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Evacuations and Evacuees', 'World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'Fires and Firefighters']
abstract: Three New York City departments are writing rules to govern what are called occupant-evacuation elevators — cars that can, in special circumstances, be used to move people down in an emergency.
lead_paragraph: “In case of fire, use elevators.”

headline: Louisiana Parish Fights Plan to Burn Tons of Propellant No One Wants
keywords: ['Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Webster Parish residents and others said they would not shy from a confrontation if the authorities proceed with a plan to openly burn an abandoned stockpile of M6 propellant.
lead_paragraph: MINDEN, La. — Just before midnight on Oct. 15, 2012, Sheriff Gary Sexton of Webster Parish was driving home from the airport when the sky lit up like midday. He flipped on his walkie-talkie to hear everyone asking: What on earth were those big booms?

headline: Gyorgy Kepes, Wizard of Light and Motion, Comes Back Into Focus
abstract: An exhibition about Kepes’s experiments with light, photography and graphics from 1937 to 1947 underlines a surge of interest in his work.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Whenever he had free time, the Hungarian designer Gyorgy Kepes would disappear into a makeshift darkroom at the Institute of Design, an experimental school he had founded with a group of friends in Chicago in 1939, to create abstract, often surreal images of familiar objects like stones, leaves and slices of bread.

headline: For ‘Alice in Wonderland’ Milestone, a Stampede Down the Rabbit Hole
abstract: A dizzying array of exhibitions has been organized across the United States to mark the 150th anniversary of the book’s publication.
lead_paragraph: While the Alice of Lewis Carroll’s “Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland” was a fictional British character, she has touched the hearts of young and old worldwide, particularly in the United States.

headline: How Often Do You Engage in ‘Fat Talk’?
abstract: How often do you complain about your body or overhear others doing so? Have you been known to say, “I’m so fat” to friends? What effect do you think public body self-disparagement like this has on the person complaining? On those who are part of the conversation?
lead_paragraph: How often do you complain about your body — or overhear others doing so? Have you been known to say, “I’m so fat” to your friends?

headline: Afghan First Vice President, an Ex-Warlord, Fumes on the Sidelines
abstract: Abdul Rashid Dostum, a strongman with an unsavory past, is being excluded from Afghanistan’s inner circle of power, a strategy that carries risks.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The security meeting was almost at a close when the first vice president of Afghanistan, the former warlord Abdul Rashid Dostum, began crying.

headline: Japan’s Businesses Respond to Abe’s Push for Higher Wages
abstract: Pay increases at companies like Toyota and Panasonic are modest but represent a step forward for the prime minister’s economic revival program.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan has been putting unusually strong pressure on his country’s businesses to raise workers’ pay, a crucial but still missing piece of his economic growth plans.

headline: ‘The Age of Cryptocurrency,’ by Paul Vigna and Michael J. Casey
abstract: A look at the rapidly evolving world of digital money.
lead_paragraph: Money, “The Age of Cryptocurrency” ­explains, is “a medium of exchange, a unit of account and a store of value.” But for Schopenhauer it was “human happiness in the abstract,” and for Dostoyevsky “coined liberty.” These passion metaphors reflect the febrile excitement about Bitcoin that Paul Vigna and Michael J. Casey, both of The Wall Street Journal, share in their wide-ranging, interesting account of the origin, past and possible future of this virtual-money wannabe.

headline: Bill Browder’s ‘Red Notice’
abstract: An American businessman confronts the Russian kleptocracy.
lead_paragraph: The grandson of the head of the American Communist Party commits the ultimate act of rebellion: He gets a business degree from Stanford. From there, he goes on to build the biggest hedge fund in Russia. After exposing widespread government corruption, he gets expelled from the country. While he’s gone, the Kremlin raids his fund and perpetrates an elaborate financial fraud. The lawyer investigating the crime is tortured and dies in prison. He avenges his lawyer’s death, exposing a cover-up at the highest levels of the Putin regime.

headline: How to Get Your Spouse to Exercise
abstract: Changes in one married partner’s exercise routine tend to be echoed in the other’s, highlighting the extent to which our exercise behavior is shaped by the people around us.
lead_paragraph: Spouses influence each other’s exercise habits, for better and worse, more than is often recognized, according to an interesting new study of the workout habits of middle-aged couples. The study found that changes in one spouse’s routine tend to be echoed in the other’s, highlighting the extent to which our exercise behavior is shaped not just by our personal intentions but by the people around us as well.

headline: Beck, Dave Grohl and John Legend to Perform at Rock Hall of Fame Ceremony
abstract: They will join other musicians to honor this year’s inductees, who include Bill Withers, Lou Reed and Stevie Ray Vaughan.
lead_paragraph: Beck, Dave Grohl and John Legend will perform at the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame induction ceremony on April 18 in Cleveland, it was announced on Wednesday. Several current Hall of Fame members will be on hand to induct the newest crop: Stevie Wonder will induct Bill Withers and Patti Smith will induct Lou Reed, who died in 2013.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get the Morning Briefing in your inbox first thing? Sign up.)

headline: The Health Concerns in Wearable Tech
abstract: Some researchers and consumers are now asking whether wearable computers will be considered harmful in several decades’ time.
lead_paragraph: EDITORS’ NOTE APPENDED

headline: Outlook for Solar Gets a Bit Brighter
abstract: Solar has seen a dramatic fall in costs, on the order of more than 60 percent over the last five years.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Here is a trick question: Which country led the European Union last year in putting new solar panels on rooftops and in countryside energy parks? If you chose sunny Spain or balmy Italy, you were wrong. Britain, the green and pleasant land often shrouded in cloud, was the leader, according to the market research firm I.H.S.

headline: Win in Israel Sets Netanyahu on Path to Rebuild and Redefine Government
abstract: Israelis paved the way for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to lead a right-leaning and religious coalition that could be easier to control.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israelis emboldened Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu with a clear mandate in balloting on Tuesday, paving the way for him to lead a right-leaning and religious coalition that could be far easier to control, since his own party holds many more seats now.

headline: Germans Protest European Austerity Measures
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Demonstrators marching toward the central bank in Frankfurt set cars on fire in a rally against European austerity programs and capitalism.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Protesters set cars on fire and clashed with police officers on Wednesday as they marched toward the European Central Bank’s new headquarters in a demonstration against austerity and capitalism that took on a markedly more heated tone than past protests.

headline: Edinburgh International Festival, Under New Director, Sets Lineup
abstract: The Edinburgh International Festival in August will be the first under the direction of Fergus Linehan.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A focus on big international stars and more diverse musical programming characterizes Fergus Linehan’s first Edinburgh International Festival, which will run Aug. 7-31. Mr. Linehan, who was the director of the Sydney festival, then head of the contemporary music program at the Sydney Opera before coming to Edinburgh, succeeded Jonathan Mills as director.

headline: New York Today: Growing Up With Robert Durst
abstract: Wednesday: A Durst brother’s tale, cold and windy weather, and New Yorkers have the longest commutes.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this cold and windy Wednesday.

headline: Aid Trickles to Vanuatu as Relief Workers Report Vast Cyclone Damage
abstract: Aid workers described a “grave situation” in the South Pacific nation devastated by Tropical Cyclone Pam, with food, clean water and shelter all in short supply.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Aid was slowly reaching Vanuatu’s storm-devastated outlying islands on Wednesday, including the remote southern island of Tanna, which was believed to have been crossed by the eye of Tropical Cyclone Pam as it tore across the small Pacific nation last weekend.

headline: Daily Report: You Can Now Send Your Friends Money on Facebook
abstract: The social network’s new feature will allow Facebook friends to send payments to one another through the Messenger app. Wall Street expects such transactions to become a big business.
lead_paragraph: Facebook‘s instant messaging service isn’t just for sending smiley faces and photos anymore. Now you can use it to send money instantly to your friends.

headline: The Invisible Primary Means No TV Ads. For Now.
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Political Advertising', 'Online Advertising', 'Television', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Voters in key states should enjoy the lull while it lasts, which could be until summer.
lead_paragraph: There’s a reason the early part of the presidential nomination contest is called the invisible primary: There are no television ads yet. Voters in key states should enjoy the lull while it lasts, which could be until summer or maybe even longer.

headline: Charles C. W. Cooke Can Fend for Himself
abstract: The National Review writer on being “conservatarian,” the Second Amendment and surviving an apocalypse.
lead_paragraph: You were born in England and moved here in 2011 to work for National Review. What made you decide to resettle in the colonies? I’d spent a lot of time in America. We have family friends in California and Arizona. I always had great love for America. I even had an Apollo 11 lunchbox.

headline: Alabama Shakes’s Soul-Stirring, Shape-Shifting New Sound
abstract: With its highly anticipated second album, this band of small-town misfits finally has a ticket out — not that they would ever leave.
lead_paragraph: In the upstairs dressing room at the Georgia Theater in Athens, Ga., in January, Alabama Shakes was getting restless. The band was about to perform songs from its second album, “Sound & Color,” for the first time, and the room was full of distractions. Friends and relatives had driven over from Alabama: cousins and uncles, wives and girlfriends, crying babies and unrestrained toddlers. Sippy cups and spilled Cheerios were scattered everywhere.

headline: Do You Tell a Friend His Daughter Is Sexually Active?
keywords: ['Ethicists, The (Times Column)', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Ethics (Personal)']
abstract: The ethicists consider reader questions about teenage sex, workplace conduct and interviewing for jobs while pregnant.
lead_paragraph: A man told me he was approached by his best friend’s daughter, a minor, who confided that she and her boyfriend had become sexually active. She wanted his opinion on birth control. The man says he would want to know if it were his daughter, but to tell the parents would violate the girl’s trust. What do I tell him? NAME WITHHELD, CONNECTICUT

headline: Today in Politics: Washington Responds to Netanyahu’s Victory in Israel
abstract: As Washington digested Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s surprisingly strong victory on Tuesday in Israel’s elections, the consensus among Republicans and Democrats was that the strategic partnership between the United States and Israel remained intact despite lingering partisan tension over Mr. Netanyahu’s address to Congress.
lead_paragraph: Good Wednesday morning from Washington, where March Madness is already starting to get political, and even St. Patrick’s Day could not bring President Obama a lucky budget from Republicans. The resignation of Representative Aaron Schock of Illinois is still the talk of the town, but Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin may have found himself a headache in Iowa. Yet for now, the biggest electoral drama is the result in Israel’s vote.

headline: How to Be Misled by Polls, Hillary Clinton Email Edition
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'E-Mail', 'News and News Media']
abstract: A report of a decline in Mrs. Clinton’s poll numbers was based on an outlier result from November.
lead_paragraph: Has the controversy over Hillary Clinton’s use of a personal email account hurt her in the polls?

headline: Hotel Review: The Godfrey in Chicago
abstract: A comfortable crash pad for the young (or young-at-heart) who value style over service.
lead_paragraph: Doubles from $109.

headline: Restaurant Report: Low Country Kitchen in Steamboat Springs, Colo.
abstract: Two Southerners draw on local ingredients from the Yampa Valley, putting new twists on dishes from back home.
lead_paragraph: For Brian and Katy Vaughn, owners of two restaurants in Steamboat Springs, Colo., it’s all about family. Before settling for good in Steamboat Springs, where the couple met, the Southern-born Vaughns took a major detour back through the South, she to attend architecture school and he to work for the chef Norman Van Aken in Miami. When they wanted to settle down and raise a family, home turned out to be the mountains of Colorado.

headline: A Pioneer for Death With Dignity
abstract: As the movement for medical aid in dying gains ground, one of its leading advocates recalls the mentor who inspired her to fight for the cause.
lead_paragraph: More than two decades before Brittany Maynard’s public advocacy for death with dignity inspired lawmakers in Washington, D.C., and at least 16 states to introduce legislation authorizing the medical practice of aid in dying for the terminally ill, Senator Frank Roberts of Oregon sponsored one of the nation’s first death-with-dignity bills.

headline: Noam Chomsky on the Roots of American Racism
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Discrimination', 'Native Americans', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Thirteenth Amendment (US Constitution)']
abstract: Slavery and oppression of nonwhites were built into the foundations of the United States, and they didn’t end in 1865.
lead_paragraph: This is the eighth in a series of interviews with philosophers on race that I am conducting for The Stone. This week’s conversation is with Noam Chomsky, a linguist, political philosopher and one of the world’s most prominent public intellectuals. He is the author of many books, including, most recently, “On Western Terrorism: From Hiroshima to Drone Warfare,” with Andre Vltchek.

headline: Iraqi Forces and Militias Said to Loot Sunni Towns
abstract: The victorious forces, which took back territory from ISIS militants with the help of U.S.-led airstrikes, carried out raids in dozens of towns, Human Rights Watch said.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Iraqi militias and security forces destroyed and looted the property of displaced Sunni civilians after reclaiming the town of Amerli from Islamic State militants last year, according to a Human Rights Watch report issued Wednesday.

headline: Serbia Arrests Eight Suspected in 1995 Srebrenica Massacre
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The detentions apparently represented a widening of the prosecution beyond high-level officials and commanders.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prosecutors in Serbia said on Wednesday that eight men suspected of having participated in the 1995 Srebrenica massacre, Europe’s bloodiest slaughter since World War II, had been arrested. The arrests were described by prosecutors as the first by the Serbian police of anyone accused of doing the killing at Srebrenica, where 8,000 Muslims died.

headline: Morning Agenda: More Scrutiny for Biomet
abstract: New bribery evidence adds a year to Biomet’s probation. | G.M.’s stock buyback suggests the clout of activist investors. | Macerich spurns a rival’s takeover bid. | S.E.C. chief backs a higher standard for brokers.
lead_paragraph: MORE SCRUTINY FOR BIOMET | The giant medical devices manufacturer Biomet, which was accused of foreign bribery, disclosed on Tuesday that prosecutors would extend its probation another year as they investigate new evidence of wrongdoing at the company, Ben Protess reports in DealBook. The Justice Department is investigating whether Biomet helped bribe government officials in Mexico and Brazil, a reminder of an earlier bribery case that Biomet settled in 2012. To resolve the first case, Biomet paid $17 million and struck a so-called deferred prosecution agreement that withheld criminal charges as long as the company behaved during three years of probation.

headline: French Court Blocks Airbus Insider Trading Trial
abstract: The Constitutional Council argued that the defendants had already been cleared by the French Financial Markets Authority in 2009.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A French court on Wednesday blocked an insider trading trial of seven current and former executives of the Airbus Group, as well as two of its former shareholders, arguing that the defendants had already been cleared by stock market regulators, making any further prosecution of the case a violation of European double jeopardy rules.

headline: N.C.A.A. Bracket Conundrum: To Pick Kentucky or Not to Pick Kentucky?
abstract: The selections of Times readers tend to fall into those two categories. We offer risk-management strategies for your bracket.
lead_paragraph: Participants in our interactive N.C.A.A. bracket, which rewards correct picks based on their overall popularity among readers, have reached a consensus: Not surprisingly, Kentucky is the team to beat. More than half of Times readers pick the Wildcats to reach the national championship, and 41 percent have chosen them to win the title.

headline: If a Woman's Place Is on the 20
abstract: Who should be the first female on U.S. paper currency if Andrew Jackson is retired?

headline: Fortescue, Big Iron Ore Miner, Pulls $2.5 Billion Debt Sale
keywords: ['Steel and Iron', 'Metals and Minerals', 'Credit and Debt']
abstract: Amid falling prices for iron ore, Fortescue Metals finds the markets “not favorable."
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Fortescue Metals Group of Australia, the world’s fourth-largest iron ore exporter, has pulled a $2.5 billion debt sale amid a 48 percent plunge in the price of iron ore that prompted investors to demand better terms than Fortescue was willing to offer.

headline: Obama May Find It Impossible to Mend Frayed Ties to Netanyahu
abstract: Benjamin Netanyahu’s victory appears to have dashed any hopes President Obama might have had for a way out of his tumultuous and often bitter relationship with the leader.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel had a poisonous relationship long before Mr. Netanyahu swept to victory on Tuesday night in elections watched minute-by-minute at the White House.

headline: College Basketball Is an Attraction. Is It Pretty? Well ...
abstract: Scoring is down. The game is slow. Players are bolting for the N.B.A. after a year. Many believe college basketball needs “an extreme makeover.”
lead_paragraph: A word of caution to those excited for the N.C.A.A. tournament: Prepare to be a bit disappointed.

headline: Microsemi to Acquire Vitesse Semiconductor for $389 Million
abstract: The deal, through a cash tender offer of $5.28 a share, represents a further consolidation in the chip-making industry.
lead_paragraph: The Microsemi Corporation announced on Wednesday that it had reached an agreement to acquire Vitesse Semiconductor for $389 million, furthering a drive toward consolidation in the chip-making inudstry.

headline: A Polite Bit of Road Rage
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: When a car full of preoccupied passengers didn’t move through a red light, the driver behind them, who didn’t have a horn, reminded them in person.

headline: Sunnyside, Queens, ‘Mayberry’ Near Midtown
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: In contrast to the modern towers of Long Island City, old-fashioned Sunnyside offers low-rise prewar buildings and mom-and-pop businesses.
lead_paragraph: Sunnyside, in western Queens, is a stark contrast to the gleaming glass residential towers rising in nearby Long Island City. Here is an old-fashioned New York neighborhood of squat prewar apartment buildings, rowhouses and shopping streets that still have mom-and-pop businesses.

headline: Law School Proximity Matters for Partner Prospects, Study Finds
abstract: Geographical proximity to a major legal market may be a good predictor of “big law” career success, a new study shows.
lead_paragraph: Elite law schools are not always a glide path to becoming a partner at a big law firm. A new study of partners’ academic pedigrees shows that a large number of graduates who reach the top rung at a law firm do not necessarily come from the top-ranked law schools.

headline: Tunisia Museum Attack Is Blow to Nation’s Democratic Shift
abstract: Gunmen killed 19 people in downtown Tunis, which dealt a new blow to a tourist industry that is vital to Tunisia as it struggles to consolidate its transition to democracy.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Gunmen in military uniforms killed 19 people on Wednesday in a midday attack on a museum in downtown Tunis, dealing a new blow to the tourist industry that is vital to Tunisia as it struggles to consolidate the only transition to democracy after the Arab Spring revolts.

headline: $1.2 Million Homes in Los Angeles, Philadelphia and Kansas City
abstract: A condo in Missouri, a contemporary in Los Angeles and a townhouse in Philadelphia
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, MO.

abstract: The real estate market in St. Martin continues to rebound after stagnating during the worldwide economic downtown in 2008; oceanfront property is the hardest to come by.

headline: E!’s ‘Fashion Police’ Is Put on Hiatus Until Fall After Hosts Exit
abstract: After the recent departure of two hosts, “Fashion Police” will not return to the air on March 30.
lead_paragraph: “Ever since Joan Rivers died in September,” Jon Caramanica wrote in The New York Times this week, “‘Fashion Police’ — the E! show devoted to poking holes in celebrity pageantry that she had hosted since its inception — has been collapsing in plain view.”

headline: Make Rice Pudding Without a Recipe
abstract: Amanda Hesser and Merrill Stubbs of Food52 show you how to make three variations of rice pudding, all without a recipe.
lead_paragraph: Amanda Hesser and Merrill Stubbs of Food52 show you how to make three variations of rice pudding, all without a recipe.

headline: ‘The Tallest Tree in the Forest,’ a Play About Paul Robeson
abstract: The life and career of the athlete, actor, singer and civil rights activist is brought to dramatic life in this play, written by and starring Daniel Beaty.
lead_paragraph: The extraordinary life and career of Paul Robeson — the athlete, actor, singer and civil rights activist — is brought to dramatic life in “The Tallest Tree in the Forest,” written by and starring the talented actor Daniel Beaty, the author and star of “Emergence-SEE!” at the Public Theater.

headline: Lisa Howard on Her Latest Broadway Show, ‘It Shoulda Been You’
abstract: Ms. Howard plays the sister of the bride in the new musical about a chaotic wedding, which opens at the Brooks Atkinson Theater on April 14.
lead_paragraph: Being told you’re too tall or short for a role is hard enough. Being told you’re too heavy would seem downright excruciating. But Lisa Howard has heard that plenty of times and nevertheless managed to persevere in a career that includes one “Twilight” movie and four Broadway shows.

headline: Netanyahu on Likud’s ‘Great Victory’
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel spoke after his ruling Likud Party scored a sound victory in the country’s election.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel spoke after his ruling Likud Party scored a sound victory in the country’s election.

headline: Ben Miles Takes On ‘Wolf Hall’ Onstage
abstract: An actor plays Thomas Cromwell, a character who is “devious, charming, playful, occasionally perverse, sometimes honorable.”
lead_paragraph: If you stroll over to the Frick Collection, as the cast of “Wolf Hall, Parts One & Two” recently did, you can see Hans Holbein’s 1530s portrait of Thomas Cromwell, the court consigliere at the center of the Royal Shakespeare Company’s stage adaptation of Hilary Mantel’s prizewinning novels.

lead_paragraph: Protesters and the police clashed in Frankfurt on Wednesday as thousands demonstrated against the European Central Bank’s austerity measures.

headline: A Splash of Flash
abstract: In a season of underdone hair, a little adornment can make all the difference.
lead_paragraph: In a season of underdone hair, a little adornment can make all the difference.

headline: An Uber Service Is Banned in Germany Again
abstract: A judge ruled that drivers for the ride-sharing service UberPop must be professionally licensed, overturning a ruling from September that had allowed it to operate.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A judge in Frankfurt dealt a setback to Uber on Wednesday, ruling that drivers for its ride-sharing service UberPop must hold the official permits required of taxi drivers to operate in Germany. The ruling reinstates one of the most severe legal restrictions faced by the company anywhere in the world.

headline: City Ballet Announces 2015-16 Season
abstract: The 2015-16 season will feature seven world premieres, including, in winter, the first full-length ballet by the choreographer Justin Peck.
lead_paragraph: World premieres: Seven. Balanchine ballets: 28. Dancers: 94. Composers danced to: 47, including Ellis Ludwig-Leone of the band San Fermin and Bryce Dessner of the National, who were commissioned to write scores.

headline: Sweden Cuts Key Interest Rate to Minus 0.25%
abstract: The Swedish central bank’s move followed a similar cut last month, and it came just hours before a meeting of the Federal Reserve in Washington.
lead_paragraph: The Swedish central bank on Wednesday again cut its main interest rate, bringing it deeper into negative territory to head off deflationary pressures.

headline: Mayor de Blasio Emerges as an Unexpected Champion of Religion
abstract: In finding new ways to commingle church and state, Bill de Blasio has carved himself a niche as a liberal who is willing to embrace religious groups rather than treat them as adversaries.
lead_paragraph: Growing up, Mayor Bill de Blasio was the only child on his block who did not attend Mass on Sundays. “Everyone else was at church, and I wasn’t,” he recalled in an interview last week. “Some of the kids envied me.”

lead_paragraph: Amy Schumer discusses writing and starring in “Trainwreck,” a comedy directed by Judd Apatow.

abstract: Scenes from Tunisian state television showed confusion outside an art museum and Parliament on Wednesday after gunmen attacked.

headline: SXSW 2015 Video: Amy Schumer on ‘Trainwreck’
keywords: ['Movies', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: The star and writer of “Trainwreck” discusses the film.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — The comedy “Trainwreck,” written by and starring Amy Schumer and directed by Judd Apatow, received an enthusiastic response at its screening here on Sunday. In this video interview recorded at the festival, Ms. Schumer discusses her role in the movie, how her screenplay drew from personal experiences, and how she finds the comedy in tragic situations.

headline: Insider City Tours From InterContinental Hotels
abstract: InterContinental Hotels is offering a package that includes a night in a suite, a private driver and specialized city tours.
lead_paragraph: Guests at InterContinental hotels in Tel Aviv, Paris and London can now take part in the company’s “Secrets of the City,” a program that offers specialized tours of each city.

headline: Clippers’ Doc and Austin Rivers Try to Balance Their Many Roles
abstract: When Doc Rivers, the Clippers’ coach and president of basketball operations, acquired his son Austin, they established the N.B.A.’s first father-son-player-coach relationship.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Spend a few moments with Austin Rivers, and it becomes clear soon enough that he is a chip off the old Doc.

headline: Deal Makers Less Upbeat About M.&.A. Growth
abstract: In a survey, 54 percent of deal makers say they believe that 2015 will surpass last year in terms of mergers activity, down from 78 percent last year.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Last year was by all accounts a banner year for mergers. But as one of the takeover industry’s main conferences prepares to begin here, a new survey has found that significantly fewer deal makers believe that 2015 will prove any better.

headline: Obama’s Bracket Is Just a Bit More Daring This Year
abstract: President Obama made his annual N.C.A.A. bracket projections, and he is going with consensus favorite Kentucky to win it all.
lead_paragraph: President Obama has made his annual N.C.A.A. bracket projections, and he is going with the consensus favorite, Kentucky, to win it all.

headline: The Brooklyn-Born-Raised-and-Based Artist Who Dripped Her Way to Chanel Sneakers and Car Service
abstract: Joyce Pensato, a 70-something-old breath of fresh air whose current and fourth solo show is currently on view at Petzel Gallery, explains her slow rise to painterly fame.

headline: 36 Hours in Dubai
abstract: Dubai has emerged as an ethnically diverse metropolis where the world’s populations mingle in markets, galleries and international restaurants, both humble and high-end.
lead_paragraph: Dubai has emerged as an ethnically diverse metropolis where the world’s populations mingle in markets, galleries and international restaurants, both humble and high-end.

headline: 36 Hours in Dubai
abstract: Superlatives notwithstanding, Dubai has an emerging alternative, arty side, with a fast-growing gallery district, indie fashion designers and cool cafes.
lead_paragraph: Dubai is impossible to ignore. As its leaders and property developers proudly trumpet, the city-state along the Persian Gulf has the world’s highest building (the Burj Khalifa), the world’s tallest hotel (JW Marriott Marquis Dubai), the world’s largest artificial island (the Palm Jumeirah) and the world’s biggest mall (Dubai Mall).

headline: Better Sleep for a Better Sex Life
abstract: A new study found that for women in romantic relationships, each extra hour of sleep corresponded to higher levels of sexual desire and an increase in the likelihood of sexual activity the next day.
lead_paragraph: A good night’s sleep may be important for a woman’s sex life, a small study suggests.

headline: Jeb Bush Picks Up a New Supporter for a Run: His Mother
abstract: Barbara Bush, often the most outspoken member of the family, put an early damper on the thought of Jeb Bush running for president with a verbal eye roll about the idea, suggesting that maybe some other American clans could produce presidential candidates.
lead_paragraph: Barbara Bush, often the most outspoken member of the family, put an early damper on the thought of Jeb Bush’s running for president with a verbal eye roll, suggesting that maybe some other American clans could produce presidential candidates.

headline: Japan Investigates Death Threats Against Caroline Kennedy, U.S. Ambassador
keywords: ['Threats and Threatening Messages', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The threats, which also targeted the American consul-general in Okinawa, were reported as Michelle Obama arrived in Japan on her first visit.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The police in Japan are investigating telephoned death threats to the United States ambassador, Caroline Kennedy, the daughter of President John F. Kennedy, and to an American diplomat in Okinawa, Japanese and international news agencies reported on Wednesday.

headline: For Perfect Pasta, Add Water and a Vigorous Stir
abstract: This simple ingredient brings classic Roman dishes to life.
lead_paragraph: On a clear fall day in Rome, I was sitting outside at Flavio al Velavevodetto, a restaurant in Testaccio, in a neighborhood that was once the city’s slaughterhouse district and is now inhabited by both older working-class people and gentrifying youngsters. Flavio de Maio, an elegant, middle-aged businessman turned chef, sat across the table from me; a translator sat between us. I had come at the recommendation of a friend, the Rome-based journalist and historian Katie Parla, who told me that if I was looking for the epitome of Roman pasta, this was the place.

headline: The Art of the Tantrum
abstract: Two new picture books find the charm in their characters’ terrible moods.
lead_paragraph: No one does cranky with quite as much panache as the French. Two picture books about bad moods, both written by Francophone authors and offered in English translations for the first time, demonstrate what may be the secret. Both take an approach that many parents struggle to master: The less you fight it, the more likely it is that irritability will give way on its own to something else — sometimes, even something charming.

headline: ‘Goodfellas’ Will Help Close Tribeca Film Festival
abstract: A remastered version of the 25-year-old gangster film will be shown, and members of the cast will be on hand.
lead_paragraph: You and a date probably won’t be able to attend closing night of the Tribeca Film Festival by entering through the basement, wending your way through labyrinthine hallways and perhaps a kitchen, greasing several palms and having seats set up in the front row. But if you’re willing to settle for buying tickets and walking through the front doors, you can watch that famous tracking shot and other memorable scenes in a newly remastered version of the Martin Scorsese gangster film “Goodfellas,” organizers announced Wednesday.

headline: ‘Wolf Hall,’ a Six-Part TV Series, Tackles Hilary Mantel’s Books
abstract: The BBC’s adaptation of Ms. Mantel’s two novels, which opened to rapturous acclaim in Britain, will make its American debut on PBS’s “Masterpiece.”
lead_paragraph: OXFORDSHIRE, ENGLAND — Thomas Cromwell was rolling a cigarette. Henry VIII was sitting on a chair amid a stretch of green lawn, eyes closed, face turned to the summer sunlight. A gaggle of ladies-in-waiting swept across the gardens. A courtier popped his head apologetically around the door of Broughton Castle. “Five minutes,” he said.

headline: National Gallery in London Appoints New Director
abstract: Gabriele Finaldi, the deputy director for collections and research at the Prado museum in Madrid, will replace Nicholas Penny on Aug. 17.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Ever since last summer, when Nicholas Penny, the director of the National Gallery here, announced his plans to retire, speculation and rumors about who might succeed him abounded. On Wednesday, the National Gallery announced that Gabriele Finaldi, the deputy director for collections and research at the Prado museum in Madrid, would take up the post. The appointment was confirmed by the British prime minister, David Cameron.

lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is putting Israel on a collision course with its allies, the Palestinian ambassador to the United Nations said Wednesday, warning that if Mr. Netanyahu succeeded in forming a new government, he would further isolate his country.

headline: Neither Simon Nor Macerich Can Claim High Road in Mall Bid
keywords: ['Shopping Centers and Malls', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: The offer by the mall owner Simon may not be as generous as it claims. But the response of the target, Macerich, is the more disingenuous.
lead_paragraph: American operators of fancy retail complexes are showing similarities to far-flung bazaar traders. The mall owner Macerich rejected an unwanted $22 billion takeover bid from a larger rival, the Simon Property Group. The premium offered may be less valuable than claimed. Even so, the target company’s response is the more disingenuous.

headline: Inquiry Into Rape of Indian Nun Is Sent to Federal Agency
abstract: No arrests have been made in the rape of the nun and the robbery of a convent school last week in the Indian state of West Bengal.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — With no arrests yet in the rape of a nun  and the robbery of a convent school last week in the Indian state of West Bengal, the state’s leader on Wednesday delegated the case to the federal investigating agency.

headline: Why Can’t We Stop Watching ‘Empire’?
abstract: A round-table on Fox’s breakout hit as its first season draws to a close.
lead_paragraph: What is it about “Empire,” the Fox series about a family of music moguls that wraps up its first season this week, that makes the show so addictive? It might be the juicy plotlines; Taraji P. Henson’s ferocious and charming portrayal of Cookie Lyon, the estranged matriarch of the family; the so-bad-it’s-almost-good soundtrack, produced by Timbaland; or some combination of all three. The soapy drama, which debuted in January, was the highest-rated new series on television this season. Its ratings and audience numbers have risen each week the show has aired — a phenomenon that is practically unheard-of. Fox has already renewed the series for a second season.

headline: Wayne Odesnik Barred From Tennis After Second Doping Violation
abstract: The International Tennis Federation said the American player Wayne Odesnik provided doping samples that tested positive for banned substances.
lead_paragraph: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — The International Tennis Federation and the United States Anti-Doping Agency announced Wednesday that the American Wayne Odesnik had been barred for 15 years after urine samples he submitted in December and January tested positive for multiple banned substances. It was Odesnik’s second doping offense in five years.

headline: Praying With Jeb Bush
abstract: Michael Paulson described attending Mass at Jeb Bush’s parish in Florida in hopes of better understanding how Mr. Bush worships.
lead_paragraph: Michael Paulson will soon begin reporting on theater for The Times, but for his penultimate article as a national religion reporter, he wrote about the role that Catholicism plays in Jeb Bush’s life.
