headline: Kansas, a No. 2 Seed, Limps Into the N.C.A.A. Tournament
abstract: The Jayhawks enter the tournament diminished by the loss of forward Cliff Alexander to an eligibility issue and injuries to Perry Ellis (knee) and Landen Lucas (hip and back).
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — At the end of a brief practice the day before the Big 12 tournament quarterfinals at Sprint Center here, Kansas forward Cliff Alexander, a freshman, left the court with his gray T-shirt drenched in sweat. Alexander, embroiled in an eligibility issue with the N.C.A.A., had no reason to hold back because he would not be playing in the tournament.

headline: A Perfectly Simple Hermès Watch That’s Simply Perfect
abstract: The French house has created a line for both men and women that marks the passing of time in the most spare and elegant way.
lead_paragraph: The new Slim d’Hermès is an expression of luxurious minimalism. Unlike timepieces designed to measure your steps while tracking your pace, the French house has created a line of watches for both men and women — its first series in over 20 years — that marks the passing of time in the most spare and elegant way. Enclosed in a slender rose gold case, the luminescent dial of the watch shown here features numerals custom-created by Philippe Apeloig, a well-regarded French graphic designer. (Apeloig is also behind the signage for Jean Nouvel’s upcoming Louvre Abu Dhabi.) A sapphire crystal case back reveals the ultrathin automatic movement, manufactured at the prestigious Swiss watchmaker Vaucher, now owned in part by Hermès. As befits a company that started out making leather harnesses for European noblemen in 1837, the hand-stitched Havana alligator strap receives the same attention to detail as does a Kelly bag. Valuing creativity and craftsmanship above all, Hermès shows how perfect simple can be.

headline: Car Bomb Targeting Afghan Officials Kills 7 Civilians
abstract: A huge explosion took place near the provincial governor’s offices in Lashkar Gah, the capital of Helmand Province.
lead_paragraph: LASHKAR GAH, Afghanistan — A huge car bomb rocked the capital of Helmand Province late Wednesday morning, killing seven people and wounding more than 45 in an attack aimed at a gathering of officials in a secure Afghan government compound.

abstract: SXSW is safety-conscious — with more police officers and barricades — but it still hasn’t figured out crowd control.
lead_paragraph: SXSW is recognizably more safety­-conscious this year after a deadly incident in 2014, when a drunken driver crashed through a barrier and killed four people waiting in line on the street outside a club, and injured others. There are more barricades, more police officers and more streets closed to traffic.

headline: Dieudonné M’bala M’bala, French Comedian, Convicted of Condoning Terrorism
abstract: Dieudonné M’bala M’bala was found guilty for a Facebook message that suggested sympathy with one of the gunmen in the deadly attacks in Paris.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The provocative French comedian Dieudonné M’bala M’bala was found guilty on Wednesday of condoning terrorism after a Facebook message he posted in January suggested sympathy with one of the gunmen in the attacks that killed 17 people in Paris.

headline: Starbucks Initiative on Race Relations Draws Attacks Online

But the coffee company’s campaign has instead unleashed widespread vitriol and derision.

lead_paragraph: Roughly a year ago, at home in Colorado, Lindsey Vonn’s mornings were devoted to grueling gym sessions rehabilitating her twice rebuilt right knee. Vonn’s afternoons were spent with the leg enveloped in ice, a routine that had kept her out of consecutive racing seasons.

lead_paragraph: A bipartisan Senate bill that would permit the medicinal use of marijuana in states that allow it is slowly gaining support among lawmakers. The latest to sign on is Senator Barbara Boxer, Democrat of California, who became a co-sponsor of the bill on Tuesday.

headline: Suspect Is Captured After Rampage in Mesa, Ariz., Leaves One Man Dead
abstract: Hours after the rampage began on Wednesday, the police arrested a man just blocks from the site of the first shooting in Mesa, Ariz.
lead_paragraph: MESA, Ariz. — After an argument in a motel, a gunman went on a deadly rampage through a quiet neighborhood here early Wednesday, leaving one man dead and at least five others wounded before being captured, the authorities said.

headline: Study Reveals Genetic Path of Modern Britons
abstract: Researchers found that the modern British population falls into 17 clusters that are all very similar but genetically distinguishable.
lead_paragraph: In A.D. 410, Roman authority in Britain collapsed and Romano-British society disappeared from history under the invading tides of Angles and Saxons from northern Europe. Historians have been debating ever since whether the Romano-British were wiped out or survived by adopting their conquerors’ language and culture.

headline: Dana Farouki on Where to Eat, Shop and Gallery-Hop in Dubai
abstract: The art collector, adviser and booster shares recommendations for what to do in the city — just in time for its annual arts week.
lead_paragraph: The art collector, adviser and booster Dana Farouki moved from New York to Dubai almost five years ago, cementing a relationship with the city that began with family when she was a child and has continued through her nearly 10 years as a curator and champion of arts organizations and initiatives in the UAE, including the Guggenheim Abu Dhabi. She has served on the Board of Patrons for Art Dubai, the ninth edition of which begins today and runs through Saturday, since the fair began in 2007. She’s also on the jury for the Abraaj Group Art Prize, whose winners (all artists from the Middle East, North Africa or South Asia) will be showcased at the fair this week.

headline: Senate Republicans Rebuff House Colleagues With Their Budget Plan
abstract: Over all, the Senate version hews closely to the budgetary intent of the House proposal. But the primary flash point is likely to be over military spending.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans on Wednesday released an austere budget that maintains strict caps on military spending and cuts trillions of dollars from health care and welfare, sending a rebuff to their House colleagues.

He was 77.

And, relatedly: Why does Mr. Cheney feel this endless need to maintain a public profile?

headline: Pope Francis to Speak at U.N. During Annual Gathering of World Leaders
abstract: Francis will be the fourth pope to visit the United Nations since its founding 70 years ago.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis, an outspoken advocate for the rights of the poor, will visit the United Nations during its annual conclave of world leaders in September, Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon announced Wednesday. Francis will be the fourth pope to visit the United Nations in its 70-year history.

headline: PlayBuzz Rides Quizzes and Lists to $16 Million in Financing
abstract: A partner at the venture capital fund 83North, which led the round of investment, said that his firm had been drawn to PlayBuzz because it provided a means for any website to attract readers.
lead_paragraph: PlayBuzz, a website and online platform for creating quizzes, lists and surveys, which has been ranked as one of the most shared sites on Facebook, said on Wednesday that it had raised $16 million in a fresh round of financing.

headline: Dissident Journalist in Yemen Is Shot and Killed
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'News and News Media', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations']
abstract: Abdulkarim al-Khaiwani, who wrote about the Houthi rebellion and survived beatings and prison under the former government, was killed outside his home in Sana.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — One of Yemen’s best-known dissident journalists, who survived beatings and imprisonment under the former authoritarian government, was shot and killed on Wednesday by unidentified gunmen outside his home in the capital, Sana, according to witnesses and officials.

headline: Both Sides in ‘Blurred Lines’ Copyright Suit Signal a Continuing Battle
abstract: Lawyers for both the Marvin Gaye family and the musicians found to have infringed on Gaye’s 1977 copyright filed documents in federal court on Monday.
lead_paragraph: The “Blurred Lines” case has resulted in one of the biggest jury verdicts in the history of music copyright, and it’s not closed yet.

headline: Review: ‘Hunchback of Notre Dame’ at Paper Mill Playhouse
abstract: There is a surprising self-seriousness to this polished but ponderous musical, with music by Alan Menken and lyrics by Stephen Schwartz.
lead_paragraph: MILLBURN, N.J. — Granted, I didn’t actually tally them up, but the words “Kyrie eleison” — that’s Greek for “Lord have mercy” — seem to be sung more frequently in the musical version of “The Hunchback of Notre Dame” at the Paper Mill Playhouse here than they are in many a Mass. Which is saying something, if you’ve heard a few Masses in your day.

headline: Nicole Najafi’s Marfa Myths Encounters, From Dev Hynes to a New Tequila Drink
abstract: The founder of the year-old brand with a cult following, Industry Standard, shares pictures from her weekend adventure in West Texas’s picturesque high desert city.
lead_paragraph: The founder of the year-old brand with a cult following, Industry Standard, shares pictures from her weekend adventure in West Texas’s picturesque high desert city.

headline: Janet Yellen Isn’t Going to Raise Interest Rates Until She’s Good and Ready
abstract: Among the signals the Fed seeks to send is that there is no preordained policy path, but instead a willingness to keep adapting to new information.
lead_paragraph: The key words in Janet L. Yellen’s news conference Wednesday were rather pithy, at least by central bank standards. “Just because we removed the word ‘patient’ from the statement doesn’t mean we are going to be impatient,” Ms. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, said.

headline: Corners of American Life
abstract: The playwright Lisa D’Amour is busy all over the country.
lead_paragraph: The playwright Lisa D’Amour is busy all over the country.

headline: Facts & Figures: New Yorkers’ Punishing Commutes
abstract: New Yorkers spend more time commuting, on average, than residents of any other major city, according to a new report.
lead_paragraph: New York City has earned a dubious honor: Its residents spend more time commuting, on average, than residents of any other major city in the country, according to a report issued by the city comptroller’s office. This news comes just a few weeks after New Yorkers learned that subway delays had increased more than 45 percent between 2013 and 2014.

headline: Review: Kate Tempest, a Young Poet Conjuring Ancient Gods
abstract: In “Brand New Ancients” and “Hold Your Own,” this rapper and writer demonstrates a knack for being able to shuttle back and forth between the mundane and the mythic.
lead_paragraph: A wunderkind rapper and spoken word performer equally influenced by Wu-Tang Clan and Joyce, Bukowski and Blake; an English poet whose musical sense of language bridges the worlds of rap and traditional lyric verse; a fan favorite at the Glastonbury music festival who became the youngest winner of the Ted Hughes poetry prize. Such dichotomies not only attest to the 29-year-old Kate Tempest’s gift for shattering — and transcending — convention and conventional genres, but they also underscore the tensions and contradictions that fuel her dynamic art.

headline: Mets Are Looking Like Lumberjacks (With Smoother Swings)
abstract: Several Mets said there were more beards in camp this year than in the recent past, and the team has even eased its facial hair restrictions on its minor leaguers.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Over the off-season, like any man on hiatus from work, Noah Syndergaard did not shave every day. He had some stubble when he came here in January to train with a group of Mets. Then he saw Bobby Parnell and Josh Edgin and their substantial beards, and Vic Black’s beard on social media, and he decided to commit to growing his own.

headline: Fed Removes Promise to Be ‘Patient’
abstract: Janet L. Yellen, chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, said that while it was unlikely that the Fed would raise a key interest rate at its next meeting in April, there might be increases later.
lead_paragraph: Janet L. Yellen, chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, said that while it was unlikely that the Fed would raise a key interest rate at its next meeting in April, there might be increases later.

headline: Federal Employee Will Not Face Criminal Charges in Drone Crash at White House
abstract: The F.A.A. is still investigating whether to fine a federal employee who was flying the hobbyist’s drone that came down on the South Lawn.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department said Wednesday that it would not criminally charge a federal employee who was operating a hobbyist’s drone that crashed on the South Lawn of the White House in January.

headline: Artek Celebrates the German Harpsichord
abstract: A two-day celebration at Immanuel Lutheran Church included Baroque concerts and workshops on musical technique and artisanal construction.
lead_paragraph: Bach’s music, played on a harpsichord representing his time and place: as natural as this may seem, it is an infrequent event, at least in New York. The Artek ensemble made that point strongly over the weekend with Harpsichords of Germany, a little festival of concerts, workshops and discussions at Immanuel Lutheran Church on the Upper East Side.

headline: Who Should Lead the New York Philharmonic? Readers Respond.
abstract: The classical music critics of The New York Times recently pondered who to choose to succeed Alan Gilbert. Here, readers offer their thoughts.
lead_paragraph: The classical music critics of The New York Times recently pondered who should take over as music director of the New York Philharmonic after Alan Gilbert steps down in 2017.

headline: At the Prague Marathon, History Is a Spectator
abstract: To run through the city’s medieval streets and working-class neighborhoods, where dissidents had conspired against Communist rule, is to run through Czech history.
lead_paragraph: The Prague International Marathon starts in Staromestske Namesti, or Old Town Square, in the heart of the city, directly between Old Town Hall, with its famous astronomical clock, built in the early 15th century, and the weathered bronze monument of Jan Hus and his followers. Hus, the Charles University philosophy professor and preacher who was burned at the stake as a heretic in 1415, stands stately and tall in the center of the square. You half expect to see a starter’s pistol in his hand.

headline: In Israel, Opera Echoes From Rocks and Ruins
abstract: In the Judean Desert, with the mountain fortress Masada as a backdrop, the Israeli Opera mounts a “festival out of nothing.”
lead_paragraph: When Eitan Campbell, the director of Israel’s Masada National Park, first came to work at the promontory in 1972, he was taken by a small etching of a sailboat on one of the fortress’s ancient stone walls. Perhaps it was a bored Herodian soldier, sitting atop the mountain in the hot sun of 30 B.C., who spied the vessel afloat in the nearby Dead Sea and painted its likeness to pass the time.

headline: European Union Moves to Limit Special Tax Deals
abstract: European officials proposed new disclosure rules meant to make it more difficult for countries to work out special tax-avoidance deals with multinationals.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — European Union officials on Wednesday proposed new rules to try to discourage tax-avoidance deals with multinational corporations, which critics say give some countries unfair business advantages.

headline: The Brooklyn-Born-Raised-and-Based Artist Who Dripped Her Way to Chanel Sneakers and Car Service
abstract: Joyce Pensato, a 70-something-old breath of fresh air whose current and fourth solo show is currently on view at Petzel Gallery, explains her slow rise to painterly fame.
lead_paragraph: The biggest change in Joyce Pensato’s life since her recent ascent to painterly panacea? “Oh, I only take car services now,” she giddily boasts. That’s also discounting the Chanel high-tops she splurged for recently at Barneys, but hey, she only bought them because they were comfortable. “Well, I got two pairs,” she confesses. In fact, that Uber is Pensato’s greatest quotidian extravagance at the age of 70 — or somewhere in that ballpark, a lady never tells — is revealing of a painter who not only remained in the New York art scene’s periphery until recently, but, like many women, took years to find the confidence to really be herself. “I was really isolated, I wasn’t connected to any scene, I felt so alone,” she says. It could be easy to lump Pensato into the art world’s growing trend of “discovering” artists in their golden years. But her big, brash, bold canvases of Batman, Bart Simpson and other pop-cultural totems, which have become instantly recognizable, actually are not simply the byproduct of some advanced-style fad. In fact, her current and fourth solo at New York’s Petzel Gallery, open until March 28, features the caricature motifs she’s been working in since as long as she can remember (as well a surrealist Pop-culture series of photographs she’s just beginning to explore). Though Pensato has been drawing her whole lifetime, her tale is one of a personal journey of self-expression and finding her own unbeaten path — even if “I never got off the L train,” she jokes.

headline: Scott Walker’s Bracket: More Conservative Than Jeb Bush’s
abstract: Walker, Wisconsin’s governor, picks even fewer upsets than Jeb Bush, his likely rival for the Republican presidential nomination.
lead_paragraph: Scott Walker’s bracket is even more conservative than Jeb Bush’s.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Israel and Elsewhere
abstract: Israel and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Israel and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Review: Ailey II Displays Acrobatic Tussles Between the Sexes
abstract: The junior troupe’s program at the Joyce offered works by Manuel Vignoulle, Dwight Rhoden and Amy Hall Gardner.
lead_paragraph: Across a foggy stage, illuminated from the sides, dancers run past like extras in a disaster movie, anxiously looking in every direction. This is the start of a work called “Breakthrough,” but if the dancers or their audiences are searching for an artistic one, they will search in vain.

headline: Winners in Norman Kay Platinum Pairs in New Orleans
abstract: The Norman Kay Platinum Pairs is one of the toughest events to win at the Spring North American Championships.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — The Norman Kay Platinum Pairs is one of the toughest events to win at the Spring North American Championships. Every entrant has to have amassed a number of platinum master points, which are awarded only in the top national championships. After two days of play, just 28 pairs qualify for the final two sessions.

headline: March 18, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Israel, Tunisia, South Sudan and the United States.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Israel, Tunisia, South Sudan and the United States.

headline: SXSW Music 2015: Playing Unpaid, and Driving for Lyft (for a Paycheck)
keywords: ['Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Music', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: Kervens Joseph, an aspiring rapper known as Acafool, came to SXSW to make contacts and play a handful of unpaid concerts. Then he discovered he could drive for Lyft and make money, too.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Like so many other musicians, Kervens Joseph, an aspiring rapper known as Acafool, came to the South by Southwest Music and Media Conference here to make contacts in the industry by playing a handful of unpaid concerts. “Just for the exposure,” he said on Wednesday, as the music portion of the festival kicked into gear following the film and interactive events.

headline: Surprise in Israel Election as Exit Polls Falter
abstract: Polls had showed Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s party in a near tie with its chief rival, but many voters had refused to participate in surveys.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israelis woke up to a surprise on Wednesday morning, having gone to bed the night before with the results of their national elections in a near tie.

headline: Philippine Airlines Resumes Flights to New York
abstract: After almost 18 years, Philippine Airlines is again flying between Manila and New York City.
lead_paragraph: After a nearly 18-year hiatus, Philippine Airlines, also known as PAL, has restored service between Manila and New York City.

headline: ‘Empire’ vs. Madonna in Battle for No. 1
abstract: Selling the most albums no longer guarantees the top spot on the Billboard album chart.
lead_paragraph: What counts as a No. 1 album? These days the answer — or at least the way the music industry tries to spin the question — is sometimes open to interpretation.

headline: Microsoft Backs Further Away From Selling Software
abstract: Microsoft’s move to make Windows 10 upgrades free in China echoes a shift at the company and the software industry’s around the world. The days of charging customers for an operating system are slowly coming to an end, piece by piece.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft dismantled another piece of its old way of doing business on Wednesday.

headline: Nicole Najafi’s Marfa Myths Encounters, From Dev Hynes to a New Tequila Drink
abstract: The founder of the year-old denim brand with a cult following, Industry Standard, shares pictures from her weekend adventure in West Texas’s picturesque high desert city.
lead_paragraph: “I don’t know what it is, but the sky there is just legendary,” says Nicole Najafi about Marfa, Texas. “It’s so blue and so clear.” Of course the founder of the year-old denim brand Industry Standard noticed the cobalt-colored heavens above West Texas’s artist-populated high desert city: Blue is, predictably, her favorite color. Najafi is just back from her first trip there, for the three-day Marfa Myths Festival, curated by Ballroom Marfa and the record label Mexican Summer, that took place Friday through Sunday. “I think what makes Marfa so special, besides being a tiny town bursting with fine art and culture in the middle of nowhere, is that it is so hard to get to — the nearest airport, El Paso, is three hours away. Festivals tend to evolve into these huge, multi-faceted events that get inundated with people and morph into something totally different from what they started as. I had just assumed that would eventually be the case with Marfa; but the more I spoke to people who have been coming for many years, I learned that Marfa hasn’t changed very much. I love that.”

headline: Pakistan Steps Up Executions of Convicts, but One Gets Reprieve
abstract: The pace of executions has quickened, with 21 prisoners put to death this week, but the authorities postponed the hanging of one convicted when he was 14.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan hanged nine prisoners on Wednesday as part of a broader acceleration of executions that has drawn loud protests from human rights groups.

headline: William Pope.L Makes Statements From the Fringes
abstract: An installation and performance artist comfortable in the role of provocateur opens his largest museum show to date.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It was a plaintive sight: a monumental American flag drooping so low on its pole that it would touch the ground were it not for a wood platform. The artist William Pope.L was tending to the flag carefully. He lifted the tail end, where the stripes were separated at the seams, and spread them apart, the way you might separate a girl’s long hair before braiding it.

headline: Pentagon Confirms Strike Killed Shabab Militant Leader in Somalia
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)']
abstract: The Defense Department said that Adan Garar, a senior member of the Shabab extremist group, had been killed in a drone strike on his vehicle last week.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon said Wednesday that airstrikes last week against the Shabab extremist group were successful, and that Adan Garar, a senior member of the group, had been killed in a drone strike on his vehicle.

headline: For Tug Captain, Job That Runs in Family Turns Deadly Off Long Island
abstract: Donald Maloney, 60, who hailed from a family of New York mariners, died when his vessel, the Sea Bear, sank along the South Shore of Long Island.
lead_paragraph: There was rain, thick fog and an ocean swell — in other words, just another day on the water for Donald Maloney, 60, as the Sea Bear, the tugboat he was captaining, traveled along the South Shore of Long Island on Saturday.

headline: Review: Paul Taylor’s American Modern Dance at David H. Koch Theater
abstract: The troupe performed “Rite of Spring” and “Promethean Fire” with Shen Wei Dance Arts.
lead_paragraph: Among the endlessly interesting aspects of the performing arts is the matter of physical projection. Why is it that this dancer (or singer or actor) stands and moves in a way that doesn’t read beyond a few rows of the auditorium, whereas another seems to effortlessly exude presence and legibility fit for a stadium? In dance, the difference is often more striking among companies.

headline: Brain Swelling Tied to Deaths From Malaria
abstract: The finding in a new study will not change medical practice immediately, but it may lead to improved treatments, researchers said.
lead_paragraph: When children die from a severe form of malaria, swelling of the brain is often what kills them, a new study finds.

headline: Natalia Osipova in the Royal Ballet’s ‘Swan Lake’
abstract: The Russian ballerina, in her second season as a principal with this British company, can be seen when the production is streamed to American movie theaters in HD.
lead_paragraph: New York has seen the sensational Russian ballerina Natalia Osipova in a wide range of ballets — but, curiously, never in the illustrious double role of Odette-Odile in “Swan Lake.” This now changes, but on screen, not onstage. Now in her second season as a principal of the Royal Ballet in London, she recently danced the role three times at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden; the last of these, performed on Tuesday, is to be streamed to American cinemas in HD, starting tonight in East Coast theaters. (West Coast streamings occur later this month.) I saw the first, on Feb. 21, during a trip to London.

headline: Dolce & Gabbana Comments Trigger Public Outrage ... and Uncomfortable Silence
keywords: ['In Vitro Fertilization', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Magazines', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Boycotts']
abstract: Critics say the designers’ views on in-vitro fertilization and family are out of fashion. But normally outspoken magazine editors aren’t saying anything.
lead_paragraph: Over the last 30 years, Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana have dressed Madonna, designed costumes for Baz Luhrmann movies and fended off one of the most convoluted tax evasion cases in recent business history.

headline: Goldwyn Heirs to Sell Art and Hollywood Hills Mansion
abstract: The art, estimated to be worth $25 million to $30 million, will be auctioned, and a Hollywood Hills mansion sold, after the death of Samuel Goldwyn Jr.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The art collection and Hollywood Hills mansion that for decades were a physical representation of the Goldwyn dynasty’s staying power in film are being sold following the death of Samuel Goldwyn Jr.

headline: Mercedes-Benz to Sponsor U.S. Version of Rock in Rio
abstract: The automaker carefully selected a musical event it thought would have a brand-conscious audience.
lead_paragraph: For Mercedes-Benz, the decision to sponsor a pop festival came down to toilets, dirt and mud.

headline: Fashion’s Love Affair With the ’70s
abstract: Some stylish options to evoke the ’70s.
lead_paragraph: Some stylish options to evoke the ’70s.

headline: In Time for Spring, Sailor Pants and More
abstract: Sailor pants from Kenzo, Ace & Jig and more; Donald Duck and Mickey Mouse motif printed scarves; NikeLab’s collaboration with Sacai; and Maison Margiela’s sweet daisy jewelry.
lead_paragraph: Sailor pants from Kenzo, Ace & Jig and more; Donald Duck and Mickey Mouse motif printed scarves; NikeLab’s collaboration with Sacai; and Maison Margiela’s sweet daisy jewelry.

headline: The ’70s Are Back in Fashion. Again.
abstract: Why does the era of glitter and grit spin like a continuous reel in designers’ heads?
lead_paragraph: What did the ’70s feel like? As recalled by Bebe Buell, a singer and onetime habitué of that fabled hipster magnet Max’s Kansas City: “Everybody’s eyelids were very heavy. I used to chuckle to myself, thinking, ‘That’s the cannabis eye, the quaalude eye’ — the look people get when they’re feeling no pain.”

headline: Before ‘Empire,’ a Foundation Laid by ‘Platinum’
abstract: “Platinum,” a brief series that ran on UPN in 2003, told a tale of a family-run hip-hop music company with dynamics quite similar to those of Fox’s “Empire.”
lead_paragraph: A family-run hip-hop label is under siege: First there are the competitors, who are stealing the label’s artists; then there are the artists themselves, who are unreliable and prideful; and finally, there’s the internal strife between brothers.

headline: Math Professor’s N.C.A.A. Bracket Tests the Value of Predicting Upsets
abstract: In trying to predict outcomes for The New York Times’s bracket challenge, a Davidson professor and his students gave weight to the unequal payoffs to be gained from backing favorites or underdogs.
lead_paragraph: The upsets are always the tricky part of the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament. The methods we have developed at Davidson College often uncover several upsets in the first round, giving us leverage in the online bracket competitions we have participated in.

headline: Cheap Thrills at Neiman Marcus’s Cut-Price Outlet Store
abstract: At Neiman Marcus Last Call Studio in Brooklyn, orderly displays show off last-season’s clothes that may include a hidden treasure.
lead_paragraph: An outlet store is an awkward stepchild. It has to be close enough to the parent brand to leech some of the elder’s prestige, but not close enough to devalue it. It must attract the right customers without offending the wrong ones. Its appearance should deftly suggest, with things like paint color and lighting, a haven of cheap thrills with the possibility of hidden treasures.

headline: SXSW 2015: George Miller on the Evolution of ‘Mad Max’
keywords: ['Movies', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: The director discusses “The Road Warrior” and “Mad Max: Fury Road” at the festival.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — When the director George Miller was announced and came onstage to introduce a 35mm screening of “Mad Max: The Road Warrior” here on Monday, the crowd rose instantly to their (happy) feet. Mr. Miller’s 1981 film built a grungy, postapocalyptic world that has often been imitated (and at this festival with the movie “Turbo Kid,” humorously saluted), but not quite duplicated. It is arguably the most discussed in the franchise by critics and audiences, with its blistering airy landscapes, sparse dialogue, inventive camerawork and amplified action. At the screening, the first audience member to ask a question was the director Robert Rodriguez. He kept his inquiry simple: “How the hell did you do it?”

headline: Facials for Those Who Can’t Hide All Day After
abstract: Time-saving treatments, like a 10-minute facial, cater to busy New Yorkers.
lead_paragraph: With the success of blowout specialists like Drybar and DreamDry, it’s scarcely surprising that similarly minded salons are proliferating, each focusing on just one service. The newest additions focus on fuss-free facials, often with unisex appeal. As with the hair services, convenience and expertise are emphasized, with prices set to encourage regular patronage, not an occasional splurge.

headline: Why a Spielberg and a Goldwyn Passed Over Their Dads’ Hollywood for Snapchat
abstract: Emily Goldwyn and Sasha Spielberg together write and star in Snapchat’s first-ever scripted series, called “Literally Can’t Even.”
lead_paragraph: When your last name is Spielberg (as in Steven) or Goldwyn (as in John, Samuel Jr. and Samuel Sr.), finding a gig that lets you work on feature-length projects headed for the silver screen needn’t be difficult.

headline: Capturing the Night in Digital Photos, Spectacularly
abstract: A photographer shows how improvements in camera sensors and software and in postproduction software have made it possible to take excellent photos at night.
lead_paragraph: VINCENT LAFORET remembers the moment he realized that digital cameras had surpassed the human eye. It was late in 2009, and Mr. Laforet, a photographer who worked for The New York Times for many years, was shooting in Los Angeles with the EOS 1D Mark IV, a Canon camera that he had gotten as an early prototype.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Fifty Years On, a Pioneering Leather Shop (Not for the Uptight) Stands Strong
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Leather and Leather Goods', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: The Leather Man, an independent mom-and-pop (or in this case, pop-and-pop), celebrates a milestone anniversary.
lead_paragraph: A sign on the front door warns: “Must be 21 to Enter.” It doesn’t portend a traditional shopping experience.

headline: French Parliament Debates Weight Standards for Fashion Models
keywords: ['Models (Professional)', 'Weight', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'ANOREXIA NERVOSA', 'Law and Legislation', 'Legislatures and Parliaments']
abstract: The legislation would effectively set minimum weights for women and girls to work as models, a step that supporters say is necessary to combat the persistence of anorexia.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — France, which often seems to have style and elegance written into its genetic code, is again confronting one of the dark sides of fashion: the glamorization of too-thin women.

headline: In Taryn Simon’s Paris Show, a Look at How a Hidden Hand Organizes Reality
abstract: The first French retrospective devoted to this American photographer explores the power dynamics shaping how we process history, identity and more.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — World Press Photo, the renowned journalism prize organization, rescinded a top award this month amid controversy over whether a documentary photographer had crossed the line into staged art. The American artist Taryn Simon pushes the boundaries in the opposite direction, creating art photographs that draw on painstaking reporting.

headline: Social Media Images of Antiterrorism Rally in Tunis
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Social Media', 'Terrorism', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Tunisians marched hours after an assault by militants on a museum in the capital, Tunis, left at least 19 dead.
lead_paragraph: Tunisians rallied against terrorism Wednesday night, hours after an assault by militants on a museum in the center of the capital, Tunis, left at least 19 people dead, mainly foreign tourists.

headline: Police Shooting Tests New Wisconsin Law
abstract: A new law in Wisconsin might offer a model for the nation in how police-involved killings are investigated.
lead_paragraph: A new law in Wisconsin might offer a model for the nation in how police-involved killings are investigated.

headline: In Wisconsin, a Trial Run for a New Law
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The fatal police shooting of an unarmed black teenager in Wisconsin stands out from similar deaths because the state has a law mandating that an outside agency investigate such cases.
lead_paragraph: Since the deaths of Michael Brown Jr. in Ferguson, Mo., and Eric Garner on Staten Island, police use of deadly force against unarmed black men has become a topic of national discussion.

headline: Shopping Events and Sales Happening This Week in New York
abstract: Anya Hindmarch opens a pop-up store in Barneys, the celebrity makeup artist Tim Quinn teaches customers how to turn runway trends into daily looks and more.
lead_paragraph: The handbag designer Anya Hindmarch is bringing her British whimsy to Barneys. On Friday, she’ll open a pop-up on the store’s first floor for the Sticker Shop, her spring collaboration with Charlotte Stockdale of Chaos Fashion. Selfie aficionados can take a picture in an “Instabooth” complete with oversize AH sticker props. There will be several store exclusives, like a silver high-shine “Have a Nice Day” featherweight Ebury bag ($1,550), as well as a range of leather stick-on letters ($55) and symbols ($75) for those who prefer to personalize their message.

headline: TK
abstract: Tktktktk
lead_paragraph: Tktktktk

headline: Obama Criticizes Republican Budget
abstract: President Obama, speaking in Cleveland, said that the Republican budget failed to address the needs of the middle class and only offered “prosperity for those who have already prospered.”
lead_paragraph: President Obama, speaking in Cleveland, said that the Republican budget failed to address the needs of the middle class and only offered “prosperity for those who have already prospered.”

headline: Underground Wrestling in Moscow
abstract: Far from the pageantry and money of American pro wrestling, Russian grapplers exist in the shadows, where the bad guys wear red, white and blue.
lead_paragraph: Far from the pageantry and money of American pro wrestling, Russian grapplers exist in the shadows, where the bad guys wear red, white and blue.

headline: Mascaras That Are Better for Batting
abstract: Three new mascaras that promise thick lashes.
lead_paragraph: My eyelashes are truly pitiful. They’re so wimpy even extensions look ludicrous, yet a fake eyelash strip feels gauche. A liquid liner and coats of mascara are as good as it gets. And when it comes to mascara, I like mine gloppy — that is, a formula and brush that generously load product onto my lashes with minimal effort. If you’re the sort who prefers a natural lash look, read no further. But if you weren’t a winner in the genetic eyelash lottery, one of these mascaras may be for you.

headline: Warnings Raised of a Greek Exit From the Euro
keywords: ['Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Euro (Currency)', 'Credit and Debt']
abstract: Concerns about a withdrawal from the euro currency union come as the war of words heats up between Greece and its creditors.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Just a few weeks ago, fears that Greece might exit the euro union subsided when Europe extended its financial bailout. But as a new war of words escalates between Athens and its creditors, talk of a “Grexit” is heating up.

headline: Treating Exotic Pets
abstract: The patients at one Manhattan hospital tend toward the exotic: animals usually found in the wild but now kept as pets.
lead_paragraph: The patients at one Manhattan hospital tend toward the exotic: animals usually found in the wild but now kept as pets.

headline: Netanyahu’s Win Is Good for Palestine
keywords: ['Israeli Settlements', 'Palestinians', 'Elections', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'International Relations']
abstract: International pressure and sanctions on a right-wing government is the only thing that will change Israel’s behavior.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — IF anyone doubted where Benjamin Netanyahu stood on the question of peace, the Israeli prime minister made himself clear just before Tuesday’s election, proclaiming that there would never be a Palestinian state on his watch. Then he decided to engage in a bit of fear-mongering against Palestinian citizens of Israel in hopes of driving his supporters to the polls. “The right-wing government is in danger,” Mr. Netanyahu announced on Election Day. “Arab voters are heading to the polling stations in droves.”

headline: G.M. Exiting Russia, for the Most Part
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Factories and Manufacturing']

headline: Sales of Streaming Music Top CDs in Flat Year for Industry
abstract: Recorded music generated $6.97 billion in 2014, down from slightly more than $7 billion in 2013, the Recording Industry Association of American reported.
lead_paragraph: The American market for recorded music was flat in 2014, but income from streaming services like Spotify and Pandora has quickly grown to become a major part of the business, eclipsing CD sales for the first time, according to a report released Wednesday by the Recording Industry Association of America.

lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Rory McIlroy’s repeated absences from the Arnold Palmer Invitational became a symbol of his divided loyalties. He turned down invitations from Palmer, the tournament host, for three years, including twice when he was ranked No. 1, to spend time with his globe-trotting girlfriend, the tennis player Caroline Wozniacki, who was competing in back-to-back events in California and Florida.

headline: Target Plans to Raise Pay to at Least $9 an Hour

lead_paragraph: Target said on Wednesday that it would increase the pay of its workers to at least $9 an hour, joining retailers like Walmart and TJX in raising its hourly wage in a more competitive job market and facing pressure from labor groups.

headline: Palestinian Leaders See Validation of Their Statehood Effort
abstract: After a recent assertion by the Israeli prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, that he would never agree to a Palestinian state, the Palestinians can argue that they no longer have a negotiating partner.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Under most circumstances, an Israeli leader’s frank admission that he would never agree to a Palestinian state would be a disaster for the Palestinian leadership. But when Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said precisely that in the heat of the recent election campaign, it seemed to have the opposite effect, validating the unilateral approach the Palestinians have decided to follow.

headline: Ebola Cases Increase in Guinea
abstract: The World Health Organization said Wednesday that 95 new cases of Ebola had been confirmed in Guinea in the week that ended last Sunday, the highest weekly total for that country so far this year.
lead_paragraph: The World Health Organization said Wednesday that 95 new cases of Ebola had been confirmed in Guinea in the week that ended last Sunday, the highest weekly total for that country so far this year. The other two West African countries that have been ravaged by Ebola — Sierra Leone and Liberia — showed continued improvements for the week. Sierra Leone reported 55 confirmed new cases but that was the country’s lowest weekly total since last June. Liberia reported no new confirmed cases for the third consecutive week. Wednesday was the 12th day since the last known Ebola patient in Liberia had a negative test. Forty-two days must elapse after that test before transmission of the highly contagious Ebola virus is considered to have ended in Liberia. The weekly update by the W.H.O. also said a total of 10,154 people had died from the Ebola epidemic so far, almost all of them in the three worst-affected countries.

headline: Netanyahu Will Make History
abstract: How is the rest of the world going to react to an Israeli government that rejects a two-state solution and employs anti-Arab dog whistles to get elected?
lead_paragraph: Well, it’s pretty clear now: Benjamin Netanyahu is going to be a major figure in Israeli history — not because he’s heading to become the longest-serving Israeli prime minister, but because he’s heading to be the most impactful. Having won the Israeli elections — in part by declaring that he will never permit a two state-solution between Israelis and Palestinians — it means Netanyahu will be the father of the one-state solution. And the one-state solution means that Israel will become, in time, either a non-Jewish democracy or Jewish non-democracy.

But during his team’s practice Tuesday inside this old but famed gymnasium off the banks of the Great Miami River, Miller, Dayton’s coach, casually paced about with his hands folded in front of him and surveyed his surroundings as if to inspect every square inch like a visitor.

headline: Bergdorf Goodman Shares Recipes for Fashionable Fetes at Home
abstract: The seventh-floor restaurant of the Fifth Avenue department store has compiled its own dishes alongside some from the industry’s biggest names in a new, petite tome.
lead_paragraph: Bergdorf Goodman, the globally renowned retailer with one fashionable Fifth Avenue address, belongs to a rare set of iconic New York City institutions that appeal not only to tourists, but also to the most elite of locals. And there’s one floor where the department store’s casual window shoppers and seasoned regulars converge seamlessly: the seventh, in the Kelly-Wearstler designed BG Restaurant. If its powder-blue walls could talk, the fashion set’s secrets — divulged there over uptown fare, classic cocktails and afternoon tea — could probably fill a book. Instead, BG is releasing a chic little tome filled with recipes ($35, out March 24 from Harper Design). Some are from its own kitchen, and others come courtesy of the fashion designers, editors and stylists who eat there.

He was 89.

headline: Sweden: At Least Two Are Killed as Gunfire Erupts in Restaurant
abstract: Several people were shot and at least two died inside a restaurant in a suburb of Sweden’s second-largest city, Gothenburg, in what the police said might have been an act of gang-related violence.
lead_paragraph: Several people were shot and at least two died inside a restaurant in a suburb of Sweden’s second-largest city, Gothenburg, on Wednesday night in what the police said might have been an act of gang-related violence. Ulla Brehm, a spokeswoman for the Gothenburg Police Department, said the shootings took place on the island community of Hesingen, an area with a history of “difficulties with youth gangs, drugs and violent criminals.” She said two people died in the shooting and several more were wounded and taken to hospitals. Ms. Brehm added that there was “nothing indicating that this was terrorism at all. Not at all.” The police said the shooting occurred around 10 p.m. in a popular local restaurant called Var Krog och Bar, which means “our tavern and bar” in Swedish, that is on a bustling square.

headline: ‘Empire’ Finale Review: A Sizzling End to Season One

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 7 P.M. (HBO) ADMISSION (2013) Tina Fey portrays Portia Nathan, an admissions officer at Princeton who seems to take a special kind of glee in controlling the fate of students applying to the university. She also has a goal of her own: to succeed the retiring dean of admissions (Wallace Shawn) and beat out her office rival (Gloria Reuben) while reclaiming Princeton’s place at the top of the U.S. News & World Report rankings. But just as her smug English-professor boyfriend (Michael Sheen) dumps her for an aggressive Virginia Woolf scholar (Sonya Walger), a fellow Dartmouth alum (Paul Rudd) comes along with an unusual student (Nat Wolff) he wants Portia to consider. “How could anyone make light of the brutal, capricious system by which our young people are judged and sorted?” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this comedy from Paul Weitz, adapted from the novel by Jean Hanff Korelitz. “I must confess that I don’t know whether to be relieved or disappointed that ‘Admission,’ which had the potential to be a sharp, satirical jab at the soft belly of middle-class anxiety, chose instead to be a warm and wacky fable of wish fulfillment.”
