headline: An Ancient Civics Lesson
abstract: How Athens and Rome empowered the poor.
lead_paragraph: ANCIENT Greek and Roman politics rested on a conundrum. Lest they undermine social peace, the poor could not routinely threaten the lives or property of the rich. But unless the laws were fair enough to the poor, why should the plebs respect them?

headline: Cervantes and the Purpose of Literary Idolatry
abstract: The discovery of bones in a convent in Madrid could be those of the writer, and would exert a powerful pull on visitors, as graves of other great writers and poets always do.
lead_paragraph: Investigators in Madrid say they have found bones that probably include those of Miguel de Cervantes Saavedra, better known as Cervantes, the creator of “Don Quixote.” That the discovery should come just in time for the 400th anniversary of the writer’s death helps explain what otherwise might have seemed a quest better suited for the knight-errant of La Mancha.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Deep Wounds and Lingering Questions After Israel’s Bitter Race
abstract: Were you following the Israeli election? What is your reaction to the results? Why?
lead_paragraph: The questions below refer to the following Times articles reporting on Tuesday’s Israeli election: “Deep Wounds and Lingering Questions After Israel’s Bitter Race,” “Breakaway Party Leader Stays Mum on Where He’ll Throw Support After Israeli Elections” and “Voters in Nazareth Cheer Gains by Arab Alliance.”

headline: Japan’s Recovery Is Complicated by a Decline in Household Savings
abstract: The drop has coincided with an erosion in pay and job security for many workers, especially younger ones.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Takazumi Fukuoka should be exactly what Japan needs to get its economy moving again.

headline: Nancy Dubuc | The Necessity of Failure
abstract: Nancy Dubuc, chief executive of A&E Networks, has made her mark on cable television by taking big risks. But for every success, Ms. Dubuc says, she has learned from important failures.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Dubuc, chief executive of A&E Networks, has made her mark on cable television by taking big risks. But for every success, Ms. Dubuc says, she has learned from important failures.

headline: Test Yourself | The Rise of ‘Empire’
abstract: Here are several paragraphs from a March 17 article, “ ‘Empire,’ the Meteor That Never Fell to Earth.” Can you choose the best word for each blank?
lead_paragraph: Here are several paragraphs from a March 17 article, “ ‘Empire,’ the Meteor That Never Fell to Earth.”

headline: Nancy Dubuc of A&E: Mixing Doers, Thinkers and Feelers
abstract: Ms. Dubuc, the chief executive of A&E Networks, tries to get the best out of her teams by balancing them with three types of people. (With video.)
lead_paragraph: This interview with Nancy Dubuc, the chief executive of A&E Networks, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Whistle for N.C.A.A. Tournament Is Instrumental to the Game
abstract: The tournament has a familiar refrain created by a specific model of whistle, the Fox 40, and this year it is being used to automatically stop the game clock.
lead_paragraph: Susan Mueller, a flutist and the chairwoman of the Nevada-Las Vegas music department, examined the referee’s whistle in her hand. She closed her office door after warning those outside that she was about to make a loud noise. She put the whistle to her lips and blew.

headline: Lisa D’Amour Juggles ‘Airline Highway’ and ‘Milton,’ a Tale of Five Towns
abstract: While the playwright Lisa D’Amour prepares her “Airline Highway” for New York, she’s developing “Milton,” a show based on interviews with residents of American towns.
lead_paragraph: Lisa D’Amour could not resist the Wobble. It’s a dance anthem set to Southern rap, made Internet-famous by a sure-footed New Orleans detective during a Mardi Gras parade last year. When Ms. D’Amour set out to write a play about New Orleans, her beloved hometown, she knew the Wobble would have to figure in. So a few weeks ago, she had it blasting in a rehearsal room, her big cast two-stepping along.

headline: How Good Are You at Coming Up With Witty Comebacks?
abstract: What’s the best comeback you’ve ever said? When is a time you couldn’t think of the right thing to say?
lead_paragraph: Many of us have dreamed of delivering the perfect comeback at the right moment. Yet all too often we don’t think of anything good to say until minutes — or even hours — later.

headline: Chechen’s Ties to Putin Are Questioned Amid Nemtsov Murder Case
abstract: Critics warn that President Vladimir V. Putin’s bargain to gain stability in Chechnya has unleashed an unpredictable despot in the region’s leader, Ramzan A. Kadyrov.
lead_paragraph: GROZNY, Russia — Ramzan A. Kadyrov, the strongman leader of Chechnya, has been at the center of intrigue surrounding the murder of Boris Y. Nemtsov, a prominent critic of the Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin. So before a busy weekend that included a night out with the boys to watch cage fighting, Mr. Kadyrov wanted to clear something up. “I am utterly devoted to Vladimir Putin and ready until the end of my life to resist the enemies of Russia,” he wrote on Instagram.

headline: As China Prospers, the Military Recruiter’s Job Gets Harder
abstract: The country’s armed forces are increasingly in need of educated soldiers, sailors and airmen to operate its rapidly growing arsenal of advanced weapons.
lead_paragraph: Who could possibly bemoan rising prosperity, greater economic freedom, a declining birthrate and increasing university enrollment?

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get the Morning Briefing in your inbox first thing? Sign up.)

headline: Militants, ISIS Included, Claim Tunisia Museum Attack
abstract: The eagerness of the Islamic State and other jihadists to associate themselves with the attack, which killed at least 21 people, underscored the looseness of their proliferating networks.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The Islamic State and other extremists on Thursday sought to claim responsibility for the deadly attack that killed at least 21 people at the National Bardo Museum in Tunis. The authorities there arrested at least nine people suspected of being accomplices as major cruise lines indefinitely suspended stops in Tunisia, a sign of the looming toll on the crucial tourist industry.

headline: Philips to Spin Off Lighting Business in I.P.O.
abstract: The move comes after the Dutch electronics giant’s plans to separate itself into two companies: one focused on health care and technology, and another on lighting.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Philips, the Dutch electronics giant, said on Thursday that it planned to spin off its lighting business through an initial public offering next year.

headline: New York Today: The Man Who Loved Port Authority
abstract: Thursday: The hidden life of a bus terminal, the chill before the snow, and a deadly sheet of windblown plywood.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this winterish Thursday.

headline: Obama Orders Cuts in Federal Greenhouse Gas Emissions
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums']
abstract: The executive order represents the latest use of presidential power to address climate change as Congress resists passing legislation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama signed an executive order on Thursday to set new goals for reducing the greenhouse gas emissions of federal agencies, his latest use of his executive authority to address the root causes of climate change and press private companies and foreign governments to follow suit.

headline: Secret Service Chief Rebuts Car Crash Reports
abstract: The agency’s director, Joseph P. Clancy, told a Senate panel that a video showed that news accounts of an accident involving two agents were exaggerated.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The head of the Secret Service told lawmakers on Thursday that news accounts of two agents crashing a car into a White House barricade this month were overblown and exaggerated.

headline: Battle for Aden Airport Stokes Fears of Wider Conflict in Yemen
abstract: At least three people were killed as rival factions fought for control of the airport, which was forced to shut down, according to witnesses and security officials.
lead_paragraph: AL MUKALLA, Yemen — In a major escalation of Yemen’s civil conflict, rival factions in the southern city of Aden fought for control of the international airport and a security base, leaving at least three people dead, according to Yemeni officials.

headline: Auto Trader Group Is Valued at $3.5 Billion in London I.P.O.
abstract: Funds advised by the European private-equity firm Apax Partners bought out its joint venture partner last year and renamed the company Auto Trader.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Auto Trader Group, the British website for buying and selling used cars, said on Thursday that it had priced its initial public offering, valuing the company at 2.35 billion pounds, or about $3.5 billion.

headline: Ayaan Hirsi Ali: By the Book
abstract: The author of “Infidel,” “Nomad” and, most recently, “Heretic” read a lot of romance novels and Jackie Collins growing up: “We didn’t discriminate between good and bad. It is now difficult to imagine that we had so few books.”
lead_paragraph: The author of “Infidel,” “Nomad” and, most recently, “Heretic” read a lot of romance novels and Jackie Collins growing up: “We didn’t discriminate between good and bad. It is now difficult to imagine that we had so few books.”

headline: Indonesia Postpones Drug-Case Executions Amid Legal Challenges
abstract: Government officials said it could take months to resolve appeals by two Australians and several others sentenced to die for drug crimes.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA — An Indonesian court on Thursday postponed a hearing for two Australians facing execution for smuggling heroin, as government officials said it could take months to resolve legal appeals by the men and several other people sentenced to die for drug crimes.

headline: Throwback Thursday | The Space Race
abstract: On Oct. 4, 1957, the space age began as the Soviet Union launched Sputnik, the first man-made satellite, into orbit. For the next dozen years, the United States and the Soviet Union battled for dominance in spaceflight capability.

headline: Today in Politics: Hillary Clinton Looks to Secure Labor Support
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton, who is likely to become a declared presidential candidate in the coming days, will spend Monday morning reconnecting with the Democratic base.
lead_paragraph: Good Thursday morning from Washington, where royalty will be paying a rare visit to the White House. Congress remains logjammed in many respects, but a warm moment between Senator Harry Reid of Nevada and Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky showed the Senate’s softer side. Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin is facing a backlash from conservatives over the handling of one of his aides, while two other would-be presidential front-runners are moving ahead with their pre-campaign machinations.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Nardwuar the Human Serviette
abstract: “Spooned and groomed, dipped and whipped, scuttered and buttered, flaked and baked.”
lead_paragraph: My favorite journalist is a shrieking British Columbian who dresses like an exploded 1970s Soviet golf catalog. He was born John Ruskin, but changed his name to Nardwuar the Human Serviette. (“Serviette” is Canadian for napkin.) He hosts a weekly radio show on CiTR Vancouver, 101.9 FM, but his best work is done on camera, in chaotic interviews with musicians that he posts on YouTube.

headline: The Brain’s Empathy Gap
abstract: Can mapping neural pathways help us make friends with our enemies?
lead_paragraph: Nyiregyhaza (pronounced NEAR-re-cha-za) is a medium-size city tucked into the northeastern corner of Hungary, about 60 miles from the Ukrainian border. It has a world-class zoo, several museums and universities and a new Lego Factory. It also has two Roma settlements, or “Gypsy ghettos.” The larger of these settlements is Gusev, a crumbling 19th-century military barracks separated from the city proper by a railway station and a partly defunct industrial zone. Gusev is home to more than 1,000 Roma. Its chief amenities include a small grocery store and a playground equipped with a lone seesaw and a swingless swing set. There’s also a freshly painted elementary school, where approximately 60 students are currently enrolled. Almost all those students are Roma and almost all of them live in Gusev.

headline: Raising Teenagers: The Mother of All Problems
abstract: Children are characters in the family story we tell — until, one day, they start telling it themselves.
lead_paragraph: My daughter complains that she can’t sleep. Sometimes I pass her room at 11 o’clock, at midnight, and see the light still on under the door. Inevitably, if I go in, I find her propped up in bed with her laptop, the blue haze from the screen on her face.

headline: Ferguson’s Other Shooter
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Attacks on Police', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: How an independent video activist captured, and almost lost, the video of last week’s police shooting.
lead_paragraph: Last Wednesday night when two police officers were shot in front of the Police Headquarters in Ferguson, Mo., Heather De Mian was on the sidewalk across the street. The headquarters has been the site of regular demonstrations since Michael Brown, 18, was killed by a Ferguson police officer, Darren Wilson, last August. Protesters had gathered to celebrate the resignation of Ferguson’s police chief after a Department of Justice report detailed systematic bias against black residents by his officers, and De Mian was broadcasting live video of the rally to the Internet from her cellphone.

headline: The Scrutiny Phase: Hillary Clinton’s Negativity Challenge
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: If it seems like recent articles about Hillary Clinton have been mostly critical, that is because they have.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, no news really is good news — or at least it’s the best news you can expect. This is especially true when you are being publicly scrutinized by a keen group of observers. Such is the dilemma of Hillary Clinton, who — before her email woes began — was being criticized for not saying enough about what she’s been up to and then for saying too much. The criticism has only intensified.

headline: Identity Crisis
abstract: A Wisconsin case offers the Supreme Court an opportunity to block a systemic assault on the right to vote.

headline: In Berkeley’s Warehouses, Foodies Find a New Home
abstract: Long a D.I.Y. answer to San Francisco’s Design District, West Berkeley is now attracting innovative culinary entrepreneurs looking to spread their wings.
lead_paragraph: West Berkeley’s warehouse district has long been known for high-end lumberyards, tile shops and other stores serving creative homeowners, a kind of D.I.Y. answer to the upscale showrooms of San Francisco’s Design District. Recently, the area’s large, relatively affordable spaces have begun attracting a different creative crowd: innovative culinary entrepreneurs looking to spread their wings. Even some big boys are jumping in. Last June, the Bay Area-based specialty chocolatier TCHO moved its headquarters to a 49,000-square-foot facility here. This new wave of good food purveyors is making the neighborhood a draw for foodies as well as design lovers.

headline: How I Buy Weed
abstract: Most of us customers are in late middle age. Soon we’ll be in knee braces, panting up the stairs to our dealer’s apartment.
lead_paragraph: His place is in one of those New York City neighborhoods that’s run-down but not dangerous. There’s no intercom in the building, so to open the downstairs door, you have to have your own key. He doesn’t take phone calls on either landline or cell. He doesn’t use the Internet. He stays off the grid.

headline: Stop Playing the ‘Race Card’ Card
abstract: People who claim that certain accusations of racism are exaggerated seek to do what they condemn: shut down the debate with a scalding-hot charge.
lead_paragraph: So, Starbucks’ chief executive, Howard Schultz, wants us to serve the country coffee and a race dialogue.

headline: Testing a Few Good Women for Combat
keywords: ['Gender', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: This month, the Marine Corps will experiment with a test of women’s performance in combat arms. It’s historic, but not a first: Teresa Fazio and seven other women took part in a similar test in 2000.
lead_paragraph: This month, the Marine Corps began a historic experiment at its base in Twentynine Palms, Calif., to test women’s performance in combat arms. This Ground Combat Element Integrated Task Force uses high-tech tools to measure the physical performance of both men and women after a federal mandate to integrate women into all military occupational specialties — or request an exception — by January 2016. This differs from the past two decades, in which combat performance has only been measured in large-scale desert exercises. As a former Marine who was encouraged by the camaraderie of gender-integrated training, I look forward to this study’s promise to increase force readiness in a corps that is not quite 7 percent female.

headline: Morning Agenda: Jana Partners Sells Stake
abstract: Jana Partners sells a 20 percent stake to an investment firm. | Markets cheer the Fed’s statement on rates. | BlackRock has a new breed of E.T.F. | A top Wall Street lawyer blasts the regulatory environment.
lead_paragraph: JANA PARTNERS SELLS STAKE | Dyal Capital Partners, the private equity unit of Neuberger Berman Group, agreed on Wednesday to buy a 20 percent stake in the activist hedge fund Jana Partners, Alexandra Stevenson writes in DealBook. The stake will be passive, meaning Dyal will not have a say in Jana Partners’ day-to-day operations.

headline: N.C.A.A. Tournament 2015 Live Blog
abstract: Live coverage of the first round of the 2015 N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament.

headline: Paying for Workers' Training
abstract: If the 'skills gap' needs to be bridged, whose responsibility is it?

headline: China Issues New Guidelines to Reduce Logging
abstract: Under a government plan, China will reduce commercial harvesting of planted forests by 20 percent and eliminate logging on state-owned natural forests by 2020.
lead_paragraph: China will reduce logging on planted forests and eventually end logging on natural forests, under a plan published this week by the State Council, China’s cabinet.

headline: Karole Armitage’s New Dance Work Traces Steps for a Greener Path
abstract: The choreographer and Dr. Paul R. Ehrlich, a professor of biology, collaborated on this work about climate change, set to premiere March 25, at the American Museum of Natural History.
lead_paragraph: It takes a committed bunhead to spend eight hours hiking over a mountain with a 13,000-foot peak just to get to ballet class. It also requires one devoted to nature. Karole Armitage is both. As a child, she spent summers at Rocky Mountain Biological Laboratory in Gothic, Colo., a former ghost town from the silver mining period where her father, a biologist, did research.

headline: GoDaddy Sets Price Range for I.P.O.
abstract: The Internet services provider, which is known for its provocative television commercials, plans to sell shares between $17 and $19 a share.
lead_paragraph: GoDaddy, the Internet services provider known for its provocative television commercials, said on Thursday that it planned to sell shares in its initial public offering priced between $17 and $19 a share.

headline: Introducing the N.C.A.A. Bracket Comparison Table
abstract: Round-by-round predictions for every team in the N.C.A.A. bracket from three forecasters and three popular public brackets.
lead_paragraph: If you’re playing our risk-adjusted N.C.A.A. bracket game, you still have a precious few hours before the games begin to find the best bargains on upsets you think others have overlooked.

headline: Daily Report: Suddenly, Lots of Streaming Options for Cord Cutters
abstract: Sony introduced a web-based TV service, aimed at gamers, that is initially available to PlayStation 3 and PlayStation 4 owners in New York, Chicago and Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: Television fans who want to break free from a traditional TV subscription now have more options than ever to pay for what they want to watch, and how they want to watch it, Emily Steel reports.

headline: Neighbors Help Chase an Ex-Boyfriend
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: His ex-girlfriend had changed the locks, but the man would not stop knocking and pleading until the whole building was laughing at his histrionics.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Wanted: Manhattan Roommates and Space to Entertain
abstract: Gillian Morris wanted to share an apartment that had plenty of space for dinners, meet-ups and house concerts.
lead_paragraph: Gillian Morris disliked her living situation. She paid almost $1,000 a month “for a storage locker and a crash pad” in Brooklyn with two roommates, many roaches and a tedious commute to Manhattan. Almost as bad, the place was so small it was difficult to entertain guests there.

headline: 2 Associates of Ex-Security Chief to Face Trial Over Bribery in China
abstract: The news came a day after the country’s highest court suggested that the offenses of the disgraced security official might have extended to political plotting.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Chinese Communist Party’s push to extinguish the political network of a man who was once one of its most powerful officials entered a new phase on Thursday when the government announced that two of his associates would soon face trial on charges of bribery.

headline: What Not to Worry About in Teaching Young Children to Read
abstract: Starting reading instruction early doesn’t yield an advantage to comprehension.
lead_paragraph: The importance of reading to children from birth. Kindergarten readiness. The various approaches to teaching reading. All of those issues have been much in the news of late (and they’re never far from the minds of parents of young children), so my “Parent-Teacher Conference” email folder is full of questions about early literacy. Fortunately, Daniel T. Willingham’s new book, “Raising Kids Who Read,” was published this month, and it addresses every single one of them.

headline: Block by Block | Union Square
abstract: Union Square is centrally located, conveniently reached by public transportation and its park is bustling seven days a week.
lead_paragraph: Union Square is centrally located, conveniently reached by public transportation and its park is bustling seven days a week.

headline: Block by Block: Union Square (Video Series)
abstract: Union Square is the focus of the next video in our new monthly series, “Block by Block.”
lead_paragraph: Union Square is the focus of the next video in our new monthly series, “Block by Block.” Watch for future installments from neighborhoods around the city.

headline: Iran Nuclear Talks Lag, With Status of New Centrifuges Another Hurdle
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry said during a break in talks in Lausanne, Switzerland, that “we are pushing some tough issues, but we made progress.”
lead_paragraph: LAUSANNE, Switzerland — A dispute over what limits should be placed on the development of new types of centrifuges has emerged as a major obstacle as negotiators try to work out an initial accord on Iran’s nuclear program, Western officials said on Thursday.

headline: United Nations Investigators Accuse ISIS of Genocide Over Attacks on Yazidis
keywords: ['Yazidi (Religious Sect)', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Rights investigators reported that the pattern of attacks against the religious minority pointed to the intention of Islamic State militants “to destroy the Yazidi as a group.”
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — United Nations human rights investigators on Thursday leveled accusations of genocide and war crimes at the Islamic State, citing evidence that the extremist group’s fighters had sought to wipe out the Yazidi minority in Iraq.

headline: Raising Teenagers: Inevitably a Problem?
abstract: Teenagers need to become the centers of their own stories. For the writing parent, is that always a loss?
lead_paragraph: Rachel Cusk is a chronicler of rich, if sometimes bleak, inner lives — sometimes her own, but more often those of her fictional characters. Now, in “Raising Teenagers: The Mother of All Problems” for The New York Times Magazine, she describes her experience of watching her children evolve into people with rich inner lives of their own. These are not the inner lives of children, into which adults are sometimes welcomed, but the inner lives of teenagers, eternal protagonists in a continuing war against the old — a group that she has, in their eyes, joined.

headline: The Next Frontier: The Great Indoors
abstract: As cities and suburbs have spread across continents, the amount of indoor shelter has exploded — and given ecologists a new field of study: the indoor biome.
lead_paragraph: In 1962, the ecologist Robert Whitaker set out to categorize the different realms of life on Earth. Some were deserts, others tundra, still others tropical forests. He coined a word for these inhabited environments, one that scientists have used ever since: biomes.

headline: David Brandon Geeting Finds Irreverence in the Everyday
abstract: The photographer’s new monograph, “Infinite Power,” collects his joyful, surreal contemporary depictions of the mundane.
lead_paragraph: The photographer’s new monograph, “Infinite Power,” collects his joyful, surreal contemporary depictions of the mundane.

headline: In Netanyahu’s Next Knesset, a More Compatible Coalition
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his Likud party achieved a surprisingly strong victory in Tuesday’s election. Now, he is likely to build a right-wing coalition of 67 of the 120 members of the Knesset, Israel’s Parliament.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his Likud party achieved a surprisingly strong victory in Tuesday’s election. Now, he is likely to build a right-wing coalition of 67 of the 120 members of the Knesset, Israel’s Parliament.

headline: ‘Lincoln and the Jews’ Explores Bonds With a Nation’s Growing Minority
abstract: This exhibition at the New-York Historical Society presents a broader story of Abraham Lincoln’s political career and the Civil War through his interactions with a religious minority beginning to claim an equal place in American life.
lead_paragraph: ON Sept. 20, 1862, Abraham Lincoln had a lot on his mind. The Civil War was raging, and just days later he would issue the preliminary draft of the Emancipation Proclamation.

headline: Rubio Ally to Lead ‘Super PAC’ Backing His Candidacy
abstract: As Senator Marco Rubio and his advisers ramp up an all-but-certain presidential run, they will have a close ally managing the “super PAC” supporting his candidacy.
lead_paragraph: As Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida, and his advisers prepare for an all-but-certain presidential run, they will have a close ally managing the “super PAC” supporting his candidacy.

headline: Well Book Club: ‘Better Than Before’
abstract: The author Gretchen Rubin explains that our habits — good and bad — provide the architecture to our lives.
lead_paragraph: Every day of your life is shaped by your habits. Are you a morning or evening person? Messy or tidy? Do you eat breakfast or skip it? Drive or commute? Pack a lunch or dine out? Exercise or watch television?

headline: Day 2 of Live March Madness Coverage Begins
abstract: We’re back for another full day of N.C.A.A. men’s tournament games. The New York Times has reporters fanned out across the country for comprehensive coverage.
lead_paragraph: We’re back for another full day of N.C.A.A. men’s tournament games. The New York Times has reporters fanned out across the country for comprehensive coverage.

headline: 1940: Chamberlain Says No Peace
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Chamberlain insists on “durable and moral” peace in 1940.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain dropped a large lump of salt today [March 19] on all palaver about a ‘‘peace offensive,’’ which is emanating from the Continent in the wake of yesterday’s Alpine rendezvous of Benito Mussolini and Adolf Hitler.

headline: Haldi
abstract: The cooking of Kolkata in Curry Hill
lead_paragraph: The cooking of Kolkata in Curry Hill

headline: In Curry Hill, a New Kid on the Block
abstract: Haldi, an Indian restaurant that opened in September, sets a notably elegant tone for Curry Hill.
lead_paragraph: On the menu it is called an egg roll, but what arrives looks more like an elongated turnover, with squared-off ends as sharp as hospital corners. The crepelike wrap is crisp but doesn’t crackle, so that all the attention goes to the interior: lamb minced fine but still juicy and shot through with just enough chile to warm, not scar you.

headline: New Chairman for El Museo del Barrio
abstract: Michael J. Garcia, a former United States attorney, will take over from Tony Bechara in June.
lead_paragraph: El Museo del Barrio, the oldest museum in the United States devoted to Latino art, is appointing a new board chairman. It said Michael J. Garcia, a former United States attorney who has served on the board since 2010, will succeed Tony Bechara, who is stepping down after leading the museum’s board for 15 years.

headline: Japan and China Inch Toward Mending Ties
abstract: The two nations, holding their first meeting on security issues in four years, discussed the creation of a hotline to ease tensions in the East China Sea.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — In a small step toward a possible thaw in relations, officials from Japan and China on Thursday held their first meeting on security issues in four years, discussing the creation of a hotline to ease tensions in the East China Sea.

headline: Kasich Looks to Republican Primaries, ‘Ohio Story’ in Hand
abstract: As Gov. John R. Kasich visits New Hampshire, Manhattan and Detroit, skeptics and admirers say, he must find a way to distinguish himself from an already overcrowded Republican pack.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Gov. John R. Kasich was sipping coffee in the sun-drenched garden room of his official residence, boasting about his “Ohio story” of economic recovery, when he was told that some Republicans thought a fellow Midwestern governor, Scott Walker of Wisconsin, was more conservative. He bolted upright.

headline: The Politics of Tweets, Candor and Corn in Iowa
abstract: Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker’s efforts to appeal to Iowa voters were compromised when an advisor’s anti-Iowa tweets went viral.
lead_paragraph: Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker’s intense focus on the Iowa caucus as his launching pad for the White House has been severely jolted by mocking comments about the state’s ballyhooed political process and iconic corn crop — observations rather proudly made by Liz Mair, a respected campaign advisor who was hired this week but then driven to resign a day later.

headline: Jeb Bush Meets Ludacris
abstract: Jeb Bush is in Georgia today, speaking to state lawmakers about education. But before delivering his remarks, Mr. Bush met the rapper Ludacris, who was being honored by the legislature for his work with the Ludacris foundation.
lead_paragraph: Jeb Bush was in Georgia on Thursday, speaking to state lawmakers about education. But before delivering his remarks, Mr. Bush met the rapper Ludacris, who was being honored by the Legislature for his work with the Ludacris Foundation.

headline: A British Proposal to Help Control Bankruptcy Costs
abstract: Bankruptcy specialists in Britain are going to have to start estimating their fees upfront, an approach that might work in Chapter 11 cases.
lead_paragraph: Beginning next October, corporate reorganization professionals in Britain are going to have do something quite amazing: At the start of a case, they are going to have to estimate what their total fees will be. And if they exceed that amount, they will have to go back to the creditors and obtain further approval.

headline: A Kentucky Team and Its Star Seek Their Own Fame
abstract: Thomas More College of Crestview Hills, Ky., is 31-0 entering the Division III women’s Final Four and is led by Sydney Moss, daughter of the former N.F.L. receiver Randy Moss.
lead_paragraph: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich. — The top-ranked, undefeated team from Kentucky arrived at the Final Four, wearing familiar blue and white, but the charter was a bus, not a plane. The trip took nine hours with a stop at Arby’s and a gym for practice. The team hotel is not five-star plush but Holiday Inn utility.

headline: True West
abstract: The purist Mark Haddawy would no sooner tweak a Haston gown than alter a great ’70s house. Even one he lives in.
lead_paragraph: The purist Mark Haddawy would no sooner tweak a Haston gown than alter a great ’70s house. Even one he lives in.

headline: Boehner Says Aaron Schock’s Resignation ‘Stunned’ Him
abstract: Speaker John A. Boehner tends to have a good feel for his caucus, but he acknowledged on Thursday that he was surprised by the abrupt resignation of Representative Aaron Schock, the Republican from Illinois who resigned this week amid questions over his adherence to spending rules
lead_paragraph: Speaker John A. Boehner tends to have a good feel for his caucus, but he acknowledged on Thursday that he was surprised by the abrupt resignation this week of Representative Aaron Schock of Illinois, who had faced questions over his adherence to spending rules.

headline: $10 Million Settlement in Target Data Breach Gets Preliminary Approval
abstract: The settlement of a class-action suit in federal court would provide $10 million to compensate victims of a 2013 online data theft that affected as many as 110 million people.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Thursday gave preliminary approval to a $10 million settlement of a lawsuit brought by customers of Target, which experienced an online attack involving confidential customer data during the holiday season in 2013.

headline: Small Dreams and Long Odds on N.C.A.A. Tournament’s First Day
abstract: At a time when super elite conferences reign supreme in college sports, increasing numbers of athletic programs are being forced to contemplate revised metrics of success.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after Hampton University defeated Manhattan on Tuesday night in the first game of the N.C.A.A. tournament, Hampton’s president, Bill Harvey, was on the phone, more proud than excited.

headline: Survivor Recounts Tunisian Museum Attack
abstract: An Italian survivor of a deadly attack on Wednesday recounted the ordeal from her hospital bed in Tunis.
lead_paragraph: An Italian survivor of a deadly attack on Wednesday recounted the ordeal from her hospital bed in Tunis.

headline: Advice on Being Left Out of Family Photos
abstract: Plus: Etiquette on whether to tell your manager about his neck hair, ordering when it comes to sharing restaurant meals and more.
lead_paragraph: When I met my boyfriend, his aunt instituted a rule that girlfriends and boyfriends not be included in family portraits until the couples are engaged. Eighteen years later, we are still together, but have decided not to marry. His aunt apologized to me ages ago. But my boyfriend’s brother still insists that I not be included in family photos. My boyfriend stood up to him, and this brother is no longer welcome in our home. But when we attend family functions, he acts friendly to me. How should I handle this?

headline: Israel’s Netanyahu Reopens Door to Palestinian State, but White House Is Unimpressed
abstract: In his first interview since his re-election victory, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said he had not intended to reverse his endorsement in a 2009 speech at Bar-Ilan University of a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Thursday tried to backtrack from his pre-election declaration that no Palestinian state would be established on his watch, but his new assertions appeared to do nothing to assuage an infuriated Obama administration.

headline: Classical Playlist: Tchaikovsky, Handel, John Adams and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: TCHAIKOVSKY: ‘Iolanta’Anna Netrebko, Sergey Skorokhodov, Alexey Markov and other singers; Slovenian Philharmonic Orchestra, Emmanuel Villaume, conductor(Deutsche Grammophon 479 3969; two CDs)Just in time for the Metropolitan Opera’s new production of Tchaikovsky’s final opera, “Iolanta,” Deutsche Grammophon has released a winning live 2012 recording from the Philharmonie Essen in Germany featuring Anna Netrebko, the star of the Met’s production, in the title role. This tender, rich one-act fairy-tale opera tells of a young princess who has been raised by her overprotective father so that she does not realize she is blind, though something about her constricted world seems off to her. Ms. Netrebko brings an engrossing combination of aching vulnerability and vocal charisma to Iolanta. The whole cast is excellent. Best of all may be the glowing, warm playing that the conductor Emmanuel Villaume draws from the Slovenian Philharmonic Orchestra. (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: On Location | London
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: A newly renovated London apartment is reminiscent of the Spring Street loft the owner had lived in during the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: A newly renovated London apartment is reminiscent of the Spring Street loft the owner had lived in during the 1980s.

headline: Powerful Afghan Police Chief Killed in Kabul
abstract: Matiullah Khan, one of the wealthiest and most powerful men in southern Afghanistan, was killed on Wednesday in a targeted suicide bombing.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Matiullah Khan, whose rise from local militia commander to powerful regional police chief left him one of the wealthiest and most powerful men in southern Afghanistan, was killed on Wednesday in a targeted suicide bombing in Kabul, officials said on Thursday.

headline: Hands-On Law School
abstract: The University of New Hampshire School of Law offers second- and third-year students the opportunity to serve a legal residency, a kind of apprenticeship that lets them participate in legal activities under supervision. Those who pass a review of their work can skip the bar exam.
lead_paragraph: The University of New Hampshire School of Law offers second- and third-year students the opportunity to serve a legal residency, a kind of apprenticeship that lets them participate in legal activities under supervision. Those who pass a review of their work can skip the bar exam.

headline: Bar Exam, the Standard to Become a Lawyer, Comes Under Fire
abstract: Many law school deans have begun to openly question the mechanics of the test, and some states are even exploring other options.
lead_paragraph: For decades, law school graduates have endured a stressful rite of passage, spending the first 10 weeks after classes end taking cram courses in the arcane details of the law before sitting down for the grueling, days-long bar exam. Those who do not pass cannot practice law, at least in nearly all the states and the District of Columbia that consider the exam the professional standard.

headline: SXSW 2015: Films That Were the Talk of the Festival
keywords: ['Movies', 'Music', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: An assessment of some of the talked-about movies at South by Southwest.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — From intimate indies to blockbuster debuts, this year’s South by Southwest film festival was again a place for discoveries.

headline: At Corison Winery, the Focus on Napa Cabernet Never Blurs
abstract: Through a quarter-century of turning out consistent, elegant cabernets, Cathy Corison has resisted joining other Napa producers whose wines are becoming more alcoholic and sweeter.
lead_paragraph: Napa Valley is not known for its reserve, subtlety and understatement. Flamboyance, yes, as well as grandiosity, weight, excess and the wines that epitomize these traits. Yet before Napa wineries began to take architectural cues from Las Vegas, the Valley was largely a quiet agricultural center that let its wines speak for themselves.

headline: ‘Empire’ Finale Draws Season-High Viewership
abstract: The two-hour episode brought in 16.5 million viewers and generated 2.4 million Twitter posts, a badly needed bump for Fox.
lead_paragraph: After last week’s episode of “Empire,” a Fox teaser warned viewers: Don’t miss the two-hour finale, or you’ll almost certainly risk being spoiled.

headline: Japanese Police Arrest Man Accused of Threatening to Bomb U.S. Embassy and Base
keywords: ['Threats and Threatening Messages', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Bombs and Explosives']
abstract: The police said the man, Mitsuyoshi Kamiya, who was arrested on Okinawa, confessed to making bomb threats in three phone calls this month.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The Japanese police said on Thursday that they had arrested a 52-year-old man on suspicion of threatening to bomb the United States Embassy in Tokyo and an American military base on Okinawa.

headline: Review: In ‘Hierba Mala Nunca Muere,’ Castro Rails Against Change
abstract: Juan Claudio Lechín’s farce at Reportorio Español portrays the Cuban leader on his deathbed, tended by two assassins masquerading as nurses.
lead_paragraph: The old bird is understandably confused. When he was a boy, Havana was sometimes called the Paris of the Caribbean. He thought he had put an end to that capitalist decadence, but now that he’s in his late 80s, some guy is suddenly trying to open Cuba back up again. And the guy is black.

abstract: The team’s top scorer, rebounder and playmaker is a 7-footer who developed himself from a gawky teenager to a national player of the year candidate.
lead_paragraph: The team’s top scorer, rebounder and playmaker is a 7-footer who developed himself from a gawky teenager to a national player of the year candidate.

keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']

lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — If the opening comments from one of the senior deal makers at the Tulane Corporate Law Institute here are to be believed, the good times for mergers and acquisitions will continue to roll.

headline: Review: In ‘Fatal Attraction,’ Piotr Uklanski’s Unblinking Gaze
abstract: Mr. Uklanski’s efforts — both artistic and curatorial — can be seen in the decorous precincts of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: As bad-boy artists go, Piotr Uklanski has always been fairly elusive. During his 20-year career he has tended to do something startling — if not shocking — and then lie low, reappearing after a decent interval. And when he does, he is often somewhere else entirely, doing something unlike anything he’s done before.

headline: Scientists Solve a Puzzle: Cosmic Dust Comes From Supernovae
abstract: Astronomers found evidence that the dust, building material for planets and stars, survived a supernova’s hot aftermath.
lead_paragraph: Cosmic dust containing elements like iron, carbon or oxygen plays an important role in the formation of planets and stars. But early galaxies consisted only of gas, and the dust appeared later. Where the dust came from has long been a mystery.

headline: The First Signs of Spring
abstract: Plants in bloom and Mister Softee trucks straining at the leash mean spring is around the corner.
lead_paragraph: Plants in bloom and Mister Softee trucks straining at the leash mean spring is around the corner.

headline: Loosening a Founder’s Iron Grip
abstract: A writer working for a company started by someone who is nearing 80 asks how to tell his boss that it may be time to let go of some responsibilities.
lead_paragraph: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

headline: A Jewelry Journey Through Rome
abstract: Adventures in Art is offering a trip to Rome to explore the city’s jewelry traditions.
lead_paragraph: Adventures in Art, a New York City company specializing in art and jewelry excursions, has a new getaway to Rome highlighting the city’s jewelry traditions: “Rome: From Etruscan Gold to Bulgari Gems,” a three-night trip from June 4 to  7.

headline: Russell Simmons Plans Musical on Early Days of Hip-Hop
abstract: A founder of Def Jam Records said he expects songs from the label to be featured in the show.
lead_paragraph: The pioneering rap impresario Russell Simmons is aiming to bring a hip-hop revue to Broadway late next year. The musical, currently titled “The Scenario,” will feature renditions of classics from the 1980s and ’90s.

lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — For several years, much of the debate at the big deal maker conference here has been whether shareholder activism is a blight on the corporate landscape.

headline: FIFA Confirms Winter World Cup for 2022
abstract: FIFA’s executive committee set the date for the 2022 final in Qatar as Dec. 18, pushing the start of the tournament to mid-November.
lead_paragraph: FIFA confirmed that the 2022 World Cup in Qatar would be played in the winter, announcing Thursday that its governing executive committee had set the date of that year’s final for Dec. 18.

headline: Wisconsin’s Frank Kaminsky Takes Pride in Growing Up
abstract: The team’s top scorer, rebounder and playmaker is a 7-footer who developed himself from a gawky teenager to a national player of the year candidate.
lead_paragraph: LISLE, Ill. — A faded school crest overlooks the A-frame Catholic school gymnasium where exposed metallic heating ducts and off-white bricks run the length of the basketball floor below.

headline: Syracuse’s Jim Boeheim Says Penalties Are ‘Unduly Harsh’
abstract: In his first news conference since the N.C.A.A. penalized his program, a defiant Mr. Boeheim said on Thursday that he planned to appeal some of the penalties on Friday.
lead_paragraph: In his first news conference since the N.C.A.A. penalized his program on March 6, Jim Boeheim, the men’s basketball coach at Syracuse, took responsibility for some of the transgressions revealed in a 94-page N.C.A.A. report, but he also lashed out at the penalties, which he called “unduly harsh.”

headline: Will Republicans Still Support a Two-State Solution Even if Netanyahu Doesn’t?
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Palestinians', 'Elections', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'International Relations', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: We asked the party’s 2016 presidential hopefuls where they stand after this week’s Israeli elections.
lead_paragraph: For the last decade and a half, Democratic and Republican politicians have, at least officially, agreed on the broad contours of what an end to the decades-long, on-again-off-again peace process in Israel and the Palestinian territories should look like. The two-state solution, as it’s called, was formally endorsed by George W. Bush early in his presidency and was formally agreed to by Israeli, Palestinian and American officials in 2007. Even the Republican Party platform declares, “We envision two democratic states — Israel with Jerusalem as its capital and Palestine — living in peace and security.”

headline: Restoration Politics
abstract: The Continental chic of Camelot in the ’60s, the gilded splendor of the Reagan-era ’80s — but what about a new take on the unique charms of Gerald and Betty Ford’s ’70s Southern California dreaming?
lead_paragraph: The Continental chic of Camelot in the ’60s, the gilded splendor of the Reagan-era ’80s — but what about a new take on the unique charms of Gerald and Betty Ford’s ’70s Southern California dreaming?

headline: Dante de Blasio, Mayor’s Fast-Talking Son, Is a State Debate Champion
abstract: For the past year and a half, Dante de Blasio has stayed largely out of public view, focusing on school, applying to college and competing in debate tournaments.
lead_paragraph: In a classroom in Lower Manhattan, two pairs of debaters fired off a rapid rat-tat-tat-tat-tat of ideas, battling it out before a panel of judges for the mantle of state champion in varsity policy debate.

headline: Ex-Trader Sentenced to 19 Months for Insider Trading in London
abstract: Julian Rifat was arrested in March 2010. He was accused of sharing inside information about Volkswagen, Barclays and other companies.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Julian Rifat, a former trader arrested nearly five years ago in what was then described as the largest crackdown on insider trading here, was sentenced to more than a year in prison on Thursday after he pleaded guilty in November to insider trading.

lead_paragraph: The Singapore-based watch magazine, which has the largest print circulation in the world, says it has to keep advancing on the digital front, too.

keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Milan Fashion Week', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Paris Fashion Week']
abstract: To mark the conclusion of the Women’s fall 2015 shows, T catalogs the bows of some fashion visionaries.
lead_paragraph: Designers project their personalities not only through their collections but also in their appearances at the end of their runway shows. To mark the conclusion of New York, Milan and Paris Fashion Weeks, we catalog the bows — some proud, some playful, some humble, some all of the above — of 31 fashion visionaries.

headline: Verbatim: Just Wanna Have Fun
abstract: Hillary Clinton on the “fun deficit.”
lead_paragraph: — Hillary Rodham Clinton, speaking in Atlantic City at an event for camp professionals.

lead_paragraph: Nick Bilton writes a tech-related column called Disruptions, but the name might have been changed to Eruptions this week, given the way readers and others reacted.

headline: First Draft Focus: The Prince Meets the President
abstract: President Obama met with Prince Charles.
lead_paragraph: President Obama offered Prince Charles a warm greeting at the White House, telling his guest how beloved he and his family are in the United States.

headline: Notre Dame Breaks Through, Holding Off Northeastern
abstract: After losing in the round of 64 in their last two N.C.A.A. tournament trips, the Fighting Irish defeated a pesky Northeastern team.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — There is a perception about the Notre Dame men’s basketball program, and it is steeped in fact. It is that, come March, come the N.C.A.A. tournament, the Fighting Irish cannot figure out how to win.

headline: French Proposal on Models’ Weights Clashes With Labor Laws, Opponents Say
abstract: A parliamentary committee rejected two provisions of an anorexia prevention measure but left open the possibility that an amended version could be approved later.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Lawmakers on the French Parliament’s health committee said Thursday that they had rejected two provisions of an anorexia prevention measure but left open the possibility that an amended version could win approval when the provisions are debated anew by the full National Assembly in early April.

headline: Scientists Seek Ban on Method of Editing the Human Genome
keywords: ['Genetics and Heredity', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Genetic Engineering', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: A group of biologists, including the scientist who developed the technique, has called for a worldwide moratorium on using the method to change human DNA.
lead_paragraph: A group of leading biologists on Thursday called for a worldwide moratorium on use of a new genome-editing technique that would alter human DNA in a way that can be inherited.

headline: Lindsey Vonn Wins World Cup Super-G Title to Tie Career Record
abstract: Vonn now has 19 World Cup crystal globes, the trophy awarded to skiers who win the season championship in any race discipline or the overall title.
lead_paragraph: Lindsey Vonn bought a house last year in her longtime home, Vail, Colo. After moving in, she asked a contractor to build a trophy case above the fireplace for her collection of World Cup crystal globes, the hefty decorative awards given to the winners of season-long ski racing championships.

headline: Body of David Bird, Missing Wall Street Journal Reporter, Is Found
abstract: Mr. Bird’s body was pulled from the Passaic River in New Jersey, more than a year after he disappeared while out walking near his home.
lead_paragraph: A body pulled from the Passaic River in New Jersey this week was identified on Thursday as that of a reporter for The Wall Street Journal who disappeared in January 2014 while out walking near his home, officials said.

headline: No. 14-Seeded U.A.B. Surges to Stun Iowa State
abstract: William Lee, a freshman from Plantersville, Ala., scored 14 points and had 12 rebounds to lead the Blazers past the third-seeded Cyclones.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Jerod Haase’s last game as a college player was in Birmingham, Ala., in 1997 in the N.C.A.A. tournament’s round of 16. His Kansas team was 34-1, with its only loss having come in double overtime against Missouri, but the Jayhawks were stunned by a nine-loss Arizona team in the tournament, 85-82. Haase knows all about the sting of defeat and the sudden, unexpected packing of bags in March.

lead_paragraph: The idea of big American banks breaking up will finally get input from the public.

headline: Touch Time, for the Blind and Everyone Else
abstract: A crowdfunded start-up, Eone Time, created a watch that indicates hours and minutes with two rotating ball bearings.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Serving in Afghanistan, Lt. Bradley Snyder, working in a United States Navy bomb-disposal squad, stepped on an improvised explosive device while trying to aid two victims of another blast. The explosion robbed him of his sight.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz: Marriage, Memory and Sex
abstract: Marriage and exercise, sexual desire and mosquito-borne illnesses: see how well you know this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: Take the Quiz

headline: Yankees’ Pinstripes May Be Slimming, but a Nutritionist Helps
abstract: The Yankees, forever looking for a competitive edge, hired a new nutritionist over the winter and charged her with recommending healthy foods and persuading players to eat them.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — The most famous player in Yankees history had the most infamous diet. Babe Ruth was said to subsist, at least in part, on hot dogs and beer, the fuel that added to his legendary persona as a charismatic, fun-loving superstar.

abstract: The exceedingly private philanthropist Maja Hoffmann shares fragments of her exquisite personal collection of art and design.
lead_paragraph: The exceedingly private philanthropist Maja Hoffmann shares fragments of her exquisite personal collection of art and design.

headline: ‘Hamilton’ Off to Hot Start at Broadway Box Office
abstract: The show has sold $6.5 million worth of tickets in its first 11 days of Broadway availability, and has group orders for another $4 million worth of seats, its lead producer said.
lead_paragraph: “Hamilton,” the buzzy musical biography of an American founding father, is off to a strong start at the Broadway box office.

headline: SXSW Music 2015: Ancient Songs With a Rocking Beat
keywords: ['Music', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: Mai Dhai, a singer from rural Pakistan, performed songs she learned from her mother and drummed as she sang.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — What may have been the oldest music at SXSW rocked as hard (if not as loudly) as anything newer. It had deep, unstoppable beats, instantly grasped melodies and vocals with a fervent bite. It was a Wednesday night set by Mai Dhai, a singer from rural Pakistan performing ancient songs she learned from her mother. She drummed as she sang, along with two more drummers and a harmonium player whose counter-melodies darted constantly around her voice. Ms. Dhai is a member of the Manganiyar tribe from the Tharparkar desert, with an Islamic culture that has a long tradition of female musicians performing at shrines and festivities.

headline: Elon Musk Says Self-Driving Tesla Cars Will Be in the U.S. by Summer
keywords: ['Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles']
abstract: The automaker’s chief executive says a software update will allow the Model S to navigate highways without the driver’s touching the wheel or pedals. But is it legal?
lead_paragraph: For many drivers who commute long distances, the prospect of owning a self-driving car — where a driver takes his hands off the wheel and feet off the gas — has been an elusive dream.

lead_paragraph: In a 12-page decision, Justice William E. Garnett of State Supreme Court decided against releasing evidence, testimony and instructions presented to the grand jury in the Eric Garner case.

headline: In Eric Garner Case, Judge Rules Against Releasing Grand Jury Evidence
abstract: Justice William E. Garnett of State Supreme Court on Staten Island said the parties seeking disclosure of the evidence had failed to establish a “compelling” need.
lead_paragraph: A judge ruled on Thursday against releasing the evidence presented to the grand jury that decided not to indict a New York police officer in the chokehold death of Eric Garner.

headline: Video Feature: Inside the F 015, Mercedes’s Self-Driving Car
abstract: Mercedes-Benz’s concept car doesn’t showcase the technology of autonomous vehicles as much as it does the (yes, luxurious) experience of riding in one.
lead_paragraph: ALAMEDA, Calif. — AUTONOMOUS car technology is now so far along that some auto executives have said they expect a completely self-driving car — one that requires no human intervention — to appear in public use within five years.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Kumiko’
abstract: David Zellner and Nathan Zellner discuss their film “Kumiko, the Treasure Hunter,” starring Rinko Kikuchi.
lead_paragraph: David Zellner and Nathan Zellner discuss their film “Kumiko, the Treasure Hunter,” starring Rinko Kikuchi.

headline: Big in Japan, Tokyobike Gets a Permanent New York Home
abstract: The cult bicycle brand, previously unavailable to buy in the States, moves into a SoHo space designed by Masonhurst’s Kyle Garner.
lead_paragraph: He just wanted to buy a bike. That’s the short answer to the question of how Dean Di Simone, the founder of the New York digital agency Tender Creative, and his wife, the model-slash-marketer Juliana Rudell Di Simone, became the Stateside keepers of Tokyobike, which celebrates the opening of its first permanent shop at the corner of Bowery and Prince tomorrow. Di Simone first became acquainted with the brand on a trip to Tokyo in 2003. Six years later, he tried to buy one of the lightweight, custom-fit bikes at an outpost in London’s Shoreditch neighborhood, but was promptly turned away. “At the time, it was frustrating,” says Di Simone; company policy held that no customer should assemble his own two-wheeler. (Which, in turn, means no overseas shipments.)

headline: Monica Lewinsky Is Back, but This Time It’s on Her Terms
keywords: ['TED Conference', 'Women and Girls', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Bullies', 'Sexual Harassment']
abstract: Once vilified as a “predatory” White House intern, Ms. Lewinsky has re-emerged, taking on the fight against cyberbullying.
lead_paragraph: Monica Lewinsky was sitting in a Manhattan auditorium last month, watching teenage girls perform a play called “Slut.” Ms. Lewinsky was in blue jeans and a blazer, her hair pulled out of her face with a small clip. She was wiping away tears.

headline: Google and Intel to Team Up with TAG Heuer on a Luxury Smartwatch
keywords: ['Android (Operating System)', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'Watches and Clocks', 'Wearable Computing']
abstract: A new generation of luxury smartwatches, essentially tiny computers meant to be fashion statements, is beginning to take shape.
lead_paragraph: Generation after generation, computers have become smaller, faster and cheaper. If technology companies have their way, they will soon be smaller and astronomically expensive.

headline: Walker Reassures S. Carolinians That Raising Money Won’t Be a Problem
abstract: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin traveled to South Carolina on Thursday for a series of fund-raisers and to recruit potential staff members in the state.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C. – Whenever he meets a new room of Republican voters, Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin usually starts off by thanking them for their prayers. He did so on Thursday afternoon, during his first swing through South Carolina as a potential presidential candidate – but he also thanked them for their money, and bragged a bit in case anyone doubted his ability to raise funds nationally for a White House bid.

headline: FIFA Awards 2019 Women’s World Cup to France
abstract: The decision will give France, a rising power in the women’s game, the chance to win the title on home soil.
lead_paragraph: FIFA awarded the 2019 Women’s World Cup to France on Thursday, rewarding a rising power in women’s soccer with the chance to win the title on home soil.

headline: Spring Is So Close You Can Almost Taste It
abstract: After a winter that has made New Yorkers grateful for a windchill temperature above 15, the hunger for spring has never been so acute and so palpable.
lead_paragraph: IT’S official. April is no longer the cruelest month. February moves into the top spot. Any nay votes? I thought not. And March has been no bargain, either, up to and including the first day of spring.

headline: The Zellner Brothers Narrate a Scene From ‘Kumiko, the Treasure Hunter’
abstract: Nathan Zellner and David Zellner discuss a sequence from the film.
lead_paragraph: In this video, Nathan Zellner and David Zellner discuss a sequence from their drama “Kumiko, the Treasure Hunter,” starring Rinko Kikuchi as a Japanese woman who is obsessed with the movie “Fargo” and believes the money buried in the film actually exists. She sets out on a quest to the Midwest on a search for it. In this scene, before her departure, she says goodby to her beloved friend, a pet bunny Bunzo.

headline: Shows at Q.E.D. in Queens, and a New York Public Library Show on Photography
abstract: Q.E.D., home to classes and shows in Astoria, Queens, is a playground for adults and a showcase for emerging performers in storytelling, music and comedy.
lead_paragraph: After-school activities at the Miser’s junior high were a mixed bag. There was that fly-tying class that has never come in handy, for example, but at least it was a chance to try something new.

abstract: In this Text to Text we feature an excerpt from “Speak,” a 1999 National Book Award finalist that is regularly taught, and regularly challenged, in schools across the country. We’ve paired it with a 2013 Op-Ed essay by a woman who was raped by a classmate when she was 16.
lead_paragraph: In this Text to Text we feature an excerpt from “Speak,” a 1999 National Book Award finalist that is regularly taught, and regularly challenged, in schools across the country.

headline: Huge Day of N.C.A.A. Upsets, Not to Be Taken Sitting Down
abstract: R. J. Hunter’s 3-point shot with 2.6 seconds remaining sent his father, Georgia State’s coach, tumbling from his chair as the No. 14-seeded Panthers eliminated No. 3-seeded Baylor on a wild first day.
lead_paragraph: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — The N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament, that annual rite that delivers agony in the form of a bracket, has produced many darlings over the years. The one who emerged from a thrilling opening day Thursday might be the unlikeliest yet.

headline: Alfredo Jaar: ‘Shadows’
abstract: This is the second project in a trilogy by Mr. Jaar exploring the power and politics of famous images.
lead_paragraph: This is the second project in a trilogy by Alfredo Jaar exploring the power and politics of famous images. The first installation focused on a 1993 Pulitzer Prize-wining photograph of a starving child in Sudan; here Mr. Jaar has chosen the Dutch photographer Koen Wessing’s “Estelí, Nicaragua, September 1978” (1978), which shows two women at the moment they learn their father has been murdered.

headline: Junior House-Hunter
abstract: 15-year-old Max Srulowitz helps hunt for an East Hamptons house.
lead_paragraph: 15-year-old Max Srulowitz helps hunt for an East Hamptons house.

headline: The Importance of Sitting With Patients
abstract: The most draining aspect of medical training, it turns out, is not long hours, brash colleagues or steep learning curves — it’s the feeling that you’re often unable to be there for your patients in the way you want.
lead_paragraph: I had never seen someone so yellow.

headline: Betty Parsons: ‘A Life in Art’
abstract: Gouaches and painted-driftwood sculptures show this artist’s more playful, less angsty sensibility.
lead_paragraph: This show has a big title for being fairly small: a total of 19 gouaches and painted-driftwood sculptures by Betty Parsons (1900-1982), the revered New York art dealer, advocate of Abstract Expressionism and an artist in her own right. Five of the pieces were seen in a larger show in 2010 at the recently closed Spanierman Gallery. But that show was the first sizable one in New York devoted to Ms. Parsons’s work since the 1980s, and who knows when another will come along.

headline: Arizona Shoots Past Texas Southern
abstract: The Wildcats turned the game into a bench-emptying exhibition of their depth.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — The weight of national championship aspirations did not slow second-seeded Arizona on Thursday, as the Wildcats breezed to a 93-72 victory over No. 15 Texas Southern.

headline: Bank of New York Mellon Will Settle Currency Trade Case for $714 Million
keywords: ['Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Currency']
abstract: The bank had assured clients they would get currency trades at the best possible price. The opposite was, in fact, true.
lead_paragraph: The Bank of New York Mellon will pay $714 million to settle accusations that it cheated government pension funds and other investors for more than a decade, federal and state authorities announced on Thursday. It is part of a deal requiring the bank to dismiss some employees and make fuller public disclosures of its foreign exchange operation.

headline: Vera Iliatova: ‘For Now, at Once’
abstract: Ms. Iliatova’s paintings feature dreamy images of girls that have a sense of urgency.
lead_paragraph: In her dreamy paintings of girls in verdant landscapes, Vera Iliatova toys with conventional associations of nature, femininity, childhood and innocence. The foregrounds of her pictures are occupied by lush, colorful floral bouquets; forests, meadows, hills and dales fill the backgrounds. Ms. Iliatova paints these with a deft, brushy touch that gives the surfaces of her canvases a sensuously tactile presence.

abstract: The bank will pay $714 million to settle accusations that it cheated government pension funds and other investors for more than a decade.
lead_paragraph: The bank will pay $714 million to settle accusations that it cheated government pension funds and other investors for more than a decade.

abstract: David W. Dunlap recalls the minuscule ads that the Durst family placed frequently on The Times’s front page.
lead_paragraph: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 40 years.

lead_paragraph: Michael Oreskes, a former senior editor at The New York Times and The Associated Press, has been appointed senior vice president and editorial director at NPR, the public broadcaster announced on Thursday.

headline: Argentine Prosecutor Urges Reopening of Case Against President
abstract: The prosecutor said an investigation into allegations against President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner and other officials, dismissed by a judge last month, should resume.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — An Argentine prosecutor asked an appellate court on Thursday to overturn a judge’s decision to dismiss allegations filed against President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner and her political supporters by another prosecutor, Alberto Nisman, days before his mysterious death from a gunshot wound to the head.

abstract: The writer Huan Hsu recounts his efforts to recover his ancestors’ lost treasure in a new memoir, “The Porcelain Thief: Searching the Middle Kingdom for Buried China.”
lead_paragraph: JOURNEY TO UNEARTH A FAMILY TREASURE

headline: Mike Maccagnan Says Jets Upgraded With Ryan Fitzpatrick
abstract: Of his willingness to enter training camp with Fitzpatrick vying with Geno Smith for the starting quarterback job, the new general manager said, “As it stands right now, absolutely.”
lead_paragraph: Mike Maccagnan, the Jets’ new general manager, said he believed he upgraded the quarterback position with the newly acquired Ryan Fitzpatrick. Of his willingness to enter training camp with Fitzpatrick vying with Geno Smith for the job, he said, “As it stands right now, absolutely.”

abstract: The rapper will choose music to preview art in a selling exhibition of contemporary works by black American artists at Sotheby’s.
