lead_paragraph: The growth of niche travel websites meets the explosion of family travel in the introduction of Feather+Flip, a hotel booking site and destination guide aimed at sophisticated parents of under-10-year-olds.

headline: Together Always, in Darkness and in Light
abstract: There is no good way to tell a new guy in your life that you’re going blind.
lead_paragraph: There is no good way to tell a new guy in your life that you’re going blind. I chose the best of lousy options: I broke the news after sex, and I packaged it right.

headline: Fears of Greek Debt Default Overshadow European Union Gathering
abstract: European Union leaders meeting in Brussels were confronted with the possibility of a Greek default, and exit from the eurozone, and possibly the bloc.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — A day before nearly $2 billion in debt becomes due for repayment by Greece’s nearly bankrupt government, European leaders gathered in Brussels on Thursday for a long-planned summit meeting now overshadowed by the mounting risk of a Greek default and revived fears about the future of Europe’s common currency.

headline: March 19, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Belgium, Switzerland, Greece and South Africa.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Belgium, Switzerland, Greece and South Africa.

headline: Carolee Schneemann: ‘Part One’
abstract: This show surveys the start of Carolee Schneemann’s influential career.
lead_paragraph: Established in 2010 by Hunter College, the Artist’s Institute is a combination of exhibition gallery, historical laboratory and studio space dedicated to meditating on the work of one contemporary artist at a time for roughly one semester. Artists who’ve been in the spotlight — or under the microscope — have included Jo Baer, Jimmie Durham, Rosemarie Trockel and Haim Steinbach. Carolee Schneemann is the subject of attention this spring, and a richer one would be hard to find.

headline: Remains of 9/11 Victim at World Trade Center Are Identified
abstract: The identification of Matthew David Yarnell was made possible by the retesting of DNA samples obtained from human remains that were recovered in 2001 and 2002.
lead_paragraph: Matthew David Yarnell, a 26-year-old employee of Fiduciary Trust Company International, has been positively identified as a victim of the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attack on the World Trade Center.

headline: Review: ‘Paint Your Wagon,’ Starring Keith Carradine, Opens at Encores!
abstract: Lerner and Loewe’s 1951 musical about the California gold rush — which has never had a Broadway revival — arrives at City Center, directed by Marc Bruni.
lead_paragraph: Men in weathered woolens and suspenders roister vigorously around the stage, hungry for booze, gold and women — not necessarily in that order — in the jovial production of “Paint Your Wagon” being presented as part of the City Center Encores! series. There’s but a single gal in the gold-mining encampment where the show takes place, at least until the end of the first act, when a stagecoach brings a bevy of working (and dancing) girls to town and the boys throw out a lusty cheer.

headline: Suzan Frecon: ‘Oil Paintings and Sun’
abstract: Ms. Frecon’s images here are obviously landscapes, but they also resemble something stranger.
lead_paragraph: Suzan Frecon came to Minimalism late, but she has persisted and her work has a deeper, quieter kind of originality: a sense of unassailable integrity and the fullness of form. Now in her early 70s, Ms. Frecon has for over three decades been homing in on one or two simple shapes seen against one color. Her newest paintings have two panels whose division forms a kind of horizon line, while the shapes themselves imply curved hillocks, small mountains, crystalline ponds, low-hanging clouds and rising or setting suns. Despite the use of ‘Sun” in this show’s title, her colors, which she grinds and mixes herself, tend toward dark. Rust, blues and greens prevail here with results that seem like nocturnes. They combine Rothko’s color at its most winey and most somber with the carefully modulated geometries of Ellsworth Kelly, but are always clearly handmade, painted with a meditative quality that evokes Morandi.

headline: Op-Talk: How Domestic Violence Costs Women Money
abstract: Survivors need help not just with the physical effects of abuse, but with the financial ones, too.
lead_paragraph: Campaigns to fight domestic violence typically focus on the physical and psychological effects of such violence. Now a new study highlights another area that both public officials and employers need to consider: the impact of domestic violence on survivors’ finances.

headline: Marsha Cottrell at Eleven Rivington
abstract: Each work here is created by tweaking image files on a computer and feeding high quality paper through the printer multiple times.
lead_paragraph: Born under another sign, Marsha Cottrell might have been a consumer tester for laser printers rather than an artist. Instead, she has created a body of work that harnesses the power of office equipment, treating it like a paintbrush or master printer’s tool.

headline: Peter Dundas Appointed as Creative Director of Roberto Cavalli
abstract: According to a company statement, Mr. Dundas’s roles would “enable a repositioning of the house established by Roberto Cavalli in the early 1970s.”
lead_paragraph: The Norwegian-born designer Peter Dundas will be the new creative director of Roberto Cavalli, the company announced today.

headline: Free Online Courses Keep Retirees in the Know
keywords: ['E-Learning', 'ADULT EDUCATION', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Retirement']
abstract: Classes offer the opportunity to continue education from the comfort of home, but they can restrict the chance to build in-person social connections.
lead_paragraph: Mary Lou Russell has a passion for learning. Since retiring 10 years ago, the 79-year-old former grant maker has taken more than a dozen classes on subjects including classical music and appreciating Andy Warhol. She has attended most of her classes from her Manhattan living room.

headline: Not Digital Art, but Art Learned Digitally
abstract: Schools, museums and some entrepreneurial individuals are experimenting with ways to teach art techniques online.
lead_paragraph: Having worked as an art teacher for 50 years, Lois DeWitt decided to try offering drawing and painting classes online. So in 2008 she established a website — Free Online Art Classes — that now attracts about 15,000 visitors a month from places like Indonesia, Africa and Germany to courses that include instruction in watercolors, oil painting and “artful lighting.” (Ms. DeWitt also happens to work in the lighting department of a Home Depot store on Sundays.)

headline: Managing Student Loan Debt as an Older Adult
keywords: ['Student Loans', 'Financial Aid (Education)', 'ADULT EDUCATION', 'Elderly', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Budgets and Budgeting']
abstract: Debt held by those 65 and older has risen significantly in recent years, but the load may be eased with careful planning or government aid, or through an employer.
lead_paragraph: Continuing your education is a lofty pursuit, but it could become an albatross if you get too deep into student loan debt.

headline: Anyone Can Be a Teacher at Skillshare, an Online School
abstract: Students pay $10 a month for unlimited access to Skillshare’s 1,000 courses, and 850,000 users are signed up with the service, the company said.
lead_paragraph: Susan Orlean was considering giving up teaching. She had taught courses at New York University and at the Bread Loaf Writers’ Conference at Middlebury College but was finding it difficult to maintain a consistent class schedule while fulfilling her obligations as a staff writer for The New Yorker.

headline: 25 Minutes of Silence in the City of Angels
abstract: The free meditation class offered weekly at the Hammer Museum in Los Angeles is credited with starting a community-mindfulness trend among American institutions.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It’s early afternoon in the city’s Westwood section, a neighborhood known for its youthful U.C.L.A. energy and horrendous traffic. Near the busy intersection of Wilshire and Westwood Boulevards, nearly 200 locals have gathered to tune out the distractions of modern Los Angeles — and tune into themselves.

headline: Turning to Education for Fun
abstract: People are turning to education for entertainment, whether from online lectures, learning vacations or television, for the love of learning new things and to stay economically viable.
lead_paragraph: In a 2013 episode of “60 Minutes,” Charlie Rose visits Bill Gates’s office to get a sense of where the billionaire philanthropist draws intellectual inspiration. First, Mr. Gates shows Mr. Rose the Codex Leicester, a 500-year-old Leonardo da Vinci manuscript that Mr. Gates bought in 1994 for $30 million.

headline: Luring Working Executives to M.B.A. Programs
keywords: ['Graduate Schools and Students', 'Business Schools', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Commuting']
abstract: Schools that offer these programs aim at commuters and use billboards, radio and a variety of social and other digital marketing tools.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The Conshohocken Curve, a bend in Interstate 76 west of Philadelphia, is one of those traffic-report designations with a plethora of nightmare rush-hour delays. Through much of the winter, nearby St. Joseph’s University took advantage of the inevitable delays to place a billboard promoting its executive M.B.A. program along the curve.

headline: In the Age of Information, Specializing to Survive
keywords: ['ADULT EDUCATION', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Intelligence and Intelligence Tests (IQ)']
abstract: As the amount of human-created information spirals ever higher, our ability to sift through it has not kept pace. Increasingly condensed specialization is one result.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Haber majored in philosophy at Harvard University. And Yale. And Stanford. He explored Kant’s “The Critique of Pure Reason” with an Oxford don and Kierkegaard’s insights into “Subjectivity, Irony and the Crisis of Modernity” with a leading light from the University of Copenhagen.

headline: More Options for Comics Artists
keywords: ['Comic Books and Strips', 'E-Learning', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Cartoons and Cartoonists']
abstract: The digital world is booming with resources to help people who want to become comic book professionals, learn the tools of the trade or improve their craft.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who remembers the 1970s Tippy the Turtle “Draw Me” advertisements on matchbooks, in magazines and on television would be amazed how much times have changed. Then, amateur artists would mail their submissions to the Art Instruction Schools in Minneapolis and could begin a correspondence class to learn still life drawing.

headline: Review: ‘Jauja,’ a Desperate Odyssey in the Argentine Desert
abstract: In Lisandro Alonso’s film, a Danish engineer travels to the Argentine frontier with his daughter, then sets off in search of her after she runs away with a soldier.
lead_paragraph: The films of the Argentine director Lisandro Alonso often feel longer than they are. That isn’t a bad thing, necessarily. Too many movies hurtle forward on fast editing and breathless plotting, and too much of life goes by in a blur. The characters in four of Mr. Alonso’s features — “La Libertad,” “Los Muertos,” “Liverpool” and now “Jauja” — undertake difficult journeys, at least partly on foot, across hostile terrain. Following them through long takes and static shots accompanied by abundant silence and sparse dialogue and music, the viewer feels the weight of time. This can be uncomfortable, but the risk of tedium can deliver a special kind of intensity, a slowing of the metabolism and an awakening of the senses.

headline: Butler Wins Few Style Points but Defeats Texas
abstract: Despite going without a field goal for nearly 11 minutes during one stretch, the sixth-seeded Bulldogs held off the No. 11-seed Texas.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — If their game on Thursday were a Dr. Seuss book, Butler and Texas would have taken shots in a house; they would have taken shots with a mouse. They would have shot from here or there; they would have shot from anywhere.

lead_paragraph: You might know that Yuja Wang is one of the best young pianists around. You’ve probably heard something about her fashion sense. Well, I can report that she’s a natural page turner, too.

headline: Sphinx Organization’s Aaron P. Dworkin Will Go to University of Michigan
abstract: The founder of the Sphinx Organization is leaving to be dean of the University of Michigan’s School of Music, Theater and Dance.
lead_paragraph: Since the violinist Aaron P. Dworkin founded the Sphinx Organization nearly two decades ago to encourage diversity in the stubbornly homogeneous field of classical music, he has held competitions and tours to showcase young black and Latino musicians, started educational programs and urged conservatories and orchestras to be more inclusive.

headline: Review: Jill Alexander Essbaum’s ‘Hausfrau,’ a Good Wife, With a Few Caveats
abstract: Ms. Essbaum has named her married, dissatisfied heroine Anna, as in Karenina, in a debut novel with a smattering of graphic sex scenes.
lead_paragraph: Have you heard the one about the only time a Swiss train runs late? Punch line: “When someone jumps in front of one.” That bit appears on the second page of Jill Alexander Essbaum’s “Hausfrau,” and I wish it were supposed to be funny only when considering what she really intends. Ms. Essbaum has named her married, dissatisfied heroine Anna, as in Karenina. So the train reference qualifies as an earnest literary allusion. And like all the rib-elbowing indications that this Anna has destructive traits, from promiscuity to pyromania, it qualifies as one of this graceless book’s ideas of foreshadowing. Big time.

lead_paragraph: In recent weeks, Gov. Bruce Rauner of Illinois has traveled the state promoting his proposal for more than $2 billion in cuts to pensions for public employees. All public employees, that is, except police officers and firefighters.

headline: Review: ‘Bloodline,’ on Netflix, Depicts a Family With Nasty Secrets
abstract: “Bloodline” is a sneaky, dissembling film noir account of a sneaky, dissembling family.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, “Bloodline” looks ominously like a poignant family drama: Members of a close-knit Southern clan gather at a gracious seaside retreat to celebrate their formidable but aging patriarch. There are anniversary cookouts and multigenerational beach volleyball, and it looks awful.

headline: Review: In ‘The Gunman,’ Sean Penn Plays a Remorseful Sniper on the Run
abstract: This globe-trotting action thriller is also, in passing, a melodrama of male sexual jealousy, an indictment of Western meddling in Africa and a concussion-awareness public service announcement.
lead_paragraph: It’s not a hard and fast rule, but in general when the main character, sometime in the third act, says, “I did some bad things ... ” and stares off into the middle distance, the implied end of the sentence is “including this movie.” I take no particular pleasure in reporting that this is the case in “The Gunman,” a globe-trotting action thriller and also, in passing, a melodrama of male sexual jealousy, an indictment of Western meddling in Africa and a concussion-awareness public service announcement.

headline: Review: ‘Richard Estes: Painting New York City’ Features Works in Abstract Realism
abstract: This exhibition at the Museum of Arts and Design features the artist’s own photographs, cut up and pieced together to create his compositions.
lead_paragraph: Painting used to be as much a craft as an art. That began to change in the late 19th and early 20th centuries as artists like van Gogh, Picasso and countless others shifted the focus from technical virtuosity to the expression of individual sensibility and intellect. Bravura skills with the brush, like those of Bouguereau and other academicians, became anathema for the early Modernists.

headline: Review: ‘Backcountry,’ a Wilderness Survival Thriller
abstract: “Backcountry” unfolds in a dense forest where two hapless hikers meet with all manner of terrors.
lead_paragraph: For most of its 91 tense, uneven minutes, “Backcountry” plays on your nerves like a kid flicking you with a rubber band. You feel the sting (thwack, thwack), but it doesn’t bother you. Over time, though, the kid grows meaner, and the flicks grow harder, faster, too, and you realize that they’re keeping time with the thudding of your heart (thump, thump). The writer and director Adam MacDonald was born in 1977, two years after “Jaws” (chomp, chomp) forced everyone out of the water. He’s set out to have you now steer clear of the lovely, dark and deep woods, too.

headline: Review: ‘Insurgent’ Brandishes a Tougher Shailene Woodley
abstract: In the second of the “Divergent” series of dystopic action films, Tris Prior, the lead character, is a more comfortable lock-and-load renegade.
lead_paragraph: Tighter, tougher and every bit as witless as its predecessor, “The Divergent Series: Insurgent” — the second segment in the cycle — arrives with a yawn and ends with a bang. In between, bodies run, leap and fall amid nuzzling lips, blasting bullets and periodic story turns that make the movie a modest cultural artifact if one largely devoid of aesthetic interest. At this point, the heroine, Tris Prior (Shailene Woodley), can easily lock and load, having been trained by a thuggishly stylish faction, Dauntless, whose members wear the usual blah-blah black, tats and piercings and guard this dystopian world. “They’re our protectors, our soldiers, our police,” Tris says of them in the first movie, if also “crazy.”
