keywords: ['Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: The announcement added 88,000 2008 Pilots, a model that had not been included in previous recalls.
lead_paragraph: Honda Motor is expanding a national recall of vehicles with Takata-made airbags to include more than 104,000 cars, including one model that had not been included in previous recalls for the defect. Takata airbags can deploy violently and send metal fragments at passengers.

headline: Monica Lewinsky Breaks Her Public Silence With a TED Talk
abstract: After 10 years out of the spotlight, the former White House intern took the stage to call for an end cyberbullying.
lead_paragraph: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — “You’re looking at a woman who was publicly silent for a decade.”

headline: Review: Al Pacino in ‘Danny Collins’ Plays a Dissolute Pop Star
abstract: In Dan Fogelman’s comic drama, a 40-year-old letter from John Lennon could change a jaded older singer’s life.
lead_paragraph: In “Danny Collins,” Al Pacino injects a zany charge of adrenaline into the title role of a rich, dissolute pop star belatedly seeking redemption for four decades of excess and wasted talent. This bogus character, introduced in a prologue set in 1971 as an intense, hungry young folk singer with a resemblance to the young Bob Dylan, is the latest in a lengthening Hollywood roster of rambunctious old goats.

headline: Pastrami Piled as High as New York, With Prices to Match
abstract: The cost of the city’s celebrated sandwich meat has risen so much, some delicatessen owners have considered taking it off the menu.
lead_paragraph: Short on dismal news? Have a look at this notice, taped to the counter at the Yankee Tavern on 161st Street in the Bronx.

headline: Clip: ‘Growing Up and Other Lies’
abstract: A scene from the film.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the film.

headline: Bloodshed in Tunisia
abstract: Even before the museum attack left at least 20 people dead, the country’s Arab Spring success story was fading.
lead_paragraph: With their massacre of at least 20 people from five countries at the National Bardo Museum in Tunis, the gunmen who carried out the rampage on Wednesday struck at Tunisia’s economic lifeblood, the tourism industry; its government; and the international community. The attack lays bare the extent to which extremists who are spreading through the region now threaten Tunisia, the only success story of the Arab Spring.

headline: Ryanair Retracts Trans-Atlantic Plans
abstract: In a surprising reversal, the board of the budget airline, Ryanair, said it had not approved plans to offer flights between North America and Europe.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — In a surprising turnabout, the board of the Irish budget airline, Ryanair, said that, in fact, it had not approved plans to offer ultracheap flights between Europe and the United States.

headline: Review: ‘Growing Up and Other Lies’ Stares Down the Advent of Adulthood
abstract: The film centers on a group of men who walk the length of Manhattan in a vain attempt to recapture the euphoria of their early 20s.
lead_paragraph: “Growing Up and Other Lies,” the story of four friends in their 30s who walk from the northern tip of Manhattan to the Battery (with detours), is nominally a buddy comedy. But the movie, written and directed by Danny Jacobs and Darren Grodsky, is so steeped in angst that you share its characters’ deep-seated dread of a future that looks anything but rosy. The prospect of parenthood is especially daunting.

headline: Verbatim: ‘Respect the Voters,’ Walker Says
abstract: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin addressed a South Carolina Republican Party dinner fund-raiser in Greenville.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, speaking at a South Carolina Republican Party dinner fund-raiser in Greenville, about the resignation of one of his aides this week.

headline: This Week’s Movies | March 20, 2015
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “The Gunman,” “The Divergent Series: Insurgent,” and “Backcountry.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “The Gunman,” “The Divergent Series: Insurgent,” and “Backcountry.”

headline: Anemic Support Greets Potential Olympic Bid in Boston
abstract: Only 36 percent of adults in the Boston region support hosting the Games, while 52 percent oppose doing so, according to the latest poll for WBUR, Boston’s NPR radio station.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Public support for Boston to host the 2024 Summer Olympics was already on the downslope, but it has plunged even further in the last month.

headline: How English Ruined Indian Literature
abstract: We have been writing in the language of our own oppression.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A BOATMAN I met in Varanasi last year, while covering the general election that made Narendra Modi prime minister of India, said, “When Modi comes to power, we will send this government of the English packing.”

headline: D’Angelo Russell and Ohio State Squeak Past V.C.U.
abstract: Russell, Ohio State’s all-American freshman guard, scored 28 points to lead the Buckeyes to a victory in overtime.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — D’Angelo Russell’s supporting cast at Ohio State did just enough Thursday to help him push the Buckeyes past Virginia Commonwealth with a 75-72 overtime victory.

headline: Republican Budgets in Both House and the Senate Add to Military Spending
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: In a battle of Congressional defense hawks versus deficit hawks on Thursday, the Pentagon won out in a victory that presages a broader revolt against tight spending limits.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congressional defense hawks seized the upper hand in their fight with deficit hawks on Thursday, securing billions of dollars for the Pentagon in a victory that presages a broader revolt against tight spending limits.

headline: Sam Saunders, a Descendant of a King of Golf, Carves His Own Path
abstract: Saunders is making his sixth start in the invitational named after Arnold Palmer, his grandfather, and was within range of the leader after the first round.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — The starter on the 10th hole, Butch Cronon, took particular delight in announcing the first player in the final threesome of the morning wave Thursday at the Arnold Palmer Invitational. “From Fort Collins, Colo.,” Cronon intoned, “please welcome home, Sam Saunders.”

headline: Review: In Eugène Green’s ‘La Sapienza,’ a Search of Ideals of Civilization
abstract: Though set in the present, “La Sapienza,” which takes its name from a venerable university in Rome, finds inspiration and sustenance in the past.
lead_paragraph: The characters in “La Sapienza,” Eugène Green’s new film, tend to look directly into the camera when they speak, to speak clearly and grammatically, and to refrain from interrupting one another. The rhythm of the editing is similarly deliberate: The camera looks at one person, then another, and patiently surveys a landscape or the interior of an old and magnificent building. This graceful, unhurried style, with its blend of austerity and artifice and its roots in classical French theatrical traditions, is Mr. Green’s signature. American by birth and ardently European by residence and vocation, he elevates formal decorum to a moral principle. “La Sapienza,” quiet and conversational as it seems, is a passionate defense of — and perhaps also an elegy for — an old and dignified ideal of civilization.

headline: Amazon Wins Approval to Test Delivery Drones Outdoors
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Delivery Services', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: While Amazon can now move its tests from inside a warehouse, the retailer still has a long way to go to realize its vision of autonomous delivery drones.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Federal regulators have given Amazon a green light to begin testing drones, but it will most likely take years before the online retailer can start delivering packages from the air to peoples’ homes.

headline: Clip: ‘She’s Lost Control’
abstract: A scene from the film.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the film.

headline: Take Google to Court, Staff Report Urged F.T.C.
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: An internal Federal Trade Commission report recommended that the agency take action against Google for anticompetitive practices. The F.T.C. voted not to bring charges.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission on Thursday faced renewed questions about its handling of its antitrust investigation into Google, after documents revealed that an internal report had recommended stronger action.

headline: Varoufakis Says Video Was Doctored
abstract: Greece’s finance minister, Yanis Varoufakis, denied making an obscene gesture in reference to Germany during a 2013 lecture in Croatia, saying video of the talk was “doctored.”
lead_paragraph: Greece’s finance minister, Yanis Varoufakis, denied making an obscene gesture in reference to Germany during a 2013 lecture in Croatia, saying video of the talk was “doctored.”

headline: Accusations of Sex Crimes Unnerve Venice High School
abstract: Since the arrests of a dozen students on suspicion of sex-related crimes, members of the Venice High School community in Los Angeles have been doing some soul-searching.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Since the arrests of a dozen students here on suspicion of sex-related crimes, members of the Venice High School community have been doing some soul-searching about what they could have done to prevent the assaults — some of which the police said took place on campus — and what they can do to try to ensure that nothing similar happens again.

headline: Review: In ‘She’s Lost Control,’ Crossing Boundaries in Pursuit of Intimacy
abstract: Anja Marquardt’s film is a chilly and bleak portrait of a behavioral psychologist who works as a sexual surrogate and takes on a client with serious intimacy issues.
lead_paragraph: “She’s Lost Control,” Anja Marquardt’s chilly portrait of a behavioral psychologist who works as a sexual surrogate, is so studiedly bleak it will pour ice water on anyone’s fantasies of earning a living as an erotic healer.

headline: T-Mobile Policy Violated Labor Law, Judge Rules
abstract: A National Labor Relations Board administrative law judge found that the wireless carrier restricted workers’ ability to organize.
lead_paragraph: A National Labor Relations Board judge ruled on Wednesday that the employment policies of the wireless carrier T-Mobile violated United States labor law by restricting workers’ ability to organize and other rights, setting a potentially important precedent for unions.

headline: Crowds and Long Delays Fray Subway System and Riders’ Nerves
abstract: With fares set to rise, riders across New York City are complaining of having to pay more when service is worse.
lead_paragraph: Fares are about to go up. Delays are driving riders to distraction. And on a recent evening, Ian Nolan’s train was out of service.

headline: Amazon Letter to the Federal Aviation Administration
abstract: This letter describes Amazon’s plans for a drone delivery system.
lead_paragraph: This letter describes Amazon’s plans for a drone delivery system.

headline: Port Authority Agrees on the Need to Replace Its Bus Terminal, but Little Else
abstract: Replacing the 65-year-old terminal in Manhattan could cost at least $10 billion, and the project wouldn’t be finished before 2027. The short-term solution was to create a subcommittee to study the problem.
lead_paragraph: The commissioners of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey agreed on Thursday that the 65-year-old bus terminal in Manhattan that their agency operates is an overcrowded eyesore that cries out to be replaced. And there the consensus ended.

headline: McConnell Urges States to Help Thwart Obama’s ‘War on Coal’
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Coal', 'States (US)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Global Warming', 'Federal-State Relations (US)']
abstract: Senator Mitch McConnell has begun an aggressive campaign to block President Obama’s climate agenda in statehouses and courtrooms, arenas far beyond his official authority.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky has begun an aggressive campaign to block President Obama’s climate change agenda in statehouses and courtrooms across the country, arenas far beyond Mr. McConnell’s official reach and authority.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 19, 2015
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: March 19, 2015

headline: Black Man’s Body Found Hanging From Tree in Mississippi
abstract: The man was hanging by a bedsheet, said Sheriff Marvin Lucas of Claiborne County, who added that it had not yet been determined if hanging had been the cause of death.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Federal, state and local law enforcement agencies are investigating the death of a black man who was found hanging from a tree in a small Mississippi town on Thursday morning.

headline: Review: ‘Lost and Love’ (‘Shi Gu’) Stars Andy Lau as a Man Searching for His Lost Son
abstract: Peng Sanyuan’s drama builds a personal story and a road movie around the scourge of child trafficking in China.
lead_paragraph: Peng Sanyuan’s “Lost and Love” could ably serve as a travelogue of China: glowingly verdant trees, winding roads, fishing shacks, ribbonlike bridges, cafes and grubby city intersections, all shot by Mark Lee Ping Bin, the cinematographer who has helped the great director Hou Hsiao-hsien sculpt time in images.

headline: More U.S. Troops Seen Staying in Afghanistan
abstract: Signs that the Taliban is divided over whether to engage in talks and a resilient Qaeda presence have upended plans to drop the number of U.S. troops in Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is nearing a decision to keep more troops in Afghanistan next year than it had intended, effectively upending its drawdown plans in response to roiling violence in the country and another false start in the effort to open peace talks between the Taliban and the Afghan government.

headline: Director of the Clark Art Institute to Retire
keywords: ['ARCHITECTURE', 'Art', 'Finances', 'Museums', 'News Sources, Confidential Status of', 'Philanthropy', 'Restoration and Renovation']
abstract: On his watch, a transformative renovation of a museum campus that is still “an envelope for surprises.”
lead_paragraph: Michael Conforti, director of the Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute in the Berkshires since 1994, who spent almost 15 years reimagining the museum through a renovation and expansion, announced on Thursday that he would retire in August.

headline: In Video, Obama Appeals to Iranian Youth on Nuclear Deal
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Youth', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: In a video with Persian subtitles, President Obama urged young Iranians to pressure their leaders for a nuclear deal and thereby improve relations with the West.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two weeks after Senate Republicans issued a letter to the Iranian leadership warning that any nuclear agreement Iran signs with the administration may be temporary, President Obama has issued a missive of his own: A video directed at Iran’s young people, urging them to pressure their leaders to accept the deal on the table.

headline: Villanova Overwhelms Lafayette
abstract: The Wildcats showed why they were a No. 1 seed with a dominating performance against the Leopards, the Patriot League champions.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — By halftime, seven Villanova players had each scored at least 5 points. The only starter who had not, Ryan Arcidiacono, was the Big East player of the year.

headline: Israel Election Result Complicates Life for Clinton
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Israeli Settlements', 'Palestinians', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Mrs. Clinton could face resistance among polarized Jewish Democrats if she is critical of the Israeli leader.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s victory in this week’s Israeli elections has reverberated through American politics, reinforcing Republican faith in the political wisdom of a hawkish foreign policy, worsening his relationship with President Obama, and energizing liberal critics of Israel’s government. But mostly it has complicated the life of Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: Clip: ‘White God’
abstract: A scene from the film.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the film.

headline: A Burst of Upsets, and Confidence, to Shake the N.C.A.A. Tournament Up
abstract: Thursday’s games showed something that cannot be found in the regular season: an inexplicable and sometimes unwarranted confidence that gives some teams the edge when it counts the most.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — There was something about the way the University of Alabama at Birmingham’s men’s basketball team took the court here at midday Thursday that made me think that the Blazers fan holding a sign that said “U.A.B. Shock the World” might not be so crazy after all.

headline: Solar Eclipse and Supermoon Have Europe Energy Providers Watchful
keywords: ['Electric Light and Power', 'Power Failures and Blackouts', 'Sun', 'Solar Energy', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Moon', 'Eclipses']
abstract: Energy operators reliant on the sun prepared for a day of headaches as a total eclipse coincided with a supermoon.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Germany has enthusiastically embraced the sun as an important source of energy, but a strange celestial trifecta on Friday evoked a shiver of ancient fears — and the more practical concern that the lights might go out.

headline: Review: In ‘Metalhead,’ an Icelandic Girl Drowns Her Sorrows in Music
abstract: Ragnar Bragason’s film stars Thora Bjorg Helga as a young woman who honors her dead brother by throwing herself into the Scandinavian heavy-metal scene that he loved.
lead_paragraph: Ragnar Bragason’s “Metalhead” — about a disaffected teenage girl on an isolated farm who finds salvation in heavy-metal music — could have been set in a Great Plains town or in any American agricultural hamlet. But it takes place near Svarthamar, an empty, rural corner of Iceland, where much social activity revolves around the church.

headline: Review: ‘Please Be Normal,’ a Couple’s Dawning Desperation
abstract: Sam Waterston, his daughter Elisabeth Waterston and her husband, Louis Cancelmi, star in Haik Kocharian’s drama about imminent parenthood, a move to the suburbs, detachment and control.
lead_paragraph: It takes courage to ask your partner “Are we happy?”— especially if, like Mary (Elisabeth Waterston), you’re pregnant and your boyfriend, Victor (played by Ms. Waterston’s husband, Louis Cancelmi), seems increasingly detached from his imminent fatherhood. That detachment, its cause and consequence, forms the shrouded heart of “Please Be Normal,” a tiny, piercing study of dawning desperation that’s all the more remarkable for being virtually silent.

headline: Coverage of Arctic Sea Ice Shrinks to a Winter Low
abstract: There was less sea ice coverage in the Arctic this winter than in any year since satellite measurements began nearly four decades ago, researchers said Thursday.
lead_paragraph: There was less sea ice coverage in the Arctic this winter than in any year since satellite measurements began nearly four decades ago, researchers said Thursday. The National Snow and Ice Data Center, a government-sponsored research group, said that in late February ice cover in the Arctic Ocean reached its maximum extent, 5.61 million square miles, which is about 7 percent less than the average from 1981 to 2010 and about 1 percent less than the previous lowest year, 2011. The center said that changes in the jet stream created warmer than normal conditions on the Pacific side of the Arctic. While the extent of Arctic sea ice is naturally variable, it has been generally declining over the past several decades as the region warms more quickly than other parts of the planet.

headline: Review: ‘The Heidi Chronicles,’ With Elisabeth Moss, Opens on Broadway
abstract: Ms. Moss plays the title role in the vibrant revival of the 1989 Tony-winning Wendy Wasserstein play that contemplates a woman’s debate of motherhood vs. career.
lead_paragraph: Do the responsibilities that come with age inevitably erode the ideals of youth? Can women achieve the most in their careers while enjoying a fully satisfying family life? Is sadness a natural — as opposed to pathological — response to the realization that life will not bring us everything we had hoped it would?

headline: Augustus, to Julius Caesar
abstract: A debut by Roland Huget.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Today marks another debut by a constructor from Canada named Roland Huget. He introduces himself in his notes, so I will limit myself to the puzzle.

headline: Review: In ‘Spring,’ Romance Gives Way to a Beastly Horror
abstract: The film, by Justin Benson and Aaron Moorhead, depicts a young American who goes to Italy to find himself and instead finds much more than he bargained for.
lead_paragraph: Justin Benson and Aaron Moorhead don’t yet have many movies to their credit, but with “Spring,” which they directed, they show that they already possess something that many makers of horror films never develop: patience.

headline: Hostility From U.S. as China Lures Allies to New Bank
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The willingness of Britain to join the China bank over American objections was an especially clear sign of China’s sophisticated strategy for winning friends, and Washington’s failure to respond effectively.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — When Xi Jinping, then the newly minted Chinese leader, first broached the idea of a new Asian development bank in a public speech in 2013, few in Washington paid it much heed.

headline: Mayor de Blasio Defends Efforts to Help Struggling Schools
abstract: At a school in Queens, Mayor Bill de Blasio spoke about “SWAT teams” for schools with poor leadership, newly aggressive language that comes as Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo pushes state involvement.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio defended his administration’s efforts to fix New York City’s troubled schools on Thursday, describing those efforts as a cross between a war and a policing operation — “the educational equivalent of house-to-house combat.”

headline: Patz Trial Jury Is Told Suspect Was Prone to Confessing
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Confessions', 'Interrogations', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: A psychologist serving as a defense witness testified that Pedro Hernandez, who has confessed to strangling 6-year-old Etan Patz in 1979, was susceptible to giving a false confession because of his low intelligence.
lead_paragraph: Pedro Hernandez, the man who has confessed to strangling Etan Patz, was susceptible to giving a false confession while being questioned by detectives because of his low intelligence, a psychologist serving as a defense witness testified on Thursday.

headline: The Gesture That Turned a Fiscal Crisis Into Twitter Fodder — or Did It?
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Television']
abstract: A media frenzy ensued in Germany over a video showing Greece’s finance minister flipping his middle finger, a video some now claim to have faked.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Did he flip Germany the bird?

headline: M.L.B. Exhibition Possible in Cuba Next Year
abstract: Commissioner Rob Manfred put a time frame on the plan to play in Cuba by telling The Wall Street Journal that the most likely time to do it would be during spring training next year.
lead_paragraph: Major League Baseball continues to highlight its intention to play at least one exhibition game in Cuba, bringing the game to the homeland of some of the league’s best players.

headline: U.S. Must Step Up Capacity for Cyberattacks, Chief Argues
abstract: Adm. Michael S. Rogers, the head of United States Cyber Command, said in Senate testimony that the country needed to increase its capacity for cyberattacks as a deterrent against hostile nations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The admiral who directs American cyberforces told a Senate committee on Thursday that the United States was “at a tipping point” where it needed to increase its ability to conduct cyberattacks, to create a deterrent against other countries that are attacking it.

headline: Greco-German ‘Fingergate’ Gets Curiouser and Curiouser
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Comedy and Humor', 'Hoaxes and Pranks']
abstract: The debate over an obscene gesture by Greece’s finance minister took a comic turn as a German satirist claimed to have faked video of it.
lead_paragraph: Amid tense negotiations between Greece and its European creditors, the eyes of the German media remained firmly focused Thursday on the Greek finance minister’s middle finger — specifically on the question of whether a two-year-old video clip of him extending that digit in Germany’s metaphorical direction was real or fake.

headline: Review: ‘Secret of Water’ Studies Liquid as an Archive of History
abstract: With constant talk of the power of love and optimism, this documentary is the flip side of absurd claims made by climate-change deniers and anti-evolutionists.
lead_paragraph: There’s a whole lot of hogwash in “Secret of Water,” a cheesy documentary stuffed full of pseudoscience masquerading as profound truth.

headline: Short-Handed Cincinnati Rallies Past Purdue
abstract: The Bearcats, who have played without their coach for much of the season, managed to defeat the Boilermakers in overtime.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Playing without its coach and suddenly its leading scorer, No. 8 seed Cincinnati rallied in regulation and defeated No. 9 seed Purdue, 66-65, in overtime in a Midwest Region game Thursday night.

headline: Review: In ‘Tracers,’ Taylor Lautner Joins a Shady Parkour Gang
abstract: Part urban crime film, part romantic fantasy, Daniel Benmayor’s film shows love not just for stunts but for the dynamic surfaces of the city.
lead_paragraph: Part urban crime film, part romantic fantasy, “Tracers” begins by zipping along with the street-level symbol of heedless New York motion, a bike messenger. When this particular speed demon, Cam (Taylor Lautner), has an accident, he slams into a young woman practicing another kind of perpetual motion, parkour, an equipment-free sport that treats urban spaces as obstacle courses. Corny twists and exchanges ensue in the wobbly story, but, delightfully, Daniel Benmayor’s film shows love not just for stunts but for the dynamic surfaces of the city.

headline: Utah Holds Off Stephen F. Austin’s Upset Bid
abstract: The Utes used their defensive prowess to shut down the high-scoring Lumberjacks.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — Utah, one of the country’s best defensive teams, clamped down high-scoring Stephen F. Austin, staving off an upset bid and advancing to the round of 32.

headline: Head of Secret Service Denies Crash
abstract: Joseph P. Clancy, the director of the Secret Service, disputed reports that an incident at the White House involving his agents was a car crash.
lead_paragraph: Joseph P. Clancy, the director of the Secret Service, disputed reports that an incident at the White House involving his agents was a car crash.

headline: Virginia Just Can’t Win With Critics of Its Style
abstract: The Cavaliers won 29 games and a second consecutive Atlantic Coast Conference regular-season crown, and their maniacal devotion to defense and excruciatingly deliberate offense are drawing criticism.
lead_paragraph: GREENSBORO, N.C. — On the way to winning 29 games and a second consecutive Atlantic Coast Conference regular-season crown, Virginia has managed to help provoke one of the more fascinating academic discussions on the state of college basketball as we know it.

headline: Charles N. Shaffer Jr., Lawyer Who Bolstered Case Against Nixon, Dies at 82
abstract: Mr. Shaffer’s detailed defense of John W. Dean III, the White House counsel, helped cost Richard M. Nixon the presidency during the Watergate scandal.
lead_paragraph: Charles N. Shaffer Jr., a fastidious litigator whose painstaking defense of John W. Dean III, the White House counsel, helped cost Richard M. Nixon the presidency during the Watergate scandal, died on March 15 at his home in Woodbine, Md. He was 82.

headline: In a Battle of the Lowly, the Knicks End Up a Bit Lower
abstract: The Knicks and the Timberwolves entered Thursday night with matching records: 14-53, which qualified them as the two worst teams in the N.B.A. Minnesota emerged with the victory.
lead_paragraph: After nearly five months of futility, the Knicks and the Minnesota Timberwolves showed up at Madison Square Garden on Thursday night with matching records: 14-53, which qualified them as the two worst teams in the N.B.A.

headline: Review: In ‘Zombeavers,’ the Flesheaters Have Overbites
abstract: The undead chompers are bucktoothed in the cheesy, gory “Zombeavers,” directed by Jordan Rubin.
lead_paragraph: Great careers have begun with flesh-eating creatures. Take the writer-director John Sayles (“Lone Star”), who got his start in movies writing trash classics like “Piranha” and “Alligator.” Now the director Jordan Rubin, a former writer for Comedy Central’s “Crank Yankers,” and Evan Astrowsky, a producer of Eli Roth’s horror film “Cabin Fever,” pool their talents for “Zombeavers,” an intermittently diverting stew of low-budget effects and potty-mouth humor. Unsurprisingly, its writers and soundtrack composers, the brothers Jon and Al Kaplan, wrote the music for Syfy’s “Piranhaconda” and “Dinocroc vs. Supergator.” (More intriguingly, they also created “Silence!,” the stage parody of “The Silence of the Lambs.”)

headline: Review: ‘Can’t Stand Losing You,’ Andy Summers’s Version of the Police
abstract: Neither Sting nor Stewart Copeland contributes to this documentary based on a memoir by the band’s guitarist, Mr. Summers.
lead_paragraph: The most exciting moment in Andy Grieve’s rather dull documentary, “Can’t Stand Losing You: Surviving the Police,” comes when we learn that Sting’s can of hair spray exploded in his face right before a 1978 television appearance. Had the actual detonation been recorded, it would have livened up a movie singularly lacking in rock-doc unpredictability and verve.

headline: Malcolm Fraser, a Leader Given Power During Crisis in Australia, Dies at 84
abstract: Mr. Fraser became prime minister of Australia during a constitutional crisis but later won three elections and led his country for eight years.
lead_paragraph: Malcolm Fraser, who was appointed prime minister of Australia by the British crown during a constitutional crisis and led his country for eight years, winning three elections, died on Friday. He was 84.

headline: Against North Carolina State, L.S.U. Lets One Slip Away
abstract: The Tigers nearly beat Kentucky in the regular season, but they also lost to SEC doormats, and on Thursday they blew a big lead against the Wolfpack.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — The problem with being the team that came closest to beating mighty Kentucky, as Louisiana State has discovered, is the burden of expectations. The Tigers know how well they are capable of playing, but then there are the days when they lose to conference doormats like Auburn and Mississippi State, and how do they explain that?

headline: Elizabeth Alexander: Eat, Memory
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Books and Literature', 'Poetry and Poets']
abstract: The poet’s memoir recounts her romance with her late husband, but it also tells the story of their romance with food. In her Manhattan home, the tastes and scents of their shared life linger.
lead_paragraph: The poet’s memoir recounts her romance with her late husband, but it also tells the story of their romance with food. In her Manhattan home, the tastes and scents of their shared life linger.

headline: A Dual Review of What’s New Starring Zaha Hadid and Ricky Gervais
abstract: Ricky Gervais and Zaha Hadid curl up in a bird’s nest while considering a floor-scrubbing robot and a lamp made from a weed.
lead_paragraph: Ricky Gervais and Zaha Hadid curl up in a bird’s nest while considering a floor-scrubbing robot and a lamp made from a weed.

headline: Word of the Day | centigrade
abstract: This word has appeared in eight New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: centigrade • \ˈsen-tə-ˌgrad, ˈsän-\ • adjective

headline: Yankees’ Jacoby Ellsbury Expects to Play on Opening Day Despite Oblique Strain
abstract: The Yankees expect Ellsbury, a center fielder who has been sidelined with a mild oblique strain, to return to baseball activities early next week.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Yankees center fielder Jacoby Ellsbury said Thursday that the mild oblique strain that had sidelined him since Sunday would not prevent him from being in the lineup on opening day, which is less than three weeks away.

headline: Treating Exotic Pets
abstract: The patients at one Manhattan hospital tend toward the exotic: animals usually found in the wild but now kept as pets.
lead_paragraph: Correction appended below.

headline: A Hulking New Mexico State Front Line Prepares to Face Kansas
abstract: The No. 15-seeded Aggies, the Western Athletic Conference champions who often dominate teams inside, will play second-seeded Kansas in a Midwest Region matchup Friday.
lead_paragraph: OMAHA — New Mexico State center Tshilidzi Nephawe stands 6 feet 10 inches with an intimidating natural scowl that belies an engaging manner. Nephawe, a South African, anchors a hulking front line for the No. 15-seeded Aggies (23-10), the Western Athletic Conference champions who often dominate teams inside.

headline: Northern Iowa and Wyoming Share a Familial Connection
abstract: The story line for Friday’s No. 5 Northern Iowa-No. 12 Wyoming matchup concerns Northern Iowa guard Wes Washpun, whose father, Jamal, played for Wyoming.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — If you put a couple dozen people in a room together, there are good odds two of those people will share a birthday.

headline: ASAP Yams’s Cause of Death: Accidental Drug Intoxication
abstract: ASAP Yams, the longtime hip-hop executive and co-owner of the ASAP Worldwide record label, was found unresponsive in his Brooklyn apartment on Jan. 18.
lead_paragraph: ASAP Yams, the hip-hop executive and co-owner of the ASAP Worldwide record label, died of an acute mixed drug intoxication (including opiates and benzodiazepine), a spokeswoman for New York City’s chief medical examiner said on Thursday in an email. The death was ruled an accident.

headline: St. John’s Will Be Short-Handed Against San Diego State
abstract: The Red Storm (21-11) will play without starting center Chris Obekpa on Friday against the Aztecs (26-8), the No. 8 seed.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Having made the N.C.A.A. tournament for only the second time in Coach Steve Lavin’s five-year tenure, and only the second time since 2002, No. 9-seeded St. John’s will be short-handed in its South Region game against San Diego State (26-8), the No. 8 seed, Friday in Charlotte, N.C.

headline: Arkansas Avoids the No. 5 Jinx by Edging Wofford
abstract: The 12th-seeded Terriers had chances to tie the score near the end of regulation, but the Razorbacks escaped with a victory.
lead_paragraph: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — Few teams cherish having a No. 5 seed, a position that seems cursed with upsets against opponents with nothing to lose. So Arkansas was in a tough spot Thursday night as it tried to fend off the 12th-seeded Wofford Terriers, who were looking for their first N.C.A.A. tournament victory in four appearances.

headline: Watch a Total Solar Eclipse Without Venturing to a Remote Island
abstract: Friday’s eclipse appeared total only on the Faroe Islands and in Svalbard, Norway, but it can be seen without going farther than your computer.
lead_paragraph: By a lucky coincidence, the moon and the sun appear to be almost the same size, each subtending about half a degree of arc in diameter. As a result, the endless and repetitive wobbly dance of the worlds causes the moon to pass directly in front of the sun every year or two, sometimes hiding it completely in a total solar eclipse.

headline: What’s on TV Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 11 P.M. (Pop) THE DESCENDANTS (2011) Matt King (George Clooney, in an Oscar-nominated role), whose ancestors include the earliest white settlers in Hawaii, struggles to make the right decision about his family’s birthright, a pristine tract on Kauai — should it be sold to developers? — while his wife, Elizabeth (Patricia Hastie), lies in a coma after a boating accident. Not long after Matt learns he is about to become a widower and a single father to unruly daughters, Scottie (Amara Miller) and Alex (Shailene Woodley), he discovers that his wife had an affair. And Elizabeth’s father (Robert Forster) blames Matt for his daughter’s condition. The director Alexander Payne, “with a light touch and a keen sense of place — this Hawaii is as real and peculiar as the Nebraska of ‘About Schmidt’ or the California wine country of ‘Sideways’ — has made a movie that, for all its modesty, is as big as life,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “Its heart is occupied by grief, pain and the haunting silence of Elizabeth, whose version of events is the only one we never hear. And yet it is also full of warmth, humor and the kind of grace that can result from our clumsy attempts to make things better.”

headline: Against Kentucky, Hampton Keeps It Close, for 12 Minutes
abstract: The undefeated Wildcats struggled at first, but eventually their size and suffocating defense proved too much for the Pirates.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — There was drama here for 12 minutes. No. 1 Kentucky led 16th-seeded Hampton, 18-14, with 8 minutes 27 seconds left in the first half, and John Calipari, the Kentucky coach, fumed at his players from the bench for misdeeds in execution.

headline: New York City’s Week in Pictures: Mar. 19
abstract: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include images of a public art sculpture in Queens, the St. Patrick’s Day parade and a comedian named Des Bishop.
lead_paragraph: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include images of a public art sculpture in Queens, the St. Patrick’s Day parade and a comedian named Des Bishop.

headline: Midmajor Upsets Are Just Part of the Tournament
abstract: For most midmajor teams, victories by Georgia State and U.A.B. would be sources of inspiration. But for Gonzaga and Northern Iowa, they are cautionary tales.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — On Thursday afternoon at KeyArena, several Northern Iowa players gathered around a smartphone in a locker room to watch the end of the Baylor-Georgia State game. The tension built as the time passed and Georgia State mounted an improbable rally.

headline: Mets’ Dillon Gee Looks Solid in Start; Daniel Murphy Tweaks Hamstring
abstract: On a day when the Mets looked to plug one hole, moving Gee from the bullpen to the rotation, another leak emerged, as Murphy played half an inning before he was sidelined by tightness in his right hamstring.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — On a day when the Mets looked to plug one hole, moving Dillon Gee from the bullpen to the rotation, another leak emerged, albeit not one as major as losing starting pitcher Zack Wheeler to season-ending Tommy John surgery.

headline: SXSW Music 2015: A Surprise Appearance From Miley Cyrus
keywords: ['Music', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: The singer made a brief three-song appearance — the pop music equivalent of saying “Remember me?” after a relatively quiet six months.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — The biggest buzz around town on Thursday, as the South by Southwest music mayhem hit its stride, was not about a breakout band from Brooklyn or Sweden, nor was it focused on the previous night’s exclusive Iggy Azalea set for Samsung. Instead, the increasingly loud whispers around Austin came straight from trending topics for 2013: Miley Cyrus was rumored to be making an appearance.

headline: Georgetown Finally Lives Up to Its Seeding and Outmuscles Eastern Washington
abstract: The Hoyas, who had built a reputation for losing to lower-seeded teams in the N.C.A.A. tournament, advanced to play Utah in the round of 32.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — Having built an unwanted reputation in recent years for losing to teams seeded far lower than itself, No. 4 Georgetown dominated No. 13 Eastern Washington, 84-74, on Thursday in the N.C.A.A. tournament’s round of 64.

headline: European Leaders Urge Greece to Accelerate Overhaul Efforts
abstract: After late-night talks, French, German and Greek leaders asserted that Greece could get back on track by speeding up the implementation of a February agreement.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — With Greece rapidly running out of money and again teetering on the edge of default, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany stood firm early Friday against pleading by the Greek prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, and prodded him to speed up efforts to overhaul his country’s gasping economy in return for cash.

headline: Rosetta Follows a Comet Through Perihelion
abstract: The Rosetta spacecraft is following Comet 67P/C-G as it makes its closest approach to the sun.
lead_paragraph: The Rosetta spacecraft is following Comet 67P/C-G as it makes its closest approach to the sun.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, March 20, 2015.
lead_paragraph: “I personally think we are just not smart enough — and won’t be for a very long time — to feel comfortable about the consequences of changing heredity, even in a single individual.”

headline: Corrections: March 20, 2015
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Friday, March 20, 2015
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Anti-Semitism in Hungary
abstract: Frank J. Perez, a high school world history teacher, responds to a Saturday Profile of Eva Fahidi, a Holocaust survivor.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Helping the Victims in Syria and Iraq
abstract: Readers respond to news articles and an Op-Ed essay.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Leniency for General Petraeus: His Lawyer’s Argument
abstract: The attorney for David H. Petraeus notes that any classified information that he gave his biographer was never made public.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Finding This Lost City in Honduras Was the Easy Part
abstract: Deciding what to do with the ancient artifacts there was harder.
lead_paragraph: RIGHT now, in the jungle some 50 miles inland from the Mosquito Coast of Honduras, sits an astounding cache of ancient artifacts, until this month most likely unseen by human eyes for somewhere between 600 and 1,000 years. I traveled there three weeks ago with a team of archaeologists, anthropologists, ethnobotanists, filmmakers and Honduran soldiers, who were following up on lidar images — a laser-based aerial surveillance technology — that suggested the presence of ruins.

headline: The Zero-Sum Moment
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'International Relations', 'Terrorism', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Elections', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: We are living through a global era characterized by doubt and fear; it may be the single biggest driver of politics, from Israel to Europe to here at home.
lead_paragraph: National elections take place within a specific global moment. In the 1990s, there was a presumption that we were living in an age of rapid progress. Democracy was spreading. Tyranny was receding. Asia was booming. The European Union was building. Conflict in the Middle East was lessening. The world was cumulatively heading toward greater pluralism, individualism, prosperity and freedom.

headline: Trillion Dollar Fraudsters
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: The modern Republican Party’s raw fiscal dishonesty is something new in American politics.
lead_paragraph: By now it’s a Republican Party tradition: Every year the party produces a budget that allegedly slashes deficits, but which turns out to contain a trillion-dollar “magic asterisk” — a line that promises huge spending cuts and/or revenue increases, but without explaining where the money is supposed to come from.

headline: The Case for Free-Range Parenting
abstract: Why are Americans so afraid to give their kids room to roam?
lead_paragraph: BETHESDA, Md. — ON her first morning in America, last summer, my daughter went out to explore her new neighborhood — alone, without even telling my wife or me.

headline: Our Federal Policy on the Use of Ethanol
abstract: Readers discuss an Op-Ed essay that criticized a law promoting the use of ethanol.

headline: The Schneiderman Remedy for Sleaze
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: The attorney general’s ethics proposals represent a challenge to Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s repeated promises, and offer a chance for a real cleanup of Albany.
lead_paragraph: Calling for an end to “a golden age of graft” in Albany, Attorney General Eric Schneiderman of New York laid out a series of adventurous ethics proposals in a speech to Citizens Union on Monday. Though in some cases his ideas will need further exploration and debate, they represent a challenge to Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s promised reforms.

headline: U.S. Allies, Lured by China’s Bank
keywords: ['Editorials', 'United States International Relations', 'International Relations', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: In significant ways, the flocking of Western nations to a potential World Bank rival is a problem of America’s own making.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration, to its embarrassment, has been spurned by Western allies flocking to a China-led Asian development bank, defying White House pleas to stand back. In a surprise announcement last week, Britain said it would become the first Western nation to join the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, a potential rival to the American-led World Bank.

headline: Test Yourself | Wake Up and Dance
abstract: Here are several paragraphs from a March 13 article, “The Rise of Early-Morning Dance Parties.” Can you choose the best word for each blank?
lead_paragraph: Here are several paragraphs from a March 13 article, “The Rise of Early-Morning Dance Parties.”

headline: The Metro Areas With the Largest, and Smallest, Gay Populations
abstract: Western regions top the list, in perhaps the most detailed analysis yet of the demography of gay and lesbian America.
lead_paragraph: The Census Bureau asks Americans about subjects as varied as race, age, annual income and even their source of home heating. But there is one glaring demographic omission: The census does not ask people about their sexual orientation. As a result, there has long been a shroud of uncertainty around the geography of gay and lesbian Americans.

headline: Hackers Attack GreatFire.org, a Workaround for Websites Censored in China
abstract: Unidentified hackers have attacked GreatFire.org, a website that provides access to news websites blocked by China.
lead_paragraph: For years, a group of anonymous activists known as GreatFire.org has monitored online censorship in China, provided access to blocked websites and collected messages deleted by censors.

headline: ‘The Salt of the Earth’ Presents a Photographer’s Life and Lens, in Focus
abstract: “The Salt of the Earth,” directed by Wim Wenders and Juliano Salgado, examines the photography of Juliano’s father, Sebastião Salgado, and sometimes strained family dynamics.
lead_paragraph: The German film director Wim Wenders was walking down La Brea Avenue in Los Angeles one day in the mid-1980s when out of the corner of his eye he caught sight of some startling photographs in the window of a gallery. Intrigued, he immediately entered, learned that the photographer was a Brazilian named Sebastião Salgado, and emerged an hour later the owner of a pair of prints — one from Mr. Salgado’s now-celebrated Serra Pelada series from a gold mine in the Amazon, the other from the Sahel in Africa — that continue to this day to hang over the director’s desk in his Berlin office.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | The Next Frontier: The Great Indoors
abstract: When have you discovered an interesting organism inside your house? Describe what you found.
lead_paragraph: In “The Next Frontier: The Great Indoors,” Carl Zimmer writes about scientific interest in the indoor biome.

headline: Adam Horovitz, a Beastie Boy in Middle Age
abstract: The rapper plays an early-to-bed, stay-at-home New York dad in Noah Baumbach’s new movie, “While We’re Young.”
lead_paragraph: Longtime fans of the Beastie Boys could be forgiven for imagining that the rappers would be perennially young, forever New York’s impish hometown heroes, ollieing past authority on their way to after-hours fun.

headline: Amour by the Seine and the Nevada Desert
abstract: Jean Renoir’s unfinished masterwork, “A Day in the Country” (1936), evinces the director’s humanism; Billy Wilder’s “Kiss Me, Stupid” (1964) reflects its filmmaker’s cynicism.
lead_paragraph: Abandoned yet nearly perfect, Jean Renoir’s “A Day in the Country” (1936) is a movie whose incomplete aspects only accentuate its freshness and spontaneity.

headline: Cement Giants Holcim and Lafarge Say Merger Is Back on Track
abstract: The companies said they sweetened the deal for Holcim shareholders and agreed that Bruno Lafont, the Lafarge chief, would step aside.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Holcim and Lafarge, the two European cement giants, have broken a deadlock that threatened their merger plans, they said on Friday, expressing confidence that they would close the $46 billion deal this summer.

headline: At Least 32 Killed After Express Train Strikes Barrier in Northern India
abstract: Dozens of people were reported injured after two coaches and the engine derailed in Uttar Pradesh, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — An express train hit a safety barrier at a railway station in northern India on Friday morning, killing at least 32 people and injuring dozens more after two coach cars and the engine derailed, the authorities said.

headline: After the Kodak Moment
abstract: Kodak has prioritized its patent portfolio and the Eastman Business Park since it declared bankruptcy in 2012. Despite some success, the company might never live up to the legacy of its own past.
lead_paragraph: Kodak has prioritized its patent portfolio and the Eastman Business Park since it declared bankruptcy in 2012. Despite some success, the company might never live up to the legacy of its own past.

headline: Brazil’s Slumping Economy and Bribery Scandal Eat Away at Dilma Rousseff’s Popularity
abstract: President Rousseff is fighting for her political survival, as her approval rating falls and the national oil company she once oversaw reels from a corruption scandal.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — President Dilma Rousseff ran for office declaring that she would harness an oil bonanza in Brazil to supercharge the economy while avoiding the corruption and mismanagement that have plagued other oil-rich countries in the developing world.

headline: Mitch McConnell Makes Changes, but Senate Gridlock Remains
abstract: Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, has been impeded by internal struggles in his party and the hostility that awaits him across the aisle.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When he became majority leader, propelled by sweeping Republican victories last year, Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky vowed to run a more productive and traditional Senate than his Democratic predecessor, Senator Harry Reid of Nevada.

headline: Nigerian Army Noticeably Absent in Town Taken From Boko Haram
abstract: Soldiers from Chad and Niger had succeeded in chasing Boko Haram out of Damasak, Nigeria, but there was not a single Nigerian soldier to be found.
lead_paragraph: DAMASAK, Nigeria — Boko Haram’s black flag is everywhere in the town of Damasak, deep in Islamist-held territory in northern Nigeria: It is painted on former administrative buildings and schools, and on the side of abandoned gas stations.

headline: What Woman Would You Want to See on the $20 Bill?
abstract: Do you support the campaign to put a woman on the $20 bill? Why?
lead_paragraph: The year 2020 is the 100th anniversary of women gaining the right to vote in the United States, and a campaign has started to put a woman’s face on paper money — to replace Andrew Jackson on the $20 bill.

headline: Refusing to Give Up on Kodak
abstract: What happens after a tech company is left for dead but the people left behind refuse to give up? At Kodak the answer is to dig into its legacy of innovation.
lead_paragraph: What happens after a tech company is left for dead but the people left behind refuse to give up? At Kodak the answer is to dig into its legacy of innovation.

headline: At Kodak, Clinging to a Future Beyond Film
abstract: What happens when a tech company is left for dead but the people left behind refuse to give up? At Kodak, the answer is to mine its patents for gold. (With video.)
lead_paragraph: Of the roughly 200 buildings that once stood on the 1,300-acre campus of Eastman Kodak’s business park in Rochester, 80 have been demolished and 59 others sold off. Terry Taber, bespectacled, 60, and a loyal Kodak employee of 34 years, still works in one of the remaining Kodak structures, rubble from demolition not far from its doors.

headline: TSB to Recommend That Investors Accept Spanish Bank’s Takeover Offer
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Banco Sabadell would acquire 50 percent of the British lender’s outstanding shares from the Lloyds Banking Group, which spun off TSB last year.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — TSB Banking Group, the lender spun out of the Lloyds Banking Group last year, said on Friday that its directors had agreed to recommend that investors accept a takeover offer from Banco Sabadell of Spain that values it at 1.7 billion pounds, or about $2.5 billion.

headline: Biogen Reports Its Alzheimer’s Drug Sharply Slowed Cognitive Decline
abstract: The drug, developed by Biogen Idec, could achieve sales of billions of dollars a year if the results from the small trial are replicated in larger trials.
lead_paragraph: An experimental drug for Alzheimer’s disease sharply slowed the decline in mental function in a small clinical trial, researchers reported Friday, reviving hopes for an approach to therapy that until now has experienced repeated failures.

headline: Ask Well: Whiter Teeth
abstract: A reader asks: What is the healthiest and most effective way to whiten your teeth?
lead_paragraph: Question:

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get the Morning Briefing in your inbox first thing? Sign up.)

headline: Q. and A.: Chang-rae Lee on His Tale of Migrants From an Environmentally Ruined China
abstract: The Korean-American author’s new novel, “On Such a Full Sea,” centers on a Chinese woman named Fan who is a laborer in a city called B-Mor, a future version of Baltimore.
lead_paragraph: Starting with his first novel, “Native Speaker,” the Korean-American author Chang-rae Lee has written of immigrant experiences in the United States. His latest novel, “On Such a Full Sea,” centers on a Chinese woman named Fan who is a laborer in a city called B-Mor, a future version of Baltimore. The novel is a dystopian tale, set in an era when nations around the world are suffering from overwhelming environmental degradation. Fan is one of tens of thousands of Chinese from smog-choked Shanxi Province who have taken jobs as food production workers in B-Mor to escape their toxic homeland.

headline: New York Today: Unbeloved Sculptures
abstract: Friday and the weekend: A final snowy blast, a judge’s refusal in the Eric Garner case, and the week in pictures.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this final winter Friday.

headline: Gay America
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: A new analysis offers the most detailed estimates yet about where people who identify as gay, lesbian, bisexual or transgender live.
lead_paragraph: A new analysis offers the most detailed estimates yet about where people who identify as gay, lesbian, bisexual or transgender live.

headline: Foreign Liberators Control the Streets of Damasak
abstract: Soldiers from Chad and Niger liberated Damasak from Boko Haram this week after a fierce firefight, and were surprised by the absence of the Nigerian Army.
lead_paragraph: Soldiers from Chad and Niger liberated Damasak from Boko Haram this week after a fierce firefight, and were surprised by the absence of the Nigerian Army.

headline: Europeans (Carefully) Gaze Upward for Glimpse of the Solar Eclipse
abstract: As officials warned of possible power failures and encouraged people to view the phenomenon only through special glasses, excitement grew for the rare celestial event.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Crowds across Europe gazed skyward on Friday to witness a solar eclipse, one where the moon came between the earth and the sun and its shadow blocked the sun in its entirety at some viewing points.

headline: Outgoing Credit Suisse C.E.O. Took Slight Pay Cut in 2014
keywords: ['Executive Compensation', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Brady W. Dougan and other members of the bank’s executive board took a voluntary cut in incentive awards after the bank admitted in May that its bankers helped wealthy Americans avoid taxes.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Brady W. Dougan, the outgoing chief executive of Credit Suisse, took a slight pay cut in 2014 as the Swiss bank faced what it described as a “challenging” macroeconomic environment and saw its annual results hurt by legacy legal issues.

headline: Traitors to Their Class
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Minimum Wage', 'Income Inequality', 'Poverty', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: These Horatio Algerians for the new Gilded Age are virtuous because they made it, or vice versa. And those who haven’t managed a similar leap are just weaklings.
lead_paragraph: You probably know from his weepy reminiscences that the speaker of the House, John Boehner, once worked as a bartender and a janitor, and took seven years to get out of college. Maybe you’ve heard that Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin is a preacher’s son who churned out burgers and fries at McDonald’s. And you had to catch that bit from Senator Joni Ernst about putting bread bags over her shoes while growing up kind of poor in rural Iowa.

headline: 11 Books About Obsessive Searches
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Exploration and Explorers']
abstract: A selection of books wherein authors undertake journeys that might be described as inadvisable.
lead_paragraph: As the author of “Turn Right at Machu Picchu,” about a trek to find the lost city of the Incas along a relatively unknown route, and “Meet Me in Atlantis,” about amateur explorers’ passionate attempts to locate the sunken island metropolis, I’m intimately familiar with travel books that might be categorized as “obsessive quests.” My favorites are those written by authors who undertake adventures of their own. Here is a selection.

headline: Tranquil, Sandy Refuges From Bustling Santiago
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Beaches', 'Surfing', 'Seafood', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: Less than two and a half hours from Chile’s capital, along a Pacific Coast highway, are intimate beaches, boutique hotels and stunning vistas.
lead_paragraph: The 35-story-tall sand dunes of Concón are grand formations that took shape over millions of years, growing into seemingly insurmountable mounds that draw thrill-seeking sand-boarders and lumbering climbers alike.

headline: My Quest for Atlantis
abstract: Most visitors go to Gibraltar, Malta or Santorini for sun, seafood and relaxation. I was searching for something more elusive: the lost sunken city.
lead_paragraph: There’s nothing like a vigorous sea-to-summit hike up the Rock of Gibraltar to clear the jet-lagged mind, especially when you’re trying to solve a nearly 2,500-year-old mystery. Following the zigzagging lines on the colorful paper place mat I’d been handed at the Gibraltar welcome center when I’d asked for a map, I climbed a steep set of concrete and stone stairs high into the green solitude of the Upper Rock Nature Preserve. As the path cut through a thick tangle of scrub, the southern coast of Spain appeared to the west, far below. A little farther on, the view widened to take in the cinched waist of the Strait of Gibraltar. A few steps later, the northern shore of Africa emerged through the last of the morning’s light mist.

headline: Casino Dream
abstract: The discovery of a parent’s gambling addiction prompts a daughter to grow up.
lead_paragraph: Two months ago, my brother asked me if I remembered playing with our father when we were children. I don’t. I remember that my father left the house early in the morning and came back in the evening, late. He always brought some chocolate for me and always put it in the same place, the kitchen cabinet. He was the kind part of the family, with a low voice. I saw him as the calm of the evening. But memories change the facts.

headline: ‘Binoculars’
abstract: Selected by Natasha Trethewey
lead_paragraph: A flicker is a type of woodpecker, but here the poet captures the word’s multiple meanings: the actual bird, wavering light and, most profoundly, how the past returns again and again, as a momentary confrontation with the things memory and self-reflection — that telescopic, magnifying lens — will not let us forget. Poem selected by Natasha Trethewey.

headline: Re: Is Most of Our DNA Garbage?
keywords: ['DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Biology and Biochemistry', 'Creationism and Intelligent Design', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)']
abstract: Scientists and readers clashed over a biological debate depicted by Carl Zimmer.
lead_paragraph: Is there garbage in our genome? Carl Zimmer’s March 8 article about the debate in the scientific community over junk DNA sparked a conversation that spread to the blogs of half a dozen scientists.

headline: Recycling Unused Medicines to Save Money and Lives
abstract: A non-profit service makes it easier for health care agencies to send unused medications to the poor.
lead_paragraph: It always troubled Deane Kirchner to throw away good medicine. When residents of the Lincoln Glen long-term facility in San Jose, Calif., where she is the director of nursing, changed dosages, had adverse reactions, or died, she did what health professionals regularly do: sent their unused medicines to be destroyed.

headline: How to Negotiate a Prenup
abstract: Be nice, for starters. And sign all the paperwork at least a month before the wedding.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes in the thick of a messy and awkward prenuptial agreement negotiation, Laura A. Wasser, a Los Angeles-based family lawyer, reminds her clients: “This is not someone you got into a fender bender with. This is someone you want to spend your life with.” So be nice, for starters. Wasser pushes clients to sign all the paperwork at least a month before the wedding, but she suggests broaching the subject much earlier. “Sit down to talk with a good bottle of wine, but don’t drink so much that you end up drunk and fighting,” she says. “Bring it up when things are good, not when you’re bickering.”

headline: Daily Report: F.A.A. Gives Amazon Limited Permission on Drones
abstract: While Amazon can now move its tests from inside a warehouse, the retailer still has a long way to go to realize its vision of autonomous delivery drones.
lead_paragraph: Federal regulators have given Amazon a green light to begin testing drones, but it will most likely take years before the online retailer can start delivering packages from the air to peoples’ homes, writes Nick Wingfield.

headline: Morning Agenda: Bank of New York Mellon in Settlement
abstract: Bank of New York Mellon will settle a currency trade case for $714 million. | Holcim and Lafarge say their merger is back on track. | The bar exam is under scrutiny. | S.E.C. chief sees virtue in activist investors.
lead_paragraph: BANK OF NEW YORK MELLON IN SETTLEMENT | Federal and state authorities announced on Thursday that the Bank of New York Mellon would pay $714 million to settle accusations that it cheated government pension funds and other investors for more than a decade, DealBook’s Ben Protess reports. The settlement is part of a broader deal requiring the bank to dismiss some employees and overhaul its foreign exchange operation.

headline: Today in Politics: With Talk of Building Ties, Clinton Draws Subtle Contrast With Obama
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton, a Washingtonian for more than two decades, is increasingly discussing her memories of a gentler era of legislative deal-making in a positive light.
lead_paragraph: Good Friday morning from Washington, where the National Cherry Blossom Festival officially begins despite a forecast of flurries. Congress is busy finding creative new ways to approve spending without voting, and there’s a very good chance a potential presidential candidate is streaming live video right now on an app called Meerkat. If that sounds too “Back to the Future” for you, at least one person who might like to move back to the White House is yearning for the good old days of bipartisanship.

headline: No Child Left Behind Law Faces Its Own Reckoning
keywords: ['No Child Left Behind Act', 'Education (K-12)', 'Tests and Examinations', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Aid (US)']
abstract: A rewrite could collapse in partisan disarray. But it could also herald a new era of education, keeping some testing but eliminating prescriptive punishments.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Ginn Academy, the first and only public high school in Ohio just for boys, was conceived to help at-risk students make it through school — experimenting with small classes, a tough discipline code and life coaches around the clock.

headline: HSBC to Shuffle Board Roles of Several Directors
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The changes come as Simon Robertson stays on for a final year as deputy chairman, but gives up several leadership roles on board committees.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British bank HSBC said on Friday that it planned to shuffle the roles of several members of its board of directors.

headline: For Europe, a Rare Glimpse at a Total Solar Eclipse

lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — An affiliate of the Islamic State that had not previously carried out any major attacks claimed responsibility for coordinated suicide strikes on Zaydi Shiite mosques here that killed more than 130 people during Friday Prayer, bringing to Yemen the kind of deadly sectarian fighting that has ripped apart Syria and Iraq.

headline: When the 13-Year-Old Picks a $14 Million Condo
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Families and Family Life', 'Children and Childhood', 'Real Estate Brokers']
abstract: Teens and preteens are getting involved in finding multimillion-dollar homes for their families, and in a few instances, doing everything but writing the check.
lead_paragraph: A year and a half ago, Skye van Merkensteijn was shooting hoops with a friend who lives at the Aldyn, a condominium-rental hybrid on Riverside Boulevard with its own indoor basketball court, climbing wall and bowling alley.

headline: An Online Sale Collects Rare Vintage Men’s Accoutrements from Hermes, Cartier and More
abstract: Paddle8’s “Gentlemen’s Accessories” collection, culled by the vintage impresario Alan Bedwell, includes quirky and beautiful items.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, an online sale put together by the vintage impresario Alan Bedwell for the auction site Paddle8 proves it’s the accessories that separate the man from the gentleman. Bedwell, the founder of the vintage accessories brand Foundwell, pulled together a range of vintage and antique items — equally practical and whimsical — to outfit the proper bar, desk and dressing room. For drinks, there’s an opulent sterling silver and crystal Champagne bottle from 1898, alongside a quirky 1960s Cartier flowerpot jigger. According to Bedwell, “a beautiful letter opener should be a part of anyone’s desk,” and the sale has several to offer, including an 1898 model bearing the brand “DuPont Explosives” and another created in 1970 by Hermès in a comically extended dachshund shape. An equally lively pair of French agate hamburger cufflinks from the ’70s are fun, but exquisitely crafted — each element was hand-cut, dyed and polished. The real standouts, though, act as conversation starters, like an ’80s Asprey rubber-band gun and a silver-plated peanut dish from the ’50s. “You do stumble across these amazing crazy pieces every now and then,” Bedwell says, “and you just think, ‘Wow, I can’t believe somebody actually sat down and made that.'”

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments

lead_paragraph: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

lead_paragraph: When Eric Perlberg, a photographer, decided to retire and renovate his London apartment, he thought about the best attributes of places where he had lived throughout his life: SoHo and Woodstock in New York, and Basel, Switzerland.

headline: Rolling With the Punches, at Any Stage of Life
abstract: Most people recover after even the most difficult changes, but it’s easier to bounce back if you have emotional, social and financial resources.
lead_paragraph: OVER the last eight years, Teresa Mears has cycled through enough change to last a lifetime: a partner’s death, helping to care for a mother with Alzheimer’s, leaving a steady job just before the recession hit, and the loss of her house.

keywords: ['Child Car Seats', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Consumer Protection', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Fines (Penalties)']

lead_paragraph: Graco Children’s Products has agreed to pay $10 million to settle claims that it failed to recall promptly about four million child car seats with a defective buckle that could make it difficult to free a child in an emergency, federal regulators said on Friday.

headline: Review: Joyce DiDonato Blends Bel Canto and Emotion at Carnegie Hall
abstract: Ms. DiDonato, sharing the stage with the Philadelphia Orchestra, wrapped up her Perspectives series in New York with arias and scenes from bel canto operas.
lead_paragraph: Detractors of the bel canto style typically dislike it because, they argue, it is only that: beautiful singing. In the music of composers like Donizetti and Bellini the action stops and words take a back seat. All that matters, for the duration of an aria, is the glory of the human voice and its ability to dart up and down octaves while dashing off trills and other ornaments in a fizzy display of vocal pyrotechnics.

headline: Latest Iran Talks End Without a Deal
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']
abstract: No initial agreement was reached on limiting Iran’s nuclear program, but the negotiations will resume next week in Switzerland.
lead_paragraph: LAUSANNE, Switzerland — An intensive round of talks on limiting Iran’s nuclear program ended abruptly on Friday with the two sides still divided over some important issues.

headline: What Else Can We Add to a Smoothie?
abstract: Over the years, Martha Rose Shulman has taught us that you can add pretty much anything to a smoothie, including nuts, seeds and an array of vegetables. Now she blends in a new addition — grains.
lead_paragraph: Over the years I have given you a number of Recipes for Health devoted to smoothies – fruit smoothies with nuts and seeds; smoothies with vegetables; dairy free smoothies. I thought I had pretty much covered all the smoothie bases. Then I came across a recipe for a “Fresh Peach, Banana and Warm Millet Smoothie” in Bryant Terry’s impressive new cookbook “Afro-Vegan,” and a bell went off. Cooked millet in a smoothie? I had never seen such a thing; yet breakfast is a great meal for cooked grains, and also for smoothies. So why not? Adding cooked grains to smoothies would be a perfect way to thicken the drinks and bulk them up. It’s also a delicious way to incorporate more grains into your diet.

headline: After Backtracking on Trans-Atlantic Flights, Ryanair Learns Its Lessons
abstract: While airline executives had discussed loose plans to create such long-haul flights, the project had never been formally discussed by its board.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — In the little more than a year since Ryanair made a belated push into the digital age, the Irish budget airline has adopted an arsenal of tools aimed at improving communications with the flying public.

H. Mumm Company, sold for $24,500,000 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In 2008, faced with increased competition from Vietnam and China, catfish producers in the United States did the unthinkable: They asked for more regulation of their industry.

headline: Winter Vegetables for Spring Holidays
abstract: There’s a place for red radishes, cauliflower and carrots at the table for Easter and Passover.
lead_paragraph: It’s that time of year again, on the East Coast at least, when spring is in the air but not in your shopping basket.

headline: 1890: Hotel de Balzac Demolition
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: The Hôtel de Balzac in Paris was demolished in 1890.
lead_paragraph: One of the landmarks of literary and historic Paris is now being removed. This is the hotel at the junction of the rue Berryer, rue de Balzac and rue du faubourg St. Honoré, formerly the residence of Balzac, from whom it took the name Hotel de Balzac. The hotel proper, which stood in a garden hid from the street, has already been demolished, while the more recently erected structure on the street is shortly to have the same fate. Of this mansion, which with its carved stonework, ogival windows and massive, iron knobbed door, and finally its desolate appearance, rendered the feature of the upper part of the faubourg, only a small portion, containing carved woodwork of great value, will be left standing. — The New York Herald, European Edition, March 21, 1890

headline: ‘Thrift,’ by Andrew L. Yarrow
abstract: A history of the 20th-century American thrift movement.
lead_paragraph: National Thrift Week, originally organized by the Y.M.C.A. in 1917, was the signature event of a nationwide moral crusade by elites to mold Americans’ behaviors. During seven days centered on Benjamin Franklin’s Jan. 17 birthday, thrift advocates taught people how to open savings accounts, buy insurance, purchase homes, pay bills promptly and share with others. By the early 1920s, Thrift Week was observed by more than a thousand cities in the United States, and still more around the globe. Thrift was put forward as the antidote to many of the nation’s perceived ills: working-class radicalism, urban poverty, squandering of natural resources and excessive consumerism.

headline: Spring Is Due at 6:45 P.M., With Snow
abstract: A storm system expected to bring several inches to New York City on Friday, with the heaviest snowfall during the evening rush, is coinciding with the vernal equinox.
lead_paragraph: Go home.

lead_paragraph: BREAK your financial life into chapters. Assign a high point, a low point and a turning point to each chapter. What’s the story and what stands out?

headline: Mortgage Amounts Rising More Quickly Than Home Prices

lead_paragraph: Mortgage amounts are rising more quickly than home prices, an unusual phenomenon that seems to confirm continued weakness at the lower end of the housing market, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association.

headline: Breast Milk Becomes a Commodity, With Mothers Caught Up in Debate
abstract: Researchers say the milk is brimming with potential therapeutic agents, for babies and also possibly adults.
lead_paragraph: CITY OF INDUSTRY, Calif. — When Gretty Amaya took an unpaid maternity leave five months ago, she started what she calls a part-time job to help pay the bills. Ms. Amaya, who lives in Miami, has made more than $2,000 so far by pumping breast milk and selling what is left over after feeding her baby daughter.
