abstract: This week, Ron Lieber discusses “The Opposite of Spoiled”; Alexandra Alter has news from the literary world; Harris Irfan talks about “Heaven’s Bankers”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Ron Lieber discusses “The Opposite of Spoiled”; Alexandra Alter has news from the literary world; Harris Irfan talks about “Heaven’s Bankers”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Judi Dench Joins Cast of Live Election-Night Play in Britain
abstract: Judi Dench joins the cast of “The Vote,” which will be broadcast live during the final hours of the British election on May 7.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In the very moments that Britons cast their vote for the next Parliament, a Dame will flicker across the nation’s TV screens.

headline: Afghan Leader Said to Be Centralizing Power as Unity Government Plan Stalls
abstract: Although President Ashraf Ghani’s aides deny the accusations, there is growing concern that cooperating with his rival, Abdullah Abdullah, is not high on his list.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Through a tumultuous first six months as president of Afghanistan, Ashraf Ghani has been living up to his promises to transform the office. But rather than decentralizing the post’s powers, as he had vowed, he has instead been quietly creating an even more dominant presidency, according to a range of current and former Afghan officials.

headline: ‘Heaven’s Bankers,’ by Harris Irfan
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Islamic finance is revolutionizing the world economy.
lead_paragraph: Tell non-Muslims or people who work outside the financial industry that you write about Islamic finance, and you will almost certainly receive one of two reactions (not including blank stares). The first — in which people assume Islamic finance is synonymous with or inherently linked to the bankrolling of terrorism — is both the most depressing and the most easily dismissed, because it is untrue. People slightly more familiar with Islam might have some notion that Islamic finance entails interest-­free banking, but beyond that things get murky pretty quickly.

headline: ‘The Seventh Day,’ by Yu Hua
abstract: In Yu Hua’s novel, the dead who can’t afford burial wander aimlessly in the afterworld.
lead_paragraph: In Yu Hua’s surreal, mordant novel “The Seventh Day,” the victims of China’s ­explosively expanding market economy include the still conscious, still suffering, still impoverished dead. They can’t afford burial plots. They’ve been separated from their families and uprooted from their ­ancestral homes. Unable to be mourned in the proper Chinese way, they’re fated to roam a “hazy, indistinct city” where snow swirls around their legs and they have the opportunity to reflect upon their lives and the circumstances of their deaths. The limping shades may then encounter the dead former friends and loved ones who also inhabit this characteristically ­Chinese mega-necropolis.

headline: The Way We Read Now
abstract: Recent global economic woes have brought the subject of money back into fashion in fiction.
lead_paragraph: This week, the Book Review looks at the ways we make, spend and obsess over money in its second annual Money Issue.

headline: Take the Money and Run
abstract: In Michael Robotham’s “Life or Death,” an inmate escapes the day before his scheduled release.
lead_paragraph: The career criminals in genre novels don’t have money problems. If they need some, they just go out and steal it. But such financial transactions can backfire, which is what happened back in 2004 when the Texas gang in Michael Robotham’s LIFE OR DEATH (Mulholland/Little, Brown, $26) robbed $7 million from an armored truck. That ill-fated enterprise ended with four people dead. One robber was shot and captured alive, but the surviving gang member was never seen again and the money was never recovered.

headline: ‘The Opposite of Spoiled,’ by Ron Lieber
abstract: How to talk with children about money.
lead_paragraph: I’m one of those people who are overcome with a strange combination of discomfort and ennui whenever they think about their children and money. Each time my husband brings up the topic of allowance, I wriggle out of the conversation, all but “la la la”-ing with my hands over my ears. Now I find I’m not alone. In his new book, “The Opposite of Spoiled,” Ron Lieber suggests that our unease about money prevents us from raising fiscally responsible kids. Open dialogue, he suggests, is the answer. Ask your children questions; listen to their answers. So I tried it. My husband and I waylaid our 16-year-old daughter, Lucy, as she headed out the door. “How much do you think we earn every year?” we asked. Lucy, who’s a pretty smart, sophisticated kid, replied after a moment’s thought: “Maybe around $10,000?” I don’t need to have an open dialogue with you, dear reader, but I will confess that’s not quite our income. I began to see how in the dark I have kept my children about our finances.

headline: ‘The Great Beanie Baby Bubble,’ by Zac Bissonnette
abstract: A history of the Beanie Baby phenomenon.
lead_paragraph: Beanie Babies, the small stuffed animals that retailed for $5, were introduced in 1993 and soon languished with mediocre sales. Then, a handful of neighbors in the Chicago suburbs discovered that each had a small collection and started trading with one another. They established some informal rules: Two Tabasco the Bull Beanies were equivalent to one of the rarer Kiwi the Toucan Beanies. Their trading spread and, eventually, went national. There were articles and TV segments about moms and dads who traded a $5 toy for thousands of dollars. Peggy Gallagher, an early trader, discovered that the Beanie craze hadn’t hit Germany yet and placed an order with a distributor in Nuremberg. She paid $2,000, including shipping, for a box of the toys that, back in the United States, had a value of $300,000, a return of nearly 15,000 percent. If she were a hedge fund trader with those numbers, she’d be the talk of Wall Street for generations. Instead, she was the talk of countless parents, who came to believe they, too, could fund their kids’ college education or an early retirement if they just got their hands on the right Beanies. The frenzy coincided with the start of eBay and the rise of home Internet use. Early on, Beanie Babies represented 10 percent of eBay’s sales.

headline: Filthy Lucre
abstract: New books by Michael Crummey, Jonas Lüscher and Jonas Karlsson.
lead_paragraph: SWEETLAND

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE LAST FLIGHT OF POXL WEST, by Daniel Torday. (St. Martin’s, $25.99.) A World War II memoir by Torday’s protagonist, a Jewish bomber pilot with the British Royal Air Force, is this utterly accomplished first novel’s book-within-a-book.

headline: ‘The Monopolists,’ by Mary Pilon
abstract: The story of Monopoly, and the woman unrecognized for her role in its creation.
lead_paragraph: The national card game of the world’s first market democracy naturally turned out to be poker, in part because money is its language, raison d’être and means of keeping score. Our favorite board game, of course, is Monopoly, which has also gone global, and for similar reasons. Played by everyone from Jerry Hall and Mick ­Jagger to Carmela and Tony Soprano, it apparently scratches an itch to wheel and deal few of us can reach in real life. The game is sufficiently redolent of capitalism that in 1959 Fidel Castro ordered the ­destruction of every Monopoly set in Cuba, while these days Vladimir Putin seems to be its ultimate aficionado.

headline: Karen E. Bender’s ‘Refund’
abstract: Money (who has it, who doesn’t) is the dark heart of these tales.
lead_paragraph: Money is ostensibly the fuel that powers Karen E. Bender’s new collection, “Refund.” In the title story, a couple falsely advertises a TriBeCa sublet just before 9/11 to pay for a fancy nursery school. In “Reunion,” a woman impulsively buys an unseen plot of land on credit. Smaller risks prove to be, if not turning points, then those moments remembered in relief as emblematic of the Before — splurging on beef Wellington for supper, say, or setting up a kids’ lemonade stand — by those now living in the After. The theme works as an organizing tenet, but Bender’s subtler preoccupation is the eroding effect of emotional want.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: MY PROMISED LAND: The Triumph and Tragedy of Israel, by Ari Shavit. (Spiegel & Grau, $17.) Drawing on historical documents, interviews and private diaries and letters — as well as his own family’s story — Shavit, a columnist for Haaretz, examines the entirety of the Israeli experience, expressing both solidarity with and criticism of his countrymen. “Shavit’s book is an extended test of his own capacity to maintain his principles in full view of the brutality that surrounds them,” Leon Wieseltier wrote here.

headline: ‘Wake Up Happy Every Day,’ by Stephen May
abstract: After the death of a wealthy businessman, a childhood friend assumes his identity.
lead_paragraph: There’s a reason many readers will forgive the comic novel a clunky narrative structure or uneven pacing; a reason they’ll forgive a predisposition to tangents, tics or lack of emotional depth. The reason is simple — because funny is hard, both to execute and to resist.

headline: ‘The Looting Machine,’ by Tom Burgis
abstract: How Africa’s mineral abundance enriches the few at the expense of the rest.
lead_paragraph: Back in the Mobutu era, I worked as a stringer in Kinshasa, the capital of what was then Zaire. “So, what do they want?” my driver Pierre would ask whenever I exited a Western embassy after a chat with a diplomat. “What’s the plan?” His question captured the sense of powerlessness that pervaded the country, a product of Big Man rule, Cold War interference and brutal colonial experience. If there was something of which Pierre felt certain, it was that he was not master of his fate.

headline: ‘Coined,’ by Kabir Sehgal
abstract: A wide-ranging survey of money’s various functions, from medium of exchange to cultural artifact.
lead_paragraph: “Nothing had an effect on people like money,” recalled a Stanford neuroscientist who once experimented with scanning people’s brain activity while they played high-stakes financial games. “Not naked bodies, not corpses. It got people riled up. Like food provides motivation for dogs, money provides it for people.”

headline: ‘God’s Bankers,’ by Gerald Posner
abstract: Gerald Posner offers a financial history of the Roman Catholic Church.
lead_paragraph: Ask a devout, theologically literate ­Roman Catholic to describe the institution of the church, and you’re likely to be told that it was founded by Jesus Christ at the moment he gave his disciple ­Peter the “keys to the kingdom of heaven” and vowed that “whatever you bind on earth will be bound in heaven.” This made ­Peter the head of the universal church, ­empowered to administer the sacraments, spread the Gospel, save souls and forgive sins until Christ’s return, as well as to pronounce with infallible authority on ­matters of Christian faith and morals. Christ also promised Peter that “the gates of hell shall not prevail” against the church — meaning that no matter how corrupt the institution might appear at any given moment of history, it will never be so consumed by evil that it ceases to be capable of fulfilling its God-appointed tasks.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Dennis Lehane is still closely identified with his native Boston, but his novel “World Gone By,” No. 8 on the hardcover fiction list, is set mostly in Florida and Cuba.
lead_paragraph: Snow and Mo: Dennis Lehane’s new novel, “World Gone By,” enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 8. Lehane remains closely identified with his native Boston, but this historical thriller — which continues a series about the fictional gangster Joe Coughlin — is set mostly in Florida and Cuba, while Lehane himself moved to Southern California a year and a half ago. He recently told The Hollywood Reporter that he was sorry to miss his hometown’s record snowfall this winter. “Bostonians, for better or worse, tend to like hard things,” he said. “You don’t really feel like something is fully worthwhile unless it’s hard-earned. It’s that sense of working-class pride, which, yeah, can be kind of annoying but can be really cool. So when I saw my friends emailing about getting the snow record, I thought, ‘What a bunch of sick bastards,’ but I really dig it. I’m jealous I’m not there, in a way.” Lehane added that his pleasure reading these days is confined to children’s books. “The go-to guy is Mo Willems,” he said. “Anyone outside of the children’s world has no idea who Mo Willems is. I didn’t. But anyone who has kids, he literally takes you from the very first book to all these great books I’m reading with my 5-year-old. He’s the Dr. Seuss of our time.”

headline: On ‘Empire': The Show, the Music and the Calamitous Finale
abstract: Jon Caramanica and Gilbert Cruz, of The New York Times, and Justin Charity, a writer at Complex, discuss the first season of “Empire.”
lead_paragraph: This week on Popcast: Reviewing the first season of “Empire,” which came to a calamitous end on Wednesday night with a two-hour episode that – spoiler alert – featured a murder, an attempted murder, an announced pregnancy and an arrest. The show has been renewed for a second season, and it will likely take the several months before it returns to process all that happened – “Empire” moves quickly, and does not stop for explanations.

headline: Akademgorodok
abstract: Inside the nuclear-physics laboratories in Akademgorodok, Siberia’s education capital.
lead_paragraph: Inside the nuclear-physics laboratories in Akademgorodok, Siberia’s education capital.

headline: What I Love | Megan Fairchild and Andrew Veyette
keywords: ['Dancing', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']

headline: New Federal Rules Are Set for Fracking
keywords: ['Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'States (US)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The Interior Department began drafting the rules during President Obama’s first term after the technology led to a surge in the production of oil and gas.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Friday unveiled the nation’s first major federal regulations on hydraulic fracturing, a technique for oil and gas drilling that has led to a significant increase in American energy production but has also raised concerns about health and safety risks.

headline: Why Is British Economic Discourse So Bad?
abstract: VSPs still living in 2011.
lead_paragraph: Still at SXSW, which accounts for lack of blog posts — I mean, seize the day and all that. Not much action this morning, except a discussion with Snoop Dogg, which I’m not going to; but whenever I think about Mr. Dogg, I think about Alan Simpson. Which brings me to the subject of this post.

headline: Nick Cave Goes Straight to Fans With ‘The Sick Bag Song’
keywords: ['Music', 'Books and Literature', 'E-Commerce', 'Poetry and Poets', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: An epic poem about Mr. Cave and his rock band’s tour across the United States in 2014, the new book will be marketed through its own website.
lead_paragraph: Nick Cave, the Australian-born poet, novelist, actor, composer and rock band frontman, has been known to cross-pollinate his various creative pursuits. His 2009 novel about a sex-addicted beauty product salesman, “The Death of Bunny Munro,” was available as an iPhone app that blended text with an audiobook narrated by Mr. Cave, set to music by one of his fellow band members. His book tour featured live music.

headline: The Strange Beauty of Soviet-Era Nuclear Relics
abstract: Pablo Ortiz Monasterio photographs the colorful labs of a scientific outpost in Siberia.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, the Russian government invited the Mexican photographer Pablo Ortiz Monasterio to come and photograph the country in advance of the Group of 20 summit meeting in Moscow. Ortiz Monasterio proposed a project on “brilliant minds,” documenting the people who work in the country’s space program or on nuclear submarines.

headline: Playful Parting Gifts Show Heads Aren’t Inflated at the Fed
abstract: Two retiring Fed members, who have repeatedly warned about inflation, were given hats with the word “hawks” prominently displayed.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve delivered a clever parting gift to a pair of retiring reserve bank presidents who have repeatedly warned it is heading down a path that may lead to dangerous inflation.

headline: A New Documentary Shines a Light On the Artist Who Gave Shape to Eloise
abstract: The film, which premieres Monday on HBO, captures the life and work of the 88-year-old illustrator Hilary Knight.
lead_paragraph: “Fantasy is probably the most important drive in my life,” Hilary Knight says in “It’s Me, Hilary: The Man Who Drew Eloise,” an HBO documentary that offers a unique view into the one-of-a-kind mind of the illustrator behind the “Eloise” books. Produced by Lena Dunham, whose friendship with Knight began through her love of Eloise, the six-year-old resident of the Plaza Hotel whose antics were featured in a series of children’s books first published in 1955, the film creates a portrait of a man whose life and art are completely intertwined. Over 35 minutes, it traces Knight’s childhood as the son of two illustrators, the creation of Eloise, his creative tussles with the “Eloise” writer Kay Thompson and a post-Eloise career that’s included work for Vanity Fair, the publication of his own books and the illustration of posters for Broadway shows like “Gypsy.” Most compelling are the scenes of Hilary moving through his magically curated home, decorated with staged bird nests, an underwater-themed bathroom and countless pieces of his parents’ work, dressing up in a full gorilla suit or directing a short musical film in his backyard.

headline: Stuff We Liked
abstract: Among the Web gems this week were maps about sunlight and measurements about laughter at the Fed.
lead_paragraph: We spotted many wonderful things around the web this week.

headline: We’re Frighteningly in the Dark About Student Debt
abstract: A $1 trillion portfolio threatens taxpayers because the Education Department can’t properly analyze its loans and doesn’t let other agencies do so.
lead_paragraph: Imagine that a big, complicated company holds a huge portfolio of loans, many of which are in default or delinquency. The company’s leadership and some vocal shareholders demand a detailed review but receive a thin and incomplete report from the loan division.

headline: Netanyahu's History on Palestinian Statehood
abstract: On the eve of the recent Israeli election, the prime minister said that no Palestinian state would be created on his watch. Two days later, he began to backtrack.
lead_paragraph: On the eve of the recent Israeli election, the prime minister said that no Palestinian state would be created on his watch. Two days later, he began to backtrack.

headline: Too Old to Commit Crime?
abstract: Research shows that most criminals, even violent ones, mature out of lawbreaking before middle age, suggesting long sentences do little to prevent crime.
lead_paragraph: DZHOKHAR TSARNAEV is facing the death penalty or life in prison for the Boston Marathon bombing. But what if, instead, the maximum prison sentence were just 21 years?

headline: Netanyahu Tactics Anger Many U.S. Jews, Deepening a Divide
abstract: Even many supporters said they were appalled at the Israeli prime minister’s warning about Arab voters and his renunciation of a two-state solution.
lead_paragraph: Long before the latest election in Israel, Benjamin Netanyahu was a polarizing figure among American Jews. But even many of his supporters said this week that they were appalled at his last-minute bid to mobilize Jewish voters by warning that Arabs were going to the polls in droves, and his renunciation of a two-state solution to the Palestinian crisis.

headline: Megan Fairchild, Ballet Dancer, at Home in Westchester
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: Megan Fairchild and Andrew Veyette, principal dancers with New York City Ballet, live in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Just so there are no misunderstandings, Megan Fairchild, a principal dancer with New York City Ballet, is thrilled about making her Broadway debut in the acclaimed revival of the 1944 musical “On the Town.” She loves playing the would-be actress Ivy Smith, a.k.a. Miss Turnstiles; she loves her cast mates, loves adding a different sort of role to her extensive résumé.

headline: 5 Babies Found Dead in French Village
abstract: The bodes, four of them hidden in a freezer, were found in a home in Louchats, a rural village in southern France.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The bodies of five babies, including four hidden in a freezer, were discovered in a house in southern France after a man told the police he had found the corpse of a baby in a cooler bag in his home, a senior police official said Friday.

headline: Azzedine Alaïa’s Collection
abstract: During four mini-shows that culminated just after Paris Fashion Week, Azzedine Alaïa presented pieces that demanded an intimate viewing.
lead_paragraph: During four mini-shows that culminated just after Paris Fashion Week, Azzedine Alaïa presented pieces that demanded an intimate viewing.

headline: At Alaïa, Clothes That Are Ready for Their Close-Ups
abstract: During four mini-shows that culminated just after Paris Fashion Week, Azzedine Alaïa presented pieces that demanded an intimate viewing.
lead_paragraph: Paris Fashion Week officially ended on March 11, but for fashion insiders it lasted until last Monday — the final day of Azzedine Alaïa’s series of four minishows. Though they took place off-schedule — Mr. Alaïa has his own time clock, and holds presentations when, and if, a collection is ready; never before — they were, for those who got to see them, entirely on point.

headline: French Court Orders Picasso’s Electrician to Return Nearly 300 Artworks
abstract: A court rules that Picasso’s electrician and his wife must return artworks that are considered stolen.
lead_paragraph: PARIS – A court in the town of Grasse in southern France on Friday found a retired electrician and his wife guilty of possessing 271 stolen works by Pablo Picasso, rejecting the couple’s claims that the trove of art was a gift from the artist’s wife.

lead_paragraph: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshot’s weekly newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

lead_paragraph: This week, Ron Lieber and Harris Irfan.

headline: 1915: Zeppelins Attack Paris
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Zeppelins attack Paris in 1915.
lead_paragraph: It was announced early this morning [March 21] that, despite the measures taken to guard against a Zeppelin raid over Paris, two of these German dirigibles succeeded in reaching the capital soon after midnight. Two incendiary bombs were dropped in the rue Dulong and the rue des Dames, in the Batignolles quarter, but they did not cause any fire. A fire broke out, however, in a house in the rue Chauveau, at Neuilly, just outside of Paris, and this is believed to be due to another incendiary bomb.

headline: Richard Fisher, Often Wrong but Seldom Boring, Leaves the Fed
abstract: The departure of Mr. Fisher, who stepped down on Thursday, means that the Fed is losing the most outspoken internal opponent of its stimulus campaign.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — In a decade as president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, Richard W. Fisher was frequently mistaken in his economic predictions but seldom boring.

keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Ms. Viner succeeds Alan Rusbridger, who oversaw the paper for 20 years.
lead_paragraph: The Guardian appointed its first female editor on Friday, giving Katharine Viner, the current editor in chief of The Guardian’s United States operation, the job of leading the liberal British newspaper and media group as it seeks to expand its global ambitions.

abstract: The sturgeon spearfishing season at Lake Winnebago, the largest lake in Wisconsin, attracts ice fishermen to the lake and relatives and neighbors to the check-ins.
lead_paragraph: The sturgeon spearfishing season at Lake Winnebago, the largest lake in Wisconsin, attracts ice fishermen to the lake and relatives and neighbors to the check-ins.

headline: Sturgeon and the Spear
abstract: The sturgeon spearfishing season at Lake Winnebago, the largest lake in Wisconsin, attracts ice fishermen to the lake and relatives and neighbors to the check-ins.
lead_paragraph: It had been four years since Steve Krueger speared a sturgeon, but the outlook in his shanty was brighter this year. In the first four days of the 2015 Winnebago lake system spearing season in Wisconsin, his friends and family caught and registered three.

headline: A TV Version of the Noah’s Ark Story That Chooses Restraint Over Rain
abstract: The UP network’s latest telling of the ancient tale acquits itself well.
lead_paragraph: The UP channel, expanding its efforts to grab some of the family-and-faith market, acquits itself pretty well Sunday night with “Noah’s Ark,” a film treatment of the religious story that relies on restraint and credible performances rather than literal and figurative thunder and lightning. Not a drop of precipitation falls until the final 10 minutes in this version of the oft-told tale; the focus is on a man’s personal ordeal rather than God’s rainy wrath.

headline: European Lawmaker Pushes Europe to Take Stronger Stance on Google
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Search Engines']
abstract: The antitrust case against Google in Europe has already gained more traction than in the United States. But like their American counterparts, competition officials at the European Commission in Brussels have been loath to bring formal charges against such a successful and powerful company.
lead_paragraph: An outspoken European critic of Google said Friday that European Union antitrust regulators should bring formal charges against Google, after new documents showed that a report had recommended an American agency take a similar step three years ago.

headline: Hillary Clinton Reaching Out to Catholics

lead_paragraph: In what could signal a coming pitch for the Catholic vote, Hillary Rodham Clinton met last week with Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan, the archbishop of New York, and on Monday she sat near the Rev. John I. Jenkins, president of the University of Notre Dame, at a St. Patrick’s Day-themed luncheon.

headline: Gene-Altered Apples and Potatoes Are Safe, F.D.A. Says
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration said that genetically engineered nonbrowning apples and bruise-resistant potatoes were as safe and nutritious as their conventional counterparts.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration said on Friday that genetically engineered nonbrowning apples and bruise-resistant potatoes were as safe and nutritious as their conventional counterparts.

headline: Off-Duty Officer Among 2 Killed in a Wrong-Way Crash on Staten Island
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Drunken and Reckless Driving', 'Police']
abstract: A car carrying four people, three of whom were off-duty officers in the Linden, N.J., Police Department, collided with a tractor-trailer early Friday morning.
lead_paragraph: A car carrying three off-duty New Jersey police officers who had been at a Staten Island strip club hurtled the wrong way down an expressway early on Friday before colliding head-on with a tractor-trailer, killing one officer and another person in the car, the authorities said.

headline: NBC’s ‘The Slap’ Finds Resonance in Park Slope, Brooklyn
abstract: The NBC mini-series about a man who slapped another family’s unruly child has prompted heated conversation in the neighborhood, where children on scooters have a menacing history.
lead_paragraph: One day last month, Louise Crawford, a 56-year-old with two grown children, was walking southward on Seventh Avenue in Brooklyn when a boy came hurtling toward her on a scooter at Nascar speed. This was already vividly contested space — Park Slope, where children on scooters have a long and menacing history and some people have practically called for legal interdiction. On this particular occasion, Ms. Crawford leapt out of the way, toward a Citibank, to avoid getting hit and in the moment, much to her surprise, found herself hurling a particularly non-PG expletive at her little would-be assailant. (The phrase she used began with, “Get the,” and ended with, “off the street.”)

headline: A Scary Movie: Filling Your 401(k) With Company Stock
keywords: ['Personal Finances', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', '401(k), 403(b) and 457 Plans', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Employer stock in 401(k) plans is less common than it used to be, but it’s still in plenty of them, including the plan at RadioShack, which filed for bankruptcy protection last month.
lead_paragraph: We’ve seen the movie before, when employees of Enron and Lehman Brothers lost large sums of money in their 401(k) plans because of investments in company stock. And now, coming to a theater (and, inevitably, a courtroom) near you, is a sequel, surely not the last, this time featuring RadioShack.

headline: ‘Draft Joe Biden’ Group Urges Race Against Hillary Clinton
abstract: Amid Hillary Rodham Clinton’s email problems and Senator Elizabeth Warren’s reluctance to run for president, the “Draft Joe Biden” movement is getting real.
lead_paragraph: Amid Hillary Rodham Clinton’s email problems and Senator Elizabeth Warren’s reluctance to run for president, the “Draft Joe Biden” movement is getting real.

headline: Pirelli’s Largest Shareholder Is Said to Be in Talks With China National Chemical
abstract: Camfin is said to be in talks to sell its stake in the Italian tire maker, in a deal that could pave the way for a full takeover of Pirelli.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The holding company Camfin, the largest shareholder of the Italian tire maker Pirelli, is in talks to sell its stake in the company to China National Chemical Corporation in a deal that could pave the way for a full takeover of Pirelli, according to a person briefed on the discussions.

headline: SXSW Music 2015: And Now for a Hiatus, at Willie Nelson’s Ranch
keywords: ['Country Music', 'Music', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: Heartbreaker Banquet is a smaller, more intimate music festival, with performances by at Nikki Lane, Heartless Bastards, Angel Olsen and Hamilton Leithauser, of the Walkmen.
lead_paragraph: LUCK, Tex. — I wanted a break from the music festival, so I went to a music festival. It was the Heartbreaker Banquet, held at Willie Nelson’s ranch, a place called Luck, Tex., located in the dry, rolling scrubland of Spicewood, Tex. It’s about 45 minutes northwest of Austin and a universe away from the frantic miscellany of SXSW. For me, it was a glimpse of the Austin I was introduced to in the early years of SXSW — one that’s still there, as evidenced in the annual Austin Music Awards held on Wednesday night, but a local flavor that gets inundated during SXSW with newer, flashier events.

headline: Turning Off the Android Texting Nanny
abstract: Some people would rather do without the word suggestions the software makes as they type a message.

headline: Merkel Warns That Greece Will Receive Aid Only if Reforms Are Met
abstract: The statement, at a European Union leaders’ summit meeting, came as Greece scraped together enough money to pay around $2.17 billion in debts.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — With Greece rapidly running out of money and again teetering on the edge of default, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany said Friday that the Greeks would receive a desperately needed financial aid payment only after creditors approved a package of reform measures that the Greek government has promised to send them soon.

headline: The Movie ‘White God’ Unleashes a Cast of Hundreds
abstract: The movie “White God” employs many dogs to tell a parable about a mixed-breed protagonist forcibly separated from his young owner.
lead_paragraph: At the start of the drama “White God,” a girl in a hoodie is biking through the eerily deserted streets of Budapest. Then, in slow motion, as a sweeping score fills the soundtrack, a large group of dogs comes running after her. Not 10, not 25, but more than 200. The scene is devoid of digital imagery. These dogs are real. Large, small, furry or short-haired, and all very determined, racing toward the camera en masse. It’s an astonishing sequence revisited in greater detail later, and it sets up a moment when subjugated animals rise up against their oppressors, fighting back, taking over and leaving audiences in awe.

headline: Outsider Artist Gets Stamp of Approval
keywords: ['Art', 'Articles of Confederation (1781-89)', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Mexican-Americans', 'Museums', 'Postal Service and Post Offices', 'Schizophrenia', 'Stamps (Postal)']
abstract: The Postal Service will honor the outsider artist Martín Ramírez, placing five of his works on stamps.
lead_paragraph: The United States Postal Service plans to issue five commemorative “forever” stamps on March 26 honoring the outsider artist Martín Ramírez, each with an image taken from one of his works.

headline: Kansas Rolls Past New Mexico State
abstract: The Jayhawks found open shots everywhere, especially behind the arc, on the way to an easy victory.
lead_paragraph: OMAHA — New Mexico State’s tall front line and extended zone defense were supposed to pose matchup problems for Kansas, the No. 2 seed in the Midwest Region of the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament. Instead, the Jayhawks found open shots everywhere, especially behind the arc, and repeatedly beat the slow-to-react Aggies down the floor to win easily, 75-56.

headline: Abiding Rifts Within Israel Threaten to Widen With Netanyahu Win
abstract: After Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s victory, Israelis began to confront the social and political fissures that crisscross the country.
lead_paragraph: SDEROT, Israel — Stores in the rundown center of Sderot, a working-class Israeli border town plagued by years of rocket fire from Gaza, were still festooned with blue-and-white Likud banners at the end of this week.

headline: SXSW Music 2015: All Rise (Too) Early for Snoop Dogg
keywords: ['Rap and Hip-Hop', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: Snoop Dogg gives the keynote for the music portion of SXSW.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — With parties and performances lasting well into the early morning hours all week, the music portion of the South by Southwest Conference was certainly asking something of its attendees by scheduling this year’s music keynote address, a Q. & A. with the incomparable Snoop Dogg, for 11 a.m. on Friday. This is not a place for morning people.

headline: White House Antagonism Toward Netanyahu Grows
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Despite Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s election victory, he is still out of the good graces of the Obama administration, which has had to reassess its policy toward Israel.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House is stepping up its antagonism toward Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu despite his victory in this week’s elections, signaling that it is in no rush to repair a historic rift between the United States and Israel.

headline: Musicians Discuss the Influence of Pierre Boulez
abstract: As he reaches his 90th birthday, the conductor remains an inspiration to many musicians.
lead_paragraph: Pierre Boulez, the distinguished composer, conductor, pianist and theorist, turns 90 on Thursday. He’s peerlessly influential, yes — but how, exactly? Six musicians explored the different facets of that influence in interviews; their replies have been condensed and edited.

headline: Michigan State Holds Off Georgia
abstract: Denzel Valentine had 16 points, and Travis Trice added 15 points and 6 assists, igniting a Michigan State fast break that accounted for 19 points.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Reaching the N.C.A.A. tournament is enough of a rarity at Georgia that the Bulldogs celebrate each appearance on a banner that hangs in Stegeman Coliseum and lists every year they have made the field. The annual expectations at Michigan State, where the banners honor national championships and Final Four appearances, are just a tad higher.

headline: Review: Piotr Anderszewski Goes for Dim Lights and Intimacy at Carnegie Hall
abstract: Mr. Anderszewski, the Polish-born pianist, performed a program that included Bach’s French Overture in B minor and Schumann’s Fantasy in C.
lead_paragraph: In “Unquiet Traveler,” a revealing 2008 documentary that follows the great pianist Piotr Anderszewski on a tour through his native Poland, this powerfully individual artist speaks of the “extreme loneliness” of a recital, of the “heroism” but also of the “cruelty involved.”

headline: SXSW Music 2015: And Now, for a Horror — Make That Ho99o9 — Show
keywords: ['Music', 'Rap and Hip-Hop', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: A barrage of adrenaline from the hip hop band, Ho99o9. The lyrics? Mostly lost in the onslaught.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Every festival needs one all-out barrage, and I got mine on Thursday night from Ho99o9 (pronounced “horror”). It’s a hip-hop group from Newark that blasts every way it can think of, which is plenty: “I’m an overload,” one song truthfully announced.

headline: Clinton Backers Say Criticizing Netanyahu  Can Wait
abstract: Some supporters of Hillary Rodham Clinton, a staunch supporter of Israel, say she need not worry about excessive blowback from moderate Jewish supporters even if she were to join progressive Jews in criticizing Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
lead_paragraph: Some supporters of Hillary Rodham Clinton, a longtime supporter of Israel, say she need not worry about excessive blowback from moderate Jewish supporters even if she were to join progressive Jews in criticizing Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

headline: Lottery-Fueled Foundation Announces Second Theater Grant
abstract: The grant will go to the Steppenwolf Theater Company to support the premiere of a new, 17-character play by Tracy Letts.
lead_paragraph: The Roy Cockrum Foundation, established recently with part of the proceeds of a $153 million Powerball jackpot, has announced that its second grant will go to the Steppenwolf Theater Company in Chicago, to support a production of “Mary Page Marlowe,” a new play by the Pulitzer Prize-winner Tracy Letts (“August: Osage County”).

headline: A French Politician Who Has Helped Refine the National Front Party
abstract: Experts say Florian Philippot has been critical in the party’s efforts to present a respectable face — and one that is ready to govern.
lead_paragraph: ST.-MACAIRE-EN-MAGUES, France — Florian Philippot was about to take the stage in this small western village in the hope of lifting the fortunes of the local candidates of the far-right National Front party.

headline: At Versailles, a Sumptuous Seven-Course Celebration of French Cuisine
abstract: The dinner celebrated Goût de France, an international initiative to advance French gastronomy.
lead_paragraph: When the French have a serious point to make, the country’s pull-out-all-the-stops invitation is to dinner at the Château de Versailles, the vast royal palace 14 miles from Paris that remains as awe-inspiring in the age of Instagram as it was when the oil paintings of French royals that crowd its walls were created centuries ago. The French foreign minister Laurent Fabius and the chef Alain Ducasse convened Paris’s diplomatic community to a sumptuous seven-course dinner there last night to celebrate Goût de France (rather infelicitously translated in the bilingual program as “Good France”), an international initiative intended to reestablish the reputation of the French culinary arts around the world.

headline: Liberia Reports First Ebola Case in Weeks
abstract: Confirmation that a patient tested positive deflated hope that Liberia was now free of the Ebola virus.
lead_paragraph: A patient in Liberia has tested positive for the Ebola virus, health officials said Friday, more than two weeks after the last known case in the country had been discharged from the hospital.

headline: An Underground Boxer’s Struggle
abstract: The BX Fight Club, though unsanctioned, has a devoted following online, and was founded as a way to foster respect and redirect aggression among young men in rough sections of the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: Chris Cunningham stood wearing a white apron behind the checkout counter at Schaller & Weber, a butcher shop on the Upper East Side, ringing up a mink-draped customer. Under the rim of his crisp paper cap, Mr. Cunningham’s brow was visibly swollen, yet his smile was quick and generous — both products from the previous night’s championship bout at an illegal boxing club in an industrial section of the Bronx.

headline: How Tim Gunn of ‘Project Runway’ Spends His Sunday
abstract: On Sundays, Mr. Gunn, who lives on the Upper West Side, turns his focus inward in order to “heal and repair.”
lead_paragraph: Tim Gunn doesn’t balk at sharing his point of view, whether it’s favorable (“Your clothes have beautiful construction details. There is a real voice here.”), controversial (“The fashion industry has an inability to accept real women and their size and shape. I find it disdainful and disrespectful.”) or confessional (“I’m terribly shy. Every time I’m in front of a camera I’m nervous.”). In his new book, “Tim Gunn: The Natty Professor,” the “Project Runway” co-host and mentor shares such observations and musings. On Sundays, Mr. Gunn, 61, who lives on the Upper West Side, turns his focus inward in order to “heal and repair.”

headline: Review: ‘The Feast’ Plumbs the Depths of a Troubling Toilet
abstract: A play by Cory Finley offers a surrealistic take on what lies beneath the drain.
lead_paragraph: Ever had a leaky faucet? Or a clogged drain? Cory Finley’s “The Feast” at the Flea is the sort of play to make you grateful for such mundane plumbing problems. Matt’s wonky W.C. is a whole lot eerier.

headline: By Land and Sea, Curaçao Seeks to Sustain Its Coral Bounty
keywords: ['Coral', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Environment', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Reefs', 'Sustainable Living']
abstract: Young filmmakers examine efforts on Curaçao to sustain the island’s coral bounty while enhancing its economy.
lead_paragraph: WILLEMSTAD, Curaçao — I apologize for the prolonged blog silence (I have withdrawal symptoms!), but this week has been devoted to filming, not writing. Since my move to Pace University five years ago, I’ve been working each spring with a colleague, Prof. Maria Luskay, to focus a long-running documentary production course on environmental stories.

headline: In Winter, Harbor Seals Become New York’s Beach Bums
abstract: The mammals, which are about a human’s size and weight and were once an abundant species in New York harbor but became a rare sight for much of the 20th century, appear to have rebounded.
lead_paragraph: As a naturalist in New York City, I have learned that a call about a sick dog on the beach is more often not about a dog. Increasingly, the beaches we abandon at the end of summer are resorts for seals in winter.

abstract: Centavrvs’s music is rooted in cumbias and rancheras and, often, praising the pleasures of romance.

headline: Form Holds as Northern Iowa Ousts Wyoming
abstract: No. 5 Northern Iowa was the better team and for much of the game looked like it.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — About halfway through the first half, Seth Tuttle, Northern Iowa’s star senior forward, crashed toward the basket during an inbound play, received the ball midair and missed the easy basket. No matter. He got his own rebound and tossed the ball a few feet to the junior guard Paul Jesperson, who made the layup.

lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Henrik Lundqvist, who was cleared to return to practice with the Rangers this week, was not at the team’s workout Friday because his wife, Therese, was close to giving birth to their second child.

lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Sixteen people who went to a Beijing detention center on Friday to push for medical treatment for one of five detained women’s rights activists were themselves taken into custody, according to one of the 16 detained and a website that documents rights violations. They were all released by 3 a.m. Saturday.

lead_paragraph: Washington — The Obama administration announced on Friday that it would give $200 million to 10 states for pilot projects to help food stamp recipients find jobs, part of a larger effort to reduce the rolls of a program that provides assistance to nearly 50 million Americans.

lead_paragraph: The fine-dining experience at Le Périgord, a French restaurant at 52nd Street and First Avenue in Manhattan, has barely changed over 50 years.

headline: Cold Enough to Warm the Heart
abstract: Two adventurers, unafraid of winter, marry in an ice hotel as a blizzard bears down.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to avoid the irony: A woman who thwarted her boyfriend’s plan for a marriage proposal because of the cold is married in a chapel made of snow and ice in Quebec, with a blizzard as a bonus.

headline: Tituss Burgess on a Role Tailor-Made for Him on ‘Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt’
abstract: Tituss Burgess, who is a roommate of the main character’s on “Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt,” talks about being cast in a perfect role.
lead_paragraph: “ ‘Looking for a wannabe Broadway actor, broke, down on his luck, who lives in Harlem in a basement apartment,’ ” said Tituss Burgess, who was recently sitting in a cafe down the street from his former Harlem basement apartment. He was remembering the casting call for what would turn out to be the second lead on Netflix’s “Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt.” It was basically him. Sure, Titus, the character on the show, lacked the additional “s” in his name. But, otherwise, the similarities — gay, black, fabulous — were undeniable. “I thought, ‘Is this a joke or am I about to get a job?’ ” Mr. Burgess said with a laugh.

headline: At Le Périgord, Few Changes Since Burton and Taylor Dined There in ’64
abstract: The French restaurant, owned by Georges and Marie-Thérèse Briguet for more than 50 years, has become a Midtown East neighborhood haunt though bills average nearly $100 per person.
lead_paragraph: On a recent chilly evening, when the weather called for a comforting meal and warm ambience, Le Périgord was as welcoming as ever. The restaurant’s 78-year-old owner, Georges Briguet, wearing a tuxedo, stood at the entry of his fancy French restaurant, greeting customers either with a handshake or a kiss on both cheeks, a ritual more than 50 years old.

headline: Bill Cunningham | The Gales of March
keywords: ['Hats and Caps', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Nineteen Hundred Twenties']
abstract: The new style of floppy, wide-brimmed felt hats is a problem in the windy streets, especially on 23rd Street and Fifth Avenue, a corner that’s said to have been known in the 1920s as “23 Skidoo.”
lead_paragraph: The new style of floppy wide-brimmed felt hats is a problem in the windy streets, especially on 23rd Street and Fifth Avenue, a corner that’s said to have been known in the 1920s as “23 Skidoo” because of the admonishment police would shout at men who waited there to see the wind lift the skirts of female passers-by.

headline: How to Manage Media in Families
keywords: ['Parenting', 'Smartphones', 'Text Messaging', 'Mobile Applications', 'Social Media', 'Children and Childhood', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: Rules on cellphone use may keep families better connected.
lead_paragraph: Parents have a love-hate relationship with firsts. Some they like: the first smile, the first steps, the first sleeping through the night. Others they dread: the first flu, the first tantrum, the first broken bone. As children get older, the firsts become more nuanced, generating both joy in our children’s independence and fear of their slipping away: the first summer away, the first date, the first driver’s license.

headline: A Visit to Vu Linh, Vietnam
abstract: The village includes a lodge that celebrates the culture of Dao, one of the country’s ethnic groups.
lead_paragraph: The village includes a lodge that celebrates the culture of Dao, one of the country’s ethnic groups.

headline: Rules for Teen and Tween Cellphone Use: Unspoken, or Printed and Signed?
abstract: Are your family’s rules about children’s mobile phone use set “rules,” or just general guidelines?
lead_paragraph: Last month, my 13-year-old bought his first mobile phone. In keeping with our family’s general electronic gadgetry policy, he saved up for it himself, and he’ll make the monthly payments himself, although he gets a good deal because he is on my brand-new “family plan.” If he referees two hockey games a month, he can cover it. (He has other income-making plans for spring and summer, and enough savings that I’m confident I won’t ever have to float him).

headline: Rand Paul Calls on Hillary Clinton to Return All Foreign Gifts
abstract: Senator Rand Paul appears to be trying to turn one of Hillary Rodham Clinton’s greatest strengths into a weakness, implicating her in a “war on women” because of gifts she has received from foreign countries.
lead_paragraph: Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, appears to be trying to turn one of Hillary Rodham Clinton’s greatest strengths into a weakness, implicating her in a “war on women” because of gifts she has received from foreign countries.

abstract: Celebrating activism, the arts and education.
lead_paragraph: Celebrating activism, the arts and education.

headline: Death of a Muse: Manuela Pavesi, Miuccia Prada’s Close Collaborator
abstract: The March 13 death of Manuela Pavesi, a photographer, stylist and Miuccia Prada’s close collaborator, saddened the fashion world.
lead_paragraph: Manuela Pavesi was a passionate archivist of her own past, hanging on over time to cherished mementos of a life in style. Not long ago, she reminisced about the pinafore she wore as a schoolgirl in her native Mantua. “I still have it,” she said.

headline: The Age of Frozen Certainties
abstract: Always wrong, never in doubt — it’s the modern way.
lead_paragraph: The Times has an interesting headline here: Richard Fisher, Often Wrong but Seldom Boring, Leaves the Fed. Because entertainment value is what we want from central bankers, right? I mean, Janet Yellen is such a drag — she just keeps being right about the economy, and that gets old really fast, you know?

headline: Lena Dunham and the ‘Man Who Drew Eloise’
abstract: Ms. Dunham’s documentary on HBO features her new friend, the 88-year-old illustrator behind the popular children’s books.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, Hilary Knight, the illustrator best known for “Eloise,” was talking with a builder he knows in East Hampton. The guy had just read a profile in New York Magazine of Lena Dunham, which mentioned she had an Eloise tattoo. “I was unaware of Lena Dunham,” Mr. Knight, 88, said recently.

headline: Young Mixed Pair Wins Lebhar Imp Title
abstract: The Vanderbilt Knockout Teams, the premier event at the Spring North American Championships in New Orleans, will have new champions after Sunday’s final.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — The Vanderbilt Knockout Teams, the premier event at the Spring North American Championships here, will have new champions after Sunday’s final. Last year’s winners, Nick Nickell, Ralph Katz, Bobby Levin, Steve Weinstein, Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell, lost in the Round of 32 to Gaylor Kasle and Larry Kozlove playing with four Europeans, Joris Lankveld and Berend Van Den Bos from the Netherlands and Bartosz Chmurski and Piotr Tuczynski from Poland by 94 international match points to 92.

headline: The Math of March Madness
abstract: There’s a simple way to predict the Final Four.
lead_paragraph: THE N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament started Thursday, but for most Americans the real action began days before, as they pored over brackets, competing to make the most accurate predictions — for money, or just office glory. These days, when statistical algorithms can figure out what breakfast cereal you want based on your browser history, stats-minded hoops fans have thrown lots of complex analysis at the problem of picking winners.

headline: A History of the First Mass-Produced Baseball Card

lead_paragraph: Q. While waiting endlessly for Opening Day, I got to wondering: What was the first baseball card?

headline: The Problem With Egg Freezing
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Eggs', 'Infertility', 'Paid Time Off', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Discussion around the practice underscores the fact that the difficulties of bearing children and then raising them fall too often on individual women.
lead_paragraph: Nobody really knows how well egg freezing works. Despite that, the practice has received significant media attention, thanks in part to a startup that now hosts “egg-freezing parties.” And while it may turn out to be effective for some women, the current discussion underscores an enduring fact: When it comes to having and caring for children, women are all too often on their own.

headline: Hillary’s Eternal Quest for Relatability

lead_paragraph: This morning, I found myself in one of those overcaffeinated, overendorphined, “what could possibly go wrong?” states as I perused my Twitter feed. Dangerous! Soon I found myself talking back to certain tweets, usually in my head. But sometimes not. I hate Twitter.

headline: Mets’ Hopes May Be Dashed, but Not by the Loss of Zack Wheeler
abstract: The dynamic right-hander will miss the season after surgery, but filling out the rotation will be easier than significantly improving their bullpen and defense.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — When Zack Wheeler learned on Monday that his job had changed from pitcher to patient, he hung up the phone and returned to the Mets’ clubhouse in a daze.

Belmont was on a run, and Virginia was in trouble.

lead_paragraph: Bonnie Prince Johnnie, flamboyant pharaoh of New York; Francesca, a.k.a. Tisiphone, Native American assassin; Maurits de Wolff, former slave and soldier extraordinaire; Akosua Van Der Zee, wrathful feminist and malicious schemer.

abstract: “Married at First Sight,” which began its second season on FYI, is part of a slew of recent reality shows about relationships at risk.
lead_paragraph: Love is a feeling, to be sure, but love is also a choice — the choice to let someone in, and to get inside someone else.

headline: A Governor Faces Down the Gun Lobby
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Law and Legislation', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: West Virginia Gov. Earl Ray Tomblin risked the wrath of gun rights adherents when he vetoed a bill that would have allowed West Virginians to carry a concealed weapon without a permit.
lead_paragraph: The power of the gun lobby over statehouse politicians has led to a raft of laws dear to gun rights adherents, from a measure allowing concealed firearms on college campuses to one legalizing the open carrying of holstered pistols for those who like to swagger into restaurants and coffee bars. The growing question of whether the lobby had nullified all serious political resistance was answered Friday when West Virginia Gov. Earl Ray Tomblin, usually a reliable supporter of the National Rifle Association, vetoed a bill to scrap the current law that citizens have to get a permit and take gun safety lessons in order to legally carry a concealed weapon in the state.

headline: Undoing the Ruins Once Wrought by Vesuvius
abstract: The fruits of a two-year restoration of a major site buried by the eruption of Mount Vesuvius were unveiled on Friday in Pompeii.
lead_paragraph: POMPEII, Italy — Despite its name, the Villa of the Mysteries, arguably the best-known monument at the archaeological site here buried by Vesuvian fury in A.D. 79, has something to reveal.

abstract: Thousands of crime scene photographs taken by New York City detectives from 1914 to 1975 will soon be viewed online for the first time ever.
lead_paragraph: The picture, of a coat and a hat, was one of seven taken that afternoon at the Latin Lounge. But why?

headline: Why Not Utopia?
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'Robots and Robotics', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Welfare (US)']
abstract: We need a future where the robots benefit all of us, not just the rich.
lead_paragraph: SOME quake in terror as we approach the Terminator scenario, in which clever machines take over the world. After all, it isn’t sci-fi when Stephen Hawking says things like, “The development of full artificial intelligence could spell the end of the human race.”

headline: Review: The Joyce Unleashed Series, With a Middle Eastern Flavor
abstract: Two works by choreographers with Israeli connections are part of this year’s offsite series by the Joyce Theater.
lead_paragraph: Is there anything more sentimental than a home video of a little kid dancing? What if you extracted only the motions and put them in a different body, on an empty stage? “Helga and the Three Sailors,” a richly detailed dance by Netta Yerushalmy, begins with an exercise in that vein. Alongside short, looping clips of herself as a child, Ms. Yerushalmy does again what she did back then, but with no emotional inflection. The physical facts of flailing in the living room or wobbling along a garden path, it turns out, make for compelling choreography.

headline: ‘Infinite Possibility’ From an Iranian Artist
abstract: The works of Monir Shahroudy Farmanfarmaian are on exhibition at the Guggenheim. At 91, she is having her first solo show at a major New York museum.
lead_paragraph: The works of Monir Shahroudy Farmanfarmaian are on exhibition at the Guggenheim. At 91, she is having her first solo show at a major New York museum.

abstract: Differing responses to the mob killing in Kabul of a mentally troubled woman accused of burning the Quran show how Afghans’ commitment to Islam can clash with Western values of individual rights.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The mentally ill woman, her face covered in blood, rose to her feet and looked out across the mob. She pleaded. But these men meant to kill her.

headline: Monir Farmanfarmaian, Iranian and Nonagenarian, Celebrates a New York Museum First
abstract: “Monir Shahroudy Farmanfarmaian: Infinite Possibility. Mirror Works and Drawings 1974-2014” is at the Guggenheim Museum in New York through June 3.
lead_paragraph: The artist Monir Farmanfarmaian used to visit the Guggenheim museum in the early 1950s, when it was still in a townhouse and still known by its ponderous first handle, the Museum of Non-Objective Painting. She was there the day in 1956 when ground was broken for Frank Lloyd Wright’s concrete spiral. And the other evening, at the age of 91, she stood in the rotunda of that spiral, using a reporter to help her fend off a crowd of admirers pressing in from all sides.

headline: What They Did in the War: Two Japanese Actresses’ Propaganda Work
abstract: A Japan Society film series looks at the careers of Shirley Yamaguchi and Setsuko Hara, including their work in films supporting Japan’s war aims.
lead_paragraph: American moviegoers may know Setsuko Hara: symbol of the quiet strength of the Japanese woman in films from the 1940s and ’50s, especially Yasujiro Ozu’s “Late Spring,” “Early Summer” and “Tokyo Story.” And we know Shirley Yamaguchi: a spitfire whose career included starring roles in Samuel Fuller’s “House of Bamboo” and King Vidor’s “Japanese War Bride.”

headline: Scott Walker’s Path
