lead_paragraph: Highlights of the political career of Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, a candidate for the Republican presidential nomination in 2016.

headline: For 2016 Run, Scott Walker Washes ‘Wiscahnsin’ Out of His Mouth
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: The governor of Wisconsin has filtered out his regional accent, cut down rambling in speeches and started dressing to please on visits to states like New Hampshire.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Out on the presidential campaign trail, Gov. Scott Walker has left “Wiscahnsin” back home in Wisconsin. He now wants to strengthen the economy, not the “ecahnahmy.” And while he once had the “ahnor” of meeting fellow Republicans, he told one group here this week that he simply enjoyed “talkin’ with y’all.”

headline: Do the Democrats and Israel Have a Future Together?
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'Palestinians', 'Elections', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: Benjamin Netanyahu’s problem in the United States isn’t liberal Jews; it’s everyone else.
lead_paragraph: Last September, on the afternoon of Rosh Hashana, the beginning of the Jewish High Holy Days, Elliott Abrams sat cross-legged on a basement carpet in Virginia playing marbles with his grandson. The former George W. Bush administration official, who supervised U.S. policy in the Middle East, is the father-in-law of a young rabbi at a reform synagogue in Washington that had been torn between its love of Israel and its loathing of Benjamin Netanyahu’s right-wing government.

headline: Louisville’s Guards Outmaneuver U.C. Irvine’s Big Men in a Close Victory
abstract: U.C. Irvine used the 7-foot-6 Mamadou Ndiaye and the 7-2 Ioannis Dimakopoulos to dominate the lane, and the lead was never larger than 5 points.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Through almost all of Louisville’s 57-55 win Friday, U.C. Irvine had the tallest player on the floor. In the first half, the Anteaters put in either the 7-foot-6 center Mamadou Ndiaye, a sophomore from Senegal, or the 7-2 center Ioannis Dimakopoulos, a sophomore from Greece.

headline: Bartolo Colon, Michael Cuddyer and Curtis Granderson Pace Mets
abstract: Colon pitched four and two-thirds innings, Cuddyer hit a two-run homer and Granderson went 3 for 3 with two doubles.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Although their baseball odometer shows a lot of mileage, Bartolo Colon, Michael Cuddyer and Curtis Granderson showed for at least one day that there was still a lot of life left in their game.

headline: Tolstoy’s Home
abstract: The one-time estate of Leo Tolstoy is now a Russian state museum.
lead_paragraph: The one-time estate of Leo Tolstoy is now a Russian state museum.

headline: In Putin’s Nationalist Russia, a Tolstoy as Cultural Diplomat
abstract: Vladimir Tolstoy, a great-great-grandson of the novelist, seeks to bridge the divide between ardent nationalists and liberal intellectuals in serving as a cultural adviser to the president.
lead_paragraph: YASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — On a sunny winter afternoon here, Vladimir Tolstoy, a great-great-grandson of Leo Tolstoy and an adviser on cultural affairs to President Vladimir V. Putin, strode up the birch-lined path that leads to the bucolic family compound where his forebear wrote “War and Peace” and “Anna Karenina.” It is now a state museum. At each step, he was greeted by staff members heading home for the day.

headline: Scott Walker’s Accent Then and Now
abstract: As Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin gets ready for a presidential campaign, his regional accent seems to be softening.
lead_paragraph: As Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin gets ready for a presidential campaign, his regional accent seems to be softening.

headline: Woman Breaks Through Chains of Forced Marriage, and Helps Others Do the Same
keywords: ['Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Marriages', 'Women and Girls', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Hinduism', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Fraidy Reiss, who was coerced in her teens to marry a man she barely knew, runs the nonprofit group that helps women get out of arranged marriages and refocus their lives.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — One day in March 2011, Fraidy Reiss went to her lawyer’s office to close on a house. The prosaic routine of paperwork somehow diminished her sense of accomplishment. Not even the seller was present to hear what she yearned to say.

headline: Friday Night Music: SOAK
abstract: A gift from Derry.
lead_paragraph: I saw a lot of great stuff at SWSX — San Fermin, Alvvays, Courtney Barnett, and more. Also ate and drank too much to make up despite some lovely long runs along the river.

headline: Robert Kastenmeier, Liberal Voice in House for 32 Years, Dies at 91
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations']
abstract: A Wisconsin Democrat was an early opponent of the Vietnam War and in 1976 earned the gratitude of authors when he managed the first general revision of copyright law since 1909.
lead_paragraph: Robert W. Kastenmeier, a Wisconsin Democrat who in 32 years in the House was an early opponent of the Vietnam War and in 1976 earned the gratitude of authors when he managed the first general revision of copyright law since 1909, died on Friday at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 91.

headline: Aging Bridge in California Needs All the Support It Can Get
abstract: Residents of a town overlooking the Pacific Ocean want to save the Albion River Bridge. They say it defines them. But state officials say it has to go.
lead_paragraph: ALBION, Calif. — Sometimes, a bridge is more than a way to get from here to there.

headline: A Car-Free Day on San Fernando Valley Roads
abstract: The San Fernando Valley will play host to CicLAvia, a day when roads will be free of motorized vehicles and open to those on bikes, on foot, and in strollers.
lead_paragraph: California’s San Fernando Valley is hosting the bike-centric event called CicLAvia for the first time on Sunday, March 22.

headline: Maryland Fends Off Valparaiso’s Upset Bid
abstract: In a battle of 3-pointers, the Terrapins held on against the Crusaders, who could not get off a shot on their final possession.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — In a skirmish of 3-pointers, Maryland slipped past Valparaiso, 65-62, and thwarted a furious bid to end its season Friday at Nationwide Arena.

headline: Cuba: Split in Dissident Group
abstract: The daughter of Laura Pollán, founder of the dissident group Ladies in White, has split from the organization, signaling divisions over the rapprochement between Cuba and the United States.
lead_paragraph: The daughter of Laura Pollán, founder of the dissident group Ladies in White, has split from the organization, signaling divisions over the rapprochement between Cuba and the United States and, perhaps, the end of an era in which the white-clad women symbolized the fight for political freedom. Ms. Pollán’s daughter, Laura Maria Labrada, announced on Thursday that she would leave the group because of differences with its leader, Berta Soler. She said the Ladies in White could no longer use Ms. Pollán’s name or her house, which had been the group’s headquarters. Ms. Pollán died in 2011. Tensions within the group have sharpened since the Dec. 17 thaw between Cuba and the United States, which Ms. Soler opposes and Ms. Labrada supports. Members this month accused Ms. Soler of being autocratic and called for her to resign, leading to a vote on her leadership, which she won.

headline: In Tunisia, Taking Stock of the Dead, and the Survivors
abstract: The victims of the attack on the National Bardo Museum in Tunis were mostly foreigners, and their families have begun arriving to take them home.
lead_paragraph: TUNIS — Still shaken on Friday by a brazen attack that killed 23 people at the National Bardo Museum in the heart of the capital two days before, Tunisian officials spent their Independence Day — a public holiday here — evacuating dead and wounded foreign tourists and burying their own.

headline: Defending a Tax Analysis
abstract: The president of the Tax Foundation, Scott Hodge, discusses its favorable report on the Republican tax reform plan.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Florida Justices Reject 70-Year Sentence for Juvenile, Likening It to Life Term
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Juvenile Delinquency', 'Teenagers and Adolescence']
abstract: The Florida Supreme Court ordered a new hearing for Shimeek D. Gridine, who was 14 when he wounded a man with a shotgun during an attempted robbery.
lead_paragraph: The Florida Supreme Court has ordered a new sentencing hearing for a man who received 70 years in prison without parole for an attempted murder at the age of 14. The court agreed with lawyers for the defendant, Shimeek D. Gridine, that his sentence violated the limits on juvenile penalties set by the United States Supreme Court.

headline: Poland: Priest’s Abuse Trial Opens
abstract: A Polish priest accused of sexually abusing minors in Poland and in the Dominican Republic offered to serve a seven-year jail sentence as his trial opened on Friday, according to a spokeswoman for a regional court in Warsaw.
lead_paragraph: A Polish priest accused of sexually abusing minors in Poland and in the Dominican Republic, where he led a parish for almost a decade, offered to serve a seven-year jail sentence as his trial opened on Friday, according to a spokeswoman for a regional court in Warsaw. The priest, the Rev. Wojciech Gil, is charged with committing 10 crimes, most of which relate to the molestation of boys under the age of 15. If convicted, he could serve up to 15 years in prison. During the trial, Father Gil for the first time since his arrest did not deny the charges, the court spokeswoman said, but it is unclear whether he pleaded guilty. Under Polish law, a defendant can offer to serve a jail term for some crimes without admitting to any guilt. The trial resumes on Wednesday.

headline: Morgan Hoffmann, a Pilot, Handles Pressure as He Seeks His First PGA Win
abstract: Hoffmann, who is winless in 67 PGA Tour starts, finished with a 65 to take a three-stroke lead Friday, one day after learning that his grandmother had died.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Morgan Hoffmann, pro golfer and amateur pilot, was performing touch-and-go maneuvers on a Stuart, Fla., runway when a vulture flew into his line of sight. Worried that the bird was on a collision course with the propeller, Hoffmann swiftly pulled up his aircraft, a six-seat Piper Lance turboprop.

headline: Cuomo Focuses on Ethics Reform, Not on Funding It
abstract: Most of the agencies that concentrate on investigating ethical lapses have seen flat budgets or even cuts, though Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is pushing to increase enforcement.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Though Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo made expanding oversight of public officials a centerpiece of his agenda this year, none of New York State’s commissions or agencies specifically charged with policing ethical lapses received an increase in funding in his proposed budget.

headline: Canada: Men Found Guilty of Terrorism
abstract: Two men who plotted to derail a passenger train traveling from New York to Toronto were convicted on Friday of various terrorism charges, including terrorism-related conspiracy to commit murder.
lead_paragraph: Two men who plotted to derail a passenger train traveling from New York to Toronto were convicted on Friday of various terrorism charges, including terrorism-related conspiracy to commit murder. Most of the evidence against the men, Chiheb Esseghaier, a Tunisian graduate student in Montreal, and Raed Jaser, a stateless Palestinian with previous criminal convictions, were recordings secretly made by an F.B.I. agent who posed as a wealthy American businessman who held radical political and religious views. The two men are to be sentenced next month.

headline: A Real-Time Peek at Traffic to U.S. Government Websites
abstract: This week, the federal government unveiled a new tool that makes public the user analytics for many government websites.
lead_paragraph: The federal government is offering the public a window into its web traffic. On Thursday, it introduced a new site that gives real-time insight into how many people are navigating to many government websites.

headline: In a Good Sign, Alex Rodriguez Hits a Home Run
abstract: Alex Rodriguez ended a 1-for-14 slump by homering off an upper-90s fastball, the type of high-velocity pitch he had been struggling to connect with.
lead_paragraph: LAKELAND, Fla. — As Alex Rodriguez rounded first base on Friday, his eyes fixed on right field, he turned back toward the bag, uncertain where to go.

headline: Netanyahu, the Palestinians and the Election in Israel
abstract: Readers react to recent statements by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu about a two-state solution.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Cincinnati Has a Bald, 5-Foot-8, Frenzied Coach. No, the Other One.
abstract: When a medical crisis arose for Mick Cronin, his like-minded and similar-looking aide, Larry Davis, stepped in for the Bearcats, who are set to play No. 1 Kentucky.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — When he became ill, Mick Cronin, the head coach at Cincinnati, did not hand the reins of the basketball program to just any coach. He handed them to his twin, to his equivalent, to a man who shares Cronin’s doctrine of maniacal basketball. Cut them open, and Cronin and the interim coach Larry Davis are the same man.

headline: Is a Streetcar Still Something to Desire?
abstract: Jacob Anbinder, a researcher on transportation and urban affairs, and Representative Earl Blumenauer, an Oregon Democrat, differ on the viability of the streetcar.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Walter Channing Jr., Vintner and Sculptor, Dies at 74
abstract: Mr. Channing combined careers as a venture capitalist, a sculptor in wood and a maker of well-regarded wines on the South Fork of Long Island, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Walter Channing Jr., who combined careers as a venture capitalist, sculptor and well-regarded vintner on Long Island, died on March 12 in Southampton, N.Y. He was 74.

headline: McConnell and Coal
abstract: A reader criticizes Senator Mitch McConnell for his opposition to rules limiting emissions.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Tinder Appoints Chief Executive to Replace Sean Rad
abstract: The mobile dating application Tinder appointed Christopher Payne to replace its former leader, who was embroiled in a sexual harassment lawsuit last year.
lead_paragraph: Tinder, the mobile dating application, said on Friday it had appointed Christopher Payne chief executive, a step toward building the two-and-a-half-year-old company into a booming business.

headline: Skills in the New Economy
abstract: Danny Groner, a reader, writes that “every role at a company, big or small, should be treated as a leadership role.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Slaughterers of Srebrenica’
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Milan Panic, a former prime minister of Yugoslavia, writes that the arrest of eight suspects “is just the start of justice.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Robert Durst’s Papers Are Seized From a Hudson Valley Cellar
abstract: About 60 file boxes belonging to the murder suspect were removed from a friend’s house north of New York City.
lead_paragraph: The authorities moved swiftly to search the home of Robert A. Durst in Houston as well as a hotel room in New Orleans after his arrest on first-degree murder charges there a week ago.

headline: Sherman’s Last Stand
abstract: The Union victory at Bentonville brought the Western Theater to an end with a whimper, not a bang.
lead_paragraph: By the final months of the Civil War, a combination of geography and human agency began to break down the long-standing distinction between the Eastern Theater, consisting of operations in and around Virginia, and the Western Theater, which encompassed everything between the Appalachian Mountains and the Mississippi River. In fact, in one of the war’s great ironies, the closing act of the Western Theater occurred in east central North Carolina.

headline: U.S. May Stay in Afghanistan After '16
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: President Obama is considering leaving American troops in Afghanistan after he leaves office, instead of only a small force to protect the embassy in Kabul, a White House official said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A White House official on Friday appeared to leave open the possibility that American troops could remain in Afghanistan after President Obama leaves office, in what would be a marked shift from the administration’s insistence that only a small force based at the embassy in Kabul would remain after 2016.

headline: Officials Urge Patience as Hanging of Black Man Is Investigated in Mississippi
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Missing Persons', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Two federal law enforcement officials suggested that the hanging of Otis James Byrd might have been a suicide, but other officials said it was too early draw conclusions.
lead_paragraph: PORT GIBSON, Miss. — Approximately 30 federal, state and local law enforcement agents have descended upon this small Southern town to investigate the death of a black man whose body was found hanging from a tree. But two federal law enforcement officials said Friday that preliminary indications suggested that the man might have committed suicide, and the local sheriff said that there was no indication that racism had played a role.

headline: A Woman’s Place Is on the $20
abstract: If Andrew Jackson were replaced on the $20 bill with a woman, who should it be? Eleanor Roosevelt? Sojourner Truth? Make your nominations heard!
lead_paragraph: You may have heard that there’s a movement afoot to kick Andrew Jackson off the $20 bill and replace him with a woman. Finally, we’ve got a current event that’s not depressing.

headline: Notre Dame Rides a Streak With Shoes Like Highlighters
abstract: Those hues of the Irish’s sneakers have streaked across basketball courts over the last two and a half weeks, offending traditionalists, clashing with the team’s gold jerseys and blinding viewers at home.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — In the second week of February, a shipment from Under Armour arrived at Notre Dame. Mixed in with hats and jumpsuits and T-shirts were the boxes that Harold Swanagan, the coordinator of basketball operations, was expecting.

headline: Bill Raftery-Grant Hill Analyst Team Has a Bland Debut but a Better Sequel
abstract: In the No. 1 CBS and Turner Sports booth for the N.C.A.A. tournament, Grant Hill sometimes seems timid beside the veteran announcer Bill Raftery.
lead_paragraph: Casting a three-announcer booth is rarely easy. You need a play-by-play announcer who can get the best out of two analysts, not the usual one. You need two analysts with different perspectives who can provide complementary commentary without each repeating what the other has just said. And you need those analysts to accommodate each other — and not fight for airtime between plays.

headline: Mexico: Elite Police Officers Slain
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Drug Cartels', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: A new, elite federal police unit intended to be a premiere force against drug gangs suffered its biggest loss this week when five members were killed in an ambush, federal officials said Friday.
lead_paragraph: A new, elite federal police unit intended to be a premiere force against drug gangs suffered its biggest loss this week when five members were killed in an ambush, federal officials said Friday, raising questions among analysts about the unit’s training. The ambush, in Jalisco State on Thursday, left five other people dead, including two civilian bystanders and three of the presumed attackers, officials said. The officers belonged to the Gendarmerie, a 5,000-officer division of the federal police formed last year by President Enrique Peña Nieto to go after organized-crime groups hurting economic interests in various trouble spots in an effort to ease foreign investors’ concerns about safety. The officers were in a convoy patrolling an industrial corridor in Ocotlan when they came under gunfire from more than a dozen vehicles. It was unclear what prompted the attack.

headline: Philadelphia Commissioner Steps Into Fray Between Police and Public
abstract: Even in a city with a black chief of police, relations between law enforcement and the public are strained.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — When Police Commissioner Charles H. Ramsey and District Attorney R. Seth Williams appeared at a town hall meeting here on Thursday, they were prepared to explain why criminal charges had not been filed against an officer who in December fatally shot a young black man in the back of the head.

headline: Georgia State’s Sixth Man Has Four Wheels and Countless Fans
abstract: The chair will be forever linked to Georgia State Coach Ron Hunter and the 14th-seeded Panthers’ upset of third-seeded Baylor.
lead_paragraph: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — A celebrity deserves better. Fame, even for 15 minutes, should carry some cachet. Maybe an upgraded suite with plush carpeting, designer seat coverings, a comfy corner to rest weary wheels? How about a place behind a fancy desk, if just for one night?

headline: Duke Shows Robert Morris It Should Be Careful What It Wishes For
abstract: Robert Morris fans chanted “We want Duke” during the play-in game on Wednesday, and on Friday they got to watch the Blue Devils’ buzz saw.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Gleeful Robert Morris fans chanted “We want Duke” in the final seconds of their N.C.A.A. tournament play-in victory against North Florida on Wednesday in Dayton, Ohio. So the fans got what they wanted.

headline: How to Make Landslides Less Deadly
abstract: We need to identify these hazards to mitigate the threat.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — IN the year since 43 people died in a landslide in Oso, Wash., we have often been asked, as researchers who investigated this tragedy, how many other potential landslide disasters exist around the country.

headline: The Greece Issue Breeds Brinkmanship in the Eurozone
abstract: Discussions about a new loan agreement seem to be going even worse than expected.
lead_paragraph: Nobody expected that the discussions between Greece and the rest of the eurozone about a new loan agreement would go smoothly. But things seem to be going even worse than expected, with both sides sniping at each other and refusing to engage in meaningful negotiations.

headline: Overtime Pay for Overworked People
keywords: ['Overtime', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Editorials', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Last year, President Obama’s call for new pay rules was a politically useful tool in the midterm campaigns. But now it’s time to finally take action.
lead_paragraph: More than a year has passed since President Obama directed the Labor Department to revamp the nation’s outdated rules on overtime pay, which are basically stuck in the 1970s. A February deadline is long gone and there has been no proposal.

headline: Backsliding on Reform in Myanmar
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The country’s military-dominated government promised its November elections would be free and fair, but that promise is looking increasingly tenuous.
lead_paragraph: This is an important year for Myanmar. Parliamentary elections are scheduled for November, and the military-dominated government of President Thein Sein promised they would be free, fair and inclusive. That promise is looking increasingly tenuous, as signs that Myanmar is retreating on democratic reform multiply.

headline: Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet Plans to Close
abstract: The company, founded by the Walmart heiress Nancy Laurie, had generous contracts for dancers and its own Chelsea theater.
lead_paragraph: Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet seemed like the dance company that had it all: a wealthy benefactor, generous contracts and benefits for its dancers, and a snazzy Chelsea home.

headline: It Comes Before Iyar
abstract: Will Shortz on a puzzle design that has seen its day.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY POST — Today’s puzzle by Frederick J. Healy will be reviewed by editor Will Shortz today, because 1) he has a lot to say about it, and 2) he is a nice person and knows that I haven’t had a day off in a very long time.

headline: Evicted Tenant Started Queens Fire, Officials Say
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Fires and Firefighters', 'ARSON', 'Evictions']
abstract: Luis Lopez, 30, was charged with starting a fire that destroyed eight homes on Wednesday night, just minutes after his landlord evicted him, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A fire that raced through a block of homes in Woodhaven, Queens, on Wednesday night was started by an angry tenant just minutes after his landlord evicted him from his apartment, the authorities said on Friday.

headline: Chris Christie’s Fair Housing Problem
abstract: Given the governor’s intransigence, the State Supreme Court put the responsibility just where it should be.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court of New Jersey has finally run out of patience with Gov. Chris Christie’s attempts to nullify its groundbreaking, three-decades-old decision in the Mount Laurel fair housing case, which prohibits wealthy towns from excluding affordable housing and requires them to write zoning laws that allow such housing to be built.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 20, 2015
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: March 20, 2015

headline: Oregon Shoots Down Oklahoma State
abstract: Thanks to Oregon’s victory, the Ducks’ coach will be able to extend his stay in Omaha, where he coached Creighton for 16 years.
lead_paragraph: OMAHA — Dana Altman’s return to Nebraska, where he grew up and coached for 16 years at Creighton, has been extended by two more days.

headline: See No Junk Food, Buy No Junk Food
keywords: ['Food', 'Food Stamps', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores', 'Fruit', 'Vegetables']
abstract: Stores that accept food stamps should give more space to produce.
lead_paragraph: FROM urban ghettos to declining inner-ring suburbs to destitute rural areas, Americans with little money live in “food deserts” where it is hard to find fresh fruits and vegetables.

headline: Obama Calls Nominee ‘Hostage’ of Trafficking Dispute
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: President Obama on Friday said that Republicans were holding Loretta E. Lynch “hostage” to a legislative disagreement unrelated to her nomination as attorney general.
lead_paragraph: President Obama on Friday said that Republicans were holding Loretta E. Lynch “hostage” to a legislative disagreement unrelated to her nomination as attorney general. “She is eminently qualified — nobody denies it,” Mr. Obama said in an interview with The Huffington Post. “Even the Republicans acknowledge she’s been a great prosecutor.” Republicans have said they will not hold the vote until a dispute with Democrats over a measure to create a fund for victims of sexual trafficking is resolved. “You don’t hold attorney general nominees hostage for other issues,” Mr. Obama said. He blamed “Senate dysfunction” and “stubbornness” by Republicans about approving any of his nominees.

headline: A Life Upended After an IV Glucose Treatment Popular Among Asian Immigrants
abstract: Two years since undergoing amputations after receiving a treatment known as a ringer, Myung Hwa Jang has become comfortable with daily routines like climbing into bed and grocery shopping.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — On a Thursday in late February, Myung Hwa Jang swung her feet off her bed and gingerly placed her pink Nike sneakers on the floor. With effort, she balanced on her artificial limbs and stood. It had been two years since both of her legs were amputated below the knees, along with her right arm and most of her left hand, after an infection raced through her body following a glucose injection she received in a storefront clinic in Flushing, Queens.

headline: Taxi Jumps Curb, Killing Pedestrian in the Bronx
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers']
abstract: One pedestrian was killed and two others critically injured when a taxi jumped a curb along the Grand Concourse in the Bronx on Friday night, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A taxi killed one pedestrian and critically injured two others in the Bronx on Friday when it jumped a curb and careered onto the sidewalk on a snowy night, the police said.

headline: Iowa’s Height Shuts Down Davidson’s 3-Point Game
abstract: The Hawkeyes, one of the tallest N.C.A.A. teams, held Davidson — which normally scores 40 percent of its points from behind the arc — to 21.4 percent on 3-point shots.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Time and again Friday night, one of Davidson’s guards — Jack Gibbs, perhaps, or Brian Sullivan, each 5 feet 11 inches — took the ball down the court and was met by a humid jungle of arms. Iowa’s lengthy, lithe forwards were outstretched, blocking passing lanes, ready to put a hand in the Davidson player’s face.

headline: Panic at New Orleans Airport as Police Shoot Man Who Attacked T.S.A. Officers
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Airport Security', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'AIRPORTS']
abstract: A man attacked security officers at New Orleans airport with wasp spray and a machete before being shot by a sheriff’s deputy stationed at the airport, officials said.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — A 63-year-old man attacked Transportation Security Administration officers with wasp spray and a machete Friday night before he was shot by a law enforcement officer at a security gate to a busy concourse at Louis Armstrong International Airport outside New Orleans, the authorities said.

headline: Jason Kidd’s Past Meets, and Beats, His Present (and Future)
abstract: The Kidd-coached Bucks lost to his old team, the Nets, in three overtimes, a result that could affect the Eastern Conference playoff race.
lead_paragraph: The juxtaposition of the Nets and the Milwaukee Bucks on Friday provided more evidence of the capriciousness of sports fates, the fallibility of best-laid plans and the peculiarity of the Eastern Conference.

headline: Oklahoma Sputters but Holds Off Feisty Albany
abstract: Albany, the 14th seed, refused to lie down for No. 3 Oklahoma, which squandered double-digit leads more than once.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Midway through the first half of Albany’s game against Oklahoma, Peter Hooley planted his feet, calibrated his hips and launched a 3-point attempt high into the air.

headline: Roosevelt Jones of Butler Is Cleared to Play
abstract: Jones, Butler’s second-leading scorer, will be available to play against Notre Dame on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Butler’s second-leading scorer, Roosevelt Jones, will be available to play against Notre Dame on Saturday.

headline: Ron Hunter Says ‘Sorry’ After a Poke at the President
abstract: Hunter had poked fun at President Obama for not picking Georgia State to win in his bracket, and was bombarded with emails and social media posts.
lead_paragraph: Occasionally at the tournament, coaches go on entertaining tangents during their off-day news conferences.

headline: Northern Iowa Player Aims to Follow Brother’s Path to Final Four
abstract: Matt Bohannon, a guard for the Panthers, is hoping to emulate his brother Zach, who made it to the Final Four with Wisconsin last year.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — In 2001, Gordy Bohannon drove his three older sons from their home in Iowa to the Final Four in Minneapolis. After watching Duke defeat Arizona for the national championship, they drove back, and the sons told themselves that their goal was to one day play in the Final Four.

headline: Readers Respond to Starbucks ‘Race Together’ Initiative
abstract: An article about a campaign intended to help spark a conversation on race in America accrued a broad range of reactions in its comment section.
lead_paragraph: It’s early and a line of sleepy folk who just want to grab a soy latte and get to work snakes through Starbucks. But first, the barista behind the counter needs to broach a sensitive subject.

headline: Suddenly Hot-Shooting San Diego State Frustrates St. John’s
abstract: San Diego State entered the game ranked 300th in total offense but overwhelmed St. John’s, which has not won an N.C.A.A. tournament game since 2000.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — D’Angelo Harrison had just exhausted himself on the offensive end, trying to help St. John’s come back from a double-digit second-half deficit. Walking toward the raucous contingent of Red Storm fans, he shook his head back at them.

headline: Gonzaga Bears Down for Win After North Dakota State’s Strong Start
abstract: The Bison jumped to a 9-4 lead, but the Bulldogs adjusted and prevailed in a game that remained close much of the way.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Gonzaga began the game pressing North Dakota State, and the Bison, the heavy underdogs, passed right through it, getting ahead of Gonzaga’s defenders to sink two 3-pointers. Nearly three minutes into the game, they led by 9-4.

headline: Wisconsin Prevails as Coastal Carolina Fades After Strong First Half
abstract: The Chanticleers shot 52 percent in the first half, but Frank Kaminsky and the Badgers proved too potent and advanced easily.
lead_paragraph: OMAHA — Coastal Carolina, the No. 16 seed in the West Region of the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament, hit just enough shots to hang with top-seeded Wisconsin for the first 13 minutes of their game in the round of 64 on Friday.

headline: Serena Williams Withdraws From Indian Wells With Knee Injury
abstract: Williams withdrew from the semifinals of the BNP Paribas Open, citing a knee injury.
lead_paragraph: Serena Williams withdrew from the semifinals of the BNP Paribas Open, citing a knee injury. Her withdrawal gave Simona Halep a walkover into the final.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (IFC) INGLOURIOUS BASTERDS (2009) This revisionist history by Quentin Tarantino takes place during World War II as Lt. Aldo Raine (Brad Pitt) leads a special unit of Jewish American soldiers, dedicated to scalping Nazis, on to a plot to kill Hitler. Shosanna Dreyfus (Mélanie Laurent) escapes the murder of her family by Col. Hans Landa (Christoph Waltz) and his men and runs a movie theater in Paris. When the Nazis choose her theater for the premiere of a propaganda film, Shosanna begins scheming. For more Tarantino, “Kill Bill: Vol. 2” plays at 8 on Showtime. The film follows Beatrix Kiddo (Uma Thurman) as she takes revenge on the Deadly Viper Assassination Squad. Mr. Tarantino’s “movies are about loss and betrayal, and ‘Kill Bill Vol. 2’ is a double-burger helping of those motifs,” Elvis Mitchell wrote in The New York Times. “It is rich, substantial and sustained, yet also greasy kids’ stuff.”

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, March 21, 2015.
lead_paragraph: “Well, I guess the question is, which one?”

headline: Dayton Upsets Providence in Front of Raucous Ohio Crowd
abstract: The 11th-seeded Flyers, who had won a virtual home game to get into the round of 64, traveled an hour east to Columbus and found another friendly reception.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — To earn a spot in the main portion of the N.C.A.A. tournament, Dayton slipped by Boise State this week in a play-in contest that was a virtual home game for the Flyers. When the team traveled an hour east to Columbus, it was as if the Flyers had moved from their living room to their kitchen.

headline: Chinese, Japanese and South Korean Ministers to Resume Three-Way Talks
abstract: Recognizing the urgent need to stop the country’s nuclear weapons program, South Korea, Japan and China issued a joint statement in which they said they would continue to try to reopen talks aimed at ending North Korea’s nuclear weapons development.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — In their first trilateral meeting in three years, the foreign ministers of South Korea, Japan and China recognized on Saturday the urgent need to stop North Korea’s nuclear weapons program, South Korean officials said.

abstract: The profitability of today’s giant cruise ships depends on a tightly choreographed routine that’s part Nascar pit stop, part Noah’s Ark.
lead_paragraph: Once a week, after touring the Caribbean, the cruise ship Oasis of the Seas calls into its home port in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., for what is called “turnaround day.”

headline: Brooklyn Fire Kills 7 Children, City’s Worst Toll Since 2007
abstract: A fire that ripped through the home of an Orthodox Jewish family, trapping the children — ages 5 to 16 — in their bedrooms, was sparked by a malfunctioning hot plate, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A hot plate warmed food in the darkened kitchen in Brooklyn, allowing an Orthodox Jewish mother to feed her family while observing the Sabbath prohibition on lighting a flame. Upstairs, she and eight children slept.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — Stressing that it was time to make tough decisions, Secretary of State John Kerry said Saturday that negotiators should stick to their goal of completing an initial accord limiting Iran‘s nuclear program by the end of March.

headline: From Minneapolis to ISIS: An American’s Path to Jihad
abstract: The chilling progression of a Minnesota man suggests that the Islamic State may rely on recruiters inside the United States and shows how hard it is to predict who will be swept away by ideological fervor.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Reading back over Abdi Nur’s Twitter feed, his chilling progression from the basketball courts of South Minneapolis to the battlefields of Syria is clear.

headline: A Tough Business
abstract: Musicians and money.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a writeup of the panel that brought me to SXSW. As you might expect, the Butler brothers from Arcade Fire are really well-spoken and interesting; basically, I’m pretty sure they could do my job, whereas there’s no way I could do theirs.

headline: Review: In the Comic ‘Baskerville’ at the McCarter Theater Center, Sherlock Holmes Investigates a Curse
abstract: “Baskerville,” a comic retelling of “The Hound of the Baskervilles” by Arthur Conan Doyle, finds Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Watson being asked to investigate a death in the English countryside.
lead_paragraph: The mystery inside the mystery of “Baskerville” is why this fairly amusing play isn’t funnier. Indeed, so many of the elements are first-rate — skilled actors and a clever staging at the McCarter Theater Center in Princeton among them — that it can feel downright puzzling when jokes miss their marks. Sure, there are laughs. But it often seems that they should be louder.

headline: Fatal Fire in Brooklyn
abstract: Seven children died in a two-alarm fire at a house in the Midwood neighborhood that was caused by a hot plate.
lead_paragraph: Seven children died in a two-alarm fire at a house in the Midwood neighborhood that was caused by a hot plate.

headline: Carter Burwell, Writing Music to Watch Corpses By
abstract: Carter Burwell has composed scores for the “Twilight” vampire saga and most of the Coen brothers’ movies, many featuring gangsters and psychopaths.
lead_paragraph: What kind of movie music best suits a psychopath?

headline: Variety: A Constrained Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon take us back in time.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — It is debatable whether the CORSET will ever regain the popularity it seems to have had during the VICTORIAN era, but there is still a contingent of women — and drag queens — who enjoy the shape it gives to their figures.

headline: In ‘The Pianist of Willesden Lane,’ Holding On to Her Mother’s Memories
abstract: In her one-woman show “The Pianist of Willesden Lane,” Mona Golabek re-enacts episodes from her mother’s troubled, sometimes turbulent adolescence in wartime London.
lead_paragraph: After performances of her one-woman show, Mona Golabek said, people sometimes ask her, “Why wasn’t I warned to bring more handkerchiefs?”

headline: Izola Ware Curry, Who Stabbed King in 1958, Dies at 98
abstract: In 1958, she stabbed the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. at a Harlem book signing — an episode that a decade later would become a rhetorical touchstone in the last oration of his life.
lead_paragraph: Izola Ware Curry, the mentally ill woman who in 1958 stabbed the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. at a Harlem book signing — an episode that a decade later would become a rhetorical touchstone in the last oration of his life — died on March 7 in Queens. She was 98.

headline: This Time, Serena Williams Is Cheered as She Leaves Indian Wells
abstract: Serena Willliams’s withdrawal rekindled memories from 14 years earlier when she was booed after her sister Venus withdrew with a knee injury shortly before a semifinal the two were set to play.
lead_paragraph: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — In a stark change from 2001, Serena Williams was cheered upon her exit from the Indian Wells tournament on Friday night. Unlike 2001, when she was booed mercilessly, she did not win the tournament, but had to withdraw from the semifinals of the BNP Paribas Open with an injury to her right knee.

headline: At Kenta in Melville, the Menu Is Adventurous and Fun
abstract: A dramatic, torch-lit welcome for diners outside, with meticulous service inside.
lead_paragraph: Few Asian restaurants on Long Island have the firepower of Kenta, a newcomer offering food described as modern Asian with Japanese influences.

headline: Chuck Bednarik, Eagles’ Man of Concrete, Dies at 89
abstract: Bednarik, the Philadelphia Eagles’ Hall of Fame center and linebacker, was one of the last N.F.L. players to commonly play on both offense and defense.
lead_paragraph: Chuck Bednarik, the Philadelphia Eagles’ Hall of Fame center and linebacker, one of the last N.F.L. players to commonly play on both offense and defense and a legendary football tough guy, died Saturday in Richland, Pa. He was 89.

headline: A Maven of Money Law
abstract: Obrea Poindexter advises companies on tech matters such as mobile payments, virtual currency, data security, privacy and electronic signatures.
lead_paragraph: Obrea Poindexter is a lawyer at Morrison & Foerster in Washington.

lead_paragraph: Last year, when Tunde Adebayo needed three inflatable bouncy castles for KidzPlay, his event-planning business in Lagos, Nigeria, he turned to an online shopping service called MallforAfrica.

lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

abstract: Two new proposals aim to make top executives think twice before taking outsize risks, because breaking rules would cost them money.
lead_paragraph: Life is not fair, I know, but this is getting ridiculous.

headline: Writing My Way to a New Self
abstract: I was awkward by phone, but charming by email.
lead_paragraph: I stared at the head counselor with a mixture of defiance, annoyance and heartbreak. She had just informed me that she was demoting me. Gone was the prestige position of senior counselor for a group of 13-year-old girls, and in its place, a midlevel position as a co-counselor for a group of 11-year-olds.

headline: Under Health Care Act, Many Tax Filers Are Discovering Costly Complications
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Income Tax', 'Taxation', 'Tax Preparers and Preparation']
abstract: Under the Affordable Care Act, people who remained uninsured last year must either pay a penalty with their taxes or claim an exemption.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — When he signed up for health insurance through the Affordable Care Act last fall, J. C. Ciesielski estimated his income at $19,400, qualifying him for a federal subsidy that cut his premiums in half. But Mr. Ciesielski, an actor, earned an extra $2,340 from a voice-over job in December, and that welcome bit of income proved problematic when he did his taxes this month.

headline: Princeton Remains Unbeaten as Obama Watches
abstract: President Obama, whose niece Leslie Robinson plays for Princeton, attended the Tigers’ first-round N.C.A.A. tournament game, a victory over Wisconsin-Green Bay.
lead_paragraph: COLLEGE PARK, Md. — They were undefeated at 30-0 and perhaps under-respected, too, with a low seeding that left them feeling like the oddest underdogs in recent N.C.A.A. tournament memory.

headline: Scottish Party May Prove Crucial to Future of Britain’s Nuclear Fleet

abstract: Scotland’s growing political importance has made the arsenal an issue in Britain’s general election campaign.
lead_paragraph: FASLANE, Scotland — Britain’s aging nuclear-armed submarines, the force that keeps the nation in the first tier of global powers, have been the target of spirited if largely ineffectual protests by antiwar activists for more than three decades here in the fleet’s home port.

headline: The Curious (and Vital) Power of Print
keywords: ['Public Editor (Times Column)', 'Newspapers', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Many Times readers are passionate about the printed paper, and they may be younger and more digitally engaged than conventional wisdom would have it.
lead_paragraph: WHO buys the print edition of the newspaper? Just a few Luddites who wouldn’t know a smartphone if their horse-drawn buggy crushed it on the cobblestones? Octogenarians and their older brothers?

headline: Second Person Dies After Taxi Jumps Curb in the Bronx
abstract: A 5-year-old girl was one of four people struck while they waited for a bus on the Grand Concourse on Friday night, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A 5-year-old girl who was among four people struck by a taxi that jumped a curb in the Bronx on Friday night has died, making her the second person killed in the crash, the police said on Saturday.

headline: Angry Protest Over New Bishop in Chile
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Priests']
abstract: Demonstrators interrupted the installation ceremony for the new Roman Catholic bishop of Osorno, Juan Barros, whom they accuse of complicity in a notorious case of clerical sexual abuse.
lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — Hundreds of demonstrators dressed in black barged into a cathedral in a city in southern Chile on Saturday and interrupted the installation ceremony for the city’s new Roman Catholic bishop, Juan Barros, whom they accuse of complicity in a notorious case of clerical sexual abuse, blocking his passage and shouting, “Barros, get out of the city!”

headline: Riled Herpetologists Press Obama Administration to Protect America’s Salamanders from a Fungal Threat
keywords: ['AMPHIBIANS', 'ANIMALS', 'Biodiversity', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Invasive Species', 'Salamanders']
abstract: Amphibian experts get righteously riled about the slow-motion federal response to an extreme, and preventable, threat to American wildlife.
lead_paragraph: The herpetologists I’ve met over the decades tend to be a retiring lot. Explore the website of the Herpetologists’ League to get the idea. They hunker down and probe under rotting logs and leaf litter for salamanders or prowl deserts to study tortoises and lizards. Some study ancient specimens in dusty jars. That was the case with the first herpetologist I got to know, during a junior semester abroad in London in 1977. I approached Garth Underwood (yes), at London’s Natural History Museum about undertaking a line of independent study. Underwood set me to work dissecting water snakes, some more than a century old, to look for differences between the sexes. (He passed away in 2002.)

headline: Why Health Care Tech Is Still So Bad
keywords: ['Electronic Health Records', 'Doctors', 'Medicine and Health', 'Science and Technology', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Electronic records will transform medicine, eventually.
lead_paragraph: LAST year, I saw an ad recruiting physicians to a Phoenix-area hospital. It promoted state-of-the-art operating rooms, dazzling radiology equipment and a lovely suburban location. But only one line was printed in bold: “No E.M.R.”

headline: For College Basketball Players, Skin Is No Longer In

lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — In a game with so many tall people, you might expect a little more leg.

keywords: ['Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism', 'Computers and the Internet']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a new online threat to American military personnel, the Islamic State has called on its members and sympathizers in the United States to kill 100 service members whose names, photos and purported addresses it posted on a website.

headline: It’s a Whole New Paranoid World
abstract: I’ve tried to stop gossiping so much in email.
lead_paragraph: THERE is probably nothing about me that is not in the hands of hackers.

headline: No Seasonal Fix for the Economy
abstract: Time and again, Easter shopping and warmer weather have not heralded sustainable improvements.
lead_paragraph: Some economic forecasters have pinned their hopes for an improvement in the economy on this year’s early Easter to boost consumer spending after a brutal winter.

headline: Gregory Doran
abstract: The artistic director of the Royal Shakespeare Company on eating rotting medlar fruit and seeing gorillas in Rwanda on his honeymoon.
lead_paragraph: Gregory Doran is the artistic director of the Royal Shakespeare Company in Stratford-upon-Avon, England.

headline: Brazil’s Dim Voice on the World Stage
abstract: President Dilma Rousseff, who has been an underwhelming leader, would be wise to spend more energy looking outward.
lead_paragraph: When Dilma Rousseff was elected president of Brazil in 2010, industry was thriving and her goal of stamping out poverty in the world’s seventh-largest economy appeared within reach. Many Brazilians hoped that Ms. Rousseff, a former political prisoner, would establish a legacy as a transformational head of state at home and abroad.

headline: Two Women, Opposite Fortunes
abstract: A story of two women: One is Africa’s youngest billionaire; the other has lost 10 children.
lead_paragraph: LUANDA, Angola — THIS is the tale of two women, each an emblem, in her own way, of one of the world’s most corrupt and dysfunctional nations.

headline: A Football Player’s Safe Exit
abstract: It takes a special kind of professional football player to walk away from cheering crowds and multimillion-dollar paychecks.
lead_paragraph: It takes a special kind of professional football player to walk away from cheering crowds and multimillion-dollar paychecks. But that is what Chris Borland, a star rookie for the San Francisco 49ers, felt compelled to do in the face of mounting evidence that the game’s repetitive head trauma could leave him gravely and permanently damaged. “I just thought to myself, ‘What am I doing?’ ” the 24-year-old defensive player explained in an interview with ESPN. “ ‘Is this how I’m going to live my adult life, banging my head, especially with what I’ve learned and know about the dangers?’ ”

lead_paragraph: Readers discuss whether undocumented immigrants should be legitimized and integrated into the United States economy.

lead_paragraph: KATHERINE BYRON, a senior at Brown University and a member of its Sexual Assault Task Force, considers it her duty to make Brown a safe place for rape victims, free from anything that might prompt memories of trauma.
