abstract: A senator’s son is 8,500 times more likely than his peers to become a senator.
lead_paragraph: THERE is a very real chance that the presidential election in 2016 will pit Jeb Bush against Hillary Clinton. According to oddsmakers, this is the likeliest outcome.

headline: What Begat What
keywords: ['Inventions and Patents', 'Wearable Computing', 'Science and Technology', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Once, you wore a barrel to signify poverty; now you launch a Kickstarter campaign.
lead_paragraph: IN a recent Daily Beast article, we learned that the two-way wrist radio worn by the cartoon character Dick Tracy helped pave the way for Apple’s new smartwatch, which can make and receive phone calls. “I have been wanting to do this since I was 5 years old,” said Apple’s chief executive, Timothy D. Cook, referring to 1965 when he became besotted with the fictional detective’s gizmo.

headline: Renewing Call to End Turkey Conflict, Kurdish Rebel Leader Hails ‘New Era’
abstract: Abdullah Ocalan, the jailed leader of the Kurdistan Workers’ Party, urged his group to hold a congress in the spring to end the insurgency.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The jailed Kurdish rebel leader Abdullah Ocalan on Saturday renewed a call for his fighters to disarm and end a long conflict with Turkey, hailing a “new era” in relations between Turks and Kurds.

headline: A Changing Los Angeles
abstract: Gentrification comes to areas of the city.
lead_paragraph: Gentrification comes to areas of the city.

headline: Viva Gentrification!
abstract: In Los Angeles, it has meant less segregation.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — FOR years, our family journeys have taken us from our hillside home, in the multiethnic Mount Washington district of northeast Los Angeles, into the flatlands of the Latino barrios that surround it.

headline: Review: Ariana Grande Leaves Nickelodeon in the Rearview Mirror
abstract: There were some tears and some flubs, but the singer showed exceptional voice, exceptional pluck and an exceptional sense of the marketplace at Madison Square Garden.
lead_paragraph: The first time Ariana Grande cried on Friday night at Madison Square Garden was a little before the halfway mark of her show.

headline: U.C.L.A. Romps Past U.A.B. With Unselfish Play and Domination in the Paint
abstract: The Bruins’ size and depth proved to be too much for the pesky Blazers to overcome.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — This time, pluck was no match for pedigree, as U.C.L.A. turned to one extraordinary offensive player after another on Saturday to thwart another upset bid by the University of Alabama at Birmingham.

headline: A 50-Year Party, A Legend Revised
abstract: The ever-innovative Meredith Monk is celebrating the 50th anniversary of her professional career.
lead_paragraph: The ever-innovative Meredith Monk, a composer, dancer, singer, choreographer, director and filmmaker, is celebrating the 50th anniversary of her professional career. On Sunday at Carnegie Hall, she is joined by her acclaimed Vocal Ensemble — which champions her distinctive technique — and a host of musicians from the classical, jazz and D.J. worlds. Those colleagues will include the Bang on a Can All-Stars, Lukas Ligeti, John Zorn, Missy Mazzoli, Jessye Norman and DJ Spooky, performing an all-Monk program. (3 p.m., Zankel Hall, carnegiehall.org.)

headline: A Toxic Wasteland Called Home
abstract: On Thursday, the Studio Museum in Harlem opens “Trenton Doyle Hancock: Skin and Bones, 20 Years of Drawing.”
lead_paragraph: Since he was a college student, the Houston artist Trenton Doyle Hancock has been drawing into existence a world that might be what Texas would look like if all of the state’s oil were to bubble up and turn it into a toxic zombie wasteland. Populated by creatures called Mounds, the work seems to be the residue of a postmodern fever dream, borrowing as much from museum walls (Peter Saul, Mike Kelley) as from comic-book pages (Basil Wolverton, Spain Rodriguez).

headline: On TV, That Thing With Feathers
abstract: Masterpiece isn’t a word to be thrown around lightly, but there’s no denying that Mark Morris’s “L’Allegro, il Penseroso ed il Moderato” is thrillingly that.
lead_paragraph: Masterpiece isn’t a word to be thrown around lightly, but there’s no denying that Mark Morris’s “L’Allegro, il Penseroso ed il Moderato” is thrillingly that. Choreographed in 1988, when Mr. Morris was the director of dance at the Théâtre Royal de la Monnaie in Brussels, this production, at long last, has been preserved on film by “Great Performances” and can be seen on PBS on Friday night. (Check local listings.) Set to Handel’s 1740 oratorio based on Milton’s pastoral poems, this performance by the Mark Morris Dance Group was recorded in 2014 at the Teatro Real in Madrid. Using dance, music, poetry and visual design — Adrianne Lobel’s series of color planes, inspired by watercolors of William Blake, moves right along with the dancers — the production, as the host, Mikhail Baryshnikov, summarizes, reveals “joy, abandon, restraint, dignity and pride for humankind.”

headline: The Lengths to Go for Love
abstract: Neil Diamond performs at the Barclays Center on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: You, there — you are worthy of love. How would you like to be loved this week? There are two options — two that count, at least.

headline: Eloise and Hilary, Together Again
abstract: Eloise, that 6-year-old imp running amok at the Plaza Hotel is the subject of “It’s Me, Hilary: The Man Who Drew Eloise,” Monday night on HBO.
lead_paragraph: Her hair was in perpetual disarray, her stomach hung over her skirt, and the things that came out of her mouth weren’t always very nice. But Eloise, that 6-year-old imp running amok at the Plaza Hotel, inspired the fantasies of many a precocious child and more than a few adults — not least Lena Dunham of “Girls” renown, who had Eloise’s likeness tattooed on her back at 17.

headline: A Mother’s Clutch Makes Its Mark
abstract: Perspectives from a local and international standpoint distinguish the fifth annual New Voices in Black Cinema.
lead_paragraph: Perspectives from a local and international standpoint distinguish the fifth annual New Voices in Black Cinema, running Thursday through next Sunday at BAMCinématek. The festival begins with the world premiere of “Knucklehead,” the writer-director Ben Bowman’s drama about a mentally disabled youth (Gbenga Akinnagbe, from “The Wire”) who struggles to survive life in Brooklyn public housing after the shooting of his brother and the predations of his abusive mother (a terrifying Alfre Woodard). Mr. Bowman and Mr. Akinnagbe field questions after the screening.

headline: Democratic Booms
abstract: Much more significant than anything that happened under Reagan.
lead_paragraph: Everyone in the Republican Party knows that Reagan presided over an economy that has never been equalled, before or since. When I was on TV with Rand Paul, he confidently declared

headline: Yankees Squint and Flail Under the Dim Lights of Their Spring Training Stadium
abstract: The Yankees traditionally play more night games than other teams during spring training, but the weak lighting at George M. Steinbrenner Field can make that particularly challenging.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — As the sun set behind George M. Steinbrenner Field on Thursday night, the lights atop the eight towers strained to illuminate the baseball game below.

headline: Threats by Yemen’s Warring Parties Escalate Crisis
abstract: A day after two suicide bombings killed 130 people in Yemen’s capital, the president traded threats with the Houthi rebels who forced his government into exile.
lead_paragraph: AL MUKALLA, Yemen — From sparring seats of power across an increasingly divided country, Yemen’s president and the Houthi rebels who forced his government into exile traded ultimatums and threats on Saturday, escalating tensions after days of unrelenting violence.

headline: Myanmar’s Fight With Rebels Creates Refugees and Ill Will With China
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: The Myanmar Army has been fighting rebels of the Kokang, a Chinese ethnic group that has lived in the mountains of northern Myanmar for more than 400 years.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — When rumors spread around the sugar-cane farms in northern Myanmar that the army was advancing, Li Jiapeng and his family packed some clothes, grabbed some cash and joined a long line of people fleeing in cars and on foot. Everyone was heading for safety on the other side of the border in China, just six miles away.

headline: With History as Their Guide, Ducks Are on a Tempered Roll
abstract: In contention for the Presidents’ Trophy as the N.H.L.’s best team during the regular season, Anaheim is wary of getting too satisfied with itself.
lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — The Anaheim Ducks have a young roster, an enviable salary-cap situation, immense resilience to adversity and the N.H.L.’s best record, yet none of that seems to matter in their dressing room.

headline: Anthony Davis Is Unstoppable, Except on the Road to His First Playoffs
abstract: Anthony Davis has made yet another leap in his third season, becoming one of the two or three best players in the N.B.A., but he has been unable to lead the Pelicans to the postseason.
lead_paragraph: It may seem odd to suggest that the clock is ticking for Anthony Davis to make the playoffs in just his third season. But when a player as talented as Davis comes around, the wait for the postseason is generally rather short.

headline: ATP Tour Officials Seek Ways to Heighten the Profile of Doubles Players
abstract: The tour would like to see strong and attractive doubles field throughout the season, such as the one at the BNP Paribas Open, which is an exception.
lead_paragraph: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — The BNP Paribas Open has long been known for the strength of its doubles field, and this year was no exception, with nine of the top 10 singles players entered. But few ATP Tour events are as fortunate.

headline: Chocolates: Reviews of Holsten’s in Bloomfield, Chocodiem in Clinton and the Fudge Shoppe in Flemington
abstract: These three New Jersey confectioneries create chocolate treats, from simple to elaborate, the old-fashioned way.
lead_paragraph: Poor Tony Soprano. When he visited Holsten’s in the final episode of “The Sopranos,” he ordered only the onion rings.

headline: White Sox Open Checkbook After Once Being Tight With Bullpen Budget
abstract: The addition of the former Yankee David Robertson and the former Brewer Zach Duke gave Chicago some late-inning firepower.
lead_paragraph: GLENDALE, Ariz. — The strategy sounds wise, because each point behind it is sound. Relief pitchers are notoriously unpredictable. With shrewd scouting and coaching, teams can find effective, low-cost bullpen arms. Therefore, it is foolish to spend big on relievers.

headline: A Review: At Coals in Bronxville, Pizza’s on the Grill
abstract: This restaurant’s grilled pizzas with superthin crusts, once available only in the Bronx and Port Chester, are topped with fresh ingredients.
lead_paragraph: Good pizza has been easy to find in Westchester for years. Beyond the traditional New York-style pizza available on virtually every streetcorner, there is the Neapolitan puffy-crusted version from places like Zero Otto Nove in Armonk, wonderful experiments with toppings like the white clam pie at Frank Pepe’s in Yonkers and numerous interpretations of flatbread pizza across the county.

headline: Curtain Rises on a Spanish Second Act
abstract: Olea, which opened in New Haven in August, specializes in elegant Mediterranean cuisine favored by its Manuel Romero, its co-owner and Spanish-born chef.
lead_paragraph: Making a great first impression in a community, never mind maintaining it for more than a decade, is a coup for any chef. But when a culinary ace has built a reputation with a particular restaurant, planning a second act presents its own challenges. How best to follow up, when your opening set has already been so well received?

headline: In ‘Just Kids From the Bronx,’ Famous Names Recall Their Roots
abstract: In her book “Just Kids From the Bronx,” the author Arlene Alda collects more than 60 evocative oral histories from a diverse group that includes Colin L. Powell, Carl Reiner, Neil DeGrasse Tysonand Chazz Palminteri.
lead_paragraph: Real New Yorkers never tire of tales about Brooklyn, but for 20th-century nostalgia, the Bronx ranks a close second. Reinforcing that point, Arlene Alda has collected more than 60 evocative oral histories in “Just Kids From the Bronx: Telling It the Way It Was” (Henry Holt and Co.).

headline: Assailant Shot at New Orleans Airport Is Dead
abstract: A machete-wielding man who attacked officers at the New Orleans airport also had a bag of fire bombs and smoke bombs in his car, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — The machete-wielding man who attacked officers at a security checkpoint at the New Orleans airport on Friday night and was shot by a sheriff’s deputy died on Saturday, law enforcement officials said.

headline: Documentaries Are the Go-To Players of Sports Television
abstract: The films, cheaper to produce than live events and attracting a reliable audience, are exploding thanks to series like ESPN’s “30 for 30.”
lead_paragraph: You have probably seen many of the films. There was “The Fab Five,” about the rise and fall of a fabled Michigan basketball recruiting class, and “The U,” which told the story of Miami football so well that its director made a sequel. More recently, “Of Miracles and Men” described the 1980 Olympic hockey tournament from the less familiar Soviet team’s point of view, and Duke-loathing basketball fans were treated to the analytic probing of “I Hate Christian Laettner.”

headline: Giants Sign Defensive End George Selvie
abstract: The Giants continued their understated accumulation of free agents by signing the former Cowboy to a one-year, $1.4 million deal.
lead_paragraph: The Giants continued their understated accumulation of free agents Friday by signing the former Dallas Cowboys defensive end George Selvie to a one-year, $1.4 million contract. Selvie is the seventh free agent the team has acquired in the last 10 days, a list that includes signed the former Jets defensive tackle Kenrick Ellis.

headline: Unstated Factor in Iran Talks: Threat of Nuclear Tampering
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: A number of officials make the case that, if a deal is reached, surveillance of Iran will intensify and covert action may become more important to ensure that Iran does not import critical materials or pursue a covert path to a bomb.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In late 2012, just as President Obama and his aides began secretly sketching out a diplomatic opening to Iran, American intelligence agencies were busy with a parallel initiative: The latest spy-vs.-spy move in the decade-long effort to sabotage Tehran’s nuclear infrastructure.

headline: Deadly Fire in Brooklyn Renews Concerns Over a Weekly Ritual
keywords: ['Fires and Firefighters', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Accidents and Safety']
abstract: For Orthodox Jews who observe the Sabbath, the admonition not to leave cooking food unattended is hard to reconcile with certain tenets of their religion.
lead_paragraph: In the hours after a malfunctioning hot plate started a fast-moving blaze that killed seven brothers and sisters in an Orthodox Jewish neighborhood of Brooklyn on Saturday, a Fire Department official went door to door at nearby homes handing out pamphlets titled “Fire Safety for Jewish Observances.”

headline: Upsides
abstract: Jeremy Newton offers a puzzle that’s on the up and up.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Hey, what’s UP? Everyone having a good spring so far? Here, in the Northeast, we are celebrating the arrival of spring not by dancing around a maypole or planning a picnic, but by shoveling snow. As my parents used to say, life is not always fair, but it is almost always interesting. The UPSIDE to a frosty spring weekend is that we can hole UP with a spicy hot chocolate and the Sunday puzzle.

headline: Arrests Made in Attack on Tunisian Museum
abstract: More than 20 people were apprehended in an investigation into the assault that left 23 people dead on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: TUNIS — The Tunisian authorities have arrested more than 20 people in the investigation into Wednesday’s attack at the National Bardo Museum in Tunis, including 10 the authorities say were directly tied to the deadly assault, a spokesman for the Ministry of the Interior said Saturday.

headline: Kentucky Doesn’t Crack, Even as Cincinnati’s Defense Raises the Pressure
abstract: The top-seeded Wildcats won in front of a horde of their blue-clad fans, with their smothering defense holding the Bearcats to 32 percent shooting.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Kentucky center Willie Cauley-Stein sat on a bench in the Wildcats’ locker room wearing a T-shirt featuring the menacing face of the Incredible Hulk and talked about Cincinnati’s menacing play.

headline: Yankees Cross a State to Play Against a Crosstown Rival
abstract: The Yankees and the Mets will play Sunday in Tampa, Fla., in the teams’ first meeting during the exhibition season since 2012.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — C. C. Sabathia chuckled at the almost apologetic question: Would it mean anything to him to be starting Sunday against the Mets and their ace Matt Harvey when the Yankees travel across the state to play their crosstown rivals?

headline: Gonzaga Becomes a Melting Pot for Recruits From Across the Globe
abstract: The Bulldogs, a No. 2 seed in the N.C.A.A. tournament, have eight players who either played in another country before college or began their college careers with a different team.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — During Gonzaga’s 86-76 victory against North Dakota State on Friday night, forward Domantas Sabonis was fouled hard under the basket. He lay on his stomach for a moment until guard Byron Wesley ran over and stuck his hands beneath him as if lifting a piece of furniture.

headline: Study Suggests That Hitters’ Production Dips After They Return From Concussions
abstract: A study published in the American Journal of Sports Medicine indicates that position players in the majors who suffer concussions do not hit as effectively in their first weeks back after their injury.
lead_paragraph: Concussions are not as common in Major League Baseball as they are in professional football, but they happen often enough, with players getting hit by pitches, running into walls or catching a knee in the head sliding into a base. Catchers are particularly at risk — a foul tip off the mask will snap the neck back and give the brain a solid rattle. Collisions at the plate take a toll, too.

headline: For a St. Francis Player, UConn, Long an Inspiration, Turns Rival
abstract: Sarah Benedetti, who was raised in Connecticut and grew up as a UConn basketball fan, played for No. 16-seeded St. Francis in a game against the No. 1-seeded Huskies in the N.C.A.A. tournament.
lead_paragraph: STORRS, Conn. — When Sarah Benedetti moved to Canton, Conn., as a fifth grader in 2004, she almost immediately started rooting for the University of Connecticut’s basketball teams. That year, UConn became the first Division I university to win the national titles in men’s and women’s basketball.

headline: Oklahoma’s Spotty Road Record Doesn’t Worry Buddy Hield
abstract: The Sooners’ star guard shrugged off the potential advantage Dayton will have when the teams meet Sunday in Columbus.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — The Oklahoma star guard Buddy Hield sat in his team’s locker room on Saturday afternoon picking at a bag of Cheetos. His snack was interrupted by a gaggle of reporters who entered the team’s lair with questions about an upcoming game against Dayton, which will play in what is essentially its third home game in five days in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: Chicago Mayor’s Race Is Cast as a Test of Liberalism
abstract: Mayor Rahm Emanuel, a former chief of staff to President Obama, faces a surprisingly competitive runoff against Jesus G. Garcia, who is supported by progressives frustrated with business-backed politics.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Mayor Rahm Emanuel had just finished the quintessential municipal politics photo op, briefly inspecting a dusty street-paving project on a block of the South Side lined with tidy brick bungalows.

headline: An Illegal Boxing Club in the Bronx
abstract: Though unsanctioned, BX Fight Club aims to foster respect and redirect aggression among young men in the rougher sections of the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: Though unsanctioned, BX Fight Club aims to foster respect and redirect aggression among young men in the rougher sections of the Bronx.

headline: Duke and San Diego State Share a Long History
abstract: Steve Fisher, San Diego State’s coach, credits Mike Krzyzewski of Duke with helping him rebuild the Aztecs, who have joined the Blue Devils among the programs with streaks of N.C.A.A. tournament appearances.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — The last time Duke Coach Mike Krzyzewski and San Diego State’s Steve Fisher faced each other in an N.C.A.A. tournament game, it was the 1992 national championship game in Minneapolis, and Fisher was coaching the Fab Five of Michigan. Of course, Krzyzewski and Duke won that game for their second consecutive title.

headline: Andalusia Election a Measure of Spain’s Disillusionment
abstract: The vote on Sunday in the country’s largest region is being closely watched as a measure of just how fractured Spanish politics has become.
lead_paragraph: SEVILLE, Spain — Spain’s Socialists have run Andalusia, the country’s largest region, for 33 years, a bastion built on the party’s role in transforming the farming region by ushering Spain into the European Union in the 1980s.

headline: A San Diego State Forward Is Monitored by His Coach and an Implant
abstract: Despite an irregular heartbeat, Dwayne Polee II has contributed to the Aztecs.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — When San Diego State forward Dwayne Polee II collapsed in the middle of a game against U.C.-Riverside on Dec. 22, it could have meant the end of his basketball career. But an irregular heartbeat that requires a monitor implanted in his chest hasn’t stopped Polee or his team.

headline: Gone Spearfishin’
abstract: The sturgeon spearfishing season at Lake Winnebago, the largest lake in Wisconsin, attracts ice fishermen to the lake and relatives and neighbors to the check-ins.
lead_paragraph: The sturgeon spearfishing season at Lake Winnebago, the largest lake in Wisconsin, attracts ice fishermen to the lake and relatives and neighbors to the check-ins.

headline: The Groups That May Decide the Chicago Mayoral Election
abstract: Who Rahm Emanuel needs to win over to keep his seat in the April 7 runoff.
lead_paragraph: Who Rahm Emanuel needs to win over to keep his seat in the April 7 runoff.

headline: Arizona Goes Long to Defeat Ohio State
abstract: The game’s star freshmen were overshadowed by a couple of long-bombing guards for the Wildcats.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — In a game featuring soon-to-be N.B.A. players and beefy big men, it was Arizona’s long-bombing guards who led the Wildcats to the round of 16 with a 73-58 victory over Ohio State.

headline: Jeb Bush’s Team Plots Vast Effort to Win Florida
abstract: As former Gov. Jeb Bush moves toward a presidential run, a plan is in place to neutralize the threats that could make him more vulnerable in a state that has vexed Republicans in national elections.
lead_paragraph: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — The political apparatus surrounding former Gov. Jeb Bush, determined to avoid embarrassment in a state that has vexed his party and family in national elections, is plotting a vast operation aimed at turning Florida into a bulwark for his presidential campaign, according to dozens of interviews.

headline: Obama Says He Told Netanyahu That Talk Before Election Hurt the Peace Process
abstract: President Obama said he told Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel that his remarks that there would be no Palestinian state on his watch had stalled efforts to resolve the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama said he has told Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu that the Israeli leader’s remarks in the closing days of his re-election campaign had upended the Israeli-Palestinian peace process and ran counter to the very nature of Israeli democracy, an unusually forceful and public condemnation of the top official of a vital United States ally.

headline: Double Eagle Bolsters Daniel Berger, a Rookie, at Bay Hill
abstract: Bay Hill was soft early on Saturday after rains the night before, and Daniel Berger was one of several golfers who took advantage of the favorable conditions.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — After a 300-yard drive on Bay Hill’s par-5 sixth hole on Saturday, Daniel Berger had a downhill lie and a difficult decision. The 540-yard hole wraps around a lake like a backward “C,” and if Berger wanted to try for the green, his second shot would be flirting with the water.

headline: As Three Alfords Lead U.C.L.A., a Fourth Anchors the Family
abstract: For Tanya Alford, the wife of U.C.L.A. Coach Steve Alford, this year’s tournament is special, as her two sons are also playing for the Bruins.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — At one point during U.C.L.A.’s victory on Saturday, the blonde behind the Bruins’ bench stood just feet behind Coach Steve Alford, and was almost his mirror image.

headline: Rematch in the Desert for Roger Federer and Novak Djokovic
abstract: Djokovic booked a spot in the BNP Paribas Open final first, beating No. 4 Andy Murray, 6-2, 6-3, and Federer followed by topping Milos Raonic, 7-5, 6-4.
lead_paragraph: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — One dominating with returns, the other with serves, Novak Djokovic and Roger Federer marched on toward another meeting in the desert.

headline: Before Judges, the Godfathers Become Sick Old Grandfathers
abstract: A generation of geriatric gangsters known as the “oldfellas” can be found in court displaying catheter bags or discussing the state of their kidneys in hopes that a judge will agree to a short sentence.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, Thomas DiFiore cut an intimidating figure. For a time, he was the highest-ranking member of the Bonanno organized crime family not behind bars, despite a long record of arrests on charges of kidnapping, assault, promoting gambling and extortion. Even at 70, Mr. DiFiore did not seem to falter when challenging another aging Bonanno leader in 2013 for more than his share of a loan payment, according to prosecutors’ account of a government wiretap.

headline: Xavier, No Stranger to Upsets, Prevents One by Georgia State
abstract: The Panthers could not continue their tournament run against the Musketeers, who were themselves once low-seeded bracket busters.
lead_paragraph: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — The Xavier Musketeers were once N.C.A.A. tournament darlings, a plucky program and bottom-bracket seed looking to make a name. They understood the ride 14th-seeded Georgia State wanted to continue Saturday night and knew an upset lurked here at Jacksonville Veterans Memorial Arena.

headline: Kansas and Wichita State’s Unfulfilled Rivalry Receives a Little Help
abstract: Kansas and Wichita State, which have not played each other since 1993, are renewing their acquaintance as N.C.A.A. tournament foes.
lead_paragraph: OMAHA — They had one conversation about it. One. And it was not even formal.

headline: North Carolina State Adds to Its Lore by Shocking Top-Seeded Villanova
abstract: North Carolina State ousted Villanova, seeded No. 1 in the East Region, with a 71-68 victory at Consol Energy Center.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — Around North Carolina State’s program, its 1983 national title comes up from time to time. Coach Mark Gottfried makes sure it does. One of his top assistants, Dereck Whittenburg, played on that team, and he, too, reminds the current players of the Wolfpack’s brush with glory.

headline: Wisconsin Forward Plays Word Games
abstract: Nigel Hayes had a test for a stenographer, and she passed it beautifully.
lead_paragraph: OMAHA — Wisconsin forward Nigel Hayes calls himself a lover of words, especially long, unusual ones. Saturday, at Wisconsin’s off-day news conference before the Badgers’ round of 32 game with Oregon, Hayes playfully tested the spelling skills of the stenographer transcribing his words for the news media.

headline: Mets Demote Steven Matz, a Top Prospect, After a Solid Outing
abstract: As expected, the Mets optioned Matz to the minor league camp after he gave up three hits in two and two-thirds innings against the Tigers on Saturday. He is expected to start the season at Class AAA Las Vegas.
lead_paragraph: LAKELAND, Fla. — Everything about Steven Matz’s spring had an air of expectation.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 21, 2015
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: March 21, 2015

headline: With Jaroslav Halak Back in Goal, Islanders Top Devils to End Four-Game Skid
abstract: Halak made 26 saves for his fifth shutout and third victory against the Devils this season.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Struggling to score goals and fighting a four-game losing streak, the Islanders made their way to New Jersey hoping to rediscover their offense.

headline: Small Player Helps Utah Beat Georgetown by Thin Margin
abstract: With two teams rich in height and bulk facing off, 5-foot-10-inch Brandon Taylor made four 3-pointers for Utah in a game in which all the leads, until the last one, were elastic.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — A tight game between Utah and Georgetown, two teams rich in height and bulk, was decided in large part by the smallest player on the court.

headline: A Teenager Is Killed Near the Scene of a Brawl Caught on Video in Brooklyn
abstract: An 18-year-old male was found shot near a McDonald’s in Flatbush, where the taped brawl took place this month, the police said. A baby girl was also shot minutes earlier in the same neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: A teenager was killed and a baby girl was injured on Saturday in separate shootings in Flatbush, Brooklyn, the police said, one of which happened across the street from a McDonald’s that was the scene of a violent brawl widely seen on social media this month.

headline: North Carolina Stays Focused in Victory Over Arkansas
abstract: The Tar Heels’ toughness and concentration had been questioned during the season, but they finished off the Razorbacks with grit and style.
lead_paragraph: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — North Carolina’s focus has wandered in so many different directions that it was hard to figure out which team would show up Saturday night against Arkansas.

headline: Erin Mulhall, Eric DeBear
abstract: The couple were wed at the Memorial Chapel on the College Park campus of the University of Maryland.
lead_paragraph: Erin Cathleen Mulhall and Eric Julien DeBear were married Saturday at the Memorial Chapel on the College Park campus of the University of Maryland. The Rev. Alexei A. Michalenko, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony, with Rabbi Harold White taking part.

headline: Lindsay Kaplan,  Peter Kane
abstract: Lindsay Kaplan and Peter Kane, both lawyers in Manhattan, were married Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Lindsay Rachel Kaplan, the daughter of Gail Nussbaum Kaplan and James M. Kaplan of Englewood, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Peter Bijur Kane, a son of Priscilla B. Kane and Gerald Kane of Manhattan. Rabbi Angela Warnick Buchdahl, a senior rabbi at Central Synagogue, officiated at the Liberty Warehouse in Red Hook, Brooklyn.

headline: Staying Calm Among the Coyotes
abstract: Lost in New Mexico, a woman realizes she has found her lifelong partner.
lead_paragraph: Lisa Perri Sommer and Dr. Joshua David Balog were married Saturday evening at the Pleasantdale Chateau, an events space in West Orange, N.J. Rabbi Karen Perolman officiated.

headline: A Pairing With Punch
abstract: The bride’s love of kickboxing and wedding-dress design intrigued the groom.
lead_paragraph: Minna Minhwa Kao and Paul Gerard Heck were married Saturday at the Queen of All Saints Church in Brooklyn. The Rev. Joseph A. Ceriello, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Alexandra Daum and Alexander Kleiner
abstract: The bride and the groom both earned M.B.A.s from Harvard.
lead_paragraph: Alexandra Devon Daum, a daughter of Julie H. Daum and Robert C. Daum of North Palm Beach, Fla., was married Saturday evening to Alexander Mark Kleiner, the son of Diana E. E. Kleiner and Fred S. Kleiner of Woodbridge, Conn. Jessica Krulis, a friend of the couple who became a minister of the American Marriage Ministries for the event, officiated at Terra Gallery, an events space in San Francisco.

headline: Hannah DeLetto, Bryan Mochizuki
abstract: The bride and groom both work for the Clinton Global Initiative in New York.
lead_paragraph: Hannah Naomi DeLetto, a daughter of Laura A. DeLetto and Vincent DeLetto of Massapequa, N.Y., was married Saturday to Bryan Paul Mochizuki, the son of Debbie C. Mochizuki and William J. Mochizuki of Clovis, Calif. Pastor John W. Quince, who was ordained through the Farmingdale Christian Church, performed the ceremony at Roslyn Presbyterian Church in Roslyn, N.Y.

headline: Valerie Brown and Garry Grant
abstract: The couple was married at the First African Baptist Church in Savannah, Ga.
lead_paragraph: Valerie Sharice Brown and Garry Fitzgerald Grant were married Saturday at the First African Baptist Church in Savannah, Ga. The Rev. Calvin O. Butts III, the Baptist minister, performed the ceremony.

headline: Paige Elliott, Timothy McAdam
abstract: Paige Elliott and Timothy McAdam were married Saturday in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Paige Christian Elliott, a daughter of Patti Elliott and James R. Elliott III of Dallas, was married Saturday to Timothy Francis McAdam, a son of Maureen K. McAdam of Glen Cove, N.Y., and the late Dennis F. McAdam. The Rev. Paul Leggett, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at Location 05, a photography studio and events space in Manhattan.

headline: Arielle Katz,  Brad Birenberg
abstract: Arielle Katz and Brad Birenberg are to be married Sunday in Huntington, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Arielle Katz and Dr. Brad David Birenberg are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Martin S. Cohen at Oheka Castle in Huntington, N.Y.

headline: Megan Marinos and Alan Freedman
abstract: The couple met at George Washington University, from which they graduated.
lead_paragraph: Lieut. Megan Pauline Marinos, the daughter of Lynn B. Marinos and Paul H. Marinos of Old Bridge, N.J., was married Saturday to Alan Benjamin Freedman, a son of Nancy Redfern Freedman of Collingswood, N.J., and Dennis I. Freedman of Langhorne, Pa. Anthony N. Marinos, the bride’s brother, became a Universal Life minister for the event and officiated at the National Museum of Women in the Arts in Washington.

headline: Kat Gang, Nathan McRae
abstract: The bride is a jazz singer. The groom is an architect.
lead_paragraph: Kat Gang and Nathan Seth McRae are to be married Sunday outside the Metropolitan Museum of Art in Manhattan, where the Rev. John E. Hickey, the bride’s stepfather and a Unitarian Universalist minister, is to give a homily and lead a brief legal ceremony.

headline: Allison Strassberg,  Matthew Klarberg
abstract: The couple were married at at Capitale, an events space in New York.
lead_paragraph: Allison Michele Strassberg, a daughter of Louise B. Strassberg and Steven V. Strassberg of Manhasset Hills, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Matthew Scott Klarberg, a son of Rindi N. Klarberg of Morristown, N.J., and Barry J. Klarberg of Greenwich, Conn. Rabbi Douglas Krantz officiated at Capitale, an events space in New York.

headline: Jennifer Klein,  Gabriel Whitman
abstract: Jennifer Klein and Gabriel Whitman were married Saturday at Battery Gardens in New York.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Melissa Klein and Gabriel David Whitman were married in New York Saturday evening. Rabbi Ramie Arian officiated, with Rabbi Dena Klein participating, at Battery Gardens restaurant.

headline: Alexis Pew and Kevin Kaminski
abstract: The bride and groom are the principals in Kaminski & Pew, an architecture and interior design firm.
lead_paragraph: Alexis Clarke Pew, a daughter of Sandra Kennedy Pew and George Thompson Pew Jr. of Bryn Mawr, Pa., was married Saturday in Philadelphia to Kevin Marc Kaminski, the son of Joanne Will-Kaminski and Karl M. Kaminski of Orchard Park, N.Y. The Rev. Daniel P. Metzger, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony at Old Zion Lutheran Church, of which he is the pastor.

headline: Bari Cohn, Jonathan Maniff
abstract: The couple met at Syracuse, from which they graduated.
lead_paragraph: Bari Elyse Cohn, the daughter of Lynn O. Cohn and Jeffrey S. Cohn of Short Hills, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Jonathan Daniel Maniff, the son of Susan H. Maniff and Maury R. Maniff of Roslyn Heights, N.Y. Rabbi Michael A. White officiated at the Pierre in Manhattan.

headline: Meryl Rosofsky and Stuart Coleman
abstract: The bride and groom are to be married at Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Meryl Suzanne Rosofsky and Stuart Hayden Coleman are to be married Sunday at Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun in New York. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein is to lead the ceremony.

headline: Notre Dame Tops Nearby Butler in Close Finish
abstract: The Fighting Irish edged the Bulldogs, an intrastate rival. Afterward, Notre Dame Coach Mike Brey revealed that his mother died Saturday morning.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — The best team in Indiana is Notre Dame. The third-seeded Fighting Irish proved as much Saturday night, escaping a tussle with sixth-seeded Butler to prevail, 67-64, in overtime, at Consol Energy Center to advance to the Midwest Regional semifinals in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: Ted Cruz Hopes Early Campaign Entry Will Focus Voters’ Attention
abstract: By becoming the first candidate to officially enter the presidential race, the Texas senator hopes to reclaim the attention of those in the G.O.P.’s right wing.
lead_paragraph: The venue has little personal significance for him, but the timing of Senator Ted Cruz’s formal entry into the 2016 presidential field on Monday is full of meaning, as he seeks to catapult to the forefront of an increasingly competitive cluster of conservatives vying for the Republican nomination.

headline: Corrections: March 22, 2015
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Sunday, March 22, 2015.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
abstract: Today’s television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 12:30 P.M. (13) IL BARBIERE DI SIVIGLIA Lawrence Brownlee sings the role of the love-struck Count Almaviva; Isabel Leonard is Rosina, the feisty doctor’s ward who has captured his heart; and Christopher Maltman, making a spectacular entrance atop a traveling barber shop pulled by admirers, is Figaro in this Metropolitan Opera revival of Rossini’s comic classic. The production, staged by Bartlett Sher, conducted by Michele Mariotti and presented here by “Great Performances at the Met,” “delivers a heady fizz,” Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim wrote in The New York Times. “And it has stars,” she added — among them, Mr. Brownlee, who made “a dashing Almaviva, singing with a focused, ardent tenor”; Ms. Leonard, “a pitch-perfect Rosina, cute but sharp-clawed”; and Mr. Maltman (above right, with Mr. Brownlee and Ms. Leonard), who “oozed sex appeal during his opening aria, ‘Largo al factotum,’ wearing a magnificent red Phrygian cap like a royal insignia.”

headline: Melody Hwang and Craig Muhlrad
abstract: The couple were married at the Los Angeles Equestrian Center in Burbank, Calif.
lead_paragraph: Melody Hwang, a daughter of May Hwang and Andrew B. Hwang of South Pasadena, Calif., was married Saturday to Craig Scott Muhlrad, the son of Patricia Samuels Muhlrad and Dr. Jeffrey S. Muhlrad of Old Field, N.Y. Rabbi Arthur Rosenberg officiated at Calamigos Equestrian Terrace, an event space at the Los Angeles Equestrian Center in Burbank, Calif.

headline: Brianna Serrano,  Jason Pierce
abstract: Brianna Serrano and Jason Pierce, who met at Cornell, were married in San Marcos, Calif.
lead_paragraph: Brianna Kay Serrano and Jason Matthew Pierce were married Friday at Twin Oaks Garden Estate in San Marcos, Calif. Bethel Nathan, a pastor in the Church of Spiritual Humanism, officiated.

headline: Lauren Mancuso,  Alexander Jurecky
abstract: The couple was married at the Harold Pratt House in New York.
lead_paragraph: Lauren Aleesia Mancuso, the daughter of Victoria G. Mancuso and John J. Mancuso of Ossining, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Alexander Joseph Jurecky, the son of Blanka P. Jurecky and George T. Jurecky of Englewood, N.J. The Rev. Deborah S. Roth, an interfaith minister affiliated with the Sanctuary of the Beloved, officiated at the Harold Pratt House in New York.

headline: Still Hoping for Future Kodak Moments
abstract: After digital technology upended Kodak’s analog film world, employees ponder how the once-iconic company can prosper and remain technologically relevant.
lead_paragraph: There were almost 200 buildings that once housed Kodak’s daily production in Rochester. Over the last two decades, 80 of those buildings have been demolished and 59 others have been sold off — 61 buildings remain, awaiting an uncertain fate.

headline: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the week’s top stories.

headline: Rebels Seize Key Parts of Yemen’s Third-Largest City, Taiz
abstract: The advance set the Houthis more firmly on a path toward military confrontation with troops loyal to the president.
lead_paragraph: Al MUKALLA, Yemen — Houthi rebel fighters have taken control of crucial installations in Taiz, Yemen’s third-largest city, including the international airport, security officials said on Sunday, in a provocative expansion of the seven-month rebel offensive that has moved the country closer to war.

headline: My Daughter Is Now Sister Mary Joseph, and No Longer Mine
abstract: My daughter is becoming a nun, and I am grieving.
lead_paragraph: My daughter is preparing to make final vows as a Catholic sister, and though I’m a devout Catholic, I am still grieving that reality. It’s one of the hardest things I’ve had to deal with in my three decades of motherhood. In many ways, I’ve come to realize, she is no longer mine.

headline: Indian Opposition Delays Modi’s Land-Acquisition Effort
keywords: ['Land Use Policies', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Legislatures and Parliaments']
abstract: The Indian prime minister’s attempts to simplify companies’ ability to obtain land for development projects has hit a wall of opposition in Parliament.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — When the government of Prime Minister Narendra Modi muscled through an executive order in December simplifying the government and private companies’ ability to obtain land for what it deems important development projects, it sent a message to voters — and Mr. Modi’s political adversaries — about his decisive style of leadership and his commitment to industry.

headline: 1940: Passenger Who Didn’t Pay Fares Because of Tobacco Is Sued
abstract: Highlight from the International Herald Tribune archives: A woman refused to pay rail fares in 1940 because other passengers were smoking.
lead_paragraph: TRENTON, N.J. — Mrs. Amy P. Shirk, sixty-two years old, is being sued for $18.72 by the Reading Railroad, it was learned today, [Mar. 22] because her ‘‘allergy to tobacco smoke’’ led her to refuse to pay for 117 rides, at 16 cents each, on the Reading’s one-car local between Pennington and West Trenton. In the suit, filed yesterday in Trenton District Court, the railroad said that Mrs. Shirk made the trips between April and September, 1939, but refused to pay because the conductor would not heed her request that other passengers be restrained from smoking.

headline: For Obama, Ghani Offers Hope of a Less Fractious Relationship
abstract: When President Obama meets this week with Ashraf Ghani, he will finally be sitting across from an Afghan leader who is not suspicious or openly belligerent toward his American allies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Obama meets this week with Ashraf Ghani, Afghanistan’s new president, he will finally be sitting across from an Afghan leader who is not brooding, agitated, suspicious or openly belligerent toward his American allies.

headline: Thousands Join Brooklyn Father Mourning 7 With ‘Faces of Angels’
keywords: ['Fires and Firefighters', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: Gabriel Sassoon’s seven children, ages 5 to 16, were remembered at funeral services this afternoon; their mother and one surviving sister are hospitalized.
lead_paragraph: The mourners pushed toward the funeral chapel, row after row of black hats and black coats bowed toward the Brooklyn asphalt.

headline: Health Care Systems Try to Cut Costs by Aiding the Poor and Troubled
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Poverty', 'Homeless Persons', 'Medicaid', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Some of the most expensive patients — so-called super utilizers of hospital care — rack up costs for avoidable reasons. Experiments across the country are trying to better manage these cases.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Jerome Pate, a homeless alcoholic, went to the emergency room when he was cold. He went when he needed a safe place to sleep. He went when he was hungry, or drunk, or suicidal.

headline: After an Uneasy Start, Finding Common Ground to Discuss Race Relations at Work
abstract: A Staten Island man found ways to overcome the social awkwardness of having frank discussions in the workplace about race relations.
lead_paragraph: Carl Jones brought it up over lunch in the company break room: the news of the shooting death of an unarmed black man by a white police officer. “Did you read about it?” Mr. Jones, a software engineer who is black, remembers asking his colleagues. “How could this happen?”

headline: ‘Insurgent’  Tops Box Office
abstract: The film, starring Shailene Woodley as the gun-wielding rebel Tris Prior, took in an estimated $54 million over the weekend, according to Rentrak, which compiles box office data.
lead_paragraph: Tris tripped on a glass slipper.

headline: Cuomo Is Called Controlling but a ‘Contender’ in an Unauthorized Biography
abstract: In “The Contender,” Michael Shnayerson describes Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s youth in Queens, his father’s campaigns, his high-profile marriage and his political future.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — In the first few pages of “The Contender,” Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is portrayed as a “brilliant tactician” and a presidential hopeful, even if not in 2016. But the tone of the unauthorized biography quickly changes, positioning Mr. Cuomo as a control-obsessed politician who showed no tolerance for criticism or retail politics.

headline: Photographing Our Most Precious Resource
abstract: Associated Press photographers ahead of World Water Day on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Associated Press photographers ahead of World Water Day on Sunday.

headline: 1965: Saigon Forces Use Tear Gas on Enemy
abstract: Highlight from the International Herald Tribune archives: U.S.-equipped South Vietnamese troops are using nonlethal nauseating tear gas against guerrillas in 1965.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — U.S.-equipped South Vietnamese troops are using nonlethal nauseating tear gas occasionally against South Vietnam’s Communist guerrillas, the United States said today [Mar. 22]. Although the State Department insisted that employment of the short-lived gas was not inhumane or internationally illegal, the use of the gas — with all its flesh crawling connotations of horror — may spark worldwide protests and give the United States a monumental propaganda black eye. The Soviet Union seized upon the gas issue immediately for a blast at the United States, with Moscow Radio charging the United States with ‘‘using increasingly barbarous methods — in particular waging chemical warfare.’’ It was unclear precisely what kind of gas was being used, but it apparently is the type, effective for about two hours, which causes tears, nausea, sneezing, coughing, nose, throat and chest discomfort or pains. The gas being used is not of the killing, stunning or nerve-affecting types. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 23, 1965

headline: Yiddish Production of ‘Death of a Salesman’ Coming to Off-Broadway
abstract: The production play at the Castillo Theater for seven weeks and aims to uncover the play’s cultural foundations.
lead_paragraph: New Yiddish Rep will bring an updated Yiddish production of Arthur Miller’s “Death of a Salesman” to New York this October. The production play at the Castillo Theater for seven weeks and aims to uncover the play’s cultural foundations.

headline: In One-Woman Show, Arafat Protégée Offers Personal Take on Conflict
abstract: A play by Raeda Taha, who became like a daughter to Yasir Arafat and worked as his press secretary, focuses on the clash between Palestinians’ public struggle and private suffering.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — In a measured voice, the middle-aged woman in the blue dress recalled how a colleague had come to her hotel room during a work trip years before and tried to rape her, retreating only after she had screamed to alert the neighbors.

headline: Sony Will Make ‘Beautiful: The Carole King Musical’ Into a Film
abstract: The film version of “Beautiful” will be produced by Tom Hanks; Gary Goetzman, a producer whose movie credits include “Mamma Mia!” in 2008; and Paul Blake, the lead producer of “Beautiful” on Broadway. Douglas McGrath, who wrote the book for the stage production, will work on the screenplay.
lead_paragraph: Sony Pictures Entertainment on Sunday said that it had closed a deal to bring “Beautiful: The Carole King Musical” to the big screen.

headline: Egyptian Official Says Protester, Shaimaa el-Sabbagh, Died in Shooting Because She Was Too Thin
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The spokesman said Ms. Sabbagh, a poet and activist hit with a blast of birdshot from a police shotgun during a march to Tahrir Square in Cairo, would have lived if she had not been so slender.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — A poet and activist hit with a blast of birdshot from a police shotgun during a march to lay flowers in Tahrir Square in Cairo died because she was too thin, a spokesman for Egypt’s medical examiner said late Saturday.

headline: Restoring the Spirit With the Sound of Big Bells High Over Manhattan
abstract: On Sunday mornings, Dionisio Lind heads for the upper reaches of Riverside Church to summon worshipers to services by playing the 74-bell carillon.
lead_paragraph: It is Sunday morning, and Dionisio A. Lind cannot find the balm in Gilead.

headline: A Bid to Save Sweet Briar College
abstract: The liberal arts institution in rural Virginia, one of a dwindling number of women’s schools, will close at the end of this term.
lead_paragraph: The liberal arts institution in rural Virginia, one of a dwindling number of women’s schools, will close at the end of this term.

headline: Anger and Activism Greet Plan to Shut Sweet Briar College
abstract: The decision to shutter the college, a women’s liberal arts school in Virginia, has stunned students, teachers and alumnae, some of whom are rallying to try to save it.
lead_paragraph: SWEET BRIAR, Va. — Here at bucolic Sweet Briar College, equestrians awaken at dawn and trek to the stables to ride on 18 miles of trails through wooded countryside, fields and dells. Women study on the boathouse dock at sunset, as geese squawk over a lake. Pearls are still in fashion, and men must have escorts. Students call it “the pink bubble.”

headline: In Performance | Leung and Lim
abstract: Telly Leung and Jennifer Lim in a scene from Frances Ya-Chu Cowhig’s play “The World of Extreme Happiness,” at the City Center Stage I through March 29.
lead_paragraph: Telly Leung and Jennifer Lim in a scene from Frances Ya-Chu Cowhig’s play “The World of Extreme Happiness,” at the City Center Stage I through March 29.

headline: Michigan State Again Sends Virginia Home Early
abstract: Travis Trice scored 23 points, and the Spartans overcame second-seeded Virginia the same way they did in the tournament last year, grinding just a bit better.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Travis Trice, a senior guard at Michigan State, received a text message Sunday morning from a former Spartans teammate, Draymond Green of the Golden State Warriors: “Don’t let this be your last game.”

headline: Review: ‘Ernani,’ With Plácido Domingo, a Tussle to Hold on to a Love
abstract: The tenor, seemingly determined to keep his career going by singing another baritone role, takes on Don Carlo in this Metropolitan Opera revival of an early Verdi work.
lead_paragraph: In a 2009 interview, Plácido Domingo said that he could not imagine retiring from opera with a series of farewell performances and public celebrations. The time to stop will just come to him when it’s right, he explained.

headline: Seoul Philharmonic Orchestra Racked by Infighting
abstract: The ensemble is reeling over accusations of harassment, defamation and fiscal corruption.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — When the respected Seoul Philharmonic Orchestra announced this month that it was canceling its United States tour set for April, it cited fiscal woes. Left unsaid were the lurid allegations of sexual harassment and financial improprieties that have rocked the orchestra recently, culminating in a police raid of its offices here.

headline: Review: In ‘Where You Go Is Not Who You’ll Be,’ Frank Bruni Examines College Admissions Mania
abstract: This book reminds young people, and their parents, that what students get from a college has almost nothing to do with where it stands in the pecking order of prestige.
lead_paragraph: Getting into a top college, even for the most accomplished high school students, has become a mad scramble. But in his sensible and sensitive book, “Where You Go Is Not Who You’ll Be,” Frank Bruni, a columnist for The New York Times, wants to help young people understand the urgent truth of his title. “Where we go to college will have infinitely less bearing on our fulfillment in life than so much else: the wisdom with which we choose our romantic partners; our interactions with the communities that we inhabit; our generosity toward the families we inherit and the families that we make.” That’s something we all know in retrospect but that’s hard to know in prospect for anyone caught in what Mr. Bruni calls the “college admissions mania.”

headline: Lee Kuan Yew, Founding Father of Singapore, Dies at 91
abstract: Mr. Lee remained until late in his life the dominant personality and driving force in what he called a first-world oasis in a third-world region.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Lee remained until late in his life the dominant personality and driving force in what he called a first-world oasis in a third-world region.

headline: Lee Kuan Yew, Founding Father and First Premier of Singapore, Dies at 91
abstract: As prime minister for 31 years, Mr. Lee transformed the tiny island outpost into a modern, affluent city-state admired for its efficiency and low level of corruption.
lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE — Lee Kuan Yew, who transformed the tiny outpost of Singapore into one of Asia’s wealthiest and least corrupt countries as its founding father and first prime minister, died here on Monday. He was 91.

headline: Apple Opens Up to Praise New Book on Steve Jobs, and Criticize an Old One
abstract: Apple brass, including its chief, Timothy D. Cook, are throwing their weight behind the unauthorized biography of Mr. Jobs, which goes on sale Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Steve Jobs prized secrecy from his executives and employees during his tenure at Apple. Now his top lieutenants are speaking out — to help shape the legacy of Steve Jobs.

abstract: The bank is among those caught in a dispute between Argentina and a group of hedge funds that hold the nation’s bonds.
lead_paragraph: There is a new twist in the fight between Argentina and a group of hedge funds that has been playing out in New York courts.

abstract: Vulgar and restrained, loud and retiring, straight-up and mysterious. On the former rude girl of British art.
lead_paragraph: Vulgar and restrained, loud and retiring, straight-up and mysterious. On the former rude girl of British art.

lead_paragraph: Rolling Stone magazine plans to publish an external review of a widely disputed article about a gang rape at the University of Virginia “in the next couple of weeks,” its managing editor, Will Dana, said on Sunday.

keywords: ['Shariah (Islamic Law)', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Capital Punishment', 'Muslims and Islam']

lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Mike Krzyzewski knows as well as anyone what it takes to win a college basketball national championship. He already has four. Could this be the team that brings No. 5?

headline: Review: ‘Sin City Saints,’ a Yahoo Basketball Comedy

lead_paragraph: Yahoo’s attempt to make its video offerings more televisionlike — which is to say more like Netflix, Amazon and Hulu — began last week with the premiere of the sixth season of “Community,” a show that had been canceled by NBC. But a better test comes on Monday, when it will post all eight episodes of “Sin City Saints,” an original half-hour comedy, at Yahoo Screen.

headline: Americans’ Retirement Funds Increasingly Contain Tech Start-Up Stocks
keywords: ['Mutual Funds', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Start-ups']
abstract: Drawn by fast-growing private tech companies, big money managers are purchasing their shares, betting that they’ll go public. But that outcome is hardly guaranteed.
lead_paragraph: The retirement accounts of millions of Americans have long contained shares of stalwart companies like General Electric, Ford and Coca-Cola. Today, they are likely to include riskier private stocks from Silicon Valley start-ups like Uber, Airbnb and Pinterest.

headline: Vanderbilt Knockout Teams Winners
abstract: The Vanderbilt Knockout Teams final was on Sunday, the last day of the Spring North American Championships in New Orleans.
lead_paragraph: The Vanderbilt Knockout Teams final on Sunday, the last day of the Spring North American Championships in New Orleans, was between Lavazza (Giorgio Duboin, Zia Mahmood, Norberto Bocchi and Agustin Madala) and Diamond (John Diamond, Brian Platnick, Eric Greco, Geoff Hampson, Marc Jacobus and Eddie Wold).

headline: Review: Paul Taylor’s American Modern Dance Offers New and Old
abstract: This season is notable for the return, after an absence of about 30 years, of one of Mr. Taylor’s greatest collaborators, the visual artist Alex Katz.
lead_paragraph: Paul Taylor’s American Modern Dance, a puzzling project on paper, is proving so in performance as well. As this new venture for the Paul Taylor Dance Company, one that expands to include works by other choreographers, continued into its second week at the David H. Koch Theater, the salient contrast remained that of previous years: Taylor versus Taylor.

lead_paragraph: Every little girl thinks she is Eloise. So did Lena Dunham. And she kind of had a point.

lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — This is a very nice puzzle by Michael Dewey, but it’s a bit early in the week to be starting a riot. Normally, we save that sort of thing for Thursday and beyond.

headline: Review: David Robertson Leads the St. Louis Symphony at Carnegie Hall
abstract: One of two potential New York Philharmonic music directors in town last week, Mr. Robertson paired Meredith Monk’s “Weave” with Debussy’s “Nocturnes.”
lead_paragraph: Two potential New York Philharmonic music directors were in town last week. Esa-Pekka Salonen was with the Philharmonic itself, not conducting but taking a composer’s bow after the orchestra played his “Nyx” (2010) under Alan Gilbert. And David Robertson, a serious contender when Mr. Gilbert was chosen in 2007 and now once again a candidate, brought his St. Louis Symphony, sounding superb, to Carnegie Hall on Friday evening.

Snoop Dogg announced the project at his keynote speech at the South By Southwest Music Conference and Festival on Friday.

headline: At SXSW, Stepping Back to Allow Hopeful Artists to Step Up
keywords: ['Music', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: SXSW, with less corporate blare and celebrity swanning than in recent years, offers the promise of a stray festival encounter for musicians can bring new opportunities.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Mitski, a songwriter based in Brooklyn, clutched her hot-pink bass and surveyed the knots of people standing in the rain to hear her on Saturday afternoon. She was playing her fourth (and last) live set in 24 hours as part of the 29th annual South By Southwest Music Conference and Festival, the five-day blowout that brings an estimated 2,000 acts — bands, solo performers, rappers, D.J.s — to Austin each year.

headline: Starbucks Ends Conversation Starters on Race
abstract: Starbucks said it had always planned to end the “Race Together” initiative on March 22, something not previously known. But the company said its conversation on race would continue.
lead_paragraph: Howard D. Schultz, the chief executive of Starbucks, said in a letter to employees on Sunday that baristas would no longer be encouraged to write the phrase “Race Together” on customers’ coffee cups, drawing to a close a widely derided component of the company’s plan to promote a discussion on racial issues.

abstract: Exit polls and early returns in the first round of voting indicated dissatisfaction with the Socialist Party of President François Hollande.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — French voters turned toward right-leaning parties in local elections held Sunday across the country, signaling their disappointment and frustration with France’s governing Socialist Party.

headline: China National Chemical Unit Nears Deal for Tire Maker Pirelli
abstract: The China National Chemical Corporation unit will buy a 26.2 percent stake held by Camfin, Pirelli’s largest shareholder, and make a takeover bid for the Italian tire maker.
lead_paragraph: A subsidiary of China National Chemical Corporation will make a takeover bid for the Italian tire maker Pirelli after agreeing on Sunday to acquire the stake of Camfin, Pirelli’s largest shareholder, the companies said.

headline: For Clintons, a Hedge Fund in the Family
abstract: When Chelsea Clinton’s husband, Marc Mezvinsky, co-founded an investment firm, Clinton family friends took an interest, illustrating how politics, family and finance can intersect.
lead_paragraph: Since marrying Chelsea Clinton five years ago, Marc Mezvinsky, a money manager, appears to have settled into his life as Bill and Hillary Clinton’s son-in-law. He has regularly appeared at charitable events, once introducing the former president at the Clinton Foundation’s celebrity poker tournament by dryly saying, “You may have heard of my father-in-law.” And at the recent N.B.A. All-Star Game, Mr. Mezvinsky took a seat next to Mr. Clinton and his partner in charitable endeavors, Dikembe Mutombo, the former basketball star.

headline: Mets See Much Potential in Steven Matz, a Tenacious Pitcher
abstract: With Tommy John surgery, a long recovery and a strong spring behind him, Matz gives the Mets reason to expect a big year.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Just months after he signed with the Mets out of high school, Steven Matz felt pain in his elbow. He tried to shake it, to massage it, but the pain persisted.

headline: Pity for the Token Booth Clerk
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A poet wonders what the lonely subway attendant in the glass booth is thinking as he does his tokenless job.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Wichita State Rules Kansas, and the Jayhawks
abstract: The Shockers made 10 of 20 3-point shots, advancing to the round of 16 with a resounding upset in a rare intrastate meeting.

headline: A Right to Die?
abstract: Jack Kevorkian’s unorthodox methods drew attention to assisted suicide. Decades later, Americans still struggle with whether doctors should be allowed to help suffering patients end their lives.
lead_paragraph: Jack Kevorkian’s unorthodox methods drew attention to assisted suicide. Decades later, Americans still struggle with whether doctors should be allowed to help suffering patients end their lives.

headline: Stigma Around Physician-Assisted Dying Lingers
abstract: Five states, in various forms, countenance doctor-assisted dying. Others are considering it. But many people wonder if doctors should be able to help incurably ill patients end their lives.
lead_paragraph: “Death is nothing at all,” the English theologian Henry Scott Holland wrote a century ago in a reflection that is often quoted at funerals. Death is but life extended, Holland said: “I have only slipped away to the next room. Nothing has happened. Everything remains exactly as it was.”

headline: For the Defense-First St. Louis Blues, the Score Gets a Rewrite
abstract: The retooled Blues are suddenly an offensive juggernaut, ranked second in scoring in the Western Conference.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — The pulsating beat of dance music boomed across the visitors’ locker room at Air Canada Centre after a St. Louis Blues practice this month.

headline: At the Box Office, It’s No Longer a Man’s World
abstract: Women are driving movie ticket sales to a degree rarely seen before, while young men, long the most coveted audience, are relatively AWOL.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Heading into the all-important summer moviegoing season, two converging box-office trends are startling studios: Women are driving ticket sales to a degree rarely, if ever, seen before, while young men — long Hollywood’s most coveted audience — are relatively AWOL.

headline: Two Maxims at Odds: Tell a Story, Tell the Truth
keywords: ['Television', 'Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'News and News Media', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The possible murder confession in HBO’s “The Jinx” has raised questions in the documentary world about the tension between accuracy and a good story.
lead_paragraph: The last interview was over. The set, a room inside a New York hotel, had gone dark. The subject, Robert A. Durst, headed for the bathroom, apparently unaware his microphone was still on. “There it is. You’re caught,” he is heard saying. “What the hell did I do? Killed them all, of course.”

headline: Shy of Majority, Socialists Win in Spain’s Andalusia
abstract: They fell short of gaining a majority in a fragmented regional Parliament in which two upstart parties will have a combined quarter of the seats, according to preliminary results.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — Spain’s Socialists won Sunday’s election in Andalusia, the country’s largest region, but fell short of gaining a majority in a fragmented regional Parliament in which two upstart parties will have a combined quarter of the seats, according to preliminary results.

abstract: The Student Digital Privacy and Parental Rights Act would place constraints on how education technology companies use or disclose students’ personal information.
lead_paragraph: Is the digital revolution in the classroom giving the education technology industry carte blanche to exploit student data?

headline: College Coaches Find No Consensus on One-and-Done Eligibility Rule
abstract: College basketball coaches have mixed views about obliging players to wait one year after graduating from high school before becoming eligible for the N.B.A. draft.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Few men’s basketball programs have been as successful as Duke in recruiting talented players who come to the university for one season before they are allowed to collect an N.B.A. paycheck.

headline: A Bid to Save Sweet Briar College
abstract: The liberal arts institution in rural Virginia, one of a dwindling number of women’s schools, will close at the end of this term.
lead_paragraph: The liberal arts institution in rural Virginia, one of a dwindling number of women’s schools, will close at the end of this term.

headline: Richard III, Previous Visit a Bust, Is Warmly Received 530 Years Later
abstract: Officials said that the crowds in Leicester, England, were heavier for the procession of King Richard III’s remains on Sunday than they were in 2012, when Queen Elizabeth II visited the city.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Nearly 530 years after King Richard III was slain on a battlefield near the city of Leicester, a coffin containing his remains was paraded through the crowded streets of that English Midlands city ahead of a formal reburial ceremony at Leicester’s Anglican cathedral scheduled for Thursday.

headline: From First Inning, Yankees and Jose Pirela Are Rattled by the Mets
abstract: Pirela crashed into the center-field wall, allowing the Mets’ leadoff hitter in the first inning to score, and was taken to the hospital as the Mets beat the Yankees, 6-0, in spring training.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — At the crack of the bat, Yankees center fielder Jose Pirela raced toward the center-field wall in pursuit of the ball. When left fielder Ramon Flores saw Pirela, a converted second baseman, still sprinting as he approached the warning track, he called out to him.

headline: Popular Demand

PETERSBURG, Russia — A motley crew of representatives of fringe right-wing political organizations in Europe and the United States used a conference here on Sunday to denounce what they called the degradation of white, Christian traditions in the West. Their hosts used the conference to advance Russia’s effort to lure political allies of any stripe.

headline: What’s On TV Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10:15 P.M. (IFC) THE BIG LEBOWSKI (1998) Jeffrey Lebowski, known as the Dude (Jeff Bridges, above, from left, with John Goodman and Steve Buscemi), is an unemployed bowling enthusiast who smokes a lot of weed. His tranquil daze is interrupted when he comes home to two goons demanding the money he owes them and urinating on his beloved rug. The goons turn out to have the Dude confused with the millionaire Jeffrey Lebowski (David Huddleston), who sends the Dude on a wild-goose chase. Ethan and Joel Coen wrote and directed this convoluted classic, which features bowling chatter, German nihilists, self-kidnapping and Creedence Clearwater Revival. Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times: “The film, which begins with a tumbleweed rolling from desert to Malibu, is narrated a bit needlessly by a mythic cowboy type (Sam Elliott) whose final assessment of the Dude’s tale goes like this: ‘It was a purty good story, don’t you think? Made me laugh to beat the band. Parts, anyway.’ Exactly right.”

His books, including “Workers,” “Migrations,” “Sahel” and, most recently, the nature-oriented “Genesis,” have consistently met with commercial and critical success.

headline: Hospitals Are Wrong About Shifting Costs to Private Insurers
abstract: Reducing or containing Medicare and Medicaid prices can put downward pressure on the prices hospitals can charge to all customers.
lead_paragraph: To hear some hospital executives tell it, they have to make up payment shortfalls from Medicaid and Medicare by charging higher prices to privately insured patients. How else could a hospital stay afloat if it didn’t?

headline: Reconsidering My August Post on Ferguson and ‘Conflicting Accounts’
keywords: ['News Sources, Confidential Status of', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | March 23, 2015
abstract: On Mondays, we publish a Times photo without a caption, headline or other information about its origins. Join the conversation by posting about what you see, and why. A live discussion is offered from 9 a.m. to 2 p.m. Eastern time.
lead_paragraph: Updated: March 24, 2015

headline: Why God Is a Moral Issue
abstract: The New Atheists and those in their camp insist that belief in a deity is more than just an intellectual mistake.
lead_paragraph: The New Atheists are not a comfortable group of people. They have scornful contempt for those with whom they differ — that includes religious believers, agnostics and other atheists who don’t share their vehement brand of nonbelief. They are self-confident to a degree that seems designed to irritate. And they have an ignorance of anything beyond their fields to an extent remarkable even in modern academia. They also have a moral passion unknown outside the pages of the Old Testament. For that, we can forgive much.

headline: Koch-Backed Group Bolsters Effort to Shut Down Export-Import Bank
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Freedom Partners, an association linked to the billionaires Charles and David Koch, will begin a new lobbying effort pressuring lawmakers to shut down the bank, a top target of conservative activists and outside groups.
lead_paragraph: A trade association linked to the conservative billionaires Charles G. and David H. Koch will begin a new lobbying effort pressuring lawmakers to shut down the Export-Import Bank, a top target of conservative activists and outside groups that will cease to exist after June 30 if it is not reauthorized by Congress.

headline: In Lee Kuan Yew, China Saw a Leader to Emulate
abstract: His decades leading Singapore gave Chinese officials a model of how to navigate economic and social transformations without politically capsizing.
lead_paragraph: With the death of Singapore’s founding leader, Lee Kuan Yew, on Monday, China lost a figure who, in the eyes of Communist Party leaders, showed that economic prosperity could be achieved under crisply efficient one-party rule, immunized from the temptations of liberal democracy.

headline: Today in Politics: Making It Official, Cruz Kicks Off Race to Replace Obama
abstract: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas put out a Twitter message early Monday saying he was running for president and that he wanted to stand with “courageous conservatives” to lead the fight to restore America’s greatness.
lead_paragraph: Good Monday morning from Washington. Congress will be tending to some budget business before a break, and Hillary Rodham Clinton’s private emails about attacks in Benghazi, Libya are unearthed. President Obama begins the week hosting a science fair at the White House, and the race to succeed him begins in earnest with a big speech from a certain Texas senator.

headline: Square Opens Square Cash App to Businesses, for a Fee

lead_paragraph: For the last few years, companies like Google, eBay’s PayPal and Facebook have dabbled in peer-to-peer payments, the business of letting people freely send money to one another through email or on their smartphones. None of these companies have found a way to make money from it.

headline: Companies Adapt to Uber and Lyft Rides on the Expense Report

lead_paragraph: LONDON — Optimal Payments said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire the digital payment service Skrill Group in a cash-and-share deal that values the business at 1.1 billion euros, or about $1.2 billion.

abstract: Will a strong dollar hurt the economy and should the Fed take action?

headline: New York Still Has More Gay Residents Than Anywhere Else in U.S.
abstract: The San Francisco metro area has the highest percentage of people who identify as gay, lesbian, bisexual or transgender — but not the largest number.
lead_paragraph: The San Francisco and Portland, Ore., metropolitan areas have the greatest percentage of residents who are gay, as we wrote last week. But those regions do not have the largest gay populations in terms of sheer size. That distinction instead goes to New York and Los Angeles.

headline: 1940: I.R.A. Riots in Dartmoor
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: I.R.A. inmates riot at Dartmoor prison in 1940.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Twelve I.R.A. members imprisoned in Britain’s grim Dartmoor prison were held responsible this evening for an Easter mutiny that raged for more than three hours during the afternoon. The mutiny broke out when convicts in a cell block overpowered two guards, who were bound and gagged, then bundled into a cell. Using their keys, the guards’ attackers freed other convicts. With wild shouts, which were heard outside by many people living near the prison, the Irish Republicans collected piles of bedding and set them on fire. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 24, 1940

headline: Okinawa Governor Orders a Halt to Work on U.S. Military Airfield

lead_paragraph: BERLIN — With time running ever shorter for an accord to ease Greece’s debt crisis and cash crunch, Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras and Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany met on Monday and sought at least to take the sting out of venomous exchanges between Athens and Berlin in recent weeks.

lead_paragraph: Tony May, an esteemed veteran in the New York dining scene, is retiring. On March 30, he expects to turn his restaurant, SD26, over to John Doherty, a former executive chef at the Waldorf Astoria who has been a consultant for the last few years.

keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'News and News Media']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jerry Warren, a newspaper editor who became the deputy White House press secretary under Presidents Richard M. Nixon and Gerald R. Ford, but who returned to newspaper work after being disillusioned by the Watergate scandal, died on Friday in Arlington, Va. He was 84.

headline: Justice Dept., Criticizing Philadelphia Police, Finds Shootings by Officers Are Common
abstract: A Justice Department report about the Philadelphia Police Department does not allege racial discrimination, but indicates that the city stands out when it comes to shootings by officers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Roughly once a week, 390 times over the past eight years, Philadelphia police officers opened fire at a suspect. The shootings involved 454 officers, most of them on patrol. Almost always, the suspects were black. Often, the officers were, too.

lead_paragraph: Maira Kalman’s most treasured cooking tool — a Sawa 2000 Deluxe Cookie Press, made about a half-century ago in Sweden — isn’t kept in the kitchen. It’s in a lingerie closet.
