headline: Police Find No Evidence of Rape at University of Virginia Fraternity
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Sex Crimes', 'Fraternities and Sororities', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The announcement came four months after a now-discredited report in Rolling Stone magazine of a gang rape at a fraternity rocked the campus.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — The police here said Monday that they had found “no substantive basis” to support a Rolling Stone magazine article depicting a horrific gang rape at a University of Virginia fraternity house and that a four-month review had identified serious discrepancies in the account by a woman identified as Jackie, who refused to cooperate with their investigation.

headline: Sashimani Devi, Last of India’s Jagannath Temple Dancers, Dies at 92
abstract: Initiated into service at the temple when she was a small girl, she was the last dancer in a centuries-old tradition that was condemned as exploitative by social reformers.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Sashimani Devi, the last ritual dancer at the Jagannath Temple in eastern India, died on March 19 in the city of Puri, bringing an end to a centuries-old tradition that was condemned as exploitative by social reformers, Victorian missionaries and the leaders of independent India. She was 92.

headline: S.E.C. Faces Tough Challenge to Enhanced Broker Rule
keywords: ['Financial Brokers', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)']
abstract: A proposal to hold stockbrokers to a higher standard when offering their clients investment advice faces staunch opposition.
lead_paragraph: In a Smith Barney commercial from the 1970s, the actor John Houseman intoned that the firm made money the old-fashioned way: “They earn it.” The question for clients is what standard their brokers should be judged by when making money off them, an issue that has proved to be divisive as the Securities and Exchange Commission considers imposing a higher standard for recommendations.

headline: How Ancient Cattle Herders Avoided Sleeping Sickness
abstract: A recent study suggests that some people were able to use areas free of tsetse flies to travel south from East Africa more than 2,000 years ago.
lead_paragraph: It has long been a mystery how long ago cattle-raising people from Central Africa managed to reach southern Africa. It was assumed that the herders were stopped by sleeping sickness, which is carried by tsetse flies and kills cattle, goats, sheep and people.

headline: Go Ahead, Help Your Child Apply to College
abstract: As a parent, you can’t escape the role of college-application Sherpa. Nor should you try.
lead_paragraph: Over the past month or two, my nightly routine has been the same: I climb into bed after 10 p.m. with the “Fiske Guide to Colleges,” pen and Post-it notes at the ready.

headline: Clever Pricing for Italian Tire Maker Pirelli
abstract: The 15 euros-a-share offer by Pirelli’s chairman and China National’s chemical unit isn’t generous, but the market price is only slightly higher.
lead_paragraph: Pirelli’s would-be new owners have pitched their price cleverly. Marco Tronchetti Provera, the Italian tire maker’s chairman and a leading shareholder, has teamed up with the state-owned China National Chemical Corporation to buy and then delist the company’s shares. The deal highlights how Italian companies are up for sale to foreign owners, even at ungenerous prices.

headline: U.S. Private Equity Firms Find a Chilly Reception in Australia
abstract: Despite the challenges presented in Australia, American private equity giants are pushing ahead with investments there.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — When the financing arm of General Electric agreed last week to sell its consumer lending business in Australia and New Zealand to a consortium of investors that included the private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the firm’s managing partner for Asia trumpeted the news.

headline: How David Geffen’s $100 Million Lincoln Center Gift Came Together
abstract: Some in the world of cultural philanthropy question whether Mr. Geffen’s gift is large enough to warrant the renaming of a building as prominent as Avery Fisher Hall.
lead_paragraph: Barbara Walters never expected a role in the renaming of Avery Fisher Hall. But it turns out that Ms. Walters, the ABC News broadcaster, was a crucial go-between who helped engineer a relationship between two of her friends that led to the unlikely, seemingly overnight emergence of the West Coast mogul David Geffen as one of New York’s most prominent philanthropists.

headline: Macaroons for Passover With a Difference
abstract: The recipe for the Jewish holiday treats traces back to Iraq.
lead_paragraph: Traditional almond macaroons for Passover were never my thing: too sweet and not chewy enough. Then I met Eileen Dangoor Khalastchy, a Jew who traces her roots to ancient Babylonia, and tried her macaroon recipe from Iraq.

headline: Review: National Council Auditions Winners Named at Grand Finals Concert
abstract: Five up-and-coming singers received $15,000 prizes at the Metropolitan Opera’s annual competition.
lead_paragraph: “Grand Opera’s answer to ‘American Idol,’ ” said Peter Gelb, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, describing the organization’s annual National Council Auditions while the judges deliberated on Sunday afternoon. The important vocal event has helped propel the careers of many young singers, including the soprano Angela Meade, who presented the Grand Finals Concert at the Met.

headline: 1890: ‘Ascanio’ Composer a Mystery
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: 1890: The whereabouts of the composer Camille Saint-Saëns.
lead_paragraph: Where is M. Saint-Saëns? For a couple of months past the question has been reiterated almost daily. Now that the production of ‘‘Ascanio’’ at the Opéra has brought its composer’s name before the public, the question has developed into as popular a problem as was that of the whereabouts of the huissier Gouffé last summer. Versions of the most varied and wildest nature are current. According to one account, M. Saint-Saëns is the inmate of a lunatic asylum; while another has it that he has died in a foreign land, and been buried in an unknown grave by alien hands. — The New York Herald, European Edition, March 24, 1890

headline: Have a Seat Next to Don Draper: Jon Hamm Unveils a ‘Mad Men’ Bench

headline: Tips From a Veteran on Making the Most of Coachella
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival', 'Deserts']
abstract: Ben Ratliff, a Times music critic, gives advice for attending the festival that’s remarkably similar to running a marathon: Drink water and be wary of the sun.
lead_paragraph: Survival tips for the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival, April 10 to 12 this year, are like advice for running a marathon. You’ll want to drink water regularly, for example, and be wary of the vicious desert sun. But with the right planning, you can avoid fatigue and make the most of a weekend with some of the biggest names in music.

headline: Robert Durst Is Denied Bail as Prosecutors Argue He Is a Flight Risk

headline: Review: Marissa Mulder Trusts Her Intuition at the Metropolitan Room
abstract: At her new show, “Instincts,” the singer, who recently turned 30, created personal statements out of her renditions and avoided self-dramatization.
lead_paragraph: Life begins at 30 when you finally start to have some idea of who you really are. That’s the concept of Marissa Mulder’s new show, “Instincts,” which played at the Metropolitan Room on Friday evening. The singer, who recently turned 30, said she had decided not to hang on to the past and to begin trusting intuition to guide her.

headline: In Zurich, a Concept Shop That Promotes Graceful, Stylish Aging
abstract: Senior Design Project appeals to the city’s aesthetically conscious elderly population (and the grandkids who love them).
lead_paragraph: The leading models in top ad campaigns for the past few seasons have shared an unusually attainable beauty ideal: age. Céline made quite a stir by casting Joan Didion in its spring campaign; she’s joined in the recent 60-plus modeling set by Joni Mitchell for Saint Laurent, Charlotte Rampling for Nars and Jessica Lange for Marc Jacobs Beauty. At age 93, Iris Apfel upstages her 22-year-old co-star, Karlie Kloss, in Kate Spade’s spring ads. Yet as Benjamin Moser of Zurich’s Senior Design Factory explains, he and his partner Debora Biffi were impelled to create their concept store, design studio and series of workshop projects because they saw a dearth of products specifically crafted for older people’s physical needs that also gave them “the confidence to not feel like they need to hide because they are old.”

headline: Jerusalem Mourns 7 Brief Lives Lost in Brooklyn Fire
keywords: ['Fires and Firefighters', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: Hundreds converged in Israel for the burial services of the Sassoon siblings, who died in a blaze at their home in the Midwood neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Hundreds of mourners stood in shocked silence, some weeping quietly, some rocking in private prayer. Clouds gathered in the Jerusalem sky as a warm afternoon turned to dusk.

headline: Iran Judge Rejects Washington Post Reporter’s Petition for Prison Furlough
keywords: ['Freedom of the Press', 'Political Prisoners', 'News and News Media', 'Iranian-Americans']
abstract: It was not clear why the judge refused Jason Rezaian a New Year furlough, sometimes granted to nonviolent inmates. His prosecution remains shrouded in mystery.
lead_paragraph: Jason Rezaian, the reporter for The Washington Post incarcerated in Iran for eight months, has been denied permission for a five-day Iranian New Year furlough from prison, his brother, Ali Rezaian, said Monday.

headline: Most Boston Residents Prefer Life Term Over Death Penalty in Marathon Case, Poll Shows
keywords: ['Boston Marathon Bombings (2013)', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Capital Punishment', 'Sentences (Criminal)']
abstract: A WBUR poll showed 62 percent of Bostonians chose life in prison as a sentence for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev if he is found guilty, while 27 percent said he should be put to death.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Despite this city’s immersion in a trial that is replaying the horrific details of the 2013 Boston Marathon bombing, the vast majority of Bostonians say in a new poll that if Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the admitted bomber, is found guilty, he should be sent to prison for life and not condemned to death.

headline: Hydrogen Bomb Physicist’s Book Runs Afoul of Energy Department
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: Kenneth W. Ford, who helped devise the weapon more than 50 years ago, has refused a federal agency’s request to delete parts of his memoir.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — For all its horrific power, the atom bomb — leveler of Hiroshima and instant killer of some 80,000 people — is but a pale cousin compared to another product of American ingenuity: the hydrogen bomb.

headline: In France, Local Elections Maintain Rightward Trend
abstract: Though the first round did not remake French politics overnight, it confirms that voters are seeking change as the National Front continues to gain ground.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The first round of local elections in France failed to remake French politics drastically, but did confirm political trends: that voters are seeking change, that the far-right National Front continues to gain ground and that the Socialist Party of President François Hollande continues to lose it.

headline: When Science Is Lost in a Legal Maze
keywords: ['Wireless Communications', 'Radiation', 'Medicine and Health', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Cellular Telephones']
abstract: A New Mexico case highlighted how unsubstantiated notions like the health dangers of electromagnetic signals can continue to get a serious hearing.
lead_paragraph: In a saner world, where science and the law meshed more precisely, a case like Firstenberg v. Monribot would have been dead on arrival in court. But that is not what happened.

headline: Searching for a Magical Creature, Finding a Need for Wild Places
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Wilderness Areas']
abstract: William deBuys’ lyrical work “The Last Unicorn,” about the saola in Southeast Asia, reminds readers that what drives conservationists most is beauty.
lead_paragraph: In May 1992, a team of field biologists set out to survey a remote patch of wilderness along the western border of Vietnam. After nine days on the trail, the group was running low on food, so two members were dispatched to a nearby village to stock up on provisions.

headline: White House Chief of Staff Says Netanyahu Declaration Could Not Be Ignored
abstract: Denis McDonough, President Obama’s chief of staff, said the Israeli prime minister’s pre-election statement on a two-state solution was “very troubling.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Denis McDonough, President Obama’s chief of staff, said that the pre-election declaration by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel that there would be no Palestinian state while he was in office raised questions about his commitment to a two-state solution that the White House could not ignore.

headline: Review: In T. Coraghessan Boyle’s ‘The Harder They Come,’ Rugged Individualism Run Amok
abstract: This T. Coraghessan Boyle novel has a take on the dark side of the American dream that opens out from the miseries of a father and his troubled son into a meditation on the frontier ethos.
lead_paragraph: The title of T. Coraghessan Boyle’s stunning new novel, “The Harder They Come,” refers less to the Jimmy Cliff movie than to a D. H. Lawrence observation quoted at the beginning of the book: “The essential American soul is hard, isolate, stoic, and a killer. It has never yet melted.”

headline: Longer Flights From La Guardia Might Be Mixed Blessing for Passengers
abstract: A proposal to end the airport’s 1,500-mile limit on flights could make it more appealing to long-haul travelers who find it convenient to Manhattan, but regional flights could be cut.
lead_paragraph: A PROPOSAL is under review that would make La Guardia Airport far more attractive to business travelers by adding domestic long-haul and coast-to-coast trips. So when I got off a short-haul flight at a teeming La Guardia last week, I wondered what this might portend.

headline: For ‘Mad Men,’ a Last Hurrah
abstract: Jon Hamm, Christina Hendricks, Elisabeth Moss and other stars of the AMC show at MoMA.
lead_paragraph: Jon Hamm, Christina Hendricks, Elisabeth Moss and other stars of the AMC show at MoMA.

headline: Deep Freeze on Great Lakes Halts Cargo Shipments
abstract: Two harsh winters have burdened ship lines and businesses that depend on their cargo, including grain and iron ore.
lead_paragraph: THUNDER BAY, Ontario — The trip to pick up a load of iron ore powder in Conneaut, Ohio, was supposed to take four days by way of the Great Lakes.

headline: Stripe Makes a Bet on Marketplaces With New Product
abstract: Stripe has created a new product aimed at helping marketplace start-ups with their mobile payments.
lead_paragraph: In the lexicon of Silicon Valley, “marketplace” is an increasingly hot buzzword. That’s because it is the business model of companies like Uber, Airbnb and Lyft, where companies act as intermediaries for thousands of people who want to sell their services to the public.

headline: Review: Myra Melford’s ‘Snowy Egret’ Taps Into Dreams
abstract: This extremely fine new album is pared down, but leaves no sense of incompletion.
lead_paragraph: Several years ago the pianist and composer Myra Melford formed the Snowy Egret quintet, its title inspired by a dream. The music for the group was a response to something more literary: “Memory of Fire,” the three-volume history of the Americas by Eduardo Galeano.

headline: Young Scientists Impress at the White House
abstract: President Obama hosted the fifth-annual science fair, in which an automatic page turner built out of Legos was among the items singled out.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama marveled on Monday as a group of 6-year-old Girl Scouts at the White House Science Fair demonstrated the automatic page turner they had built out of Legos and explained that the invention was the result of a brainstorming session.

headline: Review: Emily Coates and Yve Laris Cohen, a Dialogue of Choreographers
abstract: The third performance of Danspace Project’s Platform 2015 paired the choreographers Jillian Peña and Troy Schumacher and Ms. Coates and Mr. Laris Cohen.
lead_paragraph: Watching Emily Coates’s “Incarnations (Sketches for a Longer Work),” part of the third performance event in Danspace Project’s Platform 2015, you may wonder if your brain is turning to jelly. Ms. Coates’s embodiment of ideas about corporality and physics in relation to Isaac Newton’s Laws of Motion and the Higgs field challenges the nonscientific among us. At one point, Ms. Coates, a gorgeous redheaded, pregnant former dancer with the New York City Ballet performs Apollo’s solo from George Balanchine’s 1928 ballet of that name, while her co-performer, the Yale physicist Sarah Demers, rapidly describes Ms. Coates’s moves in terms of space, force, mass, acceleration, etc.

headline: Restoring the iCloud Drive Icon
keywords: ['Windows (Operating System)', 'iOS (Operating System)', 'Smartphones', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Software', 'Android (Operating System)']
abstract: With a few steps, the icon — and any other deleted icon on a Mac — can be brought back. Also, why Windows sometimes must restart when updating.
lead_paragraph: Restoring the Icon

headline: Obama Reviews Science Education Program
abstract: President Obama visited the White House science fair and announced $240 million in contributions to encourage more students to pursue education in science, technology, engineering and math.
lead_paragraph: President Obama visited the White House science fair and announced $240 million in contributions to encourage more students to pursue education in science, technology, engineering and math.

headline: 1956: Martin Luther King Makes a Stand
abstract: A look at the first time that the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was mentioned in The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: This feature looks at the first time famous names or terms appeared in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Send a suggestion in the comments section.

headline: Ted Cruz, an Ambitious Conservative With Sharp Elbows
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Tea Party Movement', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Republican senator from Texas, a Tea Party favorite who declared himself a presidential candidate on Monday, became known as an ambitious upstart who rubbed even some fellow Republicans the wrong way.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Back in late 2000, Ted Cruz found himself with one of the hottest tickets in town.

headline: Imagine President Ted Cruz
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Editorials', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Senator Ted Cruz’s speech announcing his 2016 presidential campaign captured so many Republican paradoxes and idiocies, especially on immigration and health care.
lead_paragraph: “Think just how different the world would be,” said Senator Ted Cruz on Monday, in a speech so packed with vision-spinning and the word “imagine” that it seemed as if John Lennon had returned, as a Hispanic Texan running a hard-right, anti-establishment, Christian-themed campaign for the White House. Weird. But weird is the essence of Mr. Cruz, who is now the first major Republican in the 2016 race. Let the fund-raising begin. Commence the swelling of the Cruz coffers, and of Mr. Cruz’s public profile beyond the gated confines of C-Span and Fox News.

headline: Review: ‘Actual Size Plus,’ Sally Silvers’s Hitchcock-Inspired Work
abstract: Scenes from “The Birds” and “North by Northwest” played out onstage in Ms. Silvers’s piece for the Harkness Dance Festival.
lead_paragraph: On Friday night at the 92nd Street Y, the choreographer Sally Silvers pulled back the curtain — “ ‘Wizard of Oz’ style,” as she put it — to show how Alfred Hitchcock helped her make a dance.

headline: N.F.L. Will Stream Game From London Next Season
abstract: The N.F.L. will stream the Buffalo Bills’ game against the Jacksonville Jaguars on Oct. 25 in London and explore streaming games on its website as a way to create more revenue.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — The N.F.L. will begin experimenting with streaming games worldwide next season as it searches for more broadcast revenue and ways to reach the growing number of consumers who do not pay for cable and satellite television.

headline: Review: David Kaplan Riffs on Schumann’s Spirit
abstract: The pianist David Kaplan played “New Dances of the League of David” at Le Poisson Rouge, in homage to Schumann.
lead_paragraph: Schumann emerged as a composer in the 1830s around the same time he started gaining attention for his critical writings. But, being Schumann, he brought an unabashed literary bent to his journalism. He fancied himself the leader of a half-real, half-imagined band of musicians called Davidsbündler (the League of David), artists who disdained the empty virtuosic display so popular in concert halls of the day and championed musical depth and substance along with genuine poetic fantasy and humor.

headline: What Would Lee Kuan Yew Do?
keywords: ['International Relations', 'United States Economy', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: A coolheaded analysis of America’s position in the Asia-Pacific region.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With China accelerating its military modernization, Russia continuing its slow-drip incursion into Ukraine, and an expanding section of the Middle East devolving into chaos, it has once again become fashionable to argue that the United States is in decline. Strangely, Americans are often far quicker to accept this diagnosis than their counterparts abroad.

headline: Intrepid in an Earthquake, but Rattled by Locking Luggage
abstract: Paige Brown’s survival skills helped her during the 2010 earthquake in Chile. They also came in handy when her locked suitcase refused to open.
lead_paragraph: MUCH of my career has been spent flying, mostly internationally. Now I’m an entrepreneur and a founder and chief executive of the technology company Dashbell, which offers a web-based booking solution for independent hotels. My travel schedule can get more than a little crazy since I may not be spending more than a few days in one place. I might be in Germany for a meeting and then have to fly to some other European country or South American spot for another meeting all in the same week.

headline: Heavenly Creatures
abstract: The artist Claudia Rankin harnesses the inner world of off-kilter animals in her quirky ceramics.
lead_paragraph: The artist Claudia Rankin harnesses the inner world of off-kilter animals in her quirky ceramics.

headline: Pictures of the Day: The United States and Elsewhere
abstract: The United States and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: The United States and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Justices Look for Reasoning Behind Texas Ban on Confederate License Plate
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Automobile Registration and License Plates', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)']
abstract: The question for the Supreme Court on Monday was whether the ban on a plate displaying the Confederate battle flag violated the First Amendment. Many of the justices were not happy with either possible answer.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The question for the Supreme Court on Monday was whether Texas had violated the First Amendment by rejecting a specialty license plate bearing the Confederate battle flag. As the argument progressed, it became clear that many of the justices were not happy with either possible answer.

headline: Review: Gypsy Flamenco With Play and Passion, Not Flash
abstract: What was evident at “Generations of Gypsy Flamenco,” a world premiere at the Town Hall, was an intense sense of rhythmic play.
lead_paragraph: The art of flamenco has changed and changed again; and nothing has changed it more than the annual circuit of festivals, which usually present flamenco that’s over-choreographed, overproduced and often over-innovative. The “Generations of Gypsy Flamenco” concert at the Town Hall on Friday night, a world premiere that went on to San Francisco on Sunday, was a deliberate turn away from that.

headline: March 23, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from the United States, Yemen, Germany and India.
lead_paragraph: Photos from the United States, Yemen, Germany and India.

headline: Online Mischief Seeks to Dull Cruz’s Luster
abstract: Across the search and social web, Senator Ted Cruz’s name was being displayed below the names of potential rivals, even when searching for “Ted Cruz.”
lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Cruz raced to be first into the 2016 presidential campaign in part to grab some of the attention that potential rivals — Jeb Bush, Gov. Scott Walker and Senators Rand Paul and Marco Rubio, to name a few — have been garnering in recent weeks.

headline: Review: ‘Songs of the City,’ a Paean to New York at 92nd Street Y
abstract: This program in the Lyric and Lyricist series, overseen by Deborah Grace Winer, impeccably matched singer to song.
lead_paragraph: “Oh, no, not again,” I groaned silently on Saturday evening while scanning the song list for the Lyrics and Lyricists program at the 92nd Street Y, “Songs of the City,” and came upon the inevitable “New York, New York.” But when the time arrived to introduce that Kander and Ebb war horse, the series’ artistic director and host, Deborah Grace Winer, said she had always thought that the song’s perspective was really that of an outsider anticipating living in the city and not the boastful declaration of a fat cat. Substituting ingenuous eagerness for egotism, the singer Darius de Haas turned it into a pop-jazz revelation.

headline: President Obama Could Unmask Big Political Donors
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Government Contracts and Procurement', 'McCutcheon v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)', 'State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Mr. Obama has talked a lot about “dark money” in politics. Now it’s time for him to do something about it.
lead_paragraph: Long before Ted Cruz became the first presidential contender to officially declare his candidacy, the competition for big-money donors was well underway.

headline: 7 Friends Drown in Reservoir in India
abstract: Young men at a celebratory picnic in Maharashtra State died when they used an abandoned boat that began leaking.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Seven friends drowned in the western Indian state of Maharashtra after taking an abandoned boat to the middle of a natural reservoir, the police said Monday. A group of men ages 18 to 23 were celebrating a birthday on Sunday evening with a picnic in a remote village in the Nagpur district when eight of them decided to climb into the boat, using a stick to row to the middle of the 10-foot-deep reservoir, said the district police chief, Arti Singh. As they were taking selfies, the boat started leaking and eventually capsized. One of the men was saved by friends who remained on shore. The bodies of the seven others were dragged from the reservoir on Monday morning by the district police.

headline: Review: ‘Big Time in Hollywood, FL’ 30-Somethings Suddenly on Own
abstract: This first serialized, scripted comedy for Comedy Central follows brothers who face a crazy chain of events after being kicked out of their parents’ house.
lead_paragraph: To say that Kathy Baker and Stephen Tobolowsky steal the new Comedy Central series “Big Time in Hollywood, FL” isn’t quite right, because it suggests an element of surprise — that there was anything else about this occasionally amusing trifle that might have stood in their way.

headline: Review: Yossi Berg and Oded Graf, Seeking Connection and Dissolving Into Humor
abstract: Israeli dancer-choreographers performed their “Heroes” duet at New York Live Arts as part of the Joyce Unleashed series.
lead_paragraph: About halfway through “Heroes,” a duet by the Israeli choreographers Yossi Berg and Oded Graf, one of the dancers breaks into song. His emphatic rendition of “Happy Together” by the Turtles — “I think about you night and day!” he squawks — doesn’t appear to register with his partner. They seem more desperate and alone.

headline: Walkabout: For National Parks, an Older Crowd
keywords: ['Eclipses', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: A weekly capsule of travel news curated by our writers and editors.

headline: Netanyahu Apologizes to Israeli Arabs
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized to Israel’s Arabs for his election-day rallying call to his supporters last week, which was called racist by opponents.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu apologized to Israel’s Arabs for his election-day rallying call to his supporters last week, which was called racist by opponents.

headline: Review: On Laura Marling’s ‘Short Movie,’ Songs of Restlessness and Solitude
abstract: The heralded British folk singer, now 25, wrote this intensely searching new album during a period of self-discovery in and around Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: “Love seems to be some kind of trickery,” Laura Marling sings about halfway through “Short Movie,” her intensely searching new album. “Some great thing to which I am a mystery.” She’s strumming an electric guitar against a rock beat, sounding steely and incredulous, unsure about a few things but not, in the end, about herself.

headline: Review: ‘The Ark Work’ Is Liturgy’s Third Album
abstract: The album keeps the group’s black-metal rhythm and guitar sound, but digs into other styles, from hip-hop to Gregorian chant.
lead_paragraph: About six years ago, Liturgy, a young band from Brooklyn, figured out a good counterintuitive response to black metal, a restricted, cultish kind of music that isn’t traditionally open to responses of any kind. It did so first through music alone. Liturgy used that subgenre’s basic musical identifying marks — its hyperactive, unsyncopated blast-beat drumming and its staccato guitar lines — but opened up the rhythms and harmonies to let in what black metal generally disallowed: tempo-warping improvisation, major keys, occasionally some nonscreamed singing. It was in the differences that you could smell the wood smoke of an original group sound.

headline: Trailer: New Directors/New Films
abstract: A look at films in the festival “New Directors/New Films,” presented by the Museum of Modern Art and the Film Society of Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: A look at films in the festival “New Directors/New Films,” presented by the Museum of Modern Art and the Film Society of Lincoln Center.

headline: Review: Earl Sweatshirt’s Latest Album Goes to Dark Places
abstract: It’s possible Earl Sweatshirt is bored.
lead_paragraph: Another week, another highly touted Los Angeles rap dissenter.

headline: Police Say No Evidence of Rape at UVA
abstract: Timothy Longo, the Charlottesville police chief, said that the investigation into claims of gang rape at a University of Virginia fraternity had been suspended because of a lack of evidence.
lead_paragraph: Timothy Longo, the Charlottesville police chief, said that the investigation into claims of gang rape at a University of Virginia fraternity had been suspended because of a lack of evidence.

headline: George Bush to Headline Dallas Fund-Raiser for Brother Jeb
abstract: George W. Bush is lending his younger brother a hand, in one of the few ways he can — for now.
lead_paragraph: George W. Bush is lending his younger brother a hand, in one of the few ways he can — for now.

headline: New Directors/New Films Festival Highlights Bold Narrative Experiments
abstract: In its second week, distinct cinematic visions (including a pack of Argentine hounds) trump the more familiar drifting stories and generic youthful ennui.
lead_paragraph: Distinct cinematic visions and bold narrative experiments help distinguish the second week of New Directors/New Films, trumping the more familiar festival-ready drifting stories and generic youthful ennui. And, for a second week, the festival is again going (happily) to the dogs: Among last week’s highlights was the astonishing Hungarian pack in “White God”; among this week’s are the less numerous Argentine hounds of “Dog Lady.”

headline: Review: In Rebecca Serrell Cyr’s ‘Assemblage,’ an All-Inclusive Approach
abstract: Ms. Cyr, a Bessie Award-winning dancer, made room for a wide range of ideas — and objects — in her new work, which premiered on Thursday at Jack in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: What to keep, and what to throw away? That question can come up in any creative process, but in “Assemblage,” Rebecca Serrell Cyr essentially waves it aside. Why not keep everything? According to press notes about the work, which had its premiere at Jack in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, on Thursday, Ms. Cyr made “a radical decision not to edit anything out.”

headline: Review: Schubert and Schnittke, a Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center Concert
abstract: The pianist Juho Pohjonen, the violinist Benjamin Beilman and the cellist Jan Vogler explored the relationship between two composers more than a century apart.
lead_paragraph: Schubert and Schnittke: Do they share anything more than alliteration? That was the question asked by the pianist Juho Pohjonen, the violinist Benjamin Beilman and the cellist Jan Vogler during a Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center concert at Alice Tully Hall on Friday.

headline: World’s Protected Areas Draw Estimated 8 Billion Visitors Annually
abstract: A team of British and American researchers has provided what they say is the first global estimate of annual visits to nature areas.
lead_paragraph: A growing number of people around the world are choosing to spend vacations and weekends in nature. But until recently no one had ever tried to quantify just how many visit protected areas each year.

headline: The Waves of the Future May Bend Around Metamaterials
abstract: Scientists have learned how to construct materials that bend waves of light, sound and seismic energy, and are working on applications that may transform industries.
lead_paragraph: BELLEVUE, Wash. — Plastics. Computers. Metamaterials?

headline: Judge Tells Korean-Restaurant Owner in Queens to Pay $2.7 Million in Back Wages
abstract: Workers at Kum Gang San Restaurant said they often worked more than 16 hours with no overtime and were ordered to pick cabbage on their day off.
lead_paragraph: During the busiest banquet season at Kum Gang San, a venerable 24-hour Korean restaurant in Flushing, Queens, employees said they often worked more than 16 hours, with no overtime, and earned less than the minimum wage. When times were slow, workers had to shovel snow from the owner’s driveway and move the owner’s son to a new apartment.

headline: Intersection | Hong Kong
abstract: While on the streets of the Wan Chai neighborhood, Grace Lam, a contributing fashion editor for Vogue China, shares her fun and edgy style icons: Bruce Lee, David Bowie and her colorblind mother.
lead_paragraph: While on the streets of the Wan Chai neighborhood, Grace Lam, a contributing fashion editor for Vogue China, shares her fun and edgy style icons: Bruce Lee, David Bowie and her colorblind mother.

headline: Lionel Messi Is Back on His Game
abstract: After a disappointing start to the club season, the Argentine World Cup star is finally reminding us why we loved watching him in the first place.
lead_paragraph: It has been a pleasure to watch Lionel Messi playing with Barcelona during the past week, in a way that it hasn’t been in a long time. When I profiled the Argentine superstar for the magazine in June of last year, just before the World Cup, he was in a bit of a funk. As one Argentine writer told me at the time, “It’s like he’s tied up.”

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Conflict, Courage and Healing in Gaza
abstract: Heidi Levine’s coverage of the Gaza conflict earned her the Anja Niedringhaus Courage in Photojournalism Award, which honors the Associated Press photographer killed in Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: Heidi Levine’s coverage of the Gaza conflict earned her the Anja Niedringhaus Courage in Photojournalism Award, which honors the Associated Press photographer killed in Afghanistan.

headline: Festival Dressing at SXSW
keywords: ['Music', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: Music lovers bring their unique style to Austin during the SXSW music festival.
lead_paragraph: Music lovers bring their unique style to Austin during the SXSW music festival.

headline: Wan Chai Style in Hong Kong
abstract: While on the streets of the Wan Chai neighborhood, Grace Lam, a contributing fashion editor for Vogue China, shares her fun and edgy style icons: Bruce Lee, David Bowie and her colorblind mother.
lead_paragraph: Grace Lam, a fashion stylist and contributing fashion editor for Vogue China, used to wear a lot of vintage clothing. But her style changed when she moved from London to Hong Kong. “In Hong Kong, there are not many vintage shops, so it’s difficult to find,” she said. “Now I’m a little more grown-up, and I can afford more designer clothes, which is great.” Recently, in the Wan Chai neighborhood, she was wearing an outfit by Johanna Ho, a local designer, with Balenciaga shoes and a Saint Laurent clutch. She credits the people in the area with taking fashion risks but still considers fashion in Hong Kong more conservative than in cities like Paris or London. This interview has been edited and condensed.

headline: Expected Benefits of Renewed Brooklyn Sewage Station Include a Creek Less Foul
keywords: ['Sewers and Sewage', 'Water Pollution', 'Water', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Restoration and Renovation']
abstract: The Avenue V sewage pumping station in Gravesend, a 100-year-old monument to the majesty of public endeavor, has just had an $8 million face-lift to go along with its $200 million in new equipment.
lead_paragraph: The jewel-like brick structure stands unmarked in a jumbled corner of Brooklyn, amid housing projects and plain rowhouses and elevated train tracks and the headquarters of the Aardvark Amusements carnival ride company.

headline: No Need to Run in Hawaii: The Lava Is Coming, but Very Slowly
abstract: Residents of the Hawaiian town of Pahoa have learned to adapt as a slow-moving lava flow menaces their community.
lead_paragraph: PAHOA, Hawaii — If a disaster movie played out in slow motion, it might look a bit like the Puna District on the Big Island of Hawaii.

headline: Microsoft Partners With Android Makers in Its Latest Mobile Push
abstract: Microsoft is serious about making its most lucrative business, Office, relevant for mobile users. What is less clear is how much money it will be able to make from them.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Microsoft is serious about making its most lucrative business, Office, relevant to mobile users. What is less clear is how much money it will be able to make from them.

headline: Lee Kuan Yew’s Mixed Legacy in Singapore
abstract: The next generation of leaders should make the country a political model, not just an economic one.
lead_paragraph: Lee Kuan Yew, the founding leader of Singapore who died Monday morning, was a towering figure on the global stage who helped transform his small city-state into an economic powerhouse. President Obama went so far as to describe Mr. Lee as a “true giant of history.”

headline: Google Fiber Plans Experiment With Targeted Ads for Television
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Cable Television', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Online Advertising', 'Television']
abstract: While Google Fiber is growing fast, it is still minuscule compared with its traditional rivals. But it shows the potential for delivering specific kinds of ads to local markets.
lead_paragraph: Cute animals. Addictive jingles. Local sports stars acting awkwardly. These are some of the charming hallmarks of local television ads, and Google would like you to see more of them.

headline: Jets Owner Woody Johnson Says He’s Not Concerned About Tampering Inquiry
abstract: Johnson said he was not worried about an N.F.L. investigation into whether the Jets broke tampering rules before signing cornerback Darrelle Revis.
lead_paragraph: Phoenix — Woody Johnson, owner of the Jets, said he was not concerned about an existing N.F.L. investigation into whether his team broke league rules on tampering before it signed the free-agent cornerback Darrelle Revis.

headline: Despite Regulatory Advances, Experts Say Risk Remains a Danger to Large Banks
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Derivatives (Financial Instruments)']
abstract: The banking industry is supposed to be safer in the wake of the financial crisis, but speakers at a Federal Reserve conference said that is not the case.
lead_paragraph: With all the new laws and regulations since the financial crisis, it would be easy to believe that the banking industry is safer. headline: Review: ‘Small Mouth Sounds,’ Silence at a Spiritual Spa
abstract: Bess Wohl’s new play at Ars Nova follows six troubled souls through a weeklong intervention without words. Only their guru talks.
lead_paragraph: A half-dozen troubled souls find that enforced silence doesn’t necessarily bring inner peace in “Small Mouth Sounds,” an enchanting new play by Bess Wohl presented at Ars Nova. As funny as it is, uh, quietly moving, Ms. Wohl’s play is also a model of ingenuity. During its 100-minute running time and with one exception — the (unseen) guru running this spiritual retreat — the characters hardly ever speak. Both the humor and the pathos spring mostly from wordless interaction, which is testimony to Ms. Wohl’s intrepid writing, to the superb acting and to the precise work of the production’s director, Rachel Chavkin.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 12:30 P.M. (AMC) AMERICAN GANGSTER (2007) Ridley Scott directs this Oscar-nominated crime drama set in the 1970s. Frank Lucas (Denzel Washington) is a gangster in Harlem who finds that he can get the best heroin cheap from Southeast Asia, smuggled to the United States in the coffins of American soldiers sent from Vietnam. He calls the heroin Blue Magic and takes over the market. Richie Roberts (Russell Crowe) is an obnoxiously honest New Jersey detective. When his partner (John Ortiz) dies from an overdose of Blue Magic, Richie is asked to lead a drug trafficking task force. A corrupt New York detective named Trupo (Josh Brolin) bridges the gap between the two lead characters. “You can almost feel Mr. Scott trying to coax the material away from its generic trappings toward something rarefied, something like Francis Ford Coppola’s 1972 definitive American story, ‘The Godfather,’ ” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “He comes closest to that goal with the suggestion that the lethal pursuit of the American dream is not restricted to one or two families — the Corleones, say, or the Sopranos — but located in a network of warring tribes that help to obscure the larger war of all against all.”

headline: Many Will Need to Repay Health Subsidies
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Half of the households that received subsidies to help pay health insurance premiums last year under the Affordable Care Act will probably have to repay some of that money to the federal government, according to a new analysis by the Kaiser Family Foundation.
lead_paragraph: Half of the households that received subsidies to help pay health insurance premiums last year under the Affordable Care Act will probably have to repay some of that money to the federal government, according to a new analysis by the Kaiser Family Foundation. The foundation also predicted that 45 percent of households that received subsidies will probably get a refund, because their 2014 income was lower than what they estimated when they applied for coverage. Under the law, people can receive subsidies to help cover the cost of insurance purchased through online marketplaces if they earn between 100 and 400 percent of the federal poverty level. Taxpayers generally receive subsidies in advance, with the amount based on their projected household income for the year the insurance policy will be in effect. But they must then reconcile the estimate with their actual income when filing federal taxes. Kaiser estimated that subsidy recipients who underestimated their incomes will owe $794 on average, while those who overestimated will receive average refunds of $773.

headline: For an Elite Girls’ Basketball Team, the Same High Standards Amid New Challenges
abstract: A writer who chronicled the season of the girls’ basketball team at Christ the King High School in Queens 16 years ago returned for an update.
lead_paragraph: After the cruelty of a 5:30 a.m. wake-up, a ride to the St. George Terminal with her father, a 6:20 Staten Island Ferry, the J train to the M train, Dominique Toussaint finally arrives at Christ the King High School in Middle Village, Queens. From her home on Staten Island, the trip can take two hours.

headline: U.S. to Delay Pullout of Troops From Afghanistan to Aid Strikes
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: President Obama is keeping troops in Afghanistan partly to bolster counterterrorism efforts there, including the C.I.A.’s ability to conduct drone strikes, officials said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s decision to maintain troop levels in Afghanistan through 2015 is partly designed to bolster American counterterrorism efforts in that country, including the Central Intelligence Agency’s ability to conduct secret drone strikes and other paramilitary operations from United States military bases, administration officials said Tuesday.

headline: Police Shooting Victim in Georgia Tried to Follow ‘Sensible’ Path
abstract: Long before two bullets from an officer’s gun tore through Anthony Hill’s chest, he had tattooed it with his grandfather’s advice: “Be sensible.” And he had done his best to heed that counsel.
lead_paragraph: MONCKS CORNER, S.C. — Long before two bullets from a police officer’s handgun tore through Anthony Hill’s chest, he had tattooed it with the words of advice that his grandfather regularly imparted to him in this small Southern city: “Be sensible.”

headline: Iraqi Forces Map Plan Against ISIS, With Strategic Use of Militias
abstract: The hard lessons of the Tikrit offensive, which brought high casualties, have Iraqi officials thinking more cautiously about their next steps.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — As a small force of Islamic State militants holds out in parts of Tikrit for a fourth week, Iraqi forces have been compelled to shift tactics, officials say: Rather than storming in to clear the city at any cost, the security forces are trying to seal off the area and begin preparing for even more challenging battles to the west and north.

headline: Meet Our Man in Tehran
abstract: In a new video series, Thomas Erdbrink, the Tehran bureau chief for The New York Times, interviews the people of Iran, a country that is slowly changing and where nothing is as it seems.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Erdbrink and Roel van Broekhoven, the director of the series on the Dutch television channel VPRO, answered some of your questions about living and reporting in Iran. To learn about new episodes of “Our Man in Tehran,” you can subscribe to The Times Video email newsletter.

headline: A Conversation With the Authors of ‘Becoming Steve Jobs’
abstract: Brent Schlender and Rick Tetzeli, who wrote “Becoming Steve Jobs,” discuss the evolution of Steve Jobs and how they won Apple’s cooperation for the unauthorized biography of its former chief executive.
lead_paragraph: Apple co-founder Steve Jobs has been the subject of myriad books. But the latest one, “Becoming Steve Jobs,” released on Tuesday, is the only one with Apple’s stamp of approval.

headline: Lanshu Chen on Dining Well on the Road
abstract: The Taiwanese chef, formerly of French Laundry, offers tips on how to stay away from generic and touristy places on the road.
lead_paragraph: For the Taiwanese chef Lanshu Chen, cooking is only part of the job. The chef, who worked at high-profile restaurants like the French Laundry in Napa Valley, owns Le Moût Restaurant in Taichung City, Taiwan, a member of the Relais & Châteaux group. In early March, Ms. Chen, 34, was in Carmel-by-the Sea, Calif., for Relais & Châteaux’s GourmetFest, featuring more than 20 well-known chefs.

headline: Getting to the Front of the Visa Line
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Visas', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Passports', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: Frustrated by visa applications for destinations like Brazil, Russia, China and India? Here’s a three-step plan for success.
lead_paragraph: Few things can dampen the joy of vacation anticipation more than the arduous process of obtaining a visa, especially for destinations such as Brazil, Russia, China and India. Wonky web forms, confounding instructions, long lines at embassies and ever-changing requirements — like Venezuela’s new immigration rules, which now require Americans to procure visas — are par for the course.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Eurozone Business Growth Nears 4-Year High, Report Shows
abstract: Purchasing managers reported that output in March expanded at the quickest pace since May 2011, according to a Markit Economics survey.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A measure of business sentiment in the eurozone has hit its highest level in nearly four years, providing one more glimmer of hope that a long-awaited European economic recovery might finally be taking hold.

headline: Driven | 2015 Lincoln Navigator
abstract: Freshened with a new bow and stern, the new Lincoln Navigator faces competition from its better-optioned rivals.
lead_paragraph: Freshened with a new bow and stern, the new Lincoln Navigator faces competition from its better-optioned rivals.

headline: Video Review: Lincoln Navigator, a Behemoth With Leather and Attitude
abstract: The S.U.V. is built on the chassis of the F-150 pickup and has replaced its V8 with a more powerful EcoBoost V6.
lead_paragraph: IN the 1990s, there was an ocean of difference between trucks and luxury cars. But that changed when Lincoln introduced the luxurious leather-lined Navigator sport utility vehicle in 1997. Obviously a fancier Ford Expedition, it was immense — and immensely profitable. Cadillac quickly followed with the Escalade.

headline: Protecting the Last of Africa’s Northern White Rhinos
abstract: Ol Pejeta Conservancy is home to three — one male and two females — of the last five northern white rhinos on the planet.
lead_paragraph: Ol Pejeta Conservancy is home to three — one male and two females — of the last five northern white rhinos on the planet.

headline: Hutchison Whampoa to Acquire British Cellphone Carrier O2
abstract: Under the deal, worth about $15 billion, the company owned by the billionaire Li Ka-shing will combine O2 with another British phone business.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Hutchison Whampoa, one of the Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing’s flagship companies, has agreed to buy O2, the British cellphone carrier owned by the Spanish telecommunications giant Telefónica, in a deal worth about $15 billion.

headline: New York Today: Cold-Weather Deniers
abstract: Tuesday: People who refuse to bundle up, one more cold day, and an aging gangster may finally go to jail.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this brisk Tuesday.

headline: Daily Report: Facebook Wants to Be Home to News Media
abstract: The social media giant is said to be in talks with several news publishers, offering to deliver their content quickly, in exchange for a certain loss of control over their readership.
lead_paragraph: Nothing attracts news organizations like Facebook. And nothing makes them more nervous, write Ravi Somaiya, Mike Isaac and Vindu Goel.

headline: Debunking the Myth of the Job-Stealing Immigrant
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Foreign Workers', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Even those of us who favor a path to citizenship are not going far enough, because we are mired in zero-sum thinking.
lead_paragraph: When I was growing up in the 1980s, I watched my grandfather — my dad’s stepdad — struggle with his own prejudice. He was a blue-collar World War II veteran who loved his family above all things and was constantly afraid for them. He carried a gun and, like many men of his generation, saw threats in people he didn’t understand: African-Americans, independent women, gays. By the time he died, 10 years ago, he had softened. He stopped using racist and homophobic slurs; he even hugged my gay cousin. But there was one view he wasn’t going to change. He had no time for Hispanics, he told us, and he wasn’t backing down. After all, this wasn’t a matter of bigotry. It was plain economics. These immigrants were stealing jobs from “Americans.”

headline: Galaxies Inside His Head
keywords: ['Poetry and Poets', 'Books and Literature', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Terrance Hayes uses poetry to show that there is more to him, and to anyone, than what you expect.
lead_paragraph: Fifty students sat at bright white desks in concentric rows in the sterile new computer center at Woodland Hills High School, their eyes on the poet Terrance Hayes. At 6-foot-5, Hayes, who is 43, is easy to see from anywhere, and he seemed eminently approachable, neither teacher nor teen: bluejeans, a black sweater, a leather cellphone case clipped to his belt. He had come to the school, in a racially mixed district that serves several disadvantaged communities in Pittsburgh, to read poetry. The students — Goths, hip-hop fans in giant sweatshirts and jocks in sports jerseys — grew quiet, ready to listen.

headline: How ‘Flawless’ Became a Feminist Declaration
abstract: To be beautiful is to be pleasing to others, but to be ‘flawless’ is a statement of radical confidence: It means pleasing yourself.
lead_paragraph: The word “flaw” is some 700 years old. It was born from fire and ice, first used to mean “ember” and “snowflake” — some fragment of a whole gone astray. It evolved to signify “defect,” initially in surfaces and soon after in character. But recently, it has become associated most closely with appearance, thanks to the popularity of its opposite, “flawless.” On social media, “flawless” has a celebratory sheen: Women apply it tenderly, reverently to one another — and triumphantly to themselves.

headline: A Persian in Therapy
keywords: ['Bipolar Disorder', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Psychiatry and Psychiatrists', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation']
abstract: In my community, this was not how you solved your problems.
lead_paragraph: My people don’t do psychotherapy. We have friends. We have families. We have pharmacies. Paying strangers to listen to our problems isn’t our style.

headline: Today in Politics: April Could Bring a Shower of Presidential Announcements
abstract: April will be the most active month in the budding 2016 presidential race, with Hillary Rodham Clinton, Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky and Senator Marco Rubio of Florida expected to make their candidacies official.
lead_paragraph: Good Tuesday morning from Washington, where Hillary Rodham Clinton has been mixing with reporters, and members of Congress are taking a moment to salute a golf legend. Secretary of State John Kerry has been hanging out at Camp David, and Senator Ted Cruz has made clear that he would like to do the same someday. Now that the Texas Republican is officially running for president, we take a look at who might be next.

headline: David Cameron Rules Out Third Term as Prime Minister of Britain
abstract: In a BBC interview, he said he would complete his second term but would not run again after that, a stance that could undermine his authority if he wins on May 7.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Just over six weeks before seeking a second term in May’s general election, Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain has ruled out serving a third, in a declaration that provoked surprise as well as criticism and put his Conservative Party on the defensive.

headline: Germanwings Crash in French Alps Kills 150; Cockpit Voice Recorder Is Found
abstract: The jet, en route from Barcelona, Spain, to Düsseldorf, Germany, went down in the southern Alps. The authorities and executives of the airline, a subsidiary of Lufthansa, had no immediate explanation for the crash.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A German jetliner en route from Barcelona, Spain, to Düsseldorf, Germany, plunged from the sky on Tuesday and slammed into the French Alps, killing all 150 people on board.

headline: The Pulpit and the Ballot Box
abstract: Why do voters care about a candidate's religion? Does it matter?

headline: Morning Agenda: Oil Prices Fall, but Airfares Stay High
abstract: Oil Prices Fall, but Airfares Stay High | S.E.C. Under Pressure Over Bank Waivers | Silence Falls on Chicago Trading Pits
lead_paragraph: OIL PRICES FALL, BUT AIRFARES STAY HIGH  | A spate of mergers has left the nation’s airline industry “increasingly looking like an uncompetitive oligopoly,” writes Andrew Ross Sorkin in the DealBook column . Evidence of that can be seen in the fact that while oil prices have plummeted, fares have not dropped.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | March 17-23, 2015
abstract: Have you been following the news? Take our quiz to see what you know and to learn more, and look for a new edition each week on Tuesday morning.
lead_paragraph: Have you been following the news?

headline: Words We Love Too Much
abstract: A colleague offers a warning about our surprising fondness for a particular fancy word: apotheosis.
lead_paragraph: My colleague Mark Bulik offers a warning about our surprising fondness for a particular fancy word:

headline: In Performance: Telly Leung and Jennifer Lim of ‘The World of Extreme Happiness’
abstract: A scene from Frances Ya-Chu Cowhig’s drama set in contemporary China.
lead_paragraph: This week’s video features the actors Telly Leung and Jennifer Lim in a scene from Frances Ya-Chu Cowhig’s “The World of Extreme Happiness,” a drama set in contemporary China. In this scene, Pete (Mr. Leung) and his sister Sunny (Ms. Lim) play a video game while discussing the perils of city living. The show, directed by Eric Ting, runs through Sunday at the City Center Stage I.

headline: Group Urges Clinton to Embrace Liberal Agenda
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A liberal group is starting a campaign Tuesday aimed at pushing Hillary Rodham Clinton to adopt a full-throated liberal agenda in her all-but-certain presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: A liberal group is starting a campaign Tuesday aimed at pushing Hillary Rodham Clinton to adopt a full-throated liberal agenda in her all-but-certain presidential campaign, signaling that even some on the far left of the Democratic Party are now more focused on shaping Mrs. Clinton’s eventual platform than they are on finding an alternative to her.

headline: ‘Finding Neverland’ Off to Strong Start at Box Office
abstract: The musical about the man who created “Peter Pan” is directed by Diane Paulus and produced by Harvey Weinstein.
lead_paragraph: “Finding Neverland,” the new musical about the man who created “Peter Pan,” brought in more than $1 million in its first week at the Broadway box office, an encouraging sign for a show whose flight path to New York has been turbulent.

headline: Attack by Gunmen on Afghan Highway Unnerves Travelers
abstract: The episode is the latest in a series of assaults on a major road connecting Kabul and Kandahar, and a grim reminder of the dangers of traveling across Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — As many as 13 people were killed on one of Afghanistan’s most important roads early Tuesday morning when gunmen opened fire on a bus and two other vehicles, the authorities here said.

headline: ‘Advance Contemporary’? Yet Another Fashion Phrase You’d Better Know
abstract: In the brand race to own every segment of the fashion market — and hence every fashion consumer — a clothing category has, apparently, returned.
lead_paragraph: Just when you thought you had enough on your shopping plate, what with distinguishing among “contemporary” and “accessible luxury” and “designer” and “luxury” and “high luxury,” another piece of head-scratching sartorial nomenclature is materializing on the industry horizon. Remember “advanced contemporary”?

headline: China Executes 3 Over Deadly Knife Attack at Train Station in 2014
keywords: ['Uighurs (Chinese Ethnic Group)', 'Capital Punishment', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Terrorism', 'Han Chinese (Ethnic Group)']
abstract: The rampage at the Kunming station in Yunnan Province last year killed 31 people and wounded 141.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A provincial court in southwestern China announced on Tuesday that the authorities had executed three men for carrying out a knife attack last year on civilians in a crowded train station in which 31 people were killed and 141 wounded.

headline: Hackers Use an Android App for Sex Extortion
abstract: Criminals are luring targets into online sex chats, then persuading them to download apps that siphon off their contact information, passwords and address books.
lead_paragraph: For years, criminals have been tricking people into performing embarrassing sexual acts on the Internet, and then blackmailing them with recordings of that behavior.

headline: The LC2 Chair, in Living Color
abstract: Cassina, which has licensed Le Corbusier’s furniture since 1964, has reached into the archives for five new frame hues.
lead_paragraph: Le Corbusier designed the LC2 chair in 1928, but its defining moment didn’t come until 51 years later, in a famous 1979 commercial by Maxell audio in which a slouching young man in aviator shades is nearly blown out of the seat by a gust of high fidelity. Little wonder he stayed put: The LC2 brings a distinctly modern profile to down-cushioned comfort. Now Cassina, which has licensed Le Corbusier’s furniture since 1964, has reached into the archives for five new frame colors, including arresting shades of blue and green, developed with the help of the two people who inspired the architect to start making his own furniture in the first place: his cousin and business partner, Pierre Jeanneret, and their collaborator, the incomparable Charlotte Perriand. Eighty-seven years after its creation, it’s still a chair you don’t want to get out of.

headline: Kushner Brothers Combine Real Estate and Technology
abstract: Their start-up, Cadre, which aims to make it easier for select clients to invest in real estate, has raised more than $18.3 million.
lead_paragraph: Jared and Joshua Kushner have charted separate careers for years, one as a real estate developer, the other as a technology venture capitalist. But the brothers have teamed up for a new company that combines their two expertises.

lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Greece will present a detailed list of proposed overhauls to its eurozone partners by Monday, a government spokesman said, as Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras met supporters and leading government ministers on his first official visit to Europe’s economic powerhouse, Germany.

keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Foreign Workers']

lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE — Among the many orders that Lee Kuan Yew issued during his five decades as leader of Singapore was the razing of his home.

keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']

headline: Google Hires Finance Chief Ruth Porat From Morgan Stanley
abstract: Ms. Porat, who has been Morgan Stanley’s chief financial officer since 2010, will become one of the most powerful women in Silicon Valley.
lead_paragraph: Google, which is facing questions about increased spending in the face of slipping prices for its ads, has turned to the big bank Morgan Stanley for its new chief financial officer, one of the most visible examples yet of the talent that has been flowing from Wall Street to Silicon Valley.

headline: ISIS Militants Stone an Iraqi Couple Accused of Adultery
abstract: The man and woman were killed in Mosul, and residents said it was one of more than a dozen stonings since the militants took control.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Islamic State militants in Iraq on Tuesday publicly stoned a man and woman to death on charges of adultery, parading the victims in a public square in the northern city of Mosul, according to witnesses and an Iraqi military official.

headline: Indian Court Voids Law That Curbed Offensive Online Posts
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Computers and the Internet']

lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The Indian Supreme Court on Tuesday struck down a section of a law that allowed the authorities to jail people for offensive online posts, in a judgment that was regarded as a landmark ruling on free speech in India.

headline: Living With Lava, a Slow-Motion Disaster
abstract: Residents in the town of Pahoa on Hawaii’s Big Island talk about what it’s like to live in the path of a very, very slow-moving natural disaster.
lead_paragraph: Residents in the town of Pahoa on Hawaii’s Big Island talk about what it’s like to live in the path of a very, very slow-moving natural disaster.

headline: A Musical Plea for Immigration Reform
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Immigration Detention', 'Music', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In a recent music video, Los Jornaleros del Norte offer a reminder of the toll detention and deportation can take on families.
lead_paragraph: Immigration reform, once such a hopeful subject, is now stuck in a scorched and barren place. Legislation is dead in Congress. The 2016 presidential primary race is about to re-energize the Republican Party’s nativists, as candidates – following the example set Monday by the hard-right Senator Ted Cruz – start lining up to denounce unauthorized immigrants and pledge their allegiance to the fantasy of a sealed border. Meanwhile, President Obama’s program to give deportation relief to some unauthorized immigrants has been stymied, nationwide, by a hostile federal district judge in Texas.

headline: How to Avoid the Sex-Trafficking Bill’s ‘Surprise’
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Human Trafficking', 'United States Politics and Government', 'ABORTION']
abstract: To prevent problems — like a limit on abortion funding tucked inside a bill — each bill could be its own web page, with links to all the laws it affects.
lead_paragraph: A once-popular bill to help victims of sex trafficking was derailed in the Senate recently when Democrats discovered that language restricting funding for abortions was in the bill — sneaked in, they charged, by Republicans.

lead_paragraph: Alabama State Coach Freda Freeman-Jackson’s play call to open the second half against Florida State on Saturday could not have been drawn up any better.

headline: Slack Said to Be in Talks to Raise Money at More Than $2 Billion Valuation
abstract: The talks come just four months after Slack, which is run by the entrepreneur Stewart Butterfield, raised $120 million at a valuation of more than $1 billion.
lead_paragraph: Slack, the San Francisco start-up that makes a​ workplace collaboration app, is back on the fund-raising trail and is​ in talks to​ rais​e money at a valuation of more than $2 billion, according to ​a person familiar with the matter.​ ​The talks come just four months after Slack, which is run by the entrepreneur Stewart Butterfield, raised $120 million at a valuation of more than $1 billion. The valuation could change because the talks are still occurring, according to this ​person, who requested anonymity because of continuing ties to the company.

headline: Ted Cruz Recruits Some Rand Paul Supporters in Iowa
abstract: Ted Cruz has peeled away three leaders of the Libertarian faction in the state, known as the Liberty movement, who are the base of Senator Rand Paul’s support in Iowa.
lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas, whose path to the Republican nomination requires a breakout performance in Iowa, has quickly recruited more than a dozen party leaders for his statewide campaign, who are to be announced in coming days, according to people told of the choices.

headline: As Arizona Struggles to Fix Foster System, Children Suffer the Consequences
keywords: ['Foster Care', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Two advocacy groups that filed a lawsuit last month against the state say children are being rescued from one bad situation only to end up in another one.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — She was just 5 months old the first time she and her siblings were taken from a mother struggling with addiction and placed in the care of the state. At times, she was separated from her brothers and sisters. She received neither the glasses she needed, nor the orthopedic shoes, leaving her with a limp. Now 10, she has spent more than half her life in foster care, having been returned to her mother only to be removed again, a routine that has been repeated multiple times.

headline: $20 Million Gift to Expand National World War II Museum
abstract: The donation was made by Donald T. Bollinger Jr., known as Boysie, a longtime supporter of the museum, and will be used, in part, to add a 150-foot-tall “Canopy of Peace.”
lead_paragraph: The National World War II Museum is to announce on Tuesday a $20 million gift that will be used to add a “Canopy of Peace” to the New Orleans campus as part of the museum’s expansion.

headline: Review: Daniel Beaty as Paul Robeson in ‘The Tallest Tree in the Forest’
abstract: In Mr. Beaty’s new solo show at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, he embodies the life story of Robeson, the African-American performer, and sings his songs.
lead_paragraph: The lives of actors often contain heady highs and dispiriting lows, so fragile is their hold on the public’s imagination and their access to the levers of power in the industry. But the story of Paul Robeson, the great African-American performer who achieved international fame in the 1920s and ’30s, only to be condemned for his political beliefs and branded a Communist during the witch hunts of the ’50s, is a particularly egregious example of a star falling at warp speed.

headline: Former Fed Board Member to Advise Hedge Fund
abstract: Jeremy C. Stein is headed to Wall Street to work as a consultant at BlueMountain Capital Management.
lead_paragraph: As a member of the Federal Reserve’s board, Jeremy C. Stein raised concerns about areas of frothiness in the financial markets.

headline: Commemoration of Death of Lincoln Features Report From a Doctor in the House
abstract: A report by Dr. Charles A. Leale, who attended Abraham Lincoln after he was shot, is a highlight of the National Archives’ commemoration of the 150th anniversary of Lincoln’s assassination.
lead_paragraph: The National Archives in Washington is commemorating the 150th anniversary of the death of Abraham Lincoln with a series of book talks, a panel discussion and the exhibition of a key document relating to the assassination: a copy of the death report drafted a day after the shooting by Charles A. Leale, a doctor in the audience at Ford’s Theater.

headline: Memo by Democrats for Education Reform Looks Ahead to 2016

lead_paragraph: Joe Williams, the executive director of Democrats for Education Reform, wrote to board members about polling conducted for the group, presumably in an attempt to set the terms for a policy discussion with candidates.

headline: Stubborn Pay Gap Is Found in Nursing
abstract: An analysis of data from almost 300,000 nurses found the pay gap had not narrowed across workplace settings and specialties from 1988 to 2013.
lead_paragraph: Male nurses make $5,100 more on average per year than female colleagues in similar positions, researchers reported on Tuesday.

abstract: The firm, under regulatory scrutiny, also said it faced potential delisting from the New York Stock Exchange.
lead_paragraph: Ocwen Financial, the mortgage servicing firm under regulatory scrutiny, disclosed on Tuesday that it planned to sell loan servicing rights for $25 billion in loans to another firm, Nationstar Mortgage.

headline: Scene City: ‘Mad Men’ Toasts Its Final Season

lead_paragraph: On Sunday night, the stars of “Mad Men” celebrated the show’s final season with a party at the Museum of Modern Art. “For better or for worse, it’s not only the longest job I’ve ever had but certainly the career-defining one, to say the least,” Jon Hamm said. “Yeah, I will definitely miss it.”

headline: Cocktail Table Service Thinks Big
