headline: 1915: Ankles Baffle Court Witness
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Divorce, Separations and Annulments']
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: New York stage star’s ankles baffle witnesses in divorce court in 1915.
lead_paragraph: The ankles of Mrs. Claudia Carlstedt Wheeler, once a New York stage favorite, were not recognized by a witness brought to testify against her in the Supreme Court yesterday [March 8]. Neither was her face or figure. Judson Rogers, night clerk of the San Remo Hotel, decided that she was not the woman with whom Walter W. Green had registered as man and wife. Mrs. Wheeler appeared before Justice Greenbaum and a jury to contest the action for divorce brought by Albert Gallatin Wheeler, Jr., son of the builder of the Chicago elevated railroad. — The New York Herald, European Edition, March 25, 1915

headline: Trusted Aide Declines Formal Role in a Clinton Campaign
abstract: Cheryl D. Mills, an close adviser to Hillary Rodham Clinton, won’t be playing a formal role in Mrs. Clinton’s soon-to-be-announced presidential bid.
lead_paragraph: Cheryl D. Mills, an adviser to Hillary Rodham Clinton who has been closer to her than perhaps any other over the last six years, will not be playing a formal role in her soon-to-be-announced presidential bid, according to people in direct discussions with the campaign.

headline: Why Wall Streeters’ Defections to Silicon Valley Are Good News for the Economy
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: If you think of finance as a back office function, it’s easier to see why some of the best and brightest young people are making moves.
lead_paragraph: It’s easy to understand why Ruth Porat, the chief financial officer of the venerable investment bank Morgan Stanley and one of the most powerful women on Wall Street, would want to head west to become C.F.O. of Google.

headline: Festival Dressing at SXSW
keywords: ['South by Southwest Music and Media Conference', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Festivals']
abstract: Music lovers bring their unique style to Austin during the SXSW music festival.
lead_paragraph: The South by Southwest festival in Austin, Tex., marks the beginning of the music festival season, and the start of springtime weather and fashion. Outside of Red7, music fans show off their bleached and dyed locks and denim.

headline: After a Baby’s Arrival, Some Visit, and Others Stay Away
abstract: A baby changes everything about you—even things you were afraid you couldn’t change.
lead_paragraph: Since our daughter Evy got the go-ahead to be in the world, the parade of visitors hasn’t stopped. Yes, we had visitors before she was strong enough to be in public, but we kept things small, limiting visits to one or two people, and no children allowed, because of their germiness. It was tough to say that to people, but thanks to Skype and FaceTime, children on both sides of the family got a chance to see Evy for themselves, even if it was via webcam.

headline: Liberals, Conservatives, and Jobs
abstract: Growth under Democrats? Inconceivable!
lead_paragraph: Just about everything I write evokes vituperative reactions from the usual suspects, but never so much as when I point out awkward facts. So there was a lot of mud-slinging when I pointed out last summer that California’s economy — which conservatives said was doomed by tax increases and generally liberal policies — was in fact experiencing an impressive recovery.

headline: A Simple Recipe for Pasta With Mussels
abstract: A vibrant linguine dish with a tomato sauce that gets added depth and intensity from the mussel broth.
lead_paragraph: Pasta with mussels is one of those complex-tasting dishes that is simple to make. Steam mussels in white wine with chopped shallot and crushed garlic for a few minutes, just until they open. Set mussels aside, then strain and reserve some of the briny broth, which will enrich a light marinara sauce.

headline: Radio and TV Martí, U.S. Broadcasters to Cuba, Emerge From Cold War Past Facing Uneasy Future
abstract: The Martís are illegal on the island, and President Raúl Castro has made their shutdown a condition of normalizing relations with the United States.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The rat-a-tat Cuban-inflected Spanish of the two Radio Martí hosts ricocheted back and forth during “Revoltillo,” a show laced with humor that airs classified ads posted in Cuba on a Craigslist-style website called Revolico.

headline: 2015 James Beard Award Nominees
abstract: A list of this year’s nominees in the restaurant and chef categories, which includes nods for Bâtard, Cosme, Blue Hill at Stone Barns and Per Se.
lead_paragraph: Nominees for the annual James Beard Awards, which honor chefs, restaurants, writers and other professionals in the world of American food, were announced Tuesday morning. The list of restaurant and chef nominees is below; the winners will be announced in Chicago on May 4. A full list of nominees in print, broadcast and other categories can be found on the James Beard Foundation website.

headline: Live Chat With Amy Klein: Tuesday, March 24, 9 P.M. Eastern Time
abstract: Amy Klein will answer questions about her journey from infertility treatment to pregnancy.
lead_paragraph: Amy Klein will be answering questions about her journey from infertility treatment to pregnancy here tonight (Tuesday, March 24, 2015) at 9 Eastern Time, and I’ll be moderating quickly so that conversation can flow fast and furious.

headline: ‘Hausfrau,’ by Jill Alexander Essbaum
abstract: The troubled heroine of this debut novel strays from her stable Zurich fold.
lead_paragraph: Anna Benz, the heroine of Jill Alexander Essbaum’s frequently engrossing first novel, is a very bad girl indeed: ­indiscriminate in her philandering, highly specialized in secrets and lies and deeply invested in her own misery. Worst of all, she can’t even come clean to her shrink. “When will you trust me enough to tell me everything?” wonders her exasperated psychiatrist, Frau Doktor Messerli.

headline: Little Park
abstract: Andrew Carmellini’s latest restaurant in TriBeCa
lead_paragraph: Andrew Carmellini’s latest restaurant in TriBeCa

headline: Restaurant Review: Little Park in TriBeCa
abstract: Andrew Carmellini and Min Kong create a fresh, natural and intuitive menu at Little Park.
lead_paragraph: It is as colorful and otherworldly as a coral reef, this row of fried cauliflower knobs in purple, ivory and marigold yellow. Wrapping each floret is a pale-gold skin of batter. It’s almost invisible, but you feel it as you bite, its soft snap reinforced by the full-on crunch of chopped almonds. Poached before it is fried, the cauliflower is nicely salted all the way down to its tender core, but it is still cauliflower, so it needs a little support. This is supplied by a lush green tomatillo, pistachio and fresh herb sauce that gets in a quick, peppery jab before it signs off.

headline: Joseph Kanon’s ‘Leaving Berlin’
abstract: In Joseph Kanon’s thriller, a German-born American writer becomes a spy in Cold War East Berlin.
lead_paragraph: Heroes in espionage fiction tend to fall into two categories: the world-weary professional and the rank amateur. Milo Weaver, the killer-spook of Olen Steinhauer’s “The Tourist,” and John le Carré’s MI6 agent George Smiley are cynical veterans of the spying game, old hands at duplicity and betrayal. At the other end of the spectrum is the mild-mannered engineer of John Buchan’s “The Thirty-Nine Steps,” Richard Hannay, who stumbles across a German spy ring and finds himself framed for murder.

headline: Israel Denies Spying on Iran Nuclear Talks
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Three top Israeli ministers rebutted a published report that Israel spied on closed-door talks between Iran and six world powers, including the United States.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Three top Israeli ministers on Tuesday denied a report that their intelligence services had spied on the closed-door negotiations over Iran’s nuclear program, as tensions continued to mount between Washington and Jerusalem.

headline: Jemima Kirke’s Workout Thwarts The Usual Fitness Trends
abstract: The “Girls” actor let T into a personal training session at Brooklyn Strength, where she engages in a mix of Pilates and kettlebell work to get strong — not skinny.
lead_paragraph: The “Girls” actor let T into a personal training session at Brooklyn Strength, where she engages in a mix of Pilates and kettlebell work to get strong — not skinny.

headline: ‘Night at the Fiestas,’ by Kirstin Valdez Quade
abstract: Wayward souls in New Mexico seek out personal deliverance in this debut story collection.
lead_paragraph: In 1985, a Yale professor named Jaroslav Pelikan published “Jesus Through the Centuries,” a book he described as “not a life of Jesus . . . but a series of images portraying his place in the history of culture.” These notions of Christ have been irreconcilably varied over 2,000 years, sometimes bolstering the powerful and sometimes consoling the powerless: the rabbi, the light of the gentiles, the king of kings, the cosmic Christ, the son of man, the monk who rules the world, the bridegroom of the soul, the universal man, the prince of peace, the teacher of common sense, the liberator, the man who belongs to the world.

headline: Review: James Corden Is Amiable, if Not Particularly Special, in ‘Late Late Show’ Debut on CBS
abstract: Mr. Corden will surely improve, but there is still no good explanation for why networks will not take a chance on a female or non-Caucasian star.
lead_paragraph: “Can’t act. Slightly bald. Also dances.”

headline: Senator Coats, Republican of Indiana, Won’t Seek Re-election
abstract: Indiana will soon have an open senate seat to fill now that Senator Dan Coats has announced that he will not seek re-election in 2016.
lead_paragraph: Senator Dan Coats of Indiana announced Tuesday that he would not seek re-election in 2016, ending a political career that has spanned more than three decades and setting up a potentially competitive race in what had been thought to be a safe Republican seat.

headline: Fringe Gone Wild
abstract: Not the wispy embellishment of days past, but a full-on takeover of a garment by its trim. At last, the ornamental becomes essential.
lead_paragraph: Not the wispy embellishment of days past, but a full-on takeover of a garment by its trim. At last, the ornamental becomes essential.

headline: ‘The X-Files’ to Return for Six-Episode Limited Series
abstract: The stars David Duchovny and Gillian Anderson will reprise their roles as Fox Mulder and Dana Scully.
lead_paragraph: Thirteen years after it went off the air, “The X-Files” is coming back to Fox.

lead_paragraph: After Republican and Democratic leaders could not agree on a proposal that linked immigration reform with an education tax credit in Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s proposed budget, the governor said on Tuesday that both would be dropped as negotiations continued.

abstract: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas has been a widely seen television guest in the last 24 hours.
lead_paragraph: As the newly minted — and only — declared candidate for president in 2016, Senator Ted Cruz, Republican of Texas, has been a popular television guest in the last 24 hours.

headline: White House Names Biden Adviser as Message Strategist
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Shailagh Murray will replace Dan Pfeiffer as one of the president’s senior advisers, helping coordinate the president’s agenda.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Shailagh Murray, a former political reporter who has spent the last four years as a senior adviser to the vice president, will move to the West Wing as the top message strategist for President Obama, the White House announced on Tuesday.

headline: Rangers’ Henrik Lundqvist Expects to Play This Weekend

lead_paragraph: The Rangers have been on a roll with goalie Cam Talbot in net, winning 17 of 24 games since he became their starter in early February.

headline: 1940: Inventor of Radio Wave Dies
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Dr. Edouard Branly, pioneer of radio waves, dies in 1940.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Edouard Branly, one of France’s greatest scientists and forerunner of Guglielmo Marconi in the development of wireless telegraphy, died at his home in Paris yesterday [March 24]. He was ninety-six years old. At the outbreak of the war he left Paris for Haute-Vienne and had returned to the city only recently. Although he was relatively unknown to the general public, scientific colleagues recognize that his experiments in the field of wave transmission by a park coil made possible the perfection of wireless by Marconi a few years later. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 25, 1940

headline: Perfectly Reasonable Question: Closed Captions on Times Videos
abstract: Readers like the emphasis on video but note that some need an extra element
lead_paragraph: A reader, Sebastian Barrett St.Troy, likes The Times’s video offerings, but wonders about one feature that, so far, is missing.

headline: Ted Cruz on How 9/11 Changed His Taste in Music
abstract: Senator Ted Cruz explained on CBS how the 9/11 terrorist attacks turned him into a country music fan.
lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Cruz, Republican of Texas and a declared candidate for president, explained on CBS how the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, turned him from a lifelong classic rock fan into a country music fan.

headline: The Mother-Daughter Thing
keywords: ['Art', 'Families and Family Life', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Writing and Writers']

lead_paragraph: You could never tell from the intriguingly opaque work of the poet Susan Howe and the artist R. H. Quaytman that the two women are related. Then you sit down with them.

headline: Ex-Gov. Rick Perry of Texas Won’t Discuss Cruz Candidacy
abstract: Former Gov. Rick Perry of Texas sought to show off his domestic and foreign policy chops Tuesday at a breakfast with reporters in Houston.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON – Rick Perry, the former governor of Texas who is considering a second run for the White House after his politically disastrous 2012 campaign, sought to show off his domestic and foreign policy chops at a breakfast with reporters here on Tuesday. But he was silent when asked about Senator Ted Cruz, the conservative firebrand who announced his campaign for president on Monday.

headline: Aging Ex-Mafia Boss Fails in Bid for Leniency on Jail Time
abstract: Thomas DiFiore, 71, a former Bonanno family street boss who has been in jail for 14 months on a debt collection charge, highlighted his faltering health while seeking a shorter sentence.
lead_paragraph: High blood sugar, stress, swelling of kidneys, swelling of skin, lung problems, vision issues: These were some of the medical problems enumerated by lawyers for Thomas DiFiore, a 71-year-old Mafia member, at his sentencing on Tuesday in Brooklyn.

abstract: A Yale research lab applies rigorous scientific methods to test the effectiveness of educational video games on children.
lead_paragraph: A three-year-old learning games company wants to raise the bar on how education technology start-ups measure and market the effectiveness of their products.

headline: Google Should Feel Lucky in Its Finance Chief Hire
abstract: The challenge for both Wall Street and Silicon Valley is to create more women like Ruth Porat, with financial, tech and government know-how.
lead_paragraph: Google should feel lucky about its search for a new chief financial officer.

headline: Grading Teachers by the Test
abstract: Use of standardized tests to measure students’ progress, and teachers’ effectiveness, has been found to have unintended consequences.
lead_paragraph: In 2004, the Chinese government decided there were too many accidental deaths. China’s safety record, it decreed, should be brought in line with those of other middle-income countries. The State Council set a target: a decline in accidental deaths of 2.5 percent per year.

headline: What Happened on the Germanwings Flight
abstract: Maps and timeline of what is known about the crash.
lead_paragraph: Maps and timeline of what is known about the crash.

headline: Arctic Ice Reaches a Low Winter Maximum
abstract: The winter ice covering the Arctic has reached its annual peak, but the extent this winter is smaller than it has been at the end of any since 1978.
lead_paragraph: The winter ice covering the Arctic has reached its annual peak, but the extent this winter is smaller than it has been at the end of any since 1978.

headline: A Few Words From Bill Belichick After a Super Bowl Win. Very Few.
abstract: At their annual round table, the N.F.L.’s coaches stayed true to form. Belichick gave short answers. Rex Ryan offered bluster. The Jets’ new coach, Todd Bowles, was eager to get going.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — The coaches’ round table is an annual ritual at the N.F.L. owners’ meeting. Reporters have an hour to meet new coaches, become reacquainted with veteran ones and try their best to draw something out of New England Patriots Coach Bill Belichick.

headline: Braised Brisket
abstract: Melissa Clark braises brisket and pairs it with a bright horseradish gremolata.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark braises brisket and pairs it with a bright horseradish gremolata.

headline: ‘Rhapsody in Blue’ to Open 92nd Street Y Season
abstract: Gershwin’s work will be performed in its orginal jazz-band arrangement when the Y’s musical season opens Oct. 20.
lead_paragraph: The 92nd Street Y will open its 2015-16 season in October with Gershwin’s “Rhapsody in Blue” in its original jazz band arrangement, pairing the pianist Kirill Gerstein with Vince Giordano & the Nighthawks, it announced Tuesday. Other pairings planned for the season will juxtapose Beethoven’s violin sonatas with contemporary works, and visual art with music.

headline: Video of Secret Service Barricade Mishap
abstract: A March 4 surveillance video released by the House Oversight Committee shows a car driven by Secret Service agents lightly knocking a barricade around a potential bomb in front of the White House.
lead_paragraph: A March 4 surveillance video released by the House Oversight Committee shows a car driven by Secret Service agents lightly knocking a barricade around a potential bomb in front of the White House.

headline: Gremolata Gives Passover Brisket a Brighter Side
abstract: Gremolata adds zest to a brisket or osso buco, relieving the meat of its heady intensity. (Article plus video.)
lead_paragraph: Osso buco is one of Italy’s most celebrated dishes. But the soft, wine-braised veal shanks wouldn’t be nearly as sublime without those vivid flecks of piquant, herbal gremolata on top. The gremolata, a jumble of parsley, garlic and lemon zest, adds its own bright notes, and functions as a contrast to the dark sauce, relieving its heady intensity.

headline: No Bad Questions
abstract: Kids pose questions during a new sex-ed class that uses openness and humor to make “The Talk” less dreadful.
lead_paragraph: Kids pose questions during a new sex-ed class that uses openness and humor to make “The Talk” less dreadful.

headline: In Reversal, Boston 2024 Wants Vote on Olympic Bid
abstract: The group trying to bring the Games to Boston said that it now supported a statewide referendum on the proposal and that it would drop the bid if the measure failed.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Stung by recent polling that showed only a third of Boston residents want the city to host the 2024 Summer Olympics, the group organizing the bid has reversed itself and now supports a voter referendum on the proposal, an inauspicious development for an already shaky bid.

headline: Justices Rule Opinions May Sometimes Be Basis for Securities Fraud Suits
keywords: ['Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans']
abstract: Statements of opinion in securities filings are untrue only if they are not sincerely held, Justice Elena Kagan wrote for the majority.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday ruled that statements couched as opinions may sometimes be the basis for securities fraud suits.

headline: The Thorny Task of Advocating Good Corporate Behavior
keywords: ['Corporations', 'Boards of Directors', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans']
abstract: Calpers, the $300 billion pension fund, has embraced the corporate sustainability movement, but pushing for change can be complicated.
lead_paragraph: In the war to control corporations, the California Public Employees’ Retirement System, the $300 billion pension fund, has decided that it is willing to actively press companies to emphasize the environment, diversity and good corporate governance, perhaps even at the expense of profitability. It may save the planet by changing the way companies are run, but will it lead to the returns Calpers desperately needs?

headline: Review: On Crackle, ‘Dead Rising: Watchtower’ Offers Second Helpings to Video Game Fans
abstract: Rob Riggle and Jesse Metcalfe star in Tim Carter’s movie version of this popular video game series.
lead_paragraph: The zombie movie “Dead Rising: Watchtower” might hold rewards for people who have spent hours immersed in the video game series on which it’s based. Judged as a free-standing film, though, it’s a time waster devoid of the wit and depth of other walking-dead fare currently available — see, for instance, the new CW series “iZombie.”

headline: Angelina Jolie: More ‘Common’ Than Any Celebrity Would Like to Be
abstract: Angelina Jolie has stripped the “Celebrities! They’re Just Like Us!” trope down to its essence.
lead_paragraph: I know I’m not the only person thinking about Angelina Jolie today.

lead_paragraph: “Lonesome Traveler” is full of familiar songs prettily sung, a sort of jukebox folk musical. Too bad it didn’t aspire to be more; still, it sounds great.

headline: Second Day as a Candidate, Cruz Jabs at Bush Over Immigration
abstract: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas has largely held his fire against other Republicans, but a day into his presidential candidacy, he took a poke at Jeb Bush over immigration, saying politicians fail when they “treat the voters as children.”
lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas hasn’t wasted much time in seeking to distinguish himself from his potential rivals for the Republican presidential nomination, taking issue with Jeb Bush on Tuesday for his position on immigration and implicitly criticizing the former Florida governor for treating “voters as children.”

headline: Kimmy Schmidt’s Revolutionary Approach to Pain
abstract: “Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt” shows us not just a strong female character but someone who’s had to work hard to maintain her sanity under terrible circumstances.
lead_paragraph: “You can stand anything for 10 seconds,” says Kimmy Schmidt. “Then you just start on a new 10 seconds.”

headline: Wynn Resorts Board Raises Objections to a Co-Founder’s Re-election

lead_paragraph: The battle between the co-founders of the Wynn Resorts casino company escalated on Tuesday, when the company urged stockholders in a lengthy letter to reject a bid by Elaine P. Wynn to remain on the board on grounds she was “self-serving” and “ineffective,” and had ceased to act in the company’s best interest.

headline: Inquiry Finds Homeland Security Official Intervened in Visa Cases
abstract: The inspector general of the Department of Homeland Security has found that Alejandro Mayorkas, the deputy secretary, intervened directly to gain fast-track consideration of visas for well-connected foreign investors when he was the head of the visa agency.
lead_paragraph: After an investigation lasting more than two years, the inspector general of the Department of Homeland Security has found that Alejandro Mayorkas, the deputy secretary, intervened directly to gain fast-track consideration of visas for foreign investors connected to Democrats when he was the head of the visa agency.

headline: March 24, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Spain, Afghanistan, Singapore and Somalia.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Spain, Afghanistan, Singapore and Somalia.

headline: In the Kitchen With Jackson Pollock
abstract: A curious photographer explored the late painter’s former pantry, and gathered what she found into a new cookbook that reveals his penchant for baking.
lead_paragraph: Everyone knows we eat with our eyes, and that the world’s best chefs, despite their origins or cuisine, turn out dishes as visually arresting as any work of art. But what happens when an artist, say Jackson Pollock, wears the apron? Thanks to his iconic drip masterpieces, the late painter has become a household name. And today, with the release of a new book stemmed from the contents of his former kitchen, Pollock begins his second legacy: as a foodie with a penchant for baking.

headline: Obama to Slow Withdrawal in Afghanistan
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)']

headline: Review: Richard Alston’s ‘Carmen’ in Fort Lauderdale
abstract: The Miami City Ballet recently presented Richard Alston’s one-act “Carmen,” along with Twyla Tharp’s “Sweet Fields” and Balanchine’s “Allegro Brillante,” at the Broward Center.
lead_paragraph: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. — Richard Alston’s one-act “Carmen,” recently performed by Miami City Ballet at the Broward Center here, is the best “Carmen” ballet I’ve seen. That is less a compliment than it sounds: Most “Carmen” ballets are clunkily melodramatic and choreographically dismal.

headline: A Clean Getaway at St. Lucia Resort

lead_paragraph: Sugar Beach, a Viceroy property on the Caribbean island of St. Lucia, will ease at least one re-entry chore for some departing guests: the laundry.

headline: Jeb Bush Returns to the Washington Fund-Raising Well

headline: March Madness, the Politics Edition

lead_paragraph: To the delight of those who see politics as sport, Senator Ted Cruz and his aides have taken to describing the Republican primary constituencies in terms of March Madness brackets, with Final Four spots for the Establishment, Libertarians, Evangelicals and the Tea Party.

headline: Manhattan Area Codes Multiply, but the Original, 212, Is Still Coveted
abstract: New York City’s original area code remains in high demand, even as the proliferation of cellphones means Manhattan may get a fourth one by late 2017.
lead_paragraph: For Kelli Parker and her husband, Andy Lippitt, finding a place to live in Manhattan was secondary to obtaining what they thought would instantly identify them as New Yorkers: his-and-hers cellphone numbers with 212 area codes.

headline: YouTube’s ‘Sunshine Girl’ Comes to Print
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Web-Original Programming', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Haunted Houses', 'Teenagers and Adolescence']
abstract: Paige McKenzie, known for her mockumentary web series “The Haunting of Sunshine Girl,” is trying to extend her brand with a series of young adult novels.
lead_paragraph: Nearly five years ago, a chirpy, animated 16-year-old named Paige McKenzie uploaded a 68-second video to YouTube. “Hey everybody, so, I know this is a little strange,” she says, then confides that her house is haunted and she aims to capture the ghost on camera.

headline: Netflix, Amazon and Hulu No Longer Find Themselves Upstarts in Online Streaming
abstract: After years of battling traditional players in the television business, the big three streaming services must defend against a variety of new offerings.
lead_paragraph: Netflix, Amazon and Hulu have suddenly found themselves playing a new role: the establishment.

headline: Review: ‘The Kidnapping of Michel Houellebecq’ Blurs Fiction and Reality
abstract: Inspired by a real disappearance in 2011, this film is an often comically absurd story about a novelist who finds something like happiness after being abducted.
lead_paragraph: The crumpled, ashen-faced man on screen stands on a corner in Paris alone and seemingly ignored. The world is not paying attention to Michel Houellebecq, save for the off-screen movie crew and us, of course. This probably doesn’t happen often to Mr. Houellebecq (pronounced WELL-beck), the French novelist whose putatively scandalous work touches on subjects — despair, sex tourism, cloning, Islamic political power, despair again — that seem calculated to provoke, especially, the humorless. A typically vulgar caricature of him was on the cover of the magazine Charlie Hebdo on Jan. 7, the day that two jihadists entered its Paris offices and set about slaughtering 12 people.

headline: From Cho Junglae, a Film on Japanese Wartime Brothels
abstract: For the Korean filmmaker Cho Junglae, a film project about women who were forced to work in Japanese wartime military brothels has been anything but easy.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The painting showed Japanese soldiers taking young women who had been forced to work in Japan’s military brothels to a burning pit. When he saw it, the Korean filmmaker Cho Junglae said, he was shocked — and inspired to make a feature film about the so-called comfort women of World War II, many of whom never made it home.

He — and with the possible exception of Lauryn Hill, it has always been a “he” — is real in the sense that every five years or so, whenever hip-hop feels too boring, or, worse, too corporate, an artist will be appointed as the spiritual future of the form.

It was cobbled together by none other than House Speaker John A. Boehner and Representative Nancy Pelosi, the leader of House Democrats, who rarely agree on anything, with the apparent blessing of a majority of their respective members.

lead_paragraph: Cancer experts said Tuesday that the actress and filmmaker Angelina Jolie Pitt was wise to have had her ovaries and fallopian tubes removed last week because she carries a genetic mutation, BRCA1, that significantly increases the risk of ovarian cancer, a disease so difficult to detect that it is often found only at an advanced, untreatable stage.

headline: Same-Sex Benefits Survive a Vote
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The United States joined the effort to defeat a Russian proposal that would have invalidated the benefits expansion to United Nations employees who are spouses in same-sex marriages.
lead_paragraph: An attempt by Russia to annul an expansion of benefits to United Nations employees who are spouses in same-sex marriages failed Tuesday in an 80-to-43 vote of the General Assembly committee responsible for the budget. The United States joined the effort to defeat a Russian proposal that would have invalidated the benefits expansion, which Secretary General Ban Ki-moon approved last July. Under the expansion, gay and lesbian employees are entitled to the same marriage benefits as heterosexual employees if they were wed in a jurisdiction that considers their union legal. Previously, gay and lesbian employees were granted benefits only if their home countries deemed such marriages legal.

headline: Greece: Ex-Official Avoids Prison
abstract: A former finance minister, George Papaconstantinou, was found guilty on Tuesday of tampering with a list of about 2,000 Greeks with Swiss bank accounts, but he was spared prison time.
lead_paragraph: A former finance minister, George Papaconstantinou, was found guilty on Tuesday of tampering with a list of about 2,000 Greeks with Swiss bank accounts, but he was spared prison time. A court found that Mr. Papaconstantinou, 53, had removed the names of three relatives from the list. The list was given to him in 2010 by Christine Lagarde, then the French finance minister, in an effort to help curb tax evasion. The court reduced the first charge against him, doctoring a document, to a misdemeanor from a felony, and imposed a one-year suspended prison term. He was cleared of a second charge of attempted breach of faith. The failure of the authorities to investigate the so-called Lagarde list, a potential source of much-needed tax revenue, fueled widespread anger in Greece during years of austerity.

headline: Canada: Role Against ISIS to Grow
abstract: Prime Minister Stephen Harper asked Parliament on Tuesday to extend and expand the country’s military mission against Islamic State militants by another year.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Stephen Harper asked Parliament on Tuesday to extend and expand the country’s military mission against Islamic State militants by another year. Canada’s involvement in the operation, which began last October, was scheduled to last just six months and has consisted of airstrikes against the Islamic State group, also known as ISIS or ISIL, in Iraq and the use of troops for training and support in Iraq. Mr. Harper said that he wanted to extend the air force’s role to include strikes on targets in Syria. Opposition lawmakers say that Mr. Harper did not fully reveal the extent of the ground troops’ role last year. The criticism increased this month after Kurdish forces mistakenly killed a Canadian military adviser in Iraq. Opposition leaders said that they did not support the extension, but Mr. Harper’s Conservatives hold a majority in the House of Commons.

headline: Egypt: Forensics Official Dismissed
abstract: Egypt’s Medical Forensics Authority on Tuesday dismissed its spokesman after he said last week that a poet and activist killed by police birdshot had died from her wounds only because she was too thin.
lead_paragraph: Egypt’s Medical Forensics Authority on Tuesday dismissed its spokesman after he said last week that a poet and activist killed by police birdshot had died from her wounds only because she was too thin. State news media reported Tuesday that the Justice Ministry was opening an investigation to determine whether or not it was true that more body fat might have obstructed the pellets that pierced her heart and lungs, the injuries that coroners said had caused her death. The poet and activist, Shaimaa el-Sabbagh, 31, was taking part in a march to lay flowers in Tahrir Square on Jan. 24 when the police fired birdshot and tear gas from a few yards away. Prosecutors charged a police officer with a form of manslaughter in the shooting but have not named the officer. The spokesman for the medical examiner, Hisham Abdel Hamid, said in a television interview on Saturday that other marchers that day survived similar blasts of birdshot but that Ms. Sabbagh died because she was “too skinny.”

headline: Pulitzer-Winning Author Says He ‘Has a Debt to Pay’

headline: Richard Russo, Pulitzer Winner, Tells Gloversville Library Thanks for the Memories
keywords: ['Libraries and Librarians', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: The town in upstate New York has tried three times to raise funds to modernize its library. Now it has turned to its most famous son, the author Richard Russo, for help.
lead_paragraph: GLOVERSVILLE, N.Y. — In 1904, Andrew Carnegie donated $50,000, then a princely sum, to this upstate community so it could build a new library. Now, 111 years later, that stately, domed Beaux-Arts structure has fallen on hard times, much like the black-and-blue, blue-collar town that surrounds it.

headline: Pakistani Christians Fight Back
keywords: ['Christians and Christianity', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Churches (Buildings)', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Minorities', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Underlying the religious violence are issues of caste and class.
lead_paragraph: LAHORE, Pakistan — LAST Monday, this city was briefly overrun with bands of sloganeering, stick-wielding youths. The demonstrators threw stones at police officers, burned car tires and smashed windows. One gang even plundered a 7Up truck, guzzling its goods before transfixed TV cameras. (I watched the footage — slow-mo jets of sparkly liquid, with strains of horror-movie music playing in the background — that night on the Internet.) There was a euphoric edge to the riots, apparent even when they took a grotesquely violent turn with the lynching of two men.

headline: An Artistic Reinterpretation of China’s ‘Century of Humiliation’
abstract: An exhibition in Hong Kong seeks to break down what the show’s co-curator calls a “monolithic vision” of the Chinese nation, while also suggesting strategies for creating alternative narratives.
lead_paragraph: When history intersects with nationalism, there is often little patience or appetite for nuance. Instead, broad brushstrokes are preferred. Take, for example, the period from the end of the First Opium War in 1842 to the victory of the Chinese Communist Party in 1949. This period — a time of wars, invasions, occupations and revolutions in China — is often summed up by Chinese political leaders as their country’s “century of humiliation.” Although more than six decades have passed, this narrative of “humiliation” at the hands of foreign powers continues to set the tone for China’s interaction with much of the outside world.

headline: Mary Russell’s Moment in Time
abstract: In an era when private moments were in fact private and snapshots truly intimate, Mary Russell partied with and documented Europe’s beau monde. For T, she opens her rarely seen archives from the 1960s and ’70s and speaks about those days.
lead_paragraph: In an era when private moments were in fact private and snapshots truly intimate, the fashion reporter and photographer partied with and documented Europe’s beau monde. For T, she opens her rarely seen archives from the 1960s and ’70s and speaks about those days.

headline: The Anti-Bully Backpack
abstract: MadPax’s eccentric, cartoonish bags are alternately spiked, bubble-covered or block-shaped.
lead_paragraph: It used to be that the only way to make a backpack look remotely cool was to wear it off of one shoulder, projecting the vibe of someone only halfway committed to going to school. But this is no longer the case, thanks to MadPax’s eccentric, cartoonish bags, which are alternately spiked, bubble-covered or block-shaped, and occasionally appear to be dipped in a rainbow of sprinkles. In 2010, the company’s co-founder Tina Huber tested a prototype by putting it on her son, a second grader, and sending him to school. “At the end of the day he got back in the car, and I was like, ‘Tell me everything,’ ” Huber says. “And he goes, ‘I seriously felt like Jesus. Everybody wanted to touch me.’ ” Before long, Willow Smith started wearing one, as did the children of Ben Affleck, Hugh Jackman and Heidi Klum. While the backpacks come in many different styles, all of them look instantly iconic, combining elements of sci-fi, exotic wildlife and Memphis design — and all of them can be worn comfortably, and with confidence, on both shoulders.

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 5 P.M. (Flix) TENDER MERCIES (1983) Robert Duvall, in an Oscar-winning role, plays a down-on-his-luck rambler trying to rebuild his life while staying at a ramshackle Texas motel whose proprietor, Rosa Lee (Tess Harper), he just can’t quit. Only after tying the knot with her guest does Rosa Lee learn that he used to be Mac Sledge, a country singer who drank his career to death. This drama — directed by Bruce Beresford and written by Horton Foote, who won an Oscar for best screenplay — follows Mac’s relationships with his ex-wife (Betty Buckley), his daughter (Ellen Barkin), his new bride and her son, “weaving them into a sadly contemporary vision of family life and heading toward a final note of affirmation,” Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. “This is a small, lovely and somewhat overloaded film about small-town life, loneliness, country music, marriage, divorce and parental love, and it deals with all of these things in equal measure. Still, the absence of a single, sharply dramatic story line is a relatively small price to pay for the plainness and clarity with which these other issues are defined.”

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Wednesday, March 25, 2015.
lead_paragraph: “To come home from Afghanistan and be killed by someone who’s supposed to protect you – that I don’t understand.”

headline: Hearing and Feeling What Photographers Are Saying
abstract: Chuck Kelton says most printers can get 90 percent of an image right. But that final 10 percent is where a printer’s darkroom skills will draw out the photo’s magnificence.
lead_paragraph: In his 35-year career as a master black-and-white printer, Chuck Kelton has held some of the most important negatives in history: from Ansel Adams’s “Moonrise, Hernandez, New Mexico” to Alfred Eisenstaedt’s “V-J Day in Times Square.” So it makes sense that when he is in his darkroom with his chemicals and classical music, nobody can – or should – disturb him.

headline: Library of Congress Opens Its Doors to the Doors
abstract: The Doors’ first album is among the selections for the National Recording Registry at the Library of Congress.
lead_paragraph: The first album by the Doors — “The Doors,” released in 1967 — and the 1964 Righteous Brothers ballad “You’ve Lost That Lovin’ Feelin’” have been added to the National Recording Registry at the Library of Congress, along with 23 other titles at least 10 years old that have been deemed culturally, historically or aesthetically significant. The registry, established by an act of Congress in 2000 to preserve the nation’s audio legacy, now has 425 recordings dating back to wax cylinders of the late 19th century.

headline: Run, Rubio, Run
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Why Democrats are cheering as the senator turns on his ex-mentor, Jeb Bush.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — FOR nearly 20 years, Florida politicos watched Jeb Bush groom Marco Rubio for power. In the late 1990s, Mr. Bush, then a new governor, handed his young protégé Mr. Rubio, then a West Miami city commissioner, his political and financial network, asking friends like Al Cardenas — until recently the head of the American Conservative Union, which puts on the Conservative Political Action Conference — to give Mr. Rubio the connections and money he needed to ascend.

headline: Look Before Leaping
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']
abstract: What’s at stake in the nuclear deal with Iran?
lead_paragraph: I can think of many good reasons to go ahead with the nuclear deal with Iran, and I can think of just as many reasons not to. So, if you’re confused, let me see if I can confuse you even more.

headline: Stop Making Us Guinea Pigs
abstract: Roundup, widely used in farming, is “probably” carcinogenic.
lead_paragraph: The issues surrounding G.M.O.s — genetically modified organisms — have never been simple. They became more complicated last week when the International Agency for Research on Cancer declared that glyphosate, the active ingredient in the widely used herbicide Roundup, probably causes cancer in humans. Two insecticides, malathion and diazinon, were also classified as “probable” carcinogens by the agency, a respected arm of the World Health Organization.

headline: Bypassing the Questions and Delays at Passport Control
abstract: Getting processed at the airport just got easier, even if it is a little impersonal.
lead_paragraph: Second perhaps only to visits to the dentist, the form of human interaction I dreaded most over the years was passport control upon arrival to the United States.

headline: Republican Budget Games
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Editorials', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: How to pay for the nation’s defense spending could lead to another showdown.
lead_paragraph: Congress generally has little trouble achieving broad agreement on defense spending. One reason is a well-established and, indeed, almost reflexive belief that throwing more money at the Pentagon will solve the security challenges that America faces. That general inclination is still there; what is not there is agreement, especially among the ruling Republicans, on how to do it this time.

headline: Schools Need Albany’s Help, Now
abstract: As the state budget deadline, there are spending issues and education reforms that still need to be resolved.
lead_paragraph: The State Legislature ended decades of feudalism, corruption and chaos in the New York City school system when it gave Mayor Michael Bloomberg direct control in 2002. The law allowed the mayor to bring stability to a system where chancellors once flew in and out the door and to clear away the bureaucratic underbrush that had defeated his predecessors.

lead_paragraph: Here are several paragraphs from a March 23 article, “Bok Kai Festival in Marysville Brings Touch of 19th Century to 21st.”

abstract: How have residents reacted to the slow-moving stream of lava?
lead_paragraph: In “No Need to Run in Hawaii: The Lava Is Coming, but Very Slowly,” Diane Cardwell writes about a town threatened by a slow-motion disaster.

headline: Germanwings Pilot Was Locked Out of Cockpit Before Crash in France
abstract: As officials struggled to explain why a jet with 150 people on board crashed, an investigator said evidence indicated that one pilot left the cockpit and was unable to get back in.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — As officials struggled Wednesday to explain why a jet with 150 people on board crashed amid a relatively clear sky, an investigator said evidence from a cockpit voice recorder indicated one pilot left the cockpit before the plane’s descent and was unable to get back in.

headline: Keeping Fires Burning in Eastern Ukraine
abstract: Avdiivka Coke and Steel in eastern Ukraine has been hit 160 times by rockets and artillery fire, but it is a vital plant and cannot close because of the prohibitive cost of restarting.
lead_paragraph: Avdiivka Coke and Steel in eastern Ukraine has been hit 160 times by rockets and artillery fire, but it is a vital plant and cannot close because of the prohibitive cost of restarting.

headline: A Close-Up of Unfolding Unrest in Yemen
abstract: A reporter took to the streets to cover the changes in the capital, Sana, after Houthi militants took full control of the city.
lead_paragraph: I arrived in Yemen days after a group of Houthi rebels took control of the capital in January. They forced the president and cabinet to resign, and many of them, in mismatched army uniforms, tried to bolster their tenuous authority, rallying their supporters and setting up checkpoints around the capital, Sana.

headline: M.L.S. Takes the Next Step, but Its Fans Are One Ahead
abstract: Many North American fans are familiar with how soccer is played at a higher level and with stars like Cristiano Ronaldo.
lead_paragraph: Three weeks into the M.L.S. season, two New York teams are leading the Eastern Conference.

headline: Campaign Finance Reform Turns to Reward and Punishment
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Political Action Committees', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Reformers are trying new lines of attack, including incentives for candidates, but they may need a scandal to focus voters’ attention.
lead_paragraph: It isn’t easy to reform the campaign finance system. Ask Lawrence Lessig, the Harvard law professor who last year raised $11 million to elect candidates who favored restrictions on unlimited contributions and spending only to find he’d become the issue’s latest Don Quixote. But he’s back with a new plan, and other groups are trying new lines of attack, hoping to change the behavior of candidates and lawmakers through rewards and punishments.

headline: A Ukraine Factory That Can’t Close, and Workers Who Won’t Quit
abstract: Thousands of workers at a plant in Avdiivka that serves as a vital cog in Ukraine’s steel industry stubbornly return to work every day despite repeated rocket and artillery strikes.
lead_paragraph: AVDIIVKA, Ukraine — The armored Mercedes-Benz pulled up to a factory chimney discharging an endless column of milk-white steam and out stepped Musa Magomedov, the broad-shouldered, bespectacled 45-year-old general director of the Avdiivka Coke and Steel plant.

headline: A Brief Resurrection for a Mural Recalling the Garment Industry’s Heyday
abstract: An exuberant mosaic mural by Max Spivak was uncovered during a renovation at a Manhattan building, but large plastic sheets have been erected in front of it, once again hiding it from passers-by.
lead_paragraph: The shadows of West 40th Street had suddenly given way to the sunny glow of the 1950s with the uncovering of an exuberant mosaic mural at the base of the 5 Bryant Park office tower.

headline: What Local ‘Microadventures’ Would You Like to Go On?
abstract: In the Travel section, an adventurer who has trekked, rowed and biked all over the world extolled the virtues of just taking simple trips close to home to help you shift perspective and feel happier. What “microadventures” near where you live can you imagine? Read the article, then post some ideas.
lead_paragraph: In the Travel section last weekend, an adventurer who has trekked, rowed and and biked all over the world extolled the virtues of just taking simple trips close to home. They, too, can help you shift perspective and feel happier, he says.

headline: Ambassador Tries to Bridge Gap With U.S., but on Israel’s Terms
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'Palestinians']
abstract: Ron Dermer, the Israeli ambassador to the U.S., is courting Democrats after discord between the countries’ leaders, but is still working against a nuclear deal with Iran.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Over an elegant dinner at his official residence Monday night, Ron Dermer, the Israeli ambassador to the United States, tried to reassure a group of congressional Democrats that the dramatic public break between President Obama and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu was nothing more than a passing disagreement.

headline: Among Germanwings Crash Victims, Opera Singers and Newlyweds
abstract: The dead, from at least 15 countries, included an American mother and daughter and the wife of a prominent Catalan politician.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — Outside the Liceu opera house in Barcelona on Wednesday, staff members gathered at noon for two minutes of silence to honor two singers who had recently performed there.

headline: ‘Where You Go Is Not Who You’ll Be’ and ‘The End of College’
abstract: How to stay sane about college admissions, and how to make education more accessible.
lead_paragraph: If you have sat through a high school commencement ceremony in the past 25 years, you may have endured an earnest recitation of the last book written by Dr. Seuss, “Oh, the Places You’ll Go!” The book is a popular gift to graduates from grown-ups who have forgotten how late adolescents feel about condescension. Here are two deeply felt, intentionally provocative alternatives for college applicants worried about getting into their first choice and parents worried about paying for it: Frank Bruni’s exhortation to go elsewhere and Kevin Carey’s invitation to go online.

headline: ‘Sherman’s Ghosts,’ by Matthew Carr
abstract: A journalist assesses claims about Sherman’s march, and considers its later effects.
lead_paragraph: This thought-provoking and at times frustrating volume is really three books rather awkwardly spliced together. The first part, roughly half of “Sherman’s Ghosts,” analyzes Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman’s destructive marches through Georgia and the Carolinas in the last months of the American Civil War. The next part discusses the supposed impact of Sherman’s actions on subsequent wars through Vietnam. In the final section, the ghosts of Sherman largely disappear as the journalist Matthew Carr leads us through a maze of conflicts from the ouster of Manuel Noriega in Panama to the continuing blood baths in the Middle East and drone attacks in Afghanistan and Pakistan. The dominant theme here is America’s “appetite for military intervention since World War II,” which “has left a trail of death, destruction and chaos and produced very few positive results.”

headline: How Exercise May Aid Cancer Treatment
abstract: A new study in mice raises the possibility that exercise may change the biology of some malignant tumors, potentially making them easier to treat.
lead_paragraph: In a new study involving mice, aerobic exercise slowed the growth of breast cancer tumors and made the cancer more sensitive to chemotherapy. The results raise the possibility that exercise may change the biology of some malignant tumors, potentially making them easier to treat.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Citigroup has hired a longtime China banker from Bank of America’s Merrill Lynch unit to be head of its investment banking in the country.

headline: New York Today: What Would You Do for a 212?
abstract: Wednesday: Newcomers vie for the city’s oldest area code, a rainy evening, and the anniversary of the Happy Land fire.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this warmer Wednesday.

headline: Daily Report: Trying to Sway the Jury in Kleiner Perkins Discrimination Trial

lead_paragraph: Silicon Valley is usually measured on its products and profits. Now, in a rare turnabout, it is about to be judged on its behavior.

headline: 2 Indian Naval Officers Missing After Plane Crashes in Arabian Sea
abstract: The aircraft crashed during a routine mission off the coast of Goa State, and the flight commander was rescued by fishermen.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — An Indian-made naval plane crashed in the Arabian Sea off the coast of the southern state of Goa on Tuesday night during a routine training mission. Two officers are missing, while the flight commander, a seasoned pilot, was rescued by fishermen.

headline: Saudi Arabia Leads Air Assault in Yemen
abstract: Saudi Arabia launched airstrikes with a coalition of 10 nations. The strikes came as Yemen was hurtling toward civil war after months of turmoil.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Saudi Arabia announced on Wednesday night that it had begun military operations in Yemen, launching airstrikes in coordination with a coalition of 10 nations.

headline: Today in Politics: Afghan President Addresses Congress
abstract: Another foreign leader will address Congress in the House on Wednesday, but this one is more likely to be thanking President Obama and America than criticizing the president.
lead_paragraph: Good Wednesday morning from Washington, where Republicans have been partying with former Vice President Dick Cheney while Congress is nearing a budget breakthrough. March Madness is getting increasingly political as the tournament rolls on, and President Obama is using the anniversary of the Affordable Care Act to take a victory lap, of sorts. Victories have not come easy in Afghanistan, however, but the country’s new president is in town to offer a status report.

headline: Kraft and Heinz to Merge in Deal Backed by Buffett and 3G Capital
abstract: The merger will create the fifth-largest food and beverage company globally, with Heinz controlling 51 percent and Kraft shareholders owning the rest.
lead_paragraph: First it was Budweiser beer. Then came Burger King Whoppers. Next up was Heinz ketchup.

headline: Swiss Private Bank Vontobel Buys Majority Stake in British Asset Manager
abstract: The bank acquired a 60 percent stake in TwentyFour Asset Management, and it is in talks to potentially acquire a German asset manager.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Swiss private bank Vontobel said on Wednesday that it had agreed to buy a majority stake in TwentyFour Asset Management of Britain and that it was in talks over the potential acquisition of a German asset manager owned by Bank of New York Mellon.

headline: Bearing Witness
abstract: As a clown working in children’s hospitals, I spent a lot of time with terminally ill people. But the view is different when it is your loved one in the bed.
lead_paragraph: As excruciating as it can be to bear witness when a loved one is at the end of life, I highly recommend it to everyone given the chance. The things I’ve learned from being in the room with souls whose journeys happen to be winding down are nothing less than sublime gifts given by the person on the bed, separated from me by a thin sheet and a trillion words, most unspoken. At this stage, sometimes there’s a suction tube. And sometimes there truly are no words. There are other ways to listen, though.

headline: How Poor Are the Poor?
abstract: The question is not merely academic. The way we define the problem affects the lives of millions.
lead_paragraph: There is a consensus among poverty experts that over the past 50 years there has been some improvement in the condition of the poor.

headline: Restaurant Report: Dstage in Madrid
abstract: Nervy young chefs like Diego Guerrero are making the Spanish capital an avant-garde culinary destination. Move over, Barcelona.
lead_paragraph: When Spain became an avant-garde culinary destination at the end of the 1980s, it was mostly thanks to chefs in the Basque Country and Barcelona. Today, however, the country’s post-molecular-cooking gastronomic credentials are being won by a constellation of nervy young chefs working in Madrid. “There’s been a 360-degree change here,” said Diego Guerrero, the chef who just won a star in the 2015 Michelin guide for his new restaurant, Dstage. “Today, the city is filled with young people taking chances.”

headline: In Hong Kong, PMQ Serves Up Food and Art
abstract: “Police Married Quarters,” a 1950s complex that once housed families, is now home to dozens of restaurants, studios and boutiques.
lead_paragraph: The image of a police officer is spray-painted on a wall at Sohofama, a Chinese restaurant in Hong Kong that sticks to its blue-collar roots with home-style dishes served on outdoor wooden tables and benches. The picture pays homage to both a founder’s father, a local officer, and the establishment’s location at PMQ, a 1950s “Police Married Quarters” that once housed hundreds of families and is now home to dozens of restaurants, studios and boutiques run by local artisans and designers, including Vivienne Tam.

headline: Let’s Talk (Frankly) About Sex
abstract: A new approach uses openness and humor to make “The Talk” less dreadful for parents and children alike.
lead_paragraph: Reasons Why I Shouldn’t Have to Go Tonight: If I wanted to talk about it, I would. / It’s my body. / It’s a waste of time. / It’s a waste of money. / I know what I need to know. / It sounds pretty stupid to me. / It’s so stereotypical because obviously I know this happens to everyone. / Considering I took the time out of my morning to write you these extremely reasonable and great reasons not to make me go (and it took forever because I can’t type very well), and the fact that I really, really, really, really . . . really, really, really strongly don’t want to go, please don’t send us to this horrible torture.

headline: Must I Drive My Friend to Have an Abortion?
abstract: The ethicists answer reader questions about squaring religious beliefs with friendship, a questionable doctor’s note and sticking it to a company-buying billionaire.
lead_paragraph: My closest friend just got pregnant and is in no way ready to take on motherhood at 18. She has already committed to her dream school and received a scholarship. She wants to get an abortion out of state and is asking me to drive her. She would do the same for me if the roles were reversed, but my religion prohibits acts like these. I’ve been putting it off for weeks, making up excuses as to why I couldn’t take her. Is it ethical for me to drive hours away, without her parents’ consent, for an abortion, when that is regarded as very shameful in my church? Name Withheld, New Jersey

headline: Anti-Keynesian Delusions
abstract: It’s a sociological problem.
lead_paragraph: I forgot to congratulate Mark Thoma on his tenth blogoversary, so let me do that now. It’s hard to imagine what current economic debate would look like without the incredible job Mark does in assembling and discussing the most important new work, every day; for sure it would be vastly impoverished. Live long and prosper, Mark.

headline: Did My Great-Grandfather Beat Robert E. Lee?
abstract: At the Battle of Fort Stedman, one of the last decisive engagements of the Civil War, my ancestor was a hero, a deserter, or both.
lead_paragraph: Griffin Stedman was 26 years old when he died from wounds suffered during the siege of Petersburg, Va., in August 1864. His monument on the field describes him as a “Typical Volunteer Soldier,” before noting a meteoric rise in the military: the Connecticut native and Trinity College graduate was commissioned as a captain in 1861, and died a brigadier general just three years later.

lead_paragraph: A lot of the recent data coming in show a substantial acceleration in European growth. And you know what will be coming next: claims that this (a) vindicates austerity and (b) shows that there is no reason to worry about Japanification.

headline: Wisconsin Bank Robbery Suspect and Trooper Die in Shootout
abstract: Law enforcement groups also mourned the death of an officer in San Jose, Calif., who was fatally shot after responding to a call about a suicidal man.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — An afternoon of gunfire and fear in eastern Wisconsin ended Tuesday with a devastating toll: Two banks robbed, a bystander shot dead and a rookie state trooper, on his first day patrolling solo, slain in a firefight while confronting and killing the suspect.

headline: Tono Studios Helps Marketers Reach Hispanics With Culturally Authentic Ads
abstract: A commercial audio company is making a name for itself by focusing on cultural nuances to create messages that resonate with Hispanics.
lead_paragraph: From his spot in the control room at Tono Studios, Jaime Zapata has a window into the growing influence, and nuance, of the Hispanic market. In the last month, his Santa Monica, Calif., commercial audio company has brought sound to advertisements for such organizations as Alaska Airlines, Acura, the Humane Society and Universal Studios. All of these spots are in Spanish.

headline: Challenges Weigh Heavily on Recovery Efforts in Germanwings Crash
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: The crash site is inaccessible by road or even foot, making helicopter flights the only way in, and most of the area is covered by steep hillside.
lead_paragraph: SEYNE-LES-ALPES, France — This mountain village was a remote place, a haven for holiday hikers and seasoned rock climbers, until this week, when it became a place of incomprehensible tragedy for the families of the passengers on a routine German flight.

headline: Mott Haven, the Bronx, in Transition
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: The waterfront enclave, a mix of industrial and residential properties, is seeing a gradual reinvention, with home renovation, residential construction and new restaurants.
lead_paragraph: Mott Haven, in the South Bronx, has heard it all before: It’s dangerous, barren and a place to pass through en route to somewhere else. But the neighborhood, a waterfront enclave with a mix of industrial and residential properties, is no longer defined by those old stereotypes. It is undergoing a gradual reinvention, with restaurants opening, scruffy buildings getting spiffed up and apartments being built on gap-toothed lots. Plans are in motion for hundreds of rental units along a stretch of the Harlem River where Jordan L. Mott, for whom the area was named, once made iron stoves and other items.

headline: Lee Radziwill on Discovering the Coats of Martin Grant
abstract: The style icon recalls her first encounter with the designer.
lead_paragraph: The style icon recalls her first encounter with the designer.

headline: Q. and A. With Fed’s Dennis Lockhart: The Year to Raise Rates
keywords: ['Inflation (Economics)', 'Deflation (Economics)', 'Interest Rates', 'Credit and Debt', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta has never voted to raise interest rates. That’s about to change.
lead_paragraph: Dennis Lockhart just entered his ninth year as president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, and during that time he has never voted to raise interest rates. He took the job during the very early days of the financial crisis, and he has never really had the chance. But that is about to change. Mr. Lockhart said in an interview Monday that he expected he would vote to start raising rates by September at the latest.

headline: HarperCollins Releases Cover for New Harper Lee Novel
abstract: The cover of “Go Set a Watchman,” featuring a dark tree and a train, was designed by Jarrod Taylor.
lead_paragraph: HarperCollins released the cover for Harper Lee’s highly anticipated new novel, “Go Set a Watchman,” on Wednesday, and hinted at new details about the book. The cover — a classic and melancholy image of a dark tree with sparse yellow leaves against a dusky blue sky, with a train approaching from the distance — is emblematic of the opening of the book, which begins with a grown-up Scout’s train ride from New York to her childhood home of Maycomb, Ala.

headline: Report Credits F.B.I. With Progress Since 9/11, but Says More Is Needed
abstract: The bureau needs to improve intelligence capabilities and hire more linguists, said the report, which looked at progress since the Sept. 11 attacks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. has made great strides since the Sept. 11 attacks but urgently needs to improve its intelligence capabilities, hire more linguists and elevate the stature of its analysts to counter the rapidly evolving threats to the United States, according to a report released on Wednesday.

headline: Making Miso Soup Without a Recipe
abstract: Kristen Miglore and Erin McDowell of Food52 show you how to make miso soup without a recipe.
lead_paragraph: Kristen Miglore and Erin McDowell of Food52 show you how to make miso soup without a recipe.

keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters']

headline: Car Bomb Kills Several Near Kabul Taxi Stand
abstract: At least seven people were killed and dozens injured in the attack, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A suicide bomber detonated a car full of explosives on a busy road in downtown Kabul on Wednesday afternoon, killing at least seven people and injuring 36, the Afghan Interior Ministry said.

headline: Could Ted Cruz Win?
keywords: ['Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Trying to map out an unlikely path to the Republican nomination.
lead_paragraph: No, I don’t think he will — not the nomination, not the presidency. But since that’s what just about everyone thinks, let’s play around a little and try to imagine how Cruz could at least imitate Barry Goldwater and become the G.O.P. nominee. Here’s The Federalist’s Ben Domenech with three reasons why the conventional wisdom on Cruz might be wrong:

headline: Cuba:  Travel Section Plans for an Emerging Hot Spot
abstract: The Times’s Travel editor describes plans to cover travel in Cuba.
lead_paragraph: Cuba! As the Obama administration eases up on travel restrictions to Cuba, the Travel editor, Monica Drake, is thinking about how the section will cover the new destination. Some insight into her thinking:

headline: Why New TV Comedies Are Choosing Plot Over Jokes
abstract: Television comedies, particularly the non-network kind, are willing to sacrifice laughs in pursuit of more varied and unpredictable pleasures.
lead_paragraph: “Big Time in Hollywood, FL,” a hyperactive new series about deluded brothers with moviemaking dreams, is packed with startling twists — sudden murders, unlikely romance and even a Cuba Gooding Jr. performance that reminds you why he won an Academy Award. But the biggest surprise may be that it’s a comedy in which every episode ends not with a joke but a cliffhanger.

headline: With Sugar on Top
abstract: Learning to make sampita, a meringue cake from Montenegro.
lead_paragraph: “I’m not from Italy or Spain, where you can talk about the food for hours,” Jasmina Bojic said, her cooks darting into the refrigerator beside her. She’s the executive pastry chef at the Four Seasons Hotel in New York, where she makes extravagant cakes fit for oligarchs, but, she said, “my country is small. It’s homey, nothing fancy about it, so I’m nervous to tell you about our food.” She was referring to Montenegro, a rough diamond set on the Adriatic, surrounded by Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Serbia, Kosovo and Albania — more borders than I thought a country the size of Connecticut could have.

headline: 1940: Tracking 2 British Liners
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: British liner approaching the Panama Canal in 1940.
lead_paragraph: PANAMA CITY — The mystery of the whereabouts of Britain’s two super liners, the 81,235-ton Queen Mary and 35,739-ton Mauretania, which slipped out of New York Harbor for an unknown destination five days ago, was partially cleared today [March 25] when it was reported that the Mauretania would reach Cristobal tonight to pass through the Panama Canal. Both ships were last reported off the coast of New Jersey. Although a number of rumors circulated concerning their destination, it was considered most likely that they will be employed to transport troops from Australia and New Zealand to points either in the Near East or France. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 26, 1940

headline: Rekindling a Love for Cooking With Subscription Meal Kits
abstract: Suppertime was starting to feel like a chore. Could a dinner-in-a-box delivery service help me get my groove back?
lead_paragraph: There came a moment, about two weeks after my first child was born, when I worried he might starve. Nursing wasn’t going well, and I was so tired I thought I could feel my eyeballs vibrating. When he squawked and squirmed and bucked his little head against the arm of the rocking chair, I began to panic. I had just one job to do, to feed my baby, and I couldn’t do it. The more I tensed up, the harder it became for him to latch on, and the more both of us cried. We were quite the disastrous pair.

headline: 1965: Astronauts Assess Flight
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Astronauts make a trip to space in 1965.
lead_paragraph: CAPE KENNEDY — Astronauts Virgil I. Grissom and John W. Young reported today [March 25] that the flight of their Gemini-3 spacecraft ‘‘turned out to be even better than we expected.’’ Maj. Grissom is the first man in history to make two separate trips into space. ‘‘We felt great,’’ he said. At the separation of the spacecraft from the rocket, there was ‘‘a sudden drop from six ‘Gs’ (the force of gravity) to one-half g,’’ he said. ‘‘There was a fair amount of debris flying around. I think it sort of gave John a jolt.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 26, 1965

headline: 36 Hours in Palm Beach, Fla.
abstract: This rarefied island, with its extravagant estates, exclusive shops and sumptuous hotels, is best viewed over the handlebars of a bike.
lead_paragraph: Ever since the oil tycoon Henry Flagler turned the alligator-infested jungle known as Lake Worth into a tropical paradise for the 1 percent (it was the Gilded Age, after all) with palatial hotels and a railroad to serve them, Palm Beach has been synonymous with the biggest and the best: fortunes, jewels, scandals. The 16-mile-long island of extravagant mansions, tony retailers and fanciful landscaping is rich in history and significant landmarks, from the magnificent Mar-a-Lago estate (completed in 1927 for Marjorie Merriweather Post, now Donald Trump’s private club) and the Paramount Theater (a former movie palace that houses a trove of vintage screen star photos) to St. Edward’s church (where the Kennedys worshiped) and Green’s Pharmacy (where John F. Kennedy enjoyed burgers in the luncheonette). But Palm Beach is also a small gem offering simple pleasures. You can ride a bike anywhere or linger over coffee at a lunch counter and never be more than a block or two from the beach. Even the new Orange Line trolley that shuttles riders between arts destinations in Palm Beach and neighboring West Palm Beach adds a down-to-earth touch to this high-rolling town (and it’s free!). When the season ends after Easter, parking spots and dinner reservations are readily available once again (not to mention discounted restaurant and hotel prices), making this perhaps the best time of all to visit.

headline: Alessandra Ambrosio’s Brazilian Discovery
abstract: The supermodel and designer was enchanted by Trancoso, a small fishing village on the country’s east coast, when she visited last month.
lead_paragraph: Last February, after hearing from multiple trusted sources about the wonders of Trancoso, a small fishing village located in Bahia, on the east coast of Brazil, Alessandra Ambrosio, the supermodel and designer of ále by Alessandra, took a six-day holiday there with her entire family. Her friends recommended she stay at Uxua, a small hotel owned by the former Diesel creative director Wilbert Das and comprised of 11 casas situated on the edge of the Quadrado, Trancoso’s 500-year-old town square. “I was a little concerned because it’s not on the beach,” she admits. But her mind changed as soon as she saw the colorful, charming property and the energy and scenery around it: “It’s pretty incredible,” she says. Ambrosio and her family stayed at two of Uxua’s casas — one that faced the Quadrado and another with a second-story room where her children, Anja and Noah, slept. “My kids loved it because it felt like a little room in a treehouse,” she says.

The poster says: “No Cover. No Plastic. No Pretense.” And whoever made it might as well have added, “No tourists.”

lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — In a carefully orchestrated spectacle calculated to dramatize a newly aggressive anticorruption campaign, the Ukrainian authorities on Wednesday arrested two senior government officials during a televised cabinet meeting in Kiev. Prime Minister Arseniy P. Yatsenyuk, who was in the room, declared it a warning to public officials about abusing their offices or stealing from taxpayers.

abstract: In this lesson, students learn about how and why scientists are studying the biodiversity of previously unexplored places, such as the insides of homes and the surface of the human body.
lead_paragraph: Overview | In this lesson, students learn about how and why scientists are studying the biodiversity of previously unexplored places, such as the insides of homes and the surface of the human body. They then sample the microbes living in their own belly buttons and consider the implications of this newly discovered microbial diversity.

headline: Globe-Trotting Denis Ten Aims to Break New Ground
abstract: Ten, who is competing at this week’s world championships in Shanghai, is the first Kazakh to win a world or Olympic medal in figure skating and is part of the Almaty bid team for the 2022 Winter Games.
lead_paragraph: If the pieces and the votes all fall into place, Denis Ten just might compete in the 2018 Winter Games in South Korea, his ancestral home, and in the 2022 Winter Games in Almaty, Kazakhstan, his home city.
