headline: Readers Respond: On ‘Angelina Jolie Pitt: Diary of a Surgery’
keywords: ['Breast Cancer', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Mastectomy', 'Ovarian Cancer', 'Ovaries', 'Surgery and Surgeons', 'Tests (Medical)', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Ms. Jolie Pitt’s recent op-ed inspired gratitude, good wishes, and laments about the costs of health care.
lead_paragraph: Readers responded with gratitude, good wishes and laments about the cost of health care Tuesday when Angelina Jolie Pitt revealed her decision to have surgery to remove her ovaries and fallopian tubes.

headline: A Big Man in the N.B.A., but Not on Campus at Columbia
abstract: Troy Murphy, 34, who left Notre Dame early to begin his 12-year N.B.A. career, is completing his undergraduate degree at Columbia’s School of General Studies.
lead_paragraph: It was just before 9 o’clock Tuesday morning, and the entire Columbia University campus seemed to want just a few more hours of sleep. In Milbank Hall, a 119-year-old building on the northern edge of the Barnard College quad, students filtered wordlessly into a third-floor classroom where a course called Introduction to Logic was about to begin.

headline: Kendrick Lamar Is No. 1
abstract: Mr. Lamar’s new album, “To Pimp a Butterfly,” made him the toast of the Internet and has racked up critical accolades.
lead_paragraph: The surprise release last week of Kendrick Lamar’s new album, “To Pimp a Butterfly,” made him the toast of the Internet, racking up critical accolades and generating more streams on Spotify than any album has had in a single day.

headline: Review: Nikolai Lugansky Plays Schubert and Tchaikovsky
abstract: Mr. Lugansky’s recital at the 92nd Street Y included the rare and the overwrought.
lead_paragraph: Maybe I’m making too much of this. Still, the fact that the Russian pianist Nikolai Lugansky was born in Moscow to two research scientists reveals a great deal about his remarkable artistry.

headline: ‘The Country of Ice Cream Star,’ by Sandra Newman
abstract: In the ruins of a future America, a devastating plague leaves few living to adulthood.
lead_paragraph: Go ahead and add Sandra Newman’s supersize third novel, “The Country of Ice Cream Star,” to the growing list of books set in a catastrophic near future. Our current fascination with postindustrial wastelands makes perfect sense, of course, given the daily dire warnings about our planet’s fate. At least our literature appears to be responding to climate change even if our energy policy isn’t.

headline: Review: In ‘Harvey Beaks’ on Nickelodeon, Life Isn’t Disney Perfect
abstract: One message in the animated series that begins on Sunday is that unlike in a Disney movie, life can be sloppy, and its messages and meanings frequently require excavation.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps your children are still obsessed with that danged “Frozen” movie, with its inescapable anthem and its spun-off books, ice-skating show and video games. If so, sit them down in front of “Harvey Beaks,” an animated Nickelodeon series that begins on Sunday night. It’s important for them to know that life isn’t really a gorgeous-looking, tuneful, tidily plotted Disney movie. It’s sloppy and incongruous, and its messages and meanings frequently require excavation.

headline: Letters: The Best Intentions
abstract: Readers respond to recent Bookends essays, a review of Barney Frank’s memoir and more.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: WOODEN: A Coach’s Life, by Seth Davis. (St. Martin’s Griffin, $18.99.) Ten N.C.A.A. championships in 12 seasons, an 88-game winning streak — John Wooden’s U.C.L.A. basketball teams reached incomparable heights in the 1960s and ’70s, but it was his off-the-court behavior that elevated him to the status of American icon. Davis’s exhaustively researched account of Wooden’s 99 years shows how hard he strove for success while revealing the man, and his human failings, behind the legend.

headline: Verbatim: A Little Bipartisan Teasing
abstract: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. teased Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina on his White House ambitions.
lead_paragraph: – Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. to Senator Lindsey Graham, the South Carolina Republican and potential presidential candidate, as he slapped his old Senate colleague on the back in the Capitol.

headline: First Draft Focus: Ghani Gets a Warm Welcome
abstract: President Ashraf Ghani of Afghanistan addressed a joint meeting of Congress in Washington on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: President Ashraf Ghani of Afghanistan addressed a joint meeting of Congress in Washington on Wednesday.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE MONOPOLISTS: Obsession, Fury, and the Scandal Behind the World’s Favorite Board Game, by Mary Pilon. (Bloomsbury, $27.) The real story behind Monopoly, and the woman who went unrecognized for her role in its creation.

headline: SXSW Pays Off for the Prettiots
keywords: ['Music', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: Kay Kasparhauser and her young band spent $10,000 to go to Austin, Tex., for South by Southwest and sometimes played to almost empty rooms. But record-label people heard them, and now things are happening.
lead_paragraph: For baby bands, the annual South by Southwest Music Conference and Festival in Austin, Tex., can be like screaming into the abyss as thousands of struggling musicians spend their own money to play a marathon of unpaid concerts for industry machers.

headline: Vanessa Hudgens as a ‘Gigi’ Tailored for the Instagram Age
abstract: Ms. Hudgens discusses her resolve to succeed on Broadway as producers prepare a new production of “Gigi” for a millennial audience.
lead_paragraph: Vanessa Hudgens, victim of many a leaked-photo scandal, was naked again — but calm yourselves. This time she was safely sequestered in a dressing room at the back of the Alice & Olivia store in SoHo, trying on possible outfits for an opening-night party celebrating a new Broadway version of “Gigi,” in which she stars.

headline: German School Mourns Students in Crash
abstract: Ulrich Wessel, the principal of Joseph-König-Gymnasium in Haltern Am See, Germany, expressed grief after 16 students and two teachers from his school where killed in a plane crash in the French Alps.
lead_paragraph: Ulrich Wessel, the principal of Joseph-König-Gymnasium in Haltern Am See, Germany, expressed grief after 16 students and two teachers from his school where killed in a plane crash in the French Alps.

headline: John Robic Is an Assistant Happy to Sweat the Small Stuff for Kentucky
abstract: Robic is described as essential to Kentucky’s success, by adeptly scouting opponents and handling roles that free John Calipari to be more effective as coach.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — When Kentucky’s basketball team emerges from timeouts, the last coach to speak to players tends to be not John Calipari but John Robic, his assistant. As the huddle breaks up, Robic grabs as many players as he can and shows them a diagram of the court on a whiteboard, walking them through what is about to happen one more time.

headline: Egyptian Woman Reveals 42-Year Secret of Survival: Pretending to Be a Man
abstract: For Sisa Abu Daooh, what began as a way to survive rural poverty evolved into her preferred way of life and a means of navigating a world dominated by men.
lead_paragraph: AL AQALTAH, Egypt — She has worked for more than 30 years among the shoeshine men of Luxor. She sits with men in coffee shops, prays with them in the local mosque and dresses just as they do in pants or a traditional floor-length tunic known as a galabeya.

headline: The Enigma of Haute Couture
abstract: These clothes couldn’t look any more modern — dramatic silhouettes, dark colors, floral appliqués — yet they are created in the most traditional manner. Is custom-made fashion a treasure or a relic?
lead_paragraph: These clothes couldn’t look any more modern — dramatic silhouettes, dark colors, floral appliqués — yet they are created in the most traditional manner. Is custom-made fashion a treasure or a relic?

headline: Rangers’ Lundqvist Will Be Backup Thursday as He Nears Return
abstract: Lundqvist, sidelined since Feb. 2, will be back on the Rangers’ bench Thursday and is expected to start at least one game this weekend.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — In the surest sign that goalie Henrik Lundqvist is close to returning, the Rangers assigned the rookie Mackenzie Skapski to Hartford of the American Hockey League on Wednesday. That will allow Lundqvist to serve as the backup to Cam Talbot on Thursday against the Ottawa Senators.

headline: George Osborne Says British Bank Tax Is Here to Stay
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Instead of eliminating the levy as banks have reduced their risk, the government has increased it to help fill its coffers.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In 2010, Britain’s chancellor of the Exchequer, George Osborne, announced a bank levy, or tax on bank balance sheets, to force the industry to pay for the mess it had made.

headline: Chip Kelly Opens Up About Eagles’ Moves as Coaches Hold Court
abstract: At the N.F.C. coaches’ round table, Kelly spoke about trading running back LeSean McCoy and acquiring the injured quarterback Sam Bradford.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Maybe it was a coincidence, but on Wednesday, Philadelphia Eagles Coach Chip Kelly sat in the same chair that New England Patriots Coach Bill Belichick did Tuesday.

headline: Mark Morris’s Transcendent ‘L’Allegro,’ Captured on Film for PBS
abstract: “Great Performances” presents the choreographer’s 1988 classic “L’Allegro, il Penseroso ed il Moderato,” danced by his company at the Teatro del Real in Madrid.
lead_paragraph: Since its premiere in 1988, Mark Morris’s full-length dance staging of Handel’s oratorio “L’Allegro, il Penseroso ed il Moderato” has provoked two widespread reactions. One: How blessed we are to live in an age in which such miraculous beauty is made! Two: When will this be filmed and made available to a wider public?

headline: Review: Debbie Harry Begins a Run at Café Carlyle
abstract: In a spare set, Ms. Harry was reflective in a program of songs taken mostly from her solo albums.
lead_paragraph: “I don’t know: Have we fulfilled our obligation?” Debbie Harry nervously wondered out from the stage of Café Carlyle on Tuesday evening after performing around a dozen songs. Behind that question was an implied plea: “How soon will this torture end, so can I get out of here?”

headline: New Guidelines to Treat Victims of Chemical Weapon Exposure

abstract: The under secretary of the Army, Brad R. Carson, apologized for the military’s treatment of American service members exposed to chemical weapons in Iraq and released new steps to provide medical support to those with lingering health effects.
lead_paragraph: The under secretary of the Army, Brad R. Carson, apologized for the military’s treatment of American service members exposed to chemical weapons in Iraq and released new steps to provide medical support to those with lingering health effects.

headline: At N.F.L. Owners’ Meeting, Roger Goodell Confronts the Aftermath of Abuse Cases
abstract: Goodell, the league’s commissioner, is still grappling with the fallout from domestic abuse scandals and botched attempts to penalize players last season.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell may be relieved that last season is over, but he is still grappling with the fallout from domestic abuse scandals and the league’s botched attempts to penalize players who dominated the headlines in 2014.

headline: Spring North American Championships Winners
abstract: The American Contract Bridge League’s Spring North American Championships ended on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: The American Contract Bridge League’s Spring North American Championships ended on Sunday. The 60-board final of the premier event, the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams, was won by Lavazza (Norberto Bocchi, Agustin Madala, Giorgio Duboin and Zia Mahmood), which defeated Diamond (John Diamond, Brian Platnick, Eric Greco, Geoff Hampson, Marc Jacobus and Eddie Wold) by 145 international match points to 110.

headline: Mitch McConnell’s Drive to Keep the Coal Fires Burning
abstract: The Senate majority leader calls the Obama administration’s pending emissions regulations a “war on coal.”
lead_paragraph: Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has never been so busy or so aggressive in his role as the defender of Big Coal’s interests as he is now. Earlier this month, the powerful Republican from coal-rich Kentucky made an unusual move in reaching beyond Congress and directly urging state governors not to cooperate with the Obama administration’s pending new regulations to reduce carbon pollution from coal-fired power plants, the nation’s largest source of greenhouse-gas emissions.

headline: Veterans Hurt by Chemical Weapons in Iraq Get Apology
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Purple Heart (Military Decoration)', 'Veterans', 'Apologies']
abstract: The Army under secretary, Brad R. Carson, said that those suffering from exposure to the weapons would be accounted for and offered medical screening.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The under secretary of the Army on Wednesday apologized for the military’s treatment of American service members exposed to chemical weapons in Iraq, and he announced new steps to provide medical support to those with lingering health effects and to recognize veterans who had been denied awards.

headline: Matthew Crawford and How to Survive Brain-Eating Distractions
abstract: This philosopher-mechanic’s newest book, “The World Beyond Your Head,” takes on the idea of the mind extended and fragmented by technology.
lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Va. — On a recent Sunday morning, it was business as usual at Classified Moto, a custom motorcycle shop in a former mule barn here.

headline: In China, Supporters of Detained Feminists Come Under Pressure
abstract: Students who signed petitions calling for the release of the women say they have been warned that their prospects for further education and jobs could be affected.
lead_paragraph: Like a modern-day Leviathan scenting challenges to its rule, the Chinese state appears to have a new target: young women.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Review: ‘Becoming Steve Jobs’ Focuses on Another Apple Era
abstract: “Becoming Steve Jobs,” a new biography by Brent Schlender and Rick Tetzeli, focuses on the period between Mr. Jobs’s first and second stints as Apple’s leader.
lead_paragraph: The main point of the new business-oriented biography “Becoming Steve Jobs,” by Brent Schlender and Rick Tetzeli is that Steve Jobs has been misrepresented. Blame Walter Isaacson’s “Steve Jobs” (2011), as the authors do, for the public perception that Mr. Jobs never outgrew the managerial style of the scheming, screaming, cheating, smelly hothead he may — may — have been in his early years. Instead, Mr. Schlender and Mr. Tetzeli say in their new book, Mr. Jobs developed a wise, mature, deliberate executive style for which he is seldom given credit, one that helped lead Apple to glorious heights.

headline: California Seeks to Head Off Initiative to Execute Gays
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Attorneys General', 'Elections, Attorneys General', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: Attorney General Kamala D. Harris said she would ask the state Superior Court to relieve her of having to clear the way for signatures to be gathered.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The California attorney general, Kamala D. Harris, moved Wednesday to block a proposed voter initiative that would mandate the execution of sexually active gay men and women, calling it “patently unconstitutional” and a threat to public safety.

headline: Earth’s Untallied Biological Bounty, from L.A. Suburbs to Deep Seabed Sediments
abstract: The dizzying extent and diversity of life on this little-known planet is illustrated from Los Angeles suburbs to sediments deep beneath the seabed.
lead_paragraph: The extent and diversity of Earth’s sheath of living things continues to surprise scientists, making Howard Ensign Evans’s classic 1966 book “Life on a Little-Known Planet” ever more germane. Here is fresh evidence from some Los Angeles back yards and the “deadest” depths of deep-sea sediments:

headline: Medical Marijuana Eases Childhood Seizures
abstract: Some parents desperate to ease their children’s epileptic seizures have moved to Colorado to seek relief through medical marijuana.
lead_paragraph: Some parents desperate to ease their children’s epileptic seizures have moved to Colorado to seek relief through medical marijuana.

headline: The Musical ‘The Demo’ at Stanford Recreates the Dawn of the Digital Age
abstract: “The Demo,” a musical and theatrical production heading to the Bing Concert Hall at Stanford, conjures a seminal presentation given by the computer scientist Douglas Engelbart in 1968.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In December 1968, the computer scientist Douglas Engelbart sat on a stage here and introduced the world to modern computing. He brought together for the first time a mouse, word processing, multimedia communication and networking to demonstrate interactive computing before an audience of a thousand leading computer scientists. His presentation would become known as the Demo.

headline: Apple and Beats Developing Streaming Music Service to Rival Spotify
abstract: The new system will not have a lower price than its competitors, and won’t offer a free version supported by ads.
lead_paragraph: In what would be the biggest change to its music strategy in years, Apple is pressing ahead with a sweeping overhaul of its digital music services that would allow the company to compete directly with streaming upstarts like Spotify.

headline: Review: Platform 2015 at St. Mark’s Church
abstract: The choreographer Pam Tanowitz; a composer-musician; and dancers Ms. Tanowitz had never worked with before performed a piece as they created it.
lead_paragraph: When does a rehearsal become a performance? In one of the last events on Danspace Project’s two-month Platform 2015 at St. Mark’s Church, the choreographer Pam Tanowitz created “a dance in a day (a dance adrift in the cosmos).” Spectators could come and go between 1 and 7:30 p.m. to watch Ms. Tanowitz, the composer-musician Dan Siegler and six dancers make a piece.

lead_paragraph: An Army spokesman, Col. Daniel King, said that Sgt. Bowe R. Bergdahl, who disappeared from his outpost in Afghanistan in 2009 and was captured by the Taliban, was being charged with desertion.

headline: Remembering the Happy Land Fire in the Bronx, 25 Years Later
keywords: ['ARSON', 'Fires and Firefighters', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: On March 25, 1990, a fire tore through the Happy Land Social Club in the Bronx, killing 87 people.
lead_paragraph: On March 25, 1990, a fire ripped through the Happy Land Social Club in the Bronx, killing 87 people. The fire began after a man quarreled with his ex-girlfriend, who worked at the club, and then set the club on fire. He was convicted of murder and arson.

keywords: ['Credit Cards', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']

lead_paragraph: The chief executive of American Express said on Wednesday that the company would seek a stay of a ruling that could ban a longstanding Amex practice: prohibiting merchants from encouraging customers to pay with lower-cost cards.

keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The 12-nation accord would let foreign corporations challenge American actions and regulations that hurt their business, a classified document obtained by The Times says.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An ambitious 12-nation trade accord pushed by President Obama would allow foreign corporations to sue the United States government for actions that undermine their investment “expectations” and hurt their business, according to a classified document.

headline: The New Whitney
abstract: Images of the Whitney Museum in its new location in the meatpacking district.
lead_paragraph: Images of the Whitney Museum in its new location in the meatpacking district.

headline: Dean Smith Documentary Pays Homage to Visionary Coach
abstract: A new Showtime film about Smith, who led North Carolina’s basketball program and died last month, presents a uniformly positive view of a major figure in college sports history.
lead_paragraph: “Dean Smith,” the new documentary about the North Carolina basketball coach, is purely a homage. The portrait is not of a difficult or meanspirited man but of one whom any recruit’s parents would want to have in their home: polite, old-fashioned, supportive, averse to cursing (but not occasional sarcasm), hypercompetitive, humble, colorblind and pro-education (really).

headline: A Chance to Soar
abstract: Young equestrians commute to Florida for their sport.
lead_paragraph: Young equestrians commute to Florida for their sport.

headline: Teenage Snowbirds? Just Part of Being a Young Equestrian
abstract: The Winter Equestrian Festival in Wellington, Fla., draws elite young riders from the New York area.
lead_paragraph: Wellington, Fla. — Each Sunday evening of the winter months, a sea of girls in riding breeches, muddy paddock boots and fitted navy blazers crowds the JetBlue gateways in West Palm Beach, Fla., heading home to the New York area for the school week.

headline: A Toast to the Final Episodes of ‘Mad Men’
abstract: Jon Hamm, Elisabeth Moss, Christina Hendricks, Matthew Weiner and others saluted the final season of the TV series that centered on the advertising industry.
lead_paragraph: For the cast of “Mad Men,” the goodbyes took place last July when the critically acclaimed show filmed its final episode.

abstract: A campaign for early childhood development will feature a lullaby, sung by New York City’s first lady Chirlane McCray.
lead_paragraph: A campaign for early childhood development will feature a lullaby, sung by New York City’s first lady Chirlane McCray.

abstract: The November Project, which began in Boston in 2011, has spread to 19 cities in the United States and Canada.
lead_paragraph: Where most people see beloved New York locales, John Honerkamp, Paul Leak and their merry band of some 100 followers see prime exercise sites.

lead_paragraph: The author works from a basement desk at New York City Hall, his following gone but his audience grown, riffing anonymously on paid sick leave and prekindergarten.

keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Social Media', 'New York Fashion Week', 'London Fashion Week', 'Paris Fashion Week', 'Milan Fashion Week', 'Fashion Shows']
abstract: Through the lens of social media, fashion month is just like any other month: ruled by the Kardashian/Jenner clan.
lead_paragraph: Lights down, arms up.

headline: Amid Affordable Care Act Fight, a Health Center Program Struggles to Stay Alive
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Medicine and Health', 'Doctors', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The future is uncertain for a program that trains doctors in underserved communities as it tries to tackle a worsening shortage of primary care physicians.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Savita Gopal, a 27-year-old resident physician at the Family Health Center of Harlem, sat in front of a computer last Thursday, peppering Jacob Doble, a 10-year-old from Harlem, with questions for 20 minutes.

headline: Justices Side With Black Lawmakers in Alabama
keywords: ['Redistricting and Reapportionment', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Discrimination', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: The Supreme Court, by a 5-to-4 vote, reversed a lower court ruling, forcing the reconsideration of a redistricting plan. The justices also revived a pregnancy discrimination suit against United Parcel Service.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Wednesday sided with black lawmakers challenging an Alabama redistricting plan and revived a pregnancy discrimination lawsuit against United Parcel Service.

headline: Disco Pioneer Nicky Siano Hasn’t Lost the Beat
abstract: At 60, the disco pioneer Nicky Siano still rules the dance floor.
lead_paragraph: Coney Island is a long way to go for a party. But that didn’t stop nearly 500 people from making the trek last Saturday night for the disc jockey Nicky Siano, the music pioneer who helped spawn the 1970s disco scene with his club the Gallery and a stint spinning at Studio 54. He was turning 60.

headline: Judge Rejects N.H.L.’s Bid to Dismiss Concussion Suit
abstract: A federal judge in Minnesota, Susan Richard Nelson, denied the league’s motions in litigation by retired hockey players who accused it of concealing the risks of repeated head trauma.
lead_paragraph: In a decision that may prompt a financial settlement, a federal judge in Minnesota on Wednesday denied an N.H.L. motion to dismiss a case brought by retired players who accused the league of concealing from them the risks of repeated head trauma and promoting violence on the ice.

headline: Victims of Germanwings Flight 9525
abstract: Passengers from at least 15 countries were aboard the flight from Barcelona, Spain, to Düsseldorf, Germany, including 72 Germans and 35 Spaniards. Here are profiles of some of the 123 victims whose families have been notified.
lead_paragraph: Passengers from at least 15 countries were aboard the flight from Barcelona, Spain, to Düsseldorf, Germany, including 72 Germans and 35 Spaniards. Here are profiles of some of the 123 victims whose families have been notified.

headline: The Happiest Hour in Greenwich Village
abstract: A new cocktail bar veers toward yuppies, brunchers and Tinder daters.
lead_paragraph: It seems fitting that the 1950s, a period of conformity and affluence, would inform a downtown night-life scene that could be described the same way. Such blitheness is on display at the Happiest Hour, a cocktail bar from Jon Neidich (an owner of Acme) and Jim Kearns (bartender at NoMad Hotel and Pegu Club) that opened last fall in Greenwich Village.

headline: F.T.C. Addresses Its Choice Not to Sue Google
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The agency issued a rare statement defending its choice not to take legal action after investigating Google for anticompetitive behavior in 2011 and 2012.
lead_paragraph: Several members of the Federal Trade Commission defended on Wednesday the actions taken by the agency in its antitrust investigation of Google, nearly a week after an internal document came to light, raising questions about the process.

headline: 3G Capital, Warren Buffett’s Favorite Partner in Deals Worth Billions
abstract: Mr. Buffett has made a habit of criticizing rapacious private equity firms over the years, but 3G Capital is different.
lead_paragraph: Warren E. Buffett has made a habit of criticizing ruthless Wall Street bankers and rapacious private equity firms over the years. As recently as last month, he railed against both in his annual letter to his shareholders at Berkshire Hathaway.

headline: Gregory Walcott, Actor in ‘Plan 9 From Outer Space,’ Dies at 87
abstract: Mr. Walcott had a career’s worth of screen and television credits in roles much different from the sci-fi B-movie that he couldn’t shed.
lead_paragraph: Gregory Walcott, a character actor whose résumé included numerous television westerns, several Clint Eastwood movies and prestige films like “Norma Rae” — but who was probably best known as one of the stars of “Plan 9 From Outer Space,” often called the worst movie ever made — died on Friday at his home in the Canoga Park neighborhood of Los Angeles. He was 87.

headline: Netanyahu Told to Mend Ties With Washington
abstract: Israel’s president also chided Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu for warning that Arab citizens were flocking to polling places in “droves.”
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel’s president on Wednesday officially handed Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu the task of forming a new government, saying its first priority was to repair relations with the United States and indirectly chiding Mr. Netanyahu for his  Election Day warning that Arab citizens were flocking to polling places in “droves.”

headline: Museum in Little Italy Seeks to Evict a Living Link to the Past
abstract: Adele Sarno was born in Manhattan’s Italian enclave and has spent her whole life there. Now 85, she is being forced from her home by the Italian American Museum.
lead_paragraph: Adele Sarno’s father, a longshoreman, emigrated from Naples, and she grew up in Manhattan’s Little Italy. As a child, she served as princess for the annual Feast of San Gennaro, she said, and one year was even crowned the queen.

headline: Player Ratings: U.S. (2) vs. Denmark (3)
abstract: Jozy Altidore’s frequently brilliant play notwithstanding, the late-game collapse against Denmark was something of a team effort.
lead_paragraph: AARHUS, Denmark — The United States national team endured yet another late-game collapse Wednesday, losing on a cold, rainy night by 3-2 to a Denmark team that was far superior in nearly every aspect of the game.

headline: Increased Military Spending Wins Out After Dueling Budget Votes in House
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Medicare', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Medicaid', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Republicans framed the debate around the imperative to shrink the government’s reach, balance the budget and begin to pay down the federal debt — without raising taxes.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Republicans beat back protests from fiscal hawks and narrowly passed a budget that increases war spending but slashes domestic programs and begins to privatize Medicare with a goal of balancing the federal books in nine years.

headline: House Leaders Confident of Passing Medicare Bill
abstract: The Congressional Budget Office released figures showing that the sweeping changes could add more than $140 billion to federal budget deficits in the coming decade.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Leaders of both parties in the House expressed confidence on Wednesday that their chamber would soon approve sweeping changes in Medicare, even though the Congressional Budget Office released figures showing that the bill could add more than $140 billion to federal budget deficits in the coming decade.

headline: Steven Smith, a ‘Marco Polo’ of American Tea, Dies at 65
abstract: Mr. Smith, who helped found the Stash and Tazo tea companies, brought back novel varieties from his global travels and developed a wide following.
lead_paragraph: Steven Smith, a tea company founder who, steeped in memories of sweet Red Rose brewed by his grandmother, helped transform the nation’s tea-drinking habits as much as any American since that party in Boston Harbor in 1773, died on Monday in Portland, Ore. He was 65.

headline: New York Police to Use Social Media to Connect With Residents
abstract: Beginning next month in the 109th Precinct in Queens, the department will use a program called IdeaScale to allow officers to solicit tips and concerns online.
lead_paragraph: The New York Police Department has faced its share of pushback on social media, most memorably when it solicited photos of police interactions on Twitter under the hashtag #myNYPD. Images of aggression by officers upended that campaign.

headline: Cost a Factor in Streaming Flight Data in Real Time
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Recording Equipment', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Another plane crash has many in aviation asking whether commercial flights should be required to transmit live data in real time.
lead_paragraph: The crash of a German passenger jet in the French Alps has once again raised the question of whether commercial airplanes should transmit flight information in real time.

headline: Former University of Oklahoma Student Apologizes for Racist Chant
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Fraternities and Sororities']
abstract: A fraternity member expelled from the University of Oklahoma said he was sorry for his role in the videotaped incident and ashamed that he participated.
lead_paragraph: OKLAHOMA CITY — A former University of Oklahoma student captured on video leading a racist chant apologized Wednesday, saying he was sorry for his role in the incident and ashamed that he participated.

headline: Shopping Events and Sales Happening This Week in New York
abstract: Five Four opens a pop-up shop in partnership with Marvel Entertainment for its capsule collection inspired by “Avengers: Age of Ultron” and more.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday from 5 to 8 p.m., the boutique Coop & Spree will host a trunk show with the Kempner designer Meggie Kempner, granddaughter of Nan Kempner, during which you can enjoy 20 percent off tweaked classics like a structured boyfriend blazer with leather detail on the sleeves ($520, originally $650). At 202 Elizabeth Street.

headline: Arizona Bill Would Delay Disclosure of Names of Officers in Shootings
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Law and Legislation', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: Gov. Doug Ducey has until Monday to decide on whether to sign or veto a measure that would require confidentiality on officers’ names for 60 days.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Gov. Doug Ducey has until Monday to decide whether to sign or veto a bill requiring state agencies to keep confidential for 60 days the identities of law enforcement officers involved in deadly or serious shootings.

headline: S.E.C. Is Investigating Dov Charney’s Departure, American Apparel Says
keywords: ['Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: The company learned last month that the S.E.C. had begun an investigation “with respect to matters arising from” an internal review into Mr. Charney’s conduct, according to its filing.
lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission has opened an inquiry into the circumstances surrounding the departure of Dov Charney, the founder of American Apparel who was ousted last year, the retailer said in a filing Wednesday.

headline: Winter Weather Stays; Its Clothes Do Not
abstract: Wearing spring clothes to ignore the lingering winter weather.
lead_paragraph: You know the look.

headline: Thousands Protest Plan to Oust University Chief in Mississippi
abstract: University of Mississippi students, employees and other supporters of Daniel W. Jones criticized the plan to change leaders as wrapped in secrecy and threatening to the future of a place that has often been central to the image of the state.
lead_paragraph: OXFORD, Miss. — Raising handwritten signs and clutching scripts for protest chants, more than 2,500 people on Wednesday demonstrated at the University of Mississippi to resist last week’s unexpected decision to oust the school’s chancellor, Daniel W. Jones.

headline: The Free-Range Parenting Quandary
abstract: Readers respond to an Op-Ed article about whether children should be given more freedom to roam.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: March 25, 2015

headline: Notre Dame’s Star on Offense, Defense and the Mound
abstract: Pat Connaughton, a swingman who has led his Notre Dame basketball team into the round of 16, was also a pitcher for the Irish and is now a minor leaguer for the Orioles.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — In March, the differences between the pulsating energy of a basketball arena during the N.C.A.A. tournament and the quiet chill of a Midwestern collegiate baseball field could not be more stark.

headline: Florida: Ex-Salvadoran Official Is Detained Pending Deportation
abstract: A former defense minister of El Salvador accused of human rights violations during the civil war in the 1980s was detained by immigration agents in Palm Coast, the first step in his deportation.
lead_paragraph: A former defense minister of El Salvador accused of human rights violations during the civil war in the 1980s was detained by immigration agents in Palm Coast, the first step in his deportation. In a precedent-setting decision, an immigration appeals court on March 12 upheld a deportation order for the official, Gen. Carlos Eugenio Vides Casanova, finding that he had participated in torture and killings by his troops when he was the highest Salvadoran military officer. The court found that Gen. Vides had aided a cover-up in the killings in 1980 of four American churchwomen. He has been living as a legal resident in Florida since 1989.

headline: Part of Washing
abstract: Byron Walden offers us a clean grid.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — There are clues that you get right away and there are clues that you ponder for what seems like an eternity before the light bulb goes on.

headline: My Biggest Financial Lesson
abstract: This special section is a collection of essays about the turning points or moments when the writers’ feelings about money crystallized.
lead_paragraph: Most of us have one, or sometimes more than one: a turning point or a moment when our feelings about money crystallize. When that happens, we know it and resolve to think about our finances in a different way while saving, spending or giving away money much more carefully.

headline: Michael P. Kelly, a Familiar Face, Is Returning to New York City’s Housing Agency
abstract: Mr. Kelly, an architect who has been called on to rescue troubled housing authorities in the past, will once again serve as general manager of the nation’s largest public housing agency.
lead_paragraph: A former general manager of New York City’s public housing authority is returning to the job at a time when the agency faces financial pressures even more dire than when he left.

headline: Amnesty International Sees Evidence of Palestinian War Crimes in 2014 Gaza Conflict
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: A 63-page report by the human rights organization came a week before a formal Palestinian accession to the International Criminal Court in The Hague.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Amnesty International has accused armed Palestinian groups, including the military wing of Hamas, of displaying “a flagrant disregard for the lives of civilians” during the 50-day war in Gaza last summer. In a report published early Thursday it said there was evidence that several deadly Palestinian rocket and mortar attacks amounted to war crimes.

headline: Paying for College and Learning a Lesson for Life
abstract: Applying for higher education provides an important opportunity for parents and their children to discuss decisions about money — and the amount of debt that will accrue by graduation.
lead_paragraph: When it came time to apply for college in the fall of 1988, my parents and I didn’t know the first thing about the financial aid process. But my mother, a veteran personal shopper who has always had a knack for figuring out just who to call to solve consumer mysteries of all sorts, knew someone who knew someone. A guy. The guy.

headline: Need Financial Advice? Ask the Future You
abstract: In personal finances, it’s easy to focus too much on the present. To overcome this, think of yourself and your needs years from now.
lead_paragraph: Eureka moments are supposed to happen in unlikely locations, like the one Archimedes had in his bath. But my revelation about planning and money came in a terribly likely spot, a centuries-old ceremonial hall at Oxford University.

headline: ‘Spent,’ a Song About Financial Hardship
abstract: An original song by Amy Speace and Neilson Hubbard about how hard it is to save for the future when you are barely making payments on today’s bills.
lead_paragraph: An original song by Amy Speace and Neilson Hubbard about how hard it is to save for the future when you are barely making payments on today’s bills.

headline: Chinese Cabbie’s Query Prompted an Epiphany
abstract: Americans are acculturated to being cagey about our personal wealth and income, but a little transparency might serve us all better.
lead_paragraph: With the Mandarin language skills of a buffalo, I began chatting with my taxi driver in Shanghai, a polite man with plenty of questions about the United States. It was early 2007, and sitting in a back seat that reeked of stale cigarettes and body odor, I certainly didn’t see a financial epiphany coming. Then, the driver went straight for the jugular.

headline: Money Admonitions From 9/11
abstract: Kenneth Feinberg determined payouts to victims of such tragedies as the Sept. 11 attacks and the shootings at Virginia Tech, giving him pause about how to handle his own money in the face of life’s vicissitudes.
lead_paragraph: In the last 30 years, presidents, governors, mayors and others have delegated to me the unenviable task of putting a value to the lives of people who are already dead.

headline: An Excuse to Splurge on Her Girls
abstract: Seven years and about $2,500 later, a mother recalls that the popular toys and accessories that she bought for her daughters also fulfilled her own childhood desires.
lead_paragraph: After I spent a weekend packing away toys that my children had outgrown, Elizabeth, Felicity, Julie, Kaya, Kirsten and Kit were nestled safely in plastic bins.

headline: Amy Speace, a Singer-Songwriter, Just Trying to Make Do
abstract: Ms. Speace lives in East Nashville, Tenn., a bohemian neighborhood, but surging development there has made it difficult for artists there to make ends meet. (With video.)
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — I live in East Nashville, a bohemian neighborhood in Music City right across the Cumberland River from downtown that, for many years, has been home to one of the most diverse populations in this city. Bisected by Gallatin Pike, where an über-trendy coffee shop might sit in between a discount liquor store and a check-cashing shop, this area is peppered with quaint cottage homes that only a short time ago were affordable to the artist class.

headline: How the Year 2000 Turned My Life Upside Down
abstract: When I bought my first New York apartment, the down payment came from my grandfather, who had long offered support and financial advice.
lead_paragraph: I’ll admit it now: All those Y2K predictions had me scared about what would befall the world when 1999 became 2000.

headline: Making Money Secondary in Decisions
abstract: A top executive learns early that money shouldn’t be the key factor in making career choices.
lead_paragraph: I was 22 years old, starting my first job out of college and at lunch with my boss, John W. Rogers Jr., the founder and chief executive of Ariel Investments. I hung on John’s every word, filing away his every utterance.

headline: Breaking a Rule on Hiring, and Paying the Price
abstract: The owner of a marketing strategy company learns that when it comes to acquiring talent, potential is great — but experience is better.
lead_paragraph: During the 12 years I’ve owned a marketing strategy company, I have set many guidelines and recommendations for myself and my employees, but few hard rules.

headline: A Teenager’s Harsh Lesson Is an Adult’s Buffer
abstract: The day after graduating from high school, a foster child was on her own. Ever since, she has saved — and been her own backup plan.
lead_paragraph: The day after my high school graduation, at the age of 17 and with an acceptance letter to an Ivy League university in hand, my foster mother asked me to move out of her house in San Diego.

headline: Kim Gordon on Not Spending Money
abstract: The co-founder of Sonic Youth discusses money uncertainty as a musician and daughter of a Depression-era mother.
lead_paragraph: Kim Gordon’s memoir, “Girl in a Band,” a New York Times best seller, details her life as a founding member of Sonic Youth and her marriage to her band mate Thurston Moore.

headline: A Costly but Valuable Lesson in Debt and Self-Confidence
abstract: Spending as a salve for growing pains causes a more serious malady.
lead_paragraph: The interest rate made my stomach drop: 27.6 percent.

headline: Finding Surer Footing
abstract: Carl Richards says an experience while mountain climbing with a friend changed how he views risk in business or personal finances.
lead_paragraph: We left the trail head at 1 a.m. and headed for the summit of the Grand Teton. I had made this climb several times, but my friend was still new to mountaineering. This trip was his first attempt at the popular peak. Our goal was to reach the top by sunrise so we had enough time to get back down before afternoon thunderstorms made the trail dangerous.

headline: Slim Thug’s Real Estate Game Plan, Dashed by a Dalliance
abstract: The rap artist saw a real estate opportunity a few years ago, but it slipped away when he and his agent became more interested in each other.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — There’s never much surprise when hearing stories of artists mixing business with pleasure, but it is surprising when too much mixing results in the artist ending up with financial losses.

headline: Passing Along the Financial Genes
abstract: Like his father, a radio host doesn’t like to think about money. So his wife handles every last penny.
lead_paragraph: When you get right down to it, it’s my dad’s fault. My relationship with money, I mean. It’s not weird or anything like that. It’s just casual. Like, whether you have it or you don’t, everything’s going to be all right somehow.

headline: It’s a Jump Ball. Kentucky Wins.
abstract: The Wildcats’ dominance of nearly every facet of play extends to the jump ball, which they win a staggering 87 percent of the time.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — In all of sports, no event may combine so much spectacle with so little meaning as the jump ball. It is competition at its purest: two players trying to jump higher than the other to get the ball. Once it is done, though, all that has happened is one team has the ball; the next team will soon enough.

headline: Pick Up the Tab: The Wages of Virtue
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Personal Finances', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Whoever makes the most, picks up the tab. For several reasons.
lead_paragraph: “Don’t even bother,” my big-shot executive pal warned me as I reached for my college-era Visa. We hadn’t seen each other since my undergrad days. “You never pay for the meal of someone who’s better off than you.”

headline: Shrieking About Questionable Whistles in the N.C.A.A. Tournament
abstract: The outcomes of several games in the opening rounds appeared to be influenced by debatable decisions of the officials.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — On Friday night at Nationwide Arena here, the most pivotal moment in a contest between Dayton and Providence to advance to the N.C.A.A. tournament’s round of 32 was not a 3-pointer feathered in at the last second. It was not a thunderous dunk that brought the fans to their feet. It was not a stirring defensive stand. Instead, it was a technical foul.

headline: Alarmed About Masahiro Tanaka’s Velocity? Slow Down, He Says
abstract: Masahiro Tanaka, who had a mixed outing against the Mets, said he was intentionally throwing more sinkers because he felt his four-seam fastball was hit hard last year. He also indicated that he was trying to relax this spring and not overthrow.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Masahiro Tanaka stood with his back to the wall, his right elbow and shoulder heavily wrapped. He frowned, fidgeted and shook his head while a group of reporters asked why the velocity on his fastball appeared to be down.

headline: The Crisis in Yemen: What You Need to Know
abstract: Yemen, the poorest country in the Middle East, is embroiled in a struggle for power that has serious implications for the region and the security of the United States.
lead_paragraph: Yemen, the poorest country in the Middle East, is embroiled in a struggle for power that has serious implications for the region and the security of the United States.

headline: Small Debris Indicates Germanwings Plane Didn’t Explode in Air
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: The French authorities said the Airbus A320 that crashed in the Alps probably disintegrated when it struck the mountain at high velocity.
lead_paragraph: Among the unusual elements of Tuesday’s crash of a Germanwings Airbus A320 in the French Alps is that debris strewn across the site was in tiny pieces rather than large chunks, with one witness describing the plane as having been “pulverized.”

headline: Collages that Challenge the Perception of Private Moments
abstract: The photographer Charlie Engman forges “a new visual language” with images that emerge from the edges of his consciousness.
lead_paragraph: In this weekly series, T’s photo editors share the most compelling visual projects they’ve discovered.

headline: The Anxiety of Fatherhood
abstract: The poet Craig Morgan Teicher and the artist Idris Khan search for solace from the endless nights of early parenthood in a simple surveillance camera.
lead_paragraph: The poet Craig Morgan Teicher and the artist Idris Khan search for solace from the endless nights of early parenthood in a simple surveillance camera.

headline: The Centuries-Old Italian House Where Cy Twombly Thrived
abstract: The artist painted some of the 20th century’s great works in the hilly coastal town of Gaeta. All the while, Nicola Del Roscio, who watched over him, quietly created his own Eden.
lead_paragraph: The artist painted some of the 20th century’s great works in the hilly coastal town of Gaeta. All the while, Nicola Del Roscio, who watched over him, quietly created his own Eden.

headline: Drones Beaming Web Access Are in the Stars for Facebook
abstract: A V-shaped unmanned vehicle is the centerpiece of the social network’s plans to connect with the five billion or so people it has yet to reach.
lead_paragraph: MENLO PARK, Calif. — In classical mythology, Aquila is the eagle carrying Jupiter’s thunderbolts skyward. At Facebook, it is the code name for a high-flying drone, indicative of the social networking company’s lofty ambitions.

headline: Word of the Day | ravage
abstract: This word has appeared in 39 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: ravage • \ˈra-vij\ • verb and noun

headline: Iran Nuclear Deal May Be Done by Next Week, U.S. Official Says
abstract: The State Department official emphasized that an agreement was not assured, adding that the talks could yet be stymied by an array of complex issues.
lead_paragraph: LAUSANNE, SWITZERLAND — In the Obama administration’s most hopeful prognosis on its talks with Iran, a senior State Department official said Wednesday that it was possible to conclude a new accord on that nation’s nuclear program by early next week.

headline: Health Agency Reports Lowest Weekly Total of New Ebola Cases
abstract: The World Health Organization on Wednesday reported the lowest weekly total of new Ebola cases so far this year in the three nations of West Africa that have been afflicted by the deadly virus.
lead_paragraph: The World Health Organization on Wednesday reported the lowest weekly total of new Ebola cases so far this year in the three nations of West Africa that have been afflicted by the deadly virus. The organization said a total of 79 new cases were reported for the week that ended Sunday: 45 in Guinea, 33 in Sierra Leone and one in Liberia. The Liberian case in particular has raised concern because the country had reported no new Ebola cases for the previous three weeks, and the precise source of the new infection, in a 44-year-old woman from the Monrovia region, has not yet been determined. The latest weekly Ebola statistics showed that 10,311 people have died from the outbreak since it began last year.

headline: Reunion Tour Continues for Arizona Coach Sean Miller
abstract: Miller has been reconnecting with familiar faces during the tournament, and all the meetings are connected to Xavier.
lead_paragraph: Arizona Coach Sean Miller gave Sister Rose Ann Fleming, the academic adviser at Xavier since 1985, a hug in the dank hallway of Staples Center. They were chatting when the Xavier coach appeared.

headline: West Virginia Coach Bob Huggins Wrote the Book on the Press. Two, Actually.
abstract: As part of a series of books called “Art & Science of Coaching,” Huggins wrote “Coaching the Matchup Press: Aggressive Defensive Principles for Winning Basketball,” in 2000, and “Press Breakers,” in 2002.
lead_paragraph: All season, West Virginia won by challenging opponents everywhere on the court, trying to force turnovers.

headline: Wisconsin Uses Fakes to Gain an Edge
abstract: The Badgers’ opponents averaged 2.0 blocks, and the secret to their success is that in shooting drills, the players executed pump fakes and lunged forward before leaning back to shoot.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — North Carolina forward Kennedy Meeks ended the regular season with at least one blocked shot in each of the Tar Heels’ final eight games. Meeks, who finished eighth in the Atlantic Coast Conference with 46 blocks, will face a tall order deflecting Wisconsin shots when the teams meet Thursday in an N.C.A.A. West Regional semifinal in Los Angeles. And not just because he has been nursing a sprained knee.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Spike) OCEAN’S THIRTEEN (2007) After Reuben Tishkoff (Elliott Gould) has a heart attack when his business partner Willy Bank (Al Pacino) pulls a fast one on him, Danny Ocean (George Clooney) gets the gang back together for a revenge plot. The gang includes characters played by Brad Pitt, Matt Damon, Don Cheadle, Casey Affleck, Scott Caan, Bernie Mac and others. They use gadgets and seduction to carry out their convoluted plan in this third film in a series directed by Steven Soderbergh. “Part of what makes the ‘Ocean’s’ films, even the self-indulgent second installment, so enjoyable is that they’re not only about Mr. Soderbergh’s obsessive aesthetic investment in every single shot, but they’re also about him trying to make the audience love his images every bit as much as he does,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “Playing inside the box and out, he has learned to go against the grain while also going with the flow. In ‘Ocean’s Thirteen’ he proves that in spades by using color like Kandinsky and hanging a funny mustache on Mr. Clooney’s luscious mug, having become a genius of the system he so often resists.”

headline: Applications for Asylum Are Surging, United Nations Says
abstract: About 866,000 people sought asylum in 2014, a 20-year high, the United Nations said. The Syrian war has driven up that number.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The war in Syria, now in its fifth year, has not only flooded countries in the region with millions of refugees. It has driven up the number of people seeking asylum across the world to a 20-year high, according to the United Nations.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Thursday, March 26, 2015.
lead_paragraph: “To me, the scandal is that we had protocols in place and the medical community knew what they were, and yet we failed in some cases to implement this across the theater. That was a mistake, and I apologize for that.”

headline: From Microsoft, a Novel Way to Mandate Sick Leave
keywords: ['Paid Time Off', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The company announced that many of its 2,000 contractors and vendors would have to give employees 15 paid days off for sick leave and vacation time.
lead_paragraph: It is difficult to imagine, at least in the current political climate, that the federal government will require paid sick leave for workers, let alone vacation time.

headline: For Children’s Seizures, Turning to Medical Marijuana
abstract: Some parents desperate to ease their children’s epileptic seizures have moved to Colorado to seek relief through medical marijuana.
lead_paragraph: By the time Grace Brunno was 3, she was suffering 400 epileptic seizures a week. Her parents, desperate to ease her suffering, took a drastic step: They left their home in Missouri and moved to Colorado so their child could start a regimen of medical marijuana.

abstract: Mary Woolley of Research!America writes that proposed cuts to discretionary spending “would dramatically slow medical progress.”

abstract: Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana rebuts criticism of his governance that appeared in a column by Charles M. Blow and an editorial.

keywords: ['Corruption (Institutional)', 'Children and Childhood', 'Poverty', 'Malnutrition', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Corporations']
abstract: It’s not a coincidence that Angola is a center for malnutrition and child mortality as well as rampant corruption.
lead_paragraph: LUANDA, Angola — There are parasites of all kinds in poor countries.

abstract: Alan Kadish, the president of Touro College, takes issue with an editorial.

headline: An Obama Friend Turns Foe on Coal
keywords: ['Coal', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: A legal scholar is wrong when he says a climate rule is unconstitutional.
lead_paragraph: LAURENCE H. TRIBE, the liberal icon and legal scholar, has grabbed headlines in recent weeks for publicly attacking President Obama’s signature climate change initiative — the Clean Power Plan — which would regulate carbon emissions from power plants. He was retained as an independent expert by Peabody Energy, the world’s largest private-sector coal company, and is representing it in a lawsuit that seeks to invalidate the plan.

headline: When Nancy Met Johnny
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Medicare', 'Law and Legislation', 'Human Trafficking', 'ABORTION']
abstract: When it comes to the ways of Washington, when should our elected representatives just make it happen?
lead_paragraph: Today, concerned citizens, we will consider when we want our elected representatives to just throw in the towel and get something done.

headline: Deadly Force in Philadelphia
abstract: The city’s historically troubled Police Department faces steep challenges on the way to reform.
lead_paragraph: In 1994, three years after the country viewed the infamous video of Los Angeles police officers brutalizing Rodney King, a black motorist, Congress gave the Justice Department the power to restructure police departments engaged in unconstitutional practices.

headline: Backing Away From Zero Tolerance
abstract: The push to reduce suspensions and expulsions in schools across the country takes hold in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: Schools across the country are rightly backing away from “zero tolerance” disciplinary policies under which children are suspended for minor misbehavior that once would have been dealt with by the principal and the child’s parents or with a modest punishment like detention. The schools are being pushed in this direction by studies showing: that suspensions do nothing to improve the school climate; that children who are thrown out are at greater risk of low achievement and becoming entangled with the juvenile justice system; and that minority children are disproportionately singled out for the harshest, most damaging disciplinary measures.

headline: A Rebuff to India’s Censors
keywords: ['Censorship', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Editorials', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: The country’s Supreme Court struck down restrictions on Internet speech, but the ruling was not as strong as it could have been.
lead_paragraph: Indian officials have repeatedly undermined the country’s right to free speech recently by seeking to ban films, intimidating authors and arresting Internet users. That’s what makes a recent Indian Supreme Court ruling striking down restrictions on Internet speech so important.

headline: To Stop Iran’s Bomb, Bomb Iran
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Tehran can’t be trusted on a nuclear deal. Force is the only option.
lead_paragraph: FOR years, experts worried that the Middle East would face an uncontrollable nuclear-arms race if Iran ever acquired weapons capability. Given the region’s political, religious and ethnic conflicts, the logic is straightforward.

headline: Linking Artist and Artisan

headline: Fatal Descent of Germanwings Plane Was ‘Deliberate,’ French Authorities Say
abstract: The co-pilot initiated the plane’s descent for unknown reasons while he was alone in the cockpit, having locked the pilot out, said the prosecutor.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Andreas Lubitz was breathing, steady and calm, in the final moments of Germanwings Flight 9525. It was the only sound from within the cockpit that the voice recorder detected as Mr. Lubitz, the co-pilot, sent the plane into its descent.

abstract: When have you been a car in which the driver was distracted from watching the road?

headline: As Dollar Heats Up Overseas, U.S. Manufacturers Feel a Chill
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'US Dollar (Currency)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Customers in places like Europe, where the euro has fallen against the dollar, say they can no longer afford American goods without deep discounts.
lead_paragraph: The dollar’s sharp rise in recent months has left Robert Stevenson and Eastman Machine, his family’s 127-year-old Buffalo company, feeling the heat on both sides of the Atlantic.

headline: C.I.A. Officers and F.B.I. Agents, Meet Your New Partner: The Analyst
abstract: As the C.I.A. and the F.B.I. confront an evolving terrorist threat, cyberattacks and other challenges, both are reorganizing to empower intelligence analysts.
lead_paragraph: Call it the revenge of the nerds, Washington-style. The gun-toting F.B.I. agent and the swashbuckling C.I.A. undercover officer are being increasingly called upon to share their clout, their budgets and even their Hollywood glamour with the humble, deskbound intelligence analyst.

headline: Viewers’ Choice: Meaningless Bowls Over Playoff Basketball
abstract: How popular is football in the United States? Nine early-round games in the men’s N.C.A.A. tournament had fewer TV viewers than last season’s Camellia Bowl did.
lead_paragraph: March Madness is huge, right? This year, the multiweek extravaganza has had its usual share of upsets, an exhilarated coach falling off his rolling chair after a victory and the presence of a dominant Kentucky team. Nearly 11.6 million brackets were submitted to ESPN.com’s annual contest. So what in college sports could be a bigger fan draw than the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament?

headline: Chirlane McCray, in Evolving Role and in Song, Finds Her Voice
abstract: Ms. McCray, the wife of Mayor Bill de Blasio, is far less involved in the day-to-day operation of New York than expected, instead hewing closely to issues that she relates to.
lead_paragraph: Inside City Hall in October, some three dozen commissioners and administration officials gathered to discuss children’s issues, rattling off statistics on cognitive development in toddlers.

headline: In Menendez Inquiry, Government Renews Push for Friend’s Cooperation
keywords: ['Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Gifts to Public Officials', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Federal investigators met with lawyers for Dr. Salomon Melgen, the wealthy donor who has given gifts to Senator Robert Menendez, whose lawyers have urged the Justice Department not to bring charges.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Robert Menendez, the powerful New Jersey Democrat, and Dr. Salomon Melgen, a wealthy Florida eye surgeon, have been close friends for years. Mr. Menendez may soon find out just how close their friendship remains.

headline: The Whitney Museum, Soon to Open Its New Home, Searches for American Identity
abstract: When the Whitney Museum of American Art opens its new home, in the meatpacking district, its inaugural exhibition will be “America Is Hard to See.”
lead_paragraph: When the Whitney Museum of American Art opens its new building in Manhattan’s meatpacking district on May 1, it’s the big things everyone will notice first: the sweeping views west to the Hudson River; the romantic silhouettes of Manhattan’s wooden water towers; the four outdoor terraces for presenting sculptures, performances and movie screenings; and the tiered profile of its steel-paneled facade, intentionally reminiscent of the Whitney’s Modernist, granite-clad Marcel Breuer building on Madison Avenue, which had been the museum’s home since 1966.

headline: A New Irish Rebellion, This Time Against Water Fees
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Taxation', 'Water', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Budgets and Budgeting']
abstract: The prospect of paying for water, which many see as yet another new tax at a time when the government has assured them that austerity is over, has prompted mass protests.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — Miranda Lumsden, 43, a single mother of four, had never protested against anything before the Irish government introduced new water fees last summer.

headline: Is Our Culture of Online Shaming Out of Control?
abstract: Whether you know who Monica Lewinsky is or not, you’ll probably know what she meant when she spoke about the dangers of online public shaming in a recent TED talk. Do you agree with her that our “culture of humiliation” has gotten out of hand? Why or why not?
lead_paragraph: Do you know who Monica Lewinsky is? She calls herself the “Patient Zero of losing a personal reputation on a global scale almost instantaneously” and says that young people know her mostly through references in rap songs.

headline: ‘Richard John Neuhaus,’ by Randy Boyagoda
abstract: A biography of the Rev. Richard John Neuhaus, an intellectual maverick of 20th-century Roman Catholicism.
lead_paragraph: At the time of his death six years ago, the Rev. Richard John Neuhaus was arguably the most prominent conservative Roman Catholic in America. He was leader of the “theocons,” as critics labeled them, right-leaning Christian intellectuals grouped around First Things, a journal Neuhaus founded. Popes John Paul II and Benedict XVI knew him personally, as well as by his work, and George W. Bush sought Neuhaus’s counsel before and during his time as president. His 1984 book on the place of faith in politics, “The Naked Public Square,” has been credited with helping to define the climate in which Ronald Reagan won re-election.

headline: Lyft Adds Profiles to Make Ride Sharing More Personalized
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Car-Pooling and Ride-Sharing', 'Start-ups']
abstract: Lyft is adding user profiles of passengers and drivers to its mobile app, so rides can be more tailored and conversational.
lead_paragraph: In 1971, Herb Kelleher, a founder of Southwest Airlines, had an idea: As competition in the burgeoning airline industry intensified, he wanted to make his small, regional carrier stand out among aviation giants.

headline: Facebook’s Yann LeCun Discusses Digital Companions and Artificial Intelligence (and Emotions)
abstract: The head of Facebook’s Artificial Intelligence Lab foresees a day when we all have artificial helpers that understand us, all of the information in the world, and what we need to know next.
lead_paragraph: Yann LeCun is director of artificial intelligence research at Facebook, and founding director of New York University’s Center for Data Science.

headline: An Upbeat Emotion That’s Surprisingly Good for You
abstract: Awe, that goose-bumpy mix of fear and wonder, appears to be particularly good for the body.

abstract: The larger than expected sale is part of the British bank’s plan to fully exit its ownership in Citizens, an American retail bank, by the end of 2016.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Royal Bank of Scotland said on Thursday that it sold $3.2 billion in shares of the Citizens Financial Group in a larger-than-expected offering as it seeks to reduce its holdings in the American retail bank after an initial public offering last year.

headline: New York Today: Celebrations of Spring
abstract: Thursday: Soggy weather, attractions open for the season, and an eviction with a twist.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this drippy Thursday.

headline: Richard III Gets a Kingly Burial, on Second Try
abstract: The archbishop of Canterbury presided over the service on Thursday, but critics said the notorious monarch should not have been given such honors.
lead_paragraph: LEICESTER, England — For an English monarchy that has lasted more than 1,000 years, there can have been few more improbable occasions than the ceremony of remembrance here on Thursday for the reburial of one of the most bloodstained medieval sovereigns, King Richard III, who was slain in battle seven years before Christopher Columbus set sail for the New World.

headline: As Twitter Introduces Periscope, Tech Titans Bet on Live Streaming Video
keywords: ['Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Mobile Applications', 'Social Media']
abstract: Apps that help users broadcast themselves live from their phones are catching the eye of tech heavyweights and venture capitalists. Periscope is Twitter’s big entry into this realm.
lead_paragraph: Tyra Banks smiled a toothy grin and chatted idly with a captive audience this week, showing off her new pixie haircut. She later flipped a blond-streaked auburn lock at the crowd, asking in a half-mocking tone, “How do you like me now?”

headline: Borse Dubai Sells Its Stake in London Stock Exchange Group
abstract: The holding company for the Dubai Financial Market and Nasdaq Dubai was the largest shareholder in the London exchange. The sale is estimated at as much as $2.2 billion.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Borse Dubai said on Thursday that it had sold its entire 17.4 percent stake in the London Stock Exchange Group, ending its nearly eight-year ownership in the stock market operator.

headline: Of Catfish Wars and Shooting Wars
abstract: Graves in the life-giving rice paddies along the Mekong Delta suggest the Asian gift for acceptance.
lead_paragraph: THANH BINH, Vietnam — I drove out through a watery landscape, the rice paddies shimmering, watermelon being planted in muddy fields. There were ducks on the canals, graves and shrines in the light green rice fields, the dead among the living, not hidden but recalled daily. Women in conical hats pushed bicycles over rickety wooden bridges. The breeze was warm, the viscous coffee sweet. Cafes set with hammocks, some advertising Wi-Fi, offered sugar cane juice pressed through small hand-cranked mills. Everything felt liquid, soft, fluid here in the Mekong Delta, an aqueous microclimate.

headline: Daily Report: Facebook’s High-Stakes Bet on Drones to Deliver Internet Service
abstract: In the high-stakes competition for domination of the Internet, Facebook is under pressure to show that it, too, can pursue projects that are more speculative than product.
lead_paragraph: A V-shaped unmanned vehicle, which has about the wingspan of a Boeing 767 but weighs less than a small car, is the centerpiece of Facebook’s plans to connect with the five billion or so people it has yet to reach, Quentin Hardy and Vindu Goel report.

headline: Egypt Says It May Send Troops to Yemen to Fight Houthis
abstract: The Egyptian announcement signaled the growing likelihood of a protracted ground war on the tip of the Arabian Peninsula.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt said Thursday that it was prepared to send troops into Yemen as part of a Saudi-led campaign against the Iranian-backed Houthi movement, signaling the possibility of a protracted ground war on the tip of the Arabian Peninsula.

headline: Today in Politics: Health Fix Heralds Rare Moment of Congressional Compromise
abstract: In a rare and potentially important exhibition of congressional compromise, the House is set on Thursday to give strong bipartisan support to a health deal negotiated between Speaker John A. Boehner and Representative Nancy Pelosi, the Democratic leader.
lead_paragraph: Good Thursday morning from Washington, where Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky is looking to capture some of the limelight seized by Senator Ted Cruz of Texas this week, while Mitt Romney seems to be enjoying the life of a noncandidate. Ben Affleck and Bill Gates have come to tell the Senate a thing or two about diplomacy and President Obama is leaving town for Birmingham, Ala., to highlight economic gains. And Congress appears to be on the brink of a bipartisan breakthrough.

headline: Officers’ Race Matters Less Than You Think
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Police', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Research']
abstract: Among the more intriguing conclusions in a new Department of Justice report: it’s not only white officers shooting black suspects, but all officers.
lead_paragraph: This week, the Department of Justice released a report about use of force by the Philadelphia Police Department (P.P.D.). I found it fascinating, but not necessarily for the reasons that resonated in subsequent headlines.

headline: N.C.A.A. Bracket Results: When Upsets Are a Good Thing
abstract: After two rounds, we review the leaders of The Times’s tournament contest. The big points are yet to come.
lead_paragraph: This year’s N.C.A.A. basketball upsets have ruined many brackets in traditional contests, but readers playing our risk-adjusted bracket game may see the surprises in a more positive light: as well-earned payouts to smart gambles.

headline: A Town on New York’s Hudson River Reinvents Itself
abstract: Stylish restaurants, quirky boutiques and a craft brewery are helping Troy, population 50,000, to mount a comeback.
lead_paragraph: Curled along the Hudson River 150 miles north of Manhattan, Troy made shirt collars that could be detached and washed, back when such fashions were in vogue in the 19th century. When that look faded, Collar City hit a rough patch. But new stylish restaurants, quirky boutiques and a craft brewery in a downtown rich with Victorian architecture are helping Troy, population 50,000, become the latest Hudson Valley address to mount a comeback. A former department store is giving way to the Tech Valley Center of Gravity, a start-up incubator, which joins the Troy Savings Bank Music Hall, a Beaux-Arts stage for comedy, bluegrass and Bach.

headline: High in the Mountains and Monasteries of Georgia
abstract: This former Soviet republic is perfect for budget travelers who like their bumpy bus rides to end in mountain villages with lots of good, affordable wine.
lead_paragraph: When paying so little for lodging, you can hardly complain if your host describes your homemade breakfast rather enigmatically, as Nana Kokiashvili, proprietor of Nana’s Guest House in the walled hilltop town of Sighnaghi, Georgia, did when she brought it to us: “Porridge, special stomach, maybe eat sugar, no sugar, tasting.”

headline: Prison Planet
abstract: Different nations take very different approaches to the convicts they deem the most dangerous.
lead_paragraph: Different nations take very different approaches to the convicts they deem the most dangerous. From Russia’s prison island to Saudi Arabia’s unexpectedly cushy cellblocks, here are some of the most notable.

headline: Baby, Meet Iowa
abstract: Seeing an old landscape through a newborn’s eyes.
lead_paragraph: We expected the baby in June, and our lease ended in July. Under the best of circumstances, I dread packing. To move is to endure a weekslong confrontation with your past selves and their poor consumer choices. You reckon with useless gifts retained from guilt, find birthday cards from the deceased. Now we were adding all that to the triage of newborn care.

headline: Throwback Thursday | The Scopes Trial
abstract: The Scopes trial has been called “the true trial of the century” — in part because similar debates still roil school systems around the country.
lead_paragraph: On March 23, 1925, the State of Tennessee banned the teaching of evolution (PDF):

headline: Matt Stainbrook Drives Strangers Around, and Xavier Onward
abstract: Stainbrook, who works as an Uber driver in his free time, had an unlikely path to starring for the Musketeers in the N.C.A.A. tournament’s round of 16.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Somewhere in suburban Cincinnati lives a woman who lost her job a few months ago and whose company, because she had car-pooled that day, arranged for her ride home. She was driven by Xavier’s leading scorer and rebounder, a 6-foot-10, 270-pound Uber driver named Matt Stainbrook.

headline: Is ‘Mistress’ a Word That Has Seen Its Best Days?
abstract: Readers object to the suggestion, in stories, that a woman is “kept.”
lead_paragraph: Language evolves. Words come and go. And sometimes, as words go, they need a little push getting out the door.

headline: Oil Prices Jump as Saudi and Yemen Fighting Escalates

lead_paragraph: LONDON — Oil prices rose sharply on Thursday amid concerns that fighting in the Arabian Peninsula between a Saudi-led coalition and Houthi rebels in Yemen could disrupt supplies.

headline: U.S. Airstrikes on ISIS in Tikrit Prompt Boycott by Shiite Fighters
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: The groups, representing about a third of the 30,000 fighters, pulled out of the fight for Tikrit in protest of U.S. airstrikes.
lead_paragraph: AL RASHID AIR BASE, Iraq — By Day 2 of the American airstrike campaign against militants holed up in Tikrit, the mission appeared beleaguered on several fronts on Thursday: Thousands of Shiite militiamen boycotted the fight, others threatened to attack any Americans they found, and Iraqi officials said nine of their fighters had been accidentally killed in an airstrike.
