headline: A First Look at the Samsung Galaxy S6 and S6 Edge
abstract: Everything about the new phones seems designed to convey a simple message: Samsung has changed.
lead_paragraph: As Samsung begins taking orders on Thursday for its new high-end phones, it’s only a slight exaggeration to say that this could be the South Korean electronics giant’s last best shot in the smartphone business.

headline: With Chosen, ‘American Idol’ Meets YouTube Meets Mobile Devices
abstract: On the new app Chosen, would-be stars upload videos of themselves performing a song, which armchair judges then critique with their own response videos.
lead_paragraph: Eventually, it seems, every successful form of entertainment gets its own app. Now it may be time for the mobile version of the TV talent show.

headline: The Radical Humaneness of Norway’s Halden Prison
abstract: The goal of the Norwegian penal system is to get inmates out of it.
lead_paragraph: Like everything else in Norway, the tw­o-­hour drive southeast from Oslo seemed impossibly civilized. The highways were perfectly maintained and painted, the signs clear and informative and the speed-­monitoring cameras primly intolerant. My destination was the town of Halden, which is on the border with Sweden, straddling a narrow fjord guarded by a 17th-­century fortress. I drove down winding roads flanked in midsummer by rich green fields of young barley and dense yellow carpets of rapeseed plants in full flower. Cows clustered in wood-­fenced pastures next to neat farmsteads in shades of rust and ocher. On the outskirts of town, across from a road parting dark pine forest, the turnoff to Norway’s newest prison was marked by a modest sign that read, simply, HALDEN ­FENGSEL. There were no signs warning against picking up hitchhikers, no visible fences. Only the 25-­foot-­tall floodlights rising along the edges hinted that something other than grazing cows lay ahead.

headline: Inside America’s Toughest Federal Prison
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Solitary Confinement', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Sentences (Criminal)']
abstract: For years, conditions inside the United States’ only federal supermax facility were largely a mystery. But a landmark lawsuit is finally revealing the harsh world within.
lead_paragraph: In prison, Rodney Jones told me, everyone had a nickname. Jones’s was Saint E’s, short for St. Elizabeths, the federal psychiatric hospital in Washington, best known for housing John Hinckley Jr. after he shot Ronald Reagan. Jones spent time there as well, having shown signs of mental illness from an early age; he first attempted suicide at 12, when he drank an entire bottle of Clorox. Later, he became addicted to PCP and crack and turned to robbery to support his habit.

headline: Denmark Steps Into the Skinny Model Debate
abstract: Denmark’s fashion community intends to ensure there are healthy models on its runways by encouraging peer pressure within the industry.
lead_paragraph: The debate over skinny models is once again rearing its controversial head. After the news that France is considering a skinny models law, Denmark on Thursday entered the arena, albeit with a somewhat different strategic approach to the problem: one that focuses more on peer pressure within the industry and less on legislative pressure.

headline: Writers Old and Young: Staring Across the Moat
abstract: When, sooner than they can possibly imagine, young writers turn into old writers, what then?
lead_paragraph: A moat? Then is it no more than the venerable if tedious question of the generations, the superannuated versus the vernal? Or is it a more principled divide? Somewhere among the profusion of his essays Edmund Wilson describes the life span of magazines, how they mimic human life itself: they rise to their prime and gradually decline, until in their undeniable irrelevance they give up the ghost — after which they fade from discourse altogether. Where now is the American Mercury, where now is Partisan Review? And where, after its posthumous transmigration into a “vertically integrated ­digital-media company,” is The New Republic?

headline: ‘Shrinks,’ by Jeffrey A. Lieberman with Ogi Ogas
abstract: A look at psychiatry’s evolution from pseudoscience to therapeutic tool.
lead_paragraph: One of the most miserable experiences of my young adulthood, in the mid-1980s, was the year I spent in formal Freudian psychoanalysis. How well I remember lying on that uncomfortable couch with its built-in simulacrum of a pillow, as I struggled desperately to just “let my mind go,” to free associate, to disinter childhood memories or impulses that might prove remotely useful to me or at least satisfy my psychiatrist, who often seemed to be picking distractedly at lint on her skirt. She was a brilliant woman, no doubt about it, yet I always left her office feeling like a failure, and the science writer in me couldn’t help wondering, Where is the clinical evidence that this excruciating and expensive ordeal really works?

headline: Prosecutor: Co-Pilot Crashed Plane
abstract: Brice Robin, the chief Marseille prosecutor, said on Thursday the co-pilot of the Germanwings Airbus A320 deliberately crashed the plane that killed himself and 149 others aboard in the French Alps.
lead_paragraph: Brice Robin, the chief Marseille prosecutor, said on Thursday the co-pilot of the Germanwings Airbus A320 deliberately crashed the plane that killed himself and 149 others aboard in the French Alps.

headline: The 9/11 Survivor Tree Returns Home
abstract: An emotional journey of caring for a wounded Callery pear tree ended when it was replanted at the National September 11 Memorial plaza.
lead_paragraph: For five years, I have been documenting the design and creation of the landscaping at the National September 11 Memorial plaza, the grove of swamp white oak trees planted in a green roof that shelters the 9/11 museum. I’ve followed the growth and progress of these 400 trees, and the stories of the men and women who tended them and designed and built the plaza, in a feature-length documentary, “The Trees.”

headline: At a Paris Museum, a Portrait of Tintin
abstract: The Musée en Herbe in Paris explores the visual world of Tintin with illustrations and objects similar to those depicted in his adventures.
lead_paragraph: The Hergé Museum was created in 2009 in the cartoonist’s native Belgium, but people will be able to see his work in Paris at the Musée en Herbe through Aug. 31.

headline: China Raids Offices of Rights Group as Crackdown on Activism Continues
abstract: Employees say the police raided the Beijing Yirenping Center, which champions gender equality and fights discrimination against people with H.I.V., hepatitis and physical disabilities.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Chinese security agents raided the offices of a leading human rights organization, according to its employees, the latest sign of the authorities’ mounting hostility toward nongovernmental groups, especially those that receive foreign funding or promote civic activism.

headline: Obama and Pope Francis to Meet at White House
abstract: President Obama will meet with Pope Francis at the White House when the pontiff visits the United States in the fall, the White House said Thursday morning.
lead_paragraph: President Obama will meet with Pope Francis at the White House when the pontiff visits the United States in the fall, the White House said Thursday morning.

headline: ‘When the Curtain Never Comes Down’ at the American Folk Art Museum
abstract: A strange and wonderful view of outsider art.
lead_paragraph: A strange and wonderful view of outsider art.

headline: 1940: Paris Subway as War Shelter
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Paris Metro acts as air-raid shelter in 1940.
lead_paragraph: While Parisians have not become completely reconciled as yet to the restrictions which the war has imposed on the Métro — their favorite means of transportation — it is beginning to be generally realized that in modern warfare the subway of a great city has functions even more important to fulfill than the mere conveyance of passengers. A recent survey reveals that the Paris Métro, on its present war-footing, is equipped to give shelter during air-raids to 300,000 persons, while maintaining traffic between 211 stations on 90 miles of tracks. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 27, 1940

headline: Review: A Strange and Wonderful View of Outsider Art
abstract: “When the Curtain Never Comes Down,” at the American Folk Art Museum, art is fresh, innovative and view-altering.
lead_paragraph: Performance art is all the rage these days, among museums, young artists and art students alike. Similarly, “performative” is the current buzzword — high praise even for traditional art objects. So it was probably inevitable that the performance-art lens would be turned on the complex realm of outsider art.

headline: Haversham Holdings to Buy BCA Marketplace for $1.8 Billion
abstract: The cash and stock transaction will take the form of a reverse merger, allowing BCA Marketplace to list its shares in London.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Haversham Holdings said on Thursday that it had agreed to buy the British used car auctioneer and reseller BCA Marketplace in a cash and stock deal for 1.2 billion pounds, or nearly $1.8 billion.

headline: South Korea Plans to Join Regional Development Bank Led by China
abstract: The United States has expressed misgivings about the proposed lender, Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, which it sees as a threat to the World Bank.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korea on Thursday became the latest American ally to announce its intention to join the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank despite Washington’s qualms about the Chinese-led regional development bank.

headline: Kevin Love Shows What He Can Do as Cavaliers See What They Can Be
abstract: Love has not always been a big part of the Cavaliers’ fun and games, but, as Wednesday’s game showed, this talented team can play even better when he is included.
lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — Kevin Love has spent large chunks of the season camped out in corners, waiting for passes that seldom arrive. It has been his traveling act with the Cleveland Cavaliers, who have no absence of scrutiny, and no player on the roster faces more of it than Love. Considering that the Cavaliers employ LeBron James, this is no small feat.

headline: Sleep Training at  8 Weeks: ‘Do You Have the Guts?’
abstract: “When we first told our in-laws what we were doing, they thought we were monsters. Now they think we’re geniuses.”
lead_paragraph: A few months ago, my husband and I took our newborn daughter to her two-month doctor’s appointment at Tribeca Pediatrics, the largest pediatric practice in New York City. We were feeling tired, but happy with our daughter’s progress. She was gaining weight, nursing like a champ, and — best of all — giving us six- to eight-hour stretches of sleep pretty consistently. When we told our pediatrician, she seemed less impressed.

headline: Collages that Challenge the Perception of Private Moments
abstract: The photographer Charlie Engman forges “a new visual language” with images from that emerge from the edges of his consciousness.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Charlie Engman forges “a new visual language” with images from that emerge from the edges of his consciousness.

keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Euro (Currency)', 'US Dollar (Currency)']
abstract: With the euro approaching parity with the dollar, it seems to be time for a shopping spree on the Continent. But currency fluctuations are complicated.
lead_paragraph: With the euro approaching parity with the United States dollar for the first time in over a decade, it’s time to dust off your passport, grab your wallet and embark on a shopping spree in Europe.

headline: A Look at Flight Recorders
abstract: Flight recorders, or the so-called black boxes, used in investigations of plane accidents since the mid-20th century have improved considerably over the years.
lead_paragraph: Flight recorders, or the so-called black boxes, used in investigations of plane accidents since the mid-20th century have improved considerably over the years.

lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney to Savannah Gutherie on “Today” on NBC, about whether he would consider being a vice presidential candidate in 2016.

headline: On Screen, Not All Artwork Is as Famous as It Appears
abstract: Wrestling real art, or some replication of it, onto the screen and capturing the works convincingly remains a knotty task.
lead_paragraph: Hanging in the London office of the production designer Suzie Davies is “The Fighting Temeraire,” an elegiac 1839 seascape by J. M. W. Turner that depicts a distinguished battleship being towed off for scrap. Ms. Davies’s painting isn’t really by Turner, of course. It isn’t really even finished.

headline: Inequality and the Marriage Crisis
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'Marriages', 'Nineteen Hundred Fifties', 'Nineteen Hundred Sixties', 'Sex', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Does a higher Gini coefficient lead to more unstable family life for the working class?
lead_paragraph: This is coming later than I’d hoped and the world has moved on, but as promised I want to take up the other frequent rebuttal to the much-debated claim that economic changes can’t explain the two-parent family’s half century of decline — the argument that it’s relative income, not absolute income, that matters most to people’s lives and hopes and aspirations, and therefore the post-1960s increase in income inequality suffices to explain the social crisis among the working class even if working-class wages themselves haven’t really fallen.

headline: ‘Mr. Bean’ Is Still Baffled, Bumbling and Beloved
abstract: A memorable character played by Rowan Atkinson endures, buoyed by a robust social media lift.
lead_paragraph: Quick: Which two television shows have the most Facebook fans?

headline: ‘Downton Abbey’ Will End After Next Season
abstract: The show’s coming sixth season will be its last.
lead_paragraph: The servants’ bells at “Downton Abbey” will soon ring for their last time, the dowager countess will dispense her final piece of tart-tongued advice, and the story of the changing fortunes of the Crawley family will come to a conclusion.

headline: Andreas Lubitz, Who Loved to Fly, Ended Up on a Mysterious and Deadly Course
abstract: The co-pilot accused of deliberately crashing a plane into the Alps passed all medical and flying tests, Lufthansa officials said.
lead_paragraph: He was 27, loved to fly and apparently raised no suspicions or showed obvious signs that he was troubled.

headline: Payday Loan Rules Proposed by Consumer Protection Agency
abstract: The rules proposed by the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau would require lenders to assess customers’ ability to repay short-term loans.
lead_paragraph: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. — The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, the agency created at President Obama’s urging in the aftermath of the financial crisis, took its most aggressive step yet on behalf of consumers on Thursday, proposing regulations to rein in short-term payday loans that often have interest rates of 400 percent or more.

headline: The Giant Retirement Community That Explains Where Americans Are Moving
keywords: ['Population', 'Census', 'Elderly', 'Retirement Communities and Assisted Living', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The Villages area in Florida shows that warmth and affordable housing have helped a pre-recession population trend reassert itself.
lead_paragraph: The Villages, Fla., an hour northwest of Orlando, may be the only retirement community that is also the center of its own census-designated statistical area. It also holds another distinction: In 2014, its population rose more quickly than that of any other census area in the United States, climbing 5.4 percent, compared with 0.7 percent for the nation as a whole.

headline: House Approves Bill on Changes to Medicare
keywords: ['Medicare', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: In a significant bipartisan move backed by President Obama, the House agreed on changing the formula for doctors’ fees and extending the Children’s Health Insurance Program.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House overwhelmingly approved sweeping changes to the Medicare program on Thursday in the most significant bipartisan policy legislation to pass through that chamber since Republicans regained a majority in 2011.

headline: The Doctor’s Rituals
abstract: Every night when I put my 6-year-old son to sleep, we go through the same routine. I do the same with my patients.
lead_paragraph: Every night when I put my 6-year-old son to sleep, we go through the same routine. At his request, I carry him upstairs, slung over my shoulder like a “sack of potatoes.” Then, I sit on his bed while he changes into his pajamas; help him brush his teeth; read exactly three stories; arrange his stuffed bunny to the right of his head and his stuffed black bear to his left; kiss him on the cheek; and finally tell him that I love him and say goodnight. But he will not return my parting words until we have the following exchange.

headline: Masha & the Bear
abstract: Russian hospitality in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Russian hospitality in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

headline: Drink Up ... or Else
abstract: At Masha & the Bear in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn, Russian hospitality is on full display.
lead_paragraph: In the time of Peter the Great, the czar’s chief of police trained a bear to offer visitors a cup of pepper brandy. Down it, and you were ushered in; fail, and you were mauled (or “hugged,” as one 19th-century account delicately put it).

headline: Jeb Bush’s Foundation Offers Online Courses on Common Core
abstract: Jeb Bush’s education foundation is offering classes to policy-makers in how to communicate about Common Core educational standards.
lead_paragraph: Jeb Bush has made it clear that he has no intention of shying away from his support for the Common Core education standards, which are widely derided by many Republicans. But the education foundation he started is going further, offering classes to policy-makers in how to communicate about standards, including referring people to materials that support the Common Core.

headline: Iraqi Defense Minister Visits Air Base
abstract: Khalid al-Obaidi, the Iraqi defense minister, visited an air base in Baghdad as Iraqi Sukhoi-25 fighter bombers took off for what were said to be bombing runs over Tikrit.
lead_paragraph: Khalid al-Obaidi, the Iraqi defense minister, visited an air base in Baghdad as Iraqi Sukhoi-25 fighter bombers took off for what were said to be bombing runs over Tikrit.

headline: Taking Netanyahu Seriously
abstract: The Israeli Prime Minister is walking back from his comments about Arab voters, but he’ll have to do more than that.
lead_paragraph: Many Israeli politicians, including some normally critical of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, as well as a number of American congressmen and analysts, have expressed surprise that President Obama is not backing away from his opprobrium of the Israeli leader over comments he made during Israel’s recent election campaign rejecting a two-state solution and portraying Arab voters as a threat.

headline: Associates Offer Details About Co-Pilot
abstract: The chief executive of Lufthansa and members of the LSC Westerwald flight club, where Andreas Lubitz had been a member, discussed the Germanwings co-pilot’s past.
lead_paragraph: The chief executive of Lufthansa and members of the LSC Westerwald flight club, where Andreas Lubitz had been a member, discussed the Germanwings co-pilot’s past.

headline: 1965: Civil Rights Worker Is Slain
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Arrests follow a civil rights worker, Viola G. Liuzzo’s death in 1965.
lead_paragraph: Televised statement by President Lyndon B. Johnson on the arrest of four Ku Klux Klan members in 1965. The LBJ Library.

headline: Germanwings Crash: How the Lock on the Cockpit Door Works
abstract: A summary of an Airbus video that describes how to lock and unlock the cockpit door.
lead_paragraph: A summary of an Airbus video that describes how to lock and unlock the cockpit door.

headline: Cooperman’s Omega Advisors Receives Subpoenas
abstract: The S.E.C. and the U.S. attorney’s office in New Jersey are seeking information on the hedge fund’s trading of specific securities, Leon Cooperman said.
lead_paragraph: Omega Advisors, the $9 billion hedge fund founded by the billionaire investor Leon G. Cooperman, has been subpoenaed by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the United States attorney’s office in New Jersey, according to a letter the hedge fund sent to investors.

headline: New Orleans Takes a Trip to Broadway in ‘Airline Highway’
abstract: Lisa D’Amour’s huge, atmospheric party of a play features bartenders, hustlers, strippers and other denizens of the city.
lead_paragraph: Miss Ruby wants to attend her own funeral, and since she lives in New Orleans, where such affairs are less likely to be full of glum ritual than probably anywhere on the planet, who could blame her? A burlesque performer, she’s one of the many eccentrics in “Airline Highway, ” a huge, atmospheric party of a play featuring bartenders, hustlers, strippers and other denizens of this city, which has a knack of inspiring artists to wax poetic (See David Simon’s HBO series “Treme”). In “Airline Highway” — a reference to the route connecting the suburban airport to the city — the playwright Lisa D’Amour takes a look at characters often ignored on Broadway, where the show begins previews on April 1. Joe Mantello, a two-time Tony-winning director, guides a cast that includes Julie White (a Tony winner for “The Little Dog Laughed”) and Judith Roberts, who plays Miss Ruby, a role she originated at the Steppenwolf Theater Company in Chicago, where the production began. (Samuel J. Friedman Theater, 261 West 47th Street, 212-239-6200.)

headline: Bank of America Chief Executive Took 7% Pay Cut in 2014
abstract: Brian T. Moynihan, the bank’s chief executive, was paid $13 million, slightly less than the pay of the firm’s investment bank head, Thomas K. Montag.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America’s chief executive, Brian T. Moynihan, took a 7 percent pay cut in 2014, as the giant bank faced mounting legal costs related to government investigations into the sale of mortgage investments leading up to the financial crisis.

headline: Molly Ringwald on Her Inspirations: Films, Singers and Even a Kids’ Cartoon
abstract: To celebrate the 30th anniversary re-release of “The Breakfast Club,” the actress shared her most formative influences with T.
lead_paragraph: To celebrate the 30th anniversary re-release of “The Breakfast Club,” the actress shared her most formative influences with T.

headline: Needle Exchange Is Allowed After H.I.V. Outbreak in an Indiana County
keywords: ['Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Hypodermic Needles and Syringes', 'Pain-Relieving Drugs']
abstract: Dozens of cases attributed to intravenous drug use in a southeastern Indiana county led Gov. Mike Pence to declare a state of emergency.
lead_paragraph: An outbreak of H.I.V. in southeastern Indiana prompted the governor on Thursday to declare a public health emergency as officials worked to stop the spread of the virus that causes AIDS.

headline: New Plays By Baker, Hudes Will Be Part of Signature Season
abstract: The theater’s 2015-16 roster also includes a new play by Naomi Wallace and the return of the clown show “Old Hats.”
lead_paragraph: The Signature Theater will stage world premieres of new works by two Pulitzer Prize-winning playwrights in 2015-16, the 25th and final season for its founding artistic director, James Houghton.

headline: Training Video on Cockpit Locking System
abstract: A training video produced in 2002 by Airbus shows the workings and features of the reinforced cockpit door, similar to the one on the Germanwings plane that crashed in the French Alps this week.
lead_paragraph: A training video produced in 2002 by Airbus shows the workings and features of the reinforced cockpit door, similar to the one on the Germanwings plane that crashed in the French Alps this week.

headline: Five Stage Actors Recall Memorable Preview Performances
abstract: Veanne Cox, Ruthie Ann Miles, Jason Danieley, Judy Gold and Ciara Renee talk about early performances of shows they’ve acted in.
lead_paragraph: It’s exciting to be in the crowd for a first preview performance, what with friends and family cheering extra loud while the director paces and takes notes from the back of the house. But what’s it like up on stage? Memorable — sometimes for the wrong reasons, as these reminiscences from five actors attest.

headline: Stage Shows Are Most Alive at the First Preview
abstract: Theater is always full of chance-taking and excitement, never more so than the first time a show has a preview.
lead_paragraph: Of all the nights to go to a show, the first preview is my favorite. The energy in the room is high, and whatever surprises the performance holds won’t yet have been spoiled by reviews written by people like me.

headline: With an Eye on Its New Streaming Service, HBO Will Show a Daily Vice Newscast
abstract: No start date was given for the new half-hour program from Vice Media, the Brooklyn-based company, which already has a newsmagazine series on HBO.
lead_paragraph: HBO, the premium entertainment network, is strengthening its relationship with Vice, the maverick media company and news organization.

headline: An Update: A Voice for Gay Marriage, Now Wed
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Bob Page, who took a lonely stand against a North Carolina constitutional amendment banning same-sex marriage, married his longtime partner on Wednesday — in North Carolina.
lead_paragraph: In 2012, I wrote a column about  Bob Page, a lonely voice against a constitutional amendment banning gay marriage in North Carolina. Mr. Page’s company, Replacements Ltd., a used china and tableware retailer, was the only one in the state to take a public stand against the ban.

headline: Reducing Risks After the Germanwings Crash
abstract: Requiring that two people be in the cockpit at all times during flight, as many airlines already do, is a sensible step.
lead_paragraph: There is a lot we still don’t know about the tragic crash of the Germanwings plane in France. But what we do know suggests that airlines can take steps to reduce the risk of pilots deliberately or inadvertently crashing a plane.

headline: ’50 Shades’  Director Departs Sequel
abstract: Sam Taylor-Johnson announced she would not return for the follow-up to the blockbuster bondage film.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – “Fifty Shades of Grey,” in part, is about a woman who finds herself in a toxic relationship and has the courage to walk out the door.

headline: Public Health Emergency in Indiana
abstract: Gov. Mike Pence, Republican of Indiana, declared a public health emergency in Scott County on Wednesday after 79 new cases of H.I.V. were confirmed.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Mike Pence, Republican of Indiana, declared a public health emergency in Scott County on Wednesday after 79 new cases of H.I.V. were confirmed.

headline: A Return to Classic Napa Style
abstract: Three bottles reflect Napa’s longtime commitment to cabernet made in classic style.
lead_paragraph: Napa Valley cabernet sauvignon is America’s best-known wine. It may also be the most divisive.

headline: Verbatim: Schock Says So Long to Congress
abstract: Representative Aaron Schock, Republican of Illinois, who decorated his House office as if it were the set of “Downton Abbey,” made his final speech on Capitol Hill on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Representative Aaron Schock, who resigned last week amid questions over improper spending, giving his final speech to Congress.

headline: Ebola Virus in Latest Outbreak Does Not Show Unusual Mutations, Study Finds
abstract: The rate of mutation appears normal, research suggests, and the high death toll stems from where the epidemic erupted, at the intersection of three vulnerable nations.
lead_paragraph: Fears that the current Ebola epidemic, the deadliest in history, was caused by a more lethal, fast-moving or easily transmissible virus than in previous outbreaks appear to be unfounded, according to a new study.

headline: Your Next Lesson: Muscadet
abstract: Yes, Muscadet wines from the Pays Nantais area go beautifully with oysters, but they can do so much more.
lead_paragraph: Next up is a wine that could not be more different from Napa cabernet, Muscadet. Instead of a powerful red often considered among the world’s best wines and priced accordingly, Muscadet is an unassuming white too often stereotyped as simple, cheap and good only when young and with oysters.

headline: In the Senate, a Day of Votes That Don’t Count
abstract: The Senate has opened its well to an unlimited number of amendments to the budget blueprint for the coming fiscal year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah, wants to make sure children do not munch edible marijuana. Senator David Vitter, Republican of Louisiana, wants to prevent “Washington elites” from forcing Americans to give up their paper dollar bills and use coins like Europeans.

headline: Aerial Footage Shows Oklahoma Tornado
abstract: Aerial footage shows a tornado making its way through Moore, Okla., on Wednesday night.
lead_paragraph: Aerial footage shows a tornado making its way through Moore, Okla., on Wednesday night.

headline: Our Sixth Annual Found Poem Challenge
abstract: The bad news? We won’t be judging the challenge this year, or declaring winners. The good news? The Learning Network is hopefully getting an upgraded commenting system soon. We hope you’ll still participate and post your poems; we’ll be posting our reactions in May in lieu of formal judging.
lead_paragraph: Here are our Reflections on Our Sixth Annual Found Poetry Challenge, with shout-outs to the work of 15 student-poets who particularly impressed us.

headline: With Car Dealerships’ Ranks Thinned, the Survivors Thrive
abstract: Battered by the recession, the auto sales industry is recovering, in part through consolidation and by embracing new information technology.
lead_paragraph: ONLY a few years ago, in the depths of the recession, the local car dealership seemed to be living on borrowed time. Franchises were closing by the hundreds as buyers stayed away from what were increasingly seen as outmoded showrooms.

headline: Living With Cancer: Clinical Trials Looking for Patients
abstract: A drug obtained through a clinical trial appears to have extended my life. So why do many trials fail to enroll sufficient patients?
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s initiative to advance personalized medicine depends on the sort of breakthroughs in cell biology that have produced cancer drugs like the one extending my life. Yet very few adults with cancer enroll in clinical trials. Why do many trials fail to enroll sufficient patients, when scientists now test less debilitating therapies than those commonly used?

headline: Brooklyn Bridge Park to Display Danish Artist
abstract: Fire-engine-red benches that spike, arch and undulate are among the whimsical installations coming to Brooklyn Bridge Park.
lead_paragraph: Fire-engine-red benches that spike, arch and undulate. A room with walls of rising water. A labyrinth of mirrored panels.

headline: High Risk but Little Reward for Whistle-Blowers
abstract: When Wall Street whistle-blowers come forward, they are too often left to twist in the wind before being fired, calling their action into question.
lead_paragraph: For the last few months, a disconnect has emerged between Wall Street regulators and prosecutors on the one hand and potential Wall Street whistle-blowers on the other. The authorities have publicly encouraged people who see wrongdoing on Wall Street to come forward and talk with them about it. They insist that witnessing wrongdoing and doing nothing about it is every bit as bad as committing the wrongdoing itself.

headline: Other People’s Happiness
abstract: Maybe the appeal of antidepressants is that they give us access to what we’ve been taught is the best club on earth.
lead_paragraph: This is the fifth installment of Going Off, a series of Anxiety posts chronicling the author’s attempt to wean off the medications she takes for depression, anxiety and insomnia.

headline: National Guardsman Accused of Trying to Join ISIS in Libya
abstract: Federal authorities arrested the 22-year-old man at a Chicago-area airport, saying he was also helping plan an attack on an American military base.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The federal authorities in Illinois arrested an Army National Guardsman who they say tried to travel to Libya to fight on behalf of the Islamic State and was helping his cousin plot an attack on an American military base, the Justice Department said on Thursday.

headline: Advice on Spreading Good News Carefully
abstract: Also, questions about sharing a name with a pet, an inconsiderate suitemate and whether to say thank you for a thank-you gift.
lead_paragraph: My husband and I were given extremely low odds of getting pregnant, even with various fertility interventions. During that time, I learned how painful it can be to hear about other people’s pregnancies — like a grenade being thrown at you. Now, I am on the other side of things. I am almost at the end of my first trimester of pregnancy. I want to be open with friends but sensitive to the fact that our joy may cause others pain. What is the best way to deal with this, especially with people with fertility issues?

headline: Bank of England Warns of Risks From Greece and Market Liquidity
abstract: Still, the central bank said that credit growth in Britain remained moderate and that its banks were increasingly resilient.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Bank of England said Thursday that Britain’s stability continued to be threatened by international risks, including Greece’s financing needs, China’s slowdown and potentially inadequate market liquidity.

headline: Reading The Times with Mohsin Hamid
keywords: ['Asylum, Right of', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'Books and Literature', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'News and News Media', 'Newspapers', 'Terrorism', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Mohsin Hamid, an author, describes his experience reading The Times.
lead_paragraph: Mohsin Hamid is the author of three novels and, most recently, a book of essays, “Discontent and Its Civilizations.” A former New Yorker, he now lives in Lahore.

headline: ‘Chamberlain/Prouvé’ at Gagosian Gallery
abstract: A single show highlights John Chamberlain and Jean Prouvé, two geniuses who used metal in new if nearly opposite ways.
lead_paragraph: An idiosyncratic show combining the work of two geniuses who used metal in new if nearly opposite ways needs to be carefully balanced. Displaying 12 crushed car-body sculptures by the American sculptor John Chamberlain (1927-2011) in and around two prefab structures by the French architect-designer Jean Prouvé (1901-1984) doesn’t quite do the trick.

headline: Molly Ringwald on Her Inspirations: Films, Singers and Even a Kids’ Cartoon
abstract: To celebrate the 30th anniversary re-release of “The Breakfast Club,” the actress shared her most formative influences with T.
lead_paragraph: There are few actors more iconic or more identifiable with a specific pop-cultural moment than Molly Ringwald. Her performances in the classic 1980s John Hughes films “Sixteen Candles,” “Pretty in Pink” and “The Breakfast Club” have created the enduring image of teen ennui for multiple generations. This week, “The Breakfast Club” is being re-released in select theaters to mark its 30th anniversary. (Fun fact: Ringwald picked out her costumes for the film.)

headline: Gaetano Pesce: ‘One-of-a-Kind Iconic Works, 1967-2015’
abstract: A Noah’s ark of eccentric creatures, characters and objects — animal, human, animistic — surreptitiously delivering social commentary.
lead_paragraph: At Gaetano Pesce‘s solo exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art in 1979, his cartoonish, riotously colored lamps, vases, chairs and drawings dealt a body blow to the sleek Modernist Bauhaus objects enshrined in the museum’s vitrines. To judge by the generous show of 90 objects and drawings at the Allouche Gallery in SoHo, this Italian iconoclast has expanded his irreverent critique, humanizing the domestic landscape with even more sass, color and social comment. The many octopus vases, centipede tables, rag chairs and lamps with ears — all cast in resins that bounce when dropped — amount to a mini career retrospective of his considerable influence in design and design theory.

headline: An Itemized Marriage Proposal via Voice Mail
abstract: After an early romance, a series of chance encounters and an onslaught of mail, a suitor makes an unusual but clear-cut offer.

headline: East Village Explosion Ignites Fire, Fells Buildings and Injures at Least 19
abstract: A blast caused two buildings to collapse and left at least 19 people injured.
lead_paragraph: A powerful explosion in Lower Manhattan on Thursday caused two buildings to collapse and ignited a large fire that quickly spread to neighboring buildings, leaving at least 19 people injured. At least one person was reported missing.

headline: Saudi-Backed Forces Gain Momentum
abstract: Annotated maps showing the Houthi rebels’ drive south, U.S. airstrikes and historical divisions.
lead_paragraph: Annotated maps showing the Houthi rebels’ drive south, U.S. airstrikes and historical divisions.

headline: At Goethe-Institut New York, a Free Taste of Germany (Beer, Too)
abstract: The cultural arm of the German government will welcome visitors to its new home on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Germany’s economy powers the eurozone. Its citizens enjoy an enviable standard of living, with a generous social-welfare system that dates back to the time of Bismarck. The German national team won the World Cup last year. All that, and Berlin is the new Prague, the city where artists, students and bohemians from all over the world want to live.

headline: A Crowd-Funded Sequel for ‘Super Troopers’
abstract: Broken Lizard, the comedy team behind the original film, raised $2 million in just over a day.
lead_paragraph: A sequel to the film “Super Troopers” is in the works, thanks to a highly successful crowd-funding campaign on Indiegogo that hit its $2 million goal in just over 24 hours.

headline: Sri Lankan President’s Brother Is Wounded in Ax Attack
abstract: The police said the assailant of Priyantha Sirisena, the brother of President Maithripala Sirisena, later surrendered.
lead_paragraph: The brother of President Maithripala Sirisena of Sri Lanka was seriously injured on Thursday when an assailant attacked him with an ax, a police spokesman said.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘While We’re Young’
abstract: The writer and director Noah Baumbach narrates a sequence from his film featuring Ben Stiller and Adam Driver.
lead_paragraph: The writer and director Noah Baumbach narrates a sequence from his film featuring Ben Stiller and Adam Driver.

headline: Traevon Jackson Carries an N.B.A. Pedigree, but Has Flourished Under His Mother’s Eye
abstract: Those who ascribe guard Traevon Jackson’s basketball skills to his N.B.A. father have little understanding of how he transformed himself into a starting guard for top-seeded Wisconsin.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The people in the stands who chanted, “Your dad was better,” at the basketball games of a young Traevon Jackson knew as much about his biological father, the former N.B.A. player Jim Jackson, as he did.

headline: Controversial Indiana Law Puts Pressure on N.C.A.A. and Other Leagues
keywords: ['Basketball (College)', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Discrimination', 'NCAA Basketball Championships (Men)']
abstract: A new law in Indiana allowing businesses to refuse service to same-sex couples may force sports officials to evaluate whether to hold major events in Indianapolis, which is hosting the Final Four next week.
lead_paragraph: A new law in Indiana allowing businesses to refuse service to same-sex couples in the name of religious freedom has put sports officials under pressure to evaluate whether to hold major events in Indianapolis.

abstract: Deep into the island nation’s hill country.
lead_paragraph: Deep into the island nation’s hill country.

headline: A History of Crashes Caused by Pilots’ Intentional Acts
abstract: Crashes caused intentionally by pilots are very rare but not unheard of.
lead_paragraph: Crashes caused intentionally by pilots are very rare but not unheard of.

abstract: Photos from Yemen, Ukraine, Poland and India
lead_paragraph: Photos from Yemen, Ukraine, Poland and India

headline: Facebook Sees Oculus Virtual Reality Headsets Shipping This Year
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media', 'Virtual Reality (Computers)']
abstract: Michael Schroepfer, Facebook’s vice president of engineering, told developers that the company’s Oculus VR unit would get its PC-based virtual reality headset to consumers this year. That puts a lot of pressure on Oculus.
lead_paragraph: Facebook, which bought Oculus VR for $2 billion last year, has been dancing around Wall Street’s questions about when Oculus, a developer of virtual reality technology, was going to start bringing in some real money.

headline: March 26, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Yemen, Ukraine, Poland and India.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Yemen, Ukraine, Poland and India.

headline: Discovering Les Lalanne Anew in a Madison Cox-Designed Fun House
abstract: Now on view at Paul Kasmin Gallery, a maze of an installation offers a new perspective on old works.
lead_paragraph: Now on view at Paul Kasmin Gallery, a maze of an installation offers a new perspective on old works.

headline: Have Recent Plane Crashes Affected Your Decision to Fly?
abstract: Has the news of another airplane tragedy caused you to change your travel plans? Have you decided to use another means of transportation?
lead_paragraph: Traveling by air is generally very safe, and airplane crashes have been becoming less and less frequent. As Matt Beardmore reported in The Times, there were fewer crashes around the world in 2014 than in any year since 1927, according to the Aircraft Crashes Record Office in Geneva.

headline: Warren Buffett and 3G May Have One Barrier to Even Bigger Deals
abstract: Merging Kraft and Heinz will take up 3G’s attention for some time. But when 3G is again ready to make a deal, Warren Buffett will be, too.
lead_paragraph: Warren Buffett and 3G Capital have created a fearsome merger and acquisition machine. The deal on Wednesday to merge the consumer food giants Kraft and H.J. Heinz, worth some $80 billion, is the boldest collaboration yet between the Sage of Omaha and the Brazilian investors behind Anheuser-Busch InBev, after earlier swoops on Heinz and Tim Hortons. The only barrier to even bigger deals may be 3G’s capacity for new projects.

headline: Asia Week New York Rings Up $360 Million in Art Sales
abstract: The nine-day event saw about $270 million in auction sales and $90 million in gallery sales.
lead_paragraph: Sales for Asia Week New York, a nine-day event that ended on March 21, totaled $360 million, up 80 percent from last year’s total of $200 million. About $270 million came from auction sales, led by the sale of Robert Hatfield Ellsworth’s Asian art collection at Christie’s, which brought in more than $124 million. The 42 galleries involved in Asia Week sold about $90 million worth of art, up from $78 million last year.

headline: For Freshmen, the Best Position May Be on the Sideline
abstract: Restoring freshman ineligibility — creating a student-first mentality on campus and having athletes take a year off from the rat race — could be a blessing.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Willie Cauley-Stein was surrounded Wednesday afternoon, answering the standard questions about the Kentucky basketball team’s unbeaten streak and its next big game, against tough-talking West Virginia on Thursday night.

headline: New York’s All-Male Oligarchy
abstract: The state’s budget decisions are made by four men in a back room. A woman deserves a seat at their table.
lead_paragraph: In a state of nearly 20 million people, the decisions about how to spend $150 billion in taxpayer money this year come down to four men in a back room.  By definition, that is an oligarchy, government policy controlled by a small group of people.

headline: Review: ‘Scenes for a New Heritage’ at the Museum of Modern Art
abstract: MoMA’s latest exhibition of works from its permanent collection features videos, installations, sculptures, drawings, prints and photographs by more than 30 artists during the past three decades.
lead_paragraph: “Scenes for a New Heritage: Contemporary Art From the Collection” is an unusually optimistic-sounding title for the Museum of Modern Art’s latest installation of works from its permanent collection. Filling the second-floor contemporary galleries, the show features videos, installations, sculptures, drawings, prints and photographs produced by more than 30 artists during the past three decades.

headline: A New Hike Explores the Bay of Fundy
abstract: World Expeditions is offering a new hiking trip that includes four days on the less-populated portion of the Fundy Footpath in Canada.
lead_paragraph: Bay of Fundy Trek, a new hiking trip offered this summer by World Expeditions, takes in the highlights of one of the last remaining stretches of coastal wilderness on the east coast of North America.

headline: Discovering Les Lalanne Anew in a Madison Cox-Designed Fun House
abstract: Now on view at Paul Kasmin Gallery, a maze of an installation offers a new perspective on old works.
lead_paragraph: “I loved Les Lalanne’s work before I met them,” the gallerist Paul Kasmin swoons about the artistic duo Claude and François-Xavier Lalanne, known simply as Les Lalanne. “I loved it even more after I met them.” Kasmin encountered and began representing the duo in 2006, and the last time he showed their work was in 2013, at a Shell Gas station on 10th Avenue: Sheep sculptures were installed on an Astroturf grass pasture, exposed to the elements and the public. This year, he’s tapping into the beloved French sculptors’ more mysterious side by bringing things indoors and recruiting the elusive garden magician Madison Cox to bring to life a maze of an exhibition.

headline: Review: In ‘52 Tuesdays,’ What a Difference a Year Makes
abstract: Sophie Hyde’s film uses unconventional methods to tell the story of a mother’s gender transition.
lead_paragraph: There’s very little about the Australian drama “52 Tuesdays” that could be considered conventional. Not the characters, all of whom are played by nonprofessional actors. Not the story, which concerns the effects of a mother’s gender transition on her teenage daughter. And not the filmmaking, whose rigid structure — once a week for a year, only on Tuesdays — was decided before any other element.

headline: Lynn Hershman Leeson: ‘Origins of the Species’
abstract: Before Cindy Sherman was creating fictional histories for the camera, Ms. Hershman Leeson was living one.
lead_paragraph: The micro-survey of Lynn Hershman Leeson’s art at the new Bridget Donahue Gallery is a tip-of-the-iceberg event with the potential force of a stealth explosive. Ms. Hershman Leeson began her career in the San Francisco Bay Area in the culturally roiling early 1960s. Like many young artists then, she identified as a painter, but one with multimedia extensions and futuristic ambitions. Almost from the start she was also working in sculpture that had a cyborglike dimension. The small assemblage in the show called “Breathing Machine II” (1968/2011), consisting of a wax face obscured by a wig, butterflies and feathers, sighs and coughs when you draw near.

headline: Documenting the Blues in the Mississippi Delta
abstract: A love of the blues led Margo Cooper to explore the Mississippi Delta, where she has photographed and interviewed the people behind the music.
lead_paragraph: A love of the blues led Margo Cooper to explore the Mississippi Delta, where she has photographed and interviewed the people behind the music.

headline: Hayv Kahraman: ‘How Iraqi Are You?’
abstract: The artist builds on the refined figuration of Persian miniatures that are part of her cultural background as an Iraqi.
lead_paragraph: Reviving once great artistic styles can be a fraught pursuit, whether or not they are part of an artist’s cultural heritage. Such styles must be transformed into something personal and contemporary that ideally also survives comparison with its inspiration. In her second solo show at this gallery, subtitled “How Iraqi Are You?” Hayv Kahraman largely pulls off this difficult feat, building on the refined figuration of Persian miniatures that are part of her Iraqi background. In Ms. Kahraman’s hands the delicacy and stylization of the source are writ large and on raw linen — evoking the pages of a Persian album — and complicated with allusions to other times, places and styles. The paintings depict pairs and groups of nearly identical women who may or may not be in a harem. Shown in conversation or listening to one of their number, these women have pale skin, gestures and becalmed features that recall both the female subjects of Renaissance painting and the powdered geisha of Japanese woodblocks. Their articulated hands seem puppetlike. Their largely strapless gowns and black bouffants seem of recent American vintage even as the fabric patterns of their gowns elaborate a veritable lexicon of Arabic geometric decoration. Ms. Kahraman has devised several stylizations of her own, especially in the ways the fabrics drape and overlap while remaining flat, and in details like eyebrows and those dark bouffants (which, for viewers of a certain age may recall Lady Bird Johnson’s hairdos).

headline: Steve Keister: ‘USOs: 1978-1981’
abstract: With their snazzy, cheap surface treatments, these works project attitudes of skeptical irreverence about art’s utopian claims.
lead_paragraph: In the late 1970s and early ’80s, Steve Keister produced a startling series of abstract sculptures, which he displayed overhead in galleries, hanging them by nearly invisible filaments. Aptly called “Unidentified Suspended Objects” (USOs), they consist of flat, geometric wooden elements assembled into angular, planar volumes with their outer surfaces clad in all kinds of inexpensive materials, including rubber, fake fur, leather and colored plastics. He painted their interiors, visible through skewed openings, with fluorescent colors so that they seemed to glow from within. This exhibition presents eight pieces. They hover close to the ceiling like a flock of strange birds or stylish drones.

headline: Review: ‘The American People, Volume 1’ by Larry Kramer Retells History With Passion
abstract: Many histories of gay men in America begin with the Stonewall riots, but Mr. Kramer’s novel rewinds to prehistoric monkeys swapping viruses in the jungle.
lead_paragraph: The playwright, novelist and gay activist Larry Kramer’s new novel, “The American People, Volume 1: Search for My Heart,” is a bit like Mr. Kramer himself: blustery, sentimental, embittered and unlikely to take no for an answer. At 775 pages, it’s a grand diva of a book, a wheezing jukebox of filthy jokes, political hit jobs, killing gossip, love songs and fluky mutterings.

headline: Review: ‘The Barber’ Stars Scott Glenn as a Suspected Serial Killer
abstract: The film, directed by Basel Owies, finds the son of a police detective searching for a murderer that his father couldn’t convict.
lead_paragraph: Scott Glenn handles the balancing act required of him in “The Barber” with his usual skill, playing a guy who might be just a harmless haircutter or might be a serial murderer with a habit of burying young women alive. The film, though, delivers its plot twists muddily and doesn’t really distinguish itself from the countless other creepy-killer tales out there.

headline: Weekend Entertainments From the Archives of The New York Times
abstract: A century ago, Coney Island’s Dreamland and Luna Park opened.
lead_paragraph: 111 YEARS AGO

headline: ‘Rinehart’s Studio’ Puts a 19th-Century Sculptor’s Career in Perspective
abstract: Nineteenth-century Rome teemed with American sculptors, competing for tourist and expat commissions.
lead_paragraph: Nineteenth-century Rome teemed with American sculptors, competing for tourist and expat commissions. Customers wanted realistic portraits of themselves, carved from stone, as well as statues of literary figures, politicians, gods and goddesses. By the mid-20th century, however, the works were considered so fusty that some descendants of original owners simply destroyed them.

headline: Buildings Collapse From Fire in East Village
abstract: A powerful explosion on Second Avenue near Seventh Street caused two buildings to collapse and damaged two others on Thursday afternoon.
lead_paragraph: A powerful explosion on Second Avenue near Seventh Street caused two buildings to collapse and damaged two others on Thursday afternoon.

headline: Things to Do on Long Island, March 29 to April 4, 2015
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: New Hampshire Legislature ‘Honors’ Fourth Graders After a Real Civics Lesson
abstract: A fourth-grade class proposing a bill was met with vitriol and mockery, then “honored.”
lead_paragraph: It was an introduction to politics that a true cynic of a parent could appreciate: When fourth graders from Lincoln Akerman School went to the New Hampshire Statehouse to watch the House debate a measure their class had proposed, they were met with mockery, vitriol and the hijacking of their bill for the purpose of grandstanding on another issue.

headline: Abel Ferrara Fights to Stop Re-Edited Strauss-Kahn Film
abstract: “Welcome to New York” is being released, but it’s not the film Mr. Ferrara, the director, made.
lead_paragraph: “WELCOME TO NEW YORK,” Abel Ferrara’s fictionalized account of the scandal involving Dominique Strauss-Kahn and a Manhattan hotel maid who accused him of rape, was screened last year at the Cannes Film Festival. The Hollywood Reporter called the movie, starring Gérard Depardieu as the Strauss-Kahn figure, “racy,” “uproarious” and a “rather fascinating bit of artistic self-indulgence that’s both made by, and about, self-indulgent men.”

headline: Clinton Hiring Raises Question About Future Openings
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s recent hiring of campaign staff raises the question of what will happen to people at some of the groups working on her behalf.
lead_paragraph: No other potential presidential candidate has a campaign operation the size of the one Hillary Rodham Clinton has built ahead of the 2016 race, with outside groups, consultants and political staff members already working to support her soon-to-be-announced bid.

headline: Homeland Security Official Didn’t Break Law on Visas, Inspector Says
abstract: Though he appeared not to have acted criminally, Alejandro Mayorkas, the department’s deputy secretary, was found to have created a perception of favoritism by expediting visas for well-known Democrats.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The inspector general of the Department of Homeland Security told a House committee on Thursday that he did not believe “there was criminal activity involved” when the head of the United States Citizenship and Immigration Services agency directly intervened to expedite the consideration of visas for foreign investors with close ties to prominent Democrats.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Review: ‘Home,’ With Rihanna and Jim Parsons
abstract: Jim Parsons and Rihanna star in this animated film about an intergalactic friendship.
lead_paragraph: The short, squat creatures that turn up in animated movies may all be starting to run together in your mind, which makes finding a distinctive voice for such characters all the more important. The creators of “Home” made an inspired choice in that regard for their little hero, recruiting Jim Parsons of “The Big Bang Theory” for the job, and they made another by pairing him with the pop star Rihanna.

headline: Walker Denies Remarks Indicating Change in Immigration Stance
abstract: Gov. Scott Walker told a private gathering of New Hampshire Republicans this month that he supported a pathway to legal status – but not citizenship – for undocumented immigrants in the United States, according to the chairman of the state’s Republican Party.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, a possible candidate for president in 2016, told a private gathering of New Hampshire Republicans this month that he supported a pathway to legal status — but not citizenship — for undocumented immigrants in the United States, according to the chairwoman of the state’s Republican Party.

headline: Videos Show Fire in East Village
abstract: Witness videos show the scene in the East Village after an explosion caused a fire on Second Avenue, affecting neighboring buildings.
lead_paragraph: Witness videos show the scene in the East Village after an explosion caused a fire on Second Avenue, affecting neighboring buildings.

headline: Citigroup Report Chides Law Firms for Silence on Hackings
abstract: The report said the reluctance of most law firms to publicly discuss breaches and the lack of reporting requirements made it impossible to determine if such attacks were increasing.
lead_paragraph: Every month it seems another American company reports being a victim of a hacking that results in the theft of internal or customer information. But the legal profession almost never publicly discloses a breach.

headline: Review: In ‘My Italian Secret,’ a Champion Cyclist Saves Jews From Nazis
keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Tour de France (Bicycle Race)', 'Bicycles and Bicycling', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Jews and Judaism', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Rescues']
abstract: Narrated by Isabella Rossellini, this documentary tells the stories of heroic Italians, including the Tour de France winner Gino Bartali, who smuggled forged papers in his bike frame.
lead_paragraph: “My Italian Secret: The Forgotten Heroes” compiles the stories of Jews who lived or sought refuge in Italy during World War II and the gentiles who helped them, particularly after German troops occupied the northern half of the country in 1943.

headline: Sally Draper Through the Seasons
abstract: Here is the astonishing transformation of Sally from an adorable girl of 6 with a few cameo scenes to one of the most compelling characters and acclaimed actors on the show.
lead_paragraph: Here is the astonishing transformation of Sally from an adorable girl of 6 with a few cameo scenes to one of the most compelling characters and acclaimed actors on the show.

headline: Jason Alexander Will Succeed Larry David in ‘Fish in the Dark’
abstract: The comedy’s Broadway run has been extended through July 19.
lead_paragraph: As cast changes go, this one was close to inevitable: On June 9, Jason Alexander will succeed Larry David as Norman Drexel in “Fish in the Dark,” and extend the show’s run at the Cort Theater through July 19.

headline: Listings for March 27-April 2
abstract: A guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.
lead_paragraph: For news about comedy, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Growing Up on ‘Mad Men’: A Conversation With Matthew Weiner and Kiernan Shipka
abstract: The show’s creator and the child star who transformed into an acclaimed young actress discuss the show, the role and the future.
lead_paragraph: Matthew Weiner, the creator, writer, producer and occasional director of “Mad Men,” paid no heed to the old showbiz adage: “Never work with children or animals.” And it’s a good thing. Otherwise, television audiences would have missed out on the astonishing transformation of Sally Draper, the character played by the actress Kiernan Shipka, from an adorable girl of 6 with a few cameo scenes to one of the most compelling characters and acclaimed actors on the show.

headline: ‘While We’re Young’ (With Movie Trailer): Noah Baumbach Discusses a Scene
abstract: The writer and director talks about his comedy, including a scene with Ben Stiller and Adam Driver.
lead_paragraph: In “While We’re Young,” the latest comedy from the writer and director Noah Baumbach, Ben Stiller and Naomi Watts play Josh and Cornelia, a middle-aged married couple restless for a change. As they grapple with growing older, they develop a relationship with a younger Brooklyn couple, Jamie and Darby (Adam Driver and Amanda Seyfried), and are invigorated by the couple’s fresh look on life. Much of the film’s comedy comes out of how the two couples relate to each other, appropriating elements from one another’s lives.

headline: Reading the Fine Print in the Heinz-Kraft Deal
abstract: A look under the hood at everything from the makeup of the board of directors to the payment of a dividend, and not cash, to Kraft shareholders.
lead_paragraph: The $70 billion combination of Kraft and Heinz is a big, big deal, but it is perhaps most interesting for how the parties have agreed to run the combined company.

lead_paragraph: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

abstract: A selected guide to concerts in the New York City area.
lead_paragraph: For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Gabriel Figueroa: A Cinematographer’s Luminous Art
abstract: This retrospective at El Museo del Barrio follows the path of this Mexican cinematographer, who collaborated well-known directors and emerged as an international star.
lead_paragraph: Painting with light is one way to define the cinematographer’s task; making the work of directors and actors shine is another. A director tells actors “go there, do that.” A cinematographer, who is the eye behind the camera, creates a visual atmosphere that can turn even the simplest action into drama. Sometimes an eye develops an atmospheric style so distinctive as to make any film its own.

headline: Latin American Design and Architecture Through the Years
abstract: Exhibitions at the Americas Society and the Museum of Arts and Design, and a third opening on Sunday at the Museum of Modern Art, show a region’s desire to be both local and global.
lead_paragraph: THE well-worn phrase “Mi casa es tu casa” may be a perfect expression of Latin American warmth and hospitality, but it leaves some basic questions unanswered, especially if you are interested in architecture and design. What kind of house? And what is inside that house?

headline: Brooklyn Stepfather of 2-Year-Old Is Charged With Murder
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: David Adams is accused of causing brain damage to Thaiya Spruill-Smith, whose parents had disagreed over whether to donate her organs.
lead_paragraph: A man accused of violently shaking his 2-year-old stepdaughter, leading to her death in November and a fight over her organs, was arraigned on a murder charge on Thursday after the girl’s death was ruled a homicide.

headline: Review: In ‘While We’re Young,’ a Coupling of Gen X and Y
abstract: In Noah Baumbach’s film, Ben Stiller and Naomi Watts play a couple in their 40s who become captivated by a younger pair who seem to freely embrace experience.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve seen Noah Baumbach’s “Greenberg” you may remember a scene in which the title character, played by Ben Stiller, unleashes a tirade against a roomful of 20-year-olds whom he believes have been ruined by sensitive parenting, among other things. (If you haven’t seen “Greenberg,” we need to talk). “While We’re Young,” Mr. Baumbach’s buoyant, vinegar-laced new film, is not a sequel — Mr. Stiller plays Josh, a reasonably pleasant and well-adjusted guy for a Ben Stiller character in a Noah Baumbach picture — but it does pick up where the earlier movie left off in its exploration of the fraught relations between ascendant millennials and the rapidly aging members of Generation X.

headline: Things to Do in New Jersey, March 29 to April 4, 2015
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: New Google C.F.O. Gets $70 Million Pay Package (and $7,500 to Move)
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Bonuses', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Google’s new financial chief will join the search giant in May after a long career at Morgan Stanley.
lead_paragraph: Ruth Porat, Google’s new chief financial officer, is joining a company that has more than 50,000 employees and is one of the most valuable corporations in the world. Thus, given Google is long past its early days, it’s not the kind of place that will make her a start-up billionaire.

headline: A Slice of Times Square, Always in Motion
abstract: Adam Magyar invented a way to insert motion into still images.
lead_paragraph: The miracle of photography is that it takes moving objects and makes them still. Yet in real life, motion is part of who we are, the pulse of the city around us. Adam Magyar invented a way to insert that motion into still images. What you see on this page are not block-wide streetscapes, but minutes in the life of a one-pixel-wide sliver of New York life, captured in all its chaos and motion.

headline: Fire and a Building Collapse in East Village
abstract: A powerful explosion on Second Avenue near Seventh Street caused two buildings to collapse and damaged two others on Thursday afternoon.
lead_paragraph: A powerful explosion on Second Avenue near Seventh Street caused two buildings to collapse and damaged two others on Thursday afternoon.

headline: Review: In ‘White God,’ Man Bites Dog, Dog Bites Back
abstract: Kornel Mundruczo’s movie follows a mixed-breed dog in Hungary named Hagen who is separated from his 13-year-old human owner and joins a pack.
lead_paragraph: The hand that feeds — and also brutalizes — is righteously bitten in “White God,” a Hungarian revenge fantasy that’s like nothing you’ve seen on screen before. The story is as simple as a parable, a campfire story, a children’s book: A faithful animal, separated from its loving owner, endures, suffers, struggles and resists while trying to transcend its brutal fate. The director, Kornel Mundruczo, has said that he was partly inspired by J. M. Coetzee’s devastating novel “Disgrace,” but the movie also invokes haunting animal classics like “Black Beauty” and “The Call of the Wild.”

headline: Review: ‘Get Hard,’ With Will Ferrell and Kevin Hart
abstract: The comic premise of this film could hardly be simpler: Mr. Ferrell is white. Mr. Hart, in contrast, is black.
lead_paragraph: The comic premise of “Get Hard” could hardly be simpler. Will Ferrell is white. Kevin Hart, in contrast, is black. But you don’t have to consult a Starbucks barista to know that race is a very complicated matter. It’s been a source of humor for a very long time, but which jokes are acceptable to whom is never an easy matter to determine. Somebody is likely to be offended. The trick in a movie like this one is to appear daring while playing it safe, to act provocative while not actually provoking anyone.

headline: Suicide by Plane Crash Is Rare but Not Without Precedent
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Pilots']
abstract: If Andreas Lubitz, the flight’s 27-year-old co-pilot, was determined to kill himself, he would not be the first to use an airplane as a tool for self-destruction or to kill passengers and other crew members in the process.
lead_paragraph: What goes through the mind of a pilot as he turns the nose of an airliner toward the ground and prepares for death, taking 149 other people with him?

headline: Review: Trio 3 Shows Off Its Jazz Avant-Garde Pedigree
abstract: The group’s first set at the Village Vanguard this week moved briskly through its allotted hour, propelled by cooperative forces.
lead_paragraph: One misperception about the jazz avant-garde is that it’s essentially reactive, a single-minded pushback against conventions of form. Whatever lump of truth or slander you might find in that idea, Trio 3, which plays at the Village Vanguard this week, provides scant supporting evidence for it.

headline: Movie Review: ‘White God’
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “White God.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “White God.”

headline: Review: Ibeyi, Twin Sisters and a Duo, Uses Songs to Show Roots
abstract: The many influences of Naomi and Lisa-Kaindé Díaz, siblings with backgrounds in Cuba and France, were heard in their concert at the Music Hall.
lead_paragraph: Ancient rituals reply to modern concerns in the music of Ibeyi, the duo of Naomi and Lisa-Kaindé Díaz, who performed on Wednesday night at the Music Hall of Williamsburg. They are twins born in France and steeped in the Cuban heritage of their father, Angá Díaz, who was a leading percussionist in Cuba.

headline: Jason Heyward’s Ability Seems Boundless. Soon, So May His Contract.
abstract: Heyward, a 25-year-old Cardinals outfielder with a wide range of skills, could become a free agent after this season.
lead_paragraph: JUPITER, Fla. — The most captivating thing about Jason Heyward may also be the most confounding. He could be any type of player you imagine, and it is almost time to put a price on his future.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Get Hard’
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Get Hard.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Get Hard.”
