abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “While We’re Young.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “While We’re Young.”

headline: This Week’s Movies | March 27, 2015
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “Get Hard,” “While We’re Young” and “White God.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “Get Hard,” “While We’re Young” and “White God.”

headline: Inside a Pilot’s Mind
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Pilots', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: Cockpit conduct is well regulated, but ruling out human flaws is harder.
lead_paragraph: I WORKED as a pilot for about 10 years before going back to school to become an architect. There are a few oddballs I can remember flying with, but mostly we’re just talking quirks and eccentricities. Never did I fear a colleague intended to kill himself, or everyone onboard.

headline: Orthodox Jews in Brooklyn Rush to Buy Smoke Detectors Before Sabbath
abstract: After a fire in Midwood, Brooklyn killed seven children on Saturday, there was a sense of urgency about buying smoke detectors and re-examining routines such as the way hot plates are used.
lead_paragraph: The Buzz, an electronics store in Borough Park, Brooklyn, had by Wednesday sold out of its supply of smoke detectors three times and then started a charity giveaway to distribute hundreds more.

headline: A Fight to Save Pieces of the Past as a Phoenix Enclave Is Reshaped
abstract: A condemned building containing two murals by an artist known for depicting the American Southwest became the center of a preservation campaign.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Inside a worn-down building on the edge of downtown, a rambling mural that covered nearly the length of one wall looked like something a traveling artist might have painted for the sole purpose of settling a bar tab — as many here suspect was the case.

headline: William King, Sculptor, Dies at 90; His Pointed Wit Was a Tool
abstract: Mr. King’s work is in the collections of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Museum of Modern Art in New York and the Smithsonian American Art Museum in Washington.
lead_paragraph: William King, a sculptor in a variety of materials whose human figures traced social attitudes through the last half of the 20th century, often poking sly and poignant fun at human follies and foibles, died on March 4 at his home in East Hampton, N.Y. He was 90.

headline: Contact Lens Makers and Discounters Tussle Over Price Setting
keywords: ['Contact Lenses', 'Discount Selling', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Eyes and Eyesight']
abstract: All the major contact lens manufacturers have enacted policies to set minimum pricing by sellers, who in turn say the rules amount to price-fixing.
lead_paragraph: Anthony D. Morrow had been wearing the same brand of contact lenses for years, so when he saw the bill for his latest order last November, he did a double take.

headline: Review: ‘Man From Reno,’ a Mystery of Missing Persons and Priceless Turtles
abstract: This Japanese film directed by Dave Boyle has an undercurrent of dark comedy as an oddball pair of sleuths (a mystery writer and a sheriff) investigate two disappearances.
lead_paragraph: The two main characters in Dave Boyle’s labyrinthine neo-noir, “Man From Reno,” make an oddball pair of sleuths. Aki Akahori (Ayako Fujitani) is a renowned Japanese mystery writer, nicknamed “the J. D. Salinger of Japan,” hiding out from the paparazzi in San Francisco. Paul Del Moral (Pepe Serna) is the sheriff of the fictional San Marco County, south of the city. The depressed, enigmatic Aki and the grizzled, avuncular Paul don’t meet until an hour into the movie, when he knocks on her hotel door while investigating a murder.

headline: In Bergdahl Case, the Rare Charge of Misbehavior
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'Desertion (Military)', 'Prisoners of War']
abstract: Army Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl is facing the serious charge that includes endangering the safety or a unit or outpost.
lead_paragraph: In the military’s case against Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, the charge of desertion, with a maximum penalty of imprisonment for five years, is the lesser count and the easier one to prove, legal experts say.

headline: Review: In ‘The Riot Club,’ an Elite British Dining Club Excels in Debauchery
abstract: A poisonous satire based on a dining club at Oxford University focuses on a group of rich students who carry snobbery and class hatred to savage extremes.
lead_paragraph: “The Riot Club,” a poisonous satire of Britain’s upper class, adapted from Laura Wade’s play “Posh,” may puncture any lingering fantasies that good breeding is synonymous with noblesse oblige. The small group of rich young men on whom it focuses belong to an Oxford University dining club that has a fabled history of drunken mischief making. As they exercise their privilege at the club’s annual bacchanal, an alternate title for the movie comes to mind: “Boozing and Vomiting.”

headline: Murky Inquiry Targets Critic of N.Y.U. Role in Abu Dhabi, and a Reporter
abstract: A private investigator making inquiries about a professor who criticized the exploitation of migrant workers building the university’s Abu Dhabi campus won’t say whom she is working for.
lead_paragraph: New York University’s fraught tenure as an intellectual prize of the Middle East has taken a new and mysterious turn: A private investigator has been making inquiries about an N.Y.U. professor who criticized the exploitation of migrant workers building the university’s campus in Abu Dhabi.

headline: Yemenis Share Reports, Rumors and Wry Commentary Online as Bombs Drop
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Twitter and Facebook updates and snatches of grainy video on Instagram and YouTube offered observers following from afar vivid glimpses of the terror.
lead_paragraph: As soon as the first airstrikes hit Yemen’s capital, Sana, in the early hours of Thursday morning, Yemenis deployed across social networks to share a stream of firsthand reports, images, analysis and wry commentary on the Saudi-led assault.

headline: Review: Bradley Cooper and Jennifer Lawrence Felling Trees in ‘Serena’
abstract: Logging and love in Appalachia are mingled in this film by the Danish director Susanne Bier, shot in the Czech Republic.
lead_paragraph: Bradley Cooper and Jennifer Lawrence will probably get a lot of grief and negative reviews for “Serena,” but this isn’t the kind of fiasco you can entirely pin on its stars. Miscast and misdirected from first ridiculous scene to last, they play George and Serena Pemberton, 1929 glamour-pusses who, soon after the story opens, marry and move to his timber camp. There, he plans to build an empire or dominate nature or something — it’s telling that it is never wholly clear what he has in mind beyond felling trees — while Serena, well, she intends to dominate poor George.

headline: A Dangerous Escalation in Iraq
keywords: ['Editorials', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Shiite Muslims', 'Sunni Muslims']
abstract: President Obama has ordered the bombing of Tikrit, but he has failed to show how it could advance American interests.
lead_paragraph: By ordering the bombing of the Iraqi city of Tikrit, President Obama has escalated America’s involvement in the fight against the Islamic State without providing a shred of evidence showing how it could advance American interests, or what happens once the bombs stop falling.

headline: Review: In ‘A Wolf at the Door,’ a Fiery Affair Turns Rancid
abstract: The Brazilian filmmaker Fernando Coimbra gives this tale of passion, betrayal and revenge the dimension of a Greek tragedy.
lead_paragraph: In the frantic opening scene of the Brazilian filmmaker Fernando Coimbra’s “A Wolf at the Door,” Sylvia (Fabiula Nascimento), a distraught mother whose 6-year-old daughter, Clara, is missing, visits the little girl’s school in a suburb of Rio de Janeiro. A harried official insists that Clara was picked up by a woman the girl appeared to adore.

headline: No Need to Prosecute Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'Editorials', 'Desertion (Military)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Prisoners of War']
abstract: Charging him for desertion and misbehaving before the enemy stands to accomplish little at this point.
lead_paragraph: It won’t be hard for military lawyers to argue that Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl violated military regulations when he slipped out of a remote outpost in Afghanistan in 2009 and became a Taliban prisoner for five years.

headline: After East Village Blast, a Familiar Sight: New Yorkers to the Rescue
abstract: The explosion and fire served as a call to action for those who could help, including one man who knocked on windows and called for people to evacuate, and pedestrians who tended to the wounds of the injured.
lead_paragraph: First there was the smell of gas, then an explosion and a burst of flying glass. Smoke and a hail of hot ash spattered onto the pavement of Second Avenue in the East Village as a red-brick building folded into itself on Thursday afternoon. Flames licked out of some windows, and the bottom floors blew out.

headline: Review: Larry Clark’s ‘Marfa Girl’ Looks at Dysfunction and Desire
abstract: This is the latest exploration — and exploitation — of teenage sexuality from Mr. Clark, who has been splitting the difference between fearless honesty and leering prurience for decades.
lead_paragraph: “Marfa Girl” is the latest exploration — and exploitation — of teenage sexuality from Larry Clark, the photographer and filmmaker who has been splitting the difference between fearless honesty and leering prurience for more than four decades. “Tulsa,” the 1971 book of portraits that made his reputation, still has the power to shock and unsettle with its blunt portrayal of drug use and promiscuity among the provincial American young. But the scandal of Mr. Clark’s more recent movies, including “Wassup Rockers” and “Ken Park” and this new one, resides more in its tedium and lack of insight than its strenuously provocative content.

headline: Man Killed by Bus at Port Authority Terminal
abstract: A 67-year-old from Garrison, N.Y., was struck on the third level at the terminal around 5 p.m., the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A man was struck and killed by a bus at the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Manhattan on Thursday, officials said, causing extensive delays and evening-rush havoc at the busy station.

headline: Michigan State Acquires a Size Advantage in a Spreadsheet
abstract: Kevin Pauga, Michigan State’s director of basketball operations, has developed his own algorithm that ranks college basketball programs to aid the Spartans’ preparation.
lead_paragraph: SYRACUSE — As Oklahoma practiced Thursday afternoon, Kevin Pauga pulled out his laptop while he sat courtside.

headline: Post-Sept. 11, Cockpits Are Built to Protect From Outside Threats
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Pilots', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: By apparently locking the captain out of the cockpit, the co-pilot of Germanwings Flight 9525 took advantage of a major safety protocol instituted after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks.
lead_paragraph: Although airplane cockpits are supposed to be the last line of defense from outside aggressors, airlines have fewer options if the threat comes from within.

headline: Ferguson Chief Takes Steps Urged in Report
abstract: Alan Eickhoff, who took his post as acting police chief in Ferguson, Mo., a week ago, said he would work to better integrate his officers with the community.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — Addressing one of the Justice Department’s primary recommendations for the Police Department here, the new acting police chief said on Thursday that he was working to better integrate his officers with the community by putting them on more bike patrols and encouraging them to walk the beat and speak with residents. The efforts pushed by Chief Alan Eickhoff, who took his post a week ago, come even as he conceded that many of his officers were still worried about their safety as anger continues after a white Ferguson police officer fatally shot an unarmed black teenager last August.

headline: Review: In ‘Cupcakes,’ an Impromptu Cellphone Video Is Noticed
abstract: Eytan Fox’s dramedy sends six more or less ordinary Israelis to a Paris song competition.
lead_paragraph: The gaudy excesses of the annual Eurovision contest have inspired filmmakers before (Farah Khan’s 2014 Bollywood extravaganza, “Happy New Year,” comes to mind), but rarely have they been employed as sure-footedly as in Eytan Fox’s dramedy “Cupcakes.” This candy-coated confection is so irresistible that you’re captivated by its sentiment even as you acknowledge its manipulations.

headline: Review: In ‘Nightlight,’ Fun and Games in a Forest Turn Deadly
abstract: In this found-footage horror film, a group of friends playing a variation on hide-and-seek encounter a malevolent spirit.
lead_paragraph: Into the pantheon of found-footage horror cinema comes “Nightlight,” a spare trifle carried largely by its leading actress. The film begins with a videotaped message from the teenage Ethan (an affecting Kyle Fain) to his parents, talking about his struggles with suicide and his hopes to see Robin (Shelby Young) at a dance. Cut to weeks later, and Robin is joining Nia (Chloe Bridges), Ben (Mitch Hewer), Amelia (Taylor Murphy) and Chris (Carter Jenkins) for a night of fun and games in a forest enclosed by barbed wire.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 26, 2015
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: March 26, 2015

headline: Notre Dame, Again Relying on Its Mental Toughness, Edges Wichita State
abstract: The Irish, playing with the intensity they displayed in winning the A.C.C. tournament, moved into the round of 8 with a victory over the Shockers.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — After Thursday night’s game, an 81-70 victory over Wichita State, several of Notre Dame’s tired but satisfied players sat in their locker room watching the tense ending of the Wisconsin-North Carolina matchup.

headline: Q. and A.: Karl E. Meyer and Shareen Blair Brysac on ‘The China Collectors’
abstract: The authors have written a rollicking account of the acquisition of Chinese art and antiquities by Americans who came to China in the 19th and 20th centuries.
lead_paragraph: Karl E. Meyer and Shareen Blair Brysac have written a rollicking account of the acquisition of Chinese art and antiquities by Americans who came to China in the 19th and 20th centuries and took back vast collections from caves, palaces and the back rooms of dealers in Beijing. In “The China Collectors: America’s Century-Long Hunt for Asian Art Treasures,” the authors describe how lovers of Chinese art roamed the country hunting for sculptures, wall panels, furniture, porcelain and paintings that are now housed in important museums in the United States. Some of the artworks they tried to send back were ruined in the process.

headline: Review: Attacca Quartet Serves Up John Adams, With Dance as a Side Dish
abstract: The string ensemble played compositions by John Adams at the Metropolitan Museum, with dancers performing works by Francesca Harper inspired by the music.
lead_paragraph: The Attacca Quartet, the string ensemble in residence at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, played a robust, gripping concert of music by John Adams on Tuesday. The program paired Mr. Adams’s 2008 “String Quartet” with selections from “John’s Book of Alleged Dances” from 1994. Mr. Adams was present, as were 17 dancers. But the choreography they performed, by Francesca Harper, was so flimsy and poorly constructed that the fanciful title of Mr. Adams’s music remained descriptive. Whether the pieces should even count as dances stayed in doubt.

headline: Off to Space for a Year, an American’s Longest Journey
abstract: NASA hopes to learn more about physical and psychological effects of space travel from the mission of Scott J. Kelly, who will have spent more time in space than any American when he returns.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times provided live updates about the launch.

headline: Review: ‘Killing Jesus,’ Biblical Tale Retold, Softer on Its Politics
abstract: This program, based on the book of the same title from Martin Dugard and Bill O’Reilly, dramatizes the life and death of Jesus.
lead_paragraph: If you’re a devotee of a particular religion, you probably don’t want the story on which its whole belief system rests told by someone facing challenges to his credibility. But that’s not even the main problem with “Killing Jesus,” which has its premiere Sunday on the National Geographic Channel and is based on a book by Martin Dugard and the embattled Bill O’Reilly. The main problem is that this three-hour affair is unrelentingly drab. The program dramatizes the life of Jesus, culminating, of course, in his crucifixion. Mr. O’Reilly and Mr. Dugard turned the tale into a best seller in 2013 with “Killing Jesus: A History,” part of a franchise that has also seen them kill Presidents Abraham Lincoln and John F. Kennedy and Gen. George S. Patton.

headline: A Policy Puzzle of U.S. Goals and Alliances in the Middle East
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: In becoming involved in a Saudi-led campaign to dislodge rebels in Yemen, the United States has created more entanglement with its alliances.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Already struggling to navigate the chaos engulfing much of the Middle East, the United States is now dipping its toe into another conflict.

headline: Having Some Strings Attached
abstract: An interesting puzzle from David Kwong.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — At first, I thought this was a puzzle about punctuation. That, of course, turned out to be wrong.

headline: Review: ‘New York Spring Spectacular’ Barrels Into Radio City
abstract: “New York Spring Spectacular,” a lavish new show with the Rockettes at Radio City Music Hall, features imposing sets, 3-D effects and breathless promotions of the city’s attractions.
lead_paragraph: Well, at least the Rockettes get to take the final bow.

headline: Jailhouse Informant Points to Alternate Suspect at Patz Trial
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Informers', 'Kidnapping and Hostages', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: The informant, Jeffrey Rothschild, said he had worked with federal prosecutors in 1991 to get information about a convicted child molester and his relationship with Etan Patz, who was 6 when he disappeared.
lead_paragraph: A jailhouse informant provided dramatic testimony on Thursday about an alternate suspect in the 1979 disappearance of 6-year-old Etan Patz.

headline: Francis C. Rooney Jr. Dies at 93; Turned Melville Into a Retail Giant
abstract: As chief executive of the Melville Corporation, Mr. Rooney transformed it from a shoe company into a retail behemoth embracing CVS, Thom McAn and Marshall’s.
lead_paragraph: Francis C. Rooney Jr., who as chief executive of the Melville Corporation transformed it from a shoe company into a retail behemoth embracing CVS, Thom McAn and Marshall’s, died on Tuesday in Greenwich, Conn. He was 93.

headline: A Giant, Upset, Lifts No. 1 Wisconsin Over North Carolina
abstract: The Tar Heels seemed poised for an upset against the top-seeded Badgers, but a fight for a rebound awakened Frank Kaminsky, who led Wisconsin to victory.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — With a little over 11 minutes left in the first West Regional semifinal Thursday, the North Carolina sophomore forward Isaiah Hicks inadvertently woke the slumping giant. Battling for a rebound under the Tar Heels’ basket, Hicks tangled with Frank Kaminsky, Wisconsin’s standout 7-foot forward.

headline: Rev. Lyle E. Schaller Dies at 91; Helped Protestant Churches Survive and Grow
abstract: Mr. Schaller had published 55 books since 1964, edited 41 more and visited about 6,000 churches, offering advice on how to grow congregations.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Lyle E. Schaller, whose half-century of practical advice on how Protestant congregations could grow — from installing air-conditioning to encouraging pastors to critique their videotaped sermons — made him the nation’s dean of church consultants, died on March 18 in Oklahoma City. He was 91.

headline: Chase Headley Is Playing Plenty, but He’s Begging for More Work
abstract: Third base is a position known as the hot corner, but it has not been in spring training for Chase Headley, who through 78 innings had only 13 chances.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Third base is a position known as the hot corner, where it helps to be as quick as a lizard’s tongue and blessed with a razor-sharp attention span since you never know when a line drive will come screaming at you.

headline: Cuomo and Lawmakers Appear Near to Ethics Reform Deal
keywords: ['Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo says the effort makes good on his vow to bring sunlight to Albany’s ethical shadows; critics say that the reforms don’t go far enough in forcing lawmakers who are lawyers to disclose outside income.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — As Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and lawmakers race to finish the state budget by the April 1 deadline, they appear close to an agreement on ethics policies that would increase what legislators have to disclose about the money they make on top of their government salaries.

headline: A Team Effort for Health
abstract: At Iora Health, doctors, nurses and health coaches share the responsibilities of looking after patients.
lead_paragraph: At Iora Health, doctors, nurses and health coaches share the responsibilities of looking after patients.

headline: Taking to Twitter, Iran’s President Argues for Rapid End to Sanctions
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: On Twitter, Hassan Rouhani described his appeals to President Obama, and the leaders of Britain, France and Russia as nuclear talks near a deadline.
lead_paragraph: LAUSANNE, Switzerland — While American negotiators maintained tight secrecy at the nuclear talks here, President Hassan Rouhani of Iran took to Twitter late Thursday to describe a letter he sent to President Obama and other world leaders justifying Iran’s positions.

headline: Long Line of Suitors for New York State’s $5.4 Billion Windfall
abstract: There is no shortage of ideas from lawmakers and business leaders across the state on how to dole out the money received from settlement payments from financial institutions.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has called the money “a gift from above”: more than $5 billion in settlement payments from financial institutions that is padding the state’s coffers.

headline: John F. Burns, Pulitzer Prize-Winning Journalist, Ends Acclaimed Run
abstract: Mr. Burns, who reported from 10 foreign bureaus, has concluded a distinguished career spanning 40 years with The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: With an article about the reburial of Richard III, John F. Burns concludes a distinguished career spanning 40 years with The New York Times, 39 of them with the international desk. Beginning with South Africa in 1976, Mr. Burns reported from 10 foreign bureaus and was chief of the Baghdad bureau during the American invasion and occupation of Iraq. Along the way, he wrote more than 3,300 articles and collected two Pulitzer Prizes for International Reporting, one in Afghanistan and the other in Bosnia. His portrait of a cellist playing on Sarajevo’s main pedestrian concourse while artillery shells exploded nearby is considered a classic of modern journalism. He will continue to contribute to the international and sports desks, among others.

headline: Sudan Joins Coalition Against Yemen Rebels
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'International Relations']
abstract: The Arab-led, American-supported coalition seeking to rout Houthi rebels in Yemen includes a leader indicted on charges of war crimes and vilified by Washington for more than a decade: President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — It is an awkward moment.

headline: Louisville’s Rick Pitino Defends Syracuse’s Jim Boeheim
abstract: Pitino, a former assistant to Syracuse Coach Jim Boeheim and now Louisville’s coach, chided the N.C.A.A. for its multiyear investigation into Boeheim’s program.
lead_paragraph: SYRACUSE, N.Y. — Louisville Coach Rick Pitino, a former assistant to Syracuse Coach Jim Boeheim, defended the embattled Boeheim on Thursday before Pitino’s fourth-seeded Cardinals practiced for their East Regional game Friday against No. 8-seeded North Carolina State in Syracuse.

headline: Coach K Will Win and Lose
abstract: The sobriquet, long synonymous with the Blue Devils boss Mike Krzyzewski, also belongs to Larry Krystkowiak, whose fourth-seeded Utes play top-seeded Duke on Friday.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Coach K wants Duke to beat Utah. Coach K also wants Utah to beat Duke. No matter what happens, Coach K will be pleased.

headline: Deputies Said to Taunt Prisoners
abstract: Four San Francisco sheriff’s deputies forced prisoners to engage in “gladiator-style fights,” a public defender said.
lead_paragraph: San Francisco’s public defender called on Thursday for an independent investigation into the Sheriff’s Department after accusations that four deputies forced prisoners to engage in “gladiator-style fights” for their own amusement.

headline: President of Argentina Won’t Face Charges
keywords: ['Bombs and Explosives', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: The president and her political supporters had been accused of conspiring to hide Iranian officials’ involvement in a bombing Buenos Aires in 1994.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — An Argentine appellate court dismissed a criminal case Thursday against President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner and her political supporters that accused them of conspiring to hide Iranian officials’ involvement in a bombing here in 1994.

headline: U.S. and Syria Discuss Missing Journalist
abstract: The father of Austin Tice, who disappeared in Syria in 2012, and a State Department official said the governments of the two countries had been in direct contact.
lead_paragraph: The United States and Syrian governments are engaged in direct talks concerning the whereabouts of Austin Tice, an American freelance journalist and photographer who disappeared in Syria more than two and a half years ago in the midst of the country’s widening civil war, a State Department official and Mr. Tice’s father said Thursday.

headline: The Sequence Of Destruction Of Three East Village Buildings
abstract: The fire started at 121 2nd Ave., set off by by a possible gas explosion in a restaurant where plumbing and gas work was being done.
lead_paragraph: The fire started at 121 2nd Ave., set off by by a possible gas explosion in a restaurant where plumbing and gas work was being done.

headline: U.N. Middle East Peace Envoy Urges Security Council to Revive Talks
abstract: Robert Serry, the departing United Nations envoy for the Middle East peace process said that Israel’s policy of building settlements in the Palestinian territories “may kill” any chance of peace.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The departing United Nations envoy for the Middle East peace process said Thursday that Israel’s policy of building settlements in the Palestinian territories “may kill” any chance of peace, as he nudged the Security Council to step in and revive talks that were halted last year.

headline: An American With Ebola Is Improving
abstract: An American aid worker being treated for Ebola at the National Institutes of Health clinical center in Maryland is doing better and has been upgraded from critical to serious condition, the N.I.H. announced Thursday.
lead_paragraph: An American aid worker being treated for Ebola at the National Institutes of Health clinical center in Maryland is doing better and has been upgraded from critical to serious condition, the N.I.H. announced Thursday. The patient, who worked with the American charity Partners in Health in Sierra Leone, was transferred to the United States on March 13. A Sierra Leonean colleague who also contracted Ebola in March has recovered and was discharged from a treatment unit, said Dr. Adikali Kamara, a district medical officer in Sierra Leone. People who came into contact with the two men, including more than a dozen Americans who were evacuated in several groups to the United States, are still being monitored for symptoms.

headline: Shooting Oysters in Northeast London
abstract: At the East End’s first raw bar, the Richmond, happy hour is a bright, salty culinary experience.
lead_paragraph: The term “happy hour” takes on a maritime meaning at the Richmond, the latest in a line of modern neighborhood restaurants turning the indistinct northeast London district of Haggerston into an unlikely but legitimate food destination. Come 5 p.m. every weekday, and 3 p.m. on weekends, fresh oysters here — the East End’s first raw bar — are an attainable £1 a pop. It’s the latest venture from the stylist Mags Crow and the Australian chef Brett Redman, who has been awarded a triumvirate of Michelin Bib Gourmands (rewarding exceptional food at modest prices) for the well-loved Elliot’s Cafe in Borough Market.

headline: Mark Haddawy’s True West
abstract: As he did with fashion — making us see vintage clothing as valuable — so he does with architecture. The purist would no sooner tweak a Halston gown than alter a great ’70s house. Even one he lives in.
lead_paragraph: As he did with fashion — making us see vintage clothing as valuable — so he does with architecture. The purist would no sooner tweak a Halston gown than alter a great ’70s house. Even one he lives in.

headline: What the First Mixologist Honored by the James Beard Foundation Is Drinking Now
abstract: Dale DeGroff shares two cocktail recipes and a look back on his 41 years of bartending, from early days at the Rainbow Room to bottling his own bitters.
lead_paragraph: This May, the James Beard Foundation will induct Dale DeGroff, 66, into its Who’s Who of Food & Beverage in America. Often credited as the grandfather of the modern cocktail revival, his trailblazing cocktail menu for the 1987 reopening of New York’s Rainbow Room brought back to life the works of pre-Prohibition bartenders like “Professor” Jerry Thomas.

headline: Gerald and Betty Ford’s Restoration Politics
abstract: The Continental chic of Camelot in the ’60s, the gilded splendor of the Reagan-era ’80s — but what about a new take on the unique charms of Gerald and Betty Ford’s ’70s Southern California dreaming? Here’s looking at the most truly American of styles.
lead_paragraph: The Continental chic of Camelot in the ’60s, the gilded splendor of the Reagan-era ’80s — but what about a new take on the unique charms of Gerald and Betty Ford’s ’70s Southern California dreaming? Here’s looking at the most truly American of styles.

headline: North Korea Claims to Have Arrested Two Spies From South
abstract: North Korea said on Friday that it had arrested two South Korean men on espionage charges for collecting military and other secrets on the isolated country, including data regarding its top leadership.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea said on Friday that it had arrested two South Korean men on espionage charges for collecting military and other secrets on the isolated country, including data regarding its top leadership, and infiltrating it with political propaganda and subversive religious materials.

headline: After a Bold Forecast, West Virginia Is Blown Away by Kentucky
abstract: A Mountaineers guard predicted a victory, but the No. 1 Wildcats (37-0) trampled West Virginia in the round of 16 of the N.C.A.A. tournament.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — On Wednesday afternoon, the day before his team was to play West Virginia, John Calipari walked into the Kentucky locker room after practice and delivered an important message with a tone of levity. He had heard about the comments made by West Virginia’s freshman guard Daxter Miles Jr., who predicted that the Mountaineers would end Kentucky’s unbeaten streak.

headline: What’s on TV Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 12 A.M. (Comedy Central) PINEAPPLE EXPRESS (2008) Seth Rogen and Evan Goldberg (“Superbad”) wrote this comic stoner caper directed by David Gordon Green. Mr. Rogen stars as Dale Denton, a process server who loves to smoke weed to escape the tedium of his life. He witnesses a murder while smoking a joint of rare marijuana and throws it out the window of his car in a rush to flee the scene. He goes to see his dealer, Saul (James Franco), and they become paranoid that the killer (Gary Cole) will be able to identify him as the witness because of the distinct pot he had been carrying. Off they run, without confirming that they are being pursued. Danny McBride plays an eccentric, backstabbing, midlevel drug dealer, and Rosie Perez portrays a crooked cop conspiring with the murderer. And a strain of pot is named “Spanish trampoline.” Writing about the film in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis said, “In the tradition of Cheech and Chong, Abbott and Costello, Hope and Crosby, Ricky and Lucy, Martin and Lewis, Rowan and Martin, Smothers and Smothers, Sanford and son, Spicoli and Hand, Bert and Ernie, Riggs and Murtaugh, cops and robbers, dumb and dumber, right brain and left, peanut butter and jelly, bong hit, roach clip and Snoop Doggy Dogg comes ‘Pineapple Express,’ a stoner comedy that partakes of a gentle indie vibe before hitting the hard stuff for a major Shane Black-style blowup and meltdown.”

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In a tournament in which one loss means elimination, Arizona’s situation is as close as a team can get to a do-over.

headline: Family Searches for Missing Son After Blast in the East Village
abstract: Nicholas Figueroa went on a lunchtime date to the restaurant at the center of an explosion on Thursday and has not been heard from since, his family said.
lead_paragraph: Nicholas Figueroa went on a lunchtime date to a restaurant where an explosion severely damaged several buildings along an East Village block on Thursday. He has not been heard from since, said his family, which was frantically searching for him early Friday.

headline: Documenting the Blues in the Mississippi Delta
abstract: A love of the blues led Margo Cooper to explore the Mississippi Delta, where she has photographed and interviewed the people behind the music.
lead_paragraph: The urgent need to preserve a cornerstone of American culture led folklorists like John Lomax to travel the country documenting early blues recordings and writers like Amiri Baraka to publish “Blues People: Negro Music in White America.” Although Margo Cooper did not know it when she began more than 20 years ago, she has followed that tradition and produced a documentary project that archives the oral and visual histories of blues musicians, their families and communities in northern Mississippi and the Delta.

headline: The Field Is Flat
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Many people think the Democrats have an advantage heading into 2016. They don’t.
lead_paragraph: Like a lot of people who pay attention to such things, I had assumed that Democrats had a huge advantage going into next year’s presidential race. Democrats do really well among the growing demographic groups, like Hispanics, single people and the young. Republicans, meanwhile, do doing sensationally well with just about every shrinking group. If 67-year-old rural white men were the future of the electorate, the G.O.P. would be rolling.

headline: Mornings in Blue America
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: When good news of solid job growth at both the national level and in states is a conservative nightmare.
lead_paragraph: Two impossible things happened to the U.S. economy over the course of the past year — or at least they were supposed to be impossible, according to the ideology that dominates half our political spectrum. First, remember how Obamacare was supposed to be a gigantic job killer? Well, in the first year of the Affordable Care Act’s full implementation, the U.S. economy as a whole added 3.3 million jobs — the biggest gain since the 1990s. Second, half a million of those jobs were added in California, which has taken the lead in job creation away from Texas.

headline: Critiquing How Cuomo Rates Teachers
abstract: Readers discuss a proposal to increase the weight of student state test scores in teacher evaluations in New York State.

headline: Give Breast Milk
abstract: Donating breast milk should be more like donating blood.
lead_paragraph: I PRODUCED more than 2,500 ounces of surplus breast milk with my first son. I am almost six months postpartum with my second child, and already my freezers are stuffed with five-ounce bags of milk. Some women are computer programmers or impressive cooks. I’m good at producing breast milk. My friends and family marvel at this talent, sort of. They like to joke that I could make real money if I sold it.

headline: As Reid Exits, Schumer Sees Door Opening
abstract: Harry Reid’s announcement that he will retire from the Senate sets off a leadership shuffle, with the top post almost assured.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Around 8 p.m. Thursday, Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the minority leader, called Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York into his office with news that would stun Washington the next morning: Mr. Reid planned to retire at the end of his term.

headline: Is There Anything UConn Can’t Do? Tweet, for One
abstract: The Huskies’ coaches want to thwart the possibility of an off-color remark or inappropriate message causing unwanted attention.
lead_paragraph: STORRS, Conn. — On Oct. 14, the day before their first practice of the season, several Connecticut women’s basketball players sent similar messages to their Twitter followers. The words differed, but the meaning was the same.

headline: Chad Strongman Says Nigeria Is Absent in Fight Against Boko Haram
abstract: President Idriss Déby of Chad has won favor with the West, which is only too happy to call on his forces in a region seething with Islamist terrorists.
lead_paragraph: NDJAMENA, Chad — Chad’s president, Idriss Déby, speaks in a soft mumble, wears spectacles and an immaculate white robe, and is to be found in the quiet inner recesses of a gilt-edged, marble presidential palace — under crystal chandeliers and vaulted arches that seem part Renaissance, part Vegas — at the dusty center of his country’s capital.

headline: As ‘Mad Men’ Comes to an End, Jon Hamm Reflects on Don Draper
abstract: The series, which revived the fashion and pop culture of a tumultuous decade and reminded viewers of the racism and sexism of the era, begins its final seven episodes on April 5.
lead_paragraph: It’s not only the 1960s that will come to an end when “Mad Men” reaches its conclusion on May 17, but also a chapter of television history. Since its debut in 2007, this influential period drama has shaped our present while turning its lens on the past: The series, which returns for its final seven episodes on April 5, has helped to revive the fashion and pop culture of a tumultuous decade, while also reminding viewers of the racism, sexism and selfishness that was endemic to one of the most picked-over eras in American history.

headline: Bronx Science Teacher in Child Pornography Case Told Students ‘You’re a Big Deal’
abstract: Former students of Jon Cruz, accused of coercing teenagers from other schools into sending him nude photos, recall his devotion, but some now question his behavior.
lead_paragraph: A trophy case framed in brass, set inside a wall near the entrance to the Bronx High School of Science, testified to the triumph of the school’s debate team. So did classroom 203, the de facto debate headquarters, where the sunlight danced off a collection of plaques and trophies.

headline: In Silicon Valley, Auto Racing Becomes a Favorite Hobby for Tech Elites
abstract: A small but growing group of mostly men gather to drive fast and network with clients and others in the tech industry.
lead_paragraph: When you get past the noise and the smell, the unbearable heat, the G-force, the surprising physical exertion and, always, the constant threat of injury or death — auto racing, like much else, comes down to math. There is an optimal path around a racetrack, a geometric arc of least resistance. It is the driver’s job to find this sweet spot of physics and stick to it, lap after lap, as consistently as a microprocessor crunching through an algorithm.

headline: Kamala Harris, California’s Attorney General, Leaps to Forefront of Senate Race
abstract: Ms. Harris has quickly established herself as the dominant candidate in what many had expected would be a sprawling battle to replace Senator Barbara Boxer.
lead_paragraph: CASTAIC, Calif. — When Kamala D. Harris, a Democrat, was the newly elected district attorney of San Francisco in 2004, she walked into a firestorm after deciding not to pursue the death penalty for a man accused in the killing of a police officer — drawing attacks from law enforcement leaders and even Senator Dianne Feinstein, one of the most respected Democrats in the state.

headline: Does Your School Do a Good Job of Teaching Sex Ed?
abstract: How do you get most of your information about sex and sexuality?
lead_paragraph: The way schools teach sex education varies widely across the country and the world. Some programs exclusively teach abstinence until marriage. Others emphasize the dangers of sexual activity, such as venereal diseases. Some classes foster more open conversations about sexual decision-making and sexuality.

headline: R.B.S. Agrees to Sell International Arm of Coutts Private Banking Unit
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'High Net Worth Individuals']
abstract: The sale to Union Bancaire Privée concerns the Coutts International business outside Britain. The price to be paid will be determined in part by assets under management on closing.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Royal Bank of Scotland said on Friday that it had agreed to sell the international operations of its Coutts & Company private banking business to the Swiss private bank Union Bancaire Privée.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz: Upbeat Emotions, Male Nurses and Whiter Teeth
abstract: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: Take the Quiz

headline: House Tour | The Ford House
abstract: The new homeowners discuss renovating Gerald and Betty Ford’s former home in Rancho Mirage, California.
lead_paragraph: The new homeowners discuss renovating Gerald and Betty Ford’s former home in Rancho Mirage, California.

headline: Co-Pilot in Germanwings Crash Hid Mental Illness From Employer, Authorities Say
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Pilots', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: Among the items found at Andreas Lubitz’s home was one doctor’s note excusing him from work the day of the crash and another that had been torn up.
lead_paragraph: DÜSSELDORF, Germany — Andreas Lubitz, the pilot at the controls of the Germanwings jetliner that crashed into the French Alps on Tuesday, had a mental illness but kept the diagnosis hidden from his employer, the authorities said Friday.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Ask Well: Does Kinesiology Tape Really Work?
abstract: Kinesiology tape is the thin, stretchy fabric in bright colors that you see athletes wearing these days. Is it better than plain, white athletic tape?
lead_paragraph: Question:

headline: New York Today: After the Fire
abstract: Friday and the weekend: the East Village building explosion, chilly rain, and a pre-Sabbath run on smoke detectors.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this drizzly Friday.At least two people are unaccounted for this morning, including a 23-year-old man, after Thursday’s explosion, fire and building collapse in the East Village, the police said.

headline: Losing the Plot
abstract: Heidi Julavits says she used to associate journal-keeping “with uncertainty — it was about wondering about my future and who I would be.”
lead_paragraph: “I have a plot problem,” Heidi Julavits said in a recent email interview. “I’ve been joking for years that I have to check into the Betty Ford Clinic for plot addicts. I can’t seem to access an imaginative world without instantly building into it a complicated mechanism of psychological and dramatic causality. And I wanted to learn a new way to move through a book.”

headline: ‘The Folded Clock,’ by Heidi Julavits
abstract: Time loops and circles forward in the essays that make up Heidi Julavits’s diary.
lead_paragraph: The self, a friend once informed me, is an illusion. We were 19 at the time, and he was reading Foucault, but that was 18 years ago, and now he doesn’t think he understood Foucault back then. “It’s real,” my friend says of the self, “but it’s made.”

headline: ‘The Boatmaker,’ by John Benditt
abstract: In this first novel, a loner is intent on a greater understanding of the civilized world, and his place in it.
lead_paragraph: Spare and solemn as a parable, John Benditt’s powerful first novel begins simply, with a man and a woman and a child in a little wooden house on remote, windswept Small Island. The man is feverish, dreaming of himself as a boy, walking toward a towering oak tree, its leaves rustling in the breeze. “Everything else is quiet; no insects or birds are singing. It’s high summer, the time of afternoon when the sun stands still and everything hushes. Even the sea.” If “The Boat­maker” were a film, Sven Nykvist would be its only possible cinematographer.

headline: Daily Report: Live-Streaming Apps Aspire to Be Next Big Thing in Social Media
abstract: Apps that help users broadcast themselves live from their phones are catching the eye of tech heavyweights and venture capitalists. Periscope is Twitter’s big entry into this realm. Other apps include Meerkat and Camio.
lead_paragraph: Periscope, a live-streaming video app that Twitter introduced on Thursday, is one among a surge of such apps with names like Meerkat and Camio that are taking the social media world by storm, Mike Issac and Vindu Goel report.

headline: Financial Conduct Authority Made a ‘Serious Error’ on Insurance Review, Panel Says
abstract: A parliamentary committee said the British regulator had failed to live up to its own listings rules when it mishandled news that it would review the life insurance industry.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Financial Conduct Authority of Britain made a “serious error” in providing an exclusive briefing to a newspaper reporter last year on its plans to review the life insurance industry, and in not responding quickly after the report inadvertently sent British insurance stocks down sharply, a parliamentary committee said on Friday.

headline: Republicans Have Little to Fear From a Divisive Primary
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A bruising presidential nomination fight is unlikely to help Hillary Clinton and the Democrats.
lead_paragraph: Will the fight for the G.O.P. presidential nomination be Hillary Clinton’s secret weapon in the 2016 election? Not according to the best political science research.

headline: In the Hills of Sri Lanka’s Tea Country
abstract: In the lush interior of the island nation, among the relics of the past, some of the world’s finest tea is grown.
lead_paragraph: The man in the khaki vest slurped noisily from his cup, descended briefly into scowling meditation, spat the contents into a sink and then unleashed a torrent of approving descriptors, lavishly rolling his r’s along the way: “No foreign taste, very refreshing, robust, strong tannins, a tingly sensation at the end of the tongue — good show!”

headline: Re: The Reach
abstract: Appreciation of technical skill aside, not everyone was ready to follow Alex Honnold up a mountain face.
lead_paragraph: Is the death-defying free-solo rock climber Alex Honnold, who appeared on the cover of our March 15 issue, really the insane daredevil that so many people made him out to be? “Life is defined by risk,” wrote Ernieh1, in Queens, on The New York Times’s site. “Every time you enter a crosswalk at a busy time of day, you take a risk.”

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Gel Manicures
abstract: Sometimes I walk home from the salon transfixed by my new nails, soothed by their uncanny identicality.
lead_paragraph: I wore less makeup when I was a makeup artist than at any other time in my life. In beauty school, they asked us to arrive wearing none at all, so that we could practice the day’s lessons on one another’s faces. Nail polish was frowned upon, too, because it flaked and chipped; the odds that clients would inhale runaway polish were high. Later, when I found work, the hassle of making early-morning call times in the strangest locations (4 a.m. on a small Ontario farm, 6 a.m. at an abandoned church in the heart of downtown Toronto) made my own appearance seem inconsequential. The years I spent helping other people look their best were years I looked my worst: purple bags under my eyes and sallow complexion. But more than anything else, I hated the look of my bare nails as I smoothed creams onto a client’s face.

headline: How to Find a Message in a Bottle
abstract: Look for a beach that juts out perpendicular to the ocean current. Living near a cruise route helps, too.
lead_paragraph: Sean Smyth has found six messages in bottles, or M.I.B.s, in the argot of serious beachcombers. Five were typical, tossed-from-a-cruise-ship messages along the lines of “Hi, my name is Dave. If you find this note, email me and tell me where it turned up.” But one green wine bottle contained a rambling love poem written by a man who apparently drank the bottle’s contents first. “That’s the only one I kept,” says Smyth, a helicopter pilot who shuttles miners and oil workers to remote locations between Vancouver, British Columbia, and Nome, Alaska.

headline: ‘Mercy’
abstract: Selected by Natasha Trethewey.
lead_paragraph: “Mercy” is full of echoes: the subtle repetition of sounds, alliteration and rhyme, and the repetition of image and action — what is taught, learned, passed down. The hinge in the middle of the poem’s one long sentence opens a space in which to contemplate what such legacies mean. Poem selected by Natasha Trethewey.

headline: Bruce Bochy Won’t Let Success Go to His Head
abstract: The manager of the San Francisco Giants on life after the World Series.
lead_paragraph: Five years ago, you had been a manager for 15 years and had never won a World Series. Now you’ve won three, you have the most wins of any active manager and you’re probably going to the Hall of Fame. How is life different? Not much. My wife still tells me to take the trash out. I guess she finds a way to make sure I stay humble.

headline: Taxi Driver
abstract: Explaining conflict — and how we could resolve it — to my young son in the back seat.
lead_paragraph: The minute we got into the taxi, I had a bad feeling. It wasn’t because the driver asked me impatiently to buckle the kid’s safety belt after I already had, or because he muttered something that sounded like a curse when I said we wanted to go to Ramat Gan. I take a lot of taxis, so I’m used to the tempers, the impatience, the armpit stains. But there was something about the way that driver spoke, half-violent and half on the verge of tears, that made me uncomfortable.

headline: Out of Debtors’ Prison, With Law as the Key
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: Across the land, rich petty offenders pay fines while the poor go to jail. But that’s against the law.
lead_paragraph: When Jack Dawley returned in 2007 to his hometown, Norwalk, Ohio, after eight years in prison and on parole in Wisconsin, he knew getting by would be difficult. He had a felony conviction and a history of past drug and alcohol abuse, although he’d been sober since 1999. He was unprepared for another obstacle, however: A few years later, he would keep landing in debtors’ prison.

headline: The End of the Slave Trade
abstract: Even in the final months of the Civil War, Southern whites were buying and selling human beings.

headline: ‘My Documents,’ by Alejandro Zambra
abstract: Alejandro Zambra’s stories draw from the age of computers and the legacy of Pinochet.
lead_paragraph: “My Documents” is the Chilean ­writer Alejandro Zambra’s first collection of short stories and at the same time his longest book to date — at 240-odd ­pages, it’s a veritable tome next to “Bonsai” (2008, 86 pages), “The Private Lives of Trees” (2010, 98 pages) and “Ways of Going Home” (2013, 160 pages). These slight, ­intimate novels created a stir when they appeared in English, attracting readers who appreciated their meshing of ­Barthesian inquiry with the muffled malaise of daily life in post-Pinochet Chile. Their chronicles of diffident romances or precarious domestic arrangements set the stage for intensely affecting examinations of the mechanics of fiction.

headline: Student Crossword | Women’s Suffrage
abstract: Test your knowledge of women’s suffrage by playing our crossword.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of the history of the women’s suffrage movement by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: Stampede at Hindu Bathing Ritual in Bangladesh Kills at Least 10
abstract: The crush, which also injured dozens of pilgrims southeast of the capital, Dhaka, may have been set off by a rumor that a bridge was collapsing.
lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — At least 10 Hindu pilgrims were killed and dozens more were injured 12 miles southeast of the Bangladeshi capital, Dhaka, on Friday when an annual bathing ritual turned into a stampede, the police said.

headline: Morning Agenda: The Fine Print in the Heinz-Kraft Deal
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Executive Compensation', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The Fine Print in the Heinz-Kraft Deal | Big Law Chided for Silence on Cyberattacks | Cooperman’s Hedge Fund Receives Subpoenas | Consumer Protection Agency Takes On Payday Loans​
lead_paragraph: THE FINE PRINT IN THE HEINZ-KRAFT DEAL | H.J. Heinz’s takeover of Kraft Foods in a stock and cash dividend deal is “odd,”  contends Steven Davidoff Solomon in the Deal Professor column. In part, that’s because Heinz is a private company so knowing how to value its stock is a tricky exercise. Heinz’s owners — Warren E. Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway and the Brazilian investment firm 3G Capital – have, he writes, “the best knowledge, and in some cases, the only knowledge, on Heinz’s value.”

headline: ‘Washington’s Revolution,’ by Robert Middlekauff
abstract: Despite a ragtag army, Washington plotted the way to victory.
lead_paragraph: Robert Middlekauff, the distinguished historian of colonial and early America, has already written about the American Revolution in his 1982 book “The Glorious Cause,” the first volume of the ­Oxford History of the United States. Now he turns to the war’s most famous figure. George Washington was commander in chief of the American Army for almost the whole of the war (1775-83). He served at a time when there was no executive branch of government, only a one-house ­Congress to guide him. He had ­direct ­command of the war’s central theater, from coastal New ­England to Philadelphia, and he was in at the death at Yorktown. The title of Middlekauff’s new book thus has two meanings: “Washington’s Revolution” is a story of the war from one man’s point of view, as well as an account of a conflict that was that man’s to win or lose.

headline: Kent Russell’s ‘I Am Sorry to Think I Have Raised a Timid Son’
abstract: Essays consider a range of American masculinities, especially at home.
lead_paragraph: A book of essays can be a constellation. Individual pieces shine like stars, but to see the whole project as a unified thing requires a mythology. You need faith to make out a shape around all those dots of light, to believe in the bear or the swan.

headline: Harry Reid to Retire From Senate in 2016
abstract: The senator from Nevada, a tactician who has led Senate Democrats since 2005, said he had been contemplating retiring for months.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Harry Reid, the tough tactician who has led Senate Democrats since 2005, will not seek re-election next year, bringing an end to a three-decade congressional career that culminated in his push of President Obama’s ambitious agenda against fierce Republican resistance.

headline: ‘The Upstairs Wife,’ by Rafia Zakaria
abstract: A personal look at the place of women in Pakistani culture.
lead_paragraph: In the mid-1950s, when the Pakistani prime minister Mohammad Ali Bogra falls in love with his secretary, it occurs to him that according to the Islamic principles on which his country is governed, he would be legally within his rights should he take a second (or even a third and fourth) wife. What he doesn’t calculate, however, are the social consequences of bigamy. His decision to remarry so infuriates his first wife, Hamida Bogra, that she initiates a women’s rights campaign calling for reforms in marriage law.

headline: Star-Struck
abstract: New books by Kate Alcott, Michael Callahan, Angelina Mirabella and Christopher Noxon.
lead_paragraph: A TOUCH OF STARDUST

headline: What’s at Stake in the Iran Negotiations
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']
abstract: Can the West trust Iran? Can Iran trust the West? A look at the bet each side is making in the nuclear talks, along with the challenges and risks that they face.
lead_paragraph: Can the West trust Iran? Can Iran trust the West? A look at the bet each side is making in the nuclear talks, along with the challenges and risks that they face.

headline: A Small Protest Movement Again Picks Up Steam
abstract: As the six-month anniversary of the start of the Occupy Central protests nears, the encampment around government offices has slowly expanded.
lead_paragraph: As the six-month anniversary of the start of the Occupy Central protests nears, the encampment around government offices has slowly expanded.

headline: Today in Politics: Marathon Vote a Challenge for Senators Thinking About 2016
abstract: Senate Republicans squeezed through their budget early Friday morning and put some pressure on a few members who might prefer to be on the trail rather than casting dicey votes.
lead_paragraph: Good Friday morning from Washington. Jeb Bush’s aides are mulling a new data strategy, while Hillary Rodham Clinton is building up her communications team. Ending a week that included the first presidential announcement, we reminisce about Ted Cruz’s old debate days. Meanwhile, members of Congress will most likely start the weekend groggy from a marathon “vote-orama.” Finally, Senator Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada, says he will not seek re-election in 2016.

headline: What’s On This Week Around The World
abstract: A film festival in Istanbul, an Easter celebration in Salzburg and the opening of new art centers in Spain and Azerbaijan.
lead_paragraph: São Paulo, Brazil

headline: Company Thinks It Has Answer for Lower Health Costs: Customer Service
keywords: ['Medicine and Health', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: An innovative practice hopes its patient-centered methods will work on a national scale, allowing it to expand without losing effectiveness.
lead_paragraph: Virginnia Schock seemed headed for a health crisis. She was 64 years old, had poorly controlled diabetes, a wound on her foot and a cast on her broken wrist. She didn’t drive, so getting to the people who could tend to her ailments was complicated and expensive. She had stopped taking her diabetes pills months before and was reluctant to use insulin; she was afraid of needles and was worried that a friend’s son, a drug addict, might use her syringes to inject them.

headline: Fancy Nancy Lands a TV Deal With Disney
abstract: Disney Junior will make an animated television movie and weekly show from the best-selling “Fancy Nancy” book series.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – With her big-screen debut stalled, Fancy Nancy will instead try her luck on a small one.

headline: Milton Glaser on Starting New York Magazine, the Serendipity of ‘I Heart NY’ and Selling His First Nudes
abstract: The 85-year-old graphic designer gives T an insider’s look at the studio where he created some of his most influential work.
lead_paragraph: The sign above the door to Milton Glaser’s Manhattan studio reads “Art is Work,” and for good reason. For the past 60-plus years, 50 of which he’s spent in the same office in Murray Hill, the influential graphic designer has made it his business to give visual identity to the very ideas that have shaped our culture — his sprawling body of work includes both the ever-present “I ♥ NY” logo and a psychedelia-inspired Bob Dylan poster that’s been a dorm-room staple since 1966. Now 85, Glaser invited T into his studio to discuss the early days of New York magazine, the origins of “I ♥ NY” and his lasting impact as a champion of ethical design.

headline: Six Months Later, Small Protest Camp Grows Again in Hong Kong
abstract: The Occupy Central movement has been slowly expanding its presence in the Admiralty district as it approaches the six-month anniversary of the start of the mass pro-democracy demonstrations.
lead_paragraph: After workers under police watch dismantled the main camp of Hong Kong pro-democracy protesters in the Admiralty district in December, a small number of holdouts vowed to fight on.

headline: Video: The Iran Nuclear Talks, and a Matter of Trust
abstract: A Yale student’s project tries to build relations with Iranians as negotiations over that country’s nuclear program reach a critical point.
lead_paragraph: Before dawn on a freezing February morning, Amar Bakshi watched as a crane lifted a gold-colored shipping container off a flatbed truck outside the Yale University Art Gallery in New Haven, Conn. As diplomats consider a deal over Iran’s nuclear program, the shipping container is Mr. Bakshi’s attempt at restoring a relationship with that country.

headline: ‘The Great Leader and the Fighter Pilot,’ by Blaine Harden
abstract: A pilot escapes North Korea in the Cold War’s early days.
lead_paragraph: Gordon G. Chang is the author of ­“Nuclear Showdown: North Korea Takes On the World,” among other books.

headline: Dow Chemical to Merge Unit With Olin
abstract: In a $5 billion deal, Dow shareholders will own 50.5 percent of the rival chemical company.
lead_paragraph: Dow Chemical on Friday took another step to streamline itself in the face of pressure from the activist investor Daniel S. Loeb, agreeing to separate its chlorine business and merge it with the Olin Corporation, another chemical company.

headline: Thomas McGuane’s ‘Crow Fair’
abstract: Thomas McGuane’s story collection, his first in nine years, returns to the untamed spaces of his native Montana.
lead_paragraph: Imagine your hands are trapped in a viscous tarlike substance. How do you get free? Every effort to push and pull embeds you deeper. Eventually, exhausted, you get sucked in all the way and die like an animal in quicksand — unless you’re Thomas McGuane, author of the new story collection “Crow Fair.”

headline: BlackBerry Reports $28 Million Profit in 4th Quarter
abstract: The smartphone maker is in the midst of a major restructuring, limiting production of phones to avoid the financial drains of the past.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — John S. Chen, executive chairman of the ailing smartphone maker BlackBerry, was again asking for patience on Friday after the company produced a surprise, but slim, profit while also posting an unexpected drop in revenue.

headline: Hey, Man, Dig the Crazy Hippie Flicks ‘The Wild Angels’ and ‘Psych-Out’
abstract: The hippie youth exploitation movies “The Wild Angels” and “Psych-Out” are offerings from American International Pictures at the studio’s most lurid and psychedelic.
lead_paragraph: American International Pictures, the studio that pioneered the low-budget drive-in fare of the 1950s, specialized in two genres: horror films and youth pictures. Often, the two modes were conflated. In 1957, AIP unleashed “I Was a Teenage Werewolf”; in 1966, the studio brought forth “The Wild Angels.”

headline: Economy Grew 2.2% in 4th Quarter, Final Estimate Shows
abstract: With recent data showing anemic activity, economists are expecting more subdued growth in the first quarter of this year.
lead_paragraph: The United States economy grew at a rate of slightly more than 2 percent as 2014 drew to a close, but economists fear some of that momentum flagged in the first quarter of this year.

headline: Friday Night Music: The Lone Bellow, Watch Over Us
abstract: A surreally good performance.
lead_paragraph: Yes, I am aware that it’s Friday morning. But I have meetings followed by travel, and probably won’t be able to blog later. Normal service will resume tomorrow.

headline: Fashion Challenges of an Orthodox Female Architect
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A woman who wore only skirts had to dress for a professional meeting and a construction-site tour, with steel-toed boots — at the same time.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: The Passive House in New York
abstract: In New York City, hundreds of new units designed to use a quarter of the energy consumed by traditional homes are in the works.
lead_paragraph: It was less than a decade ago that a building design philosophy from Germany called “passive house” jumped the Atlantic Ocean and quietly took root in Brooklyn.

headline: An Interesting Theory About the Shoe Bubble, Courtesy of Jimmy Choo
abstract: The sector is so complicated that the global giants have left it to independents, the Choo chief executive maintains.
lead_paragraph: I defy anyone these days not to go to one of the megaliths that masquerade as the shoe floor of a department store (Harrods’ 42,000 square feet of shoe space, say, or Macy’s 63,000, or the Level Shoe District in Dubai’s 96,000) and scratch her head in amazement at the sheer number of shoes in the world, followed shortly thereafter by the corollary question: Can there really be that many shoe consumers?

headline: At Least 2 People Missing After Explosion in Lower Manhattan
abstract: Emergency workers began the delicate and complicated task of sifting through the debris of three buildings in the East Village that were destroyed the day before in an explosion and fire.
lead_paragraph: Two people remained missing on Friday as emergency workers began the delicate and complicated task of sifting through the debris of three buildings in the East Village that were destroyed the day before in an explosion and fire.

headline: Harry Reid to Retire From Senate When His Term Is Up
abstract: The minority leader will leave the Senate at the end of his current term.
lead_paragraph: Harry Reid to Retire From Senate in 2016

headline: A NoLIta Condo by the Architect Tadao Ando
abstract: The revered Japanese architect has designed his first building in New York, a seven-story condo rising at 152 Elizabeth Street.
lead_paragraph: His buildings have risen in Tokyo, Milan, Shanghai and even Butwal, Nepal, but Tadao Ando, the Japanese architect lauded for his artistry and elegance, has never designed one in New York City — until now.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Jill Alexander Essbaum, whose “Hausfrau” is No. 16 on the hardcover fiction list, once called the Bible “a voluptuous buffet of bawd!”
lead_paragraph: The Naughty Bits: “Anna was a good wife, mostly.” That’s the irresistible first sentence of Jill Alexander Essbaum’s debut novel, “Hausfrau,” which recounts the tawdry affairs of a bored housewife in Switzerland (you thought I was going to say Russia, didn’t you?); it enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 16. Essbaum was a poet before she was a novelist, and she’s no stranger to the naughty bits. Her poem “On Reading Poorly Transcribed Erotica” — collected in David Lehman’s 2008 anthology “The Best American Erotic Poems: From 1800 to the Present” — begins like this: “She stood before him wearing only pantries / and he groped for her Volvo under the gauze.” In the contributors’ notes to that volume, asked to name her favorite steamy reading material, Essbaum recalls a childhood appreciation for Harold Robbins and Nancy Friday before finally settling on the Bible. “A voluptuous buffet of bawd!” she declares, singling out passages from the Song of Solomon (of course) and Jeremiah (“Thou hast played the harlot with many lovers,” Jeremiah 3:1). “But for my favorite perverse verse,” she concludes, “I’m keen to point to one that — were I equally inclined and indecorous — I might assign to particularize my own prickly proclivities: ‘There she lusted after her lovers, whose genitals were like those of donkeys and whose emission was like that of horses’ (Ezekiel 23:20). Preach it, sister!” In other words: The Bible is a Good Book, mostly.

headline: Cleaning Out Gmail
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Compact Discs', 'E-Mail', 'iPhone', 'Audiobooks']
abstract: Messages moved to Trash must be manually deleted to regain space immediately. Also, how to convert audiobook CDs for the iPhone.

headline: In Hot Pursuit of Ice and Cold
abstract: In paintings and photographs, an artist captures the incomparable blues and greens of an Arctic landscape.
lead_paragraph: In paintings and photographs, an artist captures the incomparable blues and greens of an Arctic landscape.

headline: A New Resort for Post-Hurricane Los Cabos
abstract: Last fall’s Hurricane Odile paused construction in the Los Cabos region, but the beach resort area at the tip of Mexico’s Baja Peninsula will continue its comeback with the June 13 opening of the Cape, a Thompson Hotel, the first new hotel to open in the region since the storm.
lead_paragraph: Last fall’s Hurricane Odile paused construction in the Los Cabos region, but the beach resort area at the tip of Mexico’s Baja Peninsula will continue its comeback with the June 13 opening of the Cape, a Thompson Hotel, the first hotel to open in the region since the storm.

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
abstract: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

abstract: Mr. Cruz is a major political figure. He also has virtually no chance of becoming president. How should journalists deal with that contrast?
lead_paragraph: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshot’s weekly newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

headline: Should We Keep a Low Profile in Space?
abstract: There are fears that sending messages into space could provoke alien aggression.
lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — For more than a half-century, a small group of astronomers has sought intelligent company among the stars. They’ve done so by turning large radio antennas skyward, hoping to eavesdrop on signals from an advanced society. It’s a program known as SETI, the Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence.

headline: Review: ‘On the Nature of Things,’ Karole Armitage’s New Dance Work
abstract: Ms. Armitage hopes her latest dance will inspire people to act on issues like climate change and overpopulation.
lead_paragraph: Some dances aim to entertain, some to tell a story or make a point or transport a viewer with beauty. The goal of “On the Nature of Things,” the latest work by the choreographer Karole Armitage, is to fundamentally alter human behavior and save the world.

headline: 1890: Strange Case of Lunacy
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: A strange case of lunacy on the pont de la Concorde, Paris, in 1890.
lead_paragraph: The pont de la Concorde was on Wednesday [March 26] the scene of a ‘‘bataille de dames’’ which had for its outcome the removal of one of the combattants to the Dépôt infirmary. The lady is the sister-in-law of a well known French general. On Wednesday evening, Mme. L. went for a drive, wearing over her dress a broad tricolored sash. As the carriage was passing across the pont de la Concorde, Mme. L. jumped out, and, going up to a lady pedestrian, snatched the latter’s umbrella from her hand and broke it over her head. The lady attacked defended herself to the best of her power, but she had been rather severely handled ere the police came up and dragged Mme. L. off. At the Dépôt, Mme. L. declared that she was Joan of Arc, and had been sent back into the world in the flesh to liberate her country a second time. — The New York Herald, European Edition, March 28, 1890

headline: Milton Glaser’s Legacy
abstract: 19 reasons to love the graphic-design icon.
lead_paragraph: Milton Glaser, one of the world’s most celebrated graphic designers, may also be its most iconic. The illustrator, 85, established a cult following in the ’60s and ’70s with his now-ubiquitous “I ♥ NY” logo and as the co-founder of both New York magazine and the influential design firm Push Pin Studios, though his reach extends far beyond the Empire State. A classically trained artist who studied under the painter Giorgio Morandi, Glaser creates instantly recognizable images — like the psychedelic silhouette he made of Bob Dylan in 1966 — that blur the line between fine art and graphic design. He has conceived book jackets for Philip Roth, album covers for Nina Simone and branding for the Winter Olympics, and in 2009, he became the first graphic designer to receive the National Medal of the Arts. Here, a look at the indelible mark of Manhattan’s most colorful campaigner.

headline: As Job Rate Rises, Older Workers Are Often Left Behind

keywords: ['Disabilities', 'Personal Finances', 'Families and Family Life', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Retirement']

headline: Add Uncertainty to Your Financial Plans
abstract: In an excerpt from “The One-Page Financial Plan,” the author suggests taking a best guess on the future, based on personal values.
lead_paragraph: Human beings don’t like uncertainty, especially when we’re contemplating our financial futures. It’s not enough for us to think that we’ll have enough money to send our kids to college, or to retire. We want to know exactly how much money we’ll need to achieve those goals — and precisely how we’re going to get it.

lead_paragraph: A Munich court has struck down a legal challenge by a cousin of Cornelius Gurlitt who claimed that she should inherit works from his vast art collection. Mr. Gurlitt had bequeathed the works to the Kunstmuseum Bern in Switzerland, and the court ruled that they rightfully belong there.

I almost thought it was a joke. There were plenty of fools and foolishness involved in this nonsense, but it’s not April 1 yet.

headline: 1940: Crew Not Guilty of Mutiny
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: 1940: Crew of French freighter Winnipeg not guilty of mutiny.
lead_paragraph: BORDEAUX – Thirty-nine members of the crew of the French freighter Winnipeg were absolved of charges of mutiny today [March 27] by a maritime court which deliberated forty-five minutes before giving its decision. ‘‘Much ado about nothing,’’ one of the defense lawyers characterized the two-day trial, and apparently the judges agreed with him. The crew members, who had been held in prison three months, were accused of mutiny after they refused to sail for France from a South American port on the first day of the war. ‘‘The case was born of an excited imagination,’’ said M. de Moro-Giafferi. ‘‘The crew has been imprisoned and slandered when all that the men wanted was an equitable judgment. The sailors maintained that they had not mutinied, but had refused to leave port under their captain, whom they considered irresponsible. Several testified they had heard the captain threaten to ‘‘run his ship aground and demolish it.’’ Politics or war conditions had nothing to do with the refusal, according to the crew. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 28, 1940

headline: A New View for NYTimes Photos

lead_paragraph: The New York Times loves photos. We publish around 700 images every single day. These run the gamut from delectable dessert close-ups to evidence of the ravaging effects of climate change. We have an entire blog dedicated to photojournalism, and we currently work with over 3,600 photographers who have shot over 30,000 assignments in the past two years. Photos are an important part of our journalism and the stories we tell.

headline: In Song: Tales of Personal Finance
abstract: Ron Lieber describes what inspired the Business section to commission a song about personal finance, in lieu of an article, for a recent special section.
lead_paragraph: I first heard of (and heard) Amy Speace in college, though she had no idea who I was. A lowly freshman boy with enough singing skills to land in the glee club but not enough to make the a cappella groups, I could only listen in wonder when she, a glamorous senior, sang solos in her own group.

headline: Second Thoughts
abstract: We didn’t intend to focus in this issue on previously disdained periods of design, but we did just that, and we feel really good about it.
lead_paragraph: One of the great pleasures of an interest in design is being converted to ideas you hadn’t fully grasped or admired the first time around. The style I’ve always cringed at most — that of the international, postmodern Memphis group, which existed from 1981 to 1987 — now seems kind of appealing: cheerfully earnest and playfully rigorous. The current influence of Memphis, which is popping up everywhere all of a sudden, is to be found throughout these pages. So is the renewed taste for furniture and décor from the 1970s. We didn’t intend to focus in this issue on previously disdained periods of design, but we did just that, and we feel really good about it.
