headline: What I Love | Stewart Lane and Bonnie Comley
abstract: The Broadway producers live in a 4,000-square-foot duplex penthouse on the Upper East Side.
lead_paragraph: The Broadway producers live in a 4,000-square-foot duplex penthouse on the Upper East Side.

headline: Citadel Securities Said to Close Apogee Dark Pool
abstract: The move is part of a shift in focus and resources to another off-exchange trading platform, Citadel Connect, a person close to the firm said.
lead_paragraph: Citadel Securities is preparing to close its Apogee dark pool as it focuses on another so-called off-exchange trading platform.

headline: Firefighter’s Account of East Village Blast: ‘Oh Man, It’s a Big One’
abstract: Firefighter Mike Shepherd was off duty and eating lunch near the site of the fire in Lower Manhattan on Thursday. After he heard the explosion, he raced to the scene.
lead_paragraph: Firefighter Mike Shepherd, 47, of Squad 41 in the Bronx, is a third-generation New York City firefighter, following in the path of his grandfather and great-grandfather. When there was an explosion at a building in the East Village on Thursday, he raced to the scene.

headline: Kendrick Lamar, Dissenting From the Mainstream as He Influences It
abstract: Discussing the rapper’s new album, “To Pimp A Butterfly.”
lead_paragraph: Discussing the rapper’s new album, “To Pimp A Butterfly.”

headline: Which Companies Are Buying the Election?
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Editorials', 'Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The S.E.C. still has not put political-spending disclosure on its to-do list.
lead_paragraph: Midway into a three-and-a-half-hour congressional hearing this week featuring Mary Jo White, the chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, none of the legislators had bothered to ask if or when her agency would require that corporations disclose their political spending.

headline: Obama Praises Harry Reid in Call to Radio Station
abstract: President Obama took a few minutes on Friday to call into Nevada’s National Public Radio station during an interview with Mr. Reid.
lead_paragraph: Fresh on the heels of Senator Harry Reid’s retirement announcement, President Obama took a few minutes on Friday to call into Nevada’s National Public Radio station during an interview with Mr. Reid.

headline: What the Jury in the Ellen Pao-Kleiner Perkins Case Needed to Decide
abstract: Members of the jury had to sift through seven pages of verdict questions in a trial that pitted the venture firm against a former junior partner who claimed that she was discriminated against and was ultimately let go after complaining.
lead_paragraph: Members of the jury had to sift through seven pages of verdict questions in a trial that pitted the venture firm against a former junior partner who claimed that she was discriminated against and was ultimately let go after complaining.

headline: Israeli Center-Left Leader Seeks Path Forward
abstract: Isaac Herzog, who ran to unseat Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, does not see the campaign or its result in simple win-loss terms.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — Isaac Herzog is not acting like a sore loser. He is not seeking scapegoats to blame for his center-left Zionist Union’s failure to capture enough votes in Israel’s election last week to unseat Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. He is not shouting “I told you so” as the Obama administration and Europe threaten to isolate Israel as never before.

headline: What John Bolton Gets Wrong About Iran
abstract: If bombing Iran is such a great idea, why didn’t the Bush administration do it years ago?
lead_paragraph: John Bolton’s best quality may be that he says what he thinks. Diplomats are trained to set aside personal beliefs as they fulfill their professional duties but even when Mr. Bolton was a senior official in the administration of President George W. Bush, and supposed to be exercising discretion, he was brash and outspoken.

headline: Popcast: Kendrick Lamar, Dissenting From the Mainstream as He Influences It
abstract: Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli discuss Kendrick Lamar and the rapper’s new album, “To Pimp A Butterfly.”
lead_paragraph: Last week, Kendrick Lamar released his second album “To Pimp a Butterfly” (TDE/Aftermath/Interscope), one of this year’s most anticipated releases in any genre, and also one of the least likely. (It was surprise-released online, a week before its advertised release.)

headline: Paul Walker’s Films, Beyond ‘The Fast and the Furious’
abstract: A look at the actor’s films, from “Eight Below” to “Takers,” finds a man ready to flash a smile.
lead_paragraph: When “Furious 7” opens on April 3, Paul Walker will appear one last time as Brian O’Conner, the role that introduced him to many moviegoers. Like several of Mr. Walker’s characters, O’Conner follows his heart. He begins his journey on one side of the law, but doesn’t stay there. Mr. Walker was the cool, laid-back California dude who often seemed to be having a ball on screen. In most of his films, he ran with a diverse crew and was ready with a bro handshake and a quick laugh.

headline: Slack Gets Hacked as Start-Up Technologies Become Targets
abstract: Communications start-up Slack gets hacked, just days after Twitch discloses a similar incident.
lead_paragraph: Security breaches at start-up technologies are starting to become the new normal.

headline: Beyoncé Designs a Shoe, McDonald’s Ready-to-Wear and the American Apparel Saga Continues
abstract: Plus, this is an Alaïa, no e-commerce for Céline and more from the week in style.
lead_paragraph: All the week’s fashion news that’s fit to reprint.

headline: With Keen Eye for Derby Talent, Todd Pletcher Begins Chase
abstract: Pletcher is expected to run some talented horses in the Kentucky Derby prep races, but his 1-for-40 Derby history underscores how perilous the month ahead may be.
lead_paragraph: HALLANDALE BEACH, Fla. — The horse trainer Todd Pletcher appears to be in an enviable position before the Kentucky Derby on May 2, given the caliber and depth of talent he is sending into key prep races during the next two weekends. But Pletcher’s 1-for-40 Derby history, and the stars he has developed who never got there, underscore how perilous the days ahead may be.

headline: Broadway Producers and Their Upper East Side Penthouse
abstract: Stewart F. Lane and Bonnie Comley have lived in their duplex for some 18 years.
lead_paragraph: Unlike most New Yorkers, the Broadway producers Stewart F. Lane and Bonnie Comley haven’t minded the harsh winter.

headline: A Townhouse on a Prime Block for $14,990,000
abstract: A limestone and white brick townhouse on a prime block on the Upper East Side was the sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: A stately limestone and white brick townhouse on a prime block on the Upper East Side, with a filigree wrought-iron fence guarding two sunken gardens in the front and with a paved garden in the back, sold for $14,990,000 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Dow Chemical Tempts Fate With $5 Billion Deal
abstract: The valuation looks solid, especially considering the tax savings. But investors should remain wary given the history of such complex transactions.
lead_paragraph: Dow Chemical is tempting fate with its $5 billion chlorine sale. The $54 billion company is offloading the bulk of its low-margin bleach and vinyl-related operations to a smaller rival, the Olin Corporation, using an esoteric structure known as a reverse Morris Trust. The valuation looks solid, especially considering the tax savings. Yet investors should remain wary given the history of such complex deals.

headline: Shiite Militias in Iraq Back Off Boycott Over U.S. Strikes on ISIS
abstract: A message of support from Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, a religious leader in Iraq, apparently has the militias cooperating with the role of the United States.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — A day after several Shiite militias quit the offensive against the Islamic State in protest of American airstrikes, senior Iraqi leaders made assurances on Friday that the militiamen would adhere to government command and cooperate with the American role.

headline: Steve Lavin and St. John’s Part Ways
abstract: The announcement on Friday came a week after the coach led St. John’s back to the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament for the first time in four years.
lead_paragraph: A week after leading St. John’s back to the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament for the first time in four years, Coach Steve Lavin has agreed to part ways with the Red Storm, the university announced Friday.

headline: Monica Lewinsky: Cultural Rorschach Test?
keywords: ['Bullies', 'Computers and the Internet', 'TED Conference', 'Women and Girls', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: Jessica Bennett reflects on the reaction to her recent article about Monica Lewinsky and her TED talk, “The Price of Shame.”
lead_paragraph: I told a group of friends at dinner recently that I was working on a story about Monica Lewinsky.

headline: Japanese Fabric, Illustrated
abstract: From a series for T in which the artist Leanne Shapton makes new artworks from pictures in old books.
lead_paragraph: From a series for T in which the artist Leanne Shapton makes new artworks from pictures in old books.

headline: Brothers Sentenced to Three Years for Selling Guns Overseas
abstract: The two men, a former New York police officer and a federal customs officer, were sentenced after illegally shipping military-grade weapons to the Philippines.
lead_paragraph: Two brothers, one a former New York City police officer and the other a federal customs officer, were sentenced on Friday to three years in prison for illegally exporting military-grade weapons to the Philippines for more than four years.

headline: Firefighter Searches for Blast Victims
abstract: Video shows the moments immediately after an explosion at a building in the East Village on Thursday, with a firefighter, Mike Shepherd, climbing a drop ladder to search for anyone trapped inside.
lead_paragraph: Video shows the moments immediately after an explosion at a building in the East Village on Thursday, with a firefighter, Mike Shepherd, climbing a drop ladder to search for anyone trapped inside.

headline: Learning to Say No to Dialysis
abstract: Some older adults with advanced kidney failure are resisting the usual answer by deciding the sacrifices required by the treatment aren’t worth it.
lead_paragraph: Gerald J. Hladik was 74 when the day long anticipated by his doctors arrived: His kidneys, damaged years earlier by a viral infection, had lost 85 percent of their function.

headline: British Museum to Open Gallery Dedicated to Islamic Art
abstract: The new gallery will include sections devoted to Islamic art before 1500 as well as three 16th-century Islamic dynasties.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British Museum will open a new gallery in 2018 dedicated to a broad swath of Islamic art, the museum announced.

headline: Yellen Says Fed Will Increase Rates Slowly
abstract: The return to normalcy in monetary policy will be prolonged, the Fed chairwoman said, because the American economy remains fragile.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, said on Friday that the Fed planned to raise interest rates more slowly than in past recoveries because of the unusually fragile condition of the American economy.

headline: In ‘iZombie,’ Rose McIver Devours Her Brainiest Role Yet
abstract: Rose McIver talks about her elaborate makeup job and on-camera diet as an undead former medical student in CW’s “iZombie.”
lead_paragraph: Rose McIver looks awfully alive for someone playing undead. In “iZombie,” her new CW series, she’s a vision of iron deficiency — ghostly pallor, under-eye circles the color of eggplant, brittle platinum bob — as Olivia Moore, a Type A medical student turned zombified coroner’s assistant with a taste for human brains. The twist? Those brains, fresh from the morgue’s cadavers, allow her to channel the memories of the deceased and feed crime information to the Seattle homicide division.

headline: There’s Just One Problem With Photos on Food Stamp Cards
keywords: ['Food Stamps', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Identification Devices', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores']
abstract: Under federal law, you sometimes have a right to use a food stamp card that was issued to someone else.
lead_paragraph: Putting photos on the cards people use to redeem food stamps seems like a simple anti-fraud idea. But in Massachusetts, which started putting photos on Electronic Benefit Transfer cards in 2013, it hasn’t worked out for reasons that should have been obvious from the outset, according to a report from the Urban Institute, a left-of-center think tank.

headline: ‘RainForest,’ Cunningham’s Primeval Rarity, Returns to the Joyce
abstract: The Stephen Petronio Company takes on Merce Cunningham’s “RainForest” and its Warholian clouds at the Joyce Theater.
lead_paragraph: “RainForest,” a dance made by Merce Cunningham in 1968, has décor like no other theater piece: helium-filled silver pillows by Andy Warhol that he called “Silver Clouds.” Encountering a flock of them that year at a Warhol exhibition, Cunningham at once spotted their theatrical potential. Four to six of them are moored to the stage, where they sway or bounce like forest undergrowth. Most, however, are loose; some get sent flying by performers. It’s not uncommon during the action for a cloud to float out into the auditorium.

headline: Jordi Savall’s Never-Ending Repertory
abstract: Mr. Savall, whose ethos has always been wide-ranging and open-minded, has long been an eminence, but he has become a true elder statesman.
lead_paragraph: For the Catalan early-music master Jordi Savall, who has spent decades rediscovering works that had vanished for centuries, the most difficult aspect of the 2011 death of his wife and performing partner, the singer Montserrat Figueras, may have been the music that’s once again disappeared.

headline: Alabama Police Officer Indicted in Confrontation With Unarmed Indian Man
abstract: Eric Parker, 26, is accused on a federal charge of violating the civil rights of Sureshbhai Patel, 57, whom Officer Parker slammed to the ground Feb. 6.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — An Alabama police officer has been indicted by a federal grand jury, accused of using unreasonable force against an unarmed Indian man during an episode in which the officer slammed the man to the ground while he was on an early-morning stroll through his family’s suburban neighborhood.

headline: Oklahoma Inquiry Traces Racist Song to National Gathering of Fraternity
abstract: David L. Boren, the university president, says his campus’s Sigma Alpha Epsilon members learned the song on a cruise four years ago.
lead_paragraph: NORMAN, Okla. — A racist song that caused a national uproar when it was caught on video was a fixture within a fraternity chapter at the University of Oklahoma and not an anomaly, the university reported Friday, and members first learned it at a gathering of the national fraternity four years ago.

headline: Oklahoma President on Racist Chant
abstract: David L. Boren, president of the University of Oklahoma, said that disciplinary measures had been taken against fraternity members involved in a racist chant.
lead_paragraph: David L. Boren, president of the University of Oklahoma, said that disciplinary measures had been taken against fraternity members involved in a racist chant.

headline: Weed Killer, Long Cleared, Is Doubted
abstract: The Environmental Protection Agency gave the maker of Roundup a thumbs up in 1991, but a World Health Organization group now says the active ingredient “probably” causes cancer.
lead_paragraph: Thirty years ago, an Environmental Protection Agency committee determined that the popular weed killer Roundup might cause cancer. Six years later, in 1991, the agency reversed itself after re-evaluating the mouse study that had been the basis for the original conclusion.

abstract: This week’s featured properties include homes on the Upper West Side, in Lincoln Square and Boerum Hill.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in New York City:

headline: Exposing Hedge Fund Politics in New York
keywords: ['Hedge Funds', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: The Hedge Clippers activist group works to publicize the ways hedge funds bleed the economy through self-interested practice, then extend the damage through the lavish purchase of political influence.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, several busloads of New Yorkers made a pilgrimage to Greenwich, Conn., to visit the waterfront estate of the hedge fund titan Paul Tudor Jones II, where, suffice it to say, they were not invited in to see the china. It was a rainy Saturday afternoon and the protesters, many of them ordinary working people who have felt cheated by the inequities of a tax system that favors the rarefied few, were there to call attention to Mr. Jones’s educational agenda, built on the premise that the extravagantly rich know better how to teach reading, and to his support of Republican candidates and causes in the New York State Legislature that disadvantage the poor and working class.

headline: Homes for Sale in New Jersey and Connecticut
abstract: This week’s properties include a nine-bedroom house in West Orange, N.J., and a five-bedroom house in Westport, Conn.

headline: De Blasio’s Blast Investigation Update
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio said there was a possibility that a gas line was “inappropriately accessed” before a building explosion in the East Village.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio said there was a possibility that a gas line was “inappropriately accessed” before a building explosion in the East Village.

headline: Starting a Life Together With Pi
abstract: Jaclyn Sawler and Robert Burton Jr. timed their wedding to pi: 3/14/15 at 9:26:53 a.m. tracking the irrational number.
lead_paragraph: When Robert Burton Jr. proposed to Jaclyn Sawler, he had a wedding date in mind: March 14. He had a time in mind, too: 9:26 a.m. He had his reasons.

headline: ‘Dylan, Cash and the Nashville Cats’
abstract: A new exhibition at the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum in Nashville, explores noted collaborations between rock and country acts and the session musicians who played on the recordings.
lead_paragraph: A new exhibition at the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum in Nashville, explores noted collaborations between rock and country acts and the session musicians who played on the recordings.

headline: Schumer Shores Up Support for Replacing Reid as Party Leader
abstract: The official vote to replace Senator Harry Reid as Democratic leader is still nearly two years away, but that hasn’t stopped Senator Charles E. Schumer from making his move.
lead_paragraph: The official vote to replace Senator Harry Reid as Democratic leader is still nearly two years away, but that hasn’t stopped Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York, now the chamber’s No. 3 Democrat, from making his move.

headline: ‘Dylan, Cash and the Nashville Cats,’ an Unlikely Alliance of Rock and Country
abstract: In the late 1960s and early 1970s, dozens of rock and folk acts traveled to Tennessee and emerged with an astonishing number of hits and classic recordings.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — In recent years, lots of attention has been paid to Nashville’s expansion beyond the country music community, as rockers like Jack White, the Black Keys and Kings of Leon have relocated here to take advantage of the history, atmosphere and infrastructure of Music City, U.S.A. But this, of course, isn’t the first time that artists outside the country tradition have been attracted to Nashville. In the late 1960s and early 1970s, dozens of rock and folk acts traveled to Tennessee and, in a series of unlikely alliances, emerged with an astonishing number of big hits and classic recordings.

headline: Sports Entities Begin to Digest Implications of Indiana Law
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Discrimination', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The N.C.A.A., whose Final Four is in Indianapolis, expressed concern about the law, which would allow denying service to gays and lesbians. The agent Arn Tellem urged teams and leagues to re-evaluate their plans in the state.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Dakari Johnson, one of the towering big men on Kentucky’s undefeated team, played with Derrick Gordon at St. Patrick High School in Elizabeth, N.J. Gordon, who started for Massachusetts this season, announced that we was gay last year.

headline: New Music From Amy Speace, Diagrams and Elle King
abstract: Pondering heartache and humanity, with honky-tonk and richly surreal reverberations.
lead_paragraph: Amy Speace

headline: In Mexico, Firing of Carmen Aristegui Highlights Rising Pressures on News Media
keywords: ['Freedom of the Press', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Many believe Ms. Aristegui, a leading radio personality, and her team were fired after a report on a mansion built for the president’s wife by a company with lucrative government contracts.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — When Carmen Aristegui, Mexico’s most famous radio personality, was abruptly fired this month, nobody expected her to go quietly. But anger over her dismissal has been rising steadily, and it has turned up the heat in this country’s charged political atmosphere.

lead_paragraph: Nigeria and Elsewhere – Pictures of the Day

lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

abstract: Couples tackle hard issues in premarital counseling.
lead_paragraph: The risk of self-delusion is ever-present in the days leading up to a wedding.

headline: March 27, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Nigeria, Myanmar, Somalia and the United States.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Nigeria, Myanmar, Somalia and the United States.

headline: What Explains Brazil’s Surfing Boom?
abstract: Suddenly, the country is dominating the sport.
lead_paragraph: BRAZIL has gone surf crazy.

headline: How Patricia Field, Costume Designer for Fashionable Characters, Spends Her Sunday
abstract: Patricia Field, when she is not at her namesake store on the Bowery, spends her Sundays out of the house, in her car, at the beach, in a store.
lead_paragraph: Patricia Field, a New York fashion fixture since opening her first boutique in 1966, has also become a successful costume designer, dressing Meryl Streep in “The Devil Wears Prada,” Vanessa Williams in “Ugly Betty” and Sarah Jessica Parker in “Sex and the City.” Her next project, “Younger,” will debut on TV Land on March 31. When she’s not at her namesake store on the Bowery, the fiery-headed 73-year-old lives in the Seward Park Cooperative on the Lower East Side with her poodles, Sultana and Putana, also known as Pooty.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting interesting stories from around the web. In this installment, great reads from John Branch, Jenna Wortham and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: New Excursions for Grandparents and Their Grandchildren
abstract: Road Scholar is introducing summer sessions for grandparents and their college-age grandchildren in Cuba and Costa Rica, among other destinations.
lead_paragraph: Road Scholar, a travel company that specializes in 55-and-older learning excursions, is introducing a series of intergenerational “summer sessions” for grandparents and their college-age grandchildren. The new programs include cultural exchanges in Cuba, Costa Rica and Ireland, with itineraries designed to educate and bond families.

headline: Ellen Pao Loses Silicon Valley Bias Case Against Kleiner Perkins
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Discrimination', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Venture Capital', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: A jury rejected allegations of gender discrimination against the venture capital firm, after a hitch caused the judge to order further deliberations.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — One of Silicon Valley’s most famous venture capital firms prevailed on Friday over a former partner in a closely watched suit claiming gender discrimination, but hardly got away unscathed.

headline: Hidden Healthcare Horrors
abstract: There must be victims somewhere, right?
lead_paragraph: One of the odder subplots of the health reform saga has been the almost pathetic efforts of Republicans to come up with Obamacare horror stories. You might think that given the complexity of the law and the almost unlimited resources of the propaganda machine, they’d be able to come up with someone to serve as the poster child of the law’s terrible effects on innocent Americans. As far as I know, however, we have yet to see a single credible example — all the characters featured in Koch brothers ads or GOP speeches have turned out to be potential beneficiaries of the Affordable Care Act, if only they were willing to look at their actual options.

headline: Intel Said to Be in Talks to Acquire Chip Maker
abstract: Intel is in discussions to buy Altera, a designer of specialized computer chips, in what would be one of the technology giant’s biggest deals ever, says a person briefed on the matter.
lead_paragraph: Intel is in discussions to buy Altera, a designer of specialized computer chips, a person briefed on the matter said on Friday. It would be one of the company’s biggest deals ever.

headline: New Talent, New Work
abstract: The next generation of American designers is experimenting with form — inspired by everything from organic shapes in nature to the funky geometries of postmodernism.
lead_paragraph: The next generation of American designers is experimenting with form — inspired by everything from organic shapes in nature to the funky geometries of postmodernism.

headline: The ‘Street-Level’ Artist
abstract: B. D. White, 31, who suffered a spinal cord injury as a teenager and uses a wheelchair, moved to Brooklyn to pursue his art. Ignored by galleries, he made the city his canvas.
lead_paragraph: At roughly 2 a.m. last Monday morning, B. D. White, 31, drove through Chinatown, working the gas and break with his left hand. He stopped on Division Street and eyed a graffiti-strewn section of brick wall.

headline: How to Make Investing Safer
keywords: ['Financial Brokers', 'Law and Legislation', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Personal Finances', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: In New York State, financial advisers don’t have to act in their clients’ best interests. Scott Stringer’s proposal would at least make that clear.
lead_paragraph: As the comptroller of New York City, Scott Stringer oversees five municipal public pension funds with $160 billion in assets.

headline: Indiana Law Denounced as Invitation to Discriminate Against Gays
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Discrimination', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: A measure described as protecting religious freedom was assailed by political and business leaders because it could allow businesses to refuse service to gay couples.
lead_paragraph: An Indiana law that could make it easier for religious conservatives to refuse service to gay couples touched off storms of protest on Friday from the worlds of arts, business and college athletics and opened an emotional new debate in the emerging campaign for president.

headline: ‘Hamilton’ Puts Politics Onstage and Politicians in Attendance
abstract: Political figures, including Clintons and Cheneys, have turned out to watch their “predecessors” onstage in the musical “Hamilton.”
lead_paragraph: The hip-hop musical “Hamilton,” featuring a mainly black and Latino cast playing America’s founding fathers, has drawn a steady stream of boldface names since it began its sold-out run at the Public Theater in January.

headline: Cedar Lake Ballet’s Closing Reveals the Perils of Relying on a Single Donor
abstract: With a wealthy patron, the company had been the envy of many in New York’s dance world. Then its benefactor had a change of heart.
lead_paragraph: Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet was the envy of many in New York’s dance world: It had a wealthy patron who loved dance, provided good pay and benefits to its dancers, built the troupe a chic Chelsea home and almost single-handedly bore the brunt of the company’s costs.

headline: Review: Argento Chamber Ensemble Brings Out Mahler’s Inventive Side
abstract: The ensemble played his “Songs of a Wayfarer” and contemporary selections by composers he influenced, underlining his highly original quirks.
lead_paragraph: “America for the moment has no idea of what to make of me,” Mahler wrote to a Swiss correspondent in 1908 as he was rehearsing his Symphony No. 2 with the New York Symphony Orchestra. A century later, Mahler’s music is a familiar and well-loved fixture on American concert stages. But this season the inspired Argento Chamber Ensemble is making the case for a fresh listen with a four-concert series titled Mahler as New York Contemporary. By performing the composer’s seminal works in chamber arrangements alongside contemporary pieces that reflect his influence, the group draws attention to aspects of Mahler’s music that remain bracingly original and even weird.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Spring Unfurls
abstract: As the weather fluctuated between harsh and mild, New Yorkers were on the lookout for signs of spring.
lead_paragraph: As the weather fluctuated between harsh and mild, New Yorkers were on the lookout for signs of spring.

headline: Collecting Human Voices With a StoryCorps App
abstract: StoryCorps has amassed a significant trove of American oral history. A new app will allow stories to be collected anywhere in the world.
lead_paragraph: David Isay is a Guggenheim fellow, a longtime audio documentarian and a voice familiar to anyone who has listened to public radio in the last 15 years. He is also the founder of StoryCorps, a Brooklyn organization that collects the stories of ordinary Americans. In its brief existence, StoryCorps has amassed a significant trove of American oral history. In remarks at the annual TED conference in Vancouver a couple of weeks ago, Mr. Isay said StoryCorps held “the largest single collection of human voices ever gathered.”

headline: Talking Photography With Elliott Erwitt
abstract: Elliott Erwitt has been prolific with his photo books, but he warned Todd Heisler that he was a lousy interview. He was wrong. And funny.
lead_paragraph: Elliott Erwitt has been prolific with his photo books, but he warned Todd Heisler that he was a lousy interview. He was wrong. And funny.

headline: Review: Martha Graham and Merce Cunningham Works at Juilliard Dance
abstract: Juilliard Dance’s double bill presents student dancers in Martha Graham’s “Dark Meadow” and Merce Cunningham’s “Biped.”
lead_paragraph: The Juilliard Dance performances of late March have long been one of the finest fixtures on the New York dance calendar. The programs consist of two or more works, often classics; the student dancers spend months preparing with leading authorities. The level of execution is often professionally excellent; it’s easy to believe the students will remember lessons from the choreography for the rest of their lives.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Spring Unfurls
abstract: As the weather fluctuated between harsh and mild, New Yorkers were on the lookout for signs of spring.
lead_paragraph: As the weather fluctuated between harsh and mild, New Yorkers were on the lookout for signs of spring, such as the blossoming of magnolia trees on the lawn of the Frick Collection. A stunning visual in Bryant Park was the transformation of the skating rink into a turf-covered lawn. On the fashion front, legs emerged, and New Yorkers added a surprising color to their signature black-white-and-gray looks: chrome silver.

headline: Notable Deaths of 2015
abstract: Remembering Oliver Sacks, B.B. King, Leonard Nimoy, Happy Rockefeller, E.L. Doctorow, Maya Plisetskaya, Omar Sharif and many others who died this year.
lead_paragraph: Remembering Oliver Sacks, B.B. King, Leonard Nimoy, Happy Rockefeller, E.L. Doctorow, Maya Plisetskaya, Omar Sharif and many others who died this year.

headline: Review: Melissa Manchester, Liberated, at 54 Below
abstract: High spirits predominated when Ms. Manchester performed songs from her most recent album, decades after her biggest hits.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Manchester has a history of laboring in other people’s shadows. At the start of her career, her mentors included Barry Manilow and Bette Midler, with whom she sang backup in Ms. Midler’s saucy group the Harlettes. At the height of her popularity in the 1970s, she was guided in her choice of material for both good and ill by the redoubtable record company honcho Clive Davis. Only recently has Ms. Manchester, who lives in Southern California and teaches music at the University of Southern California, emerged fully into the light.

headline: In Hamilton Heights, a Link to Ecuador
abstract: The identity of Hamilton Heights has been in flux, but the Ecuadorean community’s impact on the neighborhood is alive at Ecuatoriana Restaurant.
lead_paragraph: The identity of Hamilton Heights has been in flux, but the Ecuadorean community’s impact on the neighborhood is alive at Ecuatoriana Restaurant.

headline: Review: Trio 3 Shows Off Its Jazz Avant-Garde Pedigree
abstract: The group’s first set at the Village Vanguard this week moved briskly through its allotted hour, propelled by cooperative forces.
lead_paragraph: One misperception about the jazz avant-garde is that it’s essentially reactive, a single-minded pushback against conventions of form. Whatever lump of truth or slander you might find in that idea, Trio 3, which is playing at the Village Vanguard, provides scant supporting evidence for it.

headline: Review: John Adams Unveils ‘Scheherazade.2,’ an Answer to Male Brutality
abstract: The New York Philharmonic presented the world premiere of this symphony, a response to brutality against women in Arab folklore and around the world today.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, the composer John Adams took in an exhibition at the Arab World Institute in Paris about the history of the “Arabian Nights” collection of folk stories. He already knew, or so he thought, the tale of Scheherazade, the young woman forced into marriage with a Persian king who takes a succession of virgins as wives and has each one executed the morning after lest she have a chance to dishonor him. Scheherazade delays her own death by telling the king a riveting tale night after night.

headline: Review: Tobias Jesso Jr., Puppyish and Playful, Plays the Mercury Lounge
abstract: The singer played selections from his new album, “Goon,” in what was billed as his first official New York concert.
lead_paragraph: “I’m going to switch to guitar — that cool?” Tobias Jesso Jr. was a few songs into his first official New York concert Thursday night, and he was ready for a change. He got up from behind the piano, an instrument he began playing only a couple of years ago at age 27, and shuffled over to the other side of the stage, where a guitar was waiting for him.

headline: A Co-Pilot Bent on Destruction
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Pilots', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: Readers respond to news articles and an editorial about the plane crash in the French Alps.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Ecuatoriana Restaurant Is a Link to Ecuador in Harlem
abstract: While much of the Ecuadorean community in the Sugar Hill area of Hamilton Heights has moved out, its impact on the neighborhood remains alive at Ecuatoriana Restaurant.
lead_paragraph: On a high ridge in West Harlem, a steady wind from the bluffs of the Jersey Palisades reflects the swirling dynamics of the Sugar Hill area of Hamilton Heights, whose identity has been in steady flux since the days when Harlem was in vogue and Duke Ellington dispensed subway directions. One of the more recent cultures to pass through this historic area was that of the Ecuadoreans. And while most have moved east to Queens or north to the Bronx, and beyond into Westchester, the impression they left on the neighborhood remains alive and vital at Ecuatoriana Restaurant, on Amsterdam Avenue between West 143rd and 144th Streets.

headline: Baselworld, Where the Watch Is Still the Greatest Gadget
abstract: The giant watch fair in Switzerland draws aficionados of timepieces worn in the time-honored way.
lead_paragraph: BASEL, Switzerland — “Are you wearing a Fifty Fathoms?”

headline: What Silicon Valley Learned From the Kleiner Perkins Case
abstract: Despite the verdict, the tech industry is already rethinking its indifference to some modern workplace rules, including treatment of women like Ellen Pao.
lead_paragraph: Kleiner Perkins’s victory Friday in the gender discrimination suit brought by Ellen Pao could be seen as an affirmation of the Silicon Valley old boys club. But venture capitalists have said that the trial has already put the tech industry on notice: It can no longer operate as a band of outsiders, often oblivious to rules that govern the modern workplace — even if that has been a key to its success.

headline: A Deal From the Machlin Women’s Swiss Teams
abstract: Sunday was the last day of the Spring Nationals in New Orleans.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, the last day of the Spring Nationals in New Orleans, the Machlin Women’s Swiss Teams was won by Lynn Baker of Austin, Tex.; Karen McCallum of Exeter, N.H.; Pamela Granovetter of Cincinnati; JoAnna Stansby of Dublin, Calif.; Irina Levitina of Hackensack, N.J.; and Kerri Sanborn of Delray Beach, Fla.

headline: A Broadway Composer Takes a Night Off for Drag Queens
abstract: Jeanine Tesori took a night away from her new show, “Fun Home,” to judge an “American Idol”-style competition for drag queens.
lead_paragraph: Jeanine Tesori is the award-winning composer behind “Caroline, or Change” and “Thoroughly Modern Millie,” but Broadway shows aren’t truly her favorite thing.

headline: Review: In ‘Flexn,’ Street Dance Gets a Grand Stage
abstract: The Brooklyn street-dance form known as flex gets a show of grand proportions at the Park Avenue Armory.
lead_paragraph: Get-low, gliding, bone-breaking, connecting, pauzin, waving: Even the language of flexing, a street-dance style born in Jamaica and raised in the Brooklyn neighborhood of East New York, pops with energy. Flip through the enormous program book for “Flexn,” a show of grand proportions that opened on Wednesday at the Park Avenue Armory, and you’ll find a “Flexapedia” defining these terms. It’s a glossary of action words. Flexing is doing.

headline: Review: Shaina Taub, Prolific Earth Mother, and Friends
abstract: The singer-songwriter Shaina Taub deployed a musical army in her American Songbook concert, performing her distinctive blend of Broadway-oriented pop and gospel.
lead_paragraph: The singer and songwriter Shaina Taub belongs to a breed of performers who, apart from being artists, are gravitational forces around whom others cluster like filings to a magnet. For her concert on Wednesday at the Kaplan Penthouse as part of Lincoln Center’s American Songbook series, Ms. Taub commanded a musical army that included a sizable chorus and a horn section in a program of 19 original songs. A prolific songwriter, Ms. Taub won a 2014 Jonathan Larson Grant, awarded to rising musical-theater talents.

headline: Amanda Knox Acquitted of 2007 Murder by Italy’s Highest Court
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The acquittal of Ms. Knox and her former boyfriend, Raffaele Sollecito, ended a long-running legal drama over the killing of a British student.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Italy’s highest court overturned the murder convictions of Amanda Knox and her Italian former boyfriend on Friday, throwing out all charges and ending a long-running courtroom drama over the killing of a British student in 2007.

headline: Sustenance From the Scrap Heap
abstract: WastED, a monthlong pop-up at Blue Hill Restaurant with the idea to create high cuisine out of what is usually discarded and to highlight the dishes during a monthlong pop-up at his restaurant in the Village.
lead_paragraph: If America is a country of agricultural abundance, it is also one of great waste. Surplus at every level of the food chain, from farming to fishing to distributing and processing, goes in the trash heap. In comes Dan Barber, the renowned chef at Blue Hill restaurant, with the idea of creating high cuisine out of what is usually discarded and to highlight the dishes at a monthlong pop-up at his restaurant in the West Village, called WastED. “I was studying the history of cuisines, and I started seeing something kind of obvious, that cuisines by their nature evolved by utilizing waste,” Mr. Barber said. “Maybe some of this stuff on the menu will end up coming around to everyday food culture. Chefs and restaurants have that power.”

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Inside T’s Design Issue
abstract: Our latest issue looks backward to the aesthetics of the hedonistic ’70s and oddly alluring po-mo ’80s.
lead_paragraph: T’s latest issue examines the current state of design by looking backward — namely, to the hedonistic ’70s and oddly alluring po-mo ’80s. The onetime California home of Gerald and Betty Ford is a perfect example of this revival; its new owners have kept many of the house’s original charms (including a giant portrait of the former First Lady), while adding their own contemporary touches, to create a space that’s anything but conservative. Likewise, the purist Mark Haddawy — the co-founder of the retailer Resurrection Vintage and restorer of Modernist houses — has doubled down on his version of ’70s California cool by doing very little to his own home in Big Sur. And the fashion reporter and insider Mary Russell, who for many years was as likely to cavort among (and occasionally hop in bed with) her stylish subjects as she was to photograph them, reminisces about Europe in the freewheeling ’60s and ’70s. Elsewhere, Nicola Del Roscio, the longtime close companion of Cy Twombly, remembers the late painter while creating his own Eden in the hills of Gaeta, Italy; Sarah Lucas, the former rude girl of British art, discusses how she grew up without losing her nerve; Ricky Gervais and Zaha Hadid say yes to sriracha-flavored ketchup and a floor-cleaning robot while lounging in a giant bird’s nest; the New York magazine co-founder and “I Heart NY” creator Milton Glaser gets the By the Numbers treatment; and a handful of authors with new books out this year pay tribute to the spaces where they write. See all stories from the issue >>

headline: Review: ‘The Originalist,’ About Scalia, Opens in Washington
abstract: John Strand’s drama, having its world-premiere production at Arena Stage, stars Edward Gero as the Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Few people seeing “The Originalist,” a new play by John Strand having its premiere at Arena Stage here, are likely to have a fuzzy opinion about the character at its center, the Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia. He’s arguably among the most polarizing jurists of his stature in American history, and inarguably the most combative justice currently on the court. For that matter, it’s unlikely that anyone will emerge from Mr. Strand’s play, which is essentially a series of debates dressed up in the robes of drama, with a radically changed view of Justice Scalia’s ideas about American jurisprudence as expressed through the often heated rhetoric in his writings and speeches.

headline: A Window Into the Real Lauren Bacall
abstract: A look at the auction of the actress’s eclectic valuables, which included Henry Moore and Robert Graham sculptures, Picasso pottery, Louis XV bureaus and other treasures.
lead_paragraph: She loved animals. And piecework quilts. And Louis Vuitton suitcases.

headline: Joe Assadourian, of ‘The Bullpen,’ Visits His Former Cellmates
abstract: Mr. Assadourian gave a performance of his one-man show, now running at the Playroom Theater, at the Otisville state prison.
lead_paragraph: OTISVILLE, N.Y. — It’s a familiar enough homecoming scene: A successful performer returns to his old stomping ground and puts on a show in the gymnasium because he wants to give a little something back. Joe Assadourian, who has been starring in a one-man show in Manhattan since last June, made his pilgrimage Thursday, but the gymnasium he performed in wasn’t in a high school. It was at the state prison here, and many inmates in the audience were also his buddies, because not that long ago he was one of them.

headline: The Week In Political Pictures
abstract: A major retirement, a major announcement, and a major honor for a legend of golf.
lead_paragraph: A major retirement, a major announcement, and a major honor for a legend of golf.

headline: She Sounds Smart, but Look at Her Hair!
abstract: Female talking heads face the social-media gantlet as if they were walking the red carpet, even on C-Span.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago, I moderated a televised book-fair panel, an event I approached with a certain amount of trepidation, but that providentially went well. An overflowing audience laughed and clapped in the right places. The panelists thanked me after. I felt great.

headline: Unplugging Without FOMO
abstract: Weary of the 24-second cycle of Internet memes and viral distractions, some willingly brave the social cost of seeming out of touch.
lead_paragraph: At the Breslin Bar & Dining Room last month, Amy Chan and three friends were eating oysters when one of them mentioned “the dress.” BuzzFeed had fueled a media frenzy that day by asking readers to vote on whether a dress posted on Tumblr was white with gold trim or blue and black. Ms. Chan’s friends had argued that it was blue. Others online had declared it white.

headline: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
Contested Legacy of Dr. Ben, a Father of African Studies
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'History (Academic Subject)', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Jews and Judaism', 'ANTI-SEMITISM']
abstract: To some, Yosef Ben-Jochannan, who died on March 19, was a trailblazing Harlem scholar who challenged common narratives that had written Africa out of world history. Yet to others, he was an impostor.
lead_paragraph: The faded plaque to the right of the door said “Jochannan, Yosef B.,” but visitors to this nursing home on the northern edge of the Bronx knew the frail 96-year-old inside by another name: Dr. Ben.

headline: wastED
abstract: The chef Dan Barber’s pop-up serving food that is normally thrown out, scavenged from around the city.
lead_paragraph: The chef Dan Barber’s pop-up serving food that is normally thrown out, scavenged from around the city.

headline: At the Chef Dan Barber’s Pop-Up, WastED, Bruised and Misshapen Bits Are Dinner
abstract: For wastED, a pop-up restaurant in Greenwich Village, Dan Barber and his crew went on a crosstown hunt for scraps to transform into tasty dishes, and they mostly succeeded.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, I chopped a week’s worth of food scraps. It took most of an hour in my kitchen to reduce carrot leaves, cauliflower stems, onion butts and scallion greens to small bits that I hoped would make an appetizing lunch for the molds, mini-bugs and earthworms in the backyard compost bin.

headline: Obama Seeks to Double Funding to Fight Antibiotic Resistance
abstract: A new plan was praised by some for seeking to curb antibiotic use in humans, but criticized by others for not doing enough to deal with its use in animals.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Friday urged Congress to double the funding to confront the danger of antibiotic-resistant bacteria, calling it a major public health issue that, if left unchecked, would “cause tens of thousands of deaths, millions of illnesses.”

headline: Robert Moses, French Comic Book Hero
abstract: Robert Moses, who shaped the modern face of New York City, is the subject of “Robert Moses: The Master Builder of New York City,” a graphic biography originally published in French.
lead_paragraph: Robert Moses, the bureaucrat-visionary who shaped the modern face of New York City, has been the subject of countless symposia, museum exhibitions, a TV documentary and a Pulitzer-winning biography.

headline: A Bergdahl Court-Martial Serves Military Justice
abstract: Readers take issue with an editorial.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Review: São Paulo State Youth Orchestra Saves Razzle-Dazzle for the End
abstract: The ensemble performed works by Villa-Lobos, Beethoven and others at Alice Tully Hall, letting down its hair in some colorful encores.
lead_paragraph: You had to wait till the third encore for things to bust loose, but most of the audience did so, clearly expectant.

headline: Tammy Duckworth Expected to Challenge Senator Mark Kirk in Illinois
abstract: Representative Tammy L. Duckworth of Illinois is expected to announce next week that she will challenge Senator Mark S. Kirk in 2016.
lead_paragraph: Representative Tammy L. Duckworth, Democrat of Illinois, is expected to announce next week that she will challenge Senator Mark S. Kirk, a first-term Republican, potentially pitting two candidates with personal stories of overcoming physical handicaps against each other in 2016 in a race for President Obama’s old seat.

headline: End the Loss of Driver’s Licenses for Drug Crimes
keywords: ['Hiring and Promotion', 'Ex-Convicts', 'Drivers Licenses', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Fines (Penalties)']
abstract: Gov. Jack A. Markell of Delaware writes that “a valid driver’s license is essential to earning and keeping a job, but wrongheaded policies too often take it away.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Review: Bach Passions in New York
abstract: It’s spring, and that means several choirs are performing the popular works, though this year the activity is minimal.
lead_paragraph: You can generally count on a New York spring to produce three or four prominent performances of Bach Passions. This year the activity is minimal.

headline: Madison Square Garden Confirms Plan to Split in Two
abstract: One company will include the sports teams, the namesake arena and Radio City Music Hall, while the other will have regional sports networks.
lead_paragraph: The Madison Square Garden Company confirmed on Friday that it will break itself up, dividing the New York Knicks and Rangers professional sports teams from the company’s regional sports networks.

headline: For Consumers, Forced Arbitration Equals Injustice
keywords: ['ARBITRATION, CONCILIATION AND MEDIATION', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Consumer Protection']
abstract: Mitchell Zimmerman, a lawyer and arbitrator, and the New York State Trial Lawyers Association respond to a news article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: No Copies of Clinton Emails on Server, Lawyer Says
abstract: The House Select Committee on Benghazi had subpoenaed the server to determine which Hillary Rodham Clinton emails were personal and which were government records.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An examination of the server that housed the personal email account that Hillary Rodham Clinton used exclusively when she was secretary of state showed that there are no copies of any emails she sent during her time in office, her lawyer told a congressional committee on Friday.

headline: Review: ‘Camp Kappawanna,’ Complete With Insecurities and Bug Spray
abstract: Lisa Loeb gets one of the credits for this musical about the summer sleepaway ritual and the growing up that goes on there.
lead_paragraph: No one, you’ll be relieved to learn, sings “Kumbaya.” Arts and crafts haven’t made the list of activities. And neither, oddly, has theater.

headline: Next for the Big City Book Club: Russell Shorto’s ‘The Island at the Center of the World’
abstract: When the Big City Book Club convenes next, we’ll be reading Russell Shorto’s “The Island at the Center of the World.”
lead_paragraph: Recently we asked readers to suggest new titles for the next meeting of the Big City Book Club. We were flooded with ideas and from your suggestions drafted a short list of three titles. The final contestants were Edith Wharton’s “The Age of Innocence,” Teju Cole’s “Open City,” and Russell Shorto’s “The Island at the Center of the World: The Epic Story of Dutch Manhattan and the Forgotten Colony That Shaped America.” More than 300 votes were cast and the race was tight. But the winner is ... “The Island at the Center of the World.”

headline: Celebrating John F. Burns, War Reporter and Witness to Era-Defining Events
abstract: The two-time Pulitzer Prize-winning correspondent has written his last dispatch for The New York Times — for now.
lead_paragraph: For many Americans, the indelible image of John Burns is that unruly shock of gray curls, seemingly at odds with the stream of perfectly formed sentences illuminating the war in Iraq. His television appearances guaranteed he would be recognized by ordinary New Yorkers when he made his infrequent forays to headquarters — a place he spent most of his 40 years at The New York Times managing to avoid.

headline: Poland Charges Russian Air Traffic Controllers in Crash
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'AIR TRAFFIC CONTROL', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The 2010 plane crash in western Russia killed President Lech Kaczynski and 95 top-ranking officials traveling with him.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Polish military prosecutors charged two Russian air traffic controllers on Friday in a 2010 plane crash in western Russia that killed President Lech Kaczynski and 95 top-ranking officials traveling with him. The charges are likely to strain already tense relations between Poland and Russia.

headline: Can Data Stop Car Wrecks?
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Social Media', 'Research']
abstract: How mining automobile-owner forums can reveal clues about defects.
lead_paragraph: IN 2008 the owner of a 2001 Honda Civic posted a note on an Internet forum for Honda enthusiasts, saying that the car’s airbag had exploded in an accident, shooting shrapnel in multiple directions. “There were even strips of metal torn from the airbag backing plate that shot forward and smashed out the instrument panel,” the owner wrote.

headline: Hurdles Loom in Iran Nuclear Talks, U.S. Official Says
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']
abstract: An initial accord will not be possible unless the Iranian leadership makes “tough decisions” before Tuesday’s deadline, a State Department official said.
lead_paragraph: LAUSANNE, Switzerland — A senior State Department official said Friday night that the negotiations over Iran’s nuclear program had turned difficult and that an initial accord would not be possible unless the Iranian leadership made “tough decisions” over the coming days.

headline: Catholics on Left and Right Find Common Ground Opposing Death Penalty
abstract: On March 5, two liberal and two conservative publications shared an editorial supporting the Roman Catholic church’s opposition to executions. On other issues, like same-sex marriage and abortion, gaps remain.
lead_paragraph: As the editor of The National Catholic Reporter, a national biweekly, Dennis Coday reads his competitor, The National Catholic Register. But he does not have to agree with it.

headline: Ellen Pao Disrupts How Silicon Valley Does Business
abstract: While the verdict on Friday was a defeat for Ms. Pao, the trial has blown open a conversation about the status of women in an industry that has always been buttoned up about its shortcomings.
lead_paragraph: Silicon Valley is enamored of “disrupters,” those shrewd, brave men — it is almost always men — who are hailed for enduring years of ridicule and risking everything to shake up the conventional order.

headline: Owners of Restaurants Destroyed in East Village Explosion Mourn Their Losses
abstract: Three food shops on Second Avenue in the East Village destroyed in an explosion on Thursday were a microcosm of New York City.
lead_paragraph: Three in a row the food shops sat, a tiny stretch of New York no more than a few hundred feet long that somehow contained the city itself. The patch of Second Avenue in the East Village was home to a Japanese restaurant, owned and run by a Korean family; a shop selling Belgian-style French fries founded by a woman from the Bronx; and a bodega called Sam’s Deli, the hub of generations of one Indian family that owned it for nearly two decades.

headline: Militants Take Hostages in Deadly Attack on Mogadishu Hotel
abstract: The Shabab claimed responsibility for the attack, in which at least seven people were killed, including a Somali ambassador.
lead_paragraph: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Armed assailants attacked a Mogadishu hotel on Friday, leaving at least seven people dead, including a Somali ambassador, and seizing an unknown number of hostages, officials and witnesses said. The Shabab militant Islamist group, which routinely targets government and business sites in the Somali capital, claimed responsibility.

headline: G.O.P. Hawks Upset With Bush After Baker Speech on Israel
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A flare-up over a speech on Israel by James A. Baker III could thrust Jeb Bush into conflict with some of the most hawkish voices in his party, including a constituency determined to demonstrate its strength in the primary.
lead_paragraph: The warnings trickled in soon after an announcement began circulating last month that James A. Baker III, the former diplomat who is now a foreign policy adviser to Jeb Bush, would be a featured speaker at a conference hosted by J Street, the liberal pro-Israel advocacy organization.

headline: This Coach Doesn’t Tolerate Losing. Now, Neither Does Minnesota State.
abstract: Since taking over the hockey team at the Mankato campus in 2012, Coach Mike Hastings has emphasized speed, discipline and puck control.
lead_paragraph: MANKATO, Minn. — Everything about Mike Hastings, the coach of the Minnesota State Mankato men’s hockey team, the surprising No. 1 overall seed in the N.C.A.A. tournament, involves a story — like how his family acquired its dog, a 3-year-old golden retriever named Gracie.

headline: Mike Brey Hopes for a Nearly Impossible Win After a Personal Loss
abstract: Notre Dame will play top-seeded Kentucky in a round of 8 matchup that will be just one more challenge in what have been some of the most trying days of Irish Coach Mike Brey’s life.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Shortly after Notre Dame beat Wichita State on Thursday night, Irish Coach Mike Brey stood in a corridor just off the court and answered questions about Saturday’s opponent, which he knew would be West Virginia or Kentucky. As he spoke, the repeated roars of a partisan crowd made it clear that that opponent would be Kentucky.

headline: Housing Homeless Youth Poses Challenge for Mayor de Blasio
abstract: As New York City wrestles with an overall homeless population of more than 60,000, young people pose a challenge not just in terms of providing shelter for them, but also in providing the right kind of shelter.
lead_paragraph: Lijuan Hartfield often caught up on sleep on the subway, at friends’ apartments, sometimes at a 24-hour McDonald’s.

headline: Long Night in Senate, but Real Budget Work Awaits
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: The Senate passed its budget plan, 52 to 46, early Friday morning. Negotiations with the House on a common budget are next.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Emerging from an all-night session that was more exhausting than dramatic, Senate Republicans on Friday squeaked through a budget blueprint that would repeal the Affordable Care Act, fundamentally remake federal health care for the poor and elderly, and push the federal deficit toward zero over the next decade.

headline: Steve Vasturia Is Modest, Like His Mother, and Tough, Like His Team
abstract: Vasturia has become a key member of a scrappy, underrated team and will help lead the Irish as they face No. 1-seeded Kentucky.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Kathy Vasturia knew how hard her son Steve was working. She could see him fighting through screens, chasing Ron Baker of Wichita State all over the floor, running nonstop and bouncing off shoulders, elbows and well-placed hips.

headline: Tomas Transtromer, Swedish Poet Who Won Nobel, Dies at 83
abstract: Mr. Transtromer was known for his spare yet evocative imagery and his explorations of identity.
lead_paragraph: Tomas Transtromer, a Swedish poet who won the Nobel Prize in Literature in 2011 for a body of work known for shrewd metaphors couched in deceptively spare language, crystalline descriptions of natural beauty and explorations of the mysteries of identity and creativity, died on Thursday in Stockholm. He was 83.

headline: Healing Fire in Londonderry: The Temple Was Built to Burn
abstract: Burning a 75-foot-tall pagan temple in a Republican Catholic enclave on the loyalist Protestant side of Londonderry seemed to many like a bad idea.
lead_paragraph: LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland — The Rev. David Latimer thought it was a terrible idea. The streets of this Northern Irish city had burned in the Troubles. His Protestant church was firebombed by Catholics. Every summer, rival bonfires the size of small mountains still burn, and with them the flags and effigies of the other side.

headline: Makers of Generic Drugs Challenge F.D.A. Plan for Updated Warnings
abstract: The generics industry has proposed that the federal agency take full responsibility for altering labels whenever health risks are discovered rather than expecting companies to take the initiative.
lead_paragraph: BETHESDA, Md. — The pharmaceutical industry mounted a new challenge on Friday to a federal plan that would require generic drug companies to take the initiative to update their labels to warn consumers whenever health risks were discovered, a shift that would expose the companies to legal liability.

headline: T.J. McConnell Is a Mirror Image of Arizona Coach Sean Miller, Minus the Suit and Tie
abstract: Each man came from a basketball family in the Pittsburgh area and became a pass-first team leader.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The men’s basketball team from Pittsburgh’s Duquesne University opened the 2011-12 season with a game at highly ranked Arizona. The Duquesne coach at the time, Ron Everhart, said beforehand that his sophomore point guard, T. J. McConnell, reminded him of a young Sean Miller — a Pittsburgh-area star in high school, a four-year collegiate starter at Pittsburgh and now Arizona’s coach.

headline: Extent of Losses Begins to Come Into Focus a Day After an East Village Explosion
abstract: One young man presumed missing was on a date at a sushi restaurant on Second Avenue. The second missing person is a busboy at the restaurant.
lead_paragraph: On a wall of his rented room in Queens, Moises Ismael Locón Yac has paid tribute to the city where he has lived for seven of his 27 years: a poster of the Empire State Building and a framed cover from The New Yorker — a drawing of a cat looking out an apartment window at the cityscape.

headline: Turning a Wrongful Imprisonment Into Advocacy
keywords: ['Americans Abroad', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Eric Volz turned a wrongful conviction in Nicaragua into a vocation, helping other Americans imprisoned overseas.
lead_paragraph: ACCUSED of murder, railroaded through the Nicaraguan courts and wrongly convicted, Eric Volz can be forgiven for not having immediately recognized that his ordeal would become the foundation for his life’s work.

headline: A West Village Bar Crawl Leaves Behind a Trail of Counterfeit Green
keywords: ['Bars and Nightclubs', 'Counterfeit Money and Financial Instruments']
abstract: A pair’s night out intersected with an off-duty bartender and amateur detective, and ended in arrests that were the product of bad luck, good forgeries and poor execution.
lead_paragraph: The gray jumpsuits that inmates wear into the visiting room at the Manhattan Detention Complex can be scratchy and uncomfortable, and Eddie Ashley, 21, tugged at his collar as he thought about that night. Hard to believe it all happened just a few subway stops from his current surroundings, traditionally known as the Tombs. It was three weeks ago.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 27, 2015
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: March 27, 2015

headline: George Spitz, Civic Gadfly Who Helped Transform Marathon, Dies at 92
abstract: Mr. Spitz, who was a perennial, if not quixotic, candidate for public office, is credited with recasting the New York City Marathon from a Central Park race into a citywide event.
lead_paragraph: George N. Spitz, a relentless gadfly who is credited with recasting the New York City Marathon from a four-lap run around Central Park with 339 finishers to a celebratory five-borough race that has become the largest of its kind in the world, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 92.

headline: Matt Harvey Continues His Sterling Spring by Taming the Cardinals
abstract: The Mets’ ace has compiled a 1.45 earned run average over 18 2/3 innings, with 17 strikeouts and a walk.
lead_paragraph: JUPITER, Fla. — Matt Harvey turned 26 on Friday, and to an outsider, it might have seemed like an unremarkable moment. The Mets had a birthday cake in the clubhouse in the morning — no big deal — and Harvey pitched well against the St. Louis Cardinals in the afternoon, which, in the past, would have been no big deal, either.

headline: Guantánamo’s Charade of Justice
abstract: Unlike federal courts, military commissions have a dismal record of prosecuting terrorists.
lead_paragraph: LAST week, we learned that, only months into the job, the official in charge of the military courts system at Guantánamo Bay was stepping down, after judges ruled he had interfered in proceedings. The appointment of an interim replacement was the sixth change of leadership for the tribunals since 2003.

headline: Cops With Hearing Aids?
abstract: I used to think that was dangerous. But now I know better.
lead_paragraph: SHOULD police officers be allowed to wear hearing aids?

headline: Need Anything Else?
abstract: In which David Steinberg takes over the blog.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Confession: I’m sick. I have my annual “Great Timing, Deb, Just in Time For The American Crossword Puzzle Tournament!” cold, and it’s at the point where I can barely see my computer screen. So I’m going to turn things over to David Steinberg, today’s constructor, and let him tell you about his puzzle.

headline: Feds Gone Wild
keywords: ['Prostitution', 'Editorials', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Sex Crimes', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: Law enforcement officers posted abroad need strong, unequivocal guidance from their agencies’ leaders about sexual misconduct.
lead_paragraph: It certainly holds promise as a plot for a B-list thriller: Drug Enforcement Administration agents stationed in Colombia regularly cavort with prostitutes at parties paid for by local drug cartels. In a few instances, cash and expensive gifts appear to change hands. A local officer is kind enough to keep an eye on the agents’ guns and property while the agents are busy with the girls.

headline: Ex-Agent in Patz Case Says Sex Offender Was Suspect
abstract: Mary Galligan, the former F.B.I. agent who was assigned to the case in 1989, testified that she interviewed Jose A. Ramos, a convicted child molester cast as an alternate suspect.
lead_paragraph: An F.B.I. agent who worked on the Etan Patz case for nearly a decade testified on Friday that a previous suspect in the boy’s 1979 disappearance admitted to having sexually abused a young boy on the same day that Etan disappeared, though he called the boy “Jimmy.”

headline: Rick Pitino’s Alchemy Turns Louisville’s Bricks to Gold
abstract: The fourth-seeded Cardinals pulled away from North Carolina State for a 75-65 victory and advanced to the round of 8 for the fifth time in eight years.
lead_paragraph: SYRACUSE — Louisville’s reserve guard Anton Gill had not played more than 12 minutes in a game since mid-February. This month, he had missed every shot he tried, five field goals and two free throws. Once a top recruit, Gill came to Louisville as a shooter, having scored 50 points or more twice in one week while in high school.

headline: China’s Fear of Women With Pamphlets
keywords: ["Women's Rights", 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Editorials', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: President Xi Jinping has a chance to embrace human rights. Instead, by arresting five activists, he appears to be succumbing to Communist Party history.
lead_paragraph: China’s growing crackdown on political dissent is stirring global protests and demands for the release of five women’s rights advocates arrested this month as they sought to hand out leaflets as part of a campaign against sexual harassment on China’s public transportation.

headline: Gonzaga Recovers to Beat U.C.L.A. in Sloppy Game
abstract: The No. 2-seeded Bulldogs struggled to find a balance for much of the game, but took control against the No. 11-seeded Bruins with their size and experience.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — These were not the deadeye Gonzaga Bulldogs who could shoot opponents into submission without getting dirty underneath the basket. These Bulldogs were clanging balls off the rim at such an alarming rate Friday night that Coach Mark Few’s patience finally wore as thin as the lead U.C.L.A. had just cut to 1 point early in the second half.

headline: Arizona Fallout From Ferguson
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Editorials', 'State Legislatures', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Withholding the identities of police officers involved in shootings would only deepen community cynicism.
lead_paragraph: The nation’s grave problems of police procedures and racial insensitivity laid bare by the simmering events in Ferguson, Mo., can only be worsened by concealment. Yet that is what a bill approved by Arizona’s Legislature would do by keeping identities of police officers secret for 60 days after officers are involved in deadly or serious shootings.

headline: So Who Needs Matt Harvey?
abstract: The Mets’ decision to give this year’s opening day start to Bartolo Colon has created something of a stir, but the team has done quite well on opening days regardless of its starting pitcher.
lead_paragraph: The Mets’ decision to give this year’s opening day start to Bartolo Colon instead of Matt Harvey has created something of a stir. Then again, the Mets have done really well on opening days, whether an ace like Tom Seaver or Dwight Gooden was starting or a less-heralded pitcher was on the mound.

headline: Ted Cruz Pop Quiz
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: We officially have a 2016 presidential candidate! How well do you know him?
lead_paragraph: We officially have a 2016 presidential candidate! How well do you know him?

headline: Governor Cuomo’s Former Aide Moves to the Private Sector
abstract: Lawrence S. Schwartz, the former secretary to the governor, was known for his combative role in the troubled life of the Moreland Commission.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s former top aide and longtime confidant, Lawrence S. Schwartz, has found a job in the private sector.

headline: John Renbourn, Eclectic Guitarist Who Founded the Pentangle, Dies at 70
abstract: As part of the folk-jazz group the Pentangle, Mr. Renbourn played Carnegie Hall and opened for the Grateful Dead; he was also a scholar of medieval music.
lead_paragraph: John Renbourn, an English guitarist known for his light-fingered fusion of classical, folk, blues and jazz and for his work with the group the Pentangle, was found dead on Thursday at his home in Hawick, Scotland, near the English border. He was 70.

headline: Nets, Playing for a Playoff Spot, Grab a Win
abstract: The Nets served a jolt to the Cleveland Cavaliers on Friday night, beating them, 106-98, in front of a sellout crowd at Barclays Center.
lead_paragraph: The volume in professional sports locker rooms late at night tends to fluctuate depending on the result of a game. Losses demand silence. Wins inspire a joyous rumpus.

headline: With Little Notice, Citi Bike Is Suspended for the Weekend
abstract: Citi Bike sent an email to its members around 5 p.m. on Friday, announcing the suspension of service on Saturday and Sunday for maintenance work.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s bike share program abruptly announced on Friday evening that it would shut down for the weekend to improve the service.

headline: Kevin Durant to Have Bone Graft and Miss Rest of Season
abstract: Durant will undergo a bone graft on his right foot next week, the Oklahoma City Thunder announced, and is not expected to resume basketball-related activities for four to six months.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Durant, the N.B.A.’s reigning most valuable player, has played his final game of an injury-marred season. Durant is scheduled to undergo a bone graft next week on his ailing right foot, the team announced Friday, and is not expected to resume basketball-related activities for four to six months.

headline: Rod Hundley, an Outsize Personality on and Off the Court, Dies at 80
abstract: Hundley, known as Hot Rod, parlayed showmanship on the court with flair at the microphone to become a fan favorite for more than half a century, including many years as a broadcaster for the N.B.A.’s Jazz.
lead_paragraph: Rod Hundley, basketball’s irrepressible Hot Rod, who parlayed showmanship on the court with flair at the microphone to become a fan favorite for more than half a century, died on Friday at his home near Phoenix. He was 80.

headline: Duke’s Core of 8 Reaches the Round of 8
abstract: Led by its eight scholarship players, top-seeded Duke outlasted No. 5 Utah, 63-57, in a South Regional semifinal.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — For the last two months, Duke Coach Mike Krzyzewski has issued his team a daily reminder. Eight is enough, he tells the Blue Devils.

headline: Michigan State Edges Oklahoma With Second-Half Surge
abstract: By beating a rock-solid Oklahoma team, 62-58, in the Carrier Dome, Coach Tom Izzo brought the Spartans storming back to the round of 8 for a ninth time.
lead_paragraph: SYRACUSE — It has become almost trite and half-expected: Tom Izzo coaching Michigan State deep into the N.C.A.A. tournament, pushing all the right buttons at all the right times in March.

headline: Corrections: March 28, 2015
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, March 28, 2015.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Saturday, March 28, 2015.
lead_paragraph: “This case sends a powerful signal to Silicon Valley in general and the venture capital industry in particular.”

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 6:45 P.M. (Sundance) SHAUN OF THE DEAD (2004) Shaun (Simon Pegg) and his girlfriend, Liz (Kate Ashfield), are having problems because of Shaun’s insistence on always doing the same thing. He likes to hang out at the pub with his friend Ed (Nick Frost) and has yet to meet Liz’s mother. After Liz dumps Shaun, he continues in his habits. Shaun and Ed are so complacent that it takes them an astonishingly long time to realize that the odd events increasing in frequency around them are the result of a zombie outbreak. Shaun and Ed find themselves in a comedic fight for survival in which zombies are fought with bad records and clumsy luck in this film directed by Edgar Wright (“Hot Fuzz,” “Scott Pilgrim vs. the World”). “There is something intrinsically ridiculous about zombie movies,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. “The British horror comedy ‘Shaun of the Dead’ skillfully plays off that ridiculousness by implying that Britain may already be populated with the living dead, metaphorically speaking.”

headline: Turning Around for a Farewell Glance
abstract: As Jose R. Lopez retires after three decades at The Times, he looks back on a favorite image, where all the elements came together.
lead_paragraph: I leave The New York Times after having had an amazing 31-year career here, first spending 16 years as a staff photographer, followed by 15 more as a picture editor. During my time as a photographer, I had the honor of being based in Washington, covering the White House during the Reagan, Bush (41) and Clinton administrations.

headline: The Strip
keywords: ['Comic Books and Strips', 'US Dollar (Currency)', 'Currency', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.
lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: In Brazil, Some Inmates Get Therapy With Hallucinogenic Tea
abstract: The provision of ayahuasca, a psychedelic brew used in the Amazon basin for centuries, to inmates on short furloughs reflects a quest to ease pressure on Brazil’s prison system.
lead_paragraph: JI-PARANÁ, Brazil — As the night sky enveloped this outpost in Brazil’s Amazon basin, the ceremony at the open-air temple began simply enough.

headline: Ex-Yemeni Leader Urges Truce and Successor’s Ouster
abstract: In a 10-minute address broadcast on Yemeni television, Ali Abdullah Saleh called for elections to choose a new president.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Under pressure from a Saudi Arabian-led campaign of airstrikes, the former leader of Yemen who is backing the group that has seized the country’s largest cities said on Saturday that he was pleading for a truce, urging negotiations, but standing by demands for the ouster of his Saudi-backed successor.

headline: The Week on Instagram
abstract: Photographers featured this week on @nytimes took viewers from an explosion in the East Village to a small village in Egypt.
lead_paragraph: Photographers featured this week on @nytimes took viewers from an explosion in the East Village to a small village in Egypt.

headline: Nigeria Votes in Sharply Contested Presidential Election
abstract: Dense crowds of people sometimes waited hours to vote on Saturday, and the election had to be extended to Sunday in parts of the country where machinery malfunctioned.
