lead_paragraph: KANO, Nigeria — Eager voters waited to cast ballots all day as the most contested election in Nigeria’s post-independence history wound down to a tense conclusion on Saturday amid fears that the polarized electorate would clash regardless of the outcome in a country sharply split on ethnic and sectarian lines.

headline: Strong Dollar Yields Savings From Tour Operators
abstract: With the dollar strengthening against many foreign currencies, travel abroad may be cheaper than in the past, inspiring tour operators to offer booking rebates and increase departures.
lead_paragraph: With the dollar strengthening against many foreign currencies, travel abroad may be cheaper than in the past, inspiring tour operators to offer booking rebates and increase departures.

headline: Stress and Hope In Tehran
abstract: As Iran and world powers including the United States try to reach a deal on nuclear controls in exchange for the lifting of sanctions, Iranians from all walks of life are watching and hoping for a new start.
lead_paragraph: As Iran and world powers including the United States try to reach a deal on nuclear controls in exchange for the lifting of sanctions, Iranians from all walks of life are watching and hoping for a new start.

headline: Masquerading As a Two-Family Home
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Cooperatives']
abstract: Questions about converting a home to a legal two-family; getting into the real estate business; and limited liability company purchasers in co-ops.
lead_paragraph: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2015: Welcome to the Show
abstract: Welcome to the 2015 American Crossword Puzzle Tournament.
lead_paragraph: SPECIAL POST — Stop me if you’ve heard this one. It’s not so much a joke as a moment of recognition; a moment in a crowded elevator when you realize that, amongst a group of strangers, you’re home.

headline: Germanwings Pilot Andreas Lubitz Sought Treatment for Vision Problems Before Crash, Authorities Say
abstract: The revelation adds a new element to the portrait of the German co-pilot, who officials say was also being treated for psychological issues.
lead_paragraph: DÜSSELDORF, Germany — Andreas Lubitz, who was flying the Germanwings jetliner that slammed into a mountain in the French Alps on Tuesday, sought treatment for vision problems that may have jeopardized his ability to continue working as a pilot, two officials with knowledge of the investigation said Saturday.

headline: After Germanwings Crash, a Week of Mourning and Questions
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)']
abstract: Memorial services were held for the victims as investigators looked into Andreas Lubitz, the co-pilot who plowed the plane into a mountain.
lead_paragraph: Memorial services were held for the victims as investigators looked into Andreas Lubitz, the co-pilot who plowed the plane into a mountain.

headline: Two Men Remain Missing as Remnants of Explosion Are Scoured in Manhattan
abstract: With two men still unaccounted for after an explosion and fire in Manhattan, workers continued to sift through what remained of the three buildings that were destroyed.
lead_paragraph: With hopes fading in the search for two men who have been missing since an explosion jolted a stretch of the East Village, emergency workers on Saturday continued to scour the debris of the three buildings that were destroyed on Thursday in the blast and ensuing fire.

headline: Somali Troops End Siege at Hotel as Death Toll Rises to 15
abstract: An elite counterterrorism unit rescued 50 hostages in an episode that left dead five attackers, said to be from the Shabab, the militant Islamist group.
lead_paragraph: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Somali troops ended a 16-hour siege at a hotel in Somalia’s capital on Saturday, during which gunmen killed 15 people, officials said.

headline: Spring Pasta Night!
abstract: Martha Rose Shulman offers a new simple pasta dish for spring that is packed with flavor and elegance.
lead_paragraph: Spring cooking means fresh vegetables and simple dishes. This week Martha Rose Shulman offers a new simple pasta dish with mussels. It’s a meal that tastes like you went to a lot of work, but only you will know how simple it was to put it on the table.

headline: Linda Zecher of Houghton Mifflin Harcourt: The Danger of ‘One Size Fits All’
abstract: Ms. Zecher says that rigidity in large companies sometimes makes it difficult for employees to be entrepreneurial and grow in their roles.
lead_paragraph: This interview with Linda K. Zecher the chief executive of Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, a publishing house that also provides educational content, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Variety: Marching Bands
abstract: Brendan Emmett Quigley offers us a fun Marching Bands puzzle.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial Get More Puzzles Alert! Do you love the Marching Bands variety puzzles as much as I do? The devious constructor and man-about-town Brendan Emmett Quigley is beginning a Kickstarter campaign that will result in a whole slew of these wonderful puzzles landing squarely in your email inbox every other week. Click here for more information.

headline: At U.S. Companies, Time to Coax the Directors Into Talking
keywords: ['Boards of Directors', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism', 'Corporations', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Board members of European companies routinely make themselves available to investors, but their peers in the United States seem to fear such contact.
lead_paragraph: It’s shareholder meeting season again, corporate America’s version of Groundhog Day.

headline: Helping Veterans Get Hired
keywords: ['Veterans', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Nick Swaggert, the veterans program director for a technology staffing and services firm, sees firsthand the battles that veterans face when they look for jobs.
lead_paragraph: Nick Swaggert, 33, is the veterans program director for Genesis10, a technology staffing and services firm. He is based in its St. Paul office.

headline: Wainwright House, a Haven for the Spirit on Long Island Sound
abstract: Established in 1951, the Wainwright House in Rye has a rich history of enriching the human spirit through offerings that run from musical and other performances to yoga classes and personal-development workshops.
lead_paragraph: Before the second installment of Linda Richichi’s three-part Soul Vision workshop started at Wainwright House in Rye on a recent sunny Sunday, Joanne Mendola was feeling hopeful about dissolving what remained of her spiritual blockages.

headline: Mild Winters and Crank Economics
abstract: Spurious correlations galore.
lead_paragraph: Neil Irwin writes about migration patterns within the United States, and points out that they overwhelmingly reflect just two factors. Most important, people are moving to places with mild winters:

headline: Make Way for Generation Z
keywords: ['Youth', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Careers and Professions', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Born from the mid-1990s through the early 2000s, its members are independent, curious, mature, driven and ready to change the world.
lead_paragraph: I recall the exact moment the temperature changed in the workplace. It was 2005, and I was speaking to an audience of 100 young professionals. I was relating my experiences building a career as a Gen Xer (born 1964-79) in a world of traditionalists (born before 1945) and baby boomers (born 1946-63).

headline: No. 2 Negotiators in Iran Talks Argue Physics Behind Politics
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Forty years after they both attended M.I.T., the nuclear scientists Ernest J. Moniz and Ali Akbar Salehi have emerged as the No. 2 negotiators on Iran’s nuclear program.
lead_paragraph: LAUSANNE, Switzerland — At the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in the mid-1970s, Ernest J. Moniz was an up-and-coming nuclear scientist in search of tenure, and Ali Akbar Salehi, a brilliant Iranian graduate student, was finishing a dissertation on fast-neutron reactors.

headline: The Mystery of the Missing Mask
abstract: An $800 custom mask is damaged in transit, and the artist’s claim for compensation from UPS is denied because of a packaging mix-up.
lead_paragraph: Our episode about one man’s maddening efforts to get reimbursed by Optum, a health services provider, elicited some “me too” email from other frustrated and unhappy consumers. There was also an interesting email from a therapist, who asked that she not be identified, mostly because she could see no upside in speaking out against the company.

headline: Iraqi Forces in No Hurry to Expel ISIS From Tikrit
abstract: In the wake of American airstrikes on Islamic State positions in the city, there seemed to be little urgency to make progress on the ground.
lead_paragraph: TIKRIT, Iraq — Here at the headquarters of Iraqi ground forces, after three days of American airstrikes that at times witnesses here described as “carpet bombing,” Iraq’s military seemed in no great hurry on Saturday to press its advantage.

headline: Unreal Keynesians
abstract: What’s in a name?
lead_paragraph: Brad DeLong points me to Lars Syll declaring that I am not a “real Keynesian”, because I use equilibrium models and don’t emphasize the instability of expectations.

headline: A Wi-Fi Barbie Doll With the Soul of Siri
abstract: Companies like Mattel are readying electronic toys that will use Web connections to talk back to children, raising some concerns about privacy.
lead_paragraph: Ever since Siri appeared as a regular feature on the iPhone, certain young children — and, let’s face it, some of their parents — have spent hours chatting up the virtual assistant, curious about the details of her humanoid back story.

headline: In Bid to Inspire Faith in Senate, Kennedy Institute Has the Floor
abstract: Featuring a replica chamber, a new center aims to remind the public that an institution now known more for filibusters and dysfunction than for leadership and debate can again become a venue of national consensus.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — When creators of the Edward M. Kennedy Institute for the United States Senate set out to rebuild the crumbling image of the world’s greatest deliberative body, they started from the ground up.

headline: All Grown Up and In Charge of the Seder
abstract: Carrying on the family traditions marked my rite of passage to adulthood.
lead_paragraph: EVERY person I know remembers a specific moment, a signpost marking the day, or the year, that childhood was left behind.

headline: In the N.C.A.A. Tournament, Games Are Big, but Life Is Bigger
abstract: To the fans filling out brackets, the N.C.A.A. tournament is a zero-sum game. But long after they forget the names of the winners, players will cherish their memories, and the bonds they forged.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The victories against Coastal Carolina and Oregon cleared Wisconsin’s path to the West Regional semifinal, but long after the details of the N.C.A.A. tournament games in Nebraska are lost to memory’s slow leak, the Badger players will recall their go-karting excursion in Omaha.

headline: A Review of Encore Bistro, in Rye
abstract: At Encore Bistro in Rye, the cozy décor and familiar atmosphere compliment the classic French dishes.
lead_paragraph: There must be a company called Parisian Bistro Decorators that specializes in giving American restaurants the look and feel of something approaching French charm. Diners can take it all in at Encore Bistro in Rye, with its white ceramic tile walls, black and white hexagonal tile floor, posters in saturated colors and a horizontal mirror over a long banquette. Additional niceties please as well, like the appealing bottles of tap water that arrive after orders have been taken and the dish towels that make sturdy napkins.

headline: Sri Lankan President’s Brother Dies From Ax Wounds
abstract: President Maithripala Sirisena’s youngest brother, Priyantha Sirisena, known as Sand King for his sand mining business, was assaulted two days earlier.
lead_paragraph: A brother of Sri Lanka’s president, Maithripala Sirisena, died on Saturday from severe head wounds he suffered in an ax attack two days earlier, according to a statement by the Sri Lankan government.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2015: The Standings Emerge?
abstract: The 2015 A.C.P.T. standings are being posted.
lead_paragraph: SPECIAL POST — With three puzzles in the bag, the standings are starting to be posted for Puzzle 1.

headline: Athletes Finding Their Voice in Derek Jeter’s Digital Venture
abstract: The way David Ortiz’s first-person essay quickly went viral showed the growing reach of The Players’ Tribune, especially when an athlete has something provocative to say.
lead_paragraph: David Ortiz’s blustery rant about being unfairly branded a cheater for testing positive for a banned substance in 2003 made news Thursday, not only for its strident tone, but for where it appeared.

headline: The Chinese-Americans
abstract: A photographer explores his place in the country’s social landscape.
lead_paragraph: A photographer explores his place in the country’s social landscape.

headline: Embracing My Chinese-American Identity
abstract: A photographer explores his place in the country’s social landscape.
lead_paragraph: WHEN I was in eighth grade, in Queens, in the early 2000s, I was often picked on by other children for my almond-shaped eyes, beige complexion and jet-black hair — essentially, my Chinese face. They’d ask me if I ate vermin and felines and constantly mocked my native language. These adolescent experiences planted within me seeds of self-hatred, and for years I tried to rid myself of my cultural heritage.

headline: Altered Visions and Changing Vistas
abstract: Rare prints by Ansel Adams, offering a new perspective on his work, alongside a survey of American landscape art.
lead_paragraph: Ansel Adams, the master photographer of the American West, made small, soft-edged prints early in his career and high-contrast, large-scale prints later on. Michael Mattis, who with his wife, Judith Hochberg, owns the 41 early Adams prints (1920s to 1950s) now at the Long Island Museum of American Art, History and Carriages, compares the early prints to chamber music and the later ones to brass bands. (The analogies are apt, since Adams, who died at 82 in 1984, started out as a concert pianist.)

headline: Campus ‘Safe Spaces’
abstract: Readers discuss whether colleges should be protecting students from distressing ideas.
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss whether colleges should be protecting students from distressing ideas.

headline: Stand Up for Your Cats
abstract: We need to lose the stereotype of the pathetic female and her felines.
lead_paragraph: TAYLOR SWIFT, I salute you.

headline: Ready for 45?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: If Jeb Bush becomes Bush 45, can he ever be his “own man”?
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — JAMES BAKER can take credit for two presidencies and one vice presidency in the Bush family.

headline: What Starbucks Is Ditching Along With CDs
keywords: ['Music', 'Compact Discs', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Restaurants']
abstract: Our music collections aren’t anything we can put our hands on.
lead_paragraph: I CURRENTLY possess around six large moving boxes of compact discs tossed beneath a tarp in the dank cellar of my apartment building. Since 1999, I have been receiving promotional copies of CDs, an occupational hazard of my job as a professional music critic.

headline: The Method to Obama’s Middle East Mess
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Pax Americana is no longer feasible, but its alternative could be even worse.
lead_paragraph: LET’S recap the state of America’s commitments in the Middle East. Our military is fighting in a tacit alliance with Iranian proxies in Iraq, even as it assists in a campaign against Iranian-backed forces in Yemen. We are formally committed to regime change in Syria, but we’re intervening against the regime’s Islamist enemies. Our strongest allies, officially, are still Israel and Saudi Arabia, but we’re busy alienating them by pushing for détente with Iran. And please don’t mention Libya or Al Qaeda — you’ll confuse everyone even more.

headline: Pregnant, Obese ... and in Danger
abstract: Extremely overweight women, and their babies, face complications.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — ONE recent night on my delivery shift, eight out of 10 of my laboring patients were too heavy, with two weighing over 300 pounds.

headline: Progress on Payday Lending
keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'Payday Loans', 'Consumer Protection', 'Editorials', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau took the most important step in its four-year history this week.
lead_paragraph: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau took the most important step in its brief four-year history this week when it issued a preliminary proposal aimed at protecting the working poor from the payday lending industry, which bills itself as a source of “easy” short-term loans but earns its profits by luring borrowers into debt traps. If finalized, rules based on this proposal would protect millions of people from deceptive, predatory loans that can wreck their already fragile finances. The bureau could better protect consumers by closing one loophole that would allow some lenders of relatively small amounts to keep making high-cost loans.

headline: Preparing for Tomorrow’s Storms
abstract: Drought is not the only environmental risk California residents face.
lead_paragraph: Californians are understandably focused on the state’s severe drought, now in its fourth year. But drought is not the only environmental risk the state’s residents face.

headline: Afghanistan’s Next Chapter
keywords: ['Editorials', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Will the additional American investment prove to be worth it?
lead_paragraph: Now that President Obama has decided to slow the withdrawal of troops from Afghanistan, he and the new Afghan president, Ashraf Ghani, have an obligation to prove that the additional American investment will be worth it. It will not be easy, and it may not be possible. For more than a decade, the Afghan government has stubbornly resisted taking most of the political, economic and military steps needed to put the country on a firm footing.

headline: Why Reconstruction Matters
keywords: ['Reconstruction Era', 'Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Discrimination', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: The post-Civil War era dealt with many of the same issues we grapple with today.
lead_paragraph: THE surrender of Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee at Appomattox Court House, 150 years ago next month, effectively ended the Civil War. Preoccupied with the challenges of our own time, Americans will probably devote little attention to the sesquicentennial of Reconstruction, the turbulent era that followed the conflict. This is unfortunate, for if any historical period deserves the label “relevant,” it is Reconstruction.

headline: Katherine Meyer
abstract: A lawyer who fought for the rights of circus elephants on reading Kafka, playing the ukulele and watching “Dance Moms.”
lead_paragraph: Katherine Meyer is a Washington, D.C.-based lawyer who specializes in animal welfare, advocating on behalf of circus elephants, sea turtles and wild horses.

headline: A Little Respect for Dr. Foster
abstract: The liberal caricature of evangelicals is unfair. Meet Stephen Foster, a missionary surgeon who moved to Angola from North America 37 years ago.
lead_paragraph: ONE sign of a landmark shift in public attitudes: A poll last year found that Americans approved more of gays and lesbians (53 percent) than of evangelical Christians (42 percent).

headline: Trying to Fool Cancer
abstract: Which mutations are evil, and which are innocent?
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — WHEN it airs on Monday, the Ken Burns-produced documentary “Cancer: The Emperor of All Maladies” will emphasize how much more we now know about the genetic basis for cancer. This year, according to President Obama, cancer research and funding will focus on so-called precision, personalized or targeted medicine — using cancer’s molecular underpinnings to develop drugs that attack the genes or gene products that make up cancer’s factory while sparing normal cells. What a beautiful concept.

headline: Tweeting Mom’s Goodbye
abstract: In the loneliness of saying farewell, solace comes in 140-character bursts.
lead_paragraph: My mother finally closed her eyes amid the grim bleats of the intensive care unit for a little sleep. I slipped my hand from hers and sat back. I picked up my phone to call my wife but saw it was 3 in the morning. I looked at emails, but didn’t really read them. Then I remembered something my mother had said a couple of hours before, as we knew our time together was winding down. It had made me smile; and now I sent out a tweet:

headline: To Longtime Geno Auriemma Assistant, There’s No Better Place Than UConn
abstract: Chris Dailey, an associate head coach at Connecticut who has been at Geno Auriemma’s side for 29 years, has helped mold championship teams and the program’s image.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — It is the little things that have kept Chris Dailey by Geno Auriemma’s side for 29 years, and counting.

headline: Coffeehouses Where the Brew Is as Crucial as the Bean
abstract: Three artisanal cafes on Long Island use elaborate methods and techniques to create coffee with a more refined flavor.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Saturday afternoon, Jenna Martiello, 20, sipped a cup of coffee and admired the nearly six-foot tall roaster occupying center stage at Gentle Brew Coffee, a little coffeehouse in Long Beach. The stainless steel roaster with blue enamel accents was as shiny as a new car parked in a living room, surrounded by cafe tables, chairs and several armchairs.

headline: Plucking Notes, and Strings, of Long Ago
abstract: “The Kingdoms of Castile,” a concert with the harpsichordist Dongsok Shin, will be presented on April 12 at the Yale Collection of Musical Instruments in New Haven.
lead_paragraph: In 1640, Andreas Ruckers of Antwerp was producing harpsichords of such clarity and consistency that they were the envy of Northern Europe. Most of those harpsichords, like others of their vintage, have disappeared or been radically altered, sometimes with disastrous results.

headline: Man Killed by Bus at Port Authority Terminal Is Identified
abstract: The man who was fatally struck at the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Manhattan was identified as Samuel Rodriguez, 67, of Garrison, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: A man struck and killed by a bus at the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Manhattan this week was identified by the authorities on Saturday as Samuel Rodriguez, 67, of Garrison, N.Y.

headline: After Kleiner Trial, Expect Less Shooting From the Hip in Silicon Valley
abstract: A recurring issue was who originated investment ideas at the venture capital firm and the lack of documentation to support claims.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — John Doerr really needed a win, and late Friday the esteemed venture capitalist got one of the biggest of his career: a jury’s complete dismissal of gender discrimination claims against his firm, Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers.

headline: A Review of Falls Village Inn Restaurant in Connecticut
abstract: In a stately building that was once a stagecoach stop, the modest menu is deceiving.
lead_paragraph: One of the most stately buildings in Falls Village in the town of Canaan is the Falls Village Inn, built in the Italianate style in 1834. Nine years ago, the former stagecoach stop closed, was sold, and then reopened in 2010.

headline: Playing Shortstop for the Mets, Wilmer Flores. Really? Yeah, Really.
abstract: The Mets have been unsettled at shortstop for two years. With a live bat but a defense that remains a work in progress, Wilmer Flores still has the confidence of the team’s front office.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — A few weeks before spring training, Sandy Alderson, the Mets’ general manager, was summoned to jury duty at a Manhattan courthouse. At one point in the selection process, he was asked, “What do you do in your spare time?”

headline: Review: At Le Malt, Food Makes an Appearance but Cocktails Rule
abstract: The French article is your first hint that something is faux in Colonia, the part of Woodbridge Township where Le Malt shares a low-slung building with a liquor store called Wine Chateau.
lead_paragraph: Daylight saving time had just begun as I drove Route 1 to Le Malt early one evening, and the sun slanted over the strip malls. Heaps of exhaust-stained ice were melting, and one could have leapt for joy. But instead I walked into a windowless, beige bunker that, from the outside, looks like nothing so much as a strip club. I blinked hard, waited for my pupils to triple in diameter. Goodbye daylight, goodbye saving.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2015: Everyone Hates Puzzle 5
abstract: Is the nefarious A.C.P.T. Puzzle 5 really that bad?
lead_paragraph: SPECIAL POST — It’s a well-known fact that many people competing in the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament consider Puzzle 5 to be their personal Rubicon. Anyone can fill in as many squares as possible in Puzzles 1-4. If you make it through the devilishly hard Puzzle 5, you’ve crossed the line into hardcore solving.

headline: No Winner or Loser When a No. 1 Pick Goes Under the Knife
abstract: Brady Aiken held out after he was selected as the No. 1 pick in the 2014 baseball draft by the Houston Astros. Last week he announced he’d undergone Tommy John surgery.
lead_paragraph: In the movie “The Program,” Alvin Mack, a college linebacker played by the actor Duane Davis, appears destined for the N.F.L. That is, until a knee injury instantly rewrites his future. In a span of minutes, Mack goes from a potential first-round pick to a former player considering a future in coaching.

headline: Privatization Memories
abstract: Harry Reid turns from VSPs to DFHs.
lead_paragraph: Dave Weigel has one of the more interesting Harry Reid retrospectives, focusing on his role in fighting back Bush’s attempt to privatize Social Security — and in particular on the way he forged an alliance with liberal bloggers.

headline: Air Conditioning and the Rise of the South
abstract: How hot became cool.
lead_paragraph: Just a short further note on this subject. (If you’re wondering why I’m doing posting so much on a Saturday, I’m housebound with a cold, so why not?)

headline: Elite Chess Teams Reach Final Four, Which Should Be a Quiet Affair
keywords: ['Chess', 'Colleges and Universities', 'College Athletics', 'United States Chess Championships']
abstract: This weekend’s event in New York pits the top four chess teams from December’s Pan-American Intercollegiate Team Chess Championship.
lead_paragraph: Elite college basketball programs are battling in the N.C.A.A. tournament this weekend to reach the Final Four. For fans of chess, the top four teams are squaring off now.

headline: Henrik Lundqvist’s Return to Rangers Is Ruined by Bruins
abstract: The Rangers’ goalie was peppered with shots in his return from a throat injury and the Bruins scored four times in the first 26 minutes, taking advantage of several defensive lapses.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Rangers goalie Henrik Lundqvist had waited almost two months for this day. Sidelined by a serious neck injury, he had gone through a couple of practices this week and was cleared to start Saturday against the Bruins.

headline: Moving Onward With Cool Passion
abstract: Glaciers can be cool and awesome as they move inexorably onward.
lead_paragraph: Glaciers can be cool and awesome as they move inexorably onward. That may also describe Liz Gerring’s “glacier,” as presented by her Liz Gerring Dance Company. Neither a choreographic travelogue nor a geological survey, Ms. Gerring’s abstract dance demands cool passion of its eight dancers, requiring them to move with unbroken stamina but often at a far from glacial pace. Although it has nothing to do with ice and snow, “glacier” may nonetheless convey a sense of an awesome territory. Ms. Gerring has said that one of her inspirations was a memory of a visit to the vast North Dakota prairie where her mother grew up. Michael J. Schumacher’s taped score combines instruments like guitar, harp, cello, clarinet, recorder and piano with natural sounds recorded during a residency at Glacier Lake in Colorado. (Tuesday and Wednesday at 7:30 p.m., Thursday at 8 p.m., Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue at 19th Street, Chelsea; 212-242-0800, joyce.org.)

headline: Neglected No More, A Rich Latin Legacy
abstract: Preparing for the Museum of Modern Art’s “Latin America in Construction: Architecture 1955-1980,” which opens on Sunday, was a process of excavation.
lead_paragraph: Preparing for the Museum of Modern Art’s “Latin America in Construction: Architecture 1955-1980,” which opens on Sunday, was a process of excavation. Barry Bergdoll, who organized the show with Carlos Eduardo Comas, Patricio del Real and Jorge Francisco Liernur, made multiple visits to the region, scouring architects’ offices, tracking down architects’ descendants and borrowing material from state archives.

headline: A Last Call For ‘Cougar Town’
abstract: In the world of television, being flashy and new gets you attention.
lead_paragraph: In the world of television, being flashy and new gets you attention. So does being dumb and tasteless. But what keeps TV percolating are the shows that fit neither profile; they’re just reliably good week after week, season after season. One of those, “Cougar Town,” has its final episode at 10:30 on Tuesday night on TBS.

headline: Hollywood Hero Of the Second Rank
abstract: Joel McCrea’s early work is the subject in the Museum of Modern Art’s Acteurism series, with a program that runs from Wednesday through May 29.
lead_paragraph: He wasn’t ever as front-tier as Cary Grant or Jimmy Stewart, but Joel McCrea shared the same camera-ready ease and light touch that defined Hollywood’s biggest stars as the studio system hit its stride in the 1930s and ’40s. While directors from Alfred Hitchcock (“Foreign Correspondent”) to Preston Sturges — “Sullivan’s Travels” is, arguably, both men’s greatest film — sought him out, McCrea, a natural-born horseman, focused on westerns for the later years of his career.

headline: An Immersive History Lesson
abstract: The New Orleans-born pianist and singer Henry Butler delivers gigs as if they were full-immersion lessons.
lead_paragraph: The New Orleans-born pianist and singer Henry Butler, now in his mid-60s and a Brooklyn resident, delivers gigs as if they were full-immersion lessons: in old New Orleans repertory, gospel music, American theater songs, 1960s jazz, Southern rhythm and blues and soul. He’s a virtuosic pianist and a startling baritone singer; he’s inevitably the focus of whatever bands he plays in, and exactly the right performer to hear playing unaccompanied, tracing a casually authoritative history of American music. At Minton’s, the Harlem jazz club that has been tightening up its bookings in exciting ways, he’ll play on April 16, with sets at 7 p.m. and 11 p.m. (206 West 118th Street, 212-243-2222; mintonsharlem.com.)

headline: A Worshiper At Bach’s Altar
abstract: Lisa Batiashvili, a frequent guest soloist with the New York Philharmonic, is the orchestra’s artist in residence this season.
lead_paragraph: “People are religious or not, but Bach makes you believe in something, and for sure,” Lisa Batiashvili, the Georgian star violinist, said in a recent interview. A frequent guest soloist with the New York Philharmonic, she is the orchestra’s artist in residence this season. The run of concerts, conducted by Alan Gilbert, that begins on April 8 has a special significance for her. It features the music of Bach, which she only recently recorded after a long period of awe-struck distance, and brings her together, in Bach’s gorgeous Concerto for Violin and Oboe, with her husband, the marvelous oboist François Leleux.

headline: 7 Wounded in Spring Break Shooting in Florida
abstract: Several Alabama A&M students were among the victims Saturday in Panama City Beach, Fla. An Alabama man was arrested.
lead_paragraph: Spring break turned bloody when seven people in their early 20s were shot with a .40-caliber handgun early Saturday at a house in Panama City Beach, Fla. The shootings were described on an official Facebook page for Frank McKeithen, the Bay County sheriff.

headline: Portraying Bill Bradley, a Star Who Had a Sense of Where He Was
abstract: The author John McPhee was at the Palestra in Philadelphia in March 1965 to chronicle the exploits of Princeton’s best player, Bill Bradley.
lead_paragraph: As Harvard and Yale played for the Ivy League men’s basketball title earlier this month at the Palestra in Philadelphia, the writer John McPhee, 84, was a block away at Franklin Field. As a faculty fellow of Princeton’s men’s lacrosse team — “which means,” he said, “I stand around looking interested” — he watched the Tigers beat the Penn Quakers, 17-11.

headline: Speed on Display at Retooled IndyCar
abstract: The IndyCar racing season finally arrives this weekend, with a street race in St. Petersburg, Fla., featuring a familiar-looking cast of drivers.
lead_paragraph: The IndyCar season finally arrives this weekend with a street race in St. Petersburg, Fla., featuring a familiar-looking cast of drivers but an array of perhaps less familiar Chevrolet- and Honda-powered machines.

headline: For Golden State Warriors, Winning Isn’t the Only Thing
abstract: The standard for excellence with this team has transcended their winning percentage, which is inevitable when winning becomes so routine.
lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — What is most remarkable about the Golden State Warriors’ season has nothing to do with their N.B.A.-best record or their league-leading shooting percentages or the ease with which they regularly dismantle opposing teams of highly paid professionals.

headline: A Franchise-Changing Player
abstract: Connor McDavid is only 18, but he is already being compared to some of the sport‘s best players.
lead_paragraph: Connor McDavid is only 18, but he is already being compared to some of the sport‘s best players.

headline: Hockey’s Next Great One Draws a Crowd
abstract: One of the most anticipated N.H.L. prospect in decades, 18-year-old Connor McDavid has the fans of some teams believing that their teams can win by losing.
lead_paragraph: ERIE, Pa. — For Connor McDavid, an 18-year-old center for the Erie Otters of the Ontario Hockey League and the most anticipated N.H.L. prospect in decades, compliments accrue as steadily as goals and assists.

headline: Insurgents Seize Much of Key Syrian City
abstract: A coalition of Islamist insurgents, including a branch of Al Qaeda, seized most of the northern Syrian city of Idlib on Saturday after four days of heavy fighting.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A coalition of Islamist insurgents, including a branch of Al Qaeda, seized most of the northern Syrian city of Idlib on Saturday after four days of heavy fighting. It was an unusually dramatic front-line shift in a four-year war that has long appeared to be at a stalemate even as it grows more bloody and complex.

headline: Big Decision (and Plenty of Advice) for Hockey Prospect
abstract: Boston University freshman Jack Eichel, expected to go no worse than No. 2 in the N.H.L. draft, may find lessons in the stories of other professionals who decided to stay in school.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The image is a lasting one for David Quinn. He recalls a somewhat disheveled and unusually conversant Phil Kessel making a surprising confession during the 2007 world hockey championships.

headline: California, Here I Come
abstract: Alan Arbesfeld plans a trip.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Today’s puzzle is a letter-insertion theme by Alan Arbesfeld, wherein the state abbreviation for California, CA, is inserted at various points in phrases (for you kids out there, “REALLY BIG SHEW” at 82 Across is how 1950s – ’60s television host Ed Sullivan used to introduce his weekly variety show, SHEW being a mispronunciation of “show.”)

headline: Tailoring His Message, Ted Cruz Makes His First Swing Through New Hampshire
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: On a two-day trip that ended on Saturday, the Republican presidential candidate showed how he hoped to build a coalition.
lead_paragraph: GREENLAND, N.H. — When Senator Ted Cruz declared his candidacy for president, he said a broad coalition of “courageous conservatives” would carry him to the White House. On his first campaign swing through New Hampshire, a two-day trip that ended Saturday, he showed how he hoped to build that coalition.

headline: Liberia Recommends Ebola Survivors Practice Safe Sex Indefinitely
abstract: After an Ebola death, scientists want to gather more information on the length of time the virus might remain present in semen.
lead_paragraph: The Liberian government recommended on Saturday that survivors of Ebola practice safe sex indefinitely, until more information can be collected on the length of time the virus might remain present in body fluids including semen. Previously, male survivors were advised to abstain from sexual intercourse or to use condoms for three months, reflecting that the active virus had been detected for up to 82 days in semen.

headline: Wanted at the White House: A Fence That Says Halt! (With Curb Appeal)
keywords: ['Fences and Property Barriers', 'White House Building (Washington, DC)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Security and Warning Systems']
abstract: As the White House fence is altered to boost security, the Secret Service must balance a design that thwarts intruders but that doesn’t introduce a prison or Soviet style.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just after a Secret Service official shouted “Go!” and started a stopwatch, an agent hurtled toward a 10-foot-high fence with curving rods at the top.

headline: Tribes See Name on Oregon Maps as Being Out of Bounds
keywords: ['Names, Geographical', 'Native Americans', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Several place names in eastern Oregon include the word “squaw,” which Native Americans say is offensive. An effort to change the names has been long and difficult.
lead_paragraph: Grant County, a mountainous patch of eastern Oregon, has few Native Americans, but maps point to a different past, marking a spring, a rock, three meadows and several creeks with “squaw” in their names.

headline: Fragile Cease-Fire in Ukraine Inspires Little Confidence in West
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: Western diplomats and analysts are predicting a further escalation of tensions, possibly including the placement of Russian nuclear weapons in the annexed Crimean Peninsula.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — No one really expects Ukraine to get better before it gets worse, or for the promises contained in last month’s cease-fire agreement to be kept.

headline: A Divided Nigeria Chooses Its President
abstract: Voters cast ballots in the most contested election in Nigeria’s post-independence history.
lead_paragraph: Voters cast ballots in the most contested election in Nigeria’s post-independence history.

headline: A Franchise-Changing Player
abstract: Connor McDavid is only 18, but he is already being compared to some of the sport‘s best players.
lead_paragraph: Connor McDavid is only 18, but he is already being compared to some of the sport‘s best players.

headline: Before I Die
abstract: When doctors diagnosed Karly Koch with a rare genetic disorder, they also made a grim prognosis.
lead_paragraph: When doctors diagnosed Karly Koch with a rare genetic disorder, they also made a grim prognosis.

headline: To Avert Repeat of 2008, Clinton Team Hopes to Keep Bill at His Best
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s advisers are trying to harness her husband’s gifts and rein in his impulses to avoid a repeat of her 2008 presidential campaign, when he was often a frustrated and unpredictable presence.
lead_paragraph: Bill Clinton’s hearing has faded. With his head of white hair and frail frame, he looks older than his 68 years — “truly grandfatherly,” as one friend said. He often jokes about what would happen if he were to “drop dead.”

headline: Iran’s Top Negotiator Says Accord Can Be Drafted
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT']
abstract: Mohammad Javad Zarif, the Iranian foreign minister, said Saturday that he had had productive discussions with his European counterparts about the remaining gaps in a nuclear accord.
lead_paragraph: LAUSANNE, Switzerland — Iran’s chief diplomat said on Saturday that he had had productive discussions with his European counterparts and that Iranian negotiators were ready to begin drafting an initial agreement on a nuclear accord.

headline: In a Win Over Arizona, a Resounding Repeat for Wisconsin
abstract: For the second year in a row, the Badgers beat the Wildcats in the West Regional and advanced to the national semifinals.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It felt familiar, on both ends of the court and across the spectrum of emotions.

headline: Months Before East Village Blast, Utility Found Gas Line Was Tapped in Dangerous Way
abstract: Con Edison workers were called to 121 Second Avenue in August for a “strong odor” of gas, and found multiple leaks in hoses that had been connected to the line, creating a “hazardous situation.”
lead_paragraph: More than seven months before an explosion and fire destroyed three buildings in the East Village on Thursday, utility workers discovered that the gas line to a restaurant in one of them had been tapped in a dangerous way, Consolidated Edison and the restaurant’s owner said on Saturday.

headline: Germanwings Crash Raises Questions About Shifting Ideas of Pilot Fitness
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Pilots', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Depression (Mental)']
abstract: Aviation experts say that most screening programs in Europe and the United States are based on an honor system that relies on pilots volunteering information about their mental health.
lead_paragraph: Aviation agencies in Europe and the United States once banned all pilots from flying if they disclosed a mental illness to their employers.

headline: Teenagers Face Early Death, on Their Terms
abstract: A national push and a new guide are giving critically ill young patients a voice in end-of-life discussions.
lead_paragraph: Tumors had disfigured AshLeigh McHale’s features and spread to her organs. A year ago, AshLeigh, 17, flew from her home in Catoosa, Okla., to the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md., with a thread-thin hope of slowing her melanoma.

headline: Residents in Eastern Ukraine City Rally Against Separatism
abstract: The participants from Dnepropetrovsk had hoped to help mend a rift between President Petro O. Poroshenko and the regional governor he fired.
lead_paragraph: DNEPROPETROVSK, Ukraine — Residents of this city held what they called a “unity rally” on Saturday meant to help mend a rift between President Petro O. Poroshenko and the regional governor he fired and ease worries that Ukraine, on top of everything else, is also now at risk of unraveling into privately ruled fiefs.

headline: Louisville Coach Rick Pitino Keeps Recalling How to Dream
abstract: Pitino, who has been on the sidelines since 1974, remains a youngster when it comes to the excitement of the N.C.A.A. tournament.
lead_paragraph: SYRACUSE — Rick Pitino is 62 years old and has been a basketball coach since 1974. That is old enough to have had a handful of former players grow into established, veteran coaches. That is old enough to have a son as a coaching rival. It is old enough to have first sparred with the N.C.A.A. over allegations of recruiting violations 38 years ago — when the N.C.A.A.’s first president was in office.

headline: Haji Wright, a Rising 17-Year-Old American, Is Said to Join the Cosmos
abstract: The Cosmos are expected to formally announce the signing of Wright, a star for the United States’ under-17 national team, as early as Monday.
lead_paragraph: As the goals piled up for Haji Wright, a rising star for the United States’ under-17 national team, the biggest question was whether he would continue his development in M.L.S. or leave for Europe.

headline: Duke Turns Up the Heat With a Slap of the Floor
abstract: The gesture demonstrates the Blue Devils’ commitment to defensive intensity.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Its precise origin is ambiguous. Even the man who introduced the tradition at Duke does not remember when it began or who did it first.

headline: Australia to Join Regional Development Bank Led by China
abstract: The decision to join the bank is an about-face for the nation, which had earlier agreed with the Obama administration’s requests to stay aloof from the bank.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Australia plans to join an Asian infrastructure bank led by China, the government announced on Sunday, reversing an earlier decision taken at the urging of the United States not to become a member. The move made Australia the latest of a list of major American allies to sign up.

headline: Vin Scelsa, Host of Radio’s ‘Idiot’s Delight,’ to Retire
abstract: Vin Scelsa has been a fixture on radio for nearly 50 years and a master of free-form programming.
lead_paragraph: Vin Scelsa, a master of free-form radio who has been a standby on New York radio stations for nearly 50 years, will retire on May 2 with the last installment of his long-running show, “Idiot’s Delight,” on WFUV, he announced on the air Saturday night.

headline: Despite Inexperience, Materiality Wins Florida Derby With Stretch Run
keywords: ['Horse Racing', 'Florida Derby (Horse Race)', 'Jockeys, Drivers and Trainers', 'California Chrome (Race Horse)', 'Horses']
abstract: Materiality, facing graded stakes competition for the first time in his third career race, outslugged Upstart and won by one and a half lengths.
lead_paragraph: HALLANDALE BEACH, Fla. — No horse that went unraced as a 2-year-old has won the Kentucky Derby since Apollo in 1882. Todd Pletcher, winner of a record seven Eclipse Awards as the leading trainer in North America, may have a horse capable of overcoming that daunting history.

headline: Almost 37-1, Kentucky Isn’t Done, Holding Off a Fearless Notre Dame
abstract: The Wildcats trailed well into the second half, but ultimately managed to take the lead and keep it, advancing to the national semifinals, where they will play Wisconsin.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — When the final buzzer sounded and the desperation heave by Jerian Grant had gone safely long, the Kentucky players swarmed off the bench to jump and hug their victorious teammates on the floor, a signal of how close they had come to heartbreak.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 28, 2015
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: March 28, 2015

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, March 29, 2015
abstract: Quotation of the day for Sunday, March 29, 2015.
lead_paragraph: “When I saw him as an adult compared to a youth, I thought, ‘He really amounted to something.’ He was confident, helpful. I thought, ‘Man, he’s someone who made it.’”

headline: New Path to the Same Spot for Arizona: Just Shy of the Final Four
abstract: Falling one game short of the Final Four for the third time in four years, the Wildcats were inconsolable but didn’t feel the need to apologize.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — They played a game within the game Saturday at Staples Center. During breaks in the West Regional final between Wisconsin and Arizona, the giant video screens at midcourt showed two nearly identical pictures and asked, “What’s the difference?”

headline: Without Much Ado
abstract: Timepieces so perfectly minimal they leave you wanting for nothing.
lead_paragraph: Timepieces so perfectly minimal they leave you wanting for nothing.

headline: A Wedding Album to Savor
abstract: This month we asked our couples to dish about what they served at their receptions.
lead_paragraph: This month we asked our couples to dish about what they served at their receptions.

headline: Ashley Etienne and Nigel Stephens
abstract: The couple were married in in Rock Creek Park in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Ashley Danielle Etienne and Nigel Audley Stephens were married Friday in Rock Creek Park in Washington by the Rev. Maxine Reed-Vance, a minister affiliated with Grace Baptist Church in Baltimore.

headline: Somjen Frazer and Andrea Bowen
abstract: The couple were married at St. Stephen and the Incarnation Episcopal Church in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Melanie Somjen Frazer and Andrea Majanik Bowen were married Saturday at St. Stephen and the Incarnation Episcopal Church in Washington. The Rev. Frank Dunn, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Kristen Tracey and John Davies
abstract: The couple met at Harvard, where each received the same degree, and both now work at Knewton, an education technology start-up in New York.
lead_paragraph: Kristen Hamelin Tracey, a daughter of Marcia J. Hamelin and Dennis H. Tracey III of Weston, Conn., was married Saturday to John Oliver Davies, the son of Rebecca B. Davies and David O. Davies of Irving, Tex. The Rev. Dr. Shane Scott-Hamblen performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of St. Mary-in-the-Highlands, where he is the rector, in Cold Spring, N.Y.

headline: Deena Tauster, Peter Feldman
abstract: The couple were married at the Park Hyatt in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Deena Megan Tauster, the daughter of Michelle H. Tauster and Paul G. Tauster of Lido Beach, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Peter Garrett Feldman, a son of Lynn E. Feldman and Samuel F. Feldman of Allentown, Pa. Cantor Kevin Wartell officiated at the Park Hyatt in Washington.

headline: Geri Hirsch,  Darin Friedman
abstract: A fashion and lifestyle blogger and a Hollywood talent executive marry at an art gallery in Los Angeles
lead_paragraph: Geri Hirsch and Darin Michael Friedman were married Saturday evening at Kayne Griffin Corcoran, a contemporary art gallery in Los Angeles. Rabbi Ken Chasen officiated at the ceremony, which was led by Haley Gilbert Fisher, a friend of the bride’s family and a cantorial soloist.

headline: Nathan Cardin, Benjamin Procter
abstract: Nathan Cardin and Benjamin Procter were married Saturday in Santa Monica, Calif.
lead_paragraph: Nathan Benjamin Cardin and Benjamin Butin Procter were married Saturday evening at the Annenberg Community Beach House in Santa Monica, Calif. William Scott Calvert, a friend of the couple who was appointed a deputy marriage commissioner by the state, officiated.

headline: Sherry Shore, Auren Kule
abstract: Sherry Shore and Auren Kule were married Saturday evening at the St. Regis Hotel in New York.
lead_paragraph: Sherry Melissa Shore and Auren Justin Kule were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Gary M. Bretton-Granatoor at the St. Regis in New York.

headline: Laura Goldin, Kenneth Ames
abstract: Laura Goldin and Kenneth Ames are to marry Sunday at the Sixth & I Historic Synagogue in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Laura Rachael Goldin and Kenneth Scott Ames are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Shmuel Herzfeld at the Sixth & I Historic Synagogue in Washington.

headline: Amy Farkas, Samuel Levy
abstract: The couple were married at Liberty House in Jersey City.
lead_paragraph: Amy Rachel Farkas and Samuel Paul Levy are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Mayer Perelmuter at Liberty House in Jersey City.

headline: Haley Moss, Asher Schranz
abstract: Haley Moss and Asher Schranz, who met at Wesleyan University and who are both doctors, are to be married Sunday in Long Island City, Queens.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Haley Arden Moss and Dr. Asher Jacob Schranz are to be married Sunday by Rabbi William Berman at the Foundry, an event space in Long Island City, Queens.

headline: Emily Abate, Joshua Guttman
abstract: The bride works for the Row, a designer label. The groom is a partner in SoftBank Capital.
lead_paragraph: Emily Anne Abate and Joshua Lee Guttman are to be married Sunday at Pioneer Works, Center for Art and Innovation, in Red Hook, Brooklyn. Rabbi Amichai Lau-Lavie is to officiate.

headline: Lily Lorenzo, Bryan Boisi
abstract: The bride, Lily Lorenzo, is a manager at the Plaza Hotel. The groom, Bryan Boisi, is a vice president of a real estate firm.
lead_paragraph: Lily Elizabeth Lorenzo and Bryan Patrick Boisi were married Saturday at the Church of St. Thomas More in New York. The Rev. Edwin B. Diaz, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Emily Hom and John Le Gall
abstract: The couple were married at the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County in California.
lead_paragraph: Emily Katherine Hom and Dr. John Brian Le Gall were married Saturday at the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County in California. The officiant was Karen Chin, a cousin of the groom, who was temporarily appointed a deputy commissioner of civil marriages by Santa Clara County.

headline: Margaret Lam, Stanley Wong
abstract: The bride is a financial analyst. The groom is a management consultant.
lead_paragraph: Margaret Chiu-Leung Lam, the daughter of Christine C. Lam and Kin C. Lam of Boston, was married there Saturday evening to Stanley York Wong, the son of Elaine H. Wong and Norman S. Wong of Edison, N.J. The Rev. Enoch Y. Liao, a minister of the Boston Chinese Evangelical Church, officiated at the Lenox Hotel.

headline: Brittany Freda,  A.J. Somers
abstract: The couple were married at the Breakers in Palm Beach, Fla.
lead_paragraph: Brittany Michelle Freda and Alexander Justin Somers were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Yaron Kapitulnik at the Breakers in Palm Beach, Fla.

headline: Joanna Lack and Brendan Lowe
abstract: The bride, Joanna Lack, and the groom, Brendan Lowe, work for the Camden City School District in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: Joanna Alexander Lack, the daughter of Pamela L. Goldman of Manhattan and Andrew R. Lack of Bronxville, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Brendan Robert Lowe, the son of Bettina C. Lowe and Dr. Michael R. Lowe of Cherry Hill, N.J. Rabbi Will Berkovitz officiated at Pioneer Works, Center for Art and Innovation, in Red Hook, Brooklyn.

headline: Lauren Loeb, Keith Doll
abstract: Lauren Loeb and Keith Doll were married Saturday in Stone Harbor, N.J.
lead_paragraph: Lauren Joy Loeb and Keith Andrew Doll were married Saturday at the Reeds at Shelter Haven, a hotel resort and private events space in Stone Harbor, N.J. Carlos Cuartas, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: Ariella Morrow and Ryan Tolkin
abstract: The couple were married in Aspen, Colo.
lead_paragraph: Ariella Sarette Morrow, a daughter of Livia F. Morrow and Joel I. Morrow of Merrick, N.Y., was married in Aspen, Colo., Saturday evening to Ryan Andrew Tolkin, a son of Maggie L. Tolkin and Bradley J. Tolkin of Brookville, N.Y. Rabbi Itzhak Vardy officiated at the St. Regis Aspen Resort.

headline: Friends, First and Always
abstract: After a long close friendship, Leah Greenberg and Ezra Levin realized their feelings for each other were strong enough that they couldn’t just stay friends.
lead_paragraph: Leah Frances Greenberg, a daughter of Sara B. Anderson and Mark H. Greenberg of Chevy Chase, Md., was married Saturday evening to Ezra Philip Levin, the son of Ronda Jones Levin of Buda, Tex., and Daniel D. Levin of Austin, Tex. The ceremony, at the Mexican Cultural Institute in Washington, was led by Tom Perriello, a former Virginia congressman who received authorization from the District of Columbia as a temporary officiant.

headline: Kezia McKeague, Eric Gettig
abstract: The bride, Kezia McKeague, works for the Council of the Americas. The groom, Eric Gettig, is a candidate for a Ph.D. in history.
lead_paragraph: Kezia Frances McKeague and Eric Thomas Gettig were married Saturday at Dahlgren Chapel of the Sacred Heart on the campus of Georgetown University in Washington. The Rev. Salvador R. Jordan, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Without David Villa, New York City F.C. Falls to Sporting K.C.
abstract: With Villa out of the lineup with a strained abductor muscle, N.Y.C.F.C. was dealt its first M.L.S. defeat, a 1-0 loss to Sporting Kansas City.
lead_paragraph: The atmosphere was different on Saturday at Yankee Stadium for New York City F.C.’s second home game. The buzz outside the stadium before the club’s March 15 home opener was missing this time, and with the upper deck closed and the stadium in its reduced soccer configuration, the match against Sporting Kansas City hardly felt like a special event.

headline: Neville Wakefield’s Many Muses
abstract: From the toy sailboats he made as a boy to the large-scale installations he’s overseen in his career, the art world curator credits his rural childhood for sharpening his keen aesthetic.
lead_paragraph: From the toy sailboats he made as a boy to the large-scale installations he’s overseen in his career, the art world curator credits his rural childhood and his own children for sharpening his keen aesthetic.

headline: Latin Glamour
abstract: Modern architects, artists and designers find inspiration in the colorful, sensuous landscapes and indigenous flora of the region south of the border.
lead_paragraph: Modern architects, artists and designers find inspiration in the colorful, sensuous landscapes and indigenous flora of the region south of the border.

headline: Loving the Unlovable Decade
abstract: Long derided as tacky and vulgar, the design of the ’70s is now a source of great inspiration.

headline: Air Canada Plane Lands Short of Runway in Nova Scotia
abstract: An Airbus A320 landed among a group of antennas, shearing off its landing gear, but no one was seriously injured, officials said.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — An Air Canada Airbus A320 landed in an antenna array 1,100 feet short of a runway in Halifax, Nova Scotia, early Sunday morning, shearing off its landing gear, accident investigators said.

headline: Notre Dame Is Just the Latest to Almost Defeat Kentucky
abstract: A tenacious Notre Dame team became the most recent Kentucky opponent to say, “Almost.” But opponents and fans have learned never to count Kentucky out of any game.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — The most consistent lament of Kentucky’s opponents this season has been, “Almost.”

headline: Corrections: March 29, 2015
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Sunday, March 29, 2015.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: What’s On TV Sunday
abstract: Today’s television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) GOING CLEAR: SCIENTOLOGY AND THE PRISON OF BELIEF (2015) The Oscar-winning documentarian Alex Gibney directs this film about the Church of Scientology, based on Lawrence Wright’s book “Going Clear.” Details about the church (above, its building in Los Angeles), which was founded by the science-fiction writer L. Ron Hubbard, are revealed through profiles and interviews with former members including the Oscar-winning screenwriter Paul Haggis. “Drawing from a trove of archival material, including filmed interviews with Mr. Hubbard, Mr. Gibney paints a profile of a church that grew by leaps and bounds through profound faith and drag-out fights,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “Mr. Gibney spends a lot of time on Scientology’s celebrities, but those sections of the film pale next to the harrowing allegations of the church’s serious physical and psychological abuse, including exploited labor.”

headline: Beef Ban in India Reaches Into Cages of Lions and Tigers
abstract: The prohibition has had a broad effect on everyday life, including for animals at a national park in Mumbai.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — Palash, the largest tiger at the Sanjay Gandhi National Park in Mumbai, still paces his cage for the hour leading up to dinner and still pounces on his meal when his handlers lift the gate to his feeding room. But lately what the 440-pound feline finds is not his usual 15 pounds of raw beef, fresh from the slaughter.

headline: For Hardware Makers, Sharing Their Secrets Is Now Part of the Business Plan
keywords: ['Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Inventions and Patents', 'Open-Source Software']
abstract: Patenting everything is so 2005. Companies like Facebook and Tesla Motors have followed the lead of open-source software, and now expose hardware designs possibly worth millions.
lead_paragraph: Facebook showed plans last week for drone aircraft that beam lasers conveying high-speed data to remote parts of the world.

headline: Singapore’s Lee Kuan Yew, in His Own Words
abstract: The founder and first prime minister of Singapore, Lee Kuan Yew, was known for his blunt and pithy honesty, died in March 23 at the age of 91. Below are some of his memorable quotes.
lead_paragraph: The founder and first prime minister of Singapore, Lee Kuan Yew, was known for his blunt and pithy honesty, died in March 23 at the age of 91. Below are some of his memorable quotes.

headline: Singaporeans and World Leaders Gather for Final Farewell to Lee Kuan Yew
abstract: Thousands braved heavy rains to say goodbye to Singapore’s founder and first prime minister, whose funeral drew a long list of dignitaries from across the globe.
lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE — Thousands of Singaporeans braved a torrential downpour on Sunday for a final farewell to the country’s founding prime minister, Lee Kuan Yew, whose funeral drew a long list of leaders and dignitaries from across the globe.

headline: 1940: Russell Refutes Nudism Charge
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: 1940: Bertrand Russell refutes nudism charges from a New York woman.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — Bertrand Russell, British philosopher and peer, whose appointment as professor on the faculty of the New York City College was confirmed by the Board of Higher Education March 19 after a state-wide controversy, today [March 29] emphatically denied that he had ever conducted a nudist colony in England or gone in for salacious poetry, in answering charges made against him by Mrs. Jean Kay, wife of a Brooklyn dentist. After the board upheld the appointment by an 11-to-3 vote, Mrs. Kay, who said she was acting for irate taxpayers, gave the board eight days in which to show the action was not ‘‘contrary to the public interest,’’ before she resorted to legal action.

headline: The Truck That Sparked Our Marriage Back to Life
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Marriages', 'Parenting', 'Trucks and Trucking']
abstract: Phase 1 of our married life was over. We needed to figure out what came next.
lead_paragraph: When my husband was transferred back to the United States for work after we had been living in Germany for four years, we bought a house and moved in with our children and our dog. My parents donated their used minivan to our family cause, and we parked it in our new driveway, exhaling with relief. Life would be so much easier now, I thought.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2015: Headed to the Big Boards
abstract: The latest in the 2015 American Crossword Puzzle Tournament.
lead_paragraph: SPECIAL POST — Good morning! As the bleary-eyed competitors file into the ballroom at the Stamford Marriott, the large, final round boards are being built in a staging room behind the scenes.

headline: Question in Boston Bombing Trial: For Tsarnaev to Testify or Not
abstract: While it is rare for defendants in criminal trials to take the stand, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev could testify anytime after the prosecution rests, if his lawyers decide he would help his case.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — He swaggers into the courtroom. Freed of handcuffs and leg manacles, he occasionally taps the witness box on his way to the defense table, where he takes his place between two lawyers. During most of the proceedings, he slouches in his chair like a bored student, picking at his goatee, his mind somewhere else.

headline: An ‘Ask Me Anything’ Chat on Climate Science and Coverage
abstract: A veteran climate scientist and a longtime climate journalist interview each other about three decades of work making sense of global warming.
lead_paragraph: The event described below has taken place and the video is now posted here:

headline: Citi Bike Resumes Service After Weekend Maintenance
abstract: The New York City bike-sharing program abruptly suspended service for maintenance work on Friday. By Sunday morning, nearly all of the bike stations were operating, a spokeswoman said.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s bike-sharing program was up and running on Sunday after abruptly shutting down for part of the weekend.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2015: The Tension Mounts
abstract: An upset increases the tension.
lead_paragraph: SPECIAL POST — It’s currently unconfirmed, but the buzz amongst the judges is that there might be an upset in the top ranks.

headline: Rising From Wreckage, Australia Sweeps to World Cup Title
abstract: Australia completed its climb from the depths to the heights of world cricket on Sunday when it won its fifth World Cup, defeating New Zealand by seven wickets in the final at the Melbourne Cricket Ground.
lead_paragraph: Australia completed its climb from the depths to the heights of world cricket on Sunday when it won its fifth World Cup, defeating New Zealand by seven wickets in the final at the Melbourne Cricket Ground.

headline: Arab Nations to Form Military Force to Counter Iran and Islamist Extremists
abstract: Many analysts attributed the move, intended to counter both Iranian influence and Islamist extremism, in large part to the Arab states’ drive for more independence from Washington.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The Arab states said on Sunday that they had agreed to form a combined military force to counter both Iranian influence and Islamist extremism, a gesture many analysts attributed in large part to their drive for more independence from Washington.

headline: Flea Theater Names Niegel Smith as Next Artistic Director
abstract: Mr. Smith, a 35-year-old North Carolina native, will succeed Jim Simpson, who helped found the organization in 1996 and is stepping down. Mr. Smith was an associate director of “Fela!” and an assistant director of “Caroline, or Change.”
lead_paragraph: The Flea Theater, an Off Off Broadway company that proudly embraces being named for an irksome insect, has chosen a new artistic director who promises to continue producing risky theater while also seeking to reach out to families when the organization moves into a new TriBeCa home.

headline: Talking Econoheads
abstract: Some with beards, some without.
lead_paragraph: A couple of events I was involved in are now online:

headline: 1965: Pope Seeks Urgent Review of Birth Control Ban
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Pope Paul VI urges a review of the Roman Catholic ban on birth control in 1965, to address overpopulation and family circumstances.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — Pope Paul VI has called for utmost urgency in reviewing the Catholic ban on birth control because ‘‘the church cannot ignore’’ the population explosion, the Vatican reported  today [March 29]. The pontiff, in a speech to his secret birth-control commission, said the church must give ‘‘absolutely clear indications’’ on the controversial issue. The Pope stressed that the church owes an answer to the world and to men and women whose married life is too often impeded by uncertainties from developing ‘‘according to the design of God.’’ Pope Paul told over 50 members of the international commission on Saturday to ‘‘let mature what must mature, but you must understand the anguish of many souls. Work diligently without attention to criticism and  difficulty.’’ He added that the church at all times took care to give an adequate reply to the great problems facing men. The Vatican communiqué, released today, revealed that there were three married couples as well as other laymen on the commission,  which includes doctors, psychologists, sociologists, population  and family planning experts and theologians. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 30, 1965.

headline: Pratt Institute to Offer Master’s With a Focus on Public Space
abstract: The 40-credit, four-semester master of science degree program is part of Pratt’s Programs for Sustainable Planning and Development.
lead_paragraph: Pratt Institute’s Architecture School this fall plans to start a master’s program in “Urban Placemaking and Management,” led by David Burney, the city’s former commissioner in the department of design and construction.

headline: After Outcry Over Pink Sculpture, Queens Councilman Wants Public Hearing on City Art Plans
abstract: Objections to a pink reclining figure planned for a Queens intersection led a councilman to propose requiring more public involvement in the city’s art commissions.
lead_paragraph: After an outcry over a plan to install a boldly colored, government-financed sculpture in Queens, a councilman intends to submit a bill to the City Council this week that would allow for more public comment on public art commissions.

headline: Gene Saks, Tony-Winning Director of Neil Simon Hits, Dies at 93
abstract: Mr. Saks, who switched from acting to directing in midcareer, won three Tony Awards and became the leading interpreter of the plays of Neil Simon.
lead_paragraph: Gene Saks, an actor who switched to stage and film directing in midcareer, winning three Tony Awards and becoming the leading interpreter of the plays of Neil Simon, died on Saturday at his home in East Hampton, N.Y. He was 93.

headline: O’Malley Speaks Out Against Possible Dynastic Rematch for White House
abstract: Former Gov. Martin O’Malley of Maryland has been promoting himself to Democrats as a potential alternative to Hillary Rodham Clinton in the 2016 race for the White House.
lead_paragraph: Former Gov. Martin O’Malley of Maryland, who has been promoting himself to Democrats as a potential alternative to Hillary Rodham Clinton in the 2016 race for the White House, on Sunday spoke out against the possibility of a dynastic rematch between Mrs. Clinton and Jeb Bush.

headline: Family-Friendly ‘Home’ Takes Top Box Office Spot
abstract: “Home” trumped “Get Hard,” a Warner Bros. effort starring Will Ferrell and Kevin Hart.
lead_paragraph: The crude “Get Hard,” a Warner Bros. effort described by some critics as homophobic and borderline racist, was cowed at the weekend box office by “Home,” a family-friendly adventure from DreamWorks Animation.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2015: And the Winner Is …
abstract: And the winner is …
lead_paragraph: SPECIAL POST — Congratulations to Dan Feyer, the winner of the 38th American Crossword Puzzle Tournament, as well as to all who came to Stamford, Connecticut to be part of the fun. Dan took the championship away from Tyler Hinman yet again, with just a half second lead. That’s about as exciting as it gets without a total upset.

headline: Cyclone Roller Coaster at Coney Island Gets Stuck at Top of Track
abstract: In its season debut, the 87-year-old wooden roller coaster stopped on the track and passengers had to walk down to safety.
lead_paragraph: The Cyclone roller coaster at Coney Island got stuck near the top of its track on Sunday, marring its season debut and forcing passengers to walk down the tracks to safety, an amusement park official said.

headline: Sullivan Fortner Wins 2015 Cole Porter Fellowship in Jazz
abstract: As the winner, Mr. Fortner will receive $50,000, the opportunity to record for Mack Avenue Records, and two years of professional career services and development.
lead_paragraph: Sullivan Fortner has won the 2015 Cole Porter Fellowship in Jazz, presented by the American Pianists Association. The honor was awarded on Saturday night at the Hilbert Circle Theater in Indianapolis, after a final round of performances by the five finalists in competition. As the winner, Mr. Fortner will receive $50,000, the opportunity to record for Mack Avenue Records, and two years of professional career services and development.

headline: Before Starbucks, a Bronx Cafe Blended Coffee and Racial Dialogue
abstract: The Mix Coffeehaus, a pop-up shop, asked customers a series of questions about their racial identity as a way to prompt conversation.
lead_paragraph: Vernicia Colon did not know whether to be angry, amused or flattered when Starbucks announced its campaign to prompt barista-led conversations on race. She knew the complexities of being an overlooked “other” in the usual black-white discussions, and not just because she is the child of a Puerto Rican mother and a black father.

headline: Boehner Reflects on Bipartisan Support for Medicare Bill
abstract: In an interview that aired Sunday, Speaker John A. Boehner called the passage of the bill with bipartisan support last week “an opportunity that presented itself.”
lead_paragraph: Lately, in the House of Representatives, all it takes to claim a major success is a bill passed with support from both Republicans and Democrats.

headline: Operation Dragoon Ride
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The commander of United States Army forces in Europe conceived of the convoy as people in Poland and elsewhere grew increasingly anxious about Russia’s intentions amid the long conflict in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: The commander of United States Army forces in Europe conceived of the convoy as people in Poland and elsewhere grew increasingly anxious about Russia’s intentions amid the long conflict in Ukraine.

headline: An American Military Convoy in Europe Aims to Reassure Allies
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Military Vehicles', 'International Relations']
abstract: Operation Dragoon Ride, consisting of 120 armored vehicles and more than 500 American troops, was envisioned as part public relations event, part training exercise and part signal to Russia.
lead_paragraph: DRAWSKO POMORSKIE, Poland — The line of 4-year-olds clutched hands tightly in their matching, reflective yellow vests and stared open-mouthed at the hovering Chinook helicopters kicking up grit last week in the school parking lot. Shy teenage girls took pictures beside grinning American soldiers while Polish families clambered over a line of Stryker armored vehicles.

headline: Two Bodies Recovered at East Village Explosion Site
abstract: One of the two bodies discovered at the site of last week’s blast was identified by family members as Nicholas Figueroa, 23, who had been on a lunch date at a restaurant in one of the destroyed buildings.
lead_paragraph: As firefighters worked on Sunday afternoon to pull two bodies from the scene of an explosion that demolished three buildings in the East Village, a brother of one of the men reported missing in the blast urged his friends and relatives not to give up hope.

headline: Germanwings Crash Investigators Sorting Through Physical and Psychological Clues
abstract: Investigators are trying to understand what drove Andreas Lubitz, who was at the controls of the jetliner that crashed in France last week, to the apparent decision to fly into a mountainside.
lead_paragraph: DÜSSELDORF, Germany — As aviation experts in the French Alps piece together the shattered fragments of the Germanwings jetliner that crashed there on Tuesday, investigators here are engaged in a task that is at least as challenging: trying to understand what drove Andreas Lubitz, who was at the controls, to the apparent decision to fly the plane into a mountainside.

headline: Review: ‘So You’ve Been Publicly Shamed’ Delves Into Infamy in the Age of Social Media
abstract: Jon Ronson examines public missteps and the revenge they attracted, trying to grasp some sense of proportion between the two, or at least figure out the rules of the game.
lead_paragraph: One of the people Jon Ronson interviewed for his latest book asked him a tough question. “Given that my previous books were about such frivolous topics as military psychics (‘The Men Who Stare at Goats’) and conspiracy theorists (‘Them: Adventures With Extremists’), why did I suppose my readers would be interested in the important question of public shaming?” Mr. Ronson was asked. Since his writerly persona is that of a stellar entertainer-explorer-clown, humiliation does seem weightier and less breezy than what he usually likes to handle.

headline: Jacoby Swiss Teams Winners at the Spring Nationals
abstract: The winners combined well in the diagramed deal from the last session.
lead_paragraph: On March 22, the final day of the Spring Nationals in New Orleans, the Jacoby Swiss Teams was captured by Richie Schwartz of Aventura, Fla.; Allan Graves of St. Johnsbury, Vt.; Boye Brogeland and Espen Lindqvist from Norway; and Lotan Fisher and Ron Schwartz from Israel.

headline: Michigan State Outlasts Louisville to Advance to the Final Four
abstract: Coach Tom Izzo led the seventh-seeded Spartans to the Final Four for a seventh time since 1999 with a victory over Louisville in the East Regional final.
lead_paragraph: SYRACUSE — The moment was worth savoring, so Michigan State stayed on the court long after the final buzzer sounded, the nets came down and Travis Trice’s back began tightening up enough to almost double him over. Matt Costello skipped around, and Lourawls Nairn Jr. wept. They stayed until there was no one left to hug. Then they went into the locker room and hugged some more.

headline: Laura Marling Bids Goodbye to All That
abstract: The British singer-songwriter has always been precocious, down to her (very productive) midlife crisis at 23.
lead_paragraph: The British singer-songwriter has always been precocious, down to her (very productive) midlife crisis at 23.

headline: Review: A Present-Day ‘Parsifal’ With a Nod to the Past
abstract: Directed by Dmitri Tcherniakov, the production is respectful of the opera’s history and meanings, even when it diverges from the libretto’s particulars.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Dmitri Tcherniakov’s suggestive yet stolid production of Wagner’s “Parsifal,” which opened on Saturday at the Staatsoper here, doesn’t begin in a forest, as the libretto indicates. But it otherwise conforms to the description provided in the text: a scene “shady and solemn, but not gloomy.” The audience enters with the curtain already up on a great hall lined with columns joined by high arches, the smoky air cut by a thick shaft of afternoon light.

headline: Review: Title Fight Trades Urgency for Depth at Webster Hall
