abstract: Once a forthright basher of a band, Title Fight has become deeper, more reliant on its emotions.
lead_paragraph: Toward the end of Title Fight’s Friday night set at Webster Hall, Ned Russin, one of the band’s two singers, introduced “Rose of Sharon,” a song from the band’s new album, with a bit of hushed reverence.

headline: Review: ‘The Tempest Songbook’ Closes Gotham Chamber Opera’s Season
abstract: With this Shakespeare-inspired work, the Gotham company continued its upward path.
lead_paragraph: When the New York City Opera closed in 2013, talk soon started within opera circles about which smaller companies might be able to fill the void. There was special focus on the enterprising Gotham Chamber Opera. But its directors said that they had to be careful not to build beyond the company’s means.

headline: Globally Minded Books Win Bancroft Prize
abstract: Books on the international cotton trade and on the shipboard slave revolt that inspired Herman Melville’s short story “Benito Cereno” have won this year’s prize.
lead_paragraph: Books on the international cotton trade and on the shipboard slave revolt that inspired Herman Melville’s short story “Benito Cereno” have won this year’s Bancroft Prize, considered one of the most prestigious honors in writing about history. Sven Beckert’s “Empire of Cotton: A Global History,” published by Alfred A. Knopf, was cited as “a masterful achievement in the burgeoning field of the study of capitalism.” It was researched in archives on four continents, to provide a deeper understanding of the commodity that shaped the story of slavery, the Civil War and Reconstruction. Greg Grandin’s “Empire of Necessity: Slavery, Freedom, and Deception in the New World,” published by Metropolitan Books/Henry Holt, was similarly cited for its effort to “decenter the history of African slavery in the Americas,” while also telling a gripping story of the complex processes that brought a crew of New England seal hunters “into fateful contact with a Spanish ship under the invisible control of the enslaved men and women it was supposed to be transporting.” The prize, which comes with a $10,000 award, was established in 1948 by the Columbia University trustees with a bequest from the historian Frederic Bancroft.

headline: At Yale, a New Home for Lincoln Portraits
abstract: The rare book and manuscript library at Yale has bought a vast private collection of photographs devoted primarily to Lincoln and the Civil War.
lead_paragraph: The rare book and manuscript library at Yale has bought a vast private collection of photographs devoted primarily to Lincoln and the Civil War.

headline: Yale’s Beinecke Library Buys Vast Collection of Lincoln Photos
abstract: The Beinecke Rare Book & Manuscript Library at Yale has bought one of the largest private collections of 19th-century American photography from the Meserve-Kunhardt Foundation.
lead_paragraph: Abraham Lincoln last visited New Haven in March 1860, when, as a likely presidential candidate, he gave a speech on slavery. He is now set for a triumphal return.

headline: ‘Hot Bench,’ a Court Show From Judge Judy, Is a Surprise Hit
abstract: The new show, created by the star of “Judge Judy,” has defied the odds to become the No. 1 new syndicated offering of the 2014-15 season.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A plaintiff shuffled onto a courtroom set at Sunset Bronson Studios here with a simple complaint. She had lent money to a shady guy who — shocker — turned out to be a total deadbeat.

headline: Review: Miami City Ballet in ‘Heatscape,’ a Fleeting Chase of Romance
abstract: The corps preformed the premiere of the latest work by Justin Peck, who has quickly become the most eminent ballet choreographer in the United States.
lead_paragraph: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. — No ballet by the 27-year-old choreographer Justin Peck is much like another; with each assignment he sets himself new choreographic hurdles. But Mr. Peck has quickly become the most eminent choreographer of ballet in the United States — and two particular characteristics have propelled him to the top: the exciting formal architecture of his dances and the kinesthetic thrill of his movement.

headline: Review: In ‘Weird Loners,’ Four Single New Yorkers Dodge Commitment
abstract: Beginning Tuesday night on Fox, the show is funny in a relaxed way that is welcome in a television spectrum full of pushiness and intensity.
lead_paragraph: Among television’s current epidemics — zombies, serial killers, reality-show families with gigantic numbers of children — one is easy to overlook: rootless single characters reluctant to commit to love or anything else. “Undateable.” “About a Boy.” The recently departed “Mulaney.” And so on.

headline: Review: ‘The Dovekeepers,’ a CBS Mini-Series Starring Cote de Pablo
abstract: This two-part movie is based on Alice Hoffman’s fictional account of the siege of Masada.
lead_paragraph: Whatever happened to Ziva? Those still wondering can rest easy. She has been located on a mountaintop in the first century A.D.

headline: 2016 Hopefuls and Wealthy Are Aligned on Inequality
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Republicans Ted Cruz, Marco Rubio and Rand Paul and the Democrat Hillary Clinton agree that the income gap is a problem but diverge from public opinion on how to solve it.
lead_paragraph: Appearing at a candidate forum in late January, three likely Republican presidential contenders — Senators Ted Cruz, Marco Rubio and Rand Paul — all made a striking confession: They considered “the increasing gap between rich and poor” to be a problem.

headline: No Net Ensnares Me
abstract: Bruce Haight takes off for parts unknown.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Bruce Haight seems to be vying with Elizabeth Gorski for the title of grid artist, albeit in 15×15 grids. Today, Mr. Haight takes flight with a puzzle that is all about our avian friends. Either that, or he’s launched a whole lot of boomerangs. I’m going to go with the bird theory.

headline: News Companies See Movies as Opportunity for Growth
keywords: ['Movies', 'News and News Media', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: Some of the most aggressive contemporary purveyors of information, journalistic and otherwise, are betting on feature-length motion pictures.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When the digital wizards at a forward-leaning media company last year introduced their newest idea, an entertainment unit, they couldn’t resist an antique touch: “BuzzFeed Motion Pictures” arrived with a video logo modeled on images from a primitive movie projector called a zoopraxiscope, invented by one Eadweard Muybridge, circa 1879.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of March 30
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Credit and Debt', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: A Deadline for Greece, and U.S. Jobs Data
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'New York International Auto Show', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Automobiles']
abstract: Greece is hoping to gain approval for its economic plans on Monday so its rescuers will release the next round of bailout aid; United States employment data is due on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Here are some of the top business stories to pay attention to in the coming week.

headline: Share the Pork, Be President for Life
abstract: African voters won't tolerate the strongmen of the past, but they'll bend the rules for leaders who bring prosperity.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — The Republic of Congo’s ruling party just joined the long list of regimes in Africa that are pushing to change constitutions to alter term limits and permit sitting leaders to extend their stays in office. The country’s 2002 Constitution limits the number of presidential terms to two. Now the Congolese Labor Party has had second thoughts, and is seeking to amend the law so that, the opposition says, President Denis Sassou Nguesso will be able to run for a third term.

headline: In Delaying Vote on Loretta Lynch as Attorney General, G.O.P. Is in a Quandary
abstract: Republicans can accept Loretta E. Lynch, a nominee they oppose because she backs the president’s policies, or reject her and live with an attorney general they loathe, Eric H. Holder Jr.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans bolted for a two-week spring recess with the confirmation of Loretta E. Lynch as attorney general in jeopardy, and themselves in a quandary: Accept a qualified nominee they oppose because she backs President Obama’s policies or reject her and live with an attorney general they despise, Eric H. Holder Jr.

headline: Uzbeks Vote on Expected 4th Term for Authoritarian Leader
abstract: President Islam Karimov, in power since 1989, faced three opposition candidates who used their campaigns to praise the incumbent.
lead_paragraph: TASHKENT, Uzbekistan — Uzbeks went to the polls in droves on Sunday for an election in which the result was a foregone conclusion: maintaining President Islam Karimov in power in the authoritarian Central Asian state, which he has led since 1989.

headline: Austerity, Big and Small
abstract: Fun with bubble charts.
lead_paragraph: At this point it’s fairly common to look at the effects of austerity via cross-country scatterplots: one axis shows some measure of fiscal consolidation, while the other shows the change in GDP. Who started this practice? I think I did, here, although I’m happy to cede credit to someone else if I missed it.

headline: Duke Defeats Gonzaga to Advance to Its 16th Final Four
abstract: Justise Winslow had 16 points as the top-seeded Blue Devils advanced to the Final Four, where the senior Quinn Cook will have a chance to ease the sting of a 2013 loss.

He remembers the confetti falling and Louisville celebrating and his Duke teammates consoling one another. Their faces, the sadness, he will never forget.

headline: What’s On TV Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8:30 P.M. (ABC Family) THE GOONIES (1985) Richard Donner directed, Chris Columbus wrote the screenplay and Steven Spielberg wrote the story for this classic buddy adventure. Friends in Astoria, Ore., face the glum prospect of having their group broken apart as a country club tries to build a golf course on their properties. They a map they believe will lead them to buried treasure with which they can buy off the country club and keep their homes. They set off in search of the treasure. “The Goonies themselves are an appealing bunch: There is a smart-alecky one (Corey Feldman), a mature one (Josh Brolin), a precociously responsible one (Sean Astin), a weirdly inventive one (Ke Huy Quan) and an effervescent fat one (Jeff Cohen) who steals half the film,” Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. The film “has crooks, bats, cobwebs, skeletons, a lovable monster, an underground grotto and a treasure hidden by some of the most considerate, clue-loving pirates who ever lived.” (The Goonies, above.)

headline: Talking Photography With Elliott Erwitt
abstract: Elliott Erwitt has been prolific with his photo books, but he warned Todd Heisler that he was a lousy interview. He was wrong. And funny.
lead_paragraph: I learned long ago that it’s best to approach your heroes with trepidation, because they rarely live up to expectations. So when I met Elliott Erwitt in Perpignan, France, years ago, when we both had shows for Visa Pour l’Image, I was reluctant to talk to him. Imagine my surprise when he asked to trade prints. I upped the ante and asked whether if I bought his book, “Personal Best,” he would sign it for me.

headline: A Truce in the War Over Family
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Family Leaves', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Income Tax']
abstract: Marriage, babies and problems liberals and conservatives can agree on.
lead_paragraph: THE war over the family has been a disheartening part of American politics for decades. Conservatives saw growing numbers of children born outside of marriage and thought the family as they knew it was in trouble, the result of a cultural decline — a decrease in personal responsibility, and a growing dependence on government social welfare programs. Liberals saw families struggling and thought the problems reflected poverty and the dearth of good jobs.

headline: After 50 Years, It’s Time for a Better ‘Sound of Music’
abstract: I hate to have to say it, but I very firmly feel: That film needs fixing.
lead_paragraph: “The Sound of Music,” the movie, turns 50 this year, as popular as ever, a bedrock memory of untold millions of childhoods. Mine, for sure. Some far-off day, when neural engineers do a digital download of my dying brain, they will find, way back with the oldest grudges and PIN numbers, the “Sound of Music” soundtrack, every line and rhyme. She climbs a tree and scrapes her knee. When the dog bites. Yodel-ay-hee-hoo.

headline: Imaginary Health Care Horrors
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The Affordable Care Act is costing taxpayers much less than expected, but that hasn’t deterred the prophets of disaster.
lead_paragraph: There’s a lot of fuzzy math in American politics, but Representative Pete Sessions of Texas, the chairman of the House Rules Committee, recently set a new standard when he declared the cost of Obamacare “unconscionable.” If you do “simple multiplication,” he insisted, you find that the coverage expansion is costing $5 million per recipient. But his calculation was a bit off — namely, by a factor of more than a thousand. The actual cost per newly insured American is about $4,000.

headline: For the Police, Quality Over Quantity

headline: The Deer in the Garden
abstract: I tried everything I could think of, but I finally learned that there really isn’t anything a hungry herd won’t eat.
lead_paragraph: Eight deer of various sizes are grazing the winter azaleas and fringe of monkey grass just outside the front window. Several young ruminants are right up next to the house, tugging at a tattered rhododendron, occasionally bumping the window screen. Although the dog is flipping out in the hallway below, barking sharply, indignantly, the herd is unfazed.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | March 30, 2015

headline: Trevor Noah to Succeed Jon Stewart on ‘The Daily Show’
abstract: After only three appearances on the Comedy Central show, a 31-year-old comedian from South Africa will step up as its new host.
lead_paragraph: In December, Trevor Noah, a 31-year-old comedian, made his debut as an on-air contributor on “The Daily Show With Jon Stewart,” offering his outsider’s perspective, as a biracial South African, on the United States.

headline: Trevor Noah, New ‘Daily Show’ Host, Has an Earnest and Comedic Profile on Twitter and YouTube
abstract: Trevor Noah’s tweets and clips from his standup comedy performances may offer clues about what kind of host he’ll be when he succeeds Jon Stewart on ‘‘The Daily Show’’ on Comedy Central.
lead_paragraph: When Jon Stewart started as the host of “The Daily Show,” in 1999, Internet video was hard to come by, and social networks like Twitter didn’t exist. During his years as a professional comedian, Trevor Noah, like many of his peers, has established a strong footprint on Twitter, YouTube and Instagram. His tweets and clips from his standup performances may offer clues about what kind of host he’ll be on Comedy Central’s crown jewel nightly program.

abstract: Anti-artificial intelligence.

headline: Men’s Wear Continues Its Global Surge
abstract: Last year, men’s wear sales worldwide grew 4.5 percent, while women’s wear grew only 3.7 percent.

headline: Q. and A.: Adam Fisk on Evading Internet Censorship in China
abstract: The lead developer of Lantern, a censorship-evading tool, discusses how it works and how it has reacted to the new measures by Chinese Internet regulators.
lead_paragraph: In recent months, China’s Internet regulators have further restricted the already limited access that the nation’s 648 million Internet users have to the web. Several Google services, including Gmail and Gchat, have become inaccessible. Virtual private networks, or V.P.N.s, that once let users skirt online censorship have also been blocked.

headline: Red Meat Is Not the Enemy
abstract: Many people cite a recent study linking increased protein intake to higher mortality rates. But a closer look at the research tells a different story.
lead_paragraph: There are people in this country eating too much red meat. They should cut back. There are people eating too many carbs. They should cut back on those. There are also people eating too much fat, and the same advice applies to them, too.

headline: 1940: War Intrudes on Historians
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Historians try to write the history of WWI during WWII in 1940.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Great Britain’s official military historians are hard at work trying to finish the story of the last war and wondering when they will be able to start writing about his one. In another volume of the long series on the conflict of 1914- 1918, to be published tomorrow [March 31], the scribes have chronicled such events of 1917 as the Battles of Arras and the German retreat to the Hindenberg Line. Half the staff of writers and research workers is busy amassing and pigeon-holing data on the present war. A weary official said today: ‘‘I don’t know when we shall start writing it up. It depends on how long it lasts. It is far too early yet to get the right perspective.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, March 31, 1940

headline: Germanwings Co-Pilot Was Treated for ‘Suicidal Tendencies,’ Authorities Say
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Pilots', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']

headline: As Jobs Become Scarce, Teenagers Drive Farther to Find Work

But what happens when the corner drugstore closes, the family-owned supermarket shuts its doors, and the only jobs available for high schoolers are more than 30 minutes away?

headline: In Boston Olympic Bid Vote, More Is at Stake Than Games

lead_paragraph: BOSTON — In the glassy offices of Boston’s headquarters for bidding on the 2024 Olympics, signs remind officials: “Keep Calm and Bid On.”

headline: China Is Urged to Confront Its Own History
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: China’s insistence that Japan “face history” is raising uncomfortable questions about Beijing’s own practice of suppressing historical truths about trespasses domestic and abroad.
lead_paragraph: The tour guide outside the bloodstained classrooms of the Tuol Sleng Genocide Museum, the high school in the Cambodian capital of Phnom Penh transformed into a prison and torture center by the Khmer Rouge, paused to ask whether any tourists in the group were from China. Visibly relieved when no hands were raised, he went on to describe the enabling role that Beijing played in the Khmer Rouge’s murderous rampage that claimed the lives of an estimated 1.7 million Cambodians beginning in 1975.

headline: A Singapore Story
abstract: The funeral of Singapore’s former leader was an occasion to remind the youth not to take his remarkable successes for granted.
lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE — An hour or so after the end of the funeral ceremony at the National University of Singapore, the crowds were only just beginning to thin out. Earlier, despite torrential downpours, they had stood six-deep in some stretches of the 10-mile route of the procession accompanying Lee Kuan Yew’s coffin. It was a last homage in a week of homages and an intense outpouring of national grief.

headline: Poetry Everywhere, and They Mean Everywhere, in Miami Festival
abstract: The O, Miami Poetry Festival will place poems on buildings, fences …. and bathrooms.
lead_paragraph: On April 1 the organizers of the O, Miami Poetry Festival begin their annual monthlong campaign to put a poem in front of all 2.6 million residents of Miami-Dade County. “Miamians should watch out for poems on buildings, on fences, in the mail, even in the bathroom,” Scott Cunningham, the festival director, said.

headline: Alex Garland’s Sci-Fi Faves

headline: Walker Art Center to Begin $75 Million Renovation
abstract: The project will restructure the museum’s grounds and it tie the Walker more closely to the Minneapolis Sculpture Garden across the street.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS – To celebrate its 75th anniversary as a public institution, the Walker Art Center will embark on a $75 million renovation of its rolling campus, the final stage of an expansion that began more than a decade ago with the addition of a new building by the architects Jacques Herzog and Pierre de Meuron. The new project will restructure the museum’s grounds and add a highly visible entrance pavilion, and it will also tie the Walker more closely to the Minneapolis Sculpture Garden across the street, home to “Spoonbridge and Cherry,” the sculpture by Claes Oldenburg and Coosje van Bruggen that has become a Minneapolis landmark.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The two young men who spent the night at a nearby motel with an older man and stole his car on Monday morning may not have known exactly where they were going. But they sped into a special highway exit reserved for employees of the National Security Agency.

headline: ‘Root to Leaf,’ a Field Guide to Vegetables
abstract: Steven Satterfield’s book offers both philosophy and instruction, with recipes that reward, again and again, the minimal treatment of the very best ingredients.

headline: Supreme Court Leaves Intact New York’s Ban on Religious Services in Schools
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Religion-State Relations', 'Religion and Belief', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)']

headline: Indiana Races to Fight H.I.V. Surge Tied to Drug Abuse
keywords: ['Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Pain-Relieving Drugs', 'Hypodermic Needles and Syringes', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: The worst outbreak in Indiana’s history, which stems largely from the intravenous use of the prescription painkiller Opana, has prompted a whirlwind response effort.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Ind. — Jeanni McCarty, a nurse and native of this threadbare city of 4,200, hurried up and down Main Street in Saturday’s bright sun, handing out stacks of fliers to any business that would take them. They were announcing a hastily planned specialty clinic — FREE, they emphasized in red — that would provide H.I.V. treatment to anyone who needed it.

headline: Hanya Yanagihara’s ‘A Little Life’
abstract: In Hanya Yanagihara’s novel, four friends from college grapple with adulthood in New York.
lead_paragraph: The lock on the toolshed is smashed, the motel door is kicked in and a child ­emerges — blinky, freed from years of sexual service, the violence finally at an end. The newspapers celebrate another triumph of the human spirit, and move on. But does the victim do the same? How does someone go from years of suffering and shame to live out the rest of a life? This is the question Hanya Yanagihara, author of “People in the Trees,” takes on in her second novel.

headline: Islamic State’s Grip on City Appears Firmer Than Iraqis Acknowledge
abstract: There is evidence that Islamic State forces are more numerous in Tikrit than previously revealed by the Iraqi government.
lead_paragraph: TIKRIT, Iraq — Iraqi officials insisted for weeks that Islamic State fighters had been all but exterminated in Tikrit, confined to a few pockets in the city center. Yet on Sunday, military officials in the city were reluctant to allow journalists to head back to Baghdad by road — even though the highway skirts Tikrit well to the west.

headline: Fluoridated Water Helps Older Adults Keep Teeth, Study Says
abstract: But the research from Ireland found that fluoridation had no effect on overall bone density in adults older than 50.
lead_paragraph: Fluoridation of water supplies, long ago proved to protect children from cavities, also helps older adults keep their teeth, a new study from Ireland has shown.

headline: ‘All the Old Knives,’ by Olen Steinhauer
abstract: Olen Steinhauer’s thriller takes place, almost entirely, across a restaurant table.
lead_paragraph: A middle-aged man, dazed, drunk and unsteady, clambers up a staircase to reach the fresh air of a rooftop. Pigeons scatter. He slumps, closes his eyes, loses sight of the London skyline, loses consciousness. He has done something wrong in the restaurant downstairs — though as the scene plays out, this transgression is revealed to be little more than drunkenness. He’s been acting distant and withdrawn at a lunch date with an old flame. He may leave the Soho restaurant feeling longing and regret, wounded by her criticism of his collection of poems, but there are thankfully no bullet holes. In this filmed version of Christopher Reid’s narrative poem “The Song of Lunch,” the slumping man is played by Alan Rickman. Emma Thompson is the woman who’s been looking across the table at him with disdain. She’s gone by the time he descends.

headline: Inquiry of Silk Road Website Spurred Agents’ Own Illegal Acts, Officials Say
abstract: The agents, one with the Drug Enforcement Administration and one with the Secret Service, have been charged with money laundering and wire fraud.
lead_paragraph: On the so-called dark web, drug dealing and other illicit sales have thrived in recent years, the authorities have said, through hidden websites like Silk Road and hard-to-trace digital currencies like Bitcoins.

abstract: As a runoff with Jesus G. Garcia approaches next Tuesday, some voters say they have soured on hardball tactics and gruffness.

headline: Dozens Are Reported Killed as Saudi-Led Strike Hits Camp for Displaced Yemeni Civilians
abstract: Saudi-led military actions intensified in Yemen, including a strike on a missile depot in Sana, which set a fire that sent civilians in a nearby village fleeing.
lead_paragraph: AL MUKALLA, Yemen — Dozens of civilians were killed when, according to aid workers and officials, what appeared to be an airstrike hit a camp for displaced families in northern Yemen on Monday. It was thought to be the deadliest single episode involving civilians since Saudi Arabia began a military campaign to drive back the Houthi movement five days earlier.

headline: S.E.C. Accuses Financier Lynn Tilton of Defrauding Investors
abstract: Regulators said Ms. Tilton and her firm breached their fiduciary duty to clients by failing to value properly the assets of distressed firms.
lead_paragraph: Federal regulators have accused Lynn Tilton, who calls herself the “turnaround queen,” and her firm, Patriarch Partners, of defrauding investors by hiding the poor performance of assets she managed for them.

headline: Islamic State Destruction Renews Debate Over Repatriation of Antiquities
abstract: As militants ravage artifacts, a debate has resumed over whether Western collectors should return disputed items to their countries of origin.
lead_paragraph: Assyrian relics that have stood for 3,000 years smashed and desecrated. Ruins from Babylonian times bombed and bulldozed. Scrolls and shrines ravaged from Somalia to Timbuktu.

headline: Spokesman for Missouri Official Who Committed Suicide Is Found Dead
abstract: Only weeks after Tom Schweich, Missouri’s auditor, took his own life, Spence Jackson, a spokesman who had worked for him, appears to have done the same.
lead_paragraph: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo. — Slightly more than a month after Tom Schweich, Missouri’s auditor and a candidate for governor, took his own life, Spence Jackson, a longtime Republican spokesman who worked for Mr. Schweich, appears to have done the same.

headline: A Paris Picnic, Delivered
abstract: Paris Picnic will deliver meals to locations in the city, complete with a baguette and a blanket.
lead_paragraph: Paris Picnic is a made-to-order delivery service that offers an assist for the most quintessential of Parisian activities: laying down a blanket, breaking out some Brie and a baguette and basking in the City of Light.

headline: Velvet Worms, Squirting Slime
abstract: How do those squiggly things, which are actually more like insects, do that? A team of researchers in South America set about finding out.
lead_paragraph: Velvet worms undulate through leaf litter on many stubby legs until they find an insect or other small prey. Then the creatures, which are not worms at all, strike. They squirt slime in a wavy, oscillating stream, trapping the prey in a sticky net.

headline: Secrets of Velvet Worm Slime
abstract: A new study sheds light on how exactly the velvet worm controls the jet of slime it sprays to deter would-be predators.
lead_paragraph: A new study sheds light on how exactly the velvet worm controls the jet of slime it sprays to deter would-be predators.

headline: Stephen Posen (Yes, Zac’s Dad) Finds Poetry in Paired Photos
abstract: The artist’s new book, “Ellipsis,” features 174 images juxtaposed in surprising, thought-provoking ways.
lead_paragraph: The artist’s new book, “Ellipsis,” features 174 images juxtaposed in surprising, thought-provoking ways.

headline: Russian History Receives a Makeover That Starts With Ivan the Terrible
abstract: The 16th-century czar’s reputation was scrubbed in one of several exhibitions that have presented a generous view of the country’s history.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Ivan the Terrible, the Russian czar, should really be considered Ivan the Not So Bad, according to a wildly popular historical exhibition held recently near the Kremlin.

headline: Scott Walker: From Eagle Scout to Commander in Chief?
abstract: Asked about the prospect of leading the U.S. military, Gov. Walker discussed his time in the Boy Scouts.
lead_paragraph: It is a quadrennial political ritual: Although very few candidates for president in recent history have actually had any experience that “qualified” them to be the commander in chief of the armed forces, the contenders often feel compelled to act as though they have that experience.

headline: Florida Highway Official on Van Crash
abstract: Lt. Gregory S. Bueno of the Florida Highway Patrol gave an update on the injured passengers after a church van crashed into a canal in Glades County, Fla., killing eight people.
lead_paragraph: Lt. Gregory S. Bueno of the Florida Highway Patrol gave an update on the injured passengers after a church van crashed into a canal in Glades County, Fla., killing eight people.

headline: Profiling the Distracted Driver: Young, Female and Solo
keywords: ['Cellular Telephones', 'Driver Distraction and Fatigue', 'Text Messaging', 'Wireless Communications']
abstract: People under 25 are more than four times as likely as older people to use a cellphone while driving, a new study reports.
lead_paragraph: People younger than 25 are more than four times as likely as older people to use a cellphone while driving, a new study reports, and a driver talking on a phone is about 63 percent more likely to be a woman than a man.

headline: Ready Thyself for an All-Night Philosophy Jam
abstract: At “A Night of Philosophy,” more than 60 philosophers will hold forth on knotty problems in logic, ethics, metaphysics and religion
lead_paragraph: It might be the most intense all-nighter ever staged in New York. For 12 hours, starting at 7 p.m. on April 24, the French Embassy on Fifth Avenue and its next-door-neighbor, the Ukrainian Institute of America, will be joint hosts of “A Night of Philosophy,” an event that combines elements of a teach-in, a triathlon and a sweat-lodge ceremony. Only the mentally strong will survive.

headline: Stephen Posen (Yes, Zac’s Dad) Finds Poetry in Paired Photos
abstract: The artist’s new book, “Ellipsis,” features 174 images juxtaposed in surprising, thought-provoking ways.
lead_paragraph: The artist’s new book, “Ellipsis,” features 174 images juxtaposed in surprising, thought-provoking ways.

headline: Verbatim: To Be More Like Ted
abstract: “What if we all carried ourselves more like Ted Kennedy?” — President Obama, speaking at the opening of the Edward M. Kennedy Institute in Boston.
lead_paragraph: President Obama, speaking at the opening of the Edward M. Kennedy Institute in Boston.

headline: The White House and Paid Leave: Let Flowers Bloom
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Paid Time Off', 'Parenting', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: The Department of Labor focuses on encouraging cities, states and employers to “Lead on Leave.”
lead_paragraph: Is it “time for America to Lead on Leave” — as in, finally join the rest of the industrialized world by requiring employers to offer employees some version of paid family and sick leave? The numbers suggest the “leading” ship sailed long ago: We are one of only four countries in the world not to guarantee paid family leave to at least some portion of our work force, and the only one of 22 countries ranked highly by the Center for Economic and Policy Research in terms of economic and human development that does not guarantee that workers receive paid sick days or paid sick leave. We have not led on leave. We lag on leave.

headline: Charges Against Ex-Federal Agents in Silk Road Investigation
abstract: The two former agents, Carl Mark Force IV and Shaun Bridges, were accused of laundering Bitcoins, the digital currency used on the once-thriving website for drug dealing.
lead_paragraph: The two former agents, Carl Mark Force IV and Shaun Bridges, were accused of laundering Bitcoins, the digital currency used on the once-thriving website for drug dealing.

headline: The Golden Age of Annual Reports
abstract: David W. Dunlap takes a look back at some of The Times’s annual report covers that were influenced by Louis Silverstein, one of the paper’s design directors.
lead_paragraph: David W. Dunlap takes a look back at some of The Times’s annual report covers that were influenced by Louis Silverstein, one of the paper’s design directors.

headline: The Condition Cancer Research Is In
abstract: Dr. Harold Varmus, the departing director of the National Cancer Institute, addresses funding challenges and the state of the fight against the disease.
lead_paragraph: In a letter to colleagues announcing his departure as the director of the National Cancer Institute, Dr. Harold Varmus, 75, quoted Mae West. “I’ve been rich and I’ve been poor,” he wrote, “and rich is better.”

headline: Lawmakers Focus on How S.E.C. Does Its Job
abstract: Recently discussed legislation deals with insider trading, waivers from automatic bars and the revolving door between the S.E.C. and private industry.
lead_paragraph: Congress has taken intensified interest in how the Securities and Exchange Commission should enforce the law, introducing several legislative proposals. Although quick passage of the bills is unlikely, they signal how much interest there is, at least among Democrats, about the agency’s work.

headline: Mannequins at the Museum
abstract: A new exhibition looks back at Ralph Pucci’s 40 years of collaborating on innovative forms, from the sculptural to the anatomically accurate.
lead_paragraph: Though passers-by often fail to so much as notice them, mannequins can reveal as much about the culture of their time as the clothing they display does. And, with his family business and the help of creative collaborators, Ralph Pucci is single-handedly responsible for many of the major developments in the modern-day mannequin industry. Pucci joined his parents’ New York mannequin-repair company in 1976 and began manufacturing the forms, teaming up with such design talents as Ruben Toledo, Andrée Putman and Maira Kalman to redefine the genre through diverse and dynamic new shapes, colors and body gestures. Now, in anticipation of Pucci’s 40th anniversary in the business, 30 of the company’s greatest hits are featured in a new exhibition, “Ralph Pucci: The Art of the Mannequin,” opening tomorrow at the Museum of Arts and Design in Manhattan.

headline: Video Shows Scene of N.S.A. Shootings
abstract: Aerial video shows damaged vehicles and debris at the gate to Fort Meade, Md., where the National Security Agency has its headquarters.
lead_paragraph: Aerial video shows damaged vehicles and debris at the gate to Fort Meade, Md., where the National Security Agency has its headquarters.

headline: With Travis Trice in Control, Michigan State Keeps Calm and Moves On
abstract: The Spartans head to the Final Four on the back of a skinny guard who has gone from unheralded recruit to superstar and been a picture of poise in the N.C.A.A. tournament.
lead_paragraph: SYRACUSE — Ten seconds remained in the N.C.A.A. tournament’s tense East Regional final Sunday when the basketball unexpectedly ricocheted into the hands of the Michigan State senior guard Travis Trice.

headline: Now That Ben Bernanke Is Blogging, Here’s What He Should Write About
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Income Inequality', 'Savings', 'Robots and Robotics', 'Baseball']
abstract: Inequality, robots, secular stagnation and the role of the Federal Reserve are all topics we’d love to know his thoughts on. Also, baseball.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the wonderful world of economics blogging, Ben Bernanke! The former Federal Reserve chairman rolled out a blog and a Twitter account Monday morning, promising to engage more publicly on a range of economic issues, and occasionally on baseball.

headline: A Burrito Filled to the Brim Downtown
abstract: At El Vez Burrito, there are more than 1,200 combinations to pick from; ergonomic tongs; Parisian caramels; and more.
lead_paragraph: To Stuff: A Burrito Filled to the Brim

headline: China Appears to Attack GitHub by Diverting Web Traffic
abstract: The attack on GitHub, a code library that includes methods for viewing Internet sites blocked in China, comes as the country has increased its censorship.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Chinese government has long used a sophisticated set of Internet filters known as the Great Firewall as a barrier to prevent its citizens from obtaining access to foreign websites with information it deems threatening.

headline: A Struggle to Save the Scaly Pangolin
abstract: A peculiar creature that looks like a four-legged artichoke is thought to be the planet’s most frequently trafficked mammal.
lead_paragraph: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — With its scaly exterior, peculiar body shape and propensity for rolling into an armored ball when threatened, the pangolin has invited comparison to the artichoke and the pine cone.

headline: Endometriosis Is Often Ignored in Teenage Girls
abstract: Debilitating pain, internal bleeding and even infertility may result when the condition is overlooked or played down by physicians.
lead_paragraph: Senie Byrne began menstruating at 15, and she quickly became an expert in pain management. Every month, it felt as if 1,000 darts had plunged into her abdomen; she sometimes passed out from the cramps. She was often nauseated, constipated and exhausted. At times, she had diarrhea. She said she saw 22 doctors over the years, but none took her seriously.

headline: Facts & Figures: Millennials More Accepting of Homosexuality Than of Abortion
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Forty-two percent of millennials say sex between people of the same gender is morally acceptable, according to a new survey.
lead_paragraph: In a survey conducted by the Public Religion Research Institute, 42 percent of millennial respondents said sex between two adults of the same gender was morally acceptable, while 37 percent said the same of casual sex. Twenty-four percent said sex between minors was acceptable, and 21 percent said so of abortion.

headline: Live and Kicking: Soccer Games to Watch
abstract: This week’s schedule includes a few friendlies, one not-so-friendly and a rare low-stakes version of Der Klassiker in Germany.
lead_paragraph: This week’s schedule includes a few friendlies, one not-so-friendly and a rare low-stakes version of Der Klassiker in Germany.

headline: A World Shared With H.I.V.
abstract: David Quammen takes readers to the disease’s origins, while Dr. Susan C. Ball recalls the devastation, and the heroically humane care it spawned.
lead_paragraph: The grayest heads among us still think of AIDS as a terrible new disease. But younger adults have never known a world without it, and many of the youngest think of it only as an annoying condition you take a pill for. They know nothing of the anguish and heroism that once surrounded the word “AIDS.”

headline: BSI Becomes First Swiss Bank to Settle Under D.O.J. Disclosure Program
abstract: The private bank entered a nonprosecution agreement and agreed to pay $211 million to resolve its role in helping wealthy Americans avoid taxes.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — BSI, one of Switzerland’s largest private banks, on Monday became the first Swiss lender to reach a settlement with the Justice Department under a disclosure program intended to encourage Swiss banks to cooperate in an inquiry into wealthy Americans who used secret Swiss accounts to avoid taxes.

headline: In Vietnam, Rampant Wildlife Smuggling Prompts Little Concern
abstract: Several species, valued as food, medicine or pets, may become extinct in a country where punishment is light or nonexistent.
lead_paragraph: U MINH, Vietnam — Luc Van Ho slips through a tangled thicket of jungle, graceful as a dancer. A blanket of dried bamboo and melaleuca leaves on the forest floor barely crackles beneath his bare feet. Only the smell of cigarette smoke betrays his presence.

headline: Indiana Legislators Say They’ll Clarify Beliefs Law
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Discrimination', 'State Legislatures', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Freedom of Religion']
abstract: Legislative leaders joined Gov. Mike Pence in saying they planned to amend the law to make it clear that it did not allow discrimination against gays and lesbians.
lead_paragraph: Indiana’s legislative leaders on Monday joined Gov. Mike Pence in saying that they planned to amend a new religious freedom law to make clear that it did not allow discrimination against gays and lesbians, while still insisting that the law did not do so in its current form.

headline: UnitedHealth’s $12.8 Billion Deal Could Reduce Further Consolidation
abstract: Catamaran’s agreement to be sold indicates that benefit managers no longer need to make merger offers themselves to stay alive.
lead_paragraph: A $12.8 billion prescription should address the chronic merger game among pharmacy benefit managers. The UnitedHealth Group is paying a 27 percent premium for the Catamaran Corporation and should generate more than enough savings to cover it.

headline: Clinton’s Effort on Israel Viewed Dimly by American Jewish Leader
abstract: Malcolm Hoenlein didn’t think Hillary Rodham Clinton’s work on Israel as Secretary of State was all that constructive.
lead_paragraph: The prominent American Jewish leader who on Sunday talked with Hillary Rodham Clinton about the need to put the relationship between Israel and the United States back on “constructive footing” did not think her role as the administration’s “designated yeller” at Israel as secretary of state was all that constructive.

headline: Ask Well: Jet Crash Raises Questions on Mental Illness Risks
abstract: Dr. Richard Friedman, a professor of clinical psychiatry at Weill Cornell Medical College, is answering reader questions about depression and its risks.
lead_paragraph: The crash of the Germanwings jetliner has raised questions about mental illness and its consequences. Authorities have said that Andreas Lubitz, the co-pilot believed to have intentionally crashed the plane into the Alps, had a mental illness that he hid from the airline, that he was treated for “suicidal tendencies” before he got his pilot’s license, and that antidepressants were found in his apartment.

headline: A Cure for the Cacophony
abstract: In Beijing, a hotel for guests who want to sleep where they spa.
lead_paragraph: Life in the big city can get overwhelming, which is why Beijing’s five-star Rosewood hotel, situated among the bustling bars and hustling bankers of the Chaoyang District, is opening Sense this month, for guests who want to sleep where they spa. In addition to 11 treatment rooms, there are five suites overlooking the skyline — all decorated with limestone, dark wood and a serene palette of muted beige and gray — so that guests can opt to enjoy the extensive menu of treatments in the privacy of their own palatial accommodations.

headline: Major British Parties Struggle to Fend Off Challenges as Campaigns Begin
abstract: While a coalition government has worked well, smaller parties seem to have siphoned off traditional voters from the Conservatives and Labour.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — And they’re off! Parliament was dissolved at midnight, making Monday the official start of what is already a bitter and bad-tempered effort to win the minds, if not the hearts, of Britain’s undecided voters, who by most accounts make up close to 40 percent of the electorate. This election promises to be one of the most unpredictable British elections in recent times.

headline: Justices Hear Arguments on Intellectual Disability in Death Penalty Case
keywords: ['Capital Punishment', 'Sex Crimes', 'Search and Seizure', 'Intellectual Disabilities', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The Supreme Court also ruled on two other cases, one involving ankle bracelets and the other regarding a convicted killer’s representation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday heard arguments in a death penalty case and issued decisions on the monitoring of sex offenders and on the significance of a lawyer’s brief absence from a criminal trial.

headline: 1957: Frisbees Fly at Princeton
abstract: A look at the first time the Frisbee was mentioned in The Times.
lead_paragraph: This feature looks at the first time famous names or terms appeared in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Send a suggestion in the comments section.

headline: Greece Looks to Russia as Deal With Europe Stumbles
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: A meeting next week between Greece’s prime minister and Russia’s president raises questions as European leaders said a reform plan had fallen short.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — With the prospect of a default looming in Greece, Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras is preparing to meet next week with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia as a European deal to give more aid to Athens falters.

headline: How Not to Catch a Cold on a Plane
abstract: There are ways for passengers to avoid whatever may be going around up there.
lead_paragraph: Q. What can you do to reduce the possibility of becoming sick when you are trapped on a plane with a sneezing, coughing fellow passenger?

headline: Ignacio Mattos’s Most Treasured Cooking Tool
abstract: The chef at Estela is passionate about his Microplane, which was born to cut wood, not zest oranges.
lead_paragraph: The Microplane was never meant to be a grater. It was never designed to turn walnuts to dust, or lemon peel into sunny snow, or to make confetti of mojama — salt-cured, wind-hardened tuna loin from southern Spain — the way it does in the hands of Ignacio Mattos, the chef of the Manhattan restaurant Estela.

headline: Parsing Ronald Reagan’s Words for Early Signs of Alzheimer’s
abstract: Researchers have found subtle indications of dementia in transcripts of the former president’s news conferences.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Even before Ronald Reagan became the oldest elected president, his mental state was a political issue. His adversaries often suggested his penchant for contradictory statements, forgetting names and seeming absent-mindedness could be linked to dementia.

headline: Chirlane McCray, on the Germanwings Co-Pilot’s Mental Health
keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'Pilots', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: Chirlane McCray, New York’s first lady, writes that “it’s time to recognize the stress and responsibility that pilots face and change our regulations and policies to ensure their mental health.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: N.F.L. Punishes Falcons and Browns for Rules Violations
abstract: The league suspended Cleveland General Manager Ray Farmer for four games for sending text messages to coaches during games. Atlanta will forfeit a draft pick for piping in crowd noise.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. penalized the Atlanta Falcons and the Cleveland Browns on Monday, suspending two team executives for off-the-field infractions last season.

headline: Phytoplankton on Decline in Southern Ocean
abstract: Climate change may be a possible cause, researchers reported in Geophysical Research Letters.
lead_paragraph: A type of phytoplankton important for carbon storage in marine environments is declining in the Southern Ocean, possibly because of climate change, researchers reported in Geophysical Research Letters. Emiliania huxleyi secretes a calcite shell, helping transport carbon dioxide from the surface into the deeper reaches. From 1998 to 2014, there was about a 4 percent reduction in the calcification rate during the summer months in the Southern Ocean.

headline: A Wing That Can Recover From Midair Collisions
abstract: A new robotic wing recovers from midair collisions with a simple mechanism: a pin joint that allows it to bend.
lead_paragraph: A new robotic wing, inspired by those of birds and bats, recovers from midair collisions with a simple mechanism: a pin joint that allows it to bend.

headline: Review: Soho Rep’s ‘Washeteria,’ Staged in a Brooklyn Storefront
abstract: The theater’s first all-ages play, staged in a formerly vacant storefront, is a lightly absurdist take on a coin laundry.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, Soho Rep has offered dramas like “Blasted,” “Born Bad,” “An Octoroon” and “We Are Proud to Present a Presentation” — tough, turbulent, troubling. But in the new show, “Washeteria,” the company is running on a much, much gentler cycle, with lots of fabric softener, too.

headline: Britain Acts to Block Removal of Egyptian Statue
abstract: British authorities have temporarily blocked the removal from England of an ancient Egyptian statue that was sold by a museum to raise money.
lead_paragraph: Britain’s Culture Ministry has temporarily barred the unidentified buyer of a $27 million Egyptian statue, purchased last year from a museum in the town of Northampton, from taking the 4,400-year-old antiquity overseas, according to the BBC.

headline: Stephen Posen (Yes, Zac’s Dad) Finds Poetry in Paired Photos
abstract: The artist’s new book, “Ellipsis,” features 174 images juxtaposed in surprising, thought-provoking ways.
lead_paragraph: It’s common knowledge that the designer and “Project Runway” judge Zac Posen has always had a quirky and creative eye — long before he began creating ethereal and dramatic gowns for the likes of Reese Witherspoon and Naomi Campbell, he was repurposing yarmulkes for Barbie doll dresses. Perhaps less known is how much of the designer’s appreciation for visual shape-shifting can be credited to his father, the artist Stephen Posen, whose new photography book, “Ellipsis: Dual Visions” ($75, Glitterati), is out this week.

headline: Review: Paquito D’Rivera in Concert at Jazz at Lincoln Center
abstract: Mr. D’Rivera revisits the premise behind his album “Jazz Meets the Classics.”
lead_paragraph: Paquito D’Rivera practiced an impish historical revisionism at the Rose Theater on Friday, in his first of two nights at Jazz at Lincoln Center. At one point his darting lines on soprano saxophone came girded by the triplet thump of a Peruvian landó rhythm — not the usual musical setting for Beethoven’s “Pathétique” piano sonata. But Mr. D’Rivera had explained himself in an introduction to the piece: “Beethoven was really from Machu Picchu,” he said, agreeably. “His name was not Ludwig but Luisito.”

headline: ‘Mad Men’: Megan Sings ‘Zou Bisou Bisou’
abstract: Jessica Paré, as Megan Draper, performs the song in Season 5.
lead_paragraph: Jessica Paré, as Megan Draper, performs the song in Season 5.

headline: Questions For Indiana’s Critics
keywords: ['Freedom of Religion', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: An attempt to pin down what might come after the current religious liberty debate.
lead_paragraph: I know that I should say something about the backlash and debate over Indiana’s version of the Religious Freedom Restoration Act, but it’s been hard to come up with something that I didn’t already say in my column when it was Arizona’s variation on the same law, vetoed under pressure, that was in the news. That column made the case that the only remaining question in the same-sex marriage “debate” was what kind of space, if any, an ascendant cultural liberalism would leave to Americans with traditional views on what constitutes a marriage; that the correlation of forces (corporate now as well as cultural and legal) was such that the choice of exactly how far to push and how much pluralism to permit would be almost entirely in the hands of liberals and supporters of same-sex marriage. That’s still basically how it looks to me today: Elements of the Indiana debate have been particularly … striking, but none of it has been particularly surprising given how this played out in Arizona.

headline: Harvey Weinstein, Producer, Questioned by New York Police After Groping Accusation
abstract: Mr. Weinstein has not been charged with any wrongdoing and, after being located by detectives, voluntarily accompanied the police to be questioned about the matter.
lead_paragraph: The film producer Harvey Weinstein was questioned by the police on Saturday after a 22-year-old woman accused him of touching her inappropriately during a meeting in Manhattan, according to two law enforcement officials.

headline: Small Planes and Frequent Delays Don’t Cool Ardor for Flying
abstract: A domestic traveler has learned to roll with the inconveniences of flight, mostly because he’s having the time of his life.
lead_paragraph: I’VE been with real estate trade associations for about 40 years. But it’s really only the last four years, after joining the National Association of Realtors, that my business travel has really expanded. The association is based in Washington, but I live in Madison, Wis. What I do is help run a political education program called the Realtor Party, and I work directly with more than 1,400 local and state Realtor Association chapters in every state.

headline: Foreigners Are Attacking ... American TV!
abstract: Trevor Noah’s foreignness might be just what American television needs.
lead_paragraph: American late-night television shows have probably never had so many anchors with foreign accents as they will have soon. Trevor Noah, a South African comedian, will become at least the third non-American native to host a popular TV comedy show later this year when he takes over “The Daily Show” from Jon Stewart. He will join two Britons, John Oliver of HBO’s “Last Week Tonight” and James Corden, who recently started hosting “The Late Late Show” on CBS.

headline: Conservative Gains in Local Elections Leave Left-Leaning Parties Adrift in France
abstract: Sunday’s election was seen as a rebuke of the Socialists, who were ousted from long-held seats, and were left uncertain about how to regain popular support.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — In the aftermath of balloting on Sunday, conservatives in France were well positioned to build momentum before the presidential election in 2017, political analysts said Monday.

headline: Review: ‘The Brothers’ and the Boston Marathon Bombing
abstract: The Russian-American journalist Masha Gessen explains how the American dream went so wrong for Tamerlan and Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the brothers linked to the Boston Marathon bombing.
lead_paragraph: The lead attorney for the accused Boston Marathon bomber Dzhokhar Tsarnaev began his defense this month with a blunt and dramatic statement: “It was him.”

headline: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
abstract: Iraq and Elsewhere — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Iraq and Elsewhere — Pictures of the Day

headline: Obama at Kennedy Institute Opening
abstract: President Obama attended the opening of the Edward M. Kennedy Institute in Boston and delivered remarks praising the longtime Massachusetts senator.
lead_paragraph: President Obama attended the opening of the Edward M. Kennedy Institute in Boston and delivered remarks praising the longtime Massachusetts senator.

headline: Obama Praises Edward Kennedy, and Mourns the Loss of Collegiality
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: The president spoke at the dedication the Edward M. Kennedy Institute in Boston on Monday, calling for a new era of compromise while remembering a “lion of the Senate.”
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — President Obama on Monday condemned the demise of bipartisan compromise in American politics that he said had prompted voters to turn away in bitterness and “disgust,” using the dedication of the Edward M. Kennedy Institute to call for a new era of consensus-building.

headline: March 30, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Iraq, India, Colombia and Nigeria.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Iraq, India, Colombia and Nigeria.

headline: Jay Z Reveals Plans for Tidal, a Streaming Music Service
abstract: In a business where artists seldom have direct control over how their work is consumed, musicians will be the majority owners of the company.
lead_paragraph: As Jay Z sees it, there is a clear solution to the problems facing musicians in the streaming age. They should band together — behind him, of course.

headline: The Fifth Season of ‘The Walking Dead’ Turned Into a Post-Apocalyptic Debate Club
abstract: The sword came off the wall, but it was too late to make a difference.
lead_paragraph: The sword came off the wall, but it was too late to make a difference.

headline: Fish Oil Claims Not Supported by Research
abstract: The vast majority of clinical trials have found no evidence that fish oil supplements lower the risk of heart attack and stroke.
lead_paragraph: Fish oil is now the third most widely used dietary supplement in the United States, after vitamins and minerals, according to a recent report from the National Institutes of Health. At least 10 percent of Americans take fish oil regularly, most believing that the omega-3 fatty acids in the supplements will protect their cardiovascular health.

headline: A Farmer Ant’s Unique Fungal Crop
abstract: Newly discovered ants have domesticated a fungus deadly to other ant species.
lead_paragraph: Much like human farmers, fungus-farming ants meticulously maintain their subterranean gardens. They regularly fertilize, weed and tend to their crops.

headline: Photos That Echo Russia and Ukraine
abstract: To commemorate Russia’s annexation of Crimea, five photographers are collaborating on image mash-ups that add layers of new meaning.
lead_paragraph: To commemorate Russia’s annexation of Crimea, five photographers are collaborating on image mash-ups that add layers of new meaning.

headline: Walkabout: More Travel Warnings in Kenya; Luring Tourists to Appalachia
keywords: ['Eco-Tourism', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: A weekly capsule of travel news curated by our writers and editors.

headline: Review: ‘Living Here’ Sends Gideon Irving to Wander City Apartments
abstract: A neo-folk musician, Mr. Irving sets up in New York apartments and between songs tells stories of his travels so far.
lead_paragraph: There were only two dozen people in the audience when the folksy balladeer Gideon Irving performed “Living Here: A Map of Songs,” produced by the Foundry Theater, on Wednesday.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers respond to Times articles about science and health.

headline: Modern Explorers Seek a Place in a GPS World
abstract: When every inch of the planet seems mapped, what’s left for the adventurous?
lead_paragraph: Eric Larsen seemed ill at ease in his tuxedo. He is more inclined to trudge across an ice shelf than mingle at a fancy party in Manhattan. Yet here he was, in black tie, nibbling on canapés at the American Museum of Natural History.

headline: Review: In TV Land’s ‘Younger,’ a Woman Cheats the Clock to Land a Job
abstract: Sutton Foster stars as a 40-year-old unemployed mother who poses as 26 to win an entry-level position in the publishing industry.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to stories about time travel, male characters often focus on what they would do. Mark Twain’s hero uses 19th-century technology to outsmart medieval sorcerers in “A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur’s Court.” The time traveler in “Back to the Future” can perform “Johnny B. Goode” years before that song’s release.

headline: Rubio Confirms Date of ‘Big Announcement’
abstract: The slow walk of candidates declaring they are running for president took another step forward on Monday with Senator Marco Rubio announcing plans to make a “big announcement” in a couple of weeks.
lead_paragraph: The slow walk of candidates declaring they are running for president took another step forward on Monday with Senator Marco Rubio saying he plans to make a “big announcement” in a couple of weeks.

headline: In Performance | Lena Hall
abstract: Ms. Hall, with Watt White on guitar, sings “Falling Slowly,” a ballad from the movie and Broadway musical “Once.”
lead_paragraph: Ms. Hall, with Watt White on guitar, sings “Falling Slowly,” a ballad from the movie and Broadway musical “Once.”

headline: Big Ears in Knoxville, Tenn.
abstract: The three-day festival of experimental music took place last weekend in Knoxville, Tenn.
lead_paragraph: The three-day festival of experimental music took place last weekend in Knoxville, Tenn.

headline: Big Ears Festival Stars the Avant-Garde
abstract: This event in Knoxville, Tenn., included acts as varied as Tanya Gagaq, Rhiannon Giddens and the Kronos Quartet.
lead_paragraph: KNOXVILLE, Tenn. — The avant-garde is a notion shaped by discomfort, as well as defiance. No music gets that designation unless it makes people feel uneasy or threatened. Tanya Tagaq, a singer from Nunavut, the northernmost territory in Canada, gave an exemplary lesson in assuaging worry here on Saturday afternoon at Big Ears, an ambitious three-day festival of experimental music in a place without much of a history of nurturing it.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: ‘The Wiz’ Will Be NBC’s Next Live Musical and Then Return to Broadway
abstract: Maybe next time, “Music Man.”
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, Robert Greenblatt, the chairman of NBC’s entertainment division, announced that after “The Sound of Music Live” in 2013 and “Peter Pan Live” in 2014, his network’s next live musical production would be either “The Wiz” or “The Music Man.”

headline: Excerpt: ‘Bye Bye Birdie’
abstract: Ann-Margret performs the opening credits for the 1963 film.
lead_paragraph: Ann-Margret performs the opening credits for the 1963 film.

headline: Review: Dawn Upshaw Gets Down to Earth at Town Hall
abstract: Ms. Upshaw applied her soprano to an eclectic mix of classical songs at a show at the Town Hall.
lead_paragraph: Certain musicians are often referred to as “communicative performers,” a particularly apt description in the case of the soprano Dawn Upshaw, who sang at the Town Hall on Sunday afternoon as part of the Peoples’ Symphony Concerts series.

headline: Review: The Cellist Leonard Elschenbroich Played at the Frick
abstract: The German cellist Leonard Elschenbroich presented his New York recital debut on Sunday at the Frick Collection.
lead_paragraph: The German cellist Leonard Elschenbroich is a rising star on the European concert scene. On Sunday afternoon, together with the pianist Alexei Grynyuk, he presented his New York recital debut at the Frick Collection. In a program of just three works — one Classical, one contemporary and one Romantic — Mr. Elschenbroich not only revealed himself as a musician of great technical prowess, intellectual curiosity and expressive depth but also displayed an easygoing way of communicating with an audience.

headline: Review: 20 Years Later, Jodeci Is Back, in ‘The Past, the Present, the Future’
abstract: With K-Ci Hailey’s ecstatic wail at its center, the group’s new album mostly delivers the type of music the group was known for in its prime.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago the soul savant D’Angelo released a new album, “Black Messiah,” some 14 years after his previous one, “Voodoo.” On its own, it was an accomplishment, but it was also a reminder of many things that today’s R&B mainstream lacks: political engagement, the warmth and tension of a live band, a voice with fascinating crevices.

headline: ‘Cabaret’ Says Auf Wiedersehen With Big Week at Broadway Box Office
abstract: The Roundabout Theater Company revival closed after 388 performances.
lead_paragraph: The Kit Kat Klub closed up shop with a bang last week, as Sienna Miller led “Cabaret” to a strong finish in its run at Studio 54.

headline: The Story Behind ‘Woman in Gold’: Nazi Art Thieves and One Painting’s Return
keywords: ['Art', 'Movies', 'Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Reparations']
abstract: Gustav Klimt’s painting “Adele Bloch-Bauer I” was returned to Maria Altmann and her family.
lead_paragraph: There are many reasons that among the hundreds of thousands of cases involving artwork looted by the Nazis the story of Gustav Klimt’s “Adele Bloch-Bauer I” would particularly appeal to filmmakers. For one, there is the mesmerizing gold-flecked painting itself, which set a record price of $135 million when it was sold in 2006. Then there is the David-and-Goliath tale featuring a feisty octogenarian heroine — Ms. Bloch-Bauer’s niece Maria Altmann — taking on a recalcitrant Austrian government. And finally there is the satisfying conclusion. Ms. Altmann gets the portrait back. Justice prevails.

headline: Review: Missy Mazzoli’s Unsettling ‘Vespers for a New Dark Age’
abstract: In her latest album, Ms. Mazzoli has substituted contemporary poetry for sacred verses.
lead_paragraph: The composer and keyboardist  Missy Mazzoli has a thing for unlikely connections and startling gestures, and one of her gifts is the ability to tease out the hidden logic behind her choices. Her ravishing, unsettling album “Vespers for a New Dark Age” unfolds as a meditation on technology and spirituality, alienation and self-interest. Its ominous but propulsive score ranges from the chamber-operatic to the electronic and semiabstract.

headline: Boy Locked in Manhattan Restroom With Mother Later Dies
abstract: The child was taken to the hospital after he was found foaming at the mouth, the police said. His mother was detained by officers.
lead_paragraph: A 1-year-old boy whose mother locked herself in a restroom with him at a restaurant in Midtown Manhattan on Monday was declared dead at Bellevue Hospital Center, where he was taken after workers who unlocked the door found him unconscious and foaming at the mouth, the police said.

headline: Review: Sufjan Stevens’s Quietly Moving ‘Carrie & Lowell’
abstract: The album is named after Mr. Stevens’s mother, Carrie, who died in 2012.
lead_paragraph: A hushed, intent Sufjan Stevens contemplates death, grief, family and memory on his quietly moving new album, “Carrie & Lowell,” in songs that entwine autobiography and archetype. The music is restrained and meticulous, all graceful melodies, plucked strings and shimmery keyboard tones. But ungovernable circumstances and emotions course through the lyrics.

headline: Obama’s Passport Data Leaked in Australian Email Blunder
abstract: Passport information for President Obama and the leaders of 30 other countries was accidentally emailed by an official in Australia’s immigration department.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The government of Australia accidentally disclosed personal information about President Obama and 30 other world leaders who traveled there last fall for a summit meeting, according to a report on Monday in The Guardian.

headline: Enterovirus 68 May Be Linked to Paralysis in Children, Study Says
abstract: A new strain of a common respiratory virus may be responsible for partly paralyzing more than 100 children in 34 states since August, researchers reported.
lead_paragraph: A new strain of a common respiratory virus may be responsible for partly paralyzing scores of children nationwide, researchers reported on Monday.

headline: Labor’s $15 Wage Strategy
keywords: ['Organized Labor', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Minimum Wage', 'Fast Food Industry']
abstract: Ebony Hughes works two jobs and still struggles to make ends meet. She is an example of the kind of worker that organizers are trying to galvanize under the banner of civil rights to raise wages.
lead_paragraph: Ebony Hughes works two jobs and still struggles to make ends meet. She is an example of the kind of worker that organizers are trying to galvanize under the banner of civil rights to raise wages.

headline: Movement to Increase McDonald’s Minimum Wage Broadens Its Tactics
abstract: Unions in the United States and elsewhere are increasing pressure on the fast-food giant by protesting its corporate practices to government bodies as well as planning strikes.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — On a recent Friday, Kwanza Brooks, a $7.25-an-hour McDonald’s worker, climbed into a 14-person van to take a four-hour ride from Charlotte, N.C., to Atlanta.

headline: Teenager Faces Charges After Mocking Singapore’s Founding Father on YouTube
keywords: ['Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Social Media']
abstract: Excerpts from a YouTube tirade against Lee Kuan Yew that led to the arrest of a teenage blogger.
lead_paragraph: The Singaporean police confirmed on Monday that a teenage video blogger was arrested a day earlier for an obscenity-laced tirade posted on YouTube that celebrated the death of Lee Kuan Yew, the country’s founding father, and disparaged Christians.

headline: Thoughts at the End of the Road, and a Word of Advice
keywords: ['Business Travel', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Travel and Vacations', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: The writer sums up 16 years of On the Road columns for The Times.
lead_paragraph: ALL roads end, and now we come to the end of this one.

headline: Heated Words as Iran Deadline Nears
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Readers respond to an Op-Ed article by John R. Bolton, a former United Nations ambassador.

headline: Prosecutors Scrutinize Minority Borrowers’ Auto Loans
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Automobiles', 'Consumer Protection', 'Minorities', 'Automobile Financing', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Government officials say auto sellers are singling out minority borrowers and extending them the costliest car loans, which could exacerbate some neighborhoods’ economic distress.
lead_paragraph: Minority borrowers were once starved for credit through redlining — banks’ refusal to provide mortgages in their communities.

headline: Detroit Group Calls for Overhaul of Schools
abstract: The proposal by city leaders would end emergency management and return control to an elected school board.
lead_paragraph: A coalition of Detroit’s leaders called on Monday for sweeping changes to the city’s educational system, including an end to emergency management of the troubled public schools, the transfer of the system’s financial debt to the state, and creation of a commission to oversee the opening and closing of schools in the city.

headline: Climate Change Threatens to Kill Off More Aspen Forests by 2050s, Scientists Say
abstract: Scientists warned that the aspen forests could be doomed if emissions of greenhouse gases continue at a high level, adding to other studies that suggest the global effect of climate change.
lead_paragraph: The beloved aspen forests that shimmer across mountainsides of the American West could be doomed if emissions of greenhouse gases continue at a high level, scientists warned on Monday. That finding adds to a growing body of work suggesting forests worldwide may be imperiled by climate change.

headline: Jeb Bush Defends Indiana’s Religious Beliefs Law
abstract: Jeb Bush defended Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana and a religious freedom law the governor signed into law last week that critics are calling legalized discrimination.
lead_paragraph: Former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida weighed in Monday on the debate that has engulfed Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana over a new religious freedom law in the state that critics are calling legalized discrimination.

headline: N.C.A.A. Steps Up Pressure Over New Indiana Law
abstract: The president of the N.C.A.A. expressed concern about the ability to conduct the association’s affairs and tournaments in an environment that reflects its values.
lead_paragraph: While Indiana’s legislature and governor said Monday that they would clarify a new law that critics say could condone discrimination against gay people, the Indianapolis-based N.C.A.A., days before the Final Four was set to begin in Indianapolis, left the door open to moving future events and its own headquarters.

headline: Lauren Smithson,  Manfred Philogene
abstract: The couple were married at Carlyle on the Green, an events space in Farmingdale, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Lauren Elizabeth Smithson and Manfred Joseph Philogene were married Friday at Carlyle on the Green, an events space in Farmingdale, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Jerome D. Taylor, a Lutheran minister, officiated.

headline: Miriam Bienstock, Co-Founder of Atlantic Records, Dies at 92
abstract: Miriam Bienstock ran the business side in the early years of a record company that would later become a giant in the industry, with artists like Aretha Franklin and Ray Charles.
lead_paragraph: Miriam Bienstock, a co-founder of Atlantic Records who ran the business side of the company in its formative years, helping to lay the groundwork for what became a colossus of the recording industry, died on March 21 at her home in Manhattan. She was 92.

headline: Religious Protection Laws, Once Called Shields, Are Now Seen as Cudgels
keywords: ['Freedom of Religion', 'Discrimination', 'States (US)', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Religion-State Relations', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The Religious Freedom Restoration Act was adopted to protect vulnerable religious minorities, but it has been transformed, critics say, into a law that allows some groups to discriminate.
lead_paragraph: When the federal government adopted a religious protection act in 1993, same-sex marriage was not on the horizon.

headline: Robert Hite, 95, Survivor of Doolittle Raid and Japanese Imprisonment, Dies
abstract: Lt. Col. Hite was the last survivor among eight crewmen who were captured by the Japanese when American bombers brought World War II home to Japan in 1942.
lead_paragraph: Lt. Col. Robert L. Hite, the last survivor among eight crewmen who were captured by the Japanese when American bombers brought World War II home to Japan in Jimmy Doolittle’s daring air raid in 1942, died on Sunday in Nashville. He was 95.

headline: As U.S. and Iran Seek Nuclear Deal, Saudi Arabia Makes Its Own Moves
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
