lead_paragraph: CAIRO — As America talks to Iran, Saudi Arabia is lashing out against it.

headline: House Provision Offers Doctors More Protection Against Malpractice Suits
keywords: ['Malpractice', 'Doctors', 'Medicaid', 'Medicare', 'Hospitals', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The bill stipulates that quality standards used by Medicare, Medicaid and the Affordable Care Act should not be used to show negligence by a doctor or a hospital.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A little-noticed provision of a bill passed by the House of Representatives with overwhelming bipartisan support would provide doctors new protections against medical malpractice lawsuits.

headline: Witnesses, Who Say Police Killed Activist, Are to Be Charged in Egypt
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Witnesses', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Egyptian prosecutors are bringing criminal charges against witnesses who said they saw the police kill an unarmed poet and activist during a demonstration, a lawyer who has seen the charges said on Monday.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egyptian prosecutors are bringing criminal charges against witnesses who said they saw the police kill an unarmed poet and activist during a demonstration, a lawyer who has seen the charges said on Monday.

headline: Prosecution in Boston Marathon Trial Closes With Raw Details of Killings
abstract: The prosecution describes the deaths of an 8-year-old boy and a 23-year-old woman.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The government’s case against Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the admitted Boston Marathon bomber, ended Monday where it began, with a raw, wrenching account of the carnage wrought nearly two years ago by Mr. Tsarnaev on Boylston Street.

headline: Defense Witness Places Different Suspect in Etan Patz’s Apartment
abstract: Lawyers for Pedro Hernandez are trying to cast doubt in jurors’ minds about whether Mr. Hernandez was really the killer of Etan, 6, who disappeared in 1979.
lead_paragraph: After weeks of trying to link a convicted child molester to the 1979 disappearance of Etan Patz, defense lawyers for Pedro Hernandez called a witness on Monday who placed the molester inside the Patzes’ SoHo apartment.

headline: Arizona Governor Vetoes Bill to Shield Police Names
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Police', 'Law and Legislation', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Gov. Doug Ducey vetoed legislation that would have prevented law enforcement agencies from releasing the names of officers involved in serious or fatal shootings for 60 days.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — With just hours left before a midnight deadline, Gov. Doug Ducey of Arizona vetoed legislation on Monday that would have prevented law enforcement agencies from releasing the names of officers involved in serious or fatal shootings for 60 days.

headline: Virginia: Suit Seeks to Prevent College From Closing
abstract: State authorities filed suit to block the closing of Sweet Briar College, giving a boost to alumnae and faculty who are fighting to save the 114-year-old women’s liberal arts institution.
lead_paragraph: State authorities filed suit Monday to block the closing of Sweet Briar College, giving a boost to alumnae and faculty who are fighting to save the 114-year-old women’s liberal arts institution near rural Amherst. The Amherst County attorney, Ellen Bowyer, argued in court filings that she has jurisdiction to sue on behalf of the state, and said shutting down Sweet Briar would violate the will of its founder, Indiana Fletcher Williams, who in 1901 bequeathed her former plantation for the purpose of educating young women to be “useful members of society.” A college spokeswoman had no immediate comment.

headline: UConn Women Trail at Halftime but Surge to Another Final Four
abstract: The Huskies, led by Kaleena Mosqueda-Lewis and Breanna Stewart, overwhelmed Dayton in the second half and reached their eighth straight national semifinals.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Connecticut’s steamroller of a women’s basketball team met a head-on challenge for one half on Monday night but ultimately went merrily on its way to another Final Four, undented and undaunted.

headline: Shopping for Yacht? New York Budget Offers a Tax Break
keywords: ['Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Boats and Boating', 'Budgets and Budgeting']
abstract: Of the thousands of items packed into Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s $150 billion budget for New York State, one in particular seemed to float to the top: a tax credit for buyers of luxury boats.
lead_paragraph: Of the thousands of items packed into Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s $150 billion budget for New York State, one in particular seemed to float to the top: a tax credit for buyers of luxury boats.

headline: Obama, Last Election Behind Him, Plans First Visit as President to Kenya
abstract: President Obama will travel to Kenya in July to co-host a forum on entrepreneurship as part of an effort to support economic development in Africa.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For years, Kenya has been a political headache for President Obama and a geopolitical headache for the United States. But now in his seventh year in office, with his last election behind him, Mr. Obama has decided to embrace his heritage by visiting the land of his father for the first time as president.

headline: Dietitians Group Negotiating to End Labeling Deal With Kraft Singles
abstract: The Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics is working to terminate a deal that had allowed Kraft to affix the group’s Kids Eat Right label to its cheese slices.
lead_paragraph: The Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics said it was working with the Kraft Foods Group to end part of a deal that allowed the food company to use one of the academy’s logos on packages of Kraft Singles.

headline: 3 Injured in East Village Explosion Are Released From Hospital
abstract: The one remaining patient from the blast and buildings collapse in the East Village has been upgraded to good condition at Bellevue Hospital Center.
lead_paragraph: Three of four people who were hospitalized in critical condition after an explosion and fire in the East Village last week have been released, Mayor Bill de Blasio said on Monday.

headline: Father Stays on Sideline as Georgia State’s R.J. Hunter Enters the N.B.A. Draft
abstract: After a brief run at the N.C.A.A. tournament, Hunter will skip his final season at Georgia State, where his father is the coach.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — For its N.C.A.A. tournament coda, “One Shining Moment,” CBS could justify devoting an entire segment to the Hunters of Georgia State. During the first weekend alone, Ron, the coach-father, and R. J., the player-son, provided the types of images that endear the tournament to its rapt followers.

headline: Role of Illness in Germanwings Crash Raises Worry About Stigma
keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: The intense focus on the co-pilot’s mental illness has raised concerns that it could stigmatize mentally ill people and make it harder to identify troubled workers.
lead_paragraph: An intense focus on the role of the co-pilot’s mental illness in the Germanwings jetliner crash has raised concerns that it risks unfairly stigmatizing millions of people with mental disorders and making it less likely they will seek treatment. That, in turn, could make it even harder to identify people working in high-risk professions who pose a threat to public safety.

headline: Intersection | Seoul, South Korea
abstract: In the Hongdae neighborhood of Seoul, Mina Kwon, an illustrator, says her style is influenced by hip-hop and androgyny.
lead_paragraph: In the Hongdae neighborhood of Seoul, Mina Kwon, an illustrator, says her style is influenced by hip-hop and androgyny.

headline: Fancy, Evasive Language
abstract: Gary Cee beats around the bush and a video clip of the heart-stopping final moments of the 2015 A.C.P.T. provided by Ben Zimmer.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — An easy theme today, perhaps to help us ease our way back into solving after the exciting weekend in Stamford, Conn., at the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament. If you want to watch a video clip that will have you on the edge of your seat, check out the last moments of the A Division finals below, provided by Ben Zimmer.

headline: Cuomo Gets Timely New York Budget but Pays Price
abstract: The budget deal between Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and top lawmakers included changes to ethics rules and teacher tenure, but many of his most ambitious goals were nowhere to be found.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo started his second term with a zeal to address broad societal problems like income inequality, faltering public schools and waning trust in the criminal justice system.

headline: An Anxious Wait in Syrian City Held by Insurgents
abstract: Government forces were routed from Idlib, a provincial capital in the country’s north.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Residents of the northern Syrian provincial capital of Idlib are waiting anxiously to learn who will govern them, and how, after Islamist insurgent groups hoisted their flags over the city last weekend.

headline: Nigeria’s Presidential Race Stretches to Another Day
abstract: The incumbent president is facing a tough challenge as voting results poured in from distant states in this crowded and chaotic land.
lead_paragraph: KANO, Nigeria — The most competitive presidential race ever in Africa’s largest democracy continued to play out late into Monday night, with the incumbent president facing a tough challenge as voting results poured in from distant states in this crowded and chaotic land.

headline: Lawyer Asks Judge to Vacate Conviction in 2003 Killing of Fairfield Student
abstract: A lawyer for John Giuca, convicted of murdering Mark Fisher, filed a motion suggesting that the office of Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn district attorney at the time, mishandled evidence.
lead_paragraph: A lawyer for John Giuca, convicted of the 2003 killing of a Fairfield University student athlete, filed a motion on Monday asking a judge to vacate Mr. Giuca’s murder conviction.

headline: Chris Mullin Is Set to Lead St. John’s Again, but This Time as a Rookie Coach
abstract: Mullin, who helped St. John’s reach the 1985 Final Four, was said to have reached a deal to become the coach despite having no experience in that role.
lead_paragraph: His floppy hair, puckered mouth and timeless shooting stroke captivated New York City and the Big East Conference in the early 1980s. Now, 30 years later, Chris Mullin will return to St. John’s as the coach of the men’s basketball team, according to a person with knowledge of the agreement.

headline: A Trial Partnership for 2 Jewish Cultural Institutions in New York
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Culture (Arts)', 'Museums', 'Theater', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: The Museum of Jewish Heritage, trying to attract more visitors, and the National Yiddish Theater-Folksbiene, seeking a permanent home, could undergo a full-blown merger by 2017, officials say.
lead_paragraph: Two Jewish cultural organizations in New York City — one in need of a permanent home and the other in a quest for more visitors — have agreed to join forces.

lead_paragraph: A look at where Iran exerts influence across the region and at the emerging Saudi coalition.

headline: Citi Bike Says Shutdown Was for Fixing Software

lead_paragraph: Bear with us — Citi Bike is getting better.

headline: Mets Owner Fred Wilpon Is Making Good on His Promise to Be More Engaged With the Team
abstract: Wilpon talked with players early Monday in a closed-door meeting that was described as motivational and inspirational.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Word filtered through the Mets’ organization at the start of spring training that the owner Fred Wilpon would be around more and would be more engaged. With spring training winding down, Wilpon made good on that promise in an unusual way — at least by his standards.

headline: Replace a Legend? These Yankees Did
abstract: The Yankees have needed to “replace,” among others, Babe Ruth, Lou Gehrig, Joe DiMaggio, Mickey Mantle, Mariano Rivera and now Derek Jeter.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees are in transition again — the tricky transition of replacing a revered player. Bob Sheppard’s recorded voice will not intone, “Num-bah 2, Der-ek Jee-tah, Num-bah 2” this season. Didi Gregorius, obtained in an off-season trade, is the new shortstop. But because the Yankees have had so many revered players in winning a record 27 World Series, they have had to manage this transition every so often.

headline: Derick Brassard and Mats Zuccarello Ignite the Rangers’ Line
abstract: Brassard at center and Zuccarello on the right wing have been the team’s most consistent line for the past two seasons, regardless of who plays left wing.
lead_paragraph: On the surprising march to last spring’s Stanley Cup finals, the Rangers’ best line did not feature Derek Stepan, Martin St. Louis or Chris Kreider. And on the Rangers’ run this season to the top of the N.H.L., their best forward unit has not had any of those players either.

abstract: This word has appeared in 10 New York Times articles in the past year.

headline: IBM Scores Weather Data Deal and Starts Internet of Things Unit
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing']
abstract: IBM adds another big data source to its data analysis business in a partnership with the Weather Company.
lead_paragraph: Data partnerships are a key ingredient in IBM’s long-term strategy, and the company is announcing a big one on Tuesday with the Weather Company.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 11 P.M. (Spike) CON AIR (1997) Cameron Poe (Nicolas Cage) kills a man with his fists while defending his pregnant wife (Monica Potter). In court, a judge says that because he is a United States Army Ranger veteran he is a deadly weapon, and sentences him to 7 to 10 years in prison. When it comes time for him to return home, he finds himself the only good man on a flight full of villainous convicts, played by Ving Rhames, Danny Trejo, Steve Buscemi and others. Led by Cyrus the Virus (John Malkovich), the convicts plan to hijack the plane. Cameron must prevent the hijacking so he can get home to his wife and daughter on her seventh birthday. “As directed by Simon West and written wryly by Scott Rosenberg (“Beautiful Girls”), ‘Con Air’ is a simple setup followed by endless stunts,” Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Tuesday, March 31, 2015.
lead_paragraph: “They are profiting off of people in vulnerable situations. The cost determines when I can talk to my husband and when my son can read a book to him.”

headline: Corrections: March 31, 2015
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Tuesday, March 31, 2015.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Yemen Evacuation Shows Chinese Navy’s Growing Role
abstract: The Chinese ambassador to Yemen described the evacuation of nearly 600 people as “a significant practice of major power diplomacy with Chinese characteristics.”
lead_paragraph: China evacuated nearly 600 of its citizens from conflict-torn Yemen this week in Chinese warships, in a demonstration of Beijing’s increasing ability to extract its people from dangerous places.

headline: Photos That Echo Russia and Ukraine
abstract: To commemorate Russia’s annexation of Crimea, five photographers are collaborating on image mash-ups that add layers of new meaning.
lead_paragraph: Photography is often a fairly solitary activity. The great work of previous centuries was usually a result of a lone photographer obsessively driven to explore a topic that provoked a response from the audience. That independent aspect has been one of its attractions for those practitioners who were, shall we say, a little socially challenged.

headline: Yoox to Merge With Net-a-Porter in All-Share Deal
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'E-Commerce', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: The transaction would create an online luxury fashion retailer from two companies that posted total revenue of about $1.4 billion in 2014, Yoox said.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Yoox Group said on Tuesday that it had agreed to merge with its luxury e-commerce rival Net-a-Porter in an all-share deal.

headline: The E.P.A.’s Climate Plan

headline: What Family Traditions Do You Want to Carry On When You Get Older?
abstract: Does your family have traditions centered on food and meals? Do you have traditional songs you sing or music you listen to as a family? Are there routines or rituals you participate in together?
lead_paragraph: When we’re children, family traditions often just happen to us. We eat, we sing, we get dressed up, often without much choice in the matter. But when we get older and make our own families, we can get the opportunity to decide what traditions we want to carry on as adults, whether holiday meals on Thanksgiving or Christmas, family summer camping trips or coming-of-age celebrations such as quinceañeras.

headline: ‘The Contender,’ a Biography of Andrew Cuomo
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A biography of Andrew Cuomo shows how he has often defined himself in opposition to the record of his father, Mario.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Cuomo is not running for president. Not in 2016 — since the governor of New York is not about to throw himself in front of the freight train that is Hillary Clinton — and possibly not ever. Indeed, bypassing a White House bid would most likely be less a political than a personal calculation for Cuomo. “He is the uncommon elected official with a streak of misanthropy,” Jeffrey Toobin of The New Yorker recently wrote about him. Or as a former Cuomo aide told Toobin: “Andrew will not run for president. He’d have to talk to too many people.”

headline: How ‘You Do You’ Perfectly Captures Our Narcissistic Culture
abstract: On the popular phrase and its tautological siblings “Haters gonna hate” and “It is what it is.”
lead_paragraph: You will recall the fable of the Scorpion and the Frog. The Scorpion needs a ride across the river. The waters are rising on account of climate change, or perhaps he has been priced out of his burrow, who knows? The exact reason is lost in the fog of pre-­modernity. The Frog is afraid that the Scorpion will sting him, but his would-­be passenger reassures him that they would both die if that happened. That would be crazy. Sure enough, halfway across, the Scorpion stings the Frog. Just before they drown, the Scorpion says, “Aren’t you going to ask why I did that?” And the Frog croaks, “You do you.”

headline: Rory McIlroy Has the Best Swing in Golf
abstract: How far will it take Northern Ireland's onetime child prodigy?
lead_paragraph: Even before Rory McIlroy could walk, he was envisioning the shots of his dreams. The story has been related to him countless times: how back in the early 1990s, his father, Gerry, then a bar manager at the local golf club in Holywood, County Down, Northern Ireland, would put his 18-month-old son — in his father’s daily care while his mother, Rosie, a night-shift worker at a nearby 3M plant, slept — in a pram and wheel him a half-mile or so from the McIlroys’ small, red-brick house on Belfast Road to the club, its 18-hole course on the outskirts of Belfast nestled into a tiered wooded hillside. When his day shift ended, Gerry, an avid golfer, would bring his son out to the range, set his pram just behind the practice tee and swat out buckets of balls before his transfixed toddler.

headline: In Treatment, but in Which Language?
keywords: ['Language and Languages', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Russian Language', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation']
abstract: What you choose to speak can make a therapeutic difference.
lead_paragraph: I have a psychotherapy practice in Madrid, but I often receive email requests for counseling from people in other parts of the world, since I also practice psychotherapy online, via Skype, in several languages: English, French, Italian and Russian. Alex’s email looked like spam, and I nearly deleted it. He wrote in an abrupt English, with neither a greeting nor a sign-off. When I read more closely, I saw that he was seeking therapy, though he didn’t say much else. In his brevity I sensed hesitation, a shade of doubt.

headline: Missing Deflation and the Argument for Inflation
abstract: Absence of deflation argues for more inflation.
lead_paragraph: Matthew Klein has been going through Fed transcripts from 2009, and notes that the Fed was surprised at the persistence of inflation despite the Great Recession. headline: Morning Agenda: Auto Loans to Minorities Under Scrutiny

lead_paragraph: AUTO LOANS TO MINORITIES UNDER SCRUTINY | The Justice Department’s civil rights division is examining whether auto dealerships are steering minority borrowers to the most expensive loans, a practice known as reverse redlining, Michael Corkery and Jessica Silver-Greenberg write in DealBook. In particular, the federal authorities are looking at whether “dealer markups,” in which dealers add additional interest onto a borrower’s loan, are being used to charge minority customers higher rates than white borrowers with similar credit profiles.

headline: Fleeting Stability for a Woman Charged With Killing Her Son
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: Latisha Fisher, who was taking medication to treat her paranoid schizophrenia and had started community college classes, locked herself and her son in the restroom of a Midtown restaurant.
lead_paragraph: With the birth of her second son nearly two years ago, friends say, Latisha Fisher, a woman who had always lived as though she had nothing to lose, had begun life anew. No more sitting on her stoop on the Lower East Side of Manhattan at 2 a.m., sipping from a bottle. No more marijuana and cocaine. No more of the violence that sent her to Rikers Island and no more of the turmoil that landed her in the files of New York City’s child welfare agency.

headline: 1890: Misery in Rome
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Hundreds of workingmen demanded their rights in Rome, 1890.
lead_paragraph: ROME — A group of pale men surrounded two rude graves in  today [March 28], and tenderly laid clumsy laurel wreaths upon them. Thirteen months ago there were riots in Rome. Hundreds of workingmen demanded the means of life. The King’s troops poured around them, a bristling sea of steel. Over two hundred prisoners were taken. Next day, all were released but thirty-four. These men have been in the prison ever since, and were only tried this week. Twenty-nine were declared innocent after more than a year’s suffering. In the meantime two of the poor fellows died and the men who crowned their dust today were the released prisoners. — The New York Herald, European Edition, April 1, 1890

headline: Not an Adoption Diary. Yet.
abstract: The guy I was in January would not have sung a burp-related version of “Let It Go.”
lead_paragraph: Here is a good indication of how much things have changed since I started writing this diary 10 weeks ago: The other night, I was carrying my baby daughter, Evy, around our condo, trying to get her to burp after feeding her. Evy’s a difficult burper, to say the least; no matter how much we rub and pat her back or put her down and pick her up, she rarely lets out a burp, no matter how much she wants to. So as I walked her around the house, rubbing her back, I said a sentence I never thought I’d say in my life:

headline: In Nigeria’s Election, Muhammadu Buhari Defeats Goodluck Jonathan
abstract: Mr. Buhari, a former military strongman, defeated Mr. Jonathan, whose government has been criticized for its handling of an Islamist insurgency and sinking economy.
lead_paragraph: KANO, Nigeria — With anger swelling over corruption, inequality and a devastating Islamist insurgency in the nation’s north, Nigerians by a wide margin chose an austere former general who once ruled with an iron hand to be their next president, according to election results on Tuesday.

headline: Duke Is Still Standing Despite a Lack of Experience
abstract: The top-seeded Blue Devils were expected to reach the Final Four, but that discounts the journey of the team, which has used four freshmen among its eight top players.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The Blue Devils looked tentative under the basket, milling about in such a way that they seemed to need Coach Mike Krzyzewski’s guidance on what to do next. A ladder was set up. A net hung above them. Aside from being told not to run with those scissors in their hands, they were on their own.

headline: Could Another Democrat Beat Hillary Clinton? Strategists Offer a Blueprint
abstract: Any primary challenge to Mrs. Clinton would be a long shot, but a truth-telling, less-hawkish populist who connects with voters might stand a chance, some experts said.
lead_paragraph: She has been called inevitable. The can’t-be-stopped candidate. Hillary Rodham Clinton is such an overwhelming favorite in presidential primary polls that most prominent Democrats are taking a pass on challenging her.

headline: Queens Woman, 70, Fatally Shot at Her Door, Police Say
abstract: The woman, Leta Webb, was shot in the head and the arm after answering a knock at her front door in South Jamaica, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: The pounding at the front door came in the middle of the night, when most of those living in the gray, two-story home in Queens were asleep.

headline: Verbatim: Pence Looks to Clarify Indiana Law
abstract: I’ve come to the conclusion that it would be helpful to move legislation this week that makes it clear that this law doesn’t give businesses the right to deny services to anyone.” – Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana, asking that a fix to the law be sent to him by the end of the week and saying “I abhor discrimination.”
lead_paragraph: – Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana, asking that a fix to the law be sent to him by the end of the week and saying “I abhor discrimination.”

headline: In Italy, Matteo Renzi Aims to Upend the Old World Order
abstract: Challenging the country’s ossified political structure, the prime minister said he represented a way forward for Europe’s struggling center-left parties.
lead_paragraph: ROME — In a tailored black suit, Prime Minister Matteo Renzi stood before the Italian Senate recently and applauded lawmakers for taking some tough votes on reforms that he boasted would jump-start the country’s economy after the longest slump in its modern history.

headline: House Panel Seeks Private Talk With Hillary Clinton About Email
abstract: Representative Trey Gowdy said a transcribed interview would protect Mrs. Clinton’s privacy and allow the panel to collect information it needs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The chairman of the House committee investigating the Benghazi attacks asked Hillary Rodham Clinton on Tuesday to appear for a private interview about her exclusive use of a personal email account when she was secretary of state.

headline: 1940: Inquiry Sought Into Nazi Book
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Inquiry sought into the publication of the Nazi White Book in 1940.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Whatever the German government may have had in mind in publishing the White Book of alleged Polish diplomatic papers, wherein the United States appeared to have egged the Allies on to war against the Nazi Reich, the reaction here today [March 31] was distinctly in the tone of Secretary of State Cordell Hull’s official denial of the authenticity of views set forth in the documents. Even outside the Administration the White Book was regarded as an attempt at propaganda. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, April 1, 1940

headline: The Iran Nuclear Deal – A Simple Guide
abstract: A guide to help you navigate the deal between global powers and Tehran.
lead_paragraph: A guide to help you navigate the deal between global powers and Tehran.

headline: Daily News Said to Get Bids From Cablevision and Billionaire Grocer
abstract: John A. Catsimatidis, the owner of Gristedes, and Cablevision, led by James L. Dolan, are said to have made bids to buy the newspaper.
lead_paragraph: The billionaire owner of the Gristedes grocery chain and the owner of Newsday and the Madison Square Garden Company have both submitted bids for The Daily News in New York, according to news reports and two people familiar with the negotiations.

headline: 9 New York Doctors Are Accused of Defrauding Medicaid Using Homeless People
abstract: The doctors are accused of running unnecessary tests on homeless people, leading to $7 million in false Medicaid and Medicare billings, the Brooklyn district attorney’s office said.
lead_paragraph: “Free sneakers, shoes and boots today,” Bernard Rorie shouted, standing outside a soup kitchen in East New York, Brooklyn, where he was being recorded by investigators

headline: Raid to Rescue Hostage in Istanbul Ends in Death
keywords: ['Kidnapping and Hostages', 'Terrorism', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: A prosecutor was held captive at the city’s main courthouse on Tuesday and was killed after Turkish special forces stormed the building.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — A prominent Istanbul prosecutor, held for hours by two leftist extremists in the main courthouse here, was killed Tuesday evening after Turkish special forces stormed the building, setting off a barrage of gunfire and explosions, in a desperate attempt to rescue him. The militants were also killed.

headline: Michael Angelakis to Step Down as Comcast Finance Officer
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Mr. Angelakis was instrumental in Comcast’s $45 billion bid for Time Warner Cable, a deal that remains in regulatory limbo. He will lead a new Comcast-based investment venture.
lead_paragraph: Michael J. Angelakis, who helped steer Comcast through its acquisition of NBCUniversal and also was instrumental in the attempt to take over Time Warner Cable, is leaving his post as chief financial officer to lead a new Comcast-backed company with $4 billion in firepower for strategic investments.

headline: Rolling Stones to Tour North America This Summer
abstract: Tickets for the United States tour dates go on sale on April 13.
lead_paragraph: Once again, the Rolling Stones will spend the summer in stadiums across America.

headline: The Healing Power of Your Own Medical Records
abstract: There is evidence that letting patients see their medical files helps them take better care of themselves, but the medical establishment still resists sharing the data.
lead_paragraph: Steven Keating’s doctors and medical experts view him as a citizen of the future.

headline: Analyzing Your Twitter Life
abstract: How to use a variety of tools to get more information about your online audience.
lead_paragraph: Q. Aside from seeing “retweets” and “favorites,” how can I tell if anybody is looking at my Twitter posts?

headline: At Roberta’s, Pizza and a Broken Partnership
abstract: A fight over money and expansion plans is breaking up the group that created the pizzeria-turned-garden-and-gastro-commune in Bushwick, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: It all got rolling in the middle of 2007, when the national economy was faltering and the graffiti-tagged, barbed-wired lots of Bushwick, Brooklyn, seemed like a perfectly apocalyptic place in which to start a never-ending party.

headline: A Texas Ban on Gambling That Doesn’t Quite Work
abstract: Casinos form an underground billion-dollar industry that operates in a murky realm and engages in a perpetual cat-and-mouse game with the authorities.
lead_paragraph: SULLIVAN CITY, Tex. — Casino gambling with cash payoffs is illegal in Texas. But on a drizzly Tuesday afternoon in February, you could not tell it by the scene inside a former tire shop near this Rio Grande Valley border town: a few dozen men and women gambling on 75 slot machines in windowless rooms.

headline: Japan, Sticking With U.S., Says It Won’t Join China-Led Bank
abstract: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said it was important for strategic reasons that Japan back the United States, which has urged allies not to join the bank.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japanese leaders indicated on Tuesday that their nation would not become a founding member of a new Chinese-led Asian development bank but instead remain loyal to the United States, which has urged its allies to refrain from joining.

headline: 2007: First Presidential Campaign Speech
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton made her first appearance as a presidential candidate in January 2007 in Des Moines . She addressed rising economic inequality and being a female candidate.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton made her first appearance as a presidential candidate in January 2007 in Des Moines . She addressed rising economic inequality and being a female candidate.

headline: Why More Education Won’t Fix Economic Inequality
abstract: Although raising the wages of low earners is a worthy goal, the biggest cause of increasing inequality is the sharp rise in income at the very top.
lead_paragraph: Suppose you accept the persuasive data that inequality has been rising in the United States and most advanced nations in recent decades. But suppose you don’t want to fight inequality through politically polarizing steps like higher taxes on the wealthy or a more generous social welfare system.

headline: New Lawsuits Emerge in HP’s Long-Running Autonomy Dispute
abstract: Hewlett-Packard announced it was suing Autonomy’s executives, and the executives are suing back. It is all related to an $11 billion acquisition that went bad.
lead_paragraph: Hewlett-Packard says it is suing the founder of Autonomy, a data intelligence company that HP bought four years ago in what is now seen as a disastrous acquisition. In return, the founder says he will also sue.

headline: Lufthansa Says Germanwings Pilot Reported Deep Depression
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Pilots', 'Depression (Mental)']
abstract: The company said Andreas Lubitz, thought to have intentionally crashed a Germanwings flight, had informed it of his depressive episodes in 2009 after a break in training.
lead_paragraph: DÜSSELDORF, Germany — The co-pilot at the controls of the German jetliner that crashed in the French Alps last week informed Lufthansa in 2009 that he had suffered from severe depression, the company said Tuesday.

headline: Indiana Governor on ‘Confusion’ Over Law
abstract: Gov. Mike Pence, Republican of Indiana, says that the religious freedom law passed in the state was never intended to give a “license to discriminate” against gay and lesbian couples.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Mike Pence, Republican of Indiana, says that the religious freedom law passed in the state was never intended to give a “license to discriminate” against gay and lesbian couples.

headline: The Risks of Jay Z’s New Venture
abstract: Will artists get on board with Tidal? And if they do, will it matter?
lead_paragraph: It was probably only a matter of time before Jay Z got into the streaming-music business given its growing popularity. What’s interesting about his plans for Tidal, the service that he bought for $56 million, is that he wants to structure it as a cooperative of sorts by giving shares in it to other musicians.

headline: A Stew That Makes the Most of Spring Greens
abstract: Incorporate spring’s green market offerings, from light beans to bright jalapeño, for a vegetarian tagine.
lead_paragraph: I think in green in early April. It’s too early for some of the brighter spring vegetables, but dark green collards, light green fennel and bright jalapeño are all available at my local supermarket. And in my pantry, there’s a bag of very pale green dried flageolet beans; this early spring stew is a perfect home for them.

headline: Belarus Free Theater Returns to New York With ‘Trash Cuisine’
abstract: Banned from its homeland for its politically charged works, the troupe will bring its work to La MaMa.
lead_paragraph: The Belarus Free Theater troupe, banned from its homeland for its politically charged works, will be returning to New York this spring with the American premiere of the original play “Trash Cuisine.” The work addresses capital punishment and opens on April 29 at La MaMa’s Ellen Stewart Theater. It runs through May 17.

headline: 2004: Hillary Clinton’s D.N.C. Speech
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton introduced her husband, former president Bill Clinton, at the Democratic National Convention held in Boston in July 2004.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton introduced her husband, former president Bill Clinton, at the Democratic National Convention held in Boston in July 2004.

headline: U.S. Dance Troupes to Tour Overseas
abstract: The Limón Dance Company, Dance Heginbotham and the Los Angeles troupe Bodytraffic have been chosen as cultural ambassadors by DanceMotion USA.
lead_paragraph: In 1954, the Limón Dance Company was one of the first American dance troupes to be sent on a government-sponsored tour, to South America, under a new cultural diplomacy directive from President Dwight D. Eisenhower. Now the company will once again assume the role of cultural ambassador. On Tuesday, the Limón company was announced as one of three companies selected for the fifth iteration of DanceMotion USA, an initiative of the State Department, produced in partnership with the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Joining the Limón company are Dance Heginbotham and Bodytraffic, a Los Angeles troupe.

headline: Verizon Wireless Customers Can Now Opt Out of ‘Supercookies’
abstract: The move comes in response to criticism on Capitol Hill and elsewhere of the carrier’s user tracking program.
lead_paragraph: Verizon Wireless customers now have the ability to completely opt out of the phone carrier’s controversial ad-targeting program that tagged users with undeletable tracking codes, which critics called “supercookies.”

headline: Charter’s Deal May Not Be the Last Word on Bright House
abstract: With Comcast-Time Warner Cable still in play, the cable landscape could still realign again.
lead_paragraph: The United States cable puzzle is starting to take shape. None of the pieces is a snug fit just yet, though.

headline: Exercise Beats Vitamin D for Injury Prevention
abstract: Exercise and vitamin D supplements may help prevent injurious falls in older adults, a randomized trial found.
lead_paragraph: Exercise and vitamin D supplements may help prevent injurious falls in older adults, a randomized trial found.

headline: Angel Investors Lend Expertise as Well as Cash
keywords: ['Entrepreneurship', 'Start-ups', 'Venture Capital', 'Private Equity', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Traditionally, so-called angel investors have just provided early financing for start-ups. Now, a fledgling company is using those investors’ talents and experience, too.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Like many tech entrepreneurs, Joshua Reeves says he thinks his company can change the world. It may do it, too — with the way it was financed, as much as by the product itself.

headline: New York Times Develops an Apple Watch App
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Wearable Computing', 'News and News Media', 'Watches and Clocks']
abstract: The app will offer brief news articles written specially for users of the watch, which will be available at the end of April.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times said on Tuesday that it had developed an app to provide brief news reports for the Apple watch when it is released next month.

headline: Small Plates Grow Up
abstract: The shrunken-portions revolution has won, as top chefs enter the fray and start shaping the new rules of dining.
lead_paragraph: We live in a messy revolutionary period for restaurants. The old rules for going out to eat, under which Mom and Dad ambled down a predictable path from appetizer to main course to dessert, with Mom pausing halfway through dinner to ask about Dad’s veal chop, were repealed some time ago. In place of rules, we got small plates, and anarchy. The last decade has been the era of messy tables, of gonzo pacing, of menus that came with a spoken introduction, of senseless plating, of endless instructions to share dishes that collapsed into rubble when you tried.

headline: Clinton Team Nabs McAuliffe Adviser to Focus on Iowa
abstract: Sending an operative to Iowa like Michael Halle, who has ties with the Clinton loyalists Terry McAuliffe and Robby Mook, indicates a serious push in the caucuses there for Hillary Rodham Clinton’s expected presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton appears determined to put to rest questions about whether she will aggressively compete in the Iowa caucuses.

headline: What’s the First Thing You Should Do When You Get into College?
abstract: Before you start buying decorations for your dorm room walls, consider for a moment following a road less traveled in America: Take a gap year.
lead_paragraph: Defer.

headline: A New Exhibition Memorializes the Madness of Jean Paul Gaultier
abstract: A selection of the designer’s haute couture designs and ready-to-wear pieces will be on view alongside his sketches, costumes and red carpet looks at the Grand Palais in Paris.
lead_paragraph: The Grand Palais in Paris will celebrate Jean Paul Gaultier this spring with an extensive show featuring 175 haute couture designs, select ready-to-wear pieces and, of course, Madonna’s iconic cone bra — all presented on mannequins topped with dramatic wigs by the hairstylist Odile Gilbert. Along with sketches, film costumes, famous red-carpet looks and videos (including clips from “Eurotrash,” the talk show Gaultier co-hosted in the ’90s), there will be a section showcasing the former Hermès creative director’s rich corsetry, and a hi-tech installation that projects his ensembles onto visitors so that, says the curator Thierry-Maxime Loriot, “everyone can be a Gaultier model.”

headline: Saudi Arabia’s Ominous Reach Into Yemen
abstract: The Saudi-led bombing campaign threatens to turn a civil war into a larger Shiite-Sunni war with Iran.
lead_paragraph: The Saudi-led military intervention in Yemen threatens to turn what has been a civil war between competing branches of Islam into a wider regional struggle involving Iran. It could also destroy any hope of stability in Yemen. Even before the Saudis and their Arab allies started the bombing, Yemen was in severe distress; on Tuesday, the United Nations high commissioner for human rights warned that it is now on the brink of collapse.

headline: Iraqi Claims That ‘Tikrit Has Fallen’ Is Disputed
abstract: Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi said government forces had reached the center of Tikrit, which some took to mean a declaration of victory. But Islamic State forces still hold parts of the city.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The prime minister of Iraq claimed that his country’s security forces had reached the center of Tikrit on Tuesday. A subtitle crawling across TV screens tuned to the official Iraqiya television network went further: “Tikrit has fallen to us,” it said. On YouTube, an Iraqi flag was shown flying atop a downtown government building.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For months, White House hopefuls from both parties have been raising millions in unlimited contributions at upscale fund-raisers from Manhattan to Palm Springs, Calif. — all without officially declaring themselves candidates and becoming subject to federal caps on contributions.

abstract: The president defied efforts by Congress to block new regulations that would streamline union elections.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In his latest confrontation with Congress, President Obama on Tuesday blocked Republican efforts to overturn new union-friendly federal regulations issued by his administration.

headline: Obama Removes Weapons Freeze Against Egypt
abstract: President Obama’s decision was seen as being for national security interests, despite differences with Egypt on democracy and human rights.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Seeking to repair relations with a longtime ally at a time of spreading war in the Middle East, President Obama on Tuesday lifted an arms freeze against Egypt that he had first imposed after the military overthrow of the country’s democratically elected government nearly two years ago.

headline: Soho House Lets the Public In With Turkish Baths
keywords: ['Bathing and Showering', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Organizations, Societies and Clubs']
abstract: The members-only club will unveil two hammams in its new Istanbul location, established in a 19th-century mansion.
lead_paragraph: Soho House, the members-only social club that began in London and has since built additional outposts around England and the United States (plus one in Berlin), opens the doors of its newest location, in Istanbul, next month. The venue was constructed in a 19th-century mansion, Palazzo Corpi, which housed the U.S. Embassy for 100 years (until 2003) and was originally built as a home for a wealthy shipbuilder, Ignazio Corpi. The property’s original Italian frescoes and marble floors remain intact.

headline: South Carolina, Once a Doormat, Is Now a Step From a Final
abstract: Dawn Staley has made steady progress since becoming the coach of South Carolina’s women’s basketball team in 2008. Now the Gamecocks are in their first Final Four.
lead_paragraph: GREENSBORO, N.C. — Aleighsa Welch wore a basketball net around her neck like treasured family jewelry as she stood in the locker room Sunday afternoon at the Greensboro Coliseum. South Carolina had just defeated Florida State, 80-74, to advance to the Final Four of the women’s N.C.A.A. tournament for the first time in program history. Welch was savoring the moment — until a giddy teammate ran over and asked her for the net they had just cut down in celebration.

headline: Republican Abolishment Threats? Just ‘Politics,’ I.R.S. Chief Says
abstract: Shutting down the Internal Revenue Service — a perennial punching bag for many conservatives – has become a rallying cry for Republicans who are thinking about running for president in 2016.
lead_paragraph: The demolition of the Internal Revenue Service — a perennial punching bag for many conservatives – has become a rallying cry for Republicans who are thinking about running for president in 2016.

abstract: Amanda Hesser and Merrill Stubbs of Food52 show you how to make macaroni and cheese without a recipe.
lead_paragraph: Amanda Hesser and Merrill Stubbs of Food52 show you how to make macaroni and cheese without a recipe.

headline: Blue Note Jazz Festival to Mark Fifth Anniversary With a Wide-Ranging Lineup
abstract: Natalie Cole, Buddy Guy and Ginger Baker will be among those performing at the Blue Note Jazz Festival.
lead_paragraph: The Blue Note Jazz Festival will celebrate its fifth anniversary in June, with headliners including the pop-R&B singer Natalie Cole, the blues legend Buddy Guy and the venerable South African jazz pianist Abdullah Ibrahim. The festival runs all month long with shows at a handful of venues in Manhattan; details are at bluenotejazzfestival.com.

lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The Nasdaq OMX Group has long courted technology companies as they seek to go public.

headline: Food For Thought
abstract: Or maybe thought for food.
lead_paragraph: I once had a conversation with some Times people about reader interests, which are something the paper knows much more about than it did in the pre-digital age. And what they said, ruefully, was that what readers really seem to care about is food — sure, they may email a hard-hitting column or a revelatory piece of investigative reporting, but the sure-fire stuff is about eating (and health, and using animal training techniques on your husband).

headline: Religious Freedom and Political Lies in Indiana
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Presidential Election of 2004', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: “Religious freedom” laws like Indiana’s are fast becoming a litmus test for both parties.
lead_paragraph: One of the most popular rejoinders to the charge that so-called “religious freedom” laws, such as the one enacted last week in Indiana, are little more than vehicles for anti-gay discrimination is that no one ever uses them to discriminate.

abstract: From a series for T in which the artist Leanne Shapton makes new artworks from pictures in old books.
lead_paragraph: From a series for T in which the artist Leanne Shapton makes new artworks from pictures in old books.

abstract: The eight-part series, mixing history with fiction, picks up with Borden’s life after she was acquitted of murdering her parents.
lead_paragraph: What, you ask, became of Lizzie? Turns out she stayed very busy. Call the cops, alert the warden. No one’s safe around this Borden.

headline: What You Get For ... $1,695,000
abstract: This week’s offerings include a log house in California, Southwestern style in Arizona and an 1844 house in Georgia.
lead_paragraph: This week’s offerings include a log house in California, Southwestern style in Arizona and an 1844 house in Georgia.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting interesting stories from around the web. In this installment, great reads from Adeel Hassan, Jenna Wortham and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Quantity Time Begets Quality Time, and Parents Spend Enough of Both
abstract: It’s time to look at our family calendars as half full, not half empty.
lead_paragraph: The “quality, not quantity” trope about the time parents spend with children has been around for decades. It’s a good one, when it helps parents (particularly mothers) to release their guilt about not spending “Little House on the Prairie” amounts of time with their children. New research, well described by Brigid Schulte in The Washington Post, supports the idea that such maternal omnipresence isn’t necessary for children. “In fact, it appears the sheer amount of time parents spend with their kids between the ages of 3 and 11 has virtually no relationship to how children turn out, and a minimal effect on adolescents, according to the first large-scale longitudinal study of parent time to be published in April in the Journal of Marriage and Family,” she writes. “The finding includes children’s academic achievement, behavior and emotional well-being.”

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Pennsylvania Roots
abstract: While the future Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton grew up in Illinois, her family ties are in many ways stronger in Scranton, Pa.
lead_paragraph: While the future Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton grew up in Illinois, her family ties are in many ways stronger in Scranton, Pa.

headline: After Horror in Libya, Christians’ Grief in an Egyptian Village
abstract: When Islamic State militants in Libya killed 21 Egyptian Christians, Jonathan Rashad went to the village many called home to understand the impact.
lead_paragraph: When Islamic State militants in Libya killed 21 Egyptian Christians, Jonathan Rashad went to the village many called home to understand the impact.

headline: Review: ‘Don Carlo’ Gets a Gripping Revival at the Met Opera
abstract: The conductor Yannick Nézet-Séguin drew nuanced details, glowing sound and sure pacing from the orchestra in this long, challenging Verdi masterpiece.
lead_paragraph: A solid cast with no weak links and a probing conductor. That’s what it takes, even more than superlative individual performances, for the profundity of Verdi’s “Don Carlo” to come through. That’s what the Metropolitan Opera’s revival offered on Monday when the director Nicholas Hytner’s 2010 production, which combines traditional and contemporary imagery and was last seen here in 2013, returned to the house.

headline: OAS, Brazilian Engineering Company, Seeks Bankruptcy Protection
abstract: OAS is the third big Petrobras subcontractor to request a bankruptcy court’s protection as an investigation into a pay-for-play scheme continues.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — The corruption scandal  surrounding the petroleum giant Petrobras of Brazil has claimed another victim: The country’s third-largest engineering and construction company, OAS, requested a bankruptcy court’s protection on Tuesday.

headline: Review: Alt-J at Madison Square Garden
abstract: The band’s songs were somber but laced with hooks, well-constructed pieces presented without hoopla.
lead_paragraph: Cryptic with a crisp beat: That’s how Alt-J keeps its songs, letting listeners choose how much to decipher and how much to enjoy more simply. It’s a strategy the band probably learned from Radiohead; Alt-J also shares Radiohead’s broad but particular eclecticism and now its arena-sized audiences. On Monday night, Alt-J sold out Madison Square Garden. (On Apple keyboards, Alt-J produces the symbol for delta, used in equations to represent change.)

headline: Law Schools and Industry Show Signs of Life, Despite Forecasts of Doom
abstract: Changes in the job market have led to declining enrollment at law schools, but several new studies show reasons to be optimistic about a career in law.
lead_paragraph: Law school enrollment has plummeted to the lowest level in decades. If a bottom has been reached, is now a good time to go to law school?

headline: Review: ‘American Odyssey,’ a New NBC Series, Stars Anna Friel
abstract: In this series, Anna Friel plays an American soldier in West Africa who realizes she can’t trust her government.
lead_paragraph: Casting directors are the quartermasters of the TV and movie industries — there’s not a lot of glory or recognition for their work, but it’s vital nonetheless.

headline: Court in Turkey Acquits Military Officers of Trying to Overthrow Government
keywords: ['False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The court ruled that evidence in the case, which involved 236 defendants, was tampered with and ordered the suspects released.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — An Istanbul court on Tuesday acquitted 236 military officers who had been convicted of trying to overthrow the government after the prosecutor said that evidence in the case had been forged.

headline: Review: Paul Lewis and Lisa Batiashvili, Recital Partners at Alice Tully Hall
abstract: The pianist and the violinist performed works by Schubert, Beethoven and Telemann in their first American recital tour together.
lead_paragraph: Paul Lewis, the Liverpudlian pianist renowned for his solo Beethoven and Schubert, is fastidious in his choice of recital partners. His work with the tenor Mark Padmore has been a recent touchstone in Schubert’s lieder cycles. In piano duets, his steady temperament has beautifully complemented artists like Imogen Cooper and Steven Osborne.

headline: Strikes in Argentina Bring Transportation to Standstill
abstract: A one-day protest of income tax rules by airline, railroad, bus and other workers left roads and transportation terminals empty.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — The taut political climate in Argentina came under new strain on Tuesday as strikes by transportation workers and others brought the country to a halt.

headline: The False Hope of a Limited Government, Built on Tax Breaks
keywords: ['Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Income Inequality', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Mortgages', 'Philanthropy']
abstract: Protected from democratic accountability, the government developed into a Rube Goldberg contraption that has a weak claim to a defensible social purpose.
lead_paragraph: In the early years of the Reagan Revolution, Senator Robert Packwood, then the powerful Republican chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, offered a robust — if unusual — defense of the tax exclusion for employer-provided health insurance: It prevented the government from getting bigger.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Nigeria and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Nigeria, the United States, the Netherlands and Germany.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Nigeria, the United States, the Netherlands and Germany.

headline: U.S. Delays Deportation of Salvadoran Ex-Official Accused in ’80s Killings
abstract: Immigration authorities who have tried for years to deport Gen. Carlos Eugenio Vides Casanova now say he has to remain in the United States for at least another week.
lead_paragraph: After a 16-year legal battle, the Obama administration has received court approval to deport a former defense minister of El Salvador accused of participating in human rights abuses by his troops when he was a top military commander in the 1980s.

headline: Where Wall Street and Silicon Valley Intersect
abstract: Entrepreneurs and venture capitalists try to resist Wall Street’s entreaties, but a new relationship has lead to new fund-raising methods.
lead_paragraph: Entrepreneurs and venture capitalists try to resist Wall Street’s entreaties, but a new relationship has lead to new fund-raising methods.

headline: Obama Commutes Long Sentences of 22 Drug Offenders
keywords: ['Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons', 'Mandatory Sentencing', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: The clemency was part of an effort to correct a disparity created by measures from the 1980s and ’90s and align penalties more with current law.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama commuted the prison sentences of 22 people on Tuesday, part of an effort to correct a disparity among inmates who received lengthy sentences under laws passed during the crack epidemic of the 1980s and ’90s.

headline: March 31, 2015 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Nigeria, India, the United States and the Netherlands.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Nigeria, India, the United States and the Netherlands.

headline: Review: ‘Woman in Gold’ Stars Helen Mirren in Tug of War Over Artwork
abstract: This drama based on real-life traces the legal battle by Ms. Mirren’s character to regain possession of a priceless canvas stolen from her family by the Nazis 60 years earlier.
lead_paragraph: “Woman in Gold” rests heavily on the squared shoulders of Helen Mirren, whose character, Maria Altmann, is a proud, elderly Austrian Jewish woman who fled the Nazi scourge to settle in California. Reawakened to the past by the death of her sister, at whose 1998 funeral she is first observed, Maria wages a protracted legal battle to regain possession of a priceless canvas stolen from her family by the Nazis 60 years earlier.

headline: Orbital Publishing Accused of Fraud in Selling Subscriptions
abstract: Attorneys general in New York, Oregon, Minnesota, Missouri and Texas have accused the company of overcharging for subscriptions and keeping the difference in price.
lead_paragraph: Top prosecutors in several states accused an Oregon company on Tuesday of overcharging consumers for subscriptions to newspapers, magazines and other periodicals.

headline: Review: In Hal Hartley’s ‘Ned Rifle,’ Closure for a Son and a Series
abstract: The final piece of the director’s satirical trilogy centers on a teenager’s odyssey to find and kill his father.
lead_paragraph: Hal Hartley is no longer as dominant a figure in independent cinema as he was in the 1990s, when his deadpan humor was a mainstay in art-house theaters. His magnum opus remains “Henry Fool” (1998), whose title character (Thomas Jay Ryan), a rogue with a criminal past, inspires Simon Grim (James Urbaniak), a garbage man in Woodside, Queens, to write poetry. As a poet, Simon finds worldwide success.

headline: Plan to Keep 1,700 RadioShack Stores Open Is Approved
abstract: Judge Brendan L. Shannon of Federal Bankruptcy Court cleared the way for RadioShack to sell 1,740 of its locations to Standard General, a hedge fund.
lead_paragraph: A bankruptcy judge gave his blessing on Tuesday to a plan that would keep about 1,700 RadioShack stores open, saying he would approve the plan over a higher cash bid that would probably have liquidated the retailer but raised more money for its creditors.

headline: Supreme Court Weighs Overruling a 1964 Patent Decision
abstract: Marvel Enterprises says the 1964 ruling supports halting royalty payments to the inventor of a Spider-Man-related toy after his patent expired.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The dispute before the Supreme Court on Tuesday concerned a toy made up of a glove with a valve and a canister of pressurized foam. It was designed, Marvel Enterprises told the court in its brief, “to evoke Spider-Man, Marvel’s iconic superhero renowned for his spider superpowers and web-slinging.”

headline: John Krasinski vs. Anna Kendrick
abstract: In this exclusive clip from the new Spike TV show, “Lip Sync Battle,” John Krasinski and Anna Kendrick compete for the top spot.
lead_paragraph: In this exclusive clip from the new Spike TV show, “Lip Sync Battle,” John Krasinski and Anna Kendrick compete for the top spot.

headline: Living in Peekskill, N.Y.
abstract: The city in northwest Westchester County is being discovered by those looking for housing bargains and a reasonable commute.
lead_paragraph: The city in northwest Westchester County is being discovered by those looking for housing bargains and a reasonable commute.

headline: Player Ratings: Switzerland (1) vs. United States (1)
abstract: Player ratings for the United States national team’s friendly against Switzerland in Zurich.
lead_paragraph: Another game, another late goal for the United States national team, which tied Switzerland, 1-1, on Tuesday in Zurich.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Catch up on the day’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Catch up on the day’s top stories.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Planet of the Apes’
abstract: A scene from “Planet of the Apes,” with Charlton Heston.
lead_paragraph: A scene from “Planet of the Apes,” with Charlton Heston.

headline: Etan Patz’s Mother Testifies at Murder Trial
abstract: In Pedro Hernandez’s trial, Julie Patz said she did not recall the man whom defense lawyers cast as an alternate suspect in the boy’s death as having ever been in her apartment.
lead_paragraph: Julie Patz, the mother of Etan Patz, the 6-year-old boy who disappeared while walking to his school bus stop in 1979, testified on Tuesday that she did not recall the man whom defense lawyers for Pedro Hernandez cast as an alternate suspect in the boy’s death as having ever been in her apartment.

headline: On Spike TV, Celebrities Clash Where Everyone Can Watch Their Lips Move
abstract: The Spike TV series “Lip Sync Battle,” a spinoff of a popular segment on “The Tonight Show,” will feature celebrities performing popular songs, without going so far as actually singing them.
lead_paragraph: John Krasinski was driving on Route 101 to Los Angeles with some friends about two years ago when the global beats of Lionel Richie’s “All Night Long (All Night)” took over the car. The actor and comedian, known for playing Jim Halpert on “The Office,” grabbed an air microphone and started lip syncing.

headline: Just Don’t Call Them Bling
abstract: Gold watches are catching on with a street-smart crowd.
lead_paragraph: Gold watches are catching on with a street-smart crowd.

headline: This Will Get ‘The Lonely Goatherd’ Out of Your Head
abstract: Not everyone thinks that “The Sound of Music” could be improved upon. But here’s something we can all agree on.
lead_paragraph: An Editorial Observer piece I wrote on Monday suggested that the 1965 movie “The Sound of Music” could be improved upon, as recent theatrical revivals of Rodgers and Hammerstein musicals have been. My point was that by removing some of the Hollywood artificial sweetener, and perhaps darkening and deepening the themes already in the text, a more satisfying, more human, less mockable musical might result.

headline: Syracuse to Drop Fossil Fuel Stocks From Endowment
abstract: At $1.2 billion, Syracuse’s is the largest university endowment to divest entirely of fossil fuel stocks.
lead_paragraph: Syracuse University is dropping all fossil fuel stocks from its endowment, the university announced on Tuesday.

headline: A Conversation With Veronica Mainetti of the Sorgente Group of America
abstract: Sorgente specializes in historical preservation projects and is majority owner of New York’s Flatiron Building.
lead_paragraph: Ms. Mainetti, 36, is president of the Sorgente Group of America, one of three holding companies of the Sorgente Group of Rome, which is run by her father, Valter Mainetti, the majority shareholder and chief executive.

headline: A President’s Best Friend
abstract: A brief history of presidential pets, from Franklin D. Roosevelt to Barack Obama.
lead_paragraph: A brief history of presidential pets, from Franklin D. Roosevelt to Barack Obama.

headline: Scott Walker, Allergic to Dogs, May Run Against Political History
abstract: In his likely candidacy for the Republican presidential nomination, Gov. Walker of Wisconsin faces a different sort of constitutional challenge: overcoming his aversion to man’s best friend.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin and his wife, Tonette, had planned to spend a recent Friday night at the Nashua home of Jennifer Horn, the New Hampshire Republican chairwoman.

headline: Activist Links More Than 26,000 Twitter Accounts to ISIS
abstract: The new list was meant to expose the Islamic State’s exploitation of Twitter, but it misidentified some accounts as suspect.
lead_paragraph: A cybersecurity activist who recently helped publicize 9,200 Twitter accounts that were said to be linked to the Islamic State released a roster of 26,382 accounts on Tuesday, the biggest such list yet.

headline: A President’s Best Friend
abstract: A brief history of presidential pets, from Franklin D. Roosevelt to Barack Obama.
lead_paragraph: A brief history of presidential pets, from Franklin D. Roosevelt to Barack Obama.

lead_paragraph: RECENT SALE

headline: Buhari Supporters Celebrate in Nigeria
abstract: Supporters of the former military ruler, Muhammadu Buhari, celebrated his victory over the incumbent, Goodluck Jonathan, in the presidential election on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Supporters of the former military ruler, Muhammadu Buhari, celebrated his victory over the incumbent, Goodluck Jonathan, in the presidential election on Tuesday.

headline: Gary Dahl, Inventor of the Pet Rock, Dies at 78
abstract: The 1975 fad made Mr. Dahl, a down-at-the-heels advertising copywriter when he hit on the idea, a millionaire practically overnight, but he came to regret the brainstorm that gave rise to it in the first place.
lead_paragraph: It was a craze to rival the Hula-Hoop, and even less explicable. For a mere three dollars and 95 cents, a consumer could buy ... a rock — a plain, ordinary, egg-shaped rock of the kind one could dig up in almost any backyard.

headline: Etsy Sets Price Range for Its I.P.O.
abstract: At the midpoint of the range, the online marketplace beloved by makers of handmade jewelry and yoga bags would be valued at $1.2 billion.
lead_paragraph: Etsy, the online marketplace beloved by makers of handmade jewelry and yoga bags, is hoping that Wall Street investors will be equally ardent fans.

headline: In Canada, Unabashed Wooing of Commercial Drones
abstract: The Canadian transport minister’s enthusiasm for miniature, unmanned aircraft stands in stark contrast to the Federal Aviation Administration’s approach.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — It didn’t take long for Canada’s transport minister to exploit the promotional possibilities of Amazon testing its drone delivery service in the country — testing that the company confirmed on Monday.

headline: GoDaddy Said to Price I.P.O. Above Expected Range
abstract: The Internet registration company sold stock at $20 a share, raising $440 million and putting its market value at just more than $3 billion.
lead_paragraph: San Francisco — Nearly four years ago, GoDaddy was an Internet registration company with a history of risqué advertising.

headline: Group Linked to Islamic State Claims Responsibility for Tunisia Attack
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Museums', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The announcement, made in an audio recording that was posted Monday to YouTube, is the clearest claim of responsibility of the fatal museum attack by members of the Islamic State group.
lead_paragraph: TUNIS — A day after the Tunisian government said it had killed the orchestrator of the massacre at the National Bardo Museum and rounded up most of those involved, another group of militants declaring themselves to be members of the Islamic State operating inside Tunisia claimed responsibility for the attack and threatened more in the future.

headline: Carlos Falchi, 70, Dies; Turned Exotic Animal Skins Into Coveted Handbags
abstract: A self-taught artisan from Brazil built a fashion empire from hand-sewn leather clothing and handbags made from the skins of exotic animals, including anacondas, caimans and ostriches.
lead_paragraph: Carlos Falchi, a Brazilian-born accessories designer famous for his amiably rumpled, highly coveted handbags made of the skins of exotic animals, died on Friday in Durham, N.C. He was 70.

headline: Hollywood Reporter Signs Content Deal With Tencent, Chinese Online Giant
abstract: Tencent will pay The Reporter an undisclosed fee to license its entertainment trade news articles and videos.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – Pushing to broaden its international readership – even if that means the occasional censored article — The Hollywood Reporter said on Tuesday that it had signed an expansive content deal with the Chinese online giant Tencent Holdings.

headline: Defense Rests in Boston Marathon Bombing Trial After Just 4 Witnesses
abstract: Dzhokhar Tsarnaev’s scant defense reflected a strategy of admitting that while he participated in the 2013 attack, he was less culpable than his brother and did not deserve to die.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — After questioning just four witnesses over five hours, the defense for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev in the Boston Marathon bombing trial rested its case on Tuesday.

headline: Silicon Valley Leaders, New to Social Issues, Come Together Over Indiana Law
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Discrimination', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'State Legislatures', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: In an industry that avoids controversy, the heads of several prominent companies, including Apple and Salesforce.com, have chosen to pick a battle.
lead_paragraph: The technology industry’s leaders have found their collective voice on a social issue in the last week, rallying with great intensity against a new Indiana law that will allow businesses, they predict, to discriminate against gay couples. The heads of Apple, Salesforce.com, Yelp and Square have all publicly criticized the law, as have some leaders from other industries.

headline: Gas Utilities Reduce Leaks of Methane, Study Finds
abstract: Researchers suggested that the reduction was largely a result of equipment upgrades, including replacement of leaky old cast-iron or unprotected steel pipe.
lead_paragraph: Utilities are making progress in reducing leaks from their natural gas distribution networks, a new study has found, but the industry and regulators can do more.

headline: Amazon Dash Aims to Be a Push-Button Substitute for the Supply Run
abstract: The new program from Amazon allows customers to reorder household items like laundry detergent and paper towels with the push of a single physical button.
lead_paragraph: Amazon has built a booming business of making it easy to buy things online. It has a patented one-click ordering mechanism. It offers subscription-style services. And on Tuesday, Amazon unveiled a pilot program that allows customers to order items with the push of a single physical button.

headline: In Advertising Technology Deal, Rubicon Buys Chango
abstract: The deal gives Rubicon access to Chango’s intent marketing technology, which delivers ads based on a consumer’s intent to buy a product or service.
lead_paragraph: The advertising company Rubicon Project said on Tuesday that it had agreed to buy the Canadian start-up Chango for about $122 million, in the latest sign that the advertising technology industry is consolidating.

headline: Man in Fatal Encounter With N.S.A. Is Identified
abstract: The F.B.I. said the man who was fatally shot by police at the National Security Agency was Ricky Hall, 27, of Baltimore, who had a criminal record.
lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. on Tuesday identified a man who was fatally shot by the police at the National Security Agency as Ricky Hall, 27, of Baltimore, who had a criminal record that included convictions for prostitution, theft and assault. A passenger in the vehicle that Mr. Hall was driving, Kevin Fleming, 20, also of Baltimore, remained hospitalized for gunshot wounds. Law enforcement officials said the men were picked up by a 60-year-old Baltimore man early Monday and driven to a motel in Elkridge, Md. They stole his Ford Escape and sped down a highway exit, apparently unintentionally, that is reserved for the N.S.A. Agency police shot the men as Mr. Hall drove toward a parked police car, the N.S.A. said.

headline: Tired of War, Yemeni Bloggers Say, ‘Enough’
abstract: As the death toll mounts in Yemen, bloggers are sharing close-up views of the war in updates tagged with the Arabic word kefaya, meaning “enough.”
lead_paragraph: As the death toll mounts in Yemen, and airstrikes make life in the capital, Sana, a nerve-racking ordeal, Yemeni bloggers continue to post firsthand dispatches on social networks, frequently tagged with the Arabic word kefaya, meaning “enough.”
